title: Information Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: South Africa Delay on Namibia Seen
description: According to the best-laid plans, Tuesday is the target date for this former German colony to embark on its transition under United Nations supervision to eventual independence as the sovereign nation of Namibia.

title: Hal Lehrman, Former Journalist, Dies at 77
description: Hal Lehrman, former president of the Overseas Press Club, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his Manhattan home. He was 77 years old.

title: Keeping Hope Alive
description: At Halloween, with just a week to go, Michael Dukakis has a last chance to make this a close election. He needs to give Americans - particularly Democrats - who still don't want George Bush as President a good reason to vote Democratic after all.

title: International Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,643,000 for the quarter and $2,109,000 for the 6 months.

title: Angels in Red Berets? The British Are Edgy
description: The Guardian Angels, who patrol the subways and streets of New York, have brought their message of crime prevention to England, attracting a tempest of criticism from the Government, the police and transportation officials.

title: Describing Liberalism
description: In finally declaring himself ''a liberal,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis embraced an unpopular word and an honored but ambiguous tradition.

title: Review/Music; Period Instruments
description: The Hanover Band, which presented a concert of Haydn's ''Clock'' Symphony, Mozart's Horn Concerto in E flat (K. 447) and Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony on Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall, is a leading ensemble on the busy London original-instruments scene. But for a variety of reasons, it would be imprudent to judge the success or failure of that movement in standard repertory on the basis of this one sometimes beautiful, sometimes problematic concert.

title: Tuesday Morning Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: SEARS TO RESHAPE BUSINESS AND SELL TOWER IN CHICAGO
description: Amid a recent wave of multibillion-dollar takeover bids, Sears, Roebuck & Company today announced a broad restructuring plan intended to improve its financial performance.

title: A Dinner Where the 'L' Word Is as American as Apple Pie
description: The ''L'' word wasn't dirty in at least one place last night - the annual Liberal Party dinner.

title: Morrell Acts To Block Fine
description: John Morrell & Company today asked a Federal court to block a $4.33 million fine it received last week from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: VOLLEYBALL First Round to U.S.: The United States beat Japan yesterday to take the preliminary round of the four-nation Japan Cup tournament with a 3-0 record. The powerful United States team, which took the gold medal at the Olympic Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, defeated the Japanese squad, 15-7, 15-12, 16-14. The Soviet Union, which won the silver medal in Seoul, beat Argentina, 15-12, 15-7, 15-8, and finished second in the round with a 2-1 record. Argentina, the Olympics bronze medalist, placed third with a 1-2 record. Japan finished last at 0-3. In the semifinals tomorrow in Hiroshima, the United States will play Japan again and Argentina will face the Soviet Union.(AP)

title: Nicaragua to Continue Truce
description: The Government extended a seven-month truce with rebels today until the end of November, despite what it called continued aggression by the rebels, known as contras, and their sponsors in the United States. A Government said the decision to prolong the truce provided a contrast to the Reagan Administration's policies.

title: Genetic Tests May Help Solve a Whale Mystery
description: USING some of the newest tools of genetic research, scientists from the United States and Canada are struggling to explain one of the saddest mysteries in marine ecology: the failure of the right whale to reclaim its North Atlantic habitat.

title: V.A. Lowers Loan Rates
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it was lowering its maximum interest rate for federally backed V.A. home loan mortgages by one-half percentage point, to 10 percent.

title: Allied Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: The Race for Congress; S.I. Incumbent's Desire To Serve Is Challenged
description: The campaign in the 14th Congressional District is as much about Representative Guy V. Molinari's future -not in Congress but in a Bush administration - as about any other issue.

title: Edmonton Journal; With Death at Issue, Can Canada Wash Its Hands?
description: As a prosecutor sets out the evidence against him, Charles Ng sits impassively in the dock. Only the steady up-and-down cadence of his knees betrays whatever tension he feels as the court hears details of how at least 12 Californians, perhaps many more, died in an orgy of kidnapping, sexual abuse and murder.

title: Bush Ridicules Dukakis for Belatedly Saying That He Is a Liberal
description: ''Miracle of miracles,'' Vice President Bush said sarcastically. ''Headlines. Read all about it. My opponent finally, after knocking me in the debate, called himself the big 'L,' called himself a liberal.''

title: Fired-Up Dukakis Again Asserts The Right of Choice on Abortion
description: Michael S. Dukakis added new verses to his statement of the Democratic creed today, with one of his most forceful declarations yet on a woman's right to choose an abortion.

title: Westinghouse Pact
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would join with Multiflow Computer Inc. to market computer programs for engineers. Westinghouse will provide programs and computer systems for analyzing electricity, magnetism, heat and for other areas involved in finite element analysis. Multiflow, based in Branford, Conn., is a leader in computer technology and makes high-performance computers for science, engineering and general applications.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL)-Announced that the contract of Gordon Goldsberry, vice president of scouting, will not be extended for the 1989 season. MINNESOTA (AL)-Named Jay Robertson Northern California scout and Kevin Malone East Coast scout supervisor. Promoted Mike Radcliffe from a Midwest area scout to Midwest supervisor and Clair Rierson from part-time scout to full-time scout in the Southwest. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA)-Waived Gerald Paddio, guard-forward, and Ennis Whatley, guard. HOUSTON (NBA)-Waived Ron Cavenall and Steve Hayes, centers. LA CLIPPERS(NBA)-Waived Tracy Moore, guard. MILWAUKEE (NBA)-Waived Bruno Kongawoin, forward. NETS (NBA)-Acquired Mike McGee, guard, from the Sacramento Kings for second-round draft choices in 1991 and 1996. SEATTLE (NBA)-Waived Danny Young and Corey Gaines, guards. WASHINGTON (NBA)-Waived Cedric Maxwell, forward. CHICAGO (WBL)-Announced the resignation of David Kaplan, director of player personnel. FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES (NFC)-Activated Ron Brown, wide receiver. MIAMI (AFC)-Placed David Frye, linbacker, on injured reserve. Activated Dwight Stephenson, center, from the physically unable to perform list. NEW ORLEANS (NFC)-Signed Jeff Walker, offensive lineman. Waived Cliff Benson, tight end. TORONTO (CFL)-Activated Gill Fenerty, running back, from the injured list. Placed Lee Morris, wide receiver, on the injured list for the remainder of the season. WINNIPEG (CLF)-Released Brad Tierney, tackle. HOCKEY NHL-Suspended Rick Tocchet, Philadelphia Flyers right wing, for 10 games for a match penalty he received for an eye-gouging incident on Oct. 27. Suspended Mark Messier, Edmonton Oilers center, for six games for a stick-swinging incident on Oct. 23. Suspended Dave Hanson, Chicago Blackhawks, for 10 games for instigating a fight and deliberately attempting to injure a player on Oct. 28. DETROIT (NHL)-Sent John Chabot, center, to Adirondack of the American Hockey League. Recalled Doug Houda, defenseman, from Adirondack. WASHINGTON (NHL)-Called up Lou Franceschetti, left wing, from Baltimore of the American Hockey League. COLLEGES EAST CAROLINA-Announced the resignation of Art Baker, head football coach, effective Nov. 19, to become director of the personal development program for student-athletes on Feb. 1. LOUISIANA STATE-Suspended Torun Robinson, nose guard, for violating football team rules.

title: Telesis to Buy British Stake
description: Pacific Telesis Group and Jones Intercable Inc. said today that they had agreed to buy a majority interest in East London Telecommunications Ltd., a year-old British cable television and phone company. Terms were not disclosed. The alliance is the first between the San Francisco-based telephone company and Jones, the nation's 13th-largest cable operator, based in Englewood, Colo. The partnership hopes to capitalize on the British concern's license to serve an eight-square-mile waterfront section of eastern London that is being redeveloped as a residential and financial district. East London is privately owned.

title: Huge Philip Morris Revenues Aid Kraft Deal
description: Not many corporations could pay $13.1 billion in cash to investors without severely straining their balance sheets. Philip Morris Companies, which has agreed to pay that much to acquire Kraft Inc., is one of the exceptions, securities analysts said yesterday.

title: ISI Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pannill Knitting Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Publisher Resigns At House Beautiful
description: Marcia Miller, 46 years old, has resigned as publisher of House Beautiful magazine. When she was appointed two years ago, Ms. Miller became the first and only woman publisher at Hearst Magazines.

title: Japan Starts of Housing
description: Japan's housing starts fell 7 percent in September from a year earlier, to 144,566, and declined a seasonally adjusted 7.3 percent from the previous month, the Construction Ministry said today. In August, housing rose 2.2 percent from the period a year earlier. New construction of private homes dropped 11.8 percent, to 42,476. Rental housing starts slipped 11.8 percent, to 72,693. Construction of condominiums increased 18.1 percent, to 26,411, and building of company housing for employees rose 16 percent, to 2,986.

title: Campaign Center Vandalized
description: Vandals broke into the building in Burlington that houses the Vermont campaign offices of Michael S. Dukakis and put up bumper stickers that read, ''Smart Democrats Vote Republican,'' a campaign official said Sunday.

title: Political Power Wanes, Earning Power Endures
description: The Administration is coming to an end and you're leaving your high-profile job in Washington? No problem. You can make big money on the lecture circuit.

title: Cronus Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,491,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $1,282,000. The company said the latest third quarter is after a $12,500,000 pre-tax charge from the writedown of certain assets.

title: Versar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Knickerbocker Is Name For New Albany Arena
description: The name Knickerbocker Arena was victorious in a phone-in election here to choose the name of Albany's new sports arena.

title: Hako Minuteman reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chicago's Housing Pioneers
description: Since 1976, as a result of a Federal judge's order, a Chicago fair housing group has been plucking families from grim public housing projects and transplanting them to private, rent-subsidized suburban apartments. The program's success, documented in a new study, offers stirring lessons for all cities with isolated underclass communities.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the purchase of Kraft Inc. by the Philip Morris Companies misstated the number of Kraft shares and the total price of the deal in some editions. Kraft has 123.8 million shares. At $106 a share, the total purchase price is $13.1 billion, making it the second-largest deal in history, after the Chevron Corporation's $13.3 billion takeover of the Gulf Corporation in 1984.

title: Ruddick Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Tseng Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Making a Vocal Enemy
description: After two months in the job, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has made at least one vocal enemy.

title: Thornburgh Creates a Group To Press Drive on Pollution
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced today the creation of a ''legal SWAT team'' of Federal lawyers who would assist state and local governments in prosecuting pollution cases.

title: Reviews/Television; Of a Child Who Dies Of AIDS
description: The AIDS story remains largely untold on prime-time television dramas. Unable or unwilling to portray homosexuals or drug addicts in a manner that might be construed as sympathetic, teleplays insist on ignoring the vast majority of people with AIDS, people who desperately need support and the rudiments of human kindness. With the exception of ''An Early Frost,'' broadcast years ago, primetime television has been fostering the illusion that most AIDS carriers are the victims of tainted blood transfusions. The pretense toddles on, striving for typical television uplift with somber, moving stories of ''acceptable'' victims. Children are especially cherished and obviously easy subjects.

title: SOVIETS CITE GAINS WITH THE CHINESE
description: The Soviet Union and China have agreed to fix the position of most of their eastern border and are expanding talks to include the western frontier, a Soviet spokesman said today.

title: More Time on B.P. Sought by Kuwait
description: Kuwait has asked Britain for more time to sell its shares in the British Petroleum Company, the Kuwaiti pressagency reported. Earlier this month, Britain ordered the Kuwait Investment Office, the Government's overseas investment arm based in London, to lower its stake to 9.9 percent, from 21.6 percent, within a year. The decision followed a finding by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission that the holding's size threatened British interests.

title: Central Vermont Public Servce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 9 months includes a writeoff of $33,367,000 related to the company's investment in the Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: Matec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included an after- tax gain of $87,000 from the sale of assets.

title: Kitty Dukakis Is Hospitalized Because of a Viral Infection
description: Kitty Dukakis, wife of the Democratic Presidential nominee, was hospitalized tonight with a viral infection and a 102-degree fever, a campaign spokesman said.

title: MacDermid Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fed Intervention Bolsters Dollar
description: The Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan intervened to defend the dollar yesterday, sending the first signal of concern about its sharp devaluation of the last three weeks.

title: New Orleans Journal; An Invitation to Become The Life of the Cemetary
description: Bobbi and William Trufant Jr. took their children, Will and Courtney, on an outing last weekend, strolling in the Garden District and enjoying the sun. ''Just your basic American nuclear family, hanging out in the cemetery,'' Mrs. Trufant said.

title: Dickerson Leads Colts' Romp
description: Eric Dickerson rushed for 159 yards to go over 1,000 yards for a National Football League record-tying sixth consecutive season and scored a career-high four touchdowns as the Indianapolis Colts stunned the Denver Broncos, 55-23, in the first Monday night game at the Hoosier Dome.

title: Schwab May Repay Customers
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage firm, said today that it might take a one-time charge of $1 million to $2 million to reimburse customers for profits taken from the unauthorized trading of customers' shares.

title: Openness to Change Built Into Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Jets to Morocco
description: Morocco's national carrier, Royal Air Maroc, said it would buy 10 jets from the Boeing Company for $450 million. Air Maroc said that, besides the 737-400's and 737-500's that it had ordered, it was taking options on 10 more planes. The carrier, which now has two 747's in a fleet of 22 aircraft, has annual revenues of about $350 million and employs 4,800 people in 30 countries.

title: Panel Reviews New Evidence Of Misconduct by Lawmaker
description: The House ethics committee is reviewing evidence turned up by the Justice Department in its investigation of Representative Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, court papers indicate.

title: Tainted Cambodia Aid: New Details
description: The disclosure that Thai military officials have stolen American aid destined for the non-Communist rebels in Cambodia provides new details of an American covert assistance program that has been a part of the Reagan doctrine.

title: On Box, at Top
description: Michael Jordan was dressed to play basketball yesterday, but instead, he talked about breakfast cereal, posed with a picture of a cereal box almost as tall as he is, and got down on one knee with an actual box in hand. Such was his inauguration as the seventh ''celebrity athlete'' to be pictured on a box of Wheaties, the General Mills cereal marketed as ''the Breakfast of Champions.'' ''I'm very happy to be part of the Wheaties organization,'' said Jordan, clad in his No. 23 Chicago Bulls jersey and black sweat pants. ''A lot of people would love to be in my shoes.'' Jordan and company officials said that terms of their agreement would not be disclosed. Jordan's picture will be printed on at least 12 million boxes of the cereal. Others who have contracted with the Minneapolis-based company for the Wheaties limelight, beginning in 1956, include the pole vaulter Bob Richards, the decathlon star Bruce Jenner, Mary Lou Retton, Pete Rose, Walter Payton and Chris Evert. (AP)

title: Thrust of TV Campaign Ads Can Vary With the Territory
description: In campaign advertisements broadcast on radio stations whose audiences are largely black, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis denounces the urban terror caused by illegal guns and charges that ''in George Bush's Washington, they just say 'no' to gun control.'' But in the Dukakis campaign's television commercials broadcast in Texas, an announcer says: ''One candidate for President has voted for Federal gun control. Only one. George Bush.''

title: Lawter International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
How Can New York State Seek Budget Cuts in Mental Health?
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Issues Advance Again
description: Treasury securities prices continued to climb yesterday, largely in response to a rebound in the dollar after several interventions by the Federal Reserve and other central banks.

title: Florida Lottery Winners Sued
description: Two sisters who shared a $31.5 million Florida Lottery jackpot have suddenly found themselves facing a lawsuit by the former husband of one sister, who says all the money should be his.

title: Major New Studies Near Nuclear Plants Seek Health Effects of Radiation Leaks
description: IN an effort to determine if radiation from nuclear bomb factories or nuclear power plants has harmed nearby residents, Federal scientists have begun some of the most thorough and far-reaching studies ever made of the health effects of radiation leaking into the environment.

title: How Can New York State Seek Budget Cuts in Mental Health?; A Predictable Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Always the Diplomat
description: Michael B. Smith, who is leaving the Government after 30 years of public service, is nothing if not a diplomat. He said his current boss, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States Trade Representative, ''probably has the quickest mind'' of the five trade chiefs he has worked for, but then offered words of praise for the others.

title: Gleeful Quayle Says Dukakis Has Taken Off Mask
description: Dan Quayle was smiling broadly and rubbing his hands together with glee this morning as he climbed aboard his chartered Boeing 727 to begin another, and final, week of campaigning.

title: Intermet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Ballet; A Star Breaks Through
description: In an age of ballet companies with firm no-star policies, who would have thought the Joffrey Ballet would be the company to nurture and develop the first true shining young star American ballet has had in years?

title: South Africa Rand Sinks
description: The rand today fell to a record low of 4.39 to the British pound and plummeted against the West German mark and the yen. It sank even faster than the declining dollar, dropping to 2.47 to the dollar, its lowest level in months.

title: Armstrong World Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
49 GET TRANSFERS IN POLICE BIAS CASE IN QUEENS PRECINCT
description: Forty-nine officers, nearly a quarter of those assigned to a Queens police precinct, were transferred yesterday in response to accusations that white officers had subjected black officers to racial slurs over the last six months.

title: British Steel Plans An Offering in U.S.
description: British Steel P.L.C has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a United States offering of 24 million American depository shares. Each one represents 10 common shares of British Steel. Goldman, Sachs & Company will head the underwriters.

title: Chess
description: In a stunning surprise, a virtual unknown, 15-year-old Joel Lautier of France, won the world junior championship last month in Adelaide, Australia.

title: Civil Liberties in Britain: Are They Under Siege?
description: Although there has been little public outcry so far, the British Government may yet face a battle over its proposals to limit freedom of the press and restrict the right of defendants in criminal cases to remain silent.

title: LIBERALIZING STEPS PUSHED IN ALGERIA
description: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria has taken his boldest move yet to liberalize the country's single-party rule by ousting the most influential hard-liner.

title: The Story Goes On
description: The President of a delicately balanced country critical to the United States is killed. His top military officers die with him; so do the Ambassador and the military attache of the United States.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do dogs wag their tails?

description: The Whittaker Corporation, a specialty chemical and technology company, said today that Louis S. Caiola, a former food company executive, had offered $47.50 a share, or about $302.6 million, for the shares that he did not own.

description: b-Net income

title: Black Church, Burned Twice, Vows to Rebuild
description: Twice this year a black church has been burned to the ground, but its pastor delivers one message to the congregation: Forgive those who are responsible.

title: Ethics Panel Inquiry Leads to Changes on New York Elections Board
description: An investigation of the State Board of Elections has laid the groundwork for major changes in the board's hierarchy and for a struggle to control the bipartisan agency.

title: Campaign Trail; Yale Rally Makes Bush Turn Crimson
description: The Bush campaign expressed shock. Accusations by Michael S. Dukakis are expected. He's a Harvard man. But now the attacks are coming from our own Yalies.

title: Boeing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Off 1.24; Weakness in Dollar a Factor
description: Concern about the soaring level of takeover activity and early weakness in the dollar helped depress stocks across a broad front yesterday.

title: PS Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $593,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a loss of $2,415,000 for the quarter and net of $55,962,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations; the 9 months also included an extraordinary charge of $3,370,000. The latest periods' net from operations are after gains of $98,052,000 for the quarter and $105,543,000 for the 9 months on termination of pension plan; both periods' net from operations also included a $18.5 million writedown of proven producing gas properties. The year-ago periods' net from operations is after a gain on termination of pension plan of $3,746,000 for the quarter and the net loss from operations for the 9 months is after a gain of $11,237,000 on the termination of pension plan. Year-ago figures were restated to reflect revisions of certain items. Revenue is from continuing operations.

title: Pinning Down Liberal Label
description: The Republican team of George Bush and Dan Quayle delighted yesterday in mocking Michael S. Dukakis for asserting at last that he is a liberal, a label the two men have tried to pin on their Democratic rival for months.

title: A Texan Who Likes to Deflate The Legends of the Golden West
description: ''I'm a critic of the myth of the cowboy,'' says Larry McMurtry. ''I don't feel that it's a myth that pertains, and since it's a part of my heritage I feel it's a legitimate task to criticize it.''

title: The Message of the Marcos Case
description: It's not a shopping spree that brings the former Philippine First Lady, Imelda Marcos, to New York City this week. It's a Federal indictment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Oct. 12 about Harvard Law School guidelines on speech and dissent mistated a rule. The rule is, ''Any use of signs, prolonged standing or other activity likely to block the view of anyone in the audience should be confined to the back of the room.'' The reference was to signs, not songs.

title: Denver Inaugurating Clean Air Campaign To Win U.S. Funds
description: The Denver metropolitan area heads into its fifth annual Better Air Campaign on Tuesday trying to reduce carbon monoxide levels that are among the highest in the country and threaten its Federal highway funds.

title: Death in the Mountains: Could Two Women Fall?
description: Chestoa View, a scenic overlook jutting out from the Blue Ridge Parkway in the mountains of North Carolina, has become the focal point of a murder case full of contradictions and intrigue.

title: Kysor Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: The reduction of capital in the United States, as companies acquire huge debts in leveraged buyouts, could eventually put the banking system at risk, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned today.

description: Like his father, who founded the Johnson Chemical Company, Joseph Uddo earns his living making household disinfectants in a yellow brick building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: McDonnell Aircraft
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it was studying whether to develop a longer version of its medium-range MD-80 aircraft. The new plane would compete with the Boeing Company's 757 jetliner, a medium-range aircraft that seats about 185 people. The MD-80, with a range of about 3,000 miles, now seats 140 to 155 passengers, depending upon its configuration.

title: New Graphics Interface
description: MICROSOFT and I.B.M. announced yesterday that the long-awaited Presentation Manager interface for the OS/2 operating system is here at last. The age of the graphical user interface, which was derided as frivolous when it was first heralded by the Apple Macintosh, is now in full flower.

description: LEAD: For me, 600 of the most endangered children in the world are the 600 children who live in the shelter where I'm a social worker.

description: The prices that farmers received for raw products in October, on the average, were unchanged from a revised September index but were 13 percent higher than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Boeing Net Rises 38.5%
description: The Boeing Company today reported increased revenues and earnings for the third quarter, as well as a rise in commercial aircraft orders from the comparable period in 1987.

title: Campaign Trail; Stars Mark Age Gap In Dukakis Camp
description: The generation gap has ripped the Dukakis campaign.

title: Police Panel Member Calls for Changes
description: One of the six civilians on the Police Department's 12-member Civilian Complaint Review Board called yesterday for a series of changes to allow the panel to function more freely.

title: Two Youths Killed After Anti-Gang Sweep in West
description: Gang-related violence killed two 17-year-olds and wounded at least 13 people, including a baby, after 200 police officers conducted an anti-gang sweep.

title: National Horse Show Opens Amid Talk of Changing Site
description: The National Horse Show, Madison Square Garden's most prestigious sporting event, will be summoned to action this evening by the dulcet tones of a hunting horn for the 105th time here.

title: A Chinese Law On Bankruptcy
description: Thirty million Chinese with nothing to do at work are threatened by a bankruptcy law going into effect Tuesday.

title: Charge by Ditka
description: Another player intentionally twisted the knee of the Chicago quarterback Jim McMahon, Bears Coach Mike Ditka said yesterday in announcing that he intended to file a report with the National Football League. But the Patriots linemen who were in on the tackle denied they intentionally injured McMahon. ''That's a laugh; it's a joke,'' the defensive end Brent Williams said of Ditka's comment. ''I've never tried to intentionally hurt anybody.'' Tim Goad, a rookie nose tackle, said: ''There was no extracurricular activity there. We didn't try to hurt Jim McMahon.'' McMahon suffered the injury Sunday in the second half of the Bears' 30-7 loss to New England. He could be out from four to six weeks, his doctor said yesterday. McMahon did not suffer any torn cartilage and will not need surgery as previously feared, said the team trainer, Fred Caito. Ditka said McMahon knew he was hurt after the play. ''He was aware the knee was twisted, but he walked off the field because he didn't want to show he was hurt,'' the coach said. Ditka said Mike Tomczak would start against Tampa Bay next Sunday. McMahon, who has had a variety of injuries causing him to miss numerous games during his seven-year career, had started nine straight games this season before being injured.(AP)

title: New Theories Link Asteroid Impacts to Major Changes in Earth's History
description: CATASTROPHIC collisions with asteroids and comets have played a major role on Earth in shaping geology, climate and the evolution of life, a growing number of scientists assert.

title: Steinberg Had 'A Big Grin,' Doctor Says
description: When Joel B. Steinberg was told that Lisa Steinberg had suffered permanent brain damage, he grinned broadly and made a gruesome joke, a hospital physician testified yesterday.

title: Allen Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $550,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a $1,636,000 gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $624,000 and $2,422,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter includes $2,200,000 charge for employment termination costs. The company said the share earnings figure reduced by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Beazer to Sell Units
description: The British businessman Brian C. Beazer disclosed preliminary agreements to sell three units of the Koppers Company for a total of about $60 million. Mr. Beazer, seeking to pay down debt from Beazer P.L.C.'s $1.81 billion takeover of Koppers, said the units were Koppers International Canada Ltd., the Ivy Steel and Wire Company and Meadow Steel Products Inc. The buyers were not disclosed.

title: New Line Cinema reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Battle Mountain Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: * Avdel P.L.C., a British assembly-systems company, urged its shareholders to reject a $102 million takeover offer from Banner Industries, Cleveland. It called the offer ''wholly inadequate.''

title: Sally Field in Jet Accident
description: Sally Field, the actress, and her family were soaked with jet fuel but escaped unhurt when their private plane smashed into two parked aircraft after it lost power on takeoff. Pitkin County officials said Miss Field, 42 years old, was on her way to Burbank, Calif., Saturday when the accident occurred.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the third-quarter earnings of UAL Inc. misstated the company's gain on the sale of its interest in Covia, which manages the Appollo computer reservation system. The gain was $393 million before taxes, not after.

title: Rig Count Dips in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs fell by 10 last week, to a total of 923, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. A year ago, the count was 1,131. The count is the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, and it reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

description: b-Net loss

title: David Muss, 74, a Real-Estate Developer
description: David Muss, a real-estate developer who specialized in enclosed shopping malls, died of heart failure Saturday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sporting Life Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Seabird May Thwart Logging in Northwest
description: The Fish and Wildlife Service has agreed to consider listing the marbled murrelet, a robin-sized seabird of the Pacific Northwest, as an endangered species.

title: Episcopalian Woman Loses In Suffragan Bishop Voting
description: The Episcopal Diocese of Minnesota chose a male priest from Maryland as its new suffragan bishop over a woman priest with strong support from local clergy, a church spokesman said today.

title: A Muscular New Consumer Giant
description: When Philip Morris Companies completes its acquisition of Kraft Inc. it will be the world's largest consumer products company, standing alongside the likes of I.B.M. and General Motors, other American companies that are the largest in their fields.

title: British Outlook In Oil Reserves
description: Britain may remain self-sufficient in energy longer than expected, a British brokerage firm said today. The latest issue of County

title: Tower Expected to Bring $1 Billion
description: The sale of the 110-story Sears Tower, the world's tallest building and an august emblem of the Chicago skyline, will bring the highest price ever for a single building, more than $1 billion, real estate professionals predicted today.

title: Federal Judge in Minnesota Blocks Limit on Exit Polling
description: A Federal judge today blocked a state law that would have banned the three major television networks from conducting exit polls just outside voting places to predict winners on election night. District Judge David Doty issued a preliminary injunction against the law's enforcement, saying that the First Amendment protected the right to gather information and that the law was likely to be found unconstitutional.

title: Wilson Sporting Goods Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it does not release share-earnings data since only its debt securities are publicly traded.

title: Fibronics International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Sears, Roebuck announced a major restructuring. The giant retailer's plan, aimed at improving its financial performance, includes a stock buyback worth more than $1 billion and the sale of the Sears Tower in Chicago. The company also announced cost-cutting moves, its intention to sell part of Coldwell Banker, its real estate subsidiary, and plans to revamp its merchandising strategy. [ Page A1. ] Real estate experts predicted that the world's tallest building would bring a lofty price, more than $1 billion, despite the big risks a buyer will have to assume. [ D9. ] Philip Morris will have plenty of muscle after it completes its Kraft acquisition. What is not clear is whether its might can be used effectively. [ D1. ] The key to the Kraft deal are the huge revenues generated by the consumer goods behemoth. [ D6. ] Charles Schwab will take a one-time charge of $1 million to $2 million to pay customers for profits taken from unauthorized trading of their shares. [ D1. ] Arthur Andersen sued several of its former partners and Saatchi & Saatchi, accusing them of conspiring to take over its practice of management information consulting. [ D1. ] RJR Nabisco's stock price fluctuated sharply as Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts and a Nabisco management group continued to evaluate the company's worth and sought bank loans. [ D8. ] Wang will introduce a system tomorrow that it says will allow office computer users to communicate by using text, data, scanned images and voice messages. [ D5. ] Budget Rent-a-Car agreed to be acquired by investors headed by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The savings industry will resist any efforts to make it contribute more than a few billion dollars more to resolve its crisis, the chairman of the United States League of Savings Institutions asserted. Theo H. Pitt Jr. set a combative tone for the group's conference, contending that Congress and regulators are responsible for the problems of savings and loan institutions. [ D1. ] Prices for raw farm products held steady in October, the Agriculture Department reported. But the prices were 13 percent higher than a year earlier. [ D2. ] A $226 million settlement was reached in the Washington Public Power Supply System default case. Bonneville Power and the State of Washington joined 14 utilities in the agreement. [ D5. ] The shipbuilding industry is retrenching worldwide, and U.S. builders have been especially hard hit. [ A11. ] A disinfectant company is moving to Florida, joining hundreds of manufacturers who have fled New York City. [ B1. ] MARKETS The Fed and the Bank of Japan intervened in the currency markets - the first sign of concern about the dollar's recent drop. The Fed's action led to a rally in the dollar. Gold closed at $412.70 on the Comex, up 30 cents. [ D1. ] Stocks were depressed by concern about the soaring level of takeover activity and weakness in the dollar early in the day. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.24 points, to close at 2,148.65, after being down more than 15 points in morning trading. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury securities continued to climb, largely in response to the dollar's gains. [ D19. ] Copper futures prices reached all-time highs on the Comex. Demand for tight supplies has intensified. [ D22. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Presidential candidates have taken different approaches to health care policy. Business and Health. [ D2. ] A new variety of bridge loans is being tested. Underwriters led by First Boston are seeking to get back $1.15 billion they lent for Campeau's acquisition of Federated. Market Place. [ D10. ] Travel & Leisure's publisher is exuding confidence. The November issue will be its fattest ever. Advertising. [ D27. ]

title: South Korea Insider Case
description: Six stockbrokers and dealers have been arrested on charges of insider trading in a rare exercise of South Korea's securities laws, prosecutors said today.

title: Consumers Water Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $342,000 from the sale of property for both the quarter and 9 months; year-ago quarter includes gains of $310,000 and $316,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dallas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins center Mario Lemieux, who scored 3 goals and added 9 assists for 12 points in four games, was named the National Hockey League player of the week for the period ending Oct. 30. Lemieux, who is on a pace to score a record-breaking 276 points this season, has 16 goals and 22 assists for 38 points in 11 games. . . . The Washington Capitals called up the veteran left wing Lou Franceschetti yesterday from the club's American Hockey League affiliate in Baltimore. The 30-year-old Franceschetti has played parts of six seasons with the Capitals.

title: Abrams Sets Guidelines On Auto Advertising
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York announced new guidelines yesterday that he said would help to eliminate misleading automobile advertising in the state.

title: Investor Group to Buy Budget Rent-a-Car
description: The Budget Rent-a-Car Corporation said today that it had agreed to be acquired by an investor group headed by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd. for $333 million. The financing would be backed by the Ford Motor Company.

title: Computer Makers Set Venture Pact
description: FPS Computing, formerly known as Floating Point Systems Inc., has reached agreements with Stellar Computer Inc. of Newton, Mass., to develop technology and manufacture equipment. Under the agreements, FPS, based in Beaverton, Ore., will market, sell and service Stellar's graphics supercomputers under its name.

title: Koch Criticized on Plan To Open AIDS Shelters
description: A Koch administration plan to create housing in three boroughs for hundreds of homeless AIDS patients drew mixed reviews yesterday from community boards and local elected officials. Some vehemently opposed the housing, while others said they favored it in principle.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President Resigns Post At Rosewood Hotels
description: LEAD: Robert D. Zimmer, the designer and developer of luxury hotels, has resigned as president of the Rosewood Hotels Company, a division of the Rosewood Corporation. Mr. Zimmer said in an interview that he was stepping down in order to pursue his private interests, which include a variety of hotel and restaurant projects.

title: Vertex Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tacoma Boatbuilding Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the net income for all periods equals less than 1 cent a share.

title: From Blass and Herrera, a Tailored, Colorful Spring
description: The American spring fashion season actually began around noon yesterday when Bill Blass's legendary troops began marching into the Hotel Pierre to check out his new-season formula: lots of color, classic shapes and the return of chiffon.

title: Campaign Trail; A Bagel Fails to Rise To the Occasion
description: For Kitty Dukakis there are New York and Boston bagels and then there are Kansas City bagels.

title: Moto Photo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Robert C.L. Timpson, Banker, 80
description: Robert Clermont Livingston Timpson, an investment banker, died Saturday at his home in Southampton, L.I., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Astros Eye Five
description: The Houston Astros' general manager, Bill Wood, said yesterday that five candidates are being considered to replace Hal Lanier, who was dismissed as manager at the end of the season, and the latest prospect appears to be a former Yankee coach. ''For all practical purposes, I've completed the interviewing process,'' Wood said. Lou Piniella, the Yankees' former manager; Art Howe, the Texas Rangers' batting instructor; Matt Galante, the Astros' first-base coach, and Bill Robinson, the Mets' hitting instructor, are believed to be among the finalists. The fifth primary candidate apparently is Jeff Torborg, a former Yankees coach, who said that he was interviewed Sunday by Wood. . . . The Los Angeles Dodgers have agreed to terms on a one-year contract with Fernando Valenzuela. Financial terms were not disclosed. The accord leaves the World Series champions with seven players eligible for free agency. One of them, Alfredo Griffin, the shortstop, filed yesterday.(AP)

title: Parlex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Race for Congress; L Word to Metzenbaum Is Ticket to Re-election
description: By the standards of political oddsmaking, the Ohio Senate race should have been the Republican Party's surest bet for a major upset.

description: Last week, as the spring 1989 showings unrolled in Paris with great flair, there was hardly a collection that did not contain at least a few blouses made of one scant layer of chiffon and nothing more.

description: Mark K. Tavel, senior vice president at Value Line Inc., the big investment advisory service and money management firm, is leaving to head Rothschild Inc.'s asset management unit effective Dec. 1.

description: Dallas Green officially stepped into the New York spotlight yesterday, and his presentation to the news media might have seemed like the unveiling of the latest Paris fashion. Cameras clicked, notebooks opened, microphones gathered in every word that was spoken by the newest and latest line of Yankee managers.

description: Mayor Koch invited Kevin McAleer and his family to City Hall yesterday to soothe them. But minutes later, their lawyer arrived to sue New York City.

title: A Rosy Year For a Travel Magazine
description: JAMES S. BERRIEN had just returned from an international travel conference in Budapest last Friday, and he was bubbling with praise for an article about the Hungarian capital in the October issue of Gourmet. That seems odd only when you consider that Mr. Berrien is the publisher of a competing magazine, Travel & Leisure.

title: Bert McCord, Writer, 74
description: Bert McCord, a theater, film and entertainment reporter and critic for The New York Herald Tribune from 1943 to 1958, died of pneumonia, after several years of cancer treatment, at his home in North Pomfret, Vt., last Friday. He was 74 years old.

title: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the share earnings are pro forma and are based on the completion of the public offering of 6,740,400 common shares in August 1988. Prior to the offering, the company was a wholly owned subsidiary of Kinder-Care Inc.

title: POLAND ANNOUNCES DECEMBER CLOSING OF LENIN SHIPYARD
description: The Polish Government announced today that it would close the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, the birthplace of the Solidarity trade union, as part of what it describes as a drive to weed out unprofitable enterprises.

title: Sorting Out the Charter Amendment Questions
description: New York City charter amendment questions will be numbered 2 through 6 on the Nov. 8 ballot. The first question on the ballot deals with a proposal for a state transportation bond issue. WORDING ON THE BALLOT: Question 2 Shall the Board of Ethics be renamed the Conflicts of Interest Board, be made up of three independent citizens with no ties to government or political parties appointed by the mayor and confirmed by City Council, and be given the power to enforce prohibitions that shall both be strengthened and clarified, as proposed by the Charter Revision Commission? WHAT IT MEANS: Public employees would be barred from acquiring significant stakes in companies doing business with their city agency, and would be limited or barred from appearing before city agencies once they leave the city payroll. WORDING ON THE BALLOT: Question 3 Shall city agencies prepare and update plans for maintaining bridges, streets, parks, buildings and other major capital assets, and shall the mayor request the funds for such maintenance or explain the reasons for not doing so, as proposed by the Charter Revision Commission? WHAT IT MEANS: Public officials would have to prepare, oversee and put into effect plans to maintain such capital assets as bridges, parks, schools and prisons.

description: Two groups of gamblers and an individual player will share a $61.9 million lottery jackpot that officials say is the world's largest, it was announced today.

description: Rick Tocchet of the Philadelphia Flyers and Dave Manson of the Chicago Blackhawks were given 10-game suspensions yesterday, reflecting the National Hockey League's attempt to punish more severely players who deliberately cause injuries.

title: Man Is Given 2 Years For Threat to Jackson
description: A man was sentenced today to two years in prison and fined $100 on a charge of threatening the life of the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Presidential primary campaign.

title: Mentor Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Book Offers Medicine for Computer Viruses
description: FOR humans, a virus usually means a depressing period of runny noses, fatigue and other dispiriting symptoms. For computers, a virus is next to fatal; though the hardware survives, the information is scrambled or destroyed. It is as if your winter cold also wiped out your life savings.

title: Cadmus Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fight Seen On Savings Insurance
description: A top savings and loan executive said today that the industry would resist contributing more than an additional few billion dollars to help Congress deal with the savings crisis.

title: George B. Dippy, Executive, 88
description: George B. Dippy, a retired executive who helped build Young & Rubicam, the New York-based advertising agency, died of a heart attack Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: 2 Brothers Slain in Dispute at a Queens Bar
description: Two brothers were shot to death last night in a Long Island City bar by another patron following an argument, the police said. The assailant was taken into custody in a restaurant down the block from the bar, the police reported.

Kraft Deal Inquiry Sought
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum today called on the Federal Trade Commission to begin an antitrust investigation of the acquisition of Kraft Inc. by the Philip Morris Companies. Mr. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, said the merger, the largest ever among consumer product companies, could harm consumers.

title: Careers; A Shortage Of Women in Mathematics
description: THE American Mathematical Society recently celebrated its centennial and invited dozens of speakers to its headquarters city, Providence, R.I. But ''there was only one women speaker,'' said Rhonda Hughes, president of the Association for Women in Mathematics, pointing up the relative lack of women in the field.

title: The Brighter Side Of the Campaign Ads
description: The 1988 Presidential campaign's television advertising is so unappealing that it is making product advertising look good by comparison, a survey by Video Storyboard Tests, an independent commercial testing service, has found.

title: Change at Florida Paper
description: Eugene Patterson, 65 years old, retired today as chief executive of the Times Publishing Company of St. Petersburg and was succeeded by Andrew Barnes, editor and president. Mr. Barnes, 49, said the change of leadership would mean little change in the operations of The St. Petersburg Times. During Mr. Patterson's 10 years as chief executive, daily circulation rose to more than 300,000 from 195,000, Sunday circulation grew to nearly 400,000 from 243,000 and annual revenue increased to $160 million from $54 million.

title: Capitol as Shelter
description: Washington has a large and visible homeless community and nowhere is this more apparent than at the Capitol itself where a man has been living under the steps on the east front side for the last 13 years.

title: Chrysler Reported Ending 2 Models
description: The Chrysler Corporation will stop producing its Chrysler LeBaron GTS and Dodge Lancer models in March because of low sales, an automotive newsletter said. Ward's Auto World said halting production would bring only a few layoffs at the company's plant in Sterling Heights, Mich. A Chrysler spokesman declined to comment on the report.

title: For Trip to Courthouse, Just Basic Black Pumps
description: Imelda Marcos stepped out of her darkened limousine into the autumn chill yesterday, wearing only a lightweight, bare-backed, floor-length, dazzling turquoise traditional Philippine dress that covered not only her ankles but also her footwear.

title: U.S.C. Stays On Top
description: Southern California (7-0) easily maintained its spot as the No. 1 team in The New York Times's computer ranking this week by trouncing Oregon State, 41-20, while West Virginia (8-0) made an impressive jump -from 10th to 4th - after its 51-30 thrashing of Penn State. Notre Dame (8-0) and U.C.L.A. (7-1) switched positions. The unbeaten Irish moved into second place after beating Navy, 22-7, and the Bruins fell to third after the upset by Washington State, 34-30.

title: Venezuela Says Troops Killed 14 Fishermen in an Accident
description: Border troops killed 14 Venezuelan fishermen at a weekend picnic, mistaking them for Colombian guerrillas, the Government said today.

description: Wang Laboratories Inc. will introduce a system tomorrow that it says will allow office computer users to communicate with each other by using text, data, scanned images and voice messages.

title: Thomas B. Cooray, Cardinal, 86
description: Thomas Cardinal Cooray, the former Archbishop of Colombo, Sri Lanka, died on Saturday in Sri Lanka, the Vatican said today. He was 86 years old. The Vatican did not give the cause of death.

title: Bush Is Called Exceptionally Fit; Says He Can Now Handle Stress
description: Vice President Bush is in excellent physical shape, a White House physician says, and Mr. Bush says that psychologically he can handle stress better now than 20 years ago when he was a chronic worrier and suffered from ulcers. Still, with the Presidential election just eight days away and his travel schedule heavy, the Republican nominee says he is sleeping poorly these nights.

title: How to Look at TV, and the Future
description: In the 1990's Americans will begin to see TV, and perhaps the world, differently. Television sets will exchange their squarish shapes for a wider frame like that in movies and display high-definition images with twice as many scanning lines per frame. The picture will rival cinema in clarity. HDTV, it is called, and it embodies a profound choice for the United States:

title: Pilot Admits Slow Reaction To Jet Trouble
description: The captain of the Delta Air Lines jet that crashed in Texas in August told investigators he should have advanced his throttles to full power immediately when trouble developed instead of waiting 20 seconds, until just before impact, a Government report disclosed yesterday.

title: Narcissism Looming Larger As Root of Personality Woes
description: NARCISSISTS will be pleased to know that they now hold the fascination of psychotherapists more than ever. description: The stock price of RJR Nabisco Inc. fluctuated sharply yesterday in heavy trading as Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and an RJR Nabisco management group continued to evaluate the company's worth and sought to convince banks to lend money for a buyout.

title: Sunday Paper Seen for Post
description: Peter Kalikow, president and owner of The New York Post, will announce today that the newspaper will begin publishing on Sundays, Post executives said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Not guilty.'' - Imelda R. Marcos, in a Manhattan court. [ A8:1. ]

title: The F.B.I. Menaces Academic Freedom
description: LEAD: I resent the Reagan Administration's efforts to compromise scholars' professional reputations.In the last eight years, the

title: Midtown Pushcart Plans Disgust Many Vendors
description: The great midtown pushcart issue apparently remains a hot knish.

title: Critic's Notebook; 4 Films at Once On Holocaust Offer a Dialogue
description: Four films about the Holocaust opened in New York almost at once recently, and most filmgoers reacted like Annie Hall. When Woody Allen's character suggests seeing ''The Sorrow and the Pity'' one more time, Annie replies: ''I'm not in the mood for a four-hour documentary about Nazis.'' Who is ever in the mood for a film about Nazis? The best-intentioned people cannot find the right time to depress themselves. Others roll their eyes as if to say, ''We've seen it all before.''

title: Jepson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kansas Power & Light Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Campaign in Israel Eclipsed by Deaths In Attack by Arabs
description: As Israel's election campaign ended, politics were eclipsed today by mourning for a mother and her three children who were burned to death in a terrorist attack in the West Bank on Sunday night. And with that, the Labor Party realized its worst fears.

title: Falcons as Fake as the Real Thing
description: Sweat glistened on the round cheeks of the fat man. ''By Gad, sir, now, after 17 years!'' His eyes were moist. He hefted the weighty bundle. Then his stubby fingers made short work of the twine that bound the newspaper wrappings in place.

title: Assassination Theories
description: A quarter of a century after the assassination of John F. Kennedy, conspiracy theories are still alive and kicking, as evidenced by two new programs. At 9 o'clock tonight on Channel 31, there's ''Kwitny Report Special: The Kennedy Assassination,'' and arriving at 8 o'clock tomorrow on Channel 9 is ''American Expose: Who Murdered J.F.K.?'', with Jack Anderson as host. Since ''American Expose'' is being broadcast live, I was not able to review it, but its allegations of underworld participation in the assassination are similar to those of tonight's offering.

title: CANADA'S ELECTION NOW GROWS TIGHT
description: Seventy-seven years ago, a Canadian Government went before voters with a plan for lowering trade barriers with the United States. The Government, led by Sir Wilfrid Laurier, was routed by an opposition that fostered popular feeling with a slogan: ''No truck nor trade with the Yankees!''

title: Charter Ballot: A 3-Minute Test Of New Yorkers
description: In one week, New York City voters will be confronted by a ballot that has grafted onto its cardboard face a list of charter revision questions so vague and wordy that a more complex text of the proposals is required reading before a person enters the voting booth.

title: Thermo Process Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 20-percent stock dividend paid July 20, 1988.

title: Robinson Nugent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $160,000 from an accounting change.

title: Sale at Enron Unit
description: The Enron Oil and Gas Company, a Houston-based subsidiary of the Enron Corporation, and the American Exploration Company, also of Houston, have signed a letter of intent for American Exploration to buy certain Enron gas properties in Texas for $120 million. Enron said the transaction, expected to be completed before the end of the year, was the first phase of a plan to sell its oil and gas properties worth about $200 million to $300 million. The properties are in three Texas counties.

title: Poachers Kill Rhinoceroses At a Reserve
description: Poachers raided a special reserve Sunday night and slaughtered at least five white rhinoceroses, the authorities said today.

title: Article 259588 -- No Title
description: Bail for Imelda Marcos was set at $5 million yesterday after she pleaded not guilty to racketeering charges involving fraud and embezzlement in connection with Manhattan real-estate deals.

title: President's Namesake
description: On Nov. 15, the newly elected President and his wife will acquire namesakes at the National Aquarium: two loggerhead turtles.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. said it expected to receive a pretax gain of $110 million from the $285 million sale of its Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Mid-America unit to the Johnston Coca-Cola Bottling Group Inc. The deal should be completed before the end of the year and must be approved the board of Coca-Cola Enterprises and Johnston.

title: Lebanon Captive Tapes Plea to Next President
description: A Shiite Muslim fundamentalist group today released a videotape in which an American hostage appealed to the next American President to work for his release.

title: Savings Unit Resignation
description: J. Livington Kosberg, the chairman and chief executive of the Gibraltar/First Texas Savings Associations, two troubled savings institutions in Houston and Dallas, said he would resign both positions, effective at the end of the year.

title: Pre-Paid Legal Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,139,000 from an accounting change.

title: Giants' Woes Unmistakable
description: You look at the erratic way the Giants have been playing, especially at all the blocking breakdowns by the offensive line in Sunday's 13-10 overtime victory over the Detroit Lions, and you wonder why the Giants have a 6-3 record and lead their division.

title: Vintage Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Business and Health; Policy Differences Of the Candidates
description: GOV. MICHAEL S. DUKAKIS and Vice President Bush both say they can improve health care in the United States without breaking the bank, but they disagree in major ways on how to do it.

title: Doctors Test Radiation To Combat Rejection In Organ Transplants
description: A HANDFUL of scientists are pursuing new research into a radical form of radiation therapy for people who receive organ transplants. The researchers have shown that the radiation, which fundamentally alters the immune system, greatly reduces, or in some cases eliminates the need for the toxic drugs that combat rejection.

title: Dr. Ruth Ellen Bloustein, Pediatrician, 65
description: Dr. Ruth Ellen Steinman Bloustein, a pediatrician and clinical assistant professor at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, died yesterday at her home in Piscataway, N.J. She was 65 years old.

title: Brintec Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $376,000 and $1,345,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Extortion Of Teachers Is Charged
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a member of the Newark Board of Education today on charges that he extorted money from two teachers in exchange for using his influence to secure promotions for them.

title: Article 248188 -- No Title
description: A Federal agency and the State of Washington joined 14 utilities today in a $226 million settlement package stemming from the $2.25 billion default on bonds sold to construct two abandoned nuclear plants.

title: John Houseman, Actor and Producer, 86, Dies
description: John Houseman, who spent more than half a century in the theater as an influential producer and director but who did not achieve fame until, at the age of 71, he portrayed a crusty law school professor in the film ''The Paper Chase'' and its subsequent television series, died of spinal cancer yesterday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 86 years old and despite his failing health had been working on various projects until three days ago.

title: Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sturm, Ruger & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mortgage Investments Plus reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jets Enjoy Something Special
description: The Jets have been bad and they have been good in the 1980's, but the special teams have always been special.

title: Review/Concert; Night of European Post-Modernism
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Next Wave Festival joined forces over the weekend to present three concerts of a program of determinedly post-modernist European orchestral music in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Opera House. Each score was a major effort, lasting between 25 and 33 minutes. There was one post-modernist ''greatest hit'' and three premieres, and it was the hit that proved the highlight of Friday evening's performance.

title: Dukakis Offers Realistic Homeownership Plan; The Builder's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Barry Wright Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax restructuring charges of $550,000 and $3,670,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income Year-ago 9 months included an after-tax gain of $800,000 from the sale of a building.

title: Our Towns; Football Star Disabled on Field Stirs Thousands
description: Tommy Phillips, a 15-year-old straight-A student and emerging star in three sports at Hawthorne High School, fractured his neck making a tackle in a football scrimmage on Aug. 31. His legs and fingers are paralyzed now, and his head is braced and immobile.

title: Deep Hole Drilled to Study Dynamics of Volcano
description: IN an ambitious effort to understand the subterranean dynamics of volcanoes, scientists at Los Alamos National Laboratory last week completed drilling a deep hole in the Jemez Mountains of northern New Mexico. They penetrated 5,780 feet into the hot interior where underground water under pressure is heated to temperatures of nearly 600 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: El Paso Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,240,000 from an accounting change. The latest 12 months includes a charge of $17.6 million from a provision for securities losses. The year-ago 12 months includes a charge of $24.4 million from a writeoff of costs in connection with settlement of a rate case.

title: Tribute to 'The Meat Wagon'
description: A BANTAMWEIGHT named Charlie Phil Rosenberg, preparing for a title fight against Cannonball Martin on March 20, 1925, suffered through a stern regimen enforced by his trainer. Rosenberg, having ballooned to 155 pounds, had three months until the fight to shed 37 pounds and get down to the 118-pound limit.

title: Nasta International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lights Will Blaze for the Night Many Say the Holocaust Began
description: In churches and in synagogues, in schoolrooms and in homes, thousands of people across the country are preparing for a solemn commemoration Nov. 9 of the 50th anniversary of Kristallnacht, the night when many say the Holocaust began.

title: J. H. Wood Dies at 87; Led the Tribune Co.
description: J. Howard Wood, former president and chairman of the board of the Tribune Company and former member of The Associated Press board, died Sunday at Lake Forest Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: An Opening to North Korea The United States announced that it was relaxing restrictions on trade with, travel to and diplomatic contact with North Korea. Page A3. Review for Death Row Aid The Supreme Court agreed to decide if states must provide lawyers to indigent death row inmates for appeals on constitutional grounds. Page A23.

title: Unilever in Accord For Durkee Foods
description: Unilever United States Inc. said it had agreed to pay $185 million to buy the Durkee Industrial Foods Corporation from Hanson Industries, the American subsidiary of Hanson P.L.C., a British conglomerate. Unilever, a unit of Unilever N.V. of the Netherlands, expects to complete the purchase by the end of the year.

title: Defamation Suit Over Brawley
description: Steven Pagones, the Dutchess County prosecutor, filed an $885 million defamation lawsuit today against Tawana Brawley and her three advisers for accusing him of sexually attacking the teen-ager.

title: Books of The Times; Laurence Olivier: A Half-Century at the Pinnacle
description: Laurence Olivier By Anthony Holden Illustrated. 504 pages. Atheneum. $22.50.

title: Once Again, Rogers Faces the Turmoil of Being a Survivor
description: He needed help lifting his legs. He has lain on his back in the intensive care unit here for more than a week. Each leg, he said, felt as if it weighed 70 pounds.

title: Intensive Fishing Cuts Number of Mature Cod
description: Researchers say fishermen using more sophisticated equipment are catching cod before they are old enough to spawn, causing the number of mature fish in New England waters to plummet.

title: Chase Says It's Far From Relocation Decision
description: Amid tense negotiations that have included the highest officials in New York and New Jersey, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which is planning to move 4,600 workers to either Brooklyn or Jersey City, said late yesterday that it was far from a decision.

title: Judith Garden, Flower Arranger, Dies at 81
description: Judith Charach Wyker, who as Judith Garden delighted generations of New Yorkers with her flower designs, died of cancer yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Campaign Trail; Unmasking Bush Reveals, Well, Bush
description: For those who believe that Mr. Bush would offer more offbeat moments as President than Mr. Dukakis, there was fresh evidence on Halloween.

description: b-Includes an $19.9 million after-tax writedown of oil and gas properties. c-Includes an $9 million after-tax writedown of oil and gas properties.

New Civil War Battles
description: Many of the great Civil War battles between the Army of the Potomac and the Army of Northern Virginia were fought within a day's march or so of Washington, and the Virginia and Maryland countrysides near the capital are dotted with battle sites that are part of the National Park System.

title: Tenneco Selling Louisiana Pipeline
description: Tenneco Inc., which began a $7.3 billion sale of assets last month, said its Louisiana Gas Corporation Pipeline business was up for sale. Industry analysts estimate the unit will bring anywhere from $200 million to $500 million. The pipeline represents a small fraction of Tenneco's pipeline subsidiary, which has a total network of more than 20,000 miles.

title: New York Won't Reach Goal On Toxic Wastes, Study Says
description: New York State's goal to clean up inactive hazardous-waste sites by the year 2000 is unrealistic and the Environmental Conservation Department is undermining its credibility by sticking to the goal, a legislative commission said in a report today.

title: Dr. King's Unwelcome Heirs
description: If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, veterans of the 1960's civil rights movement can feel flattered by today's antiabortion movement.

title: From Greek Outlaws, Underground Food
description: ACROSS the mainland of Greece, people have been digging holes for their dinner for centuries. This manner of cooking - in a shallow dirt-covered pit over smoldering coals -is called steen hovoli, or in embers. But more often than not, it is affectionately referred to as klephtica -of thieves.

title: Family Steak Houses of Florida reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Reviews/Music; Improvisations With a Soviet Flavor
description: Giggles filled the Knitting Factory again and again during the first set Friday night by the duo of Sergei Kuryokhin, a pianist, and John Zorn on alto saxophone. Mr. Kuryokhin has been one of the Soviet Union's leading underground musicians, playing jazz and leading various improvisational groups he calls Popular Mechanics. On his first United States tour, he was joined for two nights by Mr. Zorn, a kindred spirit whose quick-changing, mix-and-match pieces have come to define quick-cutting downtown improvisation; the duo shared a double bill with the duo of Mal Waldron on piano and Marion Brown on alto saxophone.

title: Old Age Hasn't Become a Leisure Paradise Yet; The Real Drones

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Backer Spielvogel
description: Northern Telecom Ltd., a $5 billion worldwide marketer of telecommunications systems based in Toronto, has chosen Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York, to build its image in the United States, Europe and Asia. The budget, says one person familiar with the account, is $10 million to $12 million, a large figure considering that the holding company has done little image advertising in recent years and that the budget will initially be devoted only to print. J. Walter Thompson, Chicago and Toronto, will continue to handle product and systems advertising for Northern Telecom Canada and Northern Telecom Inc., the United States-based corporate office.

title: Howard J. Friedman, Architect, 69
description: Howard J. Friedman, chairman of the architecture department at the University of California at Berkeley, died Friday. He was 69 years old.

description: IT began as a humdrum affair, this annual dinner put on by the Professional Football Writers. This was on a night in May of 1970 at the old Americana, if memory serves. This writer finished the meal, witnessed a few annual awards presented, heard a few speeches and, naturally, began a discreet move toward the exit.

title: Sister Issues
description: Zivorad Kovacevic, the Yugoslav Ambassador to the United States, made an effort yesterday to explain the complexities of his country's politics by drawing a jesting analogy to the United States Presidential contest. Introducing the visiting president of the Slovenian Republic, Janez Stanovnik, he said that the Slovene had won his post in an election last spring after ''a televised debate on the issues'' with his opponent.

description: Vice President Bush said today that if he was elected President he would seek a summit meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ''at the earliest time that would serve the interests of world peace.''

title: For Likud, Cheers and Drums; for Labor; Disbelief
description: As early returns in Israel's general election began to reveal a slight advantage for the right-wing Likud party early today, close to 100 Likud supporters gathered outside the party's campaign headquarters in Tel Aviv.

title: Kodak Profit Rises by 9.8%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company today reported a 9.8 percent rise in its third-quarter profit as reduced taxes and increased product sales continued to make 1988 a rosy year for the photo giant.

title: Loiselle Lifts Devils With a Late Goal
description: Except for an occasional performance by a goaltender, regular fans of the Devils are not treated to remarkable individual efforts like the one tonight by Claude Loiselle, the indefatigable center.

First Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: First Bancorp is based in Troy, N.C.

title: INSIDE
description: N.C.A.A. Penalizes Kansas The University of Kansas was placed on probation for three years for recruiting violations and cannot defend its N.C.A.A. basketball title. Page B9. Soviet Missiles in Kabul Washington accused Moscow of deploying advanced missiles in the capital of Afghanistan and said they posed a threat to Pakistan. Page A8.

title: Differing Views of America's Global Role
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis appear to be offering voters fundamentally different approaches to America's role in world affairs at the end of the 20th century. But so far these differences remain only in outline, as the candidates have avoided discussing some basic issues in real detail.

title: G.E. Radio Station Sale
description: The General Electric Company has sold its San Francisco radio station, KNBR-AM, to Century Broadcasting of Chicago for $27 million, The San Francisco Chronicle reported today. The reported sale price for the 50,000-watt station eclipses recent prices paid for other stations in the area. Century owns KMEL-FM in SanFrancisco as well as stations in Chicago, Denver and St. Petersburg, Fla. The sale must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Court Stiffens Rules to Prevent Abuse in 'Adopt a Horse' Program
description: A Federal ''adopt-a-horse'' program that is supposed to protect wild horses and burros is actually sending some of them to slaughter, an appeals court has ruled in upholding restrictions on the program.

title: Loan Plan in Venezuela
description: Venezuela is considering a plan to raise up to $1 billion in new loans based on future crude oil sales and has been in touch with the Bank of America and Salomon Brothers Inc. about the plan, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Royal Charter Bond Yields Set
description: The New York Housing Development Corporation is tentatively offering $115.1 million of residential revenue refunding bonds for Royal Charter Properties Inc. The bonds, which have a maximum yield of about 7.438 percent for an issue due in 2017, are being offered through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: U.S. Agrees to Limit Pollutant Linked to Acid Rain
description: The United States joined with 24 other industrialized nations today in signing an international protocol to freeze the rate of emission of nitrogen oxides, a major source of acid rain and other serious air pollution problems.

title: Sports People; Graf Withdraws
description: Having already won the Grand Slam and an Olympic gold medal this year, Steffi Graf announced yesterday that she was withdrawing from the Federation Cup in Australia next month, the top championship in women's team tennis. Claus Stauder, president of the German Tennis Federation, said he was told by Graf's father and manager, Peter Graf, that his daughter needed to rest after a busy 1988 tournament schedule. The Bild newspaper of West Germany reported that Graf wanted to skip the tournament scheduled for Dec. 5-11 in Melbourne to spend Christmas at home with her family. With Graf, West Germany beat the United States in last year's final (AP)

description: b-Includes an $868,000 gain from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Teleconnect Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bombs Kill 23 in North India; Police Blame Sikh Militants
description: Three bombs exploded in northern India today, killing at least 23 people and wounding 64, the police and witnesses said. Officers said radicals fighting for an independent Sikh homeland in Punjab state were responsible.

title: Ruling Seen Curtailing 'Poison Pills'
description: Legal experts said yesterday that the order by a Delaware Chancery Court dismantling a ''poison pill,'' or shareholder rights plan, used by the directors of Interco Inc. was a significant precedent. If upheld on appeal, the decision would sharply limit the ability of management to use poison pills to block takeover bids that the directors find unsatisfactory.

title: State by State; Choice Is Troubling County That Picks Winners
description: ''It seems like out of 240 million Americans,'' said David Doty, a high school principal, ''with the primaries and all the rest we go through, the speeches we listen to, the miles they travel, there's got to be better people out there than these two.''
