title: Arizona Commerce Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included a $3 million allowance for writedown of assets and $250,000 for restructuring costs. The bank also said there was a $931,000 provision for possible future credit losses and an adjustment to the residual value of lease finance receivables.

title: The Political Price of Rice, Resisted
description: In the first test of the Administration under the new trade law, reason has prevailed. Clayton Yeutter, the Government's chief trade official, has rejected a plea by American rice growers to investigate Japan's ban on rice imports. Election-year politics and the facts of the case might have favored the rice growers, but Mr. Yeutter figured that a showdown at this time would yield little and would poison relations with Tokyo. His decision was a welcome sign of flexibility in applying the new law.

title: Hans Peter Kraus, 81, Book Dealer and Collector
description: Hans Peter Kraus, one of the world's foremost rare-book dealers and bibliophiles, died of pneumonia at his home in Ridgefield, Conn., yesterday. He was 81 years old and had remained active until a few days ago in the shop he had opened in Manhattan nearly half a century ago.

title: Ladd Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Insurance-Payment Schedule Gives Hospitals More Money
description: Hospitals in New York State can start getting more money from health insurers for various in-patient services provided by the hospitals, a state Health Department spokesman said today.

title: LISA S. TANKOOS MARRIES PHILLIP C. ESSIG
description: The marriage of Lisa Suzanne Tankoos, a daughter of Mrs. Willard C. Rappleye Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late S. Joseph Tankoos Jr., to Phillip Charles Essig, the son of Abraham W. Essig of Rocky Mountain, Va., and Arlene P. Essig of Robesonia, Pa., took place yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Charles Dolan performed the ceremony.

title: Pretoria Bars Major Opposition Newspaper for Month
description: The Government today barred South Africa's most prominent opposition newspaper, The Weekly Mail, from publishing for the next month.

description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today swept into the industrial midsection that he knows he must win to capture the Presidency and delivered a heated attack on Wall Street speculators and corrupt Government officials.

title: Young Shape Of Spring To Come
description: GEOFFRY GERTZ showed his first collection in April in a Greenwich Village restaurant with waiters serving margaritas while models in funky leathers sauntered through the crowd. This week, he took over a gleaming white loft and put on a professional show of grown-up clothes in rich fabrics and inventive cuts.

title: Gilbert Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 months include a charge of $2,070,000 for consolidation of certain operations.

title: Police Officer Shot to Death in Mississippi
description: A gunman shot and killed a police officer today, firing into a parked patrol car and shooting at the officer again as he got out of the car. The assailant then apparently called the sheriff's office, the police said.

title: Americans Help Establish Hungary Managers' School
description: With Abel G. Aganbegyan, economic adviser to the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, beaming approval, Hungarian, American and Italian partners today signed into being an American-style management training institute here, the only one of its kind in Communist Europe.

description: Under the precise musical direction of Christopher Keene, who is soon to take the administrative reins of the company, the New York City Opera has opened an admirable revival of ''The Turn of the Screw'' by Benjamin Britten.

title: Ken Niles Dies at 82; a Pioneer Broadcaster
description: Ken Niles, a pioneering radio broadcaster whose career extended from the 1920's through the 1940's, died of heart failure Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82 years old. Mr. Niles began his broadcasting career in Washington State and California shortly after the first radio stations went on the air. He was a producer and announcer for the Don Lee Network, a West Coast radio network that was later acquired by CBS. Mr. Niles began a series of original radio dramas called ''Theater of the Mind'' in 1928. In the mid-1930's, he was the producer and host, with Louella Parsons, of ''Hollywood Hotel,'' a variety show that featured interviews with movie stars and introduced the song ''Hooray for Hollywood.''

title: Pushing an Open Soviet Door
description: If Mikhail Gorbachev succeeds in reforming the Soviet economy, will Moscow pose more or less of a threat to Western security? Should the West link increased trade and capital flows to good Soviet behavior in arms control, regional conflict and human rights?

title: WINE TALK
description: IN the fall of 1911, the French Government sent troops into the Champagne region to battle rioting grape growers. The growers were protesting the Champagne makers' longstanding policy of buying inexpensive grapes from outside the region, yet calling the finished wine Champagne. It took time but the growers won. Today, only grapes grown in the legally defined Champagne region can be used in the making of Champagne.

title: Israeli Planes Again Raid Palestinians in Lebanon
description: The Israeli Air Force raided Palestinian guerrilla positions in southern Lebanon and the outskirts of Beirut today, killing 4 people and wounding 22, the police said.

description: Egypt and the United States signed an agreement today under which Cairo would help produce M-1A1 tanks, the most sophisticated tank in the American arsenal.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Minneapolis
description: LEAD: It may not quite rival Bayreuth, with Champagne and foie gras from the picnic basket during the opera's intervals, but it's a start. To celebrate its 10th anniversary, the 510 Restaurant, grande dame of haute cuisine in the Twin Cities, commissioned an operetta, ''Music and Mime at the Five and Dime'' - 510, get it?

title: Campaign Trail; Dukakis Is Stirring To a Reggae Beat
description: After weeks in the doldrums, the Dukakis campaign is plainly in an upbeat mood. Large crowds welcome the Democratic candidate, whose aides are busily pointing to some polls that show the gap closing, to a candidate who rolls up his sleeves and punches out strong rhetoric about Mr. Bush. On the campaign plane, called the Sky Pig by the staff and reporters, Steve Engelberg, a 46-year-old Washington lawyer, has been unofficially appointed ''Chief of Surge Operations,'' explaining to everyone within earshot that the candidate is, yes, surging.

title: Oregon Prisoners Subdued After Disturbance
description: Guards used high-pressure water hoses today to subdue prisoners protesting the way homosexual inmates are treated and other conditions at the Oregon State Correctional Institution.

title: Global Marine Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Southeastern Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Marines in Panama Fired On
description: United States Marine guards at an Air Force base in Panama exchanged sporadic gunfire with unidentified intruders for almost two hours, but no injuries or casualties were reported, the Defense Department said today. The incident, the fourth such in a month, occurred Monday night on the southern boundary of a petroleum tank area at Howard Air Force Base.

title: A Column for Meese
description: Former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, who was never thought to have much fondness for journalists, has decided to become one himself.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom Profits Up
description: The Omnicom Group announced yesterday that its net income for the third quarter of 1988 had increased 25 percent from a year earlier. The group, which includes BBDO Worldwide, DDB Needham Worldwide and Diversified Agency Services, reported net income of $3.6 million for the quarter, or 15 cents a share. Omnicom also reported that worldwide revenues from commission and fee income increased 12 percent from last year, to $633.3 million, reflecting growth rates of 9 percent domestically and 20 percent internationally.

title: Meret Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,619,109 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a $184,717 loss from discontinued operations and a $660,000 extraordinary gain.

title: Sports People; Howell Satisfied
description: Jay Howell, who was eligible for free agency, has agreed to a two-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers for a guaranteed $2.25 million. Another relief pitcher, Ron Davis of San Francisco, filed for free agency, raising the total of players declaring themselves free agents to 51. . . . Dickie Thon, an infielder with the San Diego Padres, filed a demand to be traded, meaning the Padres must trade him by March 15 or he becomes a free agent. . . . The Oakland Athletics announced that they would not exercise the option for 1989 on the contract of Glenn Hubbard, second baseman, who is eligible for free agency. ''It is very possible that we will ask Glenn to return to the A's for the 1989 season,'' said Sandy Alderson, the Oakland general manager.(AP)

title: Sports People; Review in Order
description: The World Boxing Council agreed yesterday to review tapes of last Saturday's lightweight title unification bout between Julio Cesar Chavez and Jose Luis Ramirez, before deciding whether to order a rematch. Chavez, the World Boxing Association champion, beat Ramirez, the World Boxing Council champion, by a unanimous decision after the referee halted the bout following an accidental head butt that left Ramirez bleeding. ''Ramirez deserves a review of the circumstances under which he lost the title,'' said Ramirez's manager, Michel Acari.(AP)

title: Old Age Hasn't Become a Leisure Paradise Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Held in PATH Fight, And Cameras Get Credit
description: When a group of ''skinheads'' began beating a 31-year-old New Jersey man in a Manhattan PATH station on Saturday, supervisors at the railroad's operations center four miles away in Jersey City saw the whole thing.

title: Cray to Introduce A Supercomputer
description: Cray Research Inc. said it was introducing a supercomputer that will have double the common memory available in its original Cray 2/4-256 system. The Cray 2/4-512, with a list price of $17 million, combines four processors with more than 512 million 64-bit words, or about 4.3 billion bytes, of directly addressable common memory.

title: Soviets Said to Deploy Missiles in Kabul
description: The United States accused the Soviet Union today of deploying advanced missiles in Kabul, the Afghan capital, and said they posed a threat to Pakistan.

description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1.7 million and $3.5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $3.2 million and $9.6 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Gulf and Western Unit Plans for a Retirement
description: LEAD: The Associates Corporation of North America, a commerical and consumer finance unit of Gulf and Western Inc., said yesterday that it was restructuring its senior management to accommodate the retirement of its president and chief operating officer, Ronald J. Krause, a year from now.

title: Emerson Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jockeys Bring Strike to Close
description: New York's regular jockeys yesterday announced an end to their 13-day strike and said they would resume riding today at Aqueduct Race Track under individual contracts with those owners who will pay them the higher fees they have been seeking.

title: Itel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said earnings before a non-cash federal tax provision for the latest periods were $20.7 million, or 62 cents a share, for the quarter, and $40.2 million, or $1.15 a share, for the 9 months. The year-ago periods' earnings before a non-cash federal tax provision were $15.5 million, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter, and $18.3 million, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months. The year-ago 9 months' share earnings was surpassed by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Solidarity Sees a Baited Trap in Plan to Close the Gdansk Shipyard
description: Solidarity leaders accused the Government today of seeking to provoke labor violence by closing the Lenin Shipyard, but they said they would refrain from protest strikes.

Intellicall Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Liberty Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an investment loss of $120,000 for the quarter and an investment gain of $7,078,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $2,607,000 for the quarter and $6,882,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,031,000.

title: Review/Theater Tea for 3, Laced With Gin and Sodden With Failure
description: On the evidence of ''Tea With Mommy and Jack,'' Shela Walsh specializes in the loopy monologue and the scatological soliloquy. Ms. Walsh's plot, drawn very loosely from Jack Kerouac's relations with his mommy, tends to go on hold from time to time, while Sylvia Miles (Mommy) and David Groh (Jack) give out with bursts of prose, not too much of it printable in a family journal, yet tasty even when not in the best of teatime taste.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A classic French sauce that I learned in my apprentice days but rarely see on menus today is sauce chateau. I thought about it recently when looking for an accompaniment to sauteed shell steaks. This quick sauce is made by sauteeing some shallots until wilted, then combining them with white wine, herbs and beef broth.

title: EATING WELL
description: LAST week The Living Section published an article about the growing interest in oat bran as a way to lower cholesterol, and included a list comparing the nutritional value of oat-bran muffins sold commercially. The response belies the theory that people have stopped cooking. Of the dozens of telephone calls and letters received by The New York Times, most of the people asked for recipes.

title: Klein Moves Toward Minimalism; Trigere Perfects the Princess Line
description: CALVIN KLEIN showed a minimalist collection for spring yesterday, with a strong sportswear slant that represented the designer's return to his roots.

title: Chrysler to Open High-Tech Center
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would open a high-technology center in a mothballed plant in Detroit to develop new manufacturing processes in cooperation with its leading suppliers.

Firstbank of Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $305,000 for the quarter and $1,329,000 for the 9 months, and a loss of $1,739,000 for the both periods on the sale of Firstbank Mortgage Co.'s assets. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $296,000 for the quarter and $481,000 for the 9 months.

description: To the Editor:

description: The earnings reflect the company as a wholly owned subsidiary of AGS Computers Inc., from which it was spun off on Oct. 6, 1988.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Early returns in Israel's election show a close race with the Likud party winning 40 seats and the Labor Party 38, but analysts said the pattern favored Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader. Page A1

title: Copper Prices at Record Levels
description: Copper traded at record levels yesterday as a two-week strike by Peruvian miners further tightened global supplies at a time of strong industrial demand for the metal worldwide.

title: Nabisco's Sale Seen As Likely
description: It is almost certain now that RJR Nabisco Inc., the giant food and tobacco concern, will be sold shortly, Charles E. Hugel, the company's chairman, said in a telephone interview yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the New York Marathon misstated the world's best marathon time in some editions. It was 2 hours 6 minutes 50 seconds, set by Belayney Densimo of Ethiopia on April 17. The previous record was 2:07:12, run by Carlos Lopes of Portugal in 1985.

title: GAUGE OF ECONOMY SHOWS THIRD DROP IN 5-MONTH PERIOD
description: The Government's chief gauge for predicting the economy fell one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the third decline in the latest five months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Economic Scene; Politicizing Loans To the Soviets
description: WILL Mikhail Gorbachev try to shore up support at home with foreign-financed consumer imports? In the last three years Soviet hard currency debts have nearly doubled. And in the last few weeks the Soviet Union has negotiated lines of credit exceeding $9 billion, setting off speculation that desperate Soviet leaders were about to stop worrying about foreign debt and learn to love designer jeans.

title: C.I.A. CITES DOUBTS ON SOVIET ECONOMY
description: A new study by the Central Intelligence Agency asserts that a senior economic adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, might have exaggerated the Soviet Union's economic problems before Mr. Gorbachev's rule.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Edberg Upset: Unseeded Paolo Cane of Italy stunned Stefan Edberg, the Wimbledon champion, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1, last night in a second-round match of the $642,500 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships. Cane, ranked 101st in the world, handed Edberg only his second opening-match loss in a tournament this year. He lost to Mark Woodforde of Australia at the Canadian Open in August. ''I had nothing to lose and I played very relaxed,'' Cane said. ''I knew I had a chance to beat him if he didn't serve well.'' Edberg was broken three times in the final set. Edberg said he has simply played too much in the last five weeks. Boris Becker, the No. 3 seed from West Germany, was extended to three sets by Johan Carlsson of Sweden in another second-round match before winning, 6-2, 2-6, 6-3.(AP) Smid Upsets Gilbert in Straight Sets: Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia upset Brad Gilbert, 6-1, 6-4, yesterday to highlight first-round play in the $1 million European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. Gilbert, of Piedmont, Calif., is ranked 13th and had advanced to the finals of a tournament last week in Paris before losing to Amos Mansdorf of Israel. Mansdorf won his first-round match, 6-4, 6-4, against Darren Cahill of Australia.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 5, Canucks 3: Mario Lemieux, playing with a chest injury after a slashing incident, scored twice in the third period last night to lead the Penguins at home. Lemieux intercepted Larry Melnyk's pass at the Pittsburgh blue line and beat Steve Weeks on a breakaway at 9 minutes 59 seconds for a 4-2 lead. He scored his league-leading 18th goal into the empty net with one second left. Lemieux has at least 1 point in each of Pittsburgh's 12 games. He took his regular shift despite suffering a bruised sternum in Sunday's loss to the Rangers when he was struck by the stick of David Shaw, a defenseman.(AP) Kings 3, Nordiques 1: Wayne Gretzky's 11th goal at 15:58 of the second period last night snapped a tie for the visiting Kings. Gretzky made the score, 2-1, when he tipped in a waist-high shot by Wayne McBean. John Tonelli and Luc Robitaille, with an empty-net goal, also scored for the Kings. Walt Poddubny had a goal for the Nordiques. Glenn Healy faced 30 shots in goal for Los Angeles, and made a game-saving stop off David Latta, who deflected a high shot towards the net while falling in the slot midway through the third period.(AP) Capitals 3, Red Wings 3: Mike Gartner's power-play goal with 58 seconds remaining in the third period last night lifted the visiting Capitals into a tie. Detroit took a 3-1 lead on third-period goals by Gerard Gallant and Jeff Sharples, but the Capitals started their rally midway through the period when Lou Franceschetti circled the Detroit net and banked a shot into the net off Glen Hanlon, the Detroit goaltender. Franceschetti, who has been with the Capitals longer than any other player, was recalled from Baltimore of the American Hockey League on Monday. Detroit took a 1-0 lead on Sharples's first-period, power-play goal. Dale Hunter answered with a power-play score for the Capitals midway through the second period to make it, 1-1. Washington has played four straight overtime games.(AP) Canadiens 5, Whalers 3: Shayne Corson, Claude Lemieux and Mike Keane, a rookie, scored during a 2:45 span late in the first period to spark the Canadiens at Hartford last night. Corson tied the score, 2-2, at 13:32, Lemieux put Montreal ahead at 14:28 and Keane scored at 16:13 to rally the Canadiens who fell behind by 2-0 after five minutes. Ryan Walter and Mike McPhee had a goal and two assists each for Montreal. Dave Babych, Dave Tippett and Scott Young, a rookie, scored for the Whalers, who are 1-5 in Adams Division games and have been outscored, 20-11, in the first period over 11 games. Hartford lost the veteran forward Torrie Robertson with a fractured right ankle following a second period scuffle with Montreal's Mike Lalor. When the players fell to ice, Robertson sustained the injury. During the 1986-87 season, Robertson broke his right leg in a game against Montreal.(AP)

title: Metro Datelines; Jai Alai Strike Cuts Connecticut Revenue
description: A jai alai players' strike cost the state $3.75 million in revenue and municipalities more than $500,000 through Sept. 30, a spokesman for the division of special revenue said.

title: Thatcher's Visit to Polish Shipyard Is Still On
description: The announcement that the Polish Government intends to close the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, the bastion of the banned Solidarity labor union, will not affect Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's plans to visit union leaders there on Friday, her office said today.

title: A Snoozing Bear Upsets Courtly Connecticut Politics
description: A month ago, when Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman's Senate campaign appeared to be languishing, his media advisers decided to unleash what many believed was their most powerful secret weapon: the bear cartoon.

title: Hemophiliac With AIDS Awarded $1.6 Million in a Suit Over a Drug
description: A hemophiliac has been awarded $1.6 million by a Federal jury in a lawsuit in which he said he contracted AIDS from a blood-based drug.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She'd get more votes today. Then you had Franklin D. Roosevelt and Wendell Willkie.

title: Aldo di Belardino, Importer, 77
description: Aldo di Belardino, an early importer of quality Italian wine, died of a heart attack Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Lincoln National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $21,090,000 for the quarter and $27,579,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After realized investment losses of $18,676,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $28,852,000 for the 9 months. The latest periods included a restructuring charge of $61.7 million.

title: Review/Television; 'Head of the Class' Goes to Moscow
description: The new Soviet openness creeps into prime-time entertainment as the ''Head of the Class'' gang makes a trip to Moscow to debate their Russian counterparts in a special hourlong show at 8:30 tonight. The series, you may remember, stars Howard Hesseman (''WKRP in Cincinnati'') as Charlie Moore, a teacher who finds himself in charge of a class of advanced students at Monroe High School in Manhattan. These students have higher I.Q.'s than their teachers, a situation that has led to countless weeks of wisecracks and ratings success for ABC.

title: T.R. Hardart, 70, Ex-Horn & Hardart Chief
description: Thomas R. Hardart, former president and chairman of the Horn & Hardart Company, originators of the Automat, the coin-operated cafeterias, died of prostate cancer yesterday at his home in Bronxville. He was 70 years old.

title: Book Notes
description: Judges on Probation

Cohasset Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings for year-ago 9 months is not applicable because the bank converted to stock form of ownership in May 1987.

title: Dow Up 2.31 as Investors Sit on Sidelines
description: Stock prices moved little yesterday as investors appeared ready to wait for the release of employment figures on Friday and the Presidential election next Tuesday.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Mesa Limited Partnership reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Mesa said it is continuing to evaluate the properties located outside its primary producing areas. Mesa sold one of these properties during the latest third quarter and recognized a gain of $43.3 million. An impairment of $30 million was recorded in that quarter for other properties which are expected to be sold in the future, the company said. The share earnings are in units.

title: Housing Strength a Factor In Rise in Building Outlays
description: Construction spending climbed by six-tenths of 1 percent in September as strength in housing and a rebound in governmental building offset weakness in nonresidential construction.

title: Dukakis Is Found in Fine Health; He Has Withstood Earlier Stresses
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is in fine physical health, having suffered only a few minor ailments through life. He has withstood a number of serious emotional stresses without professional counseling, according to interviews with the Democratic Presidential nominee and his physician.

title: After Politics Come Parchment and Proofreading
description: The 100th Congress has finished its work and is gone, leaving people like Donnald K. Anderson and James C. Murr to clean up after them.

title: Election Cake: Noble Tradition
description: ALL my life, growing up in a household in Connecticut that was very political, I never once heard anyone mention an Election Cake. Even as a young adult, when I worked in several campaigns, I was never served Election Cake.

title: Gavitt Gets New Position
description: Dave Gavitt, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, was named president of the Amateur Basketball Association of the U.S.A. in a move that is expected to lead the sport's national governing body into an era of National Basketball Association involvement.

title: New Health Insurance Plan Provokes Outcry Over Costs
description: Reaction to a law providing insurance for catastrophic illness has soured a bit since the measure was passed in June and hailed by legislators and retired people's groups.

title: Hybrid Grapes Born in New Mexico
description: LA CHIRIPADA - in Spanish, the stroke of luck - is no mainstream winery. It is 6,100 feet above sea level in the Rio Embudo Valley of New Mexico, about 50 miles north of Santa Fe. Its owners, an ex-Jesuit novice and a former potter, grow predominantly French-American hybrid grapes on five acres. Their advertising is limited to a few road signs set here in the hill country.

title: P.S. 33 Fights Needle Test Next Door
description: The New York City Health Department appeared yesterday to be going ahead with plans to use a clinic in Chelsea as part of a pilot project to hand out needles to drug addicts, despite complaints that it is unsuitable because it is next to a school.

title: Kelly Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago third quarter included a pre-tax gain of $2 million from the sale of five health care branches.

title: Rangers' Look Is Deceiving
description: The equipment bags were stacked neatly in the locker room. The players, dressed in jackets and ties, sat quietly waiting for the bus to the airport. Appearances, though, were never more deceiving than they were yesterday as the Rangers prepared to head for Buffalo. The team, particularly its defensive unit, was after all in considerable disarray.

title: In Mexico, This Is Not the Day to Bury Mirth
description: Amid the tombs and mausoleums of the Panteon Civil de Dolores, one of this city's largest cemeteries, families are picnicking. As the adults relax, talk and drink, children play tag as they run among the graves and hide from each other behind the tombstones.

title: John W. Houser, Hotel Executive, 78
description: John Wilson Houser, a hotel executive, died of a stroke Monday after surgery at Santa Ynes (Calif.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Solvang, Calif.

title: Review/Theater; Heroic Costume Drama
description: Year after year, the AMAS Repertory Theater, the long-running multi-ethnic music-theater company founded by Rosetta LeNoire, has tried to squeeze epic-size shows into its cramped headquarters at 1 East 104th Street. But as valiant as such efforts might be, certain shows are so extravagant in concept that the kind of bare-bones production the AMAS company is equipped to provide can only make a mockery of people's grand intentions.

description: A 35-year-old marine with emotional troubles caused by being held captive in Iran for more than a year will be given an honorable discharge soon despite his desire to remain in the Marine Crops, officials say.

description: In its first regular debenture offering since September, the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $700 million of 8.80 percent debentures due in 1995 at a price of 99.875, to yield 8.82 percent. The sale is being made through various securities dealers.

title: Aiun Journal; Ice Castles in the Sahara? Well, Ice Cubes, Anyway
description: Joumane Taib, the manager of a local ice-making plant, beamed as his workers pulled one slab of ice after another from a machine.

title: R. Gerald McMurtry, Historian, 82
description: R. Gerald McMurtry, a history professor who assembled a collection of Abraham Lincoln's possessions, letters and manuscripts while directing the Louis A. Warren Lincoln Library and Museum here, died Saturday. He was 82 years old.

description: Troubled by the sight of a five-month-old encampment of dozens of homeless protesters in City Hall Park, the Koch administration seized the camp's belongings yesterday.

description: Expressing concern that allegations of corruption would damage the reputation of the Thai armed forces, military spokesmen have denied that army officers and others in Thailand took funds intended to aid non-Communist guerrillas in Cambodia.

title: Farm Union Chief in Hospital
description: Cesar Chavez, the president of the United Farm Workers, was in the hospital today for injuries suffered when he fell eight feet from his porch to the ground. The 62-year-old Mr. Chavez, who was working at his home Sunday when the porch railing gave way, suffered a fractured wrist and bruises to his head, chest and back, said his son, Paul.

description: Israel's two major parties were locked in a virtual tie early today from Tuesday's general election, and neither had enough seats to form a Government on its own.

description: Battling persistent questions about ethical behavior, Fernand J. St Germain, a Rhode Island Congressman for 28 years who is chairman of the powerful House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee, is facing one of his strongest re-election challenges.

title: Beneficial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $5.7 million and $41.4 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; a loss from the early retirement of debt of $7.3 million for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes net from discontinued operations of $2 million.

title: Marathan; Treacy's Goal Goes Beyond the Money
description: Should John Treacy cross a finish line ahead of the competition at the New York City Marathon this Sunday, he will earn $26,385, plus a Mercedes Benz automobile valued at more than $35,000, plus the possibility of bonuses that would begin with $1,000 and increase as the numbers on the stopwatches decrease.

title: Columbia First Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the prior year includes a $2,041,624 writeoff of Columbia First's investment in the FSLIC secondary reserve. It said the writeoff reduced last year's after-tax income by $1.26 million on a primary basis and 33 cents a share on a fully diluted basis.

title: A Breakthrough For Basketball Hall
description: Ann Meyers and Nera White yesterday became the first female players to be nominated as candidates for election to the Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Reviews/Music; Carefully Planned Chaos
description: With a furious, precise, bone-rattling concert on Friday night at the Ritz, Sonic Youth reaffirmed its place as one of New York's most brilliant, most extreme bands.

title: Bridge
description: Among living players, the greatest mixed partnership may well be Alvin Roth and Barbara Rappaport Haberman, both of Manhattan. They had a string of successes in the 1970's at every level, including back-to-back wins in the Life Master Championship. These came in 1971 and 1972, the only successful defense in the 59-year history of the event.

title: Don't Go Around Trashing Massachusetts
description: To the Editor:

title: Watch Hill, R.I.
description: When Marcia and Jack Felber bought the Olympia Tea Room in the seaside resort of Watch Hill, R.I., eight years ago, they inherited a 72-year-old restaurant replete with a marble soda fountain, mahogany booths, menu items like ''Dusty Miller'' sundaes (vanilla ice cream, chocolate sauce and powdered malt). They also inherited Anne Fauliso, a waitress who has worked there for 43 years and jokes that she ''came with the building.''

title: Sag Harbor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains from tax loss carryforwards of $230,000 for the quarter and $598,000 for the 9 months. c-After gains from tax loss carryforwards of $255,000 for the quarter and $719,000 for the 9 months. The per share earnings for the year- ago periods are unavailable because the company went public on Sept. 1, 1987.

title: American Consumer Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflects a 5-for-4 stock split paid in April.

title: Crystal Lake, Ill.
description: ''I want to see caviar as popular in the kitchen as tins of sardines,'' said Carolyn Collins, who is producing some of the freshest-tasting caviar in America. It's a reasonable enough goal, she added, since ''good American caviar is 4 to 10 times cheaper than good imported caviar.''

title: Education; Lessons
description: A basic fact of life about public education is that Americans do not seem to trust their children's teachers.

title: About New York; A Playground, Sadly, Becomes A Memorial
description: Yesterday, rain fell relentlessly on the asphalt basketball courts of Baisley Pond Park in South Jamaica, Queens. It fell like tears.

title: Washington Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union Leader's Son Says He Accepted Bribes for His Father
description: The 39-year-old son of a construction union official, testifying as a prosecution witness, said yesterday that he collected and cashed paychecks from contractors made out to ''ghost'' employees and turned the money over to his father.

title: Beijing Admits Easing of Birth Limits
description: A Chinese official acknowledged today that the country is not strictly applying a policy limiting each couple to one child, and that as a result it will not meet its target for restraining population growth.

title: Mercury General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $489,000 for the quarter and $960,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $302,000 for the quarter and $546,000 for the 9 months. The results for the latest and year- ago 9 months included a special ''fresh start'' tax benefit of about 7 cents a share and 9 cents a share, respectively.

title: MS Carriers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Northern States Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reviews/Opera; 'Il Trovatore' With Millo
description: The Metropolitan Opera's performance of ''Il Trovatore'' on Monday night looked uncomfortably like the night of the living dead, and Halloween wasn't entirely to blame. Verdi's static opera itself, along with Ezio Frigerio's handsome but marmoreal set and, above all, Fabrizio Melano's stilted non-direction were the real culprits. The Met seems to be making an effort to revert to its traditional, and unlamented in some quarters, role of a ''singers' house,'' meaning ill-rehearsed vocalists of varying talent standing about stiffly and belting out their music.

title: Commodore International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $1.3 million.

title: Review/Music; No Melody, Just Raw Nature Observed
description: Peter Sculthorpe's ''Mangrove'' opens a slender but interesting new window of opportunity for the dwindling resources of so-called classical music. Mr. Sculthorpe, an Australian composer, had his piece played by the Sydney Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Sunday. The afternoon also offered Dame Joan Sutherland singing Verdi and Auber.

title: 4% German Growth Seen
description: The West German Economic Minister, Martin Bangemann, told Foreign Minister Sosuke Ono of Japan that he expected the German economy to grow by about 4 percent in real terms in 1988, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said today. Mr. Bangemann was quoted as saying the West German economy was expanding steadily. The two ministers also said the United States should take measures to reduce its trade and budget deficits, the ministry official said.

title: Home Federal Savings Bank (Seymour, Ind) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a profit from the sale of FHLMC stock of $134,000. c-Included a net gain of $801,000 from the sale of a downtown Indianapolis office building. The bank went public in January 1988.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Soft-Shell Morsels

title: American Capacity Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pacific First Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $2.3 million gain from the sale of 28,000 shares of FHLMC stock for the quarter; the 9 months included a gain of $100,000 from an accounting change and a $1.7 million gain on sale of loans and mortgage- backed securities. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $3,758,000, and a $29.8 million gain on the sale of loans and mortgage- backed securities.

title: Reagan, in the West, Asks Support of Young
description: President Reagan, cheerfully borrowing Democratic lines to turn them against Michael S. Dukakis, campaigned through the West today in support of Vice President Bush and other Republicans.

title: Campaign Trail; On Death Penalty, A Second Answer
description: The question still haunts Mr. Dukakis.

title: Liberal Party Takes Lead in Canadian Poll
description: A poll today put the opposition Liberal Party in the lead for the Nov. 21 elections, reviving the once-sagging fortunes it has tied to a fight against the free-trade agreement with the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on the Media Business page yesterday about The New York Post's plan to publish a Sunday issue misidentified the spokesman for Peter Kalikow, the paper's president and owner. He is Howard J. Rubenstein.

title: Eastman Kodak Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1988 third quarter and 9-month figures include the contribution of Sterling Drug Inc. from the effective date of acquisition on Feb. 23, 1988. The company noted, however, that third quarter and 9-month sales and earnings would have been records even without the contribution from Sterling Drug. Net earnings for both the 1988 third quarter and 9-month periods were favorably impacted by a lower effective tax rate.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In what may be the first of several public debt offerings by utilities, the Southern California Gas Company, a unit of Pacific Enterprises, is offering $125 million of 9 5/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2018 at a price of 99.364, to yield 9.69 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Food Makers Attacked In Ads on Cholesterol
description: An Omaha manufacturing executive turned up the volume yesterday in his 22-year campaign against high cholesterol, which has been identified by nutritionists as a cause of heart attacks.

title: Reviews/Music; Chicagoans Offer Wit And Rhythm
description: The Art Ensemble of Chicago opened Town Hall's Not Just Jazz Festival on Saturday night with a brilliant concert. The group has long made an art out of inference and wit, and its two sets at Town Hall weren't a deviation from normal standards: alluding to a variety of musical styles, from glass-smooth modal jazz to reggae to funk, the group drew the audience in, dropping it off willingly in the middle of dense, sophisticated free improvisations.

title: Clinton B. Axford, Editor, 89
description: Clinton B. Axford, editor emeritus of The American Banker, a daily trade newspaper, died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BT Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nets Hope a New Cast Will Improve the Show
description: Coming off the worst season in their history, the New Jersey Nets had little choice during the off season but to rebuild - again.

title: Gracie Allen Still Steals the Show
description: ''Those of you who have seen me perform know I smoke a cigar and use it as a prop. When I tell a joke, I pause and puff on my cigar. That way, when I take a puff on my cigar, the audience knows I've told a joke.'' - George Burns in ''Gracie: A Love Story''

title: 2 Officials at Rothschild Leaving to Start Firm
description: John Angelo and Michael Gordon, who head the arbitrage department of L. F. Rothschild & Company, said yesterday that they would form a firm, Angelo, Gordon & Company, that will include the eight members of the Rothschild department.

title: Curtain Is Up on Act 2 Of the Knicks' Revival
description: Let us begin with May 7, the night the Knicks' first trip to the playoffs in four seasons ended with a 102-94 loss to the Boston Celtics. Unlike most defeats, which bring their disappointments and excuses, this one focused on a brighter future.

title: Harleysville Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
USF&G Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $10,500,000 and $15,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; a gain on investments of $6,684,000 for the quarter; the 9 months include a loss on investments of $47,903,000. c-Includes a loss on investments of $3,336,000 and and $97,838,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $577,000 and $6,391,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Reformers Turning Attention to School Boards
description: Increasingly, the people behind what seems to be a national mission to improve the public schools are paying attention to an educational institution that has been largely ignored for most of this decade: the local school board.

title: Fiery End of 'Gotterdammerung' Tests the Met's Technical Magic
description: If special effects are what you're after, forget trying to track down a video cassette of ''E. T.'' or a ticket to Broadway's re-creations of the sewers and crashing chandeliers of Paris. Seekers of the spectacular in stagecraft will want to savor the third act of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Gotterdammerung.''

title: Cabot Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an $816,000 charge from the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss d-Includes a charge of $1,956,000 and $10,541,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the early retirement of debt. Latest fourth quarter includes a pretax gain of $50.5 million from pension fund reversion, a charge of $20.6 million for natural gas contracts issues, and a charge of $15 million for environmental issues. Year-ago fourth quarter loss from operations includes a net charge of $12.3 million from restructuring of operations.

title: No Debate Instructions
description: To the Editor:

title: National Savings Bank of Alany reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $383,666 for the quarter and $399,650 for the year from the reduction of income taxes.

title: Egypt Puts Nasser Kin and 17 Others on Trial
description: To the chanting of anti-Israeli slogans, 20 Egyptians, including members of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser's family, went on trial here today on charges of assassinating Israeli diplomats, wounding others and attacking United States Embassy officials.

title: George E. Uhlenbeck Dies at 87; Co-Discoverer of Electron's Spin
description: George E. Uhlenbeck, co-discoverer of the electron's spin and a former president of the American Physical Society, died in his sleep Monday at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 87 years old.

title: A Fix for the Federal Fraud Law
description: The Supreme Court is often unfairly abused for being soft on crime. But last year the Court incurred fair criticism for gutting the Federal mail fraud law. Now Congress has enacted a sensible measure to repair the damage.

title: Suit Says New York Election Law Is Illegal
description: The Justice Department filed suit here today against New York State, charging that a state election statute violates the Federal Voting Rights Act.

title: Blue Cross Unit Offers Credit Card
description: A new credit card to help finance consumer health-care charges was introduced yesterday by the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association of Maryland.

title: Citicorp Sale: Rates Down
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper for the first time in three weeks. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.255 percent, down from 8.3135 percent a week earlier.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: When the Food Doesn't Fly
description: WHEN things go awry with mail-order purchases, people have recourse, through a Federal Trade Commission regulation, if the order was placed and paid for by mail, or if the order was placed by telephone and paid for by mail.

title: Computerizing the Voting Booth
description: When the American people go to the polls next week to elect a new President, more than half the voters will use some type of computerized equipment to record their choices.

title: Metro Datelines; 5 Men Are Charged In Car-Theft Ring
description: Five men -three of them brothers - were arrested yesterday as members of a car-theft ring believed to be responsible for stealing as many as 360 cars a year off New York City streets.

title: Court Bars Interco's 'Poison Pill'
description: The Rales brothers moved closer yesterday to acquiring Interco Inc., the St. Louis-based furniture and shoe manufacturer, when a Delaware Chancery Court ordered the company to dismantle its ''poison pill'' takeover defense.

title: Campaign Trail; Quayle's Lament: Where to Now?
description: Dan Quayle was irritated.

title: U.S. Revises Its War Plan For New Age
description: The Strategic Air Command has nearly completed the most extensive revision of its nuclear war plan in a decade as new weapons have come into its arsenal, others have been deleted and targets in the Soviet Union have changed, senior officers here say.

title: Nortek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,500,000 and $8,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations, and a gain from retirement of debt of $300,000 and $5,100,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes a loss of $50,000 and $3,450,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also include a loss from retirement of debt of $550,000. Results for the latest third quarter and 9 months reflect completion of the sale of Glastic Co., a division of the company's Monogram Industries unit to a venture formed by Kobe Steel Ltd. and C. Itoh & Co. Ltd.

title: Horn & Hardart
description: An investment partnership led by a New York executive, Attilio Petrocelli, said it had acquired 6.9 percent of the common stock of the Horn & Hardart Company and might seek control of the catalogue and restaurant company. The Petrocelli group said it had one million shares of Horn & Hardart, which publishes 24 mail order catalogues offering more than 22,000 items. The company, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., also owns several restaurants and sold its Bojangles Chicken 'n Biscuits chain for $20 million in July. A full buyout would cost the investor group about $126 million.

title: Arrow Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,294,000 and $5,672,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain of $7,791,000 from the sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $4,362,000 for the quarter and $8,015,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago third quarter and 9 months net from continuing operations includes gains of $5,806,000 and $13,390,000, respectively, from the sale of property.

title: New View About 3 Mile Island
description: At least half of the nuclear reactor core at Three Mile Island melted in the 1979 accident, a Government scientist said Monday, giving an estimate higher than most previous ones.

title: Imelda Marcos's Lawyers to File Plan to Pay Her $5 Million Bond
description: Lawyers for Imelda Marcos are to meet with Judge John F. Keenan of Federal District Court this morning to present a tentative package that would meet the $5 million bond set by the court on Monday, associates of Mrs. Marcos said.

title: Review/Theater; Testimony of a Survivor
description: In her plays (''Still Life,'' ''Execution of Justice''), Emily Mann tries to find common ground between oral history and political drama. Sometimes her strict adherence to documented evidence - admirable from a historical point of view - can impede her sense of theater. Such is the case with ''Annulla, an Autobiography,'' her first play, written in 1977 and in a revised version now having its delayed New York premiere at the New Theater of Brooklyn. As testimony from an atypical survivor of the Holocaust, ''Annulla'' has a viability, but as a monodrama it needs additional structuring and clarification.

title: Aliens' Rail Trips Grow More Perilous
description: Just as it is for many Mexicans, the choice seemed clear to Jose Ibarra. ''I could go north or my family could go without shoes and clothes,'' Mr. Ibarra said. ''I went north.''

title: IPL Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $113,000 for the quarter and $426,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $270,000 for the quarter and $575,000 for the 9 months.

title: Utility Agrees to Pay More Seabrook Costs
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire, operating under protection of Federal bankruptcy laws because of its stalled Seabrook nuclear power plant, said today that it had tentatively agreed to make the Seabrook payments that another owner refuses to make.

title: 4 Killed, 38 Hurt in Rare Daytime Attack by Salvador Rebels
description: As the Salvadoran Army named a new Chief of Staff in an apparent effort to break the deadlock in the war against leftist rebels, the guerrillas staged their first daylight attack in the capital in about five years.

title: Limited License for Shoreham Backed
description: The Long Island Lighting Company's efforts to win a commercial operating license for the Shoreham nuclear power plant advanced today when the staff of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission supported the utility's request to operate Shoreham at 25 percent of capacity.

title: 2 Polls Give Bush Solid Leads
description: Two new public polls today gave Vice President Bush solid leads over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, and several Democratic poll takers said there was evidence that whatever surge there was toward Mr. Dukakis last weekend had abated.

title: Report Faults $26 Million Subway Car Wash
description: The Transit Authority has spent almost $26 million on an automated subway car wash in Brookyln that is dangerous to employees, inefficient and unable to clean any better than the old manual scrubbing method, an independent report said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Opera; Newcomers Join Met's 'Lucia'
description: There have been several newcomers to the cast of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' since the production opened. In fact, the production itself has changed a bit.

title: Bell, W & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Equipment Company of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $20,000 for the quarter and $84,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $32,000.

title: Sports People; Sabo Is Top Rookie
description: ''He reminds me of myself, but I couldn't run as fast,'' Pete Rose, the Cincinnati manager, said during the season, speaking of his rookie third baseman, Chris Sabo. Rose was voted the National League rookie of the year 25 years ago; yesterday, Sabo earned the honor. For a year in which he batted .271, hit 11 home runs, drove in 44 runs, stole 46 bases and hit 40 doubles, Sabo received 79 points and 11 first-place votes from a panel of 24 baseball writers, two from each National League city. Mark Grace, the Chicago Cubs first baseman, was second with 61 points and Tim Belcher, the right-handed pitcher of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was third with 35. Sabo's 46 stolen bases tied for fourth in the league and were the most for a Reds rookie since Bob Descher's 54 in 1909. Sabo also matched a major league mark for third baseman with 11 assists in a game. Cincinnati was going to use him as a backup infielder, but when Buddy Bell, the veteran third baseman, was hurt at the end of spring training, Sabo took over. He was the only rookie to play in the All-Star Game.(AP)

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Ease
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in light trading yesterday, as dealers used a stronger-than-expected report on construction activity in September as an excuse to take some profits made during the previous two trading sessions.

title: Harmon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Savings Bonds At 7.35% Rate
description: United States savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 7.35 percent in the next six months, the highest return since early 1986, the Treasury Department said today.

title: First American Savings (Ohio) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
We Can Learn From Italy About Banning Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Landfill on Burial Ground Is Blocked
description: Ohio's environmental agency has blocked a nine-year attempt by an excavating company to establish a landfill on land believed to be a sacred Indian burial ground.

title: Burritt Interfinancial Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Real Estate; Connecticut Office Space Adds Extras
description: NOT so long ago office tenants found little more than four walls, a floor and access to telephone lines and public utilities when they went shopping for space.

title: Hyundai's Bid to Move Up in Class
description: Hyundai, the Korean car maker that has had great success with its low-priced Excel, is trying to move up in class with a new model, the Sonata. The success or failure of the car may determine whether the company becomes a broad line manufacturer or remains stuck in one segment of the market -the least profitable one at that.

title: Sports People; Ventura Honored
description: In 1987, as a junior, Robin Ventura hit safely in 58 consecutive games to set a national collegiate record. For his four seasons at Oklahoma State, the third baseman batted a combined .428. Yesterday, he was named the 1988 winner of the U.S. Baseball Federation's Golden Spikes Award as the outstanding amateur player in the nation. Ventura, a left-handed batter who hit .409 during the Summer Olympics, was picked 10th in the first round of the amateur draft by the Chicago White Sox. ''As a hitter, you can compare him with Will Clark of San Francisco,'' said Al Goldis, the White Sox director of player development. Also at the ceremony was Joe DiMaggio, who batted safely in 56 straight games in 1941 for the major league record. He implored Ventura ''not to break my record for a while. I want it to last 50 years.''

title: Lighthouse Now Guides Troubled Teen-Agers
description: LEAD: For 125 years the Beaver Island Lighthouse, standing high on the island's southern tip, guided mariners up through the tricky passage along the northeast shore of Lake Michigan to the Straits of Mackinac between Lakes Michigan and Huron.

title: Fresh Food: Today It Has Staying Power
description: A FEW years ago Richard Rakowski, an entrepreneur, set out to distribute fresh, packaged, ready-to-use herbs to supermarkets. He began by growing the herbs in California, then harvesting, washing and slicing them and immediately shipping them to stores using an overnight-delivery company.

title: Countersuit Filed by GTE
description: The GTE Corporation said today that it had filed a libel and slander suit against Home Shopping Network Inc. in response to a $1.5 billion suit filed by the television shopping network in 1987 over problems with its GTE telephone system. In its suit, filed in Pinellas

title: Masstor Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time non-operating expense of $1.7 million to settle a class action lawsuit.

title: N.C.A.A. Acts Against Kansas
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today barred Kansas, the defending basketball champion, from post-season play in 1989 and placed the school on probation for three years for recruiting violations. Kansas will be the first N.C.A.A. champion in basketball not allowed to defend its title.

title: Rockefeller Group Aids Adler Deal
description: Adler & Shaykin, the Manhattan investment firm, said the Rockefeller Group Capital Corporation would help finance its $685 million purchase of the Best Products Company, one of the nation's biggest catalogue showroom chains. The Rockefeller Group is a private firm owned by descendants of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and trusts that benefit his descendants.

title: Lompoc, Calif.
description: Thanks to Rusty and Steve Jordan, fourth-generation farmers from Southern California, consumers can now tell an artichoke by its color. The Jordan brothers developed the ''purple blush'' artichoke, an apple-shaped, virtually thornless variety with more leaves and a bigger heart than the traditional green version, as well as a distinctive almond taste.

title: Musicians Vote Approval Of Philharmonic Contract
description: The New York Philharmonic and its musicians, who have been performing without a contract since Sept. 21, have reached a new three-year agreement, both sides announced yesterday. A tentative agreement was reached Saturday night and voted upon by the musicians Monday. The votes were counted yesterday, and the result was 73 to 24 in favor of the new pact.

title: The Dark Horse With No Name
description: Nevada is the only state in which voters can cast their ballots for ''none of these candidates,'' and one critic of the procedure says voting that way is ''a cruel thing to do.''

title: Settlement in Utility Case
description: Lawyers for bondholders announced today that they had reached agreement in principle for a $226.3 million settlement with a group of defendants in lawsuits connected with the 1983 default on two Washington nuclear plants.

title: Post Makes No Endorsement
description: The Washington Post said in its Wednesday issue that it would endorse neither Vice President Bush nor Michael S. Dukakis for President, calling this year's race a ''terrible campaign, a national disappointment.''

title: Pretoria Bans Paper for Month
description: South Africa barred the country's most prominent opposition newspaper. The Weekly Mail, from publishing for a month. Page A3.

title: National Horse Show; All in the Family For Top 3 Finishers
description: A trio of local heros were the top three finishers in the first jump stake of the evening as the 105th National Horse Show opened at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: Comcoa Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Includes tax credits of $85,824 for the quarter and $311,309 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,919 and $85,446 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Defense Expert Contradicts Davis Prosecution Testimony
description: An expert witness for the defense said yesterday that a police shotgun slug was fired at Larry Davis from a much closer distance than earlier prosecution testimony had maintained.

title: Directors Back Pacificorp Merger
description: Directors of Utah Power and Light Company and Pacificorp reaffirmed their support for a proposed $2 billion merger, signaling their acceptance of conditions imposed by Federal regulators. The decisions also included an extension until Dec. 15 for either company to terminate the merger if it was not closed by the deadline.

title: Costco Wholesale Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Includes gains of $1,160,000 from the retirement of subordinated debentures and $1,696,000 from a tax loss carryforward. c-Includes tax credits of $620,000 for the quarter and $1,510,000 for the year. The company said fiscal 1988 also include a $1,540,000 pretax capital loss related to the sale of marketable securities and a $4,000,000 pretax charge to cover the costs and expenses related to closing the company's three midwest warehouse locations. On an after-tax basis, these one-time charges together represented a 14 cents a share reduction in Costco's 1988 fiscal year earnings.

title: Equity Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Kurt Shamberg, 82, Advocate for Disabled
description: Kurt D. Shamberg, an advocate for the disabled and a producer in the early days of television, died of double pnuemonia Friday at Physicians' Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Woodhaven, Queens.

title: Mark Controls Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $720,000. c-After extraordinary credits of $400,000 for the quarter and $680,000 for the 9 months.

title: Urban Funds Spur After-School Program
description: The Los Angeles City Council, declaring that developing people is as important as erecting buildings, has helped start an after-school tutoring and recreation program using $2 million in urban redevelopment money.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Lyons P.L.C., London, said it would sell HPC Inc., its U.S. oil and gas unit, to Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. for $227 million (Canadian), or about $278 million in U.S. currency.

title: Dixie National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
D'Amato Said to Block Judge Nomination
description: In the final days of the 100th Congress, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato put a hold on the nomination of Stuart A. Summit, a Republican whom he had earlier recommended for nomination to be a judge on the Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan, people with knowledge of the incident say.

title: Omak Journal; Workers Buy a Mill and Tomorrow
description: When the aspens along the Okanogan River turn to gold and all the apples in the hillside orchards have been harvested, almost everybody in this remote mountain valley turns attention to the hunting.

title: Geraghty & Miller reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest periods' average shares reflect the 1.5 million common shares issued in February 1988 in connection with the initial public offering.

title: Medical Care International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $1,283,000 for the quarter and $3,549,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after a charge from the reversal of a tax benefit of $923,000 for the quarter.

title: Food on the Wing, Or, the Best by Mail
description: FOR at least a quarter of a century, fruitcakes, oranges and grapefruit have been staples of the holiday mail-order scene. Recipients were always quite sure that the grapefruit mailed from Florida or Texas were sweeter and larger and better in quality than those from the neighborhood supermarket. Often they were; at the very least, receiving them by mail made them special.

title: Alexander & Alexander Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,500,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-After a $10,000,000 loss on discontinued operations and a tax credit of $3,500,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: A Housekeeper Tells of Life On Capasso's Estate on L.I.
description: Life on a luxurious Long Island estate during a bitter divorce was described in court yesterday, as another episode began in the Bess Myerson trial.

title: UTILITIES IN JAPAN TO SHUN URANIUM FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: Under pressure from the United States and their own Government, Japan's giant utility companies said today that they would stop importing uranium from South Africa,a large supplier of fuel for Japanese nuclear power.

title: Good News on Angola
description: Despite delays, word here is that a settlement on Namibia can be expected soon. This will add to the list of seemingly unresolvable regional conflicts brought to solution in the new international climate of conciliation and war fatigue.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Times Sq. Michelangelos: Vanishing Breed
description: HIGH over Times Square, up where the pigeons roost, rises the monumental visage of a character named Old Joe. He is knowing. He is virile. He is a camel.

Bond Reissuing Bill Vetoed by Reagan
description: President Reagan has vetoed a bill that would have allowed state and local development companies for small business to prepay and reissue federally guaranteed bonds when interest rates fall.

title: Officials Seize 3 Apartments In Drug Raid
description: For the second time in six months, law-enforcement officials yesterday used a Federal law to seize and seal apartments in a public housing project after making arrests on drug charges.

title: Steinberg Trial Hears Doctor Tell of Bruises
description: A doctor told a grim jury yesterday that Lisa Steinberg was so covered with bruises when she arrived at St. Vincent's Medical Center that she immediately suspected child abuse and ordered photographs taken of the comatose body.

Microwave Cooking
description: SOUFFLES are a disaster in the microwave oven. After teasing the cook by rising beautifully high, they then fall flat. But therein lies an asset: the ability to easily make a type of roulade, using the fallen souffle, that can be served at lunch or as a dessert.

title: Sakharov Warns of Perils in New Soviet Setup
description: Reflecting what appears to be the view of many Soviet intellectuals, Andrei D. Sakharov warned today that planned changes in the Soviet political system would give Mikhail S. Gorbachev a dangerous monopoly of power.

title: Sister Cities
description: What is the difference between New York City and Washington? It is a subject endlessly debated at both ends of the 230-mile corridor that separates the two cities.

title: Islanders Reach Season Low
description: As an infant franchise, there were moments of ignominy for the Islanders - the winless streak of 15 games in 1972, a 10-2 loss in Philadelphia in 1973. Indeed, as the organization struggled to maturity, there were seasons of frustration and embarrassment, beginning with their initial season, when they amassed just 12 victories.

title: Holocaust Is Taught In New York Schools

title: Review/Violin; Modern Mastery From Spivakov
description: The noted Soviet violin virtuoso Vladimir Spivakov gave his first New York recital in many years at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon, making the best impression in two works of the 20th century. Stravinsky's ''Suite Italienne'' buzzed along spiffily, and Mr. Spivakov's bowing was mightily impressive in the fast finale to Bartok's Second Sonata.

title: So Give It a Gun and Let It Fight
description: rrMost industrial robots are ungainly looking machines. But the Battelle Memorial Institute in Richland, Wash., is nearing completion on a robot to test clothing for the Army that is so human-like its developers use the word ''spooky'' to describe its movements. It does almost everything but charge into combat.

title: F.T.C. Reviewing Philip Morris Pact
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission, which has been conducting an antitrust review of its $13.1 billion merger agreement with Kraft Inc., had asked for additional information. The notification, called a second request, came on the deadline before both companies would have been free to proceed with a merger.

description: Cracking a whip with his left hand, Herb McCauley whisked out of the jockeys' room at Aqueduct Race Track yesterday afternoon on his way to his first mount in two weeks.

description: James R. Shepley, a tenacious reporter who rose through the corporate ranks at Time Inc. to become president and chief operating officer, died of complications due to cancer yesterday at the M. D. Anderson Clinic in Houston. He was 71 years old and lived in Hartfield, Va.

title: Nets Acquire Rockets' Carroll
description: The Nets' long search for a bona fide center ended yesterday with the acquisition of the 7-foot-1-inch Joe Barry Carroll. One of the few National Basketball Association teams without a 7-footer, the Nets obtained Carroll and Lester Conner, a defense-oriented point guard, from the Houston Rockets in a six-player deal.

title: Cluett Group Offering Dress-Sock Campaign
description: Gold Toe Socks, a division of the Cluett Hosiery Group, goes on the air this week with the first men's dress-sock advertising in its, and maybe anyone else's, history. The commercial by Berenter Greenhouse & Webster of New York will break in nine test markets. It features a whimsical demonstration of two men hanging upside down by their hose. Gold Toe, needless to say, offers more support than the generic brand.

title: Continental Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $51,900,000 for the quarter and $59,100,000 for the 9 months, and realized capital losses of $5,200,000 and $2,400,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6,900,000 and $19,800,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and realized capital gains of $1,300,000 for the quarter and realized capital loss of $19,300,000 for the 9 months. On Oct. 19, the company said it would report a $32,000,000 charge on discontinued operations in the latest quarter, principally reflecting the tax on the sale of its Canadian unit and deterioration in both Commercial Life's and Loyalty Life's multiple employer trust group health line. The company said it uncovered an additional $5,000,000 reduction in tax benefits that it had previously anticipated. The company also said the charge includes recognition of the aftertax gain on the sales of three life insurance subsidiaries, which the company expects to have divested by year end.

title: Ruling on Polaroid
description: A Delaware judge ordered the Polaroid Corporation Tuesday to give the investor Roy E. Disney the names and addresses of workers who participate in an employee stock plan, handing Mr. Disney a minor victory in his battle to buy the instant film company. The ruling in Delaware Chancery Court could help Mr. Disney promote his hostile $2.6 billion buyout offer to Polaroid employees.
