title: Making Amends
description: When more than 1,200 AIDS victims and their backers staged a nine-hour protest at the Food and Drug Administration's headquarters in Rockville, Md., one day last month, hundreds of agency employees found themselves unable to get to their offices while others were in effect trapped in the building. All in all, the noisy though generally nonviolent demonstration, aimed at speeding F.D.A. approval of drugs to fight acquired immune deficiency syndrome, resulted in frayed nerves, snarled traffic and 176 arrests.

title: Review/Theater; Bob Berky's Interactive Clowning
description: As a wordless clown, Bob Berky speaks with his expressive face and his kazoo. Preening in the spotlight, he ''tells'' us how smartly he is dressed. His vest contrasts with his sport jacket, his socks are the same color as his shoes. Then he considers his bright red tie, looks at it quizzically and realizes that it matches his clown nose.

title: One Liberty Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Handful of Albany Races Are 'Hot'
description: Hundreds of thousands of dollars will be spent and truckloads of mailings will be sent. Billboards will flash new faces and car bumpers will sport new stickers. But on Nov. 8, when all 211 seats in the New York State Legislature will be up for grabs, neither Republicans nor Democrats expect more than a half dozen seats to change hands.

title: Home Improvement
description: WITH care, wood floors can be kept looking like new far longer than can other kinds of floors. This is because wood surfaces do not fade and can be successfully protected and refinished.

title: A Conviction In Soviet Sale
description: A British citizen was convicted today on charges involving the sale of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union that helped its Navy build quieter submarines.

title: Union Locals at Caterpillar Ratify a Three-Year Contract
description: Union workers at Caterpillar Inc. plants have ratified a new three-year contract with the company by a 3-to-1 margin, the United Automobile Workers announced Monday.

title: Bidders for Wickes Weigh Its Breakup
description: The prospective buyers of the Wickes Companies say they are considering breaking up the company and selling its retail and credit operations if their bid succeeds. The Blackstone Group and Wasserstein, Perella & Company, New York investor groups that began a $538.9 million buyout Tuesday, disclosed their intent to sell parts of the company in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The proposed takeover, negotiated with management, would be accomplished through an $11.25-a-share tender offer.

title: 2 Get 50-Year Terms In Murders of Priests In Buffalo Rectories
description: Two teen-agers were sentenced today to at least 50 years in prison for a crime spree in which two priests were murdered in their rectories.

title: Shaw Gets 12-Game Ban For Attack on Lemieux
description: The National Hockey League today suspended David Shaw, the defenseman for the Rangers, for 12 games for his stick attack on Mario Lemieux of Pittsburgh den.

title: Breeders' Cup; Strongest Races May Be Wet
description: Seventy-nine thoroughbreds were entered this morning for the seven Breeders' Cup races at Churchill Downs Saturday, when rain might muddy what otherwise looks like the strongest races since the series began in 1984.

title: Weiss Wins Award
description: Walt Weiss, the Oakland Athletics' shortstop, was selected American League Rookie of the Year yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America. It was the third straight season a member of the Athletics has won the honor. Weiss received 103 points and 17 first-place votes from a panel of 28 writers, two from each American League city. Bryan Harvey, a right-handed pitcher for the California Angels, was second with 49 points, 1 ahead of Jody Reed, a Boston Red Sox infielder who had 6 first-place votes to 3 for Harvey.

title: In Boston, a 'Sea' of Raked Gravel; Gardens in the U.S.
description: You do not have to journey overseas to visit Japanese gardens, which hold special appeal through autumn and winter. These are some major gardens open to the public all year:

title: Man Faces Gun Count After Shooting 2 to Halt Mugging
description: A man who heard a mugging victim screaming and sobbing for help sprinted out of his apartment in Brooklyn late Tuesday night, his .38-caliber revolver in his hand, and fired at two assailants as they grabbed for a watch and gold necklace, the police said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Hlasek Upsets Krickstein: Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland upset Aaron Krickstein of the United States, seeded eighth, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday at Antwerp, Belgium, and joined Guillermo Perez-Roldan, Andrei Chesnokov and Tim Mayotte in the quarterfinals of the $1 million European Community championship. Perez-Roldan, seeded fourth, beat Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-2, 6-0. Chesnokov, seeded fifth in this exhibition event, beat Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-4, 6-2, and Mayotte defeated Horst Skoff, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2.(AP) Evert Advances: Chris Evert, seeded second, who was making a belated start in the $300,000 New England Virginia Slims tournament, struggled to an opening-round victory yesterday at Worcester, Mass. Shaun Stafford, a 19-year-old from Gainesville, Fla., who turned pro last week after winning the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship, lasted 90 minutes before losing by 6-3, 7-5. In other matches, Pam Shriver defeated Leila Meski, 6-1, 6-2; Helena Sukova eliminated Mary Lou Daniels, 6-2, 4-6, 6-1; Natalya Zvereva beat Iwona Kuczynska, 6-4, 6-3; Barbara Potter defeated Wendy White, 6-4, 6-2, and Gabriela Sabatini beat Ann Henricksson, 6-1, 7-5.(AP) Wilander Rallies to Win: Mats Wilander, playing in Sweden for the first time since taking over the No. 1 ranking in the world, rallied to beat the Swedish junior Nicklas Kulti in the second round of the $642,500 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships last night. Wilander posted a 0-6, 6-4, 6-1 victory. Peter Lundgren of Sweden upset Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 7-6, in another second-round match.(AP) BOXING Mitchell Defeats McDonnell: Brian Mitchell of South Africa survived a last-round cut and an anti-apartheid protest to outpoint Jim McDonnell of Britain last night to win a unanimous 12-round decision and retain his World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title at the Elephant and Castle Leisure Center in south London. It was the sixth successful defense for the 27-year-old from Johannesburg, who improved his record to 36-2-1 by handing McDonnell his first loss in 25 pro fights.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 7, Maple Leafs 2: Keith Crowder and Cam Neely each scored two goals last night as the visiting Bruins extended their unbeaten streak to eight games. Boston, now 5-0-3 in its last eight games, leads the league with 19 points. Boston's Craig Janney scored a goal to extend his scoring streak to five games. Daniel Marois, a rookie, scored both Toronto goals. He has scored all three of the Leafs' goals in their two losses to the Bruins this season.(AP) Canadiens 5, Kings 3: Bobby Smith scored a goal at 10 minutes 53 seconds of the third period last night to break a 3-3 tie and lead the Canadiens to a home victory. The Canadiens won their second straight game for the first time this season. Wayne Gretzky assisted on all three goals for the Kings.(AP)

title: Review/Dance; Monson And King Combined
description: Like psychotherapy, improvisation doesn't tend to work well unless the personalities involved are complementary. There was a sense of sizzling promise from the moment John King and Jennifer Monson joined forces on stage, on Saturday at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, in the closing program of Movement Research's Ear to the Ground Festival. It was a pairing of two big, sleepy babies, Mr. King with a look of pink-cheeked innocence and Ms. Monson clearly a tigerish mischief-maker.

description: Mayor Koch yesterday ordered the City Health Department to drop plans to give drug addicts clean needles at a neighborhood health clinic in Chelsea because of complaints that the clinic is next door to an elementary school.

title: Life in the 30's
description: ONE of the saddest, most troubling continuing family dramas being played out in this city may well be the one involving the contractor and the commissioner, the judge and her daughter. The star of this drama was to have been the former commissioner, Bess Myerson, a onetime Miss America and New York City icon, the original girl-from-the-Bronx-who-made-good. The contractor is Ms. Myerson's paramour. The judge issued a ruling in his divorce case. The three of them are charged with conspiracy. The focus of the purported conspiracy is the judge's daughter, who the prosecution contends was given a job by Ms. Myerson in exchange for the judge's reduction of alimony payments. The daughter is a 39-year-old woman, outspoken about her liposuction and her manic-depression, named Sukhreet Gabel. Big-eyed and talkative, posing for pictures on the courthouse steps, she has wrested the starring role from her former boss. She has also become something of a public laughingstock, which is horribly sad, since she seems to be a woman with a good many problems, and unfortunate, since it diverts attention from the real issues of the case.

14 Black Legislators on Trial For Protest Over Rebel Flag
description: Fourteen black legislators, including the state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, went on trial today on misdemeanor trespass charges for trying to remove the Confederate battle flag atop Alabama's Capitol.

title: Maxwell of Britain Wins a Ruling In Battle to Take Over Macmillan
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publishing entrepreneur, has apparently won the long, bitter $2.5 billion fight for Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publishing and information services company.

title: Honor for Fugard
description: The South African playwright Athol Fugard has been named an honorary member of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, an organization dedicated to fostering an interest in the fine arts. Mr Fugard, who is known for his plays dealing with apartheid in South Africa, will be inducted during a ceremony at 6:30 P.M. today at the academy, 633 West 155th Street. The novelist John Updike, chancellor of the academy, will be the host of the ceremony.

title: Adams Russell Electronics Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Includes a $1.1 million writedown of certain assets.

title: Campaign Trail; The Vice President Makes Connections
description: The television cameras began. Reporters gripped their notebooks. Aides and Secret Service agents hovered nearby.

title: McDonald's Japan Sets Prepaid Cards
description: The McDonald's Company of Japan hopes to make fast food even faster by introducing prepaid cards at three of its Tokyo outlets. McDonald's will sell the cards in denominations of 1,000, 3,000 and 5,000 Japanese yen, (about $8, $24 and $40). Clerks will put the cards in a machine that deducts the amount of the purchases. Prepaid cards are already widely accepted in Japan in telephones, taxis, supermarkets and pinball parlors.

description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 9 months includes writeoffs of $12,300,000 for equipment upgrades and business restructuring. The company said it closed the telemarketing division of its sales department, accounting for a writeoff of about $1,500,000.

description: Inside the garden that opened last week at the Museum of Fine Arts here, a ''sea'' of raked white gravel creates a distance between most of the garden and the visitor.

title: Review/Music; Program Of Modern Works
description: The Riverside Symphony, an enterprising ensemble of young, proficient players, is to become a resident orchestra at Columbia University this season. But the group is also giving a pair of concerts at Alice Tully Hall, the first of which - a 20th-century program - took place on Monday evening.

title: Resignation At Cullinet
description: Cullinet Software Inc. said on Tuesday that George W. Tamke had resigned as president and chief operating officer for personal reasons. Earlier this year, Mr. Tamke, 41 years old, became president after the unexpected resignation of David L. Chapman and the return of John J. Cullinane, 53, the founder of the company, as chairman.

title: Dollar Slumps Again Despite Intervention
description: Despite a third day of dollar purchases by the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan, the dollar dropped sharply yesterday, falling below 125 yen. It also fell against the West German mark.

Share earnings are adjusted for a 10-percent stock dividend paid Aug. 12, 1988.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If a right-wing Government emerges in Israel and continues to ignore the moves toward moderation and the desires for a settlement articulated by the Palestinians, then we in America are going to have to put pressure on Israel to rethink these issues. That is a very uncomfortable position for American Jews.'' - Michael Lerner,editor of Tikkun,a liberal Jewish magazine. [ A14:3. ]

title: Metro Matters; It's Extra Innings For the Yankees And New York
description: When his political cronies were plotting to overthrow a popularly elected local official, it is fair to ask, where was George?

title: DISPUTE ON RADAR REMAINS STALLED
description: The Soviet Union failed to resolve American concerns over a disputed Siberian radar after three days of talks in Geneva, the Reagan Administration said today.

title: Post Makes No Endorsement
description: The Washington Post said Tuesday that it would endorse neither Vice President Bush nor Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for President, calling this year's race a ''terrible campaign, a national disappointment.''

title: Weicker and Lieberman Argue 'Politics of Trivia'
description: The race for the United States Senate seat from Connecticut has been dominated by debates on unlikely issues, and with the election just five days away more than ever the candidates are engaged in what aides call the ''politics of trivia.''

title: Campaign Trail; Bush and A.C.L.U. On the Same Side
description: Rose Mary Miller wanted to place a Bush-Quayle sign on her front lawn. City officials demanded that the schoolteacher remove the sign or risk being ticketed for violating a city ordinance barring the display of political signs. Ms. Miller promptly called the American Civil Liberties Union to defend her freedom of speech. ''I think Bush would pat me on the back and say I'm standing up for my own rights,'' she said. ''The A.C.L.U. has told me they will defend me.''

title: Centennial Beneficial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Robert Half International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $372,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DORIS DUKE OFFERS MRS. MARCOS'S BAIL
description: The tobacco heiress Doris Duke has agreed to post $5 million bail for her friend Imelda Marcos, the former First Lady of the Philippines.

title: Is Wrong Man in Jail for 3 Queens Slayings?
description: Queens prosecutors are considering the possibility that the wrong man has been jailed for 17 months on charges of killing three people during a liquor store robbery, lawyers in the case say.

title: Market Place; Higher Offer Seen For Whittaker
description: THE proposed $303 million buyout of the Whittaker Corporation is being met skeptically by traders, but some analysts say that investors should refrain from profit taking, because they expect a higher bid.

title: TV Notes
description: A 'Live' Anniversary Last month ''Saturday Night Live'' began its 14th season amid a Presidential campaign that has provided a mother lode of material fit for lampooning. The NBC program dominates the 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. time period in New York, according to Jeff Boehme, the network's director of audience measurement. Of course, the show may also benefit from the fact that a sizable part of its audience wasn't around when ''Live from New York - it's Saturday Night! '' was first exclaimed in October 1975, propelling John Belushi, Chevy Chase and Jane Curtin, among others, to stardom.

title: Chad Trying Wary Detente With Libyans
description: Workers recently removed the pink and blue billboards here that once proclaimed, ''Chad will be the tomb of Libyan imperialism.''

description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of the company's principal facility; the sale closed on Sept. 29 for $4.1 million. The company had no sales for its first quarter and said that lack of sales was a direct result of the sale of all revenue-producing operations of the company under its restructuring efforts which began over a year ago.

title: Campaign Trail; 'Voting Officials Will Be Watching'
description: For more than 10 days, emotional Spanish-language radio advertisements, aimed at voters in the Rio Grande Valley, have dominated the air waves. Democrats have denounced the commercials as ''scare tactics'' to frighten Hispanic voters from supporting the Dukakis-Bentsen ticket.

title: Lomas Mortgage Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Voter Registration for New York Shows Slump From '84 Election
description: Despite extraordinary efforts by the state and local governments and the political parties, voter registration for New York State is down by nearly 426,000 - with almost all of the decline in New York City - from the 1984 Presidential election, the State Board of Elections reported yesterday.

title: Many Arabs Say Israel's Election Results Will Mean More Violence in the Mideast
description: Reacting despondently to the Israeli election, many Arabs today forecast increased violence in the Middle East. The Palestine Liberation Organization said the vote was a ''fatal blow to peace.''

description: Administrations come and go, but Connie Gerrard has stayed put at the White House press office for 25 years.

title: Napa Valley Journal; Growers Find Small Is Beautiful if It's Vegetables
description: Taking a few hours off can be costly for Lynn Brown and his two partners, who farm five scattered acres here in the Napa Valley, producing the baby vegetables that grace nouvelle dinner plates in restaurants throughout the San Francisco Bay area.

title: Poles Stage Protest as Thatcher Arrives
description: Thousands of workers rallied at the Lenin Shipyard here today to protest the Government's decision to close it. Lech Walesa, the leader of Solidarity, said the decision ruled out negotiations between the Government and the union movement.

title: Suspect Transferred In Officer's Slaying
description: A suspected drug dealer accused of killing an undercover police officer was removed yesterday to New York after a psychiatrist determined the man was competent to stand trial.

title: 3 Aviation Aides Die in Crash
description: A twin-engine jet that apparently lost power crashed in the Allegheny Mountains about 45 miles east of Pittsburg today, killing all three Federal Aviation Administration employees aboard, officials said. Spokesmen for the Federal agency said the three had taken off from Allegheny County Airport and were making a routine check of an instrument landing system. The victims were identified as the pilot, James E. Burger, 64 years old, of Linwood, N.J.; the co-pilot, Richard M. Wadsworth, 46, of Ocean City, N.J., and a technician, Theodore L. Burdick, 56, of Egg Harbor Township, N.J.

title: Ideal Basic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $9,659,000 and a $15,552,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, and included a $4 million income tax refund. c-Net loss

title: N.B.A. Issues Fines
description: As a result of fights in National Basketball Association preseason games on Friday between the Detroit Pistons and the Washington Bullets and on Saturday between the Boston Celtics and the Bullets, fines totaling $24,500 were levied yesterday by Rod Thorn, the league's vice president for operations. Hardest hit was Rick Mahorn of the Pistons who was fined $5,000 for attacking Dave Feitl of the Bullets, who must pay $3,000. Larry Bird of the Celtics and Harvey Grant of the Bullets were ejected for fighting and fined $3,500 and $2,500, respectively. Ledell Eackles of Washington must pay $3,000 for joining the fisticuffs. Eight other Pistons and seven Celtics were fined $500 apiece for leaving the bench area during a fight. (AP)

title: H. K. Twitchell, 85, Moral Movement Chief
description: H. Kenaston Twitchell, a former executive director of Moral Re-Armament, an international religious movement founded in 1938, died of a heart attack Sunday in Princeton University Hospital in New Jersey. He was 85 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Prices of Treasury Bonds Decline
description: Treasury bond prices eased yesterday, pulled down by sharply higher prices for precious metals and a weaker dollar.

description: The Ann Taylor chain, one of the most respected and imitated group of women's apparel stores, has failed to attract much buyer interest since the Campeau Corporation put it up for sale two months ago.

description: Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods fell 1.9 percent in September, reflecting the volatility of demand for jet aircraft.

title: Sears Trading Halted in West
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco halted trading yesterday in shares of Sears, Roebuck & Company as rumors spread late in the day that someone seemed to be on the verge of making a takeover bid for the big Chicago-based retailing concern.

title: Dallas Destroys Apartments That Harbored Drug Dealers
description: Three vacant and dilapidated apartment buildings that were said to be havens for drug dealers have been demolished, marking the end of a one-year campaign by the Dallas police.

description: Earlier this week, an attempt by Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward to ease ''racial disharmony'' at a Queens station house by transferring out a quarter of its officers, both black and white, was widely hailed as a sign that he intends to respond swiftly to reports of racism in the ranks of the city's police force.

description: LEAD: Dear Imelda Marcos:

description: Mike Ditka, the coach of the Chicago Bears, suffered a mild heart attack today after his daily workout at the team's training camp and was hospitalized in serious condition.

description: This is a town that thrives on nature's blessings, especially marriage.

title: Study Calls Payments in Plane Crashes Unfair
description: Relatives of people killed in airline crashes are paid less than half their economic losses, and the legal battles give little incentive for improving safety, a Rand Corporation study says.

title: Resignation And Boycott At Sassy
description: SASSY, the irreverent magazine for teen-age girls that is laboring under an advertiser boycott organized by a conservative religious group, quietly lost its publisher last week.

title: Joseph D. Depew, TV Director, 76
description: Joseph D. Depew, a child actor in silent films who went on to direct a number of popular television programs, including ''The Beverly Hillbillies,'' died Sunday at his home here. He was 76 years old.

title: Prominent U.S. Bishops Sharply Assail Vatican
description: A panel of prominent Roman Catholic bishops in the United States has issued a scathing rejection of a Vatican document that questions the authority of regional bishops' conferences.

title: Ex-Lehman Chairman Hears Wall St.'s Call
description: Lewis L. Glucksman, who was chairman and chief executive of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. until its purchase by Shearson/American Express Inc. four years ago, said yesterday that he expected to be back on Wall Street very soon.

title: For Graduate Students, Marriage Presents a Special Problem
description: A demanding program of graduate or doctoral studies can be hazardous to a marriage, especially when only one spouse is going through the ordeal, recent studies indicate.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $68,000 for the quarter and $203,000 for the 9 months.

title: Review/Music; In Bernstein by Bernstein, The Old Vienna Swings
description: Brand names dominated the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra's concert on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall. In addition to the famous Austrian ensemble itself, there was a three-B's program - Beethoven, Brahms and Leonard Bernstein -conducted by one of the very same B's. Not to prolong the suspense, the man at the podium was Mr. Bernstein, whose annual appearances here at the head of the Vienna have become hot-ticket items.

title: American Southwest Mortage Investments Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company began operations on Aug. 26, 1987 so comparative results are not available. For the period Aug. 26 to Sept. 30, 1987, the company had earnings of $880,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: Shipment Dip In Steel Seen
description: The level of shipments from the nation's steel service centers will decline slightly next year, to 23 million tons, according to a forecast released yesterday by the Steel Service Center Institute. But the Cleveland-based association said that the industry would encounter more stable prices and more favorable lead times and inventory levels.

Topics of The Times; Keep Your Tie High and Dry
description: One of the most irritating problems known to man - not to woman - is how to keep food off his necktie. Now Paul Stuart, purveyor of men's finery, is about to respond with a shirt that features a loop for securing the tie out of the path of dropped food. It will be sewn onto the left front panel, where Ralph Lauren might stitch a little polo pony. The shirts are so special they will have no label inside the neck, just ''Stuart's Choice'' embroidered on the front shirttail. The price: $135 - enough to pay for a lot of necktie dry-cleaning, or a couple of upscale new ties.

title: Kitty Dukakis Due to Leave Hospital Today
description: Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, is expected to be released from a Minneapolis hospital today after treatment for an upper respiratory viral infection that may have been complicated by a bacterial infection, her spokesman said yesterday.

title: Calendar: A Tour Of Murray Hill Area
description: Elegant Enclave, New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street; 212-873-0125.

title: Banned Runner Returns
description: Standing in bright lights behind a podium, leaning forward into a microphone to speak in halting English, Antoni Niemczak of Poland, the only runner to produce a positive drug test at the New York City Marathon, pleaded his case. ''For me, drug test, please,'' he said yesterday. ''Every day. After next week, no problem. I never take any anabolics, any steroid.''

description: b-After an extraordinary charge for litigation settlement of $6,448,000 and a credit of $6,090,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year.

description: The political commercial that raised some of the strongest doubts about Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's record on crime seems certain to win a place in the annals of campaign advertising.

title: Newburgh Lawmaker Indicted as Tax Dodger
description: A Federal grand jury today added charges of tax evasion and obstruction of justice to an indictment for mail and bank fraud handed up six weeks ago against State Senator Richard E. Schermerhorn of Newburgh.

title: Midwest Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Artists Give Modern Cast To Limoges and Sevres
description: IN ''Past Forms Present Tense,'' a show that opens today at Artisanspace at the Fashion Institute of Technology, six artists applied their images and motifs to vases and plates made in the porcelain factories of Sevres and Limoges, which were founded in the 18th century.

title: New York Candidates on the Issues
description: From the start, Robert R. McMillan, more of a lawyer and businessman than politician, has been the underdog against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the state's senior senator, who is seeking a third term. He won by a 2-to-1 ratio six years ago and polls point to a similar margin of victory next week. However, Mr. McMillan, underfinanced and undersupported by his own party, has taken the position that no incumbent should get ''a free ride'' and that an election is an opportunity to encourage discussion of issues. With both Senator Moynihan and Mr. McMillan not straying too far from the ideological center, there have been few major differences on issues. But, they disagree on abortion, aid to the Nicaraguan Contras and the budget deficit. The two candidates were interviewed by Frank Lynn of The New York Times. Daniel Patrick Moynihan: Drugs - As co-chairman of Democratic Working Group on Drug Abuse, helped draft recent legislation that reversed past allocation of more than 70 percent of Federal funds for cutting drug supply. ''As long as there is a demand for drugs, a supply will exist.'' Bill allocates 55 percent of new funds to reducing demand by mandating treatment on request. ''Addicts who want help must get it.''

title: Nuryan LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Great Western's Step-Down Notes
description: The Great Western Bank, one of the largest savings banks in the United States and a unit of the Great Western Financial Corporation, is offering $250 million of global floating-rate notes due in 1991. The notes, priced at par, are being offered simultaneously in the United States and abroad through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Salvador Guerrillas Kill 6 More
description: Guerrillas killed six soldiers today in attacks on an army post and a bridge, the authorities said.

title: Newport Pharmaceuticals International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Some Chamber Favorites
description: Three of the four works on the program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall were selections from 20 favorites nominated by the society's subscribers. The fourth was the most colorful of the Haydn Piano Trios. It was, in other words, an afternoon of comfortable oldies -and why not?

title: A Vote for Deadlock
description: There will be no peace. For the foreseeable future, Israel will rule the 1.7 million Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza by force. Resistance will continue, and terrorism increase. Israel will respond with greater repression, spending not only its financial but its moral capital to keep the occupied territories.

title: Peerless Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
An Airport Issue Of San Jose, Calif.
description: San Jose, Calif., is tentatively offering $68.6 million of airport revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.562 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Parcells Feels Ditka's Pain
description: MINUTES earlier, Bill Parcells had heard about Mike Ditka's heart attack. And now the Giants' coach stared at somebody he had been talking with on Monday.

title: INSIDE
description: Inflation Worries Moscow After decades of calling rising prices a capitalist affliction, Soviet officials are concerned that it will invade their system. Page A12. Radar Dispute Intensifies Talks on a disputed Siberian radar broke down as Washington protested increased Soviet air attacks against rebels in Afghanistan. Page A13. Drug Testing Is Defended Two top Reagan Administration officials urge the Supreme Court to uphold the Administration's program of testing for illegal drug use. Page A20. Good Samaritan Gunman A Brooklyn man came to the aid of a mugging victim, shooting her two assailants and killing one. He is being held on a weapons charge. Page B1. Insider Case Widens In a case stemming from the ''Yuppie Five'' inquiry, two brokerages and three arbitragers were charged with insider-trading violations. Page D1. Bishops Confront Vatican A panel of bishops from the United States rejected a Vatican document questioning the authority of regional bishops' conferences. Page A20.

title: Human Rights Group Criticizes Peru
description: An American human rights organization has charged that Peru's civilian Government is tolerating growing human rights abuses by the armed forces in their eight-year-old war against Maoist guerrillas.

title: Sales of New Homes Down 7.8%
description: Sales of new single-family homes fell 7.8 percent in September, the Government reported yesterday. It was the largest monthly drop since May 1987, but the report did not cause much alarm among industry experts or economists.

title: Inspiration Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included a $26.7 million gain on the sale of the net assets of Inspiration Copper Co. The year-ago periods' nets consists of a $100,000 loss for the quarter and income of $10,698,000 for the 9 months, both from continuing operations; income of $2,438,000 from discontinued operations for both periods, and tax credits of $5,424,000 and $11,413,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The year-ago quarter also included an $11.4 million gain from capitalization of exploration expenses at a Canadian nickel property and the sale of some Canadian gold exploration properties. The year-ago 9 months also included $16.4 million in gains from the sale of mining properties.

title: Campaign Trail; Recognition Factor Is a Built-In One
description: Joining Michael S. Dukakis at a rally here were Senator Edward M. Kennedy and a Minnesota Senate candidate, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d. ''The only trouble I have with Skip Humphrey,'' said Mr. Kennedy, grinning, ''is he is trying to get along on the basis of a famous family name.''

title: Rival Views on Economy: To Nurture, or to Prune?
description: In weeks of campaigning, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Vice President Bush have outlined a huge difference in economic policy.

title: People
description: * Howard Liszt and Marvin Goldsmith have been promoted to the newly created positions of president and chief operating officer of, respectively, Campbell-Mithun-Esty's Chicago and Minneapolis offices.

title: A. A. Marberger, 41, Art Dealer Who Directed Fischbach Gallery
description: A. Aladar Marberger, a New York art dealer, died Tuesday evening at New York Hospital. He was 41 years old and had had AIDS for three years.

title: U.S. Productivity Climbed At 1.3% Rate in 3d Quarter
description: The nation's productivity rose at an annual rate of 1.3 percent from July 1 to Sept. 30, reversing a second-quarter decline when new employment outpaced growth in goods and services.

title: A.M.A. Asks States to Ban 'Smokeless' Cigarette
description: The American Medical Association filed petitions with regulatory officials in Arizona and Missouri today seeking to ban the sale and distribution of a new ''smokeless'' cigarette now being test marketed in the two states.

title: Reviews/Music; A Korean Pianist's Recital
description: Aesun Ahn, a Korean pianist who completed her studies in New York with Earl Wild and has been performing here and in Korea since 1983, gave a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening. Ms. Ahn possesses a strong and fairly secure technique, and her renderings were mature and well considered, if occasionally on the stormy side.

title: Diamond Shamrock Offshore Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SAUDIS USE 'PAIN' TO PRESSURE OPEC
description: Using what is known in OPEC circles as a ''pain strategy,'' Saudi Arabia is trying to move oil prices up for the long term by driving them down now.

title: A New Soviet Candor: Inflation Under Communism
description: After decades of insisting that rising prices were primarily an affliction of capitalism, Soviet officials have begun worrying openly that inflation is also a curse of perestroika.

title: Review/Television; How Truman Staged an Upset in '48
description: ''The Great Upset of '48'' may bring a touch of hope to the distressed Democrats of '88. As Paul Duke, the narrator of the brisk documentary about Harry S. Truman's surprise victory over Thomas E. Dewey in the 1948 Presidential race, reminds us, ''The pollsters, the press and the politicians were dead wrong.'' All, of course, had predicted a Republican sweep.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Muzzle
description: When she is right, nobody is more fiercely impressive than Margaret Thatcher. And when Britain's Prime Minister is wrong, her zeal compounds the damage and embarrassment. Now she is spectacularly wrong with a new limit on journalistic freedom and a proposal allowing a criminal defendant's silence to weigh as evidence against him.

title: Topics of The Times; Say Yes to New Jersey Education
description: Governor Kean likes to point out that in New Jersey, prosperity is directly tied to education. Next Tuesday, voters will be asked to support both by approving public Question No. 1, a $350 million bond issue for buildings and high technology centers at New Jersey colleges. The proposal merits approval.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 25 about cholesterol testing in children cited a study at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine indicating that a restricted-cholesterol diet did not impair children's growth.

title: Bush, Sensing Landslide, Ridicules Rival
description: With Republicans hinting that they might be headed for a landslide victory next week, Vice President Bush today continued to ridicule his Democratic rival as the two wrestled for the votes of conservative Democrats in the Midwest.

title: Doctors Seek Test for Lyme Disease That Is Reliable in Early Stages
description: As tick-borne Lyme disease becomes ever more widespread, researchers and clinicians say there is a pressing need for a rapid test that will help doctors diagnose the disease in its early stages before it creates chronic problems.

title: American Restaurant Parters LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter and 9 months results are reported on a pro forma basis as the company went public in August 1987.

title: Review/Dance; Garth Fagan Troupe Creates Its Own Rules
description: Something different is always on the boards when the Garth Fagan Bucket Dance Company comes to town from Rochester. Mr. Fagan's choreography has its own rules, its special dynamic. What looks misplaced acquires its own value. Energy is transmuted into emotion in the best of Mr. Fagan's dance works.

title: Fire at Complex for the Elderly Kills Woman
description: One woman was killed and at least 16 people were taken to hospitals suffering from smoke inhalation after a fire burned through a housing complex for the elderly tonight, officials said.

title: Jets' Road Is Not Easy
description: With their surprising 5-3-1 record that has them in the middle of the chase for a wild-card playoff berth, and opponents looming with mediocre records, the Jets seem to be in good shape for the stretch run. They may not be.

title: Reviews/Music; Naumberg Winner in Recital
description: Anton Nel, the 26-year-old pianist who won the Naumburg competition last year, played a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening and made an impression as a musician firmly in control of his instrument and committed to finding something of his own in each of the works he selected.

title: Knape & Vogt Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Koch Aide Tells Of Cautioning Myerson in '83
description: Mayor Koch's special assistant, Herbert Rickman, testified yesterday that he told Bess Myerson that she had made a ''mistake'' by giving Sukhreet Gabel a job in the Cultural Affairs Department of New York City.

title: U.S. Captures Nations' Cup
description: Katie Monahan Prudent piloted Make My Day through two flawless rounds of jumping last night to pace the United States team to victory in the $14,000 Bank of Montreal Nations' Cup competition at the National Horse Show.

title: Cocaine Seized on Eastern Jet
description: Federal agents have seized a shipment of cocaine aboard an Eastern Airlines jet for the second time in two weeks. Customs agents on Monday confiscated about 60 pounds of the drug on the flight from Barranquilla, Colombia, the authorities said. Last week agents seized 56 pounds of cocaine on annother Eastern jetliner.

title: Lancer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Maytag Chief Looks To Global Markets
description: When Daniel J. Krumm entered the appliance business 36 years ago, there were scores of companies competing. Today, the domestic industry has consolidated through acquisitions to just a handful of major companies, and now the industry is marked by the emergence of global appliance enterprises.

title: Canadian Oil Revenues
description: Lower oil prices and a stronger Canadian dollar will reduce production revenues of Canadian oil companies in 1988 to their lowest level in nine years, the industry magazine Oilweek said today. Revenues from oil, natural gas and sulfur will drop 18 percent, to $15.6 billion (Canadian), or $12.7 billion (United States), it predicted.

title: Guessing Begins: Who's Next on the Podium?
description: If recent history is any guide, the next music director of the New York Philharmonic will be a solid, unflamboyant conductor. Since World War II, direction of the orchestra has fluctuated between two apparent, if not necessarily real, extremes: from the dictatorial eccentricities of Artur Rodzinski (1943 to 1947) to the monklike sobriety of Dimitri Mitropoulos (1949 to 1958), from the exuberant showmanship of Leonard Bernstein (1958-1969) to the Gallic austerity of Pierre Boulez (1971 to 1977).

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Agreed to terms with Bruce Benedict, catcher, on a one-year contract. DETROIT (AL) - Agreed to terms with Luis Salazar, infielder, on a one-year contract. MINNESOTA (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Mark Pittman, Jimmy Williams and Mike Dyer, pitchers; Derek Parks, catcher, and Rafael DeLima, outfielder, from Portland of the Pacific Coast League. TORONTO (AL) - Assigned Matt Stark, catcher, outright to Syracuse of the International League. BASKETBALL NETS (NBA) - Acquired Joe Barry Carroll, center, and Lester Conner, guard, from the Houston Rockets for Frank Johnson and Lorenzo Romar, guards; Tony Brown, guard-forward, and Tim McCormick, center. BOXING WORLD BOXING COUNCIL - Re-elected Jose Sulaiman, president, to a four-year term. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Suspended David Shaw, Rangers' defenseman, for 12 games. COLLEGES CALIFORNIA (Pa.) - Named Dave Pilipovich assistant men's basketball coach. HUNTER - Named Chris Barry sports-information director. POINT PARK - Announced it will field a men's soccer team beginning next fall. TUESDAY BASEBALL OAKLAND (AL) - Announced it will not exercise the option for 1989 on Glenn Hubbard, second baseman. BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Waived Bruce Douglas, guard. HOUSTON (NBA) - Waived Jim Grandholm, forward. NETS (NBA) - Waived Derreck Hamilton and Anthony Bowie, guards. PHOENIX (NBA) - Waived Rodney Johns, guard. Placed Steve Kerr, guard, and Winston Crite, forward, on the injured list. UTAH (NBA) - Waived Scott Roth, forward, and Marty Simmons and Billy Donovan, guards. COLLEGE N.C.A.A. - Placed the Kansas basketball program on three-year probation and barred it from the 1989 N.C.A.A. tournament. COLORADO - Suspended J. J. Flannigan, tailback, for one game after his arrest for misdemeanor assault and menacing. FORDHAM - Named Joe Favorito director of sports media relations.

title: Soviets to Raise Exports of Oil
description: The Soviet Union plans to continue increasing oil exports in the face of falling world prices because it needs the foreign currency, the first deputy minister for oil said today.

title: ICN Plans to Buy Stake in Schering
description: Schering A.G. said that it had been told that ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., based in Costa Mesa, Calif., would buy up to 25 percent of the West German company. A spokesman for the company, Ralph Harenberg, said ICN had told Schering that it intended to acquire $15 million worth of the common stock in the pharmaceuticals and chemicals group, which would amount to about 1 percent of its outstanding shares, and might increase the holding up to 25 percent.

title: The Race for Congress; Liberal Vies With Moderate in Washington's Senate Contest
description: A foot-stomping liberal Democrat and a moderate Republican, endangered species in many parts of the country this year, are in a virtual dead heat in the race for an open United States Senate seat in the state of Washington.

title: Pinson Considered
description: Vada Pinson, hitting coach of the Detroit Tigers, has become the most recent addition to the list of possible new managers for the Seattle Mariners, according to a report yesterday in The Seattle Times. The paper quoted sources as saying that Mariner officials plan to interview Pinson, who was an assistant Mariners coach from 1977 to 1980 and 1982-83. Reportedly heading the list of coaching candidates is Lou Piniella of the Yankees and Jim Lefevbre, third-base and hitting coach of the Oakland A's (AP)

title: Wells, Rich, Greene
description: The Mobil Chemical Company has assigned its newest products, Lustra Giftwrap and Hefty Designs Waste Baskets, to its agency of record, Wells, Rich, Greene Worldwide. The budget for both products adds up to $5 million. As a result, the agency, which created the ''Hefty/Wimpy'' trash-bag campaign for the client, now has more than $20 million in Mobil Chemical business.

title: Calling All Castoffs: You Have a Home
description: TO Elena Lomasney, love doesn't mean never having to say you're sorry. Love means a friend calling on the telephone and saying: ''Elena, come quickly. I'm throwing something out.''

title: Designers on a Quiet Road to Success
description: SOME designers achieve success without a great deal of noise. Two such talents, Michael Kors and Charlotte Neuville, unveiled spring collections Tuesday that were both wearable and close to the fashion pulse.

The stock jumped $1.75, to $86.75, in trading of nearly 3.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the day's second-most-active issue.

France Elevates Platini
description: He was France's star soccer player throughout the glory years, when the French national team made the semifinals of the World Cup in both 1982 and 1986, and he won the European player of the year award in 1983, 1984 and 1985. Now, with France floundering as it tries to qualify for the 1990 World Cup, Michel Platini has been named head coach of the French national team. Platini, the captain of the national team from 1979 to 1987, replaces Henri Michel, whose tactics came into question after France tied lowly Cyprus, 1-1, in a World Cup qualifier on Oct. 22. Platini, 33 years old, recently retired as a player. He last played for Juventus, of Turin, Italy, and helped that club win the 1984 Cup Winners' Cup and the 1985 European Champion Clubs' Cup. (AP)

title: Philippines Seeks Loan
description: The Philippines, burdened by nearly $30 billion of overseas debt, began crucial negotiations today for a new loan from the International Monetary Fund. An I.M.F. package of $600 million over two years or $900 million over three years would open the way for an additional $4 billion from commercial banks and governments.

The victim, Abraham Greene, was burned to death in the fire, according to John Mulligan, a fire department spokesman, who declared the death a homocide. Mr. Mulligan said investigators found that several fires had been set in the bedroom.

description: WHEN the Philip Morris Companies began its hostile $11.5 billion bid for Kraft Inc. on Oct. 17, both sides started following speedy game plans that they say were thought out well in advance.

title: No Headline
description: East and West look at gardening differently. ''The East feels a spiritual unity with the landscape,'' said Stephen A. Morrell. ''The West likes to conquer it like a wild beast.'' Mr. Morrell, the curator of the John P. Humes Japanese Stroll Garden in Mill Neck, L.I., is one of four specialists who will scrutinize some inscrutable aspects of Japanese garden design at a symposium next week at the New York Botanical Garden. The subject appears to be of increasing interest to American gardeners.

title: Mehta to Step Down As Music Director Of the Philharmonic After '90-'91 Season
description: Zubin Mehta, the music director of the New York Philharmonic since 1978, announced his resignation yesterday. Mr. Mehta will step down at the end of his current contract, which extends through the 1990-91 season. At that time he will have held the post of music director longer than any other conductor in the orchestra's modern history.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When I moved into my 60-year-old apartment a couple of years ago, paint was peeling from the ceiling and the walls had bubbles on them. These would crack if you tapped them. I had all the walls and ceilings scraped, sanded, patched and painted, but last summer the bubbles were back and a few weeks ago a piece of plaster fell from the ceiling. What causes this problem, and what can be done about it? A. From your description it seems as though, at least on the ceiling, the problem may be with the plaster rather than the paint. If so, you will have to scrape out all the defective and loose sections and then do a more extensive patching job on the plaster. Or you may be better off putting up ceiling tiles or panels. As for the walls, it is not clear whether the paint or the plaster is bubbling. If the plaster is actually bubbling, then the defective material must either be scraped out and replaced or patched, or covered with paneling. If the paint is bubbling, it should all be removed, and the walls should be primed with an alkyd primer sealer before repainting. An even better solution would be to line the walls with canvas after scraping off as much of the paint as possible. You can then paint over the canvas just as you would over plaster. Q. Five years ago we had our kitchen rebuilt and installed a new ceiling with recessed lighting fixtures, which use reflector lamps. I cannot tell the exact wattage of the bulbs originally installed, but I have been replacing them with 75-watt bulbs. Lately the paint around one of the fixtures has started to bubble and crack. We thought it might be from a leak, but the nearest pipe is in a wall more than three feet away, and the plumber thinks the bubbling may be caused by the fixture. What is your opinion?< A. It sounds as if the fixture is becoming overheated and causing the paint to bubble. You may be using bulbs that are too high in wattage, or the fixture may not have enough space around it inside the ceiling to allow heat to escape harmlessly. All such fixtures are marked as to the maximum size bulbs that should be used (many are limited to 50 watts), so look for a label on the inside. If the ceiling is not accessible from above, then the fixture should be taken down. The space above and around it should be inspected from below to make certain that it is not covered by insulation or that air circulation around it is not otherwise impeded. Q. The metal cabinets in our kitchen have been faced with pressboard covered with something that looks like a contact paper with a simulated dark wood finish. This paper facing has peeled off in several places. Is it possible to paint over it with a lighter color? A. Yes. First wipe the surface with a solvent like paint thinner to make certain you remove all wax, polish, grease and soil. (This thinner is flammable, so take all precautions and make sure there is no pilot light on.) Prime with a coat of Enamelac, BIN or similar shellac-based sealer. Then paint with two coats of semigloss enamel, sanding lightly between coats. Q. My house has steel siding on the outside. Can this siding be painted, and if so what kind of paint should be used? A. The first step is to clean the siding thoroughly by scrubbing it with a brush and detergent. Then, if you are sure the siding is steel and not aluminum (you can test with a magnet), it should be primed with a metal primer, after which you can apply two coats of any good-grade alkyd base house paint. If the siding is aluminum, no primer is needed, and a latex house paint that is formulated for this purpose should be used.

title: Review/Pop; Kenny Loggins, in Different Voices
description: Unlike almost every other successful performing songwriter of his generation, Kenny Loggins has maintained a flourishing recording career without the benefit of a sharply defined public image. The singer, who opened an eight-performance engagement at the Neil Simon Theater (250 West 52d Street) on Tuesday evening, has always exuded a California-style boy-next-door ingenuousness. But neither on record nor in concert has he ever seemed to represent a distinct cultural constituency in the way that performers like Bruce Springsteen, John Denver or Barry Manilow so obviously do.

title: Prague Casino Planned
description: A Canadian casino company, the Sun-Gold Developments International Corporation, said it had reached an ''interim agreement'' with Cedok, the Czechoslovak travel agency, to run a Nevada-style gambling operation in Prague, the nation's capital. Cedok, which will have a 54 percent interest in the joint venture, expects the casino to attract tourists from non-Communist countries who visit Czechoslovakia each year. Czechoslovak citizens will not be permitted to gamble at the resort.

The club will accept entries until Nov. 30. Write to: Art Directors Club Exhibition Department, 250 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10003. Or phone: (212) 674-0500.

title: 2 Campaigners, Separated by Border, Seek Re-election in Different Worlds
description: Bob Davis and Jim Kelleher are seeking re-election to their national legislatures from districts separated only by a river. But their campaigns are more than miles or kilometers apart.

title: Only a Rumor
description: A trade of shortstops that would send Shawon Dunston from the Chicago Cubs to the Mets for Kevin Elster is only a rumor, the clubs said yesterday. According to reports in each city, the Cubs were close to trading Dunston to the Mets for Elster and the relief pitcher Roger McDowell.

description: With opinion polls showing their prospects for re-election in jeopardy, the governing Progressive Conservatives have begun to fight back against opposition assertions that they have endangered Canada's future in the free-trade pact with the United States.

title: 5-Year Term for Drug Sales
description: A woman convicted of using her 13-year-old daughter and her 15-year-old nephew to make drug sales near an elementary school was sentenced Monday to five years in prison with no possibility of parole. The woman, Terris Ann Paige, was convicted Aug. 23 of four counts of selling cocaine within 1,000 feet of a school and two counts of using minors to distribute the drug. There was no evidence that children in the school were buyers, prosecutors said.

title: Review/Television; How and Why Cary Grant Was Like No One Else
description: People of a certain age insist that today's stars of stage, screen and television can't hold a candle to show-business luminaries of the past. A pronounced element of glamour, not to mention style, has disappeared from the scene. Cher is hardly Garbo. Madonna couldn't stand on the same stage with Merman. And so on. I suspect that 30 or 40 years from now, today's young folk will be saying the same about their current heroes and heroines. We tend to protect and exalt our own icons.
