title: Interco Wins Reprieve On 'Poison Pill' Ruling
description: Interco Inc. gained a reprieve yesterday from a threatened takeover by the Rales brothers when the Delaware Chancery Court issued a temporary stay of its earlier order that Interco dismantle its ''poison pill'' defense.

title: Massachusetts Adopts Plan On Cost of Human Services
description: The Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency yesterday introduced a financing program intended to stabilize the cost of essential human services purchased by the state.

title: Small Rises For Yields
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, with most of the gains in shorter maturities.

title: President Vetoes Measures On Wilderness and Indians
description: President Reagan today vetoed bills designating 1.43 million acres of Forest Service land in Montana as wilderness and establishing a corporation to provide development capital to Indian businesses.

title: Tyson Accident Is Not Serious
description: A bus carrying Mike Tyson, the world heavyweight champion, and the promoter Don King was involved in a minor accident, but no one was injured, Jose Sulaiman, the World Boxing Council president, said today.

title: Parent & Child
description: FORMING friendships is one of the first social tasks children undertake without their parents. Recent research has found that the friendships between children as young as toddlers are far more complex and stable than earlier developmental psychologists had thought possible. The ways in which children choose and play with their friends offer a singular view of their emotional needs.

title: Accounts
description: * Daihatsu America, the American arm of the Japanese auto maker, to Kresser, Craig/D.I.K. of Los Angeles, at $10 million to $15 million.

title: S&M Company reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Pop; Black Version of Early Cajun
description: The Ardoin family, one of Louisiana's great musical clans, gave a musical lecture on the uses of music on Sunday night at the Village Gate. Playing a roughhouse black version of early Cajun music, they turned the dance floor into a roiling mass of bodies.

title: Quaker Oats Plant
description: The Quaker Oats Company said it would discontinue its corn milling operations at its foods division plant in Chattanooga, Tenn. It said the shutdown, scheduled for mid-February, would affect 68 of the plant's 140 employees.

title: PAM Transporation Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Justices Hear Thornburgh Defend Drug-Testing Plan
description: The Supreme Court today heard two top Reagan Administration officials defend parts of the Administration's wide-ranging program to detect and deter illegal drug use by Federal employees and railroad workers.

title: Review/Theater; Evergreen Aleichem
description: Yiddish theater, whose death has been proclaimed regularly for at least the last quarter of a century, started a new season over the weekend - as it has every year for a century and more. The sturdy and persistent Folksbiene Playhouse opened its colorful and humorous presentation of Sholom Aleichem's comedy with music, ''The Big Winner,'' in the comfortable auditorium of Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street.

title: Louisville Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comdata Holdings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Because Comdata Holdings' merger with Comdata Network on Sept. 9, 1987 was accounted for as a purchase transaction, only 21 days were included in the period ended Sept. 30, 1987. For that period, the company reported a loss of $510,000 on revenue of $8,201,000.

title: Hudson Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes a gain on extinguishment of debt of $10,855,146 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: Marten Transport reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $748,000 from an accounting change.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Monday said incorrectly that the House of Representatives' new anti-discrimination rules confer on members a right to refuse House employment to applicants for reasons of life style. The rules do not mention, and therefore neither authorize nor forbid, discrimination based on life style.

title: Sequent Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $194,000 and $620,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $194,000 and $691,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Reagan Signs Measure on Tracking Medical Waste
description: President Reagan has signed into law legislation intended to control infectious medical wastes like those that washed up on Atlantic Coast beaches last summer, White House officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: No Rise Seen in Natural Gas Prices
description: Unless this winter turns out to be particularly brutal, natural gas prices are unlikely to rise much above last winter's peak, many industry executives say.

title: A 30-Second Ad on Crime
description: ''Weekend Passes'' is the title of the 30-second advertisement about Willie Horton that was financed by the National Security Political Action Committee.

title: Sbarro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
Pegasus Gold Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.1 million, or 9 cents a share, from a sale of a portion of the company's investment in Pan Australian Mining Ltd.

title: Germany Rediscovers an Honored Style
description: DRIVE to the outskirts of virtually any city in West Germany and before long, apartment buildings of concrete and glass yield to farmhouses with red-tiled roofs and beams of burnished wood that slice angular patterns in their whitewashed facades.

title: CNA Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $28,759,000 for the quarter and $116,144,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment losses of $6,943,000 and $18,514,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: AIDS-Tainted Blood Is Ruled Toxic Substance
description: In what is believed to be the first ruling of its kind, a New York State Supreme Court judge has held that blood contaminated with the AIDS virus could be considered a toxic substance under a 1986 law.

title: Arnold Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the its latest third quarter's share earnings includes a net gain of 28 cents from the sale of the company's investment in Viking Freight. Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1988.

title: KEY RATES
America West Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,577,000 from a securities transaction. c-Net loss

title: America's Team Continues to Decline
description: Not that long ago, the Dallas Cowboys were living up to their self-styled billing as America's Team. From 1966 through 1985, they had 20 straight winning seasons and 13 division titles. In a nine-season span, they played in five Super Bowls.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer error, the Eating Well column in The Living Section yesterday gave incomplete instructions for Three-Way Apple Oat Bran Muffins. The fourth step should read this way: in a third bowl, combine applesauce, egg whites, oil and dried apples.

title: Lawyer Exonerated in Witness-Bribing Case
description: A prominent Manhattan negligence lawyer was acquitted yesterday of charges that he sought to bribe potential trial witnesses in a $7 million wrongful-death suit against the City of New York.

title: Venezuela Leader Urges Calm
description: President Jaime Lusinchi called for calm after a bomb killed two students today and violent protests erupted over the slaying of 14 civilians by an army patrol last weekend.

title: Takeover Defense By a French Bank
description: Societe Generale, France's third-biggest private bank, said it had begun a defense against an investor who has acquired 9.2 percent of the bank's shares. The bank's chairman, Marc Vienot, said at a news conference that a capital increase announced earlier by the bank would dilute holdings of Marceau Investissements, a concern headed by the Georges Pebereau.

title: Nixon to Stay On
description: Russ Nixon, who managed the Atlanta Braves to 42 victories in 121 games after the dismissal of Chuck Tanner last spring, agreed on Tuesday night to accept the team's offer of a one-year contract at undisclosed financial terms. Nixon had indicated last week that he would not return to manage unless he received a two-year pact. ''I never really changed my mind,'' said the manager. ''I made some proposals and they made some proposals. This is the United States of America, and you can do that here.'' Bobby Cox, the general manager, also played down the quick resolution of the seemingly polarized dispute. ''The main thing is that we wanted Russ to stay on as manager and he wanted to stay on,'' said Cox. (AP)

title: Leave That Toothsome Field of Metaphor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Reagan Campaign Magic: He Isn't Running, but He's Winning
description: In a Presidency in which images and symbols often have taken precedence over substance, Ronald Reagan shows little concern about appearing overconfident that he will be succeeded by Vice President Bush.

title: Woman Says She Was Abused and Fondled by Police
description: The Police Department is investigating a complaint by a woman that she was wrongfully arrested, punched and kicked by police officers and then fondled in a patrol car by one of them, police officials said yesterday.

title: Britton Lee Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Raytheon Gets Job
description: The Department of Transportation announced yesterday that it had awarded a contract worth as much as $282.6 million to the Raytheon Company to install radar systems in large airports nationwide. The equipment, called Doppler weather radar systems, will allow air controllers to warn planes of hazardous wind shear conditions. The systems, to be provided by Raytheon's Equipment division of Wayland, Mass., will be installed at 47 airports, with the Government holding the option to expand the order up to 102 systems. First delivery of the equipment, to the Federal Aviation Administration Technical Center in Atlantic City, is scheduled for the fall of 1991.

title: Leave That Toothsome Field of Metaphor; Faces Are Shrinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Trail; Light Conversation And Heavy Reading
description: Her husband thinks Shakespeare's plays are ''too heavy,'' but he enjoyed Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' because, as he put it, ''I like sociology.''

title: South Africa Rate Rises
description: South Africa's central bank said today that it was raising a key interest rate two percentage points to prop up the nation's currency and restrain pre-Christmas buying on credit. The rise in the discount rate, to 14 1/2 percent from 12 1/2 percent, implies higher rates on various consumer and commercial loans. The discount rate is the interest the central bank charges on loans to member banks.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions yesterday about a trial arising from attacks on Israeli and American diplomats in Egypt misstated the number of defendants. In addition to two relatives of former President Gamal Abdel Nasser, 18 people are charged.

title: Gold Fields Plans No Sales of Assets
description: The chairman of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. said that the mining company, which is facing a $4.9 billion hostile takeover offer from a group controlled by South African companies, does not expect to sell any important assets. Rudolph Agnew, chairman of Consolidated Gold Fields, told shareholders at the company's annual general meeting, ''As long as I am chairman of the company, we are unlikely to break it up.''

title: A U.N. Fund Helps Women
description: Until recently, the women of Njau used to spend four hand-blistering hours a day pounding millet into flour, their staple food. Today this is done in five minutes by the village milling machine.

title: Essex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Basquiat Memorial
description: A memorial service for the artist Jean Michel Basquiat is to be held on Saturday at 2:30 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Mr. Basquiat died Aug. 12 at the age of 27.

title: Convenience Buys Southland Stores
description: National Convenience Stores Inc. agreed to buy at least 79 San Antonio-area stores from the Southland Corporation for an undisclosed amount. The sale, which is still subject to a definitive agreement, is expected to close in January 1989, officials said.

title: Augat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter includes a pre- tax restructuring charge of $39,000,000.

title: Rockwell International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $50 million, or 18 cents a share, and $200 million, or 74 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Austerity In Stores For Youths
description: ALTHOUGH their austerity may appeal more to parents than to children, the Kinder Kind stores in Hong Kong, in their own fashion, are small playgrounds.

title: Sports People; Blood Doping Test
description: Two Scandinavian physicians said yesterday they had made a breakthrough in detecting blood doping in athletes. Dr. Inggard Lereim of Norway and Dr. Tapio Videman of Finland said their tests were 100 percent accurate in detecting use of another person's blood and 50 percent accurate in finding athletes who took transfusions of their blood.

title: Natwest Capital Offers 9 3/8% Notes
description: The Natwest Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. is offering $500 million of 9 3/8 percent subordinated notes due in 2003 at a price of 99.485 to yield 9.44 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Hibbing Journal; No Honor for the Home Of a Famed Native Son
description: Ask most people here and they say they do not see what is so special about the two-story stucco house over on Seventh Avenue. ''They say, 'Yeah, so Bobby Zimmerman grew up there,' '' said Curt Curtis, a local real estate agent who is now listing the house. ''So, big deal!''

title: Profit Taking Hits Copper, But Price Outlook Is Strong
description: Copper prices fell yesterday after having soared to record levels for three consecutive days in New York and London. Although metals analysts did not rule out further profit taking today by nervous traders and speculators, they said the shrinking global supply of copper should bolster prices until well into 1989.

title: Sportswear: Chanel and a Touch of Tahiti
description: Sportswear, meaning casual dressing, this country's main contribution to world fashion, has undergone a sea change in the spring collections shown in New York this week. Chanel of the 1930's has emerged as a major influence, expressed in carloads of gold buttons, acres of white pleated skirts and plenty of navy jackets.

title: Montana Senator Milks an Old Line
description: Forget all those slick television campaign ads about Boston Harbor, furloughed murderers, gun control, the environment and the folksy candidates at home talking fervently about family values. The talking cow is back. John Melcher, a 64-year-old Democrat who is Montana's senior Senator, is running for re-election against Conrad Burns, a Republican and farm-news broadcaster.

title: Bamberger Polymers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Few Grapes Cost $600.40
description: A man convicted of a felony for munching on grapes at a grocery store has been ordered to pay 40 cents in restitution and $600 in court costs. The 52-year-old defendant, Eli Bradley Jr., could have been imprisoned for up to four years on the larceny conviction.

title: On Your Mark!
description: The Marine Corps expects a record 13,000 long-distance runners to show up Sunday for its 13th annual marathon, which will start and end near the Iwo Jima memorial in Arlington, Va., and wend its way over the Potomac River, through the memorials and around the Capitol.

title: Indian Courts Struggling to Keep Their Identity
description: Chief Judge Elbridge Coochise never went to law school and he has never taken a bar examination. But the 42-year-old Hopi Indian is a respected jurist who presides over the sovereign courts of 16 Pacific Northwest Indian tribes in a legal system little known outside Indian reservations.

title: KMS Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Invoking Kennedy Triumph, Dukakis Tours Connecticut
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis swept up the Naugatuck Valley tonight, attacking unfavorable polls and reminding his supporters at every opportunity of John F. Kennedy's triumphant march up the same Connecticut passage on election eve in 1960.

title: Sierracin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $400,000.

title: Savings Agency Head Sees Insurance Limits
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board contended today that Congress never intended that deposit insurance premiums cover a financial crisis like the one faced now by the savings and loan industry.

title: Emotional Issues Are the 1988 Battleground
description: In their television advertisements and stump speeches, in their debates and interviews, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis have emphasized issues fraught with emotion like crime, drugs, civil liberties, gun control, abortion, the environment and ethics.

title: Review/Art; A Wide-Ranging Spread Of Artists and Installations
description: ''The New Urban Landscape'' is an exhibition that runs the gamut in just about every sense, ultimately raising more questions than it manages to answer. Alternately ambitious and amateurish, it presents installations by 26 artists, architects and collaborative groups from the United States, Canada, France, England and Japan. It is spread out over several spaces and sites, finished and unfinished, indoors and outdoors, at the newly opened World Financial Center at Battery Park City, where it has been sponsored by the center's builders, Olympia & York.

title: U.S. Agrees to Investigate Radio Ads by G.O.P. in Texas
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh agreed today to investigate a Republican advertising campaign in South Texas that Democrats contend is intimidating Spanish-speaking voters with its ''Big Brother'' tone.

title: CBI Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Theaters and Clubs Make a 'Hot' Area
description: Despite its maligned identity as the shabby back door to the theater district, Eighth Avenue actually spends nearly half of its 50-block life as the spine of Chelsea.

title: American Steel & Wire reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $42,000 from discontinued operations.

title: John J. Lindsay, Journalist, 67
description: John Joseph Lindsay, the Senate reporter for Newsweek magazine, died of cancer Wednesday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

title: Health-Mor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $20,782 for the quarter and income of $21,328 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $120,428 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $145,292 and $136,640 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $40,000 for the quarter and $130,000 for the 9 months.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Krone to Make History in Breeders' Cup
description: Julie Krone will become the first woman to ride in a Breeders' Cup race when she gets a leg up on Darby Shuffle here Saturday in the Juvenile Fillies, the second of the seven cup races at Churchill Downs. Krone will ride Dr. Bizarre in the Juvenile and Forty Niner in the Classic.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sonny Rollins

title: Stocks Rally As Dow Gains 13.51
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday, although the rally was confined mainly to blue-chip stocks and stocks tied to takeovers, real or rumored.

title: Under Bush, the Rich Would Just Get Richer
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Form Banking Firm To Test Themselves
description: M. William Benedetto and Arthur J. Gartland have formed an investment banking firm, a venture that Mr. Benedetto attributes to ''a feeling in your stomach - you've got to see if you can do it on your own.''

title: Under Bush, the Rich Would Just Get Richer; Better Under Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: In Sight: A Real World Court
description: A welcome offshoot of Moscow's new thinking about the United Nations is the Soviet rediscovery of the World Court. Few global resources are as underused. Its 15 judges sitting in The Hague have been around for decades to resolve disputes, but jostling sovereign states have shied from submitting their legal differences to the Court's binding arbitration.

title: Bentsen, in Texas, Hints That Loss by Democratic Ticket Is Possible
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen predicted today that the Congress elected next week would not recognize ''any kind of mandate'' to cooperate with Vice President Bush if he should win the Presidential race.

title: Bahrain Formally Subscribes To Non-Proliferation Treaty
description: Bahrain formally committed itself to the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty today, the State Department said.

title: Delmarva Power & Light Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Holly Asks Holders To Shun Tyson Bid
description: Officers of the Holly Farms Corporation urged stockholders to reject a buyout offer of about $940 million from a rival poultry processor, Tyson Foods Inc. of Springdale, Ark. ''The offer is inadequate and not in the best interests of the company and its stockholders,'' Holly's board said in a statement.

title: At the Movies
description: Cameron's 'Abyss'

title: EECO Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Includes a gain of $681,000, or 17 cents a share, from sale of real estate in Cambridge, England.

title: Sports People; They're Managing
description: Two recently dismissed Yankee coaches, Jeff Torborg and Chris Chambliss, were appointed managers yesterday, one on the major-league level. Torborg, a 10-year major league catcher with the Dodgers and the Angels who managed the Cleveland Indians before joining the Yankee coaching staff Aug. 1, 1979, was hired as manager of the Chicago White Sox.

title: PSE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1987 are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB No. 90.

title: Cross & Trecker Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,957,000 and $1,047,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss of $4,736,000 from discontinued operations. The loss from continuing operations for the latest quarter includes a net loss of $3.8 million related to the previously announced phaseout of a parts machining plant in Georgetown, Ky. and losses on contract settlements. The company said the loss for the fourth quarter of fiscal 1987 includes an after-tax charge of $9.7 million for restructuring.

title: Prices of Treasuries Show Gains
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds climbed as much as a half-point yesterday, buoyed by a firm dollar and a drop in commodity prices.

title: Books of The Times; Jerusalem, Where Dreams Are Shaped by Creeds
description: Jerusalem on Earth People, Passions and Politics in the Holy City By Abraham Rabinovich 225 pages. The Free Press. $19.95.

description: The share earnings are in units.

Black & Decker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25

description: b-Net loss

title: Ralston Purina Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $43 million, or 60 cents a share, from the sale of Drake Bakeries Inc. c-Includes after-tax gains from the sale of the company's domestic agricultural business and Drake Bakeries totaling $252.3 million, or $3.49 a share, and an extraordinary loss of $3.3 million from the the early retirement of debt. In July 1988 the company announced that it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its Van Camp Seafood division. As a result, Van Camp's operating results have been reported as discontinued operations with prior periods restated. The year ended Sept. 30, 1987, includes the gain on sale of the company's domestic agricultural products business of $376.8 million, before applicable income taxes of $167.5 million, net of $209.3 million, or $2.89 a share. Income taxes for the year eneded Sept. 30, 1987, include a $5.8 million provision for repeal of the investment tax credit retroactive to Jan. 1, 1986. The latest periods' nets included gains from discontinued operations of $5.5 million for the quarter and $24.4 million for the year, compared with same gains for year-ago quarter of $4.4 million and for the year of $15.8 million.

title: U.S. Judge Upsets Rule On Voters Who Move
description: A provision of the state election law that requires people who move during the month before Election Day to file for a special ballot at least a week before the election is illegal and should be voided, a Federal District Court judge ruled Wednesday.

title: Bushspeak Fans, Bend Us Your Ears
description: As the Presidential campaign wanes and Vice President Bush's confidence grows, the Republican Presidential nominee is not only more upbeat, but he also feels freer to express himself in his own way - with nouns tangled by wayward verbs and clauses ambushed by preppy adverbs.

title: Integrated Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carson Not Ready To Call It Quits
description: Harry Carson may not be the grand old man of pro football, but he is not far away.

title: Indian Troops Arrive to Put Down Coup Attempt in Island Republic
description: Indian troops landed early today in the tiny Indian Ocean republic of the Maldives to crush a coup attempt against the country's President.

title: PENTAGON REPORTS IMPROPER CHARGES FOR CONSULTANTS
description: A Pentagon investigation has found that the nation's largest military contractors routinely charge the Defense Department for hundreds of millions of dollars paid to consultants, often without justification.

title: No and Yes on Ballot Proposals
description: Six important proposals appear on Tuesday's ballot. We urge a no vote on Proposal 1, the state's Transportation Bond Issue. We urge yes votes on Proposals 2 through 6, revisions of the New York City Charter.

title: Reynolds & Reynolds Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest quarter and year figures include a gain of 58 cents a share resulting principally from the sale of the company's tax processing unit.

title: Mickelberry Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The year-ago results included the operations of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson Inc., a former unit which was sold in October 1987.

title: Boxing; Hearns Has Shot at 5th Title
description: Bob Arum, who is promoting the tripleheader here Friday night featuring Thomas Hearns, Michael Nunn and Matthew Hilton, said reports of the commercial death of his card are greatly exaggerated.

title: 12 Chilean Generals Retired, Including Pinochet's Deputy
description: President Augusto Pinochet reorganized the highest ranks of his army today, sending a dozen generals into retirement.

title: Devils Manage To Gain A Tie
description: The Devils confronted a sharp goaltender in Eldon (Pokey) Reddick of the Winnipeg Jets tonight but managed a 3-3 tie. Reddick made 39 saves, including three in the five-minute overtime, to thwart the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Best Buy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. v. Marcoses: 'Betrayal,' Doris Duke Says
description: The tobacco heiress Doris Duke said yesterday that she put up $5 million in bail for her friend Imelda Marcos because she felt that the case was ''a betrayal of all that the wonderful U.S.A. stands for.''

title: ECC International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $2,100,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: 2d Inquiry Into Killing Is Extended
description: A Queens judge yesterday gave prosecutors two more weeks to investigate whether a man has been wrongly jailed for 17 months in a triple murder at a Queens liquor store.

title: Sports People; Blyleven Traded
description: For the fifth time in his 19-year major league career, Bert Blyleven is shifting teams, but this time the move will bring the pitcher home. Blyleven, winner of 254 games (and loser of 226), was sent from the Minnesota Twins to the California Angels yesterday for three minor league players. Although he was born in the Netherlands 37 years ago, the right-handed Blyleven grew up in southern California and lives in Villa Park, 10 minutes from Anaheim Stadium.

title: Tempers Flare At Aqueduct
description: The regular jockeys began riding again at Aqueduct Wednesday, but the tension is as high as ever because many of the replacement riders are still riding. Track officials said William

title: Colonel Klink Talks His Roles With Orchestras
description: Werner Klemperer, who won a Tony nomination for his recent portrayal of the Jewish grocer in ''Cabaret,'' has played many characters on stage, film and television. But it's one television role in particular that evokes double takes from passers-by. They recognize Colonel Klink, the pompous Nazi in ''Hogan's Heroes,'' the long-running comedy that ended in 1971. The part won him two Emmys and millions of viewers, who saw the series in reruns if they didn't see the original.

title: Delta Woodside Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: The latest first quarter reflects the Sept. 7 acquisition of Stanwood Corp. The company said year-ago results were restated to reflect an acquisition.

title: Cox to Keep Link With The Miami Herald
description: Cox Enterprises Inc. expects to file a plan with the Justice Department next week that would guarantee that it receives profits from newspaper operations in Miami even after it withdraws from that market at the end of this year.

title: Rodman & Renshaw reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Pop/Jazz; Getting to New York, At Last
description: Teddy Edwards, the legendary West Coast tenor saxophonist who's making his first appearance in New York as a leader of a quartet at the Village Vanguard, is a natural storyteller. His eyes constantly check to see if his audience is getting the joke. With an obvious sense of irony, Mr. Edwards, brought up in Jackson, Miss., relishes humor.

title: What's for Lunch?
description: It figures. The Department of Commerce is supposed to foster business. So the department's cafeteria at Constitution and 15th Street has begun doing its part by advertising its daily luncheon menu with a telephone call-in service.

title: Mine Sold In Mexico
description: The Mexicana de Cobre copper mine is being sold back to its previous owner and a union in exchange for $1.36 billion worth of Mexico's foreign debt, the Government development bank, Nacional Financiera, said Tuesday.

title: INSIDE
description: New Bid for RJR Nabisco An investment group led by RJR Nabisco's chairman offered $20.9 billion for the company after talks with a rival bidder broke down. Page D1. Church Council Reorganizes The National Council of Churches, long tied to liberal causes, voted to retrench as it sought ways to survive in times hostile to liberalism. Page A16. Indian Troops to Maldives Indian troops landed in the Maldives, the tiny Indian Ocean nation, to crush a coup attempt said to involve mercenaries from Sri Lanka. Page A6.

title: Restaurants
description: Rogers & Barbero

title: Reagan Vetoes Bill to Protect 1.4 Million Acres in Montana
description: President Reagan has vetoed legislation that would protect 1.4 million acres in Montana as pristine wilderness, setting off a debate about whether his action was politically motivated.

title: At The Bar
description: It's officially called ''A Uniform System of Citation,'' though generations of law students know it simply as ''The Bluebook.'' And its function seems as bland as its name: to provide rules for referring to cases, constitutions, statutes and other legal materials. The Bluebook, like almost everything else in legal education, comes from Cambridge, Mass.; it was first published in 1926 by The Harvard Law Review (or ''Harv. L. Rev.,'' in Bluebook-ese).

title: OSLO ASSERTS INDIA GOT ATOM MATERIAL
description: The Norwegian authorities looking into the disappearance of 15 tons of Norwegian heavy water in 1983 say they have discovered that it was combined with heavy water from the Soviet Union and diverted to India.

title: Ballard Medical Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vietnam Turns Over Remains to U.S.
description: In a ceremony at the Hanoi airport, Vietnam today turned over to an American military delegation 23 sets of remains that could be those of United States servicemen unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.

title: First Connecticut Small Busiess Investment Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $97,206 and $131,329 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $16,669 for the quarter and $121,947 for the 6 months.

title: 'Virus' in Military Computers Disrupts Systems Nationwide
description: In an intrusion that raises questions about the vulnerability of the nation's computers, a Department of Defense network has been disrupted since Wednesday by a rapidly spreading ''virus'' program apparently introduced by a computer science student.

title: Taco Viva Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
description: The company's first fiscal quarter consists of 16 weeks.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Tobin Takes Over for Ditka As Bears Prepare for Bucs
description: Will Mike Ditka have a telephone hookup from Lake Forest Hospital to Soldier Field on Sunday when the Chicago Bears play the Tampa Bay Buccaneers? Will Ditka simply call at halftime? If his team is losing late, will he slip out of his hospital room to clean up matters?

title: Quartet From Cologne
description: The Auryn Quartet - Matthias Lingenfelder and Jens Oppermann, violinists; Steuart Eaton, violist, and Andreas Arndt, cellist - an ensemble based in Cologne, is to make its New York debut at Weill Recital Hall tonight at 8. The quartet's program in cludes Mendelssohn's Quartet in D (Op. 44, No. 1), Schubert's Quartet Movement in C minor (D. 703), Bartok's Fifth Quartet, and Barber's setting of ''Dover Beach'' for quartet and baritone. Sanford Sylvan is to be the soloist in the Barber. Tickets are $12. Information: 247-7800.

title: Carmike Cinemas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Invacare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The foreign occupation forces, the tigers, will have no choice but to leave Cambodian soil soon. Our duty today is to insure that the soil is not immediately reoccupied by the crocodiles, the Khmer Rouge, who exterminated one million of the country's population.'' - Kishore Mahbubani, Singapore's representativeto the United Nations. [ A3:4. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about mail-order foods gave an incorrect local telephone number for American Spoon Foods in Petoskey, Mich. Its numbers are (800) 222-5886 and (616) 347-9030.

title: Yale Society Resists Peeks Into Its Crypt
description: In a sylvan pocket tucked off High Street, masked by blank slits in an ancient stone building called the Tomb, barred from the world by a padlocked iron door, Skull and Bones keeps its secrets closely. But it casts a shadow across the country.

title: New Bedford Institution reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company converted to stock form of ownership in March 1987. Prior-year results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for loan origination fees and related costs.

title: The Motto of '88
description: ''Where's the beef?'' Walter Mondale's question has long outlived the 1984 campaign. Ronald Reagan's ''Are you better off than you were four years ago?'' recalls 1980. Jimmy Carter (''Why not the best?'' or ''lust in my heart'') may have provided the motto of 1976. What term best encapsulates 1988?

title: KEY RATES
Judge in Chicago Adds To Cheever Case Ruling
description: A judge in Chicago has reiterated that Academy Chicago has a valid contract with Mary Cheever, the widow of John Cheever, to publish a collection of his early works. In a written clarification of his preliminary ruling last September, Judge Roger J. Kiley Jr. of Cook County Circuit Court added on Wednesday that Mrs. Cheever has sole control over the contents of the book but that the manuscript she furnishes must be at least as long as the ''stereotypical John Cheever work'' of 140 to 250 pages.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Goldie Upsets Wilander: Dan Goldie, an American ranked 36th in the world, eliminated top-seeded Mats Wilander, the world's No. 1 player, 6-1, 6-4, last night to reach the quarterfinals of the $642,500 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships. Emilio Sanchez of Spain, seeded seventh, outlasted Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4. Boris Becker of West Germany beat Johan Kriek of the United States, 6-2, 6-0.(AP) Mansdorf Routs Lendl: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl, playing his first match after minor shoulder surgery, was routed, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday by Amos Mansdorf of Israel in their second-round match at the $1 million European Community championship in Antwerp, Belgium. John McEnroe beat Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-2, and Andres Gomez of Ecuador defeated Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 3-6, 6-1, 6-3.(AP) U.S. Leads Britain in Wightman Cup: Zina Garrison and Patty Fendick overwhelmed their British opponents to give the United States a 2-0 lead yesterday in the four-of-seven series of the 60th Wightman Cup tournament in London. Garrison opened defense of the trophy with a 6-2, 6-4 victory over Jo Durie. Fendick defeated Monique Javer, 6-2, 6-1.(AP) Rehe Upsets Shriver: Stephanie Rehe upset Pam Shriver, the defending champion, 1-6, 7-6, 7-5, in the second round of the $300,000 New England Virginia Slims tournament in Worcester, Mass.(AP) Golf Cochran Leads Tucson Open: Russ Cochran, a left-hander who has never won in six seasons on the PGA Tour, shot a 65 to take a one-stroke lead yesterday after the first round of the $600,000 Tucson Open in Arizona. Payne Stewart, David Frost of South Africa, Corey Pavin and Mark Calcavecchia shot 66's.(AP) Volleyball Soviet Union Wins Japan Cup: The Soviet Union beat the United States, 11-15, 15-7, 10-15, 15-12, 15-12, yesterday in the final of the Japan Cup in Hiroshima.(AP)

title: Medicare-Glaser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a gain of $168,000 from an accounting change for the both periods.

Top Koch Aide Denies Pushing Gabel's Hiring
description: Herbert P. Rickman, a top aide to Mayor Koch, angrily denied on the witness stand yesterday that he had suggested that Bess Myerson hire Sukhreet Gabel.

title: College Football Notebook; Penn to Test Lafayette Passer
description: For those in search of a good college football game to attend tomorrow, Air Force at Army would fit the bill. But since that game is sold out, an alternative might be Penn against Lafayette at Easton, Pa., 70 miles from the Lincoln Tunnel.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,000 and $19,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $608,000 for the 9 months.

title: Review/Film; Passion vs. Parenthood in 'The Good Mother'
description: The heroine of ''The Good Mother'' is a flighty, interestingly dressed woman with a scatterbrained manner all her own. She is instantly recognizable as Diane Keaton, though not as Anna Dunlap, the heroine of Sue Miller's phenomenally assured, morally troubling and meticulously precise first novel.

title: It Is the World That Needs the Cloister
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Latvian Group Quits Over Link to SS
description: The chairman of a campaign group called Latvians for Bush has resigned after it was alleged that he had been a member of an adjunct to the German SS in World War II, the Bush campaign said tonight.

title: Duratek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $14,000. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $133,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the 113th Precinct of the New York City Police Department, in some copies, incorrectly characterized the actions of a woman who says she was abused and beaten by police officers and sexually assaulted by one of them. The woman, Valerie Ann Wilson, said that when she was trying to read the badge numbers of one officer, she did not try to grab the officer or his badge.

title: What's Cooking on Eighth Avenue; Openings May Challenge Chelsea's Neighborhood Feel
description: Not long ago, Eighth Avenue in Chelsea was a colorless commercial strip of Laundromats, bodegas, shot-and-beer bars and hardware stores. Then, as if some culinary spore had blown in from the Upper East Side, little bistros and trattorias started sprouting all over. The stretch between 15th and 20th Streets has seen the most frenzied activity recently, with five places opening in the last few months. The street still has a familiar neighborhood feel, although that may not last long if it becomes known as another restaurant row.

title: 2d Conviction in Kidnapping
description: A jury has convicted a 26-year-old woman of murder and kidnapping for helping her boyfriend abduct and bury alive a member of a prominent Illinois family.

title: Three U.S. Designers, Less or More in the Mainstream
description: Blazers with sarong skirts. Pyramid-shaped tunics over voluminous pants. Tailored jackets with wide open necklines. Tent-shaped dresses. Skinny pants worn with bare-midriff tops. These are some of the myriad ideas Ronaldus Shamask offered in New York Wednesday evening in a crowd-pleasing collection that was obviously inspired by the recent showings in Paris. Echoes of Claude Montana were particularly strong.

title: Ferrofluidics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter includes an unrealized currency translation gain of $230,000, compared with a loss of $101,000 for the same period last year, resulting primarily from hedging of a Swiss franc convertible debt obligation due 1991.

title: Soviet Maneuvers: A New Strategy?
description: Despite recent Soviet assertions that the Warsaw Pact has adopted a purely defensive strategy and is cutting back its military forces, recent Warsaw Pact maneuvers in East Germany showed that Soviet forces continue to stress mass tank attacks and other offensive operations.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Krisch American Inns reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hong Kong Decides to Send 40 Vietnamese Back Home
description: The Government said today that 40 Vietnamese who sailed into this British colony seeking political asylum recently did not qualify as refugees and would be detained pending repatriation.

title: Independent Insurance Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment gains of $232,000 for the quarter and $646,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $2,096,000 and $3,281,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Korea to Aid Ailing Daewoo
description: South Korea's economic planners are working on a financial aid package for the Daewoo Group, the business conglomerate, despite a pledge earlier this year to let companies in difficulty go bankrupt.

title: State Senator Denies Guilt After New U.S. Indictment
description: State Senator Richard Schermerhorn, Republican of Newburgh, pleaded not guilty today to new charges of tax evasion and obstruction of justice, and a Federal District Court trial was scheduled for December.

title: George Folsey Dies; Film Maker Was 90
description: George Folsey, a cinematographer who was nominated for 13 Academy Awards, died at a hospital here Tuesday after a stroke and long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: U.N. Condemns Israel's Policy on Palestinians
description: The General Assembly voted 130 to 2 today to condemn Israel for its suppression of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. It said repressive Israeli actions there violate the Palestinians' human rights.

title: Indiana Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $2,479,000 from an accounting change.

title: Long Island Lighting Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months was after a writedown of $1,345,110,000, net of tax effects, reflecting the Public Service Commission's disallowance of certain costs associated with the company's investments in Shoreham, Nine Mile Point 2 and the abandoned Jamesport project. The writedown was recorded as a result of the company's adoption of the provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 90, and was accounted for as the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: Review/Film; A Pair of Sunglasses Reveals a World of Evil
description: The idea that alien forces control our media, making subliminal use of billboards, commercials and magazines to subvert our thinking, probably isn't that hard for most of us to believe. So credibility isn't the problem with John Carpenter's ''They Live,'' which opens today at the Movieland and other theaters, but execution is. Mr. Carpenter has directed the film with B-movie bluntness, but with none of the requisite snap. And his screenplay (written under the pseudonym Frank Armitage) makes the principals sound even more tongue-tied than they have to.

title: Flora Schreiber, 70, The Writer of 'Sybil' And of 'Shoemaker'
description: Flora Rheta Schreiber, the author of ''Sybil,'' a best-selling book about a woman with multiple personalities, and ''Shoemaker,'' a portrait of a Philadelphia murderer, died of a heart attack yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. She was 70 years old.

title: Eastern Utilities Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
What the Duke Wins
description: These are good days for Michael Dukakis. He is giving the very best that is in him.

title: Hanover Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $875,000 and $5,390,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $5,150,000 for the quarter and $14,140,000 for the 9 months, and the quarter includes an extraordinary charge of $187,000 from the reversal of a tax credit, and a tax credit of $128,000 for the 9 months.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Dr. Jane Katz, a professor of physical education at Bronx Community College and a world-class masters competitive swimmer, was one of seven recipients of the Townsend Harris Medal for outstanding achievement in career specializations last night at the annual dinner of the Alumni Association of the City College of New York. Dr. Katz, a former national champion in synchronized swimming and a lecturer on physical fitness, was the first athlete in the history of the C.C.N.Y. Alumni Association to be so honored. . . . Rod Strickland, the top draft choice, is the early leader among late Knicks. When he showed up after practice began on Tuesday, it marked Strickland's third offense.

title: Transcon Incorporated reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cadet Who Collapsed Dies Six Weeks Later
description: A police recruit who collapsed on Sept. 19 from heat stroke and dehydration on the first day of training died late Wednesday. The lawyer for his family today urged that the cadet's instructors be charged with manslaughter.

title: Bush and the C.I.A.
description: Have American voters really thought about the implications of electing a President who once was Director of the C.I.A. and who later attended all the high-level meetings at which the most damning failure of the Reagan Administration was perpetrated?

title: Review/Music; Choir Unites the Many Voices of Bulgaria
description: A forthright woman's voice announces a sustained, age-old melody with an upward step. A second voice, just as strong, joins in, and the two women sing in harmony so close it seems dissonant to Western ears. Soon, chords of almost weightless voices float in behind them, cushioning and transforming the traditional song, blending the earthy and the angelic.

title: Fodor at Tully Hall
description: Eugene Fodor is to be the soloist with the Yale Philharmonia Orchestra IN THE Beethoven Voilin Concerto tomorrow at 3 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The concert, which is to be conducted by Eleazar de Carvalho, is a presentation of the Beethoven Society, and also includes the ''Fidelio'' Overture and the ''Eroica'' Symphony. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: Cigna Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: Bomb Fathers to Meet
description: Last February, the Ethics and Public Policy Center, a Washington research organization, began planning its annual fall dinner with the idea of building it around the themes of science, technology and freedom and presenting an award to the American physicist Edward Teller.

title: Interstate Securities Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest year included $1.2 million pre-tax charge from discontinued Florida operations.

title: IN SOUTH KOREA, RIOTS FLARE AGAIN
description: Thousands of students demanding the arrest of former President Chun Doo Hwan clashed with riot policemen today in one of the worst street protests in recent months.

title: Caracas Loan Is Tied to Oil
description: Venezuela said it would obtain a $1 billion loan secured by oil sales of two American refining companies that it partly owns.

title: Market Place; More Confusion On Griffin Deal
description: MERV GRIFFIN gained fame as a professional communicator. But his communications with Wall Street seem to leave a lot to be desired.

title: Oilers, Colts Rise in Ranking
description: Impressive victories helped send the Houston Oilers and the Indianapolis Colts into the top 10 in The New York Times's National Football League ranking this week. The Buffalo Bills, meanwhile, moved from No. 3 last week to the head of the pack. They have the best record in the league, 8-1, and their average margin of victory is 7 points.

title: Sports People; Cade Must Wait
description: The National Football League ruled yesterday that Mossy Cade, paroled last month after serving a prison sentence for second-degree sexual assault, will not be permitted to return to the Green Bay Packers this season. Cade, 26 years old, was paroled after serving 15 months of a two-year sentence.

title: Penguins Lose, 6-2
description: Walt Poddubny scored three goals tonight as the Quebec Nordiques beat Pittsburgh, 6-2, in a game in which the Penguins' Mario Lemieux was forced to leave because of an injury to his forearm.

title: Jets Prepare to Oppose Klecko and Colts
description: In one of their unusual confrontations, the Jets are attempting to put into perspective their first encounter with Joe Klecko, probably the team's most respected player of the last decade.

title: Butler National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $81,802.

title: Hornets Ready to Celebrate Their Debut
description: The celebrations begin tonight in Charlotte, N.C. Fireworks will burst, the Charlotte Symphony will play and many in the capacity crowd of 23,000 attending the Hornets' first regular-season game at the new coliseum will be wearing tuxedos. There will be commemorative opening-night tickets encased in Lucite for all and a teal flower, to match the team colors, for each woman attending the game against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Review/Concert; Dvorak, a Violinist and a Premiere
description: There are musical works so intrinsically interesting that their quality can be apparent even in mediocre performance. That is true of some Beethoven symphonies. In a different category, however, are works of pure atmosphere such as Dvorak's Romance for violin and orchestra (Op. 11), whose fragile charms can fade into nothing if not treated with high artistry.

title: Weiman Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $186,000.

title: George L. O'Grady, Professor, 80
description: Dr. George L. O'Grady, a retired professor of dentistry at Columbia University, died of cancer yesterday in the Atlantic City Medical Center in Pomona, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in New Gretna, N.J.

title: State by State; House Leader, Praised as Presidential Timber, Tells Why He Won't Run
description: Thomas S. Foley is the kind of man whom people are always trying to persuade to run for President.

title: Michigan Consolidated Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Commerce Dept. Is Sued to Force Adjustment of 1990 Census Plan
description: A group of civic organizations, states and cities, including New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday seeking to force the Commerce Department to adjust the results of the census to be taken in 1990 to account for people inadvertently missed.

title: SUIT SEEKS TO BAR F.B.I. RETALIATION
description: A group of agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of Hispanic background charged today that they were facing retaliation after winning a lawsuit that accused the F.B.I. of discrimination in promotion and working conditions.

title: Philip H. Hiss 3d, 78, Designer of Buildings
description: Philip Hanson Hiss 3d, an architectural designer whose career also included photography, public service and public information, died Oct. 24, after a long illness, at Community Hospital of the Monterey (Calif.) Peninsula. He was 78 years old and lived in Monterey.

title: Korean Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States declined by 13.2 percent, to $6.01 billion, in the first nine months of this year, from $6.92 billion a year ago, the Korea Foreign Trade Association reported today. Korea's global trade surplus came to $5.13 billion, on exports of $42.95 billion and imports of $37.82 billion, according to an earlier Government report.

title: Playboy Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $149,000 and $614,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Hearing Date Set On Interco Appeal
description: The Delaware Supreme Court plans to hear arguments on Nov. 30 on an appeal by Interco Inc. of a lower-court ruling that the company must set aside its ''poison pill'' takeover defense. The St. Louis-based furniture and shoe maker is resisting a $74-a-share cash offer totaling $2.63 billion from Steven M. and Mitchell P. Rales of Washington. The brothers, who already own or have had tendered to them 93 percent of Interco's stock, are not allowed to buy the tendered shares during the appeal.

title: Review/Film; 'Fireflies': Growing Up In Japan
description: When it comes to growing-up-in-the-movies, East and West meet; perhaps they even borrow a little from each another. ''River of Fireflies,'' now at the Public Theater, is a Japanese version of the genre, but the elements will be familiar to moviegoers the world over: a boy's intimations of sex, his loss of childhood friendship and gain of youthful love, his arrival at a more realistic understanding of the weaknesses and strengths of his parents, and the discovery of a new maturity in himself.

title: Ogilvy Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $725,000, or 5 cents a share, and $2,432,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for restructuring and the impact of an adverse arbitration decision in the United Kingdom. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $875,000, or 6 cents a share, and $1,555,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of Ball partnership and a Swedish subsidiary.

description: Dr. Harold B. Hermann, the chief of urology at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn from 1945 to 1970, died of a stroke Wednesday at his home in Woodstock, Vt. He was 88 years old.

title: THATCHER PUSHING SOLIDARITY TALKS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain made an impassioned plea here today for greater freedoms in Eastern Europe and called on the Polish authorities to begin ''real dialogue with representatives of all sections of society, including Solidarity.''

title: Tacoma Lawyer Hailed In Bond Default Case
description: Al Malanca, a trial lawyer from Tacoma, Wash., is credited with masterminding the $226 million settlement that could end the court battles that began in 1983 over the nation's largest default of municipal bonds.

title: Bush Ad Replaces Comic Strip
description: A northern Alabama newspaper publisher today replaced the comic strip ''Cathy,'' whose main character is leaning toward Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, with a campaign advertisement for Vice President Bush.

title: Study Finds Marked Drop in Registration Level Since '84
description: In 27 of the 30 states with final figures available, there has been a pronounced decline in the percentage of eligible Americans who are registered to vote, a research group reported today.

description: A view that has been stated here before bears repeating, if only to introduce a radical solution to a continuing problem:

Pakistan Downs an Afghan Plane
description: Pakistan said it shot down an intruding Afghan warplane inside its borders today, and Afghanistan said Pakistani jet fighters downed two aircraft in Afghan territory.

description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: Tasting at Huberts$37.50 prix fixe menu allows three courses - one from each category or any other way - while a $47.50 menu allows four courses.

title: Economic Scene; The Slowdown And the Election
description: AS the 1988 election campaign draws to an end, the evidence is accumulating that the American economy is slowing down. This week the Commerce Department reported that the index of leading indicators dropped one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the third decline in five months. Real gross national product, the broadest measure of the economy's performance, slipped to an annual growth rate of only 2.2 percent in the third quarter from 3 percent in the second quarter and 3.4 percent in the year's first quarter. The business mood has grown cautious: A Dun & Bradstreet survey of plant managers reports expectations of slower production and orders in the fourth quarter.

title: Samaritan's Disparate Lives Meet In Court After 18 Months on Run
description: As Anthony Dixon, he was a hard-working cook and a church-going Christian. As Clovis Fearon, he pleaded guilty to selling crack to undercover police officers and then spent 18 months on the run.

title: Chicago Suffers Along With Ditka
description: Through the day and into Wednesday night, the newscasters and the fans and players all talked about how they couldn't believe it: Iron Mike Ditka felled by a heart attack. Say it ain't so.

title: Household International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ford Motor Issue
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $150 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due 1998 at a price of par through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Noncallable for five years, the notes yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity and are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: The Dance Is Still On At School in Missouri
description: A Federal appeals court has refused to block the first school dance in a century at Purdy High School, according to the lawyer who successfully challenged the school district's ban on dancing. The homecoming dance is planned for Dec. 10, A Federal judge in Springfield struck down the ban earlier this year, saying it unconstitutionally promoted religious values.

title: Group Bids $20.9 Billion For Nabisco
description: Increasing the pressure in the largest takeover battle in Wall Street history, a $20.9 billion takeover offer for RJR Nabisco Inc. was made yesterday by one of two investment groups that is vying for the huge foods and tobacco company.

title: Lawrence Matloff, Administrator, 62
description: Lawrence Matloff, executive vice president of Selfhelp Community Services, a New York City geriatric and home care agency, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 62 years old.

title: Connaught Biosciences reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special charge of $3,500,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Piedmont Aviation To Sell Certificates
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc., a unit of USAir Group Inc., is offering $44.8 million of equipment trust certificates through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Advertising Gets California Cooler Job
description: The Brown-Forman Corporation had trouble making a go of its California Cooler, and so it has entered into an agreement with the Stroh Brewery Company to produce and distribute it. That means the advertising account, which will probably finish the year with $2 million in billings (down from $10.8 million in 1987), will go to Grey Advertising, which already has Stroh's White Mountain Cooler, Old Milwaukee and Old Milwaukee Light beers and Schaefer beer.

title: How to Muddy The Political Waters
description: This week's mail in some newspaper offices in San Francisco included an unusual campaign package: a small vial of water described by one recipient as ''clearish with little things floating around in it.''

title: Geraldo Rivera's Nose Broken In Scuffle on His Talk Show
description: Geraldo Rivera's nose was broken and his face cut during a skirmish yesterday midway through the taping of a program entitled ''Teen Hatemongers'' on his television talk show.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Retailer's Magazine Dies in an Early Stage
description: Neiman-Marcus magazine, the glossy quarterly bearing the name of one of the nation's best-known retailers, has closed without putting out an issue.

title: George Bush and Willie Horton
description: When it became known that a prominent adviser to Vice President Bush's campaign had once made a count of Jews in the Bureau of Labor Statistics for President Nixon, the campaign dropped him in a flash. When five Bush advisory committee members were accused of anti-Semitic activities, the campaign dropped them in a flash.

title: Wall Street Innovator Is Indicted
description: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a colorful and innovative Wall Street figure who was once a special adviser to the Securities and Exchange Commission, was indicted yesterday along with his brokerage firm on 22 counts of stock manipulation, conspiracy and related offenses.

title: Bass Buys Newspaper Stake
description: The Robert M. Bass Group of Fort Worth has acquired a stake in the Times Publishing Company, owner of The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times and other properties, executives of the company said yesterday.
