title: F.B.I. Investigation Claims That Police Abused Woman
description: An investigation into a young woman's allegations of sexual and racial abuse from policemen at the 113th Precinct station house in Jamaica, Queens, widened yesterday with the entry of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Algerians Vote on Revamping Political System
description: Millions of Algerians voted today in a referendum that was expected to give President Chadli Benjedid a broad mandate to revamp a political system dominated since independence by a single party.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acme United Corp., Fairfield, Conn., a maker of scissors and other products, signed a letter of intent to acquire Emil Schlemper G.m.b.H. of Solingen, West Germany, a scissors manufacturer, for $175 million.

title: Pepperell Asks Court To Block Farley Offer
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. and its J. P. Stevens & Company subsidiary asked a Federal court in Georgia yesterday to block an unsolicited $1.3 billion offer by Farley Inc. to take over Pepperell.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: A Voice That Does 'Impossible' Things
description: The deep, male voice was measured and foreboding: ''As always, should you or any member of your I. M. Force be caught or killed, the secretary will disavow any knowledge of your actions. This tape will self-destruct in five seconds. Good luck, Jim.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Translating Environment Into Ads
description: WHEN marketers speak of the ''advertising environment,'' they are usually referring to the editorial matter or programming that surrounds their ads. But when Peter Arnell uses the phrase, he is speaking literally.

title: Idaho Power Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Marathon; Search Goes On For U.S. Hero
description: The shortage of outstanding American marathoners in the late 1980's has created the necessity for New Yorkers to conduct a search for long-distance heroes. Bill Rodgers will be a master when the 19th New York City Marathon begins with its first bi-level start across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge Sunday morning. But now Rodgers's status has less to do with dominance and more to do with the fact that he has gone beyond his 40th birthday. Tom Fleming is 37, and he has been around long enough to have competed in a marathon that never left Central Park.

title: Kinark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $228,000 from discontinued operations for the both periods.

title: Kohlberg Ends Bid for Macmillan
description: A day after losing a pivotal court ruling, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company withdrew its bid for Macmillan Inc. yesterday, clearing the way for Robert Maxwell, the British publishing entrepreneur, to take over the giant publisher.

title: Stewart Parker, 47, a Playwright On Irish Troubles, Dies in London
description: Stewart Parker, an Irish playwright whose play ''Spokesong'' was performed on Broadway at Circle in the Square in 1979, died of stomach cancer on Wednesday in London, where he lived. He was 47 years old.

title: KILLER OF WOMAN EXECUTED IN TEXAS
description: Donald Gene Franklin, whose appeal halted executions in Texas for more than nine months, was put to death early today for abducting and murdering a nurse 13 years ago. He was 37 years old.

title: Hospital Report Says Charge Of Racial Bias Is Unfounded
description: In a report released yesterday, the office of equal employment opportunity of New York City's municipal hospital system said it had found ''no evidence'' to support charges of racial discrimination that were made by a group of black managers at a city hospital on Roosevelt Island.

title: U.N. Adopts Anti-Khmer Rouge Policy
description: The General Assembly declared today that Cambodia must not return to ''the universally condemned policies and practices of a recent past'' once Vietnamese occupation forces withdraw.

title: Choice of Most Dailies Is for None of the Above
description: The editorial pages of American newspapers are exhibiting the same distaste for both major Presidential candidates that voters have expressed this fall. Hundreds of papers, including some of the largest and most influential dailies, have declined to recommend a choice to readers.

title: Tyson Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Presidential Campaign Mail Inundating New York Voters
description: New York State voters are being flooded with an unprecedented amount of locally financed campaign literature and telephone calls as the state emerges as a fierce battleground in the Presidential campaign.

title: Reviews/Ballet; Joffrey's 'Billy the Kid' Has Familiar Look
description: William H. Bonney, born in Brooklyn, died in the Wild West in 1881. The world knew him as Billy the Kid. Out of his saga of still another urban malcontent seeking the safety valve of the open frontier, an unusually distinguished group of collaborators in 1938 fashioned the American ballet classic known as ''Billy the Kid.''

title: Eagle-Picher
description: Eagle-Picher Industries dramatically increased its provision for asbestos damage claim liability and said it would then post a big net loss for the year. The diversified manufacturing company, which also said it was suspending its common stock dividend, said the plan would result in a negative net worth. After the move was announced Wednesday, the company's stock tumbled $13.50, to $15 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. But the stock recovered $2.625 a share today, closing at $17.625.

title: Hebrew Teaching in Russia Seen as Means to Win West
description: A Soviet decision to end a ban on the teaching of Hebrew and to allow the establishment of a Jewish cultural center is aimed at ''getting the Jewish question off the East-West negotiating table,'' the president of the World Jewish Congress said today.

title: U.S. Explores Another '92 European Expansion
description: Washington has rediscovered Europe.

title: EXECUTIVES CHANGES
description: * Applied Bioscience International Inc., East Millstone, N.J., a toxicological testing service, named as a director Frederick M. Frank, a managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Indian troops landed in the Maldives, a tiny Indian Ocean republic, to crush a coup attempt against the President that was said to involve mercenaries who arrived from Sri Lanka on two ships. Page A6

title: National Horse Show; French Rider Leaps Highest
description: If horses could talk, they would probably admit to being in concert with their riders on the subject of jumping the 7-foot Puissance wall.

title: Maine Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $830,300 from an accounting change.

title: First Amfed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Television; Wodehouse's Glorious Thinness
description: The world of P. G. Wodehouse was a laughable one frequented by boring old money and boorish new money who made mountains out of their negligible molehills in London and Hollywood and on Long Island. As can be seen on ''Tales From the Hollywood Hills'' on ''Great Performances'' tonight at 9 on Channel 13, his wit was formidable and his humor broad.

title: The Race for Congress; Where Incumbency Is No Guarantee: Four Close Contests in North Carolina
description: In stark contrast to the rest of the nation, where members of Congress seem to get elected for life tenure, members of the House from North Carolina have learned the hard way that incumbency is no guarantee of returning to Washington.

title: SJW Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
San Diego Gas Drops Plan to Merge With Tucson Electric
description: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company said today that it ended a proposed merger with the Tucson Electric Power Company because the utilities could not decide how to keep a rival utility from thwarting their plans. Probable regulatory problems also were cited.

title: American Bankers Insurance Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $21,000 for the quarter and realized investment losses of $621,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after realized investment gains of $946,000 and $1,437,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Review/Art; The Collages of Benny Andrews
description: In 1957, when Benny Andrews made ''Janitors at Rest,'' he was 27 years old. He had served in Korea and was one of the few black students, and one of the few Southerners, at the school of the Art Institute of Chicago. A group of Southern black janitors sat near the men's room, mops and buckets ready to bail out another student mess. He liked them, hung out with them, occasionally shared their ritual when half pints of whisky were passed around.

title: Chevron to Convert Gulf Gas Stations
description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc., the domestic operating subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, said it would convert nearly 3,000 Gulf service stations in Texas, Louisiana, Arkansas and New Mexico to the Chevron name in 1989. Since merging with the Gulf Corporation in March 1984, Chevron has marketed products in those states under the Gulf name.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Moroccan development of Western Sahara described the town of Tarfaya and its people incompletely. The town is in Morocco. But because its people are considered Saharan rather than Moroccan, they expect to take part in a referendum on Western Sahara's future.

title: Computer Automation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago first quarter is restated to reflect a change in accounting for tax loss carryforwards.

title: Property Trust of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $32,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: Review/Film; The Glory Fades in 'Everybody's All-American'
description: Bards from A. E. Housman to Bruce Springsteen have mourned the passing of the athlete's glory, but it's a subject that never goes out of style. And it has been brought vibrantly to life in Taylor Hackford's ''Everybody's All-American,'' a film that matches this director's ''Officer and a Gentleman'' in the sharpness of its sense of place, the sureness of its storytelling momentum and the larger-than-life performances of its stars.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: 'Career Girls' Murderer Is Denied Parole Again
description: Richard Robles, who has served 24 years in the famous ''career girls'' murder case, has been denied parole for a second time.

title: Convict Freed In Store Blaze That Killed 6
description: A man who has spent almost 10 years in prison for the 1978 Waldbaum's supermarket fire that killed six firefighters was set free yesterday when a New York State judge set aside his conviction.

title: Trans Leasing International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MCI Plans a Separate Facsimile Network
description: Taking advantage of the boom in the use of facsimile machines, the MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would offer to business customers a special network for transmission of facsimile messages.

title: Registration Off Since 1984 Vote
description: There has been a pronounced decline in the percentage of eligible Americans who are registered to vote, a research group reports.

title: Bay State Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about studies of radiation hazards near nuclear weapon plants gave incorrect numbers for actual and expected leukemia cases among boys and men between 1982 and 1984 near the Pilgrim nuclear power plant in Massachusetts. There were 22 cases; statistically, only 12.1 cases would have been expected.

title: Henley Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an approximate $165 million gain on the sale of the M.W. Kellogg Company. c-Net income and reflects an approximate $75 million gain on the sale of a minority interest in Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. d-Includes a first quarter charge to expense of $65 million in connection with certain modifications of the company's master support agreement with Allied-Signal Inc. The reduction in 1988 versus 1987 net revenues primarily relates to the sale of the M.W. Kellogg Company in January 1988.

title: Bridge
description: The first stage in crowning the intercollegiate champions of 1989 was taken Tuesday night when 32 groups from throughout North America tried to qualify for the national final in Reno in March.

title: Southwestern Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Pratt & Lambert Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Magnetic Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Worm of Racism Beneath Campaign's Surface
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefit for the Homeless
description: ''You can't go to a performance by anybody in this benefit without walking by or over homeless people. New York is the city these artists have chosen to live in, and the city is not dealing with all its citizens fairly. Part of the job of artists is to pay attention to the environment. And if we have all our antennae out, we can't help but see the homeless and hungry.''

title: Khartoum Journal; At the End of the Road Is the Graveyard of Hope
description: On the outskirts of this ocher and green city - the hues of the sand and the flat-roofed buildings match, trees lend contrasts - lies a graveyard of buses. The corroded hulks of more than 600 yellow Mercedes buses, their engines and seats ripped out, stand side by side, a sad metaphor of Khartoum's decay.

title: Loews Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $6.8 million, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of a tanker for the quarter; the 9 months was after net from discontinued operations of $18,067,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $4,987,000 for the quarter and $16,072,000 for the 9 months. The net from discontinued operations included a net gain on the disposition of CBS's records division for the latest 9 months and net operating results of CBS's magazine and records divisions for both year-ago periods. The latest 9 months' net included a gain on the sale of chewing tobacco and little cigar business amounting to $29.4 million, or 39 cents a share. The year-ago periods' included income tax benefits of $36,288,000 for the quarter and $53,157,000 for the 9 months. The latest periods' revenue included investment gains of $44,894,000 for the quarter and $248,042,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago periods' revenue included investment losses of $27,183,000 and $20,705,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: General RE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment losses of $19.5 million and $17.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $36.5 million. c-Includes investment gains of $700,000 for the quarter and $11.3 million for the 9 months; net from discontinued operations of $5.3 million for the quarter and $24.6 million for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a tax benefit of $11.7 million.

title: Review/Early Music; Aston Magna Plays Purcell
description: Through all its shifts of leadership, the Aston Magna organization has remained an important American center for specialists in the performance of early music - albeit now, it would seem, primarily on the level of chamber music rather than scores for larger forces.

title: Avtex Is Closing Rocket-Yarn Plant
description: Avtex Fibers Inc. began closing a plant that is the sole supplier of rayon yarn used in space shuttle rocket nozzles. Morton Thiokol Inc., the maker of space shuttle motors, said Avtex had produced enough of the yarn for the next 10 shuttle launchings - or through December 1989, if the current schedule holds. But Thiokol, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Pentagon and other contractors were talking with Avtex in hopes of averting a shutdown.

title: Dukakis Envisions A Movable Feast
description: Privately, aides to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis call it ''the regional food pander.''

title: American International Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized losses on investments of $16,901,000 for the quarter and realized gains on investments of $37,680,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $29,589,000 and $83,047,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Analysts Say Political Mud Can Yeild Gold
description: For weeks, politicians and voters have been criticizing the widespread use of negative campaigning. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg begs to differ.

title: Bush, Taking Rival's Line, Says 'Labels' Don't Matter
description: Vice President Bush, whose weeks of ideological pounding on the stump finally led Gov. Michael S. Dukakis to acknowledge that he is a ''liberal,'' told a rally in Columbus, Ohio, today, ''This election is not about labels.''

title: Review/Art: A Wealth of Masterworks, Old and New; At Brooklyn Museum, The Sumptuous World Of Gustave Courbet
description: It is a remarkable turn of events that brings to New York City at one and the same time both ''Degas'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and an ambitious and well-considered exhibition of 100 paintings and drawings by Courbet at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Church Council, Losing Appeal, Will Reorganize
description: The leadership of the National Council of Churches, long identified with such liberal issues as oppositon to prayer in public schools, voted yesterday to reorganize and retrench as it seeks to survive in times hostile to liberalism.

title: Scott Paper
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would spend more than $50 million to buy and rebuild paper machines and to convert plants and equipment to enhance its sanitary paper business in Asia. Scott said the improvements would occur at its operations in Malaysia, Thailand and Taiwan.

title: Comair Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Wealth of Masterworks, Old and New; Auction Houses Offer A Century of Art In 7 Days of Sales
description: Major works from three prominent art collections - including such familiar images as a Degas dancer, a Jasper Johns flag and an Andy Warhol Marilyn Monroe - are among the highlights in the November auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art. Most of the paintings and sculptures are to go on view this weekend at Sotheby's and Christie's.

title: 6 Weeks of the Arts, Latin and Experimental
description: Experimental performance and visual art by Latin American and American Latino artists has rarely been seen in New York theaters or galleries. But such art is thriving, as a six-week exhibition and performance series opening today at El Museo del Barrio testifies.

title: Change at Pentagon
description: Regardless who becomes the President-elect Tuesday and who becomes the Secretary of Defense-designate later, Pentagon leaders are getting ready to turn over the levers of government.

title: Britannia Airways Orders Boeing Jets
description: The British charter airline Britannia Airways Ltd. ordered eight Boeing 767-200 aircraft in a deal worth $:590 million ($1.05 billion). The order is the airline's biggest in the 26 years it has been operating. Britannia, wholly owned by Thomson Travel Ltd., said that its new Boeing airliners would be delivered in the next five years and that it had an option on eight more 767-200's to be taken by 1995.

title: Dire Prophecy on Takeovers By One Who Knows Them
description: Martin Lipton, the Park Avenue lawyer who reportedly received the largest legal fee in history in connection with a corporate merger, has told clients that the wave of acquisitions will soon cause a stock market crash.

title: Under Bush, the Rich Would Just Get Richer; Median Income Rises
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting the Jobless a Job in Itself
description: Rena V. Tieser's occupational hazards include crime, two-worker households, vacationers, dogs, prevaricators, non-English speakers, unlisted telephone numbers and people who are hostile or inebriated or undressed. Her job is to help the Government compile unemployment figures.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jazz the Soviet Way

title: Pentagon Bolsters Hospitals
description: The Pentagon, hoping to contain the cost of its health insurance plan for dependents of military personnel and for retirees, has approved 21 projects aimed at expanding the capacity of military hospitals to handle such patients.

title: RB&W Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $62,000 and $318,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: 2 Die in Mexican Labor Clash
description: At least 2 people were killed and 15 wounded in a shootout late today between rival labor factions inside a luxury hotel here, according to news reports. The private Televisa news program ''24 Hours'' said about 200 dissident labor activists stormed the Hotel Presidente Chapultepec and began firing at members of the pro-Government Mexican Workers Federation.

title: Our Towns; Group Homes: A Law Works Ever So Quietly
description: Perhaps the nicest thing you could say to mark the 10th anniversary of the Padavan law in New York is that no one has noticed, so it is working beautifully. Ever so quietly, it is helping bring about a social revolution right under New Yorkers' noses.

title: On Stage
description: Lo Bianco as La Guardia

title: Talks Continue On Plan to Shut Shoreham Plant
description: Proposals for a compromise on Governor Cuomo's plan to abandon the Shoreham nuclear power plant are being discussed in Albany as a deadline for the plan is about to be set on Long Island.

title: Review/Film; U2 Hits the Road in 'Rattle and Hum'
description: As a whole new generation of film makers cuts its teeth on rock video, the hardest thing about filming concert documentaries may be insuring that they don't look better than they should. Flashy, high-style concert footage is by now rock's most numbing cliche, and it has a way of destroying any grit or authenticity that exists in the music itself.

title: Avondale Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $3,028,000 loss from discontinued operations. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Sikh Terrorists Kill 10 Men After Pulling Them Off a Bus
description: Sikh terrorists pulled 10 people off a bus in the north Indian state of Punjab today and shot them to death, the police said.

title: Review/Theater; The Loss Of Life's Savor
description: The title ''Soul of a Jew,'' seems intended to send the playgoer reaching for his prayer shawl: ''May it not be an ethnic joke.'' Or, more fervently, ''May it not be another torturing of the much-battered subject of Jewish identity.'' Or, may the Evil Eye spare us, ''May it have nothing to do with Jewish guilt and self-loathing.'' Alas, Joshua Sobol's play, which the Haifa Municipal Theater of Israel has brought to Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, is not the answer to a prayer. Its main novelty is to combine breast-beating with music-hall turns; the result is peculiar without being either stimulating or much fun.

title: 10-Day Sales Of Vehicles Climb 6.7%
description: Late-October sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 6.7 percent from the comparable period last year, the seven domestic auto manufacturers reported today.

title: Under Bush, the Rich Would Just Get Richer; More Low-Wage Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Cary Lemkowitz, Michael Robert and Eric Weber, creative directors at Young & Rubicam's three agency groups, will each assume the title of vice chairman.

title: Gorbachev's Anti-Americanism
description: LEAD: Overlooked in the Kremlin reshuffling is a development that may someday rival in importance the replacement of the pro-Western Maxim Litvinov as Foreign Minister in May 1939 by Vyacheslav Molotov - just before the Soviet-German nonaggression pact of 1939.

title: Pacificorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sears Rises $3 On Merger Talk
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's shares rose $3 yesterday, closing at $46. There has been wide takeover speculation following the retailer's announcement on Monday of restructuring moves. Almost 8.2 million shares were traded, making it the most active issue by far on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Miami Police Want To Control Homeless By Arresting Them
description: Bracing for the annual influx of homeless people fleeing the Northern cold, the police here have proposed an emergency ordinance that would allow them to arrest some street people as a way of keeping them on the move.

title: Merck Sees $1 Billion Drug
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that it expects its blood-pressure drug, Vasotec, to have $1 billion in sales this year - a first for any drug made by the Rahway, N.J., company. Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, chairman and chief executive of Merck, added that Vasotec sales rose after receiving the Food and Drug Administration's approval in June for the treatment of congestive heart failure.

title: Cincinnati on Probation
description: The University of Cincinnati football and basketball teams were banned from post-season play for one year today and placed on probation for three years for violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules on recruiting and scholarships.

title: Let's Say No To Exit Polls
description: LEAD: On Election Day, voters throughout America have an opportunity to strike a blow for the integrity of the political process. By boycotting the exit polls, they can tell the major television networks to stop announcing winners while the public is still voting. If voters refuse to tell network pollsters lurking outside the polling places anything about how they voted, they can make it impossible for the networks to accurately project a winner.

title: Not-So-Silent Cal
description: To the Editor:

title: MEI Diversified reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $267,000 from the early extingushment of debt. The latest quarter and 9 months included pre-tax gains of $11,355,000 and $10,099,000, respectively, on the sale of current marketable securities. The year-ago periods included pre- tax gains of $4,024,000 for the quarter and $6,574,000 for the 9 months, on the sale of current marketable securities.

title: Sports People; Yankees and Stadiums
description: George Steinbrenner, still haggling with New York City over the Yankee Stadium lease, has signed a contract after two years of negotiations that will keep the Yankees in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for spring training through at least 1990. The Yankees said that if they signed a contract with nearby Coral Springs for a new minor league training complex, the parent club would stay in Fort Lauderdale through 1993.(AP)

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased $1.35 billion, to $271.96 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 129 institutional funds increased $107.70 million, to $70.71 billion. Assets of the 223 general purpose funds were up $690.60 million, to $86.32 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased $553.90 million, to $114.93 billion.

title: FGIC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: For the Record
description: Making Choices

title: Review/Circus; Big Apple Is Back With Daredevils And Slippery Stars
description: THE Big Apple Circus is single ring and convivial, the opposite of awesome. That is not to suggest that it lacks virtuosity. It has daredevil fliers and deft-handed jugglers, and even the animals could qualify as new vaudevillians. Other circuses, from the Cirque du Soleil of Canada to the Moscow Circus, have visited New York during the past year, and each has had something individual to offer. But the Big Apple is a homegrown favorite, a seasonal adjunct to New York's cultural life.

title: Student Probably Made Fake Bust at the Getty
description: A marble head of Achilles, once displayed at the J. Paul Getty Museum as 2,300-year-old antiquity, is probably the work of a 20th-century art student working from a plaster model, museum officials have said.

title: Jurors See Graphic Tape Of Nussbaum
description: A graphic and dramatic videotape of Hedda Nussbaum, showing a mass of bruises and injuries over her body, was shown to the jury in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg yesterday.

title: No Shaw Appeal Planned
description: General Manager Phil Esposito said yesterday that the Rangers would not appeal the National Hockey League's suspension of David Shaw, a defenseman.

title: Shamir Meets With Leaders of Far-Right Parties About a Coalition
description: A day after courting the religious parties, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met today with leaders of Israel's far-right parties and began listening to their demands that Palestinian demonstrators be shot, expelled or in extreme cases executed.

title: Thomaston Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
TEXAN HAS CHANCE TO SEEK NEW TRIAL
description: After 12 years behind bars for a murder he says he did not commit, Randall Dale Adams has been given a chance to win a new trial here.

title: Reviews/Ballet; Joffrey's Party Guests, Nasty and Nice
description: The Joffrey Ballet danced its way through three parties on Tuesday night at the City Center Theater. Each work on the program depicted a social occasion and the choreographic hosts were George Balanchine, William Forsythe and Gerald Arpino.

title: TV Weekend; Life Without Mother, Played for Laughs, on CBS
description: What does a husband do when his wife decides to run off and find herself, leaving him with a 15-year-old daughter? With luck, he'll find himself a weekly sitcom. ''Raising Miranda,'' created by Jane Anderson for Grant Tinker's GTG Entertainment, is having its premiere on CBS at 8:30 tomorrow evening.

title: Tunnel Diggers Fined
description: Contractors digging the railway tunnel under the English Channel will be fined a third time for working too slowly, Eurotunnel S.A., the British-French consortium running the project, said Wednesday. The amount was not disclosed. The contracting group, Trans Manche Link, has driven the tunnel only 2.2 miles from the English coast instead of the 3 miles expected by now.

title: About Real Estate; A Buyer's Market in Queens Co-ops
description: Supply has moved so far ahead of demand for moderately priced co-ops in converted garden apartment complexes in the Kew Gardens Hills area of Queens that many sponsors are now offering discounts and other incentives to encourage sales.

title: Yeshiva U. Student, 19, Stabbed in Bias Attack
description: A 19-year-old student at Yeshiva University in Washington Heights was stabbed in the leg and robbed of his jacket last night during an attack by a group of black youths that the police called bias related.

title: Dining Out Guide: Breakfast
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. American Festival Cafe

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HISPANIC DANCE

title: Federated Financial Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vanguard Shareholder Vote Asked
description: John C. Bogle, chairman of Vanguard Group Inc., requested yesterday that shareholders of the Liberty All-Star Fund be allowed to vote at the 1989 annual meeting on a proposal to convert the fund from closed-end to open-end status. The request to include the proposal in the investment company's proxy material was made to the fund's trustees, who earlier this year rejected the plan.

title: 3 F.A.A. Workers Die in Crash
description: A twin-engine jet carrying three Federal Aviation Administration employees apparently lost power and crashed in the Allegheny Mountains about 45 miles east of Pittsburg Wednesday, killing all aboard, officials said. Spokesmen for the Federal agency said the three had taken off from Allegheny County Airport and were making a routine check of an instrument landing system. The victims were identified as the pilot, James E. Burger, 64 years old, of Linwood, N.J.; the co-pilot, Richard M. Wadsworth, 46, of Ocean City, N.J., and a technician, Theodore L. Burdick, 56, of Egg Harbor Township, N.J.

title: APA Optics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Wells-Gardner Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions; Baseball
description: Agreed to terms with Dan Petry, pitcher, on a one-year contract.

title: Texas Air Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Scientific Software-Interomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After losses from discontinued operations of $53,000 for the quarter and $219,000 for the 9 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She said she preferred to live in a common apartment with us, but only if we redecorate the furniture to her taste.'' - Jerzy Urban, Polish Government spokesman,on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. [ 4:1. ]

title: US Health Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a writedown of $2.3 million of marketable securities for the quarter; the year was after a gain of $4,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: Reviews/Television; Two Programs Recall Kristallnacht
description: This week public television takes note of the 50th anniversary of Kristallnacht with two documentaries in which survivors and onlookers recall the 1938 spree of plate-glass breaking and worse in Hitler's Germany. Tomorrow night at 8 o'clock, Channel 31 presents ''More Than Broken Glass: Memories of Kristallnacht,'' and on Wednesday at 10, Channel 13 will carry ''Kristallnacht: The Journey from 1938 to 1988.''

title: Republic Automotive Parts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times; Making Cookies as a Wacky Search for Perfection
description: Midnight Sweets By Bette Pesetsky 206 pages. Atheneum, $17.95.

title: Reagan Signs Bill Ratifying U.N. Genocide Pact
description: Almost 40 years after the United Nations approved the Genocide Convention, President Reagan today signed legislation enabling the United States to become the 98th nation to ratify that international agreement.

title: Atlanta Editor Resigns After Dispute
description: Bill Kovach, editor of Atlanta's daily newspapers and a force behind an ambitious program to expand their news coverage and influence, resigned yesterday after a confrontation with his publisher.

title: EMPI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Political Memo; Yes, Late Voter Swings Do Happen, But Underdogs Can't Count on Them
description: Like many trailing candidates, Michael S. Dukakis not only is running against the polls but also is citing some of them to argue that he is enjoying a ''surge.''

title: Fahnestock Viner Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income All results are in U.S. funds.

title: Robert B. Semple, 78, Ex-Chemical Executive
description: Robert Baylor Semple, former chairman of the board of BASF Wyandotte Corporation, a multinational manufacturer of chemicals and video tapes, died of myeloma yesterday at his home in Grosse Point, Mich. He was 78 years old.

The Saddest Of News
description: Here are some news stories that weren't published during the Presidential campaign, but would have made a lot of difference if they had been. Though maybe not:

title: Multiple Choice Tests Are Still the Best We Have; Teachers Also Lose
description: To the Editor:

Telos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $89,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Vitriol Muted, but Jersey Race Is Still Bitter
description: Considering how rough the United States Senate race in this state has been, the messages the candidates are driving home in these waning days may seem a tad tame.

title: Legislative Honor Roll
description: Beyond contested races for the next New York Legislature there are incumbents who, though not seriously challenged, warrant special notice - as well as re-election next Tuesday.

title: Witness Says Numerous Injuries To Nussbaum Were Nearly Fatal
description: Hedda Nussbaum suffered so many traumatic injuries, including dozens of broken bones and countless lacerations, that she risked death from possible blood poisoning and a lack of medical treatment, a doctor told the jury yesterday in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg.

title: Fair Housing as Developers' Lever
description: With the passage almost three years ago of its fair housing law, New Jersey seemed finally to come to terms with the state Supreme Court's landmark rulings against exclusionary zoning in the town of Mount Laurel. Now, however, a decision by the agency created to administer the housing law presents a new complication.

title: A Job Fit for a Living Legend
description: There are times when fate and fame conspire to put even living legends to the test. These days Joe Franklin has been preparing for the interview of his life. This is, to be sure, a talk-show host who says he has done at least 100,000 interviews in the last four decades. But no guest has ever been as much of a challenge to Joe Franklin as Joe Franklin himself.

title: MBIA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Medalist Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,009,000 for the quarter and $846,000 for the 9 months, and a $2,852,000 loss from the disposal of discontinued operations for the both periods. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $479,000 and $982,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Pic 'N' Save Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Diagnostek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Before Going Into That Good Night
description: LEAD: Preoccupation with time has not been one of my problems. I have acquaintances, male and female, for whom reaching the age of 30 proved a disturbing experience; others have attained the age of 40 with a sudden, chilling sense of having lived more than half of their lives; a 50th birthday is a favorite occasion for neurotic behavior while, at 60, the threats of impotence and enforced retirement present rich opportunities for apprehension and gloom.

title: U.S. Says Nazi Suspect Was Guard for Army
description: A Minneapolis man accused by the Justice Department of taking part in the execution of thousands of Latvians in World War II worked for the United States Army in West Germany after the war, the Government has disclosed in court documents.

title: Peerless Tube Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Saving Unit's Sale in Jersey
description: First Nationwide Bank, the Ford Motor Company's savings and loan subsidiary, announced yesterday that it was acquiring a savings institution in New Jersey with $1.2 billion in assets. The move signals further inroads into the competitive New York-New Jersey region by First Nationwide, which is based in San Francisco. The Federal Savings and

title: KEY RATES
Lifetime Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $331,000 for the quarter and net of $145,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary gain of $181,000. The company said year-earlier results were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Isaac Mizrahi: Inspired Independence
description: Anticipation ran high as the fashion hordes inched their way into a blocklong SoHo loft for Isaac Mizrahi's spring show on Thursday night. Because his first formal show in April was a smash hit, everyone wanted to be there. It is difficult for a young designer to live up to such exalted expectations, but the 26-year-old Mr. Mizrahi did.

title: Copper-7 Ruling for Searle
description: G. D. Searle & Company, which was ordered to pay an $8.75 million judgment in September in a Copper-7 birth control device case, said today that it had won a pre-verdict ruling in a different lawsuit over the contraceptive.

title: Leo Sauvage, 75, Journalist, Dies
description: Leo Sauvage, drama critic of The New Leader and a former foreign correspondent for Le Figaro, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: Nets Let Victory Slip Away in Opener
description: For three quarters tonight, it appeared the Nets would go to sleep savoring an impressive opening-night victory. Then the Atlanta Hawks woke up.

title: York Minster Is Back to Life After '84 Fire
description: The south transept of York Minster, its 15th-century wooden arched ceiling and roof consumed by a fire four years ago, came back to life today.

title: Teen-Agers With Plans, Not Babies
description: Every year at least 33,000 New York City teen-agers - nearly half of whom are 17 or younger -get pregnant. If anyone were to ask them why, the majority would probably answer ''Why not?'' It isn't as if parenthood would stop them from finishing school, embarking on careers, buying their own homes. They hadn't planned on doing those things anyway. Most, in fact, have no plans at all.

title: Furs for Everywoman, Via Mass Marketing
description: Just 10 years ago, the average age of a woman getting her first fur coat was 50. Today it is 26, and today's woman is buying her own. With more women in the work force and with furs available in a wide range of prices, sales have grown to $1.8 billion in each of the last two years from $612.5 million in 1977.

title: Alba-Waldensian Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,300,963 and $1,447,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: THATCHER HONORS SOLIDARITY SHRINE
description: Thousands of Polish workers and their families cheered Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today as she joined Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, in laying roses at a Gdansk monument to shipyard workers killed by troops in 1970.

title: Southern Indiana Gas & Elecric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Intruders Into Computer Systems Still Hard to Prosecute
description: Despite new legal tools to combat computer fraud, prosecutors find it difficult to bring charges against those who intrude into multiple computer systems, as did the computer science student whose ''virus'' program temporarily disrupted a nationwide military data network this week.

title: Patents; Cigarette Puts Itself Out
description: An Indiana inventor won patent approval this week for a machine to make self-extinguishing cigarettes. The cigarette developed by Paul D. La Hue, a retired salesman and entrepreneur in Bloomington, Ind., contains a ''fire wall'' made of sodium silicate. When heat reaches that wall, at the cigarette's midpoint, the compound crystallizes and snuffs out the fire. The inventor's machine would be an add-on device for standard cigarette-rolling machines.

title: Jacor Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: POLAND IS BUYING 3 BOEING AIRLINERS FOR $220 MILLION
description: The Boeing Company received an order yesterday from the national airline of Poland, the first order for advanced American aircraft from an Eastern bloc country.

title: Review/Theater; The Mystery of Cuba, From Reality to Apparition
description: Two powerful men dominate the women who are the principal characters in ''A Burning Beach,'' Eduardo Machado's new play at the American Place Theater. The first is a wealthy and self-indulgent sugar plantation owner, recently deceased and continuing to be the center of his family's concern. The other imposing figure is the poet-patriot Jose Marti.

title: Hailed by Big Crowds, Dukakis Foresees an Upset
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis embarked on his final weekend of campaigning with combative defiance of the polls and pundits, urging a series of warm and cheering crowds to remember Harry S. Truman's 1948 upset.

title: Industrial Training Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes one-time after-tax expenses of $31,000 resulting from a move to new facilities. c-Includes a $21,000 received in the settlement of a contract dispute.

title: 'VIRUS' ELIMINATED, DEFENSE AIDES SAY
description: Defense Department officials said today that they had eliminated an electronic ''virus'' that played havoc with an unclassified military computer network on Wednesday. And, seeking to quell concern that crucial military computers are vulnerable to similar sabotage, they declared it was impossible for such a virus to penetrate classified computer networks that manage nuclear weapons systems and store vital secrets such as war plans.

title: Lonrho Holder raising Cash
description: The Australian businessman Alan Bond sold a $265 million stake in a leading British bank, prompting speculation that he is amassing a war chest for a takeover of the international Lonrho group. Mr. Bond, who currently holds about 20 percent of Lonrho, a conglomerate with mining, hotel and newspaper interests, said that he had sold a 14.9 percent stake in the London-based bank Standard Chartered P.L.C. for about $:150 million ($265 million). Mr. Bond raised another $:34 million ($60 million) Thursday by cashing in a 13.4 percent stake in the British investment management group M & G. A takeover bid for Lonrho would pit Mr. Bond against Roland (Tiny) Rowland, Lonrho's flamboyant chief executive who transformed the company from a sleepy African mining concern into a conglomerate with businesses represented in 80 countries. Mr. Rowland said Thursday that he had raised his personal stake in Lonrho by nearly 1 percent, to 15.6 percent.

title: Jet Makes Timely Return
description: Just in time, Alex Gordon is ready to rejoin the Jets, who face a potentially crazy-quilt offense against the Colts in Indianapolis on Sunday.

title: American Express Fee On 2 Cards to Rise $10
description: In a time of heated competition in the charge card business, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would raise the fee of its green and gold charge cards $10 a year.

title: Raphael Bronstein, 93, Noted Violin Teacher
description: Raphael Bronstein, who taught over a thousand violinists during a 65-year career in New York, died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday. He was 93 years old and had suffered a stroke Monday evening after an active day of teaching.

title: Patten Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After gains of $127,000 for the quarter and $330,000 for the 6 months, both from the extinguishment of debt.

title: COPING: With Dining Out on Holidays; Get detailed information from the restaurant, choose a time carefully and allow for extra traffic.
description: The big three holidays are coming up fast, and if you expect to celebrate in a restaurant or a hotel dining room it's time to make plans and reservations.

title: Reviews/Music; An Aural and Visual Trip In Search of Separate Roots
description: Working in the usually hard-edged medium of video, Kit Fitzgerald is a maverick sensibility. Everything she videotapes or creates on the spot, using a computerized keyboard known as a video paint box, glows with a mysterious inner radiance.

title: Harvard Concedes Victory of Clerical Workers Demanding a Union
description: In a big victory for organized labor, clerical workers at Harvard University today won their long battle to unionize when the school announced it would not seek to have the results of a union election overturned.

title: Walsh Makes Champion Bid
description: Walsh, Greenwood & Company said yesterday that it wanted to negotiate a $52-a-share cash offer for all the shares of Champion Products Inc. that it does not already own - a deal that would be worth about $163 million.

title: Fugitives Vanish Easily, Overworked Police Say
description: In many ways, Clovis Fearon matched the profile of New York City's typical criminal fugitive.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about a North Korean diplomat's address to the United Nations General Assembly misidentified a South Korean spokesman. He is Jong Hwan Suh.

title: Anchor Glass Sees Deficit in Quarter
description: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation said that it expects net losses for the fourth quarter and full year. The company attributed the expected losses to the costs of production line changes in the second half, the effects of price discounting and smaller-than-expected shipments.

title: Upper Peninsula Power Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: The latest 12 months included a gain of $1,415,000, or 97 cents a share, attributable to the sale of certain transmission facilities in December 1987.

title: An Abortion Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Disappointed by Soviet Move
description: President Reagan said today that he was disappointed by the Soviet decision to suspend the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan, and the State Department said the suspension was disturbing.

title: 42 Slain and 54 Hurt In 2 Attacks in Punjab
description: Sikh militants killed 42 people today and wounded 54 in a series of bombings at a crowded market and in an attack on a farm in Punjab State, the police and news reports said.

title: Polk Audio Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; Spaniard Tackles Neglected Rachmaninoff
description: Rachmaninoff's Fourth Piano Concerto is not one of his stronger works, much of the time sounding like a good imitation of the composer. The orchestra heaves and sighs in all the expected places and the soloist is confronted with writing for his instrument that is reminiscent of the great Third Concerto in its fiendish difficulty. At every point, it seems to promise more than it can deliver. Still, we know, if only from the evidence of famous recordings by Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli and Rachmaninoff himself, that the Fourth can be hair-raising under the right hands.

title: Wharf Resources LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' results included a $200,000 special charge. The 1987 figures are restated.

title: Coloradans to Vote on Drastic Tax Curb
description: Coloradans will decide Tuesday whether to strip the state and its local governments of the power to raise taxes without first receiving voter approval.

title: Saab Is Confident On Fighter Plane
description: The Swedish aircraft and auto company Saab-Scania A.B. said that it had overcome technical problems in the development of a new fighter plane and that a prototype would fly before the end of this year. The Swedish Defense Ministry had said Thursday it was considering scrapping the project, which is 18 months behind schedule, because of cost overruns.

title: More Mud Than Ever Slung Through the Mail
description: A pamphlet distributed in Michigan put Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana into a sort of political rogues' gallery with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran and Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama.

title: Johnson Controls Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in company's controls segment's method of accounting for long-term contracts from the completed contract method to the percentage-of-completion method.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AEG Aktiengesellschaft, Frankfurt, said it would acquire 39 percent of Siliconix Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a semiconductor and circuits company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Limit on Incomes Of Renters Is Raised
description: A bill raising the income limit for the Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption program, to $15,000 from $12,025, was signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Senate Race Is Numbing To Voters
description: This Fairfield County city is critical in the race for United States Senate, politicians and strategists say, a place where the people who live and work are ''average voters'' who, if nothing else, ''reflect what is happening out there.''

title: College Football; Wyoming Faces Its Moment of Truth
description: For teams that advance well into a season without a defeat, there is always a game that brings out the truth. Wyoming, which is 9-0, is going to play that game this afternoon.

title: Lilco Shareholders Strongly Endorse Accord to Sell Shoreham
description: Shareholders of the Long Island Lighting Company today overwhelmingly endorsed an agreement to sell the Shoreham nuclear power plant to New York State, and the utility set a deadline of Dec. 1 for the State Legislature to approve it.

title: Islanders Lose Fifth in a Row
description: Asked to evaluate his team, Bill Torrey, the Islanders' general manager, professed to be as uncertain as anyone else. In the wake of his team's worst game of the year, on Tuesday night against the Jets, he tried not to lose sight of his team's best moments. ''But,'' he asked with candor, ''which team are we?''

title: Arts Endowment Post For Susan Lubowsky
description: Susan Lubowsky, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, has been named director of the Visual Arts Program of the National Endowment for the Arts. The appointment was announced yesterday by Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, at a meeting of the National Council on the Arts.

title: L Line Service To Be Disrupted
description: Subway service on the L train, which runs from 14th Street and Eighth Avenue in Manhattan to the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, will be disrupted for the next two weekends, the Transit Authority reports.

title: George Folsey Dies; Film Maker Was 90
description: George Folsey, a cinematographer who was nominated for 13 Academy Awards, died at a hospital here Tuesday after a stroke and long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: Patents; A Computer Recognizes Some Words
description: Computers that talk have been built into everything from toys to elevators. Getting them to listen, however, has been much more difficult.

title: Jail Term in Jackson Threat
description: Tammy Williams, arrested along with her former husband for allegedly threatening to kill the Rev. Jesse Jackson, was sentenced today to 20 months in prison. The 27-year-old woman had pleaded guilty to possessing an automatic rifle, an illegal weapon. Her former husband, Londell Williams, 30, pleaded guilty in August to threatening to kill Mr. Jackson last May, and was sentenced earlier this week to two years in prison.

title: Spiegel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' results restated to reflect an accounting change. Revenue represents sales and other revenue.

title: Sabena Air Fined
description: The European Community's executive commission is fining Belgium's national airline Sabena 100,000 European Currency Units ($117,000) for barring a rival from its computer reservation system, a European Community spokesman said. London European Airways P.L.C. had complained that Sabena denied it access to the system because it saw the smaller company's lower fares from Brussels as a threat to Sabena business.

title: Northwestern Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giant Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter was adversely affected by unrealized losses on equity securities of $1,986,000 and equity in losses of affiliates of $3,868,000 with no associated tax benefits.

title: INVESTORS AWAIT A RASH OF DEFAULTS
description: As many on Wall Street are busy taking companies private using mountains of borrowed money, another portion of the investment community is quietly preparing to exploit what they believe will be corporate America's day of reckoning. They are amassing hundreds of millions of dollars to invest in good companies that may be forced into bankruptcy by excessive debt.

title: INDIAN TROOPS END COUP IN MALDIVES
description: Indian troops quickly overcame hundreds of purported mercenaries and rebels in the Indian Ocean island republic of the Maldives early today and helped its President reassert power, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said.

title: Singapore Journal; In the Global Village, Seeking an Exit
description: After years of emphasis on English as the common language in this multiracial, technocratic city-state, its leaders are voicing increasing anxiety about Westernization that seems to reflect a deeper ambivalence about the price of success and what it might mean to be Singaporean.

title: For Yankees, Time for Plan B
description: The Yankees' effort to pursue a first-class relief pitcher was stalled yesterday, hours before the midnight deadline for declaring free agency, when Steve Bedrosian, the relief pitcher they coveted most, reached agreement on a three-year contract with the Philadelphia Phillies. The contract is worth $4.35 million.

title: Bridge
description: The American women's team unexpectedly lost in the quarterfinal of the World Team Olympiad in Venice last month after playing well in the qualifying stage.

title: For Quotable Expert on Political Messages, Phone Never Stops Ringing
description: Since the Presidential nominating conventions this summer, Kathleen Hall Jamieson has been quoted more than 120 times in newspaper, magazine and news agency reports. She has lost count of the number of interviews she has done for radio and television.

title: Sale of British Printing Corp. Is Planned
description: Robert Maxwell, the flamboyant British entrepreneur, today announced plans to sell off British printing operations worth hundreds of millions of dollars, just hours after winning control of Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publisher.

Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a review of the movie ''They Live'' misidentified an actor featured in the film. He was Roddy Piper, not Keith David.

title: Reynolds & Reynolds Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest quarter and year figures include a gain of 58 cents a share resulting principally from the sale of the company's tax processing unit.

title: Jockey Fined
description: The Aqueduct stewards fined William Fox Jr., one of the replacement jockeys, $500 yesterday for his part in an altercation with one of the regular jockeys, Chris Antley, after Thursday's second race at Aqueduct. The fine was assessed after a hearing.

title: Arab Newspaper Prints P.L.O. Independence Plan
description: An Arabic-language newspaper today published what it said was a Palestinian ''declaration of independence'' that will be issued by the Palestine Liberation Organization this month.

description: President Reagan signed legislation Thursday to give consumers more and faster information about the costs of credit cards.

title: The Race for Congress; In Reagan's Home District, a Referendum of Sorts
description: Probably no race for Congress carries more symbolism than the one being fought house to house, mailbox to mailbox, in the rolling avocado ranchland and suburban reaches of Santa Barbara and Ventura Counties on California's lush central coast.

description: Campaigning for Canada's general election on Nov. 21 has taken on an uncharacteristically bitter edge, with the Government and the two opposition parties accusing each other of lies and distortions about the free-trade agreement with the United States.

description: A judge today dismissed a misdemeanor charge against a retired Air Force colonel whose prototype anti-tank gun blew up a service station here in August 1986.

title: Patents; Pulling Heat and Smoke From Burning Building
description: James W. O'Donnell, a Chicago firefighter for the last 34 years, has invented a device to suck heat and smoke from a burning building.

description: Because of the New York City Marathon, these streets will be closed to traffic in Manhattan tomorrow: First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge, Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 102d Street and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Broadway. In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, the Madison Avenue Bridge and the Verrazano Narrows Bridge will be closed.

Tylan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $121,000, or 6 cents a share, from the company's joint venture in Japan, which was sold in December 1987.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52. 1. This woman, thought to be usually reclusive, stepped into the spotlight. Who is she, what did she do and why was her assistance necessary? 2. At the Energy Department, engineers grimly joke that some of what they privately call ''national sacrifice zones'' may turn out to be larger than many of the 39 national parks. What are ''national sacrifice zones'' and what is at issue? 3. Rube Goldberg would have loved the intricate way in which the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will acquire 190 new subway cars. How will it be done? 4. On Nov. 9 lights will burn throughout the night in virtually all of the nation's 3,500 synagogues. What is the reason? 5. Using powerful supercomputers, scientists are able solve the once insoluble. What revolutionary capability does the new technology have that has simplified problem solving? 6. Leaders of the Solidarity trade union said they would not strike to protest the Polish Government's plan to close the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, the movement's birthplace. What is their reason for refraining? 7. Finally, women like the one above are having their turn at bat. Explain. 8. Although the Bush campaign disavowed an anti-Dukakis commercial that played on fears of black criminals, the commercial appeared nationally on cable television for 28 days, as scheduled. What were the circumstances? 9. The future of men's professional tennis was thrown into disarray. What happened? 10. The inconclusive results of the Israeli election may lead to dramatic changes in the country's domestic policies. Why? 11. Experts called it the largest assault ever on the nation's computer networks. What happened?

title: Polymeric Resources Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
Subject of Allegiance
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Calumnies: A Dangerous Game
description: ''Have you no sense of decency, sir? At long last, have you left no sense of decency?''

title: John J. Lindsay, Journalist, 67
description: John Joseph Lindsay, the Senate reporter for Newsweek magazine, died of cancer Wednesday at his home here. He was 67 years old.

title: Soviets Suspend Withdrawal Of Troops From Afghanistan
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was suspending the withdrawal of its troops from Afghanistan and was supplying the Afghan Army with more powerful weapons because of stepped-up military activity by guerrilla forces.

title: Soviet Scientist Faults Space Bureaucrats
description: A leading Soviet space scientist, in a frank and critical speech, has warned that the Soviet space program is in danger of losing its edge because the scientific establishment still values bureaucratic titles over scientific expertise.

title: Hawaii Developer Plans Land Sale
description: Alexander & Baldwin Inc. said it was holding negotiations to sell about 2.6 percent of its Hawaiian land holdings to two separate, unidentified buyers for about $245 million. The proposed sales include the Honolulu-based company's 1,500-acre holdings in a Maui resort, where quarter-acre home lots sell for $120,000 each, as well as 1,000 undeveloped acres in central Maui.

title: On the Front Lines in Battling Electronic Invader
description: For Stevan Milunovic, the director of information systems at SRI International, Thursday began with warning telephone calls from computer experts at the University of California at Berkeley and San Diego. A crippling software ''virus'' had infiltrated their systems, a destructive bug to which SRI was vulnerable.

title: Tennis
description: U.S. Wins Wightman Cup: Lori McNeil rallied to win her singles match, then teamed with Betsy Nagelsen to win in doubles last night as the United States retained the Wightman Cup in London by taking an unbeatable 4-0 lead over Britain in the four-of-seven-match series. McNeil overcame Sara Gomer, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, to give the Americans a 3-0 lead, then teamed with Nagelsen to beat Gomer and Julie Salmon, 6-3, 6-2, to give the Americans their 50th Cup victory in 60 meetings. Britain has not won since 1978.(AP) McEnroe Advances: John McEnroe of the United States, Amos Mansdorf of Israel and Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union scored straight-set victories yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $1 million European Community championship in Antwerp, Belgium. But Tim Mayotte of the United States, who was seeded second, lost his quarterfinal match to Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-1, 6-4. McEnroe overwhelmed Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-2, 6-1; Chesnokov swept past Ricki Osterthun of West Germany, 6-3, 6-1, and Mansdorf dominated Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 6-2, 6-4.(AP) American Rallies for Victory: Jim Courier, an 18-year-old from Dade City, Fla., saved two match points in a decisive third-set tie breaker yesterday and edged Paolo Cane of Italy to move into the semifinals of the $642,500 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championship. Courier came from behind to win, 4-6, 6-2, 7-6, in his first indoor tournament as a professional. He won the tie breaker by 8-6 after trailing by 4-6. Dan Goldie, a former all-American at Stanford, beat Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 7-6, in another quarterfinal. Courier staved off both match points with his forehand. He passed Cane with a sharp cross-court shot for 5-6, then hit a hard forehand placement to level at 6-all. Courier aced Cane to go to match point at 7-6 and then whipped a backhand down the line to clinch the match.(AP) Navratilova Beats Sukova: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova defeated fifth-seeded Helena Sukova, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $300,000 New England Virginia Slims tournament in Worcester, Mass. Third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina beat Helen Kelesi of Canada, 7-5, 6-4. Sixth-seeded Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union eliminated Stephanie Rehe of the United States, 7-5, 6-2.(AP) Golf Two-Stroke Lead for Cochran: Russ Cochran, a left-hander who has yet to win in six seasons on the PGA Tour, shot another seven-under-par 65 yesterday and took a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the $600,000 Tucson Open in Arizona. Cochran also shot a 65 Thursday. David Frost was second at 132 after his second 66 on the TPC course at StarPass. Hale Irwin had a 65, but remained four strokes back at 134.(AP) N.H.L. Flyers 4, Red Wings 3: Murray Craven scored on a breakaway with 13 seconds remaining in the third period last night as visiting Philadelphia ended a losing streak at three games. Detroit had tied the game with 46 seconds remaining when Steve Yzerman scored his third goal of the game. Craven took a stick to his face as he shot the puck and suffered a cut. He was led off the ice for treatment. Miroslav Frycer was assessed a match penalty on the play, which carries an automatic suspension pending a hearing by the National Hockey League. Also scoring for the Flyers were Scott Mellanby, Terry Carkner and Brian Propp.(AP)

Digital and A.T.&T. have met at A.T.&T.'s request, Kenneth Olsen told reporters after his company's annual meeting Thursday, but Digital made it clear before the talks that it would not discuss merging with the telecommunications giant. A.T.&T. never made a merger proposal, Mr. Olsen said.

The letter bomb of the computer age is a program that clogs up or damages recipient computers. This week, one closed down thousands of computers at universities and Government laboratories from coast to coast. A hacker's pastime has become a peril.

Guidepost; Shopping by Mail
description: Last year, 88 million Americans shopped by phone or mail from the 8,000 mail-order catalogues in the United States. In the holiday season, it's an easy way to send gifts. If you are shopping by catalogue, it's wise to use a credit card. It gives you a separate record of your purchase and, if a dispute arises, the credit-card company won't require you to pay until the matter is settled. Many companies have toll-free numbers for ordering or answering questions; some will send a free catalogue if you ask. The A.T.& T. toll-free information service or a toll-free directory can provide company numbers. Here is some advice for catalogue shoppers: $ PROCESS TIPS Ordering Procedures will be listed on order forms. Keep your own record of when you ordered and how you paid. Shipping Most orders should arrive within 30 days. Rush shipments can often be made in one or two days, for an extra fee. Delays The Federal Trade Commission requires the company to inform you of delays. You can cancel or wait. Your payment should not be processed until shipment. Returns In case of damage, the company is required to pay return costs; if you send the item back because you don't like it, you may have to pay for shipping. Help If you paid by credit card, the card company will help you if the catalogue company ignores your complaints. The Direct Marketing Association will also help if you send a record of the transaction and explanation of the problem. Source: Direct Marketing Association, 6 East 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10017

title: Maxwell Reassurance on Macmillan

But one runner, in a field of more than 23,000, will not only be allowed to take a shortcut, he will be welcomed.

First of all, that syrupy anthem belongs to the Kentucky Derby, not to the Breeders' Cup. More important, the recitation of that line would open about 50,000 waterlogged horseplayers to charges of false advertising.

The killing took place about 7:30 P.M. in front of 254 West 42d Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. The victim, who was not identified, died of head wounds at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. His assailant, who was described as a young black man, fled from the area, the police said.

description: The unemployment rate in New York and New Jersey showed little change in October, but quarterly unemployment rates showed marked improvement over last year, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

description: Poland has adopted a law allowing companies to issue bonds, and a capital market in this Communist country will probably result. The law is intended to attract private savings into Polish industry, the official P.A.P. press agency said this week.

title: Kuwait-B.P. Tie
description: The Kuwait Investment Office, which has been ordered by Britain to reduce its 21.6 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company within a year, has asked for five years in which to divest itself of its stake, the Office of Fair Trading said. Britain last month ordered the Kuwaiti agency, the nation's London-based overseas investment arm, to cut its stake in B.P., worth about $:3 billion ($5.3 billion), to 9.9 percent within a year. Asked about the status of talks on extending the deadline for the divestment, an Office of Fair Trading spokeswoman said negotiations on the matter were continuing.

Lloyd of Pittsburgh, to Con Papamahail, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Apostolos Papamahail of Adelaide, Australia, took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Judith Tattersall Baumer performed the ceremony.

description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company agreed today to sell one of Boston's oldest and most prestigious hotels, the Copley Plaza, to a local businessman for $56 million.

description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve, viewing evidence that the nation's economic growth was slowing, decided at their September meeting to leave interest rates unchanged, according to minutes of the session released today.

title: Early Dollar Rally Fades As Bearish Mood Prevails
description: The dollar rallied sharply yesterday morning on better-than-expected employment data but eased in the afternoon as the bearish tone of the last several weeks gained the upper hand.

title: No Pallone Indictment
description: Dave Pallone, the National League umpire who took a leave of absence in September because his name had been linked to a criminal case in Ballston Spa, N.Y., is not expected to face charges there, according to the Saratoga County District Attorney. ''There is no indictment pending or contemplated against an individual by that name,'' David A. Wait said when asked if Pallone would be charged in the case. Pallone will talk with National League officials about returning to his baseball job, according to his attorney, E. Stewart Jones.(AP)

title: Study Says Immigration Law Is Leading to Discrimination
description: Employers in New York City and several nearby counties, fearful of penalties under the new Federal immigration law, are engaging in widespread discrimination against legalized aliens and American citizens who appear foreign, a Cuomo administration task force has found.

The girl, Rochell Porter, was shot once in the left cheek Wednesday with a .25-caliber pistol in the hands of her mother, Ulene Porter, 37, and died at a hospital shortly afterward, the police said.

title: Geoffrey Beene: Powers of Invention
description: Geoffrey Beene brought the week of spring fashion openings in New York to a triumphant close yesterday with a brilliant collection that solidified his position as a modern master of design. The clothes towered over most collections here and abroad. Each outfit was individually and freshly conceived; nothing was derivative, except perhaps for some echoes from earlier Beene collections.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Think About the Jockeys' Strike?
description: New York's jockeys were merely seeking to be treated like jockeys everywhere. The intransigence of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association hurt the sport, already in dire financial straits, by offering a second-rate product to fans who have a plethora of other options from which to choose. CHARLIE BUTTREY East Thetford, Vt.

title: Youth Hunts Draw Scorn and Praise
description: LEAD: Twelve-year-old Brian Blumenthal put his shotgun in the trunk of his father's car and took out his yo-yo. Neither he nor his father took any game last Saturday.

description: LEAD: MARILYN'S DAUGHTER. By John Rechy. (Carroll & Graf, $18.95.)
