A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BERNARD SHAW: Volume One, 1856-1898: The Search for Love, by Michael Holroyd. (Random House, $24.95.) The fruit of 15 years' work, this first of three volumes of the authorized biography offers a coherent account of Victorian intellectual life and the work and resolve that bore the Irish wizard toward his place in it. LETTERS AND DRAWINGS OF BRUNO SCHULZ: With Selected Prose, edited by Jerzy Ficowski. (Harper & Row, $25.) Mr. Ficowski, a dedicated literary detective, has worked since 1947 to gather these scraps and remnants of the great Polish visionary novelist and literary theorist murdered by the Gestapo in 1942. FIRESTORM, by William Coyle. (Morrow, $18.95.) A solidly moral, even penitential pseudonymous novel about evil and the dissent from evil, centered on the bombing of Dresden in 1945 and an R.A.F. crewman who comes to believe what he is doing is wrong. THE COMING TRIUMPH OF THE FREE WORLD, by Rick DeMarinis. (Viking, $16.95.) Original, seductive, deeply comic short stories about people who are mostly lower middle class, marginal and hanging on - in other words, modern heroes. GREY IS THE COLOR OF HOPE, by Irina Ratushinskaya. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Soviet poet's prison memoir, distinctly feminine in tone, idyllic and exultant, registering endurance through love, example, faith and the bonding of a community of female inmates. THE VIENNESE: Splendor, Twilight, and Exile, by Paul Hofmann. (Anchor/Doubleday, $22.50.) A comprehensive, informative and lively introduction to a paradoxical city, head of a lost empire, home of pastry and waltzes, xenophobia and anti-Semitism. WHEAT THAT SPRINGETH GREEN, by J. F. Powers. (Knopf, $18.95.) The spiritual life, down on the ground where it is lived, in this dignified, generous, faultlessly colloquial and always hilarious comedy of and about Joe Hackett, a suburban priest.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on page 1 last Sunday with an article about country clubs described the setting incorrectly. The photograph showed a golfer at the New Canaan Country Club playing on a practice hole - not, of course, the 19th hole.

title: Marathon; Samuelson vs. Waitz: A Majestic Showdown
description: As the early morning gray turned to sunshine on that historic Sunday morning in Los Angeles more than four years ago, the athletic careers of two women, about a minute and a half apart, were joined forever.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Singing and Signing
description: LEAD: Singin' 'n' Signin,' '' a musical revue mounted by Westco, a White Plains-based professional theater company. The New York School for the Deaf is also in that city.

title: LOUISE WALES TO WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gwynne Wales of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Louise Carrie Wales to William Bennet Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus T. Reynolds of New York.

title: 5 Black Police Officers Sue, Alleging Unfairness in Dallas
description: Five black police officers have filed a lawsuit alleging that the Dallas Police Department has discriminated against blacks in hiring, discipline and promotions.

title: Stamps; The Burning of Books, the Shattering of Glass, the War
description: THE entry in Collier's Encyclopedia begins:

title: Chess; On Giving Heroic Defenders the Credit They Deserve
description: IT is hard to see the defender as a hero, even when he is. While the attacker can illuminate his achievement with one scintillating sacrifice that leaves the kibitzers breathless, the defender must intrepidly persist in turning back all his opponent's thrusts, move after move. Consequently, his achievement is spread out and does not often issue in one dramatic moment.

title: Something More Than Calculus
description: WHO WON the game?'' shouts the stocky teacher stalking his classroom in an effort to arouse teen-age enthusiasm. It is the morning after the second game of the World Series and the tenth-graders in East Los Angeles answer Jaime Escalante with a refrain extolling the hometown team: ''Dodgers! Dodgers!'' Like the shrewd manager who goads his underdog players to a championship, Mr. Escalante deftly transforms his class's excitement into sharp focus on a math lesson.

title: Neighborly Ambiance in Stamford
description: WHAT started in Norwalk as a small Mom and Pop restaurant known as Maria's Trattoria has become a family cottage industry. Apulia in South Norwalk was next, to be followed by the Columbus Park Trattoria in Stamford.

title:
GARDENING;
Forced Bulbs: An Early Splash of Color
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to indoor blooms, bulbs are just about the easiest to grow. Although some require a greenhouse or well-lighted sun room, others will do well on a table near a sunny window.

title: TREVOR MAHONY WED TO WILLIAM WALSH 3D
description: At St. Ignatius of Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass., Trevor Mahony, the daughter of Frederick J. Mahony Jr. of New York and Chestnut Hill and Fredericka O'Connell of Toronto, was married yesterday to William E. Walsh 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh Jr. of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Vincent O'Keefe performed the ceremony.

title: Mandating Access for the Handicapped
description: A little more than a year ago, the New York City Council approved what then seemed a modest proposal. It said that in a city that so glorifies building, architecture should not discriminate against disabled people. To implement that belief, the Council passed Local Law 58 - the handicapped-access law.

title: Debuts; Emigre Cellist From Russia, a Rostropovich Pupil
description: Yosif Feigelson

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Oct. 22 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $250,000 41 Fifth Avenue (11th St.) 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; manned elevator, two exposures; maintenance $963, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: H.H. Kleigerman Associates) TriBeCa $445,000 69 Murray Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,900-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; study, 2 storage rooms; maintenance $857, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Upper East Side $246,500 444 East 86th Street (Parker 86) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, terrace; maintenance $841, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: Arthur P. Brooks Realty) Upper West Side $515,000 101 West 79th Street (Park Belvedere) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,150-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, remodeled kitchen, Central Park view; common charge $553, taxes $300 (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Washington Heights$195,000 800 Riverside Drive (Grinnell) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, Hudson River view; maintenance $562, 12% tax-deductible (Broker: Simone Song Properties) BRONX Allerton Area $164,000 3037 Bronxwood Avenue 2-family, semi-attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths in primary unit; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in other; large kitchen in each; 23- by 60-ft. lot; taxes $1,271 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Riverdale $187,000 3755 Henry Hudson Parkway (Imperial) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer, den, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $672, includes gas heat, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) BROOKLYN Bay Ridge $312,500 361 96th Street 2-family, semi-attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each; full basement, 2-car garage, 23- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,440 (Broker: McPyel Associates) Boerum Hill $327,500 214 Wyckoff Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, 3-story, brick rowhouse; dining room, large kitchen, 2 marble fireplaces, wide-plank floors, original moldings and details, 18- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $909 (Broker: Carl F. Peek) Park Slope $159,800 221 8th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 980-sq.-ft. prewar co-op in a limestone building; dining room, windowed kitchen, new kitchen appliances; maintenance $400, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Aguayo & Knox) QUEENS Bayside $330,000 57-41 223d Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, colonial; dining room, large kitchen, family room, attached, 1-car garage, 28- by 92-ft. lot; taxes $2,280 (Broker: Happy Homes Realty) Jamaica Hills $265,000 85-21 167th Street 5-bedroom, 4-bath, single-family detached colonial; dining room, basement, garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) STATEN ISLAND Dongan Hills$188,000 185 Cotter Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached colonial; dining area, large kitchen, full basement, 30- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency) West Brighton $225,000 261 Bement Avenue 2-family, detached Victorian; 3 bedrooms in primary unit; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, large kitchen, stained-glass windows in both; separate heating, 1-car garage, 50- by 120-ft. lot; taxes $1,332 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: Jury Is Looking Into Iran-Contra Testimony
description: A newly seated Federal grand jury is investigating whether any participant in the Iran-contra affair committed perjury in testimony to a Congressional panel last year or in appearances before the grand jury that indicted them, a source familiar with the matter said today.

title: PSYCHIATRY TALKS PLANNED IN RUSSIA
description: American and Soviet negotiators in Moscow will try to work out the ground rules next week for a planned visit by American psychiatrists to Soviet mental hospitals, American specialists said today.

title: In Pakistan's Election Campaign, Bhuttos Are the Polemical Front-Runners
description: In whistle-stop tours, street-corner rallies and impassioned speeches that make up in fury what they lack in substance, the campaign for national elections has suddenly picked up momentum in Pakistan.

title: Thoughts Now TurningTo More Hearty Fare
description: INDIAN summer is now waning. It has become cold-weather time. Thoughts of tomato and mozzarella salads, chicken on the grill and fresh plum tarts are best tucked away. The appetite is whetted by hearty fare, earthy mushrooms, rich squashes and nuts.

title: TURMOIL IN THE LABS
description: I was disappointed in William J. Broad's article, ''Beyond the Bomb: Turmoil in the Labs'' (Oct. 9). Los Alamos has served this nation with pride and distinction, and I feel compelled to offer a more accurate picture of the situation at the weapons laboratories.

title: Public Sculpture In Glen Cove
description: The article ''Art and Identity in Glen Cove'' [ Oct. 23 ] may serve as a step toward more public discussion of the very important proposal for a public sculpture in Glen Cove, and follows a letter which I wrote in which I raised questions about the site of the project and the composition of the committee supervising it.

title: AN ERA TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON SLEPT HERE Colonial Revivals and American Culture 1876-1986. By Karal Ann Marling. Illustrated. 453 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $39.95.

title: TURMOIL IN THE LABS
description: Edward Teller, Lowell Wood and others have done a disservice to their colleagues and the cause of science by treating scientific research as a commodity to be bought by Congress and sold to the public. Their effort to sell the Strategic Defense Initiative by making exaggerated claims for its effectiveness is only one example of a growing tendency to oversell scientific proposals through marketing techniques that are more appropriate to the sale of toothpaste. We should be grateful to Ray E. Kidder and Roy D. Woodruff for their courage to tell the truth in spite of the negative impact on their careers. DAVID H. AUSTON New York, N.Y.

title: Bird Watching
description: To the Editor: As a fellow birder, I'd like to supplement the information that you provided R.L.L. (Q & A, Aug. 28).

title: Consolidation in Greenwich: A 285-Slip Marina Nears Final Approval
description: By the numbers, Cos Cob Marina will not bring much of a change to the Mianus River in Connecticut. Several marinas with a total of 285 boat slips will become one marina with 285 boat slips and a jumble of 10 wharf buildings will become two. Still, it has taken the developers two years and two project revisions to get to this stage of approval from the Town of Greenwich. Executive approval was given Wednesday for demolition and construction of a bulkhead. Final approval is expected Nov. 22.

title: Jersey Shore Visitors Down 22% From 1987
description: About 6.7 million people visited the Jersey Shore over the summer, a 22 percent drop from 1987, a study released today by the State Division of Travel and Tourism said.

title: DEBORAH K. HEINEMAN WEDS RALPH SCAGLIONE
description: Deborah Kay Heineman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Heineman Jr. of New York and Clayton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ralph Scaglione, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Scaglione of Spring Valley, N.Y., and Castel Frentano, Italy. The Rev. John O. Mellin performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Growing Old: At Times the Best of Times
description: ''IT'S going to be a boring evening,'' I said quietly to my husband as we came aboard the SS Stuyvesant. We had been invited on a private cruise around Manhattan, a dinner-dance benefit for a local geriatric center's 100th anniversary. We had been told that many members of the center would be there. A party full of old people was not our idea of fun, but we couldn't say no to our friend, a member of the center's board, and chairman of its centennial celebration.

title:
DINING OUT;
Lusty Italian Cuisine in Bucks County
description: LEAD: PERCHED on scenic Route 32 south of New Hope, Pa., is a little roadhouse with the quaint name of Olive. Spruced up with glass walls in one of the two cozy dining rooms and a chrysanthemum-bordered patio out front, the restaurant was opened in July by George Barlow, a genial young man who also serves as the host.

title: Theater Sound Comes Home
description: The widespread use of stereo sound in the more advanced kind of video equipment has led to a surprising discovery: When the sound is more spacious - thanks to the stereo effect - the picture seems bigger.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
CHATHAM
description: LEAD: Main Street, the ribbon of blacktop that winds through Chatham, passes a huddle of pre-Revolutionary buildings, 19th-century structures and modern supermarkets, a potpourri of architectural styles that evokes a feeling of small-town America.

title: NAVY FACES CLAIM FROM SHIPBUILDER
description: A large shipbuilding company is preparing to submit a claim against the Navy for substantial excess costs that arms industry executives, military consultants and Reagan Administration and Congressional officials say is expected to be followed by a wave of such claims.

title: A Freelancer's Lot Is Filled With Allegros
description: ''You have to be ready for anything,'' says the trumpeter Neil Balm. ''As a freelancer, you play chamber music, rock-and-roll, a Broadway show, you name it. It keeps you alive musically. Keeps you on your toes.''

title: BANKS COZYING UP TO THE STUDENT
description: Bank freebies for college students: telephones, subway maps and posters - all with no minimum monthly balance. Such inducements represent a strategy on the part of a growing number of banks nationwide to establish a relationship with students that outlives their school years.

title: California's Tranquil Ojai Valley
description: At the summit of a windswept ridge above the Ojai Valley in Southern California stands a concrete bench overlooking a narrow valley flanked by towering, barren mountains. No marker or sign alerts the casual observer, but the view inspired a page in motion picture history half a century ago, for it was from this vantage that Frank Capra filmed scenes of mythical Shangri-La for his 1937 classic ''Lost Horizon.''

title: Kurdish Refugees Are Moved To Concrete Winter Houses
description: About 8,000 Iraqi Kurdish refugees have been moved to concrete houses for the winter in the remote eastern province of Mus, officials said today.

title: Standing Up For Their Beliefs: Vigil Against Nuclear Arms
description: JUST before 11 A.M. last Saturday, cars began drawing alongside of the grassy triangle of the Salisbury Green. Robert Steck, one of the first to arrive, greeted Caroline Pope, and helped her unfurl a banner. Within a few minutes, Winston Corbett had arrived, carrying a rolled American flag. By a few minutes after 11, the line had formed, and the banner was unfurled. It read: ''We Stand for Nuclear Disarmament.''

title:
ART;
Recognizing Women Artists
description: LEAD: IN 1889, when the organization now known as the National Association of Women Artists was founded in New York, the National Academy of Design's annual exhibition featured work by 362 artists, of whom only 46 were female. In spite of increasing opportunities for serious art training and that individual female painters and sculptors had achieved renown, women as a group were not considered as gifted or as worthy of recognition as their male counterparts.

title: LOUISE B. YOUNG WEDS A. M. DYE
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Louise Braden Young, the daughter of Mrs. William Beekman Young of Greenwich, and the late Mr. Young, was married yesterday to Alexander McCandless Dye, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Merl Dye of North Platte, Neb. The Rev. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: BILLIE SHEPARD IS WED
description: Billie Shepard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irvin E. Pearlstein of Phoenix, and Andrew J. Preston Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston of Kinnelon, N.J., were married yesterday at the Camelback Inn Resort in Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Dr. G. Wesley L. Ford, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony. The bride, a stage and television actress, was previously married and divorced. Her husband is president of Electronic Mail Corporation of America, an international telecommunications concern in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Radon Testing: Where It's Needed
description: The Oct. 9 article entitled ''State Is Consulted on Radon Program'' makes the point that New Jersey was among the first of the states to deal with community radon problems.

title: MOTHER'S WORK
description: I personally detest the term housewife, and I shudder at the thought of my son checking with the domestic engineer before going to a friend's house to play (On Language: ''Mother's Work,'' by William Safire, Oct. 2). I go with mother - not at-home mother, not full-time mother - just plain mother.

title: WESTCHESTER FOLLOW-UP
description: LEAD: Municipalities Asked To Bid on Parking Aid NEW rules were announced last week for those seeking parking spaces at railroad stations, but they apply to communities not commuters.

title: Next Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: Repllies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: A Question of Ethics at the Polls is Resolved in the Wee Hours
description: When I served as an election inspector for a Presidential election some years ago, my exhausted colleagues and I were sorely tempted to report innacurate tallies.

title: Waging Wouk's 'War and Remembrance'
description: Dan Curtis sprawls on a couch in Dubbing Room 7, chewing on his finger and endlessly watching Rudolf Hoess, the commandant of Auschwitz, prepare for Heinrich Himmler's inspection of his concentration camp. That inspection will include a ''Special Action,'' staged to show Herr Himmler how efficiently Commander Hoess has learned to kill Jews. In order not to spoil Himmler's appetite, the gassing of a newly arrived trainload of Dutch Jews will take place after lunch.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE INDIA FAN. By Victoria Holt. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The best-selling romantic suspense writer Victoria Holt could turn the most resolute boob tuber into a book lover with her latest offering, ''The India Fan.'' Set in England, France and India during the Victorian period, it's the story of Drusilla Delany, a rector's daughter who lives in the shadow of the great Framling manor and finds her life inextricably bound up with the lives of the Framling family.

title: Fighter Helping Children
description: LEAD: IT isn't often that Bobby Czyz, the boxer, drops his guard and takes a punch from an opponent. The New Jersey native, who lives in Wanaque, has compiled a 33-3 record, which includes 23 knockouts, in an eight-year ring career.

title: 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH TAKES AIM AT MEDICINE
description: The budget of the Reagan Administration's controversial Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars'' program, contains money mostly dedicated for missiles. But it also contains money for laser medical research.

title: Ruggers Preparing for Playoff
description: JUST two years ago, the future of Westchester's only amateur Rugby team for adults looked grim. It was losing more games than it won, it lost its playing field in White Plains and was demoted to the second division of the New York Metropolitan Rugby League Conference.

title: MEMO TO THE NEXT PRESIDENT
description: One hopes Henry Kaufman's wise prescription is heeded by the next President and Congress (''Memo to the Next President,'' Oct. 9). He calls for a slow, rather than a sudden, precipitous, reduction of the deficits. He correctly stresses the danger of pushing the economy down when it already might be headed into a recession. A deep recession would increase the Federal deficit, provide only temporary relief on the trade front (by reducing imports during the recession) and exact large human and economic costs.

title: Bush and Dukakis Fight On, With Gap Closing a Bit; SCRAPPY DEMOCRAT BUOYED BY CROWDS
description: Michael S. Dukakis rode a wave of cheering crowds across the Middle West and South Texas today, trying to cloak his underdog campaign in the legacy of John F. Kennedy and Harry S. Truman and assailing his Republican opponents as the tribunes of privilege.

title: SALLY SIMS IS MARRIED TO SAMUEL STOKES
description: Sally Ruth Sims, a daughter of Mrs. Eugene K. Sims of Merion Station, Pa., and the late Mr. Sims, was married yesterday to Samuel Newton Stokes, a son of Isaac N. P. Stokes of Jericho, Vt., and the late Barbara Hoyt Stokes. The Rev. Daniel L. Hatch, a cousin of the bridegroom and a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Newton White mansion in Mitchellville, Md.

title: HONG KONG
description: With its bustling harbor, sleek glass skyscrapers and green, rolling hills, Hong Kong is a dramatic sight any time of the year, but in the late autumn and early winter it is at its most appealing. The hot, humid weather has dissipated and the days are sunny, crisp and clear, perfect for walking.

title: U.N. TEAM ANGERS SOME IN NAMIBIA
description: Harry Booysen, a politician from the mixed-race Labor Party, reeled off the countries designated by the United Nations to send troops to supervise Namibia's march toward independence: Bangladesh, Finland, Malaysia, Panama, Yugoslavia, the Sudan and Togo.

title: Art for Art's Sake, New Orleans Style
description: In A mirror-lined room dancers twirl to a rhythm-and-blues beat, arms arching, reaching, hands cupping the air. ''I know I can get physicality out of you,'' says the instructor. ''But I want musicality. You're counting in your head. That voice inside is keeping you from hearing the music.'' They repeat the steps, moving more fluidly now, smiling as they try to become extensions of the music.

title: Solidarity Is Caught Between 'Square Cell and Round Table'
description: After countless lesser pin pricks, the Solidarity union movement viewed last week's news that the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk would be shut as a stab at its heart.

title: College Football: West/Southwest; Wyoming (10-0) Lassoes W.A.C. Title
description: Dabby Dawson ran for 134 yards and a touchdown today as Wyoming whipped Texas-El Paso, 51-6, to claim a share of the Western Athletic Conference title. The victory sent Wyoming, 10-0 over all and 7-0 in the conference, to the Holiday Bowl on Dec. 30 as the W.A.C. representative. Brigham Young can still tie Wyoming for a share of the league title, but the Cowboys beat the Cougars earlier this year and have the tie-breaker edge. Texas-El Paso (8-2, 4-2) could not halt the nation's top offensive team and was muffled by Wyoming's defense. The Miners managed jusst tow Chris Jacke field goals and 162 yards. Dawson surpassed the 1,000-yard mark for the season on his eighth carry. Wyoming, which led by 31-3 at the half, ran the nation's longest regular-season winning streak to 19 games. The Cowboys pressured the quarterback Pat Hegarty all afternoon. He had been averaging 188.9 yards a game but completed just 7 of 25 passes for 66 yards. Texas-El Paso managed just 96 rushing yards. U.C.L.A. 16, Oregon 6

title: India Strives To Safeguard Its Woodland
description: As dusk settles across northern India these cool evenings, hundreds of people can be seen carrying bundles of sticks and twigs as they trudge or cycle their way home.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Regulating Growth in 'For Sale' Signs
description: LEAD: ''FOR SALE''signs, sprouting in increasing numbers on front lawns this year, are an indication of a soft real estate market and the determination of homeowners - and brokers - to attract buyers any way they can. On weekends, ''open house'' signs are being added.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: NORMAN DORSEN of Cornwall, the president of the American Civil Liberties Union, looks ahead to a new challenge after the Nov. 8 election. He said he would try to mend the reputation of the 250,000-member A.C.L.U. that an occasionally ''sensationalized'' Presidential campaign had misrepresented. ''We'll be trying to counteract what has happened by getting our message across all over the country,'' said the 58-year-old Mr.

title: College Football; Cornell Stays in the Hunt
description: Cornell continued its pursuit of Pennsylvania and a share of the Ivy League championship today by trouncing Yale, 26-0, with an errorless, powerful performance despite the wind and rain.

title: THE COST OF BEING BOOK-WISE
description: ''The price of textbooks will make you cry,'' said Eddie Brosa as he searched for his books at the New York University bookstore in Manhattan. Mr. Brosa, a junior majoring in dramatic writing, considers himself lucky that he will spend only $200 for the fall semester's books.

title: Journey East From Ankara
description: Anyone who absorbs the history and physical diversity of Turkey may begin to appreciate the full course of civilization itself. In other places with extensive antiquities and historical monuments, there are whole epochs in which there is little of interest, but in Turkey - positioned at the axis of the geopolitical world, from neolithic times to the Hittites and the Trojans, Lydians and Phrygians and Urartians, Greeks and Romans, Byzantines and Armenians, Seljuks and Ottomans - there is an unbroken line of important sites from 60 centuries before Jesus through 20 centuries after.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Think About the Jockeys' Strike?
description: Although I certainly acknowledge the riders' point-of-view - and indeed respect both their abilities and dedication to the cause - as a horseplayer, I cannot fully support their position. The principal incentive in any sport - especially when wagering is involved - should be to win, not to finish second or third.

title: Horse Racing; Alysheba Takes Classic by Half-Length
description: Alysheba and Personal Ensign raced into thoroughbred history today by scoring dramatic Breeders' Cup victories on a chilly, muddy afternoon at Churchill Downs.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. In our new house, the master bathroom has plastic laminate with an unpleasant pattern covering the vanity top and drawers. Is there any way to paint over this?

title: A 'Walkure' That Ranks With the Best
description: The Metropolitan Opera has now newly staged all four operas of Richard Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen,'' although we will have to wait until April to see them all assembled into a cycle. Now, Deutsche Grammophon is poised to release the first of its recordings of the four scores, with copies scheduled to arrive in stores within a few days. The performance of ''Die Walkure'' (423 389; four compact disks or three cassettes, no LP's) tops the list of modern recordings of this most popular of the ''Ring'' operas.

title: AT THE MET, EXOTIC WORKS FROM PRIMITIVE ISLANDS
description: Elaborately carved tomb doors, pig-trap sticks, a sorcerer's box and a monster-headed stone seat are among the curious and exotic artifacts and architectural elements assembled in ''Islands and Ancestors: Indigenous Styles of Southeast Asia,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Case of the Missing Flags
description: LEAD: Somers's attempt to keep an American flag continuously flying in the town seems to be having its ups and downs.

title: HOLY SECRETS
description: The Body and Mind article, ''Holy Secrets'' (By Michael Wilkes and Miriam Shuchman, Oct. 2) neglected to mention a crucial fact: because of the unusual transmission pattern of the AIDS virus, the prospects of saving partners from infection are far larger than for other sexual diseases. Most sexual diseases are most easily transmitted in the first weeks or months after an individual contracts them; in the case of syphillis, for example, by the time someone becomes sick, typically five years or longer after infection, the syphillis spirochete is virtually nontransmissible. By contrast, the AIDS virus is hard to transmit in the first few years and becomes quite easily transmitted as people start to develop symptoms, some three, four or five years later. Even at that late point, by moving quickly to notify and counsel, it is still possible to save 50 to 60 percent of steady partners from infection; with testing and earlier notification, certainly the chance exists to save 80 percent or more of partners. CHRIS NORWOOD New York, N.Y.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Judith Graham;
Seeking Vietnam's 'Unaccounted For'
description: LEAD: LAST year, Judith Graham of Edison once again put on the bracelet that honors her younger brother, Air Force Capt. Dennis Graham, who disappeared while on a bombing mission in North Vietnam 20 years ago. The bracelet bears his name and rank and the date of his disappearance, March 28, 1968.

title: MEMO TO THE NEXT PRESIDENT
description: Henry Kaufman talks about ''reforming the financial system, at home and abroad''; he talks about our trading partners, but that seems to mean Japan, Europe and, perhaps, the newly industrialized countries of Asia. Where is the third world, and, particularly, the debt-troubled countries, in his perspective?

title: Group Aids Battered Women
description: LEAD: WHEN Shamita Das Dasgupta and five other Indian immigrant women got together in 1985 to form an organization for Indian women in New Jersey, they were motivated by broad feminist goals. They were not prepared for the kind of appeals that came pouring in.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis American Sweep in Wightman Cup: The United States Wightman Cup team completed a 7-0 sweep of Britain yesterday, going through the last three matches of the series in London with the loss of just 12 games. Zina Garrison and Lori McNeil won singles matches and Garrison teamed with Gigi Fernandez to defeat Jo Durie and Clare Wood, 6-1, 6-3, in doubles.(AP) Zvereva Upsets Evert: Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union upset second-seeded Chris Evert in straight sets last night to earn a berth against Martina Navratilova in the final of the $300,000 New England Virginia Slims tournament in Worcester, Mass. Zvereva, 17, stunned Evert, 7-5, 7-6, in a match that lasted just over two hours. Navratilova beat Gabriela Sabatini, 7-5, 6-3, to advance to the championship.(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 129, Celtics 115: Cliff Robinson scored 14 points last night in a 41-point third period that sparked the 76ers at Philadelphia. Leading by 64-57, the 76ers made 19 of 26 field-goal attempts in the period, for a 105-81 lead. Robinson finished with 25 points to lead the 76ers, and Larry Bird led Boston with 27 points. (AP) Bulls 111, Bullets 98: Michael Jordan scored 29 points and Horace Grant added 25 and a career-high 16 rebounds as Chicago spoiled Washington's season opener at Landover, Md. The Bulls outscored Washington by 12-4 at the start of the final quarter to open a 93-83 lead with 8:15 remaining. Chicago then outscored the Bullets by 16-5 over the next six minutes to put the game away.(AP) Pistons 94, Hornets 85: Adrian Dantley scored 18 points in the first N.B.A. game at the Pistons' new arena, The Palace at Auburn Hills, Mich. A jumper by Charlotte's Robert Reid cut Detroit's lead to 50-46 with 10:22 remaining in the third quarter, but that was as close as the Hornets could get. (AP) Clippers 111, Heat 91: Ken Norman had 22 points and 15 rebounds and Reggie Williams led a 20-6 third-quarter spurt at Miami that gave Los Angeles the victory in the Heat's first N.B.A. game. Williams finished with 21 points, while the rookie Sylvester Gray led Miami with 17.Miami rallied briefly after the Clippers took the 22-point lead, cutting the margin to 83-69 after three quarters. But the Heat got no closer in the final period(AP) Cavaliers 105, Pacers 99: Brad Daugherty scored 24 points and Mark Price added 22, including a steal and a clinching layup with 30 seconds left, for Cleveland at Indianapolis. Indiana came from 12 points down at the end of the third quarter and took its first lead at 94-93 on a basket by the 7-foot-4-inch rookie Rik Smits. The Pacers built their lead to 3 and still led by 2 before Daugherty tied the score with less than a minute remaining. John Williams hit two free throws with 33 seconds to go to put Cleveland ahead, then Price stole the inbounds pass and drove in for an uncontested layup. Williams added two more free throws seven seconds later as Indiana fouled in desperation. (AP) N.H.L. Blues 5, Nordiques 2: Cliff Ronning and Greg Paslawski had a goal and an assist at Quebec last night to lead the Blues. Ronning opened the scoring at 12:41, beating the goaltender Bob Mason with a wrist shot from the slot. Vincent Riendeau, the rookie goalie, making his fifth N.H.L. appearance, earned his first career victory, stopping 20 of 22 shots.(AP) Canadiens 7, Jets 2: Guy Carbonneau scored two goals and set up two others as the Canadiens, playing at home, won their third straight game. Stephane Richer added a goal and two assists as the Canadiens played one of their best games of the season and had an easy time dominating the Jets.(AP) Vancouver 3, Whalers 2: The Vancouver forward Petri Skriko scored on a quick wrist shot 34 seconds into overtime to give the Canucks the victory, snapping a three-year, nine-game winless streak against the Whalers.(AP)

title: Kent

title: Lunch Boxes In Comeback As Collectible
description: Scott Bruce was wandering through the aisles of a Salvation Army thrift store when he hit upon an overlooked collectible, something that held kitsch and nostalgia, not to mention a schoolchild's social status and, at one time, a sandwich and milk: the lunch box.

title: Will Czar Cotton Still Reign Across Soviet Central Asia?

title: Kent
description: To the Editor: Your article on being possessed by Kent recalled how my wife and I were imbued with the riches of Kent 30 years ago. We were on our honeymoon and after a visit to Canterbury Cathedral were ambling back to London by whatever byways appealed to us.

title:
FOOD;
THE FEAST IS SET
description: LEAD: From early childhood, we are taught about the unshakable Thanksgiving rituals. The golden bird is set before Father so that he can impress the gathering with his carving skills. The children gasp at the size of the turkey. (I remember, however, a few tears being shed by my siblings when dear old Harry - our pet turkey for a year - got the ax.

title: Helping a Hamlet Preserve Its Heritage
description: LEAD: The road to this hamlet of about 50 families winds through a scenic, 15-mile-long valley in a corner of Schoharie County that generally has not shared in the Catskill region's real estate boom.

title: Who is George Bush?
description: In 1972, when he was Ambassador to the United Nations, George Bush wrote the foreword to a book called ''World Population Crisis.'' He was supportive of the U.N.'s activities on population, and he commended the work of Planned Parenthood.

title: A Tale: Why Poets Are Free
description: BACK in the time of the beginning when all the universe was compacted to the size of a softball that floated loosely in eternity, God designed all that is and all that ever could be, almost. From the depths of His infinite intellect, He drew forth matter that He molded into every shape and form and size. Some of these things He called particles; others were elephants or tigers or hydra.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
IDEALS OF ORDER
description: LEAD: ''Each city lets us know who governs it and how it is governed,'' wrote the German art historian Wolfgang Braunfels, who died last year, in URBAN DESIGN IN WESTERN EUROPE: Regime and Architecture, 900-1900 (University of Chicago, $39.95). Architecture reflects a society's ideals of order, according to Braunfels's book, published in German in 1976, and successful cities reveal a layering of such orders, as each era redefines its beliefs and redesigns its structures.

title: Gift Orders Filled at Top-Secret Shop Of Colorado Nuclear Weapon Plant
description: In a top-secret workshop at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapon plant, employees built a $15,000 hardwood staircase for their supervisor and then smuggled it out in pieces in false-bottom cases past guards who had been bribed.

title: Rural Libraries Angered by Proposed Regulations
description: The public library here has an annual operating budget of $22,000 to buy books, pay the librarians and meet heat, maintenance and other expenses.

description: Clinging to a clear if narrowing lead in the public opinion polls, Vice President Bush campaigned from New Jersey to the West today, vowing not to be ''out-hustled by the liberal Governor from Massachusetts.''

title: NONFICTION
description: PASSION & CUNNING: Essays on Nationalism, Terrorism and Revolution. By Conor Cruise O'Brien. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Conor Cruise O'Brien is keeping alive, in high style, the art of the political essay. ''Passion & Cunning,'' a wide-ranging collection of articles previously published in major periodicals, is a service to anyone unfamiliar with his lucid prose. Mr. O'Brien takes on the most intractable conflicts, puncturing fashionable views with pungent comments that sometimes make his fellow liberals uncomfortable. Of South Africa he says: ''It would hardly be an inconsistent development of present revolutionary activities if among the children . . . who are currently burning people alive in the name of the cause of the people, were to be found a potential Joseph Stalin.'' Of Ireland: ''It would also help if future Dublin Governments and their American backers could desist from their well-meant efforts to bring about progress towards a united Ireland; efforts whose unintended effects help on the Holy War.'' Of Norman Podhoretz: ''A writer . . . who is passionately interested in politics, without knowing much about them.'' Of course, Mr. O'Brien is not without passion, and few subjects excite him more than Pope John Paul II, of whom he says: ''The Rome Orwell knew, and did not love, is back with us.'' Mr. O'Brien would not claim infallibility; that he is insightful and a pleasure to read is enough.

title:
FILM;
Fred Schepisi Puts Gossip on Trial

The nation in question is Australia, the director's native land. The case is that of Lindy Chamberlain, accused of decapitating her infant daughter, Azaria, during a camping trip in 1980 to Ayers Rock, a popular tourist (and sacred aboriginal) site in the Northern Territory.

Before she knew it, she was standing in a swarm of people who claimed her behavior had been bizarre.

title: MAESTRO ON THE MOVE
description: As director of the New York Philharmonic since 1978, Zubin Mehta has drawn mixed reviews with praise for being a skilled technician and critcism for appearing indifferent in approaching some conducting assignments. Last week, the 52-year-old Mr. Mehta, who was born in Bombay and trained in Vienna, announced that he would step down at the end of his current contract, which runs through the 1990-91 season. By then, he will have held the post longer than any other conductor in the orchestra's modern history. After 27 years as a music director, he said, '' I must at this juncture pursue other artistic endeavors which have to do with less administrative activity that the with which a music director is usually involved.'' He did not announce his plans. The Philharmonic began looking for a successor.

title: Only Two More Fighting Days Until Election; Just TV Images
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: CLARA BOW: Runnin' Wild. By David Stenn. (Doubleday, $18.95) This rags-to-riches biography of Clara Bow is titillating and enthralling yet sad. Born in 1905 into a desperately poor Brooklyn family, in which she was sexually abused and her mother was beaten repeatedly by her father, Bow was both beautiful and smart. She supported herself from the time she was 16 and by age 20 she was America's biggest movie box-office draw. An already stellar career was boosted by Elinor Glyn, Hollywood's reigning queen of chic, who dubbed her the ''It'' girl. ''It'' was a coy euphemism for sex appeal, which Bow possessed in abundance, along with great natural talent as an actress, a feisty temperament, fiery red hair and a penchant for candor. ''Clara Bow,'' written by David Stenn, a scriptwriter for television, chronicles the silent-screen films that made her a legend and her equally legendary sexual adventures. It also portrays her decline. She was exploited by her studio, Paramount, throughout her career, although she was their biggest moneymaker; uncertain about the quality of her voice, she was terrified at the advent of talkies. A series of scandals labeled her a home-wrecking tramp and made her a has-been at 25. Bow retired, married and had two sons. The mental illness that was prevalent in her family began to emerge and she spent the last 20 of her 65 years as a recluse; she was diagnosed as schizophrenic. Her husband, the actor Rex Bell, who became a well-known Nevada politician, had her legally barred from seeing her sons and the couple were estranged. This is a touching portrait of a sad and turbulent life.

title: FICTION
description: LOVE IN THE DAYS OF RAGE. By Lawrence Ferlinghetti. (Dutton, $15.95.) Close upon the 20th anniversary of the student uprisings in Paris comes the poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti's novel about a May-September romance set against those few months of profound upheaval. Annie, an American painter living in Paris, has an affair with Julian, an older banker who, though firmly ensconced in the capitalistic hierarchy, is really an anarchist - or so he says. When Annie is skeptical, Julian woos her with stories of his revolutionary youth. As the drama of the revolt grows tense and ultimately reaches its decisive moment, Julian, at Annie's urging, must prove his allegiance to the cause with a single, incontrovertible act. Though Mr. Ferlinghetti makes an attempt at creating a memorable and passionate romance, it falls short. Annie, if anything, is continually questioning why she should remain with Julian. As for Julian, he enjoys Annie's company and her bed well enough, but with his polished, worldly demeanor he is no Abelard to her Heloise. The real hero of ''Love in the Days of Rage'' is the student uprising itself. Mr. Ferlinghetti writes very convincingly about the turbulence and energy, the sheer letting loose that was May 1968 in Paris. You can feel yourself being jostled and pushed along by all the chaos and anger. In short, you find yourself in the midst of great change. Mr. Ferlinghetti obviously has deep affection for Paris and its unique intellectual spirit. Even with its flaws, this short novel is haunting.

title: Group Show With 'Side Dish'
description: THE group show now at Rutgers's Robeson Center Gallery, in Newark, follows precedent in having a solo as a ''side dish.'' And, as usual, Alison Weld is responsible for both events. The difference is that Ms. Weld, having left Rutgers for the State Museum in Trenton, is guest instead of resident curator.

title: BEVERLY HILLS LINE
description: The Beverly Hills name and its burnished image of wealth, Hollywood glamour and easy living has helped sell movies, hotels and million-dollar mansions. Now the name adorns a clothing line intended to bolster the city's school budget.

title: The Big Ten Of College Towns
description: College town is defined first and foremost by its street life - enough jeans, backpacks and bicycles and the right ratio of greasy spoons to trendy boutiques. Because a college education is town as well as gown, choosing a college also means choosing a new, four-year home. The college towns chosen here are 10 of the nation's best for their rich mixture of atmospherics and academia. As for scholastic standing, the schools they serve include large state universities as well as superselective and prestigious private colleges - in short, something for just about everyone.

title: D.M. CHERRY WED TO MISS PATTERSON
description: The marriage of Sarah Lloyd Patterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Remington Patterson of New York, to Douglas MacMillan Cherry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Cherry of Cincinnati, took place yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony.

title: Fare of the Country; New Mexico's Pine Nuts, Sauce to Snack
description: The short-trunked, short-needled, twisted, slow-growing pinon, or Pinus edulis, is as much a part of the landscape of northern New Mexico and Arizona as pink rock and blue mesas and yellow earth. The peoples who have lived in the region have used the nuts for food, medicine, building material and fuel, in stories and in mythmaking, and in the softly rounded adobe kiva fireplaces to help along affairs of the heart. In the fall, when pinon's pungent sweet smoke begins to rise into the clear night air foretelling winter's hard bright stars and dry powdery snows, people in the smaller Spanish and Pueblo hill towns begin to talk about where and when they may find the sweet nuts.

title: NONFICTION
description: GERALD L. K. SMITH: Minister of Hate. By Glenn Jeansonne. (Yale University, $25.) Gerald L. K. Smith was a bizarre fundamentalist whose vitriolic racism was matched only by his passion for collecting Bibles. In chronicling Smith's life, Glenn Jeansonne, who teaches history at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, opens a window on the lunatic fringe. Born in Wisconsin in 1898 and raised in a populist environment, Smith became minister of a church in Shreveport, La., where he ran afoul of conservatives after prevailing on Senator Huey P. Long to intervene on behalf of some church members who were threatened by foreclosure on their mortgages. Smith then became director of Long's Share Our Wealth Society, which to many smacked of socialism. After Long's assassination, writes Mr. Jeansonne, Smith ''would cry about the blood of Huey and then dip his hands in red dye and hold them aloft.'' Mr. Jeansonne impressively records the intricacies of Smith's financial organizations, his hatred of Franklin D. Roosevelt, his cultivation of isolationist congressmen (who later spurned him) and his quixotic campaigns for the Senate and the Presidency. But the book lacks psychological insight into Smith's character; the shift from seeming liberal to professional racist is not explained by the mortgages incident, in which one of the principals among the mortgage holders was Jewish. (Long was tyrannical, but not a racist.) A charismatic orator, Smith saw Jews and Communists as universal evil agents, with blacks as malleable fellow travelers. He once wrote: ''I expect to live and die a misunderstood man by millions of my compatriots.'' And he did, thank God.

description: P.S.A.L.

title: No Inquiry for Ex-Meese Aide
description: The Justice Department has concluded there is no evidence to substantiate allegations that William F. Weld, the former head of the Criminal Division, smoked marijuana at a 1982 wedding reception, a Department spokesman said Friday.

Even the poll-takers have acknowledged this new development and have lately added a question asking people how they feel about it. Voters of all three parties - Democrat, Republican and Stayed-Home - will know only relief when it all ends Tuesday night.

title: LOTHAR BAUMGARTEN'S DISCREET PROVOCATIONS
description: Among current presences on the international art scene none is more benign than a German artist called Lothar Baumgarten, who has just made the news on two quite separate counts. At the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh, there was inaugurated a ceiling piece of majestic proportions and almost incorporeal substance that measures roughly 110 feet by 40 feet. What we see there, floating high in the air and immediately above a reduced replica of the Parthenon frieze, is a hand-cut and hand-painted version of the Cherokee alphabet that was elaborated between 1809 and 1821 by an Indian named Sequoyah. Noble forms in themselves, the characters in question made it possible for a Cherokee newspaper to be published and read as of February 1828. (One of its first subscribers was Alexander von Humboldt, the great linguist, in Berlin.) This critic has not yet seen the Pittsburgh piece, but detailed photographs make it clear that it is a major addition to the long series of discreet provocations that Lothar Baumgarten has been setting up the world over, from Caracas in Venezuela to Venice in Italy. Each letter in the Pittsburgh ceiling is positioned at an angle of 45 degrees to its neighbors, so that no matter where we stand we see characters that, from our point of view, are the right way up.

title: DECEMBER BRIDAL FOR CATHY BARTON
description: Cathy Susan Barton, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Barton of Weston, Conn., and Steven Cahn Zales, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Zales of Greenwich, Conn., plan to marry Dec. 4.

Given his recent performance level his chances of rejoining the team have seemed virtually nil.

title: Sifting for Gold In Two 'Lost' Balanchine Ballets
description: George Balanchine choreographed ''Cotillon'' in Monte Carlo in 1932 at the age of 28 and ''Mozart Violin Concerto'' in Buenos Aires in 1942. Quite unexpectedly, within one month both of these so-called lost ballets have recently been performed in New York City. Created 10 years apart, they reveal strikingly not only how Balanchine arrived at the esthetic that now identifies him but, more importantly, the influences that he sought to cast off in his youth.

title: VIVIENNE BARR MARRIES
