Barr of New York, was married last evening to Perry Howard Braun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Braun of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Stanley Davids officiated. Mrs. Braun, an associate with Chase Manhattan Bank, graduated from Bryn Mawr College and received a master's degree in international affairs from Johns Hopkins University. Mr. Braun, an associate at Goldman Sachs & Company, graduated from Yale University and the Harvard Law School.

title: EUROPE HAS AN ORIENTATION PLAN FOR THE NEXT AMERICAN PRESIDENT
description: AS they wait more or less patiently for this week's election and a new Administration in Washington, America's NATO allies are poised to offer President Bush or President Dukakis some thoughts on what his foreign policy priorities should be. And no matter which candidate is the winner, he will be visited the following week by Western Europe's most uninhibited giver of advice.

title: Why I Decided to Go to South Africa
description: WHY would anyone make a decision to brush aside his or her moral conviction and violate a sanction so severe that it hasn't been broken for 12 years? I don't know, that's not a decision I had to make when I traveled to South Africa as part of an American delegation of track and field athletes to take part in three competitions last month.

title: 'Presidential Pursuit'
description: Which American President had a toy named after him? Who was chosen President in 1800 after there was a tie in the Electoral College, and by whom? If a Vice President dies in office, how is a new Vice President selected? * Trivial and not-so-trivial questions such as these are part of ''Presidential Pursuit,'' a game making the rounds these days of all fifth- and sixth-grade public elementary school classes in Scarsdale. The Scarsdale League of Women Voters, which created ''Presidential Pursuit'' as a 1984 election project and has updated it for 1988, said it hopes the game will ''help inform students about how their government works, so when it's their turn to vote they'll make informed choices,'' said Joan Sorkin, who heads the committee in charge of the game for the Scarsdale League.

title: SCIENCE AND RELGION: FOR BOTH THE FATIHFUL AND THE SKEPTICS, RELICS HOLD THEIR MYSTERIESE
description: In religion no less than in science, finding one answer often only raises other questions. That was the case with the announcement last month that carbon-14 tests showed that a piece of linen known as the Holy Shroud of Turin and venerated as the burial cloth of Jesus actually dated from the Middle Ages.

title: JENNIFER FELDMAN AND GORDON BOCK TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Jennifer Fay Feldman's engagement to Gordon Mitchell Bock, a son of Dorothy S. Bock of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Samuel Bock, has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Wallace Feldman of Plattsburgh, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Expert Witness Details Secrets of a Drug Cartel
description: Sitting in the witness box, the stocky, middle-aged man with graying hair and horn-rimmed glasses gave few details about his personal life. In a flat monotone, he said simply that he was a mechanical engineer who was fluent in Spanish and who was married to a Colombian woman.

title: KATHERINE R. DORSEY WEDS DR. KENNETH RUSSELL STONE
description: The marriage of Katherine Rose Dorsey, a registered nurse at Hartford Hospital, and Dr. Kenneth Russell Stone, a cardiologist and attending physician at Memorial Hospital in Mount Holly, N.J., took place yesterday at the New Haven Lawn Club. Rabbi Jon Haddon officiated. The bride, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Donald T. Dorsey of Meriden, Conn., graduated from the University of Connecticut School of Nursing. Her father is a judge of the Connecticut Superior Court. Dr. Stone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Stone of Floral Park, Queens, graduated from Union College and the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center. His father is the president of Stone Textiles in New York.

title: School Boards: Elected or Appointed?
description: QUESTIONS on the ballot in two New Jersey municipalities on whether the voters prefer to have elected school boards or ones appointed by the mayor have rekindled a debate that has raged in school districts throughout the state for years.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Brattleboro, Vt.: Scaled-Down Project Rises
description: LEAD: West River Meadows, an 88-unit condominium going up on a hillside, is a remnant of a much larger ''executive housing'' proposal derailed by neighborhood opposition, environmental problems and regulatory delay.

title: Long Lines Gone at Motor Vehicle Office
description: ''ABANDON hope, all ye who enter here,'' a middle-aged man muttered recently as he climbed the steps of the Department of Motor Vehicle Office in White Plains, clutching some papers.

title: Speaking Ill Of the Dead
description: Reviewing David Roberts's biography of the novelist Jean Stafford, Joyce Carol Oates discovered a new literary genre - pathography. ''Its motifs are dysfunction and disaster, illnesses and pratfalls, failed marriages and failed careers, alcoholism and breakdowns and outrageous conduct,'' Oates noted last summer. ''Its shrill theme is 'failed promise,' if not outright 'tragedy.' ''

title: By Freighter To the Island Of St. Helena
description: Devotees of freighter travel often lament that while the cruise trade to familiar ports appears to be flourishing, the availability of off-beat freighter trips seems to be diminishing. Not to worry. There are still unique sailing experiences to be found for the searching.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 19TH-CENTURY FUNERALS ''American Funeral Customs'' is the title of a new exhibition of artifacts, clinical equipment and mourning clothing on view until Dec. 2 at the Scott Fanton Museum, 43 Main Street in Danbury. A cooperative effort by the museum and several of the city's funeral directors, the exhibition provides some unique glimpses into the burial customs of the 19th century.

title: IMMIGRATION AIDE ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: A former district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Atlanta has been indicted here on charges that he conspired to submit false documents in an effort to get favorable treatment for aliens in this country.

title: Pennsylvania to Make Schools Disclose Their Crime Figures
description: Pennsylvania, starting this month, will require its colleges and universities to make campus crime statistics and security measures available to all prospective students and their parents. Failure to comply could result in a fine of $10,000 for the school.

title:
FOCUS: BOSTON;
A Downtown Park Atop a Buried Garage
description: LEAD: Work has begun on a 1,400-space garage below - and a new 1.5 acre park for - the heart of Boston's choicest downtown office district.

title: Shootings Hurting Baltimore Schools
description: In several public high schools here, teachers are suspicious of students wearing bulky coats. Students eye each other warily. Fear stalks the corridors. In three weeks last month, four students were wounded in shootings in Baltimore high schools. The police also reported a stabbing, a student raped in a women's restroom and they say three boys, his classmates, sodomized an 11-year-old boy in a junior high school bathroom.

title:
DINING OUT;
Indian Offerings in White Plains
description: LEAD: When Dawat opened its pretty French doors one month ago, most lovers of Indian cuisine wondered whether White Plains needed another Indian restaurant. Judging from the response we witnessed on our visits, apparently it does. But diners won't be forced to choose; remarkably enough this newcomer has put together a lengthy menu of dishes so varied that guests will find little overlap between Dawat's offerings and those of other

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT was November, and when you've drawn first-period gym class and you're wearing nothing but regulation shorts and T-shirts, November is a cold month in New Jersey. In a day or two, the coaches would convene and vote to move us indoors for basketball, or to sentence us to another week of flag football.

title: Artists Choose Accents in Black and White
description: LEAD: AGAINST white-painted brick walls and columns and floors blackened from years of horses' hooves is a striking exhibition in Greenwich called ''Black and White.''

title: When 60's Meets 80's, It's a 'Rude Awakening'
description: Nestled in a tiny courtyard behind the Cooper Square Thrift Shop, members of a happy hippie commune are relaxing in the midday rays, doing their own thing. On the fire escape, a serene earth mother draped in love beads cuddles her giggling flower child in a colorful afghan, while a bearded fellow below contemplates the ankh around his neck. A few feet away, two long-haired men slowly inhale from a hash pipe and discuss the ''I Ching.''

title: BLACKBOARD
description: The eight children, some of them barely out of diapers, watched with varying degrees of concentration. ''Mains sur la tete!'' shouted Francois Thibaut. His students, accompanied by their mothers, are enrolled in French for Tots, Mr. Thibaut's program, based in a private school in New York City. The class is one of only a handful of formal language schools in this country for very young children, but it signals a growing phenomenon in preschool language education. Other schools with similar approaches are in Washington and Chicago.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Exeter Township, Pa.: Expressway Spurs Growth
description: LEAD: When the 25-mile-long Pottstown Expressway from the Philadelphia suburb of King of Prussia to just beyond Pottstown was completed in April 1985 it sparked a residential boom along its northwest path through Montgomery County and into Berks County.

title: New York's Proposal on Road Bonds
description: On Tuesday, New York voters will be asked to give the state the authority to float $3 billion worth of new bonds to pay for the expansion and repair of the state's roads and bridges. If voters approve the bond issue, which will appear on the ballot as Proposal One, it will be the largest in the state's history.

title: No Headline
description: OFFICIALS of Suffolk County and its five eastern towns reacted with pleasure and some confusion last week to news that Congress had passed, and President Reagan would soon sign, legislation nominating the Peconic Bay system for inclusion in the Environmental Protection Agency's National Estuary Program.

title: 'Spoils of War' Goes 1,092 Miles To Broadway
description: In normal traffic, a cab ride downtown from the Second Stage Theater, on Broadway near 76th Street, to the Music Box Theater, on 45th Street in the heart of the theater district, takes 12 minutes and costs $4.25 including tip.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: RONALD S. LAUDER;
Keeping Alive the Lessons of 1938 Kristallnacht
description: LEAD: ''WHAT do you know about Kristallnacht?'' Ronald S. Lauder, the former United States Ambassador to Austria, asked a visitor to his office on Madison Avenue.

title: ROBERT R. BENDETSON WED TO JO ANN GANTZ
description: Jo Ann Gantz and Robert Rome Bendetson, magna cum laude graduates of Tufts University, were married last evening at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., by Rabbi Judah Nadich.

title: LYNN A. FRANCIS TO HAVE A BRIDAL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Francis of Short Hills, N.J., have announced that their daughter Lynn Ann Francis and John Emil Delade, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Delade of Kinnelon, N.J., plan to marry Dec. 10.

title: Shirley Temple Mixes It Up
description: THE LITTLE COLONEL With Lionel Barrymore, Evelyn Venable, John Lodge, Bill Robinson. Directed by David Butler. 1935. 80 minutes. THE LITTLEST REBELWith John Boles, Jack Holt, Karen Morley, Bill Robinson. Directed by David Butler. 1935. 70 minutes. HEIDI With Jean Hersholt, Arthur Treacher, Mary Nash, Mady Christians. Directed by Allan Dwan. 1937. 88 minutes. REBECCA OF SUNNYBROOK FARM With Randolph Scott. Directed by Allan Dwan. 1938. 80 minutes. JUST AROUND THE CORNER With Charles Farrell, Joan Davis, Bill Robinson, Amanda Duff, Bert Lahr, Cora Witherspoon. Directed by Irving Cummings. 1935. 70 minutes. Playhouse Video. $19.95 each.

title: Canada Cares
description: To the Editor:

title: Dukakis or Bush on Nov. 8? To Many, Staying Home Seems the Best Choice
description: When about half of the nation's eligible voters go to the polls Tuesday to elect a President, Phyllis Braff expects to be with the other half, staying away. ''I hate to vote for the lesser of two evils,'' said the New Jersey businesswoman. ''They're both so awful.''

title: Russ Credited With Milestone
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Social Events; Drama, Music and Parties
description: Special Theater Benefit Nov. 7 - An evening of theater works by deaf writers and performers and an exhibition of how performers use sign language in their work will be held at the Hudson Guild, 441 West 26th Street. The evening, starting at 8, will benefit the guild's efforts to promote works by the deaf for all udiences. Included will be an excerpt form ''The Signal Season of Dummy Hoy,'' by Allen Meyer and Michael Nowak, about the first deaf player in professional baseball. A reception follows the performance. Tickets $20 or $50; 212-760-9836 or, for the deaf, V/TTY 212-760-9829. Briefly Noted

title: Review/Theater; 1940's Brew of Satire Within Satire
description: ''Kiss Me Quick Before the Lava Reaches the Village'' is a textbook example of the kind of musical that tries so hard to be clever it ends up outsmarting itself. Especially in the first act of its antically bumpy course, the musical farce, presented at the Theater at St. Peter's Church by Musical Theater Works, generates more laughs than the average show. But late in Act II, when its satire turns abruptly heavy, the show screeches off the tracks.

title: TEARING APART EASTERN AIRLINES
description: One Thursday afternoon recently, an Eastern Airlines L-1011 jumbo jet took off from New York bound for Miami with 37 passengers on board. ''We have a new class of service today,'' the chief flight attendant announced to her colleagues as they stared at the near-empty cabin. ''If you can find 'em, serve 'em.'' She repeated the joke several times, laughing nervously at each telling, but no one laughed with her.

title: Review/Opera; The Met Season Opens With 'Cav' and 'Pag'
description: The return Friday night of Franco Zeffirelli's 1970 Metropolitan Opera production of Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci,'' after a three-year absence, served mostly as a forum for an almost entirely new cast - three debuts and six other singers taking their parts for the first time with the company.

title: Stores Give Furniture to Formerly Homeless
description: HOMELESS people leaving shelters for permanent housing may receive furniture for their new homes from a retailers' program. The Connecticut Retail Merchants Association is calling on its 2,000 members to donate furnishings for needy people.

title: THE ECONOMY AND THE CANDIDATES: What's Their Rainy Day Plan?
description: It may not happen next year, but certainly sometime in the next two or three years, the next President, no matter what he says now, will have to face the consequences of the Federal deficit. And even at this late date in the campaign, we still have no adequate idea of how either candidate will go about it.

title: Low-Key Target In the Busy Caribbean
description: The beaches are as perfect as they are anywhere else in the Caribbean, with great white crescents of sand resting against billowing green hills. The difference here is the loneliness.

title: Tax Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: A Major in Leitmotifs
description: PEOPLE are always fascinated with my career and never cease asking me how I got to be where I am today (between projects). Well, this is not exactly true. Most people are more interested in themselves than in me. Once in a while, however, I do run into someone who has a passing interest in the sort of work I do.

title: A Times Square Church Gathers Rave Reviews
description: On Sunday each of the plush red seats in this Broadway theater is filled and dozens of people stand in the aisles. Music escapes onto the street as the audience sings along. But those attending are not clutching Playbills and the marquee does not read ''Phantom of the Opera.'' They carry Bibles and the neon sign says: The Times Square Church.

title: An Obbligato of Titters
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Two More Fighting Days Until Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Is In on Young Composers: Great!
description: CALL them prodigies, geniuses or simply talented young people. The winners of this year's Aaron Copland Competition for Young Composers (ages 5 to 13), sponsored by the Purchase Music Ensemble, a county group, are impressive by any definition.

title: Article 661888 -- No Title
description: The University of Pennsylvania has received a $10 million gift from Ronald O. Perelman, chairman and chief executive officer of Revlon Group Inc., for a student and faculty activities building.

title: Varieties of News
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics Say Election Spending Goes Too Far
description: Many House candidates spend their campaign funds on polling, salaries and advertising. Others are more creative.

title: All of City a Stage for a Jazz Harpist
description: LEAD: AT first, Daphne Hellman, who plays jazz on a harp, did not see the irony in being a street musician, playing for pennies on a stretch of Central Park pavement directly across the street from the Pierre. That is the same hotel where, as a young woman with impeccable Social Register credentials, she made her debut.

title: Give Trump A Time at Bat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pro Football; Dickerson Running Far Ahead of the Field
description: Eric Dickerson adjusted his goggles a year ago and landed in a Colts uniform.

title: HIGH MARKS FOR LOW-COSTS HOUSING IN BOSTON
description: Can there be such a thing as ''affordable housing'' that is decent, even wonderful, as a work of design? That manages to make sense both economically and esthetically? The answer, at least in Boston, is yes. Two complexes of apartments have recently been completed in this city that achieve what is often thought to be no longer possible in our age - they are desirable places to live for working-class families and at the same time they add to the city's body of good architecture. In other words, they do something both for the people who live in them and for everyone else.

title: Vote May Be Key To Statewide Trend
description: A REPUBLICAN, George Bush, and a Democrat, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, are expected to sweep Nassau and Suffolk Counties in Tuesday's elections, reinforcing Long Islanders' reputation as swing voters who do not follow party lines, at least at the top of the ballot.

title: Reagan Sees Election as Referendum on Him
description: On the final weekend of the campaign to choose his successor, President Reagan suggested today that the election Tuesday would be a referendum on his own Presidency.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Think About the Jockeys' Strike?
description: The ''jockeys' strike,'' which would appear to have been more of an owners' strike, has illustrated the fact, that even though small of stature, the jockeys proved themselves much bigger than the owners and some of their trainers. Indeed, how many owners would have been willing to turn their backs on the possibility of making more than $100,000 (Pincay) or would offer to contribute their out-of-town earnings (Cordero) to support a cause that did not help them at all?

title: Go Away, Dick and Jane
description: THE COMPETITION to get into Blue Sky News is intense. When Kalinda, who has recently moved into the Forest Edge Elementary School District in Reston, Va., offers the fact that her family has a new couch, she is almost hooted out of the classroom by her fellow first-graders. On the other hand, Brian's announcement that his cat just had nine kittens is hailed unanimously as a big story. And so Brian, a redheaded, freckle-faced 6-year-old, takes his place at the computer keyboard and types in his name. Nell Cangiano, the teacher, types in the rest of the news. When she has finished, the talking computer reads the story aloud. And Brian, after volunteering cheerfully that he can't read, reads the story himself: ''Brian's cat had nine kittens last night. Brian's cat sleeps by his bed.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Then, it was morning in America. Now, it's brunchtime.'' - Prof. John Aldrich of Duke University, on the campaigns of '84 and '88. [ 43:3. ]

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: EARLY HAUTE COUTURE

title: Bush: Foreign Affairs Sense
description: If you believe in the importance of an effective foreign policy, then you should hope that George Bush will stay in Washington next year and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will remain in Boston.

title: STARK TRUTH VS. 'FALSE REALISM': THE BOOK THAT STUNNED BEIJING
description: The recent appearance of a first literary effort by a hitherto unknown writer has caused quite a sensation in China. Since its publication last spring, ''Blood-Red Sunset,'' which, according to the author, ''is neither an autobiography nor a novel'' but which is really a sort of journalist memoir, has already gone through several printings, totaling 400,000 copies. In a population of one billion, that number may not seem great, but in China, where the novel is in such decline that sometimes even a printing of a few thousand copies does not sell out, the success of a book like ''Blood-Red Sunset,'' which is devoid of lurid sex, sensationalism and tales of the supernatural, is of extraordinary significance.

title: U.S. Composers in Spotlight
description: This is national American Music Week, the fourth yearly celebration of our country's composers and their creative work. More than 1,000 events have been scheduled nationwide, and a number of Westchester concerts today and next weekend - some by design, others through happenstance - are presenting fine examples of musical Americana.

title: Edward T. Gignoux, 72, Is Dead; Served on Federal Bench 26 Years
description: Judge Edward T. Gignoux, who presided over a number of cases of nationwide interest in his 26 years on the Federal bench, died Friday at Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 72 years old and lived in Cumberland Foreside, a seashore village near Portland.

title: Of Perestroika, Prices and Pessimism
description: With its economic reforms floundering and its citizens freer to grumble under glasnost, the Soviet Union has been stepping up its already extraordinary effort to seek loans investors and even advice from Western nations. In the last month alone, Western lenders have granted the Soviet Union credits worth at least $5 billion for the purchase of goods.

title:
The View From: Pace University, Pleasantville;
Campus Celebrates 25 Years of Change
description: LEAD: IN 1947, Pace College in Manhattan, which had been a business school since 1906, introduced a liberal arts curriculum. In 1963, the school, now Pace University, opened a second campus on the gently rolling land alongside Bedford Road here.

title: No Headline
description: Senegal Will Restore Full Ties With Libya

title: Varieties of News
description: To the Editor:

title: ABROAD BUT AGROUND
description: Among the pains of air travel, one of the most frustrating is sitting in an airplane while it goes no place. You are confined and unless you are in first or business class, you have nothing to eat or drink. Often, people waiting for you at the other end cannot learn where you are.

title: Bicycling Hall of Fame Being Developed
description: LEAD: THE bicycle and New Jersey have played an important part in each other's development, so it is fitting that the United States Bicycling Hall of Fame is being developed here.

title: Chanel's Foot Soldiers Advance
description: IT'S the kind of exquisitely simple and unfettered design that several generations of stylish women have come to expect from the House of Chanel. This particular one is a collarless jacket with two precise rows of brass buttons down the front, each button bearing the familiar logo with interlocking C's.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SMOKE AND ASHES The Story of the Holocaust. By Barbara Rogasky. Illustrated. 187 pp. New York: Holiday House. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Westfield
description: To the Editor:

title: A Great Equalizer For the Disabled
description: OF THE 45 million students now in public schools, at least 10 percent - 4.5 million - are disabled in some way, according to the Federal Government. Yet only 10 to 15 percent have severe or profound disabilities. Nearly half are considered to be learning-disabled.

title: MISS CAMPBELL WEDS IN JERSEY
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Campbell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart F. Campbell of Montclair, N.J., to James Sterling Bungerz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Bungerz of Allentown, Pa., took place yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in Montclair. The Rev. Sharon Yunker Deatz performed the ceremony.

title: Bush Still Ahead as End Nears But Dukakis Gains in Survey
description: Vice President Bush led Gov. Michael S. Dukakis going into the last weekend of the 1988 Presidential campaign, but Mr. Dukakis has gained ground, especially among voters dissatisfied with the campaign's tone, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll showed.

title: Early Data Issued on College AIDS Survey
description: Preliminary results of a study of 20 colleges suggest that about three of every 1,000 college students are carrying the AIDS virus.

title: Reagan Signs Measure Barring Sale of Fetal Tissue
description: President Reagan on Friday signed into a law a measure banning the sale of fetal organs and tissues.

title: Race for the White House: How the Candidates Are Doing State by State
description: The following state-by-state assessment of the Presidential campaign by E. J. Dionne Jr. of The New York Times is based on interviews with politicians and political consultants and on polls taken for newspapers, television and the campaigns. A number of recent polls suggest there is movement to Michael S. Dukakis in the final days of the campaign. This could overturn several narrow leads now held by Vice President Bush. The list also covers races for the United States Senate and for Governor in states where they are occurring. Most incumbent House members are expected to win re-election; the list includes only some of the most competitive House contests. ALABAMA: 9 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush the overwhelming favorite. ALASKA: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush far ahead. ARIZONA: 7 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush has big lead. Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat, favored, but his once large lead has shrunk. ARKANSAS: 6 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush has been leading, but Dukakis has outside chance. CALIFORNIA: 47 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush and Dukakis have been close for weeks. Bush appeared to have a narrow lead, but the polls have been contradictory. Dukakis has built the most extensive ground organization in the state's history and is counting on it. Republicans say absentee ballots will save the state for Bush. Senator Pete Wilson, Republican, leads Lieut. Gov. Leo McCarthy, Democrat, though McCarthy has narrowed the very expensive race. Close House race near President Reagan's home in Santa Barbara pits Rep. Robert Lagomarsino, Republican, against State Senator Gary K. Hart, Democrat. COLORADO: 8 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads, though Dukakis campaign still has hope. CONNECTICUT: 8 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush and Dukakis fighting to the end. Republican polls show late trend to Bush. Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican, faces fierce challenge from Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman. Weicker, the most vocal liberal in the Republican Party, clings to the narrowest of leads. DELAWARE: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads. Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican, favored, but Lieut. Gov. S. B. Woo is given some chance. Gov. Michael N. Castle, Republican, an overwhelming favorite for re-election. DISTRCT OF COLUMBIA: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis's surest bet in the country. FLORIDA: 21 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush locked up the state early. In fight for an open Senate seat, Rep. Buddy MacKay, Democrat, holds surprising, shaky edge over Rep. Connie Mack, a conservative Republican, despite Bush's lead. Three House seats opened up when incumbents sought the Senate seat. Porter Goss, Republican, favored to hold Mack's seat. Florida House Speaker Jon Mills, Democrat, a narrower favorite for MacKay's seat. Very close fight for the seat of Rep. Daniel A. Mica, who lost to McKay in primary. GEORGIA: 12 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads, though this is one of Dukakis's better Southern states. Feature contest is the race between Rep. Pat Swindall, a Republican under indictment, and the favored Ben Jones, a Democrat who played Cooter on the Dukes of Hazzard. HAWAII: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis led in late polling. Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, Democrat, a sure re-election winner. IDAHO: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush by a mile. ILLINOIS: 24 ELECTORAL VOTES A very close contest with Dukakis gaining ground. Rep. Jack Davis, Republican, faces strong challenge for re-election from State Senator George Sangmeister. INDIANA: 12 ELECTORAL VOTES The Bush-Quayle ticket far ahead. Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican, will be an easy winner. In the Governor's race, Secretary of State Evan Bayh, Democrat, leads Lieut. Gov. John Mutz, Republican. Bayh is the son of former Senator Birch Bayh, who was defeated by Dan Quayle in 1980. Three House incumbents, Reps. John Hiler, Republican, and Jim Jontz and Philip R. Sharp, Democrats, are in close races. IOWA: 8 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis leads in the state whose caucuses began the process. KANSAS: 7 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads comfortably. KENTUCKY: 9 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads, but Democrats say has tightened. LOUISIANA: 10 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads, but some polls last week showed Dukakis getting close. Rep. Clyde C. Holloway, Republican, is slight favorite in rematch against Faye Williams, Democrat. MAINE: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush has slight edge in state that is his summer home. Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat, hopes to break records with re-election margin. MARYLAND: 10 ELECTORAL VOTES Should be a strong Dukakis state, but polls have shown it close. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat, a heavy favorite despite spirited campaign by Alan Keyes, a former aide to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick and one of two black Republican Senate candidates this year. Peter Franchot, Democrat, has mounted a stronger-than-expected challenge to Rep. Constance A. Morella, Republican. MASSACHUSETTS: 13 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis favored in home state, but Bush has come embarassingly close. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat, has no such problem. MICHIGAN: 20 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush has led for a month, at times by a lot. But the race has tightened. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat, expected to win big. MINNESOTA: 10 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis has narrow edge. Fierce Senate battle between the incumbent Dave Durenberger and Attorney General Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, son of the former Vice President. Durenberger leads but Humphrey was closing the gap this week. Rep. Arlan Stangeland, Republican, in a close race. MISSISSIPPI: 7 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush strongly favored. Rep. Trent Lott, Republican, leads Rep. Wayne Dowdy, Democrat, for the seat of retiring Senator John C. Stennis. Dowdy hopes to score upset with a heavy black vote. A tough fight for Dowdy's House seat, while Republicans should hold Lott's seat. MISSOURI: 11 ELECTORAL VOTES Another state where Dukakis has closed the gap to make it a tight race. Senator John C. Danforth, Republican, is heavily favored over State Senator Jay Nixon. Gov. John Ashcroft, Republican, leads solidly over Betty Cooper Hearnes, Democratic challenger. MONTANA: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads in a state where Dukakis once hoped for a breakthrough. Senator John Melcher, Democrat, favored, though Republicans say their candidate, Conrad Burns, is in a position to upset him. In a spirited fight to succeed the retiring Gov. Ted Schwinden, a Democrat, former Gov. Tom Judge, a Democrat, and the veteran State Senator Stan Stephens are virtually even. NEBRASKA: 5 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush safe in this traditionally Republican state. Democrats should pick up a Senate seat as former Gov. Bob Kerrey leads Senator David Karnes, Republican. Democrats may take the House seat of Rep. Hal Daub, a Republican who lost to Karnes in the Senate primary. NEVADA: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Should be one of Bush's best states. The surprise is how well Senator Chic Hecht, Republican, has done against the popular Gov. Richard H. Bryan, Democrat. Hecht, once far behind, is now close to even. NEW HAMPSHIRE: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush far out in front. Rep. Judd Gregg, Republican, leads Paul McEachern, Democrat, in the battle for the Governorship. In the fight for Gregg's House seat, which the Democrats have not won since 1912, Mayor Jim Donchess of Nashua, Democrat, runs close to former Justice Chuck Douglas of State Supreme Court. NEW JERSEY: 16 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush built very large lead in a state where his ''Boston Harbor'' television ad hurt Dukakis badly. But in recent days, Dukakis has come quite close. Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat, has led his Republican challenger, Pete Dawkins, throughout. Democrats fear that Bush's strength could pull in Joseph Azzolina, Republican, over State Senator Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat, in the battle for the seat of the late Rep. James J. Howard, Democrat. NEW MEXICO: 5 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush ahead in yet another state Dukakis once thought he could win because of its large Hispanic vote. Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat, once thought to be threatened, is now heavily favored. One tough House race is for the seat of retiring Rep. Manuel Lujan Jr., Republican. NEW YORK: 36 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis leads, though race could be close. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will win overwhelmingly. Several close House races: Nita Lowey, Democrat, leads Rep. Joseph J. DioGuardi, Republican, in Westchester County. Rosemary Pooler, Democrat, narrowly lost to Rep. George C. Wortley, a Republican who retired. She has a tougher race against Syracuse City Council President James Walsh, Republican, who leads narrowly. Asesemblyman Bill Paxton, Republican, is leading David Swarts, Democrat, in the battle for Rep. Jack F. Kemp's seat. NORTH CAROLINA: 13 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads, having beaten back a once formidable Dukakis effort. Gov. Jim Martin, Republican, has an edge over Lieut. Gov. Bob Jordan, Democrat. The state has several closely contested House races. In what seems to be the closest, ic Rep. Stephen L. Neal, Democrat, is tested by Lyons Gray, a Republican businessman. NORTH DAKOTA: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads in a state where Dukakis once had a chance. Senator Quentin N. Burdick is 80 years old and has been ill. He has been leading Earl Strinden, Republican, but no one is certain what impact the Senator's health will have. Gov. George Sinner, Democrat, once worried about his prospects, but he leads Leon Mallberg, an antitax crusader. OHIO: 23 ELECTORAL VOTES Crucial to the Dukakis strategy, Ohio appeared close last weekend. But Bush seemed to open up a substantial lead this week. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, one of the most liberal Democrats in the Senate, is well ahead of Mayor George Voinovich, Cleveland's popular Republican Mayor. State Senator Paul Gillmor is favored to hold retiring Rep. Delbert L. Latta's seat for the Republicans. OKLAHOMA: 8 ELECTORAL VOTES Solidly for Bush. OREGON: 7 ELECTORAL VOTES Has been very close, though Dukakis may be winning an edge in a state where he is well-organized. PENNSYLVANIA: 25 ELECTORAL VOTES The Bush campaign has spoken of a surpise victory here, but the closing trend may win for Dukakis. Senator John Heinz will be an easy winner. RHODE ISLAND: 4 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis leads. Republican Senator John H. Chafee leads his energetic Democratic foe, Lieut. Gov. Richard Licht. The race for Governor between the Republican incumbent, Edward DiPrete, and Bruce Sundlun, a Democratic businessman, is bitter and close. Rep. Fernand J. St Germain faces tough challenge from Ronald Machtley, Republican. SOUTH CAROLINA: 8 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush way out in front. Rep. Liz J. Patterson, a freshman Democrat, in jeopardy from Knox White, a 34-year old Republican. SOUTH DAKOTA: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads. TENNESSEE: 11 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush ahead in a state where a Democrat should do better. Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat, is far ahead. John J. Duncan Jr., Republican, is favored to hold his father's House seat, but it could be close. TEXAS: 29 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis chose Senator Lloyd Bentsen as his running mate in large part because he hoped to win Texas. But Bush, who represented Texas in the House, has led since August. Still, polls have shown wildly varying Republican margins, and some showed the contest tightening. Bentsen himself will win re-election easily over Rep. Beau Boulter. Two close House races: one for Boulter's seat, the other a rematch between Rep. Mac Sweeney, Republican, and Greg Laughlin, Democrat. UTAH: 5 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush leads by a vast margin. This could hurt Ted Wilson, the former Mayor of Salt Lake City, a Democrat who seeks to oust Gov. Norman H. Bangerter. Wilson's once large lead has shrunk as Bangerter tried to tie Wilson to Dukakis. An antitax third-party candidate, Merrill Cook, complicates the contest. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican, far out in front. Rep. James V. Hansen, Republican, faces former Rep. Gunn McKay, Democrat, for the third time since 1980. VERMONT: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES The Presidential race is very close with some polls giving Dukakis a slight lead. Rep. Jim Jeffords, a liberal Republican, is favored over Bill Gray, Democrat, for the seat of retiring Senator Robert T. Stafford, Republican. Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin, Democrat, is heavily favored to win a third term. In a three-way fight to succeed Jeffords. Former Lieut. Gov. Peter Smith, Republican, benefits from a split in the non-Republican vote between Paul Poirer, a Democrat and the Vermont House majority leader, and Bernard Sanders, the socialist Mayor of Burlington. VIRGINIA: 12 ELECTORAL VOTES Solidly Bush. Former Gov. Charles Robb, Democrat, strongly favored over Maurice Dawkins, Republican, for the Senate. WASHINGTON: 10 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis and Bush are neck-and-neck. So are Rep. Mike Lowry, Democrat, and former Senator Slade Gorton, Republican, in the battle for the seat being vacated by retiringSenator Daniel J. Evans, Republican. Gov. Booth Gardner, Democrat, is a heavy favorite for re-election. There is a hard-fought rematch between Rep. John R. Miller, Republican, and Reese Lindquist, Democrat. Miller leads. WEST VIRGINIA: 6 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis leads. Senator Robert C. Byrd will be an easy re-election winner. In the Governor's race, Gaston Caperton, a wealthy Democratic businessman, held a large lead over Gov. Arch Moore. But some polls have shown Moore closing the gap. WISCONSIN: 11 ELECTORAL VOTES Dukakis has a slight lead. In the race for retiring Senator William Proxmire's seat, Susan Engeleiter, a 36-year-old Republican State Senator, has been closing the gap against Herb Kohl, a Democratic businessman who is spending heavily on his own race. Kohl still a slight favorite. WYOMING: 3 ELECTORAL VOTES Bush easily. Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican, is ahead of State Senator John Vinich, Democrat, but Democrats say Vinich could be the surprise winner on Tuesday.

title: Steady Rise in Birthrate Squeezes the County's Resources
description: THE number of babies in the county is multiplying rapidly, overwhelming maternity wards and recreation departments, forcing schools to consider expansions and creating consternation among planning officials.

title: Bror Blixen's Virtues
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Lives Were Shattered On the Night of Broken Glass
description: Kristallnacht, the Night of Broken Glass, when hundreds of German and Austrian synagogues were ruthlessly assaulted by Nazis, occurred 50 years ago this coming Wednesday.

title: Only Two More Fighting Days Until Election; People, Not Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopper's World; Gemstones From Maine's Quarries
description: Jewels are not what comes to mind when one thinks of Maine. Regattas, L. L. Bean and lobster, maybe. So it comes as something of a surprise to learn that many of the world's largest and most flawless tourmaline crystals have been mined in the rugged hills of southwestern Maine.

title: TURMOIL IN THE LABS
description: Certainly, there are scientists who play computer war games amid pizza boxes and Coke cans, scientists who regard nuclear-weapons design as simply another research challenge. But there are thousands of scientists who question and defy the arms race.

title: THEATER FOR READERS
description: EUGENE O'NEILL Complete Plays. Edited by Travis Bogard. Volume One: 1913-1920. 1,104 pp. Volume Two: 1920-1931. 1,092 pp. Volume Three: 1932-1943. 1,007 pp. New York: The Library of America.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Life is Easy; Cider Is Hard FOR those who want to get their kick from something other than champagne, be advised that Long Island is now home not only to fine wines but hard cider as well. And in keeping with the Island's upscale style, the hard cider is being sold in artistically labeled bottles in liquor stores throughout the Northeast.

title: Talking: Asbestos If a Report Indicates a Hazard . . .
description: In the last 18 months, asbestos inspection reports have been filed for many older New York City residential buildings to conform with Local Law 76, which became effective April l, 1987, as well as with new regulations from the New York Attorney General's office.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Finding New Use For Old Soldiers
description: THE thought struck Richard G. Stilwell after he retired as an Army general in 1976 that many old soldiers might, like himself, not be willing to fade away.

title: Candidates Woo the State
description: CONNECTICUT has only eight electoral votes - a long way from the 270 needed to elect a President. But, just judging by the attention the state is getting, the little neighbor of New York and Massachusetts is very important to both the Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: Shamir Declines to Insure Change in Law of Return
description: Caught between American Jewry on one side and Israel's newly powerful religious parties on the other, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today declined to say whether he would insure that an amendment defining who is a Jew will become law.

title: DNA Detectives
description: There were two things that the police in Pierce County, Wash., believed for a certainty last year about the rape suspect Alan J. Haynes:

title: ARE THERE A THOUSAND POINTS OF LIGHT?
description: THE LIMITS OF SOCIAL POLICY By Nathan Glazer. 215 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.

title: 4 Quit Yugoslav Posts
description: Four officials resigned Friday from their posts in Kosovo, a province where Serbian nationalists are demanding a purge of the Communist leadership. The press agency Tanjug said two Slavs, Milan Gvozdic and Vojislav Zajic, and two ethnic Albanians, Ekrem Arifi and Rahman Dedai, left Kosovo's 13-member Presidium.

title: A Particular Chunk of Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: The Coming Showdown in Car Insurance
description: American drivers get into 17,500 accidents on an average day, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That adds up to tens of billions of dollars a year in insurance claims and billions more in the premiums drivers pay for their policies.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS U.S. Owes Israel a Warning
description: Those Israelis who are distressed at their country's election results are seeking consolation in the thought that nothing is final in politics. Many look now to the U.S., and especially to American Jews, to press for a reversal of what seems to be a decision against peace.

title: College Football: Midwest; West Va. Goes 9-0; Harris Is Hurt
description: Major Harris threw for three touchdowns before leaving the game with a bruised hip today as West Virginia used big plays to remain unbeaten with a 51-13 victory over Cincinnati.

title: Lawyer Refuses to Testify and Davis Defense Rests
description: The defense rested in the Larry Davis trial last week after the new legal adviser to the New York City police union told the judge that he would invoke his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination if called as a witness for the defense.

title: LAURA DEWART WEDS RAYMOND BARTONE
description: Laura Curtiss Dewart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dewart 3d of Delray Beach, Fla., and Raymond Britt Bartone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Bartone of Garden City, L.I., were married yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Merton T. Rymph performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Patrick Mooney, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SUSAN H. COMPTON IS WED TO RICHARD ALLEN POLLARD
description: Susan Hurlbut Compton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Robert Compton Jr. of Andover Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Allen Pollard, a son of Mary McKeag of Dunedin, Fla., and the late Ernest I. Pollard. The Rev. Joseph Herring, assisted by the Rev. John Porter, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Newton, N.J.

title: Beams of Light That Help Heal the Sick
description: Lasers are becoming an increasingly common surgical tool, used in the offices of medical specialists, outpatient surgical centers, and hospitals throughout the country. These powerful beams of light are used to treat disease and discomfort quite literally from head to toe: from reducing the pressure of excess fluid in the eye associated with glaucoma to the removal of tonsils and hemorrhoids to the treatment of warts on the soles of the feet.

title: A Landmark Restaurant in Brooklyn Is Sold
description: Gage & Tollner, the landmark Brooklyn seafood and chop house, has been sold to a partnership headed by Peter Aschkenasy, a Manhattan restaurateur.

title: The Race for Congress; Enemy in California Is Voter Apathy
description: The costliest Senate race in the country is almost over, and it seems that almost nobody has noticed it go by.

title: Friends Recall Young Artist With Music and Verse
description: It was all very downtown, except that it was uptown, as about 220 of Jean Michel Basquiat's friends and admirers packed a Manhattan church yesterday to pay tribute to the artist who died in August at the age of 27.

title: Algeria Names a Prime Minister
description: President Chadli Benjedid appointed a Prime Minister today and asked him to form a new government to begin solving the country's economic crisis, the Algerian press agency reported.

title: Hanoi Considers Reviving Business Courses
description: Vietnam, which abolished its school of business administration as an unneeded vestige of capitalism after the Communist victory in 1975, is considering the reintroduction of some business courses, according to a professor at Georgetown University who has been asked to help in the effort.

title: 'Rosy' Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Faults Firm Headed by an Associate
description: Vice President Bush says it was wrong for a consulting firm run by a longtime associate of his to cite political connections in an effort to acquire new business.

title: At 12, 'Little Wizard' Is Off to a Big Start
description: POISED behind a black stage emblazoned with a fire-breathing emerald green dragon, Rodger Phillips, attired in top hat and tails, explained his patter.

title: RETAILER UNDER FIRE: Edward A. Brennan; Shielding Sears From Would-Be Raiders
description: Edward A. Brennan, the man who put the world's tallest building on the auction block last week, is attempting to redefine Sears, Roebuck & Company for its 526,000 employees, 328,000 shareholders, 10,000 suppliers, and 70 million household customers.

title: Question Of the Week; What Do You Think About the Jockeys' Strike?
description: It's about time the horse owners started to have a little sympathy toward the betting public. We were being deprived of watching the world's greatest jockeys, but what is more important, if a horse finished an easy first, it stands to reason that if the second and third place finishers were allocated a diminishing percentage of the purse, then much fairer results would occur on place and show betting, which would ultimately make racing better for the bettor all round. DAVID MCMILLAN Richmond Hill, Queens

title: KATHERINE MCDONOUGH WED
description: Katherine Ann McDonough, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. McDonough of Methuen, Mass., and Mark Frank Dichter, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Dichter of New York, were married yesterday at the New York home of Phyllis and Ira Wender. Judge Michael B. Mukasey of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated. Mrs. Dichter is a managing director of Adams & Rinehart, the corporate and financial public relations subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather. Her husband is president of Audiomated Devices, a sound recording engineering firm. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: To Hear Sharpest Advertising Attacks, Tune In to the Radio
description: What evil lurks in the heart of the 1988 political campaign, only radio knows.

title: Jazz's Future: A Soviet View
description: LEAD: ''When jazz first began, there was only American jazz. Then came a period when we were talking about European jazz, Asian jazz, South American jazz, African jazz. Now we are entering a third phase, when we have an Armenian playing with an Estonian, a Norwegian playing with a Turk. Look at Jan Garbarak, Scandinavian to his fingertips, and he's playing with Ravi Shankar from India, Eberhard Weber from Germany.

title: MARGARET MILLARD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Margaret Mary Millard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. Millard of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher J. McGrath, a son of Mrs. James J. McGrath of Douglaston, Queens, and the late Mr. McGrath. The Rev. Gerald F. Kinsella performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn.

title: A Faster, Very Versatile Processor
description: One of the most fascinating components of the Next Computer System introduced last month by Stephen Jobs is the high-speed digital signal processing chip that is built directly into the system.

title: ALISON ANN CROSS TO WED A DENTIST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur L. Cross 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Alison Ann Cross to Dr. John Phillip Blatz Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Blatz of Dedham, Mass. The couple plan to marry in the spring.

title: MISS MCDONALD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Kathryn Frances McDonald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McDonald of Hackettstown, N.J., was married yesterday to Kurt Timothy Doctor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ivan S. Doctor of Southfield, Mich. The Rev. Gary C. Hauze performed the ceremony at the Salem United Church of Christ in Doylestown, Pa.

title: The Professors Who Make a Case
description: Seated anxiously on the witness stand with a jury eyeing him skeptically, Anthony Kiorpes was talking about llamas. As the defense lawyer peppered him with questions, Mr. Kiorpes explained methodically how, in his opinion, a certain six-week-old llama had died of starvation and not of electrocution. The audience listened with rapt attention.

title: Political Notes; MOYNIHAN IS THE MISSING MAN IN DUKAKIS'S NEW YORK EFFORT
description: The infighting in political campaigns is often as interesting as the public part of the campaigning itself.

title: At Solomon Trial, a Focus on Victims' Rights
description: THE first witness in the murder trial of Matthew Solomon shifted nervously in the witness box. Dressed in a black pants suit, Diane Weaver, Lisa Solomon's mother, seemed overwhelmed as she looked out at the sea of faces staring back at her. Waiting for the prosecutor, Timothy Mazzei, to begin his questions, Mrs. Weaver looked first at the clench-jawed defendant, her former son-in-law, Matthew Solomon, now on trial for murdering her daughter.

title: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED/(Housing units)
description: Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES/(Averages)

title: Dramatist, 20, Earns Plaudits
description: ''I'VE always loved words and the things you can do with them, and the idea that I could invent my own world and tell people what to say within it appealed to me. So I sat down at the typewriter I got for my 13th birthday and wrote a play,'' Jonathan Marc Sherman said in a speech to high school students last summer.

title: 10 Actors in 25 Family Roles
description: ON the minuscule stage of the Renegade Theater Company, an epic of sorts is supposed to be taking place: 10 actors assume 25 roles, spanning four generations within five Midwestern families, from 1911 to the present.

title: Inspired Plotting?
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbra Streisand and the Showstopper Syndrome
description: In the dreamy fadeout of ''Till I Loved You,'' the title song of Barbra Streisand's first album in three years (Columbia 40880; all three formats), the star and her singing partner, Don Johnson, burst into peals of forced laughter. Listening to Mr. Johnson's ''ho ho ho's'' answered by Ms. Streisand's nervous giggling, one must assume that the impression intended is of two carefree lovers boarding a glittering musical barge to sail off into the sunset like a modern-day Antony and Cleopatra. That, however, is not quite the impression they leave.

title: A Quest That Now Seems Quaint
description: The quest to have photography treated as an equal partner of painting and sculpture has been going on since the mid-19th century. It has been responsible for some of the most provocative images taken with the camera, and it has occasioned a seemingly endless string of attempts to convince the art world, once and for all, that photography is a medium of expression as well as of description.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LAST OF HOW IT WAS, by T. R. Pearson. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Spun from twisted tales about life in rural North Carolina, this novel completes T. R. Pearson's trilogy about a mythical town called Neely. Last year, Patricia Henley said here that ''the language, earthy and elaborate, creates a world the reader will long to return to with the same abandonment of the real world one might have experienced as a child - the complete entering into the writer's dream.'' WALTZING WITH A DICTATOR: The Marcoses and the Making of American Policy, by Raymond Bonner. (Vintage, $11.95.) When Ferdinand Marcos declared martial law in 1972, Raymond Bonner writes, he cleared the move in advance with President Nixon, to whose political campaigns he may have contributed as much as a million dollars. By documenting the symbiotic relationship between the Philippine dictator and American military and business interests, Mr. Bonner has made ''a signal achievement,'' Richard H. Ullman said here last year. His ''meticulous investigation makes it plain that the Marcoses' depredations were well known to United States diplomats in Manila and to their superiors in Washington.'' THE COLOR OF BLOOD, by Brian Moore. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $7.95.) As head of the moral opposition to a repressive regime, an Eastern European cardinal becomes caught in a dangerous political balancing act. ''Almost in thriller form, [ the novel ] is also a wise and illuminating meditation on the labyrinthine forces at work in a Roman Catholic Communist country like Poland,'' Clancy Sigal said here last year. BOTTOMS UP! A Pathologist's Essays on Medicine and the Humanities, by William B. Ober. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) By day a pathologist and assistant medical examiner, at night William B. Ober writes historical essays on such kinky arcana as flagellation and the sadomasochistic influences in the madrigals of the 16th-century composer Carlo Gesualdo. ''The author is that rarest of birds - a master of lore in both the sciences and the arts,'' Richard Selzer said here last year. ''If the gift of prophecy has not deserted me, Dr. Ober will be quoted by others a hundred years from now.'' Also available from the publisher is Dr. Ober's BOSWELL'S CLAP AND OTHER ESSAYS ($8.95). Named for the gonorrhea that bedeviled Dr. Johnson's biographer, the book includes disquisitions on how medical and psychosexual afflictions shaped the art of Swinburne, D. H. Lawrence and other literati. WAITING FOR CHILDHOOD, by Sumner Locke Elliott. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Following the separate fates of seven members of an Australian family around the time of World War I, Sumner Locke Elliott conducts a fictional tour of a continent about to enter the modern world. ''The various narratives are so sensitively and refreshingly told, so neatly developed and carefully interwoven, that it is difficult not to be captivated by the sheer literary virtuosity of it all,'' A. R. Gurney said in The Book Review last year. SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR: A Life . . . a Love Story, by Claude Francis and Fernande Gontier. Translated by Lisa Nesselson. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) ''My life would be a beautiful story come true,'' wrote Simone de Beauvoir, the feminist writer and lover of Jean-Paul Sartre, ''a story I would make up as I went along.'' Last year our reviewer, Benjamin Ivry, called this biography ''a lucid, appealingly human account. . . . Indeed, there is a joie de vivre about this book . . . that explains why it might have been a lot of fun to be an existentialist.'' FLIPPING FOR IT, by Daniel Asa Rose. (St. Martin's, $7.95.) A young zoologist cannot understand for the life of him why his wife is leaving him for another man. Despite some histrionic prose, this first novel by a winner of the O. Henry Prize for short fiction ''is told with freshness, humor and . . . great openness of heart,'' Richard Goodman said here last year. DARK VICTORY: Ronald Reagan, MCA, and the Mob, by Dan E. Moldea. (Penguin, $7.95.) When he was president of the Screen Actors Guild in the 1950's, Ronald Reagan helped negotiate a deal that enabled his agent, MCA, to develop an entertainment monopoly, the author writes, that had connections with organized crime. The book contains ''interesting reading'' about Mr. Reagan's Hollywood past, Jeff Gerth said here in 1986, ''but falls short in showing that old ties make for current scandal.'' CAPTAIN BLACKMAN, by John A. Williams. (Thunder's Mouth, $10.95.) Running roughshod through American military history, a black soldier fights in the Revolutionary War, the Civil War, the War of 1812, the Battle of San Juan Hill and, finally, in Vietnam. ''The novel seems to say that the only reason black and white soldiers have not killed each other more often is that there has always been someone else to kill first,'' George Davis said here in 1972. '' 'Captain Blackman' is a boldly experimental way to get this all down.'' The same publisher has reissued Mr. Williams's novel SISSIE ($9.95), the story of a young black playwright, his sister and their mother. In 1963, Ernest Buckler said that the book put its author in the same league as James Baldwin and Ralph Ellison. THURSDAY'S UNIVERSE, by Marcia Bartusiak. (Tempus, $8.95.) Developments in astronomy are coming so fast, our reviewer, Laurence A. Marschall, said in 1986, that Marcia Bartusiak's ''authoritative'' book about cosmology should be read with dispatch. ''For a few years at least [ it ] can render the arcana of astrophysical research understandable to the public.'' To insure even greater longevity, the author has added an epilogue about the birth of last year's supernova.

title: Reviews/Dance; Flamenco Expresses 'Guernica'
description: The Zorongo Flamenco Dance Theater opened the Hispanic Heritage Month Dance Series at the Triplex on Wednesday with a probing, well-considered look at war and fate. ''Gernika,'' a full-evening piece conceived and choreographed by Susana di Palma, director of the Minneapolis-based company, was inspired by Picasso's ''Guernica'' and the act of carnage that inspired that painting. In moving program notes to the flamenco ballet, Miss di Palma writes that the 1937 bombing of the Spanish town of Gernika, in the Basque spelling, was ''the first event in the world of saturation, incendiary bombing of a civilian population.''

title: Commuter's Life: A Tale Told in Lines in Time and Space
description: THIS marks the 20th year I have been commuting to work in Manhattan (with a few years out living abroad).

title: RUNNING AWAY
description: As a probation officer with 20 years of experience working with teen-age offenders and their families, I would like to make a few comments. The author describes a number of criminal acts committed by April Savino: assaulting her mother with a knife and a television set, breaking a bottle over the head of a man who cursed at her, stealing her grandmother's jewelry, stealing a bagel truck, using illegal drugs, trespassing and stealing the firearm she allegedly used to kill herself.

title: Takeovers: A Friendly Climate
description: As the giants of American industry are bought up for ever-increasing billions, the frenzy of deal-making on Wall Street might seem to show the financial world's creative juices at work. But none of it would happen without tax and antitrust policies that can be considered a Federal blessing for this sort of activity.

title: Camera; Is Picture Taking Too Automatic?
description: SOONER or later it was bound to happen: the auto-everything backlash. As much of the world rushes to buy cameras that take control of the entire process of picture taking, some old-fashioned photographers are mounting a rear-guard protest.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 6, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 5 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families after the Civil War. 3 5 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 4 7 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent. 5 7 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 6 4 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 7 1 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 8 * 5 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The effects of a violent death. 9 2 FAVORITE SON, by Steve Sohmer. (Bantam, $4.95.) The phantasmagoria that follows a televised attempted assassination of a senator. 10 5 HEAVEN CENT, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $4.50.) A young prince's search for a missing sorcerer. 11 * 4 THE MAIDEN, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) The passion of a warrior princess. 12 * 7 LONIGAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $3.50.) Six short stories about the American frontier. 13 * 2 GLITTERING IMAGES, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Sex, love, self-analysis and reverence in English clerical circles. 14 17 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists. 15 29 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis. 16 * 1 SEARCH THE SHADOWS, by Barbara Michaels. (Berkley, $4.50.) A young woman's quest for the truth about her parentage threatens her life. 17 * 4 MEMORY PRIME, by Gar and Judith Reeves- Stevens. (Pocket, $3.95.) A new ''Star Trek'' novel. $ Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 24 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.)
