title: Why Hospitals Love Diets
description: ''Debbie, let me tell you a story,'' said one of the steadily shrinking women. ''For the first time since I got on the program, I served my all-time favorite: Empire barbecued chicken. Before I served it, I was careful. I took the skin off. I wiped off the fat. But I really didn't enjoy it as much as I remembered. My tastes have changed.''

title: YOON-MIE RHEE, A PIANIST, IS WED
description: Yoon-Mie Rhee, a pianist, and Dr. Harry P. Koo, a resident in surgery at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, were married yesterday at the Korean Grace Presbyterian Church in Rutherford, N.J. The Rev. Myung Ho Yoon performed the ceremony.

title: Buying a Hotel for Homeless Studied
description: LEAD: THE County Board of Legislators is to act tomorrow on a resolution to study the economic implications of buying and renovating the Tarrytown Hilton Hotel to house and train the homeless. The resolution will be introduced by Edward J. Brady of Thornwood, the Board's chairman, who last week called for the purchase of the 27-year-old, 243-room hotel, which is for sale.

title: Bridge; An Rx for Game
description: THE profession of surgeon is so time consuming that its practitioners rarely have time to play bridge. Two notable exceptions come to mind, one on each side of the Atlantic. In England, Rodney Smith a former head of the Royal College of Surgeons, now sits as Lord Smith in the House of Lords and represents that body in annual matches against the House of Commons. Thanks in part to his skill, the Upper House has the upper hand. They lead in the series 8-6.

title: FICTION
description: THE WHORE OF TJAMPUAN. By Harry Kondoleon. (PAJ Publications, $15.95.) Sardonic humor and verbal inventiveness enliven this strange, ultimately sad tale of a young man wandering through ''the terrible emptiness of a life exiled from love.'' The playwright Harry Kondoleon begins this first novel on the island of Bali, but it might just as well be New York, Rome, Singapore, Bangkok or any of the other places where the aimless, unhappy protagonist, Frank Klingensmith, has taken drugs, fought off craziness and had sex with a variety of peculiar people. In essence, ''The Whore of Tjampuan'' is simply another 1980's youth adrift saga. It's redeemed, however, by Mr. Kondoleon's flair for characterization and imaginative way with words. Though the cast is large for such a slender novel, each individual is strikingly defined with wit and measured sympathy. Among the more memorable are the misleadingly named title character, a respectable housewife who serves Texas-style chili in her Balinese restaurant, and Frank's parents, who watch television all day in their squalid apartment, commenting loudly on the personalities' physical attributes. While he is less vivid than these subsidiary figures, Frank holds a rather scattered narrative together by telling their stories in his own distinctive voice, which combines a sharp eye for absurdity with an ironic appreciation for the reasoning, however skewed, behind the bizarre things people do to cope with a chaotic universe. ''The Whore of Tjampuan'' has more style than substance, but its offbeat imagery and snappy prose give it considerable charm.

title: VIVIENNE MARY TOBIN WED TO BRENDAN DOYLE ON S.I.
description: The marriage of Vivienne Mary Tobin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tobin of Todt Hill, S.I., to Brendan Doyle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Doyle of New York, took place yesterday. Msgr. John C. McCarthy performed the ceremony at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in Castleton Corners, S.I.

title: SHARON WILSON IS BRIDE
description: The marriage of Sharon Flynn Wilson, a real-estate broker in West Hartford, Conn., to Michael M. Michigami, president of United Technolgies Control Systems in Farmington, Conn., took place yesterday at the Hartford Golf Club in West Hartford. The Rev. Arnold T. Wangerin, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dorothy R. Wilson of Ponte Vedra and St. Augustine, Fla. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Masashi Michigami of Sacramento, Calif.

title: 3 Million Expected to Cast Ballots
description: AFTER weeks of being bombarded by negative campaign messages, New Jersey voters will go to the polls Tuesday to cast ballots for President, United States Senator, 14 Representatives, and scores of county and municipal offices. Voters will also decide four statewide ballot questions.

title: Hit My Hot Button
description: What's a hot button?'' Newsweek asked itself in the homestretch of the 1988 campaign. ''It's something a candidate says to instantly show that his values are the voters' values.'' The newsmagazine, in the forefront of popularizers of this phrase, listed Republican >hot buttons as the American Civil Liberties Union, abortion and guns, and those of the Democrats as Social Security and Panamanian leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: My Mother, My Muse
description: Dedications tell a story. ''To Vera,''

title: People Are Yearning For a Leader, but Expecting Much Less
description: Twenty-five years ago this month, in what seems like another era, John F. Kennedy was killed by an assassin's bullet in Dallas. His murder marked a sea change in American politics. Before that awful day in 1963, most Presidents in this century had found it relatively easy to command the affection and the respect of a majority of the citizenry; since then, only Ronald Reagan has consistently managed to do that. The others - Johnson and Carter, Nixon and Ford -have had to contend with ever-growing public dissatisfaction with the whole political process.

title: GOING TO PIECES OVER MASTERPIECES
description: ''I don't know what's happening to me,'' the American woman at a nearby table said over breakfast in the Pensione Bartoli in Florence, ''I don't seem to be able to function.'' She stared off in the distance and ignored her caffe latte.

title: Wide Drive Pressed For Better Insurance On Long-Term Care
description: Battered by adverse publicity and spurred by the threat of Congressional action, state insurance commissioners and the health insurance industry are moving to improve the benefits of insurance covering long-term care of the elderly and the disabled.

title: Reworking the Classics: Homage or Ego Trip?
description: The most controversial issue in the theater today continues to be the reinterpretation or ''deconstruction'' of celebrated classical plays. There is no theatrical activity that more inflames purist sensibilities in criticism and the academy - nothing that stimulates as many caustic generalizations about the debasements of modern culture. Perhaps because ''deconstruction'' as an assonant noun if not as a method, is so perilously close to ''destruction'' and ''desecration,'' the standard purist posture is like that of Switzers before the gates of the Vatican, defending sacred texts against the barbarians. The paradox is that both sides are really devoted to the same esthetic purpose, which is the deeper penetration of significant dramatic literature. The difference is in the attitude. Is classical reinterpretation a reinforcing or a defiling act - a benign or a malignant development in the history of modern theater?

title: ANNE HELEN ARMSTRONG WED TO HARLAN COBEN
description: The marriage of Anne Helen Armstrong and Harlan Fgeoffrey Coben, both graduates of Amherst College, took place yesterday in the Johnson Chapel on the college campus in Amherst, Mass. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Daniel Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: LOVE BEYOND THE FENCES
description: HEART MOUNTAIN By Gretel Ehrlich. 412 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: LIKE INTERPRETING THE DREAMS OF PHARAOH
description: ORIGINAL INTENT AND THE FRAMERS' CONSTITUTION By Leonard W. Levy. 525 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: National Horse Show; At 17, an Ex-Hockey Player Now Aims at Top Junior Title
description: David Oliynyk looks like a quarterback, used to be a hockey player, but now, at 17, is hoping to be named the best junior rider in North America in the Rolex-Maclay Championship at the National Horse Show this afternoon.

title: FICTION
description: SPOCK'S WORLD. By Diane Duane. (Pocket Books, $16.95.) For those of us truly committed to the voyages of the Starship Enterprise and its quirky, familiar crew, there are very few unknown details, few legends left unexplored. But Diane Duane, the author of three earlier ''Star Trek'' books, has written the one irresistible story for any true Trekker: the ''history'' of the planet Vulcan, home of the Enterprise's stoic first officer, Mr. Spock. ''Spock's World,'' the latest of the ''Star Trek'' novels and the first to be published in hard cover, links the development of the fictional planet's tradition of logic and suppression of emotion with a fairly suspenseful story line that involves the possible withdrawal of Vulcan from the United Federation of Planets. The call to withdraw - a carefully engineered plot from a surprising, but ultimately logical source - is a disaster in the making. It would end the careers of both Spock and his father, Sarek, the Vulcan representative to the federation, and result in the exile of his parents from Vulcan, since every good fan knows that Spock's mother, Amanda, is human. Ms. Duane's meld of ''history'' and ''Star Trek'' lore creates a narrative that readers unfamiliar with the legendary television show may find difficult to follow. But if, like most Trekkers, you've watched the ''Journey to Babel'' and ''Amok Time'' episodes a dozen times, here is your chance to discover how Sarek and Amanda really met, whether it's true that Vulcans have no feelings and what happened to T'Pau, Vulcan's cranky and reclusive leader. Ultimately, ''Spock's World'' is an insular one; only a few million ''Star Trek'' fans will know or care what's going on.

title: Dukakis: Honest, Practical
description: I doubt many people have enjoyed this campaign much.

title: Sports People; Lalonde Speaks
description: HE called Sugar Ray Leonard ''an old welterweight'' and predicted he would knock him out tomorrow night when the two fight for the World Boxing Council light heavyweight title and the W.B.C.'s newly created supermiddleweight title in Las Vegas, Nev. And at the final news conference before the fight, Donny Lalonde, who has exuded confidence in the weeks leading up to the biggest bout in his career, said: ''I'm a hard-punching light heavyweight and I'm fighting a welterweight, an old welterweight.''

title: Ads Seek Volunteer Firefighters
description: LEAD: COUNTY officials have begun a new advertising campaign designed to increase the public's interest in putting out fires.

title: F.B.I. Agent Held in Sex Case
description: An F.B.I. agent was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing young boys on the Long Island soccer team he coached, a spokesman for the bureau's New York office said.

title: Albany to Study Striped Bass
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation will conduct a $54,000 study to figure out where the striped bass found in New York's coastal waters are spawned and nurtured.

title: College Football: South; A Rally by L.S.U. Defeats Alabama
description: David Browndyke's 34-yard field goal with 28 seconds remaining lifted Louisiana State to a 19-18 comeback victory over Alabama in a Southeastern Conference first-place showndown today.

title: New Highway Robbery: Poles and Guard Rails
description: SGT. SCOTT R. O'MARA of the police thought he had seen about every type of thievery, until reports started coming in about the stealing of guard rails, lampposts and highway signs.

title: Survival Courses For Freshmen
description: There was a time, not too long ago, when colleges largely ignored their newest students. Then, freshmen were counted on having reserves of sense, ambition and pluck that would carry them through four years of higher education intact.

title: Miami News Seeks to Extend Operating Pact With Herald
description: The owner of The Miami News is seeking to extend its joint operating agreement with The Miami Herald from 1996 until Dec. 31, 2021.

title: Where Art and Life Go Hand in Hand
description: LEAD: THE first time Yass Hakoshima went to the lumberyard, he didn't know what to ask for. Sixteen years ago, this international mime artist bought an abandoned stable here and had it moved two lots down Midland Avenue so he could begin the process of creating a home out of empty space, an extension of the art form that constitutes his daily fare.

title: 2 Worlds Overlap for a Grandmother
description: GRANDMOTHER'S thoughts have a special kind of deja vu. When I tuck my hand under the head of our brand-new grandchild and gently raise her to my shoulder, I think, ''I've been here before.''

title: Wildcare Must Seek a New Home For Itself
description: LEAD: WILDCARE has been taking injured birds under its wing and nursing them back to health since 1982 and now the nonprofit group is seeking a new home.

title:
ART;
Drawing Lines: East End Anthology
description: LEAD: ''DRAWING ON THE EAST END, 1940 - 1988,'' at the Parrish Art Museum, is one of the most important anthology exhibitions on Long Island in some time.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE GRAND COMPROMISE
description: THE MASTER OF THE GAME Paul Nitze and the Nuclear Peace. By Strobe Talbott. 416 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: THE FLIP SIDE OF DAD
description: THE LAST FARMER An American Memoir. By Howard Kohn. 270 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: The Bloody Hills of Burundi
description: Along the red dirt roads of northern Burundi, tall peasant women in ground-length dresses of neon green, iridescent red, royal purple and citrus yellow saunter with perfectly straight backs, baskets brimming with fruit and fresh vegetables stacked on their heads. The pink flowers of frangipani trees and vermillion hibiscus frame the route, casting an aura of Gauguin's Tahiti.

title: Kent
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the article on Chartwell by Joe Mysak, ''Churchill's Sanctuary in Kent'' (Travel, Aug. 28). It was very informative and should encourage readers to visit, or revisit, that very special place. On my first visit to Chartwell in 1976, I realized why Churchill was able to do so much creative work there. It is the kind of place that could easily inspire one to do great things. Let's hope, though, that the peace and tranquillity of Chartwell will not be spoiled by the influx of too many visitors. T. J. KLEIN Groton, Conn.

title: NICE GUYS DON'T WIN NOBEL PRIZES
description: SCIENCE AS A PROCESS An Evolutionary Account of the Social and Conceptual Development of Science. By David L. Hull. Illustrated. 586 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $39.95.

title: Crossover and Cross Back: You Can Go Home Again
description: Last year, Los Lobos racked up a No. 1 single with a remake of Ritchie Valens's rock oldie, ''La Bamba.'' Early this year, Ruben Blades, the Panamanian songwriter and salsa superstar with a Harvard law degree, put out ''Nothing But the Truth,'' his first album of songs in English.

title: T. L. MCLEOD MARRIES LAUREN B. WASSERMAN
description: Lauren Beth Wasserman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Wasserman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there last evening to Thomas Lawrence McLeod, a son of Thomas W. McLeod of Gaithersburg, Md., and Evelina Schlageter of Coral Springs, Fla. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club.

title: KEAN PLANS TO CURB GROWTH, WITH OR WITHOUT THE LEGISLATURE
description: WHEN their environmental bills are blocked in the State Legislature, New Jersey governors have found a detour around the obstacle: They reach for the pen to accomplish by fiat what they have been unable to do through negotiation.

title:
Numismatics;
The Era Of Wonder Coins
description: LEAD: PROOF and mint-state coins, the ones in greatest demand today, are graded on a scale from 60 to 70, with 70 representing perfection. Supergrade or wonder coins are graded between 66 and 70. These coins are bringing spectacular prices and buyers are wondering if they are really worth the money.

title: Kabul Draws Line at Power Sharing, for Now
description: Afghanistan's Prime Minister has said he is seeking immediate talks on a political settlement with the guerrillas battling his Government and its Soviet protectors.

title: Portable CD's Are Now Rivaling Home Models
description: So much attention has recently been focused on innovative developments in full-sized home CD players that improvements in portable models have largely gone unremarked.

title: NONFICTION
description: STEALING FROM A DEEP PLACE: Travels in Southeastern Europe. By Brian Hall. (Hill & Wang, $18.95.) Shortly after graduating from Harvard in 1981, Brian Hall set off on a bicycling tour of Europe with no goal other than the determination to shed the kind of provincialism that is born of, and nurtured by, 17 years of uninterrupted schooling. After several months of cycling in Western Europe, Mr. Hall, suddenly bored, decided to spend the fall exploring three ''more secretive, more elusive'' countries: Rumania, Bulgaria and Hungary. ''Stealing From a Deep Place,'' Mr. Hall's fluidly written chronicle of that journey, alternates between novelistic accounts of the adventures and misadventures of a solitary American traveling through the remote countryside and incisive observations on the history and politics of the region. Mr. Hall seems particularly interested in the daily lives of individuals he meets along the way. In Budapest, he finds that his friends' scathing remarks about Russia mask a deep concern for Hungary's national integrity under Soviet influence. Mr. Hall's patience wears thin in Rumania, where he encounters lazy customs officials, untended roads and a lack of food, which he indignantly attributes to a government more concerned with industrialization than feeding its own population. He sketches many memorable characters from Bulgaria, including Stilyan, the shady finagler, decked out in polyester and pointy-toed boots, who insists on ''helping'' Mr. Hall when his bike breaks down; and Yordan, the monk who becomes an unlikely drinking partner one cold November evening. People, much more than sites, stimulate Mr. Hall's keenest observations. The result is a book that transcends any notion of a typical tour guide.

title: Bottle Issue On Ballot In Mercer
description: LEAD: THE first countywide bottle ordinance in New Jersey - to require refundable beverage containers - will go before Mercer County voters on Tuesday and, if adopted, will become a part of the county's total recycling plan.

title: Choosing Wood Paneling
description: SHOPPING for building panels to use in construction or other projects can be perplexing unless you are familiar with the types of materials available and how they are graded.

title: Baseball; Dodgers Seem Destined To Lose Marshall and Sax
description: No one has to yell ''break up the Dodgers.'' The World Series champions are breaking themselves up.

title: Violence Worsens in South Korean Protests
description: Thousands of South Koreans battled with riot policemen in downtown Seoul today after the authorities blocked a planned march on the home of former President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: This Election Day, Let's Pick The Best President for New Jersey
description: Ocean pollution, the need for afffordable housing and educational inequities between rich and poor school districts. These and a host of other issues are facing New Jersey and its eight million citizens as we approach the 1990's. It has become increasly clear over the years that these and other problems facing our state cannot and clearly should not, be exclusively addressed by the state and local governments.

title:
INVESTING;
Playing Toy Company Stocks
description: LEAD: In past years, some lucky investors have made a lot of money by guessing correctly which new toys would be the hit of the Christmas-Hanukkah season. A trendy toy could be worth hundreds of millions of dollars in holiday sales to the lucky manufacturer, pushing up its stock price.

title: Man in Child's Death Committed to Hospital
description: A Southington man who asserted that God directed him to kill his daughter in April has been committed to a state mental hospital.

title: INQUIRY IS DELAYED IN PENTAGON FRAUD
description: A Federal bribery investigation involving Defense Department contracts has been delayed by the refusal of several principal suspects to cooperate with the authorities, Government officials and defense lawyers connected to the inquiry say.

title: Pro Hockey; Islanders End Losing Streak
description: Bryan Murray, his head bent in discussion with the line he planned on sending out next, never saw the goal. The coach of the Capitals, though, didn't have to raise his head to figure out what had happened. He merely had to remember a couple of simple, painful facts: 1) it was overtime; 2) the Capitals were playing the Islanders; 3) Pat LaFontaine was on the ice.

title: S.M.U. Cry: Wait Till '89
description: IT'S that time of year again, when the powerhouses of big-time college football are clinching conference championships and looking forward to postseason bowl games.

title: 'Spiritual' Tibetan Finds A Life in 'Material' U.S.
description: When Thubten Samphel visited a Tibetan monastery near Clifton, N.J., he was surprised to find one of the monks waiting at the bus station in a car to drive him there.

title: Deaf Truck Driver's Roadblock is a Federal Rule
description: From his home in Bridgton, Me., the very young Michael Cousins watched the big tractor-trailers roll silently by. The great rigs were the boy's dream: He wanted to be a truck driver.

title: Premiere of Mystery in Fairfield
description: ''ARE YOU SURE,'' presented by the Boston Post Road Stage Company, is one of those pretentious, pseudo-mysteries that purports to keep one guessing who's who, who's alive and what's real. Since it seems that the playwright, Sam Bobrick, would rather titillate than tell, one's patience is likely to expire before the play does, which grinds the evening down to one crucial question: ''Who cares?''

title: College Football; Army Easily Beats Air Force
description: Flushed with emotion after one of the biggest victories in his six seasons as Army's football coach, Jim Young said, ''We're going to a bowl.''

title: Sports of The Times; Opening Night: Old and Fresh
description: SOME might say it was another opening of another Shaw, and some might rather not. Fact is, there may have never been quite such a Shaw as Brian in the National Basketball Association before this, and certainly not for the Celtics.

title: Whose Movement?
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Brief Describes Illegal New York Dumping
description: The Federal authorities have determined that medical, construction and household garbage was mixed with waste dredged from the New York City waterfront in 1987 and dumped illegally in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Party Levers a Factor by Absence
description: LEAD: Tuesday's vote will be the first statewide balloting in Connecticut without party levers and some politicians and analysts expect that to mean shorter coattails for the winning Presidential candidate. The Democrats hope it will also mean an end to a pattern of Republican gains in legislative races in

title: MAKING US BELIEVE
description: LEAD: THE SHORT STORY Henry James to Elizabeth Bowen. By John Bayley. 197 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $35.

title: Christiana, Del.: Regional Malls Plan Expansion
description: The owners of Delaware's two regional shopping malls have both announced plans for major expansion and renovation.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: White Mischief Starring Sarah Miles, Joss Ackland, John Hurt, Greta Scacchi, Charles Dance, Geraldine Chaplin, Trevor Howard. Directed by Michael Radford. 1988. Nelson Entertainment. 107 minutes. $89.98. Rated R.

title: Works by Power Boothe in Stamford and Greenwich
description: POWER BOOTHE has been getting critical attention for more than a decade as a painter, film maker and set designer. He may even have received good notices for plumbing, that being his principal means of support. But it is as a painter that he is starring now at two galleries - the Hurlbutt Gallery at the Greenwich Library and the PMW Gallery in Stamford.

title: New Findings on '34 Ship Disaster
description: AN aspiring author who has obtained numerous Federal records on the Morro Castle, the passenger ship that burned off the coast of New Jersey in 1934 and came to rest on the beach in Asbury Park, says that his new account of the disaster will change how it is viewed by history.

title: A Trip to Find Furniture, and Myself
description: IT was like the death of childhood . . . ''like'' nothing: it was the death of childhood.

title: Bathhouse Project is Stalled
description: LEAD: Plans to renovate the Olympic-size pool and lockers at the Jones Beach East Bathhouse have received setback after setback, and the facilities could remain closed for another two years.

title: Dancing, With Misha
description: Fitness apparel doesn't usually rate a full fashion show, unless the line carries the name of Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: POCANTICO CONCERTS Stained-glass windows designed by Marc Chagall and Henri Matisse will provide a vivid setting for a series of three one-hour chamber-music concerts at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in North Tarrytown, performed by members of the Westchester-based Philharmonia Virtuosi.

title: No One Has Ever Done Goodbye Like Cooz
description: I once asked my mother if she had ever seen my dad cry. She said twice: when John F. Kennedy was assassinated and when Bob Cousy retired. The Kennedy tragedy, of course, happened on Nov. 22, 1963. Cousy retired eight months earlier in a very emotional ceremony at Boston Garden. I'm not sure if my dad has cried since, but I know no one has ever come up to me and said, ''Do you remember exactly where you were when you heard Bob Cousy retired?''

title: The Mood
description: Coast to coast, north to south, the dominant reaction to the Presidential campaign has been disappointment verging on disgust. Voters yearn for a leader, but expect much less. The Week in Review, Section 4. As one of the legion of non-voters said, ''I don't care who you have in there unless it's God Himself.'' An informal survey finds her view is common among those who will stay home on Tuesday. Page 43.

title: Sports of The Times; Leonard's Missing Voice
description: THE corner. Fights are won between rounds in the corner as often as they are decided in the ring itself. And it's not as if Sugar Ray Leonard's corner will be empty. Janks Morton and Ray Jacobs will be there, as they have all along. Two good men and true. So will Eddie Aliano, the new cut man. But his master's voice will be missing. For the first time in Leonard's pro boxing career Angelo Dundee won't be in the corner tomorrow night. Maybe it won't make much difference. Even at age 32 after only two fights in the last six years, Leonard is expected to handle Donny Lalonde as easily as a 3-1 favorite should.

title: Judge Refuses to Limit Time in Voting Booth
description: A state law limiting people to 10 minutes in the voting booth was struck down Friday by a Federal district judge, who cited a long and complex ballot.

title: Japan: Bullish on Pandas and Pets
description: In the middle of a recent weekday afternoon, in a large, immaculately maintained cinema off the Ginza, there were only two dry eyes in the house - mine. They really didn't count, since the film I was watching was in Japanese, supplemented from time to time by dialogue in Mandarin Chinese translated by Japanese subtitles.

title: Only Two More Fighting Days Until Election; Foolish Self-Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethnic Quota For Nigerians Is Challenged
description: At the age of 11, Adeyinka Badejo is learning the hard way about affirmative action, Nigerian style.

title: College Football: Local Colleges; Trenton State Clinches Title
description: Steve Mortellite's 1-yard touchdown run on a fourth-and-goal situation in the final quarter and Billy Donoghue's conversion enabled Trenton State to clinch the New Jersey State Conference championship by edging Kean, 14-13, Friday night at Lion Field in Ewing Township, N.J.

title: M. Joseph Blumenfeld, Judge, 84
description: M. Joseph Blumenfeld, the former chief judge of the Federal District Court in Connecticut, died of heart failure yesterday at Hartford Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Bloomfield, Conn.

title: Workers Give AIDS Patient Gift of Time
description: Phil Buchacher, so weakened by AIDS that he can no longer hold his job at the California State Lottery, spends his days in a quiet sanctuary, a one-room apartment filled with his beloved books and family photographs.

title: The Creative Spirit In Judaica
description: LEAD: A WIDELY heralded exhibition at the New York Public Library, a coming auction at Sotheby's in New York and an art show at Temple Sholom here are focusing new attention on the breadth of creativity that constitutes the rich heritage and diversity of Judaica.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GREAT WITS. By Alice Mattison. (Morrow, $16.95.) Family relationships are central to this collection of 16 carefully wrought stories, many of which first appeared in The New Yorker. The setting is New Haven, a place ''unusually rich in coincidence,'' where chance encounters are heavy with history for the educated, artistic and sophisticated characters.

title: Met Stars to Perform in New Production
description: IT'S New York in Connecticut, as the Metropolitan Opera stars Judith Blegen, John Aler and Mario Bertolino come to Stamford and Bridgeport, while the current Broadway hit ''Me and My Girl'' settles in for a week at Bushnell Hall in Hartford.

title: Roosevelt Island
description: To the Editor:

title: 20's Restoration in Brooklyn: Park and Pride
description: Imagine living on the park. Across a broad boulevard is the classic marble facade of an art museum. Just a short walk away are a lake and a zoo. Behind you, however, is not the Upper East Side, but Prospect Heights, because this is Brooklyn, not Manhattan, and the Park is Prospect, not Central. Gerald Rosengarten, converter of 49 apartments at 115 Eastern Parkway - priced from $94,500 to $204,500 - insists that not just sales bluster permits comparison between his address and one on Manhattan's Museum Mile. The Brooklyn Museum was built to rival, not complement, the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And Prospect Park was called superior to Central Park by Frederick Law Olmsted, the architect of both.

title: High School Teacher
description: LEAD: As debate swirls around school reform, students' rights and principals' prerogatives, the teacher's part is sometimes obscured. Yet the teacher is central to the education equation. It is she or he who must grapple with school policy, departmental procedure, lessons and, most important, the student.

title: Some Point Out Chinks In U.S. Computer Armor
description: In the wake of the release of an electronic ''virus'' into a nationwide military computer system, the Pentagon was quick to give flat assurances that no evil genius could possibly sneak into criticial defense and intelligence networks.

title: DEECY STEPHENS, AN INSURANCE AGENT, AND BURTON C. GRAY MARRY IN CAPITAL
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Washington, Dorothy Stephens, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Krey Stephens of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Burton Craige Gray, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Gray of Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner Jr. performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. James T. Maier, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Mississippi Showdown: Governor vs. County Aides
description: Mississippi's voters will hand Gov. Ray Mabus a report card of sorts tomorrow on his first year in office when they decide whether to replace a 100-year-old system of rural county government that has been blamed for widespread corruption and influence peddling.

title: Rachel S. Kronowitz, A Lawyer, Is Married
description: Rachel San Kronowitz, an associate in the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling, and Eric Robertson Blume, a writer and an editor, were married yesterday at the Willard-Intercontinental Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Robert Seltzer.

title: Market Place; British Petroleum May Be a Bargain
description: ITS stock has underperformed its competitors', and by many ways of valuing oil companies, the British Petroleum Company's shares look cheap. But whenever he suggests that an institution buy the stock, said Frederick P. Leuffer, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, the response is the same: ''Call me when the overhang is gone.''

title: Campaign Trail; Presidents and Class: A WASPish View
description: Does social class count in the Oval Office? Do upper-class candidates make the best Presidents?

title: What Makes Giant Corporate Buyouts Alarming
description: To the Editor:

title: Adrift in a Sea of Deregulation
description: ON Jan. 2 something truly strange will occur on the television dials of South Florida.

title: Other Incarnations Of the Vampire Author
description: ''How much tape do you have with you?'' asked the vampire . . . ''Enough for the story of a life?'' - ''Interview With the Vampire''

title: Christiana Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $137,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $43,000 and a credit of $743,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Revenue represents rental income.

title: Walesa Threatens to Call a Strike Alert
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, threatened to call a nationwide strike alert for Tuesday, apparently putting the banned union and the Polish Government on course for a showdown over the Government decision to close the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk.

title: BUSH AND DUKAKIS CLAIM MOMENTUM IN A BITTER FINALE
description: Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, each saying momentum was on his side and each warning against the dangers posed by the other's victory, battled for votes in the Rocky Mountains and on the West Coast yesterday as a suddenly spirited 1988 Presidential campaign neared its end.

title: Maryland Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The thrift converted to public ownership in June 1987.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a New York State ballot proposal to float $3 billion in bonds to repair roads and bridges incompletely explained the interest payments on the bonds. Over the life of the bond issue, up to 25 years, the state would pay a total of $2 billion in interest.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary Sunday of a retired Manhattan lawyer gave his name incorrectly. He was Max Bloom.

title: Cocoa Talks Are Delayed
description: Twelve cocoa-producing countries have postponed a two-day summit meeting in which they had planned to discuss ways to support slumping prices.

title: TRC Cos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Needle Exchange Angers Many Minorities
description: Behind the broken bricks of a Brooklyn shooting gallery, Roberto, an addict in his late 30's, sets up his practice as a ''hit doctor'' each day. For a fee of drugs or dollars he will reach inside his rumpled jacket and provide a used hypodermic syringe and may help a fellow addict find a vein able to accept the surge of freshly cooked heroin.

title: Interfaith Events Marking Kristallnacht
description: A week of solemn events commemorating the 50th anniversary of Kristallnacht got under way yesterday with John Cardinal O'Connor announcing that all 410 churches in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York would ring their bells Wednesday night to mark the event, the beginning of the Nazi Holocaust.

title: Treasury Refunding to Include 37-Day Bill
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills and the quarterly refunding that begins with three-year notes tomorrow, 10-year notes on Wednesday and 37-day cash-management bills on Thursday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Victory for McEnroe: John McEnroe of the United States won the $1 million European Community championship yesterday in Antwerp, Belgium, beating Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 7-5, 6-2. McEnroe's second victory in three years gives him a good shot at permanently winning the gold-and-diamond E.C.C. racquet, valued at about $1 million. He needs only one more victory in the next two years to take the trophy. McEnroe earned $220,000; Chesnokov earned $150,000.(AP) Becker Takes Stockholm Open: Boris Becker beat Peter Lundgren of Sweden, 6-4, 6-1, 6-1, to win the Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships.(AP) Navratilova Triumphs: Martina Navratilova defeated Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 6-7, 6-4, 6-3, to win the $300,000 New England Virginia Slims championship in Worcester, Mass.(AP) GOLF Second Title for Frost: David Frost of South Africa compiled a five-under-par 67 and coasted to a five-stroke victory in the Tucson Open in Arizona. Frost acquired his second title of the season and of a four-year PGA Tour career with a 266 total, 22 shots under par on the TPC course at StarPass. The victory was worth $108,000 from the purse of $600,000. Mark Calcavecchia, who had a 69, and Mark O'Meara, who shot a 70, shared second at 271.(AP) HORSE RACING Tuneful Tip Wins Pilgrim Stakes: Frank Generazio's Tuneful Tip, a lightly regarded shipper from Suffolk Downs, raced to a frontrunning 3 1/2-length victory in the $132,200 Pilgrim Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct. The son of Tunerup-Ram's Tip covered a mile and an eighth on the soft turf course in 1:59 with 117 pounds under Carl Gambardella to reach the wire comfortably ahead of Alydrome. Tuneful Tip earned $79,320 and paid $36.60 for $2 to win. AUTO RACING Unser Triumphs in Miami: Al Unser Jr. won the Nissan Indy Challenge at Tamiami Park in Miami by nearly a full lap over Rick Mears. The victory was his fourth of the season, moving Unser to second place behind the series champion, Danny Sullivan, in the final CART-PPG Indy-car season standings. That was worth $200,000 for Unser, 26 years old. Mears, the Indianapolis 500 winner, was second, 53.046 seconds behind the leader's Chevrolet-powered March.(AP) SOCCER Army 4, La Salle 0: Two goals by John Brence carried Army to a 4-0 victory over La Salle in the final of the Metro Atlantic Conference playoffs at Fordham University. Brence was selected most valuable player.

title: Waitz Is 9 Times the Best in Marathon
description: They have already begun to challenge the Heartbreak Hills of their careers as marathon runners, the inevitable stretch when lingering pain undermines ability and age waits patiently to defeat their competitiveness.

title: High-Living Jordan Tightens Its Belt
description: In this city long used to easy wealth and the high roll, it became unlawful today for anyone to import an automobile or artificial flowers and fruit, a chandelier, or a microwave oven, or a video cassette player, or even a statue.

title: F.D.I.C. Retreats on Mcorp's Plan to Reserve $400 Million
description: Banking regulators agreed today to back down temporarily from their plans to order Mcorp, a troubled bank holding company, to transfer capital into its ailing subsidiaries.

title: 5 Reported Wounded in Raid By Israeli Aircraft in Lebanon
description: Israeli helicopter gunships today rocketed the shop of a boat dealer accused of links with Palestinian guerrillas, demolishing the business and wounding five people, two of them seriously, the police said.

title: Southeastern PS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 6, 1988: MONDAY Carpenter Technology Lockheed Corp Data-Design Labs MBIA Inc General Motors NCH Corp Jefferson Pilot Corp TUESDAY Centex Corp Equimark Corp Champion Spark Plug McDermott Intl Cincinnati Milacron SunTrust Banks Inc WEDNESDAY Baltimore Bancorp IBP Inc CBS Inc Kay Jewelers CSX Corp Leggett & Platt Current Income Shs Outboard Marine Corp Eastern Co Sears, Roebuck Gerber Products Sunshine-Jr Stores THURSDAY Adams Express MAPCO Inc Allegheny Ludlum Maytag Corp Arvin Industries Pacific Resources Chemical Banking Corp Petroleum & Resources Cooper Tire & Rubber Rockwell International Esselte Business Sys Russ Berrie & Co Hilton Hotels Corp Wal-Mart Stores FRIDAY Chelsea Industries Oakite Products Eastman Kodak Sysco Corp Ecolab Inc Williams Cos SATURDAY General Nutrition

title: Soviet Soybean Deals
description: The Soviet Union has bought 535,000 metric tons of United States soybean meal for delivery in the 1988-89 marketing year that began on Oct. 1, the Agriculture Department reported Thursday. Earlier last week, the Soviets bought 250,000 tons of soybeans for 1988-89 delivery, the first of the new season. Although no further details were announced, the meal sales could have a value of more than $120 million, based on average market estimates of around $225 a ton.

title: Caribbean Savors a Tourism Boom
description: On a sweeping curve of empty beach, edged with coconut palms and towering pines, construction crews are laying the foundation for a 250-room hotel. A few miles away, other crews are finishing the renovation of a long-abandoned hotel. An ambitious restoration of the cruise ship harbor, near the old Spanish colonial section, has begun, and the international airport here is being dramatically enlarged.

title: TV Notes
description: Election Coverage

title: Miss Nass Is Married To Stephen M. Parish
description: Karen Elizabeth Nass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Nass of Baldwin, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Michael Parish, the son of Marion Parish of White Plains and Nathaniel Parish of New York and White Plains. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in Hewlett, L.I.

title: What Makes Giant Corporate Buyouts Alarming
description: To the Editor:

title: Klan Opposed in Philadelphia
description: About 500 people demonstrated against the Ku Klux Klan Saturday across from the Liberty Bell at Independence Mall. The demonstration was arranged to oppose a rally planned by the United States League of White Christian Patriots. But that white supremacist group was denied a permit by the Independence National Historical Park, which said there was a risk of violence.

title: Campaign Trail; High-Hat Treatment For Debra Winger
description: There are high jinks, too, aboard Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's chartered Boeing 737. Forget that a candidate who may be the next Leader of the Free World is on board. Forget that the polls show Mr. Dukakis trailing. The appearance of the actress Debra Winger on the plane, crammed largely with men and boys, left the Dukakis entourage in a euphoric state - except perhaps for Mr. Dukakis.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Held in Killing Of His Half Brother
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested for shooting his half brother to death in the street, the police said yesterday.

title: Colts Use Wishbone To Beat Jets
description: It was a wearing-down rather than a spectacular triumph, but the Colts produced a 38-14 victory over the Jets today, using touchdowns from the wishbone as bookends.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday referred incorrectly to the director of the Children's Aid Society's Teen Pregnancy Prevention Program. He is Dr. Michael Carrera.

title: Boxing; What Makes Leonard Run Back to the Ring?
description: HE is 32 years old and, depending on your point of view, Ray Charles Leonard is either a boxing wonder or just another fighter who does not know when to take proper leave of his brutal profession.

title: Ad Group Picks Woman of Year
description: Louise McNamee, president and chief operating officer of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS and the first woman to have her name added to an established agency, has been named ''Advertising Woman of the Year'' by the Advertising Women of New York.

title: Ipco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Michael Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $6,062,000 from an accounting change.

title: Northwest Teleproductions reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Smithfield Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Strategic Planning Associates Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Latest fiscal year results are unaudited. Share earnings for the latest year are adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split.

title: Was His Act of Mercy Also Murder?
description: Two years after a doctor disclosed on television that he had helped kill his terminally ill wife after her suicide attempt failed, prosecutors will call their first witness as they try to prove that the doctor committed murder.

title: Ogilvy's Profit Off 14%; Special Charge Is Cited
description: The Ogilvy Group has reported a 14 percent drop in third-quarter earnings. Net income fell to $4.9 million, or 33 cents a share, from $5.7 million, or 38 cents a share, from a year earlier, largely because of an after-tax charge of $725,000 after an adverse arbitration decision relating to a client in Britain. Revenues grew 11.7 percent, to $192.55 million.

title: F.T.C. Fights Silicone Plan
description: A proposed merger of two leading producers' silicone operations would probably harm competition, the Federal Trade Commission said last week.

title: Reinventing Sears: A Formidable Task
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company will have to do more than change its price tags and reprogram its cash registers to compete with discounters like K Mart, Wal-Mart and Target Stores.

title: Democrats Appear to Have a Lock on Congress
description: Democrats are almost certain to retain control of Congress in the election Tuesday, regardless of the outcome of the Presidential race.

title: Campaign Trail; Flash! Bush Is Angry (Or Maybe He Isn't)
description: A little disagreement in a marriage is healthy. Or so they say.

title: Patriots' Rookie Tramples Dolphins
description: John Stephens, a rookie from Northwestern Louisiana State, had over 100 yards rushing for his third straight game as he ran for 104 yards and one touchdown to lead New England (5-5) to a 21-10 victory over the Miami Dolphins (5-5).

title: Britain Active In Takeovers
description: British companies made takeover offers totaling more than $13.5 billion for American concerns in the first six months of this year, according to a new report. The report, the British-

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The nation's economy grew solidly in October after September's slackened pace, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management. The report indicated that the rate of production expanded at the highest level in three months. New orders also continued to grow at a slightly faster pace than in September but below levels for August and July, the report said. [ Page D1. ] The credit markets are becoming more pessimistic and interest rates are likely to rise, analysts said. The catalyst for the abrupt shift in sentiment was the across-the-board strength in October's employment figures, which sent a clear signal that the economy was not slowing but inflationary pressures were rising. [ D1. ] COMPANIES The $20 billion takeover battle for RJR Nabisco grew muddier over the weekend as the company's top executives considered whether to file a lawsuit to block a bid from an investment group led by Forstmann Little and Goldman, Sachs. [ D1. ] Natural gas producers think they are close to resolving the last of their disputes with the gas pipeline companies. The disputes have scared away many potential customers, who feared that the settlements might lead to much higher natural gas prices. [ D1. ] Texas Air reported a net loss of $114.1 million during its third quarter, which is ordinarily a strong period. [ D5. ] Banking regulators agreed to back down temporarily from their plans to order Mcorp, the troubled Texas bank holding company, to transfer capital into its ailing subsidiaries. [ D14. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT West Germany is about to push through a law to reduce national health insurance payments for many drugs, a move strongly opposed by pharmaceutical companies. [ D8. ] Jordan began an austerity program and banned the imports of such goods as cars and video-cassette players. [ A3. ] American officials have criticized West German plans to offer subsidies to Airbus Industrie. [ D2. ] Japan and Britain say foreign investors will be scared away from Europe unless France and Italy ease tough regulations that treat English-made Nissans as Japanese cars, subjecting them to strict import quotas. [ D4. ] Brazil has brought the interest payments on its bank debt up to date for the first time since early last year. [ D9. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Wheatland Publishing is trying to buck the trend against independent book publishers and appears to be laying the foundation for long-term growth. [ D12. ] The game of musical chairs at the Omnicom Group is not as surprising as it seems because Bruce Crawford and Allen G. Rosenshine are returning to the careers they love. Advertising. [ D11. ] Investor's Daily is struggling for recognition among readers and advertisers, and it now faces a challenge from The Wall Street Journal's revamped ''Money and Investing'' section. [ D12. ] PBS has altered the rules for corporate sponsors on public television programs as critics complain about the increasing commercialization of the network. [ D12. ] Deregulation has ended the stability of broadcasting, turning stations into hot properties to be bought and sold. Television. [ D12. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Mutual funds have a number of tax pitfalls. Investors need to understand them as they get their portfolios in order before the end of the year. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] British Petroleum's stock sells at a discount to the stocks of other oil companies, as many investors are worried about Kuwait's huge stake in the company, which the British Government has ordered it to reduce. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Review/Rock; A 60's Sound From Ireland
description: It is easy to see why the Irish rock band Hothouse Flowers has been hailed as a young group of exceptional promise.

title: Langer Biomechanics Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Unicomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
In 113th Precinct, Ambivalence to Police
description: The 113th Precinct in Queens embraces street after street of people, most of them black, who have come up in the world. In neighborhoods like Rosedale and Rochdale and St. Albans, there are large, well-maintained homes. But the area is also the epicenter of New York City's crack epidemic, where addiction among the young is growing, where drug gang members shoot each other and hit bystanders.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Yeah, we're in safe states for Republicans like West Virginia and Maryland and states like that. We're going back to Maryland, too. We're very versatile.

title: Stocker & Yale Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
College Football; Foul Day for Favorites in East
description: On the first Saturday of November, a wet and windy one, college football in the East twisted and turned as four favored teams lost.

title: Purchasers See Growth In Economy
description: The nation's economy grew solidly in October after a slackened pace in September, according to a monthly report by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Investor's Daily Learns the Hard Way
description: Nearly five years after beginning a national financial newspaper, the owner of Investor's Daily is sobered by the experience.

title: Jennifer S. Frey, A Reporter, Weds
description: Jennifer Streicher Frey, a daughter of Janie Greenwald Wertanen of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and Irving Q. Frey of New York, was married yesterday to Larry Reibstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Reibstein of Cherry Hill, N.J. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Loft in New York.

title: Good Food to Close
description: Good Food, part of the Triangle Publications package purchased by Rupert Murdoch from Walter Annenberg last summer, will close after the December issue, Murdoch Magazines announced Friday. The $3 billion acquisition included TV Guide, Daily Racing Form and Seventeen magazine, all of which survive.

title: Water Weights For Travel
description: Hand and ankle weights are as important to some athletes as the shoes on their feet. But lugging the weights around can be a chore.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Imagery on Ice
description: LEAD: There is a lot of silver and black flashing around Los Angeles these days, and not all of it is worn by the Raiders. Inspired by the image and success of professional football's baddest boys, Bruce McNall, the majority owner of the Los Angeles Kings, adopted a similar color scheme for his new-look professional hockey team.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the election, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended tomorrow in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Defects in Nuclear Arms Industry Minimized in Early Reagan Years
description: In the first months of the Reagan Administration, the Energy Department disregarded warnings that the nuclear weapon industry was beset by flaws in management and safety, and rejected recommendations to overhaul safety programs at the weapon plants, according to Government reports and interviews with current and former officials.

title: Angell Real Estate reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings are not available; the company changed from a master limited partnership to a real estate investment trust at the beginning of this year.

title: Campaign Trail; No Concessions Before Polls Close
description: It was Election Night 1980, and Ron Wyden, a newly elected Democratic Congressman from Oregon, vowed that the ''Jimmy Carter experience'' would not be repeated. In that case, Mr. Carter conceded defeat to Ronald Reagan early in the evening, while voters on the West Coast were still waiting to cast their ballots. Mr. Wyden was angry.

title: Rieses Buy 6.9% Stake in Horn & Hardart
description: The Riese brothers, the New York real estate developers who operate some 300 restaurants, think the Horn & Hardart Company is a good investment.

title: Battle Over AIDS Disclosure Ignites in California
description: A ballot measure that could carry sweeping national implications in fighting the spread of AIDS has moved to the forefront in the final days of the 1988 election campaign in California.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Suppose Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox is forced by injury to miss the last month of the regular season after batting .370. His injury also forces him to miss the 25 extra plate appearances he would need in order to qualify for another American League batting title. By season's end, though, Boggs's .370 average is still so far above that of the league's next-best hitter that even if Boggs were charged with an out for each of the 25 times at bat he fell short of qualifying, he would still have the highest average in the league, let's say, perhaps, .340. Would he be considered the batting champion?

title: California Energy Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end from Jan. 31 to Dec. 31 in 1987. For the third quarter ended Oct. 31, 1987, the company had net of $224,000, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $1,409,000, and for the 9 months, the net income was $132,000, or 1 cent a share, on revenue of $1,683,000.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Advertising column of Business Day on Friday misidentified a new vice chairman at Young & Rubicam, New York. He is Michael Robertson.

title: Bush Campaign Adds Midwest Stops
description: The campaign of Vice President Bush, while insisting that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will be unable to assemble an Electoral College majority on Tuesday, scheduled last-minute stops in battleground states today as insurance measures.

title: Horse Show; Californian Is No. 1 In the Big Apple
description: The 105th National Horse Show completed its run at Madison Square Garden last night with 31 jumpers fighting poor footing, fatigue and unnerving fences in the $50,000 Big Apple Grand Prix. The event was won by Hap Hansen after he soared over eight obstacles without mishap in a time of 36.89 seconds atop Zadok in a seven-horse jump-off.

title: Czechs Cite U.S. Duties
description: Czechoslovakia said Friday that the United States was hindering equal trade between the countries by charging excessive duties on its goods. ''Czechoslovak goods are charged with much higher duties than goods of an overwhelming majority of other countries,'' Svatopluk Stana, commercial attache at the country's Washington Embassy, told the Communist Party daily Rude Pravo.

title: Computer Invasion: 'Back Door' Ajar
description: The weakness that allowed one of the nation's most powerful computer networks to be jammed last week resulted from one of the most basic and common weaknesses in any system: human forgetfulness.

title: Devon Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is the entity resulting from the consolidation of three predecessors on Sept. 29, 1988.

title: Once on the Ropes, Canadian Liberal Surges Back
description: A pair of red boxing gloves dangles in the cabin of John N. Turner's plane as he barnstorms across Canada campaigning for the general election Nov. 21.

title: Lawyer's Client Surrenders in Hit-and-Run Death
description: The State Attorney's office announced tonight that a 55-year-old Florida restaurant owner had surrendered in the hit-and-run death of a 28-year-old electrician two years ago in a case that has drawn nationwide attention as a test of the limits of confidentiality in lawyer-client relationships.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 20 incorrectly described the duration of copyrights. A copyright on a work lasts for 50 years after the death of the author or artist. The article also gave an incorrect first name for the trademark counsel of Pepsico Inc. He is William Finkelstein.

title: Tinsley Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $73,500 and $178,200 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss Year-ago results are restated for tax benefits.

title: Marines Try to Make the Corps Better for Women
description: Despite its tradition as a ''band of brothers,'' the United States Marine Corps has been striving to make its ranks a better place for women to serve.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Civil Rights and Sacred Cows
description: There was special poignancy in the recent death of S.B. Fuller. In 1963, this self-made black businessman controlled companies with yearly sales of more than $10 million and a sales force of more than 3,000 in 38 states. Five years later, his Fuller Products Company was in bankruptcy proceedings. He kept the operation going, but when he died last month at age 83, it had shrunk to a small-time cosmetics outfit in Chicago's South Side ghetto.

title: Fitness; Biomechanics Can Aid Recreational Athlete, Too
description: IT is Tuesday morning and the biomechanics graduate students at Pennsylvania State University have gathered for their weekly research meeting. As a plastic model of a human skeleton watches from a corner in a conference room, Dr. Richard C. Nelson, director of the biomechanics laboratory, asks his students gathered around a table to report one by one on the status of their research projects.

title: Gen-Probe reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $300,000 for the purchase of rights to future technology associated with a research and development contract signed in September.

title: The Campaign Sewer Overflows
description: The corruption of public financing for Presidential elections is by now obvious to everyone but the Federal Election Commission, the agency charged with enforcing the rules. This year's brazen cheating by both Presidential candidates dramatizes the need for Congress to strengthen both the agency and the law.

title: It's Brigadoon, Runners Style
description: They started arriving at dawn and by midmorning the staging area at Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island had been transformed into a small city of 23,000 transient residents that could be called Marathonville.

title: English-Made Nissans At Center of Trade Fight
description: Angry Japanese and British officials say foreign investors will be scared away from Europe unless France and Italy ease tough regulations that treat English-made Nissans as Japanese cars, subjecting them to strict import quotas. The British also fear that jobs will be lost.

title: Surging Giants Take 4th Straight
description: In the first half today, the Giants played crunching, vintage defense and rolled to a 26-0 lead over the Dallas Cowboys. In the second half, with a new young quarterback who scrambled and kept creating minor miracles, the Cowboys roared back.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Senate Rivalry
description: While the rest of the nation has been preoccupied with the Presidential election, Senate Democrats have been busy figuring the odds on an election of their own - the three-way race to succeed the Senate Majority Leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia.

title: Slow Progress for a Publishing Newcomer
description: At a time when independent book publishers are as rare as the white rhino, Wheatland Publishing, the American company founded with Ann Getty's money and Lord Weidenfeld's publishing know-how, is trying hard to buck the trend. While the consensus in the book industry is that Wheatland has not lived up to expectations, the publisher does appear to be laying the foundations for long-term growth.

title: Reagatomics
description: By the Reagan Administration's own numbers, the Soviet Union now has 40 percent more first-strike nuclear weapons trained on the United States than it did on Inauguration Day 1981. Thus, an Administration that won office in large part on a promise to close a ''window of vulnerability'' has succeeded only in opening it farther.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alternative Health Care Systems Inc., Naugatuck, Conn., appointed Peter Aaronson president of its Columbia Life Insurance Co. subsidiary.

title: Candidates for Congress Raise $360 Million
description: Candidates in the Senate and House elections have raised nearly $360 million, with about a third of it coming from political action committees, the Federal Election Commission says.

title: Farm Credit Chief's Views
description: The head regulator of the Farm Credit System said Friday that the system could recover from its steep losses but that it might not be effectively using the tools it has.

title: Review/Ballet; A Moscow Troupe in 'Swan Lake'
description: A new and surprising ''Swan Lake'' from a young Soviet company, the Moscow Classical Ballet, opened the weekend engagement at the Wang Center here.

title: Nude Car Wash Scrubbed
description: The police shut down the Only Nude Car Wash in the Nation, advising the owner that hiring women to scrub cars while nude violated the law.

title: NEW YORK DEFICIT EXCEEDS ESTIMATE
description: New York State's budget shortfall, which state officials had earlier estimated to be nearly $1 billion, is now estimated to be almost twice that amount, officials familiar with the state's most recent revenue figures say.

title: Accounts
description: * International King's Table, Eugene, Ore., a Horn & Hardart company that operates restaurants, to Livingston & Co., estimated at $2.5 million.

title: Stock Trading Case in Japan
description: An assistant to the chairman of Japan's largest telecommunications company, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, has resigned over his role in a stock scandal, a company spokesman said today.

title: More Spanish in Crosswords, por Favor
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; After Election, Short-Term Agency Takes Power
description: With a Roy Rogers restaurant and a branch of the Bank of Pakistan on the ground floor, the office building is not very imposing. But on the eighth floor at 1825 Connecticut Avenue, across from the elevators, there is a small black and white sign on the wall reading, ''Office of the President-Elect.''

title: Germany Set To Cap Costs Of Medication
description: The West German Government is about to push through legislation that will drastically reduce national health insurance payments for many drugs, a move strongly opposed by pharmaceutical companies.

title: Refac Technology Development Corp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $327,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $79,698 and $171,464 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S. Officials Protesting German Aid for Airbus
description: American officials have criticized the plans of the West German Government to offer to Airbus Industrie, the European aviation consortium, conditional subsidies that could reach $2.3 billion during the next decade.

title: Sakharov, in the U.S. on First Trip To West, Says He Is 'Freer' Now
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights campaigner, arrived here tonight on his first trip outside the Soviet Union, saying he was ''a freer man'' because he had finally been given permission to travel abroad.

title: Harry Friedman, Cardiologist, 81
description: Dr. Harry Friedman, a cardiologist and former associate clinical professor at New York Medical College, died of heart disease Saturday at the John F. Kennedy Hospital in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: PBS Warily Alters Rules For Sponsors' Messages
description: In its latest attempt to preserve the integrity of public television yet still attract corporate sponsors, the Public Broadcasting Service has refined the rules that govern promotional announcements.

title: Police Seize Man and Gun at a Bush Rally
description: An unidentified spectator was arrested at a Bush campaign rally today after witnesses said he dropped a gun and fled, the police said.

title: Outdoors: A Change in Dinner Plans
description: I RECENTLY spent an uneasy night after setting forth in quest of ruffed grouse and returning to camp with a duck.

title: A Good Law for Bad Dogs
description: New York, like other cities, must decide between two approaches to controlling vicious dogs. One, sponsored by the Koch administration, focuses on a dog: the Mayor would ban the American pit bull terrier. A far better approach, supported by dog-owner and animal-protection groups, focuses on canine behavior.

title: People
description: * Richard Buck has joined International Advertising Sales as senior vice president.

title: It's How You Lose That Counts
description: Dear Losing Candidates, This is no country for second best, and there will be thousands of you tomorrow, officially spurned by the will of the people, branded with the real scarlet L. It doesn't matter whether you were rejected for the village council or the Oval Office; what matters is how you stand up to being knocked down. Losing gracefully doesn't mean losing graciously.

title: In Connecticut, a Last Wooing of Waverers
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, each charging the other with running the nastier Senate race, crisscrossed Connecticut today in a barrage of last-minute campaign stops aimed mostly at capturing the support of an unusually large number of undecided voters.

title: Mentor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metro Datelines; L.I. Man Is Arrested In Shooting of Friend
description: A Suffolk County man was arrested after he apparently shot a friend in the face by accident while the two were examining a handgun, the police said yesterday. The victim was critically injured. The suspect, Mark Redmond, 18 years old, was arrested late Saturday and charged with assault in the shooting of Michael Jackson, 21, of Brentwood, said a Suffolk County Police spokeswoman, Officer Susan Romann.

title: Dr. Aris Comninellis Marries D. G. Xistris
description: Dr. Aris Comninellis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eustratias Comninellis of Greenlawn, L.I., was married there yesterday to Demetrios George Xistris, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. Xistris of Montreal. The Rev. Pat Legato performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of St. Paraskevi.

title: Detective Hurt Saving 2 in Fire
description: A police detective was hospitalized for smoke inhalation yesterday after he pulled two homeless men from their burning makeshift shelter in Lower Manhattan, police and fire officials said.

title: Quayle Role As Phantom Of Campaign
description: Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, today stumped in Virginia, one of his party's safest states, while his Democratic counterpart, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, made his case before millions on two nationally televised interview programs.

title: Right Management Consultnts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $26,000 charge from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter; the 9 months include an $87,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Redskins Manage To Hold Off Saints
description: There was every reason to believe that whichever team had the ball last would enjoy the last laugh this afternoon at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. A see-saw battle between the New Orleans Saints and the Washington Redskins featured an arsenal of lofty passes and ended with Doug Williams snatching the snap from center and kneeling as time expired.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Critically Hurt Climbing IND Train
description: A man trying to board an IND subway train by climbing between two cars was critically injured yesterday when his head hit a signal box as the train left the 155th Street station of the D line, officials said.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Forgotten Moment
description: LEAD: Lewis Tillman looks back on what should have been the most memorable moment of his football career, and his mind is blank. Was it an off-tackle run? Was it a sweep? Perhaps it was a draw. Tillman has been asked about the play so many times, but he hasn't been able to provide any answers.

title: Marathon; Jones Is First at Finish and Second in Record Book
description: By the time he crossed back into Central Park and turned the final corner that led to the finish line, Steve Jones was all alone, his feet leading him past the faces that lined the last few hundred yards. Still, he looked once over his left shoulder, once over his right shoulder.

title: Dueling Bowls Raise The Ante
description: The Sunkist Fiesta Bowl's executive director, Bruce Skinner, said yesterday he felt confident about his chances of making a match between Notre Dame and West Virginia despite the Mazda Gator Bowl's willingness to increase its purse to $3 million per team for such a game.

title: Encourage English; Don't Force It
description: The Justice Department weighed into Florida's ''official English'' referendum last week on the right side. It advised a Federal appellate court panel that the public petitions putting this biased issue on the ballot should have been in Spanish as well as English. The court disagreed, so the question remains for voters. It's still a bad idea that deserves a clear ''no.''

title: Nabisco Officials Weigh Suit to Block a Bid
description: The $20 billion takeover battle for RJR Nabisco Inc. grew muddier over the weekend as its managers considered whether to file a lawsuit to block the latest suitor.

title: President, in Vintage Form, Relishes His Final Campaign
description: Is there anyone else who would literally ride off into the sunset? Who would wave his Stetson, step behind a team of horses and trot off into the orange glow of the Texas horizon?

title: Bolt Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $534,000 from the sale of land a building.

title: 'Cafe Crown' Extended
description: ''Cafe Crown,'' Hy Kraft's salute to the Yiddish theater, has been extended through Dec. 11 at the Public/ Newman Theater. The show, whose cast includes Eli Wallach, Anne Jackson and Bob Dishy, was originally to close on Nov. 20, and is sold out through that date.

title: Lalonde Relying on Power
description: Not long ago, as Donny Lalonde cornered a sparring partner against the ropes at his training camp in Lakeville, Pa., his trainer, Tommy Gallagher, shouted, ''Mug him!''

title: Afghan Rebels May Seek New Arms
description: Afghan guerrillas, including a field commander on a visit to this border city, say Soviet deployment of new missiles and aircraft in Afghanistan will not stop what they see as a steady guerrilla advance in many of country's 27 provinces.

title: Take the Guesswork Out of Buying Skis
description: BUYING new skis is a risky venture. Some skiers base their decision on a ski's appearance or advertising by the manufacturer. Or they might pick up a ski and flex it, which is the equivalent of a layman looking at a car's engine before buying. Or they might simply select bargain skis at a pre- or post-season sale. In the end, it appears that buying skis is pretty much a matter of chance and trust.

title: Metro Matters; Urban Issues Get Short Shrift In '88 Campaign
description: The role played by urban issues in the 1988 Presidential campaign appears, to many people, to be typified by a cartoon in the Washington office of William E. Davis 3d, who monitors the campaign for the National League of Cities Institute.

title: Key Tronic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net income

title: 5th Avenue's St. Regis Is Declared a Landmark
description: Eight decades after it opened as the Versailles of hostelries in New York City and five months after its last guests departed, the St. Regis Hotel on Fifth Avenue has become an official city landmark.

title: Campaign Trail; High Stakes Lottery On Air Force Two
description: High jinks in the final days on Air Force Two:

title: Congressman's Mail Citing a Polygraph Investigated by U.S.
description: The Justice Department is investigating campaign literature, mailed to constituents by Representative Pat Swindall, that referred to results of a polygraph test he took in connection with his trial on perjury charges.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Overcoming the Odds
description: LEAD: When Tom Dempsey of the New Orleans Saints kicked a 63-yard field goal in 1970 to set a National Football League record, people marveled at the distance and the fact that Dempsey did it with a deformed right foot.

title: Bears Win With Ditka in TV Audience
description: Mike Tomczak, making his first start of the year in place of injured Jim McMahon, passed for two touchdowns and set up two others today, leading the Chicago Bears to a 28-10 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Dance Theater's Insert: Networking in Action
description: Yesterday's 20-page advertising insert for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in The New York Times was the brainchild of Harold Levine, the chairman of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver. But it was created and executed by Jamison & Leary, a Backer Spielvogel Bates affiliate. And therein lies an intricate tale of networking.

title: Bentsen, Stumping in Texas, Calls Race Dead Heat
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen brought his Vice-Presidential campaign home to Texas today for the last lap, pronouncing the election a dead heat on the basis of polls showing voters moving toward the Democrats but still showing the party behind.

title: Nicaragua Bars Funds From U.S.
description: In a series of new laws and pronouncements, the Sandinista Government has forbidden opposition groups in Nicaragua to accept aid from the United States Government.

title: Review/Music; Gerard Schwarz's Unrestrained Bach Fugues
description: Tracing the threads that tie together the works on Gerard Schwarz's programs is often an interesting exercise. The concert in which he led the New York Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y on Saturday was unified by a kind of backward-glancing Romanticism.

title: Tax Watch; Some Pitfalls In Mutual Funds
description: LIKE actors in a Greek drama, mutual fund shareholders wear two masks. For investors pleased with the ease and low cost of acquiring a diversified, professionally managed portfolio, a smiling mask is apropos. But when tax time comes, shareholders may well want to don the tragic mask.

title: Thinking in Hungarian
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Years Given In Chicago Plot
description: A Colorado man was sentenced to six years in prison on charges that he masterminded a scheme to defraud the Chicago Board of Trade of $320,000 by using a disguised trader with a false mustache and forged documents. In sentencing Thompson B. Sanders and three other men on Thursday, United States District Judge Marvin E. Aspen said the case showed the Board of Trade was ripe ''for corruption and manipulation.''

title: Review/Opera; Newcomers in 'Figaro'
description: Many regard ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' as the closest thing to perfection the opera buffa repertory has to offer -a work brimming with schemes, ruses and misdirected passions and jealousies, transformed by Mozart and Da Ponte from the Beaumarchais play so cohesively, and with such consummate wit, that its four-hour duration sails by quickly.

title: Gas Producers See an End To Disputes With Pipelines
description: Natural gas producers think they are close to resolving the last of billions of dollars' worth of disputes with pipeline companies that transport the gas.

title: Indians Rescue Maldives Hostages on High Seas
description: After a two-day chase across the Indian Ocean, Indian warships today forced the surrender of a fleeing vessel carrying gunmen who had tried to overthrow the Government of the Maldive Islands, together with more than 20 hostages.

title: Golf Helps Clarify Goals for Amputees
description: LIKE any golfer, Andy Ferguson has had to learn to make adjustments. A resident of Nutley, N.J., the 37-year-old Ferguson carries a handicap of 18, and he also has ''a couple of crescent wrenches in my golf bag in case my foot comes loose.''

title: First Federal Savings & Loan -Chattanooga reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jersey Foes Take Race To People
description: Hoping to galvanize supporters and win over doubters, the candidates for United States Senator from New Jersey pounded the campaign trail long and hard this weekend.

title: MDT Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $118,000 from the early retirement of debt for the quarter and 6 months. c-After tax credits of $410,000 for the quarter and $554,000 for the 6 months.

title: Edac Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
