description: b-Net income

title: Stacy Levine, Executive, Married to A. H. Brennet
description: Stacy Lynn Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Levine of Englewood, N.J., and Andrew Howard Brennet, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Brennet of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., were married yesterday at the Chanticler in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated.

title: Review/Television; Derring-Do And Deceit In Wartime
description: Among all the required suspensions of disbelief in ''The Great Escape II: The Untold Story'' - the final half of which can be seen on NBC at 9 o'clock tonight - no doubt the most demanding is to accept Christopher Reeve as Sir Winston Churchill's cousin. Having struck career pay dirt in the ''Superman'' movies, Mr. Reeve is here portraying Maj. John Dodge, an American-born British officer who, during World War II, led a daring escape from a German stalag, or camp for prisoners of war. Major Dodge calls the British Prime Minister Winnie. He tells a fellow prisoner: ''It's a long story.''

title: The C.I.A. and the Evil Doctor
description: LEAD: The Justice Department agreed last month to pay $750,000 to settle a lawsuit brought by nine victims of the Central Intelligence Agency's brainwashing experiments in the 1950's. The research project tested the theory that a person could have some of the contents of his mind obliterated and replaced by ideas of the researcher's choosing.

title: Lyng to Join Europe Talks
description: Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng will go to Europe this month for ''one last series of meetings'' on trade problems with the European Community, he said last week.

title: Osborn Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,246,135 and a pretax gain of $12,452,345 on the sale of assets for both periods; the quarter also includes a loss of $267,132 from extinguishment of debt; and the 9 months also include a gain of $999,577 from extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

title: Management Mentality Is Killing U.S. Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Haitian Officer Charged by U.S. Is Reported Dead
description: Col. Jean-Claude Paul, who commanded Haiti's most feared army unit and was indicted in the United States on drug charges, died today at the age of 49, a radio station reported. A family friend said the death occurred under suspicious circumstances.

title: San Diegans Fight to Keep Utility That Rebuilt Image
description: When Thomas A. Page , an accountant and engineer, joined the San Diego Gas and Electric Company in 1978 as chief operating officer, he found a utility distrusted by investors, scorned by bond-rating agencies and villified by customers for its high rates.

title: Kerri L. Martin Weds Richard Bartlett
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Kerri Lucille Martin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Wilson Martin of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married yesterday to Richard Allan Bartlett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Alva Bartlett of Tuscaloosa, Ala. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Texas Air Posts Loss of $114.1 Million
description: The Texas Air Corporation reported a net loss of $114.1 million during its third quarter, which is ordinarily a strong period.

title: Angry Korea Weighs Fate Of Ex-Leader
description: From students to businessmen to politicians, the people in this nation are turning angrily, sometimes violently, against the former President, Chun Doo Hwan.

title: Norman Newhouse Is Dead at 82; Executive With Newspaper Chain
description: Norman N. Newhouse, a senior executive with the Newhouse newspaper chain who helped his brothers build it into one of the nation's largest communications conglomerates, died yesterday at his home in New Orleans after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Officials Fill Familiar Jobs At Omnicom
description: THE game of musical chairs at the Omnicom Group is not as surprising as it seems. Bruce Crawford, who has been general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is returning to the ad agency business as president and chief executive of Omnicom. He succeeds Allen G. Rosenshine, who will step down to resume the BBDO Worldwide chairmanship.

title: Laurel & Hardy Politics
description: We are deeply into the era of Laurel & Hardy politics. Remember the film classic in which they got into a mild argument with their neighbor? If memory serves, the neighbor kicked their car and a fender fell off; in retaliation, Stan Laurel ripped a shutter off his house; furious escalation followed, and by the end of the reel, both car and house lay in shambles. (Memory does not always serve; a few days ago, I credited Johnny Mercer with the 1946 song ''Personality''; a member of the Gotcha! Gang reminds me that although Mr. Mercer recorded and popularized it, the lyrics were written by Johnny Burke with music by Jimmy Van Heusen.) When did the fender-ripping and shutter-tearing of the 1988 Presidential campaign all begin? Who started this round of impugning motives and besmearing reputations, now euphemized as ''negative campaigning''?

title: Sybra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brazil Meets Its Payments On Bank Debt
description: Brazil has brought the interest payments on its commercial bank debt up to date for the first time since early last year, the nation's Central Bank said Saturday.

title: Bond Market Is Chilled by Jobless Data
description: The optimism that has prevailed in the credit markets for the last few months is quickly evaporating, analysts said late last week, adding that interest rates are likely to rise.

title: A Day in a Mental Hospital, a Dream of Life Outside
description: It is 6 A.M., and behind the barred windows at Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital a young woman blinks awake. Outside, it is chilly, but inside the locked hospital doors, steam heat rushes through metal pipes as shouts of ''Time to get up'' echo through the halls.

title: Review/Ballet; A Tribute to Diaghilev by the Joffrey
description: Sergei Diaghilev was surely 20th-century ballet's greatest artistic director. The productions he commissioned for his Ballets Russes between 1909 and his death - and his company's demise - in 1929 are notable for their seriousness of vision, variety and excellence of choreography and for their use of fine music and stage design.

title: Bridge
description: Two great figures in the New York tournament scene, sometime partners and frequent opponents, died last month, both at age 81.

title: Arthur E. Pettit, 91, Ex-Partner in Law Firm
description: Arthur E. Pettit, a former senior partner of the Manhattan law firm Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, died of heart disease Thursday at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 91 years old.

title: Forgetfulness And the 'Virus'
description: The weakness that allowed a powerful computer network to be jammed last week resulted from human forgetfulness.

title: Different Directions For Cup Winners?
description: The Filly of the Century and the Horse of the Year bounced out of their Breeders' Cup victories at Churchill Downs Saturday with one heading off to a life of retirement and the other's future in limbo.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Yale School of Organization and Management characterized the career choices of 1987 graduates incorrectly.

title: Management Mentality Is Killing U.S. Industry; Failure in Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Park Ohio Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $29,649,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $349,000 and $865,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results for the year-ago 9 months were restated after an after-tax gain of $291,000, or 5 cents a share, to reflect curtailment of a pension plan.

title: Gen. Tan Zheng, Chinese Revolutionary, 82
description: Gen. Tan Zheng, a former Deputy Defense Minister and a veteran of the Long March, died today in Beijing, the Central Military Commission said. He was 82 years old.

title: Trustees Voice 'Shock' On Dartmouth Review
description: A letter from the Dartmouth College trustees deploring a student newspaper's comparison of the school's president with Adolf Hitler will be sent to all students and faculty members, a spokesman for the college said today.

title: Murfreesboro Journal; Agonizing Over Worth of Diamonds
description: This is a town caught between a rock and a hard place.

title: Logitek Inc reports earnings for
Washington Talk: Briefing; Diplomatic Departure
description: Retired Foreign Service officers who return to their former nests in the State Department are in for ''a bit of a shock,'' a department spokesman says. Their building passes are to be confiscated by a security guard at the entrance.

title: INSIDE
description: Waitz Wins Her Ninth Grete Waitz, above, after winning the New York City Marathon for the ninth time. Steve Jones was the men's winner. SportsMonday, page C1. Haitian Coup Figure Dies Col. Jean-Claude Paul, 49, a central figure in recent coups in Haiti, has died, it was reported. Page A11. Vladimir and Estragon Frank Rich reviews ''Waiting for Godot'' starring Steve Martin and Robin Williams. Page C15.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Soviet's Exhibit
description: The international exhibition hall of the State Department this week opens a display of the work of Sergei L. Petrov, a 35-year-old Soviet photographer who has been seeking to emigrate from the Soviet Union for more than nine years.

title: Swindon Journal; The Thinker's Pub, With a Resident Philosopher
description: In this former railway town, where coal smoke spirals from chimneys and mingles with autumn's chill, the convivial regulars at the Beehive Pub sometimes order another round over discussions of Plato, the nature of the universe and, well, just what it all means.

title: The U.N. Today
description: POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: In Blur of Rallies, Dukakis Steps Up Attacks on Rival
description: In a blur of rallies and signs and chants, in a frenzied sweep of America, Michael S. Dukakis entered the home stretch of his campaign for the Presidency today with a rollicking attack on Vice President Bush.

title: Cato D. Glover, 91, Naval Commander And Early Aviator
description: Adm. Cato D. Glover, a pioneer naval aviator who commanded the aircraft carrier Enterprise in heavy combat in the Pacific in World War II, died after a brief illness Saturday at the King James Nursing Home in Navesink, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

title: Devils Regroup And Beat Rangers
description: The Devils yielded three goals in less than four minutes in the second period tonight, but they survived to defeat the Rangers, 6-5, before a crowd of 19,040 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Who Was the Last?
description: AT the moment that Steve Jones of Wales hastened across the finish line first in the New York City Marathon yesterday afternoon - his hair damp with sweat, his strong legs pumping, the crowd in sun-dappled Central Park cheering, the flags waving, the balloons floating - someone somewhere was dead last.

title: Hemodynamics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of Medirace of $71,773 and $1,040,766 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $155,000 for the quarter and $172,000 for the 9 months, and a gain from the sale of Medirace of $732,670 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Voters Approve New Caledonia Plan
description: President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Michel Rocard were rebuffed today when only 37 percent of France's registered voters heeded appeals to cast ballots on the future of the South Pacific territory of New Caledonia.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Consumer Credit Sept. Tuesday None Wednesday Wholesale Trade Inventories Sept. Thursday Producer Prices Oct. Friday None

title: Books of The Times; Odd Angles on Alcoholism and American Writers
description: Alcohol and the Writer By Donald W. Goodwin, M.D. 210 pages. Andrews & McMeel. $16.95.

title: TV's Voter Influence Extends Beyond Ads
description: In the battle of the airwaves on the final weekend of the 1988 campaign, it wasn't always easy to tell the candidates from the carpet salesmen.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Friday about October retail sales described results for F. W. Woolworth incorrectly. The company did report results for stores that have been open at least a year. For the four weeks ended Oct. 29, sales at such stores, both domestic and foreign, rose 5.7 percent; for the year to date, domestic sales at those stores rose 5.9 percent and foreign sales rose 3 percent.

title: Review/Theater; 'Godot': The Timeless Relationship of 2 Interdependent Souls
description: Late in Act I of the new Mike Nichols production of ''Waiting for Godot,'' one wait is over. Not the eternal wait for Godot, of course, but the wait to see how, if ever, Mr. Nichols and his all-star company might connect to the Samuel Beckett play that brought the theater into the terrifying limbo of the nuclear age.

title: With Question 6, New Yorkers Can Say Yes to Voter Information
description: To the Editor:

title: Children, Like Whales, Are in Need of Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: Tandycraft Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN DRAWS IRE ON GIBE AT TRUMAN
description: Some Democrats well known in Harry S. Truman's hometown have taken strong exception to President Reagan and his remark on a campaign swing for Vice President Bush that ''today Harry Truman's party is the Republican Party.''

title: Veronica Castang, 50, an Actress
description: Veronica Castang, an actress who performed on and Off Broadway, on television and in a film, died of ovarian cancer on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 50 years old.

title: Likely Shuttle Cargo Detailed
description: An intelligence-gathering satellite capable of spying on 80 percent of the Soviet Union will be carried by the secret space shuttle mission scheduled for late this month, a magazine reports.

title: Morgan Products Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Reagan Vetoes Bill Putting Limits On TV Programming for Children
description: President Reagan has vetoed a measure overwhelmingly approved by Congress that would have reimposed restrictions on television programming aimed at children.

title: Marvel Comic Book Unit Being Sold for $82.5 Million
description: New World Entertainment Ltd., the publisher of Marvel comic books, said yesterday that it expected to sell the comic book, children's books and licensing and merchandising operation of its Marvel Entertainment group to the Andrews Group for $82.5 million.

title: Lockheed Picks Chief For Aeronautical Unit
description: The Lockheed Corporation yesterday named Kenneth W. Cannestra to head its aeronautical systems group, an enterprise that generated annual sales last year of $4.6 billion and employs 35,000, mostly in Southern California and Georgia.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; As Wilson Goes, So Go the Vikings
description: Wade Wilson had just thrown a pass good for 52 yards. But it was a toss good only for George Jamison and the Detroit Lions. Jamison, a Lions linebacker, blitzed untouched, grabbed Wilson's pass and raced into the end zone, cutting the Minnesota Vikings' lead to 13-10 just before halftime on Sunday in the Metrodome at Minneapolis.

title: Copley Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
For the White House Physician, a Sensitive Role With a Public Patient
description: FOR the winner of the Presidential election today, one perquisite is the kind of health care not available to the average American.

title: Robertson, H H Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $47,728,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and $5,091,000 income from discontinued operations for the 9 months. c-Includes a $235,000 loss from discontinued operations for the quarter and income of $14,827,000 from discontinued operations for the 9 months. d-Net income The company said it had discontinued certain operations of its poor-performing Cupples Products division, triggering a writedown of $39,000,000 in the latest quarter; it also wrote down $8,000,000 against its Spectrum Products division.

title: Stewart Sandwiches Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $110,148 and $83,248 in the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Lebow Is Not Shy, But Is He Retiring?
description: At first, the idea of a New York City Marathon without Fred Lebow in charge seemed so strange that people laughed.

title: France's Minitel Seeks a Niche
description: France is at the halfway point in creating an ambitious nationwide network of telephone-linked computers in homes. By tapping at keyboards, users can obtain such things as train reservations, games, weather and stock market reports and banking services.

title: Air Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company was not a public company a year-earlier. The company said it had 1987 third quarter net income of $66.4 million on revenue of $945 million and 9-month net of $119.2 million on revenue of $2.50 billion. Share earnings for the 1988 periods are based on 41.1 million shares outstanding and do not include 30.8 million shares sold in October as part of the company's initial public offering. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Koch Aide Denies Lying in Myerson Trial
description: A special assistant to Mayor Koch, Herbert P. Rickman, finished testifying yesterday by vehemently denying that he lied in key parts of his testimony in the Bess Myerson trial.

title: Review/Theater; Women Slam-Dunking A Sports Stereotype
description: The title team in Molly Newman's ''Shooting Stars'' tours America as a minor league female equivalent of the Harlem Globetrotters. In exhibition games with men's teams, the women clown around, disguising the fact that they are at least the equal of many of their opponents. The time is 1962, years before women achieved equality on or off the basketball court.

title: Rise in Steel on Seaway
description: About 193,000 tons of American export steel is expected to move through the St. Lawrence Seaway by the end of 1988, nine times as much as the 21,000 tons that passed through it last year, seaway officials said today. The surge is expected to be most prominent in the last few months of the year. In October, the seaway began transporting what is expected to be a total of 153,000 tons of United States steel by the end of December, according to a statement from the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation, which operates the United States portion of the shipping channel. The seaway runs from the Atlantic west through the St. Lawrence River into the Great Lakes, and ends at Duluth, Minn.

title: Trio-Tech International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 3 Die in Crash of Church Van On Its Weekly Trip to Prison
description: A church van crashed Saturday while carrying relatives to visit inmates at Nottoway Correctional Center, killing 3 people and injuring 17, the police said.

title: Stop and Shop Marketing Insured Senior Eurobonds
description: The Stop and Shop Companies yesterday issued $200 million of insured senior Eurobonds backed by commercial mortgages on a group of its stores and warehouses.

title: First Central Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $109,754 and $320,886 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax benefits of $169,000 for the quarter and $392,000 for the 9 months. The company said its latest period results do not reflect the aquisition of Mercury Adjustment Bureau, which was completed last month.

title: Surgeons Test Sea Coral as a Bone Substitute
description: CERTAIN types of sea coral, collected from reefs in the Pacific Ocean, are being used to create a new bone substitute that may prove useful in some operations that now require bone grafts.

title: Toyota May Build Trucks in U.S.
description: The Toyota Motor Company has applied for an environmental permit to build 200,000 trucks a year at New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., its joint venture in Fremont, Calif., with the General Motors Corporation. The application, filed with the Bay Area Air Quality Management District in San Francisco, marked Toyota's first formal action toward selecting a site to build trucks in the United States.

title: Reviews/Dance; Harlem Troupe in a Multifaceted Retrospective
description: The many faces of the Dance Theater of Harlem were on view on Friday evening at Aaron Davis Hall of City College in a program that also served as a mini-retrospective of the company's 20-year history. Three of the ballets were by Arthur Mitchell, director of the company and its co-founder, with the late Karel Shook. Each dance has a simplicity and sense of style that serve the dancers and the audience well. Louis Johnson's ''Forces of Rhythm,'' a company signature work, is also a ballet that knows what it is about.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Off a Bit
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday as many investors continued to avoid committing themselves before the Treasury auctions $19 billion of new issues today and tomorrow.

title: Today We Elect a President-Monarch
description: LEAD: Many of my colleagues on campus and in the media scoff at the American people. Even those who are neither liberal nor Democratic sneer at Americans' excessive preoccupation with appearances rather than substance, with symbols rather than issues. Actually, the people have spoken clearly in favor of a constitutional reform: They want a political system like

title: Air Wisconsin Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $6,500,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: More Funds for Mexico, More Debt Trap
description: LEAD: If further evidence of the failure of the Reagan Administration's third-world debt policy were needed, the $3.5 billion loan to Mexico is it.

title: Church's Rejects Copeland Offer
description: The board of Church's Fried Chicken Inc. rejected the $8-a-share tender offer made by its rival, A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken and Biscuits. Church's said the offer, worth a total of about $295.7 million, was inadequate. The San Antonio-based company also said a merger of the two fried chicken chains would violate Federal antitrust laws.

title: Sports People; Vote to Lasorda
description: Tommy Lasorda, already named manager of the year in the National League by the Baseball Writers' Association of America, was the overwhelming choice as major league manager of the year in balloting conducted by The Associated Press.

title: Dillard Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Living With the Computer Whiz Kids
description: The trouble caused by a rogue program in national computer networks last week highlights increasing friction between the eccentric wizards who design and maintain these systems and a society that depends on the machines to run everything from banks to hospitals to military forces.

title: Southwest Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Poland Assails Walesa For His Strike Threat
description: Workers rallied in two cities today, and the official press criticized Lech Walesa, the founder of the outlawed Solidarity trade union, for threatening strikes to save the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Spotlight on Kohl
description: Last February, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany slipped in and out of Washington with scarcely anyone in the American press taking notice that he was here meeting with President Reagan and other United States officials. A week from today Mr. Kohl is due to spend 11 hours 50 minutes in the capital, but this time West German officials are hoping he will draw more attention.

title: Sports People; Arbitration Offers
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday offered arbitration to the right fielder Mike Marshall and the second baseman Steve Sax, who became free agents when they were unable to reach contract agreements with the World Series champions.

title: INSIDE
description: China Quake Toll Put at 600 A strong earthquake shook a remote region in southwestern China, and two state radio stations said 600 people were killed. Page A5. Britain Plans Post-1992 TV The British Government has called for more competition and less regulation in television after European trade barriers come down. Page C20. The World of Hackers The computer ''virus'' incident highlights the friction between computer wizards and a society that depends on the machines. Page A16. Just 2 Take Free Needles Only two drug addicts showed up to accept free needles on first day of New York City's controversial plan to slow the spread of AIDS. Page B1. New Titles for Leonard Sugar Ray Leonard stopped Donny Lalonde in Round 9 to win the light-heavyweight boxing title and a new super-middleweight crown. Page B7.

title: Patrick Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Perhaps He Pruned The Wrong Stop
description: What jelly beans are to Ronald Reagan, pork rinds are to George Bush.

title: Sierra Pacific Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $2,240,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: To Be or Not to Be a Physicist or Fisherman
description: FOR young people weighing career choices, or not-so-young people contemplating a change, The Perfect Career is a guidance counselor on a disk.

title: Belding Heminway Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $340,000 and $567,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from equity in earnings of real estate partnerships, and the 9 months also includes a gain of $43,000 from investment sales. c-Includes a loss of $113,000 for the quarter and a gain of $295,000 for the 9 months both from equity in real estate partnerships, and gains of $564,000 and $735,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on sales of cellular investments.

title: Mayfair Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-After a gain of $860,000 from an accounting change.

title: Brazil Assails U.S. on Trade
description: Brazil accused the United States today of using a dispute between the countries over pharmaceutical patents to improve its bargaining strength in world trade negotiations.

title: Sikorsky Contract
description: The Navy awarded a $119 million contract to the United Technologies Corporation for 14 Super Stallion helicopters. The contract, which covers purchases of the aircraft for the 1989 fiscal year, went to United Technology's Sikorsky Aircraft division. Seven of the heavy-lift helicopters are destined for the Navy and seven for the Marine Corps.

title: Sing Sing Officers Find Area Costs Confining
description: When he entered an academy two years ago to become a state correction officer, Bruce Werner thought he was making a good career move. He had a wife, two young children and a new mortgage on a house in Buffalo. A prison job would be secure, and the money decent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd., Toronto, said it had sold its real estate division to an unidentified Ontario developer for $42.4 million.

title: Navy Missile Passes A Test in Rebound From Costly Mistake
description: A Trident 2 missile was launched on a successful test flight today, seven weeks after one of the submarine-borne weapons was mistakenly blown up in flight.

title: Platinum Up; Silver and Gold Follow
description: Prices of precious metals moved modestly higher yesterday, largely because of a slightly weaker dollar and the continued strength of the platinum market. Copper prices, meanwhile, plunged amid heavy selling by commodity futures funds guided by computerized trading programs.

title: Hyde Athletic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Israeli Reservist Is Slain by West Bank Palestinian
description: A Palestinian stabbed to death an Israeli reservist soldier guarding a West Bank farm cooperative today. Immediately afterward, another soldier chased the assailant, then shot and killed him.

title: UTL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $45,588 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: CANDIDATES WAGE BATTLE TO DAWN OF ELECTION DAY
description: One of the most bitter Presidential campaigns in recent history extended into the early hours of Election Day itself, as Vice President Bush sought to portray himself as Ronald Reagan's rightful heir and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis invoked the underdog legacy of Harry S. Truman.

title: Spock Is Among 377 Arrested At Capitol Rally for Homeless
description: The police today arrested 377 people, including Dr. Benjamin Spock, the 85-year-old pediatrician and social activist, in the culmination of a long series of protests on Capitol Hill called to focus attention on the plight of the homeless in America.

title: Solomon Gross, 78, A Rabbi in Brooklyn
description: Rabbi Solomon Gross, president of the Munkacher sect of Hasidim, died of heart failure on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Comptroller Sets New Rules For Banks on Buyout Debt
description: The Comptroller of the Currency is preparing new guidelines for national banks that would require them to more closely supervise bank-lending activities for leveraged buyouts and other transactions that use large amounts of debt.

title: In New York, Easy Dressing Is the Rule for Spring
description: The New York spring openings that ended Friday reaffirmed the low-key feeling of the new season established in the European showings last month.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the election, alternate-side parking rules are suspended today in New York City. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: U.S. Questions Afghan Report
description: Weeks of investigations by United States officials have failed to confirm assertions by the Government in Kabul that Americans have been killed or captured recently while advising or fighting with Afghan guerrillas, United States officials said.

title: Sahara Casino Partners reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: The results reflect operations between the July 30, 1987 closing date of the initial public offering and the company's fiscal year-end Sept. 30.

title: Alfred D. Schiaffo, 68, Judge and Politician
description: Alfred D. Schiaffo, a judge in New Jersey Superior Court and a former Republican majority leader of the State Senate, died Saturday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Hackensack.

title: Two More Policemen Are Facing Charges In Tompkins Clashes
description: Two more police officers, including a sergeant, have been formally charged with misconduct in the Tompkins Square Park disturbances last summer, police officials said yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
FASHION: Patterns
description: Models in Running Shoes

title: The American Slumber
description: When you stop to think of it, the only really surprising thing about the Soviet decision to suspend its military withdrawal from Afghanistan was that the United States was surprised.

title: For Mexico, Union Power And Oil Wars
description: The accusation was a serious one: that the former head of the Mexican state oil company defrauded the Government of $49 million while in office. But when a leader of the powerful oil workers union made those charges recently, he was assumed to be acting not as a whistle-blower, but out of a desire for immediate political gain.

title: Reviews/Dance; Benitez Troupe's Energy
description: Although the Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company has only five dancers and three musicians, it possessed enormous energy on Saturday night at the Triplex Performing Arts Center of Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Chase Is said To Have Picked Brooklyn Site
description: Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo are expected to announce tomorrow that the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which has been planning to move 4,600 workers from Lower Manhattan, has decided to move them to downtown Brooklyn, people familiar with the negotiations said last night.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Maldives, Rare Gunfire Without Joy
description: Many residents of this one-square-mile seaport were unconcerned when they heard the first gunshots early Thursday that signaled the beginning of a coup attempt that has scarred and stunned this Indian Ocean nation.

title: Suitors Quarrel Over RJR Nabisco
description: A bitter battle of words broke out among two of the groups seeking RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday as Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. sent a sharply worded letter to Forstmann Little & Company that hinted it might take legal action if the Forstmann Little group proceeded with a bid for the food and tobacco company.

title: Lautenberg Leading in Poll
description: A new poll of New Jersey voters shows Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the incumbent Democrat, holding his lead against Pete Dawkins, the Republican challenger, even as Vice President Bush remains well ahead in the contest for the state's 16 electoral votes.

title: Masco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $6,320,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: L.I. Town, Focus of Housing Bias Ruling, Reflects Many in the New York Region
description: In ruling on a housing segregation case today, the United States Supreme Court focused solely on the Town of Huntington. But in many ways it could have been ruling on almost any other suburban town.

title: Chapter 11 Filing By Otasco Inc.
description: Otasco Inc., a Tulsa-based retail chain, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization and closed 170 stores in 11 states, said Jerry Goodman, chairman and chief executive of the company. Otasco's 1,600 employees were told that they were being discharged, he said.

title: Dixville Notch Gives Bush the Lead, 34-3
description: Voters in Dixville Notch favored Vice President Bush over his Democratic rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachustts, 34 to 3, in the first ballots cast in the 1988 Presidential election early today.

title: International Banknote Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after extraordinary charges of $231,000 for the quarter and $419,000 for the 9 months, both representing the loss after expenses on the exchange of common stock for 10 1/4 percent subordinated debentures.

title: Japanese Company Makes Amends on Doll
description: A Japanese company is donating $250,000 in toys to disadvantaged children as an apology for selling Little Black Sambo dolls that black Americans said were offensive.

title: Century Telephone Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July. Year-ago third quarter and 9 months include a gain of $2,807,000 on the sale of properties.

title: Free at Last, Free at Last
description: There are a few consolations at the end of this disappointing Presidential campaign after all. The main one, of course, is that it's almost over, but there are others of a more substantial nature.

title: Sports People; Kemp Leaves Kentucky
description: Shawn Kemp, a highly touted 6-foot-11-inch freshman center from Elkart, Ind., withdrew from the University of Kentucky yesterday. Kemp, who was ineligible to play varsity basketball this season because of academic difficulties, said he would enroll at Trinity Valley Community College in Athens, Tex.

title: Turner Sells CNN Center
description: Ted Turner announced today that he had sold CNN Center for $170 million, almost three times what he paid for the struggling office-hotel-shopping complex when he bought it two years ago and renamed it after his Cable News Network.

title: FASHION: By Design; White Nights
description: Now that the shows of spring fashions are over, it is clear that a major trend next year will be to wear white for occasions when one used to wear black.

title: T.W.A. Officers Shuffled; Icahn Seeking Another Line
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, realigned the top management at the carrier yesterday, assuming greater day-to-day control, and announced a drive to take over another airline.

title: Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $304,000 for both the quarter and 9 months from the redemption of subordinated debentures.

title: Japan Remains Savings Leader
description: Japan remained the world's leader in per capita savings last year, beating out the Swiss for a second consecutive year, an international survey published today found.

title: Public Service of North Caroina Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Talk: Briefing; Political Tact Required
description: If there is something out there today that could be viewed as an ethnic vote, then one could ponder whether catering to one bloc has the effect of alienating another, in this case the Albanian-American vote versus the Serbian-American vote.

title: Edison Brothers Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $8.7 million from an accounting change.

title: Oilers Beat Browns
description: Mike Rozier and Alonzo Highsmith led a rugged ground game with touchdown runs, and the Houston defense contained Bernie Kosar, the Cleveland quarterback, leading the Oilers to a 24-17 victory tonight.

title: A Fist Killed Lisa Steinberg, Doctor Says
description: The blunt trauma that the prosecution says killed Lisa Steinberg was caused by repeated blows to her head from the closed fist of a large man, a top physician at St. Vincent's Medical Center said yesterday.

title: In 'Must Win' New York, Push Is On for 2 Parties
description: Democratic Party and Dukakis campaign leaders said yesterday that they had mounted one of the most extensive vote pulling operations in recent years in New York City, where a victory for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is critical.

title: Texas Officials Defend Killing of a Jail Inmate
description: County officials, trying to justify the shooting death of an prisoner fired at 12 times, said state law allows the use of deadly force to prevent an escape.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Where Civil Rights Laws Are Still Just a Dream
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy likes to recall a speech he made 10 years ago in the Senate urging Congress to extend to its own employees the same job protections, minimum wages and worker safety laws that it mandates for virtually all other American workers.

title: Milgray Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $351,200, or 45 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: L & N Housing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest third quarter included a writedown of $6.1 million in its mortgage investments in four apartment properties.

title: Consumer Debt Shows Small Rise
description: Americans took out $1.88 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in September, the smallest rise in 10 months.

title: Commodore Environmental Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 29 about opposition to the sale of Cytotec, an ulcer-preventive drug that can sometimes induce abortion, referred incorrectly to the the drug's manufacturer, the G. D. Searle Company. It does not make the artificial sweetener Nutrasweet; that chemical is made by the Nutrasweet Company of Deerfield, Ill. Both companies are subsidiaries of the Monsanto Company.

title: New York City's Hospital Crisis Needs Attention Right Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Messerschmitt Plan Approved for Daimler
description: The West German Cabinet today approved a controversial plan to provide up to $2.3 billion in new subsidies for the German partner in Airbus Industrie, the European aviation consortium.

title: Save the Catskills Also
description: To the Editor:

title: Talman Home Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wind-Blown Ore
description: Wind can play a significant role in concentrating ores, according to a study conducted in the bauxite deposits of the Darling Range in Western Australia. The deposits, among the world's largest, contain about 900 million tons of bauxite, the mineral from which aluminum is derived.

title: Hit-Run Arrest Fails to End Questions
description: The lawyer for the parents of a 28-year-old electrician killed in a hit-and-run accident in 1986 questioned today whether the man arrested Saturday night had actually been the driver of the car.

title: Issues of Faith, More Than Land, Now Preoccupy an Anxious Israel
description: Overnight, the issue that has preoccupied Israel for most of the last year - what to do with the occupied territories - has nearly disappeared from public discussion. Instead, the nation's attention has been consumed by the unexpected surge in power of the religious right.

title: Kenya Newspaper Stock
description: The Aga Khan will relinquish his majority interest in Kenya's largest newspaper through the proposed public sale of 2.5 million shares by its owner, Nation Printers and Publishers Ltd., the company's chairman, Albert Ekirapa, said today. The stock sale, in which the group expects to gain at least 5,000 new shareholders, will reduce the Aga Khan's stake to 45 percent and will increase Kenyan investors' aggregate holdings to 52 percent from 35 percent, Mr. Ekirapa added. The Aga Khan, head of the Ismaili Muslim sect, which has 20,000 followers in Kenya, founded The Nation newspaper in 1960.

title: Florida Executes Killer of 4 Women
description: A man convicted of killing four women died in Florida's electric chair today minutes after the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his appeal.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beauty Labs Inc., Lake Success, L.I., a maker of cosmetic products, said Stephan A. Tuchman had resigned as president and a director to pursue other interests, but would remain a stockholder. Assuming all presidential responsibilities will be Harold Markowitz, its chief executive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perestroika is in a very acute phase. The great danger to the world as a whole would be the failure of perestroika.'' - Andrei D. Sakharov. [ A3:4. ]

title: Q&A
description: Q.Do some of the spy and detective techniques shown on television adventure series work in real life? For example, could agents like those on ''Mission Impossible'' transfer an identifiable fingerprint from a dead body to a glass, using Scotch tape? Can the police get a blood type from the saliva traces on a cigarette butt? A.Spokesmen for the forensic laboratories of the New York City Police Department expressed great skepticism about the fingerprint transfer. In the first place, the print on the glass from the tape would be a mirror image of the print a finger would make directly on a glass. And fingerprints left on objects are fragile and hard to isolate and identify in the best of circumstances.

title: Alatenn Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Hoist Stake Is Acquired
description: A group led by a Connecticut investment banker, Allan S. Gordon, has bought a 5.3 percent stake in American Hoist and Derrick Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Goldman said the American Hoist shares had been acquired for investment purposes only.

title: Northwest Pilot Strike Vote
description: The members of the Northwest Airlines pilots' union will vote this week on whether they support a strike against the carrier beginning Saturday. The leaders of the Air Line

title: 9 Railroad Workers in France Die in Passenger-Train Crash
description: A passenger train traveling from Luxembourg to Paris hit a maintenance car on a service track and derailed in a village station in northeastern France today, killing nine railroad employees.

title: In Philippines, Corruption Torrent Has Slowed; Expulsion for Marcoses
description: To the Editor:

title: Esquire Radio & Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,569,000 from a litigation award.

title: East German Military: Warsaw Pact's Finest
description: Most NATO officers rate the East German Army the best in the Warsaw Pact -the Soviet Army included - although it numbers only 120,000 and is made up of conscripts who serve only 18 months as compared to two years for most of the pact armies.

title: Porta Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
European Steel Output
description: Crude steel production in the European Community rose 12.5 percent in September from a year earlier, the 12-nation trade bloc said today. But the latest total, 11.8 million metric tons, was down 3.5 percent from August.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kornhauser & Calene Loses Vice Chairman
description: Dennis M. Barham is leaving Kornhauser & Calene, the agency where he has been vice chairman and creative director for a year and a half, to strike out on his own.

title: Talk in Vermont Is Largely of 'Bernie'
description: Everyone in Burlington seems to be talking about ''Bernie.''

title: Turks to Hold I.M.F. Talks
description: Struggling with foreign debt and high inflation, Turkey will try this week to convince officials of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank at talks in Washington that it is putting its economic house in order.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time Agrees to Set Up Fortune, Italian Style
description: Time Inc. has signed an agreement with Arnoldo Mondadori Editore, the Milan, Italy, publishing company, to set up an Italian version of Fortune magazine.

title: Imperial Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest second quarter included a pre-tax gain of $3.4 million from the restructuring of a retirement plan. The year-ago periods' results do not include those of Holly Sugar Corp., which was acquired in April 1988.

title: Heir of Gucci Loses Tax Case
description: Maurizio Gucci, an heir of the founder of the Gucci luxury goods company, was convicted today of attempted tax fraud and given a $750 fine and a one-year suspended sentence. Vittorio Ajello, the lawyer for Mr. Gucci, said the decision means Mr. Gucci will regain control of shares that will give him half of the company.

title: Thomas Hageman, Tenor, 55
description: Thomas Hageman, a noted tenor, voice teacher and flutist, died of complications arising from AIDS on Oct. 15 at his home in Manhattan, according to Gregory Mowery, a longtime friend. Mr. Hageman was 55 years old.

title: New Brunswick Scientific Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bacteria May Be Weapon In the Battle Against PCB's
description: SCIENTISTS at Michigan State University have uncovered evidence supporting a claim made last year by the General Electric Company that cancer-causing polychlorinated biphenyls, PCB's, can be broken down by natural microorganisms.

title: James Gutmann, 91, Philosophy Professor
description: James Gutmann, professor emeritus of philosophy at Columbia University, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan, after a brief illness. He was 91 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Kristallnacht will be commemorated this week, 50 years after the carefully orchestrated assault by Nazis on Jews and their shops, homes and synagogues in 1938. Page A1

title: Prime Motor Inns Plans 100 Hotels
description: Prime Motor Inns Inc. of Fairfield, N.J., has signed a joint-venture agreement with the AAA Development Corporation to develop 20 Howard Johnson Amerisuites hotels or Howard Johnson Plaza-Suites hotels a year for the next five years. The construction cost is estimated at about $100 million a year.

title: Sakharov Assails Threats to Perestroika
description: Leaving no doubt that he intends to be outspoken on his first trip outside the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights advocate, warned today that the Soviet process of liberalization is under ''grave threat'' because of new laws that would curb emerging political freedoms.

title: Leonard Knocks Out Lalonde to Win Two Titles
description: In the morning, Donny Lalonde had ridiculed Sugar Ray Leonard by calling him ''an old, fat welterweight.''

title: Market Place; A Stock Indicator Tied to Elections
description: MARKET indicators that work consistently are hard to come by. One of the most reliable - that the stock market does better in the first year of a Democratic administration than in the first year of a Republican one - has shown signs of failing in recent elections.

title: Being Able to Play's the Thing
description: Mike Withycombe, a Jets' rookie who once played Shakespeare in college and would like to be an actor, has suddenly emerged from a troupe of extras as a featured player.

title: Donegal Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $231,755 for the quarter and $533,703 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $118,063 and $498,971 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Critic's Notebook; Tokyo, City of the $12 Movie
description: With the dollar's having plunged versus the yen, the price of a ticket to a first-run Tokyo movie theater boggles the mind of the budget-conscious American visitor. The cost of the Tokyo ticket: 1,500 yen, which, at 124 yen to the dollar, comes out to approximately $12. That's enough to make one think fondly of Cineplex Odeon, the exhibition combine that pioneered the $7 ticket in New York. In terms of the earnings of the average Japanese, however, that is said to be the rough equivalent to New York's first-run price.

title: Democrats Foresee Gains of 2 to 4 Governorships
description: Democrats predict a net gain of two to four governorships in Tuesday's 12 elections while Republicans say they would be satisfied simply to stave off any Democratic increases.

title: Pantera's Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss

title: Summit Health Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Supreme Court Roundup; Court to Decide Whether Assets Tied to Crime Can Be Used to Pay Lawyer
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government can require a criminal defendant to forfeit the proceeds of the crime he is charged with if he needs those assets to pay a defense lawyer.

title: PHM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $955,000 and $1,334,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the early retirement of debt. The net income for both periods was unfavorably affected by net realizable value loss provisions of $2,013,000 and additional reserves of $3,050,000 for losses related to the liquidation of TMIC Insurance Co. The net income in the latest quarter was favorably affected by about $1 million, or 4 cents a shre, of reduced income taxes resulting from acquired thrift operations. c-Includes a loss of $514,000 and $2,291,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from early retirement of debt; the 9 months also include a gain of $32,000,000 from an accounting change. The net income for the 9 months includes the favorable effect of a lawsuit settlement of about $3,360,000, or 13 cents a share, net of certain reserves and reimbursements. All year-ago figures have been restated to present previously unconsolidated subsidiaries on a consolidated basis.

title: Careers; Temporary Job Needs of Government
description: THE temporary-help industry, whose 2,900 firms handle six million workers with a payroll of $8.6 billion, is awaiting a big new customer. The United States Government, with its eye on the budget deficit and seeking more managerial flexibility, is now preparing rules under which it will hire temporary workers from these firms, beginning next year.

title: Moore Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Britain Offers Plan for TV After 1992
description: The Government today published a plan calling for more competition and less regulation in commercial cable, satellite and broadcast television in Britain after 1992, when trade barriers between nations of the European Community will be removed. Douglas Hurd, the Home Secretary, said the result would be greater freedom of choice for British viewers, but the Government's critics said it would lead to a decline in the quality of British television.

title: Munsingwear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S.C. On Top Again
description: While undefeated Southern California (8-0) held first place this week in The Times's computer rankings of major college football teams, unbeaten Notre Dame (9-0) and West Virginia (9-0) slipped because they faced and trounced very weak opponents.

title: Sports People; Lefebvre Selected
description: Jim Lefebvre, a former infielder with the Dodgers and a coach for Oakland last season, was named yesterday as manager of the Seattle Mariners.

title: Still Smarting Over Bentsen Line
description: Even in the final hours, even as national public opinion polls show George Bush leading Michael S. Dukakis, the Bush campaign remains annoyed and frustrated that Seantor Lloyd Bentsen one-upped his Vice-Presidential counterpart, Senator Dan Quayle, with his comment, ''You're no Jack Kennedy.'' Bush aides are unforgiving about the comment.

title: Burger King Spinoff Planned
description: Facing an unwanted $5.2 billion takeover bid, Pillsbury announced plans to sell Burger King and pay a special dividend. Page D1.

title: Action Staffing Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Polaroid Meets With Shamrock
description: The Polaroid Corporation said that it met Sunday with Shamrock Holdings Inc. but that the parties had failed to reach a settlement resolving Shamrock's lawsuit to overturn Polaroid's Employee Stock Ownership Plan. The plan has been an obstacle in Shamrock's hostile bid for Polaroid. ''Because of fundamental differences between the parties, no settlement was reached,'' Polaroid said. The instant-photography company also said that an effort was being made to end testimony in the trial in Delaware Chancery Court by Thursday. The trial began Oct. 19 and has lasted longer than expected.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Newest Greek Tempest: Magnate Flees and Minister Takes the Fall
description: A Cabinet minister resigned today after a wealthy Greek-American businessman sought on fraud charges escaped police surveillance and fled the country.

title: Two Addicts Seek Needles On First Day
description: Only two drug addicts showed up yesterday to receive free needles on the first day of New York City's controversial experiment aimed at slowing the spread of AIDS, health officials said.

title: Drexel Said to Woo Howard Baker
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has been talking with Howard Baker, the former White House chief of staff, about becoming Drexel's chairman, The Washington Post reported today.

title: More Oil Rigs in Action
description: The number of active rigs in oil and gas exploration rose by 19 this week, to 942, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count was 1,141.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
First Interstate Bank Names Texas Officer
description: LEAD: In an effort to build a strong retail banking network in Texas, First Interstate Bank of Texas has appointed one of its California network managers, Linnet F. Deily, to be president and chief financial officer of its $7.5 billion asset flagship bank, the former Allied Bank in Houston.

title: Moscow Journal; Who's No. 2? Calibrating the Red Square Lineup
description: For the small band of Russians and Westerners who specialize in the arcane science of Kremlinology, the annual gathering of the Soviet leadership atop Lenin's tomb on Nov. 7 is usually a high point in a frustrating year. Today was no exception.

title: Complex Ties In the Battle For Nabisco
description: The anticipated bid for RJR Nabisco Inc. by the buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company will create a complex web of investors fighting for the company, and some of them, like the Pension Fund of New York State, will in effect be bidding against themselves and ultimately raising the price for the company.

title: Gitano Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Red Cross Seeks to Interview All P.O.W.'s in the Gulf War
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross is demanding the right to interview each of the 100,000 prisoners of war being held by Iran and Iraq to determine which want to return home and which want to stay with their captors.

title: Stories on Radio
description: Mike Feder, a radio storyteller, is to appear on weekend evenings through Dec. 4 at the Perry Street Theater, 31 Perry Street. Mr. Feder is the host of the radio show ''Hard Work,'' heard Sunday mornings on WBAI-FM. Tickets are $16. Reservations: 279-4200.

title: Possibility of Poisoning Is Raised In the Death of a Haitian Colonel
description: Jean-Claude Paul, who until his recent forced retirement was one of Haiti's most powerful army commanders, died in his brother's arms after eating a bowl of soup, the brother said today. A family friend speculated that the 49-year-old former colonel was poisoned Sunday at his suburban Fermathe home. The police and Government officials declined to comment.

title: To Compromise, or Not? P.L.O. Ponders the Issue
description: Five days before the start of a critical meeting, debate persists within the Palestine Liberation Organization over possible concessions regarded in the West as necessary for peace in the Middle East, Palestinian and other officials say.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Election Day
description: What's at Stake Voters will pick a President, a new House of Representatives, 33 Senators, 12 Governors and various local office holders. Polling Hours Polls open at 6 A.M. Eastern time in nine states. The last polls are scheduled to close at midnight Eastern time in Alaska. In New York: 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. In New Jersey: 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. In Connecticut: 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. Television Coverage Begins at 7 P.M. Eastern time on ABC, CBS and NBC. Based on exit polls, the networks will begin almost immediately projecting results in nine states where polls have closed.

title: State by State; New Yorkers, Too, Wish It Had Been Different
description: The skies were gray and a wind with the promise of winter in its teeth howled down Seventh Avenue yesterday less than 24 hours before the polls were to open for this country's 51st Presidential election.

title: Showboat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $813,000 from an income-tax accounting change. c-Includes a loss of $3,034,000 from a repurchase of bonds.

title: Kind of Like Waving A Red Flag at a Bull
description: Looking back over the last few months, the Bush campaign fondly recalls one of its most vivid photographic sessions, the Vice President visiting the Annin & Company flag factory here in September. The visit offered the candidate a perfect soapbox to extol his own patriotism and question his rival's belief in the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Country Lake Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for the year-ago periods were not available because the company was then part of Land O'Lakes Inc.

title: On Horse Racing; Projecting Winners of 1988 Campaign
description: There's a vicious rumor going around this Election Day that horseplayers couldn't care less about the voting. Not true! Racing fans are talking of little else these days but close races at the ballot box, the effect of the California vote, and the possible emergence of dark-horse candidates.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of candidates for judge in Westchester County yesterday gave incorrect party designations for five people. Judge Joan B. Lefkowitz, Ingrid S. Braslow, Judge John Carey, Judge Anthony A. Scarpino Jr. and Judge Donald N. Silverman are running on the Democratic ticket only -not on the Liberal ticket as well.

title: Enterra Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $320,000 and a gain on $13,137,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include a gain from the settlement of an insurance claim of $968,000, or 9 cents a share, for both periods. Results for the year-ago quarter includes a gain of $10,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations, and the 9 months includes a gain of $3,500,000, or 39 cents a share, from the curtailment of pension plans.

title: Trumpeter Carried Custer's Last Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Chase May Sell Its Discount Broker
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it was considering the sale of its discount brokerage subsidiary, Rose & Company Investment Brokers Inc.

title: CHINA QUAKE TOLL REPORTED AT 600
description: A strong earthquake shook a remote region in southwestern China on Sunday night killed more than 600 people, the Government reported today.

title: Smell of Victory Drawing a Crowd
description: Perhaps sensing victory, the Bush campaign has quietly printed hundreds of tickets for guests to appear at Andrews Air Force Base in a Maryland on Wednesday afternoon to welcome the ''President-elect.'' Plans call for Mr. Bush, if elected, to hold a news conference in Houston Wednesday morning, and then fly to Washington in midafternoon. Coincidentally, the flights from Washington to Houston, where Mr. Bush is spending Election night, are jammed with Republicans, friends of the Vice President and, of course, job-seekers.

title: Massachusetts Offering Bonds
description: The Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency is tentatively offering $161 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 8.10 percent for those maturing in 2021. The underwriters are led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Soccer; Berths for Brooklyn, Adelphi
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday announced its 24 bids for the Division I soccer tournament and none of the eight seeded teams are from New York or New England, two regions that traditionally have had the strongest representation in the tournament.

title: Otto Grun, Jeweler, 92
description: Otto Grun, a designer and manufacturer of jewelry and watches, died Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 92 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I., and Palm Beach.

title: Starrett City Will Stop Using Quotas to Foster Integration
description: Starrett City will stop using racial quotas to maintain integration at the huge apartment complex in southeastern Brooklyn, a spokesman for the management said yesterday.

title: Jaco Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $127,129 for the latest first quarter and $119,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Sale of Midwest Newspapers Blocked by Provision in Will
description: The proposed sale of the Harris Group, a chain of small newspapers concentrated in the Midwest, has been blocked by a little-noticed provision in a will.

title: Auto-Trol Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company recently changed its fiscal year-end to Sept. 30 from Dec. 31. The company said its pro forma results for the 12 months ended Sept. 30, 1987 were a loss of $1,804,000 on revenue of $70,258,000.

title: Theorist Applies Computer Power To Uncertainty In Statistics
description: A NEW technique that involves powerful computer calculations is greatly enhancing the statistical analysis of problems in virtually all fields of science.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about RJR Nabisco misattributed a statement linked to Theodore J. Forstmann, ''If I'm not an equal partner of yours, I'll cheer from the sidelines.''

title: Therapists Find Last Outpost Of Adolescence In Adulthood
description: WHILE adolescence by common reckoning ends with the teen years, it continues psychologically until the end of the 20's, when young people are finally able to establish a fully mature relationship with their parents, psychologists are finding.

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing Victory for Proud Puppy: Proud Puppy led all the way and posted a 2 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $90,900 East View Stakes for New York-bred 2-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. Proud Puppy is undefeated in four career starts. Ridden by Jose Santos, the winner went seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:25 3/5. Picadilly Lilly was second and Warfie finished third. Proud Puppy earned $54,540 for her owner, Paul E. Labe, and returned $2.80 for $2 to win. (AP) Tennis Upsets in Chicago: The teen-age newcomers Amy Frazier and Ann Grossman stunned seasoned opponents yesterday in first-round action at the $250,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. Frazier, 16 years old, of Rochester, Mich., defeated Helen Kelesi of Canada, 6-3, 4-6, 7-6. Grossman, 18, of Grove City, Ohio, beat Mary Lou Daniels of Chicago, 6-4, 6-3. Frazier, who is playing as an amateur, battled Kelesi, ranked 20th in the world, from the baseline, where she forced her Canadian opponent to make numerous unforced errors in the opening set. Kelesi, also a baseliner, and Frazier each had two service breaks in the first six games of the first set. But Kelesi failed to hold serve in two of the next three games. She came back to take the second set using a variety of drop shots. The final set was forced into a tie breaker, won by Frazier, 7-1. After failing to hold serve on the first point, Frazier won the next seven, ending the 2-hour-30-minute match when Kelesi hit a ball out of bounds. Grossman, who turned pro last summer and is ranked 53d, lost her service in the opening game of the first set. Daniels raced to a 4-2 advantage before Grossman gained control.(AP) N.H.L.

title: Knick Fans Set For Bulls
description: LEAD: The preseason of great expectations for the Knicks, coupled with the appearance of Michael Jordan, was more than enough to sell out the team's home opener tonight against the Chicago Bulls.

title: Regan Seeks Deficit Figures
description: Expressing ''serious concerns'' about accelerated state borrowing, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan implored Governor Cuomo yesterday to release an updated estimate of New York's budget deficit.

title: Books of The Times; Maurice Sendak's Mark Upon a Grimm Tale
description: Dear Mili By Wilhelm Grimm Translated by Ralph Manheim. Illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Unpaged. Michael de Capua Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux $16.95. Caldecott & Co. Notes on Books and Pictures By Maurice Sendak 216 pages. Illustrated. Michael de Capua Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Needle Program Is a Small One To Test Concept
description: The experiment that New York City health officials began yesterday in giving free needles to intravenous drug addicts is being conducted on a small scale to determine whether a larger, full-scale study is feasible.

title: Reviews/Music; Chamber Group's Ferocity
description: The Auryn Quartet was created seven years ago from string-playing members of the European Community Youth Orchestra. It is based in Cologne, West Germany, and spent last year in residence at the University of Maryland. The group made its New York debut at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night.

title: A Citizen's Critique Increases Uproar in Canada Over Trade
description: When Marjorie M. Bowker set out to read the text of the free-trade agreement between Canada and the United States, she did so, in her words, ''primarily as a quest for self-enlightenment.'' But if Canada rejects the agreement, which is the central issue in the general election of Nov. 21, the 72-year-old retired family court judge will have played an influential part in its undoing.

title: American Medical Stake Is Reduced
description: Investment L.P., a Fort Worth investment partnership, has reduced its stake in American Medical International Inc. to 2.4 percent from 7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the investment group said it had sold 3.7 million American Medical shares ''in a brokerage transaction'' for $17.42 a share, or $64.4 million. The investment partnership gave no reason for the sale.

title: Jefferson-Pilot Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains of $394,000 for the quarter and $1,296,000 for the 9 months, both from investment transactions. c-After gains from investment transactions of $44,895,000 for the quarter and $58,817,000 for the 9 months. The latest third quarter if after a pre-tax charge of about $8 million for group health claim reserves.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Casting a Wide Net
description: Congress cut off financing in October for the United States Information Agency's daily Worldnet satellite television news programming, but that does not deter the service from covering the Presidential election, according to a spokesman.

title: Ronson Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Includes a gain of $77,000, or 5 cents a share, from a legal expense reversal of a prior period. c-Includes a gain of $100,000, or 7 cents a share, from a grant by the company of a non-exclusive licensing agreement for Neodymium technology. Results for the latest periods included a gain of $92,000, or 6 cents a share, from an abatement of interest and penalties for taxes of prior years.

title: Home Office Reference Lab Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Space Beacons Replace the Compass
description: TO the captain of a clipper ship, a pocket-size gadget linked to artificial beacons in the sky that could infallibly guide a traveler to any point on earth might have seemed as remote from reality as a winged horse. But next year, anyone with a few thousand dollars will be able to buy just such a magic navigator.

title: PLM International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: PLM International became a public company in February 1988, so comparable earnings figures are not available.

title: Anglican Church Bars U.S.-Ordained Woman
description: An American woman has come into conflict with the Church of England after celebrating Holy Communion in an Anglican chapel, highlighting the continuing differences within the church over the ordination of women.

title: Cato D. Glover, 91, Commander Of the Enterprise in World War II
description: Adm. Cato D. Glover, a pioneer naval aviator who commanded the aircraft carrier Enterprise in heavy combat in the Pacific in World War II, died after a brief illness Saturday at the King James Nursing Home in Navesink, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

title: Pillsbury Planning a Revamping
description: The Pillsbury Company today became the latest major corporation to announce a restructuring of its businesses and finances in the face of a takeover threat.

title: Emery Air Freight Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months includes the results of operations for Purolator Courier Corp. since its April 1987 acquisition.

title: Sears Expects Pricing Plan To Save About $200 Million
description: Top executives of Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it would save about $200 million under its new lower-price policy by reducing advertising, trimming inventory and streamlining its warehouse distribution system.

title: Bid for Formica Is Abandoned
description: Malcolm I. Glazer, a Rochester businessman, has abandoned his efforts to acquire the Formica Corporation and sold his 8.5 percent stake in the Wayne, N.J., company. Mr. Glazer, the chairman of the First Allied Investors Corporation, had offered to acquire Formica last month for $20 a share. The bid was rejected by the decorative products manufacturer.

title: Boulder Journal; Therapists Offer Relief by Putting Patient on the Right Scent
description: His nerves were jangled and his back was aching, but Greg Taft knew just the remedy. He hurried off to see his aroma therapist.

title: Europe Split On Bank Plan
description: The European Community's finance ministers split today over plans for reciprocal treatment of foreign banks in the combined European market, an issue that worries American and other foreign bankers.

title: Sound Advice reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Conservative Jews in U.S. Ask Israel to Resist Orthodox Bloc
description: The largest American branch of Judaism, the Conservative movement, yesterday called on Israel's Labor and Likud parties to ''reject the blackmail demands'' of the religious parties that are seeking to impose Orthodox standards on daily life in Israel.

title: Corrections
description: A nationwide chart yesterday with an article about the election races for Congress misstated the number of House seats at stake in the three states where vacancies exist. There are 14 seats at stake in New Jersey, 34 in New York and 9 in Tennessee.

title: Geico Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $1,561,388 and $39,321,714 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $16,437,343 for the quarter and $53,262,573 for the 9 months.

title: 'Dial-a-Porn' Company to Pay a $50,000 Fine
description: A California company agreed today to pay a $50,000 fine and stop transmitting obscene messages on interstate telephone lines, in a case that the Government said would tell ''dial-a-porn'' services that they must act to keep their material inaccessible to children.

title: Reagan, in San Diego, Stumps for 'Legacy'
description: President Reagan returned to this coastal city today, as he did at the close of his two Presidential campaigns, to stump for his legacy, which he said will be realized in a victory for Vice President Bush.

title: Dukakis Nears the Wire In 9-State, 48-Hour Dash
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was completing his last dash tonight: 9 states, 11 cities and more than 8,500 air miles in a 48-hour scramble to defy the pundits and the polls predicting victory for Vice President Bush.

title: JWP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Barney Josephson Tribute
description: A number of noted performers and others in the arts, including Imogene Coca, Agnes de Mille, Jack Gilford, Betty Comden, Dick Hyman, Major Holley, Doc Cheatham, Dick Sudhalter and Oscar Brand, will take part in a memorial tribute to Barney Josephson at 3 P.M. on Nov. 16 at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Mr. Josephson, who owned the legendary jazz clubs Cafe Society Uptown, Cafe Society Downtown and the Cookery, died on Sept. 29 at the age of 86. The tribute, which is open to the public, is to include performances.

title: In Philippines, Corruption Torrent Has Slowed; What Is Being Done
description: To the Editor:

title: Father Convicted in Molesting
description: A 45-year-old father of six, convicted of molesting and sodomizing two teen-age daughters for half of their lives, faces a sentence of life in prison.

title: New Type of Owner Emerges In Wave of Company Buyouts
description: Wall Street vogues have a habit of passing through like tornadoes, leaving corporate America to pick up the pieces afterward.

title: Sports of The Times; Some Extra Sugar in the Punch
description: AT the weigh-in, Donny Lalonde stuck out his bare right hand, but Sugar Ray Leonard wouldn't take it.

title: Vietnam Rescued Cambodians From Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: For Germany's Jews, the Night Hope Died
description: For those still alive who were here 50 years ago, the sight of Karoline Kahn being dragged screaming by the hair down the cobbled Rebstock Street stands out with an agonizing clarity.

title: Review/Ballet; The Established and the New in Moscow Troupe
description: Thanks to the Moscow Classical Ballet, the ever-radiant Yekaterina Maksimova, one of the Soviet Union's greatest ballerinas, is performing in the United States for the first time in 22 years and a new generation of sensational male dancers has come to the fore.

title: Quake in West Los Angeles
description: A small earthquake measuring 2.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion was felt in West Los Angeles at 5:27 A.M. today, with its epicenter a mile south-southwest of Santa Monica. There were no reports of damage or injuries, said a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Quakes with to a magnitude of 3 usually produce little damage.

title: Review/Television; 'Cowboys': Still Riding The Range
description: ''Do You Mean There Are Still Real Cowboys?'' asks tonight's engaging documentary on ''The American Experience,'' at 10 on Channel 13. The answer: Yes, barely.

title: Reviews/Music; The Tonal and Atonal
description: Dennis Russell Davies led the American Composers Orchestra in a program that danced between the worlds of tonality and atonality on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, and, strangely enough, the performance shone a more attractive light on the dissonant works than on the consonant ones.

title: Dow Falls 21.16 Amid Fears of Fed Action
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday, pushed back by some program selling and by fears of a tightening of credit by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Metropolitan Financial Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $1.2 million loss reserve established in connection with pending litigation.

title: Assassins in Punjab Kill an Indian Army General
description: Gunmen presumed to be Sikhs assassinated a senior Indian Army general today outside his home in Chandigarh, the Punjabi capital, news agencies reported.

title: Bush, Relaxed and Upbeat, Heads Home for Finale
description: On the last full day of his campaign, a confident Vice President Bush insisted today that America was better off after eight years of President Reagan and that he was the candidate to stay the course.

title: Prof. Morris Janowitz Dead at 69; Specialized on Military in Society
description: Morris Janowitz, a sociologist who specialized in the role of the military in society as well as in patriotism and urban issues, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday at his home in Hyde Park. Ill. He was 69 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Trend Guru Is Named By Chrysler
description: IN one of the more unusual developments in the recent history of agency-client relationships, Laurel Cutler, the vice chairwoman of FCB/ Leber Katz Partners, has been named vice president for consumer affairs of the Chrysler Motors Corporation.
