title: C3 May Discuss Offer by Knoll
description: C3 Inc. said that it was willing to discuss a possible acquisition by Knoll Capital Management Inc. under certain conditions. Last month Knoll Capital offered to acquire C3 for $13 a share, giving the company a total value of about $128 million. Knoll already controls 9.6 percent of the Herndon, Va., company, which engineers computer systems for the Federal Government.

title: Bridge
description: When an average player describes a contract as ''cold,'' he means that it can be made without the slightest difficulty. An expert saying the same thing might be talking slightly tongue-in-cheek. Consider the diagramed deal from the world team championship for women, which ended in Venice on Oct. 22.

title: Louisiana General Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Fiscal 1987 included a gain of $485,000 from the sale of land.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Problems With Data Collection Hinder Efforts on Pollution, Experts Say
description: LEAD: AS currently collected, environmental data do not provide the full or accurate picture of the state of the environment needed to perform regulatory tasks, environmental spokesmen and Federal officials alike complain.

title: Edna Baer, Ex-Social Worker, Dies at 82
description: Edna Baer, a retired New York City social worker and the widow of State Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer, died of heart disease Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 82 years old.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations for noteworthy races. Poll hours in New York are 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., New Jersey 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Connecticut 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENT Michael Dukakis and Lloyd Bentsen (D-L) NEW YORK UNITED STATES SENATE Daniel P. Moynihan (D-L) PROPOSALS TRANSPORTATION BOND ISSUE

title: Inter-City Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After gains of $3.8 million for the quarter and $19.7 million for the 9 months, both from the dividends and the disposal of warrants in MICC Investments Ltd. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rubber Pact Approval Seen
description: The top rubber consuming nation, the United States, is expected to ratify the new International Natural Rubber Agreement in two weeks, a State Department official said today.

title: GATT Head Is Re-elected
description: The 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade unanimously chose Arthur Dunkel today for another two-year term as its Director General, a GATT spokesman said.

title: Vitiated Votes
description: At about 9:01 tonight, the networks are likely to declare the name of the new President - and thereby trash the votes of people in the West who have not yet cast their ballots. Many of them, interested in local races, will still go to the polls. But all may feel their citizenship diminished.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Berries
description: UNABLE to control many resistant pests with poisonous sprays, a California researcher has invented a gigantic vacuum cleaner that literally sucks harmful insects out of the strawberry patch, leaving most of the beneficial bugs behind.

title: Sports People; Pirates Pick Doughty
description: Larry Doughty, the Pittsburgh Pirates' assistant general manager since last winter, replaced Syd Thrift, his former boss, as general manager yesterday. Thrift was dismissed Oct. 4 after disagreements with several high officials in the Pirates' management.

title: Chess
description: The Fifth NatWest Young Masters Tournament, which finished Sept. 9 in London, ended in a tie for first place among Sergey Kudrin, a Stamford, Conn., grandmaster, and the British international masters Michael Adams and David Norwood. Each scored 6-3 in the nine-round, all-play-all competition.

title: Ailing Taylor, Ard Get Good Reports
description: In the second half of the 29-21 victory over the Dallas Cowboys here on Sunday, the Giants got a scare when such starters as Lawrence Taylor, Billy Ard and Mark Collins were knocked out of the game. Today, the medical reports were generally good.

title: Sports People; Astros Choose Howe
description: Art Howe, a versatile infielder for the Houston Astros from 1976-83, was named the team's 10th manager yesterday. He replaced Hal Lanier, who was dismissed Oct. 2. The 41-year-old Howe, a Houston resident, had been a coach with the Texas Rangers for the last four seasons. He had also spent four seasons managing in Puerto Rico during the winter.

title: Sowing The Whirlwind
description: Among the other distortions and absurdities that George Bush would have Americans believe on Election Day is his cop-out charge that it was Michael Dukakis who first engaged in ''negative campaigning.''

title: More Woes for Rangers
description: An injury here and an injury there and the league's 12-game suspension of Dave Shaw have converted the Rangers' defensive corps from one of the strongest to one of the weakest in the National Hockey League.

title: F.D.A. Warns Doctors On Intravenous Feeding
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration, citing the deaths of three patients, has urged doctors to make sure that liquid diets used in intravenous feedings are supplemented with vitamin B1.

title: Talking Business; with Hill of Kalan Sutton McGraw; A Weak Outlook For Toy Industry
description: Christmas is the peak season for the nation's $12 billion toy industry, but toy sales have been relatively flat for several years. Jim Hill, vice president and West Coast director for Kalan Sutton McGraw Inc., a consulting concern, tells why. He used to be a senior vice president of Mattel Toys Inc.

title: Old Republic International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a realized investment loss of $109,096 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $2,667,985 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $2,349,443 and $9,657,795 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Sports People; Florida Star Suspended
description: Dwayne Schintzius, Florida's 7-foot-2-inch junior center, has been suspended indefinitely because of an off-court incident Friday night, Coach Norm Sloan said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Begins Investigation Of Computer 'Virus' Case
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation began an official criminal investigation today of the computer ''virus'' that crippled a nationwide Pentagon data network last week, and officials indicated that a decision on whether to prosecute the author of the renegade computer program was near.

title: Homeowner Acquitted in Fatal Crash
description: A Queens homeowner was found not guilty yesterday of a charge that he had committed manslaughter by pouring oil onto a roadway to discourage drag racers, causing one young driver to die when his car skidded into a tree.

title: Talks on Angola and Namibia To Resume Friday in Geneva
description: Officials from Angola, Cuba, South Africa and the United States will meet Friday for another round of talks on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, the State Department said today.

title: Refunding Bonds From San Antonio
description: San Antonio is tentatively offering $132.68 million of general obligation refunding bonds via underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Scor US Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $17,623 and $67,607 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and also includes an $18,205 charge from the reversal of a tax credit in the quarter. c-Includes investment gains of $240,626 and $888,198 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $48,943 and $158,447 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Scholars Track the Alphabet With New Precision
description: SOME of the most learned scholars are having problems with the ABC's.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Saturday about the appointment of Susan Lubowsky as director of the visual arts program of the National Endowment for the Arts misstated her current position. She is branch director of the Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center in New York.

title: HIGH COURT VOIDS QUOTAS ON RACES IN HOUSING UNITS
description: A huge Brooklyn apartment complex lost its battle to defend racial quotas to maintain integration when the Supreme Court refused today to review a lower-court ruling that the quotas violated Federal law.

title: Elizabeth Ramos, 33; Won an AIDS Verdict
description: Elizabeth Ramos, who won a $750,000 jury verdict in an AIDS malpractice case and later became an advocate promoting understanding of the disease, died Friday. She was 33 years old.

title: Deltona Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
description: b-Includes tax credits of $133,000 and $912,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $550,000 for the quarter and $912,000 for the 9 months. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter and year-ago 9 months.

title: Typhoon Rakes Philippines
description: The second typhoon in two weeks pounded the central Philippines with 108-m.p.h. winds and torrential rains today, causing floods and mudslides. At least 10 deaths were reported, and the Government said that about 200,000 people ''affected'' by the typhoon, meaning their homes or property were damaged or destroyed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wrestling Federation To Introduce Fragrance
description: The year-old Ranjilor Development Corporation of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has called on Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss to help introduce a fragrance it is developing in a franchise arrangement with the World Wrestling Federation.

title: Restoring a Leonardo Drawing That Was Hit by a Shotgun Blast
description: A drawing by Leonardo da Vinci, damaged last year when a vandal fired a shotgun blast into it from a distance of about seven feet, has largely been restored through an elaborate process in which dozens of tiny fragments of paper were glued back together, one by one.

title: In Philippines, Corruption Torrent Has Slowed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Black College Gets Cosby Gift Of $20 Million
description: Bill Cosby and his wife, Camille, have donated $20 million to Spelman College, the elite black women's college in Atlanta.

title: Lawson Mardon Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included a $7.1 million special gain ''associated with the establishment of a joint venture in Europe.'' The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Remarkable Disk Doctor
description: HERE are a couple candidates for your software and bookshelves.

title: Reviews/Dance; New Choreographers
description: The Salon Project, organized by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy, helps new choreographers and dancers bring works before the public. Like many showcases, it features premieres. But the most successful piece presented Sunday night at the Dia Art Foundation was one that dancegoers may have seen before.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about M. Joseph Blumenfeld, a former chief judge of the Federal District Court in Connecticut, misidentified a daughter in some copies. She is Alice Kramer.

title: Our Towns; For Mentally Ill, Succor Is Found In Group Homes
description: Robert Wiebel says that the worst thing about mental hospitals was being tied down 24 hours at a time. ''A straitjacket is not that bad, but tied down, all you can do is cry.'' At 20 years old, he started hearing voices. ''Persecuting voices, commanding voices, they caused me great stress and fear.'' Three times he fled hospitals and lived in New York City, homeless. ''I begged change on corners. If you could be impervious to the cold, it wouldn't be that bad. But this time of year, on the ledge of winter, it's awful. I've seen people lose limbs from being cold too long. In Pilgrim State, I remember a man without fingers.''

title: Judge Dismisses One Charge Against North in Iran-Contra
description: One of 16 criminal charges against Oliver L. North, the former White House national security aide, was dismissed today without opposition from the prosecution in the Iran-Contra conspiracy case.

title: Fyffes in Appeal
description: A six-month battle for control of the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., which makes Jameson, Powers and Bushmills whiskies, went to Ireland's Supreme Court as the Dublin fruit importer FII Fyffes P.L.C. began an appeal of an earlier court ruling.

title: The Bad News Is Apathy
description: The good news is that the grubby, cynical campaign is over. This had to be written before the polls closed, but the bad news was telegraphed ahead: it is the number of Americans who can't be bothered to vote.

title: Pool of Mathematicians Will Keep Shrinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert C. Baldwin, Professor, 83
description: Prof. Robert C. Baldwin, who was chairman of the philosophy department at the University of Connecticut for almost 30 years, died Monday at the Riverside Nursing Home in East Hartford, Conn., after suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old and lived in Storrs, Conn.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; UTAH
description: With Mr. Bush comfortable about a state that gave Mr. Reagan 74 percent of its vote in 1984 and 72 percent in 1980, the question in Utah was whether a strong Republican showing would hurt the bottom of the Democratic ticket. Utah has five votes in the Electoral College.

title: Visual Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hooper Holmes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $3,154,500, or $1.02 a share, on the sale of the majority of the business information services group.

title: Baltic Economists Prepare for Autonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Amish, Joy Is in Celebration of the Simple
description: FOLLOWERS of the Swiss Mennonite bishop Jacob Ammann have prospered in northeastern Ohio since 1888, making their living much as their Alsatian ancestors did, as dairy farmers and loggers and more recently as carpenters and cabinetmakers. While cities have matured and modernized around them, the small communities 40 miles east of Cleveland have been left largely to themselves; indeed, for the 8,500-member Old Order Amish settlement, one of the nation's largest, time has nearly stood still.

title: The Pop Life
description: Jarrett: More With Less

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Midwest; OHIO
description: Mr. Bush won Ohio's 23 electoral votes. The state had been given top priority by both campaigns, and Mr. Dukakis had taken a pounding from Mr. Bush's assault on gun control, crime, abortion and taxes. Along with states like

title: Bush Victory Talk: 'I Mean to Be a President of All the People'
description: Following are excerpts from George Bush's acceptance speech last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Beatrice K. McClintock, Volunteer, 74
description: Beatrice Kellogg McClintock, an advocate of legalized abortion and a member of the board of Planned Parenthood, died in her sleep Sunday at her home in Glen Cove, L.I. She was 74 years old.

title: NEW YORK PASSES ROAD BOND ISSUE
description: New Yorkers approved the largest bond issue in the state's history yesterday - a $3 billion transportation proposal that state officials had promoted as the only means of avoiding a tax increase next year.

title: Swiss Denial in Cash Case
description: A Swiss company today rejected accusations that it had helped launder more than $1 billion. The money was said to have been channeled through Switzerland by a drug ring dubbed the ''Lebanese Connection.''

title: Turkey Investment Fund
description: A $60 million Turkey Investment Fund will be offered on the New York Stock Exchange next year to provide fresh cash for that country's flagging economy, bankers said today. The closed-end fund will allow foreigners to make an easily resellable investment in Turkey, although the fund itself must keep its investments there for 25 years. It is being managed in the United States by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Brooklyn Store Owner Shoots Robber to Death
description: Confronted by two men who tried to rob him at gunpoint, the owner of a variety store in Brooklyn pulled out a licensed gun and fired at them yesterday, killing one as the other fled, the police said.

title: Jets Sign Lineman
description: Because of recent injuries to their offensive line, the latest of which knocked out Guy Bingham, a guard, for from four to six weeks with a sprained right knee, the Jets yesterday signed Ron Tilton, a 6-foot-4-inch, 270-pound lineman who had been cut by the club in training camp Aug. 28. To make room for the former Tulane lineman, who was signed as a free agent in February after playing seven games for the Washington Redskins in 1986, the Jets waived Steve Hammond, a linebacker, for the second time this season.

title: Trump Taj Mahal Funding In Mortgage Bond Offering
description: Trump Taj Mahal Funding Inc. yesterday offered $675 million of 14 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 1998 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; VIRGINIA
description: Mr. Bush was the clear winner in Virginia's Presidential contest, while Charles S. Robb, the popular Democratic ex-Governor, easily won a seat in the Senate, proving once again that Virginians are not devoted to one party.

title: Top Trader Is Joining Smith Barney
description: Signaling its determination to become a major Wall Street trading house, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company announced yesterday that Lewis L. Glucksman, a widely respected stock and bond trader, would join the investment house, effective Saturday, to run all of Smith Barney's trading activities.

title: Wellco Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Year-ago quarter revenue has been reclassified to conform to current period presentation.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; KENTUCKY
description: The Dukakis campaign made a serious effort for the nine electoral votes of Kentucky, where Democrats outnumber Republicans 2 to 1. But Mr. Bush easily captured this border state.

title: HPSC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Should promising young female scientists be given grants to have their infants cared for in their homes while mother is busy in the laboratory? Carl Djerassi, professor of chemistry at Stanford University, considers such aid essential to attract more women to high-level science. He calls for five-year subsidies to allow more female scientists to enjoy motherhood without sacrificing their careers.

title: Tomball Journal; Rural Recluse Collides With an Unnatural World
description: It has never been easy being Elmer Kleb.

title: Rules on Mayoral Succession And Anti-Corruption Voted
description: Voters in New York City overwhelmingly approved a wide range of amendments to the City Charter yesterday.

Divided Panel on Budget Deficit Abandons Its December Deadline
description: Torn by dissension, the bipartisan commission appointed by Congress to propose a plan to reduce the budget deficit has abandoned its Dec. 21 deadline, its co-chairmen said today.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; FLORIDA
description: Even though Hispanic voters helped give Mr. Dukakis one of his two Southern primary victories here last March, Florida's 21 electoral votes were considered safe for Mr. Bush, and exit polls and early returns supported this expectation.

title: Boxing Notebook; Chavez Has Plans To Spar With King
description: Don King has problems with Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Association-World Boxing Council lightweight champion.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: The New York Region; NEW JERSEY
description: Mr. Bush, according to exit polls and early returns, took New Jersey and its 16 electoral votes, which Mr. Dukakis had largely written off. Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat, the incumbent, edged out his Republican challenger, Pete Dawkins.

title: High Crop Damage in Japan
description: Unusually cool and rainy weather this summer has caused severe damage to Japan's rice and vegetable crops, increasing food prices and requiring Government aid to farmers, officials reported today.

For Many New York Areas, Wait for Cable TV Ends
description: For years, Tony Triano of the Bronx said, the rest of the world seemed to have what his borough did not - cable television. Friends in Manhattan had Islanders' hockey games piped into their living rooms. His sister-in-law in Nyack, N.Y., could flick on movies at will.

description: A swarm of Africanized bees was found last week on a ship docked in Tampa.

Nixon in 1972 and for Mr. Reagan in 1984. In the Senate race, Senator Spark M. Matsunaga, a Democrat, made a strong bid for his third term against Maria M. Hustace, a rancher. Exit polls forecast that his bid would succeed. Representative Daniel

title: Asians Increasing at U.S. Colleges
description: The number of Asian students who attend colleges and universities in the United States increased significantly last year and for the first time accounted for more than 50 percent of the total enrollment of foreign students.

title: The Road to Extermination: Kristallnacht Lessons Pondered by Historians
description: Fifty years ago many Americans voiced shock at the terrible events of Kristallnacht. But not long afterward, when Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York proposed to stretch immigration quotas so that about 10,000 Jewish children could escape Nazi violence and come to the United States, the effort was defeated in a Congressional committee.

title: Red Wing Suspended
description: As a result of another stick-swinging incident in the National Hockey League, a Detroit Red Wings forward, Miroslav Frycer, was suspended for 10 games yesterday for injuring a Philadelphia forward, Murray Craven, last Saturday. The ban began at Sunday's game, which Frycer sat out under automatic suspension while awaiting his hearing, Brian O'Neill, the N.H.L. executive vice president, said. ''In my judgment, Frycer used excessive and careless tactics to check an opponent and, through this action, caused a serious injury,'' O'Neill said. ''While he did not intend to injure Craven, neither did he show any restraint.'' In the first month of the season, the N.H.L. assessed 26 major penalties for stick fouls.(AP)

title: Tennis; For Pros, a Stroke of Self-Determination
description: When the men's professional tennis union talks about running its own tour in 1990, the players cite the European Community Championship, which ended here Sunday, as the kind of event they want to promote.

title: Charges Face Divorce Lawyer
description: The state bar of California has filed seven additional charges of professional misconduct against Marvin Mitchelson, the divorce lawyer who established the principle that unmarried people may be entitled to some of their lovers' property.

title: Three Seek Fame Outside California
description: WHAT do Handley Cellars, Lamborn Family Vineyards and Rabbit Ridge Vineyards have in common? All are California boutique wineries whose wines await discovery on the East Coast.

title: The 1988 Elections; West Still Wasn't Won When TV Named the Winner
description: Polls were still open in the Western states last night when the television networks announced George Bush's victory, living up to the letter of a commitment they made to Congress but still stirring the ire of many politicians.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; IDAHO
description: Mr. Bush easily won Idaho's four electoral votes over Mr. Dukakis. That was no surprise since no Republican Presidential candidate has received less than 56 percent of the votes in the state since 1968.

title: Hackensack Names Deputy Fire Chief
description: A deputy fire chief has been appointed in this city where five firefighters were killed in a car dealership blaze, the City Manager said, and the deputy will oversee day-to-day operations of the Fire Department.

title: An Unofficial Secrets Act?
description: LEAD: On Oct. 13, the Law Lords, Britain's highest court, punched a small hole in the Official Secrets Act by permitting the publication in England of material from ''Spycatcher.'' The book, by Peter Wright, a former Government employee, reveals British intelligence activities, primarily in the 70's. The act makes it a crime to disclose any Government information without proper authorization.

title: It Was a Joke, Myerson Witness Says
description: A witness in the Bess Myerson trial told reporters yesterday that what prosecutors have implied was an attempt at witness tampering was in fact an old joke that he and Ms. Myerson had long shared.

title: Computer Whizzes Meet Their Match: A Worthy Cause
description: LEAD: While a small handful of computer experts have chosen to turn their imaginative minds to decoding and destroying seemingly secure systems, a group here saw the altruistic potential of their collective computer wisdom. The Compumentor Project, as the two-year-old group is called, has proven successful in making unlikely matches between a band of cerebral volunteers and nonprofit groups that have been reluctant to seek computer assistance.

title: Waldheim Asserts Austrians Should Not Hide Nazi Years
description: President Kurt Waldheim, found by an international historians' commission to have hidden his wartime past, said today that no veil of silence should be drawn over Austrian involvement in the Nazi crime against the Jews.

title: The 1988 Elections; Indiana Elects Bayh's Son Governor; Moore Is Ousted by West Virginians
description: Indiana elected a 32-year-old Democrat, Evan Bayh, as the nation's youngest Governor yesterday, ending the Republicans' 20-year hold on the state's top office.

title: Jersey Elects a Black Congressman
description: Voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut filled several open House seats, and voters in Newark and its suburbs elected New Jersey's first black Representative.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cheshire Financial Corp., a Keene, N.H., bank holding company, named Peter J. Baxter to succeed David B. Walters as president and chief executive.

description: b-After a gain of $35 million from an accounting change.

title: What George Bush Won
description: It was gray and windy in Portsmouth, N.H. on Thursday morning, Feb. 11, the first day of the rest of George Bush's political life. Three days before, he had finished third in Iowa, and if he couldn't overtake Bob Dole in New Hampshire his candidacy would likely be over. After wandering from lumberyard to truck stop he spoke at the Feaster Apartments for senior citizens and took his stand, as he said, warts and all.

title: Hurdles to Low-Cost Suburban Housing Felled by Ruling
description: The legal barriers to building affordable housing in the suburbs crumbled significantly on Monday when the United States Supreme Court ruled that the Town of Huntington, L.I., violated Federal fair-housing laws through exclusionary zoning.

title: THE 1988 ELECTION: The G.O.P. Advantage; Peace, Prosperity and a Disaffected South Were Among the Hurdles Facing Dukakis
description: It has never been easy to oust a party from the White House in times of peace and prosperity. That was the first underlying principle of the 1988 Presidential election.

description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as the Government securities market digested a heavy supply of new issues and all sectors were preoccupied with the outcome of the Presidential election.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: COOL weather never deters me from outdoor grilling. I have even raised a few eyebrows among dinner guests in January or February by excusing myself and slogging through the snow to retrieve meats barbecuing on my backyard patio. For the less hardy, the recipe here for Middle Eastern- style brochettes of lamb can also be prepared under a kitchen broiler with excellent results.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Midwest; KANSAS
description: Mr. Dukakis did not put up much of a struggle for Kansas and its seven electoral votes. Republicans far outnumber Democrats in Kansas, where Franklin D. Roosevelt and Lyndon B. Johnson were the only modern Democratic Presidential candidates to win. Mr. Dukakis did not join their ranks. Mr. Dukakis's slim hope in the home state of Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader in the Senate, was a sizable bloc of independent voters. Of 1.12 million registered voters in Kansas, 42 percent are Republicans, 29 percent are Democrats and 29 percent are independents.

description: Saudi Arabia and Texaco Inc., the third-largest American oil company, have completed an $800 million oil refining deal and will sign the agreement on Thursday, a spokesman said today. Under the agreement, the

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Midwest; MINNESOTA
description: A fierce Senate battle ended with the victory of the Republican incumbent, David Durenberger, incomplete totals showed.

title: Milwaukee Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Northeast; WEST VIRGINIA
description: With six electoral votes at stake in West Virginia, Mr. Bush ate away at Mr. Dukakis's early lead, but the Democrat was able to win handily. The state has favored Democrats in recent elections, although it went to President Nixon in 1972 and was no exception to the 1984 Reagan landslide. In the Senate race, Senator Robert C. Byrd, a five-term Democratic veteran, easily won re-election over Jay Wolfe, a Republican freshman in the State Senate who used a political commercial that showed a bloody fetus, which caused an uproar.

title: Sugar Ray's Time Machine
description: HE'S 32 years old, but Sugar Ray Leonard is not your usual 32-year-old boxer. He's more like a 1982 classic car that was put up on blocks and is now out on the road again, the motor purring smoothly. Because of his detached-retina surgery that put him up on blocks for most of six years, the mileage on Sugar Ray Leonard's boxing odometer resembles that of a much younger gladiator.

title: To Roll Call, Congress Is 'Small Town'
description: AT different times, Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange, considered buying The Daily News, The New York Post and The Village Voice. Instead, he purchased Roll Call, the University Press of America and half of Battery News. Surely, this is a subtle way to build a publishing empire.

title: Farm & Home Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A New Japanese Push on Chips
description: Only four years after Japan's electronics giants invested billions of dollars in new clean-rooms and precision equipment to dominate the world market in memory chips, they are doing it again.

title: ...And in Munich
description: LEAD: On the morning of Nov. 10, 1938, I was living in Munich, three months shy of my 10th birthday. The night before, in the dark hours of the evening, the Holocaust began. One dictionary definition of ''holocaust'' is ''burned offering,'' and during the night of Nov. 9 and into the next day hundreds of synagogues throughout Germany and Austria were torched.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; SOUTH CAROLINA
description: Mr. Bush easily carried South Carolina, which is home to Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr., his Southern campaign chairman. The state gave its eight electoral votes to Barry Goldwater in 1964, with a 59 percent majority, and has voted Republican ever since except in Jimmy Carter's first campaign in 1976.

description: In the Costa del Sol resort of Puerto Banus, where scores of yachts and pleasure crafts dock, several men were unloading cartons from a yacht into the trunk of a car one afternoon not long ago.

description: Mr. Bush, as expected, easily won Tennessee's 11 electoral votes. Mr. Dukakis had trouble capitalizing on the state's strong Democratic traditions, and on the support of two favorite sons, one of them his old primary rival, Senator Albert Gore Jr. Senator Jim Sasser, a Democratic colleague of Mr. Gore, also tried to help Mr. Dukakis when he was not fighting off a relatively weak challenge by Bill Anderson, a Republican law partner of Howard H. Baker Jr., the former Senate leader and White House chief of staff. Mr. Sasser retained his Senate seat by a comfortable margin.

description: Harold Stephenson Sloan, a retired manufacturer, economist, teacher and author who was a brother of the industrialist Alfred P. Sloan, died in his sleep Saturday at his home in Lopatcong Township, N.J. He was 100 years old.

title: Ford Optimistic On Models for '89
description: Executives of the Ford Motor Company said they expected its new 1989 Thunderbird sedan to eclipse the popularity of its previous restyling, which six years ago inaugurated Ford's acclaimed aerodynamic look. Ford told its dealers that they could begin taking orders for the model on Dec. 1, even though it will not be formally introduced, along with a restyled Mercury Cougar, until Dec. 26.

title: Second B-1 Bomber Crashes; 4 Fliers Eject Safely
description: A new B-1 bomber returning from a routine training flight crashed today near Dyess Air Force Base in Texas. All four aviators ejected and parachuted to safety.

description: Mr. Bush won an easy victory in reliably Republican Wyoming, a state that was never contested by the Democrats.

title: Taking Celebrity Worship To New Depths
description: LEAD: DEVOTED fans have long worshipped at the feet and doorsteps, concert halls and stage doors of their favorite celebrities. Now, however, hero worship has taken on new, and sometimes bizarre, twists. Fans are renting a red convertible once owned by Karen Carpenter, wearing Cher's old clothes, buying dirt from Dolly Parton's lawn, photographing themselves with life-size wooden replicas of Don Johnson (with a 5 o'clock shadow) and visiting Marilyn Monroe's grave.

Lieberman Edges Out Weicker; Lautenberg and Moynihan Win

Weicker Jr. as a bear hibernating during important roll call votes, scored a narrow victory over the three-term Connecticut Republican yesterday. But Mr. Weicker, refusing to concede defeat, said he would request a recount today.

title: Howard Jeffrey, 53, A Producer of Films And Choreographer
description: Howard Jeffrey, a film producer who had also choreographed for Broadway shows and movies, died of AIDS Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 53 years old.

title: Kroger Settlement On Restructuring
description: The Kroger Company has reached an out-of-court settlement with 11 of the 14 shareholders who sued to block the company's $4.6 billion restructuring plan. The remaining shareholders will fight the deal. The six class action lawsuits were filed after the Cincinnati-based company announced plans on Sept. 15 to restructure to discourage two unsolicited takeover bids. The suits, which were consolidated into one, accuse Kroger's executives of trying to protect their jobs through the plan.

title: Craft Museum's Edible Collection of Art
description: ART lovers with a taste for something different may want to visit the American Craft Museum. On Friday, the museum will unveil its new exhibition, ''The Confectioner's Art,'' an edible and edifying collection of sculpture, paintings, jewelry, toys and assorted items made of food. The show, which runs through Jan. 22, is the first of its kind in the United States, said the museum's director, Paul J. Smith.

title: Year of Family Wins Friends and Some Foes
description: A proposal for an International Year of the Family has gained widespread backing but prompted apprehension and outright opposition, particularly among women's groups, who say the occasion might be used to reverse gains in women's rights.

description: Following are excerpts from the concession speech of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, as recorded by The New York Times:

Boxing Judges Barred
description: The three judges whose disputed decision gave the gold medal to a South Korean fighter over the American Roy Jones at the Seoul Olympics have been barred from judging international amateur bouts until a final ruling is made, officials said yesterday. West German news reports in Berlin quoted Karl-Heinz Wehr, the East German general secretary of the International Amateur Boxing Federation, as saying a decision was likely on the three judges next March. The dispute revolves around the boxing judges Bob D. Kasule of Uganda, Alberto Duran of Uruguay and Hiouad Larbi of Morocco. (AP)

title: Kingman Brewster Jr., 69, Ex-Yale President and U.S. Envoy, Dies
description: Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University from 1963 to 1977 and Ambassador to Britain from 1977 to 1981, died of a brain hemorrhage yesterday in John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford, England, a Yale spokesman announced in New Haven. Mr. Brewster was 69 years old and lived in Oxford, where he had been the master of one of Oxford University's colleges since 1986.

title: Group Sees Sale Of Allegheny Units
description: A New York-based merchant banking group seeking Allegheny International Inc. said it was confident that the company's Sunbeam Appliance and Oster units could be sold as part of the deal. The group, Gilliam, Joseph, Littlejohn & Levy, has offered to acquire the company for about $703.5 million, of which $662.3 million would be in cash.

title: Arab Youths in Israel Hurl Rocks at Police
description: Hundreds of Israeli Arab youths in the village of Tiabe battled the police with rocks and burning tires for the second consecutive day today. It was the most violent rioting inside Israel since March.

title: Lieberman Upsets Weicker in Close Race; Margin of Victory Spurs Recount
description: Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut scored a narrow upset over Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. yesterday, but the Senator, refusing to concede defeat, said he would seek a recount today.

title: Union Station's Street Food
description: CONSIDER yourself fortunate if you have time on your hands at Union Station in Washington. Not only can you shop to your heart's content in this grand Beaux-Arts building that just received a $150 million renovation, but you can also eat yourself into a stupor, choosing among 15 stalls and two cafes, with more to come.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Midwest; ILLINOIS
description: The race between Mr. Dukakis and Mr. Bush for Illinois's 24 electoral votes remained very close. The two Presidential candidates fought hard and close in the state, where the campaign tested their ability to draw not only inner-city voters but also those in rural southern Illinois.

title: Freeport-McMoran Energy Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are in units.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; OKLAHOMA
description: Mr. Bush - who won in Oklahoma - was never threatened despite a Democratic registration edge of better than 2 to 1 and the popularity of Lloyd Bentsen.

title: A Profile of the RJR Nabisco Committee
description: Five directors of RJR Nabisco Inc. make up a special committee that will review bids for the food and tobacco conglomerate. CHARLES E. HUGEL, 60, who heads the committee, is chairman of RJR Nabisco and chairman and chief executive of Combustion Engineering Inc., based in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Hugel became chairman of Nabisco - a position with no day-to-day management responsibilities - in 1987.

title: Male Strippers in 'Ladykillers' on ABC
description: In recent weeks, television viewers have had Geraldo Rivera grappling histrionically with Satan and young bigots, only to wind up with a broken nose covered in blood and his face on the cover of a national news magazine. Then there was ''Favorite Son,'' using kinky sex and profound political cynicism to chalk up the highest ratings so far this year for a mini-series.

title: Lifecore Biomedical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $69,000 from the adoption of FASB standards. c-Net loss

title: Toll Reported in China Earthquake Reaches 938
description: Officials said today that 938 people were known to have died in an earthquake on Sunday in a remote area of southwestern China near the Burmese border. But rescue workers have just begun to search the region, and the death toll may rise significantly.

title: New Wave in the East River: David Burke
description: PUSHING himself to be creative has paid off for David Burke, the 26-year-old executive chef of the River Cafe in Brooklyn. In a short time, he has risen to authority in a bellwether restaurant, while his abilities have been rewarded in competition with other young chefs. He belongs to the new wave of cooking professionals who set the culinary pace.

title: Graphic Packaging Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Overseas Shipholding Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains from vessel sales of $1,023,000, or 4 cents a share, and $1,674,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes gains from vessel sales of $3,038,000, or 12 cents a share, and $4,236,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Corken International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Photon Technology Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Freeport-McMoran Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; NEW MEXICO
description: Mr. Bush mounted a strong campaign in New Mexico, with five electoral votes. Like much of the Southwest, the state's voting record held little comfort for Mr. Dukakis; it has been solidly Republican in Presidential elections since 1968.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Midwest; MISSOURI
description: Mr. Bush and two popular Republican incumbents, Senator John C. Danforth and Gov.

title: In Cape Squalor, Enter Mother Teresa
description: Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who won the Nobel Peace Prize for her unstinting work among the wretched of the earth, came today to this bleak black township erected by Government decree on the barren sand flats beyond Cape Town.

title: Retirees Are Still Paying For Years of Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Northeast; NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Mr. Bush won this traditionally Republican state, where a come-from-behind victory over Senator Bob Dole of Kansas in last February's Republican primary put him on the road to the nomination. Mr. Dukakis's residence in neighboring Massachusetts proved little help in capturing the state, which has four electoral votes and last went for a Democrat in 1964.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; COLORADO
description: Ballot issues dominated the stage in Colorado, where Mr. Bush won the state's eight electoral votes. Republicans have now carried the state in every Presidential election since 1968.

title: Newsprint Price Delay
description: Newsprint manufacturers in the United States and Canada have postponed price increases scheduled to take effect Jan. 1 because the market in the United States had been weakened by a sharp decline in newspaper advertising this year.

title: Tax Showdown Nears in Japan
description: Japan's Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, has put his political reputation on the line by leading his party's third attempt in 10 years to introduce an unpopular sales tax, political analysts said today. A similar proposal by his predecessor, Yasuhiro Nakasone, died last year amid wide protests.

title: Europe Firm On Meat Ban
description: The European Community said today that a ban on imports of meat treated with hormones would take effect as planned Jan. 1, despite threats of retaliation from the United States.

title: American Biltrite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $600,000 tax credit.

title: Lautenberg, Bucking Bush Trend, Beats Dawkins
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic incumbent, defeated Pete Dawkins last night at the end of what was regarded as one of the nastiest and most intensely personal political feuds in the nation this year.

title: Driver-Harris Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $11,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $188,000 for the 9 months.

title: Clear Channel Communicaions reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the current quarter and 9 months include a gain of $610,000 from the sale of the company's interest in the San Antonio Cellular Telephone Co.

title: Nets Rally To Win
description: When the Nets fell behind in the fourth quarter tonight, they didn't fall apart. Rallying from a 10-point deficit with five minutes left in the game, New Jersey whipped the Washington Bullets, 109-101, before 7,804 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: The New York Region; CONNECTICUT
description: Both candidates battled to the wire for Connecticut's eight electoral votes, and Mr. Bush won the state by six percentage points.

title: A New Image
description: To The Living Section:

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; PUERTO RICO
description: Puerto Rico, a commonwealth, has no electoral votes, although it had primaries to elect delegates to the national conventions. Polls have shown that

title: Nehru Year: Defining the Man Who Defined India
description: The life and legacy of India's brilliant founding father, Jawaharlal Nehru, are about to get a public airing across this vast nation, just as the Nehru political dynasty approaches a critical electoral test.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cincinnati Reds have released Leon Durham, a first baseman who had a season marred by injury and substance abuse after being obtained from the Chicago Cubs May 18. Durham, 31, hit .216 with one homer and two runs batted in in 51 games. . . . A former Green Bay Packers defensive back, Mossy Cade, who served 15 months in prison for sexual assault, has been claimed on waivers by the Minnesota Vikings. The Vikings placed Cade, who was paroled last month, on the reserve list. The N.F.L. rejected Cade's request to play this season.(AP)

title: U.S. Inspector Reports Too Much Waste at Nuclear Weapon Plant
description: Several storage areas at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapon plant near Denver are becoming dangerously overcrowded as a result of Idaho's decision last month to refuse shipments of radioactive waste from the factory, a Federal inspector said today.

title: Manville to Sell Holophane Unit
description: The Manville Corporation said it planned to sell its Holophane Lighting Systems division, based in Newark, Ohio. Alfred B. Gough, a company official, said Holophane's ''specific market niche no longer strategically fits our core businesses or future growth plans.'' Its sales should exceed $100 million this year, Manville said.

title: Halliburton Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $9 million from an accounting change. The year-ago results have been restated for the effect of consolidation of the insurance services segment as well as the reclassification of foreign currency gains and losses to non-operating income.

title: INSIDE
description: Delay on Deficit Plan

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Northeast; RHODE ISLAND
description: Mr. Dukakis won in Rhode Island with 54 percent of the vote. In the last 24 years, only Richard M. Nixon in 1972 and Ronald Reagan in 1984 have carried Rhode Island's four electoral votes for the Republicans. Senator John H. Chafee, a Republican, won a third term handily despite a strong challenge early in the campaign from Lieut. Gov. Richard A. Licht. Ethical questions dominated two other state races. Gov. Edward D. DiPrete, a Republican, was locked in a close race with Bruce G. Sundlun, who lost badly to Mr. DiPrete in the 1986 election.

title: Kristallnacht, in Solingen . . .
description: LEAD: It is Nov. 9, 1938, in Solingen, Germany.

title: The 1988 Elections; Ex-Chief Justice Supports Prison Furlough Concept
description: Warren E. Burger, former Chief Justice of the United States, defended prison furloughs today, contending that the issue had become ''very much garbled'' in the Presidential campaign.

title: Bill Hoest, Cartoonist, 62
description: Bill Hoest, an award-winning cartoonist whose work included ''The Lockhorns,'' died of lymphoma Monday at New York Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived in Lloyd Neck, L.I.

title: James Altieri, 79, Dies; Lawyer and Arbitrator
description: James V. Altieri, a New York lawyer and labor arbitrator, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Yonkers. He was 79 years old.

title: Gotaas-Larsen Shipping Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in U.S. funds.

title: Johnstown American Cos reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in its fourth quarter ended June 30 it had a writeoff of $49,000,000 of intangible assets, primarily related to the company's securities distribution system and associated goodwill, and certain purchased management and other contractual rights. The company also said it increased its provisions for continued obligations by $6,000,000, and wrote down certain fixed assets, also by $6,000,000. Comparable year-ago figures are not applicable; the company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Aug. 31--latest year consisted of only 10 months--and had a latest fourth quarter that was only one month long. For the fourth quarter ended Aug. 31, 1987, the company lost $14,320,000 on revenue of $23,810,000. For the year ended Aug. 31, 1987, Johnstown American lost $12,586,000 on revenue of $117,464,000.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS  MAN IN THE NEWS: George Herbert Walker Bush; A Victor Free to Set His Own Course
description: When George Bush declared last June that he would not raise taxes, skeptical reporters gave him repeated chances to hedge. Could he support higher excise taxes? No, Mr. Bush said. Would he use ''revenue enhancers''? No, Mr. Bush insisted.

title: Eating Well
description: THOSE who wonder why Americans have trouble sorting out what they are supposed to do about cholesterol or fat or fiber or sodium need only read the recent articles on hypertension. After having heard for a number of years that a reduction in sodium consumption would help to lower blood pressure, consumers have recently been told that new studies cast doubt on the validity of that advice.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; LOUISIANA
description: Vice President Bush continued his sweep through the South by winning this state easily, even though problems in the oil industry have plagued the region's economy.

title: A Group Where Less Is More
description: WHERE the summer heat starts in early spring and lasts well into fall, less is often better. That fits nicely with the beliefs of John T. Capps 3d, who prides himself on what he calls his ''chrome dome.''

title: British Fund Collapse
description: Britain's Government watchdog said today that he would look into the handling of the collapse of a British investment fund that caused thousands of small investors to lose their money.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; ALABAMA
description: After winning a comfortable victory in the Republican primary last March, Mr. Bush penciled Alabama on his map of safe territory and never visited the state during the general election campaign.

title: The Computer Jam: How It Came About
description: Computer scientists who have studied the rogue program that crashed through many of the nation's computer networks last week say the invader actually represents a new type of helpful software designed for computer networks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Asked waivers on Leon Durham, first baseman, for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. YANKEES (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Darrin Chapin and Dana Ridenour, pitchers; Hensley Meulens, infielder, and Oscar Azocar and Bernie Williams, outfielders, from Columbus of the International League. Purchased the contract of Kevin Maas, first baseman-outfielder, from Albany of the Eastern League. FOOTBALL INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Signed Don Thorp, defensive lineman. Waived Bill Ransdell, quarterback. JETS (AFC) - Signed Ron Tilton, offensive lineman. Waived Steve Hammond, linebacker. PHOENIX (NFC) - Signed Lester Lyles, safety. Waived Ricky Moore, fullback. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Waived Steve Cox, punter. HOCKEY WASHINGTON (NHL) - Sent Michal Pivonka and Jim Thompson, forwards, to Baltimore of the American Hockey League.

title: Review/Rock; Duran Duran, as Its Own Special Effect
description: Teen-agers were fainting when Duran Duran performed Friday night at Roseland. But as dozens of limp young girls at the front of the room were pulled up to the stage and assisted or carried into the wings, overcrowding seemed to be the main cause, not excitement.

title: Sharon Says He Could Quell Uprising
description: As Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir struggles to form a new government, Ariel Sharon is campaigning to be its next Defense Minister because, he says, he is the only man who can end the Palestinian uprising once and for all.

title: When a College Gets A Gift That Is Tainted
description: When Ralph Engelstad offered $5 million to the University of North Dakota hockey program last spring, officials were pleased but not surprised. Mr. Englestad, a Las Vegas casino operator, had contributed to the school for 20 years and the school's sports center already bore his name.

title: Optrotech Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 at Shearson May Start Firm
description: Thomas I. Unterberg and A. Robert Towbin, two well-known investment bankers, may leave Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to start their own firm.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: When I said I want a kinder, gentler nation, I meant it and I mean it.'' - Vice President Bush.

title: Quadlogic Controls Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Favors French Pill
description: To the Editor:

title: The 1988 Elections; 'Chin Up,' Says Dukakis; ' '92!' Supporters Shout
description: Michael S. Dukakis ended his long quest for the White House tonight with a sad smile and a promise to continue to fight for average American families to assure that ''every citizen can be a full shareholder in the American dream.''

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; OREGON
description: Mr. Dukakis appeared headed toward a victory; with 31 percent of precincts reporting, he was ahead with 53 percent of the vote.

title: Hunt Is On Where Turkeys Have a Say
description: Shotguns are back in the racks of pickup trucks cruising North Union Street in this former lumber town. There's a sale at K-Mart for camouflage gloves and baseball hats. It's turkey season again. Thirty years ago you couldn't have said that in here in western New York. Unregulated hunters wiped out wild turkeys in the mid-1800's. But by 1959 enough wild birds had strayed into Cattaraugus and Allegheny Counties from Pennsylvania, and the hunt was on once more.

title: Gradco Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $233,000 for the quarter and $444,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $275,000 and $405,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL Six big American companies are about to reach a deal with the Soviet Union that would remove a chief obstacle to doing business in Russia. The deal would permit them to take their profits out of the country in hard currency. If it goes through, the deal may pave the way for similar arrangements by other companies. [ Page D1. ] The South Korean Government has not answered a request by the Daewoo Group for $730 million to help save its troubled shipbuilding subsidiary, the company's chairman said. [ D9. ] THE ECONOMY A bipartisan panel on the Federal deficit has abandoned its Dec. 21 deadline for offering proposals because its 12 members are sharply divided. The delay raises questions about what influence, if any, the panel will have. [ A32. ] The Supreme Court unanimously ruled that states may tax income that oil companies earn from the offshore production of oil and gas on Federally leased property. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Burger King franchisees are angered by Pillsbury's plan to spin off the fast-food chain and saddle it with hundreds of millions of dollars in debt. They plan to seek ways to derail the move. [ D1. ] Texas Air's chairman gave Merrill Lynch permission to talk with investors interested in buying Eastern Airlines, but then he told the investment firm to drop the discussions, people involved in the effort said. [ D1. ] Top Justice Department officials will consider Drexel's arguments that criminal racketeering charges should not be filed against Drexel Burham Lambert. [ D2. ] Potential bidders for RJR Nabisco were sent the formal rules for the largest public auction in history. [ D6. ] Harris agreed to buy General Electric's semiconductor unit for $206 million in cash. [ D5. ] MARKETS Smith Barney signaled its determination to become a major Wall Street trading house. It announced that Lewis L. Glucksman, a widely respected stock and bond trader, would join the investment house to run all of its trading activities. [ D1. ] Stock prices edged higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 2.85 points, to 2,127.49. Analysts said the slight advance reflected an already discounted reaction to a general assumption that Vice President Bush would be elected President. [ D12. ] Interest rates were mixed as the Government securities market digested a heavy supply of new issues and all sectors were preoccupied with the Presidential election. [ D19. ] The dollar rose in nervous pre-election trading. Traders said that the rise mostly resulted from technical factors. [ D20. ] Prices of platinum, gold and silver futures fell sharply. [ D20. ] TECHNOLOGY The rogue program that infected many computer networks represents a new type of helpful software, scientists say. The same class of software could be used to harness computers around the world and put them to work simultaneously. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS American companies may lose the fight for dominance in the high-definition television market, but it is not clear whether the battle is worth winning. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Pillsbury is running the risk of having its most potent takeover defense - its ''poison pill'' - thrown out by Delaware courts because of its recapitalization plan. Market Place. [ D12. ] The American Stock Exchange's chairman is subtly building a publishing empire. Advertising. [ D22. ]

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Northeast; VERMONT
description: Mr. Bush beat Mr. Dukakis in a surprisingly close battle for the three electoral votes in a state that last went for a Democratic Presidential candidate in 1964.

title: Disney Stock In Bass Divorce
description: Sid R. Bass, one of four Texas brothers known for their large investments, transferred more than 1 percent of the stock of the Walt Disney Company, worth $87.1 million, to his ex-wife, Anne H. Bass, as part of their divorce settlement.

title: Givenchy Purchase
description: The French company LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, which makes Moet champagne, has completed its purchase of the Givenchy Couture Group. LVMH agreed to buy the fashion house - a showcase for the designer Hubert de Givenchy - in June. No price was disclosed.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: The New York Region; NEW YORK
description: Mr. Dukakis captured the 36 electoral votes of New York, a state his strategists believed he had to win to keep his chances alive.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Midwest; IOWA
description: This was the site of Mr. Bush's only serious defeat in the contest for the nomination, and the Democrats hoped his third-place finish in the February caucuses would be a harbinger of yesterday's results. They were right: Mr. Dukakis won the state's seven electoral votes. Mr. Dukakis had finished third in Iowa but later swung the state's national convention delegates behind him.

title: Hughes Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
6 Concerns And Russia Near Deal
description: Six of America's largest companies are on the verge of concluding an agreement with the Soviet Union that would remove a chief obstacle to doing business in Russia.

title: Civics Problem: How to Get the Young to Vote
description: No matter what the results of today's national elections, students at Mission High School here have voted overwhelmingly for Congressman Fuentes of the Stars and Stripes Party.

title: OBSERVER Nearing Rope's End
description: We have polls. We have the Gallup Poll, the Roper Poll and the Harris Poll.

title: Data-Design Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,126,000 for expenses associated with redeeming the 12 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures, a tax credit of $428,000, and a gain of $258,000 from the effect of an accounting change. c-Includes a tax credit of $160,000.

title: Baldwin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Film; 'Far North': Sam Shepard Ventures Into Directing
description: ''Far North,'' the first film directed by the playwright, actor and screenwriter Sam Shepard, begins with footage of a runaway horse and wagon. By the time the camera has finished vacillating between the horse's flying hooves, muscular flank and impassive eye, with a shot or two of wagon wheels for good measure, it's clear that the beast itself isn't the only thing out of control here.

title: In 1938, the World Knew
description: Until Nov. 9, 1938, the wishful could argue that Adolf Hitler's ravings were worse than his bite. Then came Kristallnacht, the night of broken glass. Instantly the world grasped the horror, recognized that the Nazi orgy of hate was plunging into savagery a country known for its learning and literacy.

title: Postal Service Plan on Cash
description: The United States Postal Service is considering a high-speed money-transfer service that would allow people to move funds anywhere in the country almost instantly.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day last Friday, about the cancellation of Neiman-Marcus magazine, misstated the role of Roger B. McCord at Tiffany magazine. He was a consultant and advertising sales representative; Carl Portale was the founder and publisher.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's weekly commercial paper auctions for the third time in the last four weeks, the banking company announced yesterday. Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.44 percent, up from 8.255 percent last week. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.389 percent, up from 8.165 percent a week ago.

title: FFP Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The partnership began operations in May 1987. The share earnings are in units.

title: Status of Talks on Selling Eastern Airlines Uncertain
description: Frank Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, allowed Merrill Lynch & Company to talk during the weekend with a group of investors interested in buying Eastern Airlines, but on Monday he told Merrill to drop the discussions, people involved in the effort said yesterday.

title: Forest Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Hornets Triumph; Owner in Hospital
description: The Hornets gained their first National Basketball Association victory tonight as Kelly Tripucka scored 24 points to led Charlotte past the Los Angeles Clippers, 117-105.

title: Trade May Fall if Canada Kills Pact
description: Collapse of a Canadian-American free trade agreement in the wake of Canadian elections Nov. 21 could bring fresh curbs in the world's largest two-way trading relationship, which may total $150 billion this year. More broadly, a collapse would sour the tone of 96-nation trade liberalization talks set to begin two weeks later, according to American business, academic and legislative experts.

title: 2 Retailers' Profits Rise
description: The Limited Inc. announced yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 1.7 percent as its sales began to recover from a yearlong slump. And Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which has thrived while other retailers stagnated, said its earnings rose 33 percent in the quarter.

description: Burger King franchisees, angered by the Pillsbury Company's plan to spin off the fast-food chain and saddle it with hundreds of millions of dollars in new debt, will meet next Tuesday in Miami to consider alternatives that could derail the plan, some of the franchisees said today.

Bridge
description: In terms of competitive participants, the age gap between the oldest bridge player and the youngest is surely greater than in any other sport or recreation. No doubt the oldest and youngest fishermen are a century apart, but they are hungry for fish rather than prizes.

title: Economic Scene; High Definition: TV Battleground
description: ''HDTV is coming! HDTV is coming!'' Edward Markey, chairman of the House Telecommunications subcommittee, is sounding the alarm against the best-planned invasion ever made by the Japanese consumer electronics industry. The battle for the $50 billion to $250 billion market for high-definition television could be lost, he warns, before American manufacturers even gear up for the fight.

title: Leonard Ends It After Slow Start
description: From where he sat Monday night, looking up into the Caesars Palace ring, Dave Wolf believed that his fighter, Donny Lalonde, was about to finish off Sugar Ray Leonard.

title: Religious War Ignites Anew in France
description: ''I do not know if Christians are still a majority in this country,'' exclaimed the little man with black Napoleon curls and fidgety hands, ''but I know that this country was built around cathedrals and church spires. And things are tolerated in this country that would not be tolerated in General Jaruzelski's Poland!''

title: Why Michael Dukakis Lost
description: The political coroners were so eager to perform their post-mortems on the Dukakis campaign that, as the celebrated Latin student Russell Baker observed recently, they couldn't even wait for the mortem. For two weeks they have been issuing confident conclusions about why Michael Dukakis had already lost.

Harris Signs Accord To Buy a Unit of G.E.
description: The Harris Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement to acquire the General Electric Company's semiconductor business, GE Solid State, for $206 million in cash. The deal, which was announced on a tentative basis on Aug. 15, is expected to close within 30 days.

title: GUN CURBS LINKED TO HOMICIDE RATE
description: Restricting access to pistols may reduce a community's homicide rate, according to a study that shows the risk of being killed with such firearms is almost five times as high in Seattle as in Vancouver, British Columbia, a city with stricter gun laws.

title: Cityspire To Dismantle Part of Tower
description: The developer of Cityspire, the mid-Manhattan tower that was built 11 feet taller than permitted, has agreed to remove part of the offending pinnacle until he settles the case with New York City.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Combinations
description: The Goliard Chorale and Chamber Orchestra can mix and match its varied forces in many ways. Thus, Sunday night's program at Merkin Concert Hall offered Nielsen's Little Suite for String Orchestra, Roussel's Serenade for flute, harp and strings, an instrumental trio by Sofiya Gubaidulina called ''Garden of Joys and Sorrows'' and a choral piece as well - Britten's ''Cantata Misericordium'' recounting the story of the good Samaritan.

title: Will the Real Self-Esteem Stand Up?
description: The California Task Force to Promote Self-Esteem and Personal and Social Responsibility: it seemed a parody, an idea born in a hot tub. Even many natives laughed when the task force was created a little over two years ago, though the laughter was checked a little by the realization that they were footing the bill - $735,000 - for a three-year exploration into the state of self-esteem of the state's citizenry.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: South; TEXAS
description: Mr. Dukakis counted heavily on Texas, a state Democrats have always won when they captured the White House. He picked his running mate, Mr. Bentsen, in large part to try to secure the state's 29 electoral votes against the challenge of Mr. Bush, who once represented Texas in the House.

title: Societe Generale
description: Societe Generale de Belgique said it had bought an additional 40 percent interest in a zinc company, Bolaget Vieille-Montagne, raising its stake to 90 percent. The Belgian company, that nation's largest holding company, said it purchased the shares for about $320 each. Since Vieille-Montagne has about 810,000 shares outstanding, the latest purchase was valued at nearly $260 million. The zinc company is a leading metals producer.

description: By Senator Dan Quayle's own reckoning, the 1988 election campaign aged him ''at least 10 years.''

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; WASHINGTON
description: Washington has been more favorable to Democratic Presidential candidates than its southern neighbor, Oregon, but even so, Mr. Dukakis fought intensely against Mr. Bush for the state's 10 electoral votes. The Massachusetts Governor made the state a stop on virtually all his West Coast swings.

title: At 84, a Spry Friars Club Accepts Women in Its Cast of
description: The newspaper of that venerable male bastion, the New York Friars Club, says it best, right there near the ''Friars Wives'' column and the full-page casino ad that trumpets: ''Take My Wife. Please! To the Trump Plaza.''

title: Judge Backs Sale Of Apex Oil Assets
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has cleared the way for the sale of assets of the Apex Oil Company, including its Clark Oil Company unit, to the Horsham Corporation of Toronto. Judge Barry S. Schermer approved the sale in a ruling issued on Monday. The ruling concludes a crucial element of Apex's 10-month reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: A Killer Companion in 'Child's Play'
description: Even before a killer doll turns up in ''Child's Play,'' you may feel you've dropped into ''The Twilight Zone'' -the television show, not the place. As a detective chases a murderer down a murky Chicago street and into a toy store, the scene looks so television-perfect, so shallow, artificial and lurid, that you expect the camera to pull back and reveal that we've really been watching television. Though the film never becomes so blatantly ironic, the television look suits Tom Holland's clever, playful thriller. Straddling the line between sendup and suspense, ''Child's Play'' occupies the narrow, self-conscious space that is truly ''Twilight Zone'' territory.

title: THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Northeast; DELAWARE
description: Delaware, which saw two of its own politicians emerge as disappointed candidates for the 1988 Presidential nominations, did not have the spirited contest for its three electoral votes that it might have if either Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Democrat, or former Gov. Pete du Pont, a Republican, had been nominated.

description: Top Justice Department officials will consider arguments today as to whether criminal racketeering charges should be filed against Drexel Burham Lambert Inc., the investment house that has been at the center of a criminal securities fraud investigation for two years.

title: Long California Ballot Creates Timely Debate
description: Because California has one of the longest ballots in state history this year, several counties had said before the election they would enforce a 1919 state law limiting each voter to 10 minutes in the voting booth.

title: Review/Theater; Early-1900's England In Musical 'Hired Man'
description: As an attempt to transform a humble life into musical drama, ''The Hired Man'' has both heart and purpose. Based on the novel by Melvyn Bragg, it celebrates the author's grandfather and his time in the Cumbrian region of northern England from the turn of the century through World War I. In the 1984 London Theater Critics Awards, the show was edged out by ''42d Street'' as best musical (''Starlight Express'' finished third). One might have expected that ''The Hired Man'' would arrive in the United States under commercial or, perhaps, institutional auspices. Instead, in a vest-pocket production presented by the Heritage Players, the show is playing a limited engagement (through Nov. 20) at the small Intar Theater on West 42d Street.

title: Reviews/Television; 'Kristallnacht,' Look Back in Sorrow
description: Tonight marks the 50th anniversary of Kristallnacht, or ''the night of broken glass,'' when Nazi storm troopers throughout Germany smashed the windows of Jewish shops, burned synagogues and ransacked Jewish homes. The occasion is commemorated at 10 P.M. on Channel 13 with a documentary, ''Kristallnacht: The Journey from 1938 to 1988.'' Although it duplicates some of the material in ''More Than Broken Glass: Memories of Kristallnacht,'' which was shown on Channel 31 on Sunday, it moves to the present to point up the consequences of the past.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE FREE-TRADE ACCORD
description: The Canadian-American Free-Trade Agreement, due to go into effect on Jan. 1, eliminates most barriers to trade and creates institutions for managing the world's largest two-way trading relationship. Tariffs: A phased reduction over 10 years, beginning Jan. 1, of all tariffs between the two countries. If both countries give their consent, the schedule may be accelerated. Non-Tariff Barriers: Elimination of customs user fees by 1994 and duty waivers linked to performance requirements by 1998. A phasing out over 10 years of most quantitative restrictions. Services: Establishes for the first time a set of rules governing trade in services. Each government agrees to treat each other's service businesses the way it treats its own. Regulations relaxed to provide financial institutions with greater opportunities to do business on both sides of the border. Investment: Establishes a predictable investment climate so that investment will flow more freely in the future. Energy: Drops virtually all remaining restrictions on energy shipments, such as quotas and export or import taxes. Autos: Phasing out of all duty remission programs and elimination of duty remission on exports to the United States Jan. 1. Institutions: A Canada-United States Trade Commission, headed by Cabinet-level trade officials, will have primary responsibility for carrying out the agreement. Either country may establish a binational panel to resolve disputes. Accessibility: Reduces red tape that created difficulties for various professional persons like accountants, lawyers and photographers in crossing the border.
