title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BOXING DeWitt Knocked Out: Sumbu Kalambay of Italy knocked out Doug DeWitt of the United States in the seventh round to retain his World Boxing Association middleweight title last night in Monte Carlo. It was the third defense for Kalambay, who was born in Zaire. He took command at the start and scored frequently with lefts and rights. In the seventh round, he stunned DeWitt with a left, then quickly ended it at 1 minute 10 seconds with another combination. DeWitt, from Yonkers, fell on his face and tried to get up, but he staggered as the referee counted him out. Kalambay raised his record to 46-3-1 while DeWitt, ranked fifth by the W.B.A., dropped to 30-5-4. Iran Barkley of the United States, whom Kalambay beat for the vacant W.B.A. title last year, is the World Boxing Council champion. (AP) TENNIS Gilbert Gains: Second-seeded Brad Gilbert pressured Andrew Castle into numerous errors and beat the Briton by 6-4, 6-4 in the opening round of the Benson and Hedges International Grand Prix tournament yesterday in Wembley, England. In other first-day matches, Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union, who is ranked 132d in the world, beat Johan Kriek, 6-2, 6-3; Derrick Rostagno defeated Wally Masur of Australia, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4; Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia beat Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 7-6, 3-6, 6-2, and Christian Saceanu of West Germany downed John Frawley of Australia, 6-1, 6-3.(AP) Mayotte Upset: Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany defeated Tim Mayotte, 7-5, 6-3, yesterday in the first round of the Stuttgart Classic. Andres Gomez of Ecuador beat the Olympic gold medalist, Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia by 6-4, 7-5. Mayotte, ranked ninth in the world, lost in 1 hour 13 minutes. Steeb went into the tournament as a replacement for Andre Agassi.(AP) Top-Seeded Players Advance: Three of the higher-seeded players gained convincing first-round victories yesterday at the Virginia Slims of Chicago. Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, seeded fifth, took only one hour to dispose of Carrie Cunningham, a qualifer from Livonia, Mich., 6-2, 6-1. Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, seeded sixth, took 63 minutes to eliminate 15-year-old Angelica Gavaldon of El Centro, Calif., 6-1, 6-0. Zina Garrison of Houston, seeded seventh, defeated Halle Cioffi of Knoxville, Tenn., 6-3, 6-3.

title: Ship Workers Strike, Defying Walesa
description: Hundreds of militant workers at two shipyards in the Baltic port of Gdansk staged wildcat strikes today, challenging the authority of the Solidarity founder, Lech Walesa, over Polish Government plans to close a third shipyard.

title: Improvising A Vision Of Change
description: At their best, Sonny Rollins's shows can be the most euphoric experiences in jazz. The saxophonist's improvisations, full of cascading, seemingly endless ideas, have both a brute force and a profound, expansive logic to them. Combined with his rhythmic daring, Mr. Rollins's solos have an immense, celebratory effect on an audience.

title: Arafat Visa for U.N. Linked To P.L.O. Actions at Parley
description: Actions by the Palestine Liberation Organization this weekend could affect whether the United States gives Yasir Arafat a visa that would allow him to address the United Nations, American officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Saturday about direct-mail campaigning misstated the source of a circular showing an unflattering picture of Vice President Bush and reading, ''Would You Want Your Sister to Date This Guy?'' It was mailed by a labor organization supporting Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, not by the Dukakis campaign itself.

title: Reading, Writing and Child Support
description: Long after some Mississippi teen-agers have paid for their stereo or first car, they could be making monthly payments they never anticipated: for child support.

title: About New York; A Woodsy Hunt For the Sculptor Of Prospect Park
description: We are on the prowl for one Deenps Bazile, by all accounts a mysterious and magical man. We have heard that God speaks to Deenps Bazile to point out stumps in Brooklyn's Prospect Park. He responds by transforming them into sculpture - haunting African faces sprouting from gnarled wood.

title: Doughtie's Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nicklaus Seeks Help
description: Jack Nicklaus, suffering from a degenerative disk condition in his back, said yesterday he would seek further medical advice before he decided whether he could play golf in tournaments again. ''I can't play the way I am,'' Nicklaus said after a magnetic resonance imaging examination conducted by Dr. Bruce Waxman at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., Monday confirmed the problem in Nicklaus's lower back.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article yesterday about a $20 million donation to Spelman College by Bill Cosby and his wife, Camille, misidentified the Cosby daughter who attended Spelman. She was Erinn, not Erika. The article also misidentified the college president; she is Dr. Johnnetta B. Cole. Also in some copies, it misstated the history of her office. She is the first black woman to be president, not the first woman. The article also suggested her length of service incorrectly. She took office in July 1987; she is not new in the job.

title: Acid Rain Eats Away Our Sculptural Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving League's Head Sets Goal: Credibility
description: As Frederick L. Webber recounts it, when it became known last summer that he had accepted the top job at the United States League of Savings Institutions, he ''got a number of phone calls'' from people wondering whether he knew what he was doing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Views Collide Over Changes at Yale
description: When Yale University announced this month that it would change how its graduate students study management, it provoked an outcry from students and alumni unmatched in the two-year reign of the university's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr. Mr. Schmidt and other officials defended the curriculum changes for the 12-year-old School of Organization and Management as necessary to ease financial problems and improve faculty relations.

title: Killer of Cabby Gets 25 Years to Life
description: A 20-year-old man was sentenced Monday to 25 years to life in prison for the robbery and murder of a taxicab driver in the Washington Heights section.

title: Islanders Finish in a Flourish
description: Greg Gilbert's sure shot from the doorstep drifted wide of the net late in the third period, but minutes later, his wild blast from just inside the blue line whizzed through traffic and into the net to provide the game-winning goal in the Islanders' 4-3 victory over the Rangers tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Haverty Furniture Cos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wine Talk
description: REMEMBER last year when the dollar began to slide and French wine prices started to go through the roof? Remember all the admonitory fingers shaken at the French, warning them to cut prices or lose our love?

title: Showscam Film reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 1988 ELECTIONS: Northeast; DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
description: Mr. Dukakis won easily in the nation's capital, with 86 percent of the vote. The District, with three electoral votes, has an overwhelmingly Democratic voting population.

title: College Football Notebook; Picking a Sweet 16 From Division III
description: The selection of the 16 Division III football teams that will play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's tournament will be decided Sunday in conference calls among the selectors, athletic directors and coaches from four N.C.A.A. regions.

title: Advantage Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $82,000 and $338,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $79,000 for the quarter and $158,000 for the 9 months.

title: Harland, John H Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alpharel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Famous Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE 1988 ELECTIONS: West; ARIZONA
description: A solid Republican state in Presidential elections, where the last winning Democrat was Harry S. Truman in 1948, Arizona did not get a visit by either candidate in this general election campaign. The state's seven electoral votes went to Mr. Bush.

title: EA Engineering, Science & Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TENNESSEE - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush, as expected, won handily in Tennessee. Mr. Dukakis found it impossible to capitalize on the state's strong Democratic tradition and the support of two favorite sons in the state, one his old primary rival, Senator Albert Gore Jr. Despite criticism that he lacked stature, Senator Jim Sasser, a Democratic colleague of Mr. Gore, won re-election by a comfortable margin, fighting off a relatively weak challenge from Bill Anderson, a Republican lawyer.

title: Democrats' Knives Are Out for Bush
description: LEAD: The honeymoon is over.

title: The Vote in the West
Computer Horizons Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $961,000 from an accounting change.

title: Rheometrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Philip Crosby Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Outboard Marine Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $5,841,000 gain from an accounting change. c-Includes a gain of $11,540,000 and $15,035,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the sale of tax- benefit leases.

title: NEVADA - BUSH
description: As it has since Richard M. Nixon's election in 1968, Nevada gave its four electoral votes to the Republican Presidential candidate. Mr. Bush swept the state. Senator Chic Hecht, a Republican running for re-election after his first term, was dogged by attacks not only on his effectiveness in Congress but also on his intelligence, and he lost to the state's highly popular Governor, Richard H. Bryan, a Democrat. The loss was a blow to Republican strategists who saw Mr. Hecht battling back from an overwhelming early lead by the Governor.

title: Italy to Take Warships Out of the Persian Gulf
description: Italy said today that it would withdraw its warships from the Persian Gulf by the end of the year and would stop escorting merchant vessels in the waterway this month.

title: The Vote in the Midwest
AM Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $24,000 for the quarter and $324,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: California Insurers In Turmoil
description: The California insurance market, the nation's largest, was thrown into turmoil today after voters narrowly approved a measure that mandates cuts of at least 20 percent in the rates for automobile insurance and most other types of coverage.

title: An Independent Producer Will Head Orion's TV Unit
description: Gary Nardino, an independent producer and former executive for the Paramount Pictures Corporation's television division, was named yesterday to head the television unit of the Orion Pictures Corporation.

title: Cardinals a Threat to Giants
description: The Phoenix Cardinals are hardly a reincarnation of the Green Bay Packers of the 1960's or even the champion Chicago Bears, San Francisco 49ers or Washington Redskins of the 1980's. They have only a 6-4 record, and they would be 4-6 except for last-minute victories on the last two Sundays over the Dallas Cowboys and the 49ers.

title: The Presidency State by State
DELAWARE - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush won an easy victory in an election that saw Delaware's Democratic and Republican incumbents retain their posts in the State House and in Congress.

title: The Elections: Westchester County; Lowey Says Westchester Voters Didn't 'Believe in' DioGuardi
description: A few weeks ago, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, the Republican incumbent in the 20th Congressional District, dismissed Nita M. Lowey as ''Abzug without a hat.''

title: Metro Matters; In Westchester It May Become: Not in My Village
description: If town officials formally accept a petition next month and local residents approve a subsequent referendum, Mayfair Knollwood would become New York's 559th incorporated village. It would be among the state's smaller villages, but the implications of creating it could be profound.

title: Museum Offers a Fine Catch
description: YOU don't have to be an angler to enjoy the unusual and delightful exhibition of fish illustrations on display at the American Museum of Natural History through Dec. 11.

title: Nalumino Mundia, Zambian Envoy, 62
description: Zambia's Ambassador to the United States and several other countries, Nalumino Mundia, died of a heart attack Tuesday after collapsing at a diplomatic function, the Bolivian Foreign Ministry said. He was 62 years old.

title: Metro Datelines; H.M.O. Rates to Rise By as Much as 45%
description: The 12 health maintenance organizations in Connecticut will raise rates from 8.7 percent to 45 percent next year, according to the State Insurance Department. The increases are expected to lead many employers to pass on rising health-care costs to workers.

title: Alfa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net realized investment gains of $262,254 and $1,221,146 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes net realized investment gains of $604,172 for the quarter and $1,213,471 for the 9 months.

title: VERMONT - BUSH
description: Vermonters gave Mr. Bush its three electoral votes.

title: Hamilton Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,394,000 for the quarter and $5,906,000 for the 9 months. c-After income of $1,559,000 and $5,088,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Sports People; Mahres Plan Comeback
description: The North American Pro Racing Tour has never generated the excitement of the World Cup skiing circuit, partly because there were few native sons who scored among the top finishers. This season, that may change with the entry of Phil and Steve Mahre, the twins from Yakima, Wash., who swept many of the World Cup prizes over a 10-year period. The main motivator for the Mahres is sponsor money of $300,000 to $500,000 each from Coors Light, Burlington Industries, K2 Skis, Marker Bindings and Sun Ice Clothing. Winning pro races will also bring the Mahres incentive money from their sponsors, as well as some of the $1 million in prize money over the season. Although the Mahres have not competed in four years, they say they are skiing as well as they ever have. The first pro race will be in Park City, Utah, over Thanksgiving weekend.

title: Oilers Edge Devils On Overtime Goal
description: There were about 30 seconds left in the sudden-death overtime, the Oilers and the Devils were deadlocked at two goals apiece and the puck was in the neutral zone at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Chinese Report Quake Left 100,000 Homeless
description: Officials said today that an earthquake in southwestern China had left 100,000 people homeless, and they said they would welcome assistance from other countries.

title: Colin Bell, 85, Dies; A Quaker Executive
description: Colin W. Bell, a retired executive secretary of the American Friends Service Committee who served in Quaker relief activities for many years, died after a heart attack Tuesday at Martha Jefferson Hosapital in Charlottesville, Va. He was 85 years old and lived in Kents Store, Va.

title: Penn Treaty American reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; Optimistic Views On Cattle Futures
description: AFTER a surge that lifted futures prices for live cattle sharply higher in the last two years, a mild slump is under way that many traders expect to last into December. That circumstance has raised the question in busy livestock trading pits of whether the weakness signals an end to the bull market, or whether it offers a chance for speculators to buy before prices climb further next spring.

title: Election Reports
description: Nationwide and regional reports on the elections begin today on page B1, which includes an index to the coverage.

title: Hutchinson Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Fiscal 1987 included a gain of $780,000, or 20 cents a share, from the transfer of technology.

title: Hershey Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest third quarter and 9 months' losses reflected writedowns of oil and gas properties of $1.9 million and $2,050,000, respectively.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Thompson to Handle Bally Health Club Unit
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation of Chicago has decided to consolidate all its Health and Tennis Corporation of America business at J. Walter Thompson/Los Angeles.

title: Seoul Scandal: Day and Night Drama
description: People crowd around television sets in coffee shops. Taxi drivers keep the radio on all day. Janitors stop work to listen.

title: Report Faults Licensing by Nuclear Agency
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission grants licenses for handling radioactive material without verifying claims or inspecting plants, making it ''overly vulnerable to dishonest or careless applicants,'' a Congressional report said today.

title: Vote for Senate in New Jersey
CNS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCI Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Schizophrenia Study Finds Strong Signs Of Hereditary Cause
description: An international research team has announced that it has found ''the first concrete evidence for a genetic basis to schizophrenia,'' one of the most devastating and widespread varieties of mental illness.

title: Ship Dumps Philadelphia Ash, but Where?
description: For more than two years, a ship carrying 28 million pounds of Philadelphia incinerator ash has been shunned by nation after nation as the ship sought to dispose of its cargo.

title: Those Who Chose to Vote
description: Presidential vote as a percentage of the voting-age population in each state, as estimated by CBS News.

title: The Elections: Connecticut; Weicker Concedes To Lieberman in Close Race
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., trailing by 10,000 votes out of an unofficial total of 1.3 million, conceded defeat today to Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic candidate, at an emotional news conference that seemed to signal the end of the maverick liberal Republican's political career.

title: The Elections; Transcript of President-Elect's News Conference in Houston
description: Following is a transcript of President-elect George Bush's news conference in Houston yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Koch, Citing Shortfall In Budget, Cancels Trip
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City was facing a serious drop in revenues, and to deal with it he abruptly canceled a trip to Hong Kong.

title: Review/Violin; Gidon Kremer's Version Of Busoni's Grand Vision
description: The more one knows of Ferruccio Busoni's music, the more intriguing its curious blend of grandeur and intellectual rigor becomes. He may be the next Mahler or Janacek: that is, a turn-of-the-century composer whose vision turns out to have suited a future age better than his own. His second violin sonata in E minor, composed in 1898, furthered such thoughts Sunday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Cambodia Guerrillas to Pursue Peace Effort
description: The leaders of two Cambodian guerrilla factions and the Cambodian Prime Minister agreed Tuesday to establish a ''working commission'' to pursue peace efforts.

title: Action Products International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Credit Lyonnais
description: Credit Lyonnais, a French state-owned bank, said it had signed an accord with the Soviet Sberbank to promote joint ventures in the Soviet Union. Officials of Sberbank, the Soviet savings-and-loan bank, came to Paris before President Francois Mitterrand's planned visit to the Soviet Union at the end of November. Banque Commerciale pour l'Europe du Nord (Eurobank), a Soviet-owned bank based in Paris, also signed the agreement, which aims to expand cooperation, Credit Lyonnais said. But a bank spokesman refused to comment on the chances of Credit Lyonnais offering fresh credits to the Soviet Union.

title: The Elections; A Long Line for Quayle Seat
description: Even before the polls closed in Indiana Tuesday, a number of Republicans were lining up to fill the Senate seat that will be vacated by Vice President-elect Quayle.

title: Varity Plans a Deal In North America
description: The Varity Corporation, which recently terminated a deal to buy the Fruehauf Corporation, the truck-trailer maker, plans an important North American acquisition within a year, its chairman, Victor Rice, said. Varity, the Canadian farm and industrial machinery concern formerly known as Massey-Ferguson Ltd., wants to buy a company or companies to add between $500 million and $1 billion in annual sales, Mr. Rice said in an interview. Varity is reviewing companies that make a variety of industrial components, he said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aircoa Cos., Denver, appointed Lawrence A. Dustin president and chief operating officer of Aircoa Hospitality Services Inc., a principal unit of Aircoa Hotel Management Co.

title: Voting Results in Connecticut
description: Details by county that were available at 8 P.M. yesterday.

title: Genicom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a restructuring charge of $3.8 million for the quarter; the 9 months included a gain of $4.3 million from an accounting change. c-Net income d-After a gain of $2,018,000 from an accounting change.

title: MICHIGAN - BUSH
description: Michigan was one of industrial states that Mr. Dukakis had to win if his message of ''on your side'' was to neutralize the Republicans' heavy lead in the South. But in a state troubled by high unemployment and foreign competition, Mr. Dukakis fell short.

title: NEBRASKA - BUSH
description: Mr. Dukakis had little real hope in Nebraska. The last five Republican Presidential candidates have taken the state by huge margins, and Mr. Bush had no trouble maintaining the streak.

title: Corporate Debt: Is It Riskier in U.S.?
description: The recent wave of takeovers, leveraged buyouts and corporate restructurings has highlighted the growing importance of borrowed money to corporate America. Academics and financial advisers maintain that there is nothing inherently wrong with financing a business with debt; in fact, they like to point out that Japanese and West German companies have long thrived with markedly higher levels of debt than their American counterparts.

title: BUSH NAMES BAKER AS SECRETARY OF STATE; HAILS 40-STATE SUPPORT FOR 'MY PRINCIPLES'
description: President-elect Bush today named James A. Baker 3d to be his Secretary of State, cementing their political partnership and making clear Mr. Baker's pre-eminent role in the next Administration.

title: General Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ewing Gives Knicks the Inside Track
description: LEAD: The Knicks had a simple game plan tonight.

title: OKLAHOMA - BUSH
description: The state has been hit hard by the decline in oil prices and financial collapses, but despite that, the popularity of Lloyd Bentsen and a Democratic edge of more than 2 to 1 in registration, Mr. Bush was never seriously challenged. Even Jimmy Carter, who won Texas and Arkansas in 1976, could not carry Oklahoma against President Ford.

title: Samarkand Journal; In the Land of the Proletariat, Child Labor Lingers
description: Movlida Rokova was working most of the day in the market here, rubbing dirt off tomatoes and stacking them in a pile that reached her chin. Occasionally, she would take a tomato in her hand and hold it out to shoppers, silently beckoning them to buy her wares.

title: Horizon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: RHODE ISLAND - DUKAKIS
description: Mr. Dukakis won handily in Rhode Island, a neighbor to his home state.

title: Time for Us to Forget the Myth of the Innocent Emperor
description: To the Editor:

title: Claim Dismissed Against GTE Unit
description: A state judge has stricken a $1 billion claim for punitive damages sought by Home Shopping Network Inc. in its $1.5 billion suit against GTE Florida Inc. and a subsidiary, the GTE Corporation announced. But Home Shopping, a video retailer, said Judge Howard P. Rives also denied GTE's request that he dismiss Home Shopping's complaint outright. Both sides said they were pleased with the developments.

title: SIS Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rangers Make Important Leap
description: Igor Liba, a former Czechoslovak Olympian who speaks almost no English, had to express his delight last night simply through his distant smile from the far reaches of the locker room. However, the rest of the Rangers, who had lost their previous three games, provided the words to go with his obvious sentiment in a final bit of the kind of eloquent teamwork they had displayed in beating the Flyers, 5-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Downey Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Centex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,100,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: ARKANSAS - BUSH
description: Mr. Dukakis's poor showing in what is perhaps the most safely Democratic of the Southern states illustrates his weakness throughout the region.

title: Quarex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IDAHO - BUSH
description: Idaho voters gave markedly more support to Mr. Dukakis in this election than they did to previous Democratic Presidential candidates. Jimmy Carter won only 25 percent in 1980 and Walter F. Mondale took 26 percent four years later. This time Mr. Dukakis got 37 percent, not nearly enough to deny the state's four electoral votes to Mr. Bush.

title: The Elections; HIGHLIGHTS
description: THE PRESIDENT ELECT

title: The Elections: Foreign Policy; President-Elect Sends the Soviets A Dual Message
description: President-elect Bush today sent a dual signal to Moscow: the United States' resoluteness to hold the Soviets to their troop withdrawal from Afghanistan and its eagernesss to continue the good will built up during the Reagan Administration.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think I was particularly in a Congress bashing mode for the most of the campaign, but I will have my principles. The American people, in voting for me, voted for certain things. Congress understands that, and I understand the Congress.'' - President-elect Bush. [ B3:3. ]

title: New York Buildings Inspectors Must Do Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Frontier Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment losses of $54,000 for the quarter and $181,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment losses of $10,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $58,000 for the 9 months. The latest third quarter and 9 months' nets from operations included ''fresh start'' benefits of $41,000, or 1 cent a share, and $99,000 or 3 cents a share, respectively. The year-ago periods' nets from operations included ''fresh start'' benefits of $48,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter, and $269,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Forum Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,360,000. c-Net income d-After gains from the repurchase of debentures of $634,000 for the quarter and $1,063,000 for the 6 months.

title: Saudis Plan State Oil Unit
description: In a move that advances a 15-year effort to reduce the role of United States companies in its oil industry, Saudi Arabia said today that it had decided to establish a state oil company.

title: Canadians Urged to Accept Pact
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and other supporters of the United States-Canada free-trade agreement have stepped up warnings of damage that rejecting it could do to the Canadian economy. They are concerned by opinion polls showing that Mr. Mulroney's Progressive Conservative Party could lose the Nov. 21 election and with it the opportunity to ratify the pact.

title: Cablevision Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company attributed the revenue increase primarily to its acquisition of Adams Russell Co., the SportsChannel acquisitions and other acquisitions in the third and fourth quarters of 1987 and during 1988.

title: Decision in Securities Case Might Affect Drexel Inquiry
description: In a decision that could have strong ramifications for the securities fraud action against Drexel Burnham Lambert, a Federal court yesterday dismissed an appeal by a defendant who had objected to the intervention of the United States Attorney in a Securities and Exchange Commission case.

title: 2 Waiters and Their Producer Dine at a Source of Inspiration
description: ''Enter, two Jewish waiters.'' Now what kind of stage direction is that in a script for the New York Shakespeare Festival?

title: 2 Ex-Deputies Sue Attorneys
description: Two former lawmen acquitted of civil rights violations in the death of a black jail inmate have filed a lawsuit asserting that two witnesses and two lawyers concocted the case against them.

title: GEORGIA - BUSH
description: Mr. Dukakis once had strong hopes for a victory in Georgia. It was the last Deep South state he visited before turning his attention to the East, the Midwest and the West in the final days of the campaign. In the end, Georgia went solidly for Mr. Bush.

title: NEW MEXICO - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush won with 52 percent and gained the five electoral votes of New Mexico.

title: UTAH - BUSH
description: Utah was never really a question for Mr. Bush, who won handily here, although by less than the margins Mr. Reagan had in 1980 and 1984. Republicans also scored well at the bottom of the ticket.

title: Equitable Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain of $6,450,000 from an accounting change.

title: Find-Sup Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: FLORIDA - BUSH
description: Even though Hispanic voters helped give Mr. Dukakis one of his two Southern primary victories here in March, Mr. Bush won an easy victory in Florida, destined soon to become the nation's fourth most populous state, after California, New York and Texas.

title: Halifax Engineering Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $27,000 from an accounting change. The year-ago figures restated for an accounting change.

title: Cybertek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Buckeye Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $201,000 and $1,663,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also includes a $696,000 prepayment penalty on early extinguishment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: The Elections: Defeated Democrat; Wistful Dukakis Sees No Bush Mandate
description: A philosophical Michael S. Dukakis returned to work as Governor of Massachusetts today, saying he gave his race for the Presidency his ''best shot'' and felt no bitterness about his loss.

description: (NOTE: This table may be divided, and additional information on a particular entry may appear on more than one screen.)

title: The Elections: Congress; Payne Captures a Long-Sought Prize
description: Donald M. Payne realized a 14-year ambition Tuesday when he won election in the 10th Congressional District and became the first black Representative in New Jersey's history.

title: Who Won What in the Region
description: With a big exception - approval of New York's dubious road construction bond issue - New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voters used their votes well Tuesday.

title: Environmental Control reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yields Move Up Slightly
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds moved up slightly, if at all, for the week ended yesterday.

description: b-Includes a gain of $6,200,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $600,000 for the quarter and a gain of $3,700,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The company said it has changed to calendar year reporting, with the report for the latest quarter ended Sept. 30 to be released later this month.

title: Evans & Sutherland Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest periods includes a non-recurring pretax writeoff of $4,048,000 on assets and inventory related to a joint development project with Digital Equipment Corp.

title: Reagan, Citing Costs, Vetoes Nutrition Study
description: President Reagan today vetoed legislation calling for a study of the nutritional quality of the food Americans eat, saying it would create an ''unnecessary and complex Federal bureaucracy.''

title: Baldor Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Adler & Shaykin said it had agreed to purchase more than 815,000 shares of the common stock of Best Products Co., Richmond, that had not been submitted by the expiration on Monday of its tender offer of $27.50 a share. In all, Adler & Shaykin will purchase about 98 percent of Best Products' shares outstanding.

title: Finally: A Designer Fit for a Duchess
description: Nina Campbell, one of the most talked-about interior designers in London, sat at a large rose-colored table in her Knightsbridge office and pointed toward the striped rose-colored walls.

title: Review/Music; A Sampler Of Works From Italy
description: Under the direction of the composer Dinu Ghezzo, New York University has long had an active musical exchange program with Italy. Through tomorrow, the university is presenting a number of events in its own facilities and elsewhere around town under the title Week of Italian Music in New York, and Monday night this mini-festival settled into Weill Recital Hall.

title: IOWA - DUKAKIS
description: Both Presidential candidates came in third in the Iowa caucuses last February, so for Mr. Dukakis, there was special honor in winning this state, with its seven electoral votes. It was the first time since 1964 that the Democrats carried the state.

title: Holy Bomb Blast! The Real Robin Fights On!
description: Good news from Gotham City. The original Robin of comic strip and television fame is not dead. The Boy Wonder, whose alter ego was Dick Grayson, grew up and got promoted to his own comic book. So who is that corpse in the green-and-gold costume in the current issue of Batman?

title: Treasury Bonds Take a Tumble
description: The prices of Treasury bonds tumbled with the dollar yesterday in the first day of trading after the election.

title: Laurel Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dean at Berkeley Will Fill New Education Post at Apple
description: Bernard R. Gifford, the dean of the Graduate School of Education at the University of California at Berkeley, and once a leading contender to head the New York City public schools, is joining Apple Computer Inc. as vice president of education, a new position.

title: Bernard Lubar, Advertising Executive, 66
description: Bernard Lubar, an advertising executive, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Calpe, Spain. He was 66 years old.

title: New York Lists Services for the Elderly
description: The New York City Department for the Aging recently published a new guide that lists an impressive array of services for the elderly.

description: b-Includes $13,887,000 in charges related to a public offering and a loan prepayment penalty. Share earnings and shares outstanding represent units.

title: ALGERIAN PREMIER RESHAPES CABINET
description: The new Prime Minister appointed his Government today, bringing 14 new ministers into a Cabinet that has been ordered to reshape the political and economic landscape.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $32,000 and $156,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

The earnings per share based only on First Financial, excluding National Savings and Loan Association, which was acquired March 31.

title: Kaikhosru Sorabji, 96, Composer Who Barred Playing of His Works
description: Kaikhosru Sorabji, the English composer and critic whose eccentric 36-year ban on the performance of his music became better known than the music itself, died of heart failure Oct. 15 in a nursing home in Dorchester, England. He was 96 years old.

title: CONNECTICUT - BUSH
description: In Connecticut, one of several states he claimed as home territory, Vice President Bush won handily.

description: b-Net income

title: Energy Dept. Aide Sees Delay in Reactor Startup
description: The top Energy Department safety official said Tuesday that the Government would probably not be able to begin the restart of a nuclear reactor at the Savannah River Plant in December as scheduled, further delaying the resumption of nuclear weapon production in this country.

title: Part Magazine, Part Books, All Style
description: THE project of creating a new kind of design publication had been on Barbara Radice's mind since she met Ettore Sottsass, the Italian architect, 12 years ago.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN I was 4 years old, I begged my mother for a particular brand of instant pudding I had seen advertised on television. Finally she acceded to my wishes and, following the directions on the box, mixed up several bowls of what turned out to be tasteless glop. The problem, I patiently informed my mother as I rejected the dessert, was not the pudding but the earthenware bowls she had used. The pudding in the commercial, which claimed it tasted so good and showed children enjoying it, had been served in tall glass dishes.

title: LCS Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Increased by $145,000 for both periods as a result of the termination of a deferred compensation plan, and the year reflects an additional tax provision of $237,000 related to the sale of a unit during the year. c-Net loss The 1987 fourth quarter and year results were reduced by $165,000 from the writeoff of certain deferred charges.

title: The Elections: New Jersey; Finding the Chink in Dawkins's Armor
description: Last spring a group of political scientists dined at Princeton University and discussed the coming elections. When the conversation turned to the race between New Jersey's incumbent Senator, Frank R. Lautenberg, and Pete Dawkins, the Republican candidate, there was little debate.

title: The Vote in the South
Washington Real Estate Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Ditka Heading Home
description: Mike Ditka has recovered from a mild heart attack well enough that he will go home today, be allowed to coach the Chicago Bears from the press box at Tampa Stadium in Florida, on Nov. 20 and return to the sideline full time the following Sunday, his doctors said yesterday. ''Mike Ditka is a fiery type of person and a person who goes all out,'' Dr. Jay Alexander said. ''He knows that he is going to have to cut back on his eating and type of exercise. . . . But I think it is more important for him to get his life back on track.'' Nancy Herman, a spokeswoman for Lake Forest Hospital, said an angiogram - an X-ray picture of the blood vessels - showed ''a minor irregularity'' at the right side of Ditka's heart. ''Other than that, it showed a very healthy heart,'' she said. Ditka was transferred yesterday from Lake Forest to Lutheran General Hospital in Park Ridge, where the tests were conducted. Assuming all goes well, Ditka would be allowed to run the team from the sideline when the Bears play Green Bay on Nov. 27. (AP)

title: Home Federal Savings & Loan (San Francisco) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK - DUKAKIS
description: Mr. Dukakis proved he could carry a major industrial state in taking New York's 36 electoral votes, but Mr. Bush's strategists say they forced him to spend more time and money than originally planned in a state that should have been a safe bet.

title: Markets Drop After Election Amid Worries About Deficits
description: The dollar plunged yesterday and stock and bond prices declined as the financial markets sounded an uncertain, wary note on the day after the victory of George Bush.

title: U.S. GROUNDS B-1'S OVER TEXAS CRASH
description: The Strategic Air Command said today that its entire fleet of new B-1 bombers, the nation's primary long-range nuclear bombers, had been grounded indefinitely after a crash Tuesday near Abilene, Tex.

title: Bass Group Buys Sensormatic Stake
description: An investment group led by Sid R. Bass and his brother Lee, two members of the Bass family of Fort Worth, have acquired a 6 percent stake in the Sensormatic Electronics Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that it had purchased the shares in Sensormatic, a maker of electronic surveillance equipment based in Boca Raton, Fla., for investment only.

title: Alabama Unit Offers Bonds In a $100 Million Refunding
description: The Alabama State Docks Department is tentatively offering $100 million of revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.60 percent for those maturing in 2012. The underwriters are led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: NORTH DAKOTA - BUSH
description: Although Mr. Bush won the state by a comfortable margin, Democrats fared better elsewhere on the ticket, as Gov. George Sinner defeated Leon Mallberg, an anti-tax crusader, and Senator Quentin N. Burdick, the 80-year-old Democratic incumbent, beat back a challenge from Earl Strinden.

title: The Elections: Transition; Helping Bush Prepare to Take Over
description: President-elect Bush today began assembling a team to help him prepare for the Presidency. The people he picked are likely to figure prominently in making important personnel and policy decisions in the next two and a half months.

title: INDIANA - BUSH
description: As expected, Mr. Bush easily captured the 12 electoral votes of Indiana, long a Republican bastion, where support was cemented by the presence of Dan Quayle on the ticket. The assumption is that Mr. Quayle will resign his Senate seat before January to enable departing Gov. Robert D. Orr to name a Republican replacement.

title: The Elections: Reaction Abroad; From Thatcher, Relief; From Communists, a Security in Continuity
description: Governments around the world today generally welcomed Vice President Bush's election victory in the expectation of continuity in American policy, and immediately began telling him what they wanted him to do.

title: Review/Music; An Organist's Journey From Bach to Cage
description: Brian Schober, an organist and composer based in New Jersey, gave a recital at St. Michael's Church that alternated throughout between Bach, the foundation of the organ repertory, and a quartet of contemporary works. The title, ''Bach to the Future,'' was not promising, but the playing gave satisfaction.

Corrections
description: A map yesterday showing cable television availability in New York City carried an incorrect legend, misstating the timetable for wiring in some areas. The black shading was intended to denote areas that are expected to have cable television by the end of 1989. A corrected map is printed today on page B18.

title: Trader's Aide at Drexel Charged With Perjury
description: A trader's assistant at Drexel Burham Lambert Inc.'s ''junk bond'' unit was indicted yesterday on charges of perjury and obstructing justice, the United States Attorney in Manhattan announced.

title: Biospherics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Ballet; New Leads In Joffrey's 'Billy'
description: Ballet, functioning within a repertory system, has what are called alternate casts. No one considered Rudolf Nureyev and Dame Margot Fonteyn as understudies in the days when they would consistently and triumphantly follow on the heels of another partnership in the very same ballet. A second cast is by no means subordinate to the first.

title: Sports People; Sax Wants to Talk
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates' general manager, Larry Doughty, said that Steve Sax got in touch with him yesterday and indicated he would like to play for the Pirates next season. The second baseman, who has spent his entire eight-year major league career with the Los Angeles Dodgers, filed for free agency last week. Doughty said he would get back to Sax's agent, Jerry Kapstein. ''If we can do something to get us closer to a championship, we're going to do it whether that means making a trade or signing a free agent,'' Doughty told WTAE Radio.(AP)

title: The Elections: Cuomo's Views; Governor, Tired of 'Pundits, Seers,' Is Annoyed by Questions About '92
description: Calling himself ''just the Governor of New York State, a registered Democrat,'' Mario M. Cuomo yesterday offered this analysis of Vice President Bush's Presidential victory: ''How do I know why the guy won?''

title: Chase, With $235 Million Incentive Package, Picks Brooklyn
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, backed by far more valuable government incentives than had ever been offered to a New York City company, said yesterday that it would move 5,000 workers from lower Manhattan to downtown Brooklyn.

title: Motor Club of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are reclassified to conform with 1988 presentation.

title: ISS International Service Sysem Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grand Met Holds 74.3% Of Pillsbury
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the London-based consumer giant that is pursuing the Pillsbury Company, announced yesterday that it held 74.3 percent of Pillsbury, but was not yet ready to buy the shares.

title: Children's Place Sold by Campeau
description: The Campeau Corporation said it had sold the Children's Place chain of 161 stores to the TCP Acquisition Corporation for $30 million in cash. Children's Place, a subsidiary of Federated Holdings Inc., also owns the Accessory Place chain, which is being sold in turn by TCP to the Tribeca Corporation.

title: Sunair Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW JERSEY - BUSH
description: Garden State voters have long favored Republican Presidential candidates and the state, as expected, went for Mr. Bush. But they split their tickets to re-elect Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democrat, despite a strong challenge by Pete Dawkins.

title: U.S. FACES FLOOD OF SOVIET EMIGRES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met with top aides today to seek ways to deal with a flood of Soviet citizens who have applied to come to the United States.

title: Voting by Assembly District
description: (NOTE: This table may be divided, and additional information on a particular entry may appear on more than one screen.)

title: Timothy R. Talbot, Medical Administrator, 72
description: Dr. Timothy R. Talbot Jr., who founded the Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia, died of cancer there Monday. He was 72 years old and lived in Haverford, Pa.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Study Lends Support To Price Promotions
description: Do price promotions destroy brand equity? Advertising agencies say yes, emphatically. But a new study by Frankel & Company, the Chicago-based sales promotion agency, says no.

title: Review/Music; Transcriptions for Guitar
description: Kazuhito Yamashita's assets as a guitarist include extraordinary dexterity, a big resonant tone and flare before an audience. His main failing, to judge by an Alice Tully Hall recital Sunday afternoon at which all the virtues were abundantly in evidence, is overweening ambition.

title: Health; Exercise Alone May Not Help Cholesterol Level, Study Says
description: Exercise may enhance an important form of blood cholesterol, but only because it causes people to lose weight, a new study indicates.

title: Health; Depressed People and Thought-Control Therapy
description: A new study suggests that a major cause of depression is a failure in the normal capacity to distract oneself from the depressing thoughts everyone has from time to time.

title: Graphic Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Q.I have a long rosewood laminated table that was originally treated with boiled linseed oil. About 10 years ago, I coated it with polyurethane varnish, and now this finish has started chipping off in places. How can I remove the polyurethane without harming the rosewood veneer, and then should I refinish with more polyurethane or go back to the boiled linseed oil? A.You can remove the polyurethane with a chemical varnish remover - preferably one of the semi-paste types that are nonflammable. This will not harm the veneer as long as you use caution when scraping off the softened residue.

title: Satellite Music Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PENNSYLVANIA - BUSH
description: A vital part of the Democratic base, Pennsylvania and its 25 electoral votes were narrowly taken by Mr. Bush through a fierce campaign in western parts of the state that emphasized gun control and abortion more than his vision of a gentler America.

title: The Elections: The Winner; Lieberman Quietly Savors Triumph Amid Well-Wishers
description: Bounding from his car onto the red-brick concourse of Statehouse Square, Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman looked for people to thank. They found him instead.

title: European Coin Seen Gaining
description: The first coin denominated in European Currency Units is selling at about 5 percent over the market value of its content of one-half ounce of gold, and some coin analysts believe it will soon eclipse more plentiful United States and Canadian gold coins as collectors' items.

title: Sports of The Times; With a Song In the Ball
description: THE maestro of the Knickerbockers, Mark Jackson, strode across the Madison Square Garden basketball court Tuesday night to where one of the referees was holding the game ball, the ball he'd soon be tossing into the air to start the contest between New York and Chicago. This was the opening game of the new hope-filled hoop-filled season for the Knicks and their fans, 19,591 of whom had crammed into the hall.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Veterans Day is tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Begins at 10 A.M. at 39th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, heads south to 24th Street and ends at the Eternal Light Monument about noon. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Financial Markets: Open. Transportation: Subway, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule; schedules of some bus and rail routes may be adjusted. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: VIRGINIA - BUSH
description: Proving their capacity for divided loyalties, Virginians voted to put a Democrat in the Senate and a Republican in the White House, both by overwhelming margins.

title: Regulators Rush to Close Bass Deal
description: Facing losses of up to $30 million a month at the nation's largest insolvent savings and loan institution, Federal regulators are rushing to complete a previously announced deal to sell the $30 billion American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., to the Robert M. Bass Group of Fort Worth.

title: Voting by Counties
description: (NOTE: This table may be divided, and additional information on a particular entry may appear on more than one screen.)

title: Polish Shipyard Workers End Wildcat Strikes
description: Workers at two shipyards here heeded calls today by the solidarity leader, Lech Walesa, and ended wildcat strikes.

title: RABBI CHALLENGES STATE ON MENORAH
description: A rabbi said today that the state of Iowa violated his constitutional rights when he was denied permission to erect a 20-foot menorah at the state Capitol.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush handily won this traditionally Republican state, where a come-from-behind victory over Senator Bob Dole of Kansas in last February's Republican primary put him on the road to the nomination. Mr. Dukakis's residence in neighboring Massachusetts proved little help in capturing the state, which last went for a Democrat in 1964.

title: ILLINOIS - BUSH
description: Illinois, with its 24 electoral votes, was central to the Dukakis strategy of sweeping the industrial Middle West. The Democrat campaigned vigorously there, and made it a tight race, but he fell short by a narrow margin.

title: CALIFORNIA - BUSH
description: With 47 electoral votes, California was the biggest prize of all on Tuesday, and both sides made a maximum effort in the closing days of the campaign. But Mr. Bush, riding the popularity of President Reagan, pulled out a close victory.

title: Baseball; Viola Almost Sweeps Award
description: Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins, the left-hander from St. John's University who became a World Series hero in 1987, added to his stardom yesterday when he won the Cy Young Award as the American League's outstanding pitcher in 1988.

title: Comdisco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $75,000,000 from discontinued risk arbitrage activities. c-Includes net from discontinued risk arbitrage activities of $7,000,000 and $17,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The Elections: Television; Projections With Polls Still Open Anger West Coast Voters
description: With polls still open in 11 states, first CBS News and then ABC News announced Tuesday night that Vice President Bush was the projected winner of the Presidential race.

title: OHIO - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush's victory here capped an intense battle by both campaigns for a state each candidate regarded as essential to winning the election. Mr. Dukakis, who took a pounding from Mr. Bush on gun control, crime, abortion and taxes, visited a dozen times, including an Election Eve stop.

title: The Vote in the Northeast
Aydin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $6,003,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Green Mountain Power Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ESTONIANS REJECT SOVIET PROPOSALS
description: The rebellious republic of Estonia made a new assault on the Kremlin's tranquillity today, telling an official commission in Moscow that Estonians reject the Communist Party's proposed design for a new Soviet government.

title: ARIZONA - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush won 61 percent of the vote, as Ronald Reagan did in 1980.

title: Set Limits on Presidential Campaigns, Polls and Ads; Buchanan or Fremont?
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Cheers the Bush Victory
description: Business executives are delighted with George Bush's victory, believing that his policies will offer the best chance of extending the economic expansion begun under President Reagan. But they are concerned about the trade and budget deficits, and wonder about Mr. Bush's ability to work effectively with the Democratic-controlled Congress.

title: MARYLAND - BUSH
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign once considered Maryland a sure thing since the state is a regular party supporter. But although the Democratic incumbent Senator, Paul S. Sarbanes, handily won re-election to a third term, Mr. Bush succeeded in wooing the state's 10 electoral votes into the Republican column.

title: Oceaneering International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Architecture; Pavilion Where East Meets West
description: Its winged roofs, zigzagging walls and circular towers covered in shards of green quartz loom to the west of the La Brea Tar Pits. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art's new Pavilion for Japanese Art, which opened recently, has prompted some observers here to suggest that La Brea's fake mastadons look as though they are rearing up in startled response.

title: Modern Notions Of Design: The Furniture of Gaetano Pesce
description: FOR Gaetano Pesce, to be modern is to face the world squarely and use design as a means to comment on it. For nearly 20 years, the Italian architect and furniture designer has taken advantage of modern technology to create remarkable pieces designed specifically for mass production. The only problem: since just a few have been mass produced, most people are unfamiliar with his work.

title: 'Legs Diamond' Postponed
description: ''Legs Diamond,'' the Broadway musical about the 1920's gangster that stars Peter Allen, has delayed its official opening until Dec. 11 at the Mark Hellinger Theater. The show, which is in previews, had been scheduled to open Dec. 1. The producers said technical difficulties with the sets, which delayed the beginning of previews, caused the postponement.

title: The Elections; A Hudson Elections Official Is Accused of Denying Rights
description: The Hudson County Democratic Committee is investigating the county election superintendent and allegations that he was responsible for compiling a challenge list that denied thousands their voting rights, the County Executive said today.

title: ALASKA - BUSH
description: This state has been solidly Republican for two decades and the 1988 election proved no exception as Mr. Dukakis was buried by Mr. Bush.

title: Johns's 'White Flag' Is Sold for Record Price
description: Jasper Johns's ghostlike ''White Flag,'' its surface drained of color but still strongly evocative, was sold last night at Christie's for $7 million, the highest price ever paid for a work by a living artist.

title: West Virginia Makes Foes See Red
description: There was a time in major college football when the process of red-shirting was considered less than honorable, sort of a sneaky way to store talent for use beyond the time when an athlete should have been long gone from college.

title: The Elections; 5 Submit Resignations To President Reagan
description: It is traditional for senior officials of the Federal Government to submit their resignations to the outgoing President when an administration comes to an end, as the Reagan Administration will do on Jan. 20.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I WONDER why it is always this time of year that makes me remember how it felt. Perhaps it is the early darkness, the sense that the outside world has shut down. Or perhaps it is the threatening weather just beyond the horizon, the sense of wind gathering, or snow, or storms. Yesterday, with the dry leaves shuffling in figure eights around my feet on the sidewalk, I thought about what it was like growing up, and the feeling came back to me, palpable as fever.

title: MAINE - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush swamped Mr. Dukakis in Maine for the state's four electoral votes. The Vice President owns a sprawling summer home in Kennebunkport and has long considered the state home territory. The last Democratic Presidential nominee to win there was Hubert H. Humphrey in 1968.

title: Phoenix American Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
School Basketball; Anderson, Top Recruit in U.S., Picks Georgia Tech
description: Kenny Anderson of Archbishop Molloy, the most highly sought high school basketball player in the nation, signed a letter of intent yesterday to attend Georgia Tech.

title: Ex-Salomon Officer To Join Bankers Trust
description: Gerald Rosenfeld, the former chief financial officer of Salomon Brothers Inc., has joined the Bankers Trust Company as a managing director in charge of a new merchant banking group.

title: Prime Motor Inns LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Set Limits on Presidential Campaigns, Polls and Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Instituform Mid-America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $48,844 and $223,194 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; CBS Tries 'Branding' Its Shows
description: WHEN George F. Schweitzer returned to CBS last summer after a year's sojourn at Young & Rubicam, he faced an immediate problem: how do you move a troubled dinosaur?

title: Landmark Mansion As Gallery
description: WHEN the Berry-Hill Galleries open tomorrow, visitors will be able not only to view artworks but also to inspect 30 subtle wall colors by Donald Kaufman, and muse about juxtapositions like oak plank floors against pink Tennessee marble. The 6,000-square-foot gallery at 11 East 70th Street, whose first show is titled ''Old Money: Ameri-can Trompe-l'oeil Images of Currency,'' will specialize in 19th- and 20th-century art.

title: Pillows to Complement Virtually Any Decor
description: MARJORIE LAWRENCE, the self-proclaimed ''Mother of Pillows,'' runs the Pillowry on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. ''I don't think a room ever looks complete without pillows,'' Mrs. Lawrence said. ''If you have a naked couch, it somehow isn't inviting. There's something about pillows that brings a room together.''

title: KANSAS - BUSH
description: Kansas remained true to historical form and true to the Republicans in this election. Despite several years of serious farm financial problems in the Reagan Administration and despite Mr. Bush's primary defeats of Senator Bob Dole, a native son, Kansans gave Mr. Bush the state's seven electoral votes.

title: WEST VIRGINIA - DUKAKIS
description: In this mountainous state, one of the poorest in the nation, Democrats usually do well, and West Virginians gave the Democrats a clean sweep of major races. Mr. Dukakis's message, that he would side with middle-class voters against the rich, played well in a state dominated by large mining and industrial interests.

title: Uno Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Includes a $120,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Communications Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Petroleum Equipment Tools Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: First Northern Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Durham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $784,000 for the quarter and $5,773,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $1,881,000 and $6,585,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, captions of two pictures in some copies yesterday, showing election-night reactions at the Presidential candidates' headquarters, were reversed. The picture with two people at the left clapping, at the top of page A27, showed Lee Atwater, left, and James A. Baker 3d, right, celebrating at Bush headquarters in Houston. The other picture on the page showed Democrats watching in dismay at Dukakis headquarters in Boston as returns came in.

title: Afghan Premier Seeks U.N. Peace Plan
description: The Afghan Prime Minister called today for the demilitarization of his country under international supervision. He said such a move would help bring about a coalition government by the time the Soviet Union completes its military withdrawal.

title: KEY RATES
Magnet Schools: Still a Hit Amid Criticism
description: The Manhattan East Center for the Arts and Academics in East Harlem is on the edge of a neighborhood of ravaged buildings and streets with swarms of drug dealers, but 13-year-old Shanique Garcia travels an hour every day to take advantage of the public school's special programs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M.

title: Gaylord Container Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-earlier results are for the 10 1/2 months ended Sept. 27, 1987. The figures have been restated to give effect the June 1, 1988 merger of Mid- America Packing Inc. into Gaylord Container Corp. and the concurrent issuance of Gaylord's class A and class B common as if the transaction had occurred on Nov. 17, 1986, the date of inception of Gaylord Container. The results of the operations related to certain assets of the container products division of Fibreboard Corp. that were acquired March 29, 1988 have been included in the company's results from that date.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Estonians rejected new Soviet rules that it said would allow Moscow to override individual republics on all important issues, stifling moves in the Baltic republics for greater economic and political autonomy. Page A17

title: Sports People; New Card for Soccer?
description: The British Government unveiled plans yesterday for a program aimed at reducing violence by soccer fans. If enacted by Parliament, the program would require anyone wanting to watch a soccer match at 92 stadiums in England and Wales to buy a plastic card that held their picture and bits of personal information on a metallic strip. The card would be presented at a computerized turnstile at the stadium and, if a computer check showed the holder had a history of soccer-related violence, admission would be denied. Sports Minister Colin Moynihan said that more than 6,000 people were arrested for soccer-related violence last season in England and that trouble has kept up this year. (AP)

title: Metropolitan Federal Savings & Loan (Tenn) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Keptel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GNI Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $144,160. c-Net income and after a gain from discontinued operations of $61,548 and an extraordinary gain of $42,286.

title: Fonar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $434,000 for the latest first quarter and $435,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Pessimism Overtakes Brazil Politics and Economy
description: When pessimism began to spread like a strange virus through this young and energetic nation early last year, even Brazilians were surprised to find their natural confidence in the future being sapped by unfamiliar doubts.

title: Lovingly Hand-Shaped
description: ONE hundred and twenty-five craftsmen from around the nation will show their works at the Philadelphia Craft Show, open from today through Sunday at the Armory on 33d Street in Philadelphia.

title: Chubb Agrees to Settle More Farmers' Suits
description: The Chubb Corporation agreed today to a $48 million settlement covering farmers in 10 Midwestern states who sued the company when their applications for 1988 drought insurance were denied.

title: Flextronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Health Dept. Vigilant In Controlling TB
description: To the Editor:

title: OREGON - DUKAKIS
description: Oregonians backed Governor Dukakis by a margin of six percentage points.

title: Challis Journal; Mining Town Haunted by Ghosts of Boom Times
description: As the homes in her neighborhood vanished one after another, Kathy Sullivan would peer out the kitchen window and shrug, ''There goes another one.''

title: Air Force Jet Presumed Down
description: The Air Force said today that an F-15C fighter that disappeared in low clouds and mountainous terrain Tuesday was presumed to have crashed. A civilian reported hearing explosions after seeing the jet fly over Kodiak Airport. Search teams suspended their effort Tuesday night because of low visibility and the treacherous terrain, said Lieut. Tom Saint of the Coast Guard. The plane was practicing instrument landing approaches at the airport where the cloud cover was 1,200 feet, the Air Force said.

title: Goldtex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $65,395.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA - BUSH
description: There were no surprises in South Carolina, which Mr. Bush carried easily. The state is home to both the Vice President's campaign manager, Lee Atwater, and his Southern campaign director, Gov. Carroll Campbell. The state has voted Republican in every Presidential election since 1964, exceptng 1976, when it went for Jimmy Carter.

title: Bush Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PUERTO RICO
description: Puerto Rico, a commonwealth, has no electoral votes, although it had primaries to elect delegates to the national conventions.

title: INSIDE
description: Delay at Weapon Plant The Energy Department's top safety official said he doubts that a crucial nuclear reactor can be restarted as scheduled in December. Page A20. Estonians Oppose Changes An Estonian delegation rejected the proposed design for a new Soviet government, saying it would leave too much power with Moscow. Page A17. Breast Implants Questioned Silicone implants of the kind used in more than two million women caused cancer in rats, Government documents indicate. Page A18. B-1 Bomber Fleet Grounded The entire fleet of new B-1 bombers has been grounded indefinitely after a crash near Abilene, Tex., the Strategic Air Command said. Page A23.

title: No Major Cuts Expected In Advertising by Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's planned shift in advertising is aimed at establishing a new merchandise mix, pricing policy and marketing approach more than at cutting costs, said company executives and advertising officials close to the giant retailer. The shift is an integral part of a restructuring announced last week.

title: Penn Virginia Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Conseco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GTE to Cut 7,000 Workers in U.S. by 1992
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that total employment in its domestic telephone operations will be reduced by nearly 7,000 workers by 1992 as part of its previously announced plans to streamline telephone operations.

title: The Elections: Charter; All Revisions Are Adopted In Large Vote
description: In a development that surprised and pleased political experts, more than half of the New York City voters who started at the top of their ballot choosing between George Bush and Michael Dukakis Tuesday went far enough through it to vote on a package of amendments to the city's charter.

title: First Farwest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $375,000 for the 9 months.

title: General Sciences reports earnings for Year to July 31
ALABAMA - BUSH
description: Alabama and its nine electoral votes were a safe bet for Mr. Bush, which explains why he never returned after winning the Republican primary in March.

title: American National Petroluem Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The adoption of FAS 96 increased net income by $139,000 in the year-ago third quarter, and increased net income $304,000 in the year-ago 9 months.

title: KENTUCKY - BUSH
description: As part of a national strategy that discounted much of the South and the Rocky Mountains, the Dukakis campaign made a serious effort in small border states like Kentucky, where Democrats outnumber Republicans 2 to 1. But President Reagan campaigned here twice for the national ticket and Mr. Bush was never seriously threatened.

title: In Storm's Aftermath, Jamaica Seeks Visitors
description: The morning after the most powerful hurricane of the century battered Jamaica in mid-September, Heinz Simonitsch walked through the wreckage of the elegant beach resort he manages here.

title: Altos Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Includes a $5.7 million gain from the sale of Communications Solutions Inc.

title: MMI Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
WASHINGTON - DUKAKIS
description: Though Washington has been viewed as an easy prize for a competitive Democratic candidate, Mr. Dukakis won the state's 10 electoral votes only narrowly.
