title: Silicone Implants Tied To Cancer in Test Rats
description: A study by the Dow Corning Corporation found that silicone gel implants of the kind used to augment the breasts of more than two million American women caused cancer in more than 23 percent of a group of rats tested, according to internal Government documents made public today.

title: COLORADO - BUSH
description: Mr. Dukakis had some early hopes of stealing a march from Mr. Bush in this state, which has gone for Republicans in every Presidential election since 1968.

title: Talking Deals; A Feeding Frenzy On Nabisco Fees
description: WALL STREET has traditionally been a gentlemanly place - unless tons of money and reputations are at stake. Then one really sees what the game is all about.

title: Halsey Drug reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: DOORKNOBS that incorporate a lock in the knob are referred to as locksets. Because they are less expensive to manufacture and easier to install than traditional mortise locks - in which the knob and lock mechanism are separate even though housed in a single assembly - locksets are by far the most common type of latching device for both exterior and interior doors.

title: International Remote Imaging Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MONTANA - BUSH
description: With just four electoral votes and huge open spaces under its celebrated big sky, Montana, which went for Mr. Bush, has not figured as a key Presidential state. But Montana had an upset and two Republican gains as Mr. Dukakis tried to undo 20 years of Republican voting in the Presidential race.

title: Continental Materials Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income and after a gain of $902,000 from an accounting change.

title: Nash Finch Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
Ideology, Competence and Mr. Bush
description: President-elect Bush could have found someone with weightier national security credentials than James A. Baker 3d to be his Secretary of State. But he could not have found anyone he trusts more. Mr. Baker, the former Secretary of the Treasury and a friend for 30 years, was an architect of Mr. Bush's rise from potential loser to President-elect. This resurrection is worth appraisal now that the endless campaign has finally ended.

title: Boy, 3, Shot to Death By Troops in Gaza City
description: Israeli troops in the occupied Gaza Strip today shot and killed a 3-year-old boy who was playing in the street alongside two older boys who were throwing stones at the soldiers, Arabs said.

title: Luxurious Louis XIV, Writ Small
description: ONLY a few months ago, Bonpoint, the French children's clothing store, opened a shop at 1269 Madison Avenue, at 91st Street. Now a division of the company, Louis XIV and After, has introduced a collection of furniture for children that includes not only the requisite glossy-white highchairs and cribs but also scaled-down chairs and sofas derived from traditional designs.

title: Skywest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: The Elections: Congress; Democrats Take Solace as the Party Defies History and Adds to Majority
description: Democratic leaders in Congress were buoyant yesterday, their party having defied history and gained seats in both houses while losing the Presidential election.

title: Echo Bay Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Terex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dramatic Home Decor From Kamali
description: MUSIC by Liberace sets the romantic mood. A banquet-size table is laden with crystal and silver accessories; sequined throws are draped over velvet-covered chairs and majestic silk draperies are topped with valances of dried hydrangeas.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Bulls 110, Celtics 104: Michael Jordan scored 52 points, including 19 in the fourth period, and the Bulls ended a 12-game Boston Garden losing streak last night. Jordan also had nine steals.

title: Advanta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Low Voter Turnout? Don't Believe It
description: About 89 million Americans voted Tuesday, several million less than in 1984. Not only was this the first time since 1944 that the number of voters declined from one Presidental election to the next, but the rate of voter participation appears to be the lowest since World War II.

title: Dole Tax Idea On Buyouts
description: The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, said today that he wanted to help President-elect George Bush avoid new taxes and suggested changes in the deductibility of interest payments for loans used in corporate buyouts as a possible revenue source.

title: Atmos Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the results of Western Kentucky Gas Co., acquired in Dec. 1, 1987 through Sept. 30, 1988 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a one-time charge to income tax expenses of $585,000 and a pre-tax one-time charge of $1.2 million for costs associated with an early retirement program.

title: TEXAS - BUSH
description: Texas became a hard-fought battle between two favorite sons, and George Bush, the adopted child of the Lone Star State, bested the native, Senator Lloyd Bentsen.

title: The Elections: Vice Presidency; For Quayle, Just a Sliver of Limelight
description: Vice President-elect Dan Quayle found out today what his new job will be like.

title: MISSOURI - BUSH
description: Missouri has voted for the winner in every Presidential election since 1956, which was one reason both Mr. Bush and Mr. Dukakis campaigned heavily in the state in the general election campaign.

title: Baldwin & Lyons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $216,186 for the quarter and $908,984 for the 9 months. c-Includes investment gains of $1,021,782 and $2,591,413 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: NORTH CAROLINA - BUSH
description: Republicans solidified gains won in the 1984 Reagan landslide in a state where Democrats continue to maintain a 2-to-1 registration advantage.

title: Health: Medical Techniques; Increasingly, Blood Recipients Are Getting Their Own Blood
description: Donating blood for one's own later use has become a rapidly growing part of the nation's blood program. Specialists in this field estimate that such autologous donations have doubled annually in the last two years.

title: Novo Industri A/S reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated at the Sept. 30, 1988 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equals Dkr. 7.2120. The share earnings are in American Depositary Shares.

title: Coniston Renews Its Appeal to TW
description: Coniston Partners L.P. has renewed its appeal to the board of TW Services Inc. to negotiate the New York investment group's tender offer to acquire the majority of TW Service's stock for $29 a share, or $456 million.

title: Air Force Head To McDonnell
description: Air Force Secretary Edward C. (Pete) Aldridge Jr. has resigned to become president of the McDonnell Douglas Electronic Systems Company, a new concern created by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Pentagon said today.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: If Dr. Mary S. Calderone had known all about the medications she was taking in 1985, when her troubles began, she might have been spared 30 months of debilitating, often humiliating misery. She suffered from extreme sleepiness, loss of balance, memory problems, weakness, difficulty concentrating, depression, unease and lassitude.

title: New York; New York State's Democrats Bask in Glow of Strong Showing
description: Despite losing the White House once again, New York Democrats yesterday could point to many electoral victories that reinforced the party's domination of the state.

title: Amplicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Time Management Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Home Savings & Loan Assn (Durham, NC) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lindsay Manufacturing reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
The Voters' Message
description: Pay no attention to the Splitsville Analysis of the 1988 election.

title: Restitution Set by Schwab
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm, said today that it would take a non-recurring $2.4 million after-tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reimburse customers for gains made by the brokerage in unauthorized trading of customer shares over three and a half years.

title: The Elections: Ballot Issues; 3 State Referendums Give New Impetus to Anti-Abortion Efforts
description: Anti-abortion forces won new encouragement Tuesday when voters in Michigan, Colorado and Arkansas enacted or upheld measures barring state financing for abortions.

title: Gateway Federal Savings & Loan Assocition reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $274,000 gain from an accounting change. c-Includes tax credits of $409,000 for the quarter and $2,330,000 for the 9 months.

title: Metro Datelines; Truck Hits and Kills Blind Man and Dog
description: A blind man and his guide dog were struck and killed by a dump truck as they crossed a street in this Syracuse suburb.

title: TV Notes
description: The Returns

title: In Praise of the Icons Of the Open Road
description: In their list of hallowed American landmarks, most people would not include Paul's Automatic Car Wash in downtown Detroit, where the overhead sprayer was first wedded with the chain conveyor.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Modern Variations in Tapestry Designs
description: IN Archie Brennan's tapestry, Princess Diana and a medieval maiden meet in a time warp.

title: Reviews/Television; Youth vs. Crime In ABC Series, 'Knightwatch'
description: In a prime-time world monopolized by nice middle-class people living in nice middle-class suburbs, the new ABC series ''Knightwatch'' has this much going for it: the urban heroes are blue collar, and the situations they encounter will be familiar to any city dweller who watches a local newscast. That, though, is about it. The rest is formula, steeped in the always explosive issues of vigilantism. In its premiere episode, tonight at 8, ''Knightwatch'' manages to evoke memories of youth-against-crime formats ranging from ''Mod Squad'' to ''Hell Town.''

title: Lone Star Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: John N. Mitchell Dies at 75; Major Figure in Watergate
description: John N. Mitchell, President Nixon's Attorney General who was jailed for his role in the Watergate scandals, died this evening at George Washington University Hospital after suffering a heart attack on a sidewalk in Georgetown. He was 75 years old.

title: The People Speak
description: From the beginning, American political theory has rested on the idea of popular sovereignty. In this country, James Madison wrote in 1798, ''The people, not the government, possess the absolute sovereignty.''

title: Books of The Times; Stories of a World Where the Surreal Is Possible
description: All You Can Eat Stories By Robin Hemley 180 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. Paperback. $7.95.

title: Plain Old Pokeweed, The Jewel of Autumn
description: A BRITISH horticulturist startled me last year by proclaiming it to be among the world's most beautiful of plants, especially in the autumn. A friend down South wrote me last month about suddenly seeing something gleaming like rubies and garnets in a far corner of her garden. She walked down to investigate, then felt shock when she saw what it was. It was pokeweed (Phytolacca Americana).

title: Grubb & Ellis Realty Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Elections: Polling; Surveys' Accuracy Fails to Curb the Criticism
description: After some embarrassing findings in the Presidential primary season, newspapers and television networks came about as close as polling specialists believe is possible to forecasting the results of Tuesday's election.

title: Cooper Cos. Sells Its Aquaflex Unit
description: In a continuation of its restructuring program, the Cooper Companies sold Aquaflex, its soft-contact-lens business in the United States and Japan, for about $35 million in cash to Wesley-Jessen, a subsidiary of the Schering-Plough Corporation.

title: Golf; Players Aim at a Big Late-Season Prize
description: The $3 million in individual purses and bonuses at the Nabisco Championship golf tournament this week may be chicken feed in the corporate board rooms, where upwards of $20 billion is the haggling price for RJR Nabisco. But the 30 leading money winners on the 1988 PGA Tour don't think so as they prepare to compete for the ''pocket change'' on the Pebble Beach Golf Links Thursday through Sunday.

title: Belmoral Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writeoff of tax benefits of $635,000 previously recorded for the quarter, and the 9 months includes a tax loss carryforward of $697,000. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: LOUISIANA - BUSH
description: With the slump in oil prices, Louisiana was one of the biggest holes in what Governor Dukakis called the Swiss cheese economy, but he could not exploit the opening. Vice President Bush garnered good publicity in the state during the Republican convention in New Orleans and managed to win without ever returning.

title: Homestyle Buffet reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,330 for the quarter and $25,000 for the 9 months.

title: American Heritage Life Inestment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital losses of $167,047 for the quarter and capital gains of $551,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $86,580 and $2,101,223 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Petition on T.W.A. Dismissed by U.S.
description: The Transportation Department denied a request that it investigate the economic fitness of Trans World Airlines Inc. in connection with the recent privatization of the carrier. T.W.A. was taken private on Oct. 24 by its chairman, Carl C. Icahn. The move has been criticized by the unions representing pilots and flight attendants at T.W.A., who argued that it would drain the airline of cash and weaken its financial condition.

title: ARAFAT SUBMITS U.S. VISA REQUEST
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, formally asked the United States for a visa today so he can address the General Assembly, a United Nations spokesman announced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Corrections
description: A report on Tuesday in the Advertising column of Business Day, about a forthcoming fragrance introduction, misidentified the senior vice president for business affairs and development at the World Wrestling Federation. He is Richard Glover.

title: Glenmore Distilleries Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter included one month of results of Fleischmann Distilling Co., acquired Sept. 8. The year-ago quarter included operations of Corbett Canyon Vineyards, which was sold Jan. 29.

title: Newport Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Belgian Stock Trading
description: Belgium set out a timetable today to reform its antiquated stock exchanges in time for them to survive competition in a single European market after 1992. Finance Minister Philippe Maystadt told a news conference that continuous electronic trading would begin to replace a system of chalk and blackboards early next year.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Review/Jazz; Shirley Horn's Epiphanies
description: Songs are lucky when Shirley Horn chooses them. She honors melodies just by singing them unadorned, in a voice of honey and smoke; she enunciates every word, shaping small and large peaks with just a slight pause or a lingering vowel. Accompanying herself on piano, she renders harmonies in economical chords, sustained or neatly articulated. And when the time comes to improvise, the song's emotion guides her; she drapes lyrics in bluesy curves and finds epiphanies in tender phrases.

title: Merrill Lynch Sells Step-Down Notes
description: Merrill Lynch and Company is offering $200 million of step-down floating-rate notes due in 1991 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the sole underwriter.

title: Witness Recalls Myerson's Anger at Newspaper Inquiry
description: A witness testified yesterday that Bess Myerson became ''very angry'' when a newspaper asked questions about her hiring of Sukhreet Gabel in the Cultural Affairs Department of New York City.

title: Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
description: To The Home Section:

title: Corrections
description: A restaurant review in Weekend on Oct. 14 referred incorrectly to the ownership of the Golden Unicorn restaurant in New York. It is not connected with the Golden Unicorn in Hong Kong.

title: CrownAmerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said fiscal 1988 results include a $500,000, or 46 cents a share, gain from an accounting change; a $91,000, or 8 cents a share, from foreign exchange gains and a $182,000 gain from the sale of land.

title: Woolworth, F W Co reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Benefited by $4 million and $8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from a reduction in the effective tax rate.

title: Jordan Seen in Aid Mission
description: With no senior officials accompanying him, King Hussein of Jordan flew to Qatar today on a previously unannounced trip in a reported quest for Arab aid. He has made stops in Kuwait and Bahrain and will also visit Oman.

title: Sri Lanka, Pressed by Militants, Asks All Tourists to Leave Country
description: Pressure and threats by a militant political group have prompted the Government to ask all tourists to leave the country.

title: Bronx Principal Is Arrested As a Street Buyer of Crack
description: The principal of a Bronx elementary school was arrested by narcotics officers yesterday afternoon moments after they observed him buying two $10 vials of crack on the street near his home in Harlem, the police said.

title: Electronic Associates Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Acuson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Choice for Top Cabinet Post: James Addison Baker 3d
description: He is a Texas patrician who struck up a friendship with his next-door neighbor, George Bush, 30 years ago, a lawyer whose shrewdness and toughness as a Republican political strategist have led him close to the pinnacle of power. Although James A. Baker 3d openly sought the job of Secretary of State, the choice is a risky one. The dapper, 58-year-old former marine - part Houston and part Princeton - has gained a reputation as a smiling Southern gentleman who can disarm his enemies, a masterly, some say manipulative, Washington insider. But he has had relatively scant foreign policy experience.

title: Tapes Cited in Kansas Inquiry
description: It was one of those just-between-us-coaches telephone chats between Larry Brown and Dana Kirk, and what was said in the summer of 1986 might have forever remained a secret if Kirk hadn't been taping the conversation and Brown hadn't been saying things worth taping.

title: Voters Delay Republican Hopes Of Dominance in Post-Reagan Era
description: Vice President Bush's solid victory in the Presidential election Tuesday was a personal triumph and, as the fifth Republican victory in six elections, a confirmation of his party's power in Presidential contests.

title: DIST. OF COLUMBIA - DUKAKIS
description: Governor Dukakis won easily in the nation's capital, with 86 percent of the vote. The District, with three electoral votes, has an overwhelmingly Democratic registration.

title: East German Makes State Hotel Turn Profit
description: Gisela Schultz is a loyal member of the Communist Party in East Germany, but she has the instincts of a capitalist. She survives, prospers and enjoys, while many of those around her seem only to survive and pretend to enjoy.

title: Botanical Prints: Collector's Primer
description: LEAD: PERHAPS it was the 80's mania for the English country look, or perhaps it was the increasing cost of original oil and watercolor flower studies. But in the last decade or so, botanical prints have become a popular staple of traditional interior decorating.

title: MINNESOTA - DUKAKIS
description: Mr. Dukakis took Minnesota and its 10 electoral votes by a comfortable margin, but a fierce Senate battle ended with the victory of the Republican incumbent, Dave Durenberger, over his main challenger, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, and an independent Democrat, Polly Mann.

title: Calendar: Treasures Of William And Mary
description: International Grace, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, Manhattan; 212-860-6868.

title: MISSISSIPPI - BUSH
description: Mr. Bush, as expected, won handily in the state, but Republicans scored their real victory in the hotly contested Senate race that became a symbol of the struggle between the Republican and Democratic parties of the South. Represenative Trent Lott, the Republican, won comfortably over Representative Wayne Dowdy. Both Congressmen gave up safe seats to battle for the right to succeed John C. Stennis, the 88-year-old Democrat who retired this year.

title: London's Traffic: First It Killed the Romans
description: The first thing that strikes an American in London these days is the paralyzing traffic -literally, if you look the wrong way crossing the street and forget that vehicles drive on the left.

title: WISCONSIN - DUKAKIS
description: This was one of Mr. Dukakis's safest states, but even so, his victory here was narrow. To a large extent the Presidential contest was overshadowed by the race between Susan Engeleiter and Herbert H. Kohl for the Senate seat being vacated by William Proxmire, a Democrat, who retired after 32 years.

title: THE ELECTIONS: Challenges for Bush: Agenda and Congress; President-Elect Still Hasn't Detailed Course of Action - Lawmakers Wary
description: When George Bush moves into the Oval Office next January, he will face a far more difficult political situation than his mentor, President Reagan, faced after his inauguration eight years ago. Unlike Mr. Reagan, Mr. Bush neither detailed a clear course of proposed action in his campaign nor asked the electorate to endorse specific policies. He talked ''tough'' and he talked ''gentle,'' to use two words that recurred in his campaign, and not even Washington insiders are sure what blend of the two to expect.

title: Portrait of the Electorate
description: (NOTE: This table may be divided, and additional information on a particular entry may appear on more than one screen.)

title: In Germany, Tears and Mourning for a Dark Night
description: The President, Chancellor and other West German leaders joined Jews of Frankfurt today in the main event of nationwide commemorations marking the 50th anniversary of the great pogrom that first signaled the full fury of Nazi Germany's war on the Jews.

title: Chip Ratio Down Again
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator was down for the seventh straight month today, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported decreased shipments and orders, a trade group said.

title: Shirley Burke, Literary Agent, 81
description: Shirley Burke, a literary agent who represented several prominent authors, died of a heart attack Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: New York Plan Failed Schools, A Panel Finds
description: A New York State program intended to improve the state's 500 worst schools, most of which are in New York City, has largely been a failure, an education study group said yesterday.

title: Atlantic American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $38,022,000 from the completion of the previously announced sale of Rhodes Inc., which was offset by investment losses of $6,160,000 and losses from operations of $17,047,000.

title: Dow Drops 9.25, to 2,118.24; Volume Rises
description: Stock prices closed broadly lower yesterday in moderately brisker post-election trading.

title: The Elections: Texas Power; Houston, Used to Tall Politicians, Claims Next President as a Neighbor
description: Texas has boasted such colorful politicians as John Nance Garner, Sam Rayburn, Lyndon B. Johnson and John B. Connally. And now it can claim the more mild-mannered 41st President of the United States - if you don't count his other home states of Maine, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

title: MASSACHUSETTS - DUKAKIS
description: Mr. Dukakis won Massachusetts, but not overwhelmingly.

title: Black Hole in the Jets' Offensive Galaxy
description: They rank among the National Football League's best: O'Brien, Walker, Toon, Shuler. Each has played in the Pro Bowl. But the Jets' stars are moribund these days.

title: 9 Slain in Bangladesh
description: A Bangladeshi Air Force corporal shot and killed 8 people and wounded 50 others when he opened fire with a submachine gun in a mosque at Jessore air base and then killed himself, military officials said today. The officials declined to identify the man and could not provide a motive for the killings Tuesday night.

title: HAWAII - DUKAKIS
description: Hawaii has been warm to Democratic candidates in recent years, and the state gave Mr. Dukakis one of the widest victory margins of any accorded the Massachusetts Governor.

title: Security Tag Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Lessons in Scientific Citizenship; A Lonely Dissent on 'Yellow Rain'
description: When the K.G.B. spread the story that the AIDS virus had been created in American biological warfare laboratories, the Soviet scientific establishment knew it was a lie but did not protest. In a remarkable recent speech, Roald Sagdeyev, past director of the Soviet Institute of Space Science, chided his colleagues for their silence.

title: No Point In Crying Over Split Furniture
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH you may have no intention of ever repairing a split in a piece of furniture, it can help to understand how to deal with this common fault and how it might be prevented.

title: Resisting Marketing's Grasp
description: ADVERTISING often provides the earliest opportunities to help preschool children make their own value judgments and identify and resist social pressure. Psychologists who study manipulation recommend starting with an inexpensive product, like a new breakfast cereal or toy, that your child wants to try. Ask what the cereal will taste like, why it will be better than the old cereal and what else it will do for your child. What did the commercial say playing with the toy would be like? Don't try to anticipate answers or pass judgment on them.

Action Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net income and includes a $642,100 gain from an accounting change.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Admits Cruelty At an Animal Shelter
description: An Ulster County man who has operated a shelter for unwanted dogs, cats and barnyard animals for more than 15 years pleaded guilty yesterday to four counts of cruelty to animals.

title: Sports People; 23 Cup Challengers
description: A record 23 yacht clubs from 10 countries have filed challenges with the defending San Diego Yacht Club to participate in the next America's Cup. Eight yacht clubs that submitted challenges by the deadline of midnight Tuesday are from four countries that will be first-time competitors in cup competition: Japan, Denmark, West Germany and the Soviet Union. The other countries are Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Italy and Sweden. A firm date for the next America's Cup, tentatively set for 1991, must await the outcome of proceedings that will decide whether San Diego legally defended the cup when it used a catamaran to defeat 133-foot monohulled sloop of Michael Fay of New Zealand last September. Peter de Savary, a British businessman who made an unsuccessful attempt to enter the America's Cup races won by the San Diego Yacht Club in September, said yesterday he would issue a challenge on behalf of the Royal Burnham Yacht Club as well as his own Port Pendennis Yacht Club..(AP)

title: Review/Theater; Soldiers' Tales, Here and Back There
description: As the lights come up on ''Back in the World,'' a homeless, strung-out man is lying on a ghetto sidewalk, a radio to his ear, listening to a routine traffic report being broadcast from a helicopter. Hearing the chopper blades beating the air and the announcer describe the progress of vehicles on a freeway through a background of radio static, the man begins to hallucinate that he is back in Vietnam and he goes berserk. It is a chilling scene that dramatizes the legacy so many Vietnam War veterans have inherited from a society that preferred to forget them.

title: Pincay Notches No. 7,000
description: Laffit Pincay became the second jockey to win 7,000 races when he rode three winners today on opening day at Hollywood Park.

title: WYOMING - BUSH
description: In a Far West that was solid for Mr. Bush, Wyoming proved to be no exception, but Senator Malcolm Wallop, a Republican, the incumbent, nearly lost his seat.

title: Bridge
description: A foursome from New York City's Cavendish Club that won a national title in Salt Lake City three months ago has decided not to defend it. Win Allegaert, Fred Chang, Michael Camp and Steve Beck, victors in the Grand National Teams Flight B, will not compete again partly because Allegaert is now ineligible and partly because the group wants to challenge at the open level.

title: Lessons in Scientific Citizenship; The Steady Courage of Andrei Sakharov
description: How apt that Andrei Sakharov should be a guest in the United States during an election week. Few in the Soviet Union have argued so fearlessly for greater democracy and freer speech. And if Dr. Sakharov should conclude that Americans treat their political rights frivolously, he will surely say so. As Mikhail Gorbachev has found, this unflinching dissenter steers the same straight course in fair weather or foul.

title: Air Midwest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes charges from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $146,000 for the quarter and $33,000 for the 9 months.

title: Time 'Too Painful' to Remember
description: The Golden Age Club in the basement of an upper Manhattan synagogue was abuzz with gossip, laughter and the shuffle of cards when the rabbi, himself 79 years old, struck a spoon against a metal ash tray to get everyone's attention.

title: World Bank May Give First Loan to Poland
description: The World Bank is expected to approve its first loan to Poland Thursday, a move that is seen as a tentative sign of international support for that country's economic reforms.

title: American Shared Hospital Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reviews/Television; Elie Wiesel: Self-Portrait
description: ''We must remember for the sake of the future.'' The familiar message gains special meaning when it is delivered by Elie Wiesel, who has compelled the world to remember the Holocaust. ''A Portrait of Elie Wiesel,'' the hourlong interview tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, is a self-portrait of the Nobel Prize winner's childhood in the Hungarian stetl of Sighet, his time in Auschwitz and the beginnings of his career as a writer in the West.

title: Garan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Applied Bioscience Internaional reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: THE wackiest thing at ''Modernism:

title: Blunt Bonn Speech On the Hitler Years Prompts a Walkout
description: A political controversy broke out at a special memorial session of the West German Parliament today when the Speaker gave an address in which he tried to show that most Germans let themselves be ''blinded and seduced'' by the Nazis in the 1930's.

title: Johnson Worldwide Assocites Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mattel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $19,600,000 primarily from refinancing senior subordinated notes.

title: Video Jukebox Network Appoints Its New Chief
description: Video Jukebox Network Inc., a company with a new concept in music videos that is moving out of the entrepreneurial stage, has named Andrew H. Orgel president and chief executive.

title: New York Draws Criticism On Forest Land Acquisitions
description: In 1986, New Yorkers voted overwhelmingly for a bond act that, among other things, set aside $250 million so that the State Environmental Conservation Department could acquire land to preserve and expand the state's forests, wilderness areas and parklands.

title: TEXAS IS AWARDED GIANT U.S. PROJECT ON SMASHING ATOM
description: Texas has been selected as the site of the proposed superconducting super collider, a $4.4 billion atom smasher that would be the largest and most costly scientific instrument in the world, the Department of Energy said today.

title: Athey Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Affiliated Publications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes equity in a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of the McCaw Cellular affiliate of $39,978,000 and equity in an extraordinary credit of the affiliate of $17,879,000. Latest third quarter includes equity in losses of continuing operations of the McCaw Cellular Communications affiliate of $37,247,000. Year-ago third quarter includes equity in income of continuing operations of the affiliate of $109,535,000. That amount includes a one-time gain of $121,750,000 related to the increase in shareholders equity of McCaw Cellular. Latest 9-month includes equity in the losses of continuing operations of the McCaw Cellular affiliate of $89,050,000. Year-ago 9 months includes equity in income of continuing operations of the affiiate of $105,027,000.

title: No Headline
description: In a move that might be a prelude to his entry into the mayoral campaign, Richard Ravitch said yesterday that he had turned down an offer from Mayor Koch to reappoint him as chairman of the Charter Revision Commission.

title: Jersey Sees Shortfall in Tax Revenue
description: New Jersey tax collections for the first quarter of the current budget year were lower than anticipated, state officials said today, and if the trend continues the state will finish the year with $155 million less revenue than expected.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about Jewish leaders' meeting with John Cardinal O'Connor on commemorations of Kristallnacht gave an incorrect title for Michael Wyschogrod of the American Jewish Congress. He is a professor of philosophy at Baruch College, but not a rabbi.

title: Review/Film; 'Women on the Verge,' a Farce by Almodovar
description: ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 23. The film opens today at Cinema Studio 1 and 2, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: The McGovern Touch

title: Larizza Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Begins at 10 A.M. at 39th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, heads south to 24th Street and ends at the Eternal Light Monument about noon. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Stock and commodity markets: Open Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No street cleaning. Schools: Closed. Transportation: Subway, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule; schedules of some bus and rail routes may be adjusted. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on regular weekday schedule.

title: Jasper Johns Painting Is Sold for $17 Million
description: Jasper Johns's vibrantly colored ''False Start'' from 1959 was sold last night for $17 million - the second highest price ever paid at auction in this country for any art work - to Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of Conde Nast Publications.

title: Debt Ratings Are Lowered For 2 Nynex Phone Units
description: The debt ratings of the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company have been reduced by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Both are units of the Nynex Corporation.

title:
Real Estate;
Chappaqua Project Cited As Innovative
description: LEAD: WHEN Riverwoods, a 148-unit town-house project under construction in Chappaqua, N.Y., was proposed five years ago, neighbors banded together to oppose multifamily development of the scenic 123-acre site. They were concerned about the increase in traffic and the Westchester project's impact on the environment and the surrounding community.

title: Rushdie's Banned Novel Gets Whitbread Prize
description: Salman Rushdie's novel ''Satanic Verses,'' banned as blasphemous in India and some Arab countries, has won the Whitbread literary prize.

title: A Youth's Passion for Computers, Gone Sour
description: No drama is complete without a moment of foreshadowing, something Robert T. Morris, a onetime student of ancient Greek, knows all too well. In the drama that has enveloped him and his son Robert Jr., a Cornell University graduate student who last week caused the biggest computer gridlock on record, the moment came five years ago on Capitol Hill.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Big Bear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
Raiders Acquire Defensive Help
description: Injuries to the defensive linemen Howie Long and Malcolm Taylor prompted the Los Angeles Raiders to sign Keith Baldwin, a free agent, today.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Move Higher
description: Discount rates on Treasury bills climbed yesterday as the credit market continued to be flooded with short-term Government debt. But prices of Treasury notes and bonds closed slightly higher on balance, as dealers and investors spent much of the day balancing their books for the Veterans Day holiday weekend.

title: Berkshire Hathaway Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $8,564,000 and $54,725,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $11,917,000 for the quarter and $15,532,000 for the 9 months.

title: N.C.A.A. to Review Loans to Manning
description: David Berst, assistant executive director of enforcement for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday the N.C.A.A. might reopen its investigation into the Kansas basketball program.

title: A Kinder, Gentler Nation
description: George Bush says it so often and so deliberately that the assumption has to be that he means it. He wants to use the Presidency to help make the United States a kinder, gentler nation.

title: Rafael Tavares, 43, New York Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Rafael Tavares, a psychiatrist who developed programs to prevent the spread of AIDS, particularly among Hispanic people, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital, his doctor said. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Frozen Positions
description: There were some red faces among officers of the United States Coast Guard last month when its Polar Star icebreaker failed to push through a frozen ridge in the Beaufort Sea west of Alaska and had to turn back. Their faces got redder when American efforts failed to free a couple of gray whales trapped behind an ice ridge near Point Barrow, Alaska.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Court Rejects North Bid To Throw Out Charges
description: A Federal judge, declaring that Oliver L. North had a ''skewed attitude'' toward constitutional government, today denied a request to dismiss charges that Mr. North lied to investigators and attempted to obstruct a Presidential inquiry into the Iran-contra affair.

title: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago periods' results are restated. The share earnings are in units.

title: The Missing Monument
description: One group of American veterans has a special reason to celebrate today. After years of discussion and hesitation, a memorial to those who died in the Korean War is on the way. The remembrance is long overdue.

title: Baldor Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,970,000 from an accounting change. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Foote, Cone Profit Up
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income had risen 5.3 percent, to $4.0 million, or 46 cents a share, from $3.8 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues were up 11.5 percent, to $92.7 million, from $83.1 million in 1987.

title: Chairman Plans To Leave Panel On Landmarks
description: Gene A. Norman, the seemingly imperturbable center of some of the toughest building battles of the last five years, submitted his resignation yesterday as chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Hunter Environmental Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $158,000 for the quarter and $274,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss The latest periods' figures included the results of Reynolds Smith & Hills Inc., which was acquired in February.

title: Elders Blocked On Takeover
description: The British Government today blocked Elders IXL Ltd. from buying any more stock in Scottish and Newcastle Breweries P.L.C. The move came after the Australian-based Elders had bought an additional 10 percent of the stock following a Government decision to investigate its hostile bid for Britain's fifth-largest brewer.

title: U.S. Judge to Hear Interco Argument
description: A Federal judge agreed to hear Interco Inc.'s argument that the Cardinal Acquisition Corporation violated securities laws in its hostile $2.7 billion bid for the furniture and apparel company. On Wednesday, United States District Judge William Hungate lifted a stay on Interco's action but did not set a hearing date. Interco said it would file a motion by Monday for a preliminary injunction against Cardinal's $74-a-share tender offer.

title: Foodmaker Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 2
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $10,549,000 from the restructuring of debt. The latest periods' included results for Chi-Chi's dinner houses from their acquisition in April.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16 Responding to a speech on the Nazis, dozens walked out in protest. The speech was given by the speaker of the West German Parliamentat a special session to mark Kristallnacht. Page A1

title: Equitec Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $1.5 million from discontinued operations and a gain of $188,000 from an accounting change. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,349,000 for the quarter and $4,135,000 for the 9 months.

title: Israelis Plead for Unity Government That Excludes the Religious Parties
description: A growing number of Israelis are calling for another ''national unity'' government of the Likud and Labor parties that would exclude the religious parties.

title: Hungary to Offer Multi-Party System, in Principle
description: The Government announced today that it would introduce a draft bill in Parliament next month that would establish the principle that Hungary might legalize political parties in addition to the Communist Party.

title: Warren Casey, Composer, 53
description: Warren Casey, co-author of the musical ''Grease,'' died of AIDS Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital here. He was 53 years old.

title: American Indemnity Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary gain of $1,800,000 from termination of a retirement plan.

title: 5 Striking Workers Are Killed by Troops At Brazil Steel Mill
description: Thousands of strikers occupying Brazil's biggest steel mill hurled rocks and firebombs at policemen and soldiers Wednesday night. Troops responded with tear gas, clubs and gunfire, and five workers were killed, plant officials said today.

title: LONDON'S SUBWAY CRITICIZED ON FIRE
description: An official report on the subway fire that killed 31 people last year in the King's Cross station today blamed inadequate fire safety precautions for the scale of the disaster, and the two top officials of the system resigned.

title: GWC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lily von Klemperer, Guidance Counselor, 77
description: Lily von Klemperer, who was the director of the counseling division of the Institute of International Education for 20 years, died of cancer Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GAF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $2,418,000 for the quarter and $9,370,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $11,787,000 and $135,620,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter included $15.1 million in expenses connected with the proposed management-led buyout of the company and a $1.8 million net loss in connection with GAF's investment portfolio.

title: Producer Prices Flat In October
description: Prices at the producer level were unchanged in October, the first month without an increase since February.

title: American Irish Group Honors Suzanne Farrell
description: Suzanne Farrell, the former prima ballerina of the New York City Ballet, whom Balanchine once called ''the greatest dancer I ever saw,'' received the Gold Medal of the American Irish Historical Society last night for her ''extraordinary contributions to our national culture.''

title: On Stage
description: 2 for Broadway, One Producer

title: British Petroleum Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR). The net income represents replacement cost; replacement cost profit is calculated after tax and interest expense, but it excludes inventory gains and losses. Results are in U.S. dollars; the exchange rate prevailing at the close of Sept. 30, 1988 was one pound sterling equals $1.69 and for 1987, a pound sterling equaled $1.63.

title: A Victory for the Creative Process
description: While there is nothing unusual about lawsuits charging songwriters with stealing melodies, lawyers believe a case decided in Federal District Court here this week may be the first one litigated in which a composer was accused of plagiarizing himself.

title: Sports People; 4 Gain N.Y.U. Fame
description: Four former athletes at New York University were inducted into the school's Sports Hall of Fame last night during the annual awards dinner of the N.Y.U. Varsity Club. The inductees were Ben Auerbach, Class of 1941, basketball captain; the late Irwin (King Kong) Klein, '36, the football end and member of the undefeated 1933-34 basketball team; James F. Signorile, '70, whose 1,235 points made him the sixth-highest school scorer, and Sanford D. Silverstein, '48, a pitcher on the undefeatd 1946 baseball team. Jay Horwitz, the public-relations director for the Mets, received the club's Award of Merit, and Michael Lofton, a member of the United States fencing team in the 1984 and 1988 Olympics, received the Sid Tanenbaum Memorial Award.

title: Moore Corp Ltd reports earnings for
description: All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Chase Move Lifts Spirits in Downtown Brooklyn
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announcement that it would shift 5,000 employees to downtown Brooklyn moves the Metrotech office and academic complex beyond the halfway mark in lease commitments and is another indication that the rebirth of the area as the city's third largest business and commercial district is firmly under way.

title: Judge Rejects Boston Airport Fees
description: A Federal administrative law judge ruled today that stiff landing fees aimed at keeping smaller aircraft out of Boston's Logan International Airport violated Federal aviation law because they were discriminatory and unfair.

title: Chrysler Shifts Top Management
description: The Chrysler Corporation shuffled its top management yesterday in what appears to be a tightening and clarification of executive duties. The change will also consolidate Gerald Greenwald's position as the likely successor to Lee A. Iacocca as Chrysler's chief executive.

title: Court Decides Christian Scientist Can Be Tried in Her Child's Death
description: The California Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a member of the Christian Science church could be prosecuted in the death of her child because she provided only spiritual healing and not conventional medical care.

title: Bookworms Devour Library's Lions
description: At the New York Public Library, every year at this time, they throw the lions to the people. They select two dozen or so writers as Literary Lions and then ceremoniously toss them to an equal number of voracious readers who pay $15,000 a table so they and their guests can have a lion for dinner. It's always a lovely orgy.

title: 2 Makers Of Chips See Losses
description: Two leading semiconductor companies said they expected losses for the current quarter, a sign that a recently begun industry slowdown might be worsening.

title: A Mandate to Make Sense
description: Now that George Bush has won the Presidency, the battle turns to the electorate's message. The stakes transcend words, for whoever defines the voters' mandate will shape the political terrain and gain power.

title: Chase Deal Reflects Era Of Subsidies
description: The agreement to give the Chase Manhattan Corporation a huge package of incentives to move 5,000 workers to Brooklyn underscores the fact that New York is in an era of economic vulnerability in which large, complex and individually negotiated deals are needed to retain and attract business, experts said yesterday.

title: Dining Out Guide: Thanksgiving Day
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. American Harvest

title: Sterling Chemicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $9,000,000 from the early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $8,300,000 million from an accounting change. c-Includes a charge of $1,900,000 and $4,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the early extinguishment of debt. Share earnings reflect a 75-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend paid on Sept. 15, 1988.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Paying the Price for Scalping
description: If they hold the Breeders' Cup at Churchill Downs again, and you have a couple of extra reserved seats, do not under any circumstances try selling them outside the front gates at higher than face value.

title: Currency Traders Seek Sign of Dollar Policy
description: Foreign-exchange traders are looking anxiously for some signal from the incoming Bush Administration on its policy for the dollar, they said yesterday. Without a signal, they expect the dollar's decline to continue.

title: Finally, Acknowledging the Mandate
description: LEAD: It's official. Ronald Reagan had a mandate for his revolution after all. In the closing weeks of the 1988 campaign, the media finally confirmed the results of the 1980 and 1984 elections.

title: Ranger Rookie Carving Niche on Ice
description: The exhaustion, which had somehow been warded off for months, descended with a numbing completeness as soon as the season officially ended last April. Brian Leetch, who had just suffered the second major disappointment of his 20th spring, packed away both the memories and his equipment and straggled off into the warm night outside Madison Square Garden.

title: Review/Theater; Roads Not Taken for a Family and a Generation
description: ''Why can't things be different?'' pleads Martin (Christopher Collet), the troubled 16-year-old caught in the crossfire of Michael Weller's ''Spoils of War.'' Martin is asking the question of his parents, whose divorce a decade earlier he still refuses to accept and whose reconciliation he still hopes to accomplish. The question is rhetorical, of course; things can't be different for Martin's parents now or ever. But what child of divorce ever stops asking? In Mr. Weller's climactic scene, it is harrowing to watch the cold truth at last sink in: Martin, his eyes glazed and his thin body taut with panic, stands frozen midway between his warring mother and father, paralyzed by the recognition that his lifelong pipe dream is never to be.

title: For Beijing and Moscow, a Glacial Warming
description: It has been a busy week for two countries that have supposedly still not normalized relations.

title: China Journal; There Is Rice in the Gravy and the Gravy Is Rich
description: A trophy case hangs in a squat, nondescript brick building here, filled with the treasures of those who work within: a can of Campbell's Chicken Soup with Rice, its label peeling slightly; a package of Bird's Eye Hawaiian Style Stir-Fry Vegetables with Rice, yellowing a bit; a dusty bottle of Japanese rice wine, an empty box of Uncle Ben's Country Inn Rice.

title: Businessland Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition in July 1988 of Computercraft Inc. on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Rev. David Bauer, 64, A Leader in Hockey
description: The Rev. David Bauer, the Roman Catholic priest who founded Canada's national hockey team, died of cancer Wednesday. He was 64 years old.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Donald Curry will defend his World Boxing Council super-welterweight title against Rene Jacquot of France in February in France. Curry, who won the 154-pound title on July 8 from Gianfranco Rosi, is scheduled to face the No. 1 contender, John Mugabi, next spring. . . . Doug Smith, the nose tackle for the Houston Oilers who was suspended 30 days for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse policy, will be treated at an inpatient facility, General Manager Ladd Herzeg said yesterday. He will miss at least four games. . . . The Continental Basketball Association rejected Lewis Lloyd's request to participate in a drug-rehabilitation program that would allow him to continue to play. Commissioner Jay Ramsdell said the C.B.A. would allow Lloyd to compete when he can prove he has control of the problem. Lloyd, a former Houston Rockets player, was banned from the National Basketball Association last Jan. 14 after failing drug tests.(AP)

title: Moscow Will Not Rule Out An Early Meeting With Bush
description: The Soviet Union said today that it would not rule out an early meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President-elect Bush even before Mr. Bush takes office on Jan. 20.

title: Corporate Software reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
14 Detained in Prague Raids
description: At least 14 dissidents were detained today in Czechoslovakia after the police raided their homes, a dissident in Prague said.

title: Fannie Mae Issues Total $500 Million
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, is offering $500 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities in eight classes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Copter Crashes in North Sea
description: A helicopter carrying oil rig workers crashed into the North Sea off Scotland today and all 13 people aboard were rescued, a Royal Air Force spokesman said. The Sikorsky S-61 helicopter fell just before 9:00 A.M. about 70 miles northeast of Fraserburgh in northeast Scotland and three miles from the Claymore oil platform, said a spokesman.

title: Howard's Seat in House Goes to Jersey Protege
description: When Representative James J. Howard suffered a fatal heart attack last March, his family knew who they wanted to succeed the dean of New Jersey's Congressional delegation.

title: RJR Nabisco's Stock Rises Amid Rumors of New Bids
description: RJR Nabisco Inc.'s share price rose yesterday as a flurry of rumors circulated about new bidders for the food and tobacco giant.

title: Mario Nasalli Rocca, Cardinal, 85
description: Mario Cardinal Nasalli Rocca di Corneliano, a close aide to four Popes, died Wednesday, the Vatican announced today. He was 85 years old.

title: Hershiser 24, All Other Pitchers 0
description: He finished the regular season with 59 successive scoreless innings, shut out the Mets in the seventh game of the playoff, pitched a shutout and also won the final game against Oakland in the World Series and yesterday Orel Hershiser became the unanimous winner of the National League Cy Young award.

title: Review/Art; Ingres at His Best: Small
description: It is a dream of most good dealers that one day they will beat out the museums with a show that satisfies optimum standards of care, thought and connoisseurship. That the art will be very good goes without saying. But there have to be surprises - exhibits that belong together but had never before been mated, affinities that we might never have thought up for ourselves, and memorabilia that make us feel as if the artist in question were standing beside us.

title: Babbage's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest 9 months' net did not cover preferred stock requirements.

title: Sports People; Highest-Paid Kicker
description: Gary Anderson of the Pittsburgh Steelers has signed a six-year contract, reportedly worth $2.4 million, that will make him the highest-paid place-kicker in the National Football League with $400,000 a year in salary and bonuses. Anderson is playing his final year under a contract that pays him $305,000 in salary plus a bonus. Morten Andersen of the New Orleans Saints is currently the league's highest-paid kicker with a contract worth $325,000.(AP)

title: Friedman Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included a gain of $721,000 from a liquidation of LIFO inventories carried at a cost lower than the current replacement cost.

title: Market Place; Intergroup's Parts May Lure Raiders
description: NATIONAL INTERGROUP'S reputation among investors could hardly be worse. To call it tarnished is to put the best face possible on a long record of disappointing results.

title: Madison Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Will Resign Jardine Matheson Post
description: Brian Powers, the first American to be named managing director of Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd., will resign and leave Hong Kong at the end of the year, the company said yesterday.

title: Byron V. Boone, Newspaper Publisher, 80
description: Byron Vest Boone, a Tulsa laywer and businessman who was publisher of The Tulsa World since 1959, died at his home Wednesday after several years of illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Jacobs Engineering Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $500,000, or 10 cents a share, relating to the settlement of certain litigation. The results for the latest fourth quarter and full year include the operations of Robert E. McKee Inc., which was acquired on Oct. 1, 1987.

title: Milan Journal; The Fall of Rome? Mark 1992 on Your Calendars
description: It did not sit well when word arrived the other week that Milan was the world's most polluted city.

title: American Travellers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TANKER SPLITS IN 2 IN ATLANTIC STORM
description: All 27 crewmen were missing today after an oil tanker broke in two and caught fire in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean in stormy weather.

title: Delaware Rivals Join To Bury the Hatchet
description: For today at least, there was no talk here of political polls, no sniping at rivals, no finger-pointing by the losing camps.

title: Ex-Detective Says Steinberg Had Scratches on Knuckles
description: When the police arrested Joel B. Steinberg in the beating death of a 6-year-old girl a year ago, they found his knuckles were swollen, bruised and scratched, a retired New York City police detective testified yesterday.

title: Fluke, John Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The prior year included a charge of $7.5 million related to restructuring costs involving the company's strategic alliance with N.V. Philips.

title: Perini Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said net income for all periods was increased by a lower- than-normal tax rate due to tax credits related to its share of a real estate joint venture.

title: May Stores Up; Macy Has Loss
description: The May Department Stores Company yesterday reported improved earnings from continuing operations in the third quarter while R. H. Macy & Company said it had a greater loss in its fourth quarter than in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Hadson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $4,598,000 from an accounting change.

title: The Cosbys' $20 Million Challenge
description: They had $20 million to give away, so Bill and Camille Cosby obviously could have afforded to send their daughter to any college in the country. Her choice of Spelman, a black women's college -and her parents' astounding gift of $20 million to Spelman - send a powerful message about racial pride and faith in education. That message resonates especially among blacks, but it is one all Americans can appreciate.

title: Australian Marsupials
description: The remarkable photography that distinguishes public broadcasting's nature shows, intruding into every animal lair and hideout, is present in abundance in ''The Nature of Australia,'' six one-hour documentaries that begin Sunday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: How to Get Back Into the TV Technology Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Films; 'Ernest Saves Christmas'
description: ''Ernest Saves Christmas'' features a credible Santa Claus, live reindeer and, much less surprising, commercials embedded in the scenery. The character of Ernest, a bumbling yokel whose vocabulary consists almost entirely of the words ''Hey, Vern!,'' was born in television commercials, in which he grins widely and intrudes obnoxiously on his neighbors' privacy. The strategy seems to be that you'll buy whatever soft drink or car or hardware Ernest is selling - anything just to get rid of him.

title: Dow Drops 3.55 Points, to 2,114.69
description: LEAD: The stock market was mixed yesterday in slow trading.

title: Home Federal Savings & Loan (San Diego) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $2.8 million from an accounting change.

title: People
description: * Edward Eskandarian has been named chairman and chief executive of a newly formed division of WCRS/ Worldwide, Boston, called Diversified Communications Group/North America.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE ODYSSEY,'' a play based on Homer's epic, presented by the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, and directed by Amie Brockway, 2 P.M. Sundays, through November, at the Open Eye Theater, Henry Lindenbaum Center, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: $6 and $8. Information: 769-4143. LISA LIPKIN STORY HOUR, a program of a collection of New York legends, 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street. Admission: children, free; students and the elderly, $1; others, $2. Reservations required: 838-6878. A STORY HOUR IN FRENCH, a program for ages 3 to 5, with a selection of picture books, classic and modern, 4 P.M. today, at the French Institute-Alliance Francaise Library, 22 East 60th Street. Preregisration required: 355-6100, extension 215. Admission: $1. ''MERLIN THE MAGICIAN,'' a program of magic and comedy by Jack Adams, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $8; preferred seating, $12. Information: 427-6000. ''THE SILENT SORCERER,'' a show of pantomime and magic by Craig Collis, 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Tickets: $4. Information: (914) 698-0098.

title: Reuter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Uniforce Temporary Personel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pacts Seen at GATT Talks
description: The leader of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade expects agreements on a number of subjects of concern to the United States when trade ministers meet in Montreal early next month.

title: Data Measurement Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Damon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,915,778 for the quarter and $3,820,176 for the year, and a loss from a disposal of discontinued operations of $2,155,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,011,350 and $5,602,104 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $56,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the year. The company said the fiscal 1987 results include sales of $2.5 million and income from continuing operations of $573,000 associated with the termination of a distribution agreement and sales of $1.1 million and income from continuing operations of $560,000 relating to the settlement of litigation.

title: Plush Discos Offer Rock, Rap and Romanticism
description: IN the frenetic world of New York discotheques and nightclubs, to be hot is to be new. No matter how hip the interior, no matter how long or star-studded the line at the door, the onset of old age - and in club culture, that means a couple of years - seems to trigger a collective ennui. And gossip columnists and celebutantes, as well as the ordinary folks in their wake, wait for what's next.

title: U.S.S.R. Offers to Join Talks On Independence of Namibia
description: The Soviet Union today offered to become directly involved in talks on independence for South African-ruled Namibia and the linked withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola.

title: Universal Foods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pakistani Highlanders' Defiant Note
description: ''We are the poor people, working to get something to eat,'' said Namos Khan. ''Who comes and who goes in an election does nothing for us.''

title: Economic Scene; Matters Needing Bush's Attention
description: CONSIDERING how Wall Street had rooted for George Bush's election, its reaction to his victory was hardly celebratory. Stocks fell, bonds fell and the dollar dropped. It makes one think of the woman in the New Yorker cartoon discussing a friend's failing marriage: ''She got what she wanted, but it wasn't what she expected.''

title: At the Bar
description: Few people who knew Carolyn Paris at Stanford Law School would have pegged her as a future partner in a major Wall Street law firm. It was a matter not of her intellect, which was obvious, but of her sensibilities. For her, as for many others, the transition from studying liberal arts to law was painful enough; the further step into mainstream law practice was almost inconceivable.

title: Too Soon to Gauge Economic Vigor, Experts Say
description: Despite recent unease in the currency and money markets, economists and regional Federal Reserve Bank presidents believe it is too soon to conclude that the economy is overheating, a condition that traders had feared would lead to an imminent round of Fed tightening.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Co. announced that John M. Heidt had joined its Los Angeles office as managing director in the corporate finance department.

title: Accounts
description: * Stanley H. Kaplan, scholastic test preparation centers, to Kirshenbaum & Bond, with a $1.5 million budget.

title: Hirohito's Condition Stable
description: Palace officials said Emperor Hirohito, bedridden since Sept. 19, was running a slight fever late today but otherwise was in stable condition following a major setback in his health earlier this week.

title: Chandler Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reviews/Film; Meryl Streep in 'A Cry in the Dark'
description: Fred Schepisi's ''Cry in the Dark'' is based on the sort of true story beloved by supermarket tabloids that feature headlines about mothers who boil their babies for breakfast.

title: Becton Dickinson & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,980,000 for the quarter and $13,087,000 for the year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,496,000 and $11,218,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax benefits of $1,159,000 for the quarter and $6,345,000 for the year. Year-ago fourth quarter and year figures are restated to reflect the classification of the Edmont division as a discontinued operation. The prior year includes restructuring costs, which reduced net by $3.6 million, or 9 cents a share; the prior year also includes a net gain of $16.1 million, or 38 cents a share, from the sale of the Endevco division.

title: Detrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $457,704.

title: Reagan Administration Renews Assault on 1973 Abortion Ruling
description: In a brief filed today with the Supreme Court, the Reagan Administration urged the Justices to hear an appeal in a Missouri abortion case that it said ''presents an appropriate opportunity'' for overruling Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that legalized abortion.

title: London Restores Ties to Iran But Denies a Hostage Deal
description: As expected, Britain resumed diplomatic relations with Iran today but said there had been no deal to help secure the release of British hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian radicals.

title: Sea Containers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
After the Elections; Democrats Begin Quadrennial Debate: How to Win the White House Race
description: From the rubble of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's campaign for the Presidency, Democrats have begun a fierce debate over whether they need an entirely different approach to Presidential politics or just a better-run campaign to win the White House next time.

title: Cetus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rocket-Yarn Plant Reopened by Avtex
description: The sole supplier of rayon yarn used in the space shuttle and military rockets reopened its plant as abruptly as it closed it a week ago. In a statement Wednesday, John N. Gregg, chairman and chief executive of Avtex Fibers Inc., said the company was ''able to negotiate a long-term contract with certain aerospace industry companies that will allow Avtex Fibers-Front Royal to return to full production of its fiber products.''

title: Public Service Co of New Mexico reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Jamaica Chief Said to Narrow Gap in Vote Drive
description: It is late on a Friday evening, and Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga is still at work in his small office in the white-washed mansion called Jamaica House.

title: Charter on Children's Rights Gains in U.N.
description: The General Assembly opened a debate on child abuse today that is expected to result in the adoption next year of an international convention protecting the human rights of children.

title: Prosecution Witness Says Myerson Hinted at Job Offer for Him
description: A prosecution witness testified outside the jury's presence yesterday that Bess Myerson had raised the possibility that her companion would offer him a public relations job.

title: 22 Die in India Refinery Blast
description: An explosion and fire at an oil refinery killed 22 people, and the blaze burned through the night and into today, officials said. A company spokesman said sabotage was not ruled out. Doctors said nine people remained in hospitals in critical condition with burns. Firefighters battled the blaze at the state-owned Bharat Petroleum Corporation refinery in Chembur, a suburb northeast of Bombay, throughout the night. The fire was extinguished today after burning for 27 hours.

title: Wasington Talk: Armed Forces; Navy Setting Course For the 21st Century
description: For eight years, the Navy has been steaming toward the goal of a 600-ship fleet that was set when John F. Lehman was Navy Secretary. But even before it reaches that objective, the service has started looking 50 years ahead, when ships now on the drawing boards will be obsolete.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY RADIO CITY CHRISTMAS

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about a United Nations General Assembly resolution condemning Israeli actions in the occupied territories misidentified a country that voted for the resolution but complained that it was unbalanced. It was Paraguay, not Peru.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; And Now, Iran-Contra
description: The Congressional Iran-contra committees have been out of business for nearly a year, but one staff member, Isabel K. McGinty, an assistant counsel on the Senate committee has been hard at work since then compiling a 4,600-page chronology of the affair, piecing together the story from the perspective of most of the key witnesses and documents.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CSX Corp., Richmond, a transportation and holding company, said it would lay off 200 workers at its locomotive shops.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY European and Japanese finance officials want President-elect Bush to take strong, quick action on the budget deficit. Some of these officials, whose cooperation has been crucial in keeping the dollar stable, said they would like to see the deficit shrink by $35 billion, to $120 billion, in 1989. [ Page D1. ] The dollar drifted lower after comments by an official of Germany's central bank. Traders said the decline would continue unless the President-elect gives a signal on his dollar policy. [ D15. ] Texas was awarded the Federal atom smasher project. At $4.4 billion, the superconducting super collider may be the largest and most costly scientific instrument in the world. [ A1. ] California's highest court delayed insurance rate cuts approved by voters on Tuesday. Justices said they will consider the constitutionality of the sweeping measure. [ A1. ] The U.S. lifted a 45-year ban on the manufacture of clothing and jewelry in the home. Unions vowed to fight the change. [ A1. ] A power vacuum in the Congressional banking committees could delay efforts to rescue the savings and loan industry. Neither the House nor the Senate chairmen will be returning. [ D1. ] Producer prices were unchanged in October, but the Labor Department report did little to allay fears of higher inflation. [ D1. ] Economists and Fed officials caution against reading too much into lower unemployment figures. [ D15. ] COMPANIES Chrysler shuffled its top management. The move follows embarrassing confrontations with regulators and union officials and consolidates the position of Lee A. Iacocca's likely successor. [ D1. ] RJR Nabisco's shares rose $1.25 amid rumors about new bidders. And the chairman of a House subcommittee plans hearings on the role of nonprofit organizations in leveraged buyouts. [ D5. ] The largest-ever merger of law firms was announced. Fulbright & Jaworski, the biggest firm in Texas, will join with Reavis & McGrath of New York to create the seventh-largest U.S. firm. [ B4. ] Two semiconductor makers expect losses this quarter. National Semiconductor and Advanced Micro Devices said personal computer companies had developed excess chip inventories. [ D5. ] Time Inc.'s stock rose modestly after managers affirmed the company's earnings projections. [ D16. ] Chase Manhattan agreed to move some operations to Brooklyn because of a huge package of incentives from New York City. [ B1. ] TW Services urged its shareholders to snub Coniston's bid, calling the $29-a-share offer ''totally illusory.'' [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Poland will receive its first loan from the World Bank. [ D1. ] Britain has a new tabloid newspaper. The Post is using printing techniques based on personal computers and desktop publishing. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stocks were mixed in light trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.55 points, to 2,114.69. [ D6. ] Discount rates on Treasury bills climbed as the credit market continued to be flooded with short-term Government debt. Prices of Treasury notes and bond closed slightly higher. [ D12. ] The price of copper futures plunged on reports that a Peruvian miners' strike may be ending. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Wall Street has unenthusiastically embraced George Bush, the candidate it favored, amid realizations that he painted himself into a corner on the deficit. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] National Intergroup has a bad reputation on Wall Street, but some crafty investors are buying its stock. Market Place. [ D6. ] Ads for a stop-smoking system were rejected by several national magazines. The product's developer contends that the magazines feared retribution by tobacco companies. Advertising. [ D17. ]

title: Ross Roy Deal
description: The Ross Roy Group of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire Group 243 Inc., an agency with $60 million in billings and offices in Ann Arbor, Mich., and Atlanta. The price was not disclosed. Group 243, whose best-known client is the Ann Arbor-based Domino's Pizza, will retain its name and operate within the Ross Roy Group, where it joins Calet, Hirsch & Spector; Dilorio, Wergeles; Griswold Inc., and a half-dozen other shops.

title: Planes Collide; Pilot Is Killed
description: Two Marine Corps jet fighters collided today over a training range, and one pilot was killed, a Marine spokesman said. The spokesman, Staff Sgt. Mark A. Walker, said the pilot who was killed was in an FA-18 Hornet that crashed in the Chocolate Mountains training area.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS GET A TRIP TO U.S.
description: Seven Soviet citizens long active in various campaigns for human rights, including three jailed for their activities, have been given official permission to travel to the United States.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; For the Defense
description: It is one of Washington's ways that Government scandals tend to foster cottage industries, and the Defense Department's contractor frauds that came partly to light last summer provide an example: The Defense Litigation Reporter.

title: Diner's Journal
description: East Side Italian

title: Fitchburg Gas & Electric Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
