description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $506,887 from the redemption of notes for the both periods. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter.

title: GAP Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
KEY RATES
U.S. AND MOSCOW HOLD SPACE TALKS
description: In moves to expand space cooperation, the Soviet Union has offered to carry American scientific instruments on its future flights to Mars and the United States has agreed to help select a landing site on the planet for an unmanned Soviet craft to be launched in 1994.

title: Review/Films; A Would-Be Fighter With a Lot of Distractions
description: Paul Morrissey's ''Spike of Bensonhurst'' would be a comedy of manners if anyone in the film had any. But they don't, which is very much the point. This film, set among Mafia operatives and petty crooks in the Italian neighborhood of Bensonhurst, in Brooklyn, is a humorous look at the way traditional values have deteriorated even here. Spike Fumo (Sasha Mitchell), a would-be prizefighter, is a man in the middle, with an accent and demeanor suited to old-fashioned pursuits like numbers-running, but with the looks of a petulantly perfect male model.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Time Inc. Stock Rises On Earnings Assurance
description: LEAD: Time Inc.'s stock rose modestly yesterday after top management told analysts that Wall Street's projections of the company's 1989 earnings were reasonable.

title: CRS Sirrine Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $6,924,000, or $1.11 a share, resulting from the termination of the company's defined benefit retirement plan.

title: May Department Stores Co reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $29,000,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations for both periods; the 9 months also include net from discontinued operations of $2,000,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,000,000 and $4,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Black Veterans: Justice Overdue
description: LEAD: Because a measure of recognition is now being given to the forgotten deeds of our ''invisible soldiers'' - black fighting men - this Veterans Day will be a little different from others.

title: INSIDE
description: Harsh Words for North A judge denied a motion to dismiss charges against Oliver North, saying he had a ''skewed attitude'' on constitutional government. Page A18. Largest Law Firm Merger The biggest Texas law firm and a New York partnership announced a merger that will create the nation's seventh-largest firm. Page B4. Cloud Over Africa: Locusts From the Atlantic to the Red Sea, the worst plague in 30 years is gnawing through farm lands. Page A3. World Bank Loan for Poland The World Bank voted a $17.9 million loan, a tentative sign of approval for Poland's economic reforms. Page D1. Ravitch to Step Down Saying he might run for mayor, Richard Ravitch told Mayor Koch that he would not remain as chairman of the city's charter commission. Page B1.

title: Bakker and Ex-Aide Are Ordered To Pay $7.7 Million to PTL
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge ordered today that Jim and Tammy Bakker, along with a former top aide, must repay $7.7 million to PTL for reaping undeserved profits and mismanaging the television ministry.

title: TEXANS JUBILANT ON ATOM PROJECT
description: The Energy Department's choice of a site 25 miles south of Dallas for the nation's newest Federal research laboratory could lift North Texas into the big leagues of international science in the next century.

title: Nets Are Off and Eager to Test Their Road Skills
description: People knew what to expect from the Nets whenever they played on the road last season. They didn't expect much.

title: Edwin Scalabrino, 61, Ex-Hotel Manager
description: Edwin Scalabrino, who managed several Manhattan hotels before retiring as general manager of the Milford Plaza earlier this year, died Tuesday after coronary bypass surgery at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Southampton, L.I.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Browns and Broncos Renew 'Rivalry'
description: When the Cleveland Browns visit the Broncos in Denver's Mile High Stadium on Sunday, two memories will predominate: the Drive and the Fumble.

title: U.S. Is Moving to Restrict Access To Facts About Computer Virus
description: Government officials are moving to bar wider dissemination of information on techniques used in a rogue software program that jammed more than 6,000 computers in a nationwide computer network last week.

title: Consolation Prize: Dukakis Will Have Plenty to Keep Him Busy
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis made a point of going to his Statehouse office on Beacon Hill the very morning after he lost the race for President.

title: Charges Settled by Drexel
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and two commodities firms have agreed to pay almost $500,000 to settle charges of illegal trading in gold and silver futures, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today.

title: 20th Century Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $128,375 and $5,264,762 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $469,340 and $582,702 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Third of B-1's Cleared as Safe
description: The Air Force returned nearly one-third of its B-1 bomber fleet to flight status today after conducting safety inspections following a crash.

title: Reviews/Film; An Experimental Oshima
description: Aficionados of the Japanese cinema will not want to miss ''Violence at Noon,'' Nagisa Oshima's grandly idiosyncratic 1966 film that has its New York theatrical premiere today as part of the Public Theater's retrospective devoted to Japan's Shochiku Studios. Other moviegoers may need extensive program notes.

title: Our Towns; A Rain Delay Of Hockey? Yes, For Cable Users
description: Wednesday night, it was the same story at Gregg Tanner's house. At 7:30, he flipped his Cablevision tuner to Channel 30. ''I was hoping by the grace of God the Rangers and Flyers might be on,'' he said. But no, the Lord and Cablevision work in mysterious ways. All fall, Cablevision has replaced the Rangers with a weather channel. The temperature was 56, the barometer was 30.02 and rising, there was a cold front due in and Mr. Tanner felt ill.

title: ITALY INVESTIGATES '80 AIRLINER CRASH
description: The Italian Government today opened a new investigation into the mysterious crash of a civilian airliner eight years ago. But the Defense Minister rejected allegations that the plane might have been shot down by a NATO missile, possibly fired from an Italian plane.

title: Review/Art; Whitney Retrospective Of a Bay Area Legend
description: Many supporters of David Park have been awaiting his retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art with a mixture of eagerness and dread. Eagerness because Park, who died of cancer in 1960 at the age of 49, was a wonderful painter whose silent, grave, gestural work seems to have become fuller with time. Dread because there is almost nothing in the recent history of the Whitney to suggest that it has the ability to deal effectively with a postwar artist to whom hot issues, hot galleries and cult of personality are irrelevant.

title: Markets Await Bush Signal
description: Foreign officials warned that the markets would suffer unless Presi-dent-elect Bush signals he will move quickly to cut the budget deficit. Anxi-ety is being felt mos strongly in the currency markets. Page D1.

title: More Clashes in Seoul
description: Violent clashes erupted sporadically in downtown Seoul today when riot policemen broke up attempts by radical youths to stage rallies against former President Chun Doo Hwan. There was no immediate word on injuries or arrests.

title: GTE Sets Job Cuts
description: The GTE Corporation said it expected to eliminate about 14,000 jobs in its domestic telephone operations in the next five years. In addition to the 7,000 jobs it already said it would cut as a result of streamlining, GTE said 7,000 other positions would be lost because of other, unrelated factors. GTE executives discussed the planned cutbacks during a meeting with analysts. GTE said virtually all the cuts would come from the 28,000 employees in staff and headquarters management positions.

title: Strikers at Gdansk Shipyard Can Stay On, Managers Rule
description: Shipyard workers who staged a one-day strike in Gdansk can keep their jobs for now, the yard's management announced today. State-run information media reported earlier that the strikers had been dismissed.

title: DSC Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $109,000 loss from the buyback of senior debentures for the quarter, and a $3,676,000 gain from purchase of convertible debentures.

title: After the Elections; G.O.P. Makes Few Legislature Gains
description: Vice President Bush's electoral sweep on Tuesday had little effect on state legislative races, where the Democrats blunted a five-year-old Republican drive to end Democratic dominance in the legislatures.

title: Environmental Treatment & Technologies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clarke Hinkle, 79, Former Football Star
description: Clarke Hinkle, one of the all-time stars of the Green Bay Packers, died Wednesday in his hometown of Toronto, Ohio. He was 79 years old.

title: Review/Music; Opera by Marionettes
description: Samuel Beckett, it is said, wants to write a play that does away with actors altogether. Watching the Salzburg Marionette Theater perform Rossini's ''Barber of Seville'' at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night gave one an inkling of art divorced from the performing artist.

title: International Aluminum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Antismoking Product's Ad Stirs Debate
description: A PLAN by a California company to begin national magazine advertising for its stop-smoking system has been stymied by the refusal of Time, Newsweek, Sports Illustrated, Life and US magazines to take its ad, an executive of the company says.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Lendl and Connors Upset: Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors were upset by unheralded West Germans, and John McEnroe beat Tim Mayotte, 6-3, 6-2, in the Stuttgart Classic invitation tournament yesterday in West Germany. Carl-Uwe Steeb edged Lendl, 7-6, 7-5, and Eric Jelen rallied to defeat Connors, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Mansdorf Advances: Amos Mansdorf of Israel overcame six double faults and gained the quarterfinals of the Benson and Hedges international men's indoor championships in Wembley, England. Mansdorf beat Jeremy Bates of Britain, 7-5, 6-2. In another second-round match, John Fitzgerald of Australia, seeded eighth, rallied to beat Christian Saceanu of West Germany, 5-7, 6-1, 6-3. (AP) Golf Stroke Lead for Ten Broeck: Lance Ten Broeck, seeking his first victory on the PGA Tour, shot an opening-round 65 yesterday to take a one-shot lead over Bernhard Langer and Beau Baugh in the $500,000 Centel Classic. Ten Broeck birdied the 17th hole to pull ahead of the field of 137 golfers and finished with seven birdies and no bogeys on the par-72, 7,098-yard Killearn Country Club course in Tallahassee. (AP) Boxing Blake Stops Santiago: Roddy Blake, the older brother of the former lightweight contender, Robin Blake, scored an upset when he knocked out Felix (Superstar) Santiago of Brooklyn at 2 minutes 15 seconds of the sixth round last night in a bout between welterweights at the Felt Forum. The 27-year-old- Blake, who is from Forth Worth, had fought only seven times since turning pro in 1985. Blake is 7-1 with 7 knockouts. Santiago is 21-2-1 with 16 knockouts. N.H.L. Capitals 4, Nordiques 1: Dale Hunter scored a goal and assisted on two others and Washington held Quebec to five shots on goal in the opening 31 minutes last night as the Capitals won. Washington wound up outshooting Quebec, 43-19, and won for the fourth time in seven home games this season. (AP)

title: Piper Jaffray Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eastern Gas & Fuel Assocites reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mitchell Prizes Awarded To Books on Art Subjects
description: The 12th annual Mitchell Prizes were awarded yesterday to the authors of books written in English that have made contributions to the study and understanding of the fine arts.

title: Golf; Strange Posts 64 For a 3-Shot Lead
description: Curtis Strange is the United States Open champion this year and he shot a record 62 at the St. Andrews Old Course in Scotland last year. But he could not remember a better round than the near-record eight-under-par 64 he produced today on the magnificent Pebble Beach Golf Links.

title: Trans-Lux Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $152,000 related to repurchase of stock and costs related to settlement of a derivative class action amounting to $124,000. c-Net loss and includes a pretax loss of $2,050,000 from the writedown of assets. d-Includes gain on sales of marketable securities amounting to $366,000. Share earnings have been restated to reflect the effect of the 5 percent stock dividend declared in April.

title: 'Butterfly' at the Beacon
description: A fully staged production of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' will mark the New York debut of the Western Opera Theater on Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. The performance, which will be in English, is sponsored by the West Side Cultural Center, an organization dedicated to preserving the Beacon Theater as a performance space. The Western Opera Theater is the touring company of the San Francisco Opera Center. Tickets are $25.50 and $15. Information: 496-7070.

title: Richman Band
description: Jonathan Richman is to lead his band tomorrow at 11 P.M. at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at East 15th Street (279-1984). Ticketsare $14.50.

title: Energy Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Air Force Lifts Curtain, a Bit, on Secret Plane
description: The Air Force confirmed today that it has been flying dozens of top-secret jet aircraft from a base in Nevada for the last seven years and released a photograph of what has come to be called the ''Stealth fighter.''

title: Sports People; Williams Honored
description: ''I hope I'm deserving of all this,'' Ted Williams said solemnly before being honored at the Wang Center in Boston last night by about 4,000 fans and fellow Hall of Famers. The affair for the benefit of the Jimmy Fund, the fund-raising arm of the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, was billed as ''An Evening With Ted Williams - No. 9 - and Friends.'' Ticket prices ranged from $35 to $200. Williams, 70 years old, is still sociated with the Red Sox as an ''instructor.''(AP)

title: Sports People; Inquiry Planned
description: Acting after recent claims by Tommy Chaikin, the former South Carolina defensive lineman, in a Sports Illustrated article that he used steroids between 1983 and 1987 -with about 50 percent of his teammates - a joint Federal and state investigation was announced yesterday in Columbia, S.C. It followed a preliminary inquiry by the State Law Enforcement Division into Chaikin's account of drug use. ''We asked the United States Government to join with us because it is more than just a Fifth Circuit problem,'' said Solicitor James Anders at the state division headquarters. ''It's a problem that exists throughout the country.'' Anders declined to comment on what information the agency had uncovered. The university said in a statement yesterday that ''it was pleased that the present athletic program has been given a clean bill of health by the Solicitor.''(AP)

title: Justice Is Stretched to Allow Wider Self-Defense
description: The courtroom definition of self-defense is being reinterpreted so that it is a viable defense for new categories of cases.

title: Shell Net Up; B.P. Off 10.6%
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the world's largest oil company, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 17.9 percent, while the British Petroleum Company reported a 10.6 percent drop.

title: Plan to Build Reactors Draws Protests in Idaho
description: More than a hundred Idaho residents today protested a plan to build new nuclear reactors to make fuel for atomic weapons in the desert east of here, saying they feared the reactors would damage the environment and threaten public health.

title: DST Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chief Resigns At Scherer
description: Peter R. Fink resigned today as president and chief executive of the R. P. Scherer Corporation, three months after losing a proxy battle to a group of dissident shareholders led by his estranged wife.

title: Coast Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Cash America Investments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Auctions
description: No time capsules will be available tonight to help auctiongoers attending the continuing marathon of art sales at Christie's and Sotheby's travel back to a period before Jasper Johns was painting flags and Jackson Pollock was dripping paint on canvases. At 7 this evening, as the gaveling begins at Sotheby's, gears are expected to shift automatically in bidders' minds, to Impressionist, Expressionist and modern works - the fare that will fill the stages of Sotheby's and Christie's through Tuesday.

title: Viatech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $305,000 extraordinary credit.

title: Chipher Data Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes about $2 million in pretax income related to amounts owned and paid the company by Rexon Inc. under patent litigation settled last June.

title: After the Elections; Bush Prepares to Share The Fruits of a Victory
description: President-elect Bush and his transition team began to focus today on the selection of 4,000 to 5,000 full-time political appointees who will shape the policies of his Administration.

title: Addenda
description: * A partnership of Egner Communications and Capital Cities/ABC has acquired Practical Homeowner from Rodale Press, Emmaus, Pa.

title: Cem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alan Greditor, 38, Equity Trader at Drexel
description: Alan S. Greditor, director of United States equity trading for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., died in an automobile accident yesterday in Tenafly, N.J., where he lived. He was 38 years old.

title: Spend Prison Barge Funds on Probation System
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Get Back Into the TV Technology Race; Opportunities Abound
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The U.S. is living on credit and its indebtedness totals over one trillion dollars. No country in the world can stand this.'' - Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy of France. [ D1:6. ]

title: Savings Unit's Ex-Head Cited
description: The former chairman of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, Woody F. Lemons, was indicted today by the Dallas Fraud Task Force on 13 counts of bank fraud, misapplication of funds, conspiracy and illegally sharing in the proceeds of a bank transaction made in April 1986. Vernon, which had offices in

title: Largest Legal Merger Forms 7th-Biggest Firm
description: Continuing the consolidations that have reshaped the legal industry, the biggest Texas firm and a 100-lawyer New York partnership announced the largest merger in law firm history yesterday.

title: Baldwin Piano & Organ Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Foote, Cone & Belding Comunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Spacey Sounds

title: Unwanted John Now a Free Agent
description: In a move indicative of the control George Steinbrenner has given his new manager, Dallas Green, Tommy John became a free agent yesterday after having led the Yankees in starts the past two seasons.

title: Hawaiian Electric Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company did not provide actual dollar amounts for the net income in both 9-month periods.

title: Lee Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $11,160,000, or 43 cents a share, from the sale of property.

title: Tennis; Graf to Open Against Kohde-Kilsch
description: Steffi Graf, owner of a Grand Slam title and an Olympic gold medal, was mistress of ceremonies yesterday at the unveiling of the draw for the $1,000,000 Virginia Slims Championships next week, the year's final event on the women's tennis circuit.

title: Reagan Asks the Cabinet to Resign To Give Bush Flexibility in Choice
description: President Reagan requested the resignations of all the members of his Cabinet and of all top political appointees today, in a move that will allow President-elect Bush the flexibility to decide which officials to retain.

title: Holiday Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be open today, but Government offices and many banks will be closed in observance of Veterans Day.

title: College Football Notebook; Another Chance For a Nittany Lion
description: Football at Penn State for Lance Lonergan had been a waste, a cruel disappointment. He had never been given a chance to take charge of a game as the Nittany Lions' starting quarterback.

title: P.L.O. Is Expected to Declare an Independent State
description: On the eve of an important Palestinian meeting, various factions appear ready to declare an independent Palestinian state, several Palestinian leaders say.

title: Shielding Children From TV's Hucksters
description: Children are different, and that's why President Reagan's veto of legislation to impose restrictions on children's television shouldn't be the last word. The bill deserves to be an early item of business for the next Congress and the next President.

title: After the Elections; Bentsen Back in Capital; New Prospect of Power
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen has returned from the campaign wars with one victory out of two races and probably more power in the Democratic Party as a Senator than he would have had as Vice President.

title: Elbit Computers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dollar View Disavowed
description: President-elect Bush's advisers today disavowed comments about the dollar that were made Wednesday by Martin S. Feldstein, a top economic adviser to the Bush campaign.

title: In India, a Novel Can Inflame Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; U.S.I.A. On Again
description: The United States Information Agency had to cease broadcasting its daily Worldnet television news and information programs when Congress cut off financing last month, but on Wednesday it resumed daily transmissions with a substitute, the 24-hour programming of the Cable-Satellite Public Affairs Network. C-Span, a private nonprofit cooperative, already reaches 41 million households in this country.

title: A Second Life! (in British Tabloids)
description: The story of Eddie Shah reads like a bittersweet tale plucked from a London tabloid: a daring entrepreneur helps revolutionize the British newspaper industry by creating a new newspaper, only to come up empty-handed himself when the newspaper fails to meet expectations. But the 44-year-old Mr. Shah, a self-made millionaire, is not a man who accepts defeat easily, and he is out to engineer a happy ending to the story.

title: Harman International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports of The Times; Brown Skips Town, Again
description: MINUTES earlier, the University of Kansas basketball team had lost to Duke, 71-67, in the semifinals of the 1986 N.C.A.A. championship. But now, in a gloomy gray hallway of the Reunion Arena in Dallas, the Jayhawks' coach, Larry Brown, was already looking ahead to the next season.

title: Carson Says He'll Retire
description: Harry Carson, the Giants' linebacker who has been openly irritated by speculation that he might retire after this season, has reportedly said he will retire after this season.

title: Bridge
description: A group of 59 American bridge players, led by Kathie Wei of Houston and Tom Sanders of Nashville, visited Peking in June to compete in a Chinese tournament. A few of the visitors came without partners and received Chinese ones, an accommodation that proved surprisingly successful: Dorothy Rittenhouse of Manhattan won the Open Pairs title with one Peking partner, and Angela Kaiser of White Plains was third in the same event with another.

title: Bush At the Outset
description: ''The American people are wonderful,'' President-elect Bush said in his Houston news conference, ''when it comes to understanding when a campaign ends and the work of business begins.''

title: Mercantile Stores Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AC&R Lands Foster's
description: AC&R Advertising has been named the lead agency for Foster's Lager Beer in North America. For the last three years, the agency did media placement in the United States of the creative work developed by George Patterson Proprietary Ltd., the Australian subsidiary of Backer Spielvogel Bates. Foster's television ads helped to make the Australian actor Paul Hogan an international star. Now, AC&R will do placement and creative work in the United States and Canada. The budget is reportedly $25 million.

title: After Gains, Poland Is Given Its First World Bank Loan
description: Poland has recently achieved limited successes in revamping its troubled economy, American and international economic officials say, despite the labor unrest of August and continuing tensions between the Solidarity labor movement and the Government in Warsaw.

title: Woman, 65, Is Shot to Death by 'Detective'
description: A 65-year-old woman was shot to death by a man who identified himself as a narcotics detective last night on a street in Flushing, Queens.

title: New York Stays Strong In Biomedical Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeah, Sure, Say Teammates, You Guys Are Afraid of Her
description: Sara Naison-Phillips's teammates on the 78th Precinct's bantam basketball team say she is one of its best players, with good defense and a nice jump shot. But now the league Sara plays in is considering barring her from competition because everyone she competes against is a boy.

title: Hair Testing Not Valid For Cocaine Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Grow Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $926,000 and a credit of $568,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest first quarter's loss is after unusual charges totaling $2,250,000. The unusual charges consisted of costs associated with the terminated merger agreement with PPG Industries, fires that occurred at a Grow Group facility in California in September, and a cost-saving reduction of headquarters personnel.

title: Welch Making Rapid Progress
description: On July 22, the Giants' veterans reported to training camp. The next morning, in the first hour of their first workout, Herb Welch was backpedaling in a drill with no one near him. He took a bad step with his left leg and wrecked his knee.

title: Books of The Times; How the Grand Guignol Made Fear Popular
description: The Grand Guignol Theater of Fear and Terror By Mel Gordon 188 pages. Illustrated. Amok Press. Paperback. $12.95.

title: BMC Software reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Talk: Briefing; Tribute to a Pioneer
description: Last evening the Association of Trial Lawyers of America held a dinner here honoring Amelia Lewis, a practicing lawyer for more than six decades who is a pioneer in the field of juvenile justice.

title: Jury in Kirk Trial Still Deadlocked
description: The Federal court jury deciding the fate of the former Memphis State basketball coach Dana Kirk failed to reach a decision today and went home for a three-day weekend. The jury was scheduled to resume its deliberations on Monday.

title: At The Movies
description: Bette Davis Honors

title: Betty S. Cornfeld, 44, A TV Executive, Dies
description: Betty S. Cornfeld, a television executive and writer, died Wednesday at the Swedish Hospital in Seattle. She was 44 years old and had contracted viral pneumonia following a bone marrow transplant for lymphoma.

title: Silicon Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
How to Get Back Into the TV Technology Race; Not Pentagon's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Recoton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Film; Reunion Of Veteran And Son
description: Fate works overtime developing the coincidences that shape ''Distant Thunder,'' a film that reunites a shell-shocked Vietnam veteran with his long-lost son, now 18. The veteran, Mark Lambert (John Lithgow), has been living in a remote forest in the state of Washington as the film begins, making his living collecting ferns. It should be noted that Mr. Lithgow is such an unprepossessingly fine actor that he can make any occupation seem credible, even this one.

title: Collins Foods International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 16
description: The year-ago second quarter revenue includes $25,979,000 attributable to Naugles Inc., a 171-unit Mexican- American fast-food operation, which was sold in the fourth quarter ended April 30. Year-ago 6 months includes $52 million in revenues attributable to Naugles.

title: After the Elections; G.O.P. Wins Last Senate Seat
description: Representative Connie Mack, a conservative Republican, appears to have won a narrow victory over Representative Buddy MacKay, a moderate Democrat, in their campaign for the Senate, absentee ballots indicated today.

title: The Cloud Over Africa Is Locusts
description: Dieye Rawaan pumped pesticide powder and his seven children banged pots and pans, but the cloud kept descending: millions of desert locusts seeking fresh vegetation.

title: The Electoral College Can Block Quayle
description: Dan Quayle does not have to be the next Vice President. Just ask the Framers of the Constitution, who devised the Electoral College precisely to deal with the current predicament. In fact, the post of Vice President could fall to Senator Bob Dole or even Senator Lloyd Bentsen.

title: 15 DEMONSTRATORS SLAIN IN SRI LANKA
description: Thousands of anti-Government demonstrators defied curfews in the Sinhalese heartland today and soldiers opened fire on them, killing at least 15 people, a military spokesman said.

title: GF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $1 million from discontinued operations.

title: California Court Delays Cuts By Voters in Insurance Rates
description: The California Supreme Court today delayed the start of substantial cuts in auto insurance and other coverage called for under a measure approved by the voters Tuesday.

title: British Band
description: Richard Thompson, a British songwriter, is to lead his band tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tickets are $12.50.

title: Allies Urge Bush to Act On Deficit
description: European and Japanese finance officials have made it clear that they expect President-elect Bush to take strong, quick action on the Federal budget deficit.

title: At Gospel Festival, Music Inspired by Hope
description: ''Our music,'' the Rev. Claude Jeter said a few days ago, ''goes clean back to the days of slavery. That's when my great-grandmother and -grandfather, they worked them as slaves and they worked them in the fields, and they didn't feed them on nothing but fatback and corn bread. They'd be tired, they'd be exhausted from the heat and everything, but they'd look up toward heaven, and they'd say, 'Jesus, I'm going to be there someday.' We've been living on hope for 200 years.''

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased $2.6 billion, to $274.63 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 128 institutional funds increased $596.70 million, to $71.31 billion. Assets of the 224 general purpose funds were up $828.50 million, to $87.21 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds increased $1.18 billion, to $116.11 billion.

title: Tall Order for Jets: Containing Flutie
description: The way John Galvin talked about Doug Flutie, the little guy the Jets will face Sunday seemed almost human.

title: China Doubles Estimate of Quake Homeless
description: Chinese officials said today that at least 200,000 people had been left homeless from last Sunday's earthquake in Yunnan Province, doubling their previous estimate.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for the latest periods of Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. were $3.12 for the quarter and $9.41 for the 9 months, compared with $2.52 and $7.62 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Share earnings for the latest periods of Shell Transport and Trading Co. were $1.73 for the quarter and $5.20 for the 9 months, compared with $1.39 and $4.21 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Sales represent sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: LIBRARY SPY HUNT IS CURBED BY F.B.I.
description: Bowing to pressure from a House subcommittee and continued resistance from librarians, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has set limits on its program seeking the help of librarians in detecting Soviet spies.

title: TW Urges Holders To Snub Coniston Bid
description: Calling the offer on the table ''totally illusory,'' TW Services Inc. yesterday urged its shareholders to snub a $29-a-share all-cash bid by Coniston Partners for 15.75 million of its shares. Coniston needs that number to gain control of the restaurant and food services company.

title: Soviets Offering New Plan for Republics
description: Facing unexpectedly strong resistance to their plan for redesigning the Soviet Government, Communist Party leaders promised additional measures today to widen the economic and political independence of local governments.

title: TV Weekend; The Rich in Faulkner's Hollywood
description: This weekend, ''Great Performances'' on public television continues its odd collection of productions called ''Tales From the Hollywood Hills.'' Based on the short stories of writers who worked in Hollywood, for the most part in the 1930's, the series has so far featured the work of John O'Hara, Budd Schulberg, F. Scott Fitzgerald and P. G. Wodehouse. Tonight's entry, at 9 on Channel 13, is William Faulkner's ''Golden Land,'' adapted by William Hanley and directed by Gene Reynolds. David Loxton is the executive producer.

title: U.S. WILL END BAN ON WORK IN HOME
description: The Reagan Administration today lifted a 45-year-old ban on the manufacture of most types of clothing and jewelry by people employed in the home, promising increased flexibility for workers and improved economic competitiveness.

title: L.I.R.R. Fashion Plates: An End to Baggy Pants
description: The Long Island Rail Road is dressing up its conductors. After 15 years of baggy pants and jackets that ripped in embarrassing places, many conductors are sporting new, custom-fitted uniforms that rail officials say are dressier and more durable than the old suits.

title: Japan Bank Sells Housing Loans
description: Japanese banks have begun selling housing loans in order to realign their mix of risky assets and help meet capital adequacy standards proposed by the Bank for International Settlements, officials of the banks said today.

title: Cousins Home Furnishings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net increase in the writeoff of pre-opening costs for new store openings of about $138,000.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M.

title: Neco Enterprises reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
NL Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $848,000 and $8,440,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Preferred stock dividends exceeded year-ago 9 months' net.

title: Deal With Saudis Signed by Texaco
description: Texaco Inc. said it had signed, as scheduled, a definitive agreement with Saudi Arabia on a joint venture to refine and market petroleum in the United States. Texaco will receive $812 million for a 50 percent interest in its refining assets and marketing system in 23 Eastern and Gulf Coast states. The company said it expected an additional $1 billion in cash benefits and savings from the venture.

title: Colonial Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Lewis-Johnson Bid
description: Joe Douglas, the agent for Carl Lewis, said he had been approached by a representative of Ben Johnson about the possibility of a big-money match race, according to a published report. In an interview published yesterday in The Toronto Star, Douglas said he had recently received a call from one of Johnson's advisers asking if Lewis was interested in an unsanctioned race. He did not identify the caller. Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who was stripped of his gold medal in the 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics and banned from competition for two years after he tested positive for stanozolol, the muscle-building anabolic steroid. Douglas said Lewis would not consider competing against Johnson if Lewis's status with the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the governing body of track and field, would be affected. Under the rules of his ban, Johnson cannot compete in any I.A.A.F.-sanctioned event and against any athlete in good standing with the federation.(AP)

title: Review/Concert; Humor In a Rustic Vein
description: Sir Peter Maxwell Davies decided early in the game not to wait for famous conductors to perform his music. Like Stravinsky, Copland and others, he took up conducting himself. In the 1960's he formed and led the Fires of London, a chamber group for which he composed some 50 pieces, the best known and most widely traveled being ''Eight Songs for a Mad King.'' Since the early 1970's, he has lived and worked in comparative isolation on the Orkney island of Hoy, off the northern Scottish coast, but he evidently still finds the lure of the podium strong.

title: Monarch Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $995,000 and $897,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also include a $2,767,000 gain on the sale of business. c-Includes capital gains of $8,159,000 and $10,124,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Capitol Hill Delay Seen In Savings Unit Crisis
description: At a time when rescuing the savings and loan industry is considered one of the critical issues for the next Congress, the stunning re-election loss of the House Banking Committee chairman and the retirement of the Senate Banking Committee chairman could significantly delay the effort, lawmakers and lobbyists said today.

title: Restaurants
description: Le Cygne is a serene and civilized refuge in midtown that since its opening in 1969 has quietly maintained a remarkably high level of food and service. This year, it had a changing of the guard in the kitchen when Pierre Baran, the chef for three years, moved on to the Knickerbocker Club and was replaced by Jean-Michel Bergougnoux, formerly of Le Regence and Lutece. The transition has been so smooth that most patrons probably didn't notice any difference.

title: Little Hope for Tanker Crew
description: A Canadian plane and a Soviet ship searched today for 27 crewmen from a tanker that broke in two in the stormy north Atlantic, but the authorities said there was little chance that they would find survivors. All 27 Greek and Honduran crew members were in the stern section of the 65,746-ton tanker.

title: A.L. Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Allegheny Ludlum Plans Cash Payouts
description: The Allegheny Ludlum Corporation, a specialty steelmaker enjoying one of its best years, has announced a management change, a new investment strategy and cash payouts to reward shareholders and employees. Richard Simmons, chairman and chief executive, said the company would pay a special cash dividend of $3.50 a share and increase the regular quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 12 cents. The maker of stainless steel sheet and strip and electrical steels will also pay $6 million as a 4 percent discretionary bonus to employees. Further profit-sharing payouts are expected through 1990, he said.

title: Dibrell Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Amgen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Drug Tests Threaten Employers, Too
description: LEAD: Although the Reagan Administration has been enjoined by four different United States district courts from testing its own employees for drugs, the Administration is still proceeding with plans to require private employers to compel their employees to submit to random urinalysis drug testing. These proposed and interim regulations will place a significant burden on private employers, subject private industry to suits for monetary damages brought by the employees who are tested and do little to achieve the laudable goal of a drug-free workplace.

title: Concurrent Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax loss carryforward of 100,000. The company said results include only those of the former Massachusetts Computer Corp. The company was formerly Massachusetts Computer Corp.

title: Courier Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Net income The latest year earnings include a $600,000 after-tax gain from the sale of real estate. Prior year results include a $2,100,000 after-tax gain from the sale of a 50 percent interest in Nadco. Prior year amounts are restated for an accounting change.

title: German Resigns In Speech Furor
description: The Speaker of the West German Parliament, Philipp Jenninger, resigned yesterday after setting off a political storm with a Kristallnacht anniversary speech in which he tried to show how Germans were taken in by Hitler.

title: Oak Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,436,000 from discontinued operations, a $466,000 loss on the extinguishment of debt, and a $1,282,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest third quarter included gains of $3,456,000 from the favorable resolution of an income tax issue and $2.2 million from a transaction with Allied-Signal Inc. regarding an exchange of facilities. The latest 9 months included income of $9.2 million from the Allied- Signal transaction and income tax benefit; the sale of the corporate headquarters building; the settlement of patent litigation, and the reduction of certain restructuring reserves. The year-ago quarter included an $18.2 million gain from the settlement of patent litigation.

title: Lemieux at Impasse
description: Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins' center, said he was ''done talking'' about a new contract. ''All I can say is there is no deal made,'' Lemieux said after his representatives and the team met for two hours yesterday. General Manger Tony Esposito said he proposed an eight-year deal, better than a 20-year, $20-million deal reportedly offered Thursday.(AP)

title: Vista Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advice for Actors
description: The Actors Fund of America is to present ''Successful Unemployment,'' a free evening seminar for performing artists, on Dec. 5 at 6 P.M. at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. The seminar, co-sponsored by the Institute for the Performing Artist, will address such issues as choosing ''survival jobs'' and performing without pay. Information: 221-7300.

title: Southland Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Comparable consolidated year-ago figures for Southland and its subsidiaries are not available because of the leveraged buyout of the company in December 1987. Revenue figures for both the third quarter and 9 months excluded sales from stores included in other assets held for sale and from business units being divested.

title: Jack Rosenberg, 73, Former Acting Judge In New York, Is Dead
description: Jack Rosenberg, a retired acting justice of the State Supreme Court, died after a heart attack Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Biotech Research Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reviews/Theater; Racine Tragedy on Love and Rome
description: Jean Racine is generally regarded as a master of French classicism. Over eight years, from 1669-77, he wrote six tragedies, all in verse of 12-syllable couplets, that scholars have called milestones of French literature. With that string of hits behind him, Racine quit the theater to join the court of Louis XIV, his patron. His plays are now seldom revived.

title: Brazil Unrest Spreads as Oil Workers Strike
description: Tens of thousands of oil industry workers went on strike today as labor unrest spread after a clash with troops left three strikers dead at South America's largest steel plant.

title: Drugs Seen as an Increasing Threat to Police Integrity
description: Sixteen years after the Knapp Commission found pervasive corruption in the New York City Police Department, criminal-justice experts and police commanders warn that rampant drug trafficking and efforts to control it are posing extraordinary and increasing threats to the integrity of the force.

title: United Merchants & Manufacurers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter included gain of $41,430,000 on sales of divisions.

title: U.S. Expansion For Electrolux
description: The Swedish household appliance group A.B. Electrolux said today that it had bought a United States lawn mower maker for $295 million from the General Electric Company.

title: Cade Released
description: The Minnesota Vikings have released Mossy Cade because of negative public reaction to the former Green Bay Packers' defensive back who was paroled last month after serving 15 months in prison for sexual assault. ''Although we strongly believe a person deserves a second chance after he has paid his debt to society, we also believe that we should have sensitivity to public sentiment in what really is a nonfootball matter,'' said Mike Lynn, the Vikings' general manager. Cade, 26, was claimed on waivers Tuesday by the Vikings.(AP)

title: Dairy Price Rise Seen
description: Retail prices for dairy products will rise in the months ahead partly because of tight supplies at the wholesale level, the Agriculture Department has forecast. The situation and outlook report, released by the department earlier this week, said average retail dairy costs for 1988 should rise about 2 percent from 1987 levels.

title: American Barrick Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Catalyst Thermal Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Casablanca Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tennis
description: McEnroe Beats Lendl: John McEnroe defeated Ivan Lendl, 7-6, 7-6, yesterday at the $350,000 Stuttgart Classic in West Germany, winning the tie breakers by 7-5 and 7-4. Lendl, the former top-ranked player in the world, is making a comeback after a shoulder operation in September. He and McEnroe held service to 6-6 in the first set, which McEnroe won in 59 minutes. The second set was much the same, but McEnroe capitalized on a double fault by Lendl to win the tie breaker. In other matches in the eight-man, two-group tournament, Andres Gomez of Ecuador beat Jimmy Connors, 6-3, 7-6, and Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-4, 7-6.(AP) Hlasek and Fitzgerald Advance: Fourth-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and eighth-seeded John Fitzgerald of Australia reached the semifinals of the $450,000 Benson & Hedges championship. Hlasek rallied yesterday to beat sixth-seeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel, 4-6, 6-3, 6-2. Fitzgerald defeated unseeded Robert Seguso of the United States, 6-3, 3-6, 6-0. Fitzgerald used his crisp serve-and-volley game to sweep through the third set in 18 minutes, losing only 6 points.(AP) Horse Racing Tinchen's Prince Wins MacArthur Handicap: Tinchen's Prince, who beat Cavanagh Special by just a nose in the Ashley T. Cole Handicap on Oct. 19, beat the same rival by a neck yesterday to win the $110,400 General Douglas MacArthur Handicap at Aqueduct. Tinchen's Prince, a 5-year-old gelding, collared Cavanagh Special with a furlong to go and finally wore him down in the final yards under Jose Santos. Cavanagh Special and William I. Fox held second by 5 1/2 lengths over Easy N Dirty. Tinchen's Prince carried top weight of 121 pounds, 11 more than the runner-up, and paid $3.60 for $2 to win as the favorite. The son of Cornish Prince, owned by Albert Fried and trained by Dick DeStasio, ran the 1 1/8 miles in 1:51 2/5. Golf Perry and Sander Share Lead: Kenny Perry and Bill Sander were tied for the lead yesterday after the second round of the $500,000 Centel Classic in Tallahassee, Fla. They led four other golfers by one stroke. Perry, overcoming a slow start, shot a six-under-par 66 and Sander carded a 67 to reach the midpoint of the 72-hole tournament at nine-under 135. Bernhard Langer, Bill Glasson, Mike Donald and Bob Lohr were at 136. Lance Ten Broeck, the leader after the first round, struggled to a 76 after shooting a 65 Thursday. He survived the cut of even-par 144 by three shots to remain among 73 golfers who will continue the competition for the first-place check of $90,000 at the Killearn Country Club.(AP) Football Kennedy Clinches Title: Alex Lester, a sophomore running back, carried the ball 17 times for 56 yards yesterday, scored on touchdown runs of 2 and 5 yards and also ran in a 2-point conversion to lead Kennedy High School to a 24-0 victory over Adlai Stevenson at Stevenson. The victory gave the Bronx Public Schools Athletic League defending champion the division title. Kennedy, 5-3 over all and 3-0 in the division, had to win the division outright in order to qualify for the playoffs. Stevenson fell to 2-6 and 1-3. DeWitt Clinton (5-3) of the Bronx lost its third successive game and was dropped from wild-card consideration when it lost, 14-6, to John Adams of Queens (6-2), the defending P.S.A.L. champion.

title: From Bizarre Case, a Bizarre Auction
description: ''There has never been an auction of this type and dimension in the Midwest,'' R. Bond Blackman, an antiques appraiser, says. And no one appears inclined to question the contention.

title: Altas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $407,000.

title: Sweet Harmony You Make Yourself
description: Around the nation on Christmas morning, people are likely to be picking out ''Jingle Bells'' on their new electronic keyboards. In the last five years, sales of the keyboards in the United States have skyrocketed, reaching almost 4.8 million in 1987, up from 282,000 in 1983, according to the American Music Conference, a research organization.

title: Traditional Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago net is adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split paid in June 1988. Year-ago revenue reflects an accounting change.

title: David D. Jacobus, 88, a Design Engineer
description: Dr. David D. Jacobus, a mechanical engineer who was in charge of designing nuclear accelerators at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., and at Harvard University, died of pneumonia Tuesday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

title: Heading for Sideline
description: Mike Ditka, who was released from Lake Forest Hospital in Park Ridge, Ill., on Wednesday, a week after a mild heart attack, is not planning to ease back as coach of the Chicago Bears, and his doctor is not pleased. Although the plans were for Ditka to sit in the press box at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington tomorrow when the Bears play the Redskins, he told reporters in Chicago yesterday that he planned to view the game from the sideline near the Bears' bench. ''This is not a good idea,'' said Dr. Jay Alexander, Ditka's cardiologist. ''I think he's got to remember that he had a heart attack. It's a little quicker than I would want him to come back, but Mike's going to do what Mike's going to do.''(AP)

title: Pioneer Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $119,000 and $329,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes investment losses of $43,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $671,000 for the 9 months.

title: Guggenheim Plans Exhibit of Russian Avant-Garde Art
description: A major exhibition of Russian avant-garde art from 1910 to 1930 -including paintings, sculpture, film, architecture, theater, photography and posters - will open at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in November 1991, the museum announced Thursday.

title: Avtex Fibers Has NASA Deadline
description: Financially troubled Avtex Fibers Inc., the sole supplier of rayon used in the space shuttle, has a week to prove it can make a go of it or give the product rights to NASA under a $7 million rescue by the agency. The money from NASA allowed Avtex to recall 1,300 workers Thursday at its Front Royal, Va., plant, which had closed a week earlier.

title: Union Valley Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $635,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Utah Power & Light Co reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
description: The prior 12 months' results reflected a net decrease in earnings of $43,741,076, or 78 cents a share, resulting from the company's December 1986 provision for a coal mining operations refund.

title: A Legend Campaigns In Canada
description: Canadians who will choose a government in the Nov. 21 general election are involved in a rerun of history, and if they are inclined to forget there is always Johnny Canuck to remind them.

title: Republican Is Elected Governor Of Samoa
description: Peter Tali Coleman, a Republican, has been elected Governor by an 810-vote margin.

title: Niekro Lands Job
description: Although he turned down an offer from the Atlanta Braves to manage one of their three Class A teams in 1988, Phil Niekro has agreed to be a roving pitching instructor in their minor-league system next year. ''My main desire is still to manage,'' he said. ''Bobby Cox knows how I feel, and I guess it's just a matter of something opening up before I get that chance.'' Cox is the Braves' general manager. Niekro, a knuckleball pitcher, who won 318 games and lost 274 in a 24-year career that ended in 1987, spent his first 20 seasons with the Braves in Milwaukee and Atlanta, and he pitched his farewell game for the Braves. . . . A .250 hitter in a 13-year career, Denis Menke will be the hitting instructor next season for the Philadelphia Phillies.(AP)

title: Dow Drops 47.66 Points, To 2,067.03
description: LEAD: Capping its worst post-Presidential election week performance since 1948, the stock market yesterday suffered its biggest setback in seven months.

title: Patents; Brace Designed to Keep Tennis Shoelaces Tied
description: Karen Brecher, a 15-year-old tennis player in Tenafly, N.J., has won patent approval for a Velcro brace de-signed to keep shoelaces tied. The brace attaches to the tongue of a tennis shoe and locks the knot in place.

title: Opening of Therapy Institutes Is Only Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: New System For Booking By Computer
description: A new computerized booking system that allows travelers to pick up confirmed hotel, airline or car rental reservations in their hotels will be introduced on Monday by Hotelecopy Inc., a Miami-based travel agency.

title: Feminist Businesses See the Future, and Decide It's Unisex
description: Companies founded in the spirit of the women's movement - including banks and career counseling and executive placement concerns - are changing their names and fading into the mainstream of business. That is partly because women themselves have entered the mainstream, but there is something else: marketing specialists say that women do not want to be segregated as consumers, and that they reject the feminist label.

title: Saxon Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $67,676 for the quarter and $419,519 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $268,681 for the both periods. There were no share earnings for the latest third quarter and year-ago 9 months because net income did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: International Power Machines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago third quarter share net is less than one cent.

title: Daughter of a Slave Dies
description: Miranda Reeves, a slave's daughter who was believed to be 113 years old, died Thursday at a convalescent home here.

title: Earth Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Judge in Sexist Dispute Retires
description: A Federal judge who aroused controversy last summer by ordering a lawyer to use her husband's last name in his courtroom said Thursday that he was stepping down as an active trial judge. The judge, Hubert Teitelbaum, who has been a Federal judge since 1971, ultimately apologized to the lawyer, Barbara Wolvovitz, and rescinded his order. He said Thursday, ''I'm 73 years old and I think it's about time I ease up my trial schedule.''

title: Revco to Add 11 Stores
description: Revco D.S. Inc., the drugstore chain that filed for bankruptcy protection four months ago, said today that it would open 11 new stores and relocate two others by the end of the year.

title: Tesoro Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $26,958,000 related to a tentative settlement with the Department of Energy for the both periods; the year also included a gain of $39.2 million from the sale of assets. c-Net income The prior year results included a gain of $17.3 million from the final disposition of residential fuel oil received from the Government of Trinidad and Tobago.

title: Monitor Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $254,150 from extinguishment of bank debt and a tax credit for the quarter; the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $379,150. c-Included extraordinary credits of $125,000 for the quarter and $300,000 for the 9 months.

title: Theater Move Canceled For 'Eastern Standard'
description: ''Eastern Standard,'' Richard Greenberg's play about a group of yuppies, a bag lady and a Hamptons beach house, will not move to the Ritz Theater on Broadway on Dec. 19, as was previously announced.

title: Nordstrom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
International Telecharge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Alamco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $150,000 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: Why John Jay's Farm Home Must Be Preserved
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Odds on New Games for Bettors
description: The casinos here may be saturated with slot machines, craps tables, roulette wheels and more exotic attractions like baccarat pits. But are even the most jaded gamblers prepared for Pyramid Dice, Caribbean Stud Poker and Australian video games? How about the Whirlwind of Cash?

title: Alfred Eisenstaedt, 90: The Image of Activity
description: It took four puffs, but Alfred Eisenstaedt blew out all the candles on his birthday cake Wednesday night. The total number of flames extinguished: 90.

title: Altron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Kodak Sets Bonus
description: The Eastman Kodak Company will give its 77,300 United States employees a share of a record $263 million company bonus, which Kodak calls a ''wage dividend,'' on March 10, 1989. The average worker will receive several thousand dollars, although the exact amount depends on a person's salary.

title: 288 Yards Run By Underwood
description: Terry Underwood rushed for 288 yards and 3 touchdowns and set season and career rushing records in Wagner's 31-10 victory over William Paterson tonight.

title: Old Coke Bottle Back
description: The Coca-Cola Company will sell Cokes in vintage 6 1/2-ounce glass bottles for the holidays, 51 years after its fancy ''Christmas bottles'' last appeared on store shelves. The bottle, patented on Dec. 25, 1923, will be sold in six-pack carriers with the slogan ''Sign of Good Taste.'' The packages will be available only in limited areas: Atlanta, New York State and parts of the Midwest.

title: Bush at Florida Estate: Relaxed and Unwinding
description: The driveway of the sunny yellow house at 1777 North Ocean Boulevard was thick with stony-faced men. Secret Service agents, Palm Beach Sheriff's deputies, Florida Highway Patrol officers, Florida Department of Law Enforcement officers - all forming a protective column so that the President-elect could enjoy a few days relaxing under the palms and sea grape trees.

title: Colonial Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Index Futures Contract
description: The first stock-index futures contract to be introduced since the market collapse of October 1987 started trading today in Chicago.

title: All-Mozart Concert
description: An Die Musik - Earl Carlyss, violinist; Richard Brice, violist; Daniel Rothmuller, cellist; Gerard Reuter, oboist, and Constance Emmerich, pianist - is to play an all-Mozart concert at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow at 4 P.M. The program includes the Adagio and Rondo for Oboe, Strings and Piano (K. 617), the two Oboe Quartets (K. 370 and K. 285b) and a Piano Quartet (K. 478). Tickets are $6.50 to $11. Information: 362-8719.

title: TSI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Horse Racing; Jockeys Win New Pay Scale
description: Aqueduct Race Track's owners and regular jockeys yesterday agreed on a uniform pay scale, the same one the owners rejected 15 days ago when the riders were on strike.

title: A Bombing Is Thwarted In Norwalk
description: A Queens woman described as an ardent animal rights advocate was arrested by a police stakeout team in Norwalk, Conn., early yesterday as she planted a bomb outside a surgical instruments company that has been criticized for medical procedures using dogs, the police said.

title: Brother-in-Law of Haiti's Leader Found Slain
description: A brother-in-law of Haiti's President was found murdered today in his car on a busy street in the capital, the latest victim in a new wave of crime and terrorism, the police said.

title: Morino Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Japanese in Soviet Chemical Deal
description: A Japanese consortium today announced a preliminary agreement to study the feasibility of a petrochemical complex, costing up to $6 billion, in the Soviet Union. The agreement is seen as a setback to the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, which announced in June that it intended to head the project in Siberia with Western partners.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6, 28 Israel's Prime Minister promised the country's four religious parties that he would insure passage of an amendment changing the definition of who is a Jew. The parties' leaders had demanded a change in the law as a precondition for joining the Prime Minister's party in a new government. Page 1 A West German politician resigned after giving a speech about Hitler that set off a political furor. Philipp Jenninger, Speaker of the West German Parliament, was not accused of being pro-Nazi, but was criticized for the timing and style of his remarks. 5 China's most prominent dissident says he has been invited to visit Taiwan. He would become the first prominent citizen from the mainland to visit Taiwan in almost 40 years. 6 Moscow and the Afghan guerrillas appear ready to hold their first direct talks on freeing the 313 Soviet soldiers reportedly held by the insurgents. 6 Kremlin leaders toured the Baltic, where three republics have shown resistance to the Communist Party's plan to redesign the Soviet Government. The officials apparently were assessing the extent of opposition. 6 Andrei Sakharov met Nazi-hunter, Simon Wiesenthal for the first time in New York City; it was a moment both seemed to savor - perhaps because until now, there was no place the two campaigners could meet. 6 Authorities broke up a meeting held by a group of dissenters in Prague. The police crackdown was the latest in a wave of increasingly aggressive actions to stifle dissent in Czechoslovakia. 6 A U.S. Navy destroyer in Japan, firing shells far from its practice area, narrowly missed hitting a Japanese patrol boat. The episode was the most recent in a series of tense incidents involving American military forces in Japan. 3 A relative of Haiti's leader lay dead in his car, the latest victim in a new wave of crime and terrorism in Haiti. The man, a brother-in-law of Haiti's President, had been shot several times. 28 In the Canadian general election, John Wilcox, the man touting himself as Johnny Canuck has set himself up as a sidewalk historian, traveling on money raised from a variety of anti-free-trade paraphernalia. 3 National 7-9, 32 A discount fare will be curtailed by major airlines as part of a broad restructuring of the discount fare programs that have saved consumer and business travelers hundreds of millions of dollars. 1 The dollar continued to plunge, nearing its 40-year low against the Japanese yen. Traders said they were becoming more convinced that the Bush Administration would favor a weaker dollar. 1 The Government will begin to notify more than 80,000 farmers whose loans are delinquent that they may be subject to foreclosure. Officials said the timing of the announcement was not determined by politics. 1 On Veterans Day, President Reagan visited the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, where he appealed for a healing of the divisions that overshadowed American involvement in the Vietnam War. 7 In a new study of Vietnam veterans, almost two-thirds of those who experienced heavy combat reported delayed psychological and other health effects. The finding contradicted previous Government reports. 7 Calm returned to California after two days of turmoil following passage of a ballot measure that ordered cuts in insurance premiums. The State Supreme Court temporarily halted implementation of the new law. 7 The oldest known insect fossil was discovered in Canada. It provides strong evidence that the transition of animal life from sea to land occurred earlier than thought, scientists say. 32 Researcher sentenced for supplying false data to Government 7 Bizarre criminal case yields unusual Midwest auction 7 Politics 8-9 The Presidential race was winnable, Dukakis campaign aides say. They contend it would never have been easy, but that a better set of tactical decisions could have turned the tide. 1 George Bush's first vacation was witnessed by one intrepid reporter, who revealed that the President-elect had spent the morning by the pool, returning congratulatory calls and enjoying the Florida sunshine. 9 Michael Dukakis was a critical factor in George Bush's victory, aides to the President-elect say. Of all the Democratic challengers, they argue that Mr. Dukakis was the most vulnerable to their strategy. 8 Bush personnel team aims for stiff scrutiny 9 Regional 29-32 A $2 billion New York budget gap, nearly twice the amount estimated three months ago, has led the state's budget director to freeze hiring at all state agencies and to suspend approval of new contracts. 1 The first Bronx principal arrested on drug charges Wednesday had already been suspended from his job three times, was under investigation by the Board of Education and had enrolled in a program for drug abusers. 1 The integrity of New York City police is being threatened by rampant drug trafficking and efforts to control it, police commanders and criminal-justice experts have warned. 29 New betting games were on display at the Second Annual World Gaming Congress and Expo '88, a three-day trade show at the Showboat casino. The Whirlwind of Cash was a highlight. 29 A Queens animal rights advocate was arrested as she planted a bomb in Norwalk, Conn., outside a surgical instruments company that has been criticized for medical procedures using dogs. 29 Hospital workers met at a church to plan a challenge to what they said was widespread discrimination against minorities, particularly in hiring and promotion to senior positions in the hospital system. 29 Queens merchants failed in their bid to prevent the Metropolitan Transit Authority from rerouting bus lines that now cross Jamaica Avenue in order to serve the Archer Avenue subway extension. 31 Passer-by kills woman on Columbus Avenue 31

title: 'Ode to a Cube'
description: The run of ''Ode to a Cube,'' a one-man performance piece by John Kelly, has been extended to Nov. 19 at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street. Mr. Kelly plays an actor in the throes of creating different roles, from a character in the opera ''Carmen'' to the ''Mona Lisa.'' Tickets range from $8 to $15; information: 475-7710 or 475-7708.

title: Afghan Rebels to Talk About Soviet P.O.W.'s
description: The Soviet Union and the Afghan guerrillas appear ready to hold direct talks for the first time on freeing Soviet soldiers captured by the insurgents.

title: CPC-Rexcel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Your Money; Finding the Right Levels of Risk
description: How much risk can an investor tolerate to achieve the desired return? The question lies at the heart of financial decision-making. The answers are subjective and may mean one thing to an investor but something quite different to a broker or financial planner, according to the research findings of two psychologists.

title: Study Finds Vietnam Combat Affecting Veterans' Health
description: In a new study involving several thousand veterans of the Vietnam War, almost two-thirds of those who experienced heavy combat reported delayed psychological and other health effects.

COMPANY NEWS;
Gotaas-Larsen Agrees To $670 Million Sale
description: LEAD: The Gotaas-Larsen Shipping Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be sold to David and Frederick Barclay of London, for $48 a share in cash, or $670 million.

title: The G. Gordon Liddy Story Continues With Chapter 11
description: A Miami-based security company co-founded by G. Gordon Liddy, the convicted Watergate burglar who became a television and movie villain, has sought protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Treasury Futures Move Downward
description: Treasury securities futures declined yesterday, putting further upward pressure on interest rates, as the dollar fell in overseas markets.

title: ADDRESS ON NAZIS COSTS BONN AIDE
description: The Speaker of the West German Parliament resigned today, saying he was ''shocked and depressed'' by the political storm he set off with a speech in which he tried to show how Germans were taken in by Hitler 50 years ago.

description: Anti-Semitic spray-painting has been found inside the Jewish student center on the campus of the State University of New York in Binghamton, and investigators from the university joined the New York State Police yesterday to search for evidence as students and administrators protested the incident.

title: Applause for Sakharov; Caveats From Sakharov
description: Andrei D. Sakharov was on his feet, accepting applause as it reverberated through the elegant Manhattan apartment. Simon Wiesenthal was sitting in the crowded doorway, about five feet away.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Reviews/Music; Songs of Life's Dark and Light Sides
description: Partway through Richard Thompson's late set Thursday at the Bottom Line, his band left the stage and Mr. Thompson traded his electric guitar for an acoustic one to play ''Pharaoh,'' a vision of servitude and despotism that the British songwriter dedicated to ''your next President.'' As he sang the stern, modal melody and its unforgiving lyrics (''Hidden from the eye of chance/The men of shadow dance a dance/And we're all struck into a trance,'') Mr. Thompson's accompaniment was stark and clear and ever-changing. Single notes and chords turned into chimes and drums, unwavering nudges and desolate spaces. Every note was detailed; every detail filled the song with suspense and dry-eyed lamentation. The music seemed to suspend time.

title: Reviews/Theater; Mutuality of an Irish Father and Son
description: Near the end of his solo performance in ''Bat the Father, Rabbit the Son,'' the Irish actor and playwright Donal O'Kelly sings in rapid succession two wildly different interpretations of ''You Always Hurt the One You Love.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Third Congressional District in New Jersey referred incorrectly to the late Representative James J. Howard. He was not the senior member of the state's Congressional delegation; that member is Representative Peter W. Rodino of the 10th District.

title: Hayter Memorial
description: A memorial service for Stanley William Hayter, the painter and printmaker, will be held at 4 P.M. Thursday at the Bernhard Mayer Auditorium of the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street. Mr. Hayter died in Paris on May 6 at the age of 87.

title: Reviews/Music; An Evening of Esoterica
description: The line between audacity and pretentiousness in the world of experimental singing is often very slender. But once it is crossed, if the featured singer possesses only limited vocal resources, an entire evening of such esoterica can be a numbing.

title: 'Punchline' - I Don't Get It
description: LEAD: In the movie ''Punchline,'' Tom Hanks is a medical student afraid of blood and Sally Field is a New Jersey housewife with three kids. Naturally, they become stand-up comics. Makes sense to me. How many times have we all heard future doctors and serious members of the P.T.A. say: ''I don't like this.

description: Jerome MacCarthy, a ballet dancer and a teacher with the John Cranko School of the Stuttgart Ballet in Germany, died on Oct. 17 when he jumped from Television Tower in Stuttgart. He was 36 years old. A spokesman for the Stuttgart police said Mr. MacCarthy's death had been ruled a suicide.

description: The Speaker of the West German Parliament, Philipp Jenninger, set off a controversy on Thursday with a speech marking the 50th anniversary of the Kristallnacht pogrom. Here are excerpts, translated by The New York Times and Reuters from the German.

title: Gregg Smith Singers
description: The Gregg Smith Singers are to offer the first of this season's four ''Composer's Choice'' concerts at 8 o'clock tonight at St. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue. The programs juxtapose choral works by contemporary composers with older works those composers have found influential. In this first installment, works by Francis Thorne, Igor Stravinsky, Ned Rorem and Gregg Smith are to be contrasted with pieces by Mendelssohn, Tchaikovksy, Monteverdi and Brahms. Tickets: $15; information: 874-2990.

title: Gas Sends 30 to Hospital
description: A poisonous release from the I.G.I. Adhesives Inc. plant sent 30 people to the hospital today for minor irritations and checkups, the police said. An investigation showed hydrogen bromide escaped when chemicals were wrongly mixed.

title: Moscom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dukakis Aides Acknowledge Bush Outmaneuvered Them
description: For all the arguments in the Democratic Party over whether Michael S. Dukakis was an inevitable loser, his campaign aides have a direct answer. There were difficulties, they say, but the White House seemed within their grasp, and a better set of tactical decisions could have turned the tide.

title: Principal Is Keeping Out of Sight
description: Matthew Barnwell remained a man with many questions to answer yesterday - surprisingly gentle questions from the students who still rather like him, angry questions from the parents who had trusted him, and questions both hostile and friendly from neighbors who described him as a caring and gentle man.

title: Arrest of Principal Rekindles a Debate Over School Tenure
description: Matthew Barnwell, who on Wednesday became the first New York City principal to be arrested on drug charges, had been suspended from his job three times, was under investigation by the Board of Education and had enrolled in a confidential program for drug abusers.

title: The Editorial Notebook; New York Revealed, on the Run
description: Laura Fogli, the second-fastest woman in last Sunday's New York City Marathon, explained in Italian that she and Graziella Striuli, who came in seventh, like New York because people cheer her in Italian.

The company said for the latest periods its preferred stock dividends totaled $13,289,000 for the quarter and $39,850,000 for the 9 months, compared with year-ago periods of $6,235,000 for the quarter and $18,705,000 for the 9 months. Wester Union said the 1987 figures do not include revenue from Worldcom, acquired Dec. 30, 1987. It also said that with Worldcom included, its 1987 revenue would have amounted to $253 million for the third quarter and $775 million for the 9 months.

description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir promised the leaders of Israel's four religious parties today that he would insure passage of an amendment changing the definition of who is a Jew.

title: British M.P.'s See 'Fortress Europe'
description: European Community officials have repeatedly insisted that concerns that the 12-nation community will erect higher walls against outsiders when it removes internal trade barriers by the end of 1992 are ''senseless and groundless.'' But members of Britain's Parliament believe that the fears of a ''fortress Europe'' are indeed justified, a new poll has found.

title: Review/Film; Unlikely Team of Misfits Against the Unnamable
description: It is meant as the most backhanded sort of compliment, but ''Iron Eagle II'' is not quite as silly as the original. Of course, it would be hard to match the extreme looniness of that action-fantasy, in which a teen-ager named Doug Masters flies a jet into a Middle Eastern country and rescues his father, a shot-down Air-Force pilot, just hours before he is to be executed. Doug's battle cry, as he turns up the volume on his Walkman and zooms into space, is ''rock 'n' roll!''
