title: Patents; Lens Said to Combine Best of Plastic and Glass
description: Glass or plastic? That is the lens maker's problem. Glass lenses resist scratching but shatter easily. Plastics are less likely to break but scratch easily and can become foggy from routine wear.

title: Kansas Case Closed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday it would not re-open its investigation of the Kansas basketball program. The Jayhawks were given a three-year probation for recruiting violations and barred from defending their national title. A report in the Nov. 14 issue of Sports Illustrated said other possible violations may have gone unnoticed. Small loans to players by Mike Marshall, a former Kansas player, were cited in the article. David Berst, the N.C.A.A. enforcement chief, said that the N.C.A.A. had found that the loans were made in 1984, 1985 and 1986, ''before the individual, who also was a former student-athlete at Kansas, would have been considered an athletic representative under N.C.A.A. legislation.''

title: Rangers Stop a Penalty Shot in 4-4 Tie
description: Few moments in hockey are more starkly defined than the penalty shot: two players, one shot, more than 17,000 people and two benches of players on their feet.

title: Devils Gain Tie With Islanders
description: The Islanders' first game against the Devils since the playoffs last spring was full of penalties and stopped play, with a little hockey thrown in. The Devils had 45 shots and the Islanders 22, but each team had three goals for a 3-3 tie tonight before a sellout crowd of 19,040 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about President-elect Bush's selection of his Secretary of State mistated Mr. Bush's share of the popular vote in some editions. He received 54 percent of the combined Republican and Democratic vote. A table published that day, based on the New York Times/CBS News Poll, put Mr. Bush's share at 53 percent. The table should have been labeled to show that it reflected the 1 to 2 percent of ballots cast for candidates other than Mr. Bush or Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Reviews/Dance; Sacred Works From Tibet
description: Tibetan ritual dances performed by monks who followed the Dalai Lama into exile in 1959 have been seen in New York sporadically since the 1970's. Tantric Buddhism from Tibet has increasingly attracted American followers in the past decade with the usual complement of artists and movie actors, among them Robert Rauschenberg and Richard Gere.

The company also said it increased its provisions for continued obligations by $6,000,000, and wrote down certain fixed assets, also by $6,000,000. Comparable year-ago figures are not applicable; the company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Aug. 31--latest year consisted of only 10 months--and had a latest fourth quarter that was only one month long. For the fourth quarter ended Aug. 31, 1987, the company lost $14,320,000 on revenue of $23,810,000. For the year ended Aug. 31, 1987, Johnstown American lost $12,586,000 on revenue of $117,464,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health Page on Nov. 3 about Lyme disease misstated the customary treatment for cases that are not discovered until months after the initial infection. The patients are often successfully treated with oral antibiotics; the expensive intravenous antibiotic therapy is usually reserved for patients with major complications or those who have not responded to oral antibiotics.

title: Stock Market Drop Slows Sale of Art
description: After two record-breaking sales of contemporary art since Wednesday, last night's auction of Impressionist and modern paintings at Sotheby's seemed like a lull to some and a disappointment to others. In a sale of 79 artworks, 23 did not find buyers, and the total for those that did - $79 million - was below the presale estimate of $81 million to $107 million.

title: Lost Wisdom of Paris
description: In the first place, Hemingway told the story wrong, probably to make himself look good. That was a vice of his. He would wait until you died, then tell the story wrong to make himself look good while making you look like a fool.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises
description: A decline in oil and textile imports helped increase Japan's trade surplus to $7.69 billion in October, up 13.1 percent over a year earlier but slightly lower than in September, the Finance Ministry said Thursday.

title: Marilyn Horne Honored
description: Marilyn Horne has been granted the Fidelio award, given by the International Association of Opera Directors to an outstanding performer who has made substantial contributions to the profession in opera houses throughout the world. The mezzo-soprano is the first American to receive the gold medal.

title: An Old Favorite, But Disposable
description: One of the fastest-selling items in stationery stores around the nation is a fountain pen called the Fontaine that you throw away after it lives a life 3,000 feet long; that's hard to translate into days or hours because it depends on how often, how slow or how fast you write.

Reviews/Theater; Teen-Agers With a Bent For Murder
description: In James Bosley's ''Fun,'' two teen-age girls murder an old woman for their own perverse pleasure, but, except for the ironically intended title, the play takes no moral position toward the crime. On the basis of the brief case history on stage at the Nat Horne Theater, one might assume that the murder was being regarded as part of a rite of passage.

title: Tax Bill Is Signed By Reagan
description: President Reagan signed into law today a tax bill that increases a variety of business taxes, cuts some taxes on individuals and makes extensive technical corrections in the Tax Reform Law of 1986.

title: Kite's Streak in Jeopardy
description: Tom Kite has won at least one PGA Tour event in each of the last seven years for the longest such streak extant. But time is running out on the 38-year-old Texan, who has only two days to gain a victory in 1988.

Bridge; Preliminary scores help decide bronze medalists at World Olympiad.
description: How to assign the bronze medal in a championship decided on a knockout is always a problem. The boxing event in the Olympic Games solves it by giving two bronze medals. Sometimes a playoff between the losing semifinalists is possible.

title: An Evening With The Kid
description: He was once called The Kid. He also had other nicknames: The Splendid Splinter, The Thumper, Teddy Ballgame. None of them quite apply anymore for Ted Williams, who recently turned 70 years old, except The Kid.

title: PARKINSON PATIENT GETS FETAL TISSUE
description: Doctors at the University of Colorado have implanted fetal tissue into the brain of a patient with Parkinson's disease in experimental surgery aimed at curtailing the disease's symptoms.

description: New York's Budget Director announced today that the state was facing a budget gap of almost $2 billion, nearly twice what was estimated three months ago, and that to help meet it, he was imposing a hiring freeze on all state agencies and suspending approval of new contracts.

Manning Agrees
description: Danny Manning, the first selection in the National Basketball Association draft, has agreed in principle to a contract with the Los Angeles Clippers that will pay him more than $10 million over five years, the team announced yesterday. Manning will be in uniform tonight when the Clippers play the Phoenix Suns in their home opener. He led Kansas to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship last spring and was college basketball's player of the year. (AP)

title: Woman Joins Men's Team
description: It is a Friday afternoon in November and players on college campuses around the country are preparing for basketball practice. At virtually every school, the ordeal will include drills with 10 or more players.

title: Reviews/Music; A Nicholas Brother, Solo
description: Harold Nicholas, seated on a stoolunder the plants that hang from the skylight of the Fortune Garden Pavilion (209 East 49th Street), sings as though he were still dancing with his brother Fayard in the days when they enjoyed international acclaim as the Nicholas Brothers. Backed by the pianist Tony Monte and the left-handed bassist Earl May, Mr. Nicholas used his hands, torso, facial expressions and precise, polished phrasing of lyrics to infuse his performance with the rhythmic sense that once came primarily from his feet.

title: Patents; A New Way To Give Up Cigarettes
description: Alexander H. Glassman, a New York psychiatrist, won a patent this week for a method to help smokers quit. The method suppresses not only the physical craving for nicotine, the inventor said, but also the irritability, anxiety and depression felt by many who quit.

title: Meeting on History Called by Dissenters Broken Up in Prague
description: Apparently determined to take a tough line against dissenters, the Czechoslovak authorities broke up a meeting in Prague today that had been called to discuss recent Czechoslovak history.

title: Parcells Isn't Surprised
description: When Harry Carson, the 34-year-old linebacker who is leading the Giants in tackles, ended speculation about his career Thursday night by announcing on a television broadcast he would not return for a 14th season, he surprised a lot of people.

title: Turning Over an Old Leaf
description: Heavy rain knocked the first batch of leaves off the trees the other day. Now the others are giving up and drifting down, detaching their stems from the twigs in some failure of will. Our cousins to the north can already view the harvest moon through a filagree of iron gray branches.

title: Tiny Fossil Is Identified As Oldest Known Insect
description: A little bug-eyed fossil found in Canada has been identified as the oldest known insect and provides strong evidence that the fateful transition of animal life from sea to land probably occurred earlier than had been thought, scientists reported yesterday.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Somber Offering by Garth Fagan
description: Garth Fagan makes dances of relatively simple components, none of which look like traditional dance steps or shapes. He has restricted his vocabulary, but the repetitions look intended. Organic directness - and simplicity - are hallmarks of Mr. Fagan's style. His signature arabesque, for example, looks like a rooted, branching tree. But a program by the Garth Fagan Bucket Dance Company on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater offered ample evidence that Mr. Fagan's work is also powerfully expressive and richly varied.

title: Contract for Marshall
description: Mike Marshall, the outfielder who led Los Angeles in runs batted in this season with 82 before becoming a free agent last week, has agreed to the terms of a three-year contract with the Dodgers. Marshall, 28 years old, hit .277 with 20 home runs in a career-high 144 games. He also played a major role in the Dodgers' post-season success, driving in 9 runs and collecting 18 total bases in 11 games. Before last Friday's deadline for free agents to file, the Dodgers offered Marshall a guaranteed $2.3 million for two seasons with an option for a third year that made the package worth $3.2 million. The third year was not guaranteed. The contract Marshall agreed to is believed to be worth $3.5 million. Marshall made his debut with the Dodgers in 1981 and has a career average of .273 with 126 home runs.(AP)

title: Holly to Explore Alternatives to Sale
description: The Holly Farms Corporation, the subject of a $940 million hostile takeover bid from rival chicken producer Tyson Foods Inc., said its board would explore alternatives to selling the company. Holly Farms, based in Memphis, said in a letter to Tyson's chairman that its board had authorized management to explore possible alternatives to Tyson's offer of $52 a share, which was rejected as inadequate last week.

title: Official Indicates U.S. Prefers a Stable Dollar
description: The Reagan Administration, including people who are expected to join the Bush Administration, indicated today that it did not support the dollar's decline or plan to depart from the policy of keeping the dollar stable.

title: Suitor Extends Nabisco Bid
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company announced yesterday that it was extending the deadline of its tender offer for RJR Nabisco by 10 days.

title: Bush Personnel Team Aims for Stiff Scrutiny
description: President-elect Bush and his advisers are setting up an intensive screening process by a team of lawyers for all senior Administration officials in an effort to assure rigid scrutiny of ethical and financial irregularities, members of Mr. Bush's staff said today.

title: Last Utility Settles Default Suit in the West
description: A Federal mediator announced today that a $48.7 million settlement had been reached between bondholders and the last remaining Pacific Northwest utility defendant in lawsuits connected with the 1983 default on two Washington nuclear plants. Three East Coast companies remain embroiled in the controversy stemming from the nation's largest municipal bond default, as defendants in a trial under way in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Patents; Film Coatings to Help Crops Survive Droughts
description: Walter Polovina, a chemist in Fort Myers, Fla., won patent approval this week for biodegradable film coatings designed to help fruits and vegetables survive droughts.

title: Vitronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cardiac Control Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Baby Rescue Story Is Sold
description: The parents of Jessica McClure, the baby who caught the world's attention during her 58-hour ordeal at the bottom of a well, have sold the film rights to the story of her rescue.

title: Federal Realty Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest period results included a charge of $1.3 million related to litigation.

title: Uneasy Baltic Lands Are Visited By 3 Members of Soviet Politburo
description: The Kremlin today sent three members of the ruling Politburo to the restless Baltic republics, where the Communist Party's plan to redesign the Soviet Government is encountering strong resistance.

title: Taiwan Woos Beijing's Idea Of a Bad Egg
description: China's most prominent dissident, who was recently refused Chinese permission to travel to the United States, said today that he had been invited to visit Taiwan and had applied for permission to lecture there.

title: Clashes Accompany Rallies For Polish National Holiday
description: Riot police attacked demonstrators tonight in Warsaw and three other cities as thousands of people joined in rallies and marches on the 70th anniversary of the rebirth of the Polish state.

title: Knicks Squeak By
description: Two free throws by Gerald Wilkins with 8 seconds left in overtime tonight enabled the Knicks to edge the Indiana Pacers, 121-120.

title: DVI Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Poland Now Tries To Outfox Solidarity
description: LEAD: Poland's new Prime Minister, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, has signaled that he wants to fight Solidarity differently from his predecessors. He hopes to outsmart it.

title: Central Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest first quarter includes a $2.1 million pre-tax gain on the sale of mortgage loan servicing.

title: AIRLINES DROPPING KEY DISCOUNT FARE OVER MOST ROUTES
description: Most major airlines plan to sharply curtail a popular discount fare starting next Tuesday as part of a broad overhaul of the discount fare programs that have saved travelers hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Reviews/Music; A Big Band With Lyricism
description: Ken McIntyre's 10-piece big band is like a well-conditioned fighter -loose, swinging and ready to riff.

title: Next Move: Still Up to the P.L.O.
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization failed to grasp the moment and advance a realistic peace proposal before Israel's elections. Today, as the governing Palestine National Council meets in Algiers, its leaders seem destined to miss yet another opening.

title: Philanthropist to Get Jewish Museum Award
description: Regina Gruss, an art collector and a philanthropist, will receive the Mayer Sulzberger Award, given by the Jewish Museum, on Wednesday. Mrs. Gruss donated a number of Jewish artworks to the museum that will be on display in the coming exhibition ''Golem! Danger, Deliverance and Art.''

title: Kinder-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter included a $29 million pre-tax gain from the public offering of stock of a subsidiary. Kinder-Care said it also recorded a pre-tax writedown of $15 million in the latest quarter related to inventory of oil and gas interests held for sale by one of its financial services subsidiaries.

title: John Mitchell and the Loonies
description: A reporter who first met John Mitchell as Richard Nixon's tough, superbly organized Presidential campaign chief went to visit him in his New York apartment one hot summer day in 1973. The former Attorney General had left Washington, and the Watergate cover-up was unraveling. He seemed a sad and shrunken figure, and as the shadows lengthened outside his apartment near Fifth Avenue, he poured large Scotches from a bottle of Dewar's White Label.

title: Telephone & Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $836,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $408,000 for the quarter and $897,000 for the 9 months.

title: National Health Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A Reporter's Notebook article on Tuesday about a coup attempt in the Maldives described the capture of suspects aboard a hijacked ship incorrectly. The Indian troops who captured the suspects boarded from other vessels; they did not parachute onto the ship.

title: Coping: With New Taxpayer Guidelines; Now there is a bill of rights to give you more leverage when dealing with the I.R.S.
description: If you are one of the millions of Americans who cannot seem to speak the same language as the Internal Revenue Service, help is at hand. Now there is a Taxpayer Bill of Rights to lean on. It is designed to provide more information to taxpayers, guarantee access to outside assistance during audits and increase the time allowed to respond to Government requests.

title: Jordan Dooms Nets
description: When the Chicago Bulls are in trouble, they turn to Michael Jordan. Tonight, as usual, that wasn't a bad solution.

title: Workers Tell Hospital Head To Quit Job
description: More than 200 municipal hospital employees gathered at a Harlem church Thursday night to challenge what they said was widespread discrimination against minorities.

title: Cost of Auto Insurance Increases in California
description: Three days after Californians voted for a sweeping rollback in insurance rates, insurance agents and state officials say people are paying higher premiums for automobile coverage than before, at least for the time being.

title: The Religious Right Takes On Friday Night Fever
description: Young people in Tel Aviv are flocking to the hippest nightclub of the moment, the Real Place, where hundreds jam inside and spill out onto the sidewalk every Friday and Saturday night.

title: Days Inns Sales
description: Days Inns of America Inc. yesterday completed the sale of 12 hotels and agreed to sell its last remaining company-owned hotel to Tollman-Hundley Hotels of New York City. No terms of the sales were disclosed. Henry R. Silverman, chairman and chief executive of Days Inn, based in Atlanta, said these transactions completed the sale of all of the company-owned units. There are 733 Days Inns, the third-largest hotel chain in the United States.

title: Housing Integration Loses, and Wins
description: The Supreme Court delivered both a blow and a boost this week to the elusive goal of integrated housing in New York. The Court prohibited the Starrett City housing development from using racial quotas to manage housing integration. But it also prohibited Huntington, L.I., from using local zoning to concentrate low-income housing in a minority neighborhood.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My speech was not understood in the way I meant it by many of those who heard it. I regret this deeply, and I am very sorry if I wounded anyone's feelings.'' - Philipp Jenninger, Speaker of the West German Parliament, in his letter of resignation. [ 5:1. ]

title: Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $199,249 for the quarter and $1,224,648 for the year. c-After tax credits of $476,900 and $1,150,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Patents; A Bib for Fathers To Assist in Bonding
description: Last September, Janet D. Hodson, an inventor in Ventura, Calif., won patent 4,768,612 for Pregaphone, a device designed to let expectant mothers talk to their unborn children. Consisting of a mouthpiece connected to a tube that reaches to a mother's abdomen, the $12.95 device transmits the mother's voice and, in theory, helps the baby bond before emerging from the womb.

title: About New York; Leafing Back: When Orphans Were Sent West
description: Helen Steinman washes her hands before hefting the canvas-covered volumes that are the tools of her trade. The books, handwritten, hold the barest information - but often the only information - about tens of thousands of yesterday's children.

title: K-Tron International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago periods included a pre-tax gain of $1,036,000 from the sale of a facility in Switzerland.

title: United Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter loss included a book loss of $27.6 million resulting from the company's sale of its Peak Health Care Inc. unit, a writeoff of $9.7 million related to the company's reassessment of the value of goodwill assigned to its health maintenance organizations in Georgia and Utah, and a charge of $2.3 million to write off other intangible assets and provide for restructuring costs.

title: Japan Says U.S. Salvos Almost Hit Ship
description: A United States Navy destroyer far from its target practice area fired a series of shells on Wednesday that narrowly missed a Japanese patrol boat, Government officials said Friday.

title: Josephine Bliss, Educator, 77
description: Josephine Bliss, retired director of the Weekday School at Riverside Church in Manhattan, died of cancer Nov. 2 at the home of a nephew in South Portland, Me. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Scientist Given A 60-Day Term For False Data
description: A nationally recognized drug therapy researcher was sentenced Thursday to 60 days in a halfway house for submitting false data to the National Institute of Mental Health on the treatment of mentally retarded children.

title: Downey Designs International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it recorded a non- operating loss in the latest quarter of $211,000 in settlement of amounts due from an affiliate.

title: Daisy Systems Set To Add Cadnetix
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, a Mountain View, Calif. producer of computer-aided design systems, finally succeeded in reaching an agreement to acquire the Cadnetix Corporation, a maker of similar systems based in Boulder, Colo. Daisy will pay $9.50 a share in the form of $6.50 a share in cash and the balance in a debenture convertible into Daisy common stock, giving the deal a total value of about $195 million.

title: Insituform North American Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fremont General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $2,118,000 for the quarter and $3,263,000 for the 9 months, losses from discontinued operations of $763,000 and $2,868,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $294,000 for the quarter and a gain of $914,000 from the repurchase of debt for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after investment losses of $34,000 and $723,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and losses from discontinued operations of $31,542,000 for the quarter and $32,047,000 for the 9 months. The latest third quarter includes a pretax charge of $7,000,000 relating to a re-evaluation of certain corporate investments. The company said the latest 9-month figures represent the reconsolidation of the continuing property and casualty operations, collectively named Fremont Insurance Group, which previously were not consolidated pending sale of the group.

title: Damon Biotech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes charges of $2,367,070 and $2,577,070 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the company's planned production facility in Scotland, and the year also includes a gain of $1,272,281 from the sale of a subsidiary. c-Includes revenue and income of $1,000,000 associated with settlement of litigation and also includes a loss of $1,400,000 from the company's acquisition of Damon Biotech Europe Ltd.

title:
GARDENING;
Conditions Are Right, but Moss Is Rare
description: LEAD: EARLY in this century, when the William Bayard Cutting family strolled through their estate on the South Shore of Long Island, they tread on soft, lush carpets of moss. The paths were covered with mosses, and were swept clean of fallen leaves daily.

title: THE NATION: History's Precedent; How Hoover Handled The '29 Transition
description: GEORGE BUSH is in a situation that no President-elect has had to deal with in 60 years. Not since Herbert Hoover was elected in 1928 to follow Calvin Coolidge has a new President succeeded one of the same party and thus had to decide which, if any, of his predecessor's appointees to keep.

title: Miss McDermott and Miles Esty Planning to Wed
description: A January wedding is planned by Kimberly Kavanaugh McDermott and Miles David Newman Esty, a son of Susan Esty of New York and St. John in the United States Virgin Islands, and the late William Cole Esty 4th. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. David Michael McDermott of Lyme, Conn.

title: Review/Opera; Wrestling With Guilt, in Adaptation of Poe Tale
description: Part of Edgar Allan Poe's theory of the short story was that no detail should be permitted that did not move the story toward its single climax or contribute to its single mood. There is no justice in holding an opera composer to this rule, but it was hard not to think of Poe's strictures while watching ''The Tell-Tale Heart'' by Bruce Adolphe at Marymount Manhattan College Friday evening, because every deviation from them seemed a weakness.

title: A Season of Discontent for a Soccer Town
description: IN this blue-collar town west of the Hackensack River, taverns are alive with conversation about a sports team. The talk does not center on the Mets' losing the baseball playoffs. The residents here are much more concerned with the Kearny High School soccer team and how it could have possibly lost seven games in one season.

title: Isn't There a Better Way to Run an American Election?
description: EVERY four years at about this time, some Americans sit back to ponder the system that has just produced their President, and ask themselves if it can be improved. The discussion seemed more ardent than ever this year, prompted by a campaign that was widely criticized for negativism and shallowness.

title: Dr. Douglas McLennan To Wed Ms. Duggan
description: Dr. and Mrs. John A. Duggan of Worcester and West Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Ann Duggan to Dr. Douglas McLennan, a son of Dr. Donald E. McLennan of Youngstown, Ohio, and Winona McLennan of Williamsburg, Va. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: President Signs a Bill to Aid Man Who Joined Navy at 12
description: President Reagan has signed legislation granting a World War II veteran injured at Guadalcanal the disability benefits he was denied by the Navy because he lied about his age when he enlisted at the age of 12.

title: Tit for Tat
description: Led by the sharp-shooting Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins have been well out in front of the National Hockey League in goals scored this season. Even so, the Penguins have been stuck behind the Rangers in second place in the Patrick Division standings. That's because the Rangers, the Devils, the Islanders and Pittsburgh's other divisional rivals have been employing a deceptively simple, but largely effective, strategy to neutralize the Pittsburgh attack: answering virtually every Penguin goal with a goal of their own.

title: Cooling It in the Fast Lane
description: THE really good upward mobile and savvy stuff is in the fast lane. That's where it's at, we're told. What fast lane? It sure ain't on the roads in these parts. So; when even all the upward mobility and savvy in the world doesn't change anything, and to join the frozen traffic is the give, why not take a break and look around while you're parked there on the road twixt and tween other wheels fore and aft.

title: Gamboling for Charity>Meals, Meals, Meals
description: Nov. 14 - Citymeals-on-Wheels, with the help of the New York City Department for the Aging, delivers more than 650,000 meals annually to homebound elderly in the city. For the sixth year, the city's restaurant industry will sponsor a fund-raising event involving more than 50 of New York's top dining spots. Events through Thursday cost from $40 to $500 each. Monday's event is an 11:30 A.M. luncheon at Tavern on the Green. Tickets, $200. For information about all the events, call 212-577-1758. Agnes De Mille Salute

title: Need Aircraft Tires? How To Grow Them Yourself
description: EURICIC acid vegetable oil, an extract from a large group of plants, including rapeseed and crambe, is not recommended as part of the human diet because it can severely damage the liver. But scientists have devised ways to chemically rearrange it into something resembling crude oil. From that state it can be further refined into plastics and other useful products.

title: Program at College of New Rochelle Is Computer Enhanced
description: LEAD: JANE DALY is sorry she bought a new typewriter just before she began her freshman year at the College of New Rochelle. The student from Glens Falls, N.Y., said she didn't use the typewriter at all, preferring instead to write her papers in the computer laboratory just installed at the college.

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: I suggest that the reason so many of us schedule our children's lives to the point of ''burnout'' is not simply because so many mothers are working. The underlying cause is that we of the baby-boom generation have not mastered the art of enjoying unstructured free time with our own children. For their sake, but especially for ours, it is time we learned. DIANE B. HERKENHAM Port Jervis, N.Y.

title: Water: Talk (And Toast) Of the Town
description: Nearly a year after 250 families here built a $4 million water system, they still show off to visitors their 500,000-gallon storage tank and their basement meters.

title: James Boffman, 59, Ex-Principal And School Superintendent, Dies
description: James Boffman, former superintendent of high schools in Manhattan, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Springfield Gardens, Queens. He was 59 years old.

title: Lisa Palache is Engaged
description: The engagement of Lisa Biscoe Palache to Robert Alan Carey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth B. Carey of Bakersfield, Calif., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John G. Palache Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass. The couple plan a July wedding.

title: Primo Conti, Painter, 88
description: Primo Conti, the last major surviving figure of Italy's futurist school of painting, died today, the Italian news agencies reported. He was 88 years old.

title: To Market, To Market to Sell Microwave Popcorn
description: IT'S one thing to produce an alternative crop. It's another to sell it.

title: 'Embarrassing' Night for Islanders
description: The Islanders finally achieved consistency through three periods tonight and wished they hadn't.

title: The N.R.A., Shot Down
description: In upholding a new state law to ban sales of cheap, concealable handguns - ''Saturday night specials'' - Maryland's voters sent a potent signal to lawmakers everywhere.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last week about Sears, Roebuck & Company misstated the gap between the breakup value of the company and its recent stock price. Sears's breakup value was estimated to be up to $50 a share greater than the stock's recent price of $45.

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; Needed: A New Deal On Lilco Settment
description: The Cuomo sellout to Lilco has not yet been ratified, thanks to the courageous stand of several Long Island members of the State Legislature. Without exception, the people with whom I have talked think the Cuomo deal is a bad deal for everyone except the Lilco stockholders.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 13, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 6 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 3 2 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 4 6 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 5 5 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 6 8 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent on her way to Budapest. 7 3 FAVORITE SON, by Steve Sohmer. (Bantam, $4.95.) The phantasmagoria that follows a televised attempted assassination of a senator. 8 8 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 9 6 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The effect of a violent death on an eccentric North Carolina clan. 10 3 GLITTERING IMAGES, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Sex, love, self-analysis, forgiveness and reverence in English clerical circles. 11 6 HEAVEN CENT, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $4.50.) A young prince's search for a missing sorcerer. 12 * 18 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 13 * 30 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 14 * 1 RITE OF SPRING, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $4.95.) Father Blackie Ryan tries to save a cousin who is suspected of murder. 15 2 WASHINGTON WIVES, by Maureen Dean. (Charter, $4.50.) The lives and machinations of women in the capital. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 25 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 2 3 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $6.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 3 264 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 4 22 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 5 27 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 6 15 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) A British agent's story. 7 6 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $4.95.) Her life with an alcoholic father. 8 * 19 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Murder and incest in an Oregon town. 9 8 I'M WITH THE BAND, by Pamela Des Barres. (Jove, $3.95.) The ''confessions of a groupie.'' 10 10 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Pocket, $4.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the C.I.A. 11 * 13 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race seen through mythology. 12 * 12 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Dell, $4.95.) An economist's predictions. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 7 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 2 * 3 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 3, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $10.95.) A selection of cartoons from three previously published collections. 3 24 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 9 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 5 16 NIGHT OF THE CRASH-TEST DUMMIES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The ninth collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A FAMILY THAT SEEMED TO WORK
description: THE LAST TO GO A Family Chronicle. By Rand Richards Cooper. 304 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: Natural Childbirth Evolving With Advances for Less Pain
description: The doctrine of natural childbirth, which once called for no medical intervention whatsoever in normal labor and delivery, is increasingly being bent to accommodate the advances in understanding and controlling pain.

title: Reviews/Music; Recent Pieces by Ellen Taaffe Zwilich
description: For the contemporary composer, first performances of one's latest music are relatively easy to manage. Getting them repeated is far more difficult. Thus Ellen Taaffe Zwilich was doubly blessed on Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall when the New York Philharmonic Ensembles played two of her recent, but by no means new, compositions. The Concerto for Trumpet and Five Players is almost four years old, the Double Quartet for Strings a year older.

title: Nancy Reagan Criticizes Aides to President
description: Nancy Reagan said in an interview that she felt compelled to exert influence in President Reagan's eight years in office because she did not believe that his staff generally served him well.

title: Pakistan Rules Identity Cards Must Be Presented by Voters
description: The Supreme Court of Pakistan today reinstated the rule that voters present national identity cards in order to cast ballots in elections Nov. 16 and 19.

title: A GRAND-SLAM PROFIT MAY BE IN THE CARDS
description: ''Money is a good soldier, sir, and will on.'' Shakespeare

title: Soviet Psychiatry Is Willing to Change, Up to a Point
description: ''The main syndrome of a psychiatric case is that the person is perfectly unaware that he is a psychiatric case.'' - Oleg P. Shchepin, Soviet Deputy Minister of Health, earlier this year.

title: Secondary Troupes Bring Soviet BalletInto Sharper Focus
description: Deregulation, albeit of a special sort, can affect the arts as much as airlines, and the most visible result is the increased number of Soviet dance companies that have begun to visit the United States.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
THROUGH THE FOREST WITH HER GUARDIAN ANGEL
description: LEAD: DEAR MILI By Wilhelm Grimm. Translated by Ralph Manheim. Illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Unpaged. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95. (All ages)

title: A Move to Trim Corporate Travel Costs
description: TRAVEL means different things to different people. To the business traveler, it too often means delayed flights, missed connections, inferior hotels and upset stomachs. Yet, since the days of Marco Polo, travel has been a vital and necessary part of doing business.

title: '89 Mayor Race: Key Issue May Be Koch
description: In an assessment that might have seemed exaggerated a year ago, Mayor Koch says that he is facing his toughest election and acknowledges that he is likely to be the mayoral campaign's chief issue.

title: Treating an Addiction: The Team Concept
description: There is a response to the article ''Panel Finds Excess in Drug and Alcohol Care,'' but it is not to be found in Frank Clisham's recent letter to the New Jersey editor, which seems to have a hidden agenda component and communicated a negativism about other treatment orientations.

title: 'Romero' Finds A Producer: The Church
description: Like any other Hollywood producer, Ellwood E. Kieser spent his weekdays worrying about budget overruns, script changes and daily rushes when the movie ''Romero'' was being filmed here not long ago. At week's end, however, he assumed another set of duties: donning his vestments, he would celebrate mass for the movie's cast and crew.

title: Julie Gillette To Wed in '89
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earle Peter Gillette Jr. of Minneapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter Julie McCarthy Gillette to Thomas Nelson Page Johns Jr., a son of Mrs. Johns of Richmond and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Dr. Johns. An August wedding is planned.

title: Debra Jaliman, Physician, Is Wed to Jeffrey Schwarz
description: Dr. Debra Jaliman, a dermatologist in New York, and Jeffrey Schwarz, a partner in Ralph Steinberg Inc./Sigma Leather in Brookfield, Conn., were married yesterday evening aboard the yacht Princess in New York Harbor. Rabbi Steven Listfield and Cantor Kurt Silberman officiated.

title: Don't Rule Out a Recession
description: TRAMMELL CROWE, king of the Texas real-estate developers, once remarked, ''In the history of America, the buyers have been right, and the sellers have been wrong.'' He might have gone further. He might have ventured, ''In the history of the modern world, the optimists have been right, and the pessimists have been wrong.''

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Holbrook $163,000 71 Avis Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old, brick high ranch; family room, dining room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,600. Massapequa $278,000 20 Merritt Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old high ranch; new kitchen, family room, 2-car garage; taxes $5,100. Mineola $205,000 413 Argyle Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old saltbox; dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Selden $145,000 65 March Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old high ranch; den, dining room, attached 1-car garage; taxes $2,500. Stony Brook $155,000 65 Manchester Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $3,000. Westbury $272,000 1000 Roxbury Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; finished basement, fireplace, Florida room, new kitchen, decks; taxes $5,300. OTHER AREAS Barkhamsted, Conn. $190,000 11 Chiswick Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 15-year-old Dutch colonial; horse barn, 2-car garage, 1.3 acres; taxes $1,500. Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $479,000 Comanche Court 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; brick fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,874. Livingston, N.J. $236,000 6 Scotland Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; screened porch, hardwood floors, 1-car garage; taxes $3,085.

title: AN INN THAT BLOWS ITS OWN HORN
description: It was a lovely, cool, San Francisco afternoon, but we were being drenched from hair to shoes - not a promising start to what was supposed to be an overnight of pampering at a gracious inn.

title: Meatpacker Awarded $24.6 Million Over Strikes
description: A jury has awarded a meatpacking company $24.6 million in damages for three strikes by union members at its processing plant in Sioux Falls.

title: RETAILER IN TRANSITION: Dan Storper; A Test of One Man's Taste
description: WHEN Dan Storper was 7 years old, his grandfather gave him a batch of hair brushes to sell door-to-door.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: IN this era of rapid change in New Jersey, it's nice to know that some traditions endure over the centuries. We are speaking here of corruption and bribery, which are as much a part of the state scene as the Jersey tomato, and maybe a lot more vigorous.

title: Storytellers to Celebrate With Tales
description: STORYTELLING is not just for children; it is for everyone. It is a vital form of communication, a way to learn and an esthetic experience, say Connecticut's storytellers.

title: Bush to Inherit Deficit Larger Than Expected
description: President-elect Bush will have a bigger budget headache than he thought: Officials say the Federal deficit in the next fiscal year will be $21 billion higher than the Reagan Administration first estimated.

title: THE NOTORIOUS UNKNOWN INDIAN
description: THY HAND, GREAT ANARCH! India: 1921-1952. By Nirad C. Chaudhuri. 979 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $29.95.

title: With Weicker Gone, Who'll Lead G.O.P.?
description: LEAD: WITH the defeat Tuesday of United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the state's Republican Party lost not only its sole candidate to win a statewide election in almost two decades, but also its titular head.

title: Arrest at White House Fence
description: The Secret Service said an unarmed man climbed the White House fence early Friday night and was immediately apprehended. Bill Corbett, a spokesman for the service, said the man did not resist and that his identity was being withheld pending a decision by a Federal magistrate whether the intruder should be charged or held for observation.

title: Coming Up: The Debate America Wanted
description: THROUGHOUT the long and persistently negative 1988 Presidential campaign, Americans said what they wanted - and were not getting - was a substantive debate on issues.

title:
SIGN-OFF;
WHEN INVESTORS WON'T LET GO- NO SALE
description: LEAD: ''For of all sad words of tongue or pen, The saddest are these: 'It might have been!'' - John Greenleaf Whittier [1807-1892] - A Million Investors [Oct. 19, 1987]

title: Knee Surgery for Solt
description: When the Eagles' high-priced guard, Ron Solt, turned out to have severe knee problems after being traded to Philadelphia by the Indianapolis Colts last month, some Eagle fans assumed that the Colts had palmed off damaged goods on the Eagles or that Solt had covered up his problems.

title: FICTION
description: IN PALE BATTALIONS. By Robert Goddard. (Poseidon, $18.95.) World War I was its own particularly disillusioning hell, but in Robert Goddard's superbly plotted romantic thriller, the real evil lurks in a graceful English country estate. There a wounded young lieutenant, recovering at the home of John Hallows, his dead captain and friend, is drawn into the Hallows family's tangle of secrets. The household includes a cast of standard but well-drawn characters: the captain's withdrawn, grieving father, turning his back on difficult truths to preserve the family's good name; the dead man's voluptuous, scheming stepmother; his beautiful, oddly calm widow, with whom the lieutenant falls in love; the captain's grandfather, garrulous but observant; and a wealthy, arrogant American who plots to marry the widow against her will. The principal story is told in retrospect from the point of view of the widow's daughter, who has been raised in an atmosphere of secrecy and hatred. The novel's movement through time, using additional narrators, adds layers of depth to its mysteries, which fit together as intricately as the pieces in a Chinese puzzle. ''In Pale Battalions'' contains a murder, hidden liaisons, flights and searches, as well as musings on the waste of war and the limits of duty and decency. Together they form an elegant melodrama in which the sentiments sound right, even when they border on cliche, and the author's manipulation of suspense and surprise rarely fails to dazzle.

title: Guardian for Elderly Finds Rising Demand for Services
description: LEAD: EIGHTY-YEAR-OLD Dan shuffles through the home in western Morris County he once shared with his second wife, whose name he no longer remembers. Disoriented and in frail health, he is unable to feed or dress himself and depends on a live-in nurse for nearly every need.

title: Lawsuit Against Hempstead Town Is an Opportunity for Improvement
description: THE recent class-action suit in Federal court by a civil rights group challenging the at-large voting system in the Town of Hempstead must be successful! The residents of the Town of Hempstead will be the beneficiaries and it will provide the voters with the ability to play a more significant role in government.

title: Flatiron District
description: To the Editor:

title: American Works on Programs
description: ALTHOUGH American Music Week, the annual celebration of our country's composers and their creative work, ends today, the event seems to be continuing in Connecticut, with several concerts presenting fine examples of musical Americana this week.

title: VERMONT TOURS BY CABRIOLET AND CUTTER
description: Robert Gove, a retired dairy farmer in Moretown, Vt., says he feels ''more alive, somehow'' when he's driving his sled. And it's easy to see what he means. A trip through woods and fields in one of Mr. Gove's sturdy wooden box sleds is a treat to all the senses, and one is delighted by the crisp smell of woodsmoke and pine boughs; the sight of snow-covered pastures and of Mount Mansfield - the state's highest peak - rising in the distance; the feel of the rough wool blankets; the varied cadence of the harness bells on the Belgian draft horses as they alternately plod and prance through the snow, and the taste of the hot chocolate and cookies offered after each ride.

title: Reviews/Music; Marty Ehrlich's Jazz
description: Marty Ehrlich brought a group called Polyphony to the Knitting Factory Wednesday night. Mr. Ehrlich and Stan Strickland on reeds, Jerome Harris on electric bass and Pheeroan akLaff on drums used the bright, clear blend of two saxophones to create swirling, dense sounds.

title: Spill-Proof Tie
description: To the Editor:

title: Judy J. Licht to Marry R. S. Tempchin in April
description: Mrs. Frank Licht of Providence R.I., has made known the engagement of her daughter Judy Joan Licht to Richard Scott Tempchin, a son of Gloria Tempchin of Silver Spring, Md., and Leonard Tempchin of Columbia, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: Copter Crash in Gulf Region Kills Three American Airmen
description: Three American airmen were missing and presumed dead today after their helicopter crashed on Friday in the north Arabian Sea, the Pentagon said. The helicopter was trying to land on the frigate Barbey, on duty in the region.

title: Talking; Radon Getting Rid of a Carcinogen
description: Finding out whether a home is accumulating high levels of radon gas - and correcting the problem if it is - is now considered so important that a great many people are eager to take action, even if the experts cannot agree on just how serious the long-term threat really is.

title: BROOKLYN COLLEGE UPSETS ADELPHI, 4-1
description: Michael Dominic scored two goals and Brooklyn College dominated nearly every aspect of the match as the Kingsmen upset Adelphi, 4-1, this afternoon in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's soccer tournament.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: They sure can, and also stop the fighting as well with a substantial fine and a suspension for at least two games. Any future recurrence will carry a compounding of the two games: on the next infraction four games, then eight games, etc. WILLIAM P. AVRIL Acton, Mass.

title: THE DO-IT-YOURSELF LIFE OF LUDWIG WITTGENSTEIN
description: When you finish writing a novel, you may feel brilliant and triumphant, an unsung master of your craft. But when you begin that next book, as I am now, the rock rolls down the hill. Experience fails you. Suddenly you feel inept and confused - often downright stupid.

title: CREDIT CAN MAKE OR BREAK PROFITS ON AN INVESTMENT
description: ''Ready money is Aladdin's lamp.'' Lord Byron

title: DEFYING THE CONTROLLERS)
description: LITERARY OUTLAW The Life and Times of William S. Burroughs. By Ted Morgan. Illustrated. 659 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $27.50.

title: Debuts; Recitals by a Cellist And Three Pianists
description: Claude Webster

title: Zoning Is Only One Bar to Cheaper Suburban Housing
description: ADVOCATES of desegregated housing in the suburbs celebrated a legal victory last week when the United States Supreme Court ruled that Huntington, L.I., had violated Federal fair-housing laws through exclusionary zoning.

title: Bright Hopes And Dark Clouds
description: After a rigorous summer of scouting, planning and coaching changes, a new college basketball season begins this week with 293 Division I programs competing for 32 conference championships.

title: Picking Personnel
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SUBJECT WAS NOSES
description: THE ADVENTURES OF PINOCCHIO By Carlo Collodi. Translated by E. Harden. Illustrated by Roberto Innocenti. 142 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Review/Recital; Guitarist's Four Roles
description: Sharon Isbin is a good, conscientious guitarist, and her program Wednesday night at Town Hall served to introduce one valuable new score. But beyond that, its primary interest lay in its imaginative stretching of the recital format. Ms. Isbin managed to keep herself pretty much in the center of the picture, presenting herself as a recital soloist, a duo partner, a co-soloist in a concerto and a concerto soloist pure and simple.

title: High-Tech at Home
description: THE other morning, very early, I was awakened by a loud chirp. This was not the cheerful chirp of a cricket taking shelter from the frosty night. No, it was a mechanical sound with no personality at all. Ignore it and maybe it will go away, I thought, as I buried my head under the blanket. Of course it didn't. Five minutes later it chirped again. It was the smoke alarm signaling that it needed new batteries - now.

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; An Opportunity, Not a Threat
description: I am an administrator for a child-care agency working with troubled adolescents and families.

title: SANTA CLAUS, ON THE BACK OF A FIRE TRUCK
description: WHO SAID RED? By Mary Serfozo. Illustrated by Keiko Narahashi. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books.

title: Support Group Helps Sufferers of 'Codependence'
description: LEAD: A PARENT corrects her children's homework, constructs their science projects and completes their unfinished assignments so that their teachers will not penalize them.

title: Earthquakes
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Pennsylvania Priests Accused of Molesting
description: A prosecutor has charged three Roman Catholic priests with sexual abuse, saying they had molested two altar boys who were brothers. The prosecutor also criticized the priests' diocese.

title: Review/Opera; Several New Singers In the Met's 'Carmen'
description: ''Carmen'' is not an easy work to cast. What opera is these days? Still, the Metropolitan Opera ought to be required by international law to do better by Georges Bizet than it did in the season's first performance of his much-abused masterpiece on Friday evening. The production, no landmark of the lyric theater when it was new in 1986, now staggers from act to act without much sense of direction, either in the geographical or the theatrical sense. Chorus males and females romp about aimlessly, hoping to be mistaken for macho soldiers or tobacco-factory hoydens. Scarcely a move by anyone gives the impression of having been carefully plotted for dramatic effect.

title: After 60, Sleep Poses a Challenge
description: LEAD: FOR thousands of people over the age of 60 on Long Island, getting a good night's sleep is an insurmountable challenge. The same is true for older people throughout the country, whose sleep, researchers say, begins to deteriorate considerably around retirement age.

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; Point O'Woods:
description: Open the Gates I was both appalled and sad after reading the letter from Rosemary Muench [ Oct. 16 ] .

title: Some Images Take a Bite Out of the Truth
description: In the 16 years since ''The Candidate'' first appeared, our standards certainly have shifted. What once seemed to be examples of outrageous media manipulation have come to appear disturbingly routine.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our wood garage door faces south and has been varnished several times with either a marine varnish or a polyurethane. After several months the varnish begins peeling. Our painter suggests we use paint instead of stain and varnish. What is your opinion?

title: Lemnitzer Is Dead at 89
description: Lyman L. Lemnitzer, World War II hero and ex-Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, died yesterday. Page 44. Nuclear Management Flaws Westinghouse Electric, hired to save two big nuclear weapon factories, has suffered managerial lapses. Page 38. An 'Uphill Fight' for Koch Mayor Koch says his record and personality will be the issues in an ''uphill fight'' for re-election. Page 32.

title: LOWERED AGE LIMIT FOR HUNTING URGED
description: A leading organization of sportsmen in New York has proposed lowering the minimum age for hunting small game in the state from 14 to 12.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: As with most of its other troubles, the N.H.L.'s stick-swinging problem is money-related. In all contact sports, the answer to flagrant rule infractions is length-of-the-injury suspensions. A career-ending high stick then has the same effect at both ends of the weapon. Since N.H.L. owners' money, in the form of player investments, is involved, don't hold your breath. ED WOHLMUTH Philadelphia

title: Barkhamsted Artist Captures Landmarks on Notecards
description: FROM the cascading waterfalls of Kent Falls State Park in Kent to the colonial buildings of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, if it is a notable Connecticut site, Carol Wallace will probably commemorate it on a notecard.

title: The Wrong Carolina
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our wood garage door faces south and has been varnished several times with either a marine varnish or a polyurethane. After several months the varnish begins peeling. Our painter suggests we use paint instead of stain and varnish. What is your opinion?

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: FOR ARABS, THE TALKS ARE A 'GIFT'
description: The 448-member Palestine National Council was founded in 1964 as a consultative body for Palestinians and has become the highest legislative body for the 5.5 million Palestinians dispersed around the world. Its decisions become binding policies that can sometimes paralyze or motivate Palestinian actions.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
A BIG NEW THING IN PIMLICO HILLS
description: LEAD: DINOSAUR BOB And His Adventures With the Family Lazardo. Written and illustrated by William Joyce. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row.

title:
TELEVISION;
Is 'Sesame Street' Really on the Right Track?
description: LEAD: ''Sesame Street,'' which begins its 20th anniversary season tomorrow, started its television life as an experimental effort, rooted in the social idealism of the 1960's, to amplify and strengthen a nation's commitment to its young people.

title: EASTERN TOWNSHIPS
description: The countryside east of Montreal, in mostly French-speaking Quebec, has much in common with New England. The area was settled more than 200 years ago by Colonial settlers who supported Britain during the American Revolution. Branded as traitors, deprived of their land and possessions, about 70,000 Loyalists, including Benedict Arnold, fled to Canada.

title: Dubcek, Arriving in the West, Is Amazed by the Attention
description: The former Czechoslovak leader Alexander Dubcek, ousted after the Soviet invasion of his country in 1968, expressed shock today at the amount of press attention he received on his first foreign visit in nearly two decades.

title: Carson Sets Own Terms
description: Two weeks ago, Harry Carson said he had no plans to retire from pro football. Thursday night, on an HBO program titled ''Inside the N.F.L.,'' he said he would retire after this season.

title: Viruses Revisited
description: I HAVE A DRAWER IN MY kitchen that's a jumble of odds and ends. But my junk drawer, cluttered and haphazard though it seems to the uninitiated, has an important function in our house. When something breaks down, we run to that drawer and can usually find a handy way to fix the problem. The old can opener buried under the kabob skewers, for instance, turned out to be the perfect way to reach the ''on'' switch for the coffee grinder when the right way no longer worked. And my daughters are always finding uses for the straws and pom-pons and rubber bands that more sensible mothers would have long since thrown away.

title: The View From: Yacht Haven Marine Center in Stamford; For the True Boat Addict, Withdrawal Is Traumatic
description: TO boat people along Connecticut's 618 miles of tidal coast, November is the cruelest month: the traumatic one of decommissioning.

title: Pamela Beth Morak Wed To Frank Ross in Queens
description: The wedding of Pamela Beth Morak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Morak of Brooklyn, to Frank Albert Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ross Jr. of North Scituate, R.I., took place last evening at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Joseph Binder officiated.

title: ROBIN HOOD, WORRYWART OF NOTTINGHAM
description: THE OUTLAWS OF SHERWOOD By Robin McKinley. 282 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books.

title: RIGHTISTS SEEKING REVIVED APARTHEID
description: The right-wing Conservative Party has alarmed South Africa's governing National Party as well as opponents of apartheid by threatening to bring back whites-only accommodations in towns that the Conservatives captured in the municipal elections last month.

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: I have raised children ''in the fast lane'' of Beverly Hills and have seen the next step in their development (''Kids in the Fast Lane,'' by Sara Davidson, Oct. 16). I have seen 9- and 10-year-old girls dis-invite another girl to a birthday party because she did not own a rabbit coat, and a 10-year-old boy laugh when I suggested that he join the Boy Scouts, saying, ''Why carry heavy packs up the San Bernadino Mountains when I already visited the Alps in Switzerland?'' I knew a child who was depressed because he received a Honda for his 16th birthday and his best friend received a BMW.

title: Milton Avery: Greatness Without Angst, but With Wit
description: INTRODUCING the catalogue to Milton Avery's 1982 retrospective at the Whitney Museum, the museum's director, Tom Armstrong, takes note of the boats missed by the artist in his lifetime. They were two - the ''American scene'' boat, for which he was considered too abstract, and the ''abstraction'' boat, for which he was not abstract enough.

title: Long Island Star Attracts Attention in Two Sports
description: Tom Cassese picked up the phone in his cramped office below the main gymnasium at Comsewogue High School and struggled with the caller's question.

title: TRADE PACT LOSES STEAM IN CANADA
description: The prospects of Canada ratifying the free-trade agreement with the United States after its general election on Nov. 21 appear to be diminishing as new opinion polls suggest that a minority government is the most likely outcome of the voting.

title: Jocelyn E. Grayson to Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grayson of Santa Barbara, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jocelyn Eve Grayson to Mark Louis Breslauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Breslauer of Cupertino, Calif. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Ms. Weber Weds Charles Marsden
description: Marilyn Weber, a manager of airport service agreements for Pan American World Airways, was married last evening to Charles J. Marsden, the vice president of finance and chief financial officer of the Crompton & Knowles Corporation, a chemical concern in Stamford, Conn. Cantor Daniel Rous performed the ceremony at Delmonico's restaurant in New York.

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: Sara Davidson describes California parents who have come to child-rearing late and wealthy, and who shamelessly indulge their kids.

title: Hospitals Study Right-to-Die Ruling
description: HOSPITAL administrators in the county are expressing concern about a recent court decision that ordered the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla to keep a patient alive by artificial feeding. Its effect, they say, will be to force hospitals to make a legal issue of what should, in their opinion, be an ethical and medical matter.

title: THE WORLD: Election Wednesday; After Zia, Pakistan Takes Well To Politics
description: AS Pakistan moves steadily and for the most part peacefully toward what it hopes will be the freest election in its history on Wednesday, one issue in the campaign overrides all others. Where will power lie in years ahead, and how will it be used?

title: The Horse of Cedar Creek
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Terrorism's Advocates Off British Air; Big Sister Is Watching
description: To the Editor:

title: Sewage in Santa Monica Bay
description: Nearly seven miles of beaches are closed for the weekend because a cap on a sewer main 15 miles inland failed, causing a gush of raw sewage into Santa Monica Bay. The overflow, which apparently began Wednesday, caused bacteria levels in the ocean near Marina del Rey to rise to more than twice the safe levels for swimming, a city biologist, John Dorsey, said Friday.

title: At 88, Fuchs Is Still His Own Man
description: Almost always, old violinists - unlike old pianists or conductors - slowly fade away. Not Joseph Fuchs, who at the age of 88 is giving a concert at the 92d Street Y this afternoon. And his program is typical: no catering to popular taste here. He will be playing the New York premiere of a sonata by Peter Racine Fricker, the Vaughan Williams Violin Sonata, the Second Sonata by Albert Roussel and the charming little Sonatine by Jean Francaix. Throughout the years, Mr. Fuchs has given the world premieres or first New York performances of some 40 pieces, some of them major.

title: MAMMOTH IN MORE THAN ONE WAY
description: Mammoth Mountain, in the eastern Sierra Nevada range, though not as well known as such ski resorts as Vail, Killington and Squaw Valley, certainly ranks with them in terms of sheer busyness. Mammoth, the nearest resort to the Los Angeles area, draws weekend crowds that can exceed 21,000 and had a record season in 1985-86 of 1.4 million skier days.

title: EAVESDROPPING ON THEIR TRYSTS
description: LEAD: THE ACCOMPANIST By Nina Berberova. Translated by Marian Schwartz. 94 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95.

title: POLAND: HOW IT WAS
description: MY CENTURY The Odyssey of a Polish Intellectual. By Aleksander Wat. Edited and translated by Richard Lourie. Foreword by Czeslaw Milosz. Illustrated. 407 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. THE JEWS IN POLISH CULTURE By Aleksander Hertz. Translated by Richard Lourie. Foreword by Czeslaw Milosz. 266 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $32.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: Laurie Rae Goldman Marries Brian M. Cassell
description: Laurie Rae Goldman, a daughter of Donna A. Goldman of Boca Raton and Naples, Fla., and Alan H. Goldman of Montgomery, Ala., and Naples, was married last evening to Brian Mark Cassell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Cassell of Brooklyn. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman, the uncle of the bride, officiated at the Harbor Court Hotel in Baltimore.

title: Karen Sands Is Engaged
description: Bruce A. Sands of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Amagansett, L.I., and Barbara Reiff of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Tracy Sands to Andrew Merrill Greenspan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Greenspan of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla. Ms. Sands, the sportswear buyer at Henri Bendel in New York, and her fiance, a corporate leasing executive at the Robert Martin Company in Elmsford, N.Y., plan to marry in May.

title: Gasoline
description: To the Editor: Your readers should be advised that, contrary to the information in Travel Advisory on Oct. 2 pertaining to the availability and price of gasoline in West Germany (''Filling 'er Up in 17 Countries''), we found unleaded (bleifrei) regular and super available at every refueling stop we made during a 10-day swing through West Germany, including West Berlin, this past June.

title: Knicks' Triumph Paced by Jackson
description: With 6 minutes 32 seconds remaining in the opening period last night, Mark Jackson raised his hand in triumph. On a pass from Gerald Wilkins, the Knicks' playmaker made his first 3-point basket of the season, snapping a string of eight straight misses. Jackson tried two others, in the second and third periods, and made both.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Philadelphia: A $200 Million, 58-Story Tower
description: LEAD: Construction has begun on 2 Liberty Place, the $200 million, 58-story companion to this city's tallest office building.

title: Nassau Symphony Under a New Baton
description: LEAD: WITH a three-year contract as music director in his pocket and an evolving five-year plan to see the Nassau Symphony Orchestra ''grow in quality and quantity'' in the works, Andrew Schenck takes to the podium Saturday to conduct his first concert of his first season at the symphony's helm.

title: How to Deter Computer Sabotage
description: If his friends' reports prove accurate, Robert Morris, the Cornell hacker whose virus program clogged up 6,000 computers last week, deserves to be vigorously prosecuted. There's appealing drama in this tale of father, son and a monumental electronic game, and there may be reason to mitigate the punishment. But that's different from minimizing the crime. Prosecuting the case can test the adequacy of present laws against electronic sabotage, a crime that can be deterred.

title: Review/Music; A Bit of Avant-Garde From the 14th Century
description: It was the historian Barbara Tuchman who pointed out the horrid similarities between the 14th century and our own. At Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, the Waverly Consort implied much the same with music, but it offered a little relief from the distress as well.

title: Salvage Warehouse: Pieces of History for Sale
description: Need a baluster, a shutter or a shingle? Etched, beveled or stained glass? Because they do not make them the way they used to, it is hard to find replacement parts for your house or apartment. Where to look? Try Benjamin B. G. Nistal-Moret on Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. He just might have it.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 29 about the Road of the Seven Bridges, between Arezzo and Florence, Italy, misidentified a small, privately run hotel in the village of Loro Ciuffenna. The hotel is still undergoing renovation and was prematurely described with its new name, Al Tartufo. It has been known simply as the Manneschi house.

title: Seeking a Broader Audience for Roger Sessions
description: ''There is still reason to believe that whatever is of real importance gains eventual recognition, even though this recognition sometimes comes very slowly,'' the composer Roger Sessions wrote in ''Questions About Music,'' a compilation of the Norton Lectures he delivered at Harvard in 1969. He was discussing, in general terms, the public's resistance to difficult contemporary music, a category in which many listeners placed, and still place, Sessions' own work.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SCARY KISSES. By Brad Gooch. (Putnam, $17.95.) The kisses in the title of this first novel set in the late 1970's and early 80's are shared by two male fashion models, Todd and Frank, and by Lucy, the woman who alternately lives with each man. Joining the trio is an international crew of models, agents, photographers and designers, including, in a cameo appearance, Andy Warhol.

title: The Lure of Clowning for Fun and Profit (Mostly Fun)
description: ON his death bed, Anna Biltcliffe's father, who had performed in minstrel shows, looked at his daughter and said, ''Kid, whatever you do, keep them smiling.''

title: Centuries of Blue Skies O'er a 'Pastoral Landscape'
description: Secreted among the thunderous big-name exhibitions in the National Gallery of Art in Washington, there is one that deserves our tender attention on two quite separate counts. The first is that instead of knocking us off our feet like Michelangelo (on view through Dec. 11) or Veronese (opening today and on view through Feb. 20, 1989), it consists primarily of European paintings, drawings and prints that are intimate in their appeal to us.

title: Coastal Pollution Examined
description: A SPECIAL television documentary by the New Jersey Network about coastal pollution suggests that although there is enough proof of environmental degradation to force an end to polluting the Atlantic, little has been accomplished to actually clean up the ocean and its estuaries.

title: GOBBLING IT UP
description: Economy is one of the most important qualities of a great cook -whether the chef is turning out a simple sauce or a complicated pastry. It is also one of the most difficult attributes to teach an apprentice. The resourceful cook is not avaricious or cheap; rather, he makes the most of what he has and is frugal in his use of ingredients, procedures, equipment and time. Along with good taste, every motion counts.

title: Towns of Stone In the Downs Of Wiltshire
description: Wiltshire is famous for its strong sense of local identity and of history stretching back to prehistoric times. It is just far enough from London to make commuting impracticable, and this has helped it maintain a remote and rural character. Although its landscape is dominated by the dramatic sweep of the Salisbury Plain to the south and by the subtler sweep of the Marlborough Downs to the east, the most typical aspect of the county is of a gently rolling countryside, sporadically dotted with small towns, pasture lands and the occasional forest. But it is the downs, the treeless, chalky uplands, that convey a sense of spaciousness and tranquillity in Wiltshire, a sense further enhanced by its relative underpopulation.

title: A Living Memorial For War Veterans
description: RAKE, mow, clean the power mower and store it if the trees are bare. Don't forget to make a compost pile and add those leaves; sandwich soil and a thin layer of fertilizer in between to encourage the compost to decompose faster. Pull up stakes, clean and store. Prune shade trees and overgrown shrubs that block views of cars and pedestrians. Last call to plant bulbs and evergreens. A Live Memorial

title: Maryland Crash Kills Pilot
description: A private twin-engine plane bound for Philadelphia crashed in this suburb of Baltimore Friday, killing the pilot and setting two houses on fire. There were no reports of anyone injured on the ground, said a state police spokesman, Chuck Jackson, who added that the pilot's identity was not known.

title: Dreamscapes
description: THE 19TH-CENTURY British critic John Ruskin, nipping in the bud any fashionable tendency to include native artifacts in the world of esthetics, declared, ''There is no art in the whole of Africa, Asia or America.'' He did not bother even to mention Australia. At the time he wrote, most aboriginal Australian objets d'art were in the hands of missionaries, homesteaders or anthropologists, who valued them more for what they said about the extraordinary social life of the hundreds of groups defined by language and kinship than for their beauty. Even when ''primitive'' art became a respectable interest for Europeans and Americans, the art of the native Australians remained tucked away among the bark canoes in the remotest corners of natural-history museums.

title:
INVESTING;
The Case for Natural Gas Stocks
description: LEAD: WITH both temperatures and oil prices dropping, stock analysts are taking a closer look at the companies that will be producing and distributing natural gas this winter. Despite the assumption that gas is becoming less competitive with oil, many of them are convinced that certain natural gas companies will prosper.

title: Panel on Cape's Development Gains Backing
description: Cape Cod may soon get what environmentalists have been working for all year: a commission to control all development that would affect the cape's environment or endanger its water supplies and coastline.

title: The Picture Points the Way
description: WORLD War II did not end on Aug. 29, 1944, when the United States Army paraded through Paris, past the Arc de Triomphe and down the Champs Elysees.

title: Correction
description: A front-page headline in the Travel section today carries an incorrect page number for an article about the abbeys of Wiltshire, England. The article is on page 27, not page 8.

title: BACK ALLEYS OF PSYCHODYNAMICS
description: AGAINST THERAPY Emotional Tyranny and the Myth of Psychological Healing. By Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson. 279 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: FELONS IN THE SUGAR BOWL
description: TWO BAD ANTS Written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. 31 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Correction
description: A report on Oct. 30 about the marriage of Carolyn Ann Rubin and Robert Michael Kelly referred incorrectly to the bridegroom's paternal grandmother. She is Edna Flannery, not ''the late.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Tracing Families Through Ellis I.
description: AMID screeching power saws and hammer blows, Philip Lax wandered along dusty corridors in the main immigration building, just as his parents had in the 1920's.

title:
GARDENING;
Conditions Are Right, but Moss Is Rare
description: LEAD: EARLY in this century, when the William Bayard Cutting family strolled through their estate on the South Shore of Long Island, they tread on soft, lush carpets of moss. The paths were covered with mosses, and were swept clean of fallen leaves daily.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Intensifying Competition; Northeast Fishermen Catch Everything, And That's a Problem
