description: USING new technologies to supplement their ancestral ''sixth sense'' about the sea, New England fishermen can catch more fish now than ever before. But greater efficiency has become a curse for the fishermen, who have seriously depleted the region's prime fishing waters, Georges Bank and the Gulf of Maine, raising questions about whether those waters can ever be restocked.

title: U.S.C. Breezes To 50-0 Victory
description: The afternoon in the sun was considered a potentially dangerous stop on the way to the decisive moments of the football season at the University of Southern California.

title: Terms for Manning
description: The negoiations were tough, but Danny Manning, who led Kansas to the collegiate basketball championship last spring, has reached agreement with the Los Angeles Clippers on a five-year contract that will pay him $10.5 million.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CARTOON DISPLAY

title: Look-Alike House And the Law
description: LOOK-ALIKE houses may be common in moderately priced developments. But when a couple in Scarsdale, N.Y., began to build a house that was almost identical to a $2.2 million custom one on the same block, the builder of the first house sued.

title: Effect of a P.L.O. Shift on U.S. Policy Unclear
description: For more than a decade, the United States has insisted that it will not deal with the Palestine Liberation Organization until the group meets certain conditions.

title: Sanctions Squeeze South Africa
description: REACTING to the victory of Vice President George Bush in last week's American Presidential election, the commentary on state-controlled radio here welcomed the fact that Mr. Bush had opposed his country's imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa. But South African Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha warned that with a strengthened Democratic majority in both houses of Congress, supporters of further sanctions might try to test Mr. Bush early in his term. ''A Bush victory does not mean that South Africa has escaped sanctions,'' Mr. Botha said.

title: Old Timers Out for a Spin Cut a Couple of Disks
description: The two records under consideration here might be lumped together under the title ''geezers at play,'' except that one (the far better one) sounds like playful geezers and the other like geezers hard at work to recapture something long lost.

title:
DINING OUT;
Atmosphere of a Hotel Dining Room
description: LEAD: DINING at Heritage House is like eating in hotel dining rooms: the food is comfortably familiar, if unexciting, and no worse than that in many other places in the area; and the atmosphere is grand yet aseptic. Apart from the noise compounded by the high ceilings, the dining room at Heritage House has a restful atmosphere that taken together with unhurried pacing and moderate prices makes tolerable work of dining here.

title: Great Panes
description: CLEANING AND REFURBISHING a stained-glass window is a painstaking task, accomplished piece by piece; which makes Harvard University's restoration of 100 windows in Memorial Hall an impressive labor of patience. The first window was removed in April 1987; the project's completion is planned for 1992.

title: Upper West Side Story: No Rest for the Wary
description: The question: Now that Donald Trump is considering selling his Trump City development site, will the community group formed to fight him claim victory and disband? The answer: ''Absolutely not,'' said Sandor Katz, the executive director of Westpride. Tomorrow night, the group will hold a cabaret benefit to replenish its war chest. ''We view this as a victory celebration, phase one,'' Mr. Katz said. ''We never viewed the problem as Donald Trump. We always viewed the problem to be the excessive proposal for the site.'' The 76-acre Trump City, called Television City until last year, would include a 152-story tower and eight 60-story buildings.

title: For Neil Simon, the Prescription Was Farce
description: ''I was going through some difficult times,'' Neil Simon says. ''This marriage I was in was breaking up. My daughter's husband was killed in an automobile accident. It seemed like rough going. And I said I wanted to work, because work is always a cathartic process for me, and I thought it would be really good just to get into a comedy.''

title: NONFICTION
description: THE GRAMMAR OF JUSTICE. By Elizabeth H. Wolgast. (Cornell University, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $9.95.) Democracy, equal rights and, especially, justice are concepts often invoked but seldom examined; so it is singularly useful to read Elizabeth H. Wolgast's clear-sighted and thought-provoking essays. Ms. Wolgast, a professor of philosophy at California State University in Hayward and the author of ''Equality and the Rights of Women,'' argues in ''The Grammar of Justice'' that our underlying principles square rather badly with common sense and everyday practice. For example, in a society predicated on the existence of certain basic rights, held equally by everyone, Ms. Wolgast asks, how are we to understand the debate over abortion? The fetus is not exactly a person with the same rights you or I have; yet it is certainly not a mere piece of property attached to the woman who carries it. Ms. Wolgast also considers the theoretical problems of individual rights and responsibilities, representative governments as moral agents and the philosophical problems posed by punishment. It is time, she argues, for thoughtful application of a reality principle, so that our concepts of justice can acknowledge that women are different from men and children from parents, and that human beings live in communities in which people take responsibility for one another. No reader need agree with all her conclusions to find this a thought-provoking exploration of the philosophical ground on which American prejudices, instincts and rhetoric stand.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Albuquerque, N.M.;
description: DESPITE the city's high vacancy rates, construction will begin here early next year on a 12-year, $270 million mixed-use project with nearly two million square feet of office and retail space and a 400-room hotel on a prime 36-acre site.

title: Lowey Victory: Anatomy Of an Upset
description: ARI FLEISCHER, a member of Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi's staff, glanced up at the net of balloons hanging from the ballroom ceiling at the White Plains Hotel on election night last week and sighed.

title: Corrections
description: A table last week with an article about Centocor Inc. misstated the number of employees and the 52-week stock price range. The company has 390 employees and a stock-price range of $14.75 to $30.

title:
Haworth Journal;
Utility's Plans for Development Anger Townspeople
description: LEAD: THE Oradell Reservoir and fall foliage provide a splendid backdrop for joggers, bikers and hikers enjoying the crisp autumn air. The bucolic scene offers no hint of controversy, but a proposed development of land that involves parts of the Northern Valley has embroiled local townspeople in a dispute with the Hackensack Water Company.

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: I think that it is fine to be fascinated with our children, to be able to offer them the benefit of our experiences and to make them our No. 1 event. But it is equally important to let them be babies, kids, adolescents and young adults in time. Sometimes the benefit of all of our so-called wisdom should be filed on the shelf in exchange for a few moments of reading, playing and talking in the family room. Maybe we should all slow down a bit, try less to be such overachievers and work harder to bring a sense of community back to the family so that the next generation's innocence can be prolonged a bit. JOHN M. OPPENHEIMER Mill Valley, Calif.

title:
MUSIC;
'Magic Flute' Collaboration Bound For Newark
description: LEAD: MOZART'S ''Magic Flute'' is one opera that has inspired considerable debate and controversy as to the character and meaning of the work. In an equally powerful way, the opera has touched the imaginations of several important visual artists. A coming New Jersey production of the work, bound to arouse interest and excitement, is the Jerome Hines-Maurice Sendak-Frank

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, two pages are reversed in some copies of the Week in Review today. Page 23, the editorial page, and Page 3 occupy each other's positions.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Developers Looking for Space Turn West
description: LEAD: Despite sluggish sales of both new and old houses throughout the state, developers have been building in the open spaces of rural, 364-square-mile Warren County and are gambling many millions that the market will turn around.

title: >Children's Theater: It's in the Bag
description: LEAD: AN enormous four-foot paper bag circled about the stage shouting, ''My mother, my mother, where's my mother? Have you seen my mother?''

title: IN THE MIDST OF LIFE
description: SAYING GOOD-BYE TO GRANDMA By Jane Resh Thomas. Illustrated by Marcia Sewall. 48 pp. New York: Clarion Books/Ticknor & Fields. $13.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: DETERMINED TO BE HEARD
description: In his profile of four Americans whose cases will come before the United States Supreme Court, William Glaberson characterized his subjects as ''stubborn optimists,'' who risk scorn, delay and ultimate defeat in carrying their cases to our highest tribunal (''Determined to Be Heard,'' Oct. 2).

title: Free Calculators For Chicago Pupils
description: IN an attempt to make mathematics more of a real-life experience instead of an exercise in learning by rote, the Chicago Board of Education gave personal calculators to 167,000 elementary school pupils.

title: 'THE COMING OF ALL THINGS'
description: IN THE BEGINNING Creation Stories From Around the World. Told by Virginia Hamilton. Illustrated by Barry Moser. 161 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Blue-Blood Bazaar

title: Susan Earle and John F. Pultz Marry
description: The marriage of Susan Elizabeth Earle, a daughter of Lois MacKennan Earle of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Victor M. Earle 3d of New York, to John Francisco Pultz, a son of Mrs. Frederick D. Pultz of Memphis and the late Dr. Pultz, took place yesterday at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Alice Hamilton Davies, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Sophisticated Fare in an Office Complex
description: LISBON CAFE in Lake Success was filled on a recent Friday night. These were people who knew their way around. How did they all find the obscurely situated Lisbon Cafe? Even Sherlock Holmes would have been hard pressed to read the sketchy clues that lead to this subterranean surprise in an office complex, all but abandoned at night.

title: Khmer Rouge Moves Cambodians By the Thousands to Combat Area
description: The Khmer Rouge guerrilla group is moving thousands of Cambodians out of refugee camps in Thailand to areas of combat near the Thai-Cambodian border. The move is apparently part of a plan to re-enter Cambodia and seize territory as Vietnam withdraws its troops from the country.

title: Political Ban for Casinos Challenged
description: THE casino industry and regulatory agencies are locked in a legal battle over whether New Jersey went too far in restricting casino officials from participation in the political process, and the next arbiters to have their say will be three judges of the Appellate Division of Superior Court.

title:
FOCUS: Greenville, N.C.;
On Tobacco Farms, Land Is a Cash Crop
description: LEAD: Ralph C. Tucker Jr. operates a 3,000-acre farm on the outskirts of this eastern North Carolina town, growing tobacco, soybeans and corn. He leases about 500 of these acres and would like eventually to buy all the land he farms.

title: Time to Save the Species
description: To the Editor:

title: T. J. Campbell Married To Christina Bennett
description: The wedding of Christina Mary Bennett, a daughter of John A. Bennett of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mary G. Bennett, to Thomas Justin Campbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Campbell of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Stephen J. DeLuca, assisted by the Rev. Robert F. McCormick, performed the ceremony.

title: Tresca's Enemies
description: To the Editor:

title: Views on Gesture by Heiress
description: LEAD: WHEN the tobacco heiress Doris Duke posted $5.5 million in municipal bonds as bail for Imelda Marcos recently, she had to know that people in her Somerset County backyard would form some strong opinions about the action.

title: THE DEVIL IN A RED AND WHITE ASCOT
description: TAIL FEATHERS FROM MOTHER GOOSE The Opie Rhyme Book. Edited by Iona Opie. Illustrated by 62 artists. 125 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

title:
DANCE;
Nights of 'Candlelight' and 'Tripletalk'
description: LEAD: TAKE a girl in an evening dress and put her on a garden bench, turn on some love songs recorded by Tony Bennett and the dance will almost compose itself. ''By Candlelight,'' a humorous and romantic portrait of youthful socializing, choreographed by Nicholas Rodriguez for his modern-dance company, DanceCompass, will be performed Friday and Saturday at Montclair State

title: Ostriches From Oklahoma and Big Farms of Fish
description: THE relentless sun of last summer baked Russ and Diane Erdman's farm in Alma, Mo. But unlike some Missouri growers, the Erdmans at least had something to sell this year: blueberries, blackberries and tomatoes, all of which survived with irrigation.

title: ISLAND GETAWAY IN THE GULF OF MAINE
description: A midwinter island getaway - the prospect was irresistible, but not the Long March to Kennedy or Logan airport, the queuing up at ticket counter or security checkpoint, the home equity loan to pay for the trip.

title: Venerable 'Tartuffe' Is Still Contemporary
description: HOW can modern audiences fail to find associations, evangelical and entrepreneurial, in ''Tartuffe,'' Moliere's 319-year-old classic comedy about chicanery and fraud?

title: HIS SOLDIERS DARED NOT FLINCH
description: SHAKA King of the Zulus. Written by Diane Stanley and Peter Vennema. Illustrated by Diane Stanley. Unpaged. New York: Morrow Books. $13.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: Sound Bite, Define Yourself!
description: WHEN, WEEKS from now, the hurry-up ''definitive'' history of the 1988 campaign is written, what word or phrase will emerge as the favorite locution of the election? What short, punchy sound bite most helps this campaign to define itself?

title: License Denied for Ferry Linking Boston to Island
description: Martha's Vineyard residents who complain about the hordes of tourists flocking here in the warm months have won a small victory. A direct ferry link from Boston has been denied a new license.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: The N.H.L. has the capabilities to stop major sticking incidents. The suspensions of Rick Tocchet, David Shaw and Mark Messier should be enough to warn players that excessive violence no longer will be tolerated. But perhaps the N.H.L. should also come up with an all-or-none penalty, thereby when a player is found guilty he receives a penalty of a certain number of games, with repeat offenders receiving more. DEBBIE BERN Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Anne Dillard Wed To Craig C. Perry
description: The wedding of Anne Douglas Dillard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Dillard of Winston-Salem, N.C., to Craig Crane Perry, a son of Mrs. Foster Story Osborne of West Orange, N.J., and the late Henry Ernest Perry, took place last evening at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Winston-Salem. The Rev. E. Dudley Colhoun performed the ceremony.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: On the day I started reading George Turner's major new novel, DROWNING TOWERS (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95), the Environmental Protection Agency called for studies of the effects of coastal flooding over the next two decades, just in case the ''greenhouse effect'' elevates global temperatures as predicted and the polar ice caps melt. I hope someone in the agency has the sense to consult Mr. Turner, an Australian writer whose account of a 21st-century Melbourne awash in a rising sea should give nightmares to the least impressionable bureaucrat.

title: MARCHERS SALUTE EDITOR WHO QUIT
description: Two hundred marchers held a mock funeral in New Orleans style in Atlanta's streets today, mourning the ''death of a free press'' here.

title: Leonardo of the Links
description: STEERING A GOLF CART ACROSS THE PRECIPITOUS fairways of Bossey, his mountainous course in eastern France, just across the border from Geneva, Robert Trent Jones Jr. points to several sand traps and greens, explaining that he is the only landscaper capable of having designed them.

title: New York Gives A Bank a Break; The Return Is Uncertain
description: THE kind of high-stakes deal-making that persuaded Chase Manhattan to move 5,000 workers to Brooklyn is fundamental to the governmental strategy of using real estate development to promote social objectives. By wooing and steering development, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo believe, New York City can revitalize neighborhoods by luring companies to move in, keep jobs and provide job training for the people with few skills who make up a substantial segment of the city's labor force, and prop up ailing manufacturers.

title: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN SINGERS: Twenty-Seven Portraits in Song. By Whitney Balliett. (Oxford University, $19.95.) Whitney Balliett's fine eye for detail and love for music are apparent in these portraits of popular singers as different as Margaret Whiting and Ray Charles. The pieces, all but one of which first appeared in The New Yorker, are cast in a mold that will be familiar to Mr. Balliett's fans. Each subject is introduced by several paragraphs of the author's unflaggingly patrician prose, studded with a few of his patented metaphors that range from quick and precise (Nellie Lutcher, at the piano, holds herself ''straight as a ladderback'') to ambitious (blues shouter Big Joe Turner moves through a nightclub like ''a house being moved down a road'') to bizarre (Julius La Rosa's dog lies on the floor, looking ''like a Welsh mountain range''), and one or two bold but dubious generalizations (Tony Bennett is the ''most widely admired American popular singer''; Joe Turner is ''probably the greatest of blues singers''). After the introduction, the author usually cedes the floor to his subject, who holds forth in his or her own words for the rest of the profile. This approach, which Mr. Balliett takes as predictably as a horse that follows the same route home no matter who's riding, makes for good oral history but slightly dim reading. But none of these portraits is without value and the best of them are fine indeed. For anyone interested in American popular song, ''American Singers'' will be worthwhile.

title: John N. Mitchell Is Remembered As a Victim of 'Cruel Treatment'
description: Before a gathering that included former President Richard M. Nixon, John N. Mitchell was eulogized today as ''a stand-up guy,'' a man who ''went through the most unfair, cruel treatment of a public figure in the life of this city.''

title: Books From The Times
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES GREAT LIVES OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY. Edited by Arthur Gelb, A. M. Rosenthal and Marvin Siegel. (Times Books, $29.95.) Unmatchable creativity, whether artist or politician, is the underlying theme in the lives of the 50 people whose New York Times obituaries make up this first volume in a series edited by three editors of The Times. With appraisals, news stories, photographs and selections from the subjects' works, these biographies delineate an era: ''the beginning of our careers as editors in 1963 to the present,'' writes A. M. Rosenthal, the Times columnist and former executive editor. Here are Felix Frankfurter, Golda Meir, Jackie Robinson, Pablo Casals, Zhou Enlai, the world as they saw it, and as The Times reported it - and them.

title: Social Havoc With a Giddy Air
description: When, in our own ways, we try to cope with life's overwhelming, and usually overwhelmingly petty, demands, why is it that we are judged demented failures or hopeless losers when things don't turn out conformably? Why isn't it ever life's fault?

title: TV's Tormented Master
description: IT COULD BE SAID THAT MY ILLNESS, AL-though my enemy, is also my ally, my ally in that it removes me from the hustle and bustle and makes me redefine myself. It makes me introspective.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our wood garage door faces south and has been varnished several times with either a marine varnish or a polyurethane. After several months the varnish begins peeling. Our painter suggests we use paint instead of stain and varnish. What is your opinion?

title: TV Executive Elected Officer Of Rockefeller Foundation
description: Hugh Price, a senior vice president and director of WNET/Thirteen's Production Center, has been elected a vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation.

title: Findings of a Trashologist
description: SPECIALIZATION has gone amok. I've heard of a doctor who treats only diseases of the elbow and of a lawyer who confines his practice to cases involving fishermen. I know an actor who plays only uncle roles, and there are surely a lot of flambeau chefs who perform only at tableside. I, too, have a special ability. I am a trashologist. Some would call my talent custodial expertise. Others would say I am a janitorial environmentalist. But I pursue my calling seven days a week, and my proficiency has made it a profession, even a science. I am a tried and true trashologist.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DESPERATE MEASURES. James Hannah. (Southern Methodist University, $14.95.) James Hannah's first collection of short stories features a curious cast of Southern eccentrics. The first is Susan, married to a pyromaniac who also beats her. Then there's Junior Jackson, who ends up in prison, a victim of bad luck.

title: How 'The Devil' Hauled Shaw Up From Hell
description: In 1896, when he was 40, Bernard Shaw's sense of failure had brought him to the verge of physical collapse. For the past year he had been making a living in London as a drama critic at $10 a week, but the sheer drudgery was causing headaches and neuralgia. He was the author of five unsuccessful novels and of seven plays, only three of which had achieved noncommercial productions before small audiences. The best of these, ''Candida,'' had been taken on by the actor-director Richard Mansfield, but abandoned as impossible in rehearsal. Shaw was becoming discouraged and physically run down; he wrote to the actress Ellen Terry, ''Oh, Ellen, I am the world's packhorse; and it beats my lean ribs unmercifully.'' But in the autumn of 1896, his talent for self-advertisement brought him an interesting commission, which led to his first success: ''The Devil's Disciple.'' (A revival of the play, starring Philip Bosco, Victor Garber, Roxanne Hart, Rosemary Murphy and Remak Ramsay, opens tonight at the uptown Circle in the Square.) William Terriss, the actor-manager of the Adelphi Theater, was the greatest living exponent of melodrama - those absurd plays in which the hero is exposed to a preposterous series of dangers, which he overcomes with manly fortitude and heroic self-sacrifice. More often than not his name was Tom or Dick, and he wore an open-necked shirt that exposed a muscular chest.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: No. In order to overcome the American male stereotype that guys who like to skate and speak French are ''sissies,'' the stickings and fights will continue. Otherwise hockey will attract just as many American viewers as that other great ice sport, curling. ROBERT J. MOORE Bloomfield, N.J.

title: Swing Vote Is Alive and Well
description: LONG ISLANDERS proved to be stronger swing voters than their statewide counterparts last Tuesday, and in the process laid the groundwork for what looms as one of the most significant races in the state next year: the contest for Nassau County Executive.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The First Olympics - Athens 1896 Starring Louis Jourdan, David Ogden Stiers, Edward Wiley, Hunt Block, Hutton Cobb, Jason Connery, Angela Lansbury, Gayle Hunnicutt. Directed by Alvin Rakoff. 1984. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Entertainment. 4 hours, 46 minutes. $69.95. Not rated.

title: Crack Use on the Rise in Suburbs
description: WHEN crack became a commodity about three years ago, trafficking in the drug was strictly an urban phenomenon.

title: Gun Control Backers Say Maryland Victory Will Spread to Other States
description: Advocates of gun control view the Maryland referendum last Tuesday upholding a law banning certain pistols as the beginning of a tide of victories in other states and in Congress.

title: Demand for Affordable Housing Helps Slow Redlining
description: Heavy demand for affordable housing in New York City has stimulated investment in neighborhoods that used to be terra incognita for lenders.

title: Mr. Bush: Talk to the P.L.O.
description: LEAD: The startling results of the Israeli elections, which offer the prospect of a Likud Party-led coalition as the next government, can hardly cheer those who hope for a negotiated resolution of the Palestinian problem and a diplomatic settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Indeed, continued political stalemate and escalating violence would seem to be the near-term prospect.

title: Paper Pacts
description: To the Editor:

title: Kin of Ex-Seoul Chief Seized
description: Government prosecutors today arrested the brother and cousin of former President Chun Doo Hwan on corruption charges, bringing to seven the number of Mr. Chun's family members arrested so far. Arrested today were Chun Kee Hwan, 59 years old, the older brother of the former President, and his cousin, Chun Woo Hwan, 55. The two were charged with taking bribes or diverting official funds.

title: U.S. Mediates 2d Day of Talks on Namibia
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, met with a South African delegation today in the second day of American-mediated talks for a settlement in Namibia and Angola.

title: Oyster Bay Collecting Junk Mail
description: LEAD: JUNK mail is living up to its name in the Town of Oyster Bay, where 5,000 households are participating in a pilot program to bundle up the mail along with their discarded newspapers and set it out for curbside pickup.

title: Singing Their Way to Paris
description: LA MARSEILLAISE Starring Pierre Renoir and Louis Jouvet. Directed by Jean Renoir. 1938. Interama Video Classics. 130 minutes. $39.95.

title: Taking the Hard Road With Black Athletes
description: My three-volume book, ''A Hard Road to Glory: A History of the African- American Athlete,'' began almost as an afterthought to a seminar class I was asked to give on the historical and sociological role of the African-American athlete. Though I had never seen it, I assumed some esteemed black historian, sociologist or sports reporter had compiled the entire story of the black athlete in one volume. A search found only ''The Negro in Sports,'' by Edwin B. Henderson, written in 1938 and slightly updated in 1948.

title: Philadelphia Cab Drivers Wary After Slaying
description: The fifth slaying of a taxi driver this year in Philadelphia has made cabbies wary about whom they pick up, where they go and when they work.

title: An Esoteric List
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse Recovers, 45-20
description: Todd Philcox bounced back from a shaky start to throw for three touchdowns and Syracuse rolled to its seventh straight victory in defeating Boston College, 45-20, today.

title: Keeping Terrorism's Advocates Off British Air
description: To the Editor:

title: For $50, Professor Provides a Laugh
description: At first glance, it seems like a typical morning in English class at Manhattanville College. But the faces of these freshmen and sophomores are not buried silently in Chaucer or stealing glances at the clock.

title: New Smoking Code Going to Legislators
description: LEAD: A NEW set of regulations to govern smoking in the county could take effect next summer if the Board of Legislators adopts a measure that its chairman, Edward J. Brady, plans to introduce this month.

title: Senegal Postpones a Black Cultural Festival
description: A world festival of black culture, which was expected to draw thousands of black Americans to this West African capital next June, has been postponed indefinitely, the authorities here say.

title: Fare of the Country; Philadelphia's Twist on the Pretzel
description: Along with the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, the soft pretzel is at home in Philadelphia. With an estimated 300,000 consumed daily in the city, it's no wonder that the comedian David Brenner, who is a native son, called his recent book ''Soft Pretzels With Mustard.'' Perhaps the ultimate street food, this humble twist of bread may today seem indigenously Philadelphian, but its history goes back 1,300 years.

title: O RINGS AND THE OSCILLATORY WA-WA
description: ''WHAT DO YOU CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' Further Adventures of a Curious Character. By Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: Millicent Carter to Have Bridal
description: The engagement of Millicent Gwendolyn Carter to Richard Carlton Hackney Jr., a son of Gertrude P. Hackney of Atlanta and the late Dr. Hackney, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Bernard Carter of Riegelwood, N.C., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; A Family Works
description: For Legal Change Your article was brought to our attention by Dorothy Holmgren, executive director of Parents on the Move, Long Island, who we have worked very closely with on a common goal, that being raising PINS age in New York State to 18 and lowering financial liability of parents to 18.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, an article on Oct. 30 about the Museum of Flight in Seattle omitted a passage. The section should have read: ''The museum reminds visitors that the first craft to fly under its own power was not the Wright Brothers' plane in 1903, but a European model, the Eole, which traveled 160 feet on Oct. 9, 1890, powered by a 20-horsepower steam engine. It looked like a big blue bat. At the same time a German, Otto Lilienthal, contributed enormously to flight design with his gliders.''

title: Cardinals Facing Another Blackout
description: Eight months ago, when the National Football League voted to allow the St. Louis Cardinals to move to Phoenix, this growing Sun Belt city was ecstatic. Now that the Cardinals are here and contending for a playoff berth, the greatest emotion they have evoked is anger stemming from the highest ticket prices in pro football.

title: Love Can Mean Saying Goodbye
description: I JUST took my husband to the airport for the third time in a month. My husband is a film maker, and the three-month project he is working on in the Northwest has turned us into a bicoastal family. We are always saying goodbye. Even when we say hello I hear the echo of parting in the background.

title: HOMEWARD BOUND FOR SHELTER AND PROFITS
description: Striking it rich from a primary residence - the family home - is anything but easy.

title: Daniel Sponseller Marries Mary Frances Golden
description: The marriage of Mary Frances Golden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Golden Jr. of Teaneck, N.J., to Daniel Jerome Sponseller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer J. Sponseller of Lakewood, Ohio, took place yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tenafly, N.J. The Revs. John J. Higgins and Thomas R. Jordan performed the ceremony.

title: Doris Yu Weds Dr. William Ju
description: Doris Yu, a daughter of Grace Yu of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Kuo-Ping Yu, was married in New York yesterday to Dr. William David Ju, the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Ju of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Philip Clarke performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist. Barbara Yu Larsson was maid of honor for her sister. Chesley Milton Chen was best man.

title: 5 Finnish U.N. Soldiers Held By Armed Squad in Lebanon
description: Five armed men seized a command post of Finnish peacekeeping soldiers in southern Lebanon tonight, an official said.

title: Hempstead Pounds Port Washington
description: LONG ISLAND

title: TREASURES OF THE HAPSBURGS IN VIENNA
description: The splendidly termed Secular and Ecclesiastical Treasuries of the House of Hapsburg, together with the Insignia and Jewels of the Holy Roman Empire, the Hapsburgs' Burgundian Inheritance and the Order of the Golden Fleece make up an astounding monument to the magnificence, religiosity and cupidity of Europe's premier royal family. The Hapsburgs traced their family roots to the 10th century and as an Austrian dynasty to King Rudolf of Hapsburg in the 13th century and only passed into history themselves with the abolition of the Austro-Hungarian Empire at the end of World War I. The refurbished Treasure Chamber of the Hapsburg Emperors in Vienna, which was closed from late 1983 to early 1987 for restoration, occupies two sides of the Schweizerhof courtyard in the capital's old Imperial Palace, known as the Hofburg. This rambling edifice comprises a series of interconnected courtyards dating from the Middle Ages and leading to an immense domed palace that epitomizes the gaudy splendor of the empire's final days. The Treasure Chamber consists of some 20 rooms and has been modernized, with new lighting installed and the ornate, rococo showcases regilded and cleaned. A new visitors entrance has been built, with cloakrooms and a big souvenir shop selling postcards and guides. (Despite improvements, though, the chamber is usually crowded. The free English guide available at the entrance of little help: it is almost incomprehensible.) The chamber, first organized on its present scale by the Empress Maria Theresa in 1747, is stuffed with the priceless booty of six centuries of royal rule over vast tracts of Europe, successful wars and carefully arranged dynastic marriages. Here you can see what were revered in the Middle Ages as St. Peter's tooth and a nail from the Holy Cross, as well as a bowl once thought to be the Holy Grail and crowns, jewels, scepters and other treasures beyond the wildest dreams of avarice. The chamber contains splendid robes and regalia, ornate reliquaries of exquisite workmanship, sacred vessels of gold and silver, rare jewels and bizarre and costly curiosities that together paint the story of the family's brilliant past.

title: 'YOU BAKE, SOMEONE EATS IT, IT'S GONE'
description: MIDNIGHT SWEETS By Bette Pesetsky. 206 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: The Non-Collector
description: Once again, a New Yorker reports, she's lost her chance to be a Serious Collector of Popular Culture. How? She threw out the Dino the Dinosaur thermos that, filled with soybean milk, accompanied her daughter, the allergic one, to nursery school in 1966.

title: The Set Is His Game
description: The wallpaper is a deep green, the wood paneling well burnished. The walls are busy with signed programs and photographs of stars from the Yiddish theater of the 1940's. Pickle jars anchor round tables that are just close enough to make kibbitzing convenient. When the actors in the Public Theater's revival of Hy Craft's ''Cafe Crown'' walk onto this set, they walk into a corner of Santo Loquasto's New York.

title: O'Rourke Plan on County Tourism
description: LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke is preparing a new plan that would turn over the marketing of tourism in Westchester to an outside concern, chosen through bids and overseen by an advisory board of public and private individuals.

title: Odets's Vision of Revolution
description: CLIFFORD ODETS'S ''Awake and Sing,'' first produced in 1935 by New York's legendary Group Theater, remains a prime example of 1930's social idealism.

title: Parking At Beach May End
description: LEAD: FOR as far back as anyone can remember, Peters Pond Lane, the road leading to Peters Pond Beach in Sagaponack, has always been free; that is, cars parked on the road need not have Southampton Town stickers, thus making the spot a popular one for beach day trippers.

title: IT'S ART, BUT IS IT PHOTOGRAPHY?
description: Sherrie Levine reshoots photographs by famous photographers and ''sells her small black-and-white fakes for $2,000 because of their conceptual-art links to Duchamp and Warhol.'' To prove her integrity, ''she makes only one image from each appropriated photograph . . . unique copies.'' So what does The New York Times Magazine do? It reproduces in the article a photograph of her photograph of a photograph.

title: For New Atom Plant Contractor, a Daunting Task
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which has been hired by the Government to save the nation's two biggest nuclear weapon factories as well as a third, smaller plant, concedes that it has been guilty of some of the same managerial lapses as its predecessors there.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: To Inspire the Young

title: Special Today; Personal Investing/Section 3A
description: Diversification makes sense as the economy slows. Choosing a mutual fund. Balancing risks against rewards. Year-end tax tips. Bond investors are wary. Borrowing to build assets. Plus, baseball cards, futures funds, diamonds and investment pools.

title: Do Not Despair
description: THE Roman precept ''Nil Desperandum'' was recently translated for team players as ''Don't give up hope, the others may do worse.''

title: Mr. Reynolds Resigns
description: A Presidential election inevitably means a host of Government personnel changes. The announced resignation of William Bradford Reynolds, Assistant Attorney General for civil rights, is particularly noteworthy.

title: Dr. Emily Frosh to Be Married in May
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. William A. Frosch of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Emily Jane Frosch, to Dr. Christopher Vine Plowe, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Gordon R. Plowe of Minot, N.D. A May wedding is planned.

title: ARAFAT ASKS BUSH TO CHANGE COURSE
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today urged President-elect Bush to re-examine United States policy toward Israel.

title: CHILD ABUSE AND HAPPY ENDINGS
description: In discussing the revival of interest in old-fashioned fairy tales adapted for ballet and musical comedy, Bruno Bettelheim last year restated his optimistic view that we are drawn to fairy tales because they give the child in us a chance to fulfill our childish wishes for a perfect world of enchantment. Most adults would probably agree with him. Don't we always talk primarily about the happy ending or the utopian aspect of the stories? Don't they all result in triumph for the oppressed girl like Cinderella, the small guy like Tom Thumb?

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FINAL THINGS. By John Sligo. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) The three protagonists in this compelling trio of novellas by the New Zealand writer John Sligo are linked by their struggle to escape what binds them, whether it's the provincialism of small-town life, impending death or a poisoning sense of guilt.

title: THE BEST CANDIDATES MONEY CAN BUY
description: HONEST GRAFT Big Money and the American Political Process. By Brooks Jackson. 337 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. THE NEW AMERICAN POLITICIAN Ambition, Entrepreneurship, and the Changing Face of Political Life. By Burdett Loomis. 275 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95

description: SWAN SKY Written and illustrated by Tejima. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 7)

title: DETERMINED TO BE HEARD
description: The fact that Melody DeShaney's lawsuit has gotten as far as the Supreme Court shows the degree of lunacy that the tort system has achieved. By her own admission, Ms. DeShaney abandoned custody of her son to her husband, Randy. She must have known of his violent tendencies. After all, she lived with him. Ann Kemmeter, the social worker, did not.

title: BETTER TO STAY THAN TO LEAVE
description: COLLECTED POEMS By Louis Simpson. 385 pp. New York: Paragon House. $24.95.

title: Cable TV Rates Soar to 82%
description: CABLE television companies have raised their rates as much as 82 percent since deregulation in 1986, according to State Consumer Counsel James F. Meehan.

description: LEAD: ON THEIR TOES

title: Review/Dance; Kumiko Kimoto's Map of the Clouds
description: One thing no one did in Kumiko Kimoto's ''Lost Maps/Walking Like a Velvet Cloud'' was to walk like a cloud.

title: Burglar Strangles Bronx Woman in Her Bedroom
description: A 70-year-old Bronx woman was strangled early yesterday by a man who broke into her home, apparently in a robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Center Guides Inventors From Dreams to Reality
description: James Norris, Murray Benjamin and Wesley Adams are men of different backgrounds, education and residence, but they share a common love: inventing.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Lessons of a Virus Attack; It's Clear Now: A System Can Be Too User-Friendly
description: WITH a few measured keystrokes, Robert T. Morris, the 23-year-old Cornell University computer prodigy, did more than bring a nationwide Pentagon data network to its knees on Nov. 2. He has raised troubling questions about the very limits of openness in a society that increasingly depends on an unfettered flow of information.

title: Quiet Power Endures
description: A solemn ceremony here the day after U.S. elections brought into focus the difference between the power of public position, with its heady trappings, and the power of a man with an idea. It was the centennial of the birth of Jean Monnet. His remains were brought from the rural cemetery where he was buried in 1979 to the Pantheon, the majestic resting place for those to whom France reserves its ultimate honor.

title: A Brief Season's Spare Beauty
description: FAREWELL I saw old Autumn in the misty morn, Stand shadowless like silence listening. THOMAS HOOD

title: Renewed Drive to Oust Lilco Gains
description: LEAD: KEY opponents of the Shoreham nuclear-power plant are supporting a renewed drive to replace the plant's owner, the Long Island Lighting Company, with a public power authority.

title: A Launching at Electric Boat
description: The nuclear-powered attack submarine Miami became today the first submarine to be launched at the Electric Boat shipyard here since a bitter three-month strike ended Oct. 11 with a contract ratification. During the ceremony to mark the launching, an anti-nuclear weapons group, the Coalition to Stop the Trident, demonstrated outside the shipyard. Stephen Kobasa, a protest organizer, said today's effort was a warmup for a month of vigils and demonstrations at Trident production operations in New England to begin Dec. 17 with the launch of the Trident submarine Tennessee.

title: DATA BANK: November 13, 1988
IDEAS & TRENDS: Lessons of a Virus Attack; How Secrecy on Atomic Weapons Helped Breed a Policy of Disregard

description: Mike Lodish stole the ball from the quarterback, Brian Johnson, and ran 17 yards for a touchdown in the third quarter to put U.C.L.A. ahead for good today as the Bruins beat Stanford, 27-17.

title: POLITICAL VIOLENCE UP IN GUATEMALA IN RECENT MONTHS
description: Human rights violations, including kidnappings, torture and murder, have sharply increased in recent months, especially in rural areas where the Guatemalan Government's authority is weakest, according to rights monitors, Roman Catholic Church officials and Western diplomats here.

title: Insulating Above a Basement
description: In winter, an unheated basement or crawl space can act like a block of ice beneath the rooms above.

title: RISK VS. REWARD: A BALANCING ACT
description: The amount of risk an individual is willing to assume when investing depends more on the person than on the investment. An investor's age, income, short- and long-term goals play important roles when deciding where to put money to work. A 24-year-old single investor might go for a big return with options or commodities. If there's a loss, which is likely, there is plenty of time to make it up. However, a 66-year-old retiree should avoid these investments because of their volatility.

title: New Color Film Has High Quality
description: COMPROMISE is as much as part of color film as it is of life. We'd all like to have an ultra-fast, ultra-sharp, ultra-vivid emulsion residing in the cameras, preferably one that would also countenance underexposure and overexposure without complaint. Then we could shoot away in all manner of conditions without a care in the world. But such is the stuff of pipe dreams.

description: ''Wall Street never changes. Only the pockets change.'' Jesse Livermore

The battered dollar tumbled to its lowest levels in many months against the yen and the mark, reflecting a lack of confidence that the United States is any closer to solving its No. 1 economic problem, the huge Federal budget deficit.

description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Storm of Protest
description: The special memorial session of the West German Parliament was to mark the 50th anniversary of Kristallnacht, the pogrom that confirmed the full fury of the Nazis against the Jews in Germany. But the address by the speaker, Philipp Jenninger, set off a political storm instead. Mr. Jenninger, a senior member of the governing Christian Democratic Party, tried to show that most Germans had let themselves be ''blinded and seduced'' by the Nazis to remind Germans of the enthusiasm of their ancestors in the rise of Hitler. About 50 members of Parliament walked out, accusing the speaker of seeming to justify the Nazi era. Mr. Jenninger later resigned, saying in his letter of resignation, ''My speech was not understood by many of those who heard it in the way I meant it.''

title: Deborah Jones, a Painter, Plans To Wed in April
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Gordon H. Dalsemer of Baltimore of the engagement of her daughter Deborah Lynn Jones to Christopher Ervin Buck, the son of Haydee Buck of Katonah, N.Y., and Dr. Peter Buck of Danbury, Conn. An April wedding is planned.
