title: Reviews/Music; Rock From the Beatnigs
description: It was election night in the packed Pyramid club as well on Tuesday night, and the Beatnigs, an exciting new group from San Francisco, delivered a scathing indictment of the eight years of Reaganism to an appreciative audience.

title: Correction
description: A Travel Advisory report on Oct. 30 gave an incorrect source for information about entry into Japan without a visa after Dec. 15. To avoid being turned away, travelers who have been denied visas and those with prison records may approach the Japanese Embassy or a Japanese consulate before they depart.

title: From Norwalk, a Game For Real Football Fans
description: AS a young boy, Matt Cavanaugh of Norwalk was enchanted by board games of virtually every type. ''He'd play them by the hour with his sister, Lisa, or with friends,'' his father, Hugh, recalled. ''But then he'd often get bored by the games and, starting at about the age of 9, he'd make up his own games.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
Apartheid Is Misunderstood
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: China Seeks American Help For an Educational Overhaul
description: China is turning to an American foundation to help it overhaul its university system with a view to using such non-socialist devices as an education tax and the imposition of tuitions.

title: Review/Pop; 2 Musical Homelands In Songs by Los Lobos
description: On Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, David Hidalgo of Los Lobos sang, ''Dos idiomas y dos paises/Dos culturas tengo yo.'' (''Two languages and two homelands/Two cultures have I.'') The song, by the norteno group Los Pinguinos from South Texas, sums up Los Lobos's position as the leading Mexican-American band (and probably the only one known to most of Los Lobos's English-speaking audience). With the album ''La Pistola y el Corazon'' and with Los Lobos's current tour, the band reaffirms its allegiance to Mexican music. The instrumentation is fiddle, accordion, acoustic guitars of various sizes, drums and an occasional soprano saxophone; the songs are in Mexican traditional styles, and the lyrics are in Spanish.

title: One Who Has Outgrown His Salad Days
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mystical Force of Bartok's Quartets
description: When the Emerson String Quartet first performed all six Bartok quartets in a single evening, at Alice Tully Hall in 1981 on the occasion of the composer's centenary, it smacked of youthful bravado if not a publicity stunt. Along with Beethoven's late quartets, these number among the most concentrated and astringent works in the genre, intensely demanding of performer and listener alike.

title: A Bigger American Following for Industrial Design
description: AFTER more than a decade of reacting to Japanese and European imports, American manufacturers are starting to regain the initiative in developing new products. In doing this, they are finding that good design, a web of esthetics and quality, is crucial.

title: Stymied Warriors
description: SUDDENLY, THE CODE WORDS are given and the nocturnal tranquility of the desert is shattered by the staccato sound of automatic arms fire and jarring explosions. In minutes, a small commando group has successfully completed its mission - storming the buildings, killing the terrorists and rescuing the hostages.

title: Good Times ahead for America
description: NUMEROUS articles and books have appeared recently that claim that America is in decline. Americans are living beyond their means and on borrowed time. Our prosperity is an illusion, say the pessimists - a day of reckoning is coming.

title: Court Upholds State Charges Against Coroner in Queens
description: An appeals court this week upheld the censure of the medical examiner in charge of Queens for mistakes in an autopsy in 1982 on a shooting victim.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Williamstown, Mass.: Williams Buys Hill for Houses
description: LEAD: Williams College has bought 155 acres on Pine Cobble, a 1,895-foot hill popular with hikers, for 70 homesites for tenured faculty members and other senior staff people. It completed the $386,000 purchase this summer, hired a contractor to build roads and install utilities and hopes to complete basic site work by next fall.

title: 'This Is a Quality of Life Issue'
description: PHILIP SARREL, a gynecologist and sex therapist, is researching menopause at the Yale University School of Medicine in New Haven. His research, called the Yale Mid-Life Study, is now in its fourth and final year.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
UPWARD MOBILITY IN THE KITTY GHETTO
description: LEAD: CATWINGS By Ursula K. Le Guin. Illustrated by S. D. Schindler. 40 pp. New York: A Richard Jackson Book/Orchard Books.

title: FICTION
description: THE RUB OF THE GREEN. By William Hallberg. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Ted Kendall, the narrator of this poignant, beautifully written first novel, loses himself in alcohol and hopelessly romantic dreams. He finds himself in golf, which becomes his life but not quite his salvation. ''At first,'' he tells us, ''golf was only a green shade protecting me from the gathering white heat of my mother's death.'' From that beginning, with a style that is at once lyric and spare, William Hallberg uses alternating chapters to take us back and forth in time. In the past, Ted hones his considerable talent and earns a golf scholarship to Ohio State. There he befriends Dave Traynham, the long driver and giant ego of the university golf team, and falls in love with Traynham's girlfriend, Janice. Along the way, he nurtures his dream of becoming a touring professional. Switching back to the present, Ted is in a Southern prison for a terrible deed that is somehow linked to Traynham and Janice. While in prison, he recruits other convicts to help him turn a patch of swamp into a two-hole golf course. It's the best way he knows to serve his time, and he vows to play those two holes before his release. By story's end, Ted will be free (or at least out of prison), but he knows that life offers too few second chances. ''The Rub of the Green'' is a story to be enjoyed by nongolfers and savored by those who love the game. Ted Kendall keeps on playing, through fairway and rough, always trying to follow through.

title: WHAT IT TOOK
description: What does a writer see that he didn't see before when he looks back at his published work? This is Thomas Farber's answer in ''Compared To What? On Writing and the Writer's Life'' (Norton).

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: PHYLLIS MACKLIN;
After Dismissal, Help in the Job Search
description: LEAD: PHYLLIS MACKLIN is in the business of helping executives who have been ''placed out'' of their companies look for the silver lining behind what is euphemistically called ''termination,'' ''outplacement,'' ''separation'' or ''relocation.'' In other words, if a person has been dismissed or laid off, he or she may turn to Ms.

title: Customs
description: To the Editor: Regarding Betsy Wade's article about buying duty-free products in developing nations (Practical Traveler, Aug. 14), tourists should be aware that many customs officials are unaware of these rules and may charge duty on the covered items.

title: America's Talent Can Still Soar
description: LEAD: If some genie came to me and offered any country to bet on or be part of in these decades to come, I would choose America - not only because of its wealth, size, scope and diversity, but because of its most valuable resource: talent.

title: When Machines Spawn Obsession
description: THE phenomenon is familiar in the world of ''hackers'': a young man of exceptional intelligence, feeling that he is alienated from the system and threatened by the real world, finds safety in the computer lab and develops an obsession for the technology. Shunning sleep, and limiting social relationships to the sphere of hackers with whom he shares his obsession, he pushes himself to his physical and mental limits in the quest for the ultimate hack, the fusion of elegant thought and computer code.

title: Barring the Door
description: 'Arafat should be denied access to our country until he and the P.L.O. renounce terrorism as a tool of foreign policy.' - 51 United States senators in a letter asking Secretary of State George P. Shultz to deny an expected request from Yasir Arafat for a visa to come to New York to address the United Nations.

title: Q and A; Tour de France
description: Question: I am a biking enthusiast and racer and would like to follow the Tour de France for two weeks next July. Are there any organized tours that feature the event? Would I have problems in shipping my bicycle to France? - M. C., Norwalk, Conn. Answer: Breaking Away Bicycle Tours has been running Tour de France trips for three years and has made plans for two programs starting and ending in Paris next July. (The race begins in the city of Luxembourg on July 1, goes to Belgium, then heads counterclockwise around France before finishing in Paris on July 23.) Breaking Away says bicyclists may ride as much or as little as they want with its escorted tours, which use support vans that carry luggage as well as bicycles, which go on the roof. Most participants take their own bicycles, but rentals in France can be arranged. The company's groups stay in a region along the route of the race for two or three days before moving on, ahead of the racers, to another. An escort and mechanics go along with each party, and an opportunity to meet some of the racers is scheduled. The first program, of eight days, is to begin July 5 when participants are met on arrival in Paris. The price (for land arrangements) is $995 a person, double occupancy, which includes transportation, country hotels with private baths, breakfasts and two dinners. A 12-day program, at $1,499, begins July 13, and travelers may sign up for both for the price of the two.

title: Justice and a Salty Sandwich Are Served in Pennsylvania
description: A judge has cleared a convenience store clerk of disorderly conduct for serving an oversalted ham sandwich. It was a practical joke that a state trooper with high blood pressure found in bad taste.

title: Facing the Problems
description: When Andrei Sakharov arrived in this country last week, on his first trip outside the Soviet Union, he spoke of how he respected the United States for its ''self-criticism.''

title: THOSE PEOPLE NEXT DOOR
description: BELONGING IN AMERICA Reading Between the Lines. By Constance Perin. 285 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $24.50.

title: A Bookshop's Problem With World Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: Images of An Earlier America - From a Spot Of Cannibalism To Exquisite Interiors
description: From the voyages of discovery onward there has been an unceasing demand for images of America, and until the invention of photography it was a demand supplied almost entirely by prints: engravings, woodcuts, etchings, aquatints, lithographs, decorative maps. The New York Public Library has one of the world's foremost collections of such material, and in ''Picturing America: 1497-1899,'' it has put on display some 80 of the more striking examples in its possession, along with a handful of related drawings and watercolors.

title: West Virginia Shrugs Off Rutgers
description: Rutgers, a team that has had more lows than highs this season, tested unbeaten West Virginia today at Giants Stadium and even held a brief early lead. But then the predictable happened and the mighty Mountaineers rolled to a comfortable victory, 35-25.

title: Vive la Difference
description: I CAME TO PARIS IN 1982 at the age of 30, met a Frenchwoman three years later, married her and settled down in France. The question was recently posed to me, and not for the first time: By doing this, was I rejecting the idea of life with an American woman?

title: Insects Taking a Severe Toll of Island's Pine Trees
description: LEAD: CERTAIN kinds of pine trees on Long Island have sustained unprecedented damage this year because of predatory insects.

title: The Top 20
description: 1 Duke 2 Georgetown 3 Oklahoma 4 Michigan 5 Syracuse 6 U.N.L.V. 7 Louisville 8 Arizona 9 West Virginia 10 Florida State 11 Villanova 12 Missouri 13 Arkansas 14 Oklahoma State 15 North Carolina 16 Georgia Tech 17 Iowa 18 Georgia 19 Connecticut 20 Illinois Why and How, Page 10

title: Quartet From Belgium
description: The Kuijken Quartet - Barthold Kuijken on transverse flute; Sigiswald Kuijken, violinist; Francois Fernandez, violist, and Wieland Kuijken, cellist - is to play an authentic-instruments performance of the four Mozart Flute Quartets at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, at 4 P.M. today. Tickets are $10. Information: 666-0675.

title: New Books That Can Help Investors
description: LEAD: WINNING WITH YOUR STOCKBROKER IN GOOD TIMES AND BAD. By David Koehler and Gene Walden. (Longman Financial Services, $19.95.)

title: College Top 20
description: College basketball's top teams as selected by William C. Rhoden of The New York Times. 1 Duke While Michigan has the better talent, Duke, anchored by the all-America Danny Ferry, has the staying power to end up on top when it counts. The key will be finding a defensive specialist to replace Billy King. 2 Georgetown Alonzo Mourning, the Hoyas' 6-10 prize recruit, makes Georgetown an instant contender for the Big East championship, and more. The backcourt is set with a rotation of Charles Smith, Jaren Jackson, Mark Tillmon and Dwayne Bryant. 3 Oklahoma If the Sooners had a flaw last season - and at 35-4 they didn't have many - it may have been an under-utilized bench. With Mookie Blaylock returning at guard and Stacey King at center, the Sooners can make a run at a second Final Four appearance. 4 Michigan It has become an annual ritual to discuss Michigan's talent in November and its disappointing elimination in March. With Rumeal Robinson and Sean Higgins in the backcourt, Terry Mills, Glenn Rice and Loy Vaught on the front line, the Wolverines are simply too talented - again - not to rank highly in the early going. 5 Syracuse The Orangemen's biggest problem will be chemistry, not talent. Billy Owens, the super freshman, joins a solid crew led by Sherman Douglas, the all-conference point guard, and Derrick Coleman, the 6-9 forward. 6 U.N.L.V. The Rebels are deep but inexperienced. Stacey Augmon, the sophomore forward, is the rock of this team and there are a host of talented newcomers. 7 Louisville After two seasons of meandering, it's about time for the Cardinals to focus on a national title. Four starters return from a 24-11 team that finished first in the Metro Conference. Pervis Ellison, the 6-9 forward, is the heart of the team. 8 Arizona The Wildcats won't get out of the blocks as quickly as they did last season, but they might actually be as tough a team in March. Sean Elliot is the Pacific-10's most complete player. 9 West Virginia Coach Gale Catlett had his string of seven straight 20-victory seasons snapped last year, but the Mountaineers should rebound with a vengeance with four starters returning. 10 Florida State Coach Pat Kennedy has four starters back and will push Louisville for the Metro championship. 11 Villanova The Wildcats turned what was supposed to have been a rebuilding season into a miraculous journey that ended just one game short of the Final Four. Rollie Massimino has four starters returning from that squad, including the conference's best backcourt: Doug West and Kenny Wilson. 12 Missouri Derrick Chievous is gone but the Tigers return all other starters -plus considerable firepower -from last season's 19-11 team. 13 Arkansas After three seasons of a rugged uphill climb, Nolan Richardson might be close to the moutaintop by the end of the season. 14 Oklahoma State Leonard Hamilton, the third-year coach, has quietly built a dynamo. This could be the season it kicks in. Watch his sophomore forward, Richard Dumas. 15 North Carolina Depending on how quickly and how well J. R. Reid's foot heals, North Carolina could be the force in the A.C.C. If Reid's foot does not heal quickly, the Tar Heels could find themselves muddled in the middle. 16 Georgia Tech If Bobby Cremins can find a point guard to complement Brian Oliver in the backcourt and get the ball to the forwards, Dennis Scott and Tom Hammonds, Georgia Tech might have something going. 17 Iowa The Hawkeyes have a strong returning nucleus in B. J. Armstrong, a guard, Ed Horton and Roy Marble, a forward. 18 Georgia The Bulldogs could be one of the surprises of the season, depending on the adjustment of the freshman guard, Litteral Green. 19 Connecticut Jim Calhoun has five starters back from a team that finished 20-14 and won the National Invitation Tournament. The best of the five is the center, Cliff Robinson. 20 Illinois The Illini, like Michigan, are perennially laden with talent. This season's team, despite not having a player over 6-8, is no exception. Look for a ferocious inside attack. Marcus Liberty, the 6-8 swingman returning from Proposition 48 banishment, could give this team an incredible lift.

title: Arrest Points Up Split in Animal-Rights Movement
description: A Queens animal-rights advocate who was arrested Friday on charges of planting a bomb outside a company that uses dogs in medical research was condemned and disavowed throughout the animal-rights movement yesterday.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Local Colleges; Fordham, Hofstra Near Playoff Bids
description: Fordham and Hofstra registered easy victories yesterday to remain in contention for second consecutive bids to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern playoffs. The bids will be announced today.

title: Christmas Hope Is Rekindled After the Wishes Are Stolen
description: It's a bit early for a Christmas story, but with 700 children's wishes still to fill and just six weeks left to do it, Anne Blair can't wait.

title: Vote Totals Still Not Known For Minor Party Candidates
description: George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis were not the only names on many state ballots in the Presidential race Tuesday, but the final vote totals for the minor party candidates will not be available for weeks, pending state certification of the tallies.

title: Canada's Business, Canada's Loss
description: Even if numbed by the distortions of their own political campaign, Americans may be startled to learn how they are currently portrayed by Canadian politicians: as hungry predators, poised to swarm across the 49th parallel and gobble everything in sight.

title: R. P. Hughes Wed To Miss Lessieu
description: At St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Charlotte, N.C., Catherine Anne Lessieu and Robert Pickens Hughes were married yesterday by the Rev. Walter Dziordz.

title: AS THE ECONOMY SLOWS, THE UNCERTAINTIES INCREASE
description: From nearly every economist, the message is loud and clear: the American economy is slowing down. The slowdown could turn into a recession next year or the year after. Or, ideally, the decline would halt short of a recession, and the economy would then settle into a low but satisfactory rate of growth -one that would last into the 1990's.

title: THE GUIDE
description: SOVIET CINEMA

title: Memories in a Worn Cookbook
description: IT swept over me today when I tried to find my old tried-and-true pastry recipe in the 1947 edition of ''The Joy of Cooking''; it is time for me to buy a new copy of the book.

title: THREE DIFFERNET ROUTES TO PERSONAL INVESTMENTS
description: ''A wise manwill make more opportunities than he finds.'' Francis Bacon

title: THE SCENE BEYOND THE CANVAS
description: LEAD: IMPRESSIONISM Art, Leisure, and Parisian Society. By Robert L. Herbert. Illustrated. 324 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press.

title: IT'S ART, BUT IS IT PHOTOGRAPHY?
description: In his article ''It's Art, but Is It Photography?'' (Oct. 9), Richard B. Woodward points out that an artist improves his economic situation greatly when his work is categorized as art rather than ''mere'' photography. One wonders, then, why Doug and Mike Starn, Barbara Kruger, Sherrie Levine and others don't simply walk away from the denigrating label of photographer and pronounce themselves fine artists, period.

title: Lyman Lemnitzer, 89, Dies; U.S. General and War Hero
description: Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, a World War II hero who later served as commander of United Nations forces in the Korean War, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, died of kidney failure yesterday at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Nature Centers Need the Support Of Government And the People
description: AS the heat of the summer of '88 gives way to the cooler days of fall, the volume of calls and visits to the Greenburgh Nature Center's Wildlife Information and Treatment Program is slowly beginning to taper off. Starting with February's intermittent questions and complaints about squirrels, skunks and raccoons nesting in attics, chimneys and crawlspaces, the tempo picks up in March and April with queries about what to do with the baby animals born in those nests.

title: Jodie Freeman Weds
description: At the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y., Jodie Sue Freeman, the women's dress buyer for Macy's Northeast in New York, was married last evening to Howard Bryan Adler, a tax associate at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. Rabbi Daniel Isaak and Cantor Martin Horowitz officiated. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jack Freeman of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Irving Adler of Riverdale, the Bronx. The bride will retain her name professionally.

title: 'War and Remembrance': Rewarding Relic
description: Big is not always better. But it can be, if not exactly noble, at least gallant. Consider ABC. The network did indeed take a painful drubbing a couple of years ago with its costly ''Amerika'' mini-series. But before that, ABC succeeded handsomely with two of the most-watched and ambitious mini-series in the history of American television: dramatizations of Alex Haley's ''Roots'' in 1977 and Herman Wouk's ''Winds of War'' in 1983.

title: Esposito Remarks Upset Bergeron
description: Coach Michel Bergeron of the Rangers said yesterday that he was ''absolutely shocked'' by comments attributed to Phil Esposito, the team's general manager, concerning the coach's handling of the team. In an article published yesterday in The New York Post, Esposito was quoted as saying: ''Michel and I are a team. If he says he's not going to use a player, as long as we win, that's fine. If we lose, then that's the wrong choice.''

title: Record Day for Sanders
description: Barry Sanders, the Oklahoma State tailback, broke the major-college single-season touchdown record today, scoring five times against Kansas in a 63-24 Big Eight Conference romp. Sanders has 31 touchdowns in nine games. Mike Rozier of Nebraska and Lydell Mitchell of Penn State each rushed for 29 in a season, Michell in 11 games in 1971 and Rozier in 12 games in 1983.

title: WARY BOND INVESTORS KEEP MATURITIES SHORT
description: ''Wine maketh merry: but money answereth all things.'' Ecclesiastes 10:19

title: Russian Composer Visits in Exchange
description: LEAD: THE arrival last week of the Soviet composer Gregory Korchmar on the State University campus here was the culmination of an eight-year effort that brought about the long-awaited reunion of two Soviet musicians.

title: Miss Kowalski Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon J. Kowalski of Captiva, Fla., and Woodstock, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Celia Kowalski, to John Walker Kjorlien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Kjorlien of Osterville, Mass., and Hobe Sound, Fla. The couple plan a January wedding.

title: Once Upon a Time the Phone Rang, and . . .
description: NORMAN P. ANDERSON, an 82-year-old resident of this Ocean County town and a retired boatyard owner, had quite a surprise one recent morning when a voice on the telephone announced: ''You've been acclaimed the No. 1 storyteller in New Jersey.''

title: Political Notes; Prominent New Yorkers May Join Bush Team
description: Less than a week after President-elect Bush's victory, New York Republicans are already talking about New Yorkers who might wind up in the new Administration.

title: STAR TREKKING
description: As a New Yorker, I, too, have spot-the-celebrity stories. One of mine involves the same person Peter Mehlman spotted.

title: NEIGHBORS AND WIVES
description: LAW, SEX, AND CHRISTIAN SOCIETY IN MEDIEVAL EUROPE By James A. Brundage. Illustrated. 674 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $45.

title: Kiddie City Tests Discount Toys In Manhattan
description: ''WE weren't sure what to expect,'' Marvin Katz was saying as he stood in Manhattan's new Kiddie City store next to a kangaroo bigger than him (there was nothing to worry about, since it was made out of Lego blocks). ''People wouldn't be coming in cars. They'd be riding the subways and buses. We decided not to stock many big items like bicycles. But people have been lugging some bicycles out of here.''

title: Alsace
description: To the Editor: As one who has spent much time in Alsace, including hiking over 350 miles, I was impressed with Olga Carlisle's ''Alsace Journey: The Harmony of Colmar'' (Travel, Aug. 7) and found that her observations were correct except for the comment, ''Religious wars were not as horrendous in Alsace as elsewhere in Europe,'' followed later by, ''Not that Alsace didn't have its share of bloody battles . . .'' and illustrating this remark by writing about a 16th-century peasants' revolt.

title: NONFICTION
description: OUR LONG NATIONAL DAYDREAM: A Political Pageant of the Reagan Era. By Sidney Blumenthal. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) For the journalist Sidney Blumenthal, the political landscape of the 1970's and 1980's is a desolate place, populated by muddled thinkers and incompetent campaigners. Hardly anyone escapes his indictment. President Reagan's supporters will admire Mr. Blumenthal's deft skewering of Walter Mondale, Gary Hart, John Glenn and other Democratic luminaries, who are presented in ''Our Long National Daydream'' as mired in the past, unsure of themselves and unable to craft policies that will fire the public's imagination. But Mr. Blumenthal wields his stiletto on Republicans as well, and here his material is so rich - and he builds his case so effectively - that he almost seems to be shooting fish in a barrel. George Will, James Watt and William Rehnquist, not to mention Mr. Reagan himself, provide targets that are almost too easy. Most of the essays originally appeared in The Washington Post or The New Republic between 1984 and 1988; occasionally, knowing how events turned out makes a piece seem old. And the faint air of the poli sci textbook hangs over the exposition at times. But his observations are always insightful, and usually irreverent; in his eyes, for example, a White House encounter between Mr. Reagan and the voice of Donald Duck is ''a meeting of equals.'' Where, these essays force one to wonder, is the public outrage this dismal catalogue of misfeasance, malfeasance and nonfeasance ought to provoke? These essays indict not only the politicians they describe but also the voters who allow them to flourish.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
The Restorer of Monticello Is Honored
description: LEAD: Uriah Phillips Levy has been chosen as the 1988 inductee of the Jewish-American Hall of Fame located at the Judah L. Magnes Memorial Museum in Berkeley, Calif. Without his intervention, Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson, might have been lost to posterity.

title: The N.C.A.A. Punishment Of Kansas Is Not Fair
description: The recent penalization of the University of Kansas basketball team by the National Collegiate Athletic Association causes me great concern and dismay. My feelings may be somewhat prejudiced because of my close association with the program - my son, Scooter, is a senior on the team this year - but I also believe that my opinions are a result of logical evaluation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For all practical purposes, Jim Baker will be deputy President.'' -Edward Rollins, a Republican strategist. [ 1:6. ]

title: A Delicate New Life Emerges at Midlife
description: LEAD: ''I'M building dollhouses!'' boomed my friend Mark, pointing to the armload of books he was taking out of the New Rochelle library. He used to drive me to the college where he taught photography, and I, literature. ''Not Victorian ones,'' he added gleefully, ''Frank Lloyd Wright houses!''

title: Sports of The Times; The Patriots' Cleanup Man
description: At halftime of the New England Patriots' season opener, Vic Kiam and Billy Sullivan were up in the Sullivan Stadium press box, visiting with a few sportswriters. In describing his willingness to purchase the Patriots from the financially troubled Sullivan family, Kiam was waving his arms. Suddenly, whack! He accidentally bumped a passer-by's two mustard-smothered hot dogs onto the floor. ''Oh, no,'' he said. ''My fault.'' While the others stood back and stared down at the glop of mustard near the scattered hot dogs and buns, Kiam hurried away. Returning with a handful of paper napkins, he quickly cleaned up most of the mess before a stadium worker finished the job. Then he resumed the conversation. ''As I was saying,'' Kiam said, ''I hope I've got a deal.''

title: Laos Releases 2 Americans After Failed Rescue Mission
description: Laos today released two Americans who were detained for more than a month after entering the country on a prisoner-of-war rescue mission.

title: WHAT FICTION NEEDS: MORE READERS, MORE DOGS
description: I read in the paper that students at Princeton and other colleges have been staging outdoor marathon readings of great books. They've read Joyce's ''Ulysses'' and ''Gravity's Rainbow'' by Thomas Pynchon. It took 80 students 40 hours to read aloud the 760 pages of ''Gravity's Rainbow.''

title: SEEKING SAFE HARBORS TO KEEP MONEY INTACT
description: To many investors, the markets are still treacherous territory. The economy may be stable, and the sharp swings that plagued the stock market a year ago may have subsided, but the nervousness lingers.

title: Wright Inquiry Examining Events Occurring Long Ago
description: The House ethics committee's investigation of Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has looked into events that occurred as long ago as 40 years, but it is not clear that the inquiry has been expanded beyond its original scope.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our wood garage door faces south and has been varnished several times with either a marine varnish or a polyurethane. After several months the varnish begins peeling. Our painter suggests we use paint instead of stain and varnish. What is your opinion?

title: Review/Dance; Up-and-Coming New Jersey Ballet
description: The level of ballet technique in this country has risen so markedly that even small companies like the New Jersey Ballet can reap the benefits to their creative advantage.

title: After Gilbert, Finding Bargains Under New Roofs
description: The resorts of Jamaica and Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula have not completely recovered from the damage inflicted by Hurricane Gilbert, which killed 400 people in its path in September. But vacationers who have a fondness for either area, or who are seeking low rates, should not automatically reject either one - as long as they are prepared to ask hard questions about conditions and perhaps make some allowances. With revived communications and resumption of regular flights, information is easily available on what is repaired and operating.

title: SHE'D RATHER BE A QUARTERBACK
description: FAST COPY By Dan Jenkins. 396 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95

title: A New Generation Joins Madison Ave. Boutiques
description: With so much wealth in the pockets of people shopping for fashions and footwear on Madison Avenue, makers of crystal, silverware, jewelry and housewares are moving onto the avenue to open shops with prices that soar into the stratosphere.

title: Honor for Page
description: He was an All-Pro defensive tackle with the Minnesota Vikings, an all-American at Notre Dame and now he's an assistant attorney general for the state of Minnesota. Yesterday, Alan Page was selected the Walter Camp Football Foundation's 1988 alumnus of the year.

title: Showdown Looms In Shoreham Deal
description: LEAD: THE election over, Long Island state legislators are preparing to return to Albany for the political main event: the final fight over the deal that Governor Cuomo has proposed to close the Shoreham nuclear-power plant.

title: Teaching Youth About Aging
description: LEAD: A PROGRAM to teach high school students about aging and the elderly has been introduced into the Bridgeport public schools to sensitize the students to the needs of the fastest-growing segment of society.

title:
GARDENING;
Conditions Are Right, but Moss Is Rare
description: LEAD: EARLY in this century, when the William Bayard Cutting family strolled through their estate on the South Shore of Long Island, they tread on soft, lush carpets of moss. The paths were covered with mosses, and were swept clean of fallen leaves daily.

title: In a Good Situation Look for the Best Move
description: EMANUEL Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921, advised that finding a good move is not good enough; one should always take a bit more time to find the best.

title: Radford Werner Klotz is Married to Shahnaz Batmanglidj
description: Shahnaz Batmanglidj, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hooshang Batmanglidj of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday in Jamaica to Radford Werner Klotz, a son of Mrs. Herbert W. Klotz of McLean, Va., and the late Mr. Klotz. The Rev. Dr. Wesley Green of the Hopewell Missionary Church in Jamaica performed the Protestant ceremony at the Round Hill Hotel in Montego Bay.

title: Korn Scores Twice In Devils' Victory
description: Playing without Mark Johnson, their leading scorer, the Devils got offensive production from an unexpected source tonight in their game against the Washington Capitals.

title: Maria Sanchez Marries
description: Maria Lucy Sanchez, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sanchez of Forest Hills, Queens, and Kenneth Patrick Farina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Farina of Bridgewater, N.J., were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Brosnan at Our Lady of the Angelus Roman Catholic Church in Rego Park, Queens. The bride is an operations coordinator for Rollins Burdick Hunter, an insurance brokerage in New York. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Farina is an independent accountant in New York and New Jersey.

title: INVISIBLE JOURNALIST
description: DATELINE SOWETO Travels With Black South African Reporters. By William Finnegan. 244 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: FINDING SUCCESS IN MUTUAL FUNDS
description: Financial markets involve risks as well as rewards. One way investors can manage these risks is diversification. Another is professional management. Mutual funds offer both.

title: VERY TOUGH GINNY
description: SWEET CREEK HOLLER By Ruth White. 215 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Miss Cauffman Marries Student
description: Old St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Barbara Conrad Cauffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Cauffman of Berwyn, Pa., to William Ralph Hartman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hartman of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Lewis H. Mills performed the ceremony.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: The National Hockey League can stop sticking incidents by inaugurating a series of penalties, starting with a one-game suspension; then escalating to a three-game suspension if the violation is judged to be a deliberate intention to harm; and at least a suspension of double the number of games that the victim is forced to miss as a result of the injury. Anything less would be unfair to the victim. Subsequent penalties to an offender should double the previous suspension time. WALTER O'HAGAN Auburn, N.Y.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Nebraska Tops Colorado by 7-0
description: Ken Clark rushed for 165 yards and scored the only touchdown in the third quarter to give Nebraska a 7-0 victory over Colorado today in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: Denise Roethenmund Weds S. E. Kletkewicz
description: The marriage of Denise Ermina Roethenmund, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto E. Roethenmund of Rye, N.Y., and Thun, Switzerland, to Stanley Edward Kletkewicz Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kletkewicz of Moorestown, N.J., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye. Msgr. Donald J. Pryor performed the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BONES OF CONTENTION: Controversies in the Search for Human Origins, by Roger Lewin. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Based on smatterings of fossilized fragments, theories about the ancestral lineage of man often require as much imagination as analysis, Roger Lewin shows. ''Again and again, the science of human origins comes out looking like a competitive Rorschach test,'' our reviewer, Robert Wright, said last year. ''The reader is carried along by the power of Mr. Lewin's reporting.'' THE BOYS OF WINTER, by Wilfrid Sheed. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) Jonathan Oglethorpe, a cynical editor in search of a best seller, is less interested in Billy van Dyne, an obscure but promising writer, than he is in Billy's attractive wife. Wilfrid Sheed ''may be America's closest cousin to Evelyn Waugh, although he suffers fools just a tad more gladly,'' Herbert Gold said here in 1987. His novel about a writers' colony in the Hamptons ''does the satirist's good work of demolition, but it also, alas, tells much of the truth about literary politicking. . . . There is a nostalgia for times when the Word really did seem haunted and holy.'' BEN-GURION: The Burning Ground, 1886-1948, by Shabtai Teveth. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) When this biography of David Ben-Gurion, the first Prime Minister of Israel, was published last year, our reviewer, Martin Gilbert, called it a work of ''pioneering research and historical detective work of the highest order. Even someone familiar with the general outline of Ben-Gurion's career will find many previously unknown facts and remarkable insights, illustrating his utter single-mindedness in pursuing the goal of statehood, even when that goal seemed most hopeless.'' IN THE SKIN OF A LION, by Michael Ondaatje. (King Penguin, $7.95.) During the 1920's, Patrick Lewis leaves his rural Canadian home to live among the immigrant laborers of Toronto. Last year, Carolyn Kizer said in The Book Review that in his surreal, unruly novel Michael Ondaatje writes beautifully about work. ''This is, of course, a rarity in fiction at any time, and one can only be grateful for a man who is not focused on the classroom, the bedroom and the bar.'' THE VIRTUOSI: Classical Music's Legendary Performers From Paganini to Pavarotti, by Harold C. Schonberg. (Vintage, $12.95.) In his portraits of the giants of classical music, Harold C. Schonberg, formerly the senior music critic of The Times, shows that in every age talent is often accompanied by excess. In 1985, our reviewer, Anthony Burgess, called the book (originally titled ''The Glorious Ones'') an ''entertaining survey of vocal and instrumental greatness.'' THE OLD LEFT, by Daniel Menaker. (Penguin, $5.95.) As the child of a materialistic age, David, a young college professor, finds it hard enough to be a good liberal, much less a committed radical like his aging Uncle Sol. ''Because of the elegance of [ Daniel ] Menaker's simple prose, David's sensibility engages our affection,'' our reviewer, Daniel Stern, said of these stories in 1987. ''But it is crotchety, constantly kvetching Uncle Sol who engages our respect.'' THE PARADISE OF BOMBS, by Scott Russell Sanders. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) The author considers his essays about the melancholic experience of having just one life to live in the only world there is ''experiments in making sense of things.'' ''His essays take the bifocal stance of lyric poem and chilling story,'' Kim R. Stafford said here last year. THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/New American Library, $5.95.) Evil comes to a small town in the form of Tommyknockers, nasty little creatures that live in a spaceship buried for eons in a writer's backyard. '' [ Stephen ] King's presumption that we are afraid of everything makes him a great and terrible storyteller,'' Nina Auerbach said here in 1987. MUCH DEPENDS ON DINNER: The Extraordinary History and Mythology, Allure and Obsessions, Perils and Taboos of an Ordinary Meal, by Margaret Visser. (Collier/Macmillan, $10.95.) By tracing the history of each item in a run-of-the-mill dinner, a self-styled ''anthropologist of everyday life'' shows that what we most take for granted fundamentally shapes our lives. The book is ''consistently thoughtful and entertaining,'' John Gross said in The Times earlier this year. THE SPLENDID OUTCAST: Beryl Markham's African Stories, compiled by Mary S. Lovell. (Laurel/Dell, $7.50.) In addition to ''West With the Night,'' the aviator Beryl Markham wrote short stories based on her adventures in Africa. ''She emerges from them as a woman of finely tuned observation, as well as courage, cunning and vulnerability,'' Diane Ackerman said in The Book Review last year. HARD HEADS, SOFT HEARTS: Tough-Minded Economics for a Just Society, by Alan S. Blinder. (Addison-Wesley, $10.95.) An unrepentant Keynesian says that the right mix of Government intervention and free-market principles can provide for the social welfare and even achieve full employment. ''This is a book to treasure, not least because of the author's demonstration that economists can write graceful English prose and temper their didactic impulses with modesty and humor,'' Robert Lekachman said here in 1987. HARD TO BE GOOD, by Bill Barich. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) In Bill Barich's stories about people learning to accept the limits of life, the characters give up too easily, Russell Banks said here last year. But he complimented the author on ''his graceful prose, his penchant for understatement and his affection for the homely, telling details of ordinary lives.''

title: Ms. Edelman, Lawyer, Wed
description: Cornelia Edelman, an associate at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, was married at the Century Club in New York yesterday to Peter Dudley McKillop, the acting bureau chief for Newsweek magazine in New York. The Rev. James Fenhagan, an Episcopal priest and dean of the General Theological Seminary in New York, and Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated.

title: Dynaformer Wins Discovery by Nose
description: Dynaformer, who had not won a race since the Jersey Derby last May, held off Star Attitude by a nose to win the $174,300 Discovery Handicap for 3-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct Race Track.

title: World's Fair Buffs Gather in Queens
description: As World's Fair buffs and memorabilia-collectors gathered yesterday in Flushing Meadow Park, a gleam came into the gray eyes of one of their leaders, Peter M. Warner, president of the World's Fair Collectors Society.

title: Democratic Strength Shifts to West
description: The 1988 Presidential election marked a decided shift in the strength of Democratic Party to the Midwest and the West. It also confirmed that the ''Solid South,'' once a Democratic bastion, is now solidly Republican in Presidential voting and may well stay that way for some time.

title: CLIFF DWELLINGS AND CATHEDRALS
description: ROUND BUILDINGS, SQUARE BUILDINGS, & BUILDINGS THAT WIGGLE LIKE A FISH By Philip M. Isaacson. Illustrated. 121 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: Sara Davidson and I are approximately the same age. We have both been through the cultural and psychic upheavals of the 1960's and have had children relatively late in life. So it was with interest that I read her article.

title: Hawks Surge Past Hornets
description: Reggie Theus scored 27 points and Moses Malone added 20 as the Atlanta Hawks outscored Charlotte by 15 points in the fourth quarter tonight and beat the Hornets by 132-111.

title: Travel Bookshelf
description: Walking Austria's Alps Hut to Hut By Jonathan Hurdle 239 Pages. The Mountaineers.

title: Headliners; Serious Gift
description: Bill Cosby, who has made a small industry of comedy, has appropriately registered on the Richter scale of philanthropy not like an entertainer, but like a industrialist. Mr. Cosby and his wife, Camille, gave $20 million to Spelman College, the elite black women's college in Atlanta that the Cosbys' daughter, Erinn, attended. The gift, most of which will go to build a new academic center to be named for Mrs. Cosby, was announced last week at a dinner in honor of Spelman's president, Johnnetta B. Cole. Mr. Cosby said he and his wife ''have been blessed because I found a vein of gold in the side of a mountain.'' The gift to Spelman, he said, was a way of letting Dr. Cole ''know how much we love this school.''

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: IT'S hard to believe, but Barbara Cook says it's true. She has a friend, a famous and rich performer, who doesn't stint on luxury when she's on tour. She hires limousines, stays in the best hotels, tips generously. She has elegant luggage and in that elegant luggage is an elegant wardrobe - and an iron and squares of aluminum foil.

title: CAMERA! ACTION!
description: With elements of costume epic, backstage story, frontier adventure, domestic romance and even a Dickensian scenario (an orphan that Cecil B. adopted was actually his brother's son), the story of the DeMille family seems like another C. B. extravaganza. With audacious brevity, the biographer Anne Edwards documents three generations of this remarkable clan in the lavishly illustrated THE DeMILLES: AN AMERICAN FAMILY (Abrams, $39.95). Her elegant narrative proves far more substantial than appearance suggests. Ms. Edwards incorporates information from interviews, family letters, reviews and other sources to tell the story. Prompted by his wife, Beatrice, Henry DeMille became a Broadway playwright and collaborator of David Belasco. Upon Henry's death in 1893, the enterprising Beatrice became a dramatist's agent, encouraging her two sons, William and Cecil, to pursue the family calling. Cecil would enter the fledgling movie industry, directing ''The Squaw Man,'' received with much praise in 1914. William followed Cecil to California, bringing his daughter, Agnes, who would later return to Broadway and become one of the century's most revered choreographers. Ms. Edwards dwells on Cecil and Agnes, but not entirely at the expense of their supporting casts. While relying on anecdotes and specific details to evoke the larger picture, she ventures her own insights: ''Cecil seemed unconcerned that in the opinion of his critics his works were not considered artistically significant. His only fear was that an audience might be bored.'' With Agnes completing a circle, the DeMille chronicles serve as a potent reminder that the foundation of film is in theater.

title: Travel Bookshelf
description: Cento Citta: A Guide to the ''Hundred Cities and Towns'' of Italy By Paul Hofmann. 388 pages. Henry Holt.

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; Grandmother's Plea
description: For Law and Order I have finally reached old age and have seen others go before me. But, are these my golden years, my retirement years? No! I have paid my dues, but do I have peace and quiet that goes with old age? Not at all!

title: Shattered Spirits: Growing Up With Alcoholism
description: MY father is an alcoholic. I am an adult child of an alcoholic. It's a sobering fact. A reality I live with, one day at a time.

title: The Love Between Beckett and Actors Isn't Mutual
description: Just in case you haven't been keeping tabs on Samuel Beckett lately, we should make note this morning that he has gradually arrived at his concept of ideal theater. ''The best possible play,'' he is quoted as saying by biographer Deirdre Bair, ''is one in which there are no actors, only the text. I'm trying to find a way to write one.''

title: South Berwick, Me.: >Panelized Affordability
description: The largest home builder in Maine is addressing one of the state's biggest housing problems - affordability - in Maine's largest development, this community's 110-acre Agamenticus Estates.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Caution: Handle Moratoriums With Care
description: LEAD: As it is with wit, brevity is the soul of a good moratorium. That, at least, is one of the conclusions of a new Westchester County Planning Department study of moratoriums on development adopted by local communities in the last four years. In that period, 21 of the county's 43 municipalities imposed building bans.

title: Debunking Stereotypes on the Elderly
description: I GREW UP in the big city, where birds are just birds - small, feathered creatures in an essentially treeless environment, lacking the sense to know they don't belong in a concrete forest.

title: Blacks Say Florida Site Has Ties to South Africa
description: Officials are celebrating their victory in bringing the first large-scale manufacturing plant to this city of tree-canopied boulevards, but their cheers are muffled by new stirrings of racial resentment.

title: The New Reasons for Giving to Children
description: THREE years ago, Herman and Ruth Balcoff of Millburn, N.J., opened a savings account in the name of their new grandchild, listing themselves as the custodians. They plan to do the same for their latest grandchild because ''it's a good way of giving money to the kids,'' Mr. Balcoff said.

title: Rome Picnics
description: To the Editor: Professor Chappell's article (Travel, Oct. 23) about picnicking in Rome recalls beautiful weeks spent in the Eternal City, doing just what she describes. However, neither the Janiculum - being on the ''wrong side of the river'' - nor the Pincio are among the ''Seven Hills of Rome,'' which rather include the Capitoline and the Viminal. PETER TROSTORFF Queens Village, N.Y. Sally A. Kitt Chappell replies: Mr. Trostorff is right. Modern Rome actually encompasses nine hills. The seven hills of antiquity, in Latin, are the Quirinal, Viminal, Caelian, Esquiline, Aventine, Capitoline and the Palatine. The Pincio lies to the north of the Quirinal and the Janiculum to the west across the Tiber.

title: ALL THE PRESIDENTS' CLIQUES
description: THE RING OF POWER The White House Staff and Its Expanding Role in Government. By Bradley H. Patterson Jr. 382 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Breast Implants: A Look at the Record
description: AN average of 356 American women a day receive breast implants, a procedure that in 25 years has offered more than two million women a chance to change their appearance and, for mastectomy patients, to preserve their self-esteem.

title: Outdoors; New York State Seeks Commercial Fishery for Striped Bass
description: New York State is seeking to determine whether it might have a limited commercial fishery for striped bass without violating the federal-state restoration program for that highly-prized food and game fish.

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; Raising Age Limit Is Long Overdue
description: I am a psychologist who has been associated with Dorothy Holmgren and Parents on the Move for the past two and a half years. I have seen many families who appear to be caught in this PINS age gap.

title: 'Oliver & Company' Gives Dickens A Disney Twist urban scene from an appropriate rooftop.
description: When Michael Eisner, New Yorker from Park Avenue, and Jeffrey Katzenberg, a New Yorker from Riverdale, were president and head of production at Paramount Pictures, they wanted to make a contemporary live-action musical version of Charles Dickens's ''Oliver Twist'' set in New York City - but then Disney beckoned.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. $538,000 58 Park Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 78-year-old English country house; 3 fireplaces, nursery, den, maid's room, sun porch; taxes $6,128. Elmsford, N.Y. $282,000 21 High Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, full basement, 2-car garage; taxes not yet available. Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $479,000 Comanche Court 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; brick fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,874. Barkhamsted, Conn. $190,000 11 Chiswick Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 15-year-old Dutch colonial; horse barn, 2-car garage, 1.3 acres; taxes $1,500. Deep River, Conn. $289,900 2 Cedar Swamp Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, new colonial; wooded lot, whirlpool bath, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Litchfield, Conn. $159,000 East Litchfield Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 48-year-old Cape Cod, skylights in bedroom, masonry fireplace, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,194. OTHER AREAS Mineola, L.I. $205,000 413 Argyle Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old saltbox; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Selden, L.I. $145,000 65 March Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old high ranch; den, dining room, attached 1-car garage; taxes $2,500. Chatham Township, N.J. $445,000 38 Stafford Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; finished basement, c/a, pool; taxes $5,042.

title: Toxic Chemicals, the Right Response
description: THANKS to some not-so-gentle prodding from the Federal Government, manufacturers across the country are starting to ''come clean'' - in more ways than one - with respect to the toxic chemicals they release into the environment.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: As both last year's Winter Olympics and Canada Cup proved, violence can be taken out of hockey without any negative effect on the excitement and quality of play. Sure the N.H.L. could tighten rules and all but eliminate violence, but its concern is not the red cuts and black eyes of the players, but the green dollars of the people paying to see the brawls and cheap shots. MICHAEL ROTHSTEIN Haverford, Pa.

title: SENIOR CAPITAL AT WORK
description: When she was younger, playing the market was one of Gerta Coopersmith's favorite hobbies. ''My brokers got rich on me,'' she recalls.

title: Broker Is Wed To Allison Hart
description: At the Community Church of Pound Ridge, N.Y., Allison Jeanne Hart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth N. Hart of Pound Ridge, was married yesterday to Michael Francis MacDonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John MacDonald of Westport, Conn., and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Monkman, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Jodi Jacobson Married To Mark D. Anatole
description: Jodi Jacobson, the daughter of David Jacobson of Palm Beach, Fla., and Toronto and the late Barbara Jacobson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Mark D. Anatole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Anatole of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony at Blantyre in Lenox, Mass.

title: Time Alone Will Tell Ownership
description: A derelict, turn-of-the-century sidewalk clock on Third Avenue and 85th Street was designated a landmark in 1981, but then mistakenly sold by the city to a private buyer, who removed it in 1985. The buyer returned the clock and a restoration program is now almost complete - but now three different parties, including the city, consider themselves the legal owner.

title: Garment District: A $35 Million New Look
description: Hemlines have risen and hemlines have fallen, but the skyline of Manhattan's garment district has remained the same, with new clothing flowing out of old buildings. That is about to change. Excavation has begun on 39th Street between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas for the first new building in the garment district in 20 years. Construction will start by the end of the month, and the 21-story office and showroom building will take in its first tenants in early 1991.

title: Hitler and the Bomb
description: IN DECEMBER 1938, JUST 50 YEARS AGO NEXT MONTH, TWO German chemists discovered nuclear fission. It was the research of German scientists - working in a country whose dictator had already determined on war in Europe - that opened the way to the atomic bomb; and it was the ensuing fear that Hitler might be the first to have a bomb that led to Franklin Roosevelt's decision in October 1941 - two months before Pearl Harbor, at a time when the materials from which a bomb might be made did not yet exist - to launch what would become the Manhattan Project.

title: 80's Design: Wallowing in Opulence and Luxury
description: The relationship between architecture and politics has never been an easy one to define in a pluralistic society. We have no ''official'' style of building; no architecture is made in the United States by royal decree, or even by presidential order. Presidents have tastes in design, one presumes, but they are not enforced in the manner that Louis XIV'S architectural tastes were enforced, or those of the Czars. The forces that determine design directions run in currents that are far broader than politics, if as strangely susceptible to emotion, and woe be to the observer who tries to tie them too closely to political cycles.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Ombudsman and Elderly: Abuse Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: LEAD: SINCE its landmark decision in the Karen Ann Quinlan case a dozen years ago, New Jersey's Supreme Court has generally been acknowledged as the nation's leader in formulating responsible and progressive law concerning medical care of hopelessly ill patients.

title: SILENCE IS THE BEST REVENGE
description: SPINKY SULKS Written and illustrated by William Steig. Unpaged. New York: Michael di Capua Books/Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: LONESOME JOHN FINDS A FRIEND
description: THE SCAREBIRD By Sid Fleischman. Illustrated by Peter Sis. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; A Travesty Of Justice
description: Having read the Oct. 2 article ''Emancipation Age: Should It Rise To 18?'' by Vivien Kellerman, I write to urge all parents to support the change from 16 to 18.

title: Experts Say Low 1988 Turnout May Be Repeated
description: Only half the Americans who were eligible to vote in the Presidential election this week did vote, and even simplified registration procedures in many states did not make a difference, a research group reported today.

title: Anne Lyons is Wed
description: Anne Martha Lyons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Lyons of Greenwich, Conn., and Michael Steers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Coster Steers of Greenwich, were married there yesterday at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Robert J. McDermott performed the ceremony. The bride and bridegroom are both social workers in the Stamford office of the Connecticut Department of Children and Youth Services, she an adoption specialist and he a supervisor.

title: Bomb Blast Rips Students' Union in Johannesburg
description: The headquarters of the National Union of South African Students, which is opposed to apartheid, was badly damaged by a fire-bomb early today.

title: Arthur Tildesley Jr. Plans to Marry Susan Bunnell
description: The engagement of Susan Ward Bunnell to Arthur Harold Tildesley Jr., the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Tildesley of Fair Haven, N.J., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy H. Bunnell of Middletown, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SEA-SONG TRIO Schooner Fare, a folk trio from Maine that specializes in sea songs, will return to the Hurdy-Gurdy Coffeehouse in the Central Unitarian Church in Paramus on Saturday at 8:15 P.M.

description: Butler $245,000 6 Stony Hill Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old split level; family room with fireplace, w/w carpeting, burglar-alarm system; taxes $3,239. Chatham Township $445,000 38 Stafford Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; finished basement, c/a, pool; taxes $5,042. Livingston $236,000 6 Scotland Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; screened porch, hardwood floors, 1-car garage; taxes $3,085. Phillipsburg $120,000 148 Hemlock Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, patio, professionally landscaped; taxes $1,659. West Orange $206,000 154 Old Indian Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old split level; dining room, c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $3,897. OTHER AREAS Barkhamsted, Conn. $190,000 11 Chiswick Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 15-year-old Dutch colonial; horse barn, 2-car garage, 1.3 acres; taxes $1,500. Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $479,000 Comanche Court 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; brick fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,874. Selden, L.I. $145,000 65 March Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old high ranch; den, dining room, attached 1-car garage; taxes $2,500.

title: Maldivians Threaten Captive Tamil Mercenaries
description: A coup attempt by Tamil mercenaries led by local rebels in the Maldives has aroused public anger against the attackers, according to reports from the Indian Ocean island nation.

title: Leather Wizardry
description: Roberto Vascon is a one-man Brazilian leather factory. Since coming to New York three years ago from Rio de Janeiro, he has been selling his distinctive pocketbook designs. He cuts and hand-stitches 70 to 80 leather bags a week, and sells them exclusively at . . . the Columbus Avenue Flea Market.

title: HANNAH LEARNS TO REMEMBER
description: THE DEVIL'S ARITHMETIC By Jane Yolen 170 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: 5 Dance Awards Given
description: Five New York City dance companies have been awarded grants of $3,000 each by the Emerging Dance Program of the Metropolitan Life Foundation, the foundation has announced. The companies are the Deja Vu Dance Theater, Susan Marshall and Company, Chen and Dancers/ H. T. Dance Company, Ruby Shang and Company Dancers and Ralph Lemon and Company. The program, in its second year, awards grants to outstanding small dance companies and to more established companies that support young dancers or choreographers.

title: Fresh Look at Northern Bus Service
description: LEAD: For the first time since its creation during the early 1970's, the county's Department of Transportation is conducting a detailed examination of its northern Westchester bus routes. The study will eventually involve the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and could lead to a restructuring of mass transportation in the county's fastest growing region.

title: Maybe He Can Appeal
description: JUDGMENT IN BERLIN Starring Martin Sheen (in photo), Sam Wanamaker, Max Gail, Juergen Heinrich, Heinz Hoenig, Carl Lumbly, Sean Penn, Harris Yulin. Directed by Leo Penn. 1988. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Entertainment. 95 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG. Includes low-key sex and violence.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SPECIAL EFFECTS: Disaster at Twilight Zone: The Tragedy and the Trial. By Ron LaBrecque. (Scribners, $19.95). On July 23, 1982, John Landis, director of ''Animal House'' and ''The Blues Brothers,'' was filming the climax to what he hoped would persuade his critics that he was, in fact, a serious movie maker.

title: Golf
description: Four Tied for Lead: Chris Perry figures he needs to finish in the top three in the Centel Classic to retain his PGA Tour card. He is in a good position for that after shooting a six-under-par 66 yesterday to move into a four-way tie for the lead after three rounds. Perry will start today's final round of the $500,000 event tied for the lead at 204 with Bob Lohr, Bill Glasson and Kenny Perry. Lohr and Glasson shot 68's and Kenny Perry posted a 69.(AP) Barber Sets Record: Miller Barber shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to take a five-shot lead after two rounds of the $225,000 Senior Classic at the Suntree Country Club in Melbourne, Fla. His two-day total of 15-under 129 is a Senior PGA Tour record, beating the 14-under-par mark set by three golfers: Don January and Lee Elder in 1984 and Jim Ferree in 1985.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 5, Flyers 4: Steve Yzerman scored three goals and Gerard Gallant had four assists as visiting Detroit downed Philadelphia yesterday. The victory was Detroit's third in a row, while the Flyers lost their third successive game and 10th in their last 14 after a 4-0 start. The hat trick was Yzerman's sixth of his career and second of the season against the Flyers. Tim Kerr had three of the Flyers' four goals.(AP) Flames 2, Bruins 1: Jiri Hrdina scored his 11th goal of the season with 39 seconds left in the second period to break a tie, and Calgary lengthened its lead in the overall standings to 3 points over the Bruins. The Flames have 25 points, Boston 22. Gary Suter also scored for the Flames; Jay Miller scored for the Bruins. (AP) Oilers 6, Maple Leafs 2: Esa Tikkanen scored two short-handed goals in 12 seconds to set a National Hockey League record and added a third goal late in the game as Edmonton handed Toronto its fifth consecutive loss. The previous fastest short-handed goals were scored in 25 seconds by Pat Hughes of the Oilers on Jan. 11, 1983, against St. Louis. Jari Kurri, Greg Adams and Craig Simpson also scored for the Oilers. Craig Laughlin and Dave Reid scored Toronto's goals.(AP) Bowling Floridian Wins: Joe Berardi of Wellington, Fla., captured the Professional Bowlers Association True Value Open in Indianapolis yesterday with a 247-211 victory over Don Genalo of Perrysburg, Ohio. The victory, Berardi's ninth, made him the only bowler this year to win three tournaments. The $21,000 top prize also raised his earnings this year to $105,720.(AP) Adamek Beats Top-Seeded Romeo: Donna Adamek of Victorville, Calif., won her first title in five years yesterday, defeating top-seeded Robin Romeo of Van Nuys, Calif., 211-177, to win the $30,000 first prize in the $125,000 Ladies Pro Bowlers Tour Sam's Town National Pro-Am in Las Vegas, Nev. (AP) Tennis Mecir Eliminates McEnroe: Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated John McEnroe, 5-7, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the final of the Stuttgart Classic in West Germany. Mecir will face Andres Gomez of Ecuador, who defeated Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 5-7, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Leconte Upset: Fourth-seeded Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland upset top-seeded Henri Leconte of France, 6-4, 7-5, in the Benson and Hedges Championships yesterday in Wembley, England, to reach the fifth Nabisco Grand Prix final of his career. Hlasek will play in the final against fifth-seeded Jonas Svensson of Sweden, who defeated No. 8 John Fitzgerald of Australia, 7-5, 6-4. (AP)

title: THE ORIGINAL PERFORMANCE ARTIST
description: LEAD: DICKENS A Biography. By Fred Kaplan. Illustrated. 607 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.95.

title: Panel Urges Vast Changes in Medical Schools
description: A national panel of medical professionals warned Friday that American medical education was falling out of step with society's needs and called for dramatic changes in the way medical schools admit, train and test students.

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOKKS
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1988. Since 1952, The Book Review has annually asked a panel of three judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published each year. The judges this year were Dudley B. Carlson, manager of children's services at the Princeton Public Library, New Jersey, Oscar De Mejo, an author and illustrator whose most recent book is ''Journey to Boc Boc,'' and Bernard McTigue, curator of the Arents Collections and keeper of rare books at the New York Public Library.

title: THE NATION: Together Again; With Bush in the Oval Office, Is The C.I.A. 'Back in the Saddle'?
description: VICE PRESIDENT BUSH, who will be the first President to have served as America's intelligence chief, wasted no time in signaling a new, hands-on approach to intelligence issues.

title: DETERMINED TO BE HEARD
description: Ann B. Hopkins is suing because she is ''tough-minded'' and believes she was discriminated against when she was not selected for promotion at Price Waterhouse. In their recommendation for partnership, her supervisors noted her ''strong character, independence and integrity.'' They did not commend her charm, cooperation or group spirit. One wonders whether their ''recommendation'' was a euphemism for ''one big pain in the butt.'' Forty men out of the 88 candidates were not selected for partnership either. I think she and her lawyer simply think they can stick Price Waterhouse for a lot of money. EDWARD PEIZER Pinehurst, N.C.

title: Anna Freud and Jeffrey Masson
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Ivy League; Cornell Routs Columbia by 42-19
description: Columbia's only victory of the season was over Princeton. Cornell's only loss in the Ivy League was to Princeton. Therefore, Columbia should beat Cornell. Right?

title: An Italian Newcomer in Wilton
description: WILTON, because it is still a ''dry'' town, is not a restaurant mecca. So it is always cause for celebration when a new hopeful arrives on the local dining scene. The latest restaurant optimist is Portofino's II, scion of Portofino's in Woodbury.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: ANTIQUE COVERS

title: Sports of The Times; Roadblock Jones Wins One
description: Trivia question, everybody: Who got the first hit for the Mets in the first home game they ever played? Wrong.

title: In the Spirit of Beatrix Potter
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles W. Caulkins, Banker, Wed To Gail O'Neill, College Trustee
description: Abby O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George D. O'Neill of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Charles Wells Caulkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Caulkins of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Nancy S. Taylor, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Where Army Puts Equipment Through Its Paces
description: From time to time, soldiers at the Army's sprawling test range on Chesapeake Bay north of Baltimore are ordered to test sleeping bags.

title: WHERE PINOCCHIO COMES TO LIFE
description: Since Carlo Collodi's tale first appeared more than a century ago, the gullible, often naughty wooden boy with the famous growing nose has become a symbol of Italian puppetry. And to the delight of Roman children, Pinocchio and a host of other colorful characters are still brought to life on the city's puppet stages. Visitors, particularly those with young children, may find an hour of such lighthearted entertainment an ideal counterbalance to time logged in museums, monuments, restaurants and shops. Plots are usually uncomplicated and the action easy to follow. A fairy tale might be simply staged with only a few hand puppets, such as a plush brown wolf or satin-garbed princess on a stage less than an arm's breadth. Or there are ambitious adaptations of Shakespeare or Dante on a full-size stage with spotlights, black lights, grandiose soundtracks in stereo and a cast of hundreds of puppets, some in synchronized chorus-blocks of two dozen that one puppeteer can manipulate at once. There is a theater that specializes in traditional Sicilian puppetry with armor-heavy knights dueling on stage, clanking swords and shields manipulated from above by string and rods.

title: Iona in 18-Month Computer Study
description: LEAD: IONA COLLEGE, one of the Westchester area's first educational institutions to incorporate computing skills and computer literacy into its curriculum, last week announced a project that could benefit other colleges and universities nationwide.

title: New York Food Program Advocates Self-Help
description: Many poor New Yorkers needing food turn to soup kitchens and food pantries for help. At those places, which serve more than two million free meals a month, long lines and hapless faces are common sights.

title: BAKER WILL WIELD BROAD INFLUENCE, AIDES TO BUSH SAY
description: The next Cabinet is shaping up in a way that promises broad influence for James A. Baker 3d, the newly designated Secretary of State, in many aspects of domestic and economic policy as well as foreign affairs, according to aides of President-elect Bush.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
BEN, MR. POPPER AND THE RABBITS: REMEMBERING ROBERT LAWSON
description: LEAD: Normally neither penguins nor mice are models of longevity, but Mr. Popper's penguins and Ben Franklin's ''good mouse'' Amos are hardly normal creatures, since they owe their creation - at least in part - to Robert Lawson, the late master of Rabbit Hill and a man who occupies a unique place in American children's literature as the only person to win both the Caldecott and Newbery medals.

title: Barbara Jean Kender Weds Charles Parker
description: Barbara Jean Kender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Kender of Cleveland, was married there yesterday to Charles Sumner Parker, a son of Mrs. Charles J. Parker of New Haven and the late Mr. Parker. The Rev. Patrick J. McHugh performed the ceremony at St. Malachi Roman Catholic Church.

title: EACH MAN HATES THE WOMAN HE LOVES
description: TWO AGAINST ONE By Frederick Barthelme. 264 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title: Correction
description: An article and a headline last Sunday about the marriage of Pamela Ellsworth Davis misidentified the bridegroom. He is William Booth Van Ingen.

title: CLOSE TO THE VEST
description: Chalk it up to the influence of what The New York Times movie critic Janet Maslin has called ''white flannel films,'' in which immaculate young men preen in turn-of-the-century trousers, blazers and, most strikingly, silk vests. Or to a rekindled interest in the plumage worn by such legendary dandies as Oscar Wilde, whose biography made best-seller lists earlier this year.

title: Autumn Anti-Breeze Protection
description: IN New York lately, the weather has been a little on the cool side but still relatively mild for this time of year. A wool coat is too bulky and warm, and a raincoat isn't heavy enough. Stylish women are thus confronted with the kind of challenge they are no more likely to pass up than they would a half-price sale: devising the perfect cover-up.

title: A Cozy Hotel That Matches Proper Zurich
description: Zurich is a city of polite reserve, solid prosperity and hard work. ''Zurich is so clean,'' said James Joyce, ''that should you spill your soup on the Bahnhofstrasse, you could eat it up without a spoon.'' There are many symbols of Zurich's dependable character - the Bahnhofstrasse banks, the labeled shrubs on nature trails - but few so apt as the Hotel Baur au Lac. Civilized, run with fastidious attention, here you know your shoes will be polished, your wake-up call prompt.

title: Farrell, St. Francis Advance
description: Monsignor Farrell, the regular season Catholic High Schools Football League AAA division champion, had a relatively easy time eliminating Holy Cross, 31-13, in the playoff semifinals at St. John's University yesterday. But St. Francis Prep needed an overtime to defeat St. John the Baptist, 20-14.

title: Atom Smasher May Enrich a Town, But Some Fear Price Will Be High
description: Clusters of well-preserved Victorian homes and a stately granite courthouse have made Waxahachie attractive to Hollywood directors for years as a quaint place where time appears to have stopped sometime after 1900 and before World War II.

title: CHILDREN AND THE BOMB
description: LOOKING THE TIGER IN THE EYE Confronting the Nuclear Threat. By Carl B. Feldbaum and Ronald J. Bee. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Westchester Shelter Idea Prompts Hilton to Complain of Interference
description: A legislator's proposal that Westchester County buy the Tarrytown Hilton for use as a shelter for the homeless has prompted the Hilton Hotels Corporation to complain that the proposal interferes with its efforts to sell the hotel.

title: Soviets Stage Nuclear Test
description: The Soviet Union today detonated a 20-kiloton nuclear test device beneath the Semipalatinsk proving grounds on the steppes of Kazakhstan in Central Asia, the official press agency Tass reported. ''The goal of the testing was upgrading military technology,'' Tass said. Twenty kilotons, the force of 20,000 tons of TNT, was the yield of the American atom bomb dropped on Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945.

title: 34 Slain in Colombia As Rebels Open Fire In Town, Police Say
description: Thirty-four civilians were killed and 31 wounded when guerrillas descended on the northern Colombian town of Segovia on Friday night, firing on anything that moved, the military authorities said today.

title: Nets Too Much, Even for Jordan
description: Not even Michael Jordan's heroics could keep the Nets from winning tonight.

title: Reflections on War: A Topic for Playtime?
description: ''YOU look sad, Daddy.'' Perhaps I did. Perhaps I didn't. How do you really know? Can a 5-year-old's judgment at the breakfast table be the criterion?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco;
High-Risk Mall Off Union Sq.
description: LEAD: THE San Francisco Centre, this city's new $140 million, 670,000-square-foot vertical shopping mall, represents a high-risk venture that city planners hope will rejuvenate a decaying segment of Market Street, the main downtown thoroughfare.

title:
Focus: Greenville, N.C.;
On Tobacco Farms, Land Is a Cash Crop
description: LEAD: Ralph C. Tucker Jr. operates a 3,000-acre farm on the outskirts of this eastern North Carolina town, growing tobacco, soybeans and corn. He leases about 500 of these acres and would like eventually to buy all the land he farms.

title: Agencies Divided on Treatment
description: ALTHOUGH they share the goal of successfully treating adolescents addicted to crack, public and private providers of such treatment are sometimes at odds over strategies for achieving that goal.

title: Amy C. Shull, Editor and Researcher, Wed to Joseph G. Finnerty 3d, Lawyer
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Amy Caroline Shull, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Henderson Shull Jr. of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph Gregory Finnerty 3d, a son of Alice Ann Finnerty and Mr. Finnerty Jr., both of Baltimore. The Rev. Dennis Tinder performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Nicholas T. Cooke 3d, an Episcopal priest. Elizabeth Henderson Shull was the maid of honor for her sister. Thomas Patrick Finnerty was his brother's best man. Mrs. Finnerty, a freelance copy editor and researcher, graduated from Hampshire College and received a master's degree in painting from New York University. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Davy & Shull. The bride is a granddaughter of William Henry May Jr. of Pawleys Island, S.C., who retired as a vice president of the hosiery division of Burlington Industries. She is a great-granddaughter of William Henry May of Burlington, N.C., who was a founder and president of May Hosiery Mills, which as May McEwen Kaiser merged with Burlington Industries.

title: More Coverage For Paralympics
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Move on Air Fares Raises Concern For the Travelers Without Choices
