description: The latest move by the airline industry to curtail discount fares once again raises concerns that deregulation may in the long run force passengers to pay higher fares than they would have when the industry was regulated.

title: First Black Accepted By a Business Group
description: The Maryland Club, whose 800 members include people in business and other influential roles, has accepted its first black member in its 131-year history.

title: When the Music Speaks for Itself
description: The late Jimmy Durante had a repeated complaint: ''Everybody wants to get into the act.'' That certainly seems to be true of loudspeakers. At last count, 238 firms were competing in the market.

title: A Coach Pursues Boys' Volleyball
description: LEAD: IN 1974, Ed Bengermino started the girls' volleyball program at Andrew Warde High School in Fairfield. He built it into one of the strongest in the state, maintaining its high level even after the school was consolidated with Roger Ludlowe into Fairfield High School three years ago.

title:
GARDENING;
Conditions Are Right, but Moss Is Rare
description: LEAD: EARLY in this century, when the William Bayard Cutting family strolled through their estate on the South Shore of Long Island, they tread on soft, lush carpets of moss. The paths were covered with mosses, and were swept clean of fallen leaves daily.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Where the King Lives, Alone

title: PROTESTS CAPTURE HOLIDAY IN POLAND
description: Despite efforts by the Government to seize Independence Day for itself, tens of thousands of pro-Solidarity, anti-Government demonstrators turned out late Friday in 10 cities for unauthorized rallies to mark the day 70 years ago when Poland re-emerged on the map of Europe after more than a century of partition.

title:
The View From: The Tappan Zee;
13 Lanes, Riv Vu, 8x4, Partly Furnished: Tollbooth Tales
description: FERNANDO RODRIGUEZ was listening to ''English Meadow'' early one recent morning when he realized he had left his wallet at home in West Nyack and couldn't pay the toll on the Tappan Zee Bridge. No problem. Mr. Rodriguez, a contractor who lives in Rockland and works mostly in Westchester, was calmed by the recording of birdsongs playing on the cassette tape deck of his Isuzu Trooper.

title: A Bird-Like Dinosaur In Debut at the Peabody
description: LEAD: REPLICAS of Deinonychus, a dinosaur that lived more than 125 million years ago, will be the centerpiece at the unveiling next Saturday of the new cretaceous section at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven. Deinonychus is the first new dinosaur to be added to the museum's collection since the 1940's.

title: Grace Church, 100 and Still Growing
description: LEAD: EXACTLY 100 years ago, five former slaves working as domestics in Westchester mansions and estates formed a prayer group at a black meeting hall on Eastchester Lane. Soon the group attracted others, including butlers and drivers, and a small, informal congregation was established.

title: Westport Woman Has a Mission: Litter
description: LEAD: ''IT was an extraordinary day,'' Winifred Balboni said as she began telling the story of how, on a Wednesday afternoon five years ago, she simply could no longer overlook her town's litter.

title: DON'T WORRY, BE GIDDY
description: I WANT TO BE AN ASTRONAUT Written and illustrated by Byron Barton. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell.

title: LYING FOR DOLLARS
description: ALL THE RIGHT ANSWERS By Robert Noah. 294 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: NEW JERSEY FOLLOW-UP
description: Bottle Issue A PROPOSED ordinance to require refundable beverage containers in Mercer County was defeated at the polls Tuesday by a vote of 79,674 to 31,243.

title: UConn Panel Is to Study Racial Abuse
description: IT has taken nearly a year, but this week the University of Connecticut Faculty Senate is to establish a special panel to investigate a racial incident involving eight Asian students.

title: A Plea For Surprises
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Panelized Housing Brings Industry Changes
description: LEAD: On a recent rainy day, building sites had turned into quagmires and most exterior work on houses had come to a halt.

title: Biography Is Focus At Books Meeting
description: LEAD: FOR three years, the Foundation for Westchester Community College has sponsored a literary symposium that has brought notable authors to the Valhalla campus. The tradition will continue at the Fourth Annual Literary Symposium, which this year will focus on biography and autobiography. It will take place from 3 to 5 P.M.

title: WISHES COME TRUE
description: THE FOURTH GRADE WIZARDS By Barthe DeClements. 122 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Miss Schubauer To Marry Dec. 18
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James W. Schubauer of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Hilton Head, S.C., of the engagement of their daughter Kirsten Lee Schubauer to Steven Donald Heinemann, a son of Mrs. Frank Jaeger of Arlington, Va., and Donald Heinemann of Fort Lee, N.J. The couple plan to marry on Dec. 18.

title: City Seeks 'Signature' Sculpture
description: ST. LOUIS has its Gateway Arch and San Francisco the Golden Gate Bridge. Now, New Haven is looking for something to mark the entrance to the city.

title: Sometimes Fortune Comes Right to the Doorstep
description: A FEW weeks ago I was an unwitting party to a crime. It happened on our second day in a country house we had rented for the winter. As I was washing dishes I looked out of the window and saw a large dog tussling on the lawn with a mysterious black object. It was raining hard and my husband dragged on his coat and went outside to investigate. There were feathers everywhere. The black object was an enormous wild turkey.

title: 'Clean Eating' for the Holidays
description: LEAD: IF any clear trend in our eating habits emerged over the last year it is a sudden and serious interest in clean eating, that is, consuming not too much sugar, going easy on meat fats, favoring certain fish for their cholesterol-countering properties and eyeing dairy products with suspicion.

title: Stirling Cassidy And Blair Smith To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Catherine Stirling Cassidy to Blair Webster Smith has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Arch Wilson Cassidy of Jacksonville, Fla. Mr. Smith is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Kaye Smith of Potomac, Md., and John's Island, Fla. A May wedding is planned. Miss Cassidy, who is known as Stirling, graduated from the Madeira School and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. She is a member of the Junior League of New York and was until recently a marketing consultant with the Equitable Financial Companies in New York. Her father is an agency manager for the Equitable Life Assuarance Society of the United States in Jacksonville. The future bride is a granddaughter of Arch Richard Cassidy of Jacksonville, who retired as an agency manager for the Equitable.

title: U.S. Jews Criticize Plan to Redefine Who Is a Jew
description: Twenty-seven national Jewish organizations, said to represent 90 percent of American Jews, yesterday called on the political leaders of Israel to ''heed the overwhelming voice of Diaspora Jewry'' and reject efforts to change the definition of who is a Jew.

title: Stamford Actor Meets Broadway's Challenges
description: WHEN Jeffrey De Munn was chosen to play Kate Nelligan's former husband in the Broadway production of ''Spoils of War'' last summer, he knew it was a focal but unfulfilled role. ''But I'm glad to know you're working on it,'' he recalled saying at the time to the production's playwright, Michael Weller.

title: Dr. Lawrence Madoff Is Wed to Nancy Eng
description: Nancy Eng, the daughter of Jean Eng of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and the late Shew Wai Eng, and Dr. Lawrence Madoff were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Morton Madoff of Lexington, Mass. Associate Justice Hiller B. Zobel of the Superior Court of Massachusetts in Boston officiated.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 13, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 2 2 15 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 3 5 4 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer. 4 3 8 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 5 4 5 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Colonel Qazi, an ''international terrorist,'' plots to steal American nuclear weapons. 6 7 2 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find themselves in a fantasy world where the possibilities of their pasts still exist. 7 * 8 14 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $19.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters from pre-World War I Paris to present-day Los Angeles. 8 11 2 MITLA PASS, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A writer's struggles with his heritage and two loves reach a climax during the 1956 Sinai war. 9 6 20 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 10 10 39 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 11 14 2 DRAGONSDAWN, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/ Ballantine, $18.95.) The colonists who settle on a paradisiacal planet make plans to keep it from being destroyed by a strange force. 12 12 54 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 13 9 6 PRIME TIME, by Joan Collins. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Five actresses compete for a glamorous role in Hollywood. 14 29 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 15 13 7 KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Dutton, $19.95.) Three Vietnam veterans on the trail of a friend who may be responsible for a series of murders. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 30 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 2 2 4 THE LAST LION, by William Manchester. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 3 4 3 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 4 3 5 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 5 1 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 6 11 2 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 7 9 19 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 8 5 12 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, steel mill worker, haberdashery salesman, film star, father and man. 9 6 5 SURVIVING THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) What Americans and their Government should do in the face of economic disaster. 10 * 7 3 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona and 1964 Republican Presidential nominee. 11 8 6 LANDSLIDE, by Jane Mayer and Doyle McManus. (Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Two reporters on ''the unmaking of the President, 1984-1988.'' 12 13 17 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman who married King Edward VIII. 13 17 GENERATION OF SWINE, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) Commentary on the current decade. 14 * 12 14 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of the 1969 accident on Chappaquiddick Island. 15 10 48 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 71 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 32 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 4 10 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur who deals in life insurance and investments. 4 3 5 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 5 5 163 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE MASTER OF THE GAME: Paul Nitze and the Nuclear Peace, by Strobe Talbott. (Knopf, $19.95.) A solid history of the nuclear age and of Mr. Nitze's place in it, especially as the central figure in the development of arms control in the Reagan Administration. SELECTED STORIES, by Andre Dubus. (Godine, $22.50.) Mr. Dubus's seventh collection of short fiction deals with the usually hidden lives of ordinary people; even when the tale turns to violence, interest resides in his sketching of concrete detail. ORIGINAL INTENT AND THE FRAMERS' CONSTITUTION, by Leonard W. Levy. (Macmillan, $19.95.) A leading constitutional historian argues that our governmental structure cannot be bound by the Framers' intentions (when they are known) because it has developed in ways they never could have anticipated. SELECTED LETTERS OF EUGENE O'NEILL, edited by Travis Bogard and Jackson R. Bryer. (Yale University, $35.) Nearly 600 letters of our only Nobel Prize-winning playwright, many published for the first time, revealing him in such aspects as theater agent, overwhelmed husband and lifelong anarchist. EUGENE O'NEILL: Complete Plays, edited by Travis Bogard. (Library of America, three volumes, $35 each; boxed set, $100.) This is it: 50 plays, in order of writing, with meticulous notes and chronology, in the Library of America's usual elegant format. MASCARA, by Ariel Dorfman. (Viking, $17.95.) The third novel (and the first written in English) by one of Latin America's most versatile writers explores human identity and political paranoia in the story of a nameless man born without an identifiable face. THE SHAH'S LAST RIDE: The Fate of an Ally, by William Shawcross. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The political and medical undoing of the Shah, culminating in the ''medical soap opera,'' starring doctors from five countries, that preceded his end.

title: Melissa Jay Greenwald Engaged to Rolf Kat
description: Melissa Jay Greenwald's engagement to Rolf Kat, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dirk Kat of Soest, the Netherlands, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Burton J. Greenwald of Philadelphia. A June wedding is planned.

title: Closing Arguments in Davis Trial Are to Begin
description: After 16 weeks of testimony by 73 witnesses, prosecutors and defense lawyers are to present their closing arguments tomorrow in the trial of Larry Davis.

title: Company Readies 'Barber of Seville'
description: OVER the years, opera companies have come and gone with distressing regularity, but with any luck perhaps the Westchester Opera is here to stay. Formed about a year ago with the double goal of providing performing showcases for major new talent and bringing professional-level productions to the county, the fledgling company has already developed an impressive list of corporate contributors and given several fine evenings of operatic music.

title: Soviets Reschedule First Space Shuttle Launching
description: The first launching of the Soviet space shuttle, scrubbed once because of a technical mishap in the final minute of countdown, has been rescheduled for Tuesday, the Tass press agency announced today.

title: Creating Art, and Artists, in the South Bronx
description: ''It's about an outsider, a guy who doesn't fit on the block or something. He falls in love with this girl who rejects him because he's too weird, he's too much of a nerd. And so, in sadness, he walks in the night, and as he walks the snow starts falling gently, very gently.''

title: Philadelphia Freeing 100
description: Philadelphia, acting under a court-ordered plan to relieve prison overcrowding, has begun releasing 100 more inmates awaiting trial. The release, which will take several days, was ordered Friday because the city has been violating a limit of 3,750 inmates, imposed by Federal District Court.

title: Giving Homeless Spending Money
description: GIVE the 10,000 single men and women living in New York City shelters for the homeless a modest cash allowance every month, the theory went, and it will spur them to take more responsibility for their lives and reduce the number of panhandlers on the streets.

title: STAR TREKKING
description: While Peter Mehlman is happy to spot celebrities, I harbor deeper notions (About Men: ''Star Trekking,'' Oct. 16). I fantasize that, in a chance encounter with one of my particular favorites, like Woody Allen, I will utter the perfect few words that will enable him to recognize me as a soul mate and we will become instant best friends.

title: Edwin W. Olson, Builder, 67
description: Edwin W. Olson, a director of construction at Columbia University, died Thursday of liver cancer at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cookie Mix Is Recalled After Glass Found
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is recalling three batches of its Duncan Hines Chocolate Chip Cookie Mix after customers reported finding glass inside the boxes.

title: Michigan Clinches Bowl Bid
description: Bo Schembechler is taking Michigan to the Rose Bowl for the ninth time in his 20 years as head coach of the Wolverines.

title: Secrecy on Adoptions Upheld
description: A Federal district judge in Dallas has ruled that adoptive parents have no constitutional right to records that go into detail on abuses suffered by children before adoption.

title: Late Touchdown Gives Army 7th Victory in Row
description: Army added a glorious chapter to its football history today, driving 63 yards for a winning touchdown in the waning moments of play to score a dramatic 24-19 triumph over Vanderbilt and virtually insure the Cadets of a berth in the Sun Bowl in El Paso, Tex., Dec. 24.

title: MAN DID THIS TO MAN
description: A SEASON FOR HEALING Reflections on the Holocaust. By Anne Roiphe. 220 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: THE NATION: Regulating Campaigns; How Some Other Countries Do It
description: West Germany: Campaigns may start 10 months before Election Day ... no limits on campaign spending ... sources of campaign funds include party membership fees and the state ... parties are allocated paid time on Government television stations, with the amount of time determined by how many seats they have. Turnout in last election: 84.4 percent. Britain: Once election is called, campaigning generally lasts three weeks ... on national level, parties not limited as to how much they can spend ... free air time allocated, based on strength in previous election. Turnout in last election: 75.3 percent. France: Candidates have access to official advertising billboards ... use of commercial print media or billboard advertising to promote candidates is prohibited ... candidates receive up to two cost-free hours of radio and television time ... fairness monitored by national commission ... disclosing results of public opinion polls in week before election prohibited, as is exit polling. Turnout in last election: 65.7 percent. Israel: Campaigns generally last three to four months ... no limits on campaign spending ... each party allocated state money in proportion to seats in Parliament ... television time also allotted according to strength. Turnout in last election: 79 percent. Italy: Voting not compulsory, but system exists for publicly identifying who has voted and who has not ... parties receive campaign money from state ... each party gets time on state television, based on party size, and can buy as much time as it wants on commercial channels. Turnout in last election: 88.8 percent. Denmark: Citizenship and residency required for parliamentary elections, but not for local elections, in which permanent residents can vote ... inmates of mental institutions cannot vote, but prisoners can ... no limits on campaign spending and no requirement for disclosing contributions ... parties represented in old Parliament and running for new one get equal time on state radio ... parties and candidates can buy time on local radio ... candidates cannot take part in quiz-shows or other non-news presentations on state radio or television during campaign. Turnout in last election: 85.7 percent. Japan: Registration to vote is automatic, at age 20, for all citizens who have registered with ward offices for social benefits, including enrollment in school ... law limits campaign spending, with amount depending on size of district, but many subterfuges are available ... for both houses, candidate gets free air time in six-minute sessions, five sessions on television and three on radio ... almost no tradition of debating. Turnout in last election: 71.4 percent.

title: Psychology Of Aging: Four Types
description: Linda Barbanel was recently driving in Hilton Head, an expensive resort off the coast of South Carolina, when she saw a big camper sporting a bumper sticker that read, ''We are spending our children's inheritance.'' The sight delighted her.

title: Baseball Notebook; Players Can Share Information Bank's 'Assets'
description: One lawyer calls it the greatest bank in the world. ''You don't have to make any deposits,'' he said, ''and you can make all the withdrawals you want.''

title: Churches Find the Message of the Season is Debt and Donations
description: Church leaders may soon be peppering sermons with talk of flexible freezes and revenue enhancements. The biggest interdenominational news of the season is debt.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: South Berwick, Me.; Panelized Affordability
description: THE largest home builder in the state is addressing one of the state's biggest housing problems - affordability - in Maine's largest development, this community's 110-acre Agamenticus Estates.

title: SOME TOUGH CHALLENGES FOR REAL ESTATE INVESTORS
description: ''The best investment is land, because they ain't making any more of it.'' Will Rogers

title: FICTION
description: WAITING TO VANISH. By Ann Hood. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) This spare and elegant novel, Ann Hood's second, is about the disintegration of a New England family after a freak accident: Alexander, everyone's favorite, is electrocuted during a thunderstorm as he talks on the telephone with his child. For months afterward, 6-year-old Sam refuses to speak, fearing, not unreasonably, that if he does he too will vanish. Other family members react differently to the tragedy, but all are devastated. Alexander's mother, Cal, impulsively leaves home for a new bohemian life in San Francisco; her husband, Jams, becomes a kleptomaniac, making stealing into a symbolic vengeance for the loss of his offspring. Curiously, the central figure in this drama is the least realized: Alexander's sister, Mackenzie, a photographer whose emotional life has been immobilized by her brother's fate. Mackenzie continually remembers the old family home in Rhode Island, imagining her childhood with Alexander as a perfect idyll - yet wondering now and then, as does the reader, whether she isn't inventing most of it. Ms. Hood's descriptions of Mackenzie are rather generic and improbable (''everything she touches . . . turns not to gold, but to platinum''); her lover, Jason, orders roses to match the color of her hair. Yet ''Waiting to Vanish'' is tougher and truer than it first appears. There are many ways of overcoming the past, not all of them noble; the solution for Ms. Hood's characters - as perhaps for most people, in and out of fiction - is not to face it at all, but rather to discover protected venues where the harsher truths may once again be silent.

title: Elderly Fighting Back on Medicare Surtax
description: To the Editor:

title: Emancipation Age Question: Readers Respond; Gas: Burning Up Our Energy Future
description: As talk stirs of getting on the natural gas bandwagon [ ''Energy Battle Looms Over Gas Pipelines,'' Oct. 23 ] , let me share my prophesy.

title: The Man Who Defined Modern Jazz
description: There's a magic moment in ''Swingmatism'' when Charlie Parker, 20 years old, steps out in front of the orchestra to solo. Tacking an entirely new musical language on the door of convention, his saxophone floats serenely over the swing-style horn section. The piece, recorded in 1941 by the big-band leader Jay McShann, roars along, and Parker, flicking lines out to catch melody notes, reworks the tune's harmony, all the while using a new rhythmic system. Nearly half a century later, his solo is still startling in its originality. It's a call to arms, and a beautiful, exhilarating one at that.

title: Lincoln Center Sends Out Search Parties
description: It is a time for seriousness and searching at the Metropolitan Opera as well as the New York Philharmonic. The opera will need a general manager when Bruce Crawford leaves on April 1 to return to the business world from which he came, and the orchestra is already searching for a replacement for Zubin Mehta, who will retire as music director of the Philharmonic when his contract expires in 1991.

title: Candidates Are Emerging For Top Posts Under Bush
description: As President-elect Bush gives final consideration to those who will form the inner circle of his Government, others are emerging as candidates for additional high-ranking posts.

title: Harper Names Publisher
description: Eddie Bell, the managing director of the William Collins Sons general book division, has been named publisher of Harper & Row's newly created mass-market paperback division. The division will issue its first titles next year. Collins, a British publishing house, is co-owner - with Rupert Murdoch's News America Publications - of Harper & Row.

title: FAMILY PRIDE
description: Brunello di Montalcino is the legendary red wine of Italy. Fabulously expensive, it is revered by connoisseurs around the world, who vie with each other to praise its depth and power, its wondrous complexity and its astonishing ability to last for decades. Well, maybe. And maybe not. The

title: Headliners; Trade Disagreement
description: Marjorie M. Bowker figured she ought to read the Candian-American free-trade agreement before officials in Ottawa signed it on behalf of her and her fellow citizens.

title: Karen Snowe Is Wed To Richard G. Welger
description: At Congregation Ohr-Torah in North Woodmere, L.I., Karen Jill Snowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Snowe of Commack, L.I., was married last evening to Richard Glen Welger, a son of Harris I. Welger of New York and the late Barbara Welger. Rabbi Solomon Rothstein, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Curing a Computer Virus
description: Last week, the Federal Bureau of Investigation initiated an investigation into the virus program reportedly written by Robert T. Morris Jr., a graduate student at Cornell University, that clogged the Pentagon's Arpanet research network and paralyzed an estimated 6,000 computers around the nation. A handful of computer installations escaped because they had plugged loopholes. Indeed, business and government are beginning to take viruses more seriously. Can computers really be made more secure? John M. McAfee Chairman, Computer Virus Industry Association.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SOMERSET HOMECOMING: Recovering a Lost Heritage. By Dorothy Spruill Redford with Michael D'Orso. Introduction by Alex Haley. (Doubleday, $18.95.) ''Somerset Homecoming'' is the moving story of how one black woman, inspired by Alex Haley's ''Roots,'' discovered her family's heritage. During the 1950's, when Ms.

title: KIDS IN THE FAST LANE
description: Was anyone else as bothered as I was by Sara Davidson's article on family privilege in Los Angeles? Behind the introspection was a cheer for the good times she and others enjoy. Who really cares about the micro-dilemmas of wealthy families? Next time, get someone to tell us about the dreams and rituals of being a poor child in Los Angeles. KENNELL A. JACKSON JR. Stanford, Calif.

title: Airports
description: To the Editor: Can we convince the airlines to install an electronic arrival information display outside their terminals - perhaps even on the way into Kennedy International Airport? Calling on the telephone for arrival information is not always possible - and even if reached, flight delays may occur, thus crowding the terminal. Sometimes you think you've arrived on time to meet a passenger and think it unnecessary to park (why lug heavy suitcases from terminal to parking place?). But then you find out - after temporarily double parking to run inside to get arrival information and hoping the policemen don't ticket your car - that the plane is delayed. And that can be quite a hassle.

title: Computers; Welcome to Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Horowitz Gives Recordings Of Carnegie Concerts to Yale
description: The acclaimed pianist Vladimir Horowitz has donated to Yale University 218 original recordings of Carnegie Hall concerts he gave during the 1940's and 1950's.

title: Mickey Mouse And Tick-Tack-Toe At the Japan Society
description: Japanese folk textiles - awash with dragons snorting fire, profusions of peonies, squares within squares and Mickey Mouse playing baseball - are lending drama to the interiors of the Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street. The exhibition of boldly graphic images on tie-dyed cloth, indigo dipped cottons, kimonos and quilted fireman's coats, will remain through Dec. 11.

title: Burger King May Go It Alone
description: A spinoff of Burger King is Pillsbury's plan for thwarting a takeover bid by Grand Metropolitan of Britain. The plan includes heavy borrowing by Burger King to pay a big dividend to shareholders. The hope is that shareholders will prefer the entire package - the dividend plus the new Burger King shares plus their Pillsbury shares - to Grand Met's offer of $60 a share in cash. Pillsbury gave no details on the dividend's size, but Pillsbury shares did not rise above the $60 Grand Met offered, a sign of Wall Street skepticism about the worth of the package. Many Burger King franchisees objected to the plan, contending that the huge debt would divert cash better spent on improving restaurants and promotions. Burger King, the No. 2 fast-food chain after McDonald's, has seen its performance lag in recent years. Grand Met, meanwhile, disclosed that its offer had attracted 74.3 percent of Pillsbury shares.

title: Q And A; Disparity in Rent Increases
description: Question: I recently received from the Office of Rent Administration a notice telling me that the maximum base rent on my rent-controlled apartment would be increased by 16.4 percent for 1988-1989. This increase is much higher than the 9 percent increase for tenants on two-year leases in rent-stabilized apartments. Why is there such disparity between the two rent-regulation programs? . . . W. G., Manhattan Answer: According to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the disparity exists because of the difference in the way the increase for each system is calculated. The maximum base rent, as well as the maximum collectible rent, for tenants in rent-controlled apartments is based on a mathmatical formula established by law in the 60's. The increases for rent-stabilized units are set by the Rent Guidelines Board. When determining allowable increases each year the board takes into consideration such factors as inflation and increases or decreases in building operating costs. It also considers information from public hearings held before each increase.

title:
DINING OUT;
Variety in Fare Sets the Tone in Oldwick
description: LEAD: THE Tewksbury Inn, which is not actually in Tewksbury but in Oldwick, dates from the early 19th century, and redecorations notwithstanding, it looks pretty much as it must have at the turn of the century.

title: JAMAICA'S GANGS TAKE ROOT IN U.S.
description: A few years ago the police in Jamaica were at war with violent gangs that roamed the desperately poor slums of the capital.

title:
ART;
Illustrators' Works: Look Is Familiar
description: LEAD: VISITORS to ''The Illustrator's Art,'' an exhibition on view through Dec. 18 at the Sabbeth Art Gallery of the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove, are more likely to recognize the works on display than the names of those who made them.

title:
INVESTING;
Will Boeing Add East to West?
description: LEAD: WHEN LOT, Poland's national airline, recently ordered three Boeing 767 passenger jets, the news was not the size of the deal. At $220 million, it was small potatoes for Boeing, which may top $17 billion in sales this year.

title: Journalists Practice What They Publish
description: It has been raining, raining, raining. Now it is snowing, flakes fleeing a nasty wind. Hardly convertible weather. But the new company car is very much a convertible, and the employees are acting like it's August.

title: Perspectives: Co-op Conversions; Ownership Prospects Brighten for Blacks
description: Most black families in New York City live in rental housing. But the 1987 housing census found that 136,000 black households owned their own housing. The number is higher than in any other city except perhaps Detroit, although it is only 19 percent of the total number of black households in New York.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; Auburn Thwarts Georgia By 20-10
description: Reggie Slack threw for two touchdowns on bootleg rollouts as Auburn knocked Georgia out of the Southeastern Conference race and kept its title hopes alive with a 20-10 victory today.

title: Gordon Is Back on Sack Duty
description: The Jets' best hope to get a sack -remember the last time the Jets got to a quarterback? - returns today.

title: In Town 'Liberated' by Sudan Rebels, Refugees Wither as Food Trickles In
description: Cartons of medicines, soap, disinfectant and bed sheets were heaved out of a small plane onto the dirt strip here, the latest dispatch in the slim supply line that trickles into this forlorn rebel-held town in the southernmost Sudan.

title: A Growing Backlash Against Greed
description: REVULSION over the frenzied battle to buy RJR Nabisco Inc. for the unprecedented price of more than $20 billion may do something that neither the insider-trading scandal nor any other mega-acquisition has accomplished: stir Washington and investors to try to curb takeovers.

title: THE REGION: Careers in Congress; A Local Lesson: It's Hard to Get From the House To the Senate
description: THERE are two sides to the power of incumbency in Congress: It does pay, but seniority in the Senate can make the House a home.

title: Closing on Sunday: Will It Always Be in England?
description: In England, you can buy a newspaper legally on Sunday, but not a book; drugs in a drugstore, but not dental floss; partly cooked tripe at the butcher's, but not fresh meat.

title: Strange's Lead Holds Up Again
description: Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion, lost the lead in the $5 million Nabisco Championships today for the first time since it began Thursday. But it was only a temporary four-hole lapse as the 33-year-old Virginian birdied the 15th and 16th holes on Pebble Beach Golf Links to regain the lead going into the final round Sunday.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
LITCHFIELD
description: LEAD: The center of the Borough of Litchfield, a 279-year-old, square-mile, rural community nestled among the rugged hills of northwestern Connecticut, seems misplaced in time. Only two and a half hours from New York City, it holds so much Colonial-era architecture that a saddled horse looks more appropriate there than a

title:
ART;
Landscapes by Cropsey at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich
description: LEAD: JASPER FRANCIS CROPSEY, a stalwart of the Hudson River School of landscape painting, was known as the Painter of Autumn. Currently at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Cropsey's reputation is being expanded, as the show is titled ''A Man for All Seasons.''

title: Philippine Rebel Leader Escapes During Birthday Party for Captor
description: The reputed leader of the Communist rebel army in the Philippines escaped from detention in a military camp today after being allowed to attend the birthday party of an officer he had befriended, a military spokesman said.

title: Shell and Denver Law Firm Sued in Pollution Case
description: The Shell Oil Company and a large Denver law firm have been charged in a suit with conspiring to conceal years of pollution at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal near here.

title: Why Westinghouse Likes Its New Atom Plant Role
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is a diverse company -pre-eminent manufacturer of civilian nuclear reactors, a major electronics supplier to the Pentagon, manufacturer of consumer goods, among other things - and it is looking to expand further, into the cleanup of radioactive and other hazardous waste. That is a major reason why it is one of the few companies that have expressed willingness to manage the nation's nuclear bomb production effort.

title: The Free-Needle Program Is Under Way and Under Fire
description: NEW YORK CITY has begun to give drug users free hypodermic needles in an experimental program intended to determine, ultimately, whether access to sterile needles can slow the spread of the AIDS virus. But when the long-delayed distribution started Monday, opponents of the plan far outnumbered the addicts asking for needles.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a review of ''The Sixth Great Power'' on Oct. 23 misattributed the statement ''There are six great powers in Europe: England, France, Prussia, Austria, Russia and the Baring Brothers.'' The author was the Duc de Richelieu, not Cardinal Richelieu.

title: Question Of the Week; Can the N.H.L. Stop Sticking Incidents?
description: If the N.H.L. gave harsher punishments to those who do use their sticks savagely and also to those who instigate the incident. The length of the suspension or the publicity surrounding the incident should not differ if the player involved is a superstar or a journeyman. CHRIS FARBER New York

title: Donald Judd's Boxes Are Enclosed by the 60's
description: It is hard to survey postwar American sculpture without inspecting the boxes of Donald Judd. These clean, untouchable objects, forever virginal, always looking as if they had only just been been created, have become almost synonymous with Minimalism. They are products of the 1960's, when American art was at its most ideological and brash. And they are products of an incisive and dogmatic intelligence and a belief that it was possible to bury European art forever. It is not easy to be indifferent about that decade or about him.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sunday about illegal dumping in the Atlantic Ocean incorrectly rendered remarks by Vito Turso, a spokesman for the New York City Sanitation Department, on the city's use of barges. He confirmed that the city had dumped dredged material on them, but did not say that it had placed trash on them.

title: 35-Nation Conference Addresses Global Warming
description: Representatives of 35 countries, including the United States, have begun an international effort to evaluate global climate trends and map policies to cope with the drastic consequences that a global warming would have on human life.

title: The Rich Are Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Lynn E. Usdan, a Lawyer, Weds Richard I. Shapiro
description: Lynn Ellen Usdan, a daughter of Morton Usdan of New York and Betty Zwickler of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard I. Shapiro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Shapiro of Lawrence, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Allan Blaine at the Helmsley Palace in New York.

title: Solomon Murder Trial Makes Live TV History
description: THE satellite news-gathering truck is cramped. The truck operator, cameraman and reporter, all slim, touch elbows as they sit facing the rows of television monitors, dials and oscilloscopes. Put five large people in this $400,000 mobile television studio-transmitting station and you would reach maximum operating capacity.

title: Review/Ballet; The Joffrey's Diaghilev Bill
description: The Joffrey Ballet's Diaghilev program received a nicely danced but relatively low-key performance on Thursday at City Center. Taking on the role of the Chosen One in Vaslav Nijinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps,'' Carole Valleskey suffered toward the end from that same diminished intensity.

title: Absurd Lawsuits?
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY ROAD BLOCKED, AFGHAN REBELS SAY
description: Afghan guerrillas said today that they had blocked the road north from Kabul to the Soviet border in an offensive that killed 20 Soviet soldiers.

title: Miss Hall to Wed Michael S. Cashel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Hall of New York and Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Ann Hall to Michael S. Cashel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Cashel of New Canaan, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: Amber Waves of . . . Broccoli? Endive?
description: BELGIAN endive may not have been the biggest issue of the recent Presidential campaign, but it made news in the farm belt. In a campaign stop in Omaha, Vice President-elect Dan Quayle attacked Gov. Michael Dukakis's one-time focus on Belgian endive as the kind of alternative crop that American farmers should consider. ''He suggested blueberries and Belgian endive,'' said Mr. Quayle, holding aloft an endive and drawing laughs from his farm audience.

title: For 600 Years, Shroud of Turin Has Been Known as a Forgery
description: To the Editor:

title: A Glamorous Trio To Grow Indoors
description: If anyone were to inquire about the hardest house plants to please, a trio of hanging plants immediately comes to mind: star of Bethlehem, winter-flowering jasmine and winged pea. They are also three of the most glamorous and when victory is won, efforts are well rewarded.

title: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS
description: (Residential in millions of dollars)

title: President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: The White House By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation

title: Reviews/Dance; Central American Tensions
description: Nothing on stage indicated specifically where Manuel Alum and his dancers were supposed to be. Yet the tensions of Mr. Alum's choreography always revealed that they were in troubled, dangerous places.

title: Market Place; Coniston Facing Barriers on TW
description: REMEMBER the kid in your neighborhood who was always willing to give up part of his lunch to avoid a fight with a bully? That's the reputation TW Services Inc. had on Wall Street when the latest raider to appear on its doorstep, Coniston Partners, approached in September.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 Soviet entrepreneurs have it rough as they fend off obstructive bureaucrats, envious professional rivals, criminal rackets and a public that seems increasingly hostile. Page A1

title: Rise and Fall of Peronists
description: June 1943 - A coup ousts President Ramos Castillo. Juan Domingo Peron, a colonel a political philosophy, becomes Minister of Labor the next year. February 1946 - In elections called by the military regime, Peron wins the presidency on a platform supporting greater economic and social benefits for workers. The Government begins a program of nationalization, and the armed forces play an increasingly oppressive role in the country's political life. Constitutional rights are restricted. April 1954 - Taking an anti-American stand, Peron is elected to a third term. He arrests five leaders of the opposition Radical Civic Union, including its vice presidential candidate. September 1955 - Amid growing popular discontent over inflation, oppression and corruption, Peron is ousted in a coup. He flees into exile in Spain. November 1972 - Peron is allowed to return to Argentina. July 1973 - President Hector J. Campora, a Peron backer elected because Peron is barred from running for office, resigns to make way for Peron, who takes office in October on a ticket that includes his wife, Isabel. She becomes the first woman to serve as a vice president in Latin America. July 1974 - Juan Peron dies. Mrs. Peron assumes the presidency but loses control of the Peron factions. Political violence increases and the economy falters. March 1976 - A coup led by Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla topples Mrs. Peron. She is put under house arrest. The Government begins the ''dirty war'' against the left. Almost 12,000 people are eventually killed. March 1981 - Gen. Roberto Eduardo Viola becomes President, followed by Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri. He frees Mrs. Peron, who goes into exile in Spain. May 1982 - Argentine forces invade the Falklands. Britain retakes the islands after six weeks of fighting; 255 Britons and 712 Argentines die and 14,000 Argentines are captured. Three days later, General Galtieri resigns. December 1983 - Eight years of army rule end with the election of Raul Alfonsin of the Radical Civic Union as President.

title: Review/Theater; Shaw and Philip Bosco Together Once More
description: While there are no sure things in the New York theater, the partnership of George Bernard Shaw and Philip Bosco comes close. This playwright and this actor, often in league with the director Stephen Porter, have been an irresistible, nearly inseparable pair for over a decade, whether converging at the Roundabout Theater (for ''Misalliance'') or at the Circle in the Square (for ''Major Barbara,'' to name a favorite among many). Good as Mr. Bosco has been in a wide variety of roles during his long career, Shaw seems to bring out the Ralph Richardson in him. It doesn't matter if the actor is playing one of the writer's magnates or servants or supermen: an exquisitely facetious twinkle lights up his eyes, a droll musicality infuses his chalky comic voice.

title: Review/Television; The Vices and Virtues Of a Star TV Reporter
description: Can a weekly series find happiness (i.e., ratings) with a heroine who has just returned from the Betty Ford Clinic and, though no longer drinking or smoking, still wouldn't hesitate to lie and cheat when it comes to maintaining her high-powered career? Well, it's possible, even likely, if this formidable character is being played by Candice Bergen. She has the title role in ''Murphy Brown,'' which has its premiere tonight at 9 on CBS.

title: Early Resort Openings Offer Savings for Skiers
description: IT is virtually a tradition: Killington, in Vermont, is the first Eastern ski resort to open in the fall and the last one to close in late spring. An exception occurred last season when Stratton Mountain beat Killington by one hour after a snowstorm on Oct. 4.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What major league batter hit safely in the most games during a full season?

title: Sports World Specials; Another World
description: After a ski racer has won two world championship golds, come in first four times in the United States nationals and a won a gold medal at the Olympics, not much would seem to remain to conquer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; U.S. Houses Look Abroad At Long Last
description: ONE of the most striking features of American book publishing is how quickly it has come to be dominated by foreigners.

title: Norwalk Bomb Inquiry: Did Suspect Have Help?
description: Anti-terrorist investigators have begun a major inquiry to determine if an animal-rights advocate seized in Connecticut last week had help making a sophisticated bomb that the police said she planted outside a company that uses dogs in medical procedures.

title: Disgruntled Argentines Give New Vigor to Party of Peron
description: With Argentines already dismayed by the slump in their living standards since democracy returned five years ago, a surge of support for the opposition Peronist party is feeding new political uncertainty as general elections approach.

title: Watch What We Do
description: ''Watch what we do, not what we say,'' Attorney General John Mitchell advised reporters at the start of the Nixon Administration.

title: Reviews/Music; Shunning the Genteel
description: The New York Amati Trio made its New York debut on Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall, and its members - Paul Ostrovsky, pianist; Piotr Milewski, violinist, and Yosif Feigelson, cellist - made it clear from the start that they did not intend to offer an evening of pretty, genteel chamber playing. The salient features of the group's performance were an ensemble sound that except for a few fleeting lapses was a model of precision, flexibility and unanimity, and an infectious drive, evident even in hushed slow movements.

title: Bridge
description: One of the minor advantages that President-elect George Bush will have in dealing with China is a recreational one: He will be able, on a personal level, to socialize with the leaders of the country in ways that President Reagan could not.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Puerto Rican TV Deal Attracts Investor Group
description: LEAD: An agreement last week by Cohen Cassara & Company to buy Puerto Rico's leading television station, WKAQ of San Juan, from the Telemundo Group Inc. for $160 million in cash is the latest venture of Anthony B. Cassara.

title: Hijacker Defends Achille Lauro Killing
description: Abul Abbas, the Palestinian who planned the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985, spoke publicly today about the incident, comparing the killing of an elderly American Jew aboard the ship to an automobile accident.

title: Wings Surge Past Rangers
description: Jacques Demers, the coach of the Red Wings, wanted to make clear that no disrespect toward the Rangers was intended by his calling a timeout with 12 seconds left in the game last night and his team ahead, 5-3.

title: Smarter Ways to Fight Pests
description: The age of chemical pesticides is far from over, but it can hardly end soon enough. Last month, Congress finally revised the pesticide law, making it easier to get the most dangerous chemicals off the market. But the more permanent solution lies in developing new and subtler technologies for combating pests, like biological controls and the new genetic alchemy of biotechnology.

title: Michael J. Rabin Wed To Carol A. Fierstein
description: Carol Ann Fierstein, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Fierstein of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Jay Rabin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rabin of New York. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Man Is Shot to Death After Traffic Dispute
description: An argument after a minor traffic accident here this weekend left a computer analyst from New Jersey dead and a truck driver from North Carolina charged with killing him.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; For the U.S. and Japan, The Power of Brands
description: The United States and Japan own eight of the 10 most powerful brand names in the Western world, according to a new study by Landor Associates, the San Francisco-based corporate image consultant.

title: E.M.D.S.J.K.C.Q.J.A.W. Peters
description: Mary and Gerald Peters wanted all their six children to have a part in naming the latest. The result: Eric Michael David Stephen Joshua Kevin Carl Quentin Jesse Alexander William Peters. The parents picked Eric, Kevin, Carl and William, and the children picked the rest for the baby, born Oct. 26.

title: Burger King's Angry Franchisees
description: In the world of Burger King franchisees, Steven M. Lewis is a winner. The 21 Burger Kings he and a partner own in the Philadelphia area generate profits of more than $3 million a year. But Mr. Lewis is not entirely happy with the Burger King Corporation and its owner, the Pillsbury Company.

title: Private Soviet Entrepreneurs, Under Fire, Try Closing Ranks
description: When Viktor I. Korchagin joined the budding private business sector, he was after money, not love. He did not expect, however, to be quite so unloved.

title: Sports of The Times; Flutie Not Great, but Good Enough
description: COMING through the Giants Stadium tunnel after the Patriots' 14-13 victory over the Jets yesterday, Doug Flutie was approached for a postgame interview on NBC television. Most pro football players would have hurried to the nearest camera and smiled, but the little quarterback hurried to the Patriots' locker room.

title: Sudan's Premier Is Visiting Libya After Proposal for Unity Is Signed
description: In the wake of a surprise Sudan-Libya unity proposal signed by delegations of the two nations last month, the Sudanese Prime Minister, Sadiq al-Mahdi, leaves today for Tripoli for a visit with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Cardinals Topple Giants
description: At age 31, Roy Green is playing his 10th season in the National Football League. He is a fast and elusive wide receiver, a game breaker.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: Pam Shriver vs. Sylvia Hanika, 5:45 P.M.

title: On Your Own; Paragliding Comes Into Its Own
description: For mountain climbers and long-distance hikers, the most exhausting part of a trek can be the walk back. But now there is a way to get off a slope in a fraction of the time it took to reach the summit.

title: Role of Politics In Budget Gap
description: On Friday, when the State Budget Director announced that New York's budget gap had grown to $1.9 billion and the state would have to slash several hundred millon dollars from its spending plan, few state officials seemed eager to propose cost-cutting measures.

title: College Basketball; Big East Teams Moving Toward Parity
description: Personnel is the lifeblood of any conference and the preliminary evidence suggests that the Big East, which is entering its 10th season, has more resources at its disposal than ever before.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Olympic Panel Names Officials
description: Robert Helmick was nominated for a second term as president of the United States Olympic Committee today. George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, and four other men were nominated as officers.

title: Sports World Specials; Second Chance
description: It is lucky that basketball courts are open spaces. If James Naismith had scattered a few obstacles around the floor when he was inventing the game, Greg Foster might have made his high school team.

title: BRADY TO REMAIN IN TREASURY POST, BUSH ADVISERS SAY
description: President-elect Bush has assured Nicholas F. Brady, a longtime political confidant, that he will remain as Treasury Secretary in his Administration, senior Bush advisers said today.

title: New Magazine Covers Health
description: The New York Times and four other major daily newspapers will combine forces next year to produce and market a Sunday health magazine as part of an effort by daily newspapers to attract more national advertising.

title: Dr. Alan D. Hirschfeld Wed to Barbara Gould
description: The marriage of Barbara Michelle Gould, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gould of Jericho, L.I., to Dr. Alan David Hirschfeld, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Hirschfeld of New York, took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Judge Michael Ambrosio of New York City Family Court performed the ceremony.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign Rhetoric And Science Fiction
description: The Presidential campaign is over but some of its most memorable words live on, appropriately enough, in an advertisement for the new John Carpenter film, ''They Live.''

title: INSIDE
description: Savings Losses Mount As losses at insolvent savings associations grow by more than $15 billion a year, sharp questions arise about how much the Government is spending in attempts to rescue the sickest institutions. Page D1. A Close Race in Pakistan Populist and conservative factions both appear strong as they campaign in advance of national elections on Wednesday. Page A3. Fears at Starrett City Residents of the Brooklyn housing complex, perhaps the most integrated area of the city, worry that ''white flight'' will result from a Supreme Court ruling ending racial quotas there. Page B1.

title: Pay-Per-View Television Is Ready for Takeoff
description: Just when pay television services like Home Box Office and Showtime seemed to be recovering from a three-year slump brought on largely by the video cassette boom, a rapidly growing competitor called pay-per-view television is posing a new threat.

title: Metro Matters; 2 Projects Prove Power Politics Isn't Always Bad
description: Two disparate projects in Manhattan -carefully nurtured dreams about to come true - are physical testaments to perseverance and political power-brokering at its best. When so many things that government gets involved in seem to go wrong, it's reassuring to be reminded of others, often unheralded, that work the way they're supposed to.

title: Five Bodies Unearthed Behind Rooming House
description: The police have found the bodies of five people buried in the yard of a rooming house and are hunting for the 59-year-old landlady they say may have killed them for their Social Security checks.

title: Reviews/Music; Long-Forgotten Works Of a 30's Avant-Gardist
description: Johanna Magdalena Beyer was a neglected member of the New York classical-music avant-garde in the 1930's - so neglected that she doesn't even appear in the New Grove Dictionary of American Music. But she has her champions, and Thursday night a group called Essential Music offered the first of two different programs of her music, the second scheduled for tomorrow. The site was the Greenwich House Auditorium at 27 Barrow Street in Greenwich Village - appropriate because Miss Beyer taught piano at the Greenwich House Music School and lived on nearby Jane Street.

title: On Your Own; Devlin Is Best in Running-Cycling Event
description: AFTER taking just over 1 hour 13 minutes to prove that he was the best athlete in the country in this running-cycling event yesterday, Jeff Devlin was anything but philosophical about the incredible rise the sport has experienced in the last five years.

title: Robeson County Journal; Verdict on Indians Roiling a Rural South County
description: A month after two Indians were acquitted of all Federal charges filed in connection with their armed seizure of the local newspaper, the conflicts they stirred up show little sign of abating.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Will Lose Chief in '90
description: Richard P. Simmons, who led the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation profitably through some of the worst years for the steel industry, plans to step down in 1990 as chief executive officer but remain as chairman.

title: A Wise Fetal Tissue Policy
description: LEAD: The National Institute of Health's special advisory panel on human fetal tissue has concluded that it can be acceptable to use fetal tissue for research and therapy. After a second review in November, President Reagan is expected to respond to the panel's final recommendations. The President's response will be critical for modern science.

title: Smoke Clouds a Mega-Merger
description: Velveeta, Parkay, Breyers, Sealtest, Miracle Whip, Frusen Gladje: meet Maxwell House, Birds Eye, Kool-Aid, Jell-O, Oscar Meyer, Post, Ronzoni and Miller Lite. The prospective merger of the Philip Morris Companies and Kraft Inc. will marry the formidable marketing skills of two packaged-goods giants, creating the largest food company in the world.

title: Limited Schedule of Auctions This Week
description: Treasury financings scheduled this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, followed on Thursday with an auction of new one-year bills.

title: Gerald F. Meltzer, Association Founder, 58
description: Gerald F. Meltzer, the founder and chairman of the American Hepatitis Association, died Saturday of chronic hepatitis B at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Laura M. Kurjan Is Married on L.I.
description: At Temple Sinai in Lawrence, L.I., Laura Michelle Kurjan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Kurjan of New York and Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Martin Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Goldman of Rochester. Rabbi Robert L. Rozenberg performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sports World Specials column in some copies of SportsMonday on Sept. 19 about the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame misidentified the chairman of the group's awards committee. He is Doug Kenna, not Fred Russell, who is chairman of the honors court.

title: Network Affiliates Find Few Buyers
description: For years no one had it cushier than the owners of network-affiliated television stations. The networks simply fed those stations programming, paid them to carry it and let them sell advertising time.

title: Some Subtle Problems Undermine G.O.P. Victory
description: Long-term Republican hopes of becoming the nation's dominant political party - in more than Presidential terms - suffered several key setbacks even as the party won the White House Tuesday for the fifth time in the last six elections.

title: 'Disappearances' of Filipinos Goes On Even Under Aquino
description: The last time D'Jay Lazaro saw her husband, Benjamin, a left-wing polemicist and writer of skits for street demonstrations, he was being driven away in the back seat of a white car, with armed men squeezed on either side of him.

title: Palestinian Killed at West Bank Army Checkpoint
description: Soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian man who failed to obey an order to stop his car at an Israeli Army checkpoint in the occupied West Bank today, Palestinians said.

title: NASA Accused of Cover-Up in Shuttle Deaths
description: A member of the Presidential commission that investigated the 1986 Challenger disaster charged today that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had tried to conceal details about the deaths of the seven crew members aboard the space shuttle.

title: Takeo Miki, Japanese Premier in 70's, Dies at 81
description: Takeo Miki, who advocated Japanese-American amity before Pearl Harbor and went on to spend half a century in Japanese politics, becoming Prime Minister in the 1970's, died yesterday. He was 81 years old and lived in Tokyo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the Prague Spring, in its internal development and its suffocation from outside, everything is reflected in condensed form - the crises and possibilities of socialism. The signs of democracy are political discussion, tolerance, sensitivity, dialogue. I don't say that we always succeeded in this regard, but we tried.'' - Alexander Dubcek. [ A15:1. ]

title: . . . But a High-Tech Concern May Expand
description: When Valentine O'Donovan was searching for a quotation to inscribe on a poster advertising his company's success in building components for earth-orbiting satellites, he settled on one from Robert Browning: ''Ah, but a man's reach should exceed his grasp, or what's a heaven for?''

title: The Russians Shame Us
description: For an American who is proud of his country's democratic heritage, traveling between Washington and Moscow during this political season has been a dismaying experience. Sad to say, the quality of political debate has been more intelligent and sophisticated in the world's leading closed society than in the world's leading democracy.

title: 1 Shot and 2 Beaten on S.I.; Police Investigate for Bias
description: A black teen-ager was shot by another black youth and two white brothers were beaten early yesterday in a clash in Port Richmond on Staten Island that the police are investigating as a racial incident.

title: O.A.S. Convening Today to Tackle Budget Crisis
description: Delegates to the Organization of American States arrived here over the weekend for its 18th General Assembly, which will have to deal with a financial crisis that threatens many of the group's major programs.

title: Missile Survives Despite Flaws and Inflated Costs
description: Two and a half years ago, one of the most expensive new weapon systems for the Air Force escaped cancellation by a skeptical Congress only because Caspar W. Weinberger certified in writing that costs would not increase, the design would not be changed and that the air-to-air missile would meet performance goals.

title: Review/Television; Stalin and His Times: Clues to Soviet Enigmas
description: As the title indicates, ''Stalin - the Red Czar'' starts with the premise that Josef Stalin inherited the pretensions of the rulers overthrown by the Russian Revolution and went on to rule the country himself as ''God on Earth.'' The argument is dramatically supported by paintings of Stalin done during his decades in power that picture him as a saint bringing the gospel to a worshipful people. Otherwise, saintly qualities are not much in evidence in this absorbing four-part documentary, which begins at 9 tonight on the Arts & Entertainment Network.

title: New Study On Savings Unit Crisis
description: A new study by Federal banking regulators has found that losses at the nation's insolvent savings and loan associations are growing at a rate that exceeds $15 billion a year.

title: Reviews/Dance; In 'Diaghilev Program,' First Impressions Count
description: Serge Diaghilev directed his Ballets Russes from 1909 to 1929 on the premise that applause should roll in the minute the curtain went up. To this end, he engaged the leading painters in Russia and Western Europe to create the stage designs and costumes that greeted the public in that first instant.

title: Transition Note (1)
description: The No. 3 job in the State Department, traditionally the highest post for Foreign Service officers, is Under Secretary for Political Affairs, which is held by Michael H. Armacost. With a change of administrations coming, three senior diplomats have applied for the job.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Lean vs. Light: Dunking Will Tell
description: HERE is a physics and fitness lesson: in water, fat floats and muscle sinks.

title: Melissa Billing Weds
description: The marriage of Melissa Ann Billing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Billing of Merrick, L.I., to Peter Kip Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Burke of Huntington, L.I., took place yesterday at Temple Beth Am in Merrick. Rabbi Ronald Brown officiated. The bride is a sales associate at Baby Guess, a manufacturer of children's wear in New York. The bridegroom is a financial planner at Burke Associates, corporate financial planners in Uniondale, L.I.

title: Ditka Rejects Doctor's Advice
description: ''Do you know any doctors who can keep their patients on a leash?'' asked Dr. Jay Alexander, a Chicago cardiologist. ''It was not my recommendation to Mike.''

title: Mary P. O'Callaghan Weds John F. Sullivan 3d on L.I.
description: Mary Patricia O'Callaghan, a daughter of Gloria B. O'Callaghan of New Hyde Park, L.I., and the late James C. O'Callaghan, and John F. Sullivan 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John F. Sullivan of Malverne, L.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Julian Cassar performed the ceremony at the Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church in New Hyde Park.

title: Cutting Trade Gap Further Is Tough Task Facing Bush
description: The trade deficit presents a king-size problem to President-elect Bush. Despite a projected 20 percent narrowing this year, to about $135 billion from $170 billion last year, it is not likely to shrink much more during 1989, many trade experts believe.

title: When Doctors Shun Difficult Patients
description: Even Jeanie Joshua agrees she is a troublesome patient. But, she asks, is that good enough reason for all the kidney doctors and dialysis centers in two counties to deny her the blood-cleansing treatments without which she will quickly die?

title: Reviews/Music; Two Cabaret Cutups
description: One of the odder couples of the New York cabaret world, Judy Kreston and David Lahm are a musical duo who know how to make the differences in their sensibilities work for them. With her small, quirky voice and confessional stage manner, Ms. Kreston is a cabaret singer who exudes a hypersensitive awareness and vulnerability. Mr. Lahm, her accompanist and musical director for the past eight years, is a jazz composer and arranger whose cool pop-jazz arrangements make an effective grounding wire for her edgy anxiety.

title: Vet Boswell, 77, Dead; Member of Singing Trio
description: Vet Boswell, the last surviving member of the popular and influential 1930's singing trio the Boswell Sisters, died Saturday. She was 77 years old and lived here.

title: Bluefields Journal; In a Buffeted Land, the Deadliest Blow Is Nature's
description: From a low-flying plane, southern Nicaragua's tropical rain forest looks as if it had been subject to saturation bombing.

title: Undone by the Attack of the Kamikaze Cyclists; Hit From Behind
description: To the Editor:

title: For 8 Chicago Couples, a Joyful Rite of Passage
description: The men of the Rockwell Gardens housing project became fugitives in their own homes in September, ducking and dodging security guards, holed up in apartments and afraid to leave.

title: Books of The Times; Vidal's Specialty: The Good Deeds of Subversion
description: At Home Essays 1982-1988 By Gore Vidal 303 pages. Random House. $18.95

title: Undone by the Attack of the Kamikaze Cyclists
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing; A Wealthy Alysheba Retires
description: Alysheba, who became the richest racehorse ever when he won the Breeders' Cup Classic at Churchill Downs nine days ago, has been officially retired from racing and will begin a stud career next year at Lane's End Farm in Versailles, Ky.

title: Rales Group Extends Its Offer for Interco
description: An investor group led by the Rales brothers has extended its $74-a-share tender offer for Interco Inc., the nation's largest manufacturer of furniture and men's shoes.

title: 2 Sides Getting Ready for Trial In Karate Death
description: The attack took only a couple of seconds and proved deadly.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Head of Playboy Plans To Shift Company Direction
description: LEAD: Christie A. Hefner, who last week was named chairman and chief executive officer of Playboy Enterprises Inc., plans to change the company's direction.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 13, 1988: MONDAY FPL Group Inc Pitney Bowes Inc Meredith Corp TUESDAY Briggs & Stratton CorpGuardsman Prods Inc Coleman IncKN Energy Inc Comdisco IncOhio Edison Co FGIC CorpPublic Svc Enterpr Group Fin Corp Santa BarbaraRealty Refund TR Gallagher Arthur J & Co Guardsman Prods Inc WEDNESDAY Alco Std Corp American Intl Group Inc Ametek Inc Belding Heminway Inc Bowater Inc Combustion Engr Inc Firemans Fd Corp First Bk Sys Inc First Va Bks Inc Florida E Coast Inds Inc Foote Cone & Belding GEICO Corp Johnson Ctls Inc Kansas Pwr & Lt Co Louisiana Gen Svcs Inc Southwest Airls Co USAir Group Inc Utah Pwr & Lt Co Wallace Computer Svcs Inc THURSDAY Air Prods & Chems Inc Amsouth Bancorporation Beneficial Corp Carson Pirie Scott New Champion Intl Corp Continental Corp Dresser Inds Inc Emhart Corp VA Florida Progress Corp Greyhound Corp Harsco Corp Lone Star Inds Inc Long Drug Stores Corp Marsh & McLennan Cos Ocean Drilling & Expl Co PNC Finl Corp Perkin Elmer Corp Sterling Bancorp Tiffany & Co New Unifirst Corp Union Pac Corp Vista Chem Co FRIDAY Aetna Life & Cas Co Barnes Group Inc Donaldson Inc Edwards AG Inc Fays Drug Inc General Elec Co International Multifoods Kansas City Southn Inds Lee Enterprises Inc MDC Hldgs Inc Millipore Corp Property Cap Tr South Jersey Inds Inc Texas Utils Co Whittaker Corp

title: Namibia Negotiations To Be Extended a Day
description: Officials from the United States, South Africa, Angola and Cuba have agreed to extend their current round of negotiations on a plan for Namibian independence and a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, participants in the talks said today.

title: Toward a System That Doesn't Punish Orphans
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * The American Heart Association to Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners for creative work, at $220,000.

title: New York City Street Youth: Living in the Shadow of AIDS
description: At midnight, the teen-ager stood on a Manhattan sidewalk hunched against the cold. He was painfully thin and wore only a grimy jacket, badly fitting pants and plastic beach sandals.

title: Toward a System That Doesn't Punish Orphans; Nurturing Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Scientists Hear Sakharov
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human-rights advocate, said tonight that it would be ''a total calamity'' if the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, failed in his efforts to restructure the Soviet economy and society to allow greater openness and freedom.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mitsubishi Builds Image Of Eclipse
description: ''ASTRONOMERS tell us there won't be a total eclipse in America until the year 2017,'' the commercial begins. ''They are very much mistaken.'' And so the Eclipse, the new sports car from Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America, is introduced in its first television commercial.

title: How Religious Right Gained Power in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page on Oct. 28 about an auction of a defunct law firm's assets gave an erroneous identification received from the auctioneer for the woman who is involved in a dispute over her purchase. It is Lois K. Gerard, not Peggy Vandervoort, who has filed a complaint asserting that she was unwittingly sold three items when she expected one.

title: Patriots' Defense Halts Jets
description: The Jets, struggling with second-stringers everywhere except at the skill positions, lost to a better team today, but not by much.

title: Bush Finds Fellowship But No Fish
description: The First Mother-elect arrived to meet her son at church this morning sitting regally in the back of a blue golf cart. For Dorothy Bush, 87 years old, who was wearing a sea-green dress and white beads and walking on a curved cane, it was par for the course.

title: Researchers Fear Computer 'Virus' Will Slow Use of National Network
description: Although the rogue computer program that recently disrupted thousands of computers around the country caused no permanent damage, it did cause hardship and extra work for many scholars and researchers and may discourage some from using the computer network, scientists around the country say.

title: Abortion Foes See Momentum for Their Drive
description: Anti-abortion leaders say Vice President Bush's election is just one sign that they are picking up momentum in a drive they are convinced will culminate in the reversal of the Supreme Court decision establishing a constitutional right to abortion.

title: Israelis Vote, and the Lubavitchers Rejoice
description: When Israeli voters went to the polls early this month in Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and other cities, they were handed voting cards with the picture of a Brooklyn rabbi who has never been to Israel, imploring them to vote for one of the major religious parties, Agudat Israel.

title: Broncos Romp Past Browns
description: John Elway threw two touchdown passes, and the Denver Broncos converted four Cleveland turnovers into 20 first-half points today on the way to a 30-7 romp in a rematch of the participants in the last two American Football Conference championship games.

title: Charles Sammons, 90, Executive
description: Charles G. Sammons, a billionaire and philanthropist, died Saturday at St. Paul Medical Center. He was 90 years old.

title: Southland Loss Of $46.8 Million
description: The Southland Corporation reported Friday that it had lost $46.8 million in the third quarter ended Sept. 30 because of interest and other expenses related to the leveraged buyout of the company last December.

title: TV Notes
description: Dallas Memories

title: Amazon Tree Cutting Better Than Burning
description: To the Editor:

title: Saints Stop Rams In a Fight for First
description: Bobby Hebert completed 22 of 37 passes for 249 yards and the Saints' defense frustrated the Rams most of the game as New Orleans defeated Los Angeles by 14-10 today and broke a first-place tie in the National Conference West.

title: College Football; Fiesta Bowl Eyes A More Ideal Day
description: The Fiesta Bowl matchup between Notre Dame and West Virginia would be rescheduled for the evening of Tuesday, Jan. 3, one day later than originally scheduled, if the Irish and the Mountaineers remain undefeated.

title: 2 Canadian Plants View Trade Pact
description: Canadians will go to the polls on Nov. 21 in a general election that has become a plebiscite on the free-trade agreement between Canada and the United States. Polls show a close race between the ruling Progressive Conservatives, who support the pact, and the opposition Liberals, who have vowed to tear it up. As part of their campaigns, the Progressive Conservative leader, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, and the Liberal leader, John Turner, have been visiting manufacturing plants to point out what they see as the advantages and the dangers of the pact.

title: Outdoors: Time for Zeroing In
