description: Outraged by what they see as the ''radicalization'' of courses, hiring policies and academic standards at American universities, a group of 300 American scholars has begun what it calls a movement to reclaim the academy.

title: In Defense of Yuppies, Their Basic Decency And New Perplexity
description: O.K., Richard Greenberg, let's get to the point right away. Your new play, ''Eastern Standard,'' is a comedy, a romantic and screwball comedy, but also a serious comedy, about a bunch of yuppies who invite a bag lady to a house in the Hamptons. There's a homosexual yuppie who has AIDS, another homosexual yuppie who falls in love with him, and a couple of heterosexual yuppies who are trying to work out a relationship.

title: Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago 9-month revenue included $3,000,000 received from Eastman Kodak Co. for the transfer of certain Snomax product rights.

title: Willard B. Pope, Professor, 85
description: Willard Bissell Pope, a college professor and editor, died Thursday at his home in Burlington, Vt., after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Rapist Is Sentenced To 100-Year Term
description: A 42-year-old man who has spent half his life in prison was sentenced yesterday to a new term of 100 years to life for his convictions in sexual attacks on women in Queens.

title: Witness Tells Myerson Jury Of Capasso Guilty Tax Plea
description: A witness disclosed to the jury yesterday that Bess Myerson's companion, Carl A. Capasso, pleaded guilty to tax charges last year.

title: Trust Offers $750 Million In Asset-Backed Securities
description: National Credit Trust 88-1, a special-purpose trust, is offering $750 million of asset-backed debt securities due in 1991 through Citicorp's North American Investment Bank. The securities are backed by Mastercard and Visa credit-card account receivables.

title: Strange Tops $1 Million
description: Curtis Strange, the United States Open champion, made history today with a magnificent 4-iron shot that stopped 18 inches from the pin at the beautiful 188-yard 17th hole at Pebble Beach.

title: Dow Falls by 1.95; Volume Picks Up
description: Stock prices eased a bit yesterday, but the size of the decline quelled fears that Friday's sharp drop was the beginning of a significant market downtrend.

title: Power and the Passion: Trade Pact Dogs Mulroney
description: When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced that he was calling a general election six weeks ago, he read a 10-minute campaign statement that included a single sentence, in French, about Canada's free-trade agreement with the United States.

title: Mansfield San Bids Sayonara As an Envoy
description: Mike Mansfield, the pithy, plain-speaking man who became the United States' longest-serving and much-admired Ambassador to Japan, announced today that he would resign from the post he has held for 11 and a half years.

title: Judge Says Lawyer Broke Disclosure Rules
description: An administrative law judge ruled today that George C. Kern Jr., a prominent Wall Street lawyer, violated Federal disclosure rules during the takeover battle between the Allied Stores Corporation and the Campeau Corporation in the fall of 1986.

title: Too Many Ifs in Giants' Loss to Cards
description: Two years ago, in their Super Bowl season, the Giants might have shut down the Phoenix Cardinals. A healthy Lawrence Taylor might have harassed Neil Lomax into throwing passes before his receivers were ready and a healthy Mark Collins might have kept Roy Green from turning short passes into long gains.

title: Gerry LaFurn, Jazz Trumpeter, 59
description: Gerry LaFurn, a jazz trumpeter who performed with Stan Kenton, Woody Herman, Buddy Rich and others, died of liver cancer Wednesday at St. Rose's Hospice in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, early today declared the establishment of an independent Palestinian state as part of a broad political program that recognizes Israel, at least implicitly, for the first time.

title: Topics of The Times; Sons of Minnesota
description: Bob Dylan, the singer-songwriter who was Pied Piper of the counterculture in the 1960's, is unquestionably the most famous person ever to hail from Hibbing, Minn. But like another small-town Minnesotan who won worldwide artistic fame, Mr. Dylan seems unappreciated in his hometown.

description: Three golf pros and a pilot died when their small plane crashed Sunday night as they approached a fog-shrouded airport here.

title: Instituform Gulf South reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Rig Count Off Sharply
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs plunged by 45 this week, to a total of 897, marking the largest one-week decline since February, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count stood at 1,174. The drop in the latest week continues a seesaw trend in the volatile energy industry but runs contrary to a traditional year-end increase, a Baker Hughes spokesman, Ike Kerridge, said. The count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: A High School Finds Success in Freedom
description: The sight of unsupervised students clustering in the hallways of a high school throughout the day usually means that things are not being run properly, that orderliness has given way to entropy. But at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn it means the opposite.

title: Grandmothers On Warpath Against Crack
description: Six nights a week, the grandmothers patrol their housing project for crack dealers. The grandmothers have no weapons, only their ability to embarrass the young men and women of the projects who have known these women all their lives. Round and round the Dan Daly project, the grandmothers walk until well past midnight. Over and over, Sandra Hilton, lead grandmother and tenant president, greets the young. ''Hello, doll,'' she says.

title: RUSSIAN SHUTTLE ORBITS AND LANDS
description: The Soviet Union's space shuttle was lofted into orbit for the first time today by the world's most powerful booster rocket. The unmanned craft circled Earth twice before returning in a smooth automated landing on the cold, flat Asian steppe, a few miles from where it had been launched.

title: Market Place; Failing Insurers: Bailout Cost Rises
description: THE huge cost of bailing out sick savings and loans is national news, but the cost of rescuing failing insurance companies has so far gained little attention.

title: Barry Blau & Partners Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Novel Methods Unlock Witnesses' Memories
description: The reliability of eyewitness testimony, long questioned by some scientists and legal experts, may be bolstered by relatively simple techniques explored in new research.

title: Honoring Techinical Merit
description: Nearly a million square feet of computers, peripherals and software are on display here this week at the Comdex Fall trade show. About 1,700 companies have come to this neon-lit Baghdad to display their wares to a crowd of more than 100,000 customers.

title: Balfour Maclaine reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Preacher's Journey: Long Trail of Abuse
description: For nearly 30 years, an evangelist preacher traveled the Southeast shouting to worshipers about fire and brimstone and for much of that time whispering to boys about sexual pleasure.

title: On Horse Racing; Changes in Syndication Breed Stability
description: If Alysheba had been retired four years ago instead of 48 hours ago, his owners could have sold up to 30 shares in his future as a stallion for$1 million apiece. It might have taken them all of a week to sell them, and there would have been some disappointed buyers shut out.

title: Sacred Gift Solves a Mystery, Repays a Debt
description: From the ashes of six sacred Torah scrolls, torched in a Brooklyn synagogue two months ago, grew a gentle gesture that brought the memory of a dead policeman, a burglary, a mystery and a police commissioner with a private debt together in another synagogue yesterday.

title: Mysterious Disappearance 4,500 Feet Beneath Sea
description: THE disappearance of a huge cable on the Pacific floor 250 miles off the coast of Oregon has deeply perplexed experts in several fields of oceanography. The heavy cable, 165 feet long, was being used in a project to monitor a cluster of six highly active hot springs 4,500 feet below the ocean's surface.

title: Editors of Monitor Resign Over Cuts
description: Katherine W. Fanning, the editor of The Christian Science Monitor and a prominent figure in American journalism, resigned today along with two other top editors in a dispute over the future of the highly regarded newspaper.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; Lions Dismiss Rogers as Head Coach
description: Darryl Rogers was like any new coach, confident in 1985 that he could make a difference by bringing a bag of new tricks to a franchise in desperate need of magic. He had won at Michigan State and at Arizona State and was noted for his wizardry in the art of passing the football.

title: Boeskys' Home Dome Hits Zoning Snag
description: Here in estate country, where good manners and the acres between houses usually keep neighborly friction to a minimum, a tempest is brewing over a dome.

title: Bills (10-1) Rout Dolphins
description: Ronnie Harmon ran for one touchdown and caught a 16-yard pass from Jim Kelly for another, and Robb Riddick had two 1-yard scoring runs as the Buffalo Bills maintained the National Football League's best record by beating Miami, 31-6, tonight.

title: ABC's 'War and Remembrance' Tops TV Ratings
description: The first installment of ''War and Remembrance,'' the longest and most expensive mini-series ever produced, won for ABC a sizable share of the nation's television viewers on Sunday night. But aggressive programming by the other networks - especially NBC - as well as the broad range of alternatives to network programs resulted in lower ratings than those earned by ABC five years ago with ''The Winds of War.''

description: b-Net income

title: Mr. Dubcek Speaks Out, Almost
description: Alexander Dubcek, in his first visit abroad since 1970, praised Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms and warned of a return to neo-Stalinism should the Soviet experiment fail. But in deference to the neo-Stalinists now entrenched in Czechoslovakia, Mr. Dubcek prudently refrained from reading the most sensitive written sections of his text, a scathing evaluation of his successors.

title: Resolution 242: The Basis for Mideast Peace
description: The Palestine National Council yesterday implicitly recognized Israel's sovereignty by endorsing United Nations Security Council Resolution 242, adopted in 1967, council members said. Here is the text of the resolution. THE SECURITY COUNCIL,

title: Gifts From Sakharov
description: Andrei Sakharov arrived in the United States bearing gifts. He dispenses them as he travels about, meeting with Americans interested in the human condition in the Soviet Union. Dr. Sakharov is not aware that he is distributing gifts, which of course makes them all the more valuable.

description: LIFE-STYLE changes alone, without drugs or surgery, can can halt or reverse atherosclerosis, a hardening of the arteries that can lead to heart attack, researchers reported yesterday.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Farewell for Kemp
description: It is going to be a grand gathering on Dec. 1 of supply-siders and their sometime Republican critics, including the principals of that debate of yore, President Reagan, the Great Tax Cutter; and President-elect Bush who, in his heretical days, had branded it ''voodoo economics.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Environmental Protection Agency; Soul-Searching int he Face of Outside Criticism
description: In a city whose institutions are given more to self-congratulation than self-examination, it is rare to find a Government agency pausing for moments of introspection.

title: Terrarium Dedicated At Botanical Garden
description: An orchid terrarium and a restored rotunda - the first fruits of a $21.4 million expansion and renovation project at the New York Botanical Garden - were dedicated in the Bronx last night.

title: Massachusetts to Buy Artwork for Its Prisons
description: Massachusetts has budgeted nearly $1.1 million to beautify its prisons, under a rarely used law that is being criticized by lawmakers and correction officials.

title: The Markets' Warning to Mr. Bush
description: The dollar's quick drop - despite yesterday's rebound - and the stock market's slide tell Vice President Bush that his plan for reducing the budget deficit isn't credible. Nervous investors want quick and plausible reassurance. The Presidential transition period lasts 11 weeks. President-elect Bush doesn't have that long.

title: Abbey Life Plan
description: The British insurance company Abbey Life Group P.L.C. said its shareholders had defeated the company's plans to buy five businesses from Lloyds Bank P.L.C., one of Britain's four leading clearing banks. The plan required the approval of 75 percent of Abbey Life's voting shares, but received the backing of only 64 percent at a shareholders meeting. Under the plan, Lloyds would have received 57.6 percent of Abbey Life in exchange for the businesses. The insurers said they would explore other ways of effecting a merger.

title: Pest Control: Just Add Water
description: IT has long been known that certain nematodes, microscopic worms that are harmless to humans, pets, plants and birds, are lethal to a host of insect pests that damage millions of dollars' worth of crops. As such, they are a potential alternative to chemical pesticides at a time when increasing attention is being paid to such measures of biological control.

title: Consolidated Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sale to Pentair
description: Pentair Inc., a diversified manufacturer based in St. Paul, agreed to acquire FC Holdings Inc., the holding company for Federal-Hoffman Inc., for $175 million in cash and the assumption of debt. Federal-Hoffman, a company based in Anoka, Minn., that was taken private in a 1985 buyout, operates two businesses. One, the Federal Cartridge Company, produces sporting ammunition, and the other, the Hoffman Engineering Company, makes electrical and electronic enclosures and wireways. Pentair's sales totaled $789.2 million in 1987.

title: Court to Rule On Broker Arbitration
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to revisit the contentious issue of whether brokerage firms may require their customers to agree in advance to submit all disputes to arbitration, waiving their right to sue.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Long Shots Are Favorites
description: Many basketball traditionalists, Knicks executives among them, fought desperately in 1979 against awarding 3 points for long shots. Nine years later, the 3-point field goal, which Coach Rick Pitino calls ''the great momentum breaker,'' has become a vital part of the Knicks' offense.

title: Baruch-Foster Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rev. John Patterson, Priest and Educator
description: The Rev. Dr. John Oliver Patterson, an Episcopal priest and educator, died Saturday at Children's Hospital in San Francisco, after a short illness. He was 80 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: President Seems to Disbelieve First Lady Gave an Interview
description: In an interview published Sunday, Nancy Reagan said she believed that some members of the White House staff served President Reagan badly. But since the interview was published, the President has implied that he doubts its accuracy or even authenticity, and the First Lady has seemed eager to drop the subject.

title: Smoker on Jet Sentenced
description: A man was sentenced to 15 days in jail today for bullying a flight attendant who ordered him not to light up in a no-smoking section. Federal District Judge Wallace Tashima also sentenced the man, James J. Tabacca, a 34-year-old undertaker from North Hollywood, to two years' probation, fined him $500 and ordered him to perform 100 hours of community service for causing the disturbance Dec. 30 on a Trans World Airlines flight from Boston to Los Angeles.

title: Senate Loser in Florida Asks for a Recount
description: Representative Kenneth (Buddy) MacKay, a Democrat who lost by a narrow margin to Connie Mack, a Republican Representative, in the race for the Senate, has demanded a recount in five of the state's biggest counties.

description: To the Editor:

title: Maxxam Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $6,139,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $688,000 and $13,250,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. On May 20 the merger of a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxxam with Maxxam Group Inc. was consummated and, as a result, Maxxam Group became a wholly owned subsidiary of Maxxam. Maxxam's consolidated statement of income for the 9 months ended Sept. 30 includes Maxxam Group's consolidated results of operations as if the merger occurred on Jan. 1. During the 9 months and 3 months ended Sept. 30, 1987, Maxxam Group was accounted for as an unconsolidated subsidiary of Maxxam and, as a result, Maxxam's net from continuing operations for the 9 months and 3 months ended Sept. 30, 1987, includes $36,680,000 and $28,116,000, respectively, representing Maxxam's share of the income of Maxxam Group. Commencing with the second quarter of 1988, Kaisertech Ltd. was accounted for as an unconsolidated subsidiary of Maxxam and, as a result, Maxxam's net from continuing operations for the 9 and 3 months ended Sept. 30, includes $24,266,000 and $15,278,000, respectively, representing Maxxam's share of the income of Kaisertech.

title: Walshire Assurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dionics Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Net income

title: Dorchester Hugoton Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represent units.

title: Baker at the State Dept: Pragmatism Over Zeal
description: The record of James A. Baker 3d suggests that as Secretary of State he may be inclined to seek more international economic cooperation, is not likely to be a zealous advocate of military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and would oppose restrictions on commercial-bank lending to the Soviet Union.

title: Unit Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $29,400,000 reduction in the carrying value of certain drilling equipment.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Business and Health; Medicare's Curbs On Cataract Fees
description: FEDERAL price controls are sharply limiting the revenues of cataract surgeons and manufacturers of lenses used in eye implants, in what may be a foretaste of new harsh measures to curb health care costs.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; As if Life Wasn't Tangled Enough, Here's Isabelita
description: Gen. Juan D. Peron died in 1974, but his ghost continues to wander the corridors of power in Argentina. His second wife, Eva, died 22 years earlier, but her memory is still revered with quasi-religious solemnity. His third wife, Isabel, was ousted as President in 1976 and many Argentines have tried ever since to forget her.

title: Graphic Scanning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included a $69.6 million gain on the sale of business interests.

title: Accident Delays Some Metro-North Trains
description: Service to and from Grand Central Terminal on two Metro-North lines was delayed for an hour last night after a train ran over a 50-gallon drum in the Bronx, railroad officials said.

title: Fewer Vehicles Are Crossing Hudson River
description: Motorists, faced with steeply increased tolls and mounting congestion on the Hudson River crossings, are making fewer trips on the bridges and tunnels connecting New York City and New Jersey.

title: Handy & Harman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $2.8 million. Both latest periods' figures included gains of $647,000 from the reduction in quantities of silver inventories, compared with both year-ago periods' of gains of $1,120,000.

title: Bad Real Estate Loans Hurt Northeast Banks
description: Developers and brokers are loath to talk about the weakness in the real estate market in the Northeast, but there is no denying its impact on the books of the region's banks. Overbuilding in the condominium market in particular is causing banks and savings institutions to take losses on a rising number of loans to builders and developers and to brace themselves for more trouble in the future.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Alco Health Services Agrees to a Buyout
description: LEAD: The Alco Health Services Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired for $31 a share in cash by a group that includes members of its management and is led by Citicorp Capital Investors.

title: Airlines Moving to Scale Back Underground Fare Discounts
description: For years, knowledgeable travelers have been plugged into a thriving underground economy in which airline tickets to prime destinations abroad are sold for about one-third to one-half the cost of even the lowest discount fares offered by United States airlines.

title: Yankee Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $253,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: United Systems Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Douglas & Lomason Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: AT&E Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Galactic Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results included a writedown of the assets of the company's Summitville Mine of about $40 million.

title: International Totalizer Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $54,000 and $266,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Nassau Proposes Tax Increase of 12%
description: Nassau County, facing a sharp decline in sales tax revenue, proposed today a $1.55 billion budget for next year that would raise county property taxes by about 12 percent.

title: Angels Name Rader
description: Doug Rader, the manager of the Texas Rangers during 1983 and 1984, was picked yesterday to succeed Cookie Rojas as manager of the California Angels. Rader, a third baseman for the Houston Astros from 1967 through 1975, won out over a field of contenders that was believed to include Jim Fregosi, a former manager of the Angels, and Pat Corrales, a former manager of the Cleveland Indians.

title: Tandy in PC Deal With Matsushita
description: Eager to increase the sales of its personal computers beyond its Radio Shack outlets, the Tandy Corporation said today that it had agreed to begin supplying computers to the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America, for sale under that company's Panasonic brand name.

title: Sakharov Meets With the President
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights campaigner, discussed the problem of political prisoners with President Reagan today and continued to raise blunt questions about the direction of the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Congress Must Pull Plug on Brain-Dead Thrifts; Similar to Equity
description: To the Editor:

title: Arden Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $321,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Cagle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $93,000 for the quarter and $248,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $400,000 and $678,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The latest 6 months included a pretax gain of $2.9 million on the sale of investment in Select Laboratories Inc.

title: KOREAN NOW FACES PROBLEM OF CHUN
description: President Roh Tae Woo appealed for calm today as he returned from abroad to face the most difficult political test of his nine-month presidency, the fate of his predecessor, Chun Doo Hwan.

title: Phoenix Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $204,000. c-Includes tax credits of $33,000 and $320,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: People
description: * Andrea Morris has been appointed publisher of Magazine & Bookseller, a monthly national business publication issued by North American Publishing Co.

title: Investor Buys Staubach Stake
description: The Staubach Company, a commercial real estate concern, said last week that Richard Rainwater, a Fort Worth investor formerly associated with the Bass brothers, had acquired 20 percent of the company.

title: P.L.O.'s Declaration of Independent State Is Called Contrary to U.S. Policy
description: American officials said today that the Palestinians' declaration of an independent state in territory controlled by Israel was contrary to American policy as expressed by Vice President Bush and other members of the Reagan Administration.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Traffic Is Heavy on the Art Auction Route
description: Art buyers have shuttled between Christie's and Sotheby's for more than a week, viewing and bidding on more postwar, modern and Impressionist art valued at more money than has ever been presented at auction. The numbers are staggering. Sotheby's presented 792 artworks estimated at between $166.6 million and $220.2 million and by Saturday night had sold $231.2 million - the highest total in history for such sales. Christie's offered 722 works valued at a total of $113.8 million to $155 million. By Saturday, Christie's sales of contemporary art totaled $42.9 million.

title: Voyager's Course Adjusted For Flight Closer to Neptune
description: The Voyager 2 spacecraft, flying through space 2.6 billion miles from Earth, has changed course for its August 1989 picture-taking encounter with the planet Neptune.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shandwick of Britain Buys Mona, Meyer
description: Shandwick P.L.C., the British company that has turned itself into the world's largest independent public relations agency through its aggressive acquisition strategy, yesterday announced that it had purchased Mona, Meyer & McGrath, the largest public-relations firm in Minnesota. Shandwick paid $4.8 million for the agency, said Charles Jones, president of Shandwick North America.

title: Penny-wise in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Beckett, as a Beckettian, Isn't Always the Purist
description: During a performance of Mike Nichols's all-star production of ''Waiting for Godot'' at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, a Beckett scholar sat in the audience holding a copy of the play and comparing the words spoken on stage with those that appeared in the text. Momentarily looking up from his book, he realized that Meryl Streep was staring at him, perhaps wondering why he was not looking at the actors.

title: Pure 3-D Cover For Geographic
description: The December issue of National Geographic will have an all-holographic cover.

title: 'Legs' Postponed Again
description: ''Legs Diamond,'' the musical about the 1920's gangster starring Peter Allen that is now in previews at the Mark Hellinger Theater, has postponed its opening again, this time until Dec. 26. The show had originally been scheduled to open Dec. 1, but the opening was delayed until Dec. 11. The producers said technical problems and the need for script revisions caused the additional delay.

title: SHAMIR ASKS RIVAL TO JOIN COALITION
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir invited his political rival, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, this evening to join a new government, led by Likud, that would include Labor as a junior partner.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Soviet Embassy Dinner
description: The question at the Soviet Embassy tonight is not who's coming to dinner - the guests are the usual assortment of Washington press, pols and diplomats - but what's for dinner.

title: Canada Debates Its Soul
description: LEAD: While the American Presidential campaign has ground to its predictable end, Canadians are in the last days of an astonishing political fight.

title: Former Editor of Vogue To Head New Magazine
description: Grace Mirabella, the longtime editor of Vogue who was dismissed in June, will return to the magazine world in the spring as the editor of a new fashion publication from Murdoch Magazines, the company announced yesterday.

title: Soviet Space Shuttle Orbits and Returns In Unmanned Debut
description: The Soviet Union's first re-usable spacecraft made a triumphant maiden voyage today. No hitches were reported from the moment a giant Energiya booster rocket powered the unmanned craft off a launching pad in central Asia until it glided to a smooth automated landing seven miles from the launching site.

title: It's Worth Haranguing
description: This is the 40th anniversary of the universal declaration of human rights. ''Between hope and frustration'' was the apt title for a meeting here on how to press ahead - and indeed, the record is spotty.

title: Most of B-1 Fleet Is Cleared
description: The Air Force has inspected and cleared more than two-thirds of its B-1 bombers after a crash in Texas last week that destroyed one of the long-range planes, officials said today. Lieut. Col. George H. Peck, a spokesman for the Strategic Air Command, said 63 of the command's 85 B-1's had been inspected. At least four of the remaining 13 planes, which are assigned to other units, have been cleared, he said.

title: At Vatican's Bidding, Bishops Set Aside Dispute Procedures
description: At the Vatican's request, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops have set aside procedures they developed to resolve differences with theologians who disagree with church teachings.

title: Gorbachev Visit an 'Informal Session'
description: The White House and State Department today portrayed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's talks with President Reagan and President-elect Bush next month as more a social occasion than a substantive encounter likely to produce concrete results.

title: Reviews/Music; Swans' Gospel Messages
description: The Swan Silvertones, one of gospel's most influential vocal groups, lasted from the 1940's to the 1970's. Until its final years, the group was built around the voice of the Rev. Claude Jeter, whose ascents into falsetto singing lifted the group's music toward otherworldly realms. For most of those years, his smooth lead vocals were balanced by a hard gospel shouter. Louis Johnson, the group's shouting co-lead singer from the mid-1950's on, rejoined Mr. Jeter and a harmony quartet, the Mellowtones, to re-create the group's hits as the New Swan Silvertones on Friday at the Triplex.

title: INSIDE
description: Shamir Seeks Coalition Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel invited his rival, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, to join a new national unity government. Page A11. Western Ads for Soviets Izvestia, the Soviet Government daily newspaper, plans a special supplement featuring Western ads for Western goods. Page D20. All of, Not Mostly, Mozart Lincoln Center, to observe the 200th anniversary of Mozart's death, plans the performing of all of his works during a 19-month festival. Page C21. A Bad Day for Commuters Metro-North trainmen and conductors walked off the job in a surprise strike, complicating the morning rush for 95,000 commuters. Page B1.

title: The Pop Life
description: Those Wilbury Boys

title: Economic Scene; Sharp TV Images A Complex Topic
description: ONE look at the sparkling, seemingly three-dimensional image from high-definition television is enough to convince most observers that HDTV is as big a step up from ordinary color TV as color was from black-and-white.

title: A Welcome Transition in Ethics
description: Early in his campaign, George Bush promised that if he were elected, ethical conduct would be a principal theme. That pledge put distance between him and the Reagan Administration scandals without requiring him to condemn his colleagues. The President-elect has now made a promising start on fulfilling his pledge with the code of ethics promulgated for the transition to the new administration in January.

title: Judge Blocks Effort to List AIDS as a Sex Disease
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Albany rejected yesterday an effort to force the Health Commissioner to declare AIDS and HIV infection to be communicable and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Computer Intruders Deserve Only Condemnation
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Assails Emergency Heart Procedure
description: The expensive practice of using balloon catheters to force open heart arteries immediately after heart attacks, now common at some large hospitals, is unnecessary and should be abandoned, researchers said today.

title: Reagan Tells Children Of Regret Over Deficit
description: President Reagan told a group of schoolchildren this week that the one thing he most regretted not achieving in office was a lessening of the Federal deficit.

title: Sakharov Urges Moscow to Cut Size of Its Military
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights campaigner, called on the Soviet Union today to unilaterally cut the size of its military.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advance Aviation Services Inc., Miami Springs, Fla., named Gary D. Watson president.

title: 3 Former Citisource Officials Plead Guilty to Bribery Charges
description: Three former directors of the computer company that was pivotally involved in New York City's corruption investigations almost three years ago have pleaded guilty to bribery charges in the scandal, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, announced yesterday.

title: Inquiry Examines Developer's Donations
description: A Manhattan grand jury is investigating the 1985 Poughkeepsie Town Council elections in which almost $800,000 was secretly contributed by a real-estate developer seeking approval of a proposed shopping mall.

title: Sidewalk Vision
description: On a recent autumn afternoon in New York, a painter stood before the easel he'd set up on Avenue of the Americas, staring intently at the building across the street. Every minute or so he'd bend his head, lift his hand and apply brush to canvas. Then he'd resume staring.

title: Fortune in Toys Helps to Put Americans and Russians in Touch
description: In five buildings amid the boutiques in the 3200 block of Sacramento Street are 20 organizations, backed by a fortune from manufacturing stuffed animals, whose goal is to assure that information flows between Moscow and San Francisco.

title: TV's Anti-Liberal Bias
description: Although it clearly did a lot of civic harm, the Presidential race did do some good by exploding one tenacious myth. After the 1988 campaign, no one can any longer argue, without laughing, that network news reflects a ''liberal bias.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ads by Amiga
description: The MIDI synthesizer put a lot of commercial musicians out of business. Will Commodore International Ltd.'s Amiga 500 computer do the same to companies that produce commercials? That is the implication of the new campaign for the Amiga created by Griffin Bacal. The seven 15-second animated television spots were created entirely on the computer. Norman Hajjar, the agency's vice president and management supervisor, even played creative director on this account, making several commercials on the two Amigas he has at home. Total cost: less than $50,000. ''There was no production company involved anywhere,'' Mr. Hajjar said.

title: Article 310388 -- No Title
description: Princeton University has received a $1.25 million pledge to endow a professorship in Shiite studies, which the school said would be the first such position at an American university.

title: Dayton Hudson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Nouveau Diners: The Same Old Hash
description: IN our quest for life as it once existed in this country, or more accurately, as we think it once existed, we have been recycling symbols of our past: the skirts of the 60's, the furniture of the 50's, the diners of the 40's.

title: Perfect Imitations Spur Quest For a Perfect Christmas Tree
description: The Gearhart family, which has been growing Christmas trees on its farm here for almost 50 years, plans to ship 25,000 of them in coming weeks, and each will carry a tag with a number that identifies the grower and certifies the tree's quality.

title: Pakistan Restricts Afghan Refugees
description: Pakistan has restricted the movements of Afghans living in refugee camps and has advised refugees in the cities to stay indoors until the national and provincial elections end on Saturday, refugee officials said today.

title: F.B.I. Joins Hunt for Fugitive
description: Federal agents joined the hunt today for the landlady of a boarding house where seven bodies were found, and investigators believe that the woman, Dorothea Montalvo Puente, may have fled to Nevada. Detectives and workers with shovels finished excavating the grounds where the bodies, all elderly, have been unearthed since Friday.

title: Most Fares Rise At Continental
description: Continental Airlines is raising its cheapest and most widely used discount fares for about two-thirds of its domestic routes. It will cut the fares for the rest of its system.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Growers want trees grown in their state to be known in the same way that Idaho potatoes or Florida oranges are known.'' - David E. Baumann, of the National Christmas Tree Association, on seeking a flawless Christmas tree. [ A1:5. ]

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; F.B.I. to Take Deeper Look at Political Appointees
description: Over the coming weeks, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation will fan out around the country looking for pecadilloes and worse in the background of the men and women picked by President-elect Bush to run the country.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Eskimo Pie Goes to Hawley
description: The Eskimo Pie Corporation, a 67-year-old Richmond-based ice cream maker, has moved its business to the fledgling Hawley Martin Partners in Richmond, from Ford & Westbrook, also of Richmond. The previous budget was $2 million to $3 million. Hawley Martin will help to promote several new products, including the recently introduced Sugar-Free Eskimo Pie, a vanilla ice cream pop with a chocolate coating that has 140 calories, compared with 180 for the regular version. ''A growing segment of the population is concerned about sugar in their daily diets,'' said George Murphy, vice president of marketing at Eskimo Pie.

title: Vehicle Sales Show a Strong Gain
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks in the first 10 days of November were up 17.4 percent from the comparable period a year ago, when demand was depressed by the expiration of buyer incentive programs.

title: Review/Music; Bernstein Conducts Bernstein 45 Years After Impromptu Debut
description: It was 45 years to the day since the astonishingly lithe 25-year-old assistant conductor had stepped up to the podium at Carnegie Hall to lead the New York Philharmonic for the first time, substituting on short notice for an ailing Bruno Walter. Now there stood Leonard Bernstein, a white-haired, 70-year-old patriarch, returning to conduct the Philharmonic on Monday night, in a concert of his own works. Need it be mentioned that nostalgia and sentimentality also were on the program?

title: JC Penney Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Marshfield, Vt.
description: IT looks innocent enough: a jar full of sourdough starter that comes with the recipe for Amish friendship cake, and instructions to augment the starter with milk and sugar over a nine-day period, to bake the cake and then divide the remaining starter among three friends. In north-central Vermont, however, the friendship cake is becoming known as ''the chain-letter cake'' and ''the cake from hell.''

title: Soviet Design Appears In Debt to U.S. Shuttle
description: American experts believe there are no fundamental differences in design, capability and function between the American space shuttle and the Soviet version that made its first test flight yesterday.

title: Golden Nugget Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and the 9 months included a gain on the sale of a Atlantic City casino-hotel of $169,748,000. The latest quarter included a pre- tax charge of $2,157,000 as the result of a supplemental judgment in a lawsuit that is being currently appealed.

title: BIG POLITICAL TRIAL ENDING IN PRETORIA
description: South Africa's biggest political trial in nearly three decades drew to a conclusion here today with indications that as many as 11 of the 19 defendants could be found guilty of treason or other charges.

title: Experts Divided on Benefits Of a Further Drop in Dollar
description: The sharp decline of the dollar last week and the effort by President-elect Bush to stabilize it this week are only the latest round in a long-running debate about the proper level of the dollar.

title: Drug Crackdown Is Expanded to East Harlem
description: Expanding an intensive street-level anti-drug program that the police say was a success in southeast Queens, the New York City Police Department yesterday assigned 117 narcotics officers to two drug-ridden precincts in East Harlem.

title: No Headline
description: THIS is not your ordinary produce section. There are strange-looking roots like nagaimo and oddly familiar-looking foods like Tokyo negi, which could pass for giant scallions. Bamboo shoots, which ordinarily reside in cans, are in their original incarnation, fresh, at $6.99 a pound.

title: Give the West Coast a Head Start on Election Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Carroll, McGee Lift Nets' Energy Level
description: For the Nets, beating the Charlotte Hornets tonight was as much fun as a trip to the dentist.

title: Metro Datelines; University Guards Want to Be Armed
description: Some campus security guards demonstrated at the State University at Old Westbury yesterday, demanding the authority to carry firearms.

title: 13 COUNTRIES BACK PALESTINIAN MOVE
description: At least 13 countries, most of them Arab or Muslim supporters of the Palestine Liberation Organizaton, extended diplomatic recognition today to the newly declared Palestinian state. Governments in Europe reacted cautiously while Palestinian factions opposed to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O chairman, condemned the move.

title: Taking the Real World To California Classes
description: So what is a nice high school mathematics teacher like Jeffrey M. Luscher doing hanging around a construction site this fall? He is developing a computer system to monitor the work of 52 subcontractors on the project.

title: The P.L.O.: Less Than Meets the Eye
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization meeting in Algiers proclaimed the independence of an unborn state and hinted at far-reaching moves toward a Middle East peace. But its final communique amounted to the same old fudge that Yasir Arafat has offered up for years - no explicit recognition of the Jewish state of Israel and no outright rejection of violence. The only new and mildly positive element is that the P.L.O.'s National Council has now endorsed the chairman's ambiguous language rather than the earlier die-hard line.

title: Reviews/Music; Aeolian Players In a Celebration Of Summers
description: Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., has sponsored a summer music festival and study institute since 1964. From the start, its resident ensemble has been the Aeolian Chamber Players, led since 1961 by Lewis Kaplan, the violinist. This year, Bowdoin and the Aeolians, along with a few guest performers who have been associated with the festival, are marking the 25th anniversary of the college's summer program with three performances at Merkin Concert Hall, the first of which was on Monday evening.

title: Continental Increasing Most Fares
description: Continental Airlines is raising its cheapest and most widely used discount fares for about two-thirds of its domestic routes while cutting fares for the rest of its system.

title: Education; Lessons
description: In her first two years at Marlboro College, Tracy Martin developed an interest in utilitarian Mayan pottery. She studied its form and style, reproduced it in the studio and delved into the chemistry of archeological techniques.

title: Prime Computer Gets a Hostile Offer
description: Prime Computer Inc., which earlier this year acquired the Computervision Corporation in a hostile takeover, has itself become the target of a takeover by a computer concern controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, a New York investor.

title: Devils Defeat Blues
description: Kirk Muller and Claude Loiselle each had a goal and an assist in a high-scoring first period that helped the Devils break St. Louis' four-game unbeaten streak 4-2 tonight.

title: What Marries Well With the Bird?
description: QUESTION: Red with meat, of course, and white with fish, but what do you drink with turkey? Answer: Whatever turns you on. This is the time of year when self-assured hosts reveal to the world that they are having ''the 1978 Lynch-Bages with Thanksgiving dinner,'' clearly implying that if you're not, you might as well do your holiday thing at Kentucky Fried Chicken.

title: John Hancock Investors Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net assets as of Sept. 30, $143,747,167, or $20.74 a share, compared with $139,104,330, or $20.40 a share, for year-ago period.

title: Brooklyn's Chase Advantage
description: No one doubts that Chase Manhattan Bank's decision to move computer operations to the new Metrotech office park in Brooklyn gives the borough's downtown a powerful boost. But did city and state officials pay too much to prevent Chase's departure? The answer is no.

title: Bridge
description: At the end of 1988, it is unlikely that anyone anywhere during the year will have made a more imaginative bid than the one shown in the diagram. It occurred in the spring in a Chicago game at the Cavendish Club in New York City, and the hero in the South position was Michael Camp, who has since won a national team title in Salt Lake City.

title: Realty Concern's Stake in Formica
description: Great American Realty Inc., a real estate concern based in Chicago, said it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in the Formica Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Great American also said it was seeking Federal antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the decorative surfacing products manufacturer to 15 percent.

title: First Republicbank
description: The First Republicbank Corporation, the shell-like corporation that was left over after the NCNB Corporation bought the First Republicbank group in a Federally financed bailout, said it had agreed to sell one of its few remaining assets, a data processing company, for $55 million cash. Under the terms of the agreement, NCNB Texas will take over the management of the company, the First Republicbank Services Company, in expectation of its purchase from the former bank-holding company.

title: Slaying of a Black In Portland Evokes Outrage on Racism
description: The beating death of a black man by white youths has prompted expressions of outrage by community leaders and civil rights workers here.

title: A Bill to Control Business Rents Is Called Flawed
description: A politically explosive commercial rent control bill is deeply flawed and would certainly open the city to serious legal challenges, legal experts told a New York City Council committee yesterday.

title: Frequent Flier Bonuses Raise Fear of Taxing
description: To the Editor:

title: Dukakis Defeat Is Laid To Late Liberal Stand
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis would have won the election if he had followed John F. Kennedy's example and embraced the term ''liberal'' early in his campaign, Senator Edward M. Kennedy said Monday.

title: Review/Theater; Can a Theatrical Culture Be Revived?
description: While the Public Theater is saluting the heyday of the Yiddish theater with Hy Kraft's ''Cafe Crown,'' in ''The Faithful Brethren of Pitt Street'' (which opened Monday night at the Orpheum Theater) Philip Lamb has written a play about trying to instill life into a dying theatrical culture. It is the play itself that is moribund.

title: Potomac, Md.
description: CHINESE grocery stores in the United States have traditionally sold ginseng in one form or another. Now, American health food stores are carrying ginseng extracts and capsules, along with the more usual ginseng roots and tea.

title: Thanks for the Sausage, Olives, and, Oh Yes, The Turkey
description: ''THANKSGIVING you eat, watch the football game and go to sleep on the couch.'' With those words Edward Brilhante described this American holiday as it exists in millions of homes across the nation.

title: MGM-UA Commun reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
News Corp Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $61,196,000 for the latest first quarter and $50,125,000 for the year-ago period. The share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (ADR) and each ADR represents two of the company's ordinary shares. The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Bid for Pillsbury Extended
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today extended its offer for the Pillsbury Company to midnight Friday, saying it remained confident that it would win control of the Minneapolis-based foods and restaurant giant because it already has 79.1 percent of the company's 86 million shares.

title: Combustion Engineering Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the gain on dispositions for the 9 monthsended Sept. 30, 1988 included the following: A pre-tax gain of $36.8 million, or 60 cents a share, after tax, from the completion of the previously announced disposition of Jamesbury Corporation, realizing net proceeds of approximately $136 million; a pre-tax gain of $5.4 million, or 9 cents a share, after tax, from the sale of a foreign equity basis investment; partially offset by a pre- tax provision of $14 million in connection with anticipated losses on the potential sale of certain other businesses. The company also said the gain on dispositions for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1987, included the following: A pre-tax gain of $12.7 million, or 20 cents a share after tax, from the sale of certain investments in the second quarter; and a pre-tax gain of $7.7 million, or 12 cents a share after tax, from the sale of the company's interest in Northern Engineering Industries Plc (UK) inteh first quarter. The company reported revised results for the latest periods to reflect an increase in the pre-tax provision taken in the third quarter to $165 million from $80 million for certain charges.

title: Robert M. Maynard, Executive, 65
description: Robert M. Maynard, a retired partner in Price Waterhouse, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home in Millburn, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Triton Raises Stake in Fuqua
description: Triton Group Ltd., a unit of Intermark Inc., has raised its stake in Fuqua Industries, the Atlanta-based conglomerate, to 9.9 percent from 8.7 percent and said it intends to seek voting control of the company. In a Securities and Exchange

title: Agency Opens Inquiry Into Cars' Computers
description: Federal safety officials said today that they had begun investigating allegations that a defective computer on the 1987 and 1988 models of Plymouth Sundance and Shadow automobiles causes the throttle to stick.

title: KEY RATES
Bay Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter ended Aug. 31; the company changed its fiscal year from May 31 to June 30.

title: Texaco to Sell More Oil and Gas Reserves
description: Texaco Inc. will sell 160 million barrels of oil and gas reserves, almost three times the amount it initially said it would sell, as part of its continuing program to concentrate on its most profitable assets, the company told 200 analysts here today.

title: Papineau Journal; Lost in the Cornfields Without Water
description: In this tiny town lost in the cornfields 70 miles south of Chicago, when the wells run dry there is no water. And right now, there is no water for many of the town's 180 people.

title: Citicorp Sale: Rates Jump
description: Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday, continuing to reflect the recent trend in short-term rates.

title: Industry Output Up 0.4%; Rise Is Best in 3 Months
description: The nation's industrial production rose a moderately strong four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the best increase in three months.

title: Gorbachev Visit an 'Informal Session'; A Traveling Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to meet next month with President Reagan and President-elect Bush in New York appears to be part of a Kremlin effort to consolidate diplomatic gains made in the last year.

title: Sports People; Hagan Resigns
description: Cliff Hagan resigned yesterday as athletic director at the University of Kentucky, six months after the National Collegiate Athletic Association began an investigation of the school's men's basketball program. Joseph Burch, an attorney, was named acting athletic director.

title:
KITCHEN BOOKSHELF;
No-Frills Tips on Southern Sensibilities and Meat and Potatoes
description: LEAD: THE common thread running through many of this season's cookbooks is straightforwardness. What you see is what you eat, and no one is worried about how to drag the knife tip through the multicolored sauces to get a spider-web effect.

title: Trade Study At O.E.C.D.
description: An international economic policy committee said today that the trade imbalances of the United States and Japan were declining but that the panel ''would be concerned if the pace of reduction slowed.''

title: British Industrial Output
description: Britain's industrial output fell a provisional, seasonally adjusted five-tenths of a percent in September, according to Central Statistical Office figures released today. Industrial production in the three months that ended Sept. 30 was 1 percent higher than in the previous three months and 3.4 percent higher than in the corresponding three months of 1987. Output in the third quarter was inflated by unusually high production in July and August as factories stayed at work to keep up with strong consumer spending.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The door to a Middle East peace has been opened by a high-level Palestinian meeting in Algiers, Yasir Arafat asserted. It is now up to the United States to revive the stalled negotiations, he said. Page A1

title: College Football; Orange Likes Look Of the Color Green
description: Syracuse adherents have been asking why their team, one of the best they have had, is to play in the Hall of Fame Bowl rather than in one of the major bowls: the Cotton, the Orange, the Sugar or even the Gator?

title: Give the West Coast a Head Start on Election Day; Getting Out the Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirk Is Convicted Of Tax Evasion
description: Dana Kirk, the former Memphis State basketball coach, was convicted today by a Federal jury of income tax evasion and obstruction of justice.

title: Drexel Appeal on Judge Is Dismissed
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday dismissed a challenge brought by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to the impartiality of a district judge hearing the Government's securities fraud action.

title: Review/Piano; Jarrett Plays And Embraces His Wild Muse
description: The pianist Keith Jarrett, in a rare solo concert, brought the musical equivalent of decorative art to Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night. While moments of the music were lyrical and tender, in much of it solemnity covered a lack of depth.

title: Atari Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $1,620,000 for the quarter and $13,277,000 for the 9 months. The latest periods included results of Federated Group Inc., acquired on Oct. 4, 1987.

title: Review/Television; 2d Second City's Anniversary Show
description: There is something goofy, and endearing, about the whole premise of Showtime's ''Second City's 15th Anniversary Special,'' being shown at 8 this evening on the pay-cable service. The show, which was taped in August, celebrates not the anniversary of the original Second City, an experimental cabaret theater that opened in Chicago in 1959, but of its Toronto cousin, which got under way 14 years later, not in August but in June of 1973. So who's counting? This particular production was produced and directed by Eugene Levy for Andrew Alexander Productions in association with the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Borland-I.B.M.
description: Borland International Inc. has entered an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation to package Sidekick for Presentation Manager, a desktop management software program, with I.B.M.'s OS/2 Standard Edition operating system and with the OS/2 Extended Edition with Presentation Manager. Sidekick for Presentation Manager, which Borland said is the first program for the recently announced operating system, will be provided free with all new orders for I.B.M. OS/2. ''Our agreement with I.B.M. signifies the importance of this product on this new platform,'' Philippe Kahn, Borland's president, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.

title: Bad News Was Put on Hold
description: The White House deliberately de-layed some sensitive policy moves until after the election, officials ac-knowledged yesterday. Page A29.

title: Honeywell Bull Model
description: Honeywell Bull introduced a powerful mainframe computer, the DPS 9000, on Monday. It is capable of performing more than 1,000 transactions a second. The company's three owners - Groupe Bull of France, the NEC Corporation of Japan and Honeywell Inc. - cooperated in developing the new computer.

title: Rangers Rally For a Tie
description: The Rangers had a player knocked down and out in the first period. They had another crushed into the endboards when the play had stopped in the second period. And in the third, they had their goaltender ambushed and a goal disallowed.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Scramble in Pentagon
description: Early next year a scramble for the chairmanship of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is expected because the incumbent Chairman, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., must by law retire on Sept. 30, 1989. Since the previous Chairman, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., was from the Army and the current Chairman is a Navy officer, it would normally be the Air Force's turn next.

title: United Artists Communicaions Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest periods ended Sept. 30, while the year-ago quarter and 9 months ended Aug. 31.

title: Copeland Extends Offer for Church's
description: A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., the owner of Popeye's Fried Chicken and Biscuits, based in New Orleans, said today that it had extended its tender offer of $8 a share for all common shares outstanding of Church's Fried Chicken Inc., based in San Antonio. Copeland's cash offer, which began Oct. 25, was scheduled to expire today. It was extended to accommodate a hearing for a lawsuit filed in connection with the proposed takeover.

title: U.S. Reaction to Step by Arafat Is Tepid
description: The United States reacted without much enthusiasm today to the latest actions of the Palestine Liberation Organization, saying the group's declarations did not meet American conditions for dealing with the Palestinian organization.

title: Coalition Urges Action to Save U.S. Wetlands
description: An unusual alliance of people in government, industry, agriculture and the environmental movement called today for ''sweeping new policies'' to save the nation's rapidly disappearing wetlands.

title: Israel Dismisses State As an Irrelevant Gesture
description: Israel today dismissed the Palestine Liberation Organization's declaration of an independent Palestinian state as irrelevant and unimportant, and many Palestinians in the occupied territories barely seemed to take note of it at all.

title: Allen A. Stein, Lawyer, 54
description: Allen A. Stein, a lawyer who specialized in real estate law, died of a melanoma yesterday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 54 years old and lived in Larchmont.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: About New York; Food That Looks Good Enough To, Uh, Look At
description: It's hard to miss the 20-foot likeness of Jesus on the cross made from something or other that's edible.

title: A Neo-Fascist Kills 3 in Pretoria
description: A member of a white neo-fascist group opened fire on a crowd here today, killing 3 people and wounding at least 10. All the victims were black. Witnesses said the man, a former policeman wearing a camouflage jacket and armed with a handgun, appeared to direct his fire only at blacks.

title: Social Security Programs In the Reagan Presidency
description: 1981 In his first budget, President Reagan asks that Congress eliminate the minimum benefit of $122 a month and repeal the lump-sum death benefit of $255 if the beneficiary dies without a spouse or children. Congress eliminated the death benefit but restored the minimum benefit for all people eligible before January 1982. April 1981 The Administration successfully petitions Congress to eliminate the Social Security program providing monthly payments to full-time students who are children of disabled, retired or deceased workers covered by Social Security. May 1981 The President proposes major benefit reductions for future Social Security recipients who retire before the age of 65, meets strong bipartisan opposition in Congress and drops plan. September 1981 Mr. Reagan seeks a one-time, three-month deferral of cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients, later drops proposal. May 1982 Social Security officials disclose that disability insurance benefits for more than 100,000 families have ended under an accelerated review of cases begun by the Administration. April 1983 The President signs into law the bipartisan plan passed by Congress to insure the solvency of the Social Security System, including a six-month delay in the 1983 cost-of-living increase. April 1984 The Administration suspends efforts to reduce the number of people receiving Social Security benefits and orders that benefits be continued or restored for 40,000 people who challenged their removal from the rolls. September 1984 A Social Security Administration study concludes that efforts to reduce the number of people on disability rolls has led to a ''huge volume of adverse court decisions.'' April 1985 The Reagan Administration decides to reduce the staff of the Social Security Administration by 21 percent. December 1985 The Reagan Administration announces that it will again review all 2.6 million people on disability rolls to determine if they should continue receiving benefits. March 1986 The Administration plans to establish a new court to hear cases of people denied retirement or disability benefits. May 1986 The Social Security Administration again begins removing ineligible people from disability rolls. June 1986 The Supreme Court upholds a finding that Social Security officials had a 'fixed clandestine policy' to deny disability benefits to people with mental illness. It rules that mentally disabled people have the right to sue for Social Security disability benefits. July 1986 The Reagan Administration asks the Supreme Court to uphold standards that officials use in ruling on disability benefits.

title: Oil Lobby Warns of a New Crisis
description: Cheap oil is setting up the United States for a more severe oil crisis than those of the 1970's, the oil industry's chief lobbying group said yesterday.

title: 2d Walkout at Metro-North Halts Train Service to 95,000
description: For the second time in two months, a labor dispute halted all service on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad before the morning rush yesterday, forcing its 95,000 riders to scramble for ways to get to work.

title: The Ivory Tower And the Golden Calf
description: To the Editor:

title: Macmillan Officers to Stay After Maxwell Acquisition
description: Twenty-six of Macmillan Inc.'s 31 senior executives have agreed to remain after its acquisition by the Maxwell Communication Corporation. They include William F. Reilly, the president and chief operating officer, who was recently named to the reconstituted board.

title: KOHL AND REAGAN IN NOSTALGIC TALK
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany had a nostalgic final meeting today with President Reagan and then urged President-elect Bush to speed negotiations aimed at cutting long-range nuclear weapons.

title: Wilfred American Education reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Minneapolis
description: MANY people in Minnesota dash north on Friday for a weekend at the lake. Now that north-woods feeling has been re-created in the heart of Minneapolis, on the city's busiest street.

title: Books of The Times; Mexican History in the Perspective of Daily Life
description: La Capital The Biography of Mexico City By Jonathan Kandell 640 pages. Random House. $24.95.

title: Education; New Medical School Challenge: Human Values
description: Twelve medical students are facing one another in a circle and talking about a topic that was once almost taboo: their fears about dealing with dying patients, their fears of dying themselves.

title: Education; Fewer Degrees for Black Men in Maryland
description: A study that disclosed a sharp drop in the percentage of black men earning bachelor's degrees in Maryland state colleges in the last decade has prompted an investigation by the state chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: TRADE ISSUE GIVEN A TWIST IN CANADA
description: After a year in which public debate in Canada has been dominated by discussion of the possible perils to Canada of ratifying the free-trade agreement with the United States, attention has shifted in recent days to the economic and political costs of rejecting it.

title: Tiffany & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $644,000 loss from the early repayment of debt.

title: Book Notes
description: Parker in for Chandler

title: Choppy Night at Christie's: Records and Failures
description: The art auction market fluttered again last night in a sale of Impressionist and modern art at Christie's; some works sold for record prices and several major works did not sell.

title: Luxembourg Money Law
description: The Luxembourg Government said today that it planned to impose harsh penalties for money laundering, a move that follows the indictment by the United States of a bank based here on charges of disguising the source of drug money.

title: Job Injury Rate Up 5% in 1987
description: The rate of job-related injuries and illnesses increased 5 percent last year, with 351,000 more injuries and 53,000 more illnesses reported, the Government said today.

title: Corrections
description: A chronology on Monday about the Peronist movement in Argentina dated Gen. Juan D. Peron's service as President incorrectly. His terms began in 1946, 1952 and 1973.

title: Resorts International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,000,000 from the reversal of a tax benefit. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $2,300,000. The company said that in the latest quarter it recorded a provision for the estimated loss on the sale of the Taj Mahal and certain other assets to Mr. Donald J. Trump and the fee related to the termination of a services agreement with Trump Hotel Corp. It said these charges totaled $335,690,000, including an estimate of certain related expenses.

title: If You're a Small Business, Maybe You Just Can't Win in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Pomegranates Add a Splash Of Exotic Tanginess to Fall
description: WHEN Persephone, the queen of the underworld and goddess of fertility in Greek mythology, ate some pomegranate seeds, the earth was cursed with winter half of every year. With its crimson seeds sparkling like so many rubies, the pomegranate is still tantalizing.

title: Dallas Office Site Expected for GTE
description: The GTE Corporation is expected to announce at a news conference today that Dallas will be the site of a new central office for its domestic telephone operations, people close to the giant telephone company have said. Harvey W. Greisman, GTE's vice president of corporate public affairs, confirmed that the company had scheduled a news conference in Dallas to give a status report on the company's restructuring program. Mr. Greisman declined to comment further.

title: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-After a gain of $15.3 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. c-After a gain of $10.1 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for inventory costs.
