description: HERE are some tips for selecting and using pomegranates:

title: Pelham Fritz, 68, Recreation Dept. Official
description: Pelham Fritz, assistant recreation commissioner of New York City, died of cancer Saturday at Calvary Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Hint of the Mysterious Middle East
description: Grilled Lamb in Pomegranate-Rosemary Marinade Preparation time: 25 minutes, plus 4 to 6 hours for marinating Cooking time: 20 to 35 minutes 1 leg of lamb, butterflied, 3 to 4 pounds boned weight, trimmed of excess fat and flattened to an even thickness 3/4 cup pomegranate juice 1/4 cup olive oil 1 tablespoon chopped garlic 3 tablespoons lemon juice 3 tablespoons coarsely chopped fresh rosemary 10 basil leaves, torn into pieces

title: Market Place; New Protections For Bondholders
description: WALL STREET, no small player in the war for RJR Nabisco Inc., is starting to reach out to an important constituency that has been badly burned since that heated takeover battle began: investors in corporate bonds.

title: Black Colleges Struggle Despite Rise in U.S. Aid
description: The Department of Education reported last week that Federal research and development grants to historically black colleges and universities increased $95.4 million from 1981 to 1987. The total amount of Federal aid to the colleges increased 25.5 percent, to $683.6 million in 1987 from $544.8 million in 1981.

title: Haywood Hansell Jr. Dies at 85; Supervised World War II Bombing
description: Haywood S. Hansell Jr., who commanded American strategic bombing of Germany and Japan in World War II as an Army Air Force major general after being a stunt flier in his youth, died Monday at Hilton Head Hospital in South Carolina of heart failure brought on by pulmonary edema.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Buyout Specialist Gets Top Post at Best
description: LEAD: Jerry E. Goldress, a specialist in turnarounds and leveraged buyouts, has been elected the chairman and chief executive of Best Products Inc., the Richmond-based catalogue showroom company.

title: If You're a Small Business, Maybe You Just Can't Win in New York; No Wonder They Left
description: To the Editor:

title: Service for Judge Sandler
description: A memorial service for Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, who died Oct. 23, will be held Monday at 10:30 A.M. at the Appellate Division Courthouse, Madison Avenue and 25th Street. The speakers will include Mayor Koch and Presiding Justice Francis T. Murphy of the Appellate Division.

title: Dow Rallies With 12.09 Gain on Slow Day
description: LEAD: Stock prices rallied yesterday in a sluggish session.

title: Metro Datelines; Goldin Faults School Construction
description: The average new school takes 79 percent longer to build than the Board of Education originally projects, according to a report released yesterday by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: A Panel on Trade Urges Better U.S.-Mexico Ties
description: The United States and Mexico should develop an enhanced economic and trading relationship that could eventually lead to a limited bilateral free-trade arrangement, a commission of Mexican and American luminaries recommends.

title: Du Pont to Market Genetically Altered Mice
description: The E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company will begin marketing mice genetically engineered to develop malignant tumors that will help researchers trace the growth of breast cancer, which afflicts about 150,000 women a year, the company said today.

title: Sudan Party and Rebels Agree to Cease-Fire
description: The leader of the rebel forces and the head of a political party in the Sudanese Government have signed a cease-fire agreement to end the five-year civil conflict, the Khartoum press reported today.

title: '89 Zagat Book Lists 868 Restaurants
description: THE 1989 Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey, based on a 10-page questionnaire completed by 3,500 respondents, is rolling off the presses.

title: Gibson Is Voted Most Valuable
description: In a sharply contested election, Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers was named the Most Valuable Player in the National League yesterday over Darryl Strawberry of the Mets, who conceded with sadness: ''It was a Dodger year.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Conde Nast to Buy Woman Magazine
description: Conde Nast Publications Inc. has agreed to acquire Woman magazine, an eight-year-old bimonthly with a circulation of 525,000, from Harris Publications. Woman is far less sophisticated than the publisher's crop of women's magazines. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Democrats List Some Wealthy Donors in the Campaign Year
description: The Democratic Party, waiting until after the election, today identified some of the wealthy donors who were responsible for the party's fund-raising success this year.

title: Reviews/Music; Traveling 'Butterfly' In English
description: Sunday night's meeting of the San Francisco Western Opera Theater and its very small audience at the Beacon Theater constituted a sort of no-fault accident.

title: Justice Dept. Prosecutor Says An Inquiry Has Cleared Him
description: The Justice Department's chief pornography prosecutor said today that he had been cleared of charges that he had asked another department official to destroy a document in a pending case.

title: Close Call in Air For Reagan Jet Prompts Review
description: Contending that many ''deficiencies'' allowed President Reagan's plane to fly illegally close to a commuter airliner last month, a top Federal safety agency yesterday called for an urgent review of the traffic control system throughout the Northeast.

title: Who Killed John Kennedy? After 25 Years, More Theories Than Certainty
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

title: Texas Editor to Lead Atlanta Newspapers
description: A longtime editor with the Cox newspaper chain today was named editor of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, the chain's largest papers.

title: Liberia's Leader Orders Release Of 2 Americans in Good-Will Step
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian head of state, today ordered the release of two American citizens detained four months on charges of taking part in a coup attempt.

title: Federal Home Loan Banks In a $3.7 Billion Offering
description: A total of $3.7 billion in floating-rate and fixed-rate bonds is being offered by the Federal Home Loan Banks through various securities dealers.

title: Summations Presented At Trial of Larry Davis
description: In sharply contrasting styles, prosecution and defense lawyers yesterday presented conflicting versions of evidence to the jury in the trial of Larry Davis.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Thanksgiving, to Go

title: Maryland Health Refunding Bonds
description: The Maryland Health and Higher Education Facilities Authority is tentatively offering $69.4 million of refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.422 percent for an issue due in 2009 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Thomas G. Spates, Professor, 98
description: Thomas G. Spates, a professor emeritus at Yale University's School of Engineering, and a former vice president of the General Foods Corporation, died of a lung tumor yesterday in Hamden, Conn., where he lived. He was 98 years old.

title: Flames Outclass Islanders
description: The Calgary Flames, the team with the best record in the National Hockey League, tonight exposed the weaknesses of the Islanders, the team with one of the poorest records.

title: Tennis; Navratilova Struggles to Win
description: Martina Navratilova smiled pleasantly and acknowledged that she hoped to use this Virginia Slims Championship, the final event of the 1988 circuit, as the first weapon in her arsenal for a renaissance in 1989.

title: Long Fight for Resorts Has Officially Ended
description: The battle for control of Resorts International that has raged ever since the gaming concern's founder, James Crosby, died in April 1986 ended yesterday when Merv Griffin, the former television talk show host, bought the shares owned by Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, and took the company private.

title: Lands' End Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Agents Cite Jersey's Role in Drug Trade
description: New Jersey's importance to the cocaine trade is increasing, and drug abuse problems, especially in the inner cities, are outstripping government efforts to control them, Federal and state officials testified today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chock Full o'Nuts Corp., said it had completed its acquisition of Jimbo's Jumbo's Inc., a peanut company based in Edenton, N.C., for $31.5 million.

title: Ward Alters Complaint Policy
description: All complaints of discrimination involving New York City police officers or civilian police employees must now be reported to the Police Department and delivered to Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward and other senior police officials.

title: Alco Standard Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $3,256,000 for the quarter and $10,006,000 for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $2,557,000 and $4,758,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: 3 NATIONS ACHIEVE ACCORD ON NAMIBIA
description: Negotiators from South Africa, Angola and Cuba said today that they had reached preliminary agreement on a formula for Namibian independence and for a phased withdrawal of the estimated 50,000 Cuban troops in Angola.

title: EATING WELL
description: TURKEYS come complete with giblets. The modern-day turkey may also harbor a variety of microbiological hazards that could ruin the holiday with unpleasant gastrointestinal symptoms. But with proper food handling, these can easily be avoided.

title: If Mostly Mozart Is So Good, Why Not Perform All of Him?
description: Flushed with the success of its annual Mostly Mozart Festival, Lincoln Center is upping its Mozart ante by planning a 19-month celebration in which every one of Mozart's more than 800 compositions would be performed.

title: Youths Face New Counts in Sex-Abuse Case
description: A teen-ager from Great Neck and a neighborhood friend, already charged in numerous incidents of molesting boys, were charged today with an additional 302 counts of sodomy and sexual abuse, the Nassau County District Attorney said.

title: Heat Scores 65, Third Lowest Since '55
description: The Miami Heat, an expansion team, missed 16 of its first 17 shots in the fourth quarter tonight and lost to the Boston Celtics, 84-65, matching the third-lowest total for one team since 1955.

title: Carson Pirie Scott & Co reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $36,120,000.

title: Suspended Officer Arrested on Drug Charge
description: A New York City police officer who was suspended in April after failing a drug screening test was arrested last night in Harlem and charged with possessing six vials of crack, officials said.

title: Charter Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income of $45,021,000 and $48,770,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations, and tax credits of $77,000 for the quarter and $7,192,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,186,000 for the quarter and $1,189,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $2,594,000 and $3,549,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THIS Thanksgiving season I have been experimenting with versatile turkey parts, which are ideal for couples or small families who don't want to have a week's worth of leftovers after the holiday feast. I have always been fond of turkey breast, which, when prepared correctly, can mimic more expensive veal remarkably well. The turkey breast and stuffing recipe here calls for a four-pound breast with the ribs attached.

title: Lawyer Suggests That Fall Killed Lisa Steinberg
description: The defense repeatedly attacked a medical examiner's conclusion that Lisa Steinberg died from a homicidal blow to the head and strongly suggested instead yesterday that she died from a head injury sustained in an accidental fall.

title: 3M Repurchase
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company's board of directors authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million additional shares of its common stock by May 31, 1989. The purchases are an extension of a program to reacquire shares for employee stock-purchase and savings plans and for other corporate purposes, the company said. The action brings to 14 million the number of shares authorized for purchase through next May. Minnesota Mining had 226.2 million shares outstanding as of Oct. 31. In New York Stock Exchange trading today, the company's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $59.875.

title: Frequent Flier Bonuses Raise Fear of Taxing; Choking on Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Vying for Post in Tokyo
description: There is hot competition for the post of United States Ambassador to Japan, succeeding former Senator Mike Mansfield, who announced his retirement Monday at the age of 85 after serving 11 years in Tokyo.

title: Fire Burns 20 Buildings in Oklahoma Town
description: A wind-whipped fire swept through this southwest Oklahoma town today, destroying more than 20 houses and businesses and forcing about 400 people from their homes.

title: Bush Is Reported to Have Chosen Gov. Sununu as His Chief of Staff
description: President-elect Bush will reach outside the Washington establishment to name Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire to the influential post of chief of staff, aides said today.

title: Marseilles Journal; If the Racism Tastes Sour, How Sweet Is Success
description: There are some new high-rolling players on the rough streets of Marseilles, where the last immigrant off the boat has always had to fight the hardest for survival and, later, for wealth and power. It is sometimes said that there are no true French in the city's demographic bouillabaisse, but that there are plenty of Italians, Spaniards, Poles, Armenians, Jews -and Arabs.

title: Maine Town Gets Telephone Service
description: The 45 year-round residents of this rock-bound island are putting their highly prized privacy on the line by allowing telephones in their homes in an effort to guarantee their future.

title: Short-Term Rates Continue Up
description: Short-term interest rates rose further yesterday amid new evidence that the economy has been strengthening. The evidence - better than expected retail sales and strong industrial production in October - also raised expectations that the Federal Reserve will tighten credit within a few weeks to bolster the sagging dollar and prevent a resurgence of inflation.

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4 million and $2.9 million for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain on exchange of cellular interests of $2,347,101.

title: United Air Rejects Foreign Carrier Tie
description: United Airlines Inc. has rejected a possible deal under which it would swap equity stakes with a foreign carrier, the chairman of its parent company, the UAL Corporation, said. Stephen Wolf said at a meeting with reporters that the company had been approached but was not interested in the mutual equity participation ''at this point in time.''

title: Metro Datelines; Ex-Aide to Myerson Recalls a Warning
description: A former official of New York City's Cultural Affairs Department testified yesterday that Bess Myerson's first statement to the agency's staff was a warning about ''incompetent city employees.''

title: Turkey Looks Sickly? Help Is at Your Fingertips
description: WHAT do you do when it's Thanksgiving Day and your turkey doesn't look so good? What if your new mother-in-law is due in an hour and you told her you have cooked a lot of turkeys - only you lied?

title: Indian Move On Carbide
description: Magistrate R. C. Mishra issued arrest warrants today for Warren M. Anderson, the former chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, and two other company officials in connection with murder charges in the 1984 gas disaster that killed 3,100 people.

title: Marcos and Wife Enjoy The High Life in Hawaii
description: Despite Imelda Marcos's complaint that living in exile in Hawaii for the last two years has resembled a prison sentence, some friends, associates and others say she and her husband, the former President of the Philippines, still enjoy the high life they were accustomed to in Manila.

title: Patent Rift Settled
description: Spectra-Physics Inc. and Coherent Inc., the world's two-largest laser companies, said that they had settled their long-running patent dispute with a cross-licensing agreement. According to the agreement, Coherent will grant Spectra-Physics a worldwide license to its metal ceramic laser patents, in return for which Spectra-Physics agreed to pay $2 million. Spectra-Physics granted a license for the brazing of metal disks in cooling metal-ceramic plasma tubes.

title: Walesa Agrees to Join Polish Aide in Debate
description: The Solidarity founder Lech Walesa promptly agreed today to a nationally televised debate with the head of Poland's official trade union alliance on the issue of union pluralism.

title: Baseball; Mets Pick Up Wilson's Option
description: The Mets picked up the option on Mookie Wilson's contract yesterday and will pay him $1 million for the 1989 season, which they indicated he would spend in Shea Stadium playing the part-time role that he has resisted for the last two years. And the 32-year-old center fielder, the senior member of the Mets in service, agreed that the ''chances are slim'' that he will be traded.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Western Ads Are Lured By Izvestia
description: Starting next year, the 10.5 million readers of the Soviet Government daily newspaper Izvestia will open their Tuesday papers to find a special supplement featuring Western advertisements for Western goods, paid for at the relatively inexpensive rate of $50,000 a page.

title: Queens Jury To Get Reports Of Police Bias
description: A special grand jury will investigate complaints that white police officers in three Queens precincts beat or subjected black and Hispanic people to racial abuse in at least seven recent incidents, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: John Hancock Income Securiies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net assets as of Sept. 30, $145,530,265, or $15.43 a share, compared with $140,402,784, or $15.16 a share, for year-ago period.

title: Go-Video Accepts 3 Suit Settlements
description: Go-Video Inc., which makes video cassette recorders, has agreed to accept cash settlements from three defendants in a $1.5 billion antitrust suit, R. Terren Dunlap, the company's chairman, said. Mr. Dunlap said his company had agreed to accept settlements from Hitachi Ltd. of Japan, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan and the Goldstar Company of Korea. In return, Go-Video has agreed to dismiss the three as defendants in the lawsuit.

title: U.S. DRAFTS RULES LIMITING APPEALS ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Social Security officials have drafted new rules that would sharply restrict the rights of elderly and disabled people to appeal Government decisions denying Social Security, Medicare and welfare benefits.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page in Business Day on Monday, about a Sunday health magazine to be produced and marketed by The New York Times and four other newspapers, described the magazine's cover design incorrectly. Each newspaper will prepare its own cover and contents, though the versions will share a single nameplate.

title: Mcorp Seeks Fed Loans
description: Mcorp, the giant Texas bank, said today that it was seeking short-term loans from the Federal Reserve to solve liquidity problems.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: George Maier, the only coach in Pace University's football history, resigned yesterday after 16 years at the Division III school. . . . Mark Gastineau, who retired from the Jets last month, was ordered yesterday by a four-judge panel of the New York State Appellate Court in Brooklyn to pay $10,600 in retroactive alimony and child support payments to his estranged wife, Lisa. (AP)

title: ARAFAT URGES U.S. TO PRESS ISRAELIS TO NEGOTIATE NOW
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, asserted today that the high-level Palestinian political meeting here had opened the door to peace in the Middle East and that it was now up to the United States to revive the stalled negotiations.

title: Sports People; N.B.A. Fines
description: Three National Basketball Association players have been fined a total of $3,500 by Rod Thorn, the vice president of operations, for incidents that took place in two games last week. Robert Parish of the Boston Celtics was fined $1,500 and Bill Laimbeer of the Detroit Pistons $1,000 for fighting at Boston Garden last Friday night. Parish threw a punch that cost him $500 more than Laimbeer. Rick Mahorn of the Pistons was fined $1,000 for two flagrant fouls in a game against the Atlanta Hawks last Wednesday.

title: Sports People; Double Team
description: Giant fans shouldn't despair just yet, there is a good chance that Lawrence Taylor will be ''traded,'' according to his agent Jerome Schwartz. Taylor won't be playing for the Rams or the Raiders, but for the Los Angeles Bulls, the fictional football team that is the focus of the Home Box Office series ''1st & Ten.''

title: Leonard Giving Up Titles
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, who won the World Boxing Council light heavyweight and W.B.C. supermiddleweight titles when he knocked out Donny Lalonde on Nov. 7, does not want to keep the titles.

title: Sports People; Coach Penalized
description: Coach Steve Spurrier of Duke will be barred from the Duke-North Carolina game Saturday because of comments he made about officiating after a 43-43 tie with North Carolina State last Saturday. The Atlantic Coast Conference commissioner, Gene Corrigan, said conference policy would allow Spurrier to be with his team up to one hour before game time.

title: Colorado River Authority Bonds
description: The Lower Colorado River Authority is offering $106.1 million of priority refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.69 percent for an issue due in 2016 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. For shorter maturities, yields range from 6.20 percent in 1991 to 6.60 peercent in 1993, 7.10 percent in 1998 and 7.25 percent in 2000. In addition, the authority is offering zero-coupon-type bonds in serial form, which pay no interest. If held to maturity the bonds yield 7.40 percent for an issue due 2001, at a price of $415.52 per $1,000, to 7.75 percent for an issue due 2009, priced at $217.12 per $1,000 of bonds. Underwriters said the issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P.

title: PS Enterprise Group reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Palestinian View: Big Step Forward
description: Although they were met with derision in Israel and a lack of enthusiasm in Washington, the political steps adopted by the Palestine National Council are regarded by the Palestinian leadership gathered here as a significant move away from the ''rejectionist'' views that have so dominated the movement in the past.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: EACH morning Eleanor Ensminger boards a chartered bus that takes her from her home on Staten Island to her office in midtown Manhattan, where she is an executive secretary. No problem: one hour, a few minutes more or less. There are exceptions, of course; the other morning was one of them.

title: Sports of The Times; Gibson's Rage To Victory
description: IT'S not every player who storms off the field before his first exhibition with his new team. But that's how Kirk Gibson opened his career with the Dodgers, and it is a major reason he deserved the Most Valuable Player award voted him yesterday.

title: Real Estate; Forest Hills Project Takes Garage Site
description: THE newest construction project on Austin Street, the booming shopping thoroughfare in Forest Hills, Queens, has renewed debate in the neighborhood over how to deal with a vexing side effect of commercial prosperity: mounting traffic congestion.

title: Sensitive Issues Put on the Shelf To Protect Bush
description: White House officials acknowledged today that the Reagan Administration had deliberately delayed a series of sensitive policy announcements until after the election in order to protect Vice President Bush's political interests.

title: Multiply and Subside
description: Human life expectancy gets longer and longer. At first glance this seems like good news. But hold it: human life expectancy is not the only thing getting longer and longer. So are television mini-series.

title: A New Hybrid Shows Potential
description: A NEW white-wine hybrid grape called Melody has been bred in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York. Its parents are European and American. Only one vintner in the state makes the wine, which is also made in Maryland.

title: The Barbizon, as Urban Spa
description: THE Barbizon Hotel, once the home-away-from-home for generations of proper young women making their way in the big city, is to become a haven for the overworked, and sometimes overweight: New York's first urban spa, its new owners say.

title: Home Depot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Resistance To U.S. Ads About AIDS
description: THE advertising industry, long derided by critics as a hotbed of avaricious hucksterism, is fending off a paying client in favor of working for free.

title: Sports People; Player, Coach Banned
description: The National Hockey League suspended Troy Loney of the Penguins for 10 games and the Pittsburgh coach, Gene Ubriaco for five games yesterday as the result of a fight at Vancouver last weekend.

title: Debrett's Errs; Cleric Amused
description: Debrett's, the British peerage directory, has confessed to erroneously listing the Roman Catholic Primate of England and Wales, Basil Cardinal Hume, as married. Cardinal Hume said: ''I know marriage by proxy is normal, but I wish I had been consulted first.''

title: Something for Everyone at Knife Show
description: NEW YORK CITY'S 11th annual custom knife show opens at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan Friday and continues through Sunday.

title: Atom Waste in Savannah Harbor
description: Researchers have found small quantities of a radioactive substance in material dredged from Savannah Harbor about 100 miles downstream from the Savannah River nuclear weapon plant.

title: Boesky Misled Drexel, Inquiry Is Said to Find
description: A defunct stock trading partnership controlled by Ivan F. Boesky engaged in an illegal scheme to deceive Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., according to people familiar with an investigation by London's International Stock Exchange.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: All the Fixings: Stuffing, Gravy, a Splash of Hot Sauce
description: These are some of Isabel Costa's Thanksgiving dishes. In recipes calling for hot sauce, she recommends using Vietnamese chili sauce with garlic instead of the hot Portuguese sauces available in this country. Potatoes and Sausages Preparation time: 30 minutes Cooking time: 1 hour 20 minutes 15 medium-size potatoes (5 to 5 1/2 pounds), peeled and left whole 1 8-inch chouri,co (Portuguese sausage), thinly sliced 4 cloves garlic, minced

title: Times Mirror Purchase
description: The Times Mirror Company, the newspaper and broadcasting concern, said today that it had agreed to acquire Zenger-Miller Inc., a Cupertino, Calif., company that specializes in management and supervisory training. Terms were not disclosed. Zenger-Miller is the second training-company acquisition made by Times Mirror, parent of The Los Angeles Times. In 1985, the company bought Learning International of Stamford, Conn. The field ''offers substantial growth,'' Robert F. Erburu, Times Mirror's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.

title: Economist at Du Pont Is Honored for Accuracy
description: Richard A. Stuckey, the chief economist for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, is riding high among the ranks of his prognosticating colleagues.

title: Laying Claim to 'Real' Brunswick Stew
description: LEAD: WHAT gumbo is to Louisi ana and burgoo is to Kentucky, Brunswick stew is to the Piedmont and coastal regions of Virginia, the Carolinas and Georgia. Brunswick stew is the pot around which legendary Southern politicians have secured elections and from which hundreds of rural charities are supported.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Joel Fineman has been named management supervisor/senior vice president of Burkhardt & Christy Advertising.

title: Environmental Groups Optimistic About Their Prospects With Bush
description: National environmental groups, despondent when Ronald Reagan was elected President eight years ago because of his proclaimed hostility to environmental regulations, are expressing optimism about their prospects in a Bush administration.

title: Retail Sales Up by 0.9% In October
description: Retail sales shot up by nine-tenths of 1 percent in October, the strongest increase in seven months, the Commerce Department said today in a report that heightened inflation fears in the financial markets.

title: Pakistan Supporting New Afghan Plan
description: Sensing that the Soviet Union is grasping for ways to create a government in Kabul that might be acceptable to Afghanistan's exiled King and its guerrilla armies, Pakistan is seeking international support for a new political proposal by the Pakistan-based guerrillas.

title: Review/Rock; Jimmy Page At the Ritz
description: There wasn't a restrained, safe or comfortable moment during Jimmy Page's show at the Ritz on Sunday night. Mr. Page, one of the first generation of English guitar heros and the guitarist for Led Zepplin, is a ferocious improviser who has kept an allegiance to tough, unpolished music making. For two hours, at a wall-shaking volume, he played brilliantly.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Accounts for HDM
description: HDM, Los Angeles, recently added three accounts to its roster, totaling $8.2 million. Avenue Entertainment has assigned its $5 million motion picture broadcast advertising to the agency, while the nearby Westin Bonaventure hotel, part of the Westin Hotels and Resorts chain, has given its $2 million budget to the agency. The chain has also assigned HDM the $1.2 million account for Westin La Paloma, its golf club in Tuscon, Ariz. The shop will also handle national pro bono campaigns for the Arthritis Foundation of America.

title: Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: In the latest quarter, the company took a $15 million writedown of internally produced programming. The company said the charge results from an analysis of future program needs and of the syndication potential of the programming.

title: Knicks Overcome Olajuwon's Efforts
description: Akeem Olajuwon won his statisical battle against Patrick Ewing tonight but the Knicks, by pressing, running and hitting the 3-point shot with uncanny accuracy, defeated the Houston Rockets, 126-121, the Summit.

title: Car Kills a Woman in K Mart
description: A car driven by a 72-year-old man went out of control and crashed through the plate-glass front doors of a K Mart department store in Belleville, N.J. yesterday, killing one shopper and injuring 12 others, one seriously, as the car drove 100 feet into the store.

title: Pact Reached In Collapse Of Building
description: Less than two years after a high-rise construction project collapsed in Bridgeport, Conn., killing 28 workers, a $41 million settlement of all legal claims from the disaster has been achieved through mediation.

title: The Unaffordable Atom Smasher
description: America has no coherent policy for supporting scientific research. A sign of the anarchy is the decision by Secretary of Energy John Herrington to build the proposed superconducting supercollider in Texas. The power of the Texas delegation in Congress may offer the best hope of funding the $5 billion machine. But the deeper question, given little attention by the Energy Department, is how paying for the project will affect other science.

title: O'Rourke Proposes Raising Budget 10%, but Not Taxes
description: Westchester County proposed today a $932.1 million budget for next year that is 10 percent higher than current spending but avoids a property-tax increase.

title: Calendar: A Feast of Hanukkah Lights
description: Nine Candles, The Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street; 212-860-1888.

title: Givens Sues Tyson
description: Robin Givens, the actress, filed a $125 million libel suit yesterday against her estranged husband, the heavyweight boxing champion, Mike Tyson, who was quoted in a newspaper saying that she was trying to steal his money. The lawsuit, filed in Federal court in Manhattan, accused Tyson of holding up Givens ''to public contempt, ridicule, embarrassment disgrace and prejudice.'' The latest swing in the marital strife between Tyson and Givens stemmed from a Nov. 7 New York Post article, which quoted Tyson as saying Givens was trying to ''steal'' his money and property. The Post was not named as a defendant in the lawsuit, which described the article as ''false, defamatory, malicious and libelous.'' The Post had no immediate comment. (AP)

title: Crescott Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $334,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and an extraordinary charge of $142,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $70,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After net from discontinued operations of $7,248,000 and $7,588,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $1,561,000 for the quarter and $1,138,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dow Plunges 38.59, Ending At 2,038.58
description: LEAD: The stock market continued a broad retreat yesterday from its recent post-crash highs, and the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 38.59 points, to 2,038.58.

title: Jersey Water Issue Is Tentatively Set
description: The New Jersey Water Supply Authority is tentatively offering $32.4 million of water system revenue bonds for the Delaware and Raritan system with a maximum yield of about 7.99 percent for an issue due in 2013, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Farmstead Telephone Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Triangle Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $12,725,000 and $14,249,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest third-quarter net exceeded by preferred dividend requirements. As previously reported, CJI Industries completed the acquisition of Triangle Industries and adopted Triangle's name in July. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of the Old Triangle, now called Trian Holdings, since March 1, when CJI acquired a 31.6 percent stake in Triangle, as well as CJI operations from Jan. 1.

title: Rockwood Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: National Datacomputer reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Central Jersey Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
It's Unanimous: Canseco M.V.P.
description: Continuing the youthful trend of recent seasons, Jose Canseco of Oakland, as expected, was named the American League's most valuable player yesterday. The 24-year-old right fielder, with an outstanding performance in only his third full season in the major leagues, was the first unanimous American League winner since another Athletics right fielder, Reggie Jackson, received all the votes in 1973.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Harper & Row and Viking Make Major Appointments
description: Harper & Row and Viking Penguin announced major personnel changes yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Rally Backs P.L.O.
description: With chanting, flag-waving and emotional speeches, about 900 Palestinians and their supporters from the New York area rallied in downtown Brooklyn yesterday in celebration of the Palestine Liberation Organization's declaration of an independent state.

title: PC Quote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Loan Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' results are not comparable. The bank, which is in liquidation, was created in May 1987 as part of Chemical New York Corp.'s acquisition of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc.

title: Protein Databases reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Albert Sileo, 67, Dies; A Retired Fire Chief
description: Albert J. Sileo, a retired New York City fire chief, died of heart failure Friday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 67 years old and lived in Seaford, L.I.

title: Looking for an Artist? Catalogues Can Help
description: EVEN with the growing interest in crafts, a good artist can be hard to find. A few sources, however, list craft artists, describe their work and provide information on how to contact them.

title: EnergyNorth Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $293,000 from an accounting change. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: Benafuels Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Trade Gap Shrank in September
description: The United States trade deficit shrank to $10.5 billion in September, a double-barreled $1.8 billion improvement that reflected both higher exports and lower imports.

title: Addington Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Out of the Melting Pot, a Vast Diversity of Crafts
description: SMALL wonder that people today are confused about what constitutes a craft. The term applies as readily to garden sculpture as it does to handmade books and stenciled kimonos. But while crafts-hopping through galleries, shops, museums and art centers in almost any large city in the United States, one fact remains constant: the field is greatly diverse.

title: Co-Operative Bank of Conord reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Teleprobe Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago revenue includes revenue related to the termination of the company's 1984 agreement with AT&T.

title: Banner Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $239,000 from discontinued operations and businesses held for sale and a loss of $8,070,000 from the writeoff of financing costs. c-Includes a gain of $544,000 from discontinued operations. Latest period also includes a pretax gain of $96,693,000 from the sale by a unit of 60 percent of its stock.

title: American Vanguard reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid on Nov. 1.

title: Flock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $27,981 for the quarter and $193,333 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $69,679 and $255,687 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Estonia Asserts A Right of Veto On Soviet Laws
description: The restive Soviet republic of Estonia today asserted the right to reject Soviet laws that appear to infringe on local autonomy, ignoring an appeal from a senior member of the Soviet Politburo to avoid a confrontation with Moscow.

title: Designhouse International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pro-Med Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cambridge Analytical Assocites Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $13,500 and $60,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Article 642488 -- No Title
description: The Mappa Mundi, one of the most important historical maps, will be sold to save Hereford Cathedral from bankruptcy, a spokesman said today. The 13th-century document, valued at more than $4.5 million, will be sold at auction in June, said a spokesman for the cathedral, who asked not to be named.

title: Panel Study Faults Shelters On Long Stays
description: Homeless families entering the city's shelter system are often kept in squalid barracks-style shelters far longer than state regulations allow, a report by a nonprofit advocacy group says.

title: Evert Wins After Slow Start
description: Chris Evert was justifiably anxious about her opening-round match in the Virginia Slims Championships at Madison Square Garden. Lately, this tournament had been unkind to her, and she came into her match against Barbara Potter last night inspired by the dismay first-round losses here in 1985 and 1987 had caused her.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Cardinal Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The per share earnings for the prior year is unavailable because the bank converted to stock ownership in March 1987.

title: Scott Paper Plans
description: Citing continued strength in demand for high-quality paper for magazines and catalogues, the Scott Paper Company said it would invest $475 million to expand the coated paper business of its S. D. Warren subsidiary. The program includes a third lightweight coated paper machine at its Somerset paper mill in Skowhegan, Me., and the rebuilding of its largest coated paper machine at its Muskegon, Mich., mill. The investment will increase Scott's 1989 capital spending program by $150 million over 1988's expenditures of $450 million to $500 million.

title: Consolidated Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Toys 'R' Us Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $2,025,000 on the sale of department store divisions.

title: Article 747988 -- No Title
description: In the ?inal two months of the campaign, some of the nation's wealthiest people wrote $100,000 checks to the Republican Party, according to a list of contributors made public today.

title: Canada's Biggest Paper Crusading To Defeat Trade Treaty With U.S.
description: When negotiations for the Canadian-American free trade agreement were nearing conclusion in Washington last year, Canada's chief negotiator astonished reporters on a Washington street with a sudden tirade directed at a correspondent for The Toronto Star.

title: Conservatives Looking to Quayle As Their Top Ally in White House
description: The right wing of the Republican Party, recognizing that the top jobs in the next administration will go to moderate allies of Vice President Bush, is courting Senator Dan Quayle in its efforts to get adherents of the New Right into important Government positions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing

title: A Bistro With Humor, From Glaser
description: PERHAPS only Milton Glaser could dream up a restaurant that draws artistic inspiration from Italian art academies, Il Campidoglio in Rome and the noses of approximately 32 famous Italians. This latest creation is Trattoria Dell'Arte, across Seventh Avenue from Carnegie Hall and easily identifiable by the looming sculptured nose visible in the second-floor window.

title: What Namibia Will Need If Independence Comes; The Cubans and Angola
description: To the Editor:

title: PROVIDING A GOOD ATMOSPHERE
description: THERE are times when the standard advice issued to parents about homework - find a quiet, well-lighted place for your child to study, and establish a time to start the work - simply isn't enough. What do you do if your child still rushes through, avoids, forgets or refuses to do homework?

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about Lincoln Center's intention to perform all of Mozart's works in 1991 and 1992 characterized the Metropolitan Opera's own Mozart bicentennial plans incorrectly. The company's repertory was determined before the Lincoln Center celebration was conceived.

title: Holiday Windows: Craft and Fantasy
description: THREE Fifth Avenue department stores are unveiling their annual gifts to the street: windows in which mechanical figures dance, bow, wave and curtsy. But few of the fascinated passers-by will realize how much planning, improvising and last-minute frenzy went into assembling these enchanting miniature worlds.

title: A Birthday for the Phone That Changed How We Dial
description: TOMORROW, America celebrates the 25th anniversary of a ubiquitous icon, the Touch-Tone telephone. Introduced to the nation on Nov. 18, 1963, the Touch-Tone was perfect for a country obsessed with push-buttons (though the push-button washing machine and push-button automatic transmission have gone the way of Fizzies).

title: GTE Affirms Plan to Move Unit to Texas
description: The GTE Corporation today confirmed reports that it had selected a site in Irving, Tex., near Dallas, for the headquarters of the streamlined management operations of its seven regional telephone companies.

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are in preferred shares with 14,998,210 shares outstanding. The common share earnings of 100,000 shares outstanding were $96.90 and $274.08 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, compared with year-ago periods of $85.25 a share for the quarter and $213.74 a share for the 9 months.

title: First Federal Bancorp (Pontic, Mich) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings is based on earnings from conversion date of Sept. 24, 1987. On a pro forma basis, as if net stock conversion proceeds had been received and invested at the beginning of the fiscal year at a reasonable after-tax rate of return, year-ago per share figure would have been 26 cents.

title: Baker Hughes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $20,141,000 and $43,856,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Pacad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: Keystone Camera Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,034,000 for the quarter and $1,925,000 for the 9 months.

title: Judge Finds Navistar Liable In Pension Obligations Case
description: Ruling in favor of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Federal district judge today found that the Navistar International Transportation Corporation had sold its Wisconsin Steel division in 1977 to rid itself of the troubled unit's pension liabilities.

title: IRT Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. and Bush Team Reject P.L.O. Move
description: The State Department and the transition team of President-elect Bush said today that a Palestine Liberation Organization statement implicitly recognizing Israel does not meet United States requirements to open a direct dialogue with the organization.

title: Bangladeshi - and Proud
description: It is not easy being a Bangladeshi these days. While our country is going under - literally and figuratively - the international community has responded with generous aid as well as a strong dose of cynicism and sarcasm. Ever since Henry Kissinger dehumanized Bangladesh by labeling it ''an international basket case,'' Bangladesh has been the butt of many cruel jokes.

title: Steinberg Contended That Lisa Was Given Poison, Papers Show
description: Joel B. Steinberg has contended that Lisa Steinberg was given a fatal dose of poison sometime before she died last year, court papers in his murder trial showed yesterday.

title: Canada's Historic Decision: Mulroney Pulls No Punches
description: Day after day the cities, the weather, even the language changes but the scene doesn't. Hundreds of Conservative Party regulars pack into a gym. The hard, driving beat of a rock song assaults all ears. Suddenly, a spotlight flashes to the door. Enter the jut-jawed politician with his beautiful, smiling wife. Thunderous cheers and chants.

title: Religious Views Cited In Monitor Resignations
description: Through the years, many newspaper editors have resigned over what they saw as threats to their journalistic integrity. But seldom does the decision to break from a newspaper have as much to do with religious conviction as with concern for journalistic standards.

title: Ohio State Asked To Extend Grants
description: A group charging racism in the Ohio State Athletic Department today urged the school to extend scholarship programs for black players lacking the credits to graduate.

title: Aide to Koch Testifies About Hiring of Gabel
description: A special assistant to Mayor Koch, Joseph DeVincenzo, testified yesterday that he routinely approved the hiring of Sukhreet Gabel for a job in New York City's Cultural Affairs Department.

title: MMR Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oman Suffers Polio Outbreak
description: An outbreak of polio among children living in coastal villages has set off a nationwide health alert, doctors said today. More than 80 cases of the crippling disease have been reported on the Batinah coast west of Muscat, the capital, and the number is rising. Health workers were ordered to vaccinate all children under the age of 5 in the area. ''Around 85 percent of infants under 1 have been vaccinated against polio,'' said Dr. Jacob Matthai, the Muscat representative for the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund. The cause of the outbreak was not known.

title: Consolidated Hydro Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; From Brazil, A Voice Of Colors
description: North American pop singers tend to draw firm lines between rock and pop and folk, and between lighthearted entertainment and serious messages. In Brazil, those lines aren't so impassable. On Monday at Avery Fisher Hall, Gal Costa, one of Brazil's most popular singers, gave voice to Brazilian music from delicate bossa nova to aggressive rock, from love songs to political intimations. She was by turns a sassy cabaret singer, an intimate ballad singer and a buoyant pop-rock belter whose grin lit up the stage. Her Brazilian audience is dedicated; for one of her hits at Fisher Hall, listeners sang the verses behind her wordless descant.

title: Public Workers' Strikes Jolt French Prime Minister
description: An explosion of public-sector strikes has thrown Prime Minister Michel Rocard's five-month-old Socialist minority Government off balance just as it prepares to push its first budget through a recalcitrant Parliament.

title: Mobil Will Do Oil Changes
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has entered the fast-service automobile oil change market with six Lube Express units in Dallas.

title: Thetford Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,000 and $71,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Jewish Aide Quits Over Jenninger's Speech
description: A Jewish official who defended last week's Kristallnacht speech by the Speaker of Parliament quit today after being strongly criticized by other Jews, officials said.

title: Houston Tower Is Sold
description: Heritage Plaza, the downtown area's newest and emptiest skyscraper, has been sold for $110 million to a Houston-based partnership whose leading investor is the Michigan Employees Retirement System. The 53-story tower was sold on Tuesday by 261 Associates Ltd. to the Coventry Fund III. Heritage Plaza was completed in 1986 but has yet to attract a large tenant. Only 8 percent of the 1.2-million-square-foot plaza is occupied.

The year-ago third-quarter results the loss from discontinued operations totalled $5,273,000, or $1.05 a share and include the results of the discontinued operations of the company's SWS Industries Inc. subsidiary as well as the Energy Group. The company has adopted statement of Financial Accounting Standards Number 96 on a retroactive basis. Accordingly no imputed tax benefit was provided for on the respective income and loss for the quarter and 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1988. The quarter and 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1987, were retroactively restated to eliminate imputed federal income tax provision previously recognized of $2,541,000 and $593,000, respectively. The 1987 results have also been restated to reflect the operations of the Energy Group as discontinued operations.

title: Why They Are Called 'Junk Bonds'
description: Behind the negative connotations of the nickname, ''junk bonds'' have a simple definition: They are bonds issued by companies whose credit ratings are below investment grade. According to rating agencies, investment-grade bonds are those issued by companies that have the ability to pay interest and principal through good times and bad. Issues below investment grade carry a significant risk that payments will not be made.

title: An Offer for Jackson
description: After meeting with Al Bianchi for about two hours yesterday, Don Cronson, the agent for Mark Jackson, left Madison Square Garden with an offer to extend the Knicks' second-year playmakers' contract. Neither Bianchi, the Knick general manager, nor Cronson would divulge the contents of the offer. Jackson, who will earn a reported $250,000 this season, could become a free agent 24 hours after the playoffs end next June. ''We made him a nice offer, '' said Bianchi, who said that he expected to hear from Cronson after the agent spoke to Jackson, last season's National Basketball Association rookie of the year. On the plane trip home yesterday after the Knicks' victory in Houston, Jackson, aware that the meeting was taking place, said, ''If I like it, I'll sign it.'' If Jackson rejects the offer, he could test the free-agent market. But if he does, the Knicks would still retain the right of first refusal to any offer he might get. There have been reports that Jackson was seeking a two-or three-year contract for about $1 million a year.

title: The Danger of Rigidity
description: Imagine a huge urban housing development where blacks and whites live happily together, where crime is low and children in the public schools perform superbly. That sounds like a dream in an America whose cities are too often marked by ghettos and savaged by crime. But in at least one place it is reality.

description: Transportation Secretary Burnley's program for drug testing of transport workers generated furious responses from airline pilots and truck drivers. From the public, it deserves support.

description: Eastern Airlines, said it was seeking a relaxation of financial performance requirements attached to $300 million in debt. The airline, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it could be declared in default if its banks do not grant the request.

title: Joseph Elgin, 84, Educator, Dies
description: Dr. Joseph C. Elgin, dean of the Princeton School of Engineering and Applied Science from 1954 to 1971, died Tuesday at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) Nursing Home after suffering a stroke. He was 84 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: The Wrong Way to Raise Taxes
description: Even as politicians and economists debate whether the country needs a tax increase, there is tax relief in sight for almost everyone next year. It's fair. It's substantial. And if anyone is thinking of tampering with it, he should think again.

title: Perjury Charged in Gotti Trial
description: A key defense witness at the racketeering trial that ended in the acquittal of John Gotti was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for committing perjury when he testified.

title: Payton Unhurt In Car Accident
description: Walter Payton, the former Chicago Bears running back, was involved in a minor car accident Tuesday night, but he was not seriously hurt, the police said.

Some can lighten wood's natural color, and some are capable of lifting stain that has been used to change the color of the wood.

title: DRUG USE BY ATHLETES RUNS FREE DESPITE TESTS

These experts also contend that the drug-testing programs of the International Olympic Committee and other sports associations have had no impact in reducing the use of such drugs, including anabolic steroids.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; A Little Piece of Joe Hill
description: The 73d anniversary of the execution of Joe Hill, one of America's most incandescent labor leaders, falls on Saturday, and tomorrow the National Archives will make a kind of restitution to his trade union heirs. It is turning over a sealed vial believed to contain some of Hill's ashes to his organization, the Industrial Workers of the World.

title: Surgery for Teufel
description: Tim Teufel, the Mets' second baseman, will undergo surgery tomorrow to have bone spurs removed from the back of his left hand. Dr. Richard Eaton, the Mets' hand specialist, will perform the operation at Roosevelt Hospital, and Teufel's hand is expected to be in a cast for two weeks. Teufel hurt the hand checking a swing in a game against San Diego May 16 and missed 23 games.

title: McGovern Compares Notes With Dukakis
description: George McGovern, who went down to resounding defeat in the 1972 Presidential campaign, said Tuesday that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis realizes he should have done something to thwart Vice President Bush's attacks on his liberalism, charges that ''did stick.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.We have a full basement and I am planning to make it into a large family room. I would also like to install a bathroom there, but the sewers are higher than the floor - almost overhead. I have heard of jet-pump sinks, but they seem a bit noisy for a living area. Can I get toilets and sinks that flush or drain to an overhead sewer line? A.There are special toilets you can buy that have pumps built into the base so that they will discharge to raised sewer lines. Sinks with similar pumps are also available, or you can have a separate sump installed into which the sink will drain normally. A special pump in this sump will then empty the contents periodically by pumping the waste water up into the sewer line.

The theater company presents plays in English and in Spanish at its permanent theater at 304 West 47th Street; it also tours the five boroughs of New York City every summer with a full production, trains young people in several disciplines of the performing arts, and helps budding playwrights.

title: T2 Medical Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
More Suspensions
description: A stunned Coach Gene Ubriaco will miss the Pittsburgh Penguins' next five games. One of his players, Troy Loney, a forward, is gone for 10. The National Hockey League suspended them Tuesday because of a fight at Vancouver last weekend. ''I have never been suspended before,'' Ubriaco said. ''I'm flabbergasted. I'm stupified.'' During the first period of the Penguins' game at Vancouver last Sunday, Mario Lemieux kicked the feet out from under the Canucks' Brian Bradley during a Vancouver power play. Lemieux was not penalized by Referee Dave Newell. The Canucks' Garth Butcher approached Lemieux and the two exchanged words. Loney, whom Ubriaco said was coming off the bench for a line switch, then fought with Butcher. Under N.H.L. Rule 66, the first player to leave his bench and become involved in fighting is suspended automatically for 10 games, and his coach for 5. Ubriaco also said the Penguins were fined $10,000.(AP)

Reviews/Television; CBS Replays the Weekend of Nov. 22
description: At 1:40 P.M. Eastern standard time on Nov. 22, 1963, the CBS soap opera ''As the World Turns'' was interrupted by a bulletin read by Walter Cronkite: Shots had been fired at President John F. Kennedy in Dallas. Thus began 53 hours of reporting by CBS (and similar exertions by the other networks) from the assassination of the President to his imposing state funeral.

title: Carey Again Sees Need for Change At City Hall
description: The last time Hugh L. Carey, the former Governor, engineered a challenge to an incumbent New York City mayor, his candidate lost. But so did the incumbent mayor. In the 1977 Democratic primary, as the city struggled to emerge from its fiscal crisis, both Mr. Carey's choice, Mario M. Cuomo, and the incumbent, Abraham D. Beame, were defeated by another challenger. Less than a year before - just about where we are today in the fledgling 1989 campaign, in fact - that challenger had been largely written off. His name was Edward I. Koch.

The theme of the meeting, sponsored by the National Gay & Lesbian Task Force, is ''Creating Change.'' Among the topics are city and state laws on homosexual rights; lobbying; AIDS legislation, and working with law-enforcement agencies to combat violence against gays.

description: An investigation has found that more than $500,000 worth of unauthorized international calls were billed to New York City's welfare agency last year, and Mayor Koch yesterday ordered city officials to monitor the telephone systems of all municipal agencies.

With this transaction, Enron has committed to sell about $250 million worth of its oil and gas properties. Enron, one of the nation's largest natural gas producers, has said it hopes to sell a total of $300 million of its nonstrategic properties and to use the proceeds to retire corporate debt.

Shares of companies involved in buyouts such as RJR Nabisco, Pillsbury and Interco dropped as nervous arbitragers sold some of their holdings of these issues. title: Belgium Lowers Rates
description: The Belgian central bank announced today that it was cutting its discount and Lombard rates, effective Thursday. The discount rate was being lowered by a quarter of a percentage point, to 7 1/4 percent, and the Lombard by the same margin, to 7 1/2 percent. The discount rate is used by banks for discount commercial paper at the central bank. The Lombard rate is the amount charged on advances to banks where securities are used as collateral.

title: Par Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Life in the 30's
description: I HAD forgotten how much I loved ''The Patty Duke Show'' until I tuned in by mistake on cable the other night. It ruled my life when I was a preteen-ager obsessed with finding plastic rollers exactly the right size to produce a flip on my shoulders. (Never mind that it felt as if you were sleeping with porcupines tucked between your head and your neck.) Remember the theme song? ''Meet Cathy who's lived most everywhere/ From Zanzibar to Berkeley Square./But Patty's only seen the sights a girl can see from Brooklyn Heights./What a crazy pair.'' Identical twin cousins, one studious and reasonable and with a kind of muted rich-girl English accent; the other popular and a little scatterbrained, with hair perfectly flipped. Both played, of course, by Patty Duke, who by her own admission was depressed, exploited and secretly boozing while simultaneously portraying America's average fantasy teen-ager and America's average parental fantasy of what a teen-ager should be. The first time I hit the streets of Brooklyn Heights, before I knew much about New York, all I could think was, ''This was where Patty lived.'' I've never been to Zanzibar or Berkeley Square.

title: Forstmann Declines to Bid on RJR Nabisco
description: The field of bidders for RJR Nabisco Inc. narrowed yesterday when an investment group led by Forstmann Little & Company declined to enter the corporate world's largest-ever auction.

title: Review/Music; The Guarneri in a Janacek Quartet
description: The Guarneri String Quartet offered what promised to be a lovely program at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening - the Barber Quartet, Janacek's ''Intimate Letters'' and Schubert's ''Death and the Maiden.'' All three works brim over with gorgeous, long-lined melodies and deep-running passions that can be truly searing if given a proper breath of life.

title: Japan's Lower House Approves Big Tax Overhaul
description: In a political victory for Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, the legislature's lower house approved a sweeping tax overhaul this afternoon after a marathon overnight negotiating session.

title: Peete Questionable
description: Rodney Peete has the measles and may not play in Southern Cal's showdown with U.C.L.A. on Saturday for the Pacific-10 Conference title and Rose Bowl berth. ''I'm not sure on Rodney's availability for the U.C.L.A. game,'' the Trojans' coach, Larry Smith, said yesterday regarding the condition of the U.S.C. quarterback. ''We'll go ahead with the basic game plan that we've prepared. This is something that we have to be good enough as a team to overcome. We're a team first, although Rodney is a very valuable component of our team. If it means we have to play Rodney's backup, Pat O'Hara, we have a lot of confidence in him.'' Peete, a senior who ranks among the nation's passing leaders this season, first felt ill last week. He still had one of his finest games in last Saturday's 50-0 rout of Arizona State, but has been unable to practice this week. He had been suffering from flu-like symptoms, but his illness was diagnosed as measles yesterday. Peete has guided the Trojans to a 9-0 record.(AP)

title: Dr. Dong Sun Chu, 63, Rehabilitation Expert
description: Dr. Dong Sun Chu, a specialist in rehabilitation medicine for 23 years at the New York University Medical Center, died Tuesday at White Plains Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemmorhage on Nov. 9 at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 63 years old.

title: Brazil Opposition Parties Win Important Cities in Elections
description: In a major setback for Brazil's governing party, leftist parties appear to have won control of many of the country's most important cities in municipal elections that were widely interpreted as a dry run for the Presidential elections next year.

title: Wagner to Explore Drug Testing for School Employees
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr., the president of the New York City Board of Education, said yesterday that the board would soon consider requiring drug testing for any teacher, principal or other school employee who aroused the suspicion of a supervisor.

title: Tacoma Journal; School for Homeless Children: A Rare Experience
description: At night, the Ketner children huddle next to their parents in a shelter for the homeless, wondering what their next move is going to be. But when morning light breaks through the mist of this Puget Sound port city, there is a school bus waiting outside, a ticket to another life.

title: New York's Ferry Revival
description: New figures show that traffic on bridges and tunnels connecting New York City and New Jersey declined last year by 1,600 eastbound vehicles a day - the first such drop since 1974. The dip, transportation officials say, may owe in part to the region's new waterborne transit system. Creatively nurtured, the expanding network of private ferries could provide more relief for rush-hour traffic.

title: Pretoria Treason Trial: Family's Tribulation
description: ''It is not the waiting itself which is unbearable but not knowing when the waiting will end,'' Martha Chikane said this morning as she prepared for the eight-mile journey to her husband's trial.

title: Expanding Role of 'Junk Bonds'
description: Pessimists call them ''speculative grade'' bonds. Optimists prefer the term ''high yield'' bonds. But everyone knows them as ''junk'' - risky bonds that pay high rates of interest - a fast-growing segment of the bond market that has played a critical role in the wave of corporate takeovers and reorganizations of the last few years.

title: Gorbachev Policy Has Ended The Cold War, Thatcher Says
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, have ended the Cold War.

title: Murdoch Bids For Collins
description: Rupert Murdoch, who already controls a variety of media holdings, began a $535 million takeover bid today for the British publishing concern William Collins P.L.C., of which he already owns 41.7 percent. The company reacted bitterly to the offer.

title: Sports People; Ramsay Resigns
description: Jack Ramsay has coached in a record 1,647 National Basketball Association games. His teams at Philadelphia, Buffalo, Portland and Indiana have won 864 games, second in league history to Red Auerbach's 938. But this season, his 21st as an N.B.A. coach, Ramsay's Indiana Pacers have lost all seven of their games. Yesterday, Ramsay resigned. ''I didn't like the direction the team was taking and it wasn't enjoyable any more,'' said Ramsay, whose major loss this season might have been Steve Stipanovich, the 7-foot starting center who is on the injured list with a knee problem. ''I didn't see the immediate prospects of knowing when we were going to get our full roster and this was not something I wanted to go through for 82 games.''

description: RJR Nabisco's stock price gyrated yesterday as rumors filled a void of hard information on prospects for the auction of the huge food and tobacco company.
