title: Presidential Debates: Early and Often
description: The televised debates between Vice President George Bush and Gov. Michael Dukakis left much to be desired. There weren't enough of them; they started too late in the campaign, and the rigid format inhibited spontaneity and shortchanged ideas. But still they were useful, and could have been more so. The task now is to retool for 1992.

title: Blessings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
description: The latest third quarter results include a loss of $375,600 from a writedown of the company's remaining investment in Texas American Bancshares Inc. b-Includes a loss of $1,411,700 from the writedown in the third quarter.

title: Pretoria Finds 4 Blacks Guilty In Treason Case
description: Four black leaders of South Africa's anti-apartheid movement were convicted today on treason charges after a judge here accepted the Government's argument that speeches and demonstrations could involve treasonable activity.

title: Murdoch and Disney Reported Near Accord
description: Sky Television, a satellite television programming service being set up by Rupert Murdoch, will soon announce plans to buy large amounts of programming produced by the Walt Disney Company, people close to the situation said today.

title: 3d B-1 in 14 Months Crashes; Crew Safe
description: A B-1 bomber coming in for a landing in bad weather crashed late Thursday night at Ellsworth Air Force Base in South Dakota and Air Force officials said it was probably a result of pilot error.

title: Ojeda Takes First Step on Road Back
description: In a batting cage beneath Shea Stadium yesterday, Bob Ojeda played catch with his brother-in-law and began the long recuperative process that the Mets hope will return him to the starting rotation in 1989.

title: Ventura in Bid For De Laurentiis
description: A new television production company, Ventura Entertainment Group, entered the bidding for De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc., a movie maker operating under the protection of the Federal bankruptcy court. Ventura Entertainment announced it had offered $35 million in cash and equity for De Laurentiis, which was founded by the Italian film maker Dino De Laurentiis.

title: Mor-Flo Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months included a net charge of $1,815,000 related to a patent infringement lawsuit. The year-ago 9 months included a $1.7 million gain from a change in accounting for taxes.

title: MacNeal-Schwendler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Canadian Identity Is Embedded in the Trade Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After a gain of $176,000 from an accounting change.

title: Sailor Honored
description: Larry Lemieux stood on a platform with a gleaming silver medallion draped around his neck, listening to the Canadian national anthem. The scene was one the native of Edmonton, Alberta, had hoped would be part of the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. But this ceremony was Thursday night in Spokane, Wash., where he was honored for rescuing a competitor in an Olympic sailing race. ''You spend your whole lifetime trying to achieve a goal, and my goal was winning a gold medal,'' said Lemieux, who is 33 years old. ''I didn't win a gold medal, but I've certainly gotten a lot of attention for what I did.'' Lemieux veered his one-man craft off course in midrace to rescue a South Korean sailor whose boat had capsized in rough seas. Lemieux finished 21st in the Finn Class.(AP)

title: Canandaigua Wine To Cut 20% of Jobs
description: The Canandaigua Wine Company will lay off 20 percent of its work force and close a bottling operation in Virginia in an effort to end two years of falling sales and profits. The company currently employs about 650 workers at three wineries in New York, three in California, one in Patrick, S.C., and the Petersburg, Va., operation, which will be closed by January, a company spokesman, Staford Krause, said. About 40 workers will lose their jobs when the bottling operation, Richards Wine Cellars, closes, and the remaining 90 employees scheduled to be laid off have been notified of the cutbacks.

title: Federal Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Skier Gives Up Medal
description: As a result of the recent publication of the autobiography of the winner of the women's world downhill ski championship of 1966, the runner-up in the event recently received the gold medal because the winner was a man. Erika Schinegger of Austria, who won the gold at Portillo, Chile, discovered in medical tests for the 1968 Winter Olympics that she was a man, according to Schinegger's autobiography, ''Victory Over Myself.'' Schinegger, 40 years old, is now known as Erik, is married and the father of a young daughter. Last Monday, he gave his gold medal to Marielle Goitschel of France, the runner-up, whom he called the true winner. .(AP)

title: Former Official Sentenced
description: Roger Boas, the city's former chief administrative officer, was fined $100,00 today and ordered to serve on a six-month work detail for having sexual relations with teen-age prostitutes. As a member of a work detail, the 67-year-old Mr. Boas will spend no time in jail but will be performing jobs such as picking up trash along freeways.

title: MLX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Sales represent total net sales. MLX said for the latest periods it benefited from tax loss carryforwards of $2,020,000 for the quarter and $2,310,000 for the 9 months, compared with $723,000 and $1,093,000 for the same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Burger King Franchisees Reject Spinoff
description: A group representing the franchisees of the Burger King Corporation today formally rejected the Pillsbury Company's plan to spin off the fast-food restaurant unit.

title: Yugoslav Groups Hold Rival Demonstrations
description: About 100,000 ethnic Albanians marched through the capital of Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province today in an anti-Serbian protest while Serbs decorated Belgrade with flags on the eve of a major anti-Albanian rally.

title: Richer Gets 10-Game Ban
description: Although no penalty was called on him by the game officials, Stephane Richer of the Montreal Canadiens received a 10-game suspension without pay from the National Hockey League yesterday for deliberately swinging his stick and injuring Jeff Norton, an Islander defenseman.

title: About New York; Defining Today By Looking Back And Far Ahead
description: New York is the Main Chance, the Big Deal and, always, the Fast Shuffle - the place where the promise and peril of the present is starkest. Not for nothing does the Mayor say you have to walk a little faster, talk a little faster and think a whole lot faster here.

title: Dollar Up As Support Continues
description: The dollar rose yesterday as the United States and its allies bought dollars for the second day in the foreign exchange market. But after reaching highs for the day early, the dollar drifted down slightly.

title: M/A-Com Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses of $6,235,000 for the quarter and $6,060,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: Eastern Joining in Fare Increases
description: Another major carrier, Eastern Airlines, joined others yesterday in increasing the lowest and most widely used discount fares on most of its routes.

title: With HDTV, America Can Reclaim Its Lead in Electronics; Home-Grown Tech
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Are Guilty Of Corruption In Construction
description: Ten men, including several union officers, were convicted in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last night in a case involving corruption in the billion-dollar construction industry in New York City. Four other defendants were acquitted.

title: Angola and Cuba Give Backing to Peace Plan
description: Angola and Cuba today approved a regional peace plan for southwestern Africa that provides for the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola and independence for South African-administered Namibia.

title: Does the Navy's Magic Shield Work?
description: Long before Ronald Reagan proposed putting an astrodome defense shield over America, the Navy had the same dream for protecting surface ships from enemy missiles. Its answer was the Aegis air defense system. But Aegis may be a terribly costly blunder. The first time it was fired in anger, in March 1986, the U.S.S. Yorktown shot down a low-flying cloud, believing it was a Libyan missile boat. The second time, this July, the U.S.S. Vincennes destroyed a civilian airliner.

title: Busy Day for Special Computer and Staff
description: The first sign of a breakdown in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's telecommunications system came on one of the eight black silhouettes of the United States on the wall panel in front of Cheryl Nelson.

title: Tyson Foods Ends Holly Bid
description: Tyson Foods Inc. let its $52-a-share hostile tender offer for the Holly Farms Corporation expire today without taking further action, apparently signaling its withdrawal from a takeover battle for the Memphis concern, a rival poultry producer.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 32.

title: Ackerley Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vicon Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Fiscal 1987 loss included an after- tax charge of $577,000 for takeover defense costs.

title: F. Woodbridge Constant, Professor, 84
description: F. Woodbridge Constant, former chairman of the physics department at Trinity College in Hartford died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Reducing Welfare Rolls and Adding Self-Esteem in Oklahoma
description: Her forehead furrowed in concentration, Ramona Robinson grasped an electric circular saw and carefully cut new back steps for a rundown house here. Nearby, a co-worker, Carla Scoggins, nailed on new wooden siding.

title: The Gizmo-Finding Gizmo
description: Next week Bloomingdale's, ever the pioneer in retail razzle-dazzle, introduces a new wrinkle: a computerized catalogue to assist shoppers in its busy housewares department. Can't find a sales clerk? Need to know something specific about an electronic gadget? Check out the new catalogue, the Safire Shopper, created by a group of Brown University graduates.

title: JB's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Net loss Year-ago quarter and year includes pretax charges of $1,101,000 and $1,627,000, respectively. Latest year includes pretax charges of $2,537,000.

title: A Dropout Who Drops In
description: When Matt (Andrew McCarthy), a clean-cut college senior, first sets eyes on Jewel (Molly Ringwald), it is infatuation at first sight. She's in the kitchen of a Kentucky farmhouse where assorted low-lifes and students come together to drink beer, dance and play pool.

title: Angry American Jews Press Shamir on 'Who Is a Jew' Law
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met with angry American Jews today as the debate over whether to change the definition of who is Jewish began growing into an issue strong enough to influence the makeup of Israel's next government.

title: Gap in Bridge Barriers Allowed Car to Go Off
description: A car carrying four youths from East Lyme, Conn., drove off the closed Chapel Street bridge here into the Mill River because one of three concrete barriers blocking the end of the bridge had been moved, city officials said today.

title: Justice Dept. Objecting To Iran-Contra Charge
description: The Justice Department presented legal arguments today that, if accepted by a Federal judge here, could undercut the central conspiracy charge in the indictment of Oliver L. North and other defendants in the Iran-contra case.

title: No Boards to Tread
description: To the Editor:

title: Friedman Gets 7 More Years In Bribery Case
description: Stanley Friedman, once one of the most powerful politicians in New York City, was sentenced yesterday to up to seven years in state prison for his bribery convictions in New York City's political corruption scandals. He is already serving a 12-year term in a Federal prison.

title: Northeast Air Traffic Review Ordered
description: Saying he was ''deeply disturbed'' by the mistakes made in handling the jetliner carrying President Reagan on a flight to Newark last month, Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley has ordered the Federal Aviation Administration to conduct an intensive review of its traffic control system in the Northeast.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'These Kids Aren't Going to Be Addicts'
description: If you walk along New York's Lower West Side you can see them: kids, most of them boys, waiting for somebody who wants to buy sex to drive up in the family sedan. They're out there even if it's raining so hard the streets are streaming or so cold somebody's built a bonfire in a trash can, and when they go home it's to a warehouse or a lean-to under a pier. For them, says Dr. James T. Kennedy, the medical director of Covenant House, AIDS ''is just one more piece of bad news.''

title: Corrections
description: The News Summary in some copies yesterday erroneously listed an article about bleak job prospects for people lacking a college education. In fact the article appears today, on page 8.

title: MANY IN U.S. FACE BLEAK JOB OUTLOOK
description: Young people who do not attend college have a high chance of facing unemployment or jobs with poverty-level income and little hope for advancement, said a report released Thursday.

title: BIAGGI SENTENCED TO AN 8-YEAR TERM IN WEDTECH CASE
description: Mario Biaggi, the former Bronx Congressman and dean of New York City's delegation in the House, was sentenced to eight years in prison yesterday for his role in the Wedtech racketeering scandal.

title: Henry Ciccarone, Lacrosse Coach, 50
description: Henry Ciccarone, who coached the Johns Hopkins University lacrosse team to three consecutive national championships from 1978 through 1980, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at his home in Cockeysville, Md. He was 50 years old.

title: MCI Seeks Share Of Pay-Phone Calls
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it was beginning a marketing drive to claim a piece of the $2 billion-a-year market in long-distance calls from pay telephones. It is seeking to capitalize on a recent Federal court ruling that ordered the local Bell operating companies to stop discriminating in favor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and to allow owners of public pay phones to choose a long-distance carrier.

title: Officer Hurt and Gunman Dies in Bronx Shootout
description: A 33-year-old police officer was shot and seriously wounded Thursday night in a Bronx apartment where two robbers in search of drugs were holding a man and two women hostage, the police said yesterday.

title: Bridge; Six winners in world championship to compete for American titles in Nashville.
description: About 3,000 bridge players have poured into the home of country music in the last 24 hours to take part in the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. Seven major championships and a score of minor ones will be decided in the next 10 days.

title: U.S. Plan in Coffee Dispute
description: The United States, the world's biggest coffee consumer, said today that it had suggested ways to end cut-price coffee sales to Arab and Eastern European countries.

title: Florida Steel Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reduced by $4,208,000 and $4,442,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, due to acquisition-related expenses. The latest periods' net includes a $2,100,000 loss due to the shutdown expense and abandonment of a Jackson, Tenn., mill. The company had no latested quarter and year share earnings because it was taken private in July. For Financial reporting purposes, the tender offer and merger have been treated as if they occured Sept. 1, 1988.

title: INSIDE
description: Rocky Road for 2 Products

title: Temtex Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $261,000. c-After tax credits of $407,000 and $424,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: 'Smokeless' Cigarette's Hapless Start
description: The new ''smokeless'' cigarette developed by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company is proving highly unpopular with consumers in Arizona and Missouri, where it is being test-marketed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7, 28 Four anti-apartheid leaders were convicted on treason charges in South Africa after a judge accepted the state's argument that speeches and demonstrations could entail treasonable activity. Page 1 Yitzhak Shamir and American Jews met as the debate over whether to change the definition of who is Jewish began growing into an issue strong enough to influence the makeup of Israel's next government. 1 Moscow recognized the declaration of an independent Palestinian state, but it was unclear whether this amounted to recognition of the state itself. The statement did go further than previous Soviet endorsements. 4 Lithuania declined to declare its laws supreme over Soviet law, heeding the plea of its Communist Party leader to be patient but disappointing its neighbor, Estonia. 6 Canada's ruling party hopes to win a narrow majority in the approaching elections. But the Liberal Party continues to use doubts about a trade agreement with the United States as a political weapon. 3 The Soviets warned Afghan rebels that it would react severely against ''further military escalation,'' and that it had already taken ''measures to stop subversive and terroristic acts.'' 6 Mikhail Gorbachev arrived in India for a three-day official visit to reaffirm close relations between the two countries at a time when some Indians are questioning Moscow's intentions in the third world. 6 The former South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan was reported to be ready to apologize for abuses during his administration and return money he is said to have stolen from the Government. 28

title: Comings and Goings
description: The families of three teen-age boys killed in a traffic accident in which Reggie Rogers of the Detroit Lions was injured on Oct. 20 have sued the defensive lineman in Pontiac, Mich. Rogers, who suffered a broken neck, was arraigned on three counts of involuntary manslaughter and is free on $10,000 personal bond. A preliminary examination is scheduled for Dec. 1. . . . The Boston Red Sox have re-signed Dennis Lamp, a relief pitcher who had a 7-6 record with a 3.48 earned

title: LITHUANIA DELAYS SOVEREIGNTY VOTE
description: The legislature of the Baltic republic of Lithuania decided today not to declare its laws supreme over Soviet law, heeding an ardent plea by its Communist Party leader to pursue the goal of sovereignty with patience and careful planning.

title: Northern Ireland: Freedom vs. Law and Order
description: LEAD: Americans were grateful for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's strong and loyal support for President Reagan's forceful action to curb international terrorism. It is therefore depressingly ironic that her Government's latest steps to deal with the Libyan-backed Irish Repubican Army, the most murderous and well-armed terrorist organization in Western Europe, have been so little understood by the media in the United

title: Hach Company reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to stockholders of record on Sept. 13.

title: Reviews/Film; Doings at a Haunted House
description: The title of ''Twice Dead'' refers to suicides that begin and end the story, but it also astutely describes the two lethally boring plots that collide in this exploitation film. Mom, Dad and their teen-age son and daughter inherit a crumbling house, deserted except for a ghost who hanged himself there. The family arrives to find a street gang with heavily moussed hair blocking their doorway, as if the only thing worse than a haunted house is a haunted house in a really bad neighborhood.

title: Low-Power Test for Seabrook Is Backed by Regulatory Staff
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has sided with the owners of the embattled Seabrook nuclear plant in a crucial argument over whether the plant should be allowed to begin low-power test operations.

title: Novar Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $504,400 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Rockwood Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Chip Beck's Long Fairway
description: When Chip Beck began his 10th year on the pro golf tour last January, he hadn't won a single tournament, which was frustrating enough, but he had come in second seven times, more than any other nonwinner on the tour, and that was maddening.

title: Brooklyn Youth Is Slain by Police Officer
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager was shot to death by a policeman early yesterday when, the police said, the youth ''lunged'' at the officer, hitting his right arm and causing his gun to fire accidentally.

title: Disaster Agency: Mandate and Criticism
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency, which has periodically come under attack in its 11-year history from critics of its plans for evacuation in a nuclear catastrophe, has a broad mandate to coordinate the Federal response to a range of major disasters, from floods and fires to nuclear plant leaks.

title: 3 Athletes Suspended
description: Three of the American athletes who competed in a series of meets in South Africa, as well as the organizer of the tour, were suspended indefinitely yesterday from national and international competition by The Athletics Congress, the governing body for track and field in the United States. A three-member panel in Chicago imposed the suspensions on Tyrus Jefferson, a long jumper; Ray Wicksell, a distance runner; Tom Hintnaus, a pole-vaulter, and Dick Tomlinson, the tour organizer. Eleven other athletes who participated in the South African events and Ted Banks, a coach, will have their hearings Dec. 15. The athletes were suspended because they chose to compete in a country whose membership in the International Amateur Athletic Federation has been suspended since 1976 because of South Africa's official policy of apartheid.

title: 3 Officers Deny Charges in Suspect's Death
description: Three New York City police officers pleaded not guilty yesterday to criminal charges that they used ''unjust force'' in subduing a 40-year-old Brooklyn man who the police said had become violent. The man, Juan Rodriguez, of 374 Harmon Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, died in police custody on Jan. 30.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Saving on Heat
description: Electric heaters provide portable warmth and allow you to turn down the thermostat to save on home heating bills. Most heaters are safe (many have devices that shut them off if they tip over), and this year there seem to be more models than ever. These include models with fans that circulate warm air, and heaters small enough to put on your desk at home or in the office. Most heaters use at least 1,500 watts of electricity and have adjustable thermostats. It is wise to look for a certification mark from an independent testing facility like Underwriters Laboratories Inc., although not all states require testing for safety. Heaters should not be left unattended or where children can reach them, and they should be unplugged when not in use. Your dealer can tell you which model is best for the space you want to heat. Here is a list of basic heating units. Prices range from $50 to $ 200. TYPE ATTRIBUTES Convect ion Models with fans heat rooms more quickly but can be quite hot at close range. Some models resemble radiators and have heating elements permanently enclosed in an oil or antifreeze solution. Radiant These models heat quickly, but do not have fans to circulate air. Some have a heating element inside a quartz tube. High heat is generated at short range. Positive Ceramic serves as the heating element. These heaters use fans to Temperature circulate air, and are cooler at close range Coefficient (PTC) an radiant heaters (Sources: Underwriters Laboratories Inc. and Consumer Reports)

title: Review/Opera; A Rare Butterfly, In Sound and Style
description: Puccini created an indelible character in Cio-Cio-San, the tragic little geisha of ''Madama Butterfly,'' but in doing so he also created a severe problem for sopranos who assume the title role. Though his orphan girl from Nagasaki is one of opera's most fragile, vulnerable women, he assigns her music that requires a soaring spinto voice of the nearly dramatic type seldom found in frail female bodies. That is why ''Butterfly'' has been sung believably by such large-voiced sopranos as Maria Callas, Renata Tebaldi and Leontyne Price even though the eye may have resisted total belief in the character portrayed. Callas, for instance, made Cio-Cio-San a lady of Medea-like proportions whom any Lieutenant Pinkerton would have deserted only at his deadly peril.

title: 135 Points Not Enough for the Knicks
description: The press that has carried the Knicks so far this season failed them tonight. Forced to switch to a man-to-man defense, they failed to stop the Philadelphia 76ers, Charles Barkley in particular. In the end, they lost a 137-135 shootout at the Spectrum that ended their five-game winning streak and dropped their record to 5-3.

title: Central Illinois Public Service Co reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
Class by Birgit Nilsson
description: Birgit Nilsson will give a master class in voice at the Manhattan School of Music at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $25, with all proceeds from ticket sales going to the Birgit Nilsson Scholarship Fund, which the Swedish soprano established to help young voice students at the school. The entrance is on the northwest corner of 122d Street and Broadway.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There wasn't a day I didn't suffer. I died a little bit every day. I started to die some time ago.'' - Mario Biaggi. [ 30:1. ]

title: 7 Die as Plane Crashes In Storm in Arkansas
description: All seven people aboard a twin-engine plane were killed tonight when it crashed as the pilot was trying to land in a heavy thunderstorm, sheriff's deputies reported.

title: HEI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $853,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $250,000 for the quarter and a net of $1,529,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Orient-Express Hotels Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $1.5 million from discontinued operations. c-Net income

title: Man Charged in 3 Murders May Be Set Free
description: Queens prosecutors will recommend Monday that a man who insists he has been wrongfully charged with killing three people in a robbery 17 months ago be released from jail, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Scherer, R P Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $932,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary credit of $240,000 fr the both periods.

title: Talaat Yacoub, a Palestinian Leader, Dies
description: Talaat Yacoub, leader of the Palestine Liberation Front, a small and militant Palestinian guerrilla faction, died after a heart attack in Algeria on Thursday, according to reports from Algiers and New York.

title: The Little Yugo's Giant Slump
description: The squat little Yugo from Eastern Europe was never intended to tempt the buyers of racy sports cars or leather-trimmed luxury sedans. That wasn't the point. Rock-bottom price was.

title: Will Bush Purge Nazi Collaborators in the G.O.P.?
description: LEAD: The campaign may be over, but George Bush still needs to say what he plans to do with the 20-year-old Republican Heritage Groups Council, the ethnic outreach arm of the Republican National Committee. There is substantial evidence to suggest that the council was founded and continues to be led by people and organizations that collaborated with the Nazi occupation of Eastern Europe during the Second World War.

title: De Tomaso Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures are in U.S. dollar equivalents at the exchange rate of 1,400 Italian lire to U.S..S. prevailing at Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Syracuse Advances With 92-76 Victory
description: Sherman Douglas became the Syracuse career assist leader and the Orangemen advanced to the second round of the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament tonight with a 92-76 victory over La Salle.

title: Gooden Off Probation
description: A Hillsborough Circuit Court judge in Tampa, Fla., has waived the remainder of Dwight Gooden's probation for the altercation the Mets' pitcher had with Tampa police in December 1986. Judge John Griffin praised Gooden for exceeding terms of his three-year probation, which had been scheduled to end in January 1990. Gooden told the judge he had tried to do everything asked of him. The pitcher was charged in January 1987 with battery against a law-enforcement officer and resisting arrest. Gooden's probation included 80 hours a year of community service and anti-drug efforts with children. . . . Tim Teufel, the Mets' second baseman, underwent a 75-minute operation yesterday to remove bone spurs from his left hand. . . . The Mets set their winter roster at 40 players yesterday by purchasing the contracts of five pitchers from Tidewater, including that of Terry Bross, the former center for the St. John's basketball team. The Mets also traded Reggie Dobie, a pitcher, to Seattle for Chuck Carr, an outfielder who will be assigned to Tidewater. Jeff Innis and Steve Frey, both pitchers, were sent outright to Tidewater.

title: Orange-Co reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a credit of $2,051,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Cavaliers Slip Past Nets in Last Minute
description: Every time the Nets took a bite out of tonight's game with the Cleveland Cavaliers, it crumbled a little more. When it ended, all that was left was a 95-94 loss.

title: Varlen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sheilah Graham Is Dead at 84; Wrote Hollywood Gossip Column
description: Sheilah Graham, who for some 35 years was part of what she called ''the unholy trio'' of powerful Hollywood gossip columnists - the others were Louella O. Parsons and Hedda Hopper - died Thursday of congestive heart failure at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 84 years old.

title: Steps May Cut Risk of Blindness in Diabetics
description: Diabetics who are able to keep the level of sugar in the blood well regulated are much less likely to go blind than those whose level is poorly controlled, researchers said today.

title: Death Sentences Given to 3 In Fatal Zimbabwe Bombing
description: Three former members of the Rhodesian security forces were sentenced today to be hanged after being convicted on murder charges in a bomb attack on a house owned by the African National Congress.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Couples Ahead by Five Strokes: Fred Couples shot a one-under-par 71 yesterday and took a five-stroke in the $1.2 million Dunlop Phoenix tournament in Miyazaki, Japan. Couples was nowhere near the course record of 62 he set in the first round Thursday. But he played the windy conditions without difficulty and wound up at 133, 11 under par. Three Americans were in a second-place tie at 138: Jeff Sluman, the PGA champion; Ken Green and Hubert Green. Sluman and Ken Green matched 68's - the low rounds of the day - and Hubert Green shot a 70. (AP) Tennis Hlasek Advances: Second-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland beat Matt Anger of the United States, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday and reached the semifinals of the $420,000 South African Open in Johannesburg. Two unseeded South Africans also won quarterfinal matches. Pieter Aldrich beat Kevin Curren, a South African-born American, 6-3, 6-4, and Christo van Rensburg defeated a countryman, Gary Muller, 7-6, 6-2.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 5, Bruins 2: Steve Yzerman continued his torrid scoring pace with two goals and an assist last night as the Red Wings won their sixth straight game with a victory over the Bruins at Detroit. Yzerman, who entered the game fifth in the league scoring race, set up Paul MacLean's first-period goal and scored two of his own in the middle period as the Red Wings built a 5-1 lead. A 102-point scorer last season before a knee injury forced him to miss the final 16 games, Yzerman has 10 goals and nine assists in his last eight games to run his season point total to 36.(AP) Capitals 3, Whalers 2: Dave Christian scored a power-play goal with 10:53 remaining to lift Washington to a victory the Whalers in Landover, Md. Christian's goal came off a scramble in front of the Whalers' goal and gave Washington its third victory in four home games. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 114, Bullets 108: Kevin McHale scored 27 points and Robert Parish added 26 last night for Boston. Larry Bird, who is expected to be sidelined for three months after having surgery today to remove bone spurs on both heels, watched from the bench as the Celtics struggled to their 12th consecutive regular-season home victory over the Bullets since March 14, 1984. Boston took an 89-83 lead into the fourth period, but had to rally after Washington moved ahead, 95-93, with seven and a half minutes remaining. The Celtics snapped a 97-97 tie on a 3-point play by Jim Paxson and a layup by Parish, but the Bullets kept battling and trailed, 106-102, with just over three minutes left. Ron Grandison then tipped in a rebound and McHale hit two free throws to move Boston out of danger.(AP) Warriors, 123, Heat 117: Chris Mullin scored 29 points and Winston Garland added 6 in overtime to lead Golden State. The expansion Heat (0-7) rallied from a 23-point deficit to force the overtime on Rony Seikaly's dunk with six seconds left. Garland's first basket in overtime put the visiting Warriors ahead, 113-112, with 1:55 left. Another basket by Garland with 58 seconds to go increased the margin to 117-112, and he later added two free throws. Garland finished with 22 points. Seikaly led Miami with a season-high 29 points. (AP)

title: Many Computers, but Few Hackers
description: When a young American computer hacker planted an electronic virus that paralyzed computer centers all over the United States, Japan's high-tech world expressed relief that its own young programmers rarely break into computers for sport.

title: The Basics of Anabolics
description: The chemical compounds known as steroids are widely distributed in nature and have widely varying functions essential to life. In humans, the two main types of steroids are anabolic and cortical.

title: Savannah Foods & Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Presidential Panel Backs Government Aid to Arts
description: Governmental support of the arts is needed to supplement private giving, a presidential committee told President Reagan on Thursday after a six-year study.

title: Polymer Intl Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $2,723,000 from a subsidiary's stock offering. The share earnings restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split this month.

title: Seattle-Tokyo Route Won By United
description: The Department of Transporation awarded the heavily contested Seattle-Tokyo route to United Airlines yesterday after almost two years of struggle among that carrier and Continental and American.

title: Patents; A Fiber-Optic Device For Fingerprint Image
description: Two Connecticut inventors won a patent this week for a compact fiber-optic device to make electronic images of fingerprints. Robert F. Dowling, founder of Fiber Optics Technology Inc. in Pomfret, Conn., said the device could work on battery power and fit unobtrusively in a police car.

title: Soviets in Afghanistan Threaten Action Against Guerrilla Attacks
description: The Soviet military command in Afghanistan formally warned the guerrillas today that it would react strongly against ''further military escalation.''

title: Mulroney Pollsters See Victory in Reach
description: With two days left before Monday's election, aides to Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that their polling indicates that the governing Progressive Conservatives could emerge from the voting with a narrow parliamentary majority.

title: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Healthcare Management Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,674,000 and $6,463,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect a reduction in interest expense and an increase in contractual adjustments related to the company's Chapter 11 proceedings.

title: New York and Other States Cracking Down on Auto Ads
description: Dealer advertisements for new, used and leased automobiles have become so deceptive that dealers themselves can't live with them anymore.

title: U.S. Spurns Japanese Plea To Remove Trade Sanctions
description: The Reagan Administration today rebuffed pleas by the Japanese to remove trade sanctions against their electronics products before the Bush inauguration.

title: Navratilova Upset by Loss
description: Martina Navratilova had plenty of plans to give a commanding performance at the Virginia Slims Championships, and all of them were dashed last night by eighth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, who upset second-seeded Navratilova, 2-6, 7-5, 6-3, in a quarterfinal match.

title: The Economy
description: Broad authority to draft evacuation plans for nuclear plants was granted to the Federal Government by President Reagan. The move is apparently aimed at breaking fierce local opposition to the licensing of the Shoreham nuclear reactor on Long Island and a reactor at Seabrook, N.H. Opponents of the plants asserted that the action could pave the way for full operations at both. [ Page 1. ] Owners of the Seabrook plant welcomed a recommendation from the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission favoring low-power testing of the reactor. [ 45. ] Spending on health care increased far faster than the inflation rate last year. Americans spent $500 billion on health care in 1987, a 9.8 percent increase over 1986, an annual report by the Department of Health and Human Services said. The inflation rate for 1987 was 4.4 percent. [ 1. ] Long-distance telephone service was disrupted on the East Coast when a construction crew severed a major fiber-optic cable in New Jersey. [ 1. ] Markets

title: The Late Charles Addams Gives Party and His Friends Praise Him
description: Charles Addams loved cemeteries but loathed funerals. So he gave himself a party instead, less than two months after he died.

title: Texas Train Goes for a Ride
description: A runaway train made up of three linked locomotives raced through five towns and across more than 200 miles of West Texas plains at high speed today, the authorities said. The train, a Union Pacific locomotive towing two others to which it was linked, was started by vandals in a railroad yard in Big Spring, the railroad said, and derailed when it was switched to a side track at Wild Horse Siding, about seven miles east of here. It hit a parked freight train. No one was hurt, Union Pacific said.

title: With HDTV, America Can Reclaim Its Lead in Electronics
description: To the Editor:

title: Store Hours: Is Later Better?
description: On Friday the nation's retailers begin their annual marathon. Department stores will be open as long as 12 hours a day or more, to try to get the most out of the selling season that brings the industry between a third and a half of its annual sales in a mere four weeks.

title: Northern Ireland: Freedom vs. Law and Order
description: LEAD: It may be foolhardly for an American -especially one not of Irish descent - to address the centuries old Irish political question. But we must concern ourselves with the recent British Government threat to basic freedoms in Northern Ireland.

title: Carson Will Miss At Least 4 Games
description: Harry Carson, the Giants' perennial Pro Bowl inside linebacker, underwent arthroscopic surgery today to remove a calcified growth in his right knee. He was placed on injured reserve, which means he can not return until the last game of the regular season.

title: Reagan Signs Directive on a National Crisis
description: President Reagan today signed an executive order that tells Federal departments and agencies what their responsibilities would be in a national security crisis.

title: Patents; 2 in Dispute Over Concept Of Eye Laser
description: A bitter dispute has erupted between two ophthalmic surgeons over one of the most promising new uses of lasers to correct eye problems.

title: Review/Music; Soviet Ensemble Serves Russian Fare
description: The State Symphony Orchestra of the Soviet Union, sometimes called the Moscow State Symphony on its Western visits, arrived at Carnegie Hall Thursday night for the first of two New York concerts (the second was last night in Avery Fisher Hall).

title: U.S. Health Care Spending Continues Sharp Rise
description: Despite years of efforts to control costs, spending on health care continues to increase far faster than the inflation rate.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Coping: With Audio-Video Sprawl
description: LEAD: How do you keep a component hi-fi or audio-video system from sprawling all over your living room? As new components like videocassette recorders, compact disc players and surround-sound decoders are added to modern systems, the problem becomes greater every year.

title: Granges Exploration Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Helm Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,680,000 from the repurchase of debentures. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,200,000. Results for the year-ago third quarter and 9-month periods are restated to reflect an accounting change. The company said the year-ago 9-month operating net includes after- tax gains of $2,422,000 related to the common stock offering of Bamberger Polymers Inc.

title: Jennie Lee, 84, British Legislator, Labor Party Leader and Official
description: Jennie Lee, a Scottish coal miner's daughter who rose to became a Labor Party Member of Parliament, Minister of State for the Arts and a baroness, died Wednesday at her home in London, a friend, Lord Goodman, said Thursday. She was 84 years old.

title: MAI Basic Four Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $989,000.

title: Dow Rises But Falls For Week
description: LEAD: The stock market moved gingerly higher yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 9.96 points to close at 2,062.41. It was the recently sagging Dow's second straight gain.

title: Europe Cool On U.S. Shift
description: The European Community reacted coolly today to an apparent shift in the United States position on world farm subsidies, seeing a change of style but not of substance in America's controversial demand that such assistance be scrapped.

title: Jury Finds L.I. Man Guilty in Strangling of Wife
description: A man accused of strangling his wife after an argument last Dec. 24 was found guilty today of second-degree murder.

title: GORBACHEV IN INDIA TO REAFFIRM TIES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, arrived in India today for a three-day official visit to reaffirm close relations between the two countries at a time when some Indians are questioning Moscow's intentions in the third world.

title: Hurdle for Tyson-Bruno Bout
description: Is Mike Tyson's Jan. 14 heavyweight championship bout with Frank Bruno still on?

title: Canadian Identity Is Embedded in the Trade Pact; Low Protectionism
description: To the Editor:

title: National Heritage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eagle Clothes reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $493,000.

title: Prices of U.S. Issues Rise Moderately
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose moderately in light trading yesterday, largely in response to a steadier dollar. But dealers in Government securities said much of the buying was done by those who had previously sold Treasury debt short.

title: Your Money; Advice on Hiring Asset Managers
description: People with $250,000 or more to invest might want to consider hiring a professional money manager to protect capital and try for a higher return than Treasury securities offer. There are 11,000 investment advisers registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission, so choosing correctly becomes a crucial factor.

title: Winchell's Donut Houses L P reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included gains of $2,439,000 for the quarter and $2,154,000 for the 9 months on the sale of assets; the quarter also included a charge of $500,000 for the refurbishing program. The year-ago periods included a gain of $159,000 on the sale of assets.

title: Bangor Hydro-Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a writeoff of $476,881 related to the company's investment in the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: Hotel Investors Trust and Hotel Investors Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on sales of $1,633,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and 21 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Includes gains on sales of $1,921,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and 18 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: Pantasote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $7 million for a reserve for potential warranty claims relating to its former U.S. roofing business for the quarter and 9 months; the quarter also included a tax reversal of $335,000.

title: Donaldson Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $176,000 for the latest quarter and $212,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Lilco Stands by Its Agreement to Sell Shoreham
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it remained committed to its agreement to sell the Shoreham nuclear power plant to New York State, despite President Reagan's signing of an executive order that removes a major obstacle to the plant's licensing.

title: Lilco Says Plan To Sell Is Firm
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said it remains committed to abandoning the Shoreham nuclear power plant, but would not say what it would do if the New York Legislature does not approve the agreement to buy the plant by Dec. 1.

title: Ashton-Tate Shift
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, one of the nation's largest computer software makers, said it would consolidate three operating units at a single site in Los Gatos, Calif., a move that will affect 185 employees in East Hartford and Shelton, Conn., by Jan. 1. The move more fully integrates into Ashton-Tate the operations of Multi-Mate International and Decision Resources Inc., two Connecticut-based companies acquired by the company, based in Torrance, Calif., since 1985.

title: KEY RATES
Fire Chief Is Appointed; Unions Assail the Choice
description: New York City Fire Commissioner Joseph F. Bruno yesterday named Homer G. Bishop, a 33-year fireman whose reputation as a tough, budget-conscious manager has often rankled the rank and file, to be the new chief of the department, the city's top Civil Service post.

title: Fraud Is Charged At Eagle-Picher
description: Eagle-Picher Industries and one of its divisions have been charged with fraud, submitting false claims for payment and other violations in a 13-count civil complaint served this week, United States Attorney Samuel A. Alito Jr. announced in Newark. Eagle-Picher is a Cincinnati-based concern that makes a variety of industrial products, machinery and automotive parts.

title: Jackson Rejects Offer From Knicks
description: Mark Jackson of the Knicks, who is scheduled to become a free agent on July 1, yesterday rejected the team's offer of a five-year contract.

title: 'Stepping Stone'
description: Ernie DeGregorio, a playmaking guard who was the National Basketball Association rookie of the year in 1974, will return to basketball as a coach of North Providence (R.I.) High School, which won the state Class B championship last year. DeGregorio, 37 years old, who spent five seasons in the N.B.A., was appointed by a local school committee. ''I've been keeping my eye open, looking for a coaching job,'' DeGregorio said. ''I interviewed for the Providence College coaching job, and I've been looking around. I'll use this as a stepping stone to go on to bigger and better things.''

title: Travelers Ends Moneytrac System
description: The Travelers Corporation has ended its Moneytrac personal financial management system after less than two years, saying it could not sign up enough subscribers to justify its cost. Moneytrac was a one-stop money management system offered by companies to their workers as a benefit. For a $100 annual fee, the system allowed workers to buy insurance, apply for mortgages, contribute to savings accounts and receive credit cards through Travelers. The fee was sometimes paid by the company, sometimes picked up by the worker and sometimes split between the two.

title: ORDER BY REAGAN SEEKS THE OPENING OF A-POWER PLANTS
description: President Reagan today issued an executive order that gives the Federal Government broad new authority to draft emergency evacuation plans for communities near nuclear power plants.

title: Ex-Seoul Chief Reported Ready to Apologize
description: Under intense pressure from his critics, former President Chun Doo Hwan was reported today to be ready to apologize for abuses during his administration, retire from the capital and return money he is said to have stolen from the Government.

title: Microage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $111,000 for the quarter and $764,000 for the year.

title: Occidental Makes Disaster Payments
description: Survivors of the British North Sea disaster on the Piper Alpha oil platform in July are being awarded interim compensation of $:10,000 ($18,000) each, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said.

title: Chinese Disclose That Quake In 1970 Killed About 10,000
description: Chinese officials today disclosed for the first time that an earthquake in southern Yunnan Province in 1970 killed about 10,000 people.

title: Arafat Due in Egypt to Seek Support
description: Yasir Arafat, Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is expected here soon to seek Egypt's support in persuading the United States to start Middle East peace efforts again, officials said today.

title: Aide in Charge Of Ambulances Will Leave Post
description: The executive in charge of New York City's ambulance service will leave his job, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Bankruptcy Filing By Mcorp Prevented
description: Important creditors have apparently agreed not to force Mcorp into a bankruptcy filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal code, an action that could have come as early as Monday, the troubled Texas bank-holding company said late today.

title: Canadian Prices Up 0.5%
description: The Canadian consumer price index rose five-tenths of a percent last month, to 145.7, compared with rises of one-tenth of 1 percent in September and four-tenths of 1 percent in October 1987, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: Worldcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $3.2 million. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $18,083,000.

title: Recognition Stake
description: Prospect Group Inc., a New York-based buyout fund, has acquired a 12.2 percent stake in Recognition Equipment Inc. and said it might seek talks on acquiring the troubled company. Last month two senior officials of Recognition Equipment, an Irving, Tex., information processing concern, took a leave of absence from the company after they were indicted on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States Postal System. As part of the indictment, Recognition lost its status as a Government contractor. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Prospect said that it had purchased its 1.24 million Recognition shares for an average price of $8.42. Recognition has 10.15 million shares outstanding.

title: 2 RJR Nabisco Suitors Submit Their Final Bids
description: One stage in the largest corporate auction in history wound up late yesterday when the two bidders for RJR Nabisco Inc. submitted voluminous documents near the 5 P.M. deadline for bids.

title: 100 Abortion Foes Arrested
description: More than than 100 demonstrators against abortion were arrested this morning for blocking the doors to a Planned Parenthood clinic. Thomas Webber, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, said he had asked the police to remove the protesters so employees and clients could enter.

title: Inflation Up in Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate jumped to 6.4 percent in October from 5.9 percent in September, the Government said today. The gain was in line with forecasts by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson. The financial markets had little reaction. The Government said the latest rise resulted mainly from an increase in mortgage interest payments. Mortgage rates rose on Oct. 1 to 12.75 percent from 11.5 percent.

title: International Income Property Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Transit System Seeking Help With Sleepers
description: The Transit Authority, facing a fall-off in subway ridership and an increase in homeless, disturbed and sometimes threatening people who live in the subways, plans to hire outside help to try to coax its unwanted residents out of trains and stations.

title: Bonn Names New Speaker
description: Health Minister Rita Sussmuth will be named speaker of the West German Parliament, succeeding Philipp Jenninger, who resigned last week over his speech recalling a Nazi pogrom against Jews, a senior politician said today. Mrs. Sussmuth, consistently ranked one of the country's most popular politicians in opinion polls, has the task of restoring the reputation of the post - West Germany's third highest state office -after the scandal over Mr. Jenninger's speech.

title: Gerber Scientific Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Music; Jane Scheckter, With Songs
description: Jane Scheckter's experience as a successful ''session'' singer on recordings and for television and radio jingles is evident in her performances on Tuesdays and Wednesdays at Danny's Skylight Room in the Grand Sea Palace, 346 West 46th Street.

title: Blacks Fight for a Place Among the 'Finest'
description: Change was in the wind. The civil rights movement was just beginning to stir to life in the South when a group of black New York City police officers started meeting in rooms sprinkled across Harlem. They met in secret, fearful for their jobs, but determined to organize, determined to improve life for blacks inside and outside the nation's largest police department.

title: Prize for Biography Of Langston Hughes
description: In ceremonies at the New York Public Library on Thursday, Arnold Rampersad was awarded the Clarence L. Holte Literary Prize for his biography ''The Life of Langston Hughes, Volume I, 1902-1941, I, Too, Sing of America,'' published in 1986 by Oxford University Press.

title: Bonn Panel Sees Need To Raise Mark's Value
description: Against a background of a declining dollar, the West German Government's panel of economic advisers said today that an upward revaluation of the mark within the European Monetary System was ''unavoidable.''

title: ZG Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House Speaker is Optimistic After a Meeting With Bush
description: After a 90-minute meeting with President-elect Bush today, the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, said he was encouraged about the prospects for cooperation on both foreign and budget policy.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: 3 Are Killed in Plane Crash at L.I. Airport
description: A small plane crashed shortly after takeoff at Brookhaven Airport in Suffolk County yesterday, killing all three people on board, the authorities said.

title: Much of East Coast Phone Service Is Disrupted by Jersey Cable Break
description: Millions of telephone calls, most of them on the East Coast, were disrupted yesterday when a construction crew accidentally severed a major fiber-optic communications line at a railway station in New Jersey, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said.

title: In Canada, 'No, Eh?' As Protest
description: Despite the weather, Canada's passions are aflame these days, and the national hockey team isn't even playing the neighboring Russians. The dominant issue in the national election campaign that ends with Monday's balloting is the pending free-trade agreement with Canada's other large neighbor, the United States.

title: Reading & Bates Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,802,000. c-After net of $303,000 for the quarter and a loss of $13,128,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Amfac Holders Back Bid by JMB
description: Shareholders of Amfac Inc., Hawaii's largest private landowner, approved a $49-a-share cash buyout, valued at $920 million, by the Chicago-based JMB Realty Corporation. The acquisition by JMB, America's largest real estate syndicator and a manager of $20 billion in United States and Canadian properties, was approved by 86.6 percent of shareholders.

title: Tecogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $46,000 for the quarter and tax credits of $11,000 for the year. The loss for the latest quarter resulted from writeoffs of accounts receivables and additions to reserves for bad debt. The share earnings are less than 1 cent a share for both year periods.

title: C3 Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results for the latest second quarter and 6 months were affected by the curtailment of purchases by the Department of Defense.

title: Reviews/Music; 30 Polkas, Most for Mirth And Some for Dancing
description: The omnipresent oompah that makes a polka a polka was displayed, stretched, bent, twisted, mocked, abstracted and exalted on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The occasion was ''Polka From the Fringe,'' a program of 30 polkas by 29 composers written for Guy Klucevsek, an accordionist, who performed them for three nights as part of the Next Wave festival.

title: There's Every Good Reason to Dredge the Hudson for PCB's
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AHSC Holdings Corp. said its AHSC Acquisition Corp. unit had begun its previously announced $31-a-share tender offer for up to 15.3 million shares of Alco Health Services, Valley Forge, Pa., a pharmaceuticals distributor.

description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, excerpts on Thursday from the political resolution by the Palestine National Council incorrectly rendered the first of seven points affirmed in the resolution. The corrected article reads:

Life of Indiana Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
