title: Baby, It's Cold All Over
description: When I feel a cold coming on it's down the hatch with a good nasal decongestant antihistamine, followed by nodding galore and submission to the antic whims of a fevered brain. In this condition, phrases like ''nodding galore'' spring readily to the lips. What a great name ''Nodding Galore'' would make for a future star of screen, stage and tube whose career is now languishing on welfare because her real name is Glenda Pitz.

title: A Guru Who Spreads the Gospel of Steroids
description: To law-enforcement officials, Dan Duchaine is a drug pusher whose product is anabolic steroids. In the medical community, he is regarded as a snake-oil salesman, promoting the use of dubious substances that may pose health hazards. But among body builders, Mr. Duchaine is the steroid guru, who they believe knows more about these drugs than anyone in the field of sports medicine.

title: Autodesk Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Everest & Jennings Internaional Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $172,000 for the quarter and income of $179,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $273,000 and $691,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago 9 months includes a gain of $289,000, or 4 cents a share, on the sale of real estate.

title: Colonial Life & Accident Insurnce Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $412,983 for the quarter and $457,419 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $591,876 and $694,299 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S. Envoy Quits O.A.S. Talks Over Nicaragua-Backed Plan
description: The American envoy to the Organization of American States walked out of a meeting today after a dispute over a resolution favored by the Nicaraguan Ambassador, who was expelled from Washington earlier this year.

title: The Sign of America's Decline, Under Foot
description: LEAD: In details, disaster: from the want of a nail, a kingdom lost, to hairpins in Hyde Park or a manhole cover in Greenwich Village.

title: REAGAN SIGNS BILL TO CURB DRUG USE
description: President Reagan today signed comprehensive legislation that establishes tough new civil and criminal penalties to curb the use of illegal drugs while broadening education and treatment programs.

title: Dean Witter Settles Suit
description: More than 30 investors who contended that they had lost millions because of unauthorized high-risk investments by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. have settled with the brokerage, officials said today.

title: Appeal Moot in Interco Case
description: The Delaware Supreme Court has dismissed an appeal of a lower court's ruling that required Interco Inc. to dismantle a ''poison pill'' defense it used to ward off a takeover bid by the Rales brothers.

title: Democratic Leaders Look Back at Defeat but Are Wary of Change
description: In a ritual that has become achingly familiar, Democratic state chairmen gathered here today to pick through the rubble of the 1988 Presidential election. But they were clearly wary of making broad changes in reaction to that defeat.

title: Alistair Cooke of the Many Hats Feels Free to Doff One at Age 80
description: Alistair Cooke, the genteel and erudite journalist and television host who seems to have a graceful comment for every imaginable circumstance, turns 80 years old tomorrow. And sure enough, when asked for his wisdom about that, he was not at a loss for words.

title: Last Czar's Wait for Death, as Elegy and Allegory
description: Searching for the Emperor By Roberto Pazzi Translated by M. J. Fitzgerald 196 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Review/Jazz; After Ellington, Spacemen
description: The second set of the Ellington Spacemen at Carlos 1 on Tuesday night was so infused with joy and wit that the extraordinary moments -and there were many - seemed normal.

title: Seymour Weiner, 66, School Board Official
description: Seymour W. Weiner, an executive and former head of school board associations, died of lung cancer Thursday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Glen Cove.

title: Floridian Still Won't Concede
description: Representative Bill Chappell Jr.'s aides say he is not giving up hope of keeping his seat in Congress until the last vote is counted.

title: Endevco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $480,000 and $881,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $2,736,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and after a loss of $117,000 for the quarter and net of $298,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: WAS PLAYING WITH GUN
description: A four-year-old Brooklyn girl was shot and killed yesterday, apparently by her older brother who was playing with a gun he found in the family's apartment, the police said.

title:
ART;
Burchfield: Ambition in Watercolor
description: LEAD: MORE than 70 years have elapsed since American artists like Charles Burchfield, Stuart Davis, Charles Demuth, Arthur Dove, John Marin and Charles Sheeler sought to create their nation's first independent, innovative art. Each had his own theories and found his own direction.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Robert F. Hummel;
Seeking New Tactics in AIDS Fight
description: LEAD: NW JERSEY ranks fourth in the nation after New York, California and Florida in the number of adults stricken by AIDS and second behind New York in affected children. Of the 5,312 total cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in New Jersey since 1982, 58 percent of the people have died.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MIRANDY AND BROTHER WIND By Patricia C. McKissack. Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: After the Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching of Sexual Abstinence Urged
description: A BILL that would require schools to stress sexual abstinence as the only completely reliable way of avoiding the sexual transmission of AIDS is scheduled for a vote tomorrow in the Assembly, despite objections of state health and education officials.

title: FLASHBACKS: Laurelton, 1955
description: It's a bright, crisp Saturday morning in the fall of 1955, I'm 10 years old and on my way to get a haircut.

title: A '1776' With Grand Moments
description: WHAT a peculiar musical ''1776'' is.

title: 2 Favorites Win: Fast Play, Open Mind
description: Fast Play just held on, and Open Mind just got up, as Angel Cordero Jr. rode both favorites to narrow but impressive victories yesterday in Grade I races for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct Race Track.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: NATIONAL SECURITY;
Technology Is Our Best Defense
description: LEAD: This summer, we were part of a Defense Science Board group that completed a comprehensive study of defense acquisition, readiness, and investment needs for the next decade. Our study group found that America is rapidly losing its leadership in a number of important technologies - semiconductors, computers, numerically controlled machine tools, and precision optics, to name just a few - which are essential to maintain our defense.

title: One Act Redefines 'Neighbor'
description: THIS is a Thanksgiving kind of story, although it took place almost two weeks before that lovely holiday. It happened on one of those cold and overcast days in late autumn, a time when the sun sets by late afternoon, and sometimes a darkness of the spirit, as well as of the sky, can settle in around us quite suddenly.

title: Simple Remedies For Plant Nuisances
description: ONE house plant never satisfies. Those who raise plants to have a little greenery around the house usually start with one or two pots. Soon there are four pots, then five. The house plant syndrome begins. Before long there are dozens of indoor plants to be cared for. The window space becomes crowded by leaves. Everything generally goes well - for a while. But then the little beasties begin to appear.

title:
NEIGHBORHOOD VIGNETTES FROM & NEW YORKERS;
FLASHBACKS: Staten Island Before the Bridge
description: LEAD: GROWING UP ON STATEN ISLAND in the 1950's was like growing up in the Midwest. In fact, parts of ''Splendor in the Grass,'' the Natalie Wood-Warren Beatty movie about thwarted teen-age love in Kansas, was filmed on Staten Island. Even Toto couldn't tell the difference.

title: Passion for Art Is Helping Emotionally Troubled Teen-Agers
description: AN articulate 33-year-old woman with a passion for art is making a difference in the lives of emotionally disturbed adolescents at the Four Winds Hospital here.

title: Homeowners Over 65 Deserve a Break
description: The Oct. 16 article entitled ''Revaluations Anger Homeowners'' brings to mind the plight of the elderly or retired homeowner living on a fixed income.

title: U.S. UNITS IN SEOUL TIGHTEN SECURITY
description: The United States military has tightened security around its civilian installations after an attack on an American housing compound by a group of young protesters armed with firebombs and metal bars.

title: Miss Nedorostek Weds
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York, Kathleen Louise Nedorostek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Nedorostek of Miami Beach, was married last evening to L. Robert Kaswell, the son of Celia F. Kaswell of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Richard B. Kaswell. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated. The bride, a divisional vice president at Saks Fifth Avenue, will retain her name. Mr. Kaswell, a certified public accountant, operates his own commercial real-estate agency in New York.

title:
GARDENING;
Native Persimmon Can Hold Head High
description: LEAD: A PERSON savoring a ripe native persimmon for the first time must feel he has discovered ambrosia. The flesh literally melts in the mouth and leaves an aftertaste akin to an apricot.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Barry Sanders, the tailback of Oklahoma State, should win the Heisman. He has broken the National Collegiate Athletic Association I-A record of 29 touchdowns in a single season. Before yesterday's game at Iowa State he had 31 touchdowns and his 2,003 yards rushing made him only the third collegiate player to reach this level. Sanders was averaging 222 yards a game and had three 300-yard rushing games before yesterday. He should break the single-season record of Marcus Allen, who had 2,342 yards at Southern Cal, and the Big Eight Conference record of Mike Rozier, who had 2,148 at Nebraska.

title: First Right-to-Know Violations Issued
description: THE State Department of Environmental Protection has fined more than 600 industrial concerns and other businesses in the first violations under a four-year-old statute intended to protect employees and community residents from workplace hazards and toxic industrial accidents.

title: What to Do When a Company Is in Play
description: While the potential rewards of investing in the stocks and high-yield bonds of companies involved in giant takeovers might seem great, small investors should also take into account that the risks can be great as well.

title: Advisers to RJR Nabisco Evaluating Buyout Bids
description: The bidders for RJR Nabisco Inc. spent much of yesterday explaining their complex buyout offers to the company's advisers. But none were told who had submitted the highest price for the food and tobacco company, and the evaluation of the proposals will extend at least through today.

title: St. Francis Prep Takes Title
description: Dino Kalesis, a sophomore promoted from the junior varsity only three weeks ago, kicked a 27-yard field goal in the second overtime yesterday to give St. Francis Prep of Queens a stunning 10-7 victory over Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island in the Catholic High Schools Football League championship game.

title: Knicks Explode Again And Win This Time
description: The Knicks, who couldn't reach the 100-point scoring mark in 28 games last season, continued their running and scoring rampage last night by overwhelming the Philadelphia 76ers, 141-122, before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Trying Day for Commuters
description: WHEN the phone rang in 5:30 A.M. in Eric B. Langeloh's Rye home on Tuesday, the caller was brief. ''We're not running,'' Donald Nelson, vice president of operations for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad told the county's Transportation Commissioner. ''What are your guys going to do?''

title: The Basics of Anabolics
description: The chemical compounds known as steroids are widely distributed in nature and have widely varying functions essential to life. In humans, the two main types of steroids are anabolic and cortical.

title: O'Rourke Outlines 1989 Spending Plan
description: A1989 budget that contains a 10 percent increase in spending and no new programs was unveiled last week by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who explained that rising costs in the areas of crime and homelessness were largely responsible.

title: Nancy D. Myers and Christopher Benbow Marry
description: At the Unitarian Church of Staten Island in New Brighton, Nancy Duffield Myers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Myers Jr. of Chambersburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher Hanson Benbow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terence H. Benbow of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Horace Colpitts and the Rev. Benjamin Bortin performed the ceremony. Johnette Willa Myers was the maid of honor for her sister. Jonathan Paine Benbow was his brother's best man.

title: Capitals Sting Devils' Defense
description: The Devils were forced to use two inexperienced defensemen because of injuries, but it was two veteran defensemen who let them down tonight.

title: Drama at the Solomon Trial
description: AS the Matthew Solomon murder trial wound down last week, some memorable moments remain:

title: Something Missing
description: Tulane didn't dismiss Wally English as football coach until he lost 15 games over two seasons. That was in 1984. Now Southeastern Louisiana University has dismissed English as football coach after he spent just three months on the job and didn't lose a single game. That's because Southeastern Louisiana doesn't have a team.

title: Teachers Want A Greater Voice In Education
description: I CANNOT help wondering whether Commissioner of Education Saul Cooperman realizes the stir he and his colleagues have caused by encouraging teachers attending the Commissioner's Symposium for Outstanding Teachers to form professional support groups, commonly known today as teacher cooperatives.

title: Town Votes Painting Sale
description: Efforts to spare a valuable painting from the auction block failed after voters at a town meeting approved a library's plans to raise money by selling the work, valued at up to $2 million. The meeting rejected a petition aimed at blocking the Jones Library's sale of a painting by the 19th-century American landscape artist Albert Bierstadt.

title:
DINING OUT;
All Dressed Up? Some Place to Go
description: LEAD: AFTER two years of major renovation, a seedy bar and grill has become a bright beauty of a dining spot called Cobble Creek Cafe. Shades of green form a backdrop for flowers everywhere - in the pictures shadowed with pink light, on the English china, on the table as tiny orchids and, most spectacularly, in the stained-glass panels.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Peru; 'Why is Democracy Losing Ground?'
description: AFTER almost 1,000 days of looking good in the polls, Peru's President, Alan Garcia Perez, has seen his popularity rating crash from a peak of more than 80 percent in 1985 to about 20 percent since he imposed draconian anti-inflationary measures in early September. Now his possible resignation and the possibility of a coup are openly and frequently discussed.

title: Using Sports For Freedom
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Turning Leaves: A Pilot Compost Pile
description: LEAD: FOR James J. Hogan, the leaf season has just begun. Mr. Hogan's leaves - about 250 cubic yards to date, all stored at Croton Point in a neat pile called a windrow - are bright yellow or orange or red. By next summer, they will be deep brown.

title: DATA UPDATE

WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Wild Turkey Comeback
description: LEAD: NEXT week, Joseph M. Caverly, the county's Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation will give thanks for turkey.

title: BUSH, EARLY ON: VERY MUCH INVOLVED
description: Within 10 days of his election triumph, Vice President Bush has signaled leaders of his party and the broader political community that he intends to adopt a much more energetic and more deeply involved Presidential style than that of the man he has served under for eight years, Ronald Reagan.

title: To Emigres, Sakharov Remains Above It All
description: THE night he arrived in Boston on his first trip outside the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov accepted a box of long-stemmed roses from a man he had never met - an American-born Crimean Tatar whose people have been on Dr. Sakharov's list of causes for more than 20 years.

title: No Headline
description: Much Too Modest!

title: Leveling Taxes . . .
description: To the Editor: What Herbert Stein neglected to say in ''Tax the Rich, They Consume Too Much'' (Business Forum, Oct. 23) is that a flexible and fair taxation system is beneficial to both taxpayers and to the American economy.

title: The Santa Fe Opera Announces 1989 Season
description: The Santa Fe Opera will present Verdi's ''Traviata,'' Cavalli's ''Calisto,'' Massenet's ''Cherubin,'' Richard Strauss's ''Rosenkavalier'' and the American premiere of ''A Night at the Chinese Opera,'' by Judith Weir, a Scottish composer, during its 1989 summer season, the general director, John Crosby, has announced.

title: A Coach Maligned?
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: GRACE EPISCOPAL CHURCH;
Soup Kitchen ReadiesFor Thanksgiving and More
description: LEAD: NO one chooses to spend Thanksgiving in a soup kitchen. But for someone with no alternative, the community meal at Grace Episcopal Church here might beckon.

title: Seeking New Messages for an Old Medium
description: AM radio first took to the airwaves on Nov. 2, 1920, when the nation's first AM station, Pittsburgh's KDKA, began reporting on the Harding-Cox Presidential race. Other technologies of that era, the Victrola, for example, have fallen by the wayside, and the AM radio industry is fighting hard not to become an historical artifact too.

title: F.B.I. Agent Is Target of Inquiry on Racism
description: A Chicago agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been notified that he is a target of a criminal investigation into charges that he and other white agents conducted a campaign of racial harassment, including death threats, against a black colleague.

title: Pan Goes Underground
description: The biggest concert hall in New York City is beneath the streets. Down there, beside the subway tracks, violinists saw away at Bach, accordionists squeeze out ''Rosemarie'' and would-be Springsteens shout above the roar of the trains. One day last week, two groups of South American Indians were making the loveliest sounds this side of the Andes. They were in the squalid Times Square station with big guitars, small guitars, a hip-slung drum, wooden flutes and pipes that might have been Pan's. Their music was Pan's too, wild and sweet and seductive.

title: At New Music School, It's Not Mostly Mozart
description: High school students know that Thomas Jefferson wrote most of the Declaration of Independence and was the third President of the United States. But at a new private high school in Manhattan for young musicians, they also know that Mr. Jefferson played the violin and composed for string trios.

title: A 'New' Roslyn Is Emerging
description: LEAD: THE relocation last week of a historically significant Roslyn building, the Long Island Rail Road station, heralds a host of dramatic changes in the area's physical appearance and traffic patterns.

title: Picture Research
description: TEN years ago I spent several months doing picture research on studio color photography of the 1920's, 1930's and 1940's. What I found was surprising. The images that remained from the 1920's and 1930's were still colorful, crisp and lively. But a great many from the late 1940's had faded to an overall magenta cast. These unfortunate pictures looked like the life had drained out of them.

title: Deborah Witsell Engaged To Marry Glenn D. Vivian
description: Deborah Towne Witsell and Glenn Donald Vivian, a son of Mrs. Donald G. Vivian of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Vivian, plan to marry Dec. 10, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Witsell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced.

title: History Will Not Judge The A.C.L.U.'s Worth
description: To the Editor:

title: Condo Lingo
description: To the Editor: I doubt very much if the youngsters of today will go condo-hopping, bypassing Acapulco, the Bahamas or such other popular resorts to visit their parents in the condominiums and subject themselves to learning a specialized lingua franca specially adapted to the condo modus vivendi.

title: 12 Season of Readings by Poets Opens Today
description: LEAD: THE 12th season of the Poet's Voice series of free readings by prominent American poets will begin today in Stamford, with Daniel Hoffman, poet in residence at the University of Pennsylvania, reading from his works at the Ferguson Library.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I want to stress that the long run is rapidly becoming the short run.'' Alan Greenspan, chairman, Federal Reserve Board, urging quick action on the Federal budget deficit.

title: William McRae Is Wed in Boston To Miss Wellman
description: Lesley Rainer Wellman, a freelance designer of fashion accessories in New York, and William Barry McRae, an associate at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married at King's Chapel in Boston yesterday by the Rev. Ernest W. Cockrell, an Episcopal priest.

title: 'Ideas' Seen as a Source of New Taxes
description: A COURT decision involving Wallingford and a local property tax on computer software could mean millions of dollars in new revenues for towns and cities across the state.

title: Q and A
description: No-Mortgage Co-op

title: In the Realm of the Privileged
description: EDWARD LEE CAVE is standing along the great green mall at Park Avenue and 72d Street at dusk, watching the lights go on in the apartment houses where he sells multimillion-dollar co-ops and condos. ''When you think of New York,'' he says, ''the movers and shakers, most of them live within five blocks or so of this spot.''

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Fairfield, Conn. $340,000 1406 Westport Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1734 saltbox; stone hearth with beehive oven, antique molding, 2 acres; taxes $2,433. Farmington, Conn. $390,000 72 Garden Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; Farmington River frontage, 0.75 acres; taxes $2,324. New Fairfield, Conn. $436,000 5 Brookwood Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; zoned heat, screened porch, 2 acres; taxes $3,300. Bronxville, N.Y. $700,000 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 50-year-old English style; 3 fireplaces, den, family room, walk to station; taxes $9,759. Harrison, N.Y. $400,000 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; stone fireplace, full basement, 2 acres; taxes $2,368. Montrose, N.Y. $230,000 124 Kings Ferry Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 73-year-old colonial; fireplace, workshop, walk to station, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,018. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. $199,000 6 Roosevelt Terrace 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,565. Maplewood, N.J. $352,000 465 Ridgewood Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; den, c/a, 2 fireplaces, 2-car garage; taxes $9,248. Bayport, L.I. $275,000 19 Cole Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; pool, decks, 2-car garage, on cul-de-sac; taxes $5,100.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: South; Virginia, at Last, Defeats Maryland
description: Shawn Moore threw for one touchdown and ran for another as Virginia ended 16 years of frustration against Maryland with a 24-23 Atlantic Coast Conference victory today.

title: Reviews/Music; New Work, With Reeds
description: Ned Rothenberg, the new-music composer and saxophonist, layers his music. Squeals pierce through lower-register burbling, melodic ideas cycle and circle until notes start flying off into other registers. Mr. Rothenberg, who played at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night, does it all on reed instruments - alto saxophone and bass clarinet - and his shows, as musical as they are, are also a spectacle.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 20, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 1 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 3 3 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 4 4 FAVORITE SON, by Steve Sohmer. (Bantam, $4.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Miss Stauffer Has Wedding
description: Karen Stauffer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Stauffer of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Sawyer Murphy Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York. He was assisted by the Rev. Mark Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest. Jill S. Cobbs was her sister's matron of honor, and Mr. Murphy was his son's best man.

title: FICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. THE GOOD TIMES ARE KILLING ME. By Lynda Barry. (Real Comet Press, Paper, $16.95.) In this deft and deceptively simple first novel, the cartoonist Lynda Barry gives us the world of Edna Arkins, who is coming of age in Seattle. It's a tough neighborhood, this world. Inside the house where she has lived all her life, Edna's family is beginning to unravel. Outside, the unwritten rules of childhood are changing, along with the people on her block. ''In the beginning of this street it was a mainly white street,'' Edna recalls. (The Arkins, too, are white.) ''That was a long time ago, but I can remember the houses went White, White, White, Japanese, White, White.'' Now the houses go ''Chinese, Negro, Negro, White, Japanese, Filipino.'' And now friendships - even the dreamy intimacies of summertime - can suddenly shatter under the steady pressure of racism. There is pleasure as well as pain in this tricky universe, and Edna marks both with music: songs she hears over the radio, in a black church service and on the portable record player she keeps as a shrine in the basement. Music releases her memories, and this astonishes her. ''How can a song do that?'' she asks. ''Be like a net that catches a whole entire day, even a day whose guts you hate?'' As a kind of subtext for this thought, Ms. Barry puts a ''Music Notebook'' at the novel's end, with paintings and biographies of some legendary performers. But the real music in this book comes from the cadence and rhythm of Edna's speech. Ms. Barry has an impeccable ear, and this funny, intricate and finally heartbreaking story exquisitely captures an American childhood.

title: Westbury Is Divided Over Rail Parking Plan
description: LEAD: BY 7 o'clock any weekday morning, the south parking lot at Westbury's Long Island Rail Road station is full, and the quiet streets of the nearby Breezy Hill section are invaded by convoys of commuters scrambling for a place to park.

title: A MOTHER'S FURY
description: Richard Selzer describes the ferocity of a mother elk's desperate struggle to protect her calf from three predatory coyotes, in his article ''A Mother's Fury'' (Oct. 23).

title: In Harmony With Brazil's African Pulse
description: AS we climbed off a bus at the Barra Lighthouse in Salvador, the capital of Bahia in Brazil, several young boys, smiling broadly, chanted ''Africa do Sul!'' and held their fists in the air. I was among a group of African-American friends who might have blended in with Bahia's predominantly black population had it not been for our cameras and sightseeing attire. At first I thought the boys were proclaiming their support for the freedom of South Africa. It did not take me long to realize that what they were actually telling us was that Bahia was the Africa of South America.

title: All Part of the War Effort
description: THE TURKEY WAR By Douglas Unger. 230 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Laura A. Swicker Wed To Kenderton Barber
description: The wedding of Laura Annesley Swicker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Swicker of Westfield, N.J., to Kenderton Antoine Barber, the son of Kenderton B. Barber of Scotch Plains, N.J., and the late Mrs. Barber, took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield. The Rev. Hugh Livengood performed the ceremony.

title: Accepting the Gambit Is Playing With Fire
description: THERE are those who seem to think that no more is required for successful pawn-snatching than sticky fingers and a spirit of greed. But materialism on the chessboard often involves high adventure. To accept a gambit is a commitment to running a dangerous gantlet, especially nowadays when gambits are rarely thrown around with wild abandon but almost invariably have some sort of justifying positional basis. A good example of strenuous pilfering is provided by the game between Jeroen Vanheste of the Netherlands and the Queens grandmaster Edmar Mednis from the O.H.R.A. Grandmaster Group International Tournament, which ended Aug. 11 in Amsterdam.

title: Dollar Abroad
description: To the Editor: I was happy to see that Spain was represented in your annual chart ''What Your Dollar Buys in 10 Cities in Europe'' (Travel, Oct. 9). It is unfortunate, however, that you keep using either the Villa Magna or the Ritz Hotel as price indicators.

title: Tamil Attacks Seek to Deter Local Voting
description: Tamil separatist guerrillas attacked troops and civilians in eastern Sri Lanka today in an attempt to disrupt local council elections, military officials said.

title: First Steps for Young Actors
description: ''YOU see, if I was lucky, Harold and I could've succumbed to our silly little passion and that would've been that, the end of it. And New Rochelle, of all places. At least if I had been in some nice apartment in the Village, say, with the sounds coming through the window of traffic and people, the breeze blowing the curtain over the bed, like in the movies. But, no. I lost my virginity in the attic of an old house in New Rochelle.''

title: Jerusalem Plans Annual Marathon
description: With the assistance of the New York Road Runners Club, the city of Jerusalem plans to hold an annual international marathon through the ancient streets of the Old City and around its walls, starting in 1990.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My fireplace, which was trouble-free for a number of years, now emits a pungent or sour odor after a rainfall. This odor lasts for several days after a fire has burned in the fireplace. I have had the chimney cleaned and a cap placed on it, but to no avail. Is there is anything else I can do?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'Tree of Lights'
description: LEAD: An 18-foot evergreen strung with hundreds of tiny white lights will brighten the front lawn of the Phelps Memorial Hospital Center this holiday season - and every bulb will shine in memory or in honor of someone.

title: Anything for Kafka
description: 'This is perhaps the most important work in 20th century German literature, and Germany had to have it. From my perspective, it was a very low price.' - Heribert Tenschert, a West German book dealer, after making a successful bid of $1.98 million for Franz Kafka's handwritten manuscript of ''The Trial.''

title: Marc Stone, 76, Public Relations Executive
description: Marc Stone, a public relations executive who helped start the widely circulated newsletter written by his brother I. F. Stone, died of emphysema Thursday at the Stanford Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 76 years old and lived in Palo Alto.

title: Civilization's Cancer
description: WE HAVE OFTEN seen in the breast a tumor exactly re-sembling the animal the crab. . . . In this disease the veins extending out from the unnatural growth take the shape of a crab's legs. We have often cured this disease in its early stages, but after it has reached a large size no one has cured it without operation. . . . We attempt to excise a pathological tumor in a circle in the region where it borders on the healthy tissue.''

title: The Limpid Candor Of an Unspoiled World
description: Among quiet-spoken forms of European art, German Romantic drawings stand as high as any. Dated primarily from the immediate pre-industrial era - between 1780 and 1830, that is to say - they portray an unspoiled world in which no one is ever in a hurry.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the state's Republican Party misattributed the statement ''It's time for the party to shake off the dust and get moving again.'' It was made by the minority leader of the State Senate, Reginald J. Smith, not by the party chairman, Robert S. Poliner.

title: VOODOO IN BROOKLYN)
description: UNCHARTED PLACES By Nora Johnson. 332 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: REAGAN DIRECTIVE IS CALLED TOO LATE TO HELP 2 PLANTS
description: President Reagan's executive order on nuclear emergency planning has come too late to speed the efforts by managers at the Shoreham and Seabrook nuclear power plants to begin commercial operation, Federal officials and many supporters and opponents of the plants said yesterday.

title: Stirring Up Profits at Campbell
description: It would seem that R. Gordon McGovern, the Campbell Soup Company's chief executive, should be feeling, well, M'm! M'm! Good!

title: Andre Dubus's Hard-Luck Stories
description: NAKED, IN HIS WHEELCHAIR, Andre Dubus has another story, this one about a quadriplegic friend who was recently challenged to a bar fight. Barrel-chested, with a gray beard and the weathered red countenance of a man who has both suffered and enjoyed quite a lot, Dubus, 52, is an animated raconteur. In the kitchen doorway of his pleasantly untidy house in Haverhill, Mass., he's just up from a nap, waving one hand with a cigarette in it and wheeling himself in a slow circle with the other, laughing incredulously and spewing out profane praise for his crippled and courageous buddy, Mike Loring. Now and then he'll stop and absently scratch the stump of his left leg, which two years ago was amputated at the knee after he was run down on an Interstate highway, having stopped his car to assist at the scene of an accident.

title: Sherrill Tied to Payments
description: George Smith, a former Texas A&M running back, today recanted statements attributed to him in taped interviews in which he was quoted as saying that Coach Jackie Sherrill paid him to keep quiet about National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations.

title: S.I. Museum Gives Children Close Look at News
description: With the timing of a seasoned reporter, Christian A. Pepo slipped quietly into the press preview of the Staten Island Children's Museum's newest exhibition, missing the small talk and just catching the first good quotation.

title:
NUMISTMATICS;
Memorial Medal Is Designed
description: LEAD: SINCE his assassination 25 years ago, John F. Kennedy has been the subject of many numismatic tributes, notably the Kennedy half dollar. One of the most appealing is a new medal by Paul Vincze, an international medallic artist.

title: Craft Show in New Haven is a Holiday Treat
description: LEAD: CRAFTS shows spring up at holiday time like mushrooms after a rainstorm in the woods. Some reappear for a season or two, then close up shop; a few become hardy perennials. This year, the Celebration of American Crafts in New Haven marks its 20th anniversary.

title: Suffolk Ceramics DisplayTraces Growth of Area
description: LEAD: TO some people, a plate is a plate is a plate. But to historians, a plate can provide the means for tracing the social and economic development of an area.

title: One Vote for a Trade School
description: LEAD: The stocks of companies that offer vocational training were badly hit last week. That surprised some analysts who believe that the new Welfare Reform Act, which mandates job training for many welfare recipients, will be a boon to the industry. The reason for the sell-off, analysts say, was the rumor that a big investment weekly had prepared a story denigrating the industry.

title: Angry Carson Says He Could Play Next Week
description: Less than 24 hours after he underwent arthroscopic knee surgery, Harry Carson said today he was angry and disappointed. He said the Giants never told him they were putting him on injured reserve, which meant he would miss at least four games and might never play again.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 33 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the actor who stars in the CBS series ''TV 101.'' The actor, shown in the upper right picture viewing himself on screen as Kevin Keegan, is Sam Robards.

title: When the Cat's Away The Owners Hunt All Day
description: LAST Thanksgiving day was a memorable one for our family. It was the day our beautiful white and orange house cat, Nicholas, decided to explore the outside world. I had left the back door slightly ajar to cool the kitchen, overheated from cooking Thanksgiving dinner for 14 people. Nicholas, who had never been out of the house in the 10 years of his life, must have slipped out the door while no one was looking.

title: MR. PRESIDENT! MR. PRESIDENT!
description: ON BENDED KNEE The Press and the Reagan Presidency. By Mark Hertsgaard. 408 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Receiver Key for Bayside In P.S.A.L. Quarterfinal
description: Bayside needed some fourth-quarter heroics from Moses Thompson to beat Midwood yesterday in one of three quarterfinal games in the Public Schools Athletic League. The star receiver caught five passes for 93 yards in the final period, including a 10-yard reception with 25 seconds remaining for his third touchdown of the 20-14 Bayside victory.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: 'ANYTHING GOES'

title: A. Elizabeth Sloan, Editor Marries George J. Bubrick
description: A. Elizabeth Sloan, the editor in chief of McCall's magazine, and George Joseph Bubrick, the president of the Brooks International Corporation, a management consultant in Montvale, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: Exhibits of 1880's Re-Created
description: FEMALE artists and female patrons of the arts have joined across a century to bring an unusual show to the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. ''American Women of the Etching Revival,'' which opened here Oct. 30, was assembled to celebrate the 100th anniversery of two back-to-back landmark shows that first demonstrated to the American public the high caliber of American female etchers.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Countdown to a Last Gulp THE infinite science of how many seconds Long Island Rail Road commuters can leave between their last gulp of coffee and a successful dash for the morning train has now entered a new phase.

title: Dr. Paul P. Vessa And Ms. Ozimek, A Designer, Wed
description: Kimberley Cordeaux Ozimek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. RichardThomas Ozimek of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Paul Peter Vessa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Vessa of Bergenfield, N.J. The Rev. Edward Johnson performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Crowding the Floor
description: Perhaps because they keep out of party politics, members of the British royal family tend to be adept at the politics of parties. Certainly Prince Charles made a hit last week as he celebrated his 40th birthday with 1,500 inner-city youngsters in blue-collar Birmingham.

title:
MUSIC;
Children's Programs Are in the Spotlight
description: LEAD: THE holidays are coming, and with them an array of programs especially for youngsters. To replicate an early-American Thanksgiving, for instance, Sunnyside is offering special tours, songs and demonstrations of 19th-century holiday preparations at the Tarrytown landmark home, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: AFRICANS EXTEND U.N. ECONOMIC PLAN
description: African nations agreed unanimously today to press on with ambitious but painful economic programs for two more years in an effort to overcome the crisis gripping most of their economies with falling incomes, increasing starvation and rising infant mortality.

title: THE NATION: Fear of the Deficit; The President-Elect Plummets in the Financial Markets
description: THE anonymous disciplinarians of the financial markets gave President-elect Bush a brutal warning last week: If he won't break the impasse over the Federal budget deficit, they will.

title: Cars Don't Have to Take a Back Seat in the Movies
description: LEAD: The film's director had loved the car for years and said the man who wrote the original story was a ''true car buff.'' He added that after the shooting was completed, the cars used in the film were sold at an auction for up to $150,000 each.

title: For the Mideast, A 'False Dawn'
description: The relief is great in the Jewish world. The Palestinians have given Israel still another gift of ambiguity.

title: Rebecca Abrams to Marry in Spring
description: The engagement of Rebecca Ann Abrams to David Benjamin Sayles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Sayles of New York, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. George E. Ehrlich of Philadelphia and Basel, Switzerland, the stepfather and the mother of the future bride. Miss Abrams is the daughter also of Dr. Stanley L. Abrams of Philadelphia. A spring wedding is planned.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: East Craftsbury, Vt.;
Preservation, With Housing
description: LEAD: THE 772-acre Brassknocker Farm was two weeks away from the auctioneer's gavel in the spring of 1987 when the Vermont Land Trust stepped in with $575,000, most of it borrowed, to try to keep this northern Vermont town of 884 people - which has no zoning - from being overrun by condominiums.

title: Laser That Turns Many Eyes and Ears
description: They came out in the pouring rain to look at the car, truckers abandoning their coffee. It's that kind of car. ''What is it?'' one of them yelled. ''A Laser!'' I hollered back from the gas pump at the Connecticut truck stop. ''A Blazer?'' Incredulity. ''No, no - a Laser! A Plymouth Laser!''

title: Broadway Rebound
description: ON BROADWAY NEAR 86th Street, morning commuters push past empty windows of the Boulevard, a new 21-story tower seeking chic merchants for its retail space and young professionals for its quarter-million-dollar condominiums above. A marketing brochure spares no modesty: ''To live at The Boulevard,'' it says, ''is to experience a constant sense of well-being.''

title: Mary Ann Oratz And Carl Siegel, A Lawyer, Marry
description: The marriage of Mary Ann Oratz, a daughter of Murray Oratz of New York, to Carl Siegel, a son of Mrs. Maurice T. Siegel of Baltimore and the late Mr. Siegel, took place last evening at the Puck Building in New York. Rabbi Jose Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony.

title: From a Pretoria Jail, A Plea to Blacks
description: LEAD: I reject the approach of those of our countrymen who would refuse white South Africans the right to join in the national effort to eliminate oppression.

title: Does Race Doom the Democrats?
description: The dirty little secret of Democratic Presidential politics, according to recent standard analysis, is race. By embracing blacks and the civil rights agenda in the 1960's, the Democrats have lost white support - especially among males, the working class and in the South. Thus, the traditional New Deal Democratic coalition is sundered - as newly demonstrated by George Bush's overwhelming triumph among Southern whites.

title: U.S. Won't Bring Criminal Charges In Building Collapse in Which 28 Died
description: Federal authorities will not file criminal charges and will forgive a record $5 million in fines levied against contractors in the collapse of a high-rise complex that left 28 workers dead and 16 others injured in Bridgeport, Conn., 19 months ago.

title: Swiss Embroidery and Lace
description: SWITZERLAND has been a world embroidery center for 400 years. The reputation of Swiss needlework was established in 16th-century St. Gallen, in the canton of Appenzell, and secured with 19th-century Swiss expertise on the embroidery machine.

title: FLASHBACKS: At Home in Harlem
description: Before he met my mother, Daddy was a high roller, a gambling man. Whenever he hit it big, he used to tell us, he'd head out of Chicago for New York, for Harlem. There he'd surround himself with the finest women, go to all the clubs, watch the lines form around the Apollo, kick back at Small's Paradise. I must have been 6 or 7 when he started telling us these stories, and he made me want to come to New York in the worst way. More than that, he made me want to live in Harlem.

title: Getting Insurance When Self-Employed
description: Setting up shop in a spare room or the garage can seem the perfect solution to the hassles of commuting, juggled child care and bad office coffee. But moving from dreams to the reality of self-employment requires you to assume a burden that many employed people leave to their employers: insurance. Suddenly, there are a bewildering number of decisions to be made, and a string of premiums to be paid.

title: Democratic Leaders See No Rejection of Party in Dukakis's Defeat
description: Four years ago, when Democratic state chairmen met in the Virgin Islands after Walter F. Mondale's landslide defeat, they spoke with urgency of the need to change their party's image and its system of nominating candidates. The mood was one of clear alarm.

title: 3 Giant Windmills: Is There a Buyer?
description: IN the days of expensive oil, look, it wasn't such a bad idea: Set three of the biggest windmills in the world on 200-foot towers and let them churn out 7.5 megawatts of electricity, or enough for 2,000 homes.

title: GROWING UP IN JERUSALEM
description: The caption under the photograph of an Israeli soldier standing in front of the Western Wall reads: ''Time has not been a great healer. A heavily armed Israeli soldier stands watch as Jews gather by the Wailing Wall to pray.''

title: Democrats Losing Out on Judgeships
description: LEAD: WHEN Victor J. Orgera walks into work in the morning, people stand in respect.

title: Nights of Jazz
description: Bobby Watson, an alto saxophonist, is to lead his jazz group tonight at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: SAKHAROV TO LEAD PANEL ON PRISONS
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights campaigner, will lead an international panel looking into prison conditions around the world, members of the panel agreed last week.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Hand-Held TV/VCR Unit: Breakthrough or a Gimmick?
description: For the last two months, passengers boarding the Hokutosei, a 16-hour overnight express train from Tokyo to Sapporo, Japan, have been given a new toy just for the ride: a combination television set and videocassette recorder, shrunk to the size of a tall paperback book.

title: Iranians Say Carter Asked to Aid Hostages
description: Iranian radio reported today that former President Jimmy Carter wrote to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini offering to serve as a ''neutral American channel'' in efforts to free United States hostages in Lebanon and improve American-Iranian ties.

title: MARRYING FOR MONEY - AND TO MAKE MUSIC TOGETHER
description: When it comes to programming, AM and FM stations generally go their separate ways. But when it comes to finance, they do not. Broadcast lenders are now refusing to bankroll what they consider the dead-end of the industry: solo AM stations. As a result, AM stations are finding that capital is available, but only if they link up with an FM partner.

title: Familiar Sounds
description: He could hardly believe his ears. There across the net from John McEnroe at the Little Caesars Championship Tennis Tournament in Detroit was 18-year-old Jim Courier sounding very much like McEnroe did 11 years ago, when he was 18. Courier, distressed with his play in a 6-2, 6-4 quarterfinals loss, started muttering obscenities under his breath after losing several points. Then he began uttering obscenities directly at McEnroe.

title: PEEPING AT THE SISTERS NEXT DOOR
description: COVER ME By Lon Otto. 142 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: THE REGION: $7 Million in Federal Aid; If It's a War on Drugs, New York Wonders, Where's the Artillery?
description: AFTER pushing through a drug bill in the final days of their session last month, many members of Congress indulged in lusty self-congratulation, calling it a powerful blow against illegal narcotics. President Reagan, signing the legislation Friday, declared that ''in the eleventh hour of this Presidency, we give a new sword and shield'' to narcotics officers.

title: Christina Onassis, Shipping Magnate, Dies at 37
description: Christina Onassis, the head of a family business empire and stepdaughter of Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis, died of a heart attack while visiting friends in Argentina yesterday, according to local news reports from Buenos Aires. She was 37 years old.

title: THREE CHEERS FOR MY DAUGHTER
description: My skin tingled after reading Kathleen Cushman's saucy ''Three Cheers for My Daughter'' (Hers column, Oct. 23). Since the demise of my saddle shoes in 1974 and the dawning of feminism in my soul, I have been hiding my high-school identity: I was one of 12 loud, sturdy, enthusiastic and precise cheerleaders. I don't believe I joined the squad just to be popular, have more dates and to strut. Perhaps, as Ms. Cushman suggests, we were 12 revelers of female power. DEBRA SANACORE Maple Shade, N.J.

title: THE WARREN COMMISSION: Why We Still Dont's Believe It
description: THE TRUTH IS that Lee Harvey Oswald was the lone gunman who murdered President John F. Kennedy and Dallas Police Officer J. D. Tippit on that tragic Friday afternoon, Nov. 22, 1963, in Dallas. Yet 25 years after the event, a majority of the American public does not believe the truth. Rather, polls have shown that most Americans believe President Kennedy was assassinated as an outgrowth of a conspiracy.

title: spano to Seek County's Top Post
description: LEAD: THE 1989 election year began last Wednesday when County Clerk Andrew J. Spano announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for County Executive.

title: Chinese Artists in Southport
description: AT 2600 Post Road in Southport, there is a shopping enclave - small, but equipped with what now seem to be the essentials for life in suburban Connecticut, including a Computerland, a gourmet store and an art gallery. This is nice, even if it does bring on a twinge of nostalgia for those intersections in the South, where there's nothing but a 7-Eleven, a gas station and a beauty parlor.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 20, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $19.95.) Four nuns become pawns in a struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 2 1 5 THE QUEEN OF THE DAMNED, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $18.95.) Continuing the chronicle of 6,000 years of vampirism begun in ''Interview With the Vampire'' and ''The Vampire Lestat.'' 3 2 16 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 4 6 3 ONE, by Richard Bach. (Silver Arrow/Morrow, $17.95.) A man and his wife find themselves in a fantasy world. 5 3 5 ANYTHING FOR BILLY, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The exploits of Billy the Kid, as shared by a dime-novel writer. 6 8 3 MITLA PASS, by Leon Uris. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A writer's struggles with his heritage and two loves reach a climax during the 1956 Sinai war. 7 5 6 FINAL FLIGHT, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Three Vietnam veterans on the trail of a friend who may be responsible for a series of murders. 15 * 12 55 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.)
