The second volume of a biography of Winston Churchill, covering the years 1932-40. 2 1 31 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 3 * 6 3 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 4 5 2 CHILD STAR, by Shirley Temple Black. (McGraw- Hill, $19.95.) The autobiography of the No. 1 film actress of the mid-1930's. 5 4 6 THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Knopf, $22.95.) A historian's view of the American Revolution. 6 10 4 GOLDWATER, by Barry M. Goldwater with Jack Casserly. (Doubleday, $21.95.) The memoirs of the longtime Senator from Arizona. 7 3 4 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 8 7 20 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 9 1 DON'T BEND OVER IN THE GARDEN, GRANNY, YOU KNOW THEM TATERS GOT EYES, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $15.95.) Humor with a Southern accent. 10 1 GRACIE, by George Burns. (Putnam, $16.95.) The life of the comedian Gracie Allen, recalled by her widower and show business partner. 11 * 8 13 THE RAGMAN'S SON, by Kirk Douglas. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The actor recalls his life as poor immigrant's son, waiter, steel mill worker, haberdashery salesman, film star, father and man. 12 14 15 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of the 1969 accident on Chappaquiddick Island. 13 12 18 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman who married King Edward VIII. 14 1 THE SACKETT COMPANION, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $19.95.) The author's commentaries on his 17 novels about a family of Western pioneers. 15 9 6 SURVIVING THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) What Americans and their Government should do in the face of economic disaster. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 72 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 4 6 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 3 1 THE DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr., Joseph F. Kett and James Trefil. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) An annotated list of ideas and facts ''Americans need to know.'' 4 2 33 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 5 3 11 ALL YOU CAN DO IS ALL YOU CAN DO, BUT ALL YOU CAN DO IS ENOUGH! by A. L. Williams. (Nelson, $14.95.) The philosophy of a highly successful entrepreneur. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) DICKENS: A Biography, by Fred Kaplan. (Morrow, $24.95.) The garish, driven writer in this deterministic account endlessly cannibalizes the family Grand Guignol of his childhood. FAST COPY, by Dan Jenkins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The clod-kicking, cussing, small-town Texas characters in this novel about the 1930's are devoted to the wars: football and newspapers. TWO AGAINST ONE, by Frederick Barthelme. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $17.95.) This intermittently shocking and admirably brave novel about modern marriage depicts several intersecting triangles in a painful geometry of romance with no solutions. DATELINE SOWETO: Travels With Black South African Reporters, by William Finnegan. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) There is a bitter irony in this rich and useful primer: black reporters working on the wrong side of apartheid risk their safety to serve primarily the interests of the white minority. MIDNIGHT SWEETS, by Bette Pesetsky. (Atheneum, $17.95.) If a novel based on cookies can be written, this is it: quirky, disjointed and sweet, especially the heroine - master baker as artist. OUTLAW: The Life and Times of William S. Burroughs, by Ted Morgan. (Henry Holt, $27.50.) The life of an unaffiliated conservative anarchist in which the focus is on celebrity and chronology rather than subversive writer. THE LAST TO GO: A Family Chronicle, by Rand Richards Cooper. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) A haunting first novel about the history and dissolution of a family that is wonderful to read. ''WHAT DO YOU CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'':

title: Sununu Answers His Critics: 'I Have to Be Tough Enough'
description: John H. Sununu said today that the White House staff he will direct for President Bush will be filled with ''talent'' and not necessarily longtime Bush supporters. And he said he did not believe he would be hampered by the fierce struggle with other Bush associates that preceded his appointment.

title: Mass Transit: It's Still A Good Idea
description: THOUGH politicians may ignore the idea of mass transit and push a fourth and fifth lane for Sunrise Highway, it is time we take a hard look at what the reliance on automobiles has done to our lives. Many Long Islanders spend over an hour a day on the road commuting. During a lifetime, a commuter can spend years behind the steering wheel. In a culture that places such a value upon time, it is a pity that so much time is wasted twisting the dial of a radio or playing with an electronic gizmo that makes machinegun noises at the car ahead.

title: INSIDE
description: Unrest Grows in Yugoslavia

title: Correction
description: Because of a distributor's change of plan, a picture caption last Sunday with the film listings in some editions of the Arts and Leisure section, about the opening of ''A Forgotten Tune for the Flute,'' was outdated. No date has been set; the film did not open Friday.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My fireplace, which was trouble-free for a number of years, now emits a pungent or sour odor after a rainfall. This odor lasts for several days after a fire has burned in the fireplace. I have had the chimney cleaned and a cap placed on it, but to no avail. Is there is anything else I can do?

title: Turning the Tide on Japanese Food
description: BOTH Japanese food lovers and haters will find Restaurant Yamaguchi in Port Washington to their liking. I was accompanied there by a couple who have battled over Japanese food for years. She loves it, he doesn't. At meal's end, he surrendered, a happy convert.

title: Lions (2-8) Have Best Season Since '78
description: Columbia ended its most successful season in a decade yesterday by crushing Brown, 31-13. It is the first time since 1978 that Columbia won twice in a season.

title: CONSPICUOUS CONSUMERS
description: Next to the club soda, Perrier and cat food in the refrigerator are 150 tubes of lipstick. There's hardly room for such clutter in the bathroom. That is crowded with 100 or so bottles of fragrance and uncounted cases of eyeshadow, blusher and other necessities. This shrine to makeup is Margot Rogoff's apartment. And while Mrs. Rogoff works for Revlon, her cosmetics collection far predates her recent career.

title: Coming of Age
description: BILOXI BLUES Starring Matthew Broderick (in photo, left), Christopher Walken, Matt Mulhern, Corey Parker, Markus Flanagan, Penelope Ann Miller. Directed by Mike Nichols. 1988. MCA Home Video. 106 minutes. $89.95. Rated PG-13. Full of uproariously vulgar language.

title: Nicaragua and Rebels Expect Fresh Effort From Bush to Resolve Conflicts
description: Leaders of both the Nicaraguan Government and the anti-Government rebels expect the Bush Administration to make fresh efforts to resolve conflicts here and elsewhere in Central America.

title: MASTERS OF SELF-CONGRATULATION
description: THE DURRELL-MILLER LETTERS 1935-80. Edited by Ian S. MacNiven. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: New Directions. $26.95.

title: Soviet Court Sentences Man To Death in Armenian Riots
description: The Supreme Court has sentenced a man to death by firing squad for leading a mob that killed seven people in ethnic riots this year, reports today said.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Midwest; Kolesar Goes 100 To Rally Michigan
description: John Kolesar returned a kickoff 59 yards to set up his 41-yard touchdown reception with 1 minute 37 seconds to play, and Mark Spencer's interception ended a final Ohio State threat, giving Michigan a 34-31 Big Ten Conference victory today.

title: Miss Ferenbach Weds in Newport
description: At the chapel of St. George's School in Newport, R.I., Elizabeth Ferenbach, the daughter of Hannah Ferenbach of New York and Colin Ferenbach of Royal Oak, Md., was married yesterday to Martyn Frank Edward Walker, a son of Mrs. Horace F. Walker of London and the late Mr. Walker. The Rev. John S. Rogers, the chaplain of St. George's, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: NONFICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. WHY CAN'T SHARON KOWALSKI COME HOME? By Karen Thompson and Julie Andrzejewski. (Spinsters/Aunt Lute, Cloth $20.95; Paper $10.95.) After the car driven by the woman she loved was struck by a drunken driver in Minnesota in November 1983, Karen Thompson faced far more than the grim prospect of nursing her brain-damaged companion back to health. For the first time, she had to confront her homosexuality and the reactions it would generate from her lover's family, her own parents, her church and the courts. The story of Ms. Thompson's relationship with Sharon Kowalski, both before and after the accident, is powerful and poignant, particularly as it describes how Ms. Kowalski's parents used the legal system to keep her away from the woman she had lived with for four years. Her story identifies many villains: not just Ms. Kowal-ski's family, but assorted judges, doctors, nurses, newspapermen, clergymen, even Ms. Thompson's own lawyers, whom she now thinks were too timid, and Ms. Kowalski's court-appointed counsel. Particularly as the indictments mount - the book often reads like a legal brief and a repetitious one at that - one wishes at least some of these people could be heard. Still, Ms. Thompson's account (written with Julie Andrzejewski, a professor of human relations at St. Cloud State University in Minnesota) is convincing, in part because her personality is so pleasing. As she describes her experiences, and her evolution from reclusive physical education teacher to feminist activist, she comes across as modest, thoughtful, sincere and vulnerable. Her narrative is largely free of shrill, self-righteous sloganeering. Only toward the end, after she has lost the legal battle to become Ms. Kowalski's guardian, when she mouths ritualistic incantations against ''racism, sexism, ageism, classism, handicapism and homophobia,'' does the reader suspect the voices are those of Ms. Thompson's advisers as much as her own.

title: Immigration Law Said to Harm U.S. Citizens
description: Many United States citizens and aliens eligible for residence are experiencing discrimination in employment, housing and other services in New York City because of widespread concern about Federal sanctions, representatives of community organizations, immigration experts, public officials and immigrants themselves say.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $275,000 19 Cole Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; pool, decks, 2-car garage, on cul-de-sac; taxes $5,100. Copiague $200,000 245 East Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; dining room, den, 50 feet of bulkheaded waterfront; taxes $2,500. Farmingdale $200,000 45 Intervale Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. Patchogue $115,000 117 Chapel Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old ranch; dining room, basement; taxes $1,050. Westbury $240,000 54 Hunters Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 31-year-old split level; finished basement with bar, family room; taxes $5,200. Williston Park $195,000 37 Prospect Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 60-year-old colonial; dining room, den, attic; taxes $2,200. OTHER AREAS Farmington, Conn. $390,000 72 Garden Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; Farmington River frontage, 0.75 acres; taxes $2,324. Harrison, N.Y. $400,000 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; stone fireplace, full basement, fenced yard, 2 acres, walk to transportation, schools and shopping; taxes $2,368. Springfield, N.J. $217,500 115 Salter Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; family room, screened porch, formal dining room; taxes $2,666.

title: Maggie Dugan Marries David Gang in Rochester
description: Maggie Dugan, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick D. Dugan of Penn Yan, N.Y., and the late Judge Dugan of the Yates County (N.Y.) Court, was married yesterday in Rochester to David Andrew Gang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Gang of Lockport, N.Y. Justice Robert M. Quigley of the State Court of Claims officiated at the University Club of Rochester.

title: A Corner of Jungle and Sea
description: As we stepped onto the narrow footbridge that marks the start of the Abel Tasman Coast Track, our packs held a schizophrenic inventory. Much of it was familiar backpacking gear: sleeping bags, tents, stove, fuel, and so on. But other items gave mixed clues about the upcoming hike: in addition to a compass, we carried a tide table; we'd packed both rain pants and SPF-16 sun goop as well as long underwear, swimming trunks, a woolen balaclava and a beach towel. And strapped to the top of my pack, I lugged an immense pair of black rubber swim fins, making me look from behind, observed Anne, like a 1959 Cadillac Fleetwood.

title: FROM PRETORIA, HOPEFUL SIGNALS
description: While South Africa says publicly that it is still studying the detailed plan for regional peace in southern Africa that Angola and Cuba approved Friday, there were indications today that the Pretoria Government was likely to give its assent.

title: Rally in Belgrade Protests Ethnic Albanian Surge
description: Hundreds of thousands of chanting Serbs marched through the streets of the capital today, demanding a greater say in the affairs of their divided nation.

title: The Writer's Condition
description: To the Editor:

title: A TALE OF TWO TYRANTS
description: THE DEADLY EMBRACE Hitler, Stalin and the Nazi-Soviet Pact 1939-1941. By Anthony Read and David Fisher. Illustrated. 687 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Reviews/Music; The Stockholm Arts Trio
description: A fine young Swedish ensemble called the Stockholm Arts Trio came to Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night. Its program resonated on several levels. Superficially there was a tinge of diplomacy, with Bo Linde's Sonata a Tre placed beside an American trio by Charles Ives.

title: Robert Adam's Derbyshire Jewel
description: SOLID grandeur, with references to ancient Rome: that, it seemed to Sir Nathaniel Curzon, was the very least an English gentleman could expect when building himself a house. Of course, it helped that he owned, among other things, quarries rich in marble and alabaster. But even more than an expression of his wealth, Kedleston, the country seat he started building in Derbyshire in 1759, is a perfect symbol of the pride, power and pomp of 18th-century England.

title: A BOLSHEVIK SOCCER TEAM
description: LEAD: KITH AND KIN By Andre Kaminski. Translated by Harry Zohn. 311 pp. New York: Fromm International. $19.95.

title: The View From: Heritage Village; Where the Residents Are Busy Doing What They Want to Do
description: FRANK AUBREY is retired from his job as a designer of packaging for novelty items for a New York City company, but his artistic talents are still in demand. One morning last week, he was happily putting the finishing touches on a series of cutouts of showgirls, sequined beauties that later dangled from the ceiling of the Activity Center at Heritage Village as part of the decor for a dinner held by the Brush and Pencil Club that night.

title: Prospects; Interest Rates Climb
description: The fall in the value of the dollar against the yen last week raised expectations that the Federal Reserve Board would push interest rates higher to prevent the dollar from sinking further. In the bond markets, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds increased on Thursday to 9.17 percent before retreating slightly at the close of the week. At the same time, the Federal funds rate on loans between banks was also up slightly, to just above 8 1/4 percent. Will interest rates continue to rise? Francis H. Schott Chief economist, the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

title: Cynthia Reed Weds David Eliot Klein
description: The marriage of Cynthia Elizabeth Reed, a daughter of Adrian Pryor Reed of Centreville, Md., and Ariane Wellin of Greenwich, Conn.. to David Eliot Klein, the son of Mrs. David Aylwin Klein of Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Klein, took place yesterday at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans performed the ceremony.

title: In Japan, The Quinella is King
description: NEXT SUNDAY AFTERNOON, THE WORLD'S first $2-million horse race outside the United States will be run, and not at Royal Ascot in the English countryside or Longchamps on the outskirts of Paris. Whichever one of a dozen thoroughbreds from around the world wins the Japan Cup at Tokyo Race Course will earn his owner nearly $1 million, with the runners-up sharing the rest.

title: Increasingly, Parking Difficulties Plague Prosperous Towns
description: COMPLAINTS of parking shortages throughout Long Island have become more widespread than ever, and the loudest protests are that overdevelopment has resulted in communities' running out of space.

title: FICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. KLYTAIMNESTRA WHO STAYED AT HOME. By Nancy Bogen. (Lintel, $17.95.) If ''Klytaimnestra Who Stayed at Home'' is a bellwether, we may have to anticipate sympathetic fictional treatments, from self-styled feminist viewpoints, of Lady Macbeth, the Wicked Witch of the West and Snow White's evil stepmother. The problem with Nancy Bogen's first novel, originally published in 1980 in paperback and now reissued in a hard-cover edition, is not that it reworks the mythology of Clytemnestra, wife and ultimately murderer of Agamemnon, who led the expedition to recapture her wayward sister, Helen, from Troy. Homer and the tragedians, above all Aeschylus, demonstrate the variety, flexibility and profundity with which the Greek literary tradition approached this complex female figure: bereaved mother of Iphigenia; adulterer with Aegisthus; victim of her own avenging son and daughter, Orestes and Electra. Rather, Ms. Bogen's treatment is dismaying because its revisionist perspective drains the titanic Clytemnestra of passion and resolve. Multiple interior monologues, shifting from the aristocratic principals to servants and spear-carriers, have a leveling, not an individualizing, effect: everyone is weary, vacillating and preoccupied with sex. This mundane view occasionally has touching results, as when the conquering hero, Agamemnon, beaching his ship at last, absently registers the tattered, unwashed condition he shares with his fellow victors over Troy. But despite the novel's anachronistic surges of conspiracy theory, the edges of its plot are blurred and the characters finally sink under the weight of their mutual weakness. This thoroughly modern style of ''humanizing'' the story creates an incredible shrinking myth in which, ironically, the women are most diminished. Cassandra in particular - the captive Trojan princess whose prophecies are both infallible and unheeded - is an opportunity missed here: what a burden of consciousness might have been explored. For power, dignity and emotional urgency in characters of both sexes, readers had best sidestep Ms. Bogen's version for the Greek vision.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My fireplace, which was trouble-free for a number of years, now emits a pungent or sour odor after a rainfall. This odor lasts for several days after a fire has burned in the fireplace. I have had the chimney cleaned and a cap placed on it, but to no avail. Is there is anything else I can do?

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: East; Rutgers Trounces Colgate by 41-22
description: Scott Erney threw for three touchdowns and the defense forced three turnovers and blocked two punts today as Rutgers broke a four-game losing streak with a 41-22 victory over Colgate in the season finale for both schools.

title:
GARDENING;
Native Persimmon Can Hold Head High
description: LEAD: A PERSON savoring a ripe native persimmon for the first time must feel he has discovered ambrosia. The flesh literally melts in the mouth and leaves an aftertaste akin to an apricot.

title: DATA BANK: November 20, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF ROY COHN, by Sidney Zion. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) While Roy Cohn was dying of AIDS, he collaborated with a friend, the journalist Sidney Zion, on the story of his life. At about the same time, Nicholas von Hoffman was writing CITIZEN COHN (Bantam, $5.50), an unauthorized biography of Cohn, who is probably best known for his stints as chief counsel to Senator Joseph McCarthy during the 1950's and as a prosecutor of the Rosenbergs. ''These two books should be read in tandem,'' Tom Wolfe said in The Book Review last year. ''Both hum along at a merry clip, thanks in part, perhaps, to the two authors' headlong dead-heat race to publication.'' FIRST LOVE AND OTHER SORROWS, by Harold Brodkey. (Vintage, $7.95.) In a story called ''The Quarrel,'' two young esthetes from Harvard become a mutual admiration society, convincing themselves that no one else sees life with the same refinement. On a trip to the south of France, however, they discover that they are really quite ordinary after all. ''The surface simplicity of Mr. Brodkey's stories is disarming,'' one reviewer said in 1958. ''It is, of course, the result of real ability and hard work. Mr. Brodkey writes well, in a clear, uncomplicated, unaffected prose. He sees well, too; more important, he thinks about what he sees.'' CHILE: Death in the South, by Jacobo Timerman. Translated by Robert Cox. (Vintage, $6.95.) To overcome the oppression of the Pinochet years, Jacobo Timerman writes, Chileans must steer a course between the left and right extremes. ''His analysis is a good deal more subtle than the usual binary, superpower thinking,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ''And his experiences on the South American continent have clearly earned him the right to feel the way he does.'' The same publisher has also reissued PRISONER WITHOUT A NAME, CELL WITHOUT A NUMBER ($6.95). Translated by Toby Talbot, the book tells of Mr. Timerman's experience as a prisoner of the Argentinian junta in the late 1970's. Mr. Timerman ''writes with passion, but a passion controlled almost to the point of detachment,'' Anthony Lewis said here in 1981. ''The effect is devastating.'' CUTS, by Malcolm Bradbury. (King Penguin, $5.95.) Henry Babbacombe, an ascetic British author of post-modern novels, is hired by Eldorado Television to write a blockbuster miniseries. ''There is so much fun, fury and intelligence in this little novel, one can forgive its insistent cartoonishness or those rare moments when the wit is less rapier than spoon,'' Lorrie Moore said here last year. INVISIBLE FRONTIERS: The Race to Synthesize a Human Gene, by Stephen S. Hall. (Tempus, $8.95.) Driven by the quest for knowledge and dreams of enormous profits, three teams of scientists competed during the late 1970's to synthesize the gene that makes insulin. Last year, our reviewer, Daniel J. Kevles, said Stephen S. Hall ''succeeds marvelously in making the science accessible to the general reader, mixing straightforward description with inventive metaphors, similes and analogies.'' FRIED GREEN TOMATOES AT THE WHISTLE STOP CAFE, by Fannie Flagg. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) Mrs. Threadgoode spends her twilight days in a nursing home, reminiscing about the eccentric characters who gathered during the Depression at the Whistle Stop Cafe in Alabama. This is ''a real novel and a good one,'' Jack Butler said here last year. THE RISE OF THE COUNTER-ESTABLISHMENT: From Conservative Ideology to Political Power, by Sidney Blumenthal. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $9.95.) Tracing the intellectual origins of Reaganism, Sidney Blumenthal shows how a band of conservatives - who, paradoxically, wanted radical change - set up their ''counter-establishment'' in Washington. He ''traces in a masterly way how the tiny bands of guerrilla conservatives rode down from the hills and captured the fat cities and the Presidential palaces of American life,'' Godfrey Hodgson said here in 1986. ''This is a thoughtful and fair-minded book.'' TIDINGS, by William Wharton. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) Beset by a variety of problems, both ethereal and mundane, a philosopher and his family spend Christmas at their old mill in France. ''It is some measure of how engaging and sympathetic Mr. Wharton makes these characters in the midst of their obsessive, solipsistic musings that the reader really worries that they are going to miss out on Christmas morning,'' Susan Kenney said here last year. ''We have a heartwarming tale of family love and reconciliation in the season to be jolly.'' IT'S RAINING IN MANGO: Pictures From a Family Album, by Thea Astley. (King Penguin, $6.95.) While telling the story of four generations of an Australian family, Thea Astley describes a continent whose magic is being overwhelmed by drugs, prostitution, development and suicide. Last year, The Times's Michiko Kakutani praised the author for her ''concise, elliptical style, her wit and her narrative ingenuity.'' THE SOCRATIC METHOD, by Michael Levin. (Ivy, $3.95.) Rebecca Shepard's chances of becoming the first tenured female professor at fictional McKinley Law School are not helped by the fact that she has written an article condemning the brutalities of the American system of legal education. Last year, our reviewer, Scott Turow, called this novel ''an energetic, intelligently motivated and often extremely funny book.''

title: Study Says Country-Western Style and Drinking Are Linked
description: Patrons of country and Western bars drink faster to ''wailing, lonesome, self-pitying music,'' an anthropologist said in reporting the findings of two studies of drinking in Missoula, Mont., and the Minneapolis area.

title: Canada's Deeper Identity NOT Made in the U.S.A.
description: On this last weekend before a national election that will reset the fundamental political and economic directions of the second largest country in land size in the world, Canadians drove their Chevrolets, Plymouths and Fords to Sears stores past the Holiday Inns and Midas muffler shops. They ate lunch at McDonald's or Kentucky Fried Chicken and bought their groceries at Safeway. They took a pizza home from Domino's, brushed their teeth with Colgate toothpaste and laughed at ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Shriver Ends Graf's 46-Match Winning Streak
description: The invincible one was felled by a common cold and an uncommon performance by Pam Shriver yesterday. Shriver stood sentry at the net and achieved a 6-3, 7-6 victory in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims Championships that snapped Steffi Graf's winning streak at 46 matches.

title: Former Selectman Returning To Maine to Face Charges
description: A former selectman and Boy Scout leader in Maine, missing for four months before being captured by the Las Vegas police Monday, has waived extradition and will return to Maine to face sexual misconduct charges.

title: Japan's Best Movies Aren't a Leading Export
description: Throughout Mitsuo Yanagimachi's ''Fire Festival'' (''Himatsuri''), one of the finest films to be made here in recent years, there recurs a series of images that are initially funny but which, as the film progresses, become increasingly disturbing.

title: Anti-Drug Talks Begin
description: Sports ministers from around the world are expected to approve an Olympic anti-drug charter at a conference here this week sponsored by Unesco. In addition, the Olympic committees from the United States and the Soviet Union will meet to consider an anti-steroid exchange program.

title: Students Protest Canceling Of School Christmas Program
description: Ninety-three high school students have been suspended for three days after boycotting classes over the cancellation of an annual Christmas ceremony.

title: 'WE THREW ANDY OUT OF OUR ORGY'
description: FAMOUS FOR 15 MINUTES My Years With Andy Warhol. By Ultra Violet. Illustrated. 274 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My fireplace, which was trouble-free for a number of years, now emits a pungent or sour odor after a rainfall. This odor lasts for several days after a fire has burned in the fireplace. I have had the chimney cleaned and a cap placed on it, but to no avail. Is there is anything else I can do?

title: A Quest in the Park for a Graveyard
description: It was a good day to look for skeletons in Washington Square Park.

title: Works in Progress; Native Ground
description: AS ART, IT IS NOT EXACTLY eternal, but its aspect changes with the seasons and to appreciate it fully requires an elevated perspective. The portrait of Saginaw Grant (above), in a 30-acre wheatfield near Lawrence, Kan., is the work of Stanley J. Herd. It's his seventh ''large field piece,'' as he calls them, since 1980. On the stubbled field, Herd used a two-bladed plow to create dark lines. ''I mowed some areas, for another color,'' he says. ''And I used a disc, a tool farmers use to turn stubble on its side. Each implement turns the ground another way, and I used them like different pencils.''

title: Reviews/Music; 'Ghosts' That Alter Sounds
description: Electronic-music concerts can be a trial: clinically impersonal or technically inept or oddly artsy or doggedly polemical in their exposition of a single stylistic school. The judiciously selected, surely produced program offered Tuesday night at the Manhattan School of Music by the New Music Consort happily avoided nearly all of these pitfalls.

title: Dirty Campaigns - a Hallmark of U.S. History
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S NOT EASY TO WRITE FOR LEGS
description: LEAD: TIME AND THE DANCING IMAGE By Deborah Jowitt. Illustrated. 431 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title:
MUSIC;
18th-Century Songs To Be Revived
description: LEAD: DR. GORDON MYERS, a baritone and a retired Trenton State College professor who is known for his research and performance of early American music, will perform his own edition of Francis Hopkinson's ''Seven Songs for Harpsichord or Forte Piano'' this afternoon at Trenton State College.

title: THE NATION: New York; The Next Move Is Cuomo's; Will It Be Taxes?
description: IN New York, Governor Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature are grappling with a budget gap that has grown to almost $2 billion in just six months.

title: POLITICAL MISUSE OF GIFTS DISPUTED
description: Speakers at a political meeting here have sharply disagreed over whether private unregulated gifts of money were a problem in the Presidential campaign.

title: Dubliners Cheer as B.C. Wins
description: American college football came to Ireland today, complete with cheerleaders, marching bands, mascots and hot dogs, and a result that pleased most of the 42,525 fans at Lansdowne Road Stadium here: Boston College 38, Army 24.

title: Peete Leads U.S.C. to Rose Bowl Berth
description: For two nights this week, he was Willie Jackson, an identity Willie and Edna Peete's youngest son derived from his father's first name and his mother's maiden name.

title: New Groups Change Crime in Jersey, Official Says
description: Colombian cocaine organizations, Jamaican gangs and factions of the Sicilian Mafia have changed the face of organized crime in New Jersey and confounded efforts to stop their drug operations, the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation said this week.

title: WHERE THE DAWN IS COUNTERFEIT
description: LEAD: POET IN NEW YORK By Federico Garcia Lorca. Edited, and with an introduction, by Christopher Maurer. Translated by Greg Simon and Steven F. White. Illustrated. Bilingual. 276 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25. POEM OF THE DEEP SONG By Federico Garcia Lorca. Translated, and with an introduction, by Carlos Bauer.

title: The Art of Defense
description: IF you had polled the cognoscenti half a century ago and asked them to name the world's strongest partnership they would surely have named two of the Four Aces: Howard Schenken, David Burnstine, Oswald Jacoby and Michael Gottlieb. Thirty years ago Alvin Roth and Tobias Stone would have received votes, and the Europeans would have claimed the title for Pierre Jais and the late Roger Trezel of France or for Terence Reese and Boris Schapiro of Britain.

title: The Rumpled Anarchy of Bill Murray
description: AS HOLLYWOOD parties go, the one in full swing this past spring in a handsome, Georgian Revival home off Sunset Boulevard was an anomaly.

title: How 2 Burger Flippers Stack Up Photo of burger eaters in Chicago (NYT/Richard Derk) and San Fransico (NYT/Terrence McCarthy)
description: In the struggle for control of the Pillsbury Company, many of Pillsbury's Burger King franchisees have said that they would not mind if the company were sold to Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. They claim Pillsbury has managed the company poorly, and cite such evidence as Pillsbury's lack of investment in new restaurants. On Friday, they rejected a Pillsbury proposal to spin off Burger King.

title: NOVELIST'S GRANT TO AID 2 SCHOOLS
description: At many New York City high schools, the only student newspapers are old, yellowed issues hanging from the walls.

title: NOT WHAT KRISHNA HAD IN MIND
description: MONKEY ON A STICK Murder, Madness, and the Hare Krishnas. By John Hubner and Lindsey Gruson. Illustrated. 414 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: A Forgotten Fort At the End of Nowhere
description: BEYOND the glitter of Miami and the party lights of Key West there is a bit of America that borders on nowhere. At first sighting on a sunlit day in the Dry Tortugas, Fort Jefferson rises from the sea like a specter from a dark fable.

title: Straightening the Record
description: Alexander Dubcek, whose Prague Spring gave way to a frosty Moscow Autumn 20 years ago, is apparently hoping for a season of reconciliation. Mr. Dubcek, who was ousted as leader of the Czechoslovak Communist Party in 1968 when the Soviet Union sent troops to put an end to his experiments with democratization, harked back to those times while in Italy last week to receive an honorary degree from the University of Bologna. His nation's attempt to ''unite socialism with democracy'' would have succeeded but for Soviet intervention, said Mr. Dubcek, who disappeared from public life after his ouster.

title: Sununu as Others Know Him
description: A decisive, sometimes abrasive man: That is how some people in New Hampshire view the future White House chief of staff. Page 28.

title: Susan Hagaman Wed To Brian F. Loveman
description: At Temple Emanuel in Greensboro, N.C., Susan Elaine Hagaman, a public relations executive, and Brian Fain Loveman, a stockbroker, were married last evening by Rabbi Arnold Task.

title:
ART;
African and Pre-Columbian Works in a Charming Show
description: LEAD: THE current exhibition at the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art is there for a roundabout reason, but that doesn't make it any less charming or instructive. The gallery is now putting together a retrospective of the watercolors of Ralph Rosenborg it has arranged in New York City (Mr. Rosenborg is a veteran New Jersey artist linked to the Abstract

title: A Hidden Tresaure of Women's Humor
description: FOR centuries, people have ignored, dismissed or even failed to recognize the humor of women. That is because women's humor is unconventional, subversive and different from that of men.

title: Reviews/Dance; Idiosyncratic Vision Of Gettysburg Address
description: Linda Mussmann blends speech, movement and inventive visual effects into an unusually smooth and thought-provoking whole. Provocatively, too, she is dealing with historical themes at this point in her career as a director, writer and designer. And she chooses her casts well, filling historical and contemporary roles with the performers who make the characters seem their own. But her ''Go Between Gettysburg,'' performed on Tuesday and throughout the week at the Theater of the Riverside Church, is a disappointment.

title: Breaking a Taboo, to a Child's Delight
description: PARENTS have always been the guardians at the gate of potential danger for their children. Since there are different degrees of danger, children rely on parents to provide an honest hierarchy.

title: Mileposts Along the Overseas Highway
description: THE highway mile markers in the Florida Keys once aided the driver as the sextant aided the explorer. Like highway mile posts in rural Alaska today, these state-posted markers were the surest reference for the traveler, and all directions in the Keys were given in mile markers. Today they are still there on the Overseas Highway, or U.S. 1, stretching about 100 miles from Key Largo to Key West. But they are obscured and largely obsolete as driver aids, just one more reminder of the Keys that are no more.

title: The Whole Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Condo Lingo
description: To the Editor: I was appalled that you saw fit to print the disrespectful article about condo living.

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: Charles Peters of The Washington Monthly is quoted in your article as saying ''. . . it is shocking for my Aunt Alice to be able to use her Social Security to go to Europe, which she does.''

title: >Goodbye to an Old Friend, My '66 Iron
description: WHEN I plugged in my iron and it refused to heat up, I was surprised and distressed.

title: IT'S UP TO WOMEN
description: THE HAT OF MY MOTHER By Max Steele. 185 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $13.95.

title: Cuomo's War; Lilco's Victory?
description: In order to intelligently evaluate the Shoreham settlement one has to actually read it or risk falling victim to the ''media blitz'' William Wrigg mentioned in his article [ ''Cuomo's War, Lilco's Deal,'' Oct. 16 ] .

title: U.S. and Europe Near Trade War Over Hormone Use in Beef Cattle
description: The United States and the 12-nation European Community moved to the brink of a trade war today over the Community's ban on use of growth hormones in beef cattle.

title: What's the Law in China? It's No Secret (Finally)
description: China will no longer classify as secret the new national laws that local citizens and foreigners are obliged to obey, according to China's official newspapers.

title: Changes in Military Training Recommended
description: A Congressional panel proposed Friday that professional military education be substantially reshaped to put greater emphasis on strategy and joint operations.

title: Sit-In Ends at SUNY-Binghamton; Pact Is Reached on Crime and Bias
description: Students at the State University of New York campus here called off a 37-hour sit-in at the administration building early today after university officials agreed to address their concerns about ethnic and sexual prejudice and sexual crimes.

title: Jennifer L. Root Weds a Physician
description: Jennifer Lynne Root, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen W. Root of Tampa, Fla., was married there yesterday to Dr. Peter Lee Mayer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Mayer of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi David J. Susskind performed the ceremony at the Hyatt Regency Westshore.

title: Wagner Tumbles in Overtime
description: It took more than the regulation 60 minutes yesterday, but Ithaca made certain that there would be no national championship celebration on Staten Island this year.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: I think that Rodney Peete of U.S.C. should win. Not only is he having an excellent season, but in the last two games before yesterday he passed for more than 300 yards in each. SETH GROSSBARD Millwood, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: More Puzzling Matters

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: Each time I read an article like John Tierney's, I pull out my checkbook and make another contribution to a senior political-action committee. As a matter of fact, I have stopped sending money to my political party and devote all my contributions to the senior cause now. Ironically, this essentially defensive reaction has strengthened senior organizations to the point that they may be able to regain some of the ground lost in the last decade, and that would be only simple justice.

title: Blue Hill Show Combines Painting, Sculpture
description: AT the Blue Hill Cultural Center here is a double bill featuring Francoise Gilot and Minoru Niizuma. The catalogue says that when the two artists met 10 years ago each experienced an immediate esthetic rapport. As to the nature of this rapport, both the catalogue and the work remain mum. But more of this later.

title: FLASHBACKS: Along the Broadway Bazaar
description: BETWEEN WEST 106TH and West 111th Streets, Broadway is a wonderland, a six-block dance through the Western Hemisphere. Going out to mail a letter courts sensory overload.

title: Rabbinical College Is Attracting Families
description: LEAD: FROM the outside, the newly constructed married students' apartments at the Rabbinical College of America here look like those on any other college campus. But the residents do not dress like typical students: the men have long beards and wear black coats and hats; the women are modestly clothed in dresses and skirts and have their heads covered.

title: Police Train for the Drug
description: LEAD: THE three officers circled the house quickly and then, with their semiautomatic pistols drawn, bounded stealthily up the wooden steps to the apartment entrance. ''Come out, now!'' one yelled. ''We have a warrant.'' After a few moments the house was still silent. The officers exchanged anxious glances and continued to grip their weapons tightly with both hands.

title: Some Unions Make a Move Against Kock
description: Some of New York City's most politically active unions are involved in an effort to organize an anti-Koch coalition for the next mayoral campaign, a significant development in a city that was once known as a labor town.

title: THE WORLD: No Giants in Sight; After Deng, the Committee of Five
description: FOR most of the history of the People's Republic of China, there have been larger-than-life commanders at the helm, giants like Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai and, to a lesser degree, China's current leader, Deng Xiaoping. But these days, as the 84-year-old Mr. Deng seems finally to be showing signs of his age, the giants have been replaced by a committee.

title: Curb on AIDS Testing Upheld
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court has unanimously overturned regulations that would have banned AIDS testing for health insurance and some disability and life insurance coverage.

title: City Ballet at 40: Balanchine's Legacy Lives
description: George Balanchine is dead. Any appraisal of the New York City Ballet on its 40th anniversary must begin with this fact and its finality. As the City Ballet prepares to celebrate its first four decades, the question of its future direction becomes as important as its contribution to the past.

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: Social Security is entirely self-financing, including provision for cost-of-living adjustments. It has a tremendous surplus against the day when the baby-boomers who don't expect to get their fair share back reach 65.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Columbus, Ga.;
Old Mill Stream, New Luxury
description: LEAD: SPURRED by better highways and economic diversification that has brought more jobs and higher incomes, developers are creating luxury communities along the Chattahoochee River, which separates Columbus, Ga., and Phenix City, Ala.

title: 1 for Afternoon Tea, 1 for Eggs
description: INVETERATE shoppers who enjoy browsing from town to town in Fairfield County have long lamented the absence of an attractive place in which to have a post-shopping, English-style afternoon tea.

title: Quayle Says His Work Will Take Care of Image
description: Dan Quayle admits that his image was badly battered in the political campaign by charges that neither by character nor experience was he up to the job of Vice President. But the Vice President-elect says his task now is not to concentrate on rehabilitating that image but rather to serve George Bush totally.

title: Help for War Memorial
description: One family traveled from the Southwest last Christmas to see the black granite obelisk with the names of the 215 Westchester men killed or missing in action in the Vietnam War. But their winter journey to Lasdon Park in Somers ended at the closed iron gate that marks the entrance to the county-owned site. The county ordered the gates shut, fearful of liability claims if visitors should slip and fall at the unpaved site.

title: THE JOKE'S ON US
description: There's probably no better tool for coping with the frustrations of New York City than a sense of humor (perhaps a dark one, with an edge to it), or a sense of whimsy, or of the absurd. Wisecracks, puns and one-liners are the stuff of daily life here, and the generic New York joke has been a staple for humorists since Mark Twain.

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: It may be that no society can afford to pay adequate retirement benefits to its senior citizens. However, it is more likely that paying the elderly a fair share of the gross national product, as well as paying workers a fair wage, is precisely what makes our capitalism work. REV. RICHARD D. HUNTER Clifton Park, N.Y.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Phoenix
description: Outdoor recreation is the major draw to what Arizonans call the Valley of Sun - that is Phoenix and the surrounding cities of Scottsdale, Tempe and Mesa. Phoenix has more than 1,000 tennis courts and 90 golf courses within its 400 square miles. The mild climate encourages these sports, and others, such as hang-gliding and hot-air ballooning. The annual statistics tell the weather story: about 300 sunny days and seven inches of rain.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
The Office Vacancy Rate Rises to 22.1%
description: LEAD: THE state's office market ended the third quarter this year much as it began the first quarter - with a big oversupply of space. Of the 87.2 million square feet of offices currently in the 11-county northern portion of the state, 19.2 million are empty - a vacancy rate of 22.1 percent, up 0.25 percent from the start of 1988.

title: POSTINGS: Queens Mini-mall; Multiplex Twist
description: In a switch on the multiplex cinema, the old Madison Theater just reopened in Ridgewood, Queens, with 200 ''compartment stores'' and is now known as the Busy Bee mini-mall.

title:
SMALL PRESSES IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books.

title: Athletes Go For the Money
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Two Soloists Make a Different Kind of Duo
description: A glance through the Lincoln Center Great Performers schedule for this season reveals an unusual number of recitals billed as duos rather than solo turns. This afternoon, the violinist Elmar Oliveira and the pianist Horacio Gutierrez take the stage together. Upcoming combinations include the pianist Bella Davidovich and the violinist Dmitri Sitkovetsky, who are also mother and son; Shlomo Mintz and Yefim Bronfman, violin and piano, and James Levine with (one at a time) the singers Christa Ludwig, Elisabeth Soderstrom, Dawn Upshaw and Tatiana Troyanos.

title: Sununu Is Called Smart, Decisive and Impatient
description: People here who have watched John H. Sununu closely in his three terms as Governor say that when people walk in the door of the White House to make a pitch Mr. Sununu will already have made up his mind.

title: Wedding Is Planned By Diane Debrovner
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Debrovner of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter Diane Hope Debrovner to Charles Stanwood Carignan, a son of Elizabeth G. Pulver of Wells, Me., and Francis Carignan of Freeport, Me. The couple plan a June wedding.

title: Columbia Does It Again
description: WHILE some Baker Field regulars were off witnessing the Mets and the Dodgers in their aquatic Jay-Howell-pine-tar game on Oct. 8, Columbia was busting Princeton for its first victory after 44 straight losses.

title: Impetus For Reflection
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese A.D.R.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaction Mixed to U.S. Random Drug Testing Plan
description: A Federal proposal to require random drug testing of four million transportation workers has drawn anger from union leaders and support from managers of transportation companies.

title: When Eight Carriers Call the Shots
description: When airlines recently announced that they were raising their ticket prices yet again, academics and consumer advocates were quick to sound the death knell of airline competition and lament the failure of deregulation.

title: FLASHBACKS: Back to Bay Ridge
description: Bay Ridge, in my memory, is where my grandfather drove the Borden's Milk wagon up to the house every morning to get his breakfast, in the middle of his route. He came into the house on Sixth Avenue, and my grandmother gave him eggs and sausages and bakery rolls for the drippings, and the white horse ate from the oat bag tied around his nose. I never got to give him a piece of sugar, Grampa's orders.

title: Homeless Get Ticket To Leave
description: Church Street Marketplace is a merchant's dream: a cobblestone mall ringed by the sort of trendy boutiques and cafes that attract the affluent shoppers of this prosperous city. But the area also attracts street people, who are not so welcome.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The former executive director of the National Invitation Tournament, Pete Carlesimo, has been voted a perpetual honor. The championship trophy for the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament has been named for him. . . . . . . Janet Evans, who won three gold medals in swimming at the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, will serve as grand marshal of the Fiesta Bowl parade in Phoenix Dec. 31.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Berlin, Md.;
Doorstep Golf Near the Ocean
description: LEAD: RIVER RUN, a $50 million golf condominium community is under construction just a few miles west of Maryland's Atlantic beaches. The first models are scheduled to open in April.

title: POSTINGS: French for Jersey; A Little Love and Joy for Each House
description: Jacques Teze, who from 1964 to 1968 was president of the French Builders Association in Paris, has been working in the United States for 15 years, but he still tries to put a little francais into his jobs. Sometimes it's in the name: Lafayette Place in Boston or L'Appartement in Manhattan. This time, he said, at StoneHedge in Stockholm, N.J., it's in the architectural details and in the brass shields to be attached to the entrances of the 45 houses in the development. Each shield will bear the image of trees and an American eagle and the words ''Amour et Joie,'' meaning love and joy - ''the best you can wish to people moving into a new house,'' Mr. Teze said. The plaques are being made by Les Metalliers Champenois of Paris and Paterson, N.J., who helped restore the Statue of Liberty's copper skin and flame.

title: Baseball Notebook; Bo Jackson's Contacts Swing From Backfield to the Outfield
description: Before Bo Jackson suffered a devastating hamstring tear two months into the past season, he seemed to have finally figured out the difference between his two vocations. In autumn, he is supposed to try to avoid making contact; in the summer, he is supposed to try to make contact.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
An Export Surge Brings Few Cheers
description: LEAD: The trade deficit shrank by $1.8 billion in September, to $10.5 billion. Exports rose sharply, to a record $28.2 billion, while imports fell. The result was welcome, but the surge in exports caused new worries that the American economy is growing fast enough to make inflation a problem. That conviction was supported by reports that retail sales gained nine-tenths of a percent in October, the strongest increase in seven months; that housing construction rose 7.2 percent in October, its biggest jump in eight months, and that industrial production advanced four-tenths of a percent in October.

title: New York Dissolves Units That Claimed To Fight Child Abuse
description: Two groups that had claimed to protect children from cruelty have been dissolved on grounds that they served no public purpose and ''merely gave their agents the opportunity to carry guns and feel important,'' state officials said this week.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'INDEX' ART

title: FLASHBACKS: Before El Barrio
description: I came to New York in 1957, young and full of dreams. In those days I wanted two things: to become a boxing champion and to live near my uncle, Miguel Flores. Since coming here as a merchant seaman in the 1930's, he had lived in Brooklyn, the place he called ''the cradle of the first Puerto Rican community in this country.'' I was an angry young man then, proud of my Puerto Rican heritage and just out of the United States Army, where I had experienced the lessons of racism and prejudice.

title: NONFICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. OFF THE COAST OF HISTORY

title: Teamster Local, Once Run by Mob, Tries the Ballot Box
description: JUDGMENT DAY is near for the Federal Government's most ambitious effort to restore internal democracy to a racketeer-controlled union local.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Without a doubt this year's Heisman should go to Barry Sanders of Oklahoma State. His 31 touchdowns and 186 points scored are both N.C.A.A. single-season records. Anyone who witnessed his performance against Oklahoma Nov. 5 knows he ranks among the great running backs like Herschel Walker, O. J. Simpson, Tony Dorsett and the two-time Heisman Trophy winner, Archie Griffin. BILL ELLIS Smithtown, N.Y.

title: Nicaraguans Crowd the Miami Welcome Mat
description: From the street, the storefront here looks festive, its window covered by a giant blue and white flag of Nicaragua, photographs of a smiling Pope John Paul II and a poster announcing ''Gran Fiesta Danzante'' (''A Big Dance Party'').

title: 10-0 Irish Send Penn State to 5-6
description: Notre Dame celebrated its Fiesta Bowl invitation today by doing the thing it did all season in order to earn the invitation: winning.

title: Can He Save Mexico?
description: EARLY IN THE DAY, small knots of supplicants and well-wishers begin forming outside an elaborately carved door that opens onto 90 Cracovia Street, on the south side of Mexico City. As they linger near the gate, hoping for just a glimpse of the great man inside, the limousines pull up, disgorging a steady stream of luminaries both Mexican and foreign: politicians, bankers, cabinet ministers, union leaders, ambassadors, industrialists. All are here to confer with the man who on Dec. 1 will become the leader of Mexico, President-elect Carlos Salinas de Gortari, now presiding in the quiet of his sober, wood-paneled office.

title: Harvard and U.C.L.A. Face Inquiries on Quotas
description: The Department of Education has begun inquiries to determine whether Harvard and the University of California at Los Angeles have established illegal quotas to limit the number of Asian American students they admit.

title: NEW YORK GAZETTEER
description: There are 300 neighborhoods in New York, according to the City Planning Commission, and not one has an official definition.

title: Private Rocket in Brief Flight
description: A 10-foot rocket bearing four experiments made a five-minute flight Thursday in a private commercial space venture. The tiny rocket pushed the payload container to an altitude of about 14,000 feet. The launcing by the E Prime Aerospace Company of Titusville, Fla., was the first time a privately owned rocket had been launched from either Air Force or space agency facilities here. Jim Mizell, the E Prime operations director, said the experiments on board the flight were from paying customers. He declined to say how much they had paid.

title: 'Four Days' Relives Kennedy Slaying
description: WITH ''Four Days of November,'' the play that coincides with the 25th anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy, the Clockwork Repertory Theater in Oakville is heightening its identity as a local showcase devoted to docudrama.

title: France
description: To the Editor: I think the French have gotten a bum rap.

title: Of Alcoholism And Reality
description: Re: ''Working to Defeat Alcoholism'' (New Jersey Q & A), on Oct. 30:

title: Banks Prepare for Aggressive Growth
description: LEAD: MOTIVATED by increasing competition and restless shareholders, some well-known Long Island savings banks are evolving from complacent local institutions into aggressive players in the financial world.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Oklahoma State's Barry Sanders is simply having the best year of any college running back in history.

title: Worst Year for Forest Fires Is Over
description: The nation's worst season of forest fires since the 1920's is ending, after flame fed by drought swept more than six million acres, left 10 firefighters dead and cost the Federal Government $583.8 million.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Worcester Mass.;
Paul Revere Gets a Skywalk
description: LEAD: THE Paul Revere Insurance Group is nearing completion of a year-long, $7 million renovation of a former high school for use as office space. Occupancy of the old North High Annex at the corner of Walnut and Eden Streets is scheduled for January.

title: GROWING UP IN JERUSALEM
description: Richard Selzer's article made me remember a winter in Idaho, when I was 12. The deer had not migrated south before a big snow, and coyotes were waiting as the deer struggled to free themselves from the drifts. We were small children, not guides, and we had no weapons, but we spent days and nights chasing those cowardly killers with sticks and shouts and anything else we could muster. The deer were stuck, they were outnumbered, and we did everything in our power to save them.

title: Running the Risk Of Banishment
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Adventures For Flute And Piano
description: There was another inventive and substantial addition to New York's recital life - this one at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night. It featured Sue Ann Kahn and Andrew Willis in an evening of flute and piano music and was only the latest in a series of unrelated concerts small and large during this young season that have abandoned the safe and the cliched and moved toward more adventurous music. Dare we hope for a trend?

title: Correction
description: A table on Oct. 23 with an article about European trade omitted the value of goods and services imported by the European Community from the five nations of the European Free Trade Association. Switzerland should have been third on the list (after the United States and Japan), with $30.6 billion; Sweden fourth, with $23.2 billion; Austria fifth, with $17.5 billion; Norway seventh (after the Soviet Union), with $14.1 billion, and Finland eighth, with $9.2 billion.

title: Review/Dance; Twins' Secret World
description: Fred Holland has put together an evening of absorbing, highly imaginative theater-dance in ''What I Like About Us . . . ,'' which will be presented at the Kitchen through Sunday. Mr. Holland has promising material to work with in the story of June and Jennifer Gibson, English twin sisters who remained silent to the outside world but created a separate reality for themselves that was depicted in ''The Silent Twins,'' a recent book, and a television special of the same name. And with one or two very small exceptions, there is not an unnecessary or wrong-seeming moment in this eerie reconstruction of the twins' world.

title: Pro Bono Work is Good for Business
description: LEAD: WHEN Davidoff and Partners, an advertising and public relations agency in Westport, agreed to create a promotion campaign pro bono for a children's advocacy group, the company's president, Denny Davidoff, was simply practicing what she preaches.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 6 about management changes at the Omnicom Group of advertising agencies misstated the company's ranking. It is the world's third-largest advertising-agency group. The second-largest is the Interpublic Group.

title: Raising the Roof
description: What's a 10,000-square-foot domicile without a dome?

title: GOING TO EXTREMES
description: THE ARCTIC GRAIL By Pierre Berton. Illustrated. 672 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: GROWING UP IN JERUSALEM
description: I left Jerusalem in 1979, after living there for nine years. In return visits, I have seen the growing contrast between the two sides of the city. In the West city, millions of dollars have been spent on parks, shopping centers, apartment complexes, hotels, cultural centers and playgrounds. In the East city, neglect is ever more apparent. The old border cutting through the city is a rubble-strewn scar, which Mayor Kollek's 50,000 tulips cannot hide.

title: Mileage Points Can Fly Away
description: AIRLINES can act like careless lovers. Oh, they lure you into their frequent travel program with wonderful promises and then when you ask for proof of their good intentions, they turn around and act as if they never met you.

title: STREETSCAPES: Washington Mews; Gates for Protection Against The Threatening City Beyond
description: THE cobblestoned Washington Mews is one of the most unusual lanes in Manhattan, its converted two-story stables making it a sort of retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city. Originally open, then later closed by gates, the Mews was open again after 1916.

title: Editors' Note
description: A review of ''Bob Knight: His Own Man'' by Joan Mellen, about the Indiana basketball coach, appeared in The Times Book Review on Oct. 30.

title: Tchaikovsky's Death - The Riddle Endures
description: Lives of great men do not only remind us that we can make our lives sublime. Read with a suitably cold eye, they also remind us that personal history and myth want to tangle and merge. In the hands of many biographers, truth and fact become illusions or malleable intellectual concepts, as in the work of the more dogmatic literary Deconstructionists. Myth, they argue with Joseph Campbell, can be a higher form of truth. Some historians are more rigorous in method than others, of course, but even the most scholarly attempt to recapture a celebrated life must often rely on second-hand anecdotes, doctored or suppressed documents and faulty memories. So, biography must always be regarded skeptically: at best as an unfinished portrait, at worst as a fable with footnotes. The bit of history/myth I wish to deal with today is the unresolved and by now probably unresolvable mystery of Tchaikovsky's death, the subject of rumor and speculation for nearly a century. We still do not know beyond question whether he died in 1893 of cholera, as virtually all biographers accepted until recent years, or if he may have committed suicide for dark reasons growing out of his homosexual entanglements and fear of creating a scandal that could destroy his family.

title: Condo Lingo
description: To the Editor: In her attempt to be humorous, Carol Cott Gross (''Condo Spoken Here,'' Travel, Oct. 16) displays an amazing lack of both sense and sensibility. The elderly people in Florida who worked hard all their lives, in most cases, to buy those condos and not be a burden to their children up north, should be admired instead of ridiculed. How easy it is to make fun of them now!

title: Nonprofit Groups Protest change in Slaes-Tax Law on Fuel Bills
description: WHEN the bright green fuel truck rolled up to the service entrance right on schedule this month, the manager of the 20 buildings of the Community Housing Management Corporation in Elmsford was pleased - until he got the bill.

title: Two Voices Born From Gospel In Search of Soul
description: The first thing that stands up and asks to be noticed on both Etta James's ''Seven Year Itch'' (Island 7 91018-2; all three formats) and Anita Baker's ''Giving You the Best That I Got'' (Elektra 9 60827-2; all three formats) is the production: the way the sound on the recordings is conceived and presented. Ms. James's, raw and tough, redolent of Southern soul but updated in a rock style, is radically different from Ms. Baker's restrained, puffy sophistication. Records are meant to sell, and these sounds, more than the songs themselves, let us in on whom the records are intended for and what message each is trying to promote.

title: XX, XY AND WHY
description: THE FEMALE ANIMAL By Irene Elia. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: A Donald Hutter Book/ Henry Holt & Company. $21.95.

title: Pricing a Home in a Mushy Market
description: DURING the 11 years that she has sold real estate among the tall trees and quiet streets of Montclair, N.J., Irene Brenneis has had to set prices on hundreds of homes. But for a particular three-bedroom colonial on Central Avenue she handled recently, she knew she would have to pinpoint just the right price or bear the blast of complaints from the sellers, her 29-year-old son, Mark, and his wife, Nora, who planned to buy another house in town.

title: Troop 315: Boy Scouts of Merit
description: LEAD: ON paper, the accomplishments of Boy Scout Troop 315 hardly seem unusual. Last year, the troop worked on and received merit badges in athletics, scholarship and journalism. This year members are going for art, theater, personal safety and golf.

title: The Fit Of a Princess
description: Remember the princess wrap dress? The handiwork of Diane Von Furstenberg, it flourished in the mid-1970's, when most women were in blue jeans or pants suits. It flattered most figures and could be tossed in the washing machine.

title: Broken Line Disrupts Airport
description: Dozens of flights were disrupted and scores of passengers were delayed at the San Francisco International Airport Friday after contractors broke a 12-inch underground jet fuel line near a terminal. Incoming flights were diverted to other West Coast airports, and numerous departing flights were delayed several hours, said an airport spokesman, Ron Wilson. The pipeline break affected supplies to all three terminals, he said.

title: Beth Susan Trueman To Wed Paul F. Cody
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Trueman of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter Beth Susan Trueman to Paul Frederick Cody, a son of Rosemarie Cody of Quincy, Mass., and the late Frederick M. Cody. The couple plan to wed next summer.

title: An Unusual Tree
description: COMPOST leaves and garden refuse. Last call to dig, dry and store tender tubers such as those of tuberous begonias, dahlias, caladiums. Clean and store power tools. Pull up stakes and store. Clean hand tools and coat with rust inhibitor. Deciduous Conifer

title: Plan for More Parking In Manhasset Subsides
description: LEAD: A FLURRY of excitement in Manhasset over the prospect of increased parking capability at the Long Island Rail Road station on Plandome Road seems to have subsided as the result of official assurances that no action will be taken without community approval.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; The Race Is On for the First Regional Mall
description: IN a fast-developing area southwest of Hartford, the City of Waterbury and the Towns of Cheshire and Plainville are in a heated race to get the first regional shopping mall, with around a million square feet of space.

title: Walt Whitman Ideal
description: O I see flashing that this America is only you and me, . . . Freedom, language, poems, employments, are you and me, Past, present, future, are you and me. I dare not shirk any part of myself. . . . - ''By Blue Ontario's Shore,'' Walt Whitman

title: From Royal Court To Rustic Colony
description: Baroque splendors - sumptuous silver wine coolers, elaborately painted cabinets, tasseled textiles in jewel colors and a chimney wall covered to the ceiling with blue-and-white porcelains - await at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street. The exhibition ''Courts and Colonies: The William and Mary Style in Holland, England and America'' impressively documents the regal architectural style that reigned in the late 17th century on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-22

title: PROUST AND A DOG
description: MARJORIE KINNAN RAWLINGS Sojourner at Cross Creek. By Elizabeth Silverthorne. Illustrated. 374 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $19.95.

description: Hieng Sieng, a thin and nervous man who is 41 years old, was conscripted to work as a porter for the Khmer Rouge three times, carrying Chinese ammunition, mines and mortar shells into Cambodia under heavy guard. Between March 1987 and last month, Hin Hon, 25, was impressed seven times for the same task.

title: A Century of History for the Hobbyists
description: SCOTT'S has just issued the fourth and last volume of its alphabetical listing of stamps of the world. Now that the basic series is complete for this year (a specialized catalogue of United States stamps is due this month), and the flap over Scott's price revisions has died down, it may be restful to look back to the very first Scott catalogue. That first catalogue, published in September 1868, has recently been reprinted.
