title: New Campus Notes
description: LEAD: ''WE have a rather fearsome looking studio,'' said James McElwaine, a professor of music at the State University of New York campus here. ''We have thousands of knobs, and racks and racks of equipment. And as impressive as it is, it's a drop in the bucket compared to the ones in the 'real' world.''

title: THIS ABOVE ALL: BE CLEAR
description: LEAD: One should never impose limits or rules on creative writing. Those who do generally obey political taboos or atavistic fears: actually, a written text no matter how it is written, is less dangerous than is commonly thought; the famous judgment passed on Silvio Pellico's ''My Prisons,'' which supposedly harmed Austria ''more than a lost battle,'' is hyperbolic.

title: Hovercraft Trips
description: To the Editor: We want to alert other travelers to avoid a problem that we encountered. After buying round-trip Hovercraft/rail tickets between London and Brussels, we began our trip at Victoria Station. A uniformed gateman checked our tickets and, as is done at airport boarding gates, removed a part of each ticket before returning them and waving us through.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: THE bride is always beautiful and the bridesmaids are - well, put it this way, they aren't what they used to be. At least not always. They are, increasingly, not only an extra added attraction but the source of raised eyebrows, bulging eyeballs and astonished murmurs. These days, bridesmaids, some of them, wear black. This isn't a revolt on the part of bridesmaids fed to the teeth with wearing pastels and later trying to convert fluffy orchid or pale yellow tulle into passable dinner dresses. Rather, it is almost always the bride's idea, for any one of a number of reasons. Sometimes, it's because she's basically a nonconformist, a bit of a rebel. Sometimes (and not infrequently), it's because she and her attendants are young but no longer dewy-eyed teen-agers.

title:
FOOD;
Savoring Spain
description: LEAD: The three-year-old Harlequin Restaurant in New York City wears a new striped awning announcing ''Alta Cocina Espanola.'' ''At first, we deliberately kept our Spanish connection low key,'' says Ileana Barcena, co-owner and wife of the chef Jose Barcena. ''We wanted to avoid being cast aside as just another among dozens of Spanish restaurants.

title: Gorbachev Faults U.S. On Afghan Agreement
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that the United States and Pakistan appear intent on forcing Moscow to abandon the accords providing for a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: NONFICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. THE UNDERGROUND ARMY: Fighters of the Bialystok Ghetto. By Chaika Grossman. Edited by Sol Lewis. Translated by Shmuel Beeri. (Holocaust Library, 216 West 18th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $10.95.) Chaika Grossman was a principal organizer of the revolt against the Nazis in the ghetto in Bialystok, Poland, during the war and one of the few who survived it. She later immigrated to Israel where she was active in politics and in 1986 was elected deputy speaker of the Knesset. Now her story, which first appeared in Hebrew in 1949, has been published in a readable English translation. As a ''privileged'' Jew - that is, one with blue eyes and blond hair - Ms. Grossman passed herself off easily as an Aryan and acted as a go-between for the various ghettos in Poland and Lithuania, smuggling weapons for her comrades. ''The Underground Army'' is written in a straightforward and dispassionate style. Even the head of the Bialystok Judenrat, the Jewish organization that collaborated with the Germans, appears as a sort of decent man who tried his best at a time when traditional moral codes had broken down. At times some readers might become disoriented by the rapid pace of Ms. Grossman's narrative, but that flaw is outweighed by the author's vivid attention to day-to-day life, with episodes full of peril and suspense.

title: 'Coriolanus': A 20th-Century Power Play
description: Shakespeare's ''Coriolanus,'' the tale of Rome's great warrior, has received only flickering attention over the last two centuries, when it was staged as often in adaptations as in its original shape. But Shakespeare's own play has been steadily performed and scrutinized since the 1930's, in part because it is a work that speaks directly, and ominously, to the politics of our times. Though the late scholar James E. Phillips wrote that T. S. Eliot's ''Coriolan'' fragments promoted this intenser interest, the rise of Fascism is the more probable cause. (Or is that saying the same thing? Eliot's poems end with a quote from the proto-Fascist Charles Maurras.) Though the play, drawn from Plutarch's ''Lives,'' takes place early in the Roman Republic, the new production (in Joseph Papp's series of the complete plays) is set in the late 1920's, when Fascism, royalism, corporatism and other forms of stricter authority were being advanced and resisted. The New York Shakespeare Festival production, directed by Steven Berkoff and starring Christopher Walken in the title role and Irene Worth as Volumnia, opens Tuesday at the Public Theater.

title: Outdoors; Wood Fires Under Scrutiny
description: The National Wildlife Federation recently had some chilling news for those who have long warmed their hearts and hands before a wood fire, but the situation is not as depressing as it first seemed to be.

title: Cape May To Become Dickensian
description: LEAD: IT could be said that if ever there is a town that knows how to keep Christmas well, it is Cape May.

title: 12 Personal Favorites
description: They've been to a Broadway show, peered out from the Empire State Building and strolled through the World Trade Center. They've had a meal in Chinatown and seen the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall. Where else can you take your out-of-town friends?

title: Bell Is Back
description: The Kansas City Chiefs reactivated defensive end Mike Bell yesterday. Bell served a 30-day suspension for violating the N.F.L.'s substance-abuse policy. He was suspended Oct. 21 after failing a drug test. The 1979 first-round draft choice of the Chiefs, Bell was convicted in Federal District Court in Wichita, Kan., in June 1986 of two counts of using a telephone to facilitate distribution of cocaine and one count of attempting to possess cocaine. He served four months of a one-year prison term.(AP)

title: New 'Breakfast of Champions': A Recipe for Victory or Disaster?
description: After 30 years of scientific uncertainty about whether anabolic steroids can enhance athletic performance, medical opinion is slowly tilting toward the conclusion that steroids do help some athletes add muscle bulk and weight, and even set world records.

title: College in Middle Over 'Health' Film
description: LEAD: A Nassau Community College health course that includes the showing of a film that depicts sexual intercourse drew criticism last week because, among other reasons, it is taught in a ''value-neutral'' manner.

title: In Racial Politics, Democrats Losing More Than Elections
description: ONE of the Democratic party's biggest political problems is as clear as black and white. Among black voters, Michael S. Dukakis was overwhelmingly elected President. But among white voters, and hence the nation at large, he lost decisively to George Bush.

title: Four Million More Subjects; Drug-Testing Technology Speeds Up
description: WITH drug screening of private employees on the rise and the largest Government-mandated program yet on the horizon, even people in the drug-testing business worry about human error and privacy issues. But they have few doubts about the technical capability for accurate and sensitive testing.

title: Linda G. McCausland to Wed in April
description: The engagement of Linda Gamble McCausland to William Joseph Davis 3d, the son of Mrs. Davis Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Davis, has been made known by her parents, Mrs. William F. Waddington of Mendham, N.J., and Robert G. McCausland of Hamilton, Bermuda. An April wedding is planned.

description: FARM acreage in Connecticut dropped more than 10 percent from 1982 to 1987, but farm income rose by more than 30 percent, according to a Federal agricultural census released last week.

Flickinger of Middlebury, Vt., and James Bruce Witkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Witkin of Philadelphia, took place yesterday at the Rockville (Md.) Civic Center Manor. The Rev. Harry V. Quiett, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
New-Home Buyers Getting Concessions

title: Miss Daisy Goes Home To Atlanta
description: I don't wish to debunk a southern myth, but you can go home again. I just did it. I returned to Atlanta recently for the local premiere of my play, ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' which is, in turn, about memories from my Atlanta childhood. More particularly, memories of my grandmother, who was Jewish, and her chauffeur, who was black. It was a week of interconnecting wheels, recorded as follows:

title: State Helping Laid-Off Staff In Campaigns
description: Workers laid off from the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis can turn to his administration's employment program for help in finding new jobs. Unemployed workers of the campaign for Vice President Bush are welcome, too.

title: To Commute Is to Meditate
description: I SPEND three hours of my life every working day rocking and rolling on a bus on the New Jersey Turnpike with 50 strangers - and I have grown to love it. It used to be hard to think of it as anything but a waste of time. Now I realize that commuting is a form of meditation.

description: One person was killed and 10 others were injured yesterday in an explosion at a vacant warehouse in in Smithtown, L.I., that was apparently caused by a ruptured gas line.

description: Is the International Olympic Committee in danger of killing the goose that laid the golden egg? I believe so, unless the I.O.C. rethinks its objectives and procedures regarding Olympic television.

description: The last of the great sailing records - an 89-day-8-hour passage in 1854 of the clipper ship Flying Cloud from New York to San Francisco - could be toppled this winter.

description: At an upstart private school here, there are no lush green playing fields sporting finely tailored teams. The number of personal computers would evoke envy in only the poorest of public schools.

To some, the White House and the Washington Monument symbolize the capital of the free world; to others, they epitomize the trappings of a company town. The Capitol building and the Pentagon can evoke images of dedicated Government servants or of greedy lobbyists.

title: 4,478 Signatures
description: The Times reported recently on a new disposable $2 fountain pen that writes for 3,000 feet before the non-smudging ink runs dry. How many signatures, the writer wondered, could be written with 3,000 feet of ink? The answer, writes Richard G. Hawn, a good-natured engineer from Erie, Pa., is 4,478, at least if your name is Richard G. Hawn.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Arverne Plan; Oceanfront Site Terms Challenge Builders
description: THE name ''Arverne'' is synonymous with urban-renewal deadlock, although it should evoke the excitement of development opportunity. Except for a cluster of high-density rentals put up for low-income tenants in the early 70's and a small community of older houses that survived the demolitions of the site-preparation process in the 60's, this 308-acre oceanfront tract on Rockaway Peninsula in Queens is barren.

title: Restarting Radiators
description: RESTARTING hot water or steam radiators at the beginning of a new heating season may produce a few surprises. Insufficient heat, minor leakage and noises all are common symptoms.

title: Criticism on Halting Of Microwave Study
description: STATE public health officials have halted a study to determine whether radiation from a large satellite communications industry here is responsible for what residents say is an abnormally high level of birth defects in this rural township. The officials cited not being able to find an appropriate method to measure microwave exposure as the major reason for curtailing the study without conclusive findings.

title:
GARDENING;
Native Persimmon Can Hold Head High
description: LEAD: A PERSON savoring a ripe native persimmon for the first time must feel he has discovered ambrosia. The flesh literally melts in the mouth and leaves an aftertaste akin to an apricot.

title: Leveling Taxes . . . Taxing 'Abuse'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rome Picnics
description: To the Editor: Another great spot for a picnic lunch on one of Rome's seven hills (''Picnicking Atop the City's Seven Hills,'' Travel, Oct. 23) is the Arancio (Orange Tree) Park, so named for its grove of glossy-leaved orange trees, on the northwest corner of the Aventine Hill. The spectacular sweep of Rome, ranging from Trastevere to the ''wedding cake'' Victor Emmanuel II Memorial, rivals the view from the Janiculum Hill mentioned in the article. But perhaps a picnic supper is a better idea. Viewing the gorgeous sunsets over the Tiber seems to be a Roman tradition; whole families gather late in the day for the spectacle, and while the soccer-playing children seem unimpressed, the lovers seem especially inspired by the flaming sun. JUNE OLIANSKY Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Prenatal Tests Increase Options
description: SEVERAL months ago, when 33-year-old Elizabeth Birmingham of Babylon was encouraged by her obstetrician to have amniocentesis, she said she did not think twice.

title: A Perfect Ending By West Virginia
description: In an unusual pregame locker-room ceremony tonight, West Virginia formally accepted a bid to meet Notre Dame in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl Jan. 2. Then the Mountaineers went out and completed the first undefeated and untied football season in their history by trouncing Syracuse, 31-9, in a cold rain.

title: Will It Make Canada the 51st State?
description: When Canadians vote in a general election tomorrow, they will be deciding the fate of the free-trade agreement between Canada and the United States. The agreement, already approved by Congress and signed by President Reagan, would, over a 10-year period, eliminate all remaining tariffs on $150 billion in annual trade between the two countries. It would also eliminate or lower non-tariff barriers in areas ranging from agriculture to energy to investment and other services.

title: Oiler Scores 4 To Rout Leafs
description: Glenn Anderson scored four times, tonight, including two goals 84 seconds apart in the first period that sparked Edmonton to a 9-1 rout of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Q and A
description: Down to Rio

title: In the New TV Season, The Tint Is Blue
description: Hobbled by the writers' strike, the fall season on commercial television is finally under way and its content is distinguished largely by an utter shapelessness. The one new wrinkle seems to be a preference for adding more shocking shades of blue material.

title: Heavy Industry Is Up, and So Is a Corner of Minnesota
description: THE mines are busy again on Minnesota's Iron Range, working at near capacity to feed iron ore to the resurgent steel mills of Cleveland and Gary and Chicago.

title: De Chirico - Life After Death In Venice
description: Long before his death 10 years ago at the age of 90, Giorgio de Chirico had passed away, so far as many painters and critics were concerned. Having created, between 1910 and 1920, canvases of deserted piazzas whose eerie stillness inspired the likes of Andre Breton, Max Ernst, Rene Magritte and Yves Tanguy, the artist vigorously renounced his links to Modernism. What he ceaselessly churned out during the last half-century of his career - copies of works by Old Masters, portraits, still lifes and scenes of gladiators, horses and ancient temples - came to be seen by detractors as products of a daft and cynical painter hewing to outmoded ideas.

title: A Pitfall
description: To the Editor:

title: BeeBee Horowitz Is Wed
