Rabbi Reyfield Helman performed the ceremony at the Martha's Vineyard Hebrew Center in Vineyard Haven, Mass. The bride, known as BeeBee, owns the Toy Box in Vineyard Haven. Dr. Kendall is an internist on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Why We Still Dont Believe It
description: THE TRUTH IS that Lee Harvey Oswald was the lone gunman who murdered President John F. Kennedy and Dallas Police Officer J. D. Tippit on that tragic Friday afternoon, Nov. 22, 1963, in Dallas. Yet 25 years after the event, a majority of the American public does not believe the truth. Rather, polls have shown that most Americans believe President Kennedy was assassinated as an outgrowth of a conspiracy.

title: Ms. Newburger, Producer, Weds
description: The marriage of Patricia Ann Newburger, the daughter of Shirley P. Newburger of New York, to Bradley J. Wechsler, the son of Eunice Wechsler of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Lawrence Wechsler of New York, took place last evening at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: A Measure of Success
description: If you took the 20 active college basketball coaches with the most career victories and lined them up in order, starting with the one with the highest winning percentage, how many victories would it take to make the line, and who would be at the head? Those are a couple of the questions that Elmore (Scoop) Hudgins asks himself every year in compiling his Top 20 Coaches list.

title: When 'Normal' Is Unfair
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Reasonable Dose of Wilderness
description: NUTS and berries philosophers from Thoreau to Edward Abbey insist that reasonable doses of wilderness are necessary for the mental health of urban humans.

title: Rock Label Bows on the Classical Scene
description: The classical-music record business is in a state of churning flux these days, but nobody could accuse it of inactivity. While major American companies have been sold off to foreign corporations, other, newer classical lines have been founded, expanded or revitalized. And, at long last, record companies swollen with rock profits have begun - for whatever reasons - to stretch out toward the classics (and jazz and ethnic music and new-age music, as well) to create so-called ''full line'' companies.

title: FICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. LOST RIVER. By Roger Sheffer. (Night Tree Press, R.D. 2, Box 140-G, Gorge Road Route 46, Boonville, N.Y. 13309, Paper, $14.95.) The thread that connects the tales in Roger Sheffer's fine collection of short stories is that each occurs in the fictional Adirondack township of Lost River. This section of upstate New York easily qualifies as a depressed area, a desolate place ribbed by snowmobile tracks and rarely traveled mountain trails. With little indigenous industry to sustain them, most year-round citizens exist on welfare. Those who don't live hand to mouth, earn a meager living tending bar, waiting on tables in sparsely filled diners, pumping gas or servicing the ramshackle cabins and somewhat more presentable summer camps that dot the area. Unlike other parts of the Adirondacks, Mr. Sheffer's Lost River lacks even the saving grace of being scenic: it is a spiritual and geographical dead end from which few escape. Yet its people, however desperate, have inner lives, and Mr. Sheffer writes about them very touchingly. In one of the best stories, ''Deer Flies,'' we meet Harold Shink, an outcast in a town of outcasts, who makes his living by repairing the homes of summer visitors. Shink is an inarticulate man who, as described by the owner of the local general store, ''is a fat and disgusting thing for me to look at every day.'' But he has a sensitive side, which is depicted when he shows a summer resident a hidden waterfall that only occurs after a heavy rain, a phenomenon he's named for his sister. Throughout these stories, lives intersect briefly then drift off in other directions. Some sections of ''Lost River'' are stronger and more successful than others; together, however, they create a cohesive picture of what life in this desolate section of the Adirondacks is like.

title: Greenport Queried on Wells
description: LEAD: ALMOST 10 years ago, the State Department of Environmental Conservation gave the Greenport water system permission to dig two new wells.

title: Sheep in Wolf's Clothing
description: To the Editor:

title: Handsome Dan XIII Enjoys a Dog's Life at Yale
description: AFTER a two-hour grilling, Christopher and Evelyn (Toddie) Getman of New Haven were told they would make suitable parents. ''Deals were made,'' Mr. Getman said furtively.

title: After 25 Years, His Aura Resists The Chill of History
description: FOR much of the 25 years since John F. Kennedy was killed, his death has tended to overwhelm his life, casting his Presidency as a virtuous road to martyrdom. But in recent years both that life and that Presidency have been weighed from critical perspectives that either did not exist during his thousand days or only matured later - influences like feminism, the Vietnam peace movement, the New Left and neoconservatism.

title: High Anxiety But Few Jobs In Argentina
description: Plastered with campaign posters, the School of Medicine seemed ready for a fierce ideological battle of the kind traditional in Argentine universities. Yet improving the world was not uppermost in the minds of those voting in student elections here this month.

title: 20 Years Later, No Harvard Magic
description: With just a few minutes left today in The Game and trailing by 9 points, Harvard recovered a Yale fumble. Instantly, memories of that magical Crimson comeback 20 years ago were summoned in the crowd of 36,000. In that legendary game played for the Ivy League championship, Harvard scored 16 points in the last 42 seconds to earn a tie. ''Harvard Wins 29-29,'' read The Harvard Crimson.

title: Hemingway & Co. in Key West
description: KEY WEST is no longer just a small Southern town. Since the 60's, the island has become a major international resort, attracting figures from the overlapping worlds of the arts, publishing and fashion. Even so, it keeps its large black and Cuban-American population, as well as the Conchs, white fishermen and ship workers who have lived on the island for generations.

title: FICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. METAPHYSICS IN THE MIDWEST. By Curtis White. (Sun and Moon, Cloth, $15.95; Paper, $10.95.) In his second collection of stories, Curtis White holds all-American cultural stereotypes up to a fun-house mirror. Reflected is a splintered, disjointed version of traditional Middle Western Americana, one that is full of antic imagination and wild humor. Mr. White's stories are littered with familiar characters who have taken on a fourth dimension: the young man rising in his job at Sears, the tough nightclub singer with a heart of gold, the earnest immigrant. In one of the best stories, ''The Order of Virility,'' a barker at a carnival sideshow, who travels with and loves the show's hermaphrodite, makes a point of seducing the local wives while his companion lures, then shocks, their husbands. Sex is frequently on the characters' minds, but it is sneaky and uncomfortable sex. What keeps each story in ''Metaphysics in the Midwest'' intact is neither conventional plot nor logic nor turn of mind, but a boldness that moves the reader from scene to scene without relaxing its grip. The problem is that this kind of modernist, Dadaesque comedy, which depends on excess, requires the finest discrimination: how much excess is, well, excessive? In making the choices in this collection, Mr. White, a professor of literature at Illinois State University, fails more often than he succeeds. Too many of the stories adopt the pumped-up cadences that come from trying too hard. Still, there is a real voice here, an original and aggressive one that is worth following.

title: Palestinian Nationhood And Israeli Resolve
description: WITH a larger than average dose of pomp and fanfare, Palestinian leaders proclaimed a new state in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip last week. But when the dust settled and the residents of the ''state'' looked around to assess their new status, they realized that nothing had really changed.

title: Notes to Myself
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Carlisle Broadus Engaged To Wed Carl Saling Jr. in January
description: The engagement of Margaret Carlisle Broadus to Carl Albert Saling Jr. has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Carlisle Broadus of New York. Mr. Saling is the son of Madeline A. Hickman of Penn Valley, Pa., and the late Mr. Saling. A Jan. 21 wedding is planned.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Checkup Is Fine but the Patient 's Worried
description: LEAD: AN apple a day keeps the doctor away, but a checkup a year keeps him in Acapulco.

title: THE SNEAKY THRILL OF BREAKING THE LAW
description: SEDUCTIONS OF CRIME Moral and Sensual Attractions in Doing Evil. By Jack Katz. 367 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: A.T.&T. Acting to Thwart New Mass Disruption
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it was laying more fiber-optic communications lines for big metropolitan areas to avoid another widespread disruption in telephone service like the one that occurred Friday.

title: For Jackets, The Simplest Of Necklines
description: FOR members of the exclusive L.W.L. Club (Ladies Who Lunch), the hottest item on the menu these days is neither the delectable coquilles St. Jacques nor the irresistible tuna carpaccio with piquant lime sauce. No, it's the smashing collarless ringneck jacket a la Bill Blass, which is having high midday impact in some of the hautest of our city's cuisineries. At a recent morning fashion show, no fewer than four women were wearing the Blass jacket, with its bold, color-block pattern.

title: Finding Adventure in Venture Concerns
description: ENTREPRENEUR is ''an unfortunate term,'' according to Arthur Lipper 3d, a seminar leader at the recent conference on entrepreneurship held at Manhattanville College here. As chairman of Venture magazine, a publication for and about entrepreneurs, Mr. Lipper is himself often described as a successful entrepreneur. But the word, he said, ''gives the wrong concept, especially when it almost always describes people who are willing to take the responsibility for the lives of others by becoming employers.''

title: Death in a Clothes Dryer
description: Rafael Benitez, 18 years old, was found locked in a commercial clothes dryer in this Los Angeles suburb Friday and died later in Los Angeles County-U.S.C. Medical Center, the police reported. He was found in the locked and running dryer by a fellow employee at American Textile Conditioner, a dry-cleaning company. ''He died from being bounced around inside,'' said Sgt. Carl Heintz.

title:
GARDENING;
Native Persimmon Can Hold Head High
description: LEAD: A PERSON savoring a ripe native persimmon for the first time must feel he has discovered ambrosia. The flesh literally melts in the mouth and leaves an aftertaste akin to an apricot.

title: Cornell and Penn Share Ivy Title
description: Cornell, described as ''the sleeping giant of the Ivy League'' by its coach, Maxie Baughan, had a wide-awake football team today that defeated Pennsylvania, 19-6, and gained its first share of the Ivy championship in 17 years.

title: Review/Music; The Gentler Aspects of the Trumpet
description: Like most other European instruments, the trumpet has developed in brilliance over the last 200 years. Yet as Stephen Burns and various colleagues showed us at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights on Nov. 12, modern engineering allows it to be gentle as well.

title: 'Being on Welfare Was Not Great'
description: LAST month, President Reagan signed a bill intended to help people on welfare become independent of it. The legislation, the first major changes in the country's welfare system since its inception in 1935 during the Depression, will affect many of the 3.7 million families on welfare, including 35,000 in Connecticut who receive benefits under the program known as Aid to Families With Dependent Children.

title: Armchair Travel
description: To the Editor: Tomorrow's Travel section (I salute The Times for delivering most of Sunday's paper on Saturday - the greatest boost to civilized life since indoor plumbing) persuasively relates the trials of air travelers imprisoned on delayed flights (Practical Traveler: Aboard but Aground, Nov. 6) and the ''panic states'' of tourists to Italy overloaded with culture who may well agree with Mark Train, who ''couldn't help noticing how superior the copies (of great art) he had seen in America were to the original (''Going to Pieces Over Masterpieces'').

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: East Craftsbury, Vt.;
Preservation, With Housing
description: LEAD: THE 772-acre Brassknocker Farm was two weeks away from the auctioneer's gavel in the spring of 1987 when the Vermont Land Trust stepped in with $575,000, most of it borrowed, to try to keep this northern Vermont town of 884 people - which has no zoning - from being overrun by condominiums.

title: Surgery For Bird
description: In Boston, where the pantheon of heroes includes such famous basketball figures as Red Auerbach, Bob Cousy and Bill Russell, a couple of unknowns sought instant Celtic immortality yesterday. Based on an initial evaluation, they may have achieved it.

title: GROWING UP IN JERUSALEM
description: In his article ''Two Generations: Growing Up in Jerusalem'' (Oct. 16), Meron Benvenisti writes that he contemplates fleeing Jerusalem for Tel Aviv. Ultimately, he chooses to stay and ''watch the blossoming of the tulips'' that Jerusalem's Mayor Teddy Kollek planted between Jewish and Arab neighborhoods. As former Deputy Mayor of Jerusalem, Mr. Benvenisti might influence his hometown to follow the example of Shlomo Lahat, Mayor of Tel Aviv, Mr. Benvenisti's ''asylum of the sane.''

title: POSTINGS: On West 17th; The Inn Crowd
description: A suite at the new Chelsea Inn rents for $130 a night, but for travelers who find that too rich there also are $60-a-night rooms available. All have kitchenettes, and all are just a short walk to Fifth Avenue.

title: THE GUIDE
description: CELTIC FOLK MUSIC

title: Golf
description: Two-Shot Victory for Gilder: Bob Gilder started with three consecutive birdies and finished with a six-under-par 66 that gave him a two-shot victory yesterday in the Isuzu Kapalua International golf tournament in Hawaii. Gilder won his first title in almost six years - since the 1983 Phoenix Open - with a 266 total, 22 under par on the Kapalua Bay course. While it came in an approved but unofficial event on the PGA Tour, the $150,000 first prize represented the biggest check of Gilder's 13-year career, more than doubled his earnings for the year and was more than he had won in any season since 1982. John Mahaffey, who also had a 66, was second at 268.(AP) One-Shot Lead for Couples: Fred Couples of the United States shot a four-under-par 68 but saw his 5-shot lead cut to 1 yesterday after the third round of the $1.2 million Dunlop Phoenix Golf Tournament in Miyazaki, Japan. Couples, who had an opening-round 62, was closely pursued by his American playing partners Ken Green and Jeff Sluman. Green, who shot 64, carded nine birdies to move into second place at 14-under 202. Sluman, who had a 65, held third at 203. (AP) Elder Leads After Two Rounds: Lee Elder, who suffered a heart attack after last year's tournament, birdied two of the last three holes yesterday and shot a one-under-par 70 for a one-stroke lead over Harold Henning after two rounds of the $300,000 Senior PGA Tour event at Key Biscayne Golf Course in Florida. Elder, 52 years old, was at five-under 137 heading into the final round today. Henning shot a 70 and was at 138.(AP) Bowling Karlsson Beats Holman: Mats Karlsson of Sweden took advantage of two open frames by Marshall Holman of Medford, Ore., and beat him by 231-199 to capture the Professional Bowlers Association Brunswick Memorial World Open yesterday in Glendale Heights, Ill. Karlsson earned $33,000 along with his third P.B.A. title. In the final round, Ron Palombi Jr. of Erie, Pa., defeated Mark Williams of Beaumont, Tex., 245-226. Holman then eliminated Palombi by 247-187 and defeated Parker Bohn 3d of Freehold, N.J., 244-219. (AP) Soccer Penalty Shot Costly to Norwich City: A disputed penalty spoiled pace-setting Norwich City's perfect road record and allowed its pursuers to gain ground in the English League First Division standing as Norwich tied 1-1 at Everton yesterday. Norwich appeared headed for its sixth road victory when Malcolm Allen scored the game's first goal. But the referee awarded Everton a penalty shot with 15 minutes to play and the England international midfielder, Trevor Steven, produced the tying goal. The result allowed runner-up Arsenal, which whipped Middlesbrough by 3-0 at home, to cut Norwich's lead to 2 points. Third-place Millwall also improved with a 4-0 trouncing of last-place Newcastle United, while defending champion Liverpool moved up to fourth by winning by 1-0 at the Queens Park Rangers.(AP) U.S. Gains in Under-16 Play: The United States and Trinidad have assured their places in the semifinals of a regional under-16 championship. The United States team posted a 6-0 victory over St. Lucia in the Group 2 playoff Friday. The 10 teams are divided into two groups. Nidal Baba scored goals in the 12th, 31st and 34th minutes for the United States. David McGuire added a goal in the 63d minute, and Anthony Wood in the 70th minute. Trinidad and Tobago scored a 1-0 victory over Honduras and will meet the United States Sunday in the final game of Group 2.(AP) Harness Racing Kentucky Spur Breaks World Record: Kentucky Spur, driven by Dick Stallings, set a record for 2-year-old pacers and held off Totally Ruthless yesterday to win the $495,838 Breeders Crown 2-Year-Old Colt Pace at Pompano Park in Pompano Beach, Fla. Kentucky Spur won by a head in 1:53 2/5, lowering the world record for a 2-year-old pacer on a five-eighths of a mile track. Central Park West had set the record at 1:53 3/5 earlier in the evening in winning the Breeders Crown 2-Year-Old Filly Pace and clinching the 2-year-old filly title after a 7 3/4-length victory.(AP) Auto Racing Petty Leads Qualifiers: Richard Petty, the seven-time series champion and winner of 200 Nascar stock car races, led second-day qualifying yesterday for the Atlanta Journal 500 today. Petty, driving a Pontiac Grand Prix, turned a lap of 177.303 miles an hour on the 1.522-mile oval at Atlanta International Raceway in Hampton, Ga. That lap would have been good enough for third place on the 42-car grid if Petty had turned it on Friday, when Rusty Wallace, also driving a Pontiac, set a track qualifying record of 179.499 m.p.h. The top 20 positions were filled Friday, so Petty will start 21st in the 500-mile race.(AP) Cross-Country Terronez Wins Title: David Terronez of Augustana covered the five-mile course at Forest Park in St. Louis in 24 minutes 43.2 seconds to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III championship. Kevin Sullivan of Hunter College was fifth in 24:55.9. Anna Prineas of Carleton was the gold medalist in the women's 5,000-meter race in 17:38. Wisconsin-Oshkosh swept the team titles.

title: Readings by Poets To Begin Today
description: LEAD: THE 12th season of the Poet's Voice series of free readings by prominent American poets will begin today in Stamford, with Daniel Hoffman, poet in residence at the University of Pennsylvania, reading from his works at the Ferguson Library.

title: 2 Health Inspectors Get Jail Terms in Extortion
description: One was a corrupt New York City restaurant inspector who was so greedy that his co-workers called him ''Hungry Joe.'' He not only demanded payoffs from restaurants, a Federal prosecutor said, but once ''charged'' a Brooklyn restaurant an extra $100 for cab fare back to his office in Manhattan.

title: Thinking About South Africa
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ELVIS EVERY MORNING, EVENING AND NIGHTTIME, TOO
description: To combat a 20-year decline in listeners, AM radio today is crackling with innovative - some would say gimmicky - programming generally aimed at niches that have gone unrecognized.

title: To the Heights of Simplicity
description: BATTERY PARK CITY in lower Manhattan began with an idea so simple it seems almost banal: that the best way to make a new neighborhood is to look at old neighborhoods, see what makes them work and emulate their best features. By the standards of modern planning, however, this idea was not banal at all; it was more like sacrilege. Most large-scale developments in the postwar age have been designed in accord with the modernist notion that there was little to be learned from the past, that looking back was weak and sentimental.

title: Desperately Seeking Paradise, for Just a Few More Dollars
description: I NEVER thought we'd move, not only because the price of real estate in our community had escalated beyond my capacity for simple arithmetic, but because after three years of concerted house hunting, we hadn't seen anything we liked, regardless of price.

title: Some Variations on the Traditional Thanksgiving Menu
description: DESPITE its strong roots and tradition, the Thanksgiving menu can always use some fresh new ideas. In order to be appealing, these must pay homage to the tried and true, especially with ingredients such as cranberries, sweet potatoes, turkey and pumpkin that are expected to appear on the holiday table.

title: China's Urbanization Is Bureaucratic Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Dance; Young Artists at Juilliard Confront the Baroque
description: The Juilliard Dance Ensemble presented an evening of pleasantly civilized dance, created by faculty members and graduates of the Juilliard School dance division, on Monday at the Juilliard Theater.

title: For Yevtushenko, a Search for a Little Respect
description: ''I know that popularity and talent are not equal things,'' said Yevgeni Yevtushenko, once the boy-rebel of Soviet poetry. ''But some poets cannot forgive other poets for being very popular. It is psychology.''

title: The Other Delaware: A River Reborn
description: LEAD: JOE KASPER squinted through the slowly lifting haze on the river and pointed out a gray heron. It was standing bandylegged and impassive next to a warm water discharge pipe running from a nearby industrial plant.

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: It is not ''granny bashing'' to be offended by greed, arrogance and cynicism.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT was the pup who found it. He'd been rooting in the leaves that carpeted the road and in the process discovered the shotgun shell. I traded him a stick for it. Both of us figured we'd gotten the best of the deal.

title: Six Gripes in Search of a Column
description: More often than not, I'm grateful to be in my line of work. Still, total immersion in concerts and recordings yields a gripe or two. O.K., six: 1. It Ain't I, Babe

title: Tansactions
description: BASEBALL

title: In the Marketplace of Ideas, Americans Ask for Protection
description: THE desire to collect the fruits of innovation is as old as man the inventor. The American colonists recognized it, as did the leaders of ancient Greece. As early as 500 B.C., in the upscale Greek colony of Sybaris, the Sybarites decreed that any confectioner or cook who created a unique dish had the exclusive rights to profits from it for one year.

title: Visiting Rights
description: I FIRST VISITED NEW York in 1962, when my novel ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie'' appeared full-length in The New Yorker. No one would leave me alone in England in those days. Friends, family, business associates were all making claims on me and my precious novelist's time. I hadn't yet learned how to cope with success. It was a godsend when William Shawn offered me an office to work in on the 18th floor at The New Yorker.

title: Dissecting Fundamentalism, the Principles and the Name
description: IT has been almost a decade since the Rev. Jerry Falwell formed the Moral Majority and since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini took power in Iran - two very different developments involving two different religions, often linked by the single label of fundamentalism. Ever since, scholars have tried to understand what looked and still looks like a worldwide resurgence of religious fervor, and even to decide what to call it.

title: POLITICS DELAYED ORDER ON A-PLANTS
description: A Presidential order that overrides local safety objections to nuclear power plants was debated at length but withheld until after the Nov. 8 election to avoid possible political consequences, an Administration official familiar with the discussions said today.

title: Trottier Celebrates His 'Day'
description: For the Islanders, the game was coming unraveled. A 5-1 lead over the Penguins had suddenly shrunk to 5-3 with 52 seconds left. But Bryan Trottier, who had been honored before the game, soon enjoyed the entirely appropriate distinction of ending it.

title: NONFICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. I WAS A WHITE SLAVE IN HARLEM. By Margo Howard-Howard with Abbe Michaels. (Four Walls Eight Windows, Paper, $12.95.) After reading ''I Was a White Slave in Harlem,'' it is impossible to imagine a conversation that Margo Howard-Howard would not dominate. His life was a breathless walk on the wild side. Stories were for embellishing, rules for breaking and people either fools or toys - or, less often, mythical figures of the sort that Howard-Howard, the grand drag queen, manifestly considered himself to be. For decades, until his death in September, he breezed through a slick New York scene of transvestites and tricksters. Figures of New York legend appear in the book (written with Abbe Michaels, a New York freelance writer) like flickering images on a shifting screen. Now here, suddenly gone, are the likes of James Dean, Truman Capote, Andy Warhol - most of them conveniently dead. What is true, not quite so true or downright false eventually becomes less urgent than what will happen next. Howard-Howard lengthily proclaims his lineage - from British royalty; that the connection was fabricated matters little. Underlying the layers of glitz is a gritty story of an often troubled person. His mother thought her only son belonged in the circus; a customer willing to pay $100 for a kiss nearly bit off Howard-Howard's tongue. The title refers to the years he claimed that he was a willing prisoner of Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, Harlem's heroin king. Finally, there is escape, Methadone treatment and a final ego trip: Howard-Howard began a New York society to honor Mary, Queen of Scots, filling it with society matrons, some of whom whispered that her voice seemed a bit husky. Last year, on the 400th anniversary of Mary's beheading, Margo visited England and met Queen Elizabeth II. The book's last line: ''She's a rather nice lady, said one queen of the other.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Aspen, Colo.;
A Ritz Hotel For the Ski Set
description: LEAD: THE Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company plans to build a 292-room hotel on a three-acre site near the base of Aspen Mountain in this resort community.

title: Some States Stumble In Balancing Their Books
description: WHY, in this age of technocratic government, of sophisticated fiscal and economic forecasting, have California, New York and Massachusetts struggled this year to overcome budget shortfalls while states like Minnesota, North Carolina and Maryland wallow in comfortable surplus?

title: Arthur Cohen Weds Elizabeth Karcher
description: Elizabeth Anne Karcher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Karcher of Sayreville, N.J., and Arthur Alan Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Cohen of Haworth, N.J., were married yesterday in Somerset, N.J. Judge Rosemary K. Reavey of New Jersey Superior Court, an aunt of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Somerset Hilton.

title: THANK HEAVEN FOR WEALTHY GIRLS
description: THE LAP OF LUXURY By William Hamilton. 293 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: Christina I. Kimmich Plans June Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ludwig Kimmich of Morristown, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Christina Ingeborg Kimmich to Richard Schuyler Hawkes, a son of the Rev. Daphne Wolcott P. Hawkes of Princeton, N.J., and the late Dr. Dudley Farrand Hawkes. A June wedding is planned.

title: Arafat Foes to Set Up A Rival P.L.O. Group
description: Palestinian opponents of Yasir Arafat have announced plans to set up their own Palestine Liberation Organization to challenge his leadership and policy.

title: Pakistani Rivals Seek Mandate in 2d Election
description: Awaiting the formation of a new government, Pakistanis voted again today to elect members of four provincial assemblies.

title: The Aging Grace of Roquefort
description: THE worst-looking loaf of bread imaginable is proudly displayed under glass in the Roquefort cheese caves of the Societe, the largest producer in the French region of Aveyron. But it is this bread, crumbling and rotting gray-green with mold, along with the particular atmosphere in the caves, that makes Roquefort possible.

title: TALKING: Titles; Insuring Against Claims
description: VIRTUALLY everyone who buys a home these days is required to take out title insurance. The only buyers likely to be exempt are those paying all cash - or those using private, rather than institutional, financing.

title: FICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. WELCOME TO MY CONTRI. By Geoffrey Fox. (Hudson View Press, 2643 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10025, Paper, $6.95.) This frequently powerful collection of short stories enters Latin America as if through the rickety back door of a burlesque house: ''Goo' mornin', all you wonnerful people,'' begins the title story as a tour guide leads his Anglo flock through the imaginary splendors of a city called Santo Abismo. The low-rent stand-up routine serves to lure unsuspecting readers to some pretty dank depths, and although the stories of violence draw from a familiar well (a peasant is mutilated, a village decimated, a rebellion plotted), when he turns to accidental clashes between conflicting cultures, Geoffrey Fox steps out on his own. Most fictional treatments of such encounters feature at least one ugly American, but ''Welcome to My Contri'' does not resort to easy cliche. The Northerners who appear here do not tramp carelessly on third world freedoms; instead, they inadvertently knock them over. A bit like characters from Graham Greene, they don't quite understand the rules by which others play the game, with the result that the game itself is deeply suspect. In this short and impressive work, Mr. Fox, who has taught Latin American politics and society at New York University, has created a memorable set of players who, while not natural antagonists (they often share the same dreams and goals), are still somehow bent on confrontation. Watching their sometimes vicious, often darkly humorous interactions leaves us thoroughly wrung out - and aware that we are in the presence of a formidable new writer.

title: Other First Ladies Were First in Their Fashion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paterno Tastes A Bit of Defeat
description: The last time Penn State had a losing football season, it was 1938 and Joe Paterno was 11 years old.

title: Susan Edwards and Jeffrey Zimmer Are Married
description: Susan Ellen Edwards, the daughter of Madeline Edwards of New York and the late Richard Edwards, was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York to Jeffrey Johnson Zimmer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Tedrick Zimmer of Naples, Fla. The Rev. Harry Schlitt performed the ceremony.

title: Thanksgiving a La Carte
description: NOT all that long ago, Thanksgiving was truly ''Over the river and through the woods, to grandmother's house we go.''

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should the Yankees Trade Don Mattingly?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: The First Steps
description: The Palestine National Council meeting in Algiers last week could be the beginning of a new phase - a diplomatic-political phase - in the Middle East conflict. That potential arises from these factors:

title: Trying to Save A Doomed Globe
description: IT WAS believed to be the largest revolving manmade globe in the world - a 25-ton steel sphere, 28 feet in diameter, with tiles painted to resemble the earth. But it fell prey to the elements, lost its tiles and stopped revolving more than five years ago.

title: Ellen Hayes Hoffmann Marries John Wallop
description: Ellen Hayes Hoffmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Hoffmann of Bridgehampton, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Michael Wallop, a son of Edward J. Wallop of Big Horn, Wyo., and the late Toni R. Wallop. The Rev. Ronald G. Abrams performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: Reputed Mob Leader and 16 Others Are Convicted
description: In what prosecutors call the most sweeping mob conviction ever, Nicodemo Scarfo, the alleged crime boss of Philadelphia and Atlantic City, and 16 associates were convicted today on charges of murder, extortion and other crimes.

title:
SMALL PRESSES IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION Earning Your Turkey In a Five-Mile Race
description: IT seemed like a good idea at the time. My friend called to tell me about a race on Thanksgiving Day. The Turkey Trot, they call it.

title: 'Drugstore Cowboy' Rides Through a Bleak Terrain
description: When director Gus Van Sant calls for action, Matt Dillon may find himself sawing through a pharmacy roof, jimmying a hospital narcotics cabinet, or diving for drugs behind the counter while his accomplices create a diversion elsewhere in the drugstore.

title: Reviews/Music; Pretre and Vienna's Other Orchestra
description: The Vienna Symphony was founded in 1900, and has lived in the musical shadow of that city's more venerable Philharmonic all its life. Lately, however, the orchestra has enjoyed a thriving recording career, and it is currently on its sixth American tour.

title: From the Viennese,'Traditional Favorites'
description: STRIKES have delayed the start of the Hartford and New Haven symphony seasons, but the cities are not without other enticements. The Vienna Symphony will appear in the capital this week, and Orchestra New England is giving its annual Colonial Concert in New Haven.

title: Anxiety on the Rails: Riders Seek Cures
description: ANOTHER Sunday and the stations of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad are, as usual, oddly quiet.

title: Katy Kinsolving Engaged to Marry A Lawyer in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Lee Kinsolving of Bethesda, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter Katharine Cole Kinsolving to Richard Mark Baumann, a son of Mrs. Werner B. Baumann of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and the late Mr. Baumann. The couple plan an April wedding.

title: Dirty Campaigns - a Hallmark of U.S. History; Eulogy for Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: In Europe, Tracing the Art Of the Outsider
description: LEAD: ART BRUT. Raw art. Outsider art. In the 1940's, the French artist Jean Dubuffet coined the term to describe the artistic creations of the insane, the isolated, the eccentric. Not merely Sunday painters or naive artists, these individuals are driven to create by their often incommunicable, and usually arcane, obsessions.

title: Nicaraguan Court Clears 16 Jailed After a Protest in July
description: An appeals court Friday absolved 16 people who had been jailed since taking part in an anti-Sandinista rally July 10, and conditionally freed 9 others.

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: As a longtime member of the American Association of Retired Persons, I resent the one-sided article by John Tierney, ''Old Money, New Power'' (Oct. 23). At the age of 35 (and probably making good money), he finds it hard to conceive of elderly people who worked hard all their lives, living on Social Security alone. He thinks that Medicare covers our medical bills. Think again. First, it pays only 80 percent of approved expenses; we pay the rest. Also, we pay a hefty premium, which is deducted from our Social Security every month, and that premium is going to be increased to pay for the so-called catastrophic program. I say ''so-called,'' because it does not provide nursing-home care. Also, there is a high deductible before anyone can get reimbursement. Welfare, indeed! ALIX SZILASI Princeton, N.J.

title: Big Eight Title To Nebraska
description: Steve Taylor sneaked a yard for a touchdown, capping an 80-yard march after the opening kickoff, and Nebraska ended four years of frustration by defeating Oklahoma, 7-3, today for the Big Eight title.

title: A CASE FOR RESURRECTION
description: LEAD: THE JUDGMENT DAY ARCHIVES By Andrei Moscovit. Translated by Robert Bowie. 402 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $18.95.

title: For 300 Years, A World Apart By Lawrence Block; Lawrence Block, the author of the Matt Scudder and Bernie Rhodenbarr mystery series, frequently sets scenes of his novels in Greenwich Village.
description: IN ''THE MALTESE FALCON,'' there's an aside wholly unrelated to the plot in which Sam Spade recounts the story of a man named Flitcraft. One day Flitcraft was on his way to or from his office when a beam at a construction site fell as he passed, narrowly missing him. Flitcraft then disappeared without a word. By the time Spade had tracked him down he was living under another name in another city, having settled there in circumstances not unlike those he'd left, with a job and a wife similar to those he'd walked away from.

title: BABY BELL BOSS: Sam Ginn; Taking Telesis off the Beaten Track
description: Sam Ginn's interest in telecommunications began so casually it might be described as a fluke. As a freshman at Alabama's Auburn University in 1955, he went to the gymnasium where the Reserve Officers Training Corps was recruiting and headed for the R. O. T. C. unit with the shortest line. It turned out to be the Signal Corps.

title: The Early Returns of a Toxic Poll
description: Returning members of Congress will learn something they may not have bargained for when they amended the toxic waste cleanup law in 1986.

title: Reviews/Music; Sonnerie, in French Mode
description: The Trio Sonnerie, founded in 1982, virtually incarnates the internationalism of today's early-music community. The trio, which played a delightful, mostly French Baroque concert Friday night at Weill Recital Hall, has two American members and one British, all of whom have studied and performed all over Europe and the world.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: WE all know where to find mainstream movies, their sequels and their sequels' sequels. But for those looking for an alternative movie experience they may find the answer to their celluloid dreams at four cultural outposts in Connecticut: Cinema City in Hartford, Cinema IV Bantam in Bantam, SoNo Cinema and Video in South Norwalk and the York Square Cinema/Lincoln at York Square in New

title: Adele M. Raso and Herman Raspe, Lawyers, Plan to Marry Next Spring
description: The engagement of Adele Margaret Raso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gennaro V. Raso of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Herman Henri Raspe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Raspe of Brussels, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: The Clearly Unclear P.L.O.
description: Why was the response in the West so lukewarm to the Algiers declarations adopted last week by the Palestine Liberation Organization? The P.L.O. did in fact move forward in endorsing U.N. Resolutions 242 and 338, thereby implicitly accepting Israel's right to exist. But this statement and others were surrounded by gamesmanship and murkiness. It took a leap of faith to credit and trust what Yasir Arafat said he was doing.

title: Dregs of the Oil Crisis
description: Even the winners have lost. Fifteen years after the explosion of oil prices in 1973, the price of petroleum in real terms is not a lot higher than it was just before.

title: A Rough Trip
description: ACROSS THE GREAT DIVIDE Starring Kirk Douglas, Virginia Mayo and Walter Brennan (all in photo). Directed by Raoul Walsh. 1951. Warner Brothers. $9.95.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Anna Starring Sally Kirkland, Robert Fields, Paulina Porizkova. Directed by Yurek Bogayevicz. 1987. Vestron Video. 100 minutes. $79.98. Closed captioned. Not rated.

title: Truck Accident Stalls Traffic
description: A diesel-fuel tank split away from a tractor-trailer truck crossing the Quinnipiac Bridge on Interstate 95 today, spilling about 4,300 gallons and forcing the authorities to close the highway in both directions for several hours, the police said. The accident occurred at 9 A.M., backing up traffic for seven miles, the police said. The truck driver's name and his company were not immediately available, the police said.

title: A COLONY OF THE DISGRUNTLED
description: THE HIGH ROAD By Edna O'Brien. 214 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title:
Voorhees Township Journal;
Residents Fighting Hospital's Emergency Helipad
description: LEAD: HOSPITALS are in the business of saving lives, not possibly endangering them. At least that's what some of the more than 19,000 residents of this Camden County township think about their local hospital.

title: Ryan Ready to Grasp Opportunity as Starter
description: Pat Ryan, self-styled grump, says he will be angry Sunday if the Bills' sack specialist, Bruce Smith, starts to mouth off.

title: Agency Says Tax Increase Is Needed to Reduce Deficit
description: Rejecting proposals like that offered by President-elect Bush to reduce the deficit, the General Accounting Office said today that new taxes would be needed as part of a ''credible'' effort to solve the nation's budget problem.

title: FICTION
description: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books. To mark the occasion, The Book Review this week devotes its In Short reviews to publications from small presses. The Crime column, Page 40, also highlights small presses. APPALACHIAN PATTERNS. By Bo Ball. (Independence Publishers, P.O. Box 29905, Atlanta, Ga. 30359; $12.95.) One wishes to hear ''Appalachian Patterns'' read aloud. In language both musical and quirky, Bo Ball gives life to the inhabitants of his native Appalachia. Set during the 1930's and 40's, these 11 stories show the dwellers of a rural community called Copperhead as they spend their years in simple yet timeless pursuits: caring for babies, laboring to make ends meet, going crazy from love, dreaming of and often fearing a world beyond their own. Despite some characters who come close to being folksy caricatures, there is real emotional resonance in most of these colorful tales. A literature and writing professor at Agnes Scott College in Georgia, Mr. Ball seems essentially a poet, packing his sentences with inventive images and sometimes producing beautiful effects. But when it comes to rendering dialogue he often gets lost in a brier patch of fractured spelling. (What good does it do a story if the reader has to spend a long minute figuring out that ''Slike sprang'' means ''It's like spring''?) When Mr. Ball's risks as a writer pay off, however, they pay off well. In ''Idie Red, Idie Blue,'' for example, twin sisters named Gaye and Faye come of age rambling the country roads, much sought after by men and soon seeking out their attentions. This story, which richly displays the author's unusual voice, magically combines elements that are lyrical, erotic and plain down-home.

title: Quechee Lakes
description: To the Editor: I was surprised to read the letter from Frank Kolbert of Miami Beach (Travel, Oct. 23) about his unhappy experience at Quechee Lakes, Vt., because our experience was so different.

title: Children of Choice
description: THERE WERE A LOT of kids at our housewarming party -babies, toddlers, even one or two who were big enough to pointedly inform their parents how bored they were. The last time we moved, seven years ago, there hadn't been any. So here we are, I thought, almost 40, and really it hasn't turned out so badly for a lot of the women I know: we've got nice husbands -maybe not the first man we married, but everyone makes mistakes - work that interests us and (except for the writers among us) pays a grown-up living, and adorable healthy children we love to bits.

title: Iran-Iraq Feuding Holds Up OPEC Price Accord
description: Lingering bitterness and mutual suspicions engendered by the long war between Iraq and Iran have stymied an effort here by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to stop the fall in oil prices.

title: OLD MONEY, NEW POWER
description: Your article includes the statement that a worker collects $4 of Social Security benefits for every dollar paid in. That strikes me as a low rate of return.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Five Towns
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after Rockaway Boulevard crosses the Queens-Nassau border, becoming Rockaway Turnpike, it leaves a honkytonk world of fast-food outlets and discount stores and enters a quiet suburban setting of tree-lined streets, well-tended lawns and substantial houses in Cedarhurst and Inwood.

title: MUSIC THAT FALLS FROM SATELLITES IN THE SKY
description: Today's new-fangled technology is providing a much-needed survival strategy for some AM radio stations.

title: Dhiren Shah Wed To Linda Hanson
description: Linda Ann Hanson, a daughter of Mrs. Everett W. Hanson of Morris Township, N.J., and the late Mr. Hanson, and Dhiren Harkisandas Shah, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harkisandas Shah of Bhavnagar, India, were married yesterday at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Carl Sutter, a Lutheran minister.

title: POSTINGS: Seaport Condo; A New Tack
description: The developer of Seaport Mews is in the uncomfortable position of having to market what he once sought to demolish. James Buden bought the 1835 warehouse at 266 Water Street with plans to replace it with a 15-story apartment tower, but then the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission began to consider adding that section of Water Street to the South Street Seaport Historic District. No decision has been reached, but in the meantime all projects there have been halted. Rather than wait, Mr. Buden is adapting the warehouse. Working with his architect, John Wipple Barton, he received permission to add a floor and a penthouse to the six-story building. The interior is being gutted and rebuilt, and the first-floor, cast-iron facade and decorative tin capitals are being refurbished. The work is costing $5.6 million, and though the 24 condominium lofts will sell for $250,000 to $1.2 million, Mr. Buden said he will not make much of a profit because he bought the building for $3 million, triple what its price would be in a landmark district.

title: Trade Optimist
description: To the Editor:

title: Stealth Would Target Soviet Shelters
description: The primary target for the Stealth bomber when it becomes operational will be heavily protected command posts intended to shelter Soviet civilian and military leaders deep in the ground, the Chief of Staff of the Air Force said Friday in an interview.

title: Phoebe Doubleday to Marry Carl W. Timpson 3d in June
description: Mrs. Paul J. Chase of Mill Neck, L.I., and Nelson Doubleday of Locust Valley, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Florence McKim Doubleday to Carl W. Timpson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Timpson Jr. of Locust Valley. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
DINING OUT;
Contemporary Meets Italian-American
description: LEAD: AS you breeze down the western end of Route 208 through Oakland, it would be easy to miss Ruga. But for a smart little neon sign, the restaurant's facade resembles the neighboring houses in a mostly residential section near the Bergen County border.

title: FOCUS: Anchorage; Homesteading Is Alive, and Sort of Well, in Alaska
description: Homesteading - acquiring ownership of government land by the sweat of one's brow - was a dream of millions of Americans 125 years ago. Even today, some older cities give tax-forfeited, deteriorated working-class homes to striving families who pledge to restore them. That's called Urban Homesteading, a pale imitation of what still exists in but one state - Alaska.

title: 'The Nerd' Drops In Again
description: THIS season, three Long Island theaters are presenting Larry Shue's comedy ''The Nerd.''

title: What's Happening on the Street of Dreams
description: IN THE SUMMER OF 1955, when I was 19 and the Grand Concourse was in bloom in every respect, I decided to take a walk in my newly purchased Bermuda shorts. These were the earliest days for Bermudas; they were seldom seen on the streets of the city, and you wore them with high argyle socks. I was striding along the Concourse when a middle-aged woman stepped in my path, glared at my bare knees and proclaimed, ''You're a disgrace to the Bronx!''

title: A Father and Son Bridge the Gap
description: ONE maxim that I grew up with and learned to appreciate because of my father was that you give an honest day's work and do not cut corners where quality is concerned. Of course, he could only tell me this so many times. I really began to appreciate it when I worked with him.

title: Yale Students Lend a Hand to An Abused Building
description: The Yale Art and Architecture Building is the tragic hero of contemporary American architecture. It is bold, ambitious, glorious, intense, harsh and as frustrating to live with as any building of our time. It is now a quarter of a century old, and during that time it has been adored and it has been hated; in 1969 someone apparently hated the building so much that he set fire to it, and seriously.

title: Reviews/Music; Ives With a Bit of Help
description: Leonard Bernstein is devoting this week's New York Philharmonic subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall entirely to 20th-century music. But such is the charm of his personality that even the conservative Friday afternoon audience turned out in force.

title:
SMALL PRESSES IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: About 100 publishers are scheduled to exhibit at a Small Press Book Fair, to be held Nov. 26 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Nov. 27 from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., at the Small Press Center, 20 West 44th Street, in Manhattan. The event, which is free and open to the public, will include readings, crafts demonstrations, lectures and the chance to browse and to buy books.

title: The New Illegals: The Irish
description: ''LEGALIZE THE IRISH,'' reads the latest green-and-white poster in the hallowed old Hibernian precincts centered on Woodside, Queens, and the Bronx and Brooklyn neighborhoods where a flood of illegal aliens has been quietly arriving from Ireland for the past six years.

title: Grandpa's Bridges Falling Down, and a Family Rallies
description: AS soon as Bobby finished reading the story in the daily paper he immediately phoned Uncle George. ''Uncle George,'' said Bobby. ''They want to tear down the bridges.'' Uncle George was in the midst of reading a very interesting article about vitamin therapy for arthritis and did not immediately understand what Bobby was talking about. ''Bridges? What bridges?'' ''Great-grandpa's bridges.'' At the mention of ''great-grandpa,'' Uncle George dropped his magazine, stood up, put his left fist on his hip and bellowed, ''Who wants to tear down Grandpa's bridges?''

title: Pupils Help Design Play Area
description: AT Melissa Jones Elementary School in Guilford, one pupil wanted a built-in, heated swimming pool. Another wanted a water slide. Still another insisted that a roller coaster was a must.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, a picture caption on page 8 of The Long Island Weekly today is erroneous. The photograph shows Joseph N. Mondello, the Nassau County Republican leader.

title: Town Clerk Nears 90 With Zest
description: LEAD: WHEN Old Bridge Township Clerk Mary Brown reaches 90 a week from tomorrow, little will change for her. She will still go to her office at the Municipal Building each morning, leaving when the workday is over, often to return for a Township Council meeting that may go on until after midnight.

title: Review/Dance; Expressing Job-Related Impulses
description: Life and art merged on Wednesday afternoon when Ann Carlson presented ''Real People'' in the sculpture court of the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris.

title: Margot Murray Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Margot Elizabeth Murray to Paul Christopher Leary took place yesterday at Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in New Rochelle, N.Y., The Rev. Gerald E. Murray Jr., the brother of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Refuge for Mothers And Their Children
description: LEAD: IN what used to be the storefront of a Singer Sewing Machine shop in downtown Norwich, a group of six toddlers sit on a floor, coloring madly. Occasionally, a child breaks away to show the artwork to one of the five members of a foster grandparents program who volunteer as baby sitters. Previous art projects decorate the walls of this makeshift but well-stocked nursery.

title: CRIME
description: By their passion to their causes shall ye know them, those intriguingly titled mysteries by people you've never heard of, published by small presses with euphonious names, operating out of cities you've never visited.

title: No. 7 Line -- The Orient Express
description: RATTLING AT ROOF-TOP level toward Queensboro Plaza, down Queens Boulevard, then up the center of Roosevelt Avenue, past Shea Stadium and into Flushing, the No. 7 IRT provides tantalizing glimpses of the new Queens - from the borough's first skyscraper at Courthouse Square to the startling proliferation of South American and Asian shops and restaurants wedged between old family businesses, garden apartments and Irish pubs. As one travels farther east the signs of the Orient become more pronounced: Chinese and Korean writing begins to appear on storefronts, office buildings and churches. And where the No. 7, known as ''The Orient Express,'' comes to the end of the line in Flushing, Asian businesses dominate entire blocks.

title: Molly Ann Hood Becomes a Bride
description: Molly Ann Hood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Hood Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to George Augustine O'Brien, a son of Dorothy Thompson Fisher of White Plains and the late George A. O'Brien Jr. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church.

title: In Foreign Policy, the Bush Era Is Here
description: ALL new Presidents want a decisive victory early in the season, a quick opportunity to show that they are in place and in command. ''He wants the public to have the perception that he is doing things of value, that he has a sense of positive motion,'' a senior adviser to the Bush transition team said. ''People actually want the change of Presidents to be a process of renewal.''

title: Maine Game Wardens See a Rise in Illegal Hunting of Moose
description: Donald Higgins had heard talk of illegal moose hunting around Pretty Barrens, a level stretch of blueberry fields near Maine's northeastern coast. His fears were confirmed by the telltale sign of a dead animal: ravens circling overhead.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Steve Walsh, quarterback at the University of Miami, deserves to win the Heisman. Walsh, a junior, has already tied Miami's season record of 26 touchdown passes thrown by the 1986 Heisman winner, Vinny Testaverde. With three regular season games remaining before last night's game at Louisiana State, Walsh will easily shatter the old school record. He is a poised leader, a superb athlete and an accomplished student. MAUREEN A. DONNELLY Brooklyn

title: An Aqueduct of Cries
description: For some people, travel becomes a kind of inspired lunacy. This is from ''Kinds of Water'' by Anne Carson, who went to Spain, apparently, in the rainy season. It is one of 20 pieces in ''The Best American Essays 1988,'' edited by Annie Dillard (Ticknor & Fields).

title: Beth Reynolds Marries
description: The wedding of Helen Elizabeth Reynolds, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Reynolds of Bedminster, N.J., to James Elam Lesher, a son of Louise M. Lesher of Sun Valley, Idaho, and John L. Lesher Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Brigid in Peapack, N.J. Msgr. George M. Brembos performed the ceremony. The bride is known as Beth. She is the head teller at the Peapack-Gladstone Bank in Far Hills, N.J. The bridegroom is the director of marketing at the Hills Development Company, a real-estate concern in Bedminster.

title: A Melding of the Popular and the Elite
description: A VISITOR to ''Fiber, Metal and Wood,'' the latest exhibition in the series of New Jersey's Arts Annuals, is likely to become confused. At the entrance to one gallery in the Noyes Museum here stands a life-size female figure in armor. It is made of kitchen utensils liberated from function. Across the room is a set of silver spoons for garnishes, inventively designed for utility.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Bourbon Street Opens to Cars In the Daytime

title: A Guide to Village Jazz
description: An average week's worth of jazz in Greenwich Village is like a jazz festival anywhere else. New York is the center of the jazz world, and the Village, with its abundance of clubs and piano bars, is the center of the center, indisputably.

title: Lately, Seeing Isn't Believing Jodie Foster and Kelly McGillis in ''The Accused'' (Rob McEwan)which takes a high-minded and effective approach to its titillating subject
description: As the heroine of ''The Good Mother'' - with no ambiguity, the film presents Anna as the best-intentioned mom of all time - Diane Keaton walks down a charming street near Harvard Square and suddenly bursts into histrionics. Her lover, Leo, is an artist who has asked angrily why she is not more passionate about her work. Anna, a part-time piano teacher and the divorced mother of a 4-year-old, fights back with the illogic and defensiveness of someone whose most sensitive nerve has just been hit. ''I might have been a composer, or a musician,'' she screams hysterically. ''That was the plan for me, but I wasn't good enough! So I made a different kind of life for myself, with Molly! And I really hate being told there's no honor in it!''

title: Ferry, With 23 Points, Leads Duke to Easy Victory in Tipoff
description: Duke confirmed its high hopes for the college basketball season and Kentucky realized its worst fears today as the Blue Devils routed the Wildcats, 80-55, in the Tipoff Classic.

title: Can't Wait for Improved TV? It's Here Now.
description: Everyone agrees on the need for a radical updating of technical television standards - even the Federal Communications Commission. There's been lots of progress since our basic system of television system was frozen by law in 1953. It's time to catch up, and the main question is: How soon?

title: Cuomo's War; Lilco's Victory?
description: Mario Cuomo's comments about Shoreham make clear that our Governor does not have the courage to be a political leader. Knowing that most Long Islanders oppose the opening of a nuclear plant, he lists a number of reasons why it shouldn't. Perhaps most disingenuous is the notion that we shall pay more if Shoreham opens. He neglects to mention the debt service for buying the plant.

title: FLASHBACKS: Blue Sky and Blood on 10th Avenue
description: WHEN I WAS GROWING up I spent five years in Spanish Harlem and ten years in the upper Upper West Side. The streets were always crowded with different types of people: kids from the projects, white liberals, students from Columbia. But I didn't hang out much. You could find me in my room, or in the park by the river. Facing south on an afternoon and seeing the angles of sunlight gave me a weird sense of orientation. As a child, I felt: ''The sun is there. It's high and on my right. I am here. Everything is O.K.'' As an adult I had stopped going to the park on the weekends, and that feeling rarely, if ever, visited again.

title: FOCUS: Anchorage; Homesteading Is Still Alive in Alaska
description: HOMESTEADING - acquiring ownership of government land by the sweat of one's brow - was a dream of millions of Americans 125 years ago. Even today, some older cities give tax-forfeited, deteriorated working-class homes to striving families who pledge to restore them. That's called Urban Homesteading, a pale imitation of what still exists in but one state - Alaska.

title: Reagan Backs U.S. Research in Superconducting
description: Over objections of Energy Secretary John S. Herrington, President Reagan today signed legislation establishing a program to speed research and development in superconductivity, a new field of science that could revolutionize energy, electronics and transportation industries.

title: THREE CHEERS FOR MY DAUGHTER
description: No wonder Kathleen Cushman's daughter became a cheerleader. It was probably to spite her mother for forcing her to go on all those Mondale and Ferraro marches. As for describing a cheerleading contest as ''a wild concatenation of female passions, a screaming, ritualized celebration of sex and power under the sanction of the state,'' I can only say, Hey, ease up. That is enough to make all but the most punctilious liberal wish that her daughter marry a Republican. JOE MYSAK Brooklyn

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Maine Eatery Gets New Life

title: Who Is H-Bomb's Real Father? A Paternity Test
description: To the Editor:

title: MODERATE TO A FAULT?
description: JOURNEY CONTINUED An Autobiography. By Alan Paton. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.50.

title: Dirty Campaigns - a Hallmark of U.S. History; A 54 Percent Landslide?
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Trees 200 Years Old
description: ENVIRONMENTALISTS termed it ''the second battle of Bunker Hill,'' a struggle to keep the Government from cutting down a 110-acre virgin forest on Bunker Hill near Marcola, Ore. At stake were hundreds of trees at least 200 years old.

title: A CHOICE BETWEEN BAD AND WORSE
description: ISRAEL'S FATEFUL HOUR By Yehoshafat Harkabi. Translated by Lenn Schramm. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: Mariam I. Potter Wed To Robert A. Gerard
description: At Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in the Georgetown section of Washington, Mariam Isabel Potter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John F. Potter of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Robert A. Gerard, a son of Mrs. Leon Falk Jr. of Pittsburgh and New York, and the late Michael A. Gerard. The Revs. Daniel Gatti and Lawrence Madden performed the ceremony.

title: Repairing to the Steam Era
description: IT'S officially billed as the North Carolina Transportation Museum and, true, among the hundreds of exhibits are cars, an airplane, a 2,000-year-old Indian dugout canoe, a 1918 horse drawn mail buggy and other vehicles. But the main reason people come to the site of the Southern Railway Shops is steam trains.

title: Something's Afoot: More Police Patrols
description: MORE and more neighborhoods are deciding that a police officer on foot is not an anachronism; it is a necessity.

title: Few Changes Are Expected in the Onassis Empire
description: The sudden death of Christina Onassis in Argentina over the weekend presaged no changes in the shipping and real-estate empire founded by her father, Aristotle S. Onassis, according to several members of a multinational board that has run the business since he died in 1975.

title: Hubbell Injured In Car Accident
description: Carl Hubbell, the Hall of Fame pitcher who played for the New York Giants from 1928 through 1943, was in critical condition today after his car struck a metal pole, the authorities said.

title: Boonton Electronics Corp reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
The Nuclear Power War
description: President Reagan's decision Friday to weigh in to the battles over the Seabrook and Shoreham nuclear power plants was a thunderbolt to nearly everyone but the Department of Energy and advocates of nuclear power, who have been mulling over just such a step for nearly four years.

title: Conservative Jews Adhere Fully to Jewish Law
description: To the Editor:

title: MSR Exploration Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DOC Optics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Building A Market for Ohio Wines
description: IN the annals of tough sells - a list that includes refrigerators to Eskimos and coals to Newcastle - peddling Ohio wines to Ohioans ranks high.

title: Three Are Charged in Attack Attributed to Neo-Nazi Gang
description: Three men were arrested and charged in connection with the beating death of an Ethiopian immigrant that the authorities say was carried out by a neo-Nazi group, the police said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Now That It's Over . . .
description: Forget about tracking polls, getting the negatives down, wooing the Reagan Democrats. For a fresh political buzzword, try PessRums.

title: Spy Says Life Sentence Is Too Harsh for Crime
description: In his first interview since he was sentenced to life imprisonment for spying, Jonathan Jay Pollard says he was the victim of political vengeance by the United States Government.

title: Meeting To Open on OPEC Rift
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries begins a crucial meeting here Monday after initial negotiations among its key oil ministers failed to bridge a wide gap between Iraq and Iran.

title: 3 Playoff Losses For Area Teams
description: For Columbia, for Cornell and for the Coast Guard Academy, the final Saturday of football brought unaccustomed reward.

title: Reviews/Television; Humans and Sexuality
description: ''Inside the Sexes'' may not be the most euphonious title of the television season, but it is accurate. Through the miracle of microphotography, the hourlong documentary at 10 o'clock tonight on CBS enters human reproductive organs at work and play. The pictures go much further than the narration, which jumps from elementary sex education to advances in surgical techniques to the workings of the AIDS virus.

title: Merger Record In '88 Is Seen
description: There were 28 mergers and acquisitions worth $1 billion or more through the first three quarters of the year, suggesting that a record number of such mega-deals will be completed in 1988, according to figures released on Thursday by Mergers & Acquisitions magazine.

title: International American Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: For the latest 6 months, revenues and net income from the sale of investment land were $3,284,000 and $580,000, respectively, compared with revenues and net income of $402,000 and $15,000, respectively, for the same year-ago periods. The share earnings were 7 cents for 1988 and no share earnings for 1987.

title: Days of Rediscovery for Soviet Poles
description: Jan Plater-Gajewski survived years in a Moscow prison and numerous arrests and interrogations by the Soviet police. The sole crime of the 79-year-old native of Cracow, in southern Poland, was an untiring advocacy of the rights of one million to two million ethnic Poles scattered in all corners of the Soviet Union.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; U.S.-Cuba Phone Link
description: On Nov. 13 a fire in Cuba's central telephone exchange in Havana cut off all international calls. Telephone specialists say the damage will take many months to repair, with initial costs estimated at $37 million.

description: Britons Are Uneasy

title: Police Revise Training of New Cadet Corps
description: The training program for New York City's new Police Cadet Corps was sharply revamped this year after a confidential report warned that the on-the-job experiences for the first group of recruits might have backfired.

title: Jury in Bronx Acquits Larry Davis In Shooting of Six Police Officers
description: Larry Davis won his second courtroom victory in nine months yesterday when a Bronx jury acquitted him of attempted murder of nine police officers in a blazing shootout in 1986.

title: Books of The Times; The Era of Martin Luther King Jr.
description: Parting the Waters: America in the King Years 1954-63 By Taylor Branch Illustrated. 1,064 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title: Giants' Overtime Loss Is Hard to Take
description: In a heavy, unending rain, the Philadelphia Eagles scored three odd touchdowns today and upset the Giants, 23-17, in overtime.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme-Cleveland Corp., Cleveland, a manufacturer of machine tools, elected as a director Karl E. Ware, chairman and chief executive of Ware Industries, Elyria, Ohio, a maker of wire forms and steel components.

title: A Publisher Leaves Well Enough Behind
description: Contemporary Books of Chicago has carved out an important and profitable publishing niche in the past decade, particularly in areas like sports, self help, cooking and leisure. In four years the privately owned company's sales have climbed to about $20 million from $10 million, and profits have risen steadily.

title: A-Plant Orders: Is It a New Era?
description: Some nuclear energy experts fear the implications of an order by President Reagan providing for Government control of civilian nuclear plants in a national emergency.

title: Beauty Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said it has revised its results for the first quarter ended June 30 due to undetected clerical errors at the time of filing. It also said that it lost $837,899 in the quarter, instead of the $404,564 originally reported. Sales were virtually unchanged by the restatement, with a reported figure of $3,962,411.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe Wins: John McEnroe continued his comeback yesterday by defeating Aaron Krickstein, 7-5, 6-2, to win the Little Caesars Championship in Detroit. McEnroe earned $59,500 by winning his second tournament this year and the 72d of his career. He was able to break Krickstein's serve three times in each set and kept him off balance with numerous drop shots. (AP) GOLF Elder Triumphs: Lee Elder, who suffered a career-threatening heart attack a year ago, shot a final round of six-under-par 65 yesterday to win the $300,000 Senior PGA Tour event at the Links of Key Biscayne in Miami. Elder's victory, his first since 1986, was by five shots over Al Geiberger, who closed with a course-record 63. Elder, 54 years old, shot a 54-hole total of 11-under-par 202 to win $45,000.(AP) SQUASH RACQUETS Final Match Set: In the semifinal doubles matches yesterday in the Xerox North American Open, Allen Grant and Jamie Bentley, both of Toronto, defeated Hugh Labossier of Seattle, and Bill Doyle of Greenwich, Conn., 15-8, 15-11, 15-7, at the Greenwich Country Club. In the second match, the top-seeded team of Todd Binns of Toronto and Tom Page of New York defeated Alex Doucas of Montreal and Ned Edwards of New York, seeded third, 15-6, 15-9, 11-15, 15-13. AUTO RACING Elliott Clinches: Rusty Wallace won another race, but Bill Elliott earned his first Nascar Winston Cup championship with an 11th-place finish yesterday in the Atlanta Journal 500 in Hampton, Ga. Elliott needed only to finish 18th or better to clinch the $400,000 title. He started 29th in a 42-car field in 500-mile race at Atlanta International Raceway. Wallace earned his fourth victory in his last five starts and his sixth of the season. (AP) ROAD RACING Crabb and Dainty Sweep: Steve Crabb and Jillian Dainty, both of Britain, swept the titles in the Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge International Championship road race in heavy rain yesterday. Crabb, eliminated in the semifinals of the 1,500-meter run at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, covered the 3.5-mile course in Manhattan in 16 minutes 15 seconds. Dainty won the women's championship in 18:39. Ian Archibald, also of Britain, was second among the men in 16:20. Dennis Simonaitis of Tyngsboro, Mass., was third in 16:25. Katherine Kanes of Pasadena, Calif., finished 55 yards behind Dainty in 18:50. Elaine Van Blunk of Bala Cynwood, Pa., trailed in 19:13.(AP)

title: Contrasts In Mood Inform A Cello Recital
description: Janos Starker is not an overpowering cellist, but the listener had only to look around at Friday's Metropolitan Museum of Art audience - one that was filled with his performing colleagues - to understand the respect in which Mr. Starker is held.

description: Max H. Seigel, a radio news editor and newspaper reporter for nearly half a century, died of lung cancer yesterday at University Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: The Alden twins, David and Christopher, are honorable, sometimes outrageous variants of Peter Sellars - directing contemporized versions of standard operas, which some people love and some people despise.

description: The chemical compounds known as steroids are widely distributed in nature and have widely varying functions essential to life. In humans, the two main types of steroids are anabolic and cortical.
