Geotek owns all of the operating and manufacturing activities of Patlex.

title: A Venture in Concrete: New York City Pays a Price
description: More than two years ago, New York City, concerned about high prices for concrete, helped set up a company that would supply the city's needs in Manhattan and, it hoped, bring down prices industrywide.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL The U.S.-Canada trade agreement is likely to lead to significant changes in global trading. It is expected to reduce both countries' cost of doing business, increasing their productivity and competitiveness. Prime Minister Mulroney said he would use his majority to seek rapid approval. [ Page A1. ] The political fortunes of Japan's Finance Minister worsened as he again changed his explanation of a stock scandal. [ D15. ] ECONOMY The Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in October. The climb in food prices eased, but clothing, cable television and automobile insurance rose sharply. [ D1. ] Prices in the New York area rose 0.2 percent. [ D5. ] Experts said higher clothing prices reflected the new seasonal lines and the rising cost of materials. [ D5. ] President-elect Bush will open negotiations with Congress on his first day in office in an effort to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Mr. Bush said he would be personally involved in the talks. [ A1. ] Extensive changes in airline fares took effect, raising the cost of flying for business and leisure travelers on most routes. The changes affect 95 percent of the U.S. airline system. [ A1. ] A change in working conditions is the goal of a settlement by the Government, a meatpacking company and its union. [ A16. ] The U.S. could lose its lead in personal computers and semiconductors if it fails to become a leading player in high-definition television, an industry group warned. [ D1. ] COMPANIES First Boston asked three well-known deal makers to participate in its contemplated offer for RJR Nabisco. The three are Harry J. Gray, Melvyn N. Klein and Dan W. Lufkin. [ D1. ] The stock price of Hospital Corporation fell $3.625, to $43, after the board accepted a management buyout offer of $51. [ D1. ] Interco's board approved slight changes in the package of cash and securities it will distribute to shareholders. [ D4. ] Grand Metropolitan reaffirmed its willingness to negotiate its offer to acquire Pillsbury. [ D4. ] MARKETS Petroleum markets were shaken by reports emanating from the OPEC meeting in Vienna. The spot price of crude oil ended up 88 cents on the New York Merc, at $13.86. [ D1. ] Stock prices were higher as volume languished. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.73 points, to 2,077.70. [ D8. ] Short-term interest rates continued their recent dramatic rise, narrowing the gap with longer-term Treasuries. [ D14. ] The dollar slipped lower despite intervention by the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve. [ D16. ] President Reagan appointed Mary Schapiro to the S.E.C. She is general counsel of the Futures Industry Association. [ D2. ] Federal regulators approved the first U.S. futures contracts for foreign government bonds and foreign stock indexes. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY An exotic carbon material is being considered for use in nuclear waste containers, laser shields in space weapons systems and even replacements for human bones. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The California vote to roll back auto insurance premiums is more a focus for frustration than a practical way to tame premium inflation. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Atlantic Richfield's plans to sell half of its petrochemical subsidiary in an initial public offering comes as the chemical industry appears to be at its peak. Market Place. [ D8. ] Wesray Capital bought half of Ally & Gargano, the 26-year-old advertising agency, whose creative mantle has been frayed by the loss of several key clients. Advertising. [ D15. ]

title: Oilfield Contracts
description: The first contracts have been awarded in the $:200 million ($365 million) development of a new oil field in the North Sea off Scotland, a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said. The Osprey oil field lies 80 miles northeast of the Shetland Islands in the British sector of the North Sea. Oil companies expect to start taking oil out of the field in late 1990 and production is expected to reach a peak of 25,000 barrels a day the following year. Contracts worth $:37 million ($67 million) have already been placed with British companies. Shell, Britoil, and the Exxon Corporation's British subsidiary, Esso, have been licensed to operate the field.

title: Topics of The Times; Currency Exchange
description: A New Yorker driving to the Poconos crossed the Delaware Water Gap toll bridge, giving the toll taker a $1 bill for a 50-cent toll. Only as he drove off did he notice that one of the quarters he'd received in change was Canadian.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Pacers 105, Bucks 91: In its first start under George Irvine, the new coach, Indiana won its first game of the National Basketball Association season last night. Chuck Person scored 10 of his 18 points in the fourth period as the Pacers handed Milwaukee its third straight loss. The Pacers scored 10 straight points, a run featuring 4 points by Stuart Gray and capped by Vern Fleming's layup, for a 75-63 lead with 2 minutes 43 seconds to play in the third quarter. Vern Fleming, who hit nine of 11 shots, finished with 20 points. Paul Pressey had 15 points for the visiting Bucks, and Jeff Grayer, out since training camp because of chicken pox, added 13 in his N.B.A. debut.(AP) 76ers 130, Bullets 103: Mike Gmimski and Hersey Hawkins scored 8 points each during a 27-9 Philadelphia run midway through the third quarter last night for the visiting 76ers. Philadelphia, which had lost its first three road games, led by 68-66 with 2:18 gone in the second half. Charles Barkley made a layup and a tipin, Cliff Robinson made an eight-foot jumper and Gminski hit a layup. Gminski completed the run by making two free throws with 2:46 left in the quarter, giving the 76ers a 95-75 lead. Ron Anderson scored a career-high 34 points for Philadelphia, giving him 62 in his last two games.(AP) Pistons 99, Hornets 93: Joe Dumars scored 20 of his 26 points in the first half as the visiting Pistons pulled away in the third quarter last night to win. Charlotte, which trailed by 54-46 at halftime, pulled to 67-65 with 3:33 left in the third quarter. Bill Laimbeer scored 8 of his 19 points in the quarter. Robert Reid scored 19 points for Charlotte, and Kurt Rambis added 16 points and 14 rebounds.(AP) Cavaliers 114, Celtics 102: The Cleveland Cavaliers ended a 10-year, 26-game road losing streak against Boston last night, beating the Celtics, 114-102, behind 28 points by Mark Price and 22 by Larry Nance in a game played at Hartford. Cleveland had not beaten Boston on the road since a 115-101 victory on Oct. 13, 1978. The streak included two games in Hartford. Brad Dougherty scored 16 points for Cleveland, which is 4-0 on the road. Nance had 12 rebounds. Danny Ainge scored 28 points for Boston, which dropped to 4-6.(AP) N.H.L. Kings 6, Flyers 1: Bernie Nicholls continued his torrid scoring with three goals in the third period to lead the visiting Kings last night. The victory was the Kings' seventh in the last eight games, while the Flyers have won only once in the same span. With the Kings leading, 3-1, early in the third period, Nicholls, the league's leading goal-scorer with 26, scored a short-handed goal when he beat Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia goaltender, with a backhander at the crease at 5 minutes 14 seconds. It took him another 1:48 to connect again as Nicholls intercepted a pass in the Philadelphia zone and beat Hextall high to the glove side. He finished his second hat trick of the season when he again intercepted a pass deep in the Philadelphia zone and fired a shot between Hextall's pads at 8:31.(AP) Tennis Chesnokov Gains: Second-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union defeated Pedro Rebolledo of Chile, 4-6, 7-5, 7-6, yesterday in the opening match of the $305,000 Citibank Open tournament in Rio de Janeiro. Chesnokov, ranked 16th in the world, outlasted Rebolledo in a two-and-a-half-hour match. He won the tie breaker by 7-5 after trailing, 5-1. In other matches, Jim Courier of the United States defeated Ivan Kley of Brazil, 6-4, 6-2; Cassio Motta of Brazil defeated a countryman, Fernando Roese, 7-5, 6-1, and Horacio de la Pena of Argentina beat Francisco Roig of Spain, 3-6, 7-6, 6-4. The tie breaker was 7-5.(AP) Masur and Westphal Advance: Wally Masur of Australia, seeded No. 8, and Michael Westphal of West Germany scored first-round victories yesterday in the $490,000 Belgian Indoor Championship Grand Prix tournament in Brussels. Westphal defeated Johan Vekemans of Belgium, 6-3, 7-6. The tie breaker was 7-2. Masur came back to beat Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-4, 6-0. The tie breaker was 4-7.(AP)

title: Coles Myer Plan
description: Coles Myer Ltd., Australia's largest retailer, expects to make a substantial foreign acquisition, most likely in the United States, the company's chairman, Brian Quinn, said. Mr. Quinn said the company was looking to move into the United States or Britain within the next two or three years and that he personally favored the United States. Coles Myer had clearance to enter United States retailing from its largest shareholder, the K Mart Corporation, a department store chain based in Troy, Mich., Mr. Quinn said. K Mart has a 21 percent stake in Coles.

title: Review/Theater; Jagged, Percussive 'Coriolanus' From Steven Berkoff
description: Politics is a dirty business, yet, in a democracy, someone has got to do it. But who? To many Americans, the answer was hardly satisfactory in 1988, a year in which the handlers, the pollsters and the advertising men often seemed to have more say than either the candidates or the voters. The national disenchantment that was registered on Nov. 8, when a low turnout produced a mandate of dubious import, could hardly find more articulate or sorrowing expression than it does in ''Coriolanus,'' Shakespeare's corrosive view of Roman democracy in the fifth century B.C. ''Coriolanus'' is a tragedy in which the political process proves every bit as chaotic and poisonous as war.

title: Reviews/Film; At Issue: Is It Better to Have a Lot of Trouble and Die, or Not?
description: If you, like the characters of ''Cocoon,'' had spent the last several years on the planet Antarea losing track of earthly time, you might well mistake this story's latest installment for a V, a VI or a VII, instead of the mere II that it is. ''Cocoon: The Return'' is so tired, in fact, that it can barely recapitulate the winning formula of the original hit.

title: Now, Many Mobile Homes Must Move On
description: Loretta Van Alstyne and her three teen-age children moved here four years ago to a two-bedroom mobile home from her mother's house nearby. They felt fortunate. ''It was affordable, it was cozy and it was in the area,'' said Mrs. Van Alstyne, a 47-year-old typist with the New York State Education Department who grew up in this hamlet of 1,500 people 20 miles south of Albany.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day last Thursday, with an article about the ''junk bond'' market, misstated the nine-year compounded return for high-grade corporate bonds. It is 197 percent, not 156.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Wolanin
description: The Devil defenseman Craig Wolanin underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee last night at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. Wolanin's injury, suffered against St. Louis eight days ago, was at first diagnosed as a sprain. The Devils said the extent of the injury would be known today.

title: Neoax Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $20 million after-tax charge related to the company's decision to dispose of certain of its custom vehicle operations. This charge includes an $18 million writeoff of goodwill as well as anticipated disposition costs and other asset writedowns. c-Net income Sales and operating losses for these operations for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1988 were $23 million and $1.7 million, respectively.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: NEW YORKERS tend to become oblivious to the majority of panhandling subway riders. On a recent evening, Carol Hartley was on an R train heading homeward, a few pages of ''Presumed Innocent'' to go. Suddenly an ear-piercing blast resounded through the car. Ms. Hartley looked up from her book to see the compulsory entertainment of the evening - a musician asking his fellow passengers for enough spare change so that he could get his saxophone repaired.

title: Indiana Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank said the third-quarter earnings were affected by an increase in loan loss reserves of $848,000.

title: Real Estate; Office-Hotel Development Set for L.I.
description: WHEN Schmergel Enterprises acquired a 7.8-acre parcel of land on Route 110 in Melville, L.I., late last year, the development company took the last available portion of a 42-acre site considered to be among the most valuable pieces of empty land in the region. The transaction also completed a large development plan for the tract that had been stalled for more than a decade by a legal dispute and failed attempts by other builders.

title: Stock Scandal in Japan Snags Finance Minister
description: Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, already under pressure for his connection to a stock trading scandal, saw his political fortunes worsen today as he was again forced to change his account of his involvement.

title: Boxing Notebook; Tyson-Bruno: Off, On, Off. . . .
description: Mike Tyson's heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno, scheduled for Jan. 14 at the Las Vegas Hilton, has been postponed.

title: Review/Film; Bill Murray in 'Scrooged': Meanness's Outer Limits
description: Locked deep inside Bill Murray there is a small, hyperactive misanthrope fighting to be heard through the large heavy body that contains him. The misanthrope never sleeps. He's a busy demon, peering out through Mr. Murray's squinty eyes, seeing all and remaining actively unimpressed. By the time his nastiest observations fight their way to the surface, however, much of their sting has been absorbed by flesh, leaving a sometimes revivifying but thoroughly domesticated skepticism.

title: Conflicting News on OPEC Makes Oil Prices Fluctuate
description: Petroleum markets were convulsed yesterday by conflicting reports emanating from the Vienna meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: In Pastry, All That Sparkles Isn't Spun Sugar, Judges Find
description: ''Oh no!'' said the judge. ''A toothpick. What a shame.'' He was removing a chocolate rose from a chocolate cake covered with a chocolate handkerchief. And with his discovery, at least one point was deducted from the entry in the American finals on Sunday for the first World Cup of Pastry, or La Coupe du Monde de la Patisserie.

title: Speed-O-Print Business Mahines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carl C. Pfeiffer, Pharmacologist, Dies at 80
description: Dr. Carl C. Pfeiffer, a pharmacologist who specialized in research on the causes of schizophrenia, allergies and other diseases, died Friday at Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey. He had suffered a heart attack at the Bio Center, a research and treatment center that he directed. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: STV Engineers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said STV-Michael Lynn & Associates, a subsidiary acquired in November 1987, incurred losses in excess of $1.4 million for the year. External market conditions resulted inhigher-than-anticipated costs for this subsidiary. A subsequent restructuring resulted in the writeoff of intangible assets such as leasehold improvements, lease rights and contract rights. These items, when aggregated, accounted for $1,055,000 of the loss in the latest year.

title: Prime Medical Services Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $14,513,000 and $17 million in losses related to correction of books and records. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $673,000.

title: Brady, W H Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $190,000 from an accounting change.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Goetz's Gun Conviction
description: New York State's highest court yesterday unanimously upheld the 1987 conviction of Bernhard H. Goetz on an illegal weapons charge, clearing the way for sentencing that was delayed pending the ruling.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in October as upward pressure on food prices abated while big increases were posted for such diverse items as clothing, cable television and automobile insurance and finance charges.

title: Betting on Baker
description: Some people are wondering how well James A. Baker 3d's reputation for political acumen, managerial ability and Washington savvy will wear in his new job as Secretary of State.

title: Chelsea Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income

title: Michaels Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Mulroney to Push Approval of U.S.-Canadian Pact
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that he would move ''at the first opportunity'' to use the parliamentary majority he won in Monday's election to formally approve Canada's free-trade agreement with the United States.

title: Exams Conflict With Michigan
description: A late final-examination schedule could disrupt Michigan's preparations for the Jan. 2 Rose Bowl game against Southern California, according to Coach Bo Schembechler.

title: Sigma Designs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Cruise Lines Inc., Haddam, Conn., an American river cruise company, said it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Tech Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Streaking Capitals Outpace Islanders
description: Once again, the Islanders were their own victims.

title: Study Says Prejudice in Suburbs Is Aimed Mostly at Blacks
description: Because of persistent prejudice by whites, blacks are much more likely to find themselves segregated when they move to suburbs than other minority groups, a study by a University of Chicago sociologist has found.

title: U.S. Cites Safety Gains, but Also Lapses, by Delta
description: A government agency, winding up an inspection prompted by an Aug. 31 crash that killed 14 people, said yesterday that Delta Air Lines had made significant safety improvements but that numerous ''deficiencies'' uncovered a year ago had still not been corrected.

title: BRE Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 Presidents-Elect Discuss Future of U.S.-Mexican Ties
description: President-elect Bush met Mexico's incoming President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, today in an effort to smooth the troubled and delicate United States-Mexican relationship.

title: AME Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes the impact of change in depreciable lives of certain assets from five years to seven years, increasing net earnings by $340,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,080,000, or 22 cents a share, for the year, and pretax gains on disposition of fixed assets of $37,470 and $130,697 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a pretax loss of $37,947 for the quarter and a gain of $132,793 for the year, both on disposition of fixed assets.

title: Bush Is Seeking Blacks And Women for Cabinet
description: President-elect Bush, with a chief of staff and three Cabinet officers chosen, still faces the politically sensitive challenge of completing his Cabinet in a way that will satisfy his hopes of giving representation to blacks, women and Democrats.

title: Charming Shoppes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Dance Benefit
description: Four dance companies and two soloists from the United States and Canada are to perform in a benefit for Amnesty International on Dec. 19 at 7:30 P.M. at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. The performers include Pilobolus, I.S.O., the David Parsons Company and La La La Human Steps, with solo dancing by Margie Gillis and Alan Boeding. Tickets for the performance alone are $75; with a dinner at the Man Ray Bistro after the performance, the prices are $500, $250 and $150. Information: 633-4122.

title: Janet Kidd, British Socialite, 80
description: Janet Kidd, socialite daughter of the first Lord Beaverbrook, the Canadian-born press baron and politician, died on Friday at home in Ewhurst, southwest of London, her family reported today. She was 80 years old. No cause of death was given.

title: La-Z-Boy Chair Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Jacobs Taking Over As Designer at Ellis
description: Marc Jacobs will take over next Monday as the designer responsible for the Perry Ellis women's collections, according to Nicholas Di Paolo, president of the Salant Corporation, the parent company of Perry Ellis Sportswear.

title: Harold Katz, 65, Dies; Engineer and Executive
description: Dr. Harold W. Katz, a business executive and electrical engineer, died of cancer yesterday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Buffton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $718,675 from an accounting change.

title: Witness Tells of Bitten Fingernails And Red Knuckles on Steinberg
description: Joel B. Steinberg methodically bit his fingernails one by one, chewed for a moment and then swallowed hard before his hands were to be videotaped for evidence, a prosecution witness testified yesterday at Mr. Steinberg's murder trial.

title: System Integrators reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

description: b-Includes a loss of $78,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and the 9 months include net from discontinued operations of $880,000. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $1,032,000 and $285,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Youth Is Convicted Of Setting Pair Afire
description: An 18-year-old youth was found guilty of assault yesterday for pouring gasoline on the blanket of a couple sleeping in Prospect and setting it afire.

title: Interface Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Varieties For the Bookshelf
description: SOMEONE once complained that the Venetian composer Antonio Vivaldi wrote the same concerto 450 times. It's different with wine: the book, like the concerto, doesn't change; only the writers do. Each year around this time the new books appear, most of them reinventing the wheel, or the grape, one more time.

title: Ohio Mattress Chief Sees Value in a Name
description: Ernest M. Wuliger built the world's largest bedding enterprise, prosaically known as the Ohio Mattress Company. Now, Mr. Wuliger and the company's board have put the Cleveland-based concern up for sale.

title: BUSH VOWS TALKS ON HIS FIRST DAY TO CUT THE DEFICIT
description: President-elect Bush said today that he would open negotiations with Congress on his first day in office in an effort to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Devaluation in Vietnam
description: Vietnam has devalued its currency, the dong, to 2,600 to the dollar, from 368, but this is still far higher than the black market rate, a Western diplomat said today. The Hanoi-based diplomat said a dollar fetches 4,600 dong on the black market. State-run hotels in Ho Chi Minh City, the commercial center, were openly giving guests a rate of 3,600, he said. Neither the Communist Government nor the state bank formally announced the change, which took effect earlier this month.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: L.P.G.A. Picks Commissioner
description: The Ladies Professional Golf Association yesterday appointed William Blue as commissioner, replacing John Laupheimer, who resigned in July after almost seven years in the position.

title: Jersey Savings Law in Effect
description: New Jersey banking officials announced Monday that the state's new interstate savings and loan association law had taken effect, allowing savings institutions from 13 other states to make acquisitions in New Jersey.

title: Odyssey Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: In the year-ago second quarter and 6 months, the company was in development and had no revenue.

title: Empire State Life reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $1,741. c-Net income and the 9 months is after capital gains of $252,358.

title: Still Cooking, After a Century Of Thanksgivings and Other Feasts
description: ''THESE days I'm cooked out,'' said Mattie Ball Fletcher as she beat a bowl of boiled turnips with a wooden spoon, carefully adding sugar. So she says, but Mrs. Fletcher - Mattie Ball to her friends - was certainly giving those turnips a workout. The setting was her kitchen in Washington, Va., about 90 miles southwest of the nation's capital. Tomorrow Mrs. Fletcher will celebrate her 101st Thanksgiving. Today is her 100th birthday. Among family and friends, Mrs. Fletcher has always been known as a good cook. The older she's got, however, the more serious a cook she's become. ''When she stopped driving in her late 80's it gave her more time for cooking,'' said her 70-year-old son, Jim Bill Fletcher, a lawyer and farmer like his late father.

title: Mayfair Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $57,000 for the quarter and $831,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $552,000 and $1,449,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Latvia Rejects Challenge to Kremlin
description: The legislature of Latvia decided tonight not to declare itself sovereign, apparently giving the Kremlin another success in its efforts to blunt the Baltic republics' opposition to proposed constitutional changes.

description: b-Includes an investment gain of $74,000 and $1,117,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss from discontinued operations of $34,000 and $124,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss

description: To the Editor:

title: Victor A. Lowe, 81, Philosophy Professor
description: Victor A. Lowe, professor emeritus of philosophy at Johns Hopkins University, died of pneumonia Nov. 16 at Union Memorial Hospital in Baltimore . He was 81 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Market Place; ARCO's Offering On Its Subsidiary
description: THE Atlantic Richfield Company's plans to sell at least half its petrochemical subsidiary in an initial public offering early next year come at a time when the chemical industry appears to be at its peak. Rising demand for commodity petrochemicals has increased prices throughout the last year, and some companies expect 1988 earnings to reach levels not seen in more than five years.

title: Bank Forecasts '89 U.S. Growth
description: The nation's economy will grow in 1989 for the seventh straight year, despite a Federal budget deficit that will swell to $170 billion, a Bank of America study said. The bank's 1989 United

The Soviet Economy: Worse Than We Thought
description: LEAD: In what is becoming a familiar pattern, an announcement from the Kremlin has confounded some received wisdom in the West about the Soviet economy.

title: Noel Gerson, 75, Dies; Author of 325 Books
description: Noel B. Gerson, who wrote 325 books of fact and fiction under his own name and several pseudonyms, died of a heart attack on Sunday at Boca Raton (Florida) Community Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Hall Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss was attributable to its unrealized losses on investments. The company also said on Aug. 31, Hall Real Estate Group merged with and into May Petroleum Inc. to form Hall Financial Group Inc. The merger was accounted for on a processor cost basis, which is similar to the pooling of interest method of accounting. As such, the financial information gives effect to the merger as if it had occured at the beginning of the periods presented.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $127,000 and $321,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $95,000 and $310,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: British Bar Harper's on Spy Story
description: The British Government has broadened its efforts to censor the memoirs of a former secret service agent by blocking the distribution of the current issue of Harper's magazine in Britain. The December Harper's includes excerpts from the book, ''Inside M.I.6,'' by Anthony Cavendish, who retired more than 30 years ago.

title: Where Do Cranberries Come From, Anyway? The Answers
description: JACK ANGLEY settled back in his easy chair and tried to get some sleep. It was going to be a long night. Mr. Angley is not a father-to-be or a physician on call. He is a cranberry grower here in Carver, about 35 miles southeast of Boston, and this particular night he was expecting to be jolted from sleep by the sound of an alarm indicating that the temperature outside had dropped below freezing.

title: Clothing Jump: New Lines and Costly Wool
description: The introduction of higher-priced fall and winter merchandise and the rising cost of raw materials, particularly wool, are mostly responsible for a continuing surge in clothing prices, Government economists, industry executives and securities analysts said today.

title: Retailing Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Kabul Journal; Whose Sky? Boys Fly Kites, and Men Fire Shells
description: Multicolored kites, attached to cheerful boys below, dot the Kabul sky just above the tawdry buildings and vehicular and pedestrian chaos of this shapeless, war-swollen capital.

title: Raymond A. Dart Is Dead at 95; Leader in Study of Human Origins
description: Raymond A. Dart, the anatomist who in 1924 revolutionized the study of human origins with his discovery of an early human fossil in Africa, died yesterday in Johannesburg. He was 95 years old.

title: Mary K. Frank, Producer, 77
description: Mary K. Frank, a theatrical producer, died Sunday at her home in Grand View-on-Hudson, N.Y. She was 77 years old.

title: Founder to Drop a Title At Henson Aviation
description: Richard A. Henson, the founder of Henson Aviation, a commuter airline based in Maryland, is handing over some controls after a colorful career that began in 1931.

title: Termiflex Corp reports earnings for
Kennebunkport Journal; Slight Anxiety Over the Return of 2 Old Friends
description: As President-elect Bush prepares for a triumphant Thanksgiving holiday return to his longtime summer home here, this usually tranquil seaside town is abuzz with questions:

title: Transcisco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $145,000 for the quarter and income of $4,946,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $1,599,000 and $2,979,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Depleted Nets Are Routed
description: The high-powered offense of the Nuggets and the high altitude in Denver caused big trouble for the undermanned Nets tonight.

title: Review/Theater; The Art, Life and Death of Joe Orton
description: Joe Orton's violent death at the hands of Kenneth Halliwell transformed his life into theatrical mythology. Though his body of work is small - three full-length plays and several shorter ones - his reputation as a modern-day Oscar Wilde remains ascendant. At the same time, his bizarre personal life continues to be a source of public interest, as chronicled in John Lahr's biography ''Prick Up Your Ears'' and, last year, in the Stephen Frears film of the same name.

title: First Boston Seeks Help On Nabisco
description: In an effort to bolster its bid for RJR Nabisco Inc., an investment group led by the First Boston Corporation has asked three well-known deal makers to participate in what would be the largest purchase ever of a corporation.

title: About New York; Done Reading That Cereal Box? Meet the Author
description: As the short, rumpled man pushes his cart up and down supermarket aisles, he tries to strike up conversations with fellow New Yorkers. Lest you've already concluded he's unhinged, perverted or participating in some weirdo Learning Annex course, let it be hastily stated that the man has an unimpeachable ulterior motive.

title: Spear Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $33,978 and $537,010 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Reviews/Film; 'Full Moon,' Down Home In Texas
description: In spite of the participation of a number of talented people, ''Full Moon in Blue Water'' is almost as immediately forgettable as its title. The film is set in a town named Blue Water, on the Gulf Coast of Texas, and it takes place during a full moon. The full moon is seen by the audience, and a character says at one point, ''There's a full moon tonight.''

title: Review/Film; A Heist, a Small-Time Hood and His Family Life
description: Though Buster Edwards played a role in one of the biggest heists in recent history, he was strictly small-time. His exploits were petty enough to include, for instance, the middle-of-the-night theft of baby clothes, with a shopping list supplied by his pregnant wife. So what makes Buster a fit subject for a feature-length film biography? Perhaps nothing more than Buster's feisty, indefatigable manner, and the fact that he was there.

title: Bridge
description: Players from the New York metropolitan area captured two major titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Monday night.

title: George Washington reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $49,815 for the quarter and realized investment losses of $127,701 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $912,483 for the quarter and realized investment losses of $295,910.

title: Now, Down the Stretch . . .
description: Measuring the speed of a computer is one of the most hotly debated issues in the computer industry. Manufacturers routinely choose yardsticks that show their products in the best light.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Canadian election carried an erroneous dateline in some editions. It should have read, ''Toronto, Tuesday, Nov. 22,'' not Thursday.

title: Sports People; Nicklaus Optimistic
description: The back problem that threatened to end the golf career of Jack Nicklaus, who holds a record 18 major professional titles, has improved enough for him to consider picking up his clubs again, perhaps by this weekend.

title: Exploration Co of Louisiana reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title: Max Goldschein, 89, Ex-Prosecutor for U.S.
description: Max H. Goldschein, a lawyer who brought cases against organized crime figures in a 24-year career in the Federal Justice Department, died Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Steve's Homemade Ice Cream Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss On Aug. 24, 1988, Steve's consummated the merger with Swensen's Inc.

title: Topics of The Times; Incomplete Message on Sex
description: In 1981 New Jersey became one of the few states to require instruction in schools about human sexuality. Local districts, however, may decide content and message - which helps explain why the programs have had strong parent and community support.

title: Accord Is Seen Reducing Injury In Meatpacking
description: The Government and the nation's largest meatpacking company, along with its union, have negotiated an innovative agreement that could mean a dramatic break with assembly-line procedures in use in the meatpacking industry for a quarter of a century.

description: Dictionary of the Khazars A Lexicon Novel in 100,000 Words By Milorad Pavic Translated by Christina Pribicevic-Zoric. Illustrated. 338 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

description: The names of the first 30 American high schools that will participate next year in an exchange program with Soviet secondary schools were announced today.

description: The NCNB Corporation said today that it had completed, as expected, the purchase of 20 percent of NCNB Texas National Bank for $210 million. The North Carolina banking company said it continued to retain a five-year option to acquire the balance of the Texas unit's equity from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Upjohn Plans TV Spots For Anti-Baldness Drug
description: The Upjohn Company of Kalamazoo, Mich., the only American company to get Food and Drug Administration approval to market a baldness treatment containing minoxidil, will be running its first 30-second TV spot for the product this evening during ABC's ''War and Remembrance.''

description: The Bank of New York Company is publicly offering $100 million of fixed- and adjustable-rate noncumulative preferred stock through Morgan Stanley & Company.

Harvey Herman Agency Adds Kaufman Carpet
description: Harvey Herman Associates has added the Kaufman Carpet Company, with 37 stores, almost all of them in the New York metropolitan area, to its roster of retail clients.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, reflecting the recent increase in short-term rates. Since the beginning of the month, rates at the auction have risen better than one-half of a percentage point.

title: Giant Food Inc reports earnings for 12wk to Nov 5
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 100 percent stock dividend issued June 3, 1988.

title: Petrie Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $57,100,000.

title: U.S. Welcomes Move By South Africans On Peace Agreement
description: The United States welcomed the announcement today by South Africa that it had joined Angola and Cuba in approving a peace plan for the independence of Namibia and the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Canada Grasps the Future
description: Brian Mulroney now has the mandate he sought for free trade with the United States. More important, Canadian voters rejected the opposition's anti-American pandering and helped redefine their nation as a forward-looking, self-confident participant in an interdependent world.

title: Claire's Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $530,000 from an accounting change.

title: Managers May Buy Media Buying Company
description: Senior management at Media General Broadcast Services has received the go-ahead, at least in principle, to purchase the company for an undisclosed amount by January. The media buying company, whose revenues for 1988 are expected to exceed $75 million, specializes in buying spot TV and spot radio time. Its parent company is Media General Inc., Richmond.

title: Wheat Rebound Seen
description: The United States wheat crop could rebound next year by almost 40 percent, to 2.5 billion bushels, with good weather and increased plantings, the Agriculture Department said on Monday. The output rise would follow steep drops this year as a result of the drought.

title: Farm Credit Unit Sets Bond Yields
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering a total of $2.58 billion in bonds with maturities of three months, six months and one year through various securities dealers. All the bonds are priced at par.

title: Stocks Higher in Light Day; Dow Up 11.73
description: Stock prices ended moderately higher yesterday, but volume continued to languish in advance of the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: U.S. on an Arafat Visa: No Shortcuts
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that the United States had agreed to grant him a visa allowing him to address the United Nations. But the State Department, deeply divided on the question, said it had not made a decision.

title: Intel Wins Round in Suit
description: The Intel Corporation said today that an administrative law judge for the International Trade Commission had issued an initial determination finding that the Hyundai Electronics Company of Korea and six affiliated United States companies had violated two of Intel's seven patents pertaining to certain electronically programmable read-only memory chips, or Eprom's. The judge found the other five patents valid, but not infringed.

description: When President-elect Bush held a news conference today to announce his choice for national security adviser, he added a new acronym to Washington's alphabet soup of departments, agencies and organizations.

description: The dollar fell to a 40-year low against the Japanese yen in New York trading yesterday, shrugging off intervention by the Federal Reserve and again raising the question of how far the United States and its economic allies will let the dollar fall.

description: The judge in the Iran-contra case today gave Oliver L. North until Dec. 19 to specify any additional Government secrets he would disclose in defending himself at his trial on conspiracy charges.

title: U.S. Set to Require Shoulder Harnesses In Rear Seats of Cars
description: The Transportation Department said today it plans to require automakers to install shoulder harnesses for passengers in rear seats of cars beginning with the 1990 model year.

title: Brent Scowcroft's Several Strengths
description: George Bush said yesterday that he wanted an ''honest broker'' in the sensitive job of national security adviser. He not only defined the adviser's proper role but has named the best candidate on his short list. Brent Scowcroft's most obvious strength is that he filled the same job capably from 1975 to 1977.

title: GREEN SUSPENDS THE SCHOOL BOARD IN BRONX DISTRICT
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, suspended a local school board in the Bronx yesterday, citing a grand jury investigation into complaints that some of its members have used and distributed illegal drugs, stolen school equipment and extorted money from teachers, principals and other school employees.

title: Cycare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1,480,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Review/Theater; A Pan Asian Chekhov
description: ''The Three Sisters'' takes place in a provincial town in an unspecified part of Russia. In the Pan Asian Repertory Theater production, the town is ''on the Siberian-Mongolian border.'' That geographic specification, a reasonable shift, is the company's principal alteration to allow for nontraditional casting in the Chekhov drama. This is in direct contrast to the previous Pan Asian productions of a ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and ''Shogun Macbeth,'' which, with intriguing results, transposed Shakespeare in time and place.

title: Cuomo Faces Big Challenge In Budget Gap
description: Governor Cuomo, who in times of economic growth has maintained a popular image as both a compassionate liberal and a fiscal conservative, is confronting the daunting political challenge of sustaining this dual image in the face of a $2 billion budget gap.

title: Peru, Its Economy in Crisis, Plans New Austerity Moves
description: The Peruvian Government has announced new austerity measures aimed at battling the country's sharp inflation and huge budget deficit.

title: Amwest Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $36,000 for the quarter and $80,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $72,000 and $69,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: A Bower Of Gardeners' Holiday Gifts
description: THE choice of gifts for the gardener on your holiday list is vast. From the whimsical to the practical, the possibilities are as close as your telephone or mailbox, with no worries about color or fit. Prices listed here include shipping, except where otherwise noted. Minnesota Birch Birdhouse

title: Books of The Times; More Veronica Geng Wit, With a Personal Twist
description: Love Trouble Is My Business By Veronica Geng 167 pages. Harper & Row. An Edward Burlingame Book. $15.95.

title: Waterhouse Investor reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: North American Trade Bloc? Mexico Rejects Such an Idea
description: President Reagan's vision of a North American Common Market that would extend ''from the Yukon to the Yucatan'' is not likely to be realized soon. Although approval of a free-trade agreement with Canada is imminent because Prime Minister Brian Mulroney won a parliamentary majority in Monday's election, a similar agreement with Mexico remains little more than a dream.

title: BRIEFING
description: Cluing In Senators

title: Election Chief Fined On Contributions To G.O.P. in Jersey
description: The chairman of the State Election Law Enforcement Commission was found guilty of ethical violations today for making political contributions and was fined $1,100 by the Executive Committee on Ethical Standards.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/A3-17

title: Prices Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light pre-holiday trading yesterday.

title: Kentucky Central Life Insur reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $259,040 for the quarter and $1,571,859 for the 9 months. c-After a capital loss of $456,457 for the quarter and a capital gain of $2,389,619 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $100,000 and $2.6 million for the same periods, respectively. The latest periods included an non- recurring after-tax gain of $2.6 million, or 19 cents a share, on the sale of broadcasting properties. The year-ago periods included non- recurring after-tax gains of $6.3 million, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter, and $8.6 million, or 67 cents a share, for the 9 months, both on the sale of broadcasting properties.

title: To Catch a Thief (and Enroll Him)
description: For shoplifters, Peter D. Berlin is both a scourge and a savior.

title: Liquid Diet Safe But Demanding
description: Doctors who specialize in treating obesity say liquid protein diets, when medically supervised, are safe and effective in helping extremely fat people lose weight.

title: EX-JUDGE SETTLES MISCONDUCT CASE
description: A former assistant county judge, Jane Wheel, has agreed not to contest a finding that her actions violated Vermont's code of judicial conduct, ending a two-year-old case that had implicated three Vermont Supreme Court justices.

title: Stake Held in Artra
description: Philip Elghanian, a British citizen with offices in New York, has bought a 5.1 percent stake in Artra Group Inc., a manufacturer of diversified plastics and metal machinery based in Northfield, Ill. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Elghanian said he had purchased the Artra shares as an investment. Mr. Elghanian bought his 159,400 Artra shares on the open market for an average price of $24.98 a share. The company's share price rose 75 cents today, to $24.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Reagan Decides To Kill Measure On Ethics Rules
description: President Reagan announced today that he would pocket veto legislation tightening restrictions on lobbying by former Government officials and imposing them on members of Congress for the first time.

title: Father, Struggling on His Own, Is Aided by Neediest Cases
description: On one plaster wall of his apartment, high in a plain brick building in the heart of the South Bronx, Melvyn Griffen has drawn, in careful pencil, the beginnings of a mural. A pharaoh stares east as a princess hovers behind his throne, and a magnificent bird soars above them.

title: Vons Cos. reports earnings for 16wk to Oct 9
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $300,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months is after a tax credit of 1,700,000. Results include operations of the Southern California operations of Safeway Stores Inc. that were acquired on Aug. 29, 1988. Latest quarter consists of 16 weeks. Year-ago figures were not comparable.

title: GEO International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
City Center Mezzanine To Be Named for Joffrey
description: The Joffrey Ballet will donate the proceeds of its matinee performance tomorrow of ''The Nutcracker'' to the City Center in honor of Robert Joffrey, founder of the company, who died on March 25. The donation, commemorating the 31-year association of the troupe and the theater, will be used in part to renovate the theater's mezzanine, which will be renamed the Robert Joffrey Mezzanine.

title: Mechanical Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Africa's Locust War Perils Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Daisy Sets Terms Of Bid for Cadnetix
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, a Mountain View, Calif., producer of computer-aided design and engineering systems, announced the definitive terms of its agreement to acquire the Cadnetix Corporation, a producer of similar systems, based in Boulder, Colo.

title: Bhutto Accuses Foes of Bribery and Intimidation
description: Benazir Bhutto accused her political rivals today of bribing and intimidating legislators to prevent her from becoming Prime Minister.

title: Review/Piano; Alicia de Larrocha Plays 'Iberia' Suite
description: There is really nothing in Isaac Albeniz's ''Iberia'' that a good three-handed pianist could not master, given unlimited years of practice and permission to play at half tempo. But there are few pianists thus endowed. So, because the composer's suite of 12 impressions of his Spanish homeland ranks near the top of the scale in technical difficulty and sheer staying power, the few pianists who undertake to play the complete ''Iberia'' in public are usually so overwhelmed by the keyboard problems that any poetic intentions tend to be buried under an avalanche of meaningless notes.

title: Andrew Haswell Green, Where Are You When We Need You?
description: To the Editor:

title: S&K Famous Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $401,400.

title: Jets' Rookie Safety No Friend of Marino
description: Erik McMillan is the spoilsport who boos the hero's aria, the wise guy who cheers the villain. He even gives quarterbacks no respect.

title: Armatron International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $22,000 and $33,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and the year is after net from discontinued operations of $1,500,000.

title: Israeli Election System Could Be Reformed
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay-by-Bag Trash Disposal Really Pays, Town Learns
description: Tossing out the household trash here requires care and some ingenuity these days. Reckless old habits cost money, now that residents pay for garbage disposal by the bag.

title: Cenvill Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of land of $1,420,000, or 21 cents a share, for both the quarter and 9 months, partially offset by an addition to loan-loss reserves of $191,000. c-Included a gain from the sale of land of $713,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: Standard Havens reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $591,298 and $1,969,298 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $325,834 and $1,308,834 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ABC Publishing, a unit of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., said it had acquired Worthy Publishing, a company specializing in Bibles, children's books and personal growth books, from Sweet Publishing Co. of Fort Worth. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Copper Prices Rise To Record
description: A pound of copper sold for a record $1.60 yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York. So great was the demand that prices closed with the largest one-day rises on record at the 55-year-old Comex.

title: British Output Rises by 1.4%
description: Britain's real gross domestic product, measured by the output of goods and services, rose 1.4 percent in the third quarter from the previous three months and was up 5 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, the Government said today.

title: Affiliate of Xerox In Soviet Venture
description: The Soviet Union's first public copy centers will begin opening early next year under a joint venture between the Xerox Corporation's European affiliate and a Soviet agency. Under the agreement, the Eastern Export Operations division of Rank Xerox Ltd. will cooperate with Vnesghtorgizdat, the international division of the Soviet state publishing organization. Together they will open, equip and train staff for the copy centers.

title: Search Ends at Brokerage
description: Federal agents have ended a four-day search of financial records at Blinder, Robinson & Company, and the police said a craps table and slot machine had been seized from the penny-stock firm.

title: Blacks to Be in Selma Runoffs
description: In an election on Tuesday, four blacks moved into primary runoffs in a campaign to elect the first black member to the Dallas County Commission in more than a century.

title: Schoolchildren Benefit From California Law on Volunteerism
description: Ten-year-old Miguel Pineda is still weak on spelling, but the fifth-grader's reading is markedly improved since he hooked up in September with a tutor, Ralph Manak, an undergraduate at San Francisco State University.

title: Abbey Life Plans New Lloyds Deal
description: Abbey Life Group P.L.C. said it was restructuring its proposals to buy five businesses from Lloyds Bank P.L.C. in an attempt to salvage a proposed merger with the leading British bank. Under the new terms, Abbey Life, a British life insurance company, would acquire the businesses in exchange for 380 million Abbey Life new ordinary shares, amounting to 57.6 percent of the enlarged capital.

title: Too Much Lemieux As Rangers Lose
description: The game was as unseemly and dangerous as both the Rangers and the Penguins had professed to fear it would be. There were high sticks and slashes to go with trips and hooks and cross-checks.

title: King-Cayton Joust Continues
description: A new date, Feb. 25, has been offered for Mike Tyson's mandatory heavyweight title defense against Frank Bruno of England. But questions remain whether this date at the Las Vegas Hilton will prove to be any more solid than the previous ones for a fight that has been postponed several times over the past few months.

title: BLACKS SPARED DEATH IN PRETORIA
description: President P. W. Botha today commuted the death sentences of six South African blacks whose case had become the focus of an international campaign for clemency.

title: Panel Calls for Review Of Breast Implant Safety
description: A Federal advisory panel says there is not enough evidence of health risk to ban silicone breast implants, but it is calling for a long-term study of the safety of such implants.

title: NDL Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sununu Tells Leaders of Jewish Groups He Firmly Backs Israel
description: Gov. John H. Sununu, picked by President-elect Bush to be his White House chief of staff, sought to assure leaders of American Jewish groups yesterday that he was a strong supporter of Israel.

title: Correction
description: An article on Tuesday about the indictment of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee Garcia, misstated her role at the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Mrs. Garcia was president of the board for five years, until June 1987. She remained on the board until June 1988.

title: Herbert Alexander, Pocket Books Editor And Publisher, 78
description: Herbert W. Alexander, former publisher and editor in chief of Pocket Books, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Salvador Rebels: Where Do They Get the Arms?
description: In the midst of stepped-up guerrilla attacks in El Salvador, Salvadoran and American officials are again accusing Nicaragua of materially supporting the left-wing rebels in El Salvador.

title: Towers Agrees to Charges
description: The Towers Financial Corporation, the big New York-based factoring firm, today consented to Federal civil charges that it had failed to register $34 million worth of securities before selling them to the public.

title: U.S. Cites Japan On Dumping
description: The Commerce Department issued a final ruling on Tuesday that Japan has been selling digital industrial equipment in the United States at less than cost. The ruling represents the first step toward imposing permanent antidumping duties.

title: Let Parents Regulate Children's Viewing
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 460 money market mutual funds increased by $1.07 billion, to $280.40 billion, for the week that ended on Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 131 institutional funds decreased by $501.5 million, to $72.28 billion. The assets of the 229 general purpose funds were up by $660.50 million, to $89.90 billion. The 100 broker-dealer funds increased by $906.9 million, to $118.23 billion, the institute said.

title: Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, 87, Is Dead; Ex-President of Teachers College
description: Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, president of Teachers College of Columbia University from 1954 to 1962, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at the retirement community of Samarkand in Santa Barbara, Calif., where he had lived since 1972. He was 87 years old. Dr. Caswell, who became Marshall Field Jr. Professor of Education at the college after stepping down as president, retired in 1967. He was the fifth president of the 101-year-old institution and had served on the faculty for nearly three decades. A 1929 graduate of the college, he was its dean for five years before assuming the presidency.

title: Parents Face Baby Sale Charge
description: The parents of a 2-month-old baby have been charged with selling their son for $3,500 and three ounces of uncut cocaine, the police said. Charles Albert Pannuty and Gayle Duty, both 35 years old, of Severn, were arrested in a parking lot Tuesday, said Sgt. Joseph Bisesi of the Anne Arundel County Police Department. The baby, Joseph Patrick Pannuty, was turned over to child protective services, he said. The couple has four other children, but Sergeant Bisesi said he did not know whether they had been turned over to authorities.

title: Royal Business Group reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $75,000 loss from discontinued operations, a $2,570,000 gain on the disposal of a discontinued division, a $467,000 gain from the extinguishment of debt, and a $2,202,000 tax credit.

title: Computer & Communications Technologies Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Some Koreans Still Ask Action on Chun
description: Former President Chun Doo Hwan retreated to a monastery today after an abject televised apology, but he faced renewed calls from South Koreans for an accounting for abuses during his eight-year rule.

title: Chrysler Recalls 580,000 Cars to Fix Hoses
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had recalled 580,000 front-wheel drive autos from the 1985 through 1987 model years to repair a fuel-hose problem.

title: Botanical Garden Dishes Up The Dirt
description: PEOPLE who like to play in the dirt can now shun the ordinary kind and wallow in a designer mixture from the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Celina Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $27,000 and $235,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and investment gains of $114 for the quarter and $3,925 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After a reversal of a tax credit of $85,111 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $82,790 for the 9 months, and investment gains of $119,341 and $154,801 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $186,000, pretax gains of $655,000 from the curtailment of a pension plan, and $427,000 from the sale of its headquarters. c-Includes a tax credit of $186,000. d-Net loss

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $292,000 and $574,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $173,000 and $362,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also include a $212,618 gain relatd to the sale of undeveloped land.

title: Second Victim Dies In Crash at K Mart
description: The mother of the woman killed when a car smashed through a K Mart department store in Belleville, N.J., last week has died of injuries related to the accident, officials said.

title: Peete Recovers
description: The case of laryngitis that had raised questions about the ability of the Southern California quarterback, Rodney Peete, to call signals against Notre Dame on Saturday has eased. Peete was speaking normally yesterday and expects no problems during the game.(AP)

title: Colombia Defense Chief Unhurt in Bombing
description: Dynamite hidden in a lamppost exploded near Defense Minister Jaime Guerrero Paz as he was leaving his office Tuesday night, killing three of his bodyguards and wounding two others but leaving the minister unhurt, authorities said.

title: 2 Charged in Scheme To Aid Drug Dealers
description: A Haverstraw police officer and the Rockland County affirmative action director have been charged with giving drug dealers information about police undercover operations in exchange for cocaine and marijuana, officials said yesterday.

title: Group Buys Stake In Liberty All-Star
description: A group led by the New York investment adviser John A. Levine purchased a 5.15 percent stake in Liberty All-Star Equity Fund and said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it supports a proposal to change Liberty's classification from a closed-end fund to open-end status. Mr. Levin's investment group includes the Continental Casualty Company, an insurance concern controlled by the Loews Corporation and the New York investors Preston R. Tisch and Laurence A. Tisch.

title: Court Bars Certifying Of Florida House Vote
description: The Florida Supreme Court today ordered the state not to certify the results of a Congressional race that Representative Bill Chappell Jr. had lost in a recount.

title: Syntro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
John Ragazzini, 76, Educator and Engineer
description: Dr. John R. Ragazzini, an educator and electrical engineer, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Howe Avenue Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 76 years old and was a longtime resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Terrific Teeny TV's
description: Some market analysts are wondering if Sony will find many buyers for its new Video Walkman, a hand-held color television that can play videotapes. But a friend who recently bought a tiny black-and-white television set at a garage sale says she wonders why anybody would want a TV set that's bigger. The evening news seems much less cataclysmic when reduced to the size of a matchbook, she says. The stature of politicians is more in proportion to the words coming out of their mouths. ''The Honeymooners'' is no less funny, Ted Koppel's head looks more comely, and staying home to watch television with a friend becomes wonderfully cozy. Fortunately, she has no interest in watching sports events. She says that, on her midget screen, they look like flea circuses.

title: In Giving Thanks, Some Remember the Indians
description: Navajos in northeastern Arizona have sent 6,000 sprigs of sage, a sacred plant, to a cathedral in Manhattan. The Onondagas of upstate New York are sending the Ankle Deep singers, with their water drums. And Indian nations from the North, South, East and West are sending chiefs and other tribal leaders to mark Thanksgiving Day.

title: Vehicle Sales Up by 3.5% In Mid-November Period
description: Sales of new domestic cars and light trucks were up by 3.5 percent in mid-November from the comparable period last year, when buyer incentives were weaker.

title: Were 2 Dolphins Saved or Abducted?
description: While attention was focused on three whales trapped by ice off Alaska last month, the fate of two performing dolphins half a world away went largely unnoticed: no Soviet vessels to their rescue, no message from President Reagan.

title: Apache Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,520,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary gain of $342,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $672,000 for the quarter and $1,617,000 for the 9 months.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Brent Scowcroft; Sentinel of Security
description: In selecting Brent Scowcroft as his national security adviser, President-elect Bush has chosen a highly experienced Washington hand whose independent views on arms control have often put him at odds with Reagan Administration policies.

title: CPAC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Cyclamens: Subtlety In Fall's Palette
description: EACH autumn for several years now, I have ordered several plants of the hardy cyclamens C. coum and C. hederifolium from Montrose Nursery here. For me, these cyclamens signal the closing of another garden year. They are far from spectacular, but they have a dainty beauty that invites gardeners to their knees to take a closer look.

title: Nutrition: Diet That Made Oprah Winfrey Slim Demands Discipline, Specialists Say
description: A growing number of physicians say that very low-calorie diets, when medically supervised, can be valuable in treating seriously obese people who have failed on more conservative diets.

title: Reporter's Notebook; The Honorable 'Prince of Darkness'
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers like to call Acting Justice Harold J. Rothwax the ''Prince of Darkness,'' an ominous sobriquet they offer more in awe than in anger - and never to his face.

title: Ruth Foreman Is Dead; Theater Producer, 81
description: Ruth Foreman, a theater producer, died of a brain tumor on Tuesday at her home in North Miami. She was 81 years old, according to published reports and associates.

title: Florida Freebies
description: Some of New York's most influential lawmakers thought nothing of accepting free air fare and accommodations to attend last week's New York Savings Bank convention in Boca Raton, Fla. In the process they threw a shadow over both banking and government.

title: Social Scene: For Bushes, Coziness Is In and the Jellybean Out
description: When it comes to establishing social cachet here, it helps to be sprinkled with a little White House glitter dust. So the announcement that President-elect Bush had chosen John H. Sununu, the New Hampshire Governor, as his White House chief of staff was duly noted by Embassy Row social secretaries, Georgetown residents and this city's party planners, who are keeping a close watch on all announcements coming out of the office of the President-elect.

title: FOR THE INDIANS, NO THANKSGIVING
description: LEAD: Maybe those Pilgrims and Wampanoags actually got together for a November picnic, maybe not. It matters only as a facile, ironical footnote.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHEN Ben Abella, a freshman at Washington University in St. Louis, returned to Chicago for a few days in October, he said something that stopped his mother cold. ''My son started calling his dormitory 'home,' '' said his mother, Mary Ann Abella. ''And if that doesn't wound you as a parent . . .''

description: b-Net income

title: Nets Defeat Suns With Late Rally
description: Mike McGee scored 29 points, Walter Berry added 26 and Roy Hinson had 8 of his 25 in the fourth quarter as the Nets rallied to beat the Phoenix Suns, 133-129, tonight.

title: 7 Are Accused In Bank Fraud
description: Seven people were arrested today and accused of conspiring to defraud the London branch of the Union Bank of Switzerland of $:32 million ($58.6 million).

title: Potomac Electric Power reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
Columbia Aide May Face Dismissal
description: An assistant football coach for Columbia might be dismissed as a result of his accusing Larry McElreavy, the head coach, of personal misconduct, the school's vice president for academic affairs said yesterday.

description: b-Net income Year-ago revenue includes $3,879,000 from an insurance settlement. The company said excluding the insurance settlement and including a one-time reversal of certain federal and state deferred tax liabilities totaling $1,560,000, its 1987 net loss would have been $5,339,000.

title: Saving an Endangered Species, the Vintage Home
description: LEAD: THERE are, as yet, only two houses finished at Woodbury Lane on Nantucket Island. One is authentic, the other imitation. One, the 1795 Bradford Storey House, was moved here from Vermont; the other is a 1988 reproduction of Nantucket's own Capt. Obed Bunker House, which once stood on the corner of Fair and

title: 886 Bowling Series
description: Pat Landry, a student at Michigan State University who was a substitute on a team on Tuesday, matched a 49-year-old world record by bowling an 886 series in Lansing, Mich. The 21-year-old resident of Pontiac, Mich., rolled 33 strikes in 36 balls with games of 298, 300 and 288. A perfect series is 900. The 886 was set by Allie Brandt in Lockport, N.Y.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: In the annual struggle to find appropriate and affordable holiday gifts, you may overlook an important consideration: allergic reactions to many of the most popular gifts, from fragrances and jewelry to foods, furs, feathers and pets. Consider these common reactions:

title: Yields Post Strong Rise
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose for the week that ended yesterday, as surges in short-term money market rates continued to narrow the gap with yields offered on longer maturities.

title: Comnet reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $36,000 for the quarter and a gain of $885,000 for the 6 months, both on disposal of discontinued operations, and the 6 months also included a loss from discontinued operations of $122,000. c-Net income d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $20,000 and $56,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter's loss was attributable primarily to start-up costs and production ineffeciencies associated with a unit's new facility in Maryland.

title: Raymond Lewenthal, 62, Pianist Of Romantic 19th-Century Pieces
description: Raymond Lewenthal, a colorful and imaginative explorer of forgotten Romantic piano repertory, died of a heart attack Monday night. He was 62 years old and lived in Hudson, N.Y.

title: Q&A
description: Q. About 10 years ago we covered the walls around the bathtub and shower in our upstairs bathroom with Formica. Recently I found a small crack near a corner of the soap dish that has now spread across the main wall. We are afraid to use the shower because we fear water will get into the wall and eventually leak down to the first floor. Can we repair this crack or must the wall be recovered? A.You can fill in and seal the crack with a clear epoxy, sold in hardware and marine-supply outlets. You can then touch this up with a matching paint, or use a kit for repairing and touching up plastic laminates.

title: Synbiotics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $162,000.

title: Lan Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pioneer Finance
description: The Pioneer Finance Corporation is making a public offering of $120 million in 13 1/2 percent first-mortgage bonds with a final maturity in 1998. The issue, made through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, is priced at par. Noncallable for three years and nonrefundable for five years, the high-yield financing is rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Vega Biotechnologies reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and reflects a $209,000 writeoff of registered stock from a canceled stock offering.

title: Dow Climbs by 14.58 In Another Slow Day
description: LEAD: Aided by surging transportation and mining sectors, the stock market moved sharply higher yesterday in a slow pre-holiday session.

title: Homefree Village Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

CURRENTS;
An Unintentional Coffeetable Book
description: LEAD: IN the pages of the offbeat English magazine The World of Interiors, you rarely see the carefully arranged coffeetable books that many decorators use to ''accessorize'' a living room.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: Washington and Moscow appear to be on the brink of renewing the huge United States-Soviet Union grain agreement, ending eight months of difficult negotiations, Government officials said today.

title: Bridge
description: A Texan was bidding for a second straight title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today. Mike Passell of Dallas, who was a winner of the Men's Board-a-Match Team Championship Monday, led after the qualifying stage of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship. Passell, who won a world team championship in 1979, scored 1277.6 match points, or 65 percent, with Gene Freed of Los Angeles.

title: Sax Signs 3-Year Contract With Yankees
description: Writing off Willie Randolph, their second baseman of 13 years, the Yankees last night snatched Steve Sax away from the Los Angeles Dodgers, signing him to a three-year contract worth $4 million.

title: Abrams Asks Power To Force Repairs
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams asked the Legislature yesterday to give him the power to require landlords to repair serious violations before they can convert apartment buildings from rentals to cooperatives or condominiums.

title: Review/Television; To Serve and Reign
description: Up until around World War II, tonight's documentary on ''Smithsonian World'' reminds us, Groton, the famous preparatory school in Massachusetts, was dedicated to providing ''an Episcopal school education for Christian gentlemen.'' It prepared an elite band of Protestant patricians with names like Roosevelt, Harriman, Acheson and Auchincloss to exercise ''responsibility, service and power.''

title: Board Cites Dip in Complaints Against Police
description: The New York City Police Department Civilian Complaint Review Board, under increasing fire over its effectiveness, issued a glowing report yesterday on its performance in 1987, citing a 7.1 percent drop in complaints against officers over all.

title: Long Shots Help Knicks Top Pistons
description: The Detroit Pistons came into the game tonight with a 9-1 record, the best in the National Basketball Association. They had limited their opponents to an average of 98.6 points a game, the second-best record in the league, despite eight games on the road.

title: Reviews/Music; Sine Nomine Goes Baroque
description: In the 20 years since Harry Saltzman founded the Sine Nomine Singers, the chamber choir has become an important part of the New York choral scene, highly regarded for its smooth blend, its crisp, precise diction and the invariably interesting programs Mr. Saltzman dreams up for it. On Saturday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, Mr. Saltzman and his choir marked their 20th anniversary with an unusual program of Baroque music.

title: Canada Girds for Action on Trade Bill
description: With the Progressive Conservatives still celebrating their return to power in Monday's general election, political pressures began building today for action to assist industries and employees who lose their jobs as the country moves into an economic free market with the United States.

title: U.S. to Bar Arms Aid Unless the Recipient Vows to Fight Fraud
description: The United States plans to demand that foreign countries agree in advance to cooperate with Federal investigators as a condition of receiving American aid for the purchase of warplanes, missiles, tanks and other weapons.

title: Perception Technology reports earnings for Year to Oct 1
Beating Cancer Can Sometimes Be Just the Start of the Fight
description: An increasing number of people are surviving cancer only to face another ordeal: job discrimination and social ostracism.

title: Rent-A-Wreck reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Xplor reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: INSIDE
description: Fears of Free Trade

description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,002,000 and $2,008,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $925,000 for the quarter and $2,118,000 for the 9 months.

title: Decom Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $5,000 for the quarter and $232,000 for the year.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $448,000 for the quarter and $1,407,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a $610,000 loss on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $424,000 for the quarter and $764,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a tax benefit of $3,291,000.
