Wright Urges U.S. Action to Slow Buyouts
description: House Speaker Jim Wright said today that the Government should act quickly to slow the pace of leveraged buyouts and hostile corporate takeovers, which he said were having an adverse ''psychological and economic'' impact on the nation.

title: 3 Soviet Soldiers Die As Riots Flare Anew In Southern Region
description: Three soldiers were killed and 126 people were injured in rioting in the southern republic of Azerbaijan on Tuesday, Soviet officials reported today.

title: Some Ailing Giants Are Feeling Better
description: When the Giants started preparations today for Sunday night's game against the Saints in New Orleans, Phil Simms and Doug Riesenberg watched and Eric Dorsey and Zeke Mowatt were limited.

title: 4-Year-Old Pilgrims
description: What was so special, this week, about 80 children dressed up as Pilgrims and singing Thanksgiving songs in Brooklyn's Public School 179? Isn't that what schoolkids are supposed to do? Yes, but not usually at age 4. These children, like 6,000 others, are enrolled in Project Giant Step, a pre-kindergarten program initiated by Mayor Koch in 1986.

title: Lions Still Trying To Catch Carter
description: For the Detroit Lions, Anthony Carter has always been right there, a fingertip grasp away.

title: Lowe's Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Hello? How Do I Change a Diaper?
description: Consumer hot lines are heating up: in the coming weeks millions of Americans will call consumer products companies at toll-free long-distance numbers to ask questions on everything from why the Christmas tree lights will not light to why the dishwasher will not wash.

title: CTS Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $625,000 from an accounting change. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $228,000 for the quarter and $1,043,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Includes a $902,000 gain from an accounting change. Year-ago results restated for an accounting restatement.

title: Zayre Corp. reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $28,644,000 and $78,517,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a $160,000,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations for both periods. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $813,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued opertions of $17,203,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also include a $20,536,000 gain from an accounting change and an after-tax gain of $95,900,000 from the sale of a minority interest in TJX Cos.

title: WITNESS IN TRIAL FAULTS LAROUCHE
description: A man who was a security aide to Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. described his former employer today as a paranoid liar but denied that he harbored hatred toward him.

title: Lester Bogen, an Executive, Is Dead at 63
description: Lester H. Bogen, an executive, philanthropist and community leader in Bergen County, N.J., died of pneumonia Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 63 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title:
CURRENTS;
To the Lighthouse, Creatively
description: LEAD: FOR its Winternight '88 benefit next Wedenesday, the New York Association for the Blind is auctioning 62 miniature lighthouses donated by architects and designers. The designs run the gamut from C to D, that is, from classicism to deconstructivism.

title: Strasbourg Journal; Not Quite the Paper Parliament You Might Think
description: It used to be amusingly fashionable to make fun of the European Parliament, which was ritually portrayed as a self-important but irrelevant debating society bizarrely parked in the northeastern corner of France. Times are changing. As the European Community knits a patchwork of economic interdependence, and as important chunks of sovereignty are surrendered to the organization's Brussels-based bureaucracy, the 518 elected members of the European Parliament are discovering that they have clout, too.

title: Britain Prices British Steel
description: Britain put a value of $4.5 billion on its profit-making steel industry today when it announced details of the largest privatization of an industrial manufacturing concern by the Conservative Government. Each share of British Steel

title: Windmill Case Guilty Plea
description: A Pittsburgh man has pleaded guilty to fraud in connection with false representations made to nearly 100 people seeking windmill dealerships.

title: 2 New Flagships Dock on Madison
description: TWO famous French companies, one known for Art Nouveau glass, the other for Art Deco silver, are opening flagship American boutiques on Madison Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Bush Offers Some Pledges to His Maine Neighbors
description: In the political world of George Bush, good manners count. So when he arrived for Thanksgiving this afternoon in this oceanside village that he claims as one of his hometowns, he did not just breeze through in a dark rush of limousines and Secret Service agents.

title: Review/Dance; Re-creating a First Night of 40 Years Ago
description: History recalls its own great moments only in retrospect. The ballet performance that took place on Oct. 11, 1948, at the City Center of Music and Drama featured no work that any alert dancegoer would not have seen previously.

title: E&B Marine Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a tax loss carryforward of $369,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $925,000 for the 9 months. The company changed the end of its third quarter accounting period to Oct. 2 from Sept. 30 in 1987. Of the $1,091,512 decline in third quarter sales, the company said $938,000 reflected the date change.

title: Man of a Thousand Voices, Speaking Literally
description: Sputtering, spitting, spraying and stuttering, Mel Blanc sits on the couch in his son's Beverly Hills home.

title: Reserve Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Vote Is Near For Drug Test
description: After three days of condemning the use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes, sports ministers from more than 100 countries will be presented with an opportunity Thursday to take action on the subject.

title: Rights Plan at Chevron
description: The Chevron Corporation said Tuesday that it had adopted a shareholder rights plan intended to strengthen its ability to thwart a hostile takeover. George M. Keller, chairman of the San Francisco-based oil company, said Chevron had instituted the rights plan ''in recognition of an extremely active merger and acquisition environment in which hostile, non-negotiated takeover bids have become common.'' The company, which in 1984 acquired the Gulf Oil Company in the largest acquisition in history, said details of the plan would be outlined in a letter to be mailed to shareholders after Dec. 15.

title: Andy Williams Is Out
description: Andy Williams has ended his association with San Diego's annual Professional Golfers Association, tournament after 21 years as host of the event. ''The emphasis has shifted to corporate support of purses,'' said Tom Morgan, the executive director of the Century Club, which organizes the tournament.

title: OPEC Session Rescheduled as Iran-Iraq Impasse Persists
description: After seven days of talks, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries remains mired in a deadlock that reflects the political dispute between Iran and an Arab coalition led by Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.

title: Decoy Decor: Rusticity For Fans of Americana
description: ''PEOPLE want something lovely in the home, and decoys certainly are that,'' said William Bender, the owner of Grove Decoys in Greenwich Village. ''If someone wants a duck, the place to come is here.''

title:
CURRENTS;
Angeles and S.F., Magazines of Design
description: LEAD: FOR the last few years architects and designers have been saying that Los Angeles is the new center of energy for their fields. They say the shift from the East Coast, fueled by a flourishing economy, has paralleled the growth of a vital art community there.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the talks in Jerusalem on forming a new Israeli government misstated results of the Nov. 1 election in some editions. Likud and its rightist allies won 47 seats in Parliament; Labor and its leftist allies won 49.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Instead of extending a welcoming hand to talented people to spend time in Government, it says, 'Warning: Government service may be hazardous to your livelihood,' '' - Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, on ethics bill. [ A1:2. ]

title: FEW AFGHANS END EXILE IN PAKISTAN
description: Seven months after the signing of the Geneva agreements, which provided for the return of more than five million Afghan refugees from exile in Pakistan and Iran, no major movement back into Afghanistan has got under way.

title: Michael Mok, Journalist, 58
description: Michael Mok, a journalist who won a half dozen awards for his reporting, died of a heart attack Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Methode Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Lame-Duck Appointments by President Touch Off Questions About Timing
description: President Reagan's lame-duck appointment of four overseas ambassadors left foreign policy analysts, and at least one appointee himself, wondering today if the new diplomats would have to pack their bags again after just eight weeks.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: ''WHEN I was a little girl, somebody shot the President,'' I said. ''Why?'' said my son. ''I don't know,'' I replied, sounding tired.

title: Calendar: Recalling Holidays of the Past
description: Portrait of an Era, New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street; 212-873-3400.

title: Talking Deals; A Peek at World's First Capitalists
description: THE subject is usury, trade wars, leveraged buyouts, fluctuating currency values, financial flimflam, hostile takeovers, doing business in politically unstable areas, recession fears.

title: TV Notes
description: A Worker Moves Up

title: Bancroft Convertible Fund Inc. reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Assets represent total net assets. The company said its assets were reduced by $18,732,000 in November 1987 in connection with a self-tender offer.

title: Abrams Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Music; Meridian Strings At Weill Hall
description: The Meridian String Quartet (formerly the Queens String Quartet) had an uneven night at Weill Recital Hall on Monday. In Haydn's ''Lark'' quartet and the first of Beethoven's ''Razumovsky'' quartets, the four were plagued by problems of ensemble and intonation that cannot - to judge from good reports - be characteristic of their best work. As so often happens in the delicate art of chamber music playing, one mishap seemed to lead to another as the players' nerves were put on edge. The recurring half-note chords in the Beethoven's first movement were ragged each time.

title: Bigger Stake Seen in Bank
description: Georges Pebereau, the president of Marceau Investissements, said he would probably increase his stake this week in Societe Generale, France's third-largest commercial bank and the only one that is publicly held, to more than 10 percent, from 9.16 percent.

title: JUSTICES DISMISS SUIT OVER CLERGY
description: In a case that had prompted national alarm among church leaders, the California Supreme Court held today that neither the clergy nor others unlicensed as counselors or therapists could be held legally liable for failing to provide proper care for the people they advise.

title: Louis Meltz Marrid To Karen C. Kirschen
description: Karen Cheryl Kirschen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Kirschen of Old Bethpage, L.I., was married yesterday to Louis Solomon Meltz, the son of Ronald Meltz of Pretoria, South Africa, and the late Valerie Meltz. Rabbi William Berman performed the ceremony at Fox Hollow, a restaurant in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $992,000 from casualty loss insurance reimbursements for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes gains of $54,000 for the quarter and $297,000 for the 9 months, from similar insurance reimbursements.

title: Integra-A Hotel & Restaurant Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $895,000 for the quarter and $2,185,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After gains from discontinued operations of $1,889,000 for the quarter and $5,181,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $794,000 and $663,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Hungary Nominates an Economist as Premier
description: Hungary's Communist Party nominated a 40-year-old economist described as a ''young, dynamic workhorse'' for Prime Minister today.

title: Robert Kerr, 71, Dies; An Episcopal Bishop
description: Robert S. Kerr, the seventh Episcopal Bishop of Vermont, died of a heart attack Friday at Medical Center Hospital in Burlington, Vt. He was 71 years old and lived in Vermont.

title: Wrigley Stays True to Gum
description: Compared with other food companies, the William Wrigley Jr. Company seems a throwback. Yet it is among the most successful companies in the business.

title: Zenith Criticizes Dissident Group
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation urged owners of its 27 million shares against siding with dissidents bent on dismantling the last important television manufacturer in the United States. In a letter, Zenith's chairman, Jerry K. Pearlman, acknowledged that the Chicago-area company ''has had some rough times in the past several years,'' but he maintained that the investor group Brookhurst Partners ''has no experience whatsoever in our business.''

title: Sports of The Times; Thanksgiving Thank-Yous
description: Too often the scoundrels are in the headlines. And too often the good folks are taken for granted. But at Thanksgiving it's time to remember those who make sports' little corner of the world a better place to be. Those who deserve a thank-you note just for being themselves:

title: KEY RATES
Acclaim Entertainment reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: The company reported prior year earnings of $84,000 on revenue of $925,000; the prior year represents the period from February 1987, when it began operations, to Aug. 31, 1987.

title: Padres Bid for Hurst
description: Bruce Hurst, the free-agent left-handed pitcher who has been offered a three-year contract worth about $4.7 million from the San Diego Padres, spent a day in San Diego earlier this week, meeting with Padre executives. Dick Freeman, the interim president, and Jack McKeon, the manager, met with Hurst.

title: Beach Use Decision Appealed
description: The prolonged controversy over whether anglers have a right to use more than a mile of privately owned beach on East Island in the city of Glen Cove, L.I., has entered a new phase.

title: Quaker Group Sues U.S. Over Requiring Dismissals of Aliens
description: The service arm of the Quakers has filed a suit in Federal District Court here seeking for itself a religious exemption to new immigration laws that require employers to dismiss illegal aliens.

title: Rail Concern Investigated
description: Burlington Northern Inc., which includes the nation's largest rail system, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for possible insider trading, company officials say.

title: Pact Eases Strike Threat at Chicago Sun-Times
description: Barely averting a strike that industry analysts said could have doomed the newspaper, The Chicago Sun-Times arrived at a tentative labor accord late Tuesday with the Chicago Newspaper Guild.

title: Award for Garrett
description: Jason Garrett, Princeton's quarterback and captain, was named the Ivy League's outstanding performer by vote of the league coaches and thus won the Asa S. Bushnell Cup. Garrett set Division I-AA records for completion percentage, 68.2, and consecutive passing attempts in a season without an interception, 176.

title: Bermuda Star Lines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Music; Shirley Verrett Sings With St. Luke's Group
description: John Eliot Gardiner made his reputation conducting early music, but in this decade he has been spreading his wings into the standard repertory and standard ensembles. He spent five years as music director of the Lyons Opera in France, and Sunday night he appeared with the modern-instruments Orchestra of St. Luke's at Carnegie Hall in a 19th-century program.

title: Howtek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCOWCROFT CHOSEN BY BUSH TO BECOME TOP SECURITY AIDE
description: President-elect Bush today selected as his national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, an arms control specialist widely regarded as a cerebral, low-key centrist.

title: Engineered Systems & Develpment Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Executive Receives No. 2 Post at Ametek
description: John P. Dandalides has been named president and chief operating officer of Ametek Inc., a maker of industrial products, in an executive change brought about by a spinoff of part of the company.

title: Correction
description: The About Education column on the Education page yesterday misstated the party affiliation of Sen. Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey. He is a Democrat.

title: Human Rights Commissioner Recalls Hiring Sukhreet Gabel
description: A former head of New York City's Human Rights Commission testified yesterday that she hired Sukhreet Gabel as a $40,000-a-year executive assistant in 1984, but soon decided to dismiss her.

title: Whitehall reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago 9-month figures are restated to reflect a $2,494,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: SCE Raises Merger Bid For Utility
description: The parent of the Southern California Edison Company increased its takeover offer for the San Diego Gas and Electric Company today by about $190 million, to about $2.53 billion, and offered a top position to its chairman.

title: Income Opportunity Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods' losses included a $1,257,000 provision for possible losses related to the impending foreclosure of a property collateralizing a mortgage receivable arising from a prior year property sale.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS The price of copper soared to a record $1.60 a pound on the Comex, and copper posted the largest one-day increases ever at the exchange. The buying reflected a dramatic reversal of the widespread belief that prices would continue to decline for a long time and followed reports of clashes in Peru between striking copper miners and police, disruptions of production in Zaire and Zambia and a dramatic reduction in inventory. [ Page D1. ] The dollar fell to a 40-year low against the yen in New York trading, shrugging off intervention by the Federal Reserve. Statements by President-elect Bush and other officials in support of a stable dollar have not convinced the market that the Bush administration will oppose a further decline in the dollar. [ D1. ] The stock market moved sharply higher in a slow session, aided by surging transportation and mining sectors. The Dow Jones industrial average posted its fifth consecutive gain, adding 14.58 points, to close at 2,092.28. [ D5. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in very light pre-holiday trading. [ D10. ] Yields rose on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week that ended yesterday. [ D13. ] ECONOMY House Speaker Wright said the Government should act quickly to slow the pace of leveraged buyouts and hostile corporate takeovers. He said the takeovers were having an adverse ''psychological and economic'' impact on the nation. [ D1. ] President Reagan rejected a petition from the bearing industry for protection from foreign competition. [ D14. ] Sales of new cars and light trucks rose 3.5 percent in mid-November from the comparable period last year. [ D4. ] Orders to factories for durable goods rose 2.4 percent in October, reflecting the biggest gain since June in military orders. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL A free-trade agreement with Mexico remains unlikely. Mexican leaders have many reservations about any such pact. [ D1. ] Some Canadians fear many factories will move to the U.S. if the U.S.-Canada trade accord is approved. [ A3. ] After seven days of talks, OPEC remains mired in a deadlock between Iran and a coalition led by Iraq and Saudi Arabia. [ D2. ] Britain put a value of $4.5 billion on British Steel, announcing details of the largest privatization of a manufacturing concern by the Conservative Government. [ D3. ] Peru announced austerity measures aimed at battling the country's sharp inflation and huge budget deficit. [ D5. ] Sweden is contemplating a cut in taxes - the first major tax change in more than 50 years. [ D2. ] COMPANIES The parent of Southern California Edison raised its offer for San Diego Gas and Electric by $190 million, to $2.53 billion. [ D3. ] Barely averting a strike, The Chicago Sun-Times reached a tentative labor accord with the Newspaper Guild. [ D18. ] A growing number of physicians believe that medically supervised very-low-calorie diets can help some seriously obese people, but they say the regimen is not suitable for many dieters. [ B17. ] Rodamco offered $2.4 billion for Hammerson Property, Britain's third-largest property company. Rodamco is the property fund of the Dutch investment concern Robeco Group. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMN A trove of papers from an Italian banking family show 500 years of concern about usury, trade wars, buyouts, fluctuating currency values, hostile takeovers, doing business in unstable regions and fear of recession. Talking Deals. [ D2. ]

title: New Debentures From Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday priced its first issue of floating-rate debentures. Morgan Stanley & Company is the sole underwriter for the financing, which totals $750 million.

title: Signal Improved, U S Sprint Says
description: The U S Sprint Communications Company said it had deployed a system of signal enhancements that will speed voice and data transmissions through its fiber optic network. The system will improve call setup time to put calls through an average of three seconds faster, and it will improve the company's automated validation system to increase its ability to detect toll fraud, U S Sprint said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., elected Albert D. Ernest Jr. president and chief operating officer and Allen L. Lastinger Jr. vice chairman and chief banking officer.

title: U.N. Chief to Head Effort for a Coalition To Rule Afghanistan
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced today that he was taking charge of United Nations efforts to promote a political settlement in Afghanistan.

title: Oslo Currency at Issue
description: Norway's Finance Minister, Gunnar Berge, said today that Norway should consider joining the European Monetary System to give its currency more stability, but only when the country's economy was in better shape. He said in an interview with the state radio that Norway's big current-account deficit must be rectified before such a move could be considered.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FOR painting large flat surfaces, particularly room interiors, rollers rather than brushes are best. Surfaces like walls and ceilings can be covered in a fraction of the time required for painting with a brush, and with better-looking results.

title: Chief Rabbis of Israel Assail U.S. Jews' 'Fuss'
description: Israel's two Chief Rabbis criticized American Jewish groups today for making a ''big fuss'' over a proposed change in the legal definition of who is a Jew.

title: Franz B. Tuteur, Professor, 65
description: Franz B. Tuteur, a professor of electrical engineering at Yale University, was killed Monday in a traffic accident in Tel Aviv. He was 65 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: J.T. Moran Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Release Sought On Health Data In Atomic Work
description: A research group in Pennsylvania filed a legal petition asking the Federal District Court in Harrisburg today to compel the Department of Energy to release the health records of 300,000 people who have worked at American nuclear weapon plants and laboratories, it was learned here.

title: Reviews/Music; Works Old and New
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra was founded 16 years ago as an ensemble of some 35 musicians that performed without a conductor and made decisions collectively concerning repertory and interpretation. During the last 10 years, the group has become a popular fixture at Carnegie Hall, where on Saturday evening it performed an ingratiating program that sandwiched the premiere of Michael Gandolfi's ''Points of Departure'' between works by Handel and Haydn.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about a memorial service for the impresario and nightclub owner Barney Josephson misidentified a speaker. He was Jerrold Ross, an associate dean at New York University.

title: Prima Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Metal & Abrasives Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bearing Makers Lose In Plea for Protection
description: President Reagan has rejected a petition from the $2 billion-a-year domestic bearing industry for protection from foreign competition despite the industry's contention that imports threaten national security, Administration officials said today.

description: b-Net income

Devils Lose to Flames
description: Lanny McDonald's 498th career goal, at 11 minutes 37 seconds of the third period, gave the Calgary Flames a 3-2 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: Washington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Hormel (Geo. A.) & Co.  (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Transcript of Bush News Conference on Choice of Scowcroft
description: Following is a transcript of President-elect Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News. OPENING STATEMENT

title: Review/Film; High School Students Face Demons
description: The cleverest thing about ''Night of the Demons'' is its advertising campaign. ''Angela is having a party,'' the ads read. ''Jason and Freddy are too scared to come.'' Well, that's partly true. The plot involves a Halloween party at a demonically possessed former funeral home, but my guess is that even the mass-murdering heroes of the ''Friday the 13th'' and ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' series would rather stay home and wash their hair than go to this film. And if Jason and Freddy's taste is too good for this, you know what to expect.

title: A Long Shot Comes In
description: When international conflicts that have caused misery and death for decades find a diplomatic solution, it is time for celebration. Even more so when the solution gives promise of peace and economic gains for a whole region.

title: Tax Revision in Sweden Would Lighten Burden
description: Heavily taxed Swedish citizens would keep more of their paychecks under proposed legislation that would bring about the first major tax revision since the welfare state was created more than 50 years ago, the Finance Minister said today.

title: Capitals Set Back Islanders
description: Washington scored three goals in a 43-second span of the second period tonight, and Bengt Gustafsson had four assists as the Capitals defeated the Islanders, 7-6, for their fifth straight victory.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Armco Chief Completes Search for Rich Partner
description: LEAD: Several years ago, Armco Inc., the first American steel company to diversify its holdings, found that its original business was making money and that its new ones were not. So it embarked on a plan to shed its acquisitions in the oilfield supply and insurance businesses to focus on steel, for which it needed a rich partner to help foot the bill.

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West. Travels to Columbus Circle, down Broadway to 34th Street and Seventh Avenue. Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only. Main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Some branches closed tomorrow. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collection or street cleanings. Schools: Closed today and tomorrow. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on holiday schedule with extra trains. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. State and municipal offices also closed tomorrow. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Local option tomorrow. Transportation: N.J. Transit on holiday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Local option tomorrow. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

The company said the latest 9 months included a $3.9 million pretax charge for the settlement of litigation.

2.4% Increase In Durable Goods Orders
description: Orders to the nation's factories for durable goods rose 2.4 percent in October, reflecting the biggest gain since June in orders for military goods.

title: Closings Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. Banks, government offices and most businesses will also be closed.

title: G.M. May Consider Increasing Payout
description: If the earnings rebound of the third quarter continues at the General Motors Corporation, the company may consider increasing the $5-a-share annual dividend paid to shareholders, top G.M. officials said. But a company spokesman said today that such an increase would be paid only if the company starts consistently earning $14 to $15 a share annually. The possibility of a dividend increase was reported today in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Abiomed reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Includes a pretax loan charge of $583,000.

title:
CURRENTS;
A Dressy Showroom for Kashiyama
description: LEAD: TOSHIKO MORI designed a Seventh Avenue showroom the way a couturier might design a dress - with a straightforward emphasis on strong materials, crisp lines, elegant details and seamless craftsmanship.

title: Reviews/Music; Equality of Violin and Piano
description: The violinist Elmar Oliveira and the pianist Horacio Gutierrez joined forces to play sonatas by Mozart, Beethoven and Prokofiev on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. Their performance was a fine display of chamber music democracy - at least, to the extent that each work allowed for that. And they left the satisfying impression that the point was not merely the matching of promising young soloists, but rather musical communication.

title: Red Cross Halts Work After Sidon Abduction
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it had suspended its activities in Sidon in southern Lebanon after the abduction of one of its delegates there last Thursday.

title: Roanoke Electric Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Erich Fried, 67, Dead; A Poet and Translator
description: Erich Fried, a poet who translated Shakespeare's works into modern German, died of cancer Tuesday at a hospital in Baden-Baden, West Germany. He was 67 years old.

title: TPA of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $9,779,958 and $7,600,508 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,274,568 and $2,333,701 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Buckeye Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

CURRENTS;
'33 Toaster Sells for An '88 Price
description: LEAD: COLLECTORS always complain that there are no bargains left. Now they can complain a little louder. Last week Jacques Caussin, who owns the First Half antiques shop in the SoHo section of Manhattan, sold a toaster for $5,000.

title: The Success of 'Beauty and the Beast'
description: One part Gothic romance, one part crime busters-in-action, ''Beauty and the Beast'' was nobody's idea of a sure thing when it had its premiere in September 1987 on CBS. The weekly series told the story of an Upper East Side woman whose life of comfort and privilege is transformed by the love of a grotesque denizen of a fantasy world beneath the city. Here was the ultimate ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' a modern fable about idealized love across the barrier of two worlds that coexist but never merge.

title: Don't Blame Registration in Low Voter Turnout
description: To the Editor:

title: YUGOSLAVIA BANS ETHNIC PROTESTS
description: Officials in Kosovo Province today banned public assemblies, prohibiting further demonstrations by ethnic Albanians who have been asserting their political rights with a series of protest marches.

title: Cliffs Drilling Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago figures included a writedown of $23,698,000. The company also said because of a provision for federal income tax benefits of $2,571,000, its previously reported third-quarter and 9 months losses have been reduced for the current fiscal year.

title: Voicemail Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Piano's History, Quietly Celebrated
description: AN offbeat museum, tucked in a back room on West 58th Street in Manhattan, has some of the best examples of American piano making and one of the worst: a concrete grand.

title: Probert Returning
description: The Detroit Red Wings suspended Bob Probert without pay on Sept. 23 for disciplinary reasons, but put the right wing back on the payroll Nov. 4 after threats of legal action from his agent, Patrick Ducharme. But Probert, a resident of Windsor, Ontario, was not able to gain a work visa for his job in Detroit for several weeks because of chronic alcoholism. His return to the Red Wings was finally cleared when he obtained the visa and passed a medical examination by the team's physician, Dr. David Collom.(AP)

title: MAI Basic Pursues Prime Computer
description: The financier Bennett LeBow released a letter intended to assure the management of Prime Computer Inc. that he has no hidden agenda in the $970 million hostile takeover attempt by his much smaller computer business, MAI Basic Four Inc. Prime, based in Natick, Mass., is second to the International Business Machines Corporation in the field of computer-aided design and manufacturing systems. MAI Basic, a small concern based in Tustin, Calif., is offering $20 a share, or $970 million, for Prime.

title: Syracuse Trounces Indiana in N.I.T.
description: Syracuse, playing with the verve of a veteran team and buoyed by a boisterous crowd, rolled to a 102-78 victory over Indiana last night in the semifinals of the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament.

title: Lexicon reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $518,000. c-Net income and after a net gain from discontinued operations of $3,365,000 and a tax credit of $835,000. Fiscal 1988 included $803,000 of unrealized and realized losses on marketable securities and investments, as well as start-up costs for Lexicon Sports Corp.

title: Cleveland Journal; Is a Prostitute Entitled to Legal Aid?
description: According to Judge Carl Stokes, Donna Leisinger is ''the single most active prostitute in town.''

title: Newport Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Aer Lingus Is Investigated on Iran Shipments
description: The United States Customs Service is investigating whether Aer Lingus, the Irish national airline, supplied Iran with spare aircraft parts in violation of American law, a United States official said tonight.

title: Mohasco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income The latest third quarter and 9 months included certain fees and expenses incurred in connection with the acquisition of Mohasco by MHS Holdings Corp. and costs associated with the ''push-down'' accounting adjustments totaling $33.8 million, after taxes. The year-ago 9 months included an after-tax loss on the sale of Mexican operations of $13,553.

title: Oxford Energy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Elections, the Canadian Way
description: The re-election of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government in Canada means closer relations between the world's second-largest country and the world's richest, thanks to the U.S.-Canada free trade agreement, which Ottawa will now ratify. Canadians who fought this partnership feared that their culture would be overwhelmed by ''the American way'' of doing things. But a quick scan of their election process suggests that America could learn from ''the Canadian way.''

title: Metro Matters; Another Triumph For Agriculture: Designer Oats
description: Seats for the Lincoln Center Theater's revival of ''Waiting for Godot'' may be the hottest cultural ticket in town, but now they have a culinary equivalent.

title: Cal Fed Income Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Share earnings represent units.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for 13wk to Oct 29
A Warm Return For Injured Jockey
description: It was only the fourth race at Aqueduct on a chilly Wednesday in November, a six-furlong dash for elderly claiming fillies. But for Richard Migliore and his many fans in the grandstand, it was a Grade I moment.

title: Paterno Cuts Down
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State said he would cut back his out-of-town travel for charity, university fund-raising and professional organizations and spend more time with his Penn State players and coaches. The decision comes after the school finished at 5-6, its first losing season in 50 years.

title: Nearly $4 Million in Jewels Are Stolen From Florida Store
description: Five gunmen wearing Halloween masks robbed nearly $4 million in jewels from a jewelry story Tuesday using smoke bombs to cover their escape and later firing at a pursuing officer, the police said.

title: Tribune-Swab-Fox reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leora Ron Marries
description: Leora Ron, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shimon Ron of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Robert Allen Blau, a son of Helen Suchow of Huntington, L.I., and Dr. Harold Blau of Levittown, L.I., were married yesterday at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Charles Klein and Cantor Avi Albrecht officiated. The bride, a dancer and choreographer, is the artistic director of the Dance Theater of Queens in Flushing. The bridegroom is the president and chairman of Chez-Zam, a producer of special events in Deer Park, L.I.

title: Jury Awards $125,000 to Student Strip-Searched at a Bronx School
description: A 15-year-old girl who was strip-searched when school officials suspected her of carrying marijuana was awarded $125,000 in damages yesterday by a State Supreme Court jury in the Bronx.

title: Bara Bazaar Journal; Soviet Test Market Blooms Close to Khyber Pass
description: Want a new Soviet refrigerator? Not pretty, but it's cheap. Or a nice new Soviet TV for one-sixth the price of a Japanese model? Or enough Russian cloth to make your next suit for $4.95? A samovar, maybe? Might there be caviar or vodka?

title: Manville Reaches Pact on Insurance
description: The Manville Corporation has reached agreement with the Colorado Insurance Guaranty Association settling certain Manville claims for asbestos insurance coverage provided by two insurers that have gone out of business. The state association is organized under state law to pay certain claims on behalf of Colorado companies under policies written by insurers that have become insolvent.

title: In Retaliatory Step, Hungary Expels a Rumanian Diplomat
description: Hungary expelled a senior Rumanian diplomat today in retaliation for the expulsion of a Hungarian diplomat from Bucharest last week.

title: Letter: On Medicine; Alternative Treatment for Parkinson's
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Newspaper Says Roh Plans To Seek Clemency for Predecessor
description: President Roh Tae Woo was reported today to be preparing to seek or declare clemency for his predecessor, Chun Doo Hwan, and to balance that move with steps to distance his Government from Mr. Chun's legacy.

title: Train Strikes an Auto in Fog In North Dakota, Killing Five
description: A train struck an automobile at a railroad crossing in the fog Tuesday, killing five members of a family and injuring three others.

title: Drug Plan Gains Approval
description: Sports ministers and other officials from more than 100 countries approved by acclamation today an anti-drug charter that establishes guidelines for governments to combat trafficking in and use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Man Weighing 270 Pounds Wins a Discrimination Suit
description: A local man has become the first person in the state to win damages for being denied a promotion because of his weight.

title: Wagner Says Scandal in Bronx May Speed Change in Albany
description: The president of the Board of Education said yesterday that scandals over drug abuse, theft, patronage and other allegations against a Bronx school board might speed the way for legislation to shift local school boards away from politics in New York City.

title: PENALTY ON NAVY ALLOWED BY JUDGE
description: Maine's authority to fine the Navy up to $25,000 a day for violating state regulations on hazardous waste at a nuclear submarine overhaul base in Kittery has been upheld by a Federal district judge.

title: On Stage
description: How to Get a Theater Sometimes nice things happen in the theater and the story of the new 130-seat Gertrude and Irving Dimson Theater, scheduled to open in February in Zeckendorf Towers on Union Square, is one of them. It's a tale of city and state governments, private companies and individuals pitching in to help, including a neighborhood resident who donated a grand piano after reading a list of needed items posted on a window. It's also a story of approaching the right person at the right time - and having the right parents.

title: Bonn Official Seeks a Lebanon Hostage Role
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher will try to negotiate the release of foreign hostages held in Lebanon during a visit to Iran that is to begin Sunday, diplomats said today.

title: 17 Slain as Gunmen Attack Philippine Chapel
description: A band of about 20 gunmen opened fire with automatic weapons during an evening church service in a remote mountain village, killing 17 people and wounding at least 12, the military said Thursday.

title: AIDS DRUG FOUND TO PROLONG LIFE
description: The only AIDS-fighting drug approved by the Federal Government greatly prolonged survival among almost 5,000 people who suffer from the disease, a new study by the drug's maker says.

title: Economic Scene; Budget Outlook: A Lengthy Battle
description: A DEADLOCK between the Bush administration and Congress looms on how to cut the budget deficit. James C. Miller 3d, until recently President Reagan's director of the Office of Management and Budget and a veteran of budgetary battles, expects the deadlock to last until September, the end of the current fiscal year. If that happens, it will make 1989 a harrowing year for the financial markets.

title: Transition Fever in the Capital
description: The rush for choice jobs in the Bush Administration is at a fever pitch, generating the kind of intricate maneuvers and intrigue on which the capital thrives. Page B12.

title: Two Bands That Survived The Summer of Punk Rock
description: IN 1977, the summer of punk rock, bands weren't thinking about building careers. They had other things on their minds, among them overturning an ossified superstar system and reclaiming rock's rawness, simplicity and do-it-yourself spirit. But by the time college radio stations and an alternative circuit of clubs and independent labels had arisen that could support them, most of the first-generation alternative bands were gone. Some had spectacular flameouts, others simply dissolved as their rebellion was transformed into a fashion statement. But two punk-rooted bands that have carried on uncompromising, self-directed careers since 1977 will be back in New York clubs this weekend - the Feelies at the Ritz tonight and the Mekons at CBGB tonight and tomorrow.

title: Our $92 Million Worth From the Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title:
About Real Estate;
Jersey City Project on an Enviable Site
description: LEAD: A groundbreaking ceremony in Jersey City on Monday will begin construction of Liberty Towers at Portside, a mixed-use project containing 525 condominium apartments and 62,000 square feet of commercial and retail space.

title: Fugitive Greek Banker Is Arrested by the F.B.I.
description: A fugitive Greek banker, indicted in a $300 million scandal that has shaken the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, has been arrested, the F.B.I. said today.

title: The U.N. Today General Assembly
description: POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/A3-19

title: Galantine of Veal and All the Trimmings
description: Alfred Mayer, the executive chef at the Manor restaurant for 16 years, began work at 3 A.M. today, supervising the first tasks - including the roasting of 36 turkeys for the Salvation Army, which were done and delivered by 7 A.M.

title: 5,000 Protest Use of Torture By Police in Algeria Unrest
description: About 5,000 protestors today defied Algeria's ban on public demonstrations to take part in a march against security forces accused of using torture in riots last month.

title: Review/Stage Design; Julie Taymor's Theater Imaginings
description: A magical landscape awaits visitors to the main gallery of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. Wherever one looks, there are gigantic flying creatures, richly costumed characters, sculptural masks and shadow puppets - a stunning assemblage of the designs and dreams of Julie Taymor.

title: Ben Johnson Comeback
description: The way Ben Johnson sees it, it is a good thing there are four years between Olympic Games. That is because the Canadian sprinter wants to make a comeback at the next Olympics, but has been banned from competition for two years and figures he will need another year after that to get back on the world-record track. Johnson, who was given a two-year suspension after a steroids was detected in his system at the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, gave his prognosis for the 1992 Games in Barcelona, Spain, in an interview published by Europeo, an Italian weekly. ''I believe that 1992 will be something that people will never forget,'' he said. Johnson was stripped of his gold medal after winning the Olympic 100 meters.(AP)

title: Rival Muslim Militias Clash In Southern Beirut Suburbs
description: Fierce battles broke out today between rival Shiite Muslim militias in Beirut's southern suburbs in violation of a day-old Syrian-sponsored truce, the police said.

title: G.M., Toyota In Truck Talks
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and the General Motors Corporation are negotiating the joint production of Toyota's one-ton truck in the United States, a Toyota official said today.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about an appointment to the five-member Securities and Exchange Commission misstated the number of vacancies there. The appointment fills the last one.

title: Schoolgirl Sets Record
description: Christy Cooper, averaging 60 points a game for her high school team, already has broken one national scoring record and has her eye on other marks. With 1,434 points, the Circleville, W. Va., senior has passed the national high school record for most points scored in a season set by Cheryl Miller. Miller, who attended Riverside Poly in California before playing at the University of Southern California, scored 1,197 points in the 1981-82 season. In leading Circleville to a 23-1 record and a berth in the state playoffs, Cooper, a National Honor Society student, shot 60 percent from the field and 73 percent from the foul line.

title: All-America Selections
description: It was 99 years ago that a former Yale football coach named Walter Camp had a brainstorm. Camp, a former Yale player, decided to honor the best players of the year by selecting them for something he called the All-America team. The name and the practice stuck. Now the Walter Camp Foundation in New Haven has announced its 1988 All-America team, and it offered few surprises. Among the 11 offensive members are such familiar names as Troy Aikman of U.C.L.A. at quarterback, and three well-known running backs, Barry Sanders of Oklahoma State, Anthony Thompson of Indiana, and Tim Worley of Georgia, along with a lineman big enough to block for all three at once, Tony Mandarich of Michigan State. On the defensive team are such well-known players as Derrick Thomas of Alabama and BroderickThomas of Nebraska, both linebackers.(AP)

title: Irmgard Seefried Is Dead at 69; Soprano Known for Mozart Roles
description: Irmgard Seefried, a German-born Austrian soprano who gained great success in the postwar years in operas of Mozart and Richard Strauss, died of cancer yesterday in Vienna. She was 69 years old.

title: AIDS Show Ending
description: ''AIDS Alive,'' a series of theatrical vignettes about the social and personal repercussions of AIDS by the People With AIDS Theater Workshop, will conclude a four-month run at the cabaret Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, tomorrow night at 10. The revue, performed by actors diagnosed with AIDS or AIDS-related complex, will resume performances in March. There is a $10 cover charge and a two-drink minimum. Reservations: 757-0788.

title: Tests Find 600 Transit Authority Buses Safe
description: Six hundred New York City Transit Authority buses that were called unsafe last year by State Senator Franz S. Leichter have been vindicated after an independent investigation and follow-up tests.

title: Old Rivalry Returns to a Big Welcome
description: The cars started filing into the Martens Stadium parking lot at about 9:30 A.M. today, bringing alumni, students, cheerleaders and members of the bands. There was a sense of excitement around the stadium, and the kickoff was still an hour and a half away. Only on Thanksgiving Day could two high school football teams with 1-7 records transform their communities into cheering sections.

title: Sports of The Times; Dick Schultz Has a Good Idea
description: WHILE sitting around the house having a sarsaparilla and watching the football games on television yesterday, did you stop to ask a few questions about those beer commercials? For example, how did those noisy drinkers get to that clean, well-lighted bar?

title: OPEC SETS QUOTAS ON OIL PRODUCTION AFTER IRAN YIELDS
description: After weeks of standing firm against Arab pressure, Iran agreed today to yield its historical role as the second-largest oil producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Its concession will allow Iraq to produce as much oil as Iran.

title: Market Place; Retailers' Outlook For the Holidays
description: AMERICA'S retailers are primed for a reasonably strong Christmas, but Wall Street seems to be growing cautious as the holiday shopping season begins.

title: Holiday for Markets
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday on Thanksgiving Day. The stock exchanges will be open today. But the New York Mercantile Exchange, the New York Commodity Exchange and the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange will be closed.

title: Opera
description: It was Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' that made Yoko Watanabe want to become an opera singer when she was 16 years old. And the role has been a lucky one for the 35-year-old Japanese soprano ever since. She met the man she eventually married, Renato Grimaldi, at a Tokyo competition in which he won first prize for his portrayal of Pinkerton, while she took second place for her Cio-Cio-San. This season, she is singing the role at the Metropolitan Opera, to considerable acclaim. (There is a performance tonight at 8 o'clock. Tickets: standing room $7 to $10, at the Met box office. Information: 362-6000). ''For me, Butterfly is a role that embodies pain and joy,'' Ms. Watanabe said in an interview. ''It is a complete character, as are so many of Puccini's roles. I have sung several of them: Mimi, Manon Lescaut, Suor Angelica. They are my favorites, because they are integral characters, and very theatrical. They give a singer opportunities not only to sing, but to act. That combination is what I love about opera, and Puccini's in particular.'' Mixes Acting Styles

title: Creighton Helps Out
description: Things have gone well for Tony Barone, the head basketball coach at Creighton University in Omaha. So to help celebrate Thanksgiving, Barone decided to do something to help those less fortunate than himself. He volunteered his team to help serve breakfast to the homeless at a shelter in Omaha. ''I want our players to understand what the world is about,'' he said when he announced his plan. That's how it came to pass that Barone showed up at the shelter early yesterday morning with 14 players and four assistant coaches. The Creighton contingent helped other volunteers prepare and serve 129 meals, a gesture of giving that was apparently so satisfying to Barone that he decided to give a little more. According to the shelter director, the coach helped wash and dry dishes. (AP)

title: Human-Rights Struggle Portrayed on the Screen
description: Human rights became a global goal 40 years ago, when the United Nations unanimously adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Private organizations like Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch have publicized and condemned abuses, and advanced the principle that everyone is entitled to basic legal, political, economic and cultural rights.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Unearthing Truffle Dishes

title: Television
description: The season's new crop of television programs has turned up some noticeable new faces - new, at least, as regulars on a series.

title: Theater
description: Dylan Baker and Patricia Clarkson have come to the lobby of the Manhattan Theater Club to talk about their starring roles in ''Eastern Standard,'' the Richard Greenberg play that moves to Broadway, to the Golden Theater, on Dec. 19.

title: Auctions
description: Picasso Rarity

title: At Home, With a Very Orthodox Israeli Family
description: When tens of thousands of Israelis petition, protest and complain about the suddenly powerful influence of rigorously Orthodox Jews on political and social life, they are talking about people like Philip and Miriam Marcus.

title: 2 Face Baby-Selling Charge
description: The parents of a 2-month-old baby have been charged with selling their son for $3,500 and three ounces of uncut cocaine, the police said. Charles Albert Pannuty and Gayle Duty, both 35 years old, of Severn, were arrested in a parking lot Tuesday, said Sgt. Joseph Bisesi of the Anne Arundel County Police Department. The baby, Joseph Patrick Pannuty, was turned over to child protective services, he said. The couple has four other children, but Sergeant Bisesi said he did not know whether they had been turned over to authorities.

title: European Growth Accelerates
description: Western Europe's economy is growing at its fastest rate in a decade, and many economists predict that next year it will grow faster than the United States' economy.

title: People
description: * Ed McCarrick has been named ad sales director at Life magazine.

title: At the Movies
description: A Chaplin Biography

title: He's NATO's President, Too, You Know
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Planning to Sell Its Waterworks
description: The British Government today began the latest and most contentious step in its sweeping privatization program by presenting its plans for selling off the nation's state-owned water industry.

title: Kristallnacht Was the Name the Nazis Gave It
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Raby, Civil Rights Leader In Chicago With King, Dies at 55
description: Albert A. Raby, a former teacher in the public schools who became one of the most important civil rights leaders in Chicago in the 1960's, died there Wednesday night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: European Consortium Gets Fighter Contract
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that a four-nation consortium of which it is a member had been awarded a contract to develop a new fighter plane. The contract is worth about $10 billion.

title: David Moxley, Executive, 57
description: David Moxley, who was recently appointed managing director of the Manhattan law firm of Lord Day & Lord, Barrett Smith, died of a heart attack Monday at his Manhattan home. He was 57 years old.

title: Review/Pop; Ozziddi, an African-Caribbean-Funk Synthesis
description: While British, American and Brazilian songwriters have been working on world-spanning pop, so have Africans. Sonny Okosun, the Nigerian bandleader who came to Sounds of Brazil on Tuesday, has come up with a thoroughly international, English-speaking synthesis of West African, Caribbean and funk rhythms, often linked with political sentiments. Mr. Okosun calls the music ozziddi, and it could please anyone but a diehard purist.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. Mandela still remains a prisoner of the South African Government and there is no indication of any release.'' - Winnie N. Mandela. [ A3:4. ]

title: New Faces for the Holiday Season
description: ONCE upon a time there was a series of Broadway revues called ''New Faces.'' Its quality varied, but through the years there was one constant: Its young, eager performers were always hoping for their first major success. The earliest of the revues, in 1936, featured Imogene Coca. The 1952 edition introduced Eartha Kitt. The last, in 1968, gave us Madeline Kahn and Robert Klein. The revues have stopped, but the flow of talented young people has not.

title: Bruins Halt Seven-Game Skid
description: Bob Sweeney scored twice, including the game-winner eight seconds into overtime tonight, leading Boston past the Philadelphia Flyers 2-1 and giving the Bruins their first victory in eight games.

title: Law Firm on Trial: Was It on Both Sides or None?
description: Joe Jamail, the Houston lawyer who won billions for Pennzoil in its battle with Texaco, will be there. So will Geoffrey C. Hazard, Jr., the Yale law professor and ethics expert. And Jack Pope, a former Justice of the Texas Supreme Court. And James Sales, president of the Texas Bar Association.

title: US Life's No. 2 Officer Resigns After a Year
description: In the insurance industry, Gordon E. Crosby Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the US Life Corporation, has a reputation as being a difficult man to work for. That reputation was reinforced this week.

title: Santos Building Case for Jockey Award
description: What does Jose Santos have to do to win the Eclipse Award as the nation's outstanding jockey?

title: The Message of the Davis Case
description: The acquittal of Larry Davis may be a first: when before has a defendant in New York, or anywhere, won his freedom by asserting that he shot uniformed police officers in self-defense? The bitter reaction is understandable. Mr. Davis's gunfire inflicted serious injury. His escape humiliated the police. And his exploits brought a measure of national outlaw celebrity to a gunslinging drug suspect.

title: Flooding in Thailand Leaves 70 Dead and Others Missing
description: Four days of heavy rains and flash floods have cut off large parts of southern Thailand, disrupting communications and transport and resulting in the deaths of at least 70 people.

title: Pernod-Ricard Bid Prevails In Battle for Irish Distillers
description: Pernod-Ricard S.A. received final clearance today for its bid to acquire the Irish Distillers Group when the Irish Government approved its $442 million bid.

title: Addenda
description: * Charles/Benetos/Partners, an advertising, marketing and design firm, has been set up by Charles Goldman, John Benetos and George Cohn.

title: Ayn Rand Adaptation By Italian
description: Made in Italy during World War II, at first approved by the Fascists and then banned from theaters, ''We the Living'' has lost its political urgency. But it has gained historical interest, not to mention unintended kitsch. Seeing Rossano Brazzi play an aristocratic White Russian, standing in the fakest snow that wartime supplies could buy, may be the most peculiar twist of all in the curious story of how Ayn Rand's autobiographical first novel came to the screen.

title: Film
description: Alex Vincent became an actor because he saw the little girl down the block in television commercials. ''I said, I know I'm going to be on that screen someday,'' explained the star of the movie thriller ''Child's Play.'' ''I thought, if she can do it, maybe I can do it.'' His motivation would be an unforgivable Hollywood cliche if he were any more than 7 years old, but a small boy who is interviewed while eating chocolate ice cream always gets the benefit of the doubt.

title: 2 Asian Allies Get Assertive With the U.S.
description: When President-elect Bush looks across the Pacific to Japan and South Korea, he will find his two staunchest Asian allies with new ideas about their role in the world and new questions about their traditional relationship with the United States.

title: 'We Have Lived Long Enough for Others'
description: To the Editor:

title: Battered and Abused
description: The Presidential candidates did not mention and probably few Americans noticed a brief, chilling New York Times report from Beijing on Oct. 28: 20 million Chinese may starve and another 80 million will endure severe food shortages in the coming months.

title: Foreign Reporters Will Get Soviet Jet on Gorbachev Trip
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry has announced that it has arranged for a charter aircraft to take Moscow-based foreign correspondents on Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to New York, Havana and London, scheduled for Dec. 6 to 14.

title: Egypt and Algeria Restore Diplomatic Ties
description: Egypt and Algeria restored full diplomatic relations today, leaving Lebanon, Syria and Libya as the only Arab nations without full ties with Cairo.

title: China-South Korea Trade: Boom, Yes, but a Quiet One
description: Chinese maps still show a single Korea, with its capital in the north. But these days map-makers and nearly everyone else in China are very conscious of Seoul and the rest of South Korea.

title: Lone Star to Sell Venture to Tarmac
description: Lone Star Industries has announced that an American branch of Tarmac P.L.C. of Britain will acquire the remaining 40 percent interest in a Lone Star-Tarmac joint venture in cement, concrete and concrete products for $188 million in preferred stock. In 1986, Lone Star sold a 60 percent interest in those businesses in Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina to Tarmac, a building-materials company based in London.

title: The Post Price to Rise To 40 Cents at Stand
description: The New York Post will raise its newsstand price to 40 cents in New York City beginning Monday, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Study Urges U.S. Shift On Natural Gas Policy
description: If changes in Federal policy are put into effect, the use of natural gas could increase by one-third during the next 20 years, cutting oil imports by two million barrels a day while reducing the trade deficit, acid rain and smog, a recent study concluded.

title: In Nicaragua's Press, a Softer Voice
description: A group of young journalists, determined to break with Nicaragua's tradition of strident and politicized reporting, has launched a new weekly newspaper pledged to independence and balance, but with an unabashed anti-Sandinista tint.

title: Atlantic City Bans Motorized Chairs As of Next Summer
description: The motorized rolling chairs that became popular among tourists on the famed Boardwalk this summer were banned by the resort's City Council.

title: The Strategy Of Murdoch's Mirabella
description: JUST when it seemed there was no room for another fashion magazine, Rupert Murdoch decided differently and announced plans for Mirabella.

title: Airline Denies Supplying Iran
description: The Irish national airline, Aer Lingus, denied today that it had illegally supplied Iran with millions of dollars in American aircraft parts.

title: One Reason Voters Didn't Vote
description: The final returns on voter turnout are as dismal as predicted: only half of America's eligible voters actually voted in the 1988 election, the lowest proportion since 1924. The figures offer no magic solution. But they argue strongly that more people would vote if voting could be made easier.

title: SAFETY STEP URGED AFTER JET CRASH
description: The Air Line Pilots Association says its own inquiry into a Delta jetliner crash at Dallas in August has led it to seek an emergency modification in takeoff warning systems on all Boeing 727 jetliners.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about sales of the Yugo automobile misstated Consumer Reports magazine's review of the Hyundai Excel. The Excel was rated better than the Yugo but not so good as several other small imported cars.

title: INSIDE
description: Waterworks for Sale

title: Trading Articles
description: There are divisions in what is sometimes called ''the foreign policy community'' in this country - between conservatives and liberals, for instance - but evidently they do not apply to the nation's two principal international affairs journals. Both are edited by former high-level Government specialists on foreign affairs.

title: Dollar Declines Overseas; Gold Up Slightly
description: The American dollar moved lower today against all leading currencies in overseas trading, despite reports of central-bank intervention in Japan and West Germany. Gold prices were somewhat higher.

title: N.F.L.'s Top Defense Keeps Lions Down
description: Three and out.

title: U.N. CYPRUS PLAN NEAR BREAKDOWN
description: A United Nations peace initiative aimed at ending the division of Cyprus into Greek and Turkish communities by next June is close to breakdown after new talks here this week, diplomats and other officials say.

title: Managing the Scramble for the Spoils
description: Chase Untermeyer, personnel director for the transition to George Bush's Presidency, dreaded the moment that he had to face the mound of papers on his desk. Each outlined the kind of solid background and bright prospects that the President-elect simply must have in his new administration.

title: No-Smoking Policy Brings Rift in Kentucky
description: Lawmakers in Kentucky, the nation's leading tobacco producer, are putting pressure on the University of Louisville to drop its plan to restrict smoking on campus.

title: 2 Marks Within Tucker's Range
description: Several times Wednesday night in the Knicks-Pistons game at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich., the public-address announcer played basketball trivia games with the crowd.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Andean Tradition

title: Detroit Journal; The Old Is New Again: A Film Palace's Rebirth
description: The neon lights went on again at the grand old Fox Theater last week, and one of the country's largest and gaudiest remaining movie palaces reopened amid hope that it might hold the magic to turn Detroit around.

title: Iraq Plans Stock Market
description: Iraq will establish a formal stock exchange to deal with a growing volume of transactions in shares of new private or Government-owned companies, the Minister of Finance announced today. The Minister, Hikmat Omer al-Hadithi, told the daily newspaper Thawra that the market would be small initially and would be temporarily housed at the Industrial Bank. The Minister did not specify when trading would begin.

title: He Almost appears to Be Running Things As He Etches Line Between 2 Presidencies
description: George Bush, through his appointments and his comments at news conferences, has begun to draw some sharp distinctions between the Administration that is ending and the one that is beginning.

title: Colombian Jet Seized For Carrying Cocaine
description: Federal Customs Service agents seized a Colombian cargo jet Wednesday and fined the airline that operated it $4 million after finding 250 pounds of cocaine in the aircraft's hold, a spokesman for the service said.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Gospel Saxophone

title: Pretoria Won't Return Mandela to Jail
description: The South African Government said tonight that Nelson R. Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, would not be returned to prison once he recovered fully from tuberculosis in a Cape Town clinic.

title: Connecticut Schools Seeking Black Teachers
description: Connecticut's efforts to improve teacher pay and tighten training standards have helped attract teachers in some areas. But at the same time, educators say, recruiting black and Hispanic teachers from other states has been complicated by the new standards.

title: The Military: Navy Sees Gulf Activity As Portent of New Era
description: The difficulties encountered by the Reagan Administration in negotiating rights to bases this year with the Philippines, Spain and Greece are, in the view of senior Pentagon officials, a portent that in the future fewer overseas bases will be available for American use. Recent Defense

title: Prague Steps Up Harassment of Religious Groups
description: Augustin Navratil, a railway worker from rural Moravia, symbolized religious revival earlier this year when he began a petition for religious liberty that collected nearly 600,000 signatures.

title: Review/Music; A Bernstein Premiere
description: During the New York Philharmonic's season-long celebration of his 70th birthday, Leonard Bernstein has been taking the opportunity to champion a sometimes misunderstood and underappreciated composer whose works he understands better than any other conductor alive. That man, of course, is Leonard Bernstein, whose revised and expanded version of ''Jubilee Games'' had its first United States performance on Wednesday evening under the composer's direction.

title: Short Stay Costly for Rangers
description: The Rangers, concerned about the volatile atmosphere surrounding their rematch with the Penguins, arrived in Pittsburgh on Wednesday morning on a charter flight, stayed at a hotel outside of town and were probably hoping to make a quick exit that night.

title: Bridge
description: A Texas pair led into the final two sessions of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today.

title: Iona Prep Rallies for Tie
description: Scott Cade came off the bench late in the fourth quarter to lead two drives that enabled Iona Prep to tie New Rochelle, 14-14, yesterday in a high football school game in New Rochelle, N.Y. The quarterback entered the game with four minutes remaining and his team down, 14-0. First he threw a 40-yard scoring pass, and on the Gaels' next possession he tossed a 25-yarder to Dwight Brewster at the 2-yard line with 15 seconds left, setting up the tying score. It was the 41st meeting between the two Westchester schools and only the second tie.

title: Review/Art; Joseph Beuys asTeacher and Artist
description: The exhibition of the work of Joseph Beuys currently at Hirschl & Adler Modern is the largest show to be held here since his Guggenheim Museum retrospective in 1979-80. Although it includes none of the West German artist's large-scale sculpture, it provides a kind of intensive training or immersion course in his way of life, thought and art that is both useful and timely. Although Beuys died nearly three years ago, his legacy is still very much with us, not only in his own art but in the efforts of the countless artists he influenced as well.

title: Review/Music; The Chamber Society
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, celebrating its 20th anniversary and faced with the prospect of a radical turnover in its personnel, is offering a season-long retrospective consisting of both subscribers' favorites and notable commissions. Unfortunately, the two don't always coincide.

title: Mother of AIDS Victim Shares Her Story to Teach Others
description: In one bold move, Mildred Pearson broke the rules. She brought her son, a homosexual stricken with AIDS, home to die, giving little thought to how the neighbors in her Brooklyn housing project might react.

title: Scofield on Guitar
description: John Scofield, a guitarist, is to lead his band tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 and 11:30 at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tickets are $12.50.

title: With a Dispute, Iran and Iraq Begin Exchange of P.O.W.'s
description: A 10-day exchange of about 1,500 sick or wounded prisoners of war held by Iran and Iraq started today, but the Red Cross complained that the two nations were slowing down the operation.

title: No Easy Job: Seeking Help For Holidays
description: Jon E. Knuptila has two thick folders, each containing the names of at least 20 people seeking jobs. In one folder are people he might consider hiring. The other contains his rejects.

title: Clerk, 60, Slain by Robbers
description: A 60-year-old clerk at a round-the-clock newsstand in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn was shot to death in an apparent robbery attempt by two men yesterday evening. The victim, identified as Zulfuquar Siddiqi of 104 Parkville Avenue in Flatbush, was pronounced dead of a gunshot wound in the stomach at 8:45 P.M., an hour after he was shot at the newsstand at McDonald and 18th Avenues. Witnesses told the police that the assailants, described as a white man and a black man, both in their late 20s or early 30s, fled on foot and may have been picked up by a gray station wagon.

title: Dance
description: Many outstanding dancers will appear this weekend in performances by the Joffrey Ballet, the New York City Ballet and smaller modern dance companies like the Victoria Marks Performance Company. Six new and newly outstanding dancers are interviewed here. Interestingly, they have in common a number of things that were once not at all part of a dancer's profile: all started their training as young children; none ever seriously considered another profession, and all were supported by their families in their decisions to become dancers.

title: Girl Killed on Florida Fair Ride
description: A spinning carnival ride collapsed at the Broward County Fair Wednesday night, killing a teen-age girl and injuring at least six people, the authorities said.

title: Shortage Of Chips Is Easing
description: The severe shortage of memory chips that has plagued computer manufacturers all year is abating, industry executives and analysts say.

title: Major Banks Stabilizing Prime Rate
description: Although short-term interest rates have risen in recent weeks, commercial banks have been reluctant to increase their prime lending rate.

title: No Reminders Wanted
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: It is 9:25 P.M. at Indochine, the still-trendy-after-all-these-years Southeast Asian restaurant near Astor Place in Greenwich Village. We are waiting, ravenous, at the three-deep bar for our 9 P.M. reserved table. The lone bartender is in trouble, and he knows it, lurching about frantically as he tries to fill a cascade of orders. A sullen hostess wearing a baseball cap, in contrast, is as calm as a yoga instructor. She has mastered deflecting tension by repeating the mantra ''A few minutes'' whenever confronted by an impatient customer.

title: Syracuse to Meet Missouri in Final
description: The college basketball season is barely one week old, but Syracuse and Missouri have already inspired some lofty aspirations among their fans.

title: Our Towns; Poetic Injustice? A Grocer Sees Insults in an Ode
description: Life could have been kinder to Ronald Albamonti, what with the wife's medical bills, the divorce, the snooty summer visitors patronizing him like a local servant and a dwindling number of customers frequenting his corner grocery, a humble little shop called Roland's Market. (It was named after his father, who died two years ago.) The nastiest slap, though, came last month in an unlikely form: a poem published in The New York Review of Books and penned by James Merrill, Pulitzer Prize winner, poet-laureate of Connecticut, scion to the Merrill-Lynch brokerage fortune and a part-time Stonington Borough resident.

title: Oilers Win, 25-17
description: A 5-yard scoring pass from Warren Moon to Drew Hill in the fourth quarter today helped the Houston Oilers rally to a 25-17 victory over the Dallas Cowboys, who lost their ninth game in a row.

title: Shamrock Blocked In Bid for Polaroid
description: A Federal appeals court in Delaware has blocked Shamrock Holding Inc.'s $2.6 billion tender offer for the Polaroid Corporation until Shamrock discloses further material, Shamrock said. The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit issued a ruling late Wednesday instructing the Federal District Court in Delaware to issue a preliminary injunction halting Shamrock's bid for the photo company based in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Review/City Ballet; Wide Range in One Style
description: Remember the days when they said all Balanchine ballets looked alike? Even in times when this old saw was new, such confusion of style with content was hard to fathom.

title: Bills Still Rule the Roost
description: The Buffalo Bills, with a record of 11-1, kept their No. 1 position this week in The New York Times's computer ranking of National Football League teams. The Bills next play the Cincinnati Bengals (9-3), who stayed at No. 4.

title: Showcase Theater, Outlet for Inspired Nobodies
description: How do new plays by little-known writers make it to the stage, out-of-work actors get exposure and theater-hungry audiences find low-cost, inventive productions, all in one package? The answer is showcase theater. Showcases are nonprofit productions meant to display the talents of actors to agents, casting directors and producers in the hope that they will be chosen for roles in other shows or that the play will be picked up by a producer. The actors receive no weekly salaries.

title: Administration Asserts It Has Met Budget Goal
description: The Reagan Administration said Wednesday that it had reached the goal of cutting its final budget by $35 billion without raising taxes.

title: Few Holiday Guests for the Bushes
