description: There was no pumpkin pie and there were no children or grandchildren present. But other than that, George and Barbara Bush spent a typical Thanksgiving Day at their Maine home.

title: House Special in Indiana Is the 'Speaker du Jour'
description: The Indiana House, evenly split between Republicans and Democrats for the first time in its 172-year history, broke a two-day stalemate today by agreeing to the sharing of power by alternating Speakers in what is being called the ''Speaker du jour'' plan.

title: For the Record
description: Editorials as Evidence In seeking to disqualify Federal District Judge Milton Pollack from presiding in the securities fraud trial of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., defense lawyers cited a Forbes Magazine editorial critical of the judge's role in the case as evidence that a ''reasonable person'' might question his impartiality. In an opinion last week written by Judge Richard J. Cardamone, the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit rejected the argument.

title: What Poland Did
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Musical Premieres
description: The Kronos Quartet - David Harrington and John Sherba, violinists; Hank Dutt, violist, and Joan Jeanrenaud, cellist - is to play music by John Zorn, Somei Satoh, Gyorgy Ligeti, Charlie Mingus and Kevin Volans tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Included on the program are the world premieres of Mr. Zorn's ''Cat O'Nine Tails'' and Mr. Volans's ''Songlines,'' and the New York premiere of Mr. Satoh's ''Shirasagi.'' Tickets are $18. Information: 874-6770.

title: Story With No End
description: The other day I mentioned to a friend, a journalist, that I was going to take part in a meeting in New York about Raoul Wallenberg. He looked at me in astonishment. ''Wallenberg? The man has been missing for what, 40 years, more -ever since the end of World War II. Nobody lives that long in a Russian prison! What is there to talk about anymore?''

title: Out of Hatred, Turkey With Kimchi
description: An anti-Asian campaign late last year in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section brought about a Thanksgiving dinner sponsored by Korean businessmen and residents for elderly people yesterday.

title: Americans in Iran
description: While the plight of nine Americans held hostage by pro-Iranian forces in Lebanon is relatively well known, several Americans are held captive by Iran itself. Former President Jimmy Carter took note of one in a recent letter to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini that was made public last week in Teheran. The letter asked him ''to help in the release from prison of a U.S. citizen by the name of David Redham, who has been imprisoned in Iran for more than eight years.''

title: Rifka Rosenwein Wed To Barry Lichtenberg
description: Rifka D. Rosenwein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Zvi Rosenwein of New York, was married yesterday to Barry Lichtenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lichtenberg of Belle Harbor, Queens. Rabbi Shalom Carmy officiated at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: British Utility Executive To Join Unit of Citicorp
description: John King, the managing director of the overseas division of British Telecom P.L.C., will leave the company next week to become the managing director of Citicorp's Information Business International unit and the chairman of Quotron Systems International, based in London.

title: Hearst Seeks Full Pardon for Bank Robbery
description: The newspaper heir Patricia Hearst Shaw is seeking a full Presidential pardon for her role in a bank robbery 14 years ago, according to a report published today.

title: Myerson Judge Shows Humor, Anger and an Aversion to Theatrics
description: Flashes of anger and humor, as well as consistent common sense, have characterized Judge John F. Keenan as he conducts the Bess Myerson trial.

title: Glasnost in Wide Screen: Hush, Hush, Old Stalinist
description: There is a moment in the new Soviet film ''Little Vera'' that seems to serve notice that Soviet cinema will no longer deal in the pretty half-truths pleasing to the authorities and comforting to many Soviet moviegoers.

title: 3 Former Drug Agents Charged in Fraud Scheme
description: Three former agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Los Angeles have been charged with laundering more than $608,000 that was apparently accumulated while dealing in narcotics, the authorities said.

title: Food Vendors and a Toothless Council
description: On a weekday, a pedestrian in search of a noontime nosh can count 12 food carts on 50th Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues alone. Seven more are strung out along the stretch between Sixth and Rockefeller Plaza, and a pretzel seller faces a falafel vendor at the corner of Fifth.

title: You Look Familiar. Aren't You . . . Uh?
description: LEAD: A long time ago, I discovered that we all have enormous fantasies about the famous, about what it's like to be known. Saul Bellow said that being known isn't much more than being an identity - similar to a dog who responds to his name. A dog's known, too. In fact, I recently took my dog on a television show and the next day, as we walked to Central Park, a doorman who previously ignored us called my dog's name in greeting.

title: For Trade Post
description: Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, has joined the queue of those seeking to become the United States trade representative in the Bush administration.

title: For Head of Metals Concern, Merger Creates Top Ranking
description: Jean Gandois, 58, became chairman of the world's largest packaging business when Pechiney S.A., the French state-owned metals giant agreed this week to acquire Triangle Industries Inc. of the United States for $1.26 billion.

title: Postal Service TV Campaign
description: Just in time for the rush of holiday mail, the Postal Service will begin its ''We Deliver'' campaign during Monday Night Football on ABC.

title: In Brooklyn, Business (Especially Small Business) Is Booming
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Europe Drafts TV Rules
description: Broadcast ministers moved closer today to an agreement regulating Western Europe's television programs.

title: 11-Year-Old's Plan For Graduate School Is Blocked by Court
description: The parents of an 11-year-old boy who graduated from college in June have agreed to let him be named a temporary ward of the court, halting for now his plans to go to graduate school.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL OPEC members agreed to limit their oil production under a compromise plan in which Iran will yield its historical role as the cartel's second-largest producer. The accord will allow Iraq to produce as much oil as Iran. OPEC's total output will be restricted to 18.5 million barrels a day, much less than the recent production of 23 million barrels. Analysts predicted that oil prices would jump sharply as a result, but some said that a huge worldwide oil surplus might then push prices back down. [ Page A1. ] Western Europe's economy is growing at its fastest rate in a decade, and many economists say it will grow faster than the U.S. economy next year. But European unemployment is high. [ D1. ] Trade is booming between China and South Korea, two countries without diplomatic relations. Much of the commerce is directed through Hong Kong and Japan, and corporate relationships remain notably unofficial. [ A1. ] Britain's water industry would be sold to investors under the most contentious plan in the Thatcher Government's sweeping privatization program. Many economists, politicians and union officials, as well as the public, are skeptical. [ D1. ] The Irish Government approved the purchase of Irish Distillers by Pernod-Ricard in a friendly deal valued at $442 million. Grand Metropolitan said it would allow its higher, hostile offer of $499 million to lapse. Pernod will not be allowed to dispose of any Irish Distillers brands without Government approval. [ D1. ] NATO awarded a $10 billion contract to develop a fighter plane - the biggest Western European arms project since World War II. The deal is a boon to a consortium including British Aerospace, Casa of Spain, Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm of West Germany and Aeritalia of Italy. [ D3. ] Western Europe's broadcasting officials agreed on a proposal that could result in the continent's first program guidelines. [ D2. ] THE ECONOMY A shortage of computer memory chips is abating, experts say. The computer industry has shown signs of a slowdown, and some companies have added capacity to produce more of the most advanced memory chips. Some executives are even suggesting that there could be a glut by the middle of next year. [ D1. ] Commercial banks are reluctant to raise the prime rate, even though short-term interest rates have been rising. The hesitancy stems from weak demand for business loans and an economy that is not so robust that it needs to be restrained by the Fed. [ D1. ] A study urged changes in Federal policy that could increase use of natural gas by one-third during the next 20 years. The study, which was paid for by natural gas companies, was done by former Government officials with close ties to President-elect Bush. [ D2. ] COMPANIES General Motors and Toyota may jointly produce a one-ton truck in the U.S. The companies could use their joint automobile plant in Fremont, Calif. [ D3. ] The New York Post will raise its newsstand price. Starting Monday, the paper will cost 40 cents in New York City. The price will remain 50 cents outside the city. [ B4. ] MARKETS The dollar moved lower against leading currencies overseas, despite reports of central-bank intervention in Japan and West Germany. Gold prices were somewhat higher. [ D4. ] Stock prices drifted lower in Britain. Traders said that with the U.S. markets closed for Thanksgiving, there was little momentum in other countries. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A deadlock looms on how to cut the budget deficit. An extended impasse between the Bush Administration and Congress could make 1989 a harrowing year for the financial markets. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Retailers expect a fairly strong Christmas, but Wall Street sees little cheer in their stocks' prospects. Market Place. [ D4. ] Rupert Murdoch's new fashion magazine is aimed at a somewhat older readership than Vogue or Elle. If Mirabella succeeds, Mr. Murdoch will have tweaked his rival, Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., who owns Conde Nast, and further legitimized a category of magazines aimed at older women. Advertising. [ D6. ]

title: Chrysler Orders
description: The Chrysler Corporation has received orders for 60 percent more Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim cars than it will be able to build, the Chrysler Motors Corporation's chairman, Bennett Bidwell, said in an interview. Production of the new four-door sedans began a month ago at Chrysler's plant in Newark, Del., and the cars are sold out for the model year. Mr. Bidwell said the company had fleet orders of about 40,000 and dealer orders of about 160,000. Chrysler will be able to build fewer than 125,000 of the cars, he said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Eagle-Picher Industries, Cincinnati, which makes industrial machinery, elected Melvin F. Chubb Jr. senior vice president.

title: Review/Art; The Lean, Sharp Formalism of Stuart Davis
description: A writer once described Stuart Davis as a man who looked as if he were on his way to shoot craps, but the painter was in fact a bookish sort who studied and wrote intensively about art history. His lean brightly colored canvases - snapshots of an America that listened to jazz and deported itself with a certain naive swagger - were made by an artist who declared that subject matter was not important to him and who looked to Europe for inspiration: Mr. Davis was not yet 20 years old when his paintings were exhibited in the Armory Show of 1913 alongside works by Gauguin, van Gogh and Matisse. He later termed it ''the greatest single influence I have ever experienced in my work.''

title: Body of Christina Onassis Arrives in Greece for Burial
description: The body of Christina Onassis, the Greek shipping heiress, arrived in Greece today from Argentina for burial on her family's privately owned island in the Ionian Sea.

title: Armed, Sophisticated and Violent, Two Drug Gangs Blanket Nation
description: Two California gangs, fanning out along the interstate highway system, are spreading a sophisticated pattern of violence and drug dealing across the country. Federal and local law-enforcement officials say the gangs have reached as far east as Baltimore and Washington, staking out claims along the way in middle-size cities like Omaha.

title: Farm Agency Head Resigns
description: Vance L. Clark, head of the Farmers Home Administration for more than three years, has resigned, the agency said Wednesday.

title: Lionel Stake Rises
description: A group led by the New York investor Robert I. Toussie has raised its stake in the Lionel Corporation to 8.85 percent, from 7.8 percent, and repeated its interest in acquiring the New York-based toy store company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Toussie said he had started discussions about ''the possibility of retaining an investment banker'' in connection with his investment. Lionel operates 78 toy supermarkets under the names Kiddie City and Playland.

title: Injuries Hampering Bavaro
description: For an ordinary tight end, the season statistics are not that bad: 45 catches for 530 yards and two touchdowns. For Mark Bavaro of the Giants, the premier tight end in pro football the last two years, those figures represent a season of frustration.

title: Arab Woman Is Slain At Gaza Strip Market
description: A 40-year-old Palestinian woman was shot to death while shopping in a Gaza Strip market today, and Arabs said she had been killed by Israeli soldiers. But the army said the woman had probably been killed in a feud between families.

title: CANCER INSTITUTE GETS NEW LEADER
description: President Reagan has chosen Dr. Samuel Broder, a Federal research scientist who pioneered the use of the drug AZT in treating AIDS, to head the National Cancer Institute, a senior official of the Department of Health and Human Services said today.

title: RACES COMPARED ON BIRTH WEIGHT
description: Medical care in pregnancy helps increase the birth weight of black babies more than whites and can narrow the wide gap between the races in the frequency of dangerously small infants, a study concludes.

title: Money Is the Subject, Art the Object
description: Financiers, mergers and overnight fortunes, so much a part of today's economic scene, also fascinated a group of artists who found inspiration in the social and economic turmoil of America's industrial growth in the late 19th century. The subject of their art was money, and their work is now being rediscovered by collectors, galleries, auction houses and contemporary artists.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Football Texas A&M Wins, 28-24: Darren Lewis, Texas A&M's star running back, rushed for 212 yards and a 15-yard touchdown, and John Roper returned a block field goal 48 yards for a score yesterday as Texas A&M defeated Texas, 28-24, before a sellout crowd of 77,809 at Austin. The victory for Texas A&M (7-4) also marked the return of Coach Jackie Sherrill after a self-imposed one-game absence. Texas, a shadow of the team that once dominated the Southwest Conference, finished at 4-7, its worst record since 1956. The Longhorns, trailing by 28-0 in the second quarter, scored three touchdowns on passes by a freshman, Mark Murdock. Wayne Clements then kicked a 39-yard field goal by to scare the favored Aggies. It was A&M's fifth straight victory over Texas, which leads the series, 63-27-5. Sherrill voluntarily sat out the Texas Christian game last Saturday in the wake of a published report that quoted a former player as saying he had received $4,400 in ''hush money'' from Sherrill during an investigation of the Aggies' football program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The player later recanted his story. (AP) ROAD RACING Coghlan Wins 5-Mile Run: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, a former world record-holder for the mile, won the 17th annual Hyde Thanksgiving Day five-mile run yesterday in 25 minutes at Port Washington, L.I. Ira Meyer of Philadelphia, winner of the Long Island Marathon in 1985, trailed by 145 yards in 25:29. Laurie Harfenes of Plainview, L.I., was the women's winner in 31:46.

title: Man Who Befriended the Homeless Is Slain
description: A Bronx man who befriended two homeless men was stabbed to death by one of them during an argument over money Wednesday night, the police said. The victim's attacker died a few hours later after suffering a heart attack.

title: Randolph Has Sad Holiday
description: Willie Randolph, suddenly out of a job after enjoying remarkable stability with the most unsettled team in baseball, was pictured yesterday as sad and surprised but prepared to continue his career elsewhere.

title: I.R.A. Bomb Meant for the Police Kills 2 Civilians
description: A bungled guerrilla bombing of a village police station killed a 67-year-old Roman Catholic civilian and his 13-year-old granddaughter and wounded eight people, the police reported.

title: Jet Defense Misses Gastineau
description: The Jets have become a team without a pass rusher in the five games since Mark Gastineau went to Arizona.

title: Accounts
description: * Sun Line Cruises to AC&R Advertising, at $2.5 million.

title: TV Weekend; Series on Fall of Marcos
description: ''A Dangerous Life,'' produced for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is one of Home Box Office's more successful acquisitions in recent years. The mini-series tackles nothing less than the overthrow of President Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines by Corazon Aquino. The first of the production's three parts, being shown on consecutive evenings, can be seen on the pay-cable service this Sunday at 8 P.M.

title: Mahres Return
description: After a four-year layoff, Phil and Steve Mahre went for the gold and got it. In qualifying for the America's Opening pro ski race in Park City, Utah, yesterday, Steve finished with the second-fastest combined time, and Phil finished third. The only racer to beat the twins from Yakima, Wash., was Niklas Lindquist of Sweden, a rookie on the pro circuit tour this year. The top three qualifiers were awarded gold bars. A field of 32 men and 16 women were selected in the qualifying runs to compete in slalom and giant slalom runs scheduled for today, tomorrow and Sunday. Steve Mahre said he and his brother could have skiied better, but were satisfied at being able to qualify in their first attempt. ''To tell you the truth, I didn't feel that fast,'' he said. It was the first time the Mahre brothers had raced since the 1984 Olympics in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.(AP)

title: Review/Theater; 'Ariadne Obnoxious,' Legend Retold
description: Ethyl Eichelberger has invigorated so many evenings with his cross-dressed clowning that he is entitled to an off night, which is the most discreet way to characterize his ''Ariadne Obnoxious'' at the Joyce Theater. The pity is that Black-Eyed Susan is also allowed to amble desultorily through the Greek legend of Ariadne and Theseus.

title: Books of The Times; America Explained by a Visitor Who Stayed
description: America Observed By Alistair Cooke Selected and introduced by Ronald A. Wells. 233 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''PROFESSOR PUTTER AND HIS GADGETORIUM,'' a program of magic, music and comedy, noon and 2 P.M. today and tomorrow, and 1 P.M. Sunday, at the Samuel Beckett Theater, 410 West 42d Street. Tickets: children, $4; adults, $6. Reservations: 594-2826. ''THE SECRET GARDEN,'' a play based on the story by Frances Hodgson Burnett, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 11 A.M. and 2 P.M. tomorrow at the Emelin Theater, Library Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Tickets: $4. Information: (914) 698-0098. ''IN A BOOK,'' a reading and performance of ''Green Eggs and Ham'' and ''I Can Read With My Eyes Shut,'' stories by Dr. Seuss, presented by members of the Readers Theater Workshop, 2 P.M. tomorrow, at the Queens Museum, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Flushing. Free with museum admission: children, $3; adults, $4. Information: (718) 592-2405. ''BAREFOOT IN BROOKLYN,'' a program of dancing presented by the Barefoot Dance Company from Ireland, 1:30 and 3 P.M. today, at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue. Donation: $2. Information: (718) 735-4400. ''IT'S NEWS TO ME,'' a new exhibition about news and the media, with information about editing and transmitting, and hands-on activities, at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The museum is open 1 to 4 P.M. Wednesdays through Fridays and 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays and most school holidays. Donation: $2. Information: (718) 273-2060. ''THE ODYSSEY,'' a play based on Homer's epic, presented by the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, and directed by Amie Brockway, 2 P.M. Sunday, at the Open Eye Theater, Henry Lindenbaum Center, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: $6 and $8. Information: 769-4143. ''SUSAN B,'' a play about Susan B. Anthony, the suffragist, by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway at 76th Street. Tickets: $10 and $14. Information: 677-5959. ''WILBUR THE CHRISTMAS MOUSE,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, 1:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, and ''Santa Claus and the Magic Bell,'' 3 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 765-9540. ''TALES OF THE FIRST THANKSGIVING,'' a program of stories about the holiday told by Jonathan Kruk, 2 P.M. Sunday at the Trailside Nature Museum, Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, Route 121, off Route 35, Cross River, N.Y. Free. Information: (914) 763-3993. ''PETER AND THE WOLF'' and ''THE FROG PRINCE,'' two shows presented by Puppetworks, 11 A.M. and 1:30 and 3 P.M. tomorrow, at the Donnell Public Library, 20 West 53d Street. Free. Information: 621-0620 or 621-0639. A similar show will be given at 1 and 3 P.M. Sunday, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: children, $3.75; adults, $4. Reservations: (718) 834-1828. ''FUNZAPOPPIN'' a play, at 1:30 P.M. Sunday, by Michael Taubenslag Productions, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Tickets: $4.50. Reservations: 772-9180. ''THE ROSE THAT REFUSED TO BLOOM,'' a musical with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Snow White Show,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677.

title: AT THE BAR
description: Abraham Zapruder, the Dallas dressmaker and coincidental film chronicler of the assassination of President Kennedy, died in 1970. His 486 famous frames of Kodachrome now sit in the United States Archives, alongside Eva Braun's home movies. But the question of who should own the Zapruder film, like the matter of just what it reveals about the killing, is still hotly debated.

title: Texas Utility Filing
description: The Houston Lighting and Power Company, a unit of Houston Industries, said it had filed for an increase of $432 million in its electricity rate with the Public Utility Commission of Texas. Houston Lighting said the proposal would increase electric bills for its customers by about 15 percent. The company said it needed to raise rates to cover its investment in nuclear- and lignite-powered units. It said the rate request was the first of three that it expects to file over the next few years.

title: Seeding Hostility Among the Thais
description: LEAD: United States trade policy is beginning to fracture relations with Thailand, a key ally in Southeast Asia. While Thais have had a strong affection for Americans for decades, our recent actions on trade are changing those feelings.

title: A Day of Thanks for a Soviet 'Twin'
description: On a balmy day at the Larchmont Temple in Westchester County last May, Jeremy Lizt had two bar mitzvahs: one for himself and one for a boy his age whom he believed to be trapped in the Soviet Union, denied the central rite of passage in the Jewish faith.

title: 3 Children Die And 2 Are Hurt In Jersey Blaze
description: Three children died and two others were seriously injured today when an early morning fire sparked by a kitchen stove ravaged their home, the authorities said.

title: Soviets Ask Halt In Ethnic Unrest In 2 Republics
description: Government officials appealed for calm today in the southern Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan as security forces moved to quell renewed ethnic unrest in the region.

title: Study Says Older Smokers Gain by Quitting
description: Smokers are never too old to benefit from quitting, say researchers who found that even people in their 70's could significantly reduce their risk of heart attack and death.

title: Pontiac Incentive
description: Owners of Pontiac Fieros, two-seater cars that are no longer being made, can get a $500 credit toward the purchase of a new Pontiac, the division of the General Motors Corporation said. A G.M. spokesman, William J. O'Neill, said the Pontiac division was mailing special coupons to 150,000 Fiero owners, offering them the cash if they buy any model 1989 Pontiac. The offer expires Sept. 30, 1989, the end of the 1989 model year, and is available in addition to any other incentive the company has offered.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
description: Smirnoff Vodka, a product of Heublein Inc., will initiate a $10 million campaign in two weeks, featuring a four-color holiday photo with gleaming ornaments, a Smirnoff bottle, a glass and the theme ''Great to give, even better to receive.''

title: Stock Prices Fall in London
description: Stock prices drifted lower today in light trading, taking a cue from Wall Street, which was shut down for the Thanksgiving holiday. ''I'm afraid that when the

title: Massachusetts Sewage Spill Closes Some Shellfish Beds
description: About 9.5 million gallons of untreated sewage flowed into New Bedford Harbor on Wednesday when the power failed at a city treatment plant, officials said.

title: NEW LAW COMPELS SWEEPING CHANGES IN CHILD SUPPORT
description: As a consequence of a new Federal welfare law, the nation is about to embark on a sweeping overhaul of the system for guaranteeing the financial support of children whose parents have divorced or perhaps never married. The changes, aimed largely at forcing working fathers to meet their legal obligations, will involve states more heavily in assuring that payments are made in full and on time.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY GILBERT AND SULLIVAN

title: Dining Out Guide: Winter Dishes
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants reviewed in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Bellevues Diner's Journal (July 1, 1988), 496 Ninth Avenue, at 38th Street (967-7855) - Bellevues, a casual diner-like restaurant, features daily specials: cassoulet on Monday, pot au feu on Thursday, and lamb curry on Sunday are examples. Entrees from $11.50 to $13.75. Dinner served from 6 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, and from 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. Sunday. Chez Josephine

title: Kentucky Seeks Tougher Standards for Buses
description: Six months after 27 people died in a church bus accident, a special panel has recommended 17 changes in Kentucky's bus safety standards, including adding a new emergency exit.

title: Redmen Romp in Lapchick
description: With his dynamic backcourt broken up, his center playing basketball in Italy and his front line relying on two freshmen, Coach Lou Carnesecca may be facing the biggest challenge in his 21 seasons as coach of St. John's.

title: Agency Faulted on Toy Safety
description: A consumer group has accused the Consumer Product Safety Commission of ''pitiful ineptitude'' in ridding the market of toys that can be dangerous to children, but the agency defended itself.

title: Brandon Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Auburn Ties for S.E.C. Title
description: Auburn gained a share of the Southeastern Conference championship and a berth in the Sugar Bowl today by using its specialty: defense.

title: Six Awards to 'Struttin' '
description: A musical about life in the theater dominated the 16th annual Audelco awards Monday at Aaron Davis Hall at City College, 134th Street and Convent Avenue. The awards were presented by the Audience Development Committee, founded by several Harlem residents to encourage black theatrical patronage and recognize black achievements in theater.

title: Cut in Farm Subsidies Urged
description: One of George Bush's first tasks as President should be to slash agricultural subsidies and ''get farmers off the dole,'' in the view of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research body with close ties to the Reagan Administration.

title: Suffield Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: California Micro Devices Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes a $1,522,000 provision reserve for aquisition expenses related to the Aug. 11 purchase of assets and specified liabilities of American Mirosystems Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Gould Inc.

title: Danger of New York Streets Comes From Kamikaze Pedestrians
description: To the Editor:

title: Endlessly Grudging in South Africa
description: What a rare and welcome step in South Africa: the commutation Wednesday of death sentences against six black prisoners. The news seemed the better when followed by the announcement that Nelson Mandela would not be returned to prison after his treatment for tuberculosis at a private clinic. But Pretoria's contorted, crabwise steps invite the conclusion that any movement away from repression is illusory.

title: Psychiatry Bears Guilt in Brainwashing Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With all the jillions of mousetraps, the best one is still the simplest.'' - Clifford R. Feldman, who patented a new mousetrap. [ 32:1. ]

title: Michigan Energy Resources Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $379,000 for the quarter and $1,105,000 for the 9 months, and an estimated loss on disposition of discontinued operations of $3.3 million for the both periods. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $393,000 for the quarter and $969,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income

title: New York Schools Call It Teaching
description: LEAD: When I began teaching in New York City high schools, I heard a story that I thought apocryphal. It goes this way: A teacher is being observed by the principal. The teacher gives a stunning performance. There's an enthusiastic response from students eager to contribute to a lively discussion. At the end of the lesson, the principal, beaming, shakes the teacher's hand.

title: Nets Lose to Clippers, 100-93
description: Quintin Dailey scored 25 points and Danny Manning scored 18 tonight to help keep the Clippers unbeaten at home as Los Angeles downed the Nets, 100-93.

title: Alphaeus Cole, a Portraitist, 112
description: Alphaeus Philemon Cole, who began his career as a portraitist when Post-Impressionists like Seurat and Signac were considered avant-garde painters, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in the Chelsea Hotel. He was 112 years old.

title: Danger of New York Streets Comes From Kamikaze Pedestrians; License Bicycles
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadien Suspended
description: Craig Ludwig, a defenseman for the Montreal Canadiens, was given a five-game suspension by the National Hockey League yesterday for elbowing Trent Yawney of Chicago in a game Nov. 19.

title: The Tribune Backs Pact
description: The Chicago Tribune said today that it had agreed to a settlement involving cash buyouts and lifetime annuities for union printers who walked out three years ago over work rules at the newspaper.

title: John Houseman Tribute
description: Virgil Thomson, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Kevin Kline, Robin Williams and Patti LuPone are among the artists who will take part in a memorial tribute to the producer and director John Houseman, Tuesday at 4 P.M. at the Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street. Mr. Houseman died on Oct. 31 at the age of 86. The event is open to the public.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1988
description: International

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots Motorist
description: An off-duty Transit Police officer fired three shots in a traffic dispute with a postal worker in Brooklyn Heights yesterday, striking the man twice and apparently shooting himself in the wrist, the authorities said.

title: Alice Grant, 66, Labor Relations Specialist
description: Alice Bacon Grant, an educator and labor relations specialist, died of cancer on Nov. 17 at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. She was 66 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: Calstar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Wickes Plans to Sell Credit Card Provider
description: The Wickes Companies, the diversified manufacturing and retailing concern, will sell its WCI Financial Corporation subsidiary for about $300 million to a corporation founded by two of the company's executives, Wickes announced today.

title: Micheners Give Away Two Art Collections
description: To protest the rise in art prices, the novelist James Michener and his wife have given two schools their entire collections of Japanese prints and American paintings, valued at more than $18 million.

title: Cooper Surgical
description: The Cooper Companies signed a definitive agreement for the previously announced sale of the assets of its ophthalmic surgical products business to Alcon Laboratories Inc., a subsidiary of Nestle S.A., for about $325 million in cash. The sale of Cooper Surgical, initially announced on Oct. 6, is subject to review and approval of directors of both companies and regulatory agencies. Cooper said the proposed transaction should be completed by the end of the year.

title: Syracuse Wins N.I.T. in Overtime
description: Stephen Thompson took control for Syracuse in overtime last night as the Orangemen defeated Missouri, 86-84, to capture the Big Apple National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Callahan Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: HIGH YIELDS
description: Short-term deposit rates have been rising significantly faster than longer-term rates, producing the highest yields for six-month bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts since bank deregulation. This means that depositors do not have to tie up their money for a long time to receive yields normally offered for longer maturities. For instance, the average yield on a six-month certificate of deposit last November was 132 basis points below the yield offered for a five year C.D.; since then, that yield spread has been nearly reduced by half. Analysts at Donoghue's Money Fund Report say the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund is at a three year high, with room for further increases. Here are some of the highest yields and rates available to consumers: Instrument Rate/Yield Six-Month Treasury bill 8.08 Six-Month bank C.D. 8.89 (Highest Yield) Mini Jumbo C.D. ($25, 000) 8.89 (Highest Yield) Bank Money market Account 8.33 (Highest Yield) Money Market Mutual Funds 8.46 (Average of the Highest Yields)

title: Bush, With New Zest, Steps Into Foreground
description: A needlepoint pillow on a love seat outside George and Barbara Bush's bedroom in their oceanfront house here offers a good summary of the President-elect's approach to life: ''Enthusiasm,'' the inscription says, ''is the greatest asset - more than power or influence or money.''

title: Aequitron Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sweepstakes That Yield Little for Charity
description: As appeals for charitable contributions soar during the holidays, government and private consumer-protection agencies are warning about nationwide sweepstakes that are raking in millions of dollars for fund-raisers who give little to the charities they represent.

title: Reviews/Pop; Salsa Singing And Dancing
description: Oscar d'Leon, the bassist, bandleader and singer, brought a tight and articulate 13-piece salsa band to the Village Gate Monday night. Mr. d'Leon, who is from Venezuela, is a charismatic performer: singing, leading his band and dancing around on stage. He's the type of leader who uses lots of tricks to keep an audience's mind from straying.

title: Energy Ventures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,974,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated for the change in reporting entity for oil and gas investments, as well as the cumulative effect of adoption of statement of FAS No. 96.

title: SOVIET ARMY PUTS ARMENIAN CAPITAL UNDER ITS CONTROL
description: A military commandant took control of the Armenian capital today as the Soviet Government moved to prevent further ethnic violence in a region shaken by months of unrest.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Top-Seeded Pair Advances: The top-seeded team of Robin White of the United States and Gigi Fernandez of Puerto Rico beat Anne Smith of the United States and Janine Thompson of Australia, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the Virginia Slims world doubles championship in Tokyo. The Smith-Thompson pair broke serve in the fifth game and the White-Fernandez team broke in the eighth game before going into a tie breaker. In another first-round match, Katrina Adams and Zina Garrison of the United States posted a 5-7, 6-2, 7-5 triumph over second-seeded Lori McNeil and Betsy Nagelsen, also Americans. Elizabeth Smylie of Australia and Eva Pfaff of West Germany beat the American pair of Beth Herr and Candy Reynolds, 7-5, 6-4, and an American, Patty Fendick, and a Canadian, Jill Hetherington, defeated the Bulgarian sister team of Manuela and Katerina Maleeva, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3.(AP) Leconte Gains: Top-seeded Henri Leconte of France beat Wally Masur of Australia, 6-4, 1-6, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $490,000 Belgian Indoor Championship in Brussels. Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, seeded second, also advanced with a 7-5, 6-4 victory over Tom Nijssen of the Netherlands. In other quarterfinal matches, John Fitzgerald of Australia beat Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-1, 3-6, 6-0, and another West German, Patrick Kuhnen, overpowered Eric Winogradsky of France, 6-4, 6-2. Leconte meets Fitzgerald, seeded fourth, in one of the semifinals today, while Hlasek plays unseeded Kuhnen in the other.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 6, Jets 3: Tim Higgins and Steve Yzerman scored goals 1 minute 3 seconds apart in the first period last night and the Red Wings killed off more than seven minutes of power plays by Winnipeg early in the final period to beat the Jets. The goals by Higgins and Yzerman gave the Red Wings a 3-0 lead after one period and started them to their eighth victory in nine games. The visiting Jets had won four straight before last night. A rash of penalties early in the final period forced Detroit to play short-handed for 7:18, including a 1:32 span when the Red Wings were two men short. But Detroit's penalty killers, led by Higgins, Dave Barr, Mike O'Connell and Shawn Burr, held the Jets to just three shots during the span.(AP) Sabres 5, Blackhawks 4: Phil Housley scored 3:15 into overtime to lift the Sabres, playing at home, to their first overtime victory in almost two years. Housley's goal, his ninth of the season, came on a point-blank shot from in close set up by Adam Creighton. It was Buffalo's first overtime victory since Jan. 18, 1987. North Stars 5, Maple Leafs 3: In Bloomington, Minn., Brian Bellows got a hat trick, including two goals in a span of 1:13 in a four-goal Minnesota first period. Minnesota, with the fewest points in the N.H.L. at 14, rushed to a 4-0 lead with goals from Brian MacLellan and Neal Broten, in addition to two from Bellows. Minnesota peppered the Toronto goaltender, Ken Wregget, with 15 shots in the period.(AP) Penguins 5, Capitals 3: In Landover, Md., Rob Brown scored three power-play goals and Mario Lemieux added a short-handed goal and two assists as Pittsburgh defeated Washington, snapping the Capitals' five-game winning streak. The Penguins won despite being outshot, 39-16, by the Capitals. Brown scored twice in the first period as Pittsburgh opened a 3-1 advantage and then completed his second hat trick of the season 4:41 into the final period.(AP)

title: Home Resales Drop by 1.1%
description: Sales of existing homes fell 1.1 percent in October for the second consecutive month, even though mortgage rates declined slightly, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: The Mania of Art Auctions: Problems as Well as Profits
description: The effects of the huge prices paid at this month's art auctions are reverberating through the art world. Where the sellers and the auction houses happily see profits, many dealers, curators, artists and collectors see problems.

title: Kabul Aide Sees Soviets Leaving by Deadline
description: An Afghan Politburo member said today that Moscow would meet the Feb. 15 deadline for the removal of all its troops from Afghanistan.

title: Christie's 'Mousetrap' Alive and Well at 36
description: The crime thriller that Agatha Christie gave her grandson for his ninth birthday is still keeping theater audiences on the edge of their seats 36 years later.

title: Executone Information Sysems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma and presented as an approximation of the results which would have been reported if the business combinations had been in effect for that period. Year-ago first quarter pro forma loss was $10,782,000 on revenue of $89,883,000. Executone was formed through the consolidation of Vodavi Technology Corp., Isotec Communications Inc. and Executone.

title: Crippling the Disabled
description: LEAD: Because of polio, I have no use of my arms and a severe spinal curvature. I sleep with a ventilator. I earned my Ph.D. in history and my first book, about George Washington, was published this month. My disability has not prevented me from working hard, but it does incur enormous expenses.

title: Teach Kids to Protect, Not Kill, Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: William Thomas, 75, Ex-Red Cross Official
description: Willliam Stewart Thomas, a field director for the American National Red Cross from 1943 to 1963, died of cancer of the esophagus Tuesday at his home in Newport, R.I. He was 75 years old.

title: Tyson Sues Cayton
description: The conflict for control of Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, has taken another turn to the courts, with Tyson suing his manager, Bill Cayton, to invalidate Cayton's contract with him.

title: Dow Falls 17.60, to 2,074.68; Volume Plunges
description: Stock prices dropped broadly yesterday as volume slipped to its lowest level in almost two years.

title: Malartic Hygrade Gold Mines (Canada) Ltd (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a special gain of $1,630,416. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Reviews/Pop; The Lucid Improvisations of Edie Brickell
description: On their debut album, ''Shooting Rubberbands at the Stars,'' Edie Brickell and New Bohemians play smooth pop-folk songs centered on Ms. Brickell's sweet, breathy voice. But on stage at the Bottom Line last weekend, the focus shifted, and Ms. Brickell's voice became just one element in full-band grooves that bubbled with improvisation.

title: Lady Vols Open With 81-50 Rout
description: Bridgette Gordon sat out most of the second half but had 22 points to lead top-ranked Tennessee to an 81-50 victory over Illinois today in the opening round of the Hawaii Wahine Classic.

title: The Great American Lockout
description: It's embarrassing having to complain constantly about progress, because progress is really what America is all about unless they've been lying to us. Plus and also (people talk like this nowadays; it's progress) - plus and also, it is banal, boring, trite and tedious to complain about progress, in addition to which you can't stop progress.

title: Bond Prices Depressed by Oil Move
description: Treasury note and bond prices dropped and bill rates rose yesterday in an abbreviated post-holiday trading session.

title: NESB Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After securities gains of $280,000 for the quarter and $765,000 for the 9 months. c-After securities gains of $454,000 and $2,430,332 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: 'Strong' Quake Shakes Northeast
description: An earthquake centered in southeastern Canada shook parts of the United States last night, rattling homes, windows and furniture and frightening many people.

title: New Opera News Editor
description: Patrick J. Smith, since 1985 direc-tor of the opera-musical theater program at the National Endowment for the Arts, has been appointed editor of Opera News. The announcement was made Tuesday by Alton E. Peters, president of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, which publishes the magazine. Mr. Smith succeeds Patrick O'Connor, who became editor on Jan. 1 and who is returning to his native England because of illnesses in his family. Mr. Smith is to take over the post on March 1.

title: Books of The Times; An Allegory and a Memoir of Nazi Rule Entwined
description: W, or the Memory of Childhood By Georges Perec Translated by David Bellos. 164 pages. David R. Godine. $16.95.

title: Odd Alliance Would Speed New Drugs
description: AIDS patients and their advocates are finding themselves in strange company these days. Many have grown disenchanted with their longstanding liberal allies in Congress and the consumer movement and are joining with conservative groups on the issue of greatest importance to them: speeding the release of experimental new drugs.

title: A Lutoslawski Premiere By the Philharmonic
description: The pianist Krystian Zimerman will be the soloist for the United States premiere of Witold Lutoslawski's Piano Concerto, in four concerts by the New York Philharmonic, next Thursday, Friday, Saturday and on Dec. 6 at Avery Fisher Hall. Zubin Mehta will conduct. A composition by the American composer Ellen Taaffe Zwilich will be included in each of the four concerts. ''Symbolon'' will be played on Thursday and Dec. 6, and Concerto Grosso 1985 at the two other performances. Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 3 (''Scottish'') will complete the program.

title: Mexico Is Near Sale of Airline
description: The Mexican Government is close to selling the national airline Aerovias de Mexico, familiarly known as Aeromexico, for $340 million, the state-owned Banobras bank announced. A group of private investors and the Government bank Bancomer are to acquire 75 percent of the stock of Aeromexico. The remaining 25 percent is being offered to the national pilots' union, ASPA, which has yet to close its financing.

title: Review/Theater; Madcap Clowns Clad In Drag and Flowerpots
description: Bloolips, the British company of zany clowns that descends on New York every few years to tickle an adoring cult audience, elevates drag merriment to a dimension that transcends conventional female impersonation.

title: Bid Rejected in Britain
description: The property company London Shop P.L.C. said today that it had rejected a takeover bid of $:269 million, or $492.3 million, from Peel Holdings P.L.C., a property development company. John Bushell, chairman of London Shop, said, ''The offer does not reflect the value of the company and will be firmly rejected.''

description: b-Net income

description: International 3-6, 24
