title: Q And A
description: Mortgage Information Question: I would like to refinance my Manhattan co-op apartment. I have called and visited several banks, but I get confused trying to sort out the different terms and policies. Is there any state or city agency or banking group that can provide information for someone in my situation? . . . C. T., Manhattan Answer: Yes. The Federal Reserve Board in Washington publishes a booklet called ''A Consumer's Guide to Mortgage Refinancing.'' Some banks make it available to the public or you can write to the Federal Reserve Bank, Public Information Office, Washington, D.C. 20551. Other consumer-oriented booklets available through the agency offer information on adjustable-rate mortgages and mortgage closings. Water-Pressure Problem Question: I am a member of an eight-family co-op, where all shareholders sit on the board of directors. I have been having difficulty getting my fellow board members to respond to a water-pressure problem that affects only my apartment.

title: Signs of Harmony At an Oil Meeting
description: OPEC worked out an accord on production limits after the Iranian oil minister agreed to allow Iraq to have a quota equal to Iran's. The minister, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, left the meeting in Vienna to return to Tehran and try to get his Government to accept the accord. Under the agreement, total production of all 13 member nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would be limited to 18.5 million barrels a day; production has been as high as 23 million barrels a day recently. Iraq and Iran would each get to produce 2.6 million barrels a day. The accord could still unravel, as parity with Iraq may not be acceptable to the hard-liners in Iran, still bitter over the eight-year war with Iraq. Skeptics also noted that OPEC has an extremely poor record when it comes to getting members to adhere to quotas. Still, it was the first time in a long time that an OPEC meeting had achieved any sort of consensus, and oil prices moved up sharply.

description: I am an independent film maker. Since 1968, 20 of my documentaries have been broadcast on public television. title: Anita Sethi Weds Eric D. Lefcowitz
description: Anita Sethi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Uttam Sethi of Sands Point, L.I., and Eric David Lefcowitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Allan B. Lefcowitz of Bethesda, Md., were married last evening in Mineola, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsy performed the ceremony at the Jericho Terrace. The bride, who will keep her name, graduated from Clark University and received a master's degree in education and psychology from the University of California at Berkeley. She teaches children with learning disabilities at the Sky's the Limit school in San Rafael, Calif. Her father is the president of the Wildflower Vitamin Corporation in Mineola. Her mother, Amrit Sethi, is the director of the Happy Montessori School in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Who Skis?
description: STANDING, LIKE A CANDIDATE, BEHIND A podium in a restaurant in midtown Manhattan, George N. Gillett Jr. is addressing a roomful of travel industry representatives, pitching the attractions of the winter season at Vail, the Colorado ski resort he has owned since 1985. A diminutive, 50-year-old entrepreneur who made a fortune in the meatpacking business and another as the owner of television stations, Gillett is now leading a campaign to rejuvenate the ski industry.

title: Off-Duty Officer Kills Man During Robbery
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed a man who tried to rob him at knifepoint in the Bronx yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Good Sound for Audiophiles on a Budget
description: Music is an art for all seasons; even so, most sound equipment is bought in fall and winter. Christmas has something to do with it, no doubt. But perhaps it is also that late autumn fosters domesticity. Dark days and long nights stir primal feelings for the hearth - except that nowadays the hearth has been largely supplanted by a video screen or a pair of loudspeakers.

title: An Encore for an Aging Theater
description: LEAD: FOR many residents, the Garde Theater in downtown New London symbolizes a city that is constantly on the verge of salvation. More than once, plans to restore the former movie house and vaudeville theater to its past grandeur have foundered just as a long-awaited citywide rebirth has yet to happen.

title: A Feel for Traditional Forms
description: LEAD: FROM 1970 to 1974, when Steven Sanfilippo was in the Navy and stationed in Norfolk, Va., music was what brought the facets of his life together.

title: CORRESPONDENT'S CHOICE  Eight Settings for the Holiday Season From Rio's Heights to Rome's Heart; ITALY: When the Romans reclaim the Piazza Navona
description: For the last three years I have been lucky enough to work in an office just a few hundred yards from the Piazza Navona, and so I have seen this landmark in all its guises. During a rainstorm on a winter afternoon its Baroque intricacies can seem austere, and just after dawn on a summer morning the ocher facades almost glow.

title: Kansas Penalty Is Applauded
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bush Orders Prompt Report on Budget
description: President-elect Bush, under pressure to move quickly to reduce the Federal budget deficit, has ordered his two chief advisers on the issue to report to him next week about the most effective ways to deal with the entire budget process, Bush aides said today.

title: Law as a Part-Time Job
description: When the third-grade class at the Edgewood Elementary School in Scarsdale took a Wednesday trip recently to visit Wayside Cottage, they were accompanied by a senior associate at Cuddy & Feder, a law firm with headquarters in White Plains. The lawyer, Helen K. Rosenberg, is the mother of 8-year-old Stuart, and a familiar presence at his school, particularly on Wednesdays.

title: OUT OF THE KITCHEN, INTO THE CABINET
description: ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT tasks facing each new Administration is the formation of its Cabinet.

title: Holiday Choral Offerings
description: A VARIETY of chamber programs and the start of the Christmas choral season are among the week's concert highlights, starting this afternoon at 4 when the Riverside Piano Trio - Adela Pena, Astrid Schween and Mark Selman - makes its local debut in New Canaan's Carriage Barn.

title: A Haunting,Striking 'Mojo' In New Brunswick
description: AISHAH RAHMAN has written an original, engrossing, at times quite beautiful and moving half of a play. What happens to disrupt its flow and cramp her very striking style, just when the play's most poignant line is spoken, is simple enough to identify. It is called the intermission. But its aftereffect is inexplicable and its consequences are unfortunate.

title: Free at Last?
description: Nelson R. Mandela, who has served 24 years of a life sentence for sabotage, will not go back to jail after recuperating from tuberculosis at a private clinic, the South African Government said last week. Without elaboration, it said he would be sent instead to a ''suitable, comfortable and secure'' accommodation. That did not impress Winnie N. Mandela, wife of the 70-year-old leader of the African National Congress. ''Mr. Mandela still remains a prisoner of the South African Government,'' she said, ''and there is no indication of any release.''

title: Casting a Critical Eye at the Met's Casting
description: For as long as I have been following the Metropolitan Opera, which is more than 30 years, people have complained about the unacceptably low quality of some casts. Justifiably, too. A company whose tradition requires it to put on seven performances a week for six and a half months each season constantly faces the problem of where to find enough good - even passable - singers and conductors. To be conservative, let us figure that 10 leading artists and comprimarios must be engaged per performance. Over the 224-performance season, that adds up to more than 2,000 names to be matched to roles and written into the blanks. Before computers, the first qualifications of a Metropolitan casting director were an aptitude for chess and a resistance to writer's cramp or typist's elbow.

title: POSTINGS: Somerset Office Center; Rivalry in Jersey's Watchung Range
description: Not all intraregional competition in the metropolitan area is between New York City and New Jersey. An even narrower rivalry has arisen in New Jersey's Watchung Mountains between Morris County and its neighbor to the south, Somerset County. Morris has long been a favorite location for corporate headquarters, while Somerset remained predominantly residential.

title: Too Hot to Handle
description: ABOUT HALFWAY through the coming-of-age film ''Diner,'' a streetwise character named Boogie, played by Mickey Rourke, and his inexperienced friend Eddie, played by Steve Guttenberg, are having a man-to-man talk at the counter. As he washes down a mouthful of sugar with a Coca-Cola chaser, Boogie turns to his friend, suddenly intuiting the reason for the conversation. ''So you're a virgin, heh?'' His secret exposed, Eddie, his voice cracking as he tries to stay cool, answers, ''Technically.''

title: Lou Holtz of Notre Dame Raps the Gavel Again
description: ''There's no excuse for anybody being late now, because everyone got a Cotton Bowl watch. That's why going to a bowl game was one of our goals: to make sure everybody would be on time.'' - Lou Holtz Tony Brooks and Ricky Watters were the two fastest players on the Notre Dame team. But even with their Cotton Bowl watches, they sometimes weren't fast enough to get to meetings and practice on time. And in the hours before Notre Dame stunned Southern Cal, 27-10, yesterday, the two sophomores who suddenly had been suspended by Holtz for ''repeated, irresponsible tardiness,'' were on a jetliner returning them to the South Bend, Ind., campus.

title: Christin Anne Englert Weds Paul Stockton
description: Christin Anne Englert and Paul Noble Stockton were married yesterday at the Hand Chapel of Mount Vernon College in Washington. The Rev. Patrick J. Sullivan, dean of the Graduate Center of Fordham University, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: The Coming Crunch for the Military Budget
description: AS President-elect Bush works on plans to slow down Federal spending, the first casualties are likely to be in military programs where the Reagan legacy is already proving short-lived.

title: Actor Who Writes Roles Based on Life
description: JOHN TURTURRO is wrapping up critical accolades on top of considerable popular adulation as an actor in wild and crazy roles on the stage and screen, However, it is Mr. Turturro's perseverance as a writer that is his most telling current pursuit, and that, coincidentally, heightens his performance in the off-Broadway comedy ''Italian American Reconciliation.''

title: SURVIVAL ODDS
description: Perri Klass writes of physicians who feel like ''torturers'' when they provide intensive care for very premature newborns (Body and Mind: ''Survival Odds,'' Oct. 23). She writes of physicians, like herself, who would give birth in remote community hospitals or in the woods to escape intensive care for their own infants.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yankees Trade Don Mattingly?
description: Although I would prefer not to see Mattingly traded I could easily live with it, if the Yanks are overwhelmed with an outrageous offer for him. Let's face facts. The Yanks have won nothing with Mattingly. I can clearly understand Steinbrenner's anger at Mattingly. How many of us can publicly attack our bosses and show up for work the next day? ANGELA GREEN New York

title: Religious Leaders Try To Heal Rift in Chicago
description: The worshipers at Congregation Hakafa in nearby Winnetka overflowed the sanctuary and spilled into the adjacent hallways Friday, a standing-room-only audience that had come to hear a special guest, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, give an address to the evening service.

title: The Feeling Is Mutual
description: CHARLES DICKENS fuzzed up the meaning of a good word when, in 1865, he titled a novel ''Our Mutual Friend.''

title: FROM LASSIE TO PEE-WEE
description: Yo! That's Bonita Granville Wrather, the producer of ''Lassie,'' with Jon Provost and Lassie, not me, in the picture accompanying your article on children's television. JUNE LOCKHART Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Ex-Patient Is State Hospital Official
description: A woman who was misdiagnosed and kept in a state mental hospital for more than 15 years has returned to the hospital as a full-time administrator. She has earned a master's degree at Harvard.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOLLYWOOD'S PRIME Robert D. Lippet of Great Neck has film clips and will travel. Since his retirement from the advertising business, Mr. Lippet has turned his interest in old movies - he's a card-carrying member of the Society for Cinephiles - into a full schedule of library-hopping throughout the three-state area with his film-illustrated lectures.

title: For a Bowling Widow, a Split Isn't Just Two Lonely Pins
description: I USED to think a split was three scoops of ice cream on a sliced banana with whipped cream. Then, I married a man who bowls. Now I know. Splits are the work of wicked gremlins who make bowling pins on opposite sides of the alley stand up straight, while all the rest fall down.

title: Working to Help Irish Immigrants Stay, Legally
description: On a recent evening in a basement in Woodside, Queens, half a dozen volunteers sat under defiant green-and-white posters that read, ''Legalize The Irish.''

title: Thomas Tyree To Wed Kathleen Lewis
description: The engagement of Kathleen Barry Lewis to Thomas Burdick Tyree Jr., the son of Joan Brophy Tyree of Pawling, N.Y., and the late Mr. Tyree, has been announced by Margaret S. Lewis of Barrington, R.I., and Roger S. Lewis of East Providence, R.I., parents of the future bride.

title: Fruitcakes Made in a Kentucky Abbey
description: AT 3 A.M. a bell peals across the misty, moonlit fields of central Kentucky. For the monks of the Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani, another day of prayer, meditation and manual labor begins.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'WINTER LIGHTS' BENEFIT
description: LEAD: Rupert Holmes -- Broadway composer, arranger, orchestrater an playwright, record producer, pop songwriter, Scarsdale resident and Westchester arts booster -- will sing and play piano at ''Winter Lights,'' the 11th yearly benefit for the Council for the Arts in Westchester to be held Saturday night at the Market Hotel in Tarrytown.

title: Maine Power Line Faces Opposition
description: Kathy and John Sutton moved to this little town in mountainous western Maine more than 15 years ago to begin the slow process of restoring a 100-year-old farmhouse.

title:
MUSIC;
School for All Ages and Abilities
description: LEAD: ONLY three and a half years ago, the Suburban Community Music Center was little more than an idea. Founded by Judith G. Wharton, now its executive director, the center opened its doors to 56 students in January 1986 and now serves more than 300 students of all ages.

title: Plane for Bhutan Opens Many Lost Horizons
description: The tiny and remote landlocked Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan took a major new step toward improving its communications with the outside world recently when it bought its first passenger jet.

title: Brookhaven Lab Isn't Brown Tide Culprit
description: The article ''Peconic Bay Cleanup Gains'' [ Nov. 6 ] appropriately noted that researchers do not yet fully understand the causes of the ''brown tide'' algae blooms that have affected the Peconic Bay since 1985. I take exception, however, to the statement that ''Others suggest that wastes once dumped by the Brookhaven National Laboratory into the Peconic River, which empties into the bay, could be the culprit.''

title: The Joffrey Lives Up To Its Past
description: A memorial program for Robert Joffrey will be held on Tuesday afternoon at 2 at the City Center, where the Joffrey Ballet is currently appearing through next Sunday. But the most profound tribute to the company's artistic director and founder, who died on March 25, will remain the spirited and high level on which his dancers performed throughout the season.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Norweb Sale Reaches More Than $20 Million
description: LEAD: A rare 19th-century gold piece was hammered down for $600,000 at the third and final segment of the Norweb Sale held on Nov. 15 in New York City. With the 10-percent buyer's fee, its total cost came to $660,000, the fourth-highest price paid at auction for a single coin.

title: Stamford: The City Seeking a Good Word
description: FEW states have had as many nicknames attached to their cities as Connecticut. Some, like the Insurance City for Hartford and the Hardware City for New Britain, are still appropriate. Others, like the Elm City for New Haven, are tenuous; Dutch elm disease may soon cause the elm trees in the city to be outnumbered by the maples.

title: 'Nixon in China': The Single
description: What does John Adams have in common with Verdi, Puccini, Bellini and dozens of other opera composers of the past? Critics of the modern Minimalist composer will probably snort, ''Nothing!'' Admirers may point to melodic invention or character delineation or dramatic substance.

title: PRETORIA RELEASES 2 OLD NATIONALISTS
description: The South African Government today freed two longtime black nationalists, both in ill health, on humanitarian grounds.

title: GANNETT STRESSING MINORITY GROUPS
description: Newspapers owned by the Gannett Company, the nation's largest newspaper chain, are increasingly adhering to a policy of making members of minority groups more visible in their news columns, Gannett executives say.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Steroid Use By Athletes Be Allowed?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: For Business, the Thrills and Chills of Life With Debt
description: WHETHER it is to fend off a raider or to take a company private, corporate America is piling on debt. From Montgomery Ward to Union Carbide and Burlington Industries, companies are recasting their balance sheets, sometimes with borrowings as high as 99 percent of assets. And the pace has quickened since last year's stock market crash.

title: DATA BANK: November 27, 1988
PROPOSALS FOR PEACE
description: Thomas L. Friedman's article ''Proposals for Peace'' (Oct. 30) might be titled more accurately ''How to Get Rid of the Palestinians Without Appearing to Expel Them and to Come Out Smelling Like a Rose.'' Both of his proposals would have the Israelis withdraw from those sections of Gaza and the West Bank they don't want and to pretend that this provides Palestinians with a chance ''to try to build a little dignity in a national home.'' In South Africa, this device would be called a Bantustan. Mr. Friedman calls it ''a diplomatic solution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.''

title: THE WORLD: Military Moves; India Is All Over, and South Asia Resents It
description: IN December, when Pakistan plays host to a summit meeting of South Asian nations, the leaders will discuss a longstanding concern:

title: The Man Behind the Scenes at PATH
description: LEAD: FOR a man responsible for getting about 70,000 New Jerseyans to work in Manhattan in the rush hour every morning - and seeing to it that the 18.2 million trips they make every year are safe, on schedule and reasonably comfortable - Edward N. Rehm appears surprisingly calm.

title: Japan's Consumers: Oppressed Class
description: For weeks, my family begged my parents in America for an early Christmas present: fleece-lined slippers to save us from chilblains. We can't wear our shoes indoors, the floors are cold and the Japanese-made cloth slippers available locally are, to be polite about it, nothing special in quality or price.

title: Canoe and Hike Guide Becomes Best Seller
description: A LITTLE book that deals with such features of eastern Connecticut as the Little River and a big boulder has become a hit.

title:
THE TALK OF ELMSFORD;
Village Says It Needs HelpIf It Is to Help the Homeless
description: LEAD: THERE is a sign on the side of a bus shelter along Saw Mill River Road, not far from the heart of this community of 3,200 people, that reads ''We want to help you to a better way of life.''

title: Addicted to Debt?
description: To the Editor:

title: LOST AMONG THE GIRLS
description: In ''Lost Among the Girls'' (About Men, Oct. 30), Rand Richards Cooper nicely describes his life in a girls' school - the combination of minority status and the special treatment of token pet. I was hoping that from this experience he would draw insights about the day-to-day struggles that women, blacks, Native Americans, Latinos and Asians face in this country. Instead, he drew back into safe, white male superiority and privilege. He wanted the young boy, to whom he pointed out the old sign, to ''be a man and feel the shame'' of being in a girls' school. He didn't even report that the shame was mixed with a pride of accomplishment - of having survived a trial, of having worked for acceptance under adverse circumstances. PATRICIA T. GLOWA, M.D. Woodsville, N.H.

title: A Queens Firefighter Dies Fighting L.I. Fire
description: A Queens firefighter died yesterday after a ceiling collapsed on him as he was battling a fire in Port Washington, L.I., where he was a volunteer firefighter.

title: Deborah Rogers and Howard Segal Are Married
description: Deborah Dee Rogers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Rogers of Wayne, N.J., and Howard Paul Segal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander D. Segal of Philadelphia, were married last evening at Shomrei Torah Synagogue in Wayne by Rabbi Richard Eisenberg.

title: Not Afraid of Sounding Major
description: TO URANIA By Joseph Brodsky. 174 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Focus: Knoxville, Tenn. Braking the Mobile-Home Industry Skid
If You Thought That Was Funny, Wait Until You . . .
description: MOVE over, Tom Hanks and Sally Field. Forget ''Punchline.'' As one who did it a few years ago, let me give a blow-by-blow description of how one becomes a real-life stand-up comedian:

title: That Insecure Feeling About Airports
description: JUST when I thought it was safe to go back on an airplane, I was proved wrong. Just when I started to feel secure that stateside security had been tightened, I learned otherwise.

title: Voodoo Economics?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Godot' and Other Trash
description: LEAD: The current wee brouhaha over Samuel Beckett, occasioned by the appearance of Steve Martin and Robin Williams in ''Waiting for Godot'' at Lincoln Center, has not touched upon the only important point: the cause, and effect, of a pleasantly lugubrious, collegiate skit writer like Mr. Beckett being taken seriously in the first place.

title: Fulbright Scholar at Purchase
description: LEAD: THE first senior Fulbright Scholar at the State University of New York campus here is 30-year-old Alvaro Zinno, a Uruguayan engineer and photographer. He is spending three months on the campus, working in the photography studios and auditing classes with two faculty members, Jan Groover and Jed Devine.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ARE YOU LISTENING RABBI LOW. By J. P. Donleavy. (Atlantic Monthly Press, $18.95.) Siggy (Isadorable) Schultz has written a play: ''Kiss It, Don't Hold It, It's Too Hot.'' It's a monster hit. So the American-born Schultz struts and frets around London's West End, enjoying his impresario status and waiting for the show to open on Broadway.

title: John E. Reardon Is Dead at 45; Ex-Mayor of Kansas City, Kan.
description: Former Mayor John E. (Jack) Reardon, who underwent a heart transplant nearly two years ago, died of heart failure Friday night. He was 45 years old.

title: THE GUIDE
description: ON SEX BIAS AT WORK

title: No More Nasty Surprises In Hair-Dos and Makeup
description: THE Glemby hair salon, located in bustling Macy's of Manhattan, has been turning heads of late with its new ''computerized mirror.'' Customers in the salon see their own faces on a television screen, and watch as a hairstylist superimposes any of several hundred hair styles; the stylist fine-tunes the look by touching the screen with an electronic ''light pen.''

title: TEMPTING DESSERTS, WITH APPLES AND PEARS
description: AT this time of year, apples and pears are practically being given away. In most country stores, you can buy bags of the fruit at very low prices. Apples store well, but after a few months, no matter how carefully controlled the environment, they will have lost much of their flavor and become mealy. Pears, too, are best eaten now - even if they have been picked too early, as is usually the case. They should be allowed to ripen at room temperature or be cooked.

title: Lenape Expert Assails Phone Flier
description: DR. HERBERT C. KRAFT, an expert on the Lenape Indians, said last week that a flier published about the Indians and Thanksgiving by New Jersey Bell was ''bunk'' and a misrepresentation of the state's Indian heritage.

title: Two Performances In the Baroque Style
description: THROUGH one of those unfortunate but all-too-frequent scheduling conflicts, two world-renowned specialists in Baroque performance styles (although, as it happens, both are equally fine players of contemporary music) are to be soloists on Saturday night. So a choice will have to be made between the harpsichordist-organist Anthony Newman, appearing with the Westchester Symphony at 8 P.M., and the Danish recorder virtuoso Michala Petri, who joins the Philharmonic Symphony of Westchester at 8:30 P.M.

title: Which War?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Guide for the Perplexed In the World of Ski Racks
description: THE good part about skiing is certainly not getting skis to the slopes. When you're driving, skis go either in the car (inconvenient and possibly dangerous) or on the car (inconvenient and time-consuming). When you're flying or taking a bus or train, skis need to be packaged and carried - also inconvenient and cumbersome.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The radiators in our house are painted silver and most are pitted with rust, especially in the bathrooms. How can we remove this paint, and can we then repaint them white?

title: As Congress Opens, Algerians Cry Out for Change
description: President Chadli Benjedid meets the biggest challenge of his career Sunday at a congress of Algeria's single party, where he will try to break the 26-year monopoly by Algeria's National Liberation Front.

title: SURVIVAL ODDS
description: In July 1987, I gave birth to a 610-gram (1 pound, 5 ounce) baby boy. I was just 26 weeks pregnant. The baby was given a 25 percent chance to survive. My husband and I were thrown into a world of high-tech machines, lights, noise and scientific terms that terrified us. Our baby was on a respirator because he had respiratory distress syndrome. He was having brain bleeds. We were told these could cause severe neurological damage. His head had to be shaved for IV lines, because the largest veins were found in his scalp. My baby was black and blue from head to toe. I felt guilt, fear, frustration and rage.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The radiators in our house are painted silver and most are pitted with rust, especially in the bathrooms. How can we remove this paint, and can we then repaint them white?

title: Strike Closes Louvre
description: The Louvre has been closed since Monday because of a strike by guards who are protesting a plan to change the hours that the museum is open to the public, officials said on Thursday. The museum administration is proposing a schedule of 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., instead of the current one of 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Dr. Bryann Bromley Becomes Bride Of Dr. James Nuzzo in Massachusetts
description: Dr. Bryann Bromley and Dr. James L. J. Nuzzo were married last evening at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., by the Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Unitarian minister.

title: Model's Success Is in Her Hands
description: REGARDLESS of the temperature, Pat Tilley wears white gloves when she is outdoors. She hides her hands beneath a jacket when gloves are not in season to avoid answering questions about the odd attire. If people only knew.

title: Camille S. Cooper Weds Dr. Kenneth L. Rossner
description: Camille Sutro Cooper, a daughter of the late Lotte Weil Cooper and the late Dr. David Paul Cooper of East Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Leslie Rossner, a son of Esther Palumbo of Watertown, Mass., and the late Edward Rossner. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's cousins Mr. and Mrs. Michael Hirschberg in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: Knicks Win Battle of Rising Teams
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, one of the youngest, deepest and best teams in the National Basketball Association, entered yesterday afternoon's game having limited their opposition to 97.2 points a game, the best defensive mark in the league. They had allowed only two teams to score more than 100 points and had not permitted an opponent to shoot better than 50 percent from field, But the young, running, pressing Knicks have been building a reputation of their own.

title: DATA UPDATE: November 27, 1988
description: *4*INDEXES OF HOUSING COSTS/N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area* % change from % change from Oct. Sep. Oct. 87 Rents 144.7 0.7 8.1 Homeowner's costs 148.2 0.6 7.5 Fuel and utilities 92.0 -3.2 -0.9 *4**Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, *4*Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, *4*Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. Indexes: 1982-84-100 *3*(Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics) MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.64 10.53 10.89 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.25 8.20 8.04 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 10.43 10.33 10.74 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.14 8.11 8.01 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.56 10.47 10.93 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.55 8.50 8.07 Co-ops (N.Y.) Conventional (30-yr) 11.22 10.96 10.73 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.45 8.43 7.95 Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 8.55 8.35 7.01 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.11 9.11 8.86 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title: THE WORLD'S RICHEST MUSEUM
description: With the acquisition of the Ludwig Collection of medieval and Renaissance illuminated manuscripts, and subsequent dramatic additions, the Getty Museum has acquired, in less than a decade, a collection that can be ranked among the most important of such material in this country. Painting in the hand-produced book was the premier graphic medium of the Middle Ages. The entry of the Getty Museum into the field of the illuminated manuscript has helped bring this neglected medium of art out of the closet. ROGER S. WIECK Associate Curator Manuscripts and Rare Books The Walters Art Gallery Baltimore

title: Prophecies of a Greedy Observer
description: CHEKHOV A Spirit Set Free. By V. S. Pritchett. 235 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Fancy Stickwork
description: As a teen-ager he has played hockey with Wayne Gretzky, so when the Great One came to Detroit for a game against the Red Wings last week, Dr. Murray Howe, the son of the hockey legend, Gordie Howe, decided to make a belated delivery of a wedding present, a stick once used by his dad in the playoffs.

title:
GARDENING;
Taking Care to Satisfy That Urge to Prune
description: LEAD: THE autumnal rise in interest in pruning results perhaps from a desire for outdoor activity when other chores have diminished. Indeed, some pruning now is a good idea, but some is best left until spring..

title: Horse Racing; High Brite Regains Winning Form
description: High Brite, a star of the summer who had been tailing off throughout the fall, regained his best form yesterday to win the $85,800 Sport Page Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: A Challenge For Golfers
description: The only way to get there is by boat, twice daily. The course has only 12 holes. And the near-freezing weather is so unpredictable that golfers are given 10 days to finish the three-round tournament. Sound like a golfer's nightmare? Not so, said organizers of a unique amateur tournament being staged this week at Blackwaterfoot on the Isle of Arran, off the west coast of Scotland.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Holyoke, Mass.;
Downtown Revitalization
description: LEAD: A COMMERCIAL building long considered a key to the revitalization of this industrial city's downtown, but unused for five years, has been bought by a developer for renovation.

title: Rangers' Granato at Center Stage
description: Tony Granato's finest game of the season, when he scored four goals against the Penguins last month, was overshadowed by the small riot that marred the third period of a 9-2 victory at the Garden. His most courageous performance of the season, a determined effort against the Penguins last Wednesday, was also lost, this time against the overall timidity and futility of his teammates, who went down in an 8-2 thumping at Pittsburgh.

title: When Three Generations Go on Location
description: In David Cronenberg's psychological thriller ''Dead Ringers,'' Jeremy Irons has the difficult task of playing identical twin brothers. But in ''Danny the Champion of the World,'' currently being filmed in the Oxfordshire countryside about 10 miles from here, Mr. Irons has a far tougher assignment: He appears not only with his 9-year-old son, Sam, but also with his 78-year-old father-in-law, Cyril Cusack (no mean film-stealer), and 200 pheasants.

title: Why the RJR Nabisco Deal Means So Much to Wall Street
description: AS the bidding battle for RJR Nabisco Inc. was heating up last week, an investment banker involved in the competition ran through an awesome series of aggravations and risks he was facing. In the end, he mentioned, the deal might well prove barely profitable for his firm.

title:
DINING OUT;
Tastes of Spain, Portugal in Ossining
description: LEAD: At last this pretty restaurant (the old Cafe Keenan) is in use once more; Cafe Algarve has recently reopened the doors, and diners will find the new kitchen offering Spanish and Portugese cuisine. Old-timers will remember the dining room's mirrored walls, sublte color scheme and glowing sconces, all still in evidence, a fitting backdrop for the lght inventive French-American dishes that were once served here.

title: James Flaherty Weds Lisa Cond'e Fondeur
description: The wedding of Lisa Conde Fondeur, the daughter of Barbara A. Fondeur of West Orange, N.J., and Ralph H. Fondeur of Montclair, N.J., to James Gerard Flaherty, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Edward J. Flaherty of Upper Montclair, N.J., took place yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Montclair. The Rev. Cormac Kinkead, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert F. Grady.

title: Thrift Shops Are Finding a Broader Appeal
description: LEAD: THE sale of used clothing is becoming a booming business in New Jersey, and in the process thrift shops are removing the stigma against secondhand wear, giving it an acceptable and even trendy new public image.

title: Gail Ann Collins Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman R. Collins of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Gail Ann Collins to Victor S. Khosla, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ranpat Rai Khosla of New Delhi. The couple plan to marry in February.

title: THE REGION: Pro & Con  Should Merchants Be Put on New York's Rent-Control Track?; The $1,600 Problem for a Dentist in Jackson Heights
description: FIVE years ago, Dr. Arthur W. Stulbaum, a dentist, was paying slightly less than $500 a month to rent his office on the ground floor of an apartment building in Jackson Heights, Queens. His rent today has reached $1,600 a month.

title: A 3-Year-Old Heiress
description: With the death last weekend of 37-year-old Christina Onassis, her 3-year-old daughter and only child, Athena Onassis, stands to become one of the world's richest people. Athena was the child of Ms. Onassis and her fourth husband, Thierry Roussel, a French pharmaceuticals magnate and a multimillionaire. They were married in 1984. Athena was born in January 1985 and the couple began divorce proceedings eight months later. Friends said that Mr. Roussel will now have custody of the child.

title: Marian P. Welch, 88; Editor for Birch Society
description: Marian P. Welch, the editor of two publications for the John Birch Society, which was founded by her late husband, died Tuesday at Glover Memorial Hospital. She was 88 years old.

title: Prospect Heights Beginning Climb To Gentrification
description: EACH weekend they appear, climbing out of the IRT station at Grand Army Plaza and looking around at the unfamiliar trees and landmarks of Brooklyn until they zero in on Eastern Parkway. Then off they pad on expensive running shoes to test the air and the low real estate prices of Prospect Heights, the city's latest emerging middle-class neighborhood.

title:
ART;
A Potent Look Back at 1968: A Visual Memory of Social Change
description: LEAD: ''The Turning Point: Art and Politics in 1968'' at the Lehman College Art Gallery in the Bronx is one of the most potent exhibitons mounted in the New York City area in a long time. Everyone has his memories of that year; Irwin Unger, professor of history at New York University, begins his historical contribution to the exhibiton catalogue by paraphrasing Charles Dickens.

title: Favorites Lag Behind For Major Bridge Title
description: One major title remained to be decided when the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals continued here today. None of the favorites were among the leaders in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship, which will help determine the 1989 United States World Championship team, but two New York teams were in contention.

title: Ex-School Official to Appeal
description: The former superintendent of Bennington-area schools, George Sleeman, will appeal his embezzlement conviction to the state's highest court, his attorney said. Mr. Sleeman was convicted Oct. 8 of eight counts of embezzlement and one of false swearing. Prosecutors alleged he had embezzled $8,425 in school funds under the guise of rental income for property he owned that housed school offices. On Monday Judge Francis McCaffrey denied Mr. Sleeman's motion for acquittal or a new trial. Mr. Sleeman faces sentencing in January.

title: Reviews/Music; Ashley Putnam Sings Title Role in 'Rusalka'
description: Antonin Dvorak's Western fame rests securely on his instrumental music, but ''Rusalka,'' the ninth of his 10 operas, is revived with some regularity, and with good reason. It is a rich, atmospheric high-Romantic score. Dramatic tautness it lacks, but in its best moments the music surges forward to embody the characters' emotions in the way that is the heart of opera as drama.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 27, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.50.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 2 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 3 4 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Pocket, $4.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 4 5 GLITTERING IMAGES, by Susan Howatch. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Sex, love, self-analysis and forgiveness in English clerical circles. 5 8 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Dell, $5.95.) Two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 6 10 THE DARK TOWER: The Gunslinger, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $10.95.) Volume One of a series about a young man's pursuit of an evil force. 7 7 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Plume/NAL, $8.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 8 * 8 HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER, by Marilyn French. (Ballantine, $5.95.) A chronicle of four generations of women. 9 5 FAVORITE SON, by Steve Sohmer. (Bantam, $4.95.) The phantasmagoria that follows a televised attempted assassination of a senator. 10 8 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Avon, $4.95.) The effect of a violent death on an eccentric North Carolina clan. 11 * 3 SEARCH THE SHADOWS, by Barbara Michaels. (Berkley, $4.50.) A young woman's quest for the truth about her parentage threatens her life. 12 3 RITE OF SPRING, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $4.95.) Father Blackie Ryan tries to save a cousin who is suspected of murder. 13 2 A MAN RIDES THROUGH, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The concluding volume in the fantasy ''Mordant's Need.'' 14 10 MURDER IN THE CIA, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A C.I.A. operative investigates the suspicious death of a literary agent. 15 19 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 5 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Penguin, $6.95.) A self-styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 2 27 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The importance of a patient's mind and emotions. 3 266 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 4 * 1 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 5 24 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) How mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 21 SMALL SACRIFICES, by Ann Rule. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Murder and incest in an Oregon town. 7 29 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Touchstone/S&S, $7.95.) A critique of American liberal arts education. 8 15 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race seen through mythology. 9 17 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 10 9 I'M WITH THE BAND, by Pamela Des Barres. (Jove, $3.95.) The ''confessions of a groupie.'' 11 * 18 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Vintage, $6.95.) A discussion of what ''every American needs to know.'' Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 5 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 3, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $10.95.) A selection of cartoons from three previously published collections. 2 9 THE ESSENTIAL CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 3 26 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 11 TALES TOO TICKLISH TO TELL, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) ''Bloom County'' cartoons. 5 66 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: SETTING IT UP
description: Table settings are simply environments in miniature. Pulled together with the same precision as furnishing an entire house, they require a careful balance of just the right elements. And like all areas of home design, they are a reflection of the eye and taste of the creator. On the following pages, an antiques dealer, a decorator and an architect have readied their dining tables for the holidays. Suitably, each approached the task with his or her own panache. The antiques dealer used rare 18th-century objects as ornaments both on the table and around the room. The decorator mixed her own collection of antique tabletop accessories with a traditional array of garlands and topiary made from the greenery in her own backyard. And the architect chose a selection of china and glasses of his own design that are not so very different from the buildings and philosophies that have long been his signature. In each case, the result is not only personal but a feast for the eye.

title: Learning Disabled Learn of Colleges
description: LEAD: HIGH-school students with learning disabilities and their parents said they felt wiser about how to select a college and more hopeful of the chances for success as a result of a regional conference sponsored by school guidance counselors from southern Westchester.

title: Philadelphia Ash Gone After 2-Year Odyssey
description: A ship finally unloaded its toxic ash from Philadelphia after wandering the world's seas for more than two years in search of a place to dump its unwanted cargo, a port official here said today.

title: They Began With the Spirit of Jazz
description: Hoagy Carmichael and Bing Crosby have always existed on the fringes of jazz history, their fame enduring through popular song and Hollywood movies rather than a tradition of rhythmic experiment and improvisation. Both began their careers, however, infused with the pulse of ragtime and the ensemble spirit of jazz in the 1920's. They absorbed the innovations of Louis Armstrong and Fats Waller - a relaxed and unsolemn attitude toward the melody; and from their tenure in the late 20's with the Paul Whiteman Orchestra, they learned the commercial value of ''crossing over'' to different audiences.

title: Courtside Analysis
description: LOVE and marriage, we are told lyrically, go together like a horse and carriage. But there are other well-matched pairs that are less obvious. Recreationally speaking, bridge and tennis go together extremely well: Many bridge stars play tennis enthusiastically for exercise, and many tennis stars, including Martina Navratilova, play bridge happily when they are not needed on court.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Floyd's $75,000 Putt: Ray Floyd, making his first appearance in the four-man, two-day, 18-hole Skins Game, made a putt worth $75,000, won five skins and then added $15,000 with his fourth birdie of the day on the sixth hole in La Quinta, Calif., yesterday. Jack Nicklaus, showing no evidence of the back troubles that bothered him most of the season, birdied the last two holes and won $75,000 at the halfway point of the made-for-television event. Nicklaus said his back did not bother him. ''My back was terrific,'' he said. ''If you'd asked me two weeks ago if I'd be playing, I'd have said 'no change.' '' Lee Trevino and Curtis Strange were shut out. Another nine holes, with a total of $285,000 up for grabs, will be played today at the PGA West course.(AP) Calcavecchia Ahead by 5 Shots: Mark Calcavecchia of the United States shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday for a five-shot lead after the third round of the $295,000 Australian Open tournament in Sydney. Calcavecchia was 16 under par with a 200 total over the par-72, 6,807-yard Royal Sydney layout. The Australian PGA champion, Wayne Grady, the second-round leader, had a third round of 72 to stand second at 205.(AP) Tennis Top-Seeded Pair Gains: The top-seeded pair of Robin White of the United States and Gigi Fernandez of Puerto Rico and the American pair of Katrina Adams and Zina Garrison won their semifinal matches yesterday in the Virginia Slims world doubles championship in Tokyo. Fernandez and White beat Patty Fendick of the United States and Jill Hetherington of Canada, 7-5, 7-5, and the Adams-Garrison team defeated Eva Pfaff of West Germany and Elizabeth Smylie of Australia, 2-6, 6-0, 6-1. (AP) Hlasek and Leconte in Final: Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, one victory from his third consecutive Nabisco Grand Prix title, and top-seeded Henri Leconte of France reached the final of the $490,000 Belgian Indoor Championship yesterday in Brussels. Hlasek led Patrick Kuhnen, 7-6, 3-0, when the West German retired because of stomach flu. Leconte overcame fourth-seeded John Fizgerald of Australia, 6-4, 2-6, 6-2.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 8, Blackhawks 2: Ray Bourque scored his 200th National Hockey League goal 26 seconds after the opening face-off and the rookie Greg Hawgood followed with his first last night, sparking Boston to a victory over visiting Chicago. The Bruins unloaded a 53-shot barrage in handing the Blackhawks their fifth consecutive loss. Also scoring for Boston were Bob Joyce and Ken Linseman, with two goals apiece, and Randy Burridge, who scored on a power play. Dave Manson scored both of Chicago's goals.(AP) Whalers 4, Nordiques 2: Ray Ferraro scored three power-play goals and Peter Sidorkiewicz blocked 37 shots to lead Hartford to a triumph in Quebec. The Whalers defeated Quebec for the second time in four days and moved ahead of the Nordiques into sole possession of fourth place in the Adams Division. Dean Evason also scored for Hartford. Scoring for the Nordiques were Michel Goulet and Jeff Brown.(AP) Penguins 4, Flyers 3: Phil Bourque and Kevin Stevens scored third-period goals and Frank Pietrangelo made 41 saves as Pittsburgh gave visiting Philadelphia its eighth loss in 10 games. Also scoring fo the Penguins were Randy Cunneyworth and Dan Quinn. Scoring for the Flyers were Terry Carkner, Rick Tocchet and Scott Mellanby.(AP) Weight Lifting Two World Records Set: Leonid Taranenko of the Soviet Union set two world records yesterday in the super-heavyweight division in Canberra, Australia. Taranenko, competing in the Bicentennial championships at the Australian Institute of Sport, set a total lift mark of 1,045 pounds that also included a mark of 585 1/4 in the clean-and-jerk section, a quarter of an inch better than his previous record. The previous total lift record of 1,038 1/2 pounds was set by his compatriot and an Olympic gold medalist in Seoul, South Korea, Aleksandr Kurlovitch, last year at the world championships in Czechoslovakia.(AP) Boxing Zaragoza Retains Title: Daniel Zaragoza of Mexico stopped Valerio Nati of Italy at 1 minute 6 seconds of the fifth round and retained his World Boxing Council super-bantamweight title last night in Forli, Italy. A left hook to the jaw by the 30-year-old champion ended the fight. The victory improved Zaragoza's record to 37 victories - 19 by knockout - 1 draw and 4 losses. Nati, a former Euopean super-bantamweight champion, saw his record drop to 43 victories, 3 draws and 4 losses.(AP) Skiing French Woman Wins Super-G: Carole Merle of France won the season-opening World Cup Super-G race yesterday in Schladming, Austria, after starting from the 25th starting position. She swept down the 1,961-yard Planai course, which drops 1,551 feet, in 1 minute 25.36 seconds. Ulrike Maier of Austria was second in 1:26.01. The track had 41 gates.(AP)

title: Delayed Perfection
description: After rolling 279 five times or so, Mike Wolfe was beginning to think he'd grow old trying to bowl a perfect 300 game. Actually he did age a bit in his pursuit of bowling perfection. He didn't roll a perfect game until a match a week or so ago in his hometown of Clarkson, Ind. By then Wolfe was already a month past his 12th birthday, too old by three months to be the youngest bowler to accomplish the feat. Acording to the American Bowling Congress, Wolfe is the second youngest to bowl 300, after John Jaszkoski, who was 11 years old when he did it in 1982.(AP)

title: Why Remodeling Stocks Won't Shine
description: ALTHOUGH housing construction increased by 7.2 percent in October, the biggest month-to-month jump since February, many analysts note that building this year is still running almost 10 percent behind 1987 levels and predict a further deterioration in 1989. Since this scenario suggests that people will stay in their current houses and renovate them instead of moving, some investors might assume it should be a boon to companies that produce materials and tools for the home remodeling market.

title: Rise Seen in Haitians Flying Illegally to U.S.
description: In the uncertain aftermath of a coup here in mid-September, scores of Haitians have been using fake travel documents to board airliners bound for the United States, American officials say.

title: In Computers, as in Nature, Variety Is Desirable; Invasion of Property
description: To the Editor:

title: American Chess Captain Weds a Soviet Champion
description: The captain of the American Olympic chess team secretly married a Soviet woman ranked second among the world's woman chess players and left with her for the United States today.

title: From 'Migrant' to State House in Massachusetts
description: In his youth, Nelson Merced says, he was like many Puerto Ricans, ''a back and forth migrant'' between the Northeast and the Caribbean. Two weeks ago Mr. Merced became the first Hispanic person elected to statewide office in Massachusetts.

title:
WINE;
Help With Choices For Holiday Season
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of the many flavors offered simultaneously on holiday dinner plates, selecting an appropriate wine to accompany the food can become quite a chore. In addition, the large number of guests usually attending these repasts precludes, for most of us, serving wine priced at more than $25 a bottle.

title: Acquitted Again
description: Last March, in a verdict that surprised even his defense lawyers, Larry Davis was acquitted by a jury in the Bronx of the murder of four suspected drug dealers. Last weekend, another jury in the Bronx acquitted Mr. Davis, 22 years old, of trying to kill nine police officers during a shootout at his sister's apartment in 1986.

title: Giants '88: Woulda, Coulda, Shoulda
description: We Giant fans may be crazy, but we do know the difference between Murder One and a bad bounce. When 10 years ago last week all we had to do to beat the Eagles was sit on the ball, and the coaches sent in a handoff and Joe Pisarcik didn't lay it in right for Csonka and so Herman Edwards ran in for Philly - that was Murder One. When Lawrence Taylor last Sunday heroically blocked a field-goal attempt in overtime and an Eagle picked it up and ran it in against us - that was a bad bounce. Elementary? Not if you read the papers or watched the television the next day. It was The Kick and The Fumble, as in same old story, same old Giants.

title: Israeli Right Urges Left to Resume Talks
description: Right-wing Likud leaders are publicly urging the rival Labor Party to resume talks over a broad-based coalition government, just days after Labor declared the talks futile.

title: For Parents, the Road to College Is Long and Bumpy
description: I HAVE had to shelve the book I was writing. It was a parental ''how-to'' book - ''How to Help Your Child Apply to College.''

title: Q and A
description: Hong Kong

title: Thai Aides Expect Deaths From Floods To Approach 1,000
description: As rescue work continues and flood waters recede in southern Thailand, Thai officials said today that the number of dead was likely to approach 1,000.

title: Now Is Not the Time To Put Women on Hold
description: HAS the women's movement been put on the back burner? Rumor has it that it has run out of steam and women are stampeding back into the kitchen. Others say that since foot-binding, went out, women's lives have never been so good. Let's have a look; maybe we've been here before.

title: Wrong Question
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Truisms
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Gottuvadyam Concert By Ravikiran of India
description: The World Music Institute offered its devoted followers a bit of exotica outside its usual exotic norm Friday night at Washington Square Church. The organization is used to presenting Indian and other forms of non-Western music; nothing new there. But on Friday the featured performer was Ravikiran, a young virtuoso of the gottuvadyam, which not too many Indian-music devotees in this country can claim to have heard live.

title: THE WORLD'S RICHEST MUSEUM
description: It is really ironic (''The World's Richest Museum,'' by Michael Kimmelman, Oct. 23). The J. Paul Getty Museum, which contains precious, irreplaceable art, is built on the Pacific Palisades, the area in California most vulnerable to landslides and earthquakes.

title: Baritone Thrives on Soprano Sax but Covets Singing at Met
description: LIKE many singers who aspire to the Metropolitan Opera, Ben Cutler practices his scales every day, his clear, deep baritone a familiar sound to his neighbors on Wallace Avenue here.

title: Hilary J. Frankel Engaged To Carl Loeb Kempner Jr.
description: The engagement of Hilary Joy Frankel to Carl Loeb Kempner Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kempner of White Plains, has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Frankel of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. The couple plan to marry in March.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A POLITICAL EDUCATION: A Washington Memoir, by Harry McPherson. (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95.) In 1956 Harry McPherson, a liberal young lawyer from Texas, packed his Buick and drove to Washington for a sobering stint as an aide to Senator Lyndon Baines Johnson. When this insider's guide to politics was published in 1972, The Times's Anatole Broyard said it was ''fascinating to read'' and called the author ''refreshingly candid in both his praises and his criticisms.'' THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Bantam, $5.95.) For Sherman McCoy, an investment banker with a palatial apartment on Park Avenue, it was frightening enough when he accidentally took the wrong exit off the expressway, descending into the netherworld of the South Bronx. Little did he know that from that moment on his carefully ordered life was fated to be torn asunder. For years, Tom Wolfe, the doyen of New Journalism, had threatened to strike a blow against post-modern fiction with a Fieldingesque novel of social realism. The result is ''a big, bitter, funny, craftily plotted book that grabs you by the lapels and won't let go,'' Frank Conroy said here last year. ''Fast as it is - like falling downstairs, sometimes - the pace is superb, and the action, twists of plot, comic setups and jumps from track to track always occur at just the right times.'' DOLLARS AND DREAMS: The Changing American Income Distribution, by Frank Levy. (Norton, $7.95.) As the gap between rich and poor keeps growing and the middle class shrinks, fewer and fewer people are able to buy their way into the American dream, the economist Frank Levy argues. Earlier this year, Robert Lekachman said in The Book Review that this book is ''admirably lucid and mercifully concise.'' INTO LOVE AND OUT AGAIN, by Elinor Lipman. (Washington Square/Pocket, $6.95.) When Tim and Hannah fall in love at the Registry of Motor Vehicles they embark on a romance that lasts throughout seven of these 16 short stories. Writing here in 1987, Sara Vogan praised this book for moments that are ''very funny, even poignant.'' SHEER FICTION, by Paul West. (McPherson & Company, $10.) The author of ''Rat Man of Paris'' condemns America's flat, minimalist ''tofu fiction'' about ''little people with mortgages'' as ''a way for the ungifted to have a literary career.'' Last year our reviewer, David Sacks, said the ''verbal fireworks'' in these essays are ''sheer joy.'' A FAN'S NOTES, by Frederick Exley. (Vintage, $7.95.) To coincide with the publication of ''Last Notes From Home,'' the conclusion of Frederick Exley's fictional memoirs, Vintage has printed a new edition of his first novel, which many critics consider the best of the trilogy. This story about a heavy-drinking, half-mad writer who yearns to be as great as his idol, the football star Frank Gifford, was praised for the ''exuberance'' of its style by John P. Sisk in The Book Review in 1968. The same publisher has also reissued the middle volume, PAGES FROM A COLD ISLAND ($6.95), in which the narrator (obsessed this time with the literary lion Edmund Wilson) is confronted with the problem of sudden fame. THE GOLDEN ORIOLE, by Raleigh Trevelyan. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Born to a family of Britons who served under the British Raj, Raleigh Trevelyan returned to India to trace his ancestors' past. This ''may well be one of the last in the long line of Anglo-Indian memoirs, and by a happy chance it is certainly one of the best,'' Jan Morris said in The Book Review last year. L'ABBE C, by Georges Bataille. Translated by Philip A. Facey. (Marion Boyars/Kampmann, $9.95.) In the days of the French Resistance, twin brothers - one a priest, one a sexual libertine - become engaged in an obsessive triangle with a prostitute. In Georges Bataille's novel, first published in France in 1950, ''the style is crisp, and this translation is quite remarkable,'' Marianne Veron said here in 1984. THE RACE TO FASHODA: European Colonialism and African Resistance in the Scramble for Africa, by David Levering Lewis. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $11.95.) In the late 19th century, Britain, France, Italy and Belgium competed for dominance in the Nile Valley, a final stage in the colonization of Africa. This history of that period is ''elegantly written and thoroughly researched,'' William Boyd said here earlier this year. THEIR PRIDE AND JOY, by Paul Buttenwieser. (Laurel/Dell, $8.95.) Born to a philanthropic family of overachievers, the Gutheim siblings have lofty goals: one brother anticipates a Supreme Court clerkship, the other a performance at Carnegie Hall. Then sister Joan comes home from Bennington with what is now known as anorexia nervosa. Last year our reviewer, Joel Conarroe, said this novel set in New York in 1960 ''makes some telling points about the timeless dynamics of family relationships.'' AN URCHIN IN THE STORM: Essays About Books and Ideas, by Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $7.95.) In a collection of book reviews, the paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould explains how one can reject strict Cartesian reductionism while remaining firmly on the side of the rationalists. For people ''serious about writing or thinking,'' this is ''nearly a perfect study in method,'' Caroline Rand Herron said here last year.

title: What the People Say
description: Should abortion be legal as it is now, or legal only in such cases as rape, incest, or to save the life of the mother, or should it not be permitted at all?

title: Confronting the Past Without Looting It
description: BRONSTEIN'S CHILDREN By Jurek Becker. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 264 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Under the New Law, Illegal Aliens Suffer Much in Silence
description: IN New York City, a half-million illegal aliens form what amounts to a new sub-class of the poor, more vulnerable than ever to sweatshop operators, eviction and criminals.

title: The Business of Young Talent
description: SOME children are willing to trade in their toy robots and Barbie dolls for a resume and an 8-by-10 black-and-white glossy. They give up afternoons playing with friends in exchange for days in New York City auditioning for television commercials or movies.

title: The Roles Historians Play
description: In Westchester we are fortunate to have a number of historians, in both the private and public sector, who work very hard to promote and preserve Westchester County's great history.

title: Down and Out in London
description: OLIVER TWIST Starring Alec Guinness, Robert Newton and Anthony Newley. Directed by David Lean. 1948. Paramount Home Video. 116 minutes. $19.95.

title: Holiday Antiques Show Offers a Scandinavian Motif
description: LEAD: ANTIQUARIUS, the annual antiques show that signals the start of the holiday season, will open on Friday at the Greenwich Civic Center in Old Greenwich, and this year it will feature a Swedish theme.

title: Emancipation Law: Children Are Victims
description: I am Peter, the school principal referred to in your Oct. 2 article, ''The Emancipation Age: Should It Rise to 18?'' More and more of the uninitiated are being enlightened when they become unsuspecting victims of an emancipated 16-year-old. In the final analysis, the lives of many children, including my daughters, are being irreparably damaged, and the dilemma of parents, rendered helpless by the law, continues.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Division III Playoffs; Ithaca Holds Off Cortland State
description: Paul Parker scored the winning touchdown on a 16-yard run with 8 minutes 6 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter today, and Ithaca held off a second-half rally by Cortland State for a 24-17 victory over the previously unbeaten Red Dragons in the Division III East Regional.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: JUST IN TIME: Notes From My Life. By Phyllis Newman. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Phyllis Newman is a talented actress and musical comedy performer with a Tony award to her credit, a show business personality who was one of Johnny Carson's first guests and, more recently, a featured performer on a popular soap opera.

title: Mavericks End Jazz's Streak at 7
description: Derek Harper hit three 3-pointers and added a 3-point play during a 14-0 streak in the third period tonight as the Dallas Mavericks snapped the Utah Jazz's seven-game winning streak, 113-93.

title: Tampering With the Safety Net
description: THE insurance on deposits of up to $100,000 at most banks and savings institutions has come to feel as sacrosanct as turkey on Thanksgiving. Yet for the first time since the 1930's, many policy makers and analysts are now saying the deposit insurance system is flawed and badly in need of an overhaul.

title: Air Fares Need Not Soar
description: The nation's airports have been jammed with a record two million travelers this weekend and, on many flights, the atmosphere makes commuter buses look good. There's a big consolation. Flying is still cheap. The question is, will it remain so for long?

title: DINING OUT
description: Homestyle Italian in Danbury

title: Accessibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Susannah C. Lawrence Is Wed in Connecticut
description: At the Congregational Church of Christ in Norfolk, Conn., Susannah Coffin Lawrence, a daughter of Mrs. James F. Lawrence of New York, and the late Mr. Lawrence, was married yesterday to Willard Lyman Wood, a son of Mrs. C. Daggett Harvey of London and Clement B. Wood of Water Mill, L.I. The Rev. Bruce Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: To Run or Not to Run: Dinkins's Struggle
description: David N. Dinkins is waiting, taking a measure of his city, his prospects and his own heart.

title: Review/Music; Female Artists' Tribute To Record Company
description: The mood at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening was unusually jubilant as a sold-out house consisting almost entirely of women, many clad in tuxedos, gathered to celebrate the 15th anniversary of Olivia Records.

title: Machine Tool Orders Drop For 2d Month
description: Continuing a decline that began in September, orders for American-made machine tools dropped 19.5 percent in October, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: Vagaries of English
description: To the Editor:

title: Study of Athletes May Spur Changes
description: A study of the impact of athletics on students, recently completed for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, is expected to influence intercollegiate sports for at least the next decade.

title: Serkin Cancels Recital
description: Rudolf Serkin has canceled his Dec. 6 recital at Carnegie Hall because of ''extreme fatigue,'' the hall has announced. The recital has not been rescheduled. Refunds for tickets obtained at the box office or by mail are available at the box office Mondays through Saturdays from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sundays from noon to 6 P.M. All tickets charged by telephone must be returned by mail to Carnegie Charge, 881 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019. Refund requests must be received no later than Jan. 9. Information: 247-7800.

title: A Priority for Bush
description: In Brazil's great undeveloped Amazon basin, the national Government spent $600 million in tax credits to subsidize the development - between 1965 and 1983 - of 469 cattle ranches averaging 23,000 hectares each (about 57,500 acres).

title: Unusual Ads Help a Foreign Vodka to the Top
description: The American importers of Swedish-made Absolut Vodka have begun the latest in a series of high-priced, imaginative promotions that beverage analysts credit with helping Absolut grow from an unknown into the nation's best-selling imported vodka in less than six years.

title: Trade Tussle Inside the Computer
description: Japan's negotiators recently asked Washington to lift the sanctions imposed against its electronic products, a request the Administration could only rebuff. Sanctions are a regrettable way for friendly nations to conduct business. But so is Japan's behavior. Its markets are still only barely open to American computer chips, and Japan now wants to exclude an important kind of American software - operating systems - from new classroom computers.

title: Reviews/Television; The Mystery of the Korean Airliner
description: Television docudramas are in the ascendancy at the moment, and as usual, the results are not only uneven but also worrying. Tonight's entry, on NBC at 9, is ''Shootdown,'' the fact-based story of one mother's crusade to discover the truth behind the Soviet destruction of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on Sept. 1, 1983. The mother, here named Nan Moore, is played by Angela Lansbury, who convincingly demonstrates that several seasons of playing the charmingly smug Jessica Fletcher on ''Murder, She Wrote'' haven't dulled her versatility.

title: Teheran Suspends P.O.W. Trade With Baghdad
description: Iran announced today that it was suspending the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war with Iraq because the exchange was uneven.

title: Free Speech Takes Step Backward in Ideological Exclusion Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Saul Mills, Ex-Labor Organizer, Dies at 78
description: Saul Mills, a former labor organizer and advertising executive, died Saturday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla., after a long illness. He was 78 years old and had moved to Florida from Great Neck, L.I., two years ago.

title: An Acquittal In Gucci Case
description: A Florence court has acquitted the former chairman of Guccio Gucci S.p.A., the Italian leather goods fashion house, of violating foreign exchange laws because his activities were no longer a criminal offense.

title: U.S. Magazine Readers Love British Royalty
description: Two British monthly magazines that do nothing but follow the royal family are finding the United States market even more fertile than their home country's.

title: Onassis Child Gets Bulk of Estate
description: The will of Christina Onassis, formally presented in an Athens court over the weekend, grants the vast bulk of her fortune to her 3-year-old daughter but provides a $1.5 million annuity to her fourth and last husband, from whom she was divorced in 1987.

title: Review/Recital; Soprano in All-English Bill
description: Janis-Rozena Peri's song recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night had perhaps more originality than substance, but there was enough intermittent interest to sustain this evening of largely American and completely English-language music.

title: Sununu Keeps Link to Tufts 6 Years After Quitting Faculty
description: Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire is still on the faculty of Tufts University six years after he last taught there. The arrangement has allowed his children to receive tuition waivers and aid from the school.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The U.N. may move this session of the General Assembly to Geneva for part of its time so that Palestine Yasir Arafat can address the Assembly on Palstinian independence, Arab diplomats said. Page A1

title: Unitel Video Rejects Bid
description: The Crown Communications Corporation, a private satellite communications concern based in Alexandria, Va., disclosed that it had offered earlier this month to acquire Unitel Video Inc. for $12.50 a share in cash, or $30 million, but that the offer had been rejected by the Unitel board as inadequate.

title: France Plans Soviet Loans
description: France said that it was ready to offer $2 billion in loans to the Soviet Union but that it would also keep an eye on the progress of disarmament talks while it helps to finance the modernizing of the Soviet economy. Thursday, on the eve of a visit to the Soviet Union by President Francois Mitterrand, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas confirmed reports that a credit line worth 12 billion francs ($2 billion) was in the works. Finance Minister Pierre

title: Reviews/Dance; Jock Soto Dominates For a Day at City Ballet
description: It was Jock Soto day on Saturday, or so it seemed from the matinee and evening programs presented by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. For Mr. Soto was a highlight of the day, dancing a new role in Lar Lubovitch's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' in the afternoon and familiar ones in George Balanchine's ''Bugaku,'' also in the afternoon, and Balanchine's ''Stars and Stripes'' in the evening.

title: Myron S. Nightingale, Wine Maker, 73
description: Myron S. Nightingale, a California wine maker for four decades and former president of the American Society of Enology and Viticulture, died Friday at the age of 73.

title: MILITARY SAVINGS SUGGESTED TO BUSH
description: The man picked by President-elect Bush to serve as national security adviser has proposed consideration of a number of far-reaching measures to curtail military spending, including transferring military units from active to reserve status and cutting back on aircraft carrier operations far from United States territory.

title: Browns Shock Redskins at Finish, 17-13
description: The Washington Redskins, the defending Super Bowl champions, saw their hopes of reaching the playoffs virtually disappear in the rain today as the Cleveland Browns defeated them by 17-13.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Giants Defeat Saints at Wire
description: Phil Simms and Carl Banks could not play because of bruised right shoulders. The Giants' running game gained only 14 yards on 17 carries. The Giants' quarterbacks were harassed all night by a strong, aggressive defense.

title: Islanders Defeated By Rangers Again
description: The insults, as they have in years past, rained down on the Islanders from the Garden's rafters. And the Islanders, as they have in years past, absorbed them stoically.

title: Review/Music; Lessons in Concert
description: Richard Kapp uses his Philharmonia Virtuosi chamber orchestra to indulge a couple of old-fashioned notions. One is to offer solidly packed programs at prices considerably below the standard for an orchestral evening, and that seems all for the best. The other is to spoon-feed his audience a music appreciation lesson. His presentation Tuesday evening at Town Hall left doubts about the merits of the second endeavor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Justamere to Handle Big Entertainment Job
description: The Justamere Agency of Hopatcong, N.J., has been named to handle the advertising for New York Night Life Magazine, Long Island Night Life Magazine as well as cable shows that are spinoffs of the entertainment magazines. In addition, the agency will do the advertising for New York Sports Monthly, which is expected to be introduced next year. The entire budget is expected to reach $7 million, according to Michael Cutino, who runs the local entertainment properties.

title: Gorbachev Says Ethnic Unrest Could Destroy Restructuring Effort
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has warned that ethnic tensions could be ''disastrous'' because they threaten his efforts to reshape the Soviet Union.

title: Chemicals in Salt Caverns Hold Pain for Texas Town
description: Only about 50 families are left on Barbers Hill, perched precariously atop a salt dome where industry stores more volatile hydrocarbons than anywhere else in the world.

title: Credit Markets; Defensive Mood Seen On Bonds
description: Continuing disagreement among OPEC oil ministers, uneasiness about the dollar and a slew of economic reports are all likely to keep credit market participants in a defensive, uncertain frame of mind this week.

title: In Making National Policy, the Buck Starts Here
description: To the uninitiated, the Office of Management and Budget may call to mind Government bean counters, gimlet-eyed naysayers, actuaries who lack the personality to become accountants.

title: Notre Dame Rises To the Occasion
description: Long before nearly 94,000 people took their seats, before the bands played and the noise swelled in the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, the outcome of the most important college football game so far this season began to take shape in a conversation between two coaches at Notre Dame.

title: Shake-Up In Belgium
description: Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's biggest company, said Friday that it had cut its management work force by 25 percent in a shake-up begun after a bitter takeover battle earlier this year.

title: Companies Search for Next $1 Billion Drug
description: This year four pharmaceutical companies are expected to have drugs that each generate annual sales of a billion dollars or more. Such sales were unheard of just a few years ago, and the companies have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to use their windfall profits to develop major new drugs.

title: Argentina's Privatization Battle
description: When Rodolfo H. Terragno took on the quixotic challenge of shrinking and modernizing Argentina's infamously inefficient state enterprises last year, he harbored no illusions that it would be an easy task.

title: Paul Rosengren Marries Betsy Golden
description: Betsy Jane Golden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Balfour H. Golden of Ridgewood, N.J., and Paul Lief Rosengren, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Rosengren, also of Ridgewood, were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green in New York. The Rev. Neil Hamilton, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: FIGHTING INTENSE FOR AFGHAN CITIES
description: Fighting between the Afghan guerrillas and soldiers of the Soviet-backed Afghan Government has intensified in the last month, particularly in provinces bordering Pakistan where some of the heaviest fighting of the war is under way, Western diplomats in Islamabad say.

title:
The Recruiting of Kenny Anderson;
Coaches Take Turn Wooing, Waiting
description: LEAD: THE recruitment of first-rank high school athletes is at best a peculiar process, governed by a byzantine array of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules and by the desires of teen-aged heroes accustomed to commanding adult attention.

title: Nippon Telegraph Profit
