description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, Japan's telecommunications giant, on Friday announced virtually flat profits and cited rate cuts and competition from companies that entered the field last year. The company said it had net profits of $832 million in the six months ended Sept. 30, compared with $833 million in the corresponding period last year. Nippon Telegraph had a monopoly on Japan's domestic telecommunications market until September 1987.

title: Ethiopia's President Looks Toward Better U.S. Relations ETHIOPIA: AT A GLANCE
description: President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, the leader of one of the world's most rigid Marxist-Leninst states, says that the election of George Bush presents ''a new opportunity'' for improved relations with the United States.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf One-Stroke Victory for Mize: Larry Mize overcame a double bogey yesterday and shot a 73 to win the $750,000 Casio World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan, by one stroke. Mize also had three birdies and two bogeys on the 6,985-yard, par-72 Kaimon course at the Ibusuki Club in southern Japan, finishing with 284. Masashi Ozaki, Japan's leading money winner this season, finished in second place.(AP) Calcavecchia Wins Australian Open: Mark Calcavecchia shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to win the Australian Open at Royal Sydney by six strokes over Mark McCumber. Calcavecchia finished with a four-round total of 269, 19-under-par, equaling Jack Newton's tournament course record, set in the 1976 New South Wales Open.(AP) Road Racing Irish Runner Triumphs: Martin Ryan of Dublin won the New York Road Runners Club's 30th annual 15-kilometer championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The 21-year-old Ryan covered the 9.3-mile course in 50 minutes 24 seconds yesterday to capture the Pete McArdle Memorial Trophy. Diane Weissman of the Van Cortlandt Track Club was the women's gold medalist in 1:04.45. Tennis Leconte Defeats Hlasek: Henri Leconte of France defeated Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 7-6, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday to win the $490,000 Belgian Indoor Championships in Brussels. Leconte never lost his serve in a sparkling display of his all-court play. It was Leconte's second Grand Prix victory this year. (AP) Adams and Garrison Win: Katrina Adams and Zina Garrison beat top-seeded Robin White and Gigi Fernandez, 7-5, 7-5, yesterday to win the Virginia Slims world doubles championship in Tokyo. Adams, of Chicago, and Garrison, of Houston, split the first-place prize of $75,000. (AP) Horse Racing Pay the Butler Triumphs in Japan: Pay the Butler, an American horse ridden by Chris McCarron, ran neck-and-neck with Tamamo Cross of Japan before surging ahead in the final furlong to win the Japan Cup by a half-length yesterday near Tokyo. Pay the Butler, a 4-year-old colt, covered the 2,400 meters (about 1 1/2 miles) in 2:25.5 and earned $1,033,000.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 109, Heat 80: Ron Harper scored 26 points and brought Cleveland back from an early 14-point deficit last night to keep Miami without a victory. Harper scored 5 points during a 15-0 Cleveland run in the second period that wiped out a 42-30 Miami lead. The Heat (0-10) cut the Cavaliers' lead to 1 point at halftime, but Cleveland (8-3) gradually pulled away in the third quarter behind 10 more points from Harper. (AP) Trail Blazers 109, Warriors 94: Clyde Drexler scored 29 points and Kevin Duckworth had 12 of his 18 points in the third period to lead Portland. The victory was the fourth straight for Portland (7-5). The Warriors (5-6) have lost four games in a row. (AP)

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Last month, the Jets, after losing to them nine times, finally defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers for the first time in the history of the franchise. Are there any teams left in the National Football League that have never beaten another league member?

title: U.S. Currency Policy Speeds Japan in Vast Economic Role
description: The United States, which set out three years ago to restore American competitiveness by championing a strong yen, has ended up speeding Japan's emergence as a financial superpower and challenger to American economic leadership.

title: Ms. Folsom Wed To Yvon Rivest
description: The marriage of Lindsey Cole Folsom, the daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Samuel B. Folsom of New York, to Yvon Rivest, a son of Irene Bellemare Rivest of Montreal and the late Gerald Rivest, took place yesterday at the Table of Contents, a loft in New York. The Rev. Dr. Charles T. Yerkes, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Reviews/Television; Some Facts of the Flight 007 Matter
description: The docudrama is a hybrid form that leaves a lot of room for reshaping events. But the writers of ''Shootdown,'' about the destruction of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter five years ago, have handled the technical parts of the disaster with close attention to facts.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: Hartsfield Journal; Recipe for Airport Chaos: Take a Holiday Weekend; Add Rain
description: It was the second busiest day of the year in the nation's second busiest airport, but that didn't console Ed and Janet Hohenstein or Phillip and Alice Crabtree, all of Austin, Tex.

title: Palestinians Make Genuine Concession to Israel; Unwanted Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Overwork Killed Judge, Official Rules
description: A workers' compensation commissioner has ruled that a Superior Court judge who was described as ''the epitome of the work ethic'' died of overwork. The commissioner then awarded the judge's widow $21,000 a year in benefits.

title: Injured Bears Prevail, 16-0
description: Neal Anderson called his 80-yard touchdown run ''icing on the cake'' that ''helped take the pressure off Jim Harbaugh.''

title: Port Authority Faces Shortfall And Cutbacks
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, known in municipal finance circles as a cash machine because of its easy ability to generate money, is facing a cash shortfall and trying to slash next year's spending by $150 million.

title: New Twists for Multimillion-Dollar Book Contracts
description: Multimillion-dollar contracts have become the norm for proven authors and potential best sellers by lesser-known writers. But to cite only the big numbers can be misleading. The deals are being structured in new and different ways that, in the case of paperback reprints, at least, result in more money for the author and give the publisher more time to recoup its investment.

title: Sexual Harassment Of Teachers Charged
description: The Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, said yesterday that the investigation of community school boards in the Bronx had expanded to encompass charges that district teachers had been sexually harassed by school board members or employees.

title: Blaze in Minneapolis Kills Four in a Family
description: Arson is suspected in a fire Saturday that killed a woman, two of her sons and a young man who was visiting them in an apartment house here.

title: On Your Own; Matching Navigational Skills With a Computer
description: IT'S mostly too cold for boating in New York at this time of year.

title: Out of Time
description: LEAD: Between the end of 1987 and the beginning of 1988, scientists added one second to the world's clock. It wasn't nearly enough.

title: Gorbachev Sees Peril in Unrest
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, warned that ethnic agitation in the Transcaucasus and the Baltic republics could be ''disastrous'' to his efforts to introduce greater openness to the country's economy and society.

title: GATT Reports a Rift on Services
description: Trade negotiators adopted a report Friday that delegates said reflected deep divergences between advanced and developing countries on how to work out international rules for service industries.

title: ARAB OFFICIALS SAY VOTES ARE IN HAND TO MOVE U.N. TALKS
description: Arab diplomats said today that they had the votes in the United Nations General Assembly to move part of this year's session to Geneva so that Yasir Arafat can address the Assembly on Palestinian independence.

title: Forget the Myths About Fragile Females
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryan Has to Stop After Rolling Along
description: For Pat Ryan, the understudy who almost becomes a star each time he takes over for Ken O'Brien, today marked another appearance that ended with an injury.

title: High Court Curbed Runaway Electoral College
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Outshoot Dolphins
description: The Jets and the Dolphins traveled 3,111 feet today, more than 10 football fields, to produce another of those zany, emotional shootouts that have marked their intense rivalry.

title: A Religious Party Ends Likud Coalition Talks
description: The smallest of Israel's rigorously Orthodox religious parties announced tonight that it was breaking off coalition talks with the Likud party. It called instead for a national unity government between Likud and the Labor Party.

title: Shultz's 'No' to Arafat; Personal Disgust for Terrorism Is at Root Of Secretary's Decision to Rebuff the P.L.O.
description: In denying a visa to Yasir Arafat, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has made a strong personal statement expressing visceral contempt for terrorism and left an imprint on Middle East policy that could last well into the Bush Administration.

title: On Your Own; Can Exercise Alter The Aging Process?
description: A BOSTON research group has been teaching nursing-home residents to lift weights, and anyone who is prone to turn off the alarm clock and sleep another hour instead of going out for a run should pay attention to the findings.

title: Dominican Ex-Leader Convicted
description: Former President Salvador Jorge Blanco and two business executives were found guilty today of corruption during his administration and were sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: Sports World Specials; 'We Want Our MSG'
description: Being a Ranger fan has never been easy. The Rangers have gone almost half a century without winning a Stanley Cup. The club has gone to the finals only three times since 1940. Two times they lost in the seventh game, twice by scores of 1-0. Ranger fans have seen it all.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Cuba will be the location of a $4 million coconut processing factory to be built by Cimmco Ltd., a subsidiary of India's family-owned Birla conglomerate. Cimmco's president, D. K. Goyal, said the plant in the eastern city of Baracoa would produce edible oil and fiber for carpets, curtains and mattresses. The factory is to begin operating in June 1990.

title: Tennis; At Garden, Last Stand for Top 8 Players
description: Some tennis is for glory. Wimbledon and the United States Open come to mind. Some tennis is for money. Any major tournament will do. And some tennis is even for fun. Against your 4-year-old kid, for example.

title: Reviews/Music; The Kronos Quartet Stretches Perimeters
description: Concerts like the Kronos Quartet's evening at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday are important even when their contents aren't. So-called classical music is in desperate need of new sources, and it is equally desperate for new ears to embrace them. This program and its large, mostly young and very open-minded audience offered both. Not all of Saturday's music dwells firmly in the memory, but together it represented a healthy reaching out beyond the European tradition, an inheritance that still engages mass listenership but inspires contemporary composers less and less.

title: Venezuela's Oil To Back Loans
description: The state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, will commit 130,000 barrels per day of crude at $15 a barrel for seven years to guarantee $1 billion in credit for Venezuela, the daily newspaper El Nacional said today.

title: Fordham Plaza Vitalizes its Area, but Not Itself
description: When Fordham Plaza opened in the summer of 1986, the striking round office building of yellow stone, black marble and polished chrome was praised by city and state officials as the herald of commercial renaissance in the Bronx. Its owners said the 12-story layer-cake structure would become ''the crossroads'' of the borough and advertised it as combining ''the luxury of Park Avenue with the convenience and economy of the Bronx.''

title: Digital Audio Tape Dispute
description: A solution to a two-year conflict between the music industry and electronics companies over digital audio tape recorders may be close, a spokeswoman for Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics company, said Thursday.

title: Pernod Sees More Links
description: The successful takeover of Irish Distillers Group by the French company Pernod Ricard will probably be the first in a string of mergers as the liquor business consolidates, the head of Pernod said in an interview.

title: AIDS DANGER RISES FOR COCAINE USERS
description: The AIDS virus is spreading even faster among people who inject cocaine than among heroin users, according to new research conducted in San Francisco and New York City.

title: 700 See Tyson Baptized
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, was baptized today in a ceremony attended by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the boxing promoter Don King and a crowd of about 700 people at a Baptist church on Cleveland's east side.

title: TV, Election Spoiler
description: LEAD: Question: Did you know that, according to some studies, the average length of a television news sound bite dropped from 14.8 seconds in the 1984 Presidential campaign to 9 seconds in the 1988 campaign? That is, of course, long enough for simplistic sloganeering - ''Read my lips, no new taxes'' - but hardly long enough for George

title: Palestinians Make Genuine Concession to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Make Genuine Concession to Israel; Missed Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacteria Clue Found In Death of Woman
description: Salmonella bacteria have been found in the intestinal tract of the woman who died after eating a tainted turkey dinner, but the exact cause of her death has not been determined, a Westchester health official said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketing Movies for Children
description: CHRISTMAS may be a time of joy for children, but to the companies that make movies for children, the holiday season can sometimes be a headache. With dozens of new films fighting for audiences, getting children's attention at this time of year is a struggle.

title: Sports of The Times; Lou Holtz's Discipline
description: DISCIPLINE is a football coach's favorite word. And like everything else in football, it's as old as blocking and tackling.

title: Letter: On U.S. Industrial Future; Make HDTV a Public-Private Venture
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans in Brussels Delight Dance Fans
description: The American choreographer Mark Morris and his dance company have scored a triumph here in their new role as residents of the Monnaie Theater, succeeding Maurice Bejart.

title: TV Notes
description: Leslie Caron as Chanel

title: Homeless in Park Sticking to a Cause
description: A rain-soaked sign, small and partially obscured on a bench in City Hall Park, read 178 - denoting the consecutive days a group of homeless people calling itself Homeward Bound Community Services has been living on the front lawn of New York City's most prominent house of government.

title: On Your Own: Correction
description: An article on the On Your Own page last Monday, about golf instruction videos, gave the incorrect price and telephone number for ''Lee Trevino's Tips for Youngsters.'' The tape costs $24.95. The number is (800) 272-5858.

title: Market Place; Curbing Stocks For Foreigners
description: MAKING the foreigners pay more than the locals is a time-honored tradition in stocks as well as in other areas. The foreigners do not like paying the price, but they can be even less happy when the rules are changed.

title: L.I. Fire Company Mourns Its First Loss in Action in 40 Years
description: The American flag outside Alper's hardware store on Main Street was at half-staff today as this community of about 15,000 mourned Lieut. Robert Dayton, a 28-year-old firefighter who died early Saturday after being trapped in a smoke-filled building.

title: Vacancies in Military Hospitals Seen As Helping in Drugs and AIDS Cases
description: State and local health authorities around the country are looking at partly vacant military hospitals, assessing their potential as treatment centers for thousands of intravenous drug users and AIDS patients who are straining civilian programs.

title: Kleinwort Benson Group Selects a New Chairman
description: Kleinwort Benson Group P.L.C., a British investment banking and securities conglomerate, has announced that its chairman, Robert Henderson, will retire on Jan. 1. He will be succeeded by David Peake, who has been chairman of the investment banking arm, Kleinwort Benson Ltd., since the beginning of the year.

title: After 2 Years, Ship Dumps Toxic Ash
description: A ship finally unloaded its toxic ash from Philadelphia after wandering the world's seas for more than two years in search of a place to dump its unwanted cargo, a port official here said Saturday.

title: European Nations Assail Decision By U.S. to Deny a Visa for Arafat
description: Western European governments today expressed criticism, some forcefully and some quietly, of Washington's decision to deny Yasir Arafat a visa to address the United Nations.

title: Eagles Strengthen Position
description: Once the Philadelphia Eagles started holding onto the football, they had an easier time holding onto first place in their division.

title: Committee Tried a 'Pre-emptive Strike'
description: One of the clearest examples of how the House Armed Services Committee failed to aggressively oversee the nuclear weapon complex occurred this fall.

title: Opponent of Yemen Government Is Unhurt in Shooting in Michigan
description: Shots were fired here Saturday night from a passing car at a group of people who included a leading opponent of the Government of Yemen.

title: Bridge
description: An unexpected foursome headed the field of 10 teams into the final two sessions of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, ahead of bunches of world-class stars.

title: Margaret E. Samson Weds Martin Byman
description: Margaret E. Samson and Martin R. Byman, 1983 graduates of the Cornell University Law School, were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi James Prosnit.

title: On Your Own; Bringing New Shots Into Your Game
description: JERRY MCLAUGHLIN, a Westport, Conn., artist, has played tennis at a highly skilled recreational caliber for 40 years. Until recently, though, he had never had an overhead that he could count on in competition. But after hours of instruction, that's finally changing.

title: Books of The Times; Dissecting the CBS Westmoreland Documentary
description: Fair Play CBS, General Westmoreland, and How a Television Documentary Went Wrong By Burton Benjamin Illustrated. 218 pages. Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: A New Rio Grande Bridge?
description: This year marks only the third time that new presidents have been elected simultaneously in Mexico and the United States. George Bush and Carlos Salinas de Gortari, heirs to a legacy of United States intervention and Mexican insularity, could improve relations if they resist the temptation to propose or dismiss lofty or purely symbolic initiatives.

title: Danilova Bequest Is a Thank-You to New York
description: Alexandra Danilova, who was 84 years old on Nov. 20, has decided to celebrate with a gift to someone else. Miss Danilova will donate to the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library the paintings, sculptures, costume sketches and set designs she has acquired during a career of some six decades as an internationally acclaimed prima ballerina and dance teacher.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * W. H. Brady Co., Milwaukee, a maker of adhesives and coatings, elected Paul G. Gengler president and chief executive. He is replacing James E. Larson, who will be retiring as of Dec. 31 but will continue as a director.

title: Sports World Specials; The Mandarich Diet
description: ''I like to watch people's eyes the first time they meet me,'' said Tony Mandarich, the 6-foot-6-inch, 315-pound offensive tackle for Michigan State who is favored to win the Outland Trophy as the best interior lineman in college football. ''I mean people who say, 'I can't believe you're so big and still in college.' ''

title: For a Last Goodbye
description: In his seven years as Canada's Ambassador, Allan Gotlieb presided over the planning and construction of his country's new embassy, and he frequently expressed the wish to wind up his ambassadorship in the new building.

title: INSIDE
description: A Texan for Commerce A Houston financier, Robert A. Mosbacher Sr., is to be chosen as Commerce Secretary. Page A20. Secrecy for a Shuttle Flight The space shuttle flight this week, the second mission since the Challenger disaster, is a strictly military operation cloaked in secrecy. Page A21. A Special Return to Albany The Legislature resumes today in an effort to decide whether to accept a deal that would close the Shoreham nuclear power plant. Page B3. Dinkins Mulls It Over David N. Dinkins takes stock of New York City and himself as he decides whether to run for Mayor. Page B1.

title: Correction
description: An article in some copies Saturday on art auctions misidentified the owners of the Jasper Johns painting ''False Start'' during a recent sale. It was consigned to Sotheby's by Francois and Susan de Menil. A chart with the article misidentified the gallery at which Picasso's painting ''Motherhood'' was sold. It was sold at Christie's.

title: Reviews/Music; Verdi's Obscure Study Of Marital Forgiveness
description: Little-known works by great composers are often early efforts that have been ignored by posterity for good reason; and while it can be fun to dust them off and give them a hearing now and then, they tend not to change our view of the composer's oeuvre much.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It is not reasonable for the United States in this manner to decide what countries should appear in the United Nations.

title: Review/Music; Multitude of Voices in One
description: Shelley Hirsch, unlike so many experimental vocalists, is a singer whose warblings and inventions of strangely evocative musical languages never sink into sterile technical exercises. The singer, who performed at Dance Theater Workshop on Monday and Tuesday evenings, is a woman of a thousand voices, all of which seem to evolve out of one another naturally to flow in a smooth emotional progression.

title: Arabs Denounce Exclusion of Arafat
description: Arab nations reacted with annoyance and sometimes astonishment today to the American decision to prevent Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, from speaking to the United Nations General Assembly this week.

title: Horse Racing; Scarlet Ibis Shows His Preeminence
description: Scarlet Ibis picked up another fat check for proving once again that he is clearly the best New York-bred 2-year-old around, with a 5 3/4-length romp in the $200,000 New York Stallion Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Richard Andrew Edelman Is Married to Alison Gale
description: The marriage of Alison Gale, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard P. Pearl of Hewlett, L.I., to Richard Andrew Edelman, a son of Jack Edelman of Palm Desert, Calif., and Dorothy D. Lipman of Beverly Hills, Calif., took place yesterday at the Ballroom in New York. Cantor Ellen Math officiated.

title: Metro Matters; Racial Tipping Is a Pivotal Issue In Fighting Bias
description: Mention tipping to most people and they will matter-of-factly suggest a gratuity of 15 percent. But in the argot of racial integration, the figure cited more frequently is closer to 50 percent. When members of minority groups collectively constitute half the population of a given school or neighborhood, many experts agree, the balance tips and white flight begins.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Houston Financier Is Called Choice as Commerce Chief
description: President-elect Bush plans to name a Houston financier, Robert A. Mosbacher Sr., as Commerce Secretary, transition aides said today. The announcement could come as early as this week, they added.

title: Why Fight Leveraged Buyouts?
description: As melodrama, the big doings at RJR Nabisco Inc. are proving irresistible even to people who don't care a Fig Newton about business. The original $17 billion takeover bid from the company's own managers has now been topped three times, with the First Boston Corporation offering up to an incredible $26.8 billion for the food and tobacco giant.

title: Strength in Manufacturing Overstated by Faulty Data
description: When the Reagan Administration reports that manufacturing is thriving in the United States, it bases its optimistic assessment on a Government statistic that is probably exaggerated, the Commerce Department now admits.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Mr. Peanut Is Back To Sell Planters Nuts
description: Mr. Peanut has been brought back to represent Planters Nuts in new animated commercials created by Lintas: New York for the Planters Lifesavers Company. The campaign is called ''A Whole Lotta Nuttin Goin' On.'' The commercials will be broadcast during prime-time television programs. The spots, featuring young people on the beach, at a baseball game and bicycling, will be closing with Mr. Peanut surrounded by Planters nut products.

title: Fibreboard Rejects Bid
description: A group led by Raymond P. Park, the Cleveland investor, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had offered last month to purchase all outstanding shares of the Fibreboard Corporation for $17 a share in cash, or $65.8 million. But the group said in its filing made Friday that the offer had been rejected by Fibreboard's management.

title: Handcuffed Man Had Drug History, Widow Says
description: The widow of a Bronx man who died shortly after being handcuffed by Transit Police officers Friday afternoon said yesterday that her husband had disappeared that morning, possibly to buy drugs.

title: Stalin Victims Are Mourned By Throngs
description: The exhibit was billed as the focus of ''a week of conscience,'' to remember the victims of Stalin's repressions, but seven days stretched to eight, and still today the crowds clamored to take part in the mourning that had waited 50 years to find its voice.

title: Outdoors: Fishing Within City Limits
description: THREE HUNDRED feet above New York Harbor my vertigo fairly roared as I crawled across the scaffolding that encircled the Statue of Liberty. I was working on a film to raise money for the restoration of the statue. One day, I thought, I could tell my children that I had placed my hand on the torch. As I looked down, I saw a small boat off Liberty Island with two fishermen in it, catching lots of fish. When the construction elevator deposited us at ground level the two anglers were still catching and releasing striped bass.

title: U.J.A., at 50, Is Thriving but Also Being Challenged
description: Since the birth of Israel, the United Jewish Appeal has been the crucial financial link between American Jews and the Jewish state. Now it finds itself challenged on several fronts, most dramatically by the threat posed by the debate in Israel over ''who is a Jew.''

title: Trouble at Atomic Bomb Plants: How Lawmakers Missed the Signs
description: The Congressional committees charged with supervising the nation's nuclear weapon industry largely overlooked evidence of the severe safety and management problems that have become public knowledge in recent months, legislators, environmentalists, nuclear scientists and other specialists say.

title: The Lunch Counter
description: The scene: The sedate private dining room of the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Special Session in Albany Will Tackle Shoreham Deal
description: State legislators return here Monday to try to accomplish two contradictory goals: give approval to a deal to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant and at the same time suggest that they have struck a better deal for residents of Long Island.

title: Reviews/Television; 'Pyramid,' a Documentary
description: ''Pyramid'' is an ill-constructed documentary about ancient Egypt's greatest construction. Based on a book by the historian David Macaulay, who also serves as the on-screen narrator, the program at 9 tonight on Channel 13 and at 8 on Channel 21 digs into the whys and wherefores of the building of the Great Pyramid of Giza around 2500 B.C. The subject is as rich as the tombs of the Egyptian rulers were before they were looted - but moving forward and backward in time and back and forth between location photography and animation, the hour seems designed to strike adults as childish and children as confusing.

title: Bengals Run Over Bills, 35-21
description: Sam Wyche, the Cincinnati Bengals' coach, said today that he directed his offensive line this way: ''Block somebody. And when you get through, go block somebody else.'' That simple. At least it looked that way against the Buffalo Bills and their defense, ranked first in the American Conference, as Cincinnati won, 35-21, before 58,672 in Riverfront Stadium.

title: Radon-Cancer Link Examined in Study
description: State health officials are reviving a 1982 study of lung cancer in women to determine if radon gas contributed to the incidence of cancer among the survey's subjects.

title: Gorbachev's Address: 'We Are One Family'
description: Following are excerpts from the speech on ethnic issues by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, on Saturday, as translated and distributed by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: School Board 9 in Bronx Has a History of Accusations
description: Community School Board District 9 in the Bronx, the center of scandal in the last several weeks, has been the target of allegations of mismanagement, patronage and misuse of money since the New York City school system was decentralized 18 years ago.

title: Indiana Stops Seton Hall
description: Jim Crockford, a junior fullback, poked in his own rebound for the winning goal with just over 10 minutes to play as ninth-ranked Indiana defeated third-ranked Seton Hall, 3-1, in a quarterfinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 27, 1988: MONDAY Albertson's Inc Bank New England Corp BellSouth Corp Chemical Waste Mgmt Crane Co Detroit Edison Co San Diego Gas & Elec Co Waste Mgmt Inc Watkins Johnson Co TUESDAY Angelica Corp Becton Dickinson & Co Coachmen Inds Inc Connecticut Nat Gas Corp Home Depot Inc Ipalco Enterprises Inc Philip Morris Cos WEDNESDAY E Sys Inc Green Mountain Pwr New Jersey Res Corp Pilgrims Pride Corp United States Shoe Corp Wynns Intl Inc. THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Inc Angel Real Estate Co Atlantic Energy Corp Brown Group Inc Chrysler Corp Great Atlantic & Pac Tea Illinois Pwr Co MCA Inc Marriott Corp RLI Corp SPS Technologies Inc Universal Corp VA Zayre Corp FRIDAY Commonwealth Edison

title: New Demand by Saudis Endangers OPEC Accord
description: In an unexpected move that could send oil prices plummeting again, Saudi Arabia demanded today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries adopt a floor price of $15 a barrel for the oil it sells.

title: Assignment From Moscow: Get U.S. Crime War Secrets
description: ''Turf? What does this mean?''

title: 20 Nobel Winners Due
description: More than 20 American winners of Nobel Prizes are to assemble in the capital Dec. 9, to be joined by the 1987 Nobel Laureate for peace, President Oscar Rafael Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica.

title: Sports World Specials; Laugh When It Hurts
description: No one is suggesting that anyone, let alone a professional athlete, would deliberately subject himself to injury just to undergo a novel surgical experience. But there was a tantalizing hint last week that something more than coincidence may be involved in the spate of hand injuries that has sent an army of Mets traipsing to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: Korean G.N.P. Gains
description: South Korea's economy grew at an annual rate of 12.6 percent in the third quarter, even though a stronger currency has slowed export industries, the central bank said Thursday. Provisional figures from the Bank of Korea show that the gross national product, which measures the total value of goods and services produced, rose to 18.59 trillion won, or $27 billion, from 16.5 trillion, or $24 billion, in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Set to Sell Stake In Syndication Division
description: Grey Advertising has reached an agreement in principle to sell a majority stake in its television syndication subsidiary, LBS Communications, to Henry Siegel, LBS's chairman, and a new company formed by the Warburg, Pincus Capital Company, a venture capital firm.

title: Will Bush and Dole End Their Grand Old Rivalry?
description: In Bangkok, in Singapore and in Jakarta, the word reached Bob Dole.

title: The Hard Issue of Opening Cable TV to the Baby Bells
description: THERE are the stirrings of debate in Washington, soon likely to be raging conflict, over the proposition that the future of television in America is the telephone. Or, more precisely, that the future of television is the telephone companies.

title: Debt Payment Curb in Manila
description: The Philippine Senate passed a bill Thursday that would limit foreign debt payments to 20 percent of export receipts, a move foreign bankers said would make access to new loans more difficult.

title: Reviews/Music; Recasting of Met 'Barbiere'
description: A major effort of Bruce Crawford's brief administration at the Metropolitan Opera has been to do something about the second-cast mess - the house's inability to find adequate replacements for singers original to a production. Thursday's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' reminded us how far this problem is from being solved.

title: Mexico City Journal; From Reviled Ex-Leader, a Double-Barreled Blast
description: On Thursday, Miguel de la Madrid will step down as President of Mexico and Carlos Salinas de Gortari will take his place. But in the cafes of the Mexican capital and on radio talk shows, the two men have suddenly been forced to share the limelight with a former President who left office six years ago under the darkest of clouds: Jose Lopez Portillo.

title: The Recruiting Of Kenny Anderson; Star Stands Firm With His Decision
description: AROUND 2 P.M. on Nov. 9, Kenny Anderson ended one of the most rigorous recruiting processes in recent New York City basketball history. The 6-foot-2-inch guard from Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens announced that he would accept a basketball scholarship to Georgia Tech next fall.

title: TV Program for Executive Job Hunters
description: Want a better job? A new career? You may be able to search from your armchair if your goals are upscale but not too upscale.

title: Seagate Cuts 980 Workers
description: Seagate Technology said Friday that it had laid off 800 full-time production employees in Singapore and 180 temporary employees at its plant at Watsonville, Calif. Seagate, the largest independent manufacturer of hard disk drives for personal computers, employs about 27,000 people worldwide, with other plants in Thailand as well as Fremont, Calif.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Alfa Romeo To Ross Roy
description: Out of a field of 100 agencies, Ross Roy Advertising, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has been chosen to handle the Alfa Romeo car account. The budget is about $10 million.

title: For Neediest, Woman Forgoes Gifts
description: Among the early gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which opened its 77th annual appeal yesterday, were contributions from Paul and Cathy Skurman of Manhattan and Barbara and Richard Meager of Spring Valley in Rockland County in honor of Celia T. Seigerman of Manhattan.

title: Compromise Candidate Picked by French Bank
description: In a move that was seen in Paris as surprising, Philippe Jaffre, 43, has been named managing director of the Caisse Nationale de Credit Agricole, France's largest bank, based on its assets of $214 billion.

title: Bard on Trial Again, And Again He Wins
description: Nearly 300 scholars, academics and literature buffs, many with notebooks and tape recorders, gathered here Saturday at Middle Temple Hall for a mock trial to determine who wrote ''Hamlet,'' ''The Tempest'' and ''Measure for Measure.''

title: Unmaking of Solidarity's Birthplace
description: Along Dock Street, at the main gate of the big Lenin shipyard, candles flicker amid flowers at the foot of towering steel crosses, recalling workers slain by the police during food riots in 1970. A decade later, on a legendary day in August 1980, accords were signed here between workers and Government representatives, giving birth and recognition to Solidarity, the East bloc's first free trade union.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Dearfoam Campaign
description: Drossman Lehmann Marino has put together a national TV campaign for the R. G. Barry Corporation's Dearfoam slippers. The campaign features the actress Zsa Zsa Gabor and is entitled ''Dearfoams Daahling.'' It will include three 30-second spots during the pre-Christmas season. The ads were directed by David Steinberg, director of the TV series ''The Golden Girls.''

title: Business and the Law; New Rules Limit Lie Detectors' Use
description: BUSINESSES that rely heavily on polygraph tests will have to look elsewhere to find out about their workers come next month.

title: Marietta Optimistic as Boom Ends
description: Norman R. Augustine, chairman of the Martin Marietta Corporation, the big aerospace and electronics company, has no doubt that the military spending boom of the Reagan years is over.

title: Soviets and Afghan Rebels in First Talks
description: Four Soviet representatives met here today for the first time with members of the Afghan guerrilla alliance fighting to overthrow the Communist Government in Kabul.

title: Ex-Officer at Citicorp Is Norwest President
description: Richard M. Kovacevich, a former Citicorp banker who developed Citibank's consumer operation, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Norwest Corporation, a big banking company based in Minneapolis.

title: Jordan to Be Honored
description: Barbara C. Jordan is remembered in the capital as a three-term Democratic Congresswoman from Texas, but on Thursday she is to be honored for her work in an entirely different field.

title: Britain Clears Harrods Deal
description: The British Government said Friday that it was not calling in its monopolies panel to examine a controversial 1985 takeover by three Egyptian-born brothers of the company that owns London's famous Harrods department store.

title: Reviews/Dance; Motions of the Elements
description: Nadine Helstroffer's choreography appears to be inspired by winds and waves. The dances she presented Monday night at the Washington Square Methodist Church were filled with gusts and eddies of movement.

title: Retarded Man Found After 3-Day Search
description: A 30-year-old retarded man who strayed from his group at the Thanksgiving Day parade in Manhattan was found yesterday in good condition in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Targets for Canada Bank
description: The Royal Bank of Canada continues to be interested in acquiring a United States bank, but so far the purchase prices have been too high, its chairman, Allan Taylor, told financial analysts Thursday. ''We continue to see the U.S. as a great opportunity for us in the future,'' he said. But, institutions that Royal Bank has been interested in would have cost more than two and a half times book value, he added. That, along with amortized good will associated with the transaction, would keep Royal Bank from its target of an 18 percent return on equity.

title: On Your Own; A Folding Sled For All Ages
description: Gordon Kennel, a rancher in Havre, Mont., recalls watching children sledding down a hill one wintry day. They would run and belly-flop onto the sleds at the start. But as often as not, the sled runners would dig into the ground, stalling the descent.

title: Mississippi Paper Is Transformed Into an Outsider
description: A sense of loss envelops the people of this old river town, not because the Mississippi no longer flows past the foot of Main Street (the Army Corps of Engineers detoured it 35 years ago to eliminate a bend), but because their newspaper, The Delta Democrat-Times, seems to have bypassed them as well.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Shuttle Flight Readied Behind a Curtain of Secrecy
description: The second space shuttle mission since the Challenger disaster is scheduled this week, but there will be no fanfare, no daily news conferences, not even the usual press kit about the crew, payload and mission. The flight of the shuttle Atlantis is a strictly military operation cloaked in secrecy.

title: Bid for Air New Zealand
description: A second group announced that it was bidding for up to 100 percent of Air New Zealand Ltd., the country's profitable domestic and international carrier. The investment bank DFC New Zealand Ltd. said it was bidding in conjunction with British Airways P.L.C. and the EIE Development Company, a Japanese investment company. Brierley Investments Ltd. and Qantas Airways Ltd. of Australia have already announced that they are leading a consortium seeking to buy the airline.

title: Kean Hints He Has Rejected A Job in Bush Administration
description: Governor Kean said in a television interview today that he had been offered a post in the Administration of President-elect George Bush but that he wanted to remain chief executive of New Jersey.

title: Allied Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment losses of $113,875 for the quarter and investment gains of $269,672 for the 9 months. c-Includes investment gains of $69,152 and $110,660 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest and year-ago 9 months included fresh start tax benefits of $354,000 and $495,000, respectively.

title: Jacobs Group Buys Stake in Shaklee
description: A group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has bought a 6.39 percent stake in the Shaklee Corporation and said it might determine to seek control of the direct marketing and sales concern, based in San Francisco. Shaklee has 13.1 million shares outstanding. The company's shares rose $1.50 in New York Stock Exchange trading today, closing at $26.75. At that price the company is worth about $350 million.

title: Andean Condors Readied for U.S. Study
description: Scientists are preparing to release six Andean condors into the wild in an experiment aimed at saving California condor from extinction.

title: Arafat, Elevated
description: Secretary of State George Shultz erred badly when he denied Yasir Arafat a chance to address the United Nations. The decision does nothing to encourage diplomacy. It shifts the focus of debate from the P.L.O.'s inability to speak clearly about peace with Israel to America's unwillingness to listen. It insults the U.N.

title: Bonn Calls for Group of 7 Talks Soon After Jan. 20
description: West Germany today added its voice to calls for an early meeting of the United States and its leading trading partners.

title: OPEC SIGNS ACCORD TO LOWER OUTPUT FOR HALF A YEAR
description: After days of contentious negotiations, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ratified an agreement today in which for the first time in two years all 13 members accepted a quota system intended to limit production and raise oil prices.

title: Egyptian Scroll Called Oldest Geological Map
description: A 3,100-year-old papyrus scroll, depicting gold mines in ancient Egypt, is probably the oldest surviving geological map and earliest evidence of geological thought, two American researchers have concluded.

title: 3-D Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Prior-year results are not available since the company did not have sales prior to Jan. 1. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Belgrade Journal; A Serb Patriot to the Core, but Is That Enough?
description: Proud Serbs by the thousands have been breaking two cardinal rules of Yugoslav politics by marching around with portraits of Serbia's Communist Party leader, Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Drug-Test Program May Start Quickly
description: Random drug testing of athletes training for the Olympics might begin as early as next spring, according to the top official of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Burnup & Sims Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said it had redeemed for $39 million in cash all of its outstanding preferred stock issued to affiliates of American Financial Corp. in connection with the July 11 purchase of the Posner block of Burnup & Sims stock.

title: From Africa to Jersey, a Relief Worker Fights Poverty
description: There are not many people in New Jersey, America or indeed the world who know poverty as Dawit Wolde Giorgis does.

title: An Iranian Health Authority Is Reported Slain at a Clinic
description: Kazem Sami, Iran's first Health Minister after the 1979 Islamic revolution, was killed last Wednesday, the Iranian press agency said on Saturday.

title: A.T.&T. Services
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it plans to accelerate the introduction of a new class of digital telephone services designed for business customers. A.T.&T. said the services, now offered in 18 United States cities, would be available in another 44 cities by June 30, 1989, six months earlier than previously planned. More cities will be added later in 1989. The services are A.T.&T.'s first to use the integrated services digital network, or I.S.D.N, a set of tentative global technical standards that allow voice, computer data and video to combine.

title: Hoping to Repair Defects, Doctors Take Aim at Gene Targets
description: SCIENTISTS are closing in on the long-sought goal of changing and even repairing individual genes within living cells. The concept is known as ''gene targeting,'' the creation of a specific genetic change exactly when and where the scientist wants it.

title: Dealers Bid for a Share Of Art Auctions' Success
description: A show-and-sell art fair that is a first of its kind for New York is to run for five days in mid-February at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 66th Street. The Art Show, as it is called, is meant to reveal the rich resources of the city's art dealers, and take the competitive edge off the glamorous appeal of the auction houses.

title: City Council Challenges Mayor Over Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Analysis & Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Medical Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains from tax loss carryforwards of $136,932 for the quarter and $274,156 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a loss from a litigation settlement of $4,238,600. c-Net income d-Included gains from tax credits of $117,936 and $323,041 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Insteel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $445,000 for the quarter and $2,220,000 for the year; the year also included a gain of $600,000 from an accounting change. c-After net from discontinued operations of $257,000 for the quarter and $948,000 for the year, and a tax credit of $346,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,231,000 from an accounting change for the year. Insteel said it elected to adopt FASB 96 effective for the 1988 fiscal year.

title: Qmax Technology Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Painting by Manet Is Stolen At Museum on Long Island
description: Someone, carrying an oil painting by Manet worth more than $1 million, walked out the front door of the Heckscher Museum here on Sunday afternoon, museum officials said today.

title: Harrier Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company reported no revenue for the year-ago first quarter when it was in the development stage.

title: In Major Drug Case, A Woman Gets Life
description: The first woman ever convicted under the Federal drug kingpin law was sentenced to life in prison Monday by a judge who called her dealings the ''moral equivalent of murder.''

title: In Africa, a Cow Is Still Not Just a Cow
description: To the Editor:

title: German Prince Kills Himself After Wife Dies of Overdose
description: A 33-year-old West German Prince shot himself to death after finding his wife dead of a drug overdose, the Austrian police said today.

title: NATO ARMS COUNT SHOWS EAST AHEAD
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's latest compilation of conventional military strengths in Europe continues to show quantitative superiority of the East bloc over the West.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The State of New York yesterday priced a $500 million issue of tax- and revenue-anticipation notes that will mature on Jan. 31, 1989, through Shearson Lehman Hutton as sole underwriter. The firm was awarded the issue after submitting the winning bid in competition.

title: Home Office Software
description: IT is a familiar predicament: A computer could undoubtedly streamline some aspects of your professional or personal life, but you are unwilling to invest the time required to learn complicated, general-purpose programs and then adapt them to your purposes.

title: Isomedix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $631,271 from an accounting change. The latest 9 months included a $93,600 after-tax charge for costs of responding to an unsolicited tender offer. The year-ago 9 months included a $95,200 after-tax charge for corporate restructuring.

title: Andersen Plans a Restructuring
description: In an attempt to remedy a growing discontent among its consulting partners, Arthur Andersen & Company today proposed to revise its compensation system and to restructure its business into separate consulting and accounting operations.

title: Block, H & R Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NORTH SEEKS USE OF CLASSIFIED DATA
description: Attorneys for Oliver L. North asserted today that the former White House aide had a constitutional right to use 40,000 pages of classified documents at his trial on charges stemming from the Iran-contra affair.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $152,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4,716,000 and $8,918,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a non-recurring gain from the settlement of certain pension plans of $5,879,000, pretax, for both periods. Sales are from continuing operations.

title: PATTERNS
description: Markdowns vs. Bargains

title: Bethlehem Is Canceling Christmas Celebrations
description: The town where Jesus was born has canceled its traditional Christmas celebrations in solidarity with the yearlong revolt against Israeli occupation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bond International Gold Inc., London, a mining company, appointed as a director Dr. Hugo E. R. Uyterhoeven, a professor of business administration at Harvard Business School.

title: Theory Ties Earthquakes In Pacific To El Nino
description: IN a radical new theory, researchers have suggested that events on the ocean floor, rather than in the atmosphere and at the sea surface, may trigger the enormous shifts in Pacific Ocean currents and air pressure known as El Ninos. These reversals in the equatorial Pacific cause changes in water temperature and climate over several continents, often with catastrophic effects.

title: Court Unit Asks Ouster of Judge Over Free Loans
description: A New York State investigative panel called yesterday for the removal of Jerome D. Cohen as a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn after finding that he had obtained interest-free loans improperly in return for funneling trust funds he controlled to a credit union.

title: Despair, Thy Name is Squirrel-Control
description: LEAD: Those who confidently subscribe to the theory of evolution have never tried to keep gray squirrels out of a bird feeder. The half dozen squirrels that call our backyard home thoroughly understand my nature and habits and have long since made me their Pavlovian experiment.

title: Judge Halts Bid for Church's
description: A Federal district judge in New Orleans issued a temporary injunction today against A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., the owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken, which is waging a hostile takeover battle for its rival, Church's Fried Chicken Inc., of San Antonio.

title: SYRIANS ROUND UP PRO-IRANIAN GROUP
description: Syrian soldiers tightened security in West Beirut today and rounded up scores of suspected members of a pro-Iranian Shiite Muslim fundamentalist group, the Party of God.

title: A German Plan On Markets
description: West Germany's Finance Minister proposed changes in the Government's financial market regulations today in an effort to halt the flow of trading in bonds and stocks to foreign financial centers. The key item in the proposals, drawn up by a panel of experts, is a legal framework for a futures and options exchange.

title: Hart's 1984 Campaign Agrees To Pay $12,000 Civil Penalty
description: Gary Hart's 1984 Presidential campaign has agreed to pay a $12,000 civil penalty to the Federal Election Commission for election law violations that include the former Colorado Senator's use of a personal credit card for expenses that should have been paid by the campaign.

title: Careers; Temporary Positions for Executives
description: THE rent-an-executive business has plenty of potential in these days of management cutbacks and quick takeovers.

title: Reagan's Last Budget Is Expected To Suggest 2-Year Spending Plans
description: President Reagan is expected to recommend in his last budget that Federal spending plans be prepared for at least two years at a time, a proposal that could ease President-elect Bush's struggles to lower the deficit.

title: Review/City Ballet; Unruly Passions and a Thin Veneer
description: George Balanchine's ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet'' is a long, grandiose and slightly strange ballet. But once one gets used to its oddities, it can be rewarding to watch since it contains fine roles for many dancers, as was demonstrated on Sunday when the New York City Ballet offered it, with slightly different casts, at both the matinee and evening performances at the New York State Theater.

title: Small Towns Build Artificial Wetlands to Treat Sewage
description: SCIENTISTS are helping communities achieve low-cost sewage treatment by designing and building artificial marshes that can clean sewage as well as, or better than, conventional treatment plants while providing other benefits to wildlife and the environment.

title: DEBATE EMERGING ON MISSILE OUTLAY
description: In a sign of emerging debate between outgoing and incoming administration officials, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that the country could not afford the Midgetman missile, which has been backed by President-elect Bush's designated national security adviser.

title: Sununu Sees Himself in Background
description: For some who have held the White House chief-of-staff job, the emphasis in the title was clearly on the chief rather the staff.

title: Stake in Beverly Enterprises Held
description: The Los Angeles investor David H. Murdock has bought a 6.3 percent stake in Beverly Enterprises Inc., a Pasadena, Calif., long-term health care company that has been dealing with losses and regulatory complaints of poor care of patients.

title: Cuomo Seeks Halt in Funds For Mergers
description: The Cuomo administration asked the trustee of New York State's $36 billion pension fund today to halt further investment in corporate takeovers.

title: Stocks End Mixed After Seesaw Session
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday after another seesaw session, with analysts saying the market got some encouragement from a higher dollar and rising bond prices.

title: Margeotes Account
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss is taking on the American Standard plumbing and fixtures account. The budget is $5 million. Initially, 14 agencies participated in the six-week review. The other two agencies left in the final round were Della Femina, McNamee WCRS and Chiat/Day. The former agency is Kornhauser & Calene.

title: Advanced Micro Official Reported Going to Actel
description: John East, one of the key executives at Advanced Micro Devices Inc., has resigned from the struggling semiconductor company and is expected to be named the chief executive officer of a start-up company, the Actel Corporation, later this week, industry sources said.

title: Judge Freezes the U.S. Assets of a Fugitive Greek Banker
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday froze the United States assets of a fugitive Greek banker who has been indicted in Greece in a $300 million scandal that has shaken the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Giants' Hopes Are on the Rise
description: As Paul McFadden's winning place-kick found its wobbly way through the goal post in the New Orleans Superdome Sunday night, the Giants' playoff chances also soared a little - from poor to fair, at the least.

title: Fed Backs Irving Deal
description: The Bank of New York Corporation received final approval from the Federal Reserve Board yesterday to acquire all of the shares of the Irving Bank Corporation. The Fed's official sanction frees the Bank of New York to buy the shares of Irving that have been tendered to it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers 109, 76ers 104: Magic Johnson had 32 points, 20 assists and 11 rebounds last night as the Lakers ended the 76ers' four-game winning streak. James Worthy had 27 points and Byron Scott added 18 for the Lakers, who won for the fourth time in five games. Charles Barkley had 31 points and 23 rebounds for the 76ers. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who was honored before the game by the capacity crowd of 18,168 at the Spectrum, scored 13 points.(AP) N.H.L. Oilers 7, Nordiques 4: Jari Kurri and Jimmy Carson each scored two goals last night for the visiting Oilers. Keith Acton, Craig MacTavish and Kelly Buchberger also scored for Edmonton.(AP) TENNIS Provis Advances: Nicole Provis of Australia defeated Allison Scott yesterday to advance to the second round of the $100,000 Southern Cross Classic tournament in Adelaide, Australia. Provis, seeded second and a French Open semifinalist last May, trailed by 5-2 in the second set before coming back to beat her Australian opponent, 6-4, 7-5. In other first-round matches, Laura Garrone of Italy, seeded eighth, was beaten by Rachel McQuillan of Australia, 7-6, 6-4; Catarina Linqvist of Sweden, seeded fourth, beat Jo-Anne Faull of Australia, 6-2, 4-6, 6-1; Tine Scheuer-Larsen of Denmark beat Pam Jung of the United States, 6-3, 6-4; Dianne Balestrat of Australia, seeded sixth, defeated Cecilia Dahlman of Sweden, 6-1, 6-3, and Olga Tsarbopoulou of Greece downed Laura Lapi of Italy, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) HORSE RACING Happy Cherokee Is Winner: Happy Cherokee, with Robert Thibeau Jr. aboard, led for most of the race in scoring a 2 1/4-length victory in the $41,000 Indian Maiden Handicap for fillies and mares 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Running over a sloppy track, Happy Cherokee dueled for command into the stretch with the favored Clever Power before racing ahead. Barbicue Sauce rallied to be runner-up in the field of four, a neck ahead of Clever Power. Hardeeni was the trailer. The victory was the third in 13 starts this year for Happy Cherokee, who earned $24,600 for Harry T. Mangurian after covering six furlongs in 1:12 2/5. The winner returned $14 and $5.80 for $2. Barbicue Sauce paid $6.40. There was no show betting.(AP)

title: Details of Eight Years in the Life Of the Beatles as They Worked
description: ''Imagine what it was like for me, walking into Abbey Road Studios, opening tape boxes that had not been touched since they were shelved 20 years ago, and listening through professional equipment to the Beatles' recording-session tapes,'' said Mark Lewisohn, describing the major part of his research for his new book, ''The Beatles Recording Sessions: The Official Abbey Road Studio Session Notes 1962-1970.''

title: Oil-Dri Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Malcolm Monroe, Philanthropist, 71
description: Malcolm Monroe, president of the Jay R. Monroe Memorial Foundation, a philanthropic organization with headquarters in Millburn, N.J., died of intestinal cancer Nov. 21 at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Kingman Brewster Service
description: A memorial for Kingman Brewster, former president of Yale University and former Ambassador to Britain, who died on Nov. 8, will be held at 2 P.M. Saturday in the Battell Chapel at Elm and Chapel Streets in New Haven.

title: Coach Resigns
description: After a second season in which his team won only one game, Leon Fuller, the head football coach at Colorado State, resigned yesterday. In his seven seasons, Fuller had a record of 25-55. After Saturday's 32-28 loss to Tulsa, the Rams finished at 1-10. They had a 1-11 mark a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia described American-Ethiopian diplomatic relations incorrectly in some copies. They were downgraded in 1980 when Ethiopia asked for the recall of the American Ambassador; they were not severed.

title: Albany's Duty on City Schools
description: In the wake of allegations of wrongdoing on several local school boards, Mayor Koch, Robert Wagner Jr., the Board of Education president, and Schools Chancellor Richard Green are in Albany to push for badly needed school reforms. At least three items awaiting final action deserve more active support from the Senate majority leader, Warren Anderson, and the Senate Education Committee chairman, James Donovan.

title: Injury for Peete
description: Rodney Peete, the Southern Cal quarterback, has a slight separation of his left shoulder. X-rays disclosed the injury, which occurred late in the first half of his team's 27-10 loss to Notre Dame last Saturday when he was sacked by Frank Stams.

title: Reviews/Music; Shifts in 'Cav' and 'Pag'
description: At Saturday's matinee of ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci,'' the Metropolitan Opera squandered an opportunity, modest but appreciable, in a way that is emblematic of some of the house's - and Italian opera's - problems.

title: Leonid Bolotine, 87, Violinist and Guitarist
description: Leonid Bolotine, a violinist and guitarist, died of heart failure on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Salomon Will Move to Trade Center
description: A year after withdrawing from a controversial plan for high-rise offices in Columbus Circle, Salomon Brothers, the securities concern, said yesterday that it would move its headquarters and 3,000 workers to the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan.

title: ARABS AT U.N. SET ARAFAT STRATEGY
description: Arab delegates agreed today on a step-by-step approach to counter the American decision to bar an appearance by Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, before the General Assembly.

title: Executing the Emperor Could Not End Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gunshots Cost Hospitals $429 Million, Study Says
description: Injuries caused by firearms cost an estimated $429 million a year in hospital expenses alone and 85.6 percent of that is borne by taxpayers, according to three epidemiologists at the University of California at San Francisco.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories, Abbott Park, Ill., said it expects the Food and Drug Administration to approve its blood test for HTLV-1, a rare and fatal form of leukemia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Jackie Mason's appearance at the Palladium in London misidentified A-Ha, a performing group in the show. It is a Norwegian pop-music group based in England.

title: Fine Feathers: More Men Are Paying the Price
description: Calling all peacocks. Men's wear, traditionally practical and conservative, has taken a turn toward the outrageous, not so much in cut and silhouette as in extravagant fabrics, detailing and, of course, prices. Try these on for size:

title: Identix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.F.L. Notebook; Harbaugh to Start for Bears
description: Jim Harbaugh was learning the tedious lesson rookie quarterbacks must endure. On most teams - especially winning ones - rookies do not start at quarterback. It takes time -a lot more time than Harbaugh imagined.

title: Supreme Court; Justices Will Address Labor Role in Railroad Sales
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a labor issue of mounting concern to the railroad industry and its workers: whether a railroad that sells part of its operations to another company is required to bargain with its employees over the impact of the sale on job security and working conditions.

title: LARGE BANKS RAISE PRIME LOAN RATE TO 10 1/2% FROM 10%
description: In a move that was quickly followed by other large banks, the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday raised its prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 10 1/2 percent.

title: Rifts on Mars
description: Scientists have detected signs that Mars, whose planetary crust is now geologically quiet, went through an earlier phase in which tectonic rifts similar to California's San Andreas Fault allowed its crust to slip and slide like that of the Earth today.

title: An Opportunity on Ethics, Trashed
description: With his pocket veto of a bipartisan ethics bill, President Reagan threw away the chance to strike a blow for clean government and repair his own damaged reputation on the ''sleaze'' issue. That leaves an essential piece of unfinished business for which President-elect Bush shares responsibility.

title: Reviews/Television; Anthology of Specials From Barbara Walters
description: Once upon a time, Norman Mailer published a collection of his essays under the title ''Advertisements for Myself.'' Tonight at 9 o'clock on ABC, Barbara Walters is offering video clips from her past in a two-hour album called ''The 50th Barbara Walters Special.''

title: Tension Called High In Armenia Capital, With 1,400 Arrests
description: More than 1,400 people were detained overnight for curfew violations in Yerevan, the capital of the uneasy southern republic of Armenia, during the weekend, according to an editor at the official Armenian press agency.

title: Savings Industry Crisis Plan
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board raised the possibility today that it would ask for emergency powers to remove the management of savings and loan institutions that are ailing but not yet insolvent. The board also took a step toward substantially raising the capital requirements of savings associations.

title: Pennies for a Plaque
description: Four years ago, Washington's unprepossessing though historic Rhodes Tavern was demolished to make way for new construction, despite years of efforts by preservationists.

title: Grand Met Extends Bid for Pillsbury
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. extended for the fifth time its $60-a-share cash tender offer for the Pillsbury Company while it battles in court to overcome Pillsbury's takeover defenses. The tender offer now is scheduled to expire at midnight Friday. So far, 85.3 percent of Pillsbury's outstanding shares have been tendered and not withdrawn, Grand Met said.

title: The Relief About OPEC
description: Americans have less to fear from a strong Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries than from one in disarray, oil experts say. Page D6.

title: Sale Near on 2 Teams
description: The Quebec Nordiques and the Toronto Argonauts, both owned by Carling O'Keefe Breweries, are to be sold to different buyers this week, the Nordiques and a Toronto newspaper said yesterday.

title: Banister Continental Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. and Soviet Union Extend Grain Pact
description: The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to extend their grain pact for 27 more months. The agreement will allow the Russians to buy millions of tons of wheat, corn and soybeans, and it will provide billions of dollars in business for American farmers.

title: Study of Dust Storms
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union will undertake a joint study of dust storms and their effect on climate, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: Healthdyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $120,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 9 months; the quarter also included a gain of about $330,000 from the sales of investment securities, a charge of $229,000 for restructuring the company and in financial and legal costs relating to a takeover proposal from Continental Health Affiliates Inc. c-Included an extraordinary tax charge of $365,000 for the quarter; the 9 months included a tax credit of $135,000 and $2.9 million in gains on the sale of investment securities.

title: Big Gasoline Price Rise Is Considered Unlikely
description: American motorists will probably see little change in prices at the gas pump despite the agreement signed today by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce production sharply in an attempt to bolster oil prices.

title: Behind Abnormal Fears, Normal Aches and Pains
description: HYPOCHONDRIACS do have something different about them, but it is not the elusive diseases that they are convinced they suffer.

title: Ozzie G. Simmons, 69, Sociology Researcher
description: Dr. Ozzie G. Simmons, a sociologist and anthropologist who lectured and conducted research at several educational institutions, died of lung cancer Saturday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived in River Vale, N.J.

title: 2 Families to Sue New Haven In Teen-Agers' River Deaths
description: The families of two of the four teen-agers who died when their car went down a closed road and into a river will file a lawsuit against the city, charging it with responsibility for the deaths, the families' lawyer said today.

title: Minority Recruiters for Bush
description: The Bush transition office today named a team to recruit women, blacks and Hispanic officials for the new administration. They are Betty Heitman, a former co-chairman of the Republican National Committee, Jose E. Martinez, a Texan who worked on the Bush campaign, and Constance Newman, a former assistant secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Honda Keeps The Stealth
description: Although the Air Force introduced its B-2 Stealth bomber last week, Rubin Postaer & Associates wants the world to know that it will continue to run its magazine ads for the Honda CRX that feature an almost-life-size mockup of the supposedly secret plane. After all, the agency disclosed its Stealth first. The shop got a jump on the

title: Addendum
description: * Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners has formed a technology marketing group to provide services to hardware, software and telecommunications companies.

title: Athletics Sign Moore
description: The Oakland Athletics solidified an already strong starting rotation yesterday by signing the free agent pitcher Mike Moore to a three-year contract.

title: Executing the Emperor Could Not End Wars; Role of Japanese Navy
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-GTE Executive Named Chief of FPL
description: James L. Broadhead, former president of the GTE Corporation's telephone operations, was named yesterday to be president and chief executive of the FPL Group, which owns the Florida Power and Light Company, the Colonial Penn Group, and other subsidiaries.

title: Elderly Depend on Those Painted Subway Steps
description: To the Editor:

title: Convicted Dominican Ex-Leader Going Home
description: Salvador Jorge Blanco, a former President of the Dominican Republic who has been convicted in abstentia on charges of corruption, said yesterday that he would return to his country on Wednesday to try to reopen the case and defend his honor.

title: Merchants Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included goodwill writedowns of $2,589,000 for the quarter and $10,443,000 for the 9 months; the quarter also included restructuring charges of $1.6 million, and a $400,000 provision for an estimated loss on the sale of the company's mutual fund management subsidiary, and the 9 months also included restructuring charges of about $2 million. c-Net income

title: Benihana National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $826,311 for the quarter and $1,152,113 for the 6 months.

title: 'Samaritan' Is Imprisoned In Drug Case
description: A Brooklyn man who came to the aid of a mugging victim - shooting and killing one assailant and wounding another - pleaded for mercy yesterday but was sentenced to 1 1/2 to 4 1/2 years in state prison for an earlier drug conviction.

title: Biocraft Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
State Dept. Excludes the Blind as Diplomats
description: The State Department, after a decade of accepting Foreign Service job applications from blind people, has ruled that they are not suited to be American diplomats.

title: Why Evan Bayh Won Indiana Governor's Race
description: To the Editor:

title: HANOI TROOPS FOIL KHMER ROUGE PLAN
description: Two weeks of heavy shelling by the Vietnamese have driven back several thousand Cambodian refugees who had been moved close to the Thai-Cambodian border by the Khmer Rouge, relief officials said today.

title: Iraqi Chief Pays an Impromptu Call on Egypt
description: To the surprise of Egyptian leaders, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq flew unannounced into Cairo today for his first visit since Baghdad formally restored relations with Egypt a year ago.

title: Good Will and Progress Mark a Brief Tenure
description: A bit of Irish luck seems to have rubbed off on C. William Verity Jr., the pixyish retired steel company chairman who over the last 14 months has managed the Commerce Department as its 27th Secretary.

title: John Rogan, 71, Dies; A Virginia Developer
description: John B. Rogan, developer of the Boar's Head Inn and other properties in Charlottesville, Va., died of gastrointestinal cancer on Saturday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville. He was 71 years old and lived at Oakencroft Farm in Charlottesville.

title: Experimental Transplant Alters Biological 'Clock'
description: SCIENTISTS have for the first time altered the basic biological rhythms of animals by transplanting a small area of brain tissue believed to serve as the body's master ''clock.''

title: Central Maine In Bond Offering
description: The Central Maine Power Company is offering $75 million of general refunding and mortgage bonds due in 2018 through Kidder, Peabody.

title: Horizon Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Man Shoots and Kills Boy Aiming Toy Gun
description: A man apparently annoyed by a boy making faces and pointing a toy gun at him shot and killed the child Sunday through a window of the boy's home, the state police said today.

title: E.D.S. Buys Videostar Connections
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today that it had acquired Videostar Connections Inc., a privately held company specializing in satellite broadcasting services, for an undisclosed amount earlier this month.

title: Green Offers to Protect Those Telling of School Corruption
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor said yesterday that school employees who reported wrongdoing would generally be protected against ''adverse personnel actions'' but that the protection would not extend to those who had themselves ''engaged in improper or illegal activities.''

title: Merrill Lynch Restructuring
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced the formation of a new merchant banking group, to be managed by Jeffrey L. Berenson and Raymond J. Minella, and said it had restructured its mergers and acquisitions operations.

title: Peruvian Official Quits
description: Economy Minister Abel Salinas has resigned only a few days after announcing austerity measures aimed at ending the country's economic crisis.

title: Theodore Morrison, Poet and Professor, 87
description: Theodore Morrison, a former professor of English and creative writing at Harvard, a poet, and the author of several novels, died Sunday at the Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: 2 MIAMI POLICEMEN SLAIN IN STRUGGLE
description: Two police officers were disarmed and fatally shot in the head today as they struggled with a man who had been released from prison 10 days ago, the police said.

title: Suit Filed to Protest Firehouse Closings
description: The Brooklyn and Bronx Borough Presidents, joined by the head of the firefighters' union, sued Mayor Koch and the city yesterday to block the closing of a firehouse and force the reopening of another.

title: Calprop Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CDI Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,639,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Integrated Computer Graphcs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $682,544 for the quarter and $1,080,913 for the 6 months, and a loss of $1,023,135 from the disposal of discontinued operations for the both periods. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $130,377 for the quarter and $166,091 for the 6 months.

title: Stone Age 'Factory' Discovered in Australia
description: Archaeologists have discovered a huge Stone Age site where aborigines crafted stone blades and cutting tools for barter 2,000 years ago.

title: Elliott Is First
