description: Bill Elliott of Dawsonville, Ga., who won the 1988 Nascar Winston Cup stock-car racing championship in the third-closest point chase in history, finished the season as the circuit's leading money-winner.

title: Gottschalks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After a gain of $689,000 from an accounting change.

title: Most at High Risk Don't Get Flu Shot
description: Although state and local flu vaccine programs are increasing, only about 20 percent of people at high risk of complications from the flu are immunized against the disease each year, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: On Horse Racing; One Viewer's Most Stirring Thoroughbred Moments in '88
description: What were the best thoroughbred races of the year?

title: ACC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $592,657 for the quarter and $757,939 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $148,457. d-Net loss and includes a loss of $195,489 from discontinued operations.

title: Plan to Cut Federal Health Payments Draws Fire
description: President Reagan's Office of Management and Budget has proposed that Medicare and Medicaid payments be allowed to grow $7 billion less than currently projected, prompting strong opposition from Congressional leaders and health professionals.

title: Republican Says It's Not a Budget Gap
description: Rejecting Gov-ernor Cuomo's analysis of the state's financial troubles, the chairman of the State Senate Finance Committee, John J. Marchi, said today that New York is facing not a huge revenue shortfall but an ''easily manageable'' cash flow problem.

title: Investors Savings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TVI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $174,000 and a loss of $75,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $101,000 and $127,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect year-end adjustments.

title: Business and Health; Employers Unite To Improve Care
description: IF the Boeing Company could buy health care for its employees as carefully as it buys parts for its airplanes, its medical bill might look a little less intimidating. So Boeing has decided to join other employers in the Seattle area in studying the formation of a purchasing group for medical services. Like its parts-buying counterparts, the health-care purchasing group would try to select a supplier - in this case, a network of hospitals and doctors - that offers high quality at a good price.

title: A.& S. Opening In Manhattan in '89
description: The Campeau Corporation said that Abraham & Straus would open its first Manhattan store in the A.& S. Plaza development in mid-August of 1989. The Plaza, occupying the former Gimbels store building, will face the Avenue of the Americas between 32d and 33d Streets. A.& S. will occupy the first eight floors of the Plaza's 11 floors.

title: Walker Street Buys 7.4% of Intergroup
description: Walker Street Associates L.P., an investment partnership, has acquired a 7.4 percent stake in National Intergroup Inc. and said it might propose a leveraged buyout of the Pittsburgh-based holding company, which has interests in steel, oil and pharmaceuticals.

title: Antimatter Study Urged
description: Research into antimatter, a rare, enigmatic form of matter, is so important and so close to a series of breakthroughs that its growth should be speeded with an infusion of $400 million over the next decade, a report made public yesterday by the RAND Corporation says. The corporation is a private research group in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Skolnik's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Chess
description: Maya Chiburdanidze of the Soviet Union won the women's world championship last month by defeating her countrywoman Nana Ioseliani in their title match in Telavi in the Soviet Republic of Georgia.

title: The Old Jew and the Cardinal
description: On a March day in 1938, Theodor Cardinal Innitzer drove up to the Imperial Hotel in Vienna.

title: Pro-Dex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GORBACHEV PLANS GET PARTY BACKING
description: The Communist Party Central Committee today approved constitutional changes proposed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that have stirred strong opposition in some Soviet republics.

title: CVN Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and includes an investment gain of $1.3 million. c-Net loss and included the fourth quarter investment gain of $1.3 million. Year-ago figures were restated to reflect the change of the company's reporting period to an Aug. 31 year from a calendar year. CVN Cos. said the results for 1988 include the full operating results of Cable Value Network, which became a wholly owned subsidiary in August 1987.

title: The Toast of Paris?
description: Next year, it has been noted, will mark the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution. But - attention trivia buffs! - it will also mark the 150th anniversary of France's diplomatic recognition of the Republic of Texas. With several Texans, including James A. Baker 3d as Secretary of State, in the Cabinet of a Texan President, George Bush, this could bring up interesting situations.

title: John Carradine, Actor, 82, Dies; Appeared in Numerous Film Roles
description: John Carradine, a lanky, saturnine character actor who appeared in more that 200 films and, on screen or the stage, played roles as disparate as Hamlet and Dracula, died Sunday in a hospital in Milan. He was 82 years old.

title: Fluorocarbon Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Holco Mortgage Acceptance I reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago quarter reflected period from Aug. 26, 1987 issuance of company's stock.

title: Steinberg Hit Lisa in Face, Witness Says
description: A witness testified yesterday that Joel B. Steinberg struck a sleeping Lisa Steinberg on the side of her face 13 days before she died from a beating the prosecution contends Mr. Steinberg gave her.

title: TRIAL CHALLENGES RIGHTS OF CASINOS
description: The right of Nevada casinos to hire and dismiss casino workers at will, a right the industry has had since it was legalized more than 50 years ago, is on trial in a suit brought by 37 workers dismissed by the Las Vegas Hilton.

title: Security Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Algerian Chief Named As the Sole Candidate
description: Algeria's ruling party nominated President Chadli Benjedid today as the sole candidate in presidential elections on Dec. 22.

title: Judge Removes 3 Trustees Of the Dalkon Shield Fund
description: The Federal judge supervising the bankruptcy proceeding of the A. H. Robins Company yesterday ordered the removal of three of the five trustees supervising the $2.4 billion trust for victims of the Dalkon Shield birth-control device.

title: Botha Is Urged to Legalize Banned Groups
description: In his first public appearance since his release from prison, the president of an outlawed anti-apartheid group today challenged President P. W. Botha to legalize his group and other banned political organizations.

title: Treasury Issues Advance Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in very sluggish trading yesterday despite a sharp rise in oil prices.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Heritage Media Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company also reported results for the period from Aug. 7, 1987, when it began operations, to Sept. 30, 1987. It had a loss of $2,372,000 on revenue of $6,484,000.

title: Two Die and Three Are Hurt In Los Angeles Gang Violence
description: Gang violence over the Thanksgiving weekend left two men dead and three others wounded, the police said today.

title: Lonrho Wine Unit Is Sold to Brent
description: The British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C., facing a possible takeover bid by the Australian multimillionaire Alan Bond, sold its European Wines and Spirits division to the Brent Walker Group P.L.C., a British entertainment company, raising $:180 million, or $330 million, in cash.

title: The Army's Germ Warfare Against Civilians
description: The Army's biological warfare program has drawn heavy criticism in recent months.

title: Seagram Will Pare U.S. Brands
description: At a time when many companies are chasing growth as a way to reap economies of scale, Joseph E. Seagram & Sons said yesterday that it would stop marketing 25 of the 48 distilled spirits brands that it sells in the United States.

title: Taylor's One-Arm Show
description: SOMEHOW the Giants held together for a 13-12 victory over the Saints here Sunday night on Paul McFadden's 35-yard field goal with 21 seconds remaining. And now, across their locker room Bill Belichick, the defensive coordinator, described his unit's effort as the ''most courageous'' he had ever seen.

title: Accord on Oil Has Benefits, Analysts Say
description: Fifteen years after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries convulsed world oil markets and quadrupled oil prices by sharply reducing its output, many oil analysts say that the United States has less to fear from a strong OPEC than from one in disarray.

title: Congregation in Jersey Gives Thankfully to Neediest Cases
description: Although they are mostly retired, on fixed incomes or poor, the members of the congregation of Trinity Episcopal Church in Paterson, N.J., decided to share their special Thanksgiving Day collection with The New York Times Neediest Cases.

title: The Tangle Thickens in Two Sets of East-West Talks
description: For almost two years now, negotiators from East and West and all of Europe have been wrestling to unravel a diplomatic web that entangles the future of conventional-arms negotiations and progress on human rights.

title: The Face Is Familiar Max Marlin Fitzwater
description: Marlin Fitzwater, named today as George Bush's White House spokesman, is hardly the fresh face the President-elect promised to recruit for his administration.

title: Trade Deficit Narrows For 3d Quarter in a Row
description: A drop in oil prices and higher prices for farm products helped provide a 5.4 percent improvement in the nation's trade deficit from July 1 to Sept. 30, the third consecutive quarterly decline this year, the Government reported today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL OAKLAND (AL) - Signed Mike Moore, pitcher, to a three-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Sheldon (Chief) Bender vice president for player personnel. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Traded Denny Gonzalez, infielder, to the Cleveland Indians for a player to be named later. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Activated Detlef Schrempf, forward, from the injured list. Placed Roy Tarpley, forward, on the injured list. FOOTBALL MIAMI (AFC) - Placed Mark Dennis, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. Claimed Bruce Plummer, cornerback, on waivers from the Denver Broncos. COLLEGE COLORADO STATE - Announced the resignation of Leon Fuller, football coach. TEMPLE - Announced that Bruce Arians, head football coach, has relinquished his duties in a mutual agreement with school officials.

title: Korea's Careful Path to Democracy
description: It's a dazzling time for South Korea. Its economy is churning out the world's highest growth rate. The Seoul Olympics won wide applause. And now, most impressive of all, the nation steadily consolidates a new and remarkably supple political democracy. That suppleness now faces its trickiest test. The initial response seems encouraging. Backed by broad public opinion, an opposition majority in the National Assembly demands that former President Chun Doo Hwan be held accountable for a litany of abuses, from corrupt diversion of funds to the 1980 massacre of civilians at Kwangju.

title: Holmes, D H Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $5,457,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Atlantic Southeast Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CSC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $2,304,000 from a change in method of determining cost of product inventories.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: A Small-Business Boom in Britain
description: Christopher Livingstone Canaan would seem an unlikely convert to the ''enterprise culture'' that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is trying to create in Britain. He is a 25-year-old with a punkish hairdo from the inner city of Birmingham, a stronghold of the Labor Party.

title: Notre Dame Moves to Top
description: With its 27-10 victory over Southern California last Saturday, Notre Dame moved past the Trojans into the top position in The Times's computer ranking of major college football teams. The Fighting Irish (11-0) were No. 4 in last week's poll.

title: Soviet-Afghan Talks Focused on P.O.W.'s
description: The Soviet Union said today that its weekend talks with Afghan rebel representatives, the first in the 10-year Afghan guerrilla war, were entirely confined to the question of Russians captured in the fighting.''

title: New Version Of Lotus 1-2-3 Is Revealed
description: LOTUS 1-2-3, the No. 1 spreadsheet, is the most popular software application for personal computers and a crucial tool for most businesses. It has been more than three years since the current version, 2.0, was introduced and the delay in shipping version 3.0, now scheduled for sometime in the second quarter of 1989, has prompted great turmoil within the Cambridge, Mass., company.

title: Study Faults Strategy in New York Drug Crackdown
description: New York City's new anti-crime strategy of making saturation arrests of low-level drug dealers in designated areas is destined to fail, a private research group asserted yesterday.

title: The Star Wars Program Prepares for a Year of Reckoning
description: AFTER incubating for nearly six years in laboratories across the nation, often under great secrecy, the diverse technologies of the Strategic Defense Initiative are being readied for the most extensive and costly series of experiments in the program's history.

title: Salvador Dali Is Hospitalized in Spain
description: The artist Salvador Dali was transferred to the intensive-care unit of a Barcelona hospital today after the pneumonia and heart condition he had suffered since Sunday worsened, a hospital staff member said.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Bide-A-Wee Home Association, a nonprofit animal welfare organization, to Bergelt Litchfield.

title: Let Them Be Insurers
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Yes, You Can Sue Sloane, All Right; But Win? Well...
description: Leonard Sloane lives in a beautiful home full of antiques on a large wooded lot with a pool. His wife carves delicate marble sculpture. As a yacht broker, Mr. Sloane mixes with the rich for a living, getting a 10 percent fee for each yacht he sells. ''My niche is $75,000 to $300,000 yachts,'' he said. A dapper man, a John Huston look-alike, Mr. Sloane seems younger than his 69 years. One process server who handed him a summons here thought he was 55.

title: A Successful Toy Year For Bohbot
description: THE toy industry's lackluster performance has not dimmed the holiday season for Bohbot Communications Inc.

title: James Irving Raymond, Architect, 82
description: James Irving Raymond, an architect, died Thursday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a stroke. He was 82 years old and lived in Norwalk.

title: Cencor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,560,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $993,000 and $2,202,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Reviews/Music; Roches' Moments of Truth
description: ''Nocturne,'' one of the Roches' most incisive new songs, re-creates the anxious moment when would-be casual lovers simultaneously realize that their desire has evaporated. ''My room is anxious to expel him/He hurries to be free of my feelings,'' sings the narrator, describing the rush to separate. The final image of a song punctuated with a wistful little ''la-la-la'' chorus is of a man ''looking for his shoes, a shadow in the doorway.''

title: Georgia Power reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: The year-ago period included $229 million after-tax writedown for costs in excess of a ratemaking ''cap'' for plant Vogtle. Georgia Power is a unit of the Southern Co.

title: Eminent Harvard Professor Quits Over Plagiarism, University Says
description: One of the nation's most eminent psychiatrists has resigned his positions at Harvard Medical School and as head of one of its major teaching hospitals after he admitted plagiarizing large sections of four papers he wrote in medical journals and textbooks, Harvard officials announced yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * Beauty Labs to Kirshenbaum & Bond for a new nail care product. Budget at $2 million.

title: Reviews/Television; High School Journalism Goes Video
description: Take ''Welcome Back, Kotter,'' ''The White Shadow,'' ''Head of the Class'' and any other sitcom ever set in a high school, shake well and you could effortlessly come up with ''TV 101,'' the new series beginning at 8 o'clock tonight on CBS. In this case, we get a newly divorced teacher in his late 20's returning to his old high school to teach journalism. The difference? He decides to dump the school newspaper and start a video news report controlled entirely by his students. Welcome to the 1980's.

title: Pioneer Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the results for the fiscal year included $28.5 million of loan loss provisions and valuation reserves relating primarily to income property loans, mostly in the southwestern and western U.S.

title: Shelley Duvall, Producer, Helps Nourish Cable TV
description: Shelley Duvall, the actress-turned-producer who created ''Faerie Tale Theater'' for cable television in 1982, is extending her involvement in the cable industry. Earlier this year she founded Think Entertainment, a Hollywood company that will produce movies and series for cable television.

title: Books of The Times; John Cheever's Letters Fleshed Out by His Son
description: The Letters of John Cheever Edited by Benjamin Cheever Illustrated. 397 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Arians Leaves Temple
description: Bruce Arians stepped down as head football coach of Temple yesterday in a ''mutual agreement'' with university officials.

title: KEY RATES
LATINS WANT BUSH TO HELP ON DEBTS
description: Sapped by the strain of huge foreign debt payments, Latin American governments are looking to the Bush Administration for help in preventing the growing economic turmoil from destroying the region's precarious democracies.

title: Fresno Journal; Ornery Saroyan, in Death as in Life
description: It has been more than seven years since William Saroyan, with his booming voice, walrus mustache and funny hats, died of a cancer that, with the same orneriness that made him spurn a Pulitzer Prize, he left untreated. It has been much longer than that since his literary reputation faded.

title: Europeans Plan to Study Big Moon Of Saturn
description: After six years of studying rival ideas for an international deep-space mission, the European Space Agency has decided to explore Saturn's moon Titan for information on the origin of life.

title: Market Place; The Lonely Bulls Make Their Case
description: BETTING against prevailing sentiment on Wall Street is often the right thing to do, especially when that sentiment reaches extreme levels.

title: California Acts On 2 Insurers
description: California's Insurance Commissioner, Roxani M. Gillespie, today ordered two of the state's largest auto insurers to stop their practice of writing new policies exclusively under costly high-risk plans.

title: Yes! And It Counts! Say That 302 Times
description: Loyola-Marymount tied the National Collegiate Athletic Association record for points in a basketball game tonight, beating Azusa Pacific by 164-138.

title: 2 Major Parties In Israel Reopen Coalition Talks
description: The Labor and Likud parties formally reopened negotiations to form a coalition government today after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir decided that he would agree to Labor's demand for control of half the senior posts in a new Cabinet.

title: Japanese Growth Seen
description: Japan's economy will continue to expand in the near future, the Economic Planning Agency said today as it released its monthly leading indicator. ''The basic trend remains unchanged,'' an agency official said. ''The economy has remained in an expansionary phase and will continue to do so.''

title: U.S. and Soviets Resolve a Minor Dispute on Missile Treaty
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have quietly resolved a dispute over Soviet adherence to detailed provisions of the new accord banning medium- and shorter-range missiles, officials said today.

title: New Accord in Default Case
description: Two architecture and engineering companies announced today that bondholders had agreed to accept a $25 million settlement in the litigation arising from the securities default in 1983 after two Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear plants were canceled.

title: U.S. Won't Oppose U.N. Geneva Session
description: The United States said today that it did not oppose the convening of a special session of the United Nations General Assembly in Geneva to hear Yasir Arafat, and that American diplomats intend to take part in any debate held there.

title: Pentagon to Survey Sexual Harassment In Ranks of Military
description: The Defense Department is about to start one of the most extensive surveys ever undertaken to spotlight sexual harassment in the workplace.

title: Putting Zip, Juice - Interest - Into Campaigns
description: LEAD: All the fun seems to have gone out of electing a president these days. The process used to have suspense and drama; voters got excited about their candidate; people wore buttons and went to rallies.

title: 4 Killed, 151 Injured as Tornadoes Batter Raleigh
description: Tornadoes tore through North Carolina's capital early today, smashing homes and churches. Four people were killed, including a 12-year-old boy and an 8-year-old girl, and 151 people were injured.

title: People
description: * John Leonardi has been promoted to executive vice president, creative director at Venet Advertising/New Jersey, Union, N.J.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The election is over and we both have obligations and certainly mine is to help him become a great President and I intend to do that.'' - Senator Bob Dole, after a lunch with President-elect Bush. [ B8:1. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY Banks raised their prime rate to 10 1/2 percent, from 10 percent. The increase, first announced by Chase Manhattan, is the fourth rise in the prime - all by a half-point - this year and it puts the base lending rate at its highest level since May 1985. Bankers said the increase was a reflection of their rising costs of funds. Many analysts and economists said they expected further increases in the prime in the next few months. [ Page A1. ] Emergency powers for dealing with savings institutions before they become insolvent may be requested by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The board also moved toward raising the capital requirements of savings associations. [ D1. ] The U.S. and the Soviet Union agreed to extend their grain pact for 27 months. The agreement will allow the Soviets to buy millions of tons of wheat, corn and soybeans. [ D1. ] The nation's trade deficit shrank by 5.4 percent in the third quarter, aided by a drop in the price of oil, a major import category, and higher prices for farm products, an important export. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL OPEC ratified an agreement in which for the first time in two years all 13 members accepted a quota system intended to limit production and raise oil prices. The accord sets a production limit of 18.5 million barrels of oil a day, compared with the current 23 million. OPEC is hoping to lift prices to $18 a barrel, from a current worldwide average of about $12. Crude oil rose $1.06 a barrel in New York. [ A1. ] Many oil analysts say the U.S. has less to fear from a strong OPEC than from one in disarray. [ D6. ] Motorists will probably find little change in gasoline prices. [ D6. ] COMPANIES A judge ordered three of the five trustees removed from supervision of the $2.4 billion trust set up by A. H. Robins for victims of the Dalkon Shield birth-control device. [ D1. ] Arthur Andersen proposed revisions to its compensation system and a division of its business into two operating units, consulting and accounting. [ D1. ] Manville emerged from bankruptcy, a move that enables the trusts it set up to begin paying asbestos-injury claims. [ D5. ] Salomon Brothers intends to move its headquarters and 3,000 workers to 7 World Trade Center in lower Manhattan. [ B3. ] Brown's Hotel in the Catskills was sold for $5.3 million to a Brooklyn company at a foreclosure auction. [ B6. ] MARKETS Governor Cuomo wants an end to takeover investments by New York State's pension funds. About $1 billion of the funds' money has been committed to buyout firms, officials said. [ D1. ] The dollar rose sharply on the expectation of higher interest rates. [ D20. ] West Germany added its voice to calls for an early meeting of the Group of Seven. [ D19. ] Stock prices ended mixed after another seesaw session. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.76 points, to 2,081.44. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in sluggish trading despite the sharp rise in oil prices. [ D18. ] Platinum futures soared on the New York Merc, and other precious metals posted moderate gains. [ D20. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Companies are cooperating in buying health care services in an effort to use greater leverage to control rising medical costs. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Billings are up at Bohbot Communications, even though the New York agency specializes in placing advertisements for a toy industry that is enduring a slump. Advertising. [ D25. ] Contrarians think widespread gloom is a prelude to a rally, and they are encouraged that one measure of market pessimism is at its highest level in more than six years. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Bridge
description: A very rare double marked the finale of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Sunday night. Jim Cayne, Manhattan; Chuck Burger, Detroit; Bob Hamman, Bob Wolff and Mike Passell, Dallas, and Mark Lair, Canyon, Tex., who won the Men's Board-a-Match Teams six days earlier, captured the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams title by a decisive margin. They qualify as one of four teams to represent the United States in the 1990 world championships in Geneva.

title: Dollar Increases Sharply On Belief Rates Will Rise
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday on the growing expectation of higher interest rates, a belief that was bolstered by the production agreement reached by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Article 581288 -- No Title
description: Picasso's ''Acrobat and Young Harlequin,'' a 1905 gouache from the artist's rose period depicting a pair of sad-eyed circus performers, was sold yesterday at Christie's in London for $38.45 million, a record at auction for a 20th-century artwork and the third-highest price ever paid for a painting.

title: Prospect Park Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said all per-share figures were adjusted to reflect a special 5 percent stock dividend which was declared yesterday and is payable Dec. 22 to shareholders of record Dec. 8. The company is the parent of Prospect Park Savings Bank.

title: Edward Ellenbogen, Rabbi, 76
description: Rabbi Edward Ellenbogen, who was once the ranking Jewish chaplain in the United States armed forces, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Banking on Peace
description: The Federation of American Scientists has just persuaded three of the largest banks in the United States -Citicorp, Bank of America and Manufacturers Hanover - to offer a resolution to their shareholders aimed at preventing a nuclear arms race among debt-plagued Latin American countries.

title: One Killed, One Hurt In Fiery 2-Car Crash
description: One person was killed and another was critically injured yesterday in a fiery two-car accident on Interstate 91 that shut down the northbound lanes of the highway for about 90 minutes, the state police said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are moths drawn to light? A. Insects, including moths, exhibit a complex range of responses to light and no unifying explanation has yet been found, according to Randall Schuh of the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Aritech Corp reports earnings for
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months reflected the acquisition of Moose Products Inc. in late 1987.

title: What the Host Must Not Do
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and officials of many member nations have challenged the legality of the American decision to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, who had been invited to address the General Assembly. Here are the relevant sections of Article IV of the 1947 Headquarters Agreement between the United States and the United Nations concerning the obligation of the United States as host country not to impede the travel of people on United Nations business. Section 11

title: Rig Count Dips in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs fell by 12 last week, to 911, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The decline, following a gain of 26 rigs the previous week, continues to reflect an unstable trend in the count. A year ago it stood at 1,161, Baker Hughes said. The count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity. It reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Knicks' Scoring Opens Some Eyes
description: Those who wondered during the preseason where the Knick points would come from might now be asking when was the last time a New York team averaged 121 points a game for the season, which is their current pace. The answer: Never.

title: Valley Federal Savings Bank (Sheffield, Ala) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $20,000. c-After extraordinary credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $40,000 for the year. There are no common per share earnings for the year-ago periods because the bank converted to a stock company from a mutual in October 1987.

title: Jets Unsettled at Quarterback
description: Suddenly, Joe Walton has two quarterbacks who are presenting him with a problem following their dramatic appearances in Sunday's 38-34 victory over the Dolphins.

title: Landmark Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of $982,000 for the quarter and $2,774,000 for the 9 months. c-Included tax benefits of $1,093,000 for the quarter and $3,064,000 for the 9 months.

title: Quadrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago net is equal to less than 1 cent a share.

title: Lori Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,724,000. c-After income of $707,000 for the quarter and a loss of $367,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The year-ago periods' results are restated to reflect the second quarter discontinuance of the Park Lane unit. The latest 9 months' loss from discontinued operations included a $3.6 million net charge.

title: NAMING OF BHUTTO SEEN IN PAKISTAN
description: Benazir Bhutto is expected to be named Prime Minister of Pakistan on Thursday, easing concern that the military and some conservative politicians were trying to manuever her into a coalition with her political rivals.

title: Cimco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $344,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Bush and Dole Vow to Join Efforts on Reducing Deficit
description: President-elect Bush and Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, pledged today to work together to deal with budget deficit reductions and other key issues, ending, at least publicly, a bitter rivalry.

title: By Design; Pouf Replacement
description: Ah, the pouf. A year ago this delightfully zany short and puffy evening fashion was at its zenith. Every woman seemed to think she needed one. But alas, the pouf has gone, as fads are wont to do. And while it would be fun to report that some other silhouette has been taken up with equal fervor, such is really not the case.

title: Former Head of Rolm Takes Post at Echelon
description: M. Kenneth Oshman, who co-founded and headed the Rolm Corporation for many years, will become president and chief executive of a new company founded by another Silicon Valley legend, A.C. Markkula Jr., the chief executive of Apple Computer in its early years.

title: Chimney Holds Suspect
description: Hector Medina, 27 years old, was arrested for attempted burglary today after he was found wedged in the chimney of a building. ''We knew he wasn't Santa,'' a Fire Department spokesman said after firefighters rescued Mr. Medina, who had been calling for help. ''He wasn't suited up for the part but he was somewhat covered with soot.''

title: Boeing-G.M. Project
description: The Army today named the Boeing Company and the General Motors Corporation to co-develop a new guided missile to destroy enemy tanks and helicopters in a program that could mean $2 billion in total contracts for the companies. Boeing and the Hughes Aircraft Company division of G.M. will work jointly to develop the new FOG-M fiber-optic guided missile. They will then compete against each other for production. Boeing and G.M. won out over a competing team of the Raytheon Company and the Martin Marietta Corporation. The FOG-M will be part of the Army's new Forward Area Air Defense system, intended to improve battlefield cover for ground divisions.

title: Goldfield Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $416,947 for the quarter and $701,875 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $400,950 and $545,838 for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $283,865 for the quarter and $540,387 for the 9 months. The year-ago periods were restated to include the results of discontinued mining operations.

title: Inflation Hits Peak in China
description: Inflation in China has surged to record levels despite Government countermeasures, official figures showed today.

title: Carroll's Cast Replaced
description: Doctors removed the hard cast from Joe Barry Carroll's left wrist yesterday. Carroll, who has missed the last seven games for the Nets with torn wrist ligaments, was fitted with a soft cast and may return as early as Sunday, in a home game against Detroit.

title: Hotel in Catskills Sold To Brooklyn Company
description: Brown's Hotel, a family-owned resort in the Catskill Mountains, was sold today for $5.3 million to a Brooklyn company at a foreclosure auction.

title: Bohemia Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $518,000 and $1,972,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Mutual Federal Savings & Loan (North Carolina) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
College Basketball; Seton Hall Wins Alaska Shootout
description: Ramon Ramos, Seton Hall's 6-foot-8-inch, 250-pound center, scored 10 of his 16 points in the second half tonight to help the Pirates pull away for a 92-81 victory over Kansas in the championship game of the Great Alaska Shootout.

title: Philharmonic Seeks Sponsor for Radio Series
description: The weekly radio broadcasts of concerts by the New York Philharmonic are to be suspended after the program of Dec. 25, the orchestra's managing director, Albert K. Webster, has announced. The orchestra will seek a sponsor to replace Exxon.

title: Astro-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
description: b-Year-ago share earnings has been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 15.

title: Shorewood Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Senate Democrats Focus on Picking Their Leader
description: The Senate was consumed with internal politics today as the three Democrats vying for the job of majority leader made last-minute appeals for support in a contest that will be decided Tuesday by secret ballot.

title: Loyola Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Black Executive Moves to Top of N.L. List
description: Gilroye A. Griffin Jr., a lawyer and labor-relations expert who is a vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, has emerged as a leading candidate for president of the National League, a position that would make him the highest-ranking black executive in baseball or any professional sport.

title: American Learning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a $425,000 tax benefit.

title: Jersey's Assembly Approves Bill for Aquarium in Camden
description: The State Assembly today gave final approval, on a 67-to-9 vote, to a bill appropriating $32 million for the construction of an aquarium in Camden and sent the measure to Governor Kean, who said he would sign it.

title: Pervasive Chemical, Crucial to the Body, Is Indicted as an Agent in Brain Damage
description: THE common amino acid glutamate, a protein component found in every cell of the body, plays a central role in the workings of the brain and may play a prominent role in the brain damage that results from injuries, strokes, seizures and a variety of neurological diseases, scientists are concluding.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chinese Bronze Is Withdrawn From Sale
description: An ancient bronze vessel reportedly stolen from a Chinese museum last June has been withdrawn from this morning's auction at Sotheby's.

title: Meret Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a credit of $4,450. c-After a loss of $228,224 from discontinued operations and a credit of $8,515.

title: End of a Manhunt Brings Respite in the Capital's Violent Drug War
description: The arrest of a man on charges that he committed at least three drug-related murders in Washington this year was being described today as a dramatic development in the capital city's escalating drug war.

title: INSIDE
description: Suspense in Pakistan Benazir Bhutto is expected to be named Prime Minister on Thursday.

title: Chase to Share Army Contract
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and Bear, Stearns & Company have been awarded a contract by the Army to design and underwrite a lease financing program.

title: E. J. McCormick, 76; Headed 2 Companies
description: Edmund J. McCormick, an executive and philanthropist, died of kidney failure Sunday at Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry.

title: Krieg Throws for 5
description: Dave Krieg threw five touchdown passes as the Seattle Seahawks overcame a devastating series of turnovers to beat the Los Angeles Raiders, 35-27, tonight and move into a first-place tie with Denver in the American Football Conference's West Division.

title: Suit Asserts Bias Against Women in State Scholarship Awards
description: Two women's groups and the parents of 10 high school seniors with grade point averages of at least 90 charged in Federal District Court yesterday that New York State discriminates against women in awarding $40 million a year in college scholarships.

title: Rangers Win On Late Goal
description: Three weeks ago, John Ogrodnick was badly confused. He wasn't sure about his future, except perhaps that he was convinced he didn't have one with the Rangers. He wasn't so clear about the past either: What it was that had gone so wrong, so completely wrong?

title: G.E. Charged in $22 Million Pentagon Fraud
description: A Federal grand jury today charged the General Electric Company, the Pentagon's third-largest contractor, and one of its subsidiaries with trying to defraud the Defense Department of $22 million in connection with a battlefield computer system.

title: Carter Told He's Safe as Starter for 1989
description: The Mets said yesterday that they had told Gary Carter he would not be traded this winter and would return as their regular catcher next season. But his performance next year, at the age of 35, will determine whether they will offer him a new contract beyond the 1989 season.

title: Ban Sought on Drugs to Halt Flow of Milk After Childbirth
description: Two health advocacy groups petitioned the Food and Drug Administration today to ban the use of hormones and drugs for stopping milk production and breast engorgement that is sometimes painful in women who do not breast feed after giving birth.

title: Book on Vietnam War Wins National Award
description: Neil Sheehan's 16-year effort to write a book that he hoped would clarify the Vietnam War for himself and his country, an effort that culminated in the publication earlier this year of ''A Bright Shining Lie,'' was rewarded last night when the book was named winner of the 1988 National Book Awards for nonfiction.

title: U.S. Warns on Global Trade Talks
description: The top United States trade negotiator said today that no agreement would be preferable to a ''bad'' agreement in the global trade talks that begin next week in Montreal.

title: Fretter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $630,036 from an accounting change.

title: Primerica's Executive Windfall
description: The incumbent management of the Primerica Corporation will enjoy a $98.2 million windfall after the sale of the company to the Commercial Credit Corporation, according to newly public company documents.

title: Honeywell's Chip Plans
description: Honeywell Inc. said it would sell a substantial part of its semiconductor division as part of an effort to streamline its business and focus on electronic control operations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19 A ban on Solzhenitsyn's writing in the Soviet Union will remain, the top Kremlin ideologist said, because ''to publish Solzhenitsyn's work is to undermine the foundations on which our present life rests.'' Page A1

title: Met-Pro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Whiting Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First American Health Conepts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: BRITISH-BORN Thomas Catherall has received considerable recognition lately as one of the South's foremost chefs. He was featured in the September issue of Bon Appetit; listed as one of the region's ''star chefs'' in this month's edition of Food and Wine, and was awarded a Gold Medal With Distinction at the Culinary Olympics held last month in

title: Moscow vs. Its 'Mafia'
description: In the movie ''Red Heat,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger plays a Soviet police officer who pursues a Russian drug dealer to Chicago. There he teams up with a stumble-footed city detective played by James Belushi. In one scene Mr. Belushi attempts to cajole information from a suspect, without success. An impatient Mr. Schwarzenegger shows how it's done in Moscow: he breaks the suspect's fingers, eliciting the desired intelligence and, from one American audience, cries of approval.

title: Pass, Punt and Talk
description: I went to a professional football game in Washington. It was remarkably restful, and the game was good and interesting to the very end. The visiting players, working for a company licensed in Cleveland, won by the football equivalent of a hair in the final minute.

title: G.N.P. Rate Up to 2.6% In Quarter
description: The nation's economy grew at a 2.6 percent annual rate in the third quarter, somewhat faster than the 2.2 percent initially estimated, the Commerce Department reported today. The inflation rate was also revised upward.

title: Sanderson Farms Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $1,250,000.

title: Soviet Chefs in U.S., Marigold Petals and All
description: ZENA GOZALESHVILI walked into Fairway Market on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, past the star fruit and the figs, beyond the checkout counters, navigating her cart through the crowds as if she had had always shopped at this bustling Broadway fruit and vegetable emporium. Swiftly and expertly, she selected several eggplants, then moved on to the tomatoes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Comfed Bancorp Inc., Boston, to Heller Breene, a WCRS Group company, with a $1.5 million budget.

title: Make Supercollider America's Challenge for the 90's
description: To the Editor:

title: MITCHELL OF MAINE IS CHOSEN TO LEAD SENATE DEMOCRATS
description: Looking to reaffirm their party's traditional values and sharpen its public image, the Senate's 55 Democrats today selected George J. Mitchell of Maine as majority leader.

title: Master of Radio: Welles on the Air
description: The setting in a fourth-floor gallery of the Museum of Broadcasting is not really a time capsule, but it is being used these days to transport visitors 50 years back in time to the days when home entertainment meant closing the eyes and opening the ears.

title: Premiere by Harlem Troupe
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will present the world premiere of ''The Cape,'' a work by Gail Kachadurian, Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at the Tilles Center of C. W. Post College, Northern Boulevard in Greenvale, L. I. The program, part of the Friends of the Arts' Dazzling Dance series, also includes works by Arthur Mitchell, Frederic Franklin and Geoffrey Holder. Tickets are $20 and $15. Information: (516) 922-0061. To charge by telephone: (516) 888-9000.

title: Education; Lessons
description: In their never-ending search for bold new teaching methods, modern-day school reformers are returning to a staple of the one-room schoolhouse: letting students teach and counsel each other.

title: Autumn in Paris, Adrift In Anarchy and Apathy
description: President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist in politics but by temperament a republican monarch, is thinking grand thoughts and traveling a lot abroad these days.

title: John Houseman Is Eulogized at Memorial Service
description: John Houseman, the producer, director, actor and teacher who died on Oct. 31 at the age of 86, was eulogized yesterday afternoon at a memorial service at the Lyceum Theater on West 45th Street.

title: Review/Pop; Austere and Direct, Tracy Chapman Mixes Musical Worlds
description: Tracy Chapman is wary of her pop stardom. Although her debut album, ''Tracy Chapman,'' has sold two million copies, she shrugs off adulation and simply sings her songs. Ms. Chapman writes about racial tension, domestic violence, poverty-line living and the struggle for honest dignity -there's also an occasional love song - with stark, unpoetic lyrics in bare-bones settings. And her voice, a deep contralto, holds reservoirs of determination and sorrow behind every word. With her unexpected mass popularity, she has become doubly careful not to make a false move.

title: Litton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
50 Are Hurt in Crash Of Casino-Bound Bus
description: A bus carrying 49 passengers from Brooklyn to Atlantic City for a day at the casinos went out of control on the Garden State Parkway this morning and turned on its side, injuring all of those on board and the driver, the state police said.

title: Nazi's Lawyer Killed In Plunge in Jerusalem
description: A lawyer for the convicted Nazi war criminal John Demjanjuk died today after jumping from the 15th story of an office tower, a police spokesman said. The spokesman said the death of the lawyer, Dov Eitan, 53 years old, appeared to be a suicide.

title: Pep Boys--Manny, Moe & Jack reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,688,000 from an accounting adjustment. Latest net income includes a 2-cent per share charge to consolidate administrative functions.

title: French-Soviet Venture
description: A French-Soviet joint venture has been set up to modernize Soviet airports and build hotels. Under an accord signed Saturday, the French construction group Bouyges and the Soviet airline Aeroflot plan projects valued at $740 million. In the first, they will modernize the airport and construct a hotel next year at the Crimean city of Simferopol. A hotel is also planned at nearby Yalta.

title: Crash Pilot Tells of Apparent Bending of Rules
description: The pilot of a Delta Air Lines jetliner that crashed in Dallas on Aug. 31, killing 14 people, testified today that some rules might have been bent in readying the Boeing 727 for takeoff. But he asserted that the preparations were adequate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agencies Are Looking To East Bloc
description: WHILE much of the marketing community is setting its sights on the economic unification of Western Europe at the end of 1992, several of the largest advertising agencies are burrowing deeper into the much more pristine fields of Eastern Europe.

title: Firm Stance By European
description: The European Community will strongly respond to any attempt by the United States to adopt protectionist trade measures, the president of the community's executive commission said today.

title: Donors Remember Friends and the Neediest
description: When Donna Whiteman of Manhattan died in June, a memorial notice expressed her wish that anyone wanting to remember her should contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Stoneridge Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a $2.3 million loss from a subsidiary equity offering. c-Net income and included for the year a gain from an accounting change of $2,051,000 and a gain of $9.5 million, or $2.17 a share, from a transaction with American Agronomics in which Stoneridge's Orange-Co Florida subsidiary was merged with American Agronomics. Stoneridge Resources owns more than 50 percent of the stock of the surviving company, Orange-Co Inc.

title: Intelligent Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Real Estate; Jersey City Mall Attracts New Yorkers
description: THOUSANDS of New Yorkers are ignoring Mayor Koch's plea to keep their business in the city. Instead they take the PATH to the Newport Centre shopping mall in Jersey City to shop and dine in the 105 outlets that are already open in the mall, which is described as the largest mall close to Manhattan.

title: U.S. to Reduce Its Payments For Home Kidney Dialysis
description: The Department of Health and Human Services, beginning Jan. 1, will reduce payments for Medicare patients who receive professionally assisted kidney dialysis at home.

title: Investor's Daily Resignation
description: Stephen P. Fox, editor of Investor's Daily, has resigned effective Dec. 23, the Los Angeles-based business newspaper disclosed yesterday.

title: Greenwich Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains on the sale of real estate of $600,000 for the quarter and $950,000 for the year. The bank converted to public ownership April 14, 1988.

title: Rocking Horse Child Care Centers of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Neiman-Marcus Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a charge of $10,542,000 related to new accounting policies. Preferred stock dividends exceeded final net in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Jan-Hein Donner, Chess Grandmaster, 61
description: Jan-Hein Donner, a Dutch grandmaster who won the Dutch national chess title three times in the 1950's, died Sunday in the Vreugdehof nursing home in Amsterdam, where he had been treated since having a stroke in 1984. He was 61 years old.

title: Canyons of Capitalism Lure Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev hopes to visit the New York Stock Exchange, have lunch with bankers, open a Soviet commercial exhibition and do some sightseeing during a visit to New York next week, Soviet officials said today.

title: A Soviet General Says NATO Distorts Arms Comparison
description: A high-ranking Soviet military official today rejected as propaganda a recent NATO appraisal of conventional forces in Europe and said it did not provide a basis for East-West negotiations.

title: Farm Export Forecast
description: The value of United States farm exports should increase slightly, to $36.5 billion this year, but the volume of sales will fall about 8 percent largely because of last summer's drought, the Agriculture Department predicted today. Richard W. Goldberg, the Acting Under Secretary of Agriculture in charge of international affairs and commodity programs, said that export values will grow by $1 billion in the 1989 fiscal year. Volume, however, is expected to drop to 136 million metric tons, down from a six-year high of 147.5 million metric tons in the year ended Sept. 30. Mr. Goldberg made the forecast at the opening session of the department's annual Agricultural Outlook Conference.

title: Yes, Mr. Shultz, Keep Arafat Out
description: LEAD: The rollercoaster of emotions that we have experienced ever since that day in 1985 when our father Leon Klinghoffer was murdered on the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro has continued.

title: Latest Thing in Water: Truffles
description: ''I'VE had water that was this foul, but only in the coal fields of West Virginia and that was in the 50's.''

title: Judge Sued by Yonkers Homeowners
description: A coalition of Yonkers homeowners has filed suit against the Federal judge in the city's housing discrimination case, contending that he ''exceeded his statutory and constitutional jurisdiction'' in ordering that subsidized housing be built in the city's white neighborhoods.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Health pages on Aug. 4 about a new, rapid test to detect the herpes virus misstated its availability to the public, on the basis of information supplied by the manufacturer. The test, made by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, is now available only at a few commercial laboratories around the country. Du Pont reports that many other testing laboratories say they are evaluating the procedure.

title: For College Athletes In the Major Sports, Games Come First
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association spent $1.75 million over the last year studying the life of college athletes. Today, it released some of the results of that study and they appeared to confirm what most people had suspected all along: that football and basketball players on campuses with major athletic programs spend more time on their sports during the season than they do studying and attending class.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Major Harris, the quarterback of West Virginia, was voted Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I-A Player of the Year by coaches and sports information directors of the conference yesterday. . . . Dave Andreychuk, the leading scorer for the Buffalo Sabres the last three seasons, will be sidelined with a knee injury for at least three weeks. Jim Pizzutelli, the Buffalo trainer, said Andreychuk strained medial collateral ligaments in his left knee during Sunday night's game with the Philadelphia Flyers. . . . Kevin Rooney, trainer of Mike Tyson, the heavyweight boxing champion, was sentenced to three years' probation Monday night in Catskill (N.Y.) Village Court for assaulting his estranged wife's boyfriend last month. Village Justice Frank McDonald said the terms of probation were ''basically that he stay out of trouble.'' . . . Damon Bailey of Bedford, a sensational player who is still a junior at North Lawrence High School in Indiana, announced yesterday that he intends to attend Indiana University and play for Coach Bob Knight. Bailey, a 6-3 forward who averaged 23.6 points as a freshman and 31.1 last season, said he wanted to announce his choice early to take pressure off himself and his teammates.(AP)

title: Kings Score 5 in 3d To Rout Devils, 9-3
description: Dave Taylor, Mike Allison and Wayne Gretzky scored two goals apiece tonight as the Los Angeles Kings topped the Devils, 9-3.

title: In Sickness and in Health, but in Retirement?
description: Retirement may not bring couples closer together, and it could damage a shaky marriage, a study has found. In fact, retirement has no beneficial effects on the quality of marriages among older people, says Gary Lee, a gerontologist and sociology professor at the University of Florida.

title: Radical Delusions
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Mysteries Served as a Main Course
description: LEAD: THE first clues came with cocktails, and the denouement unfolded with dessert. The murder was foul, a main dish was fish, and the diners played detective. The show, which played recently at Charlies' restaurant in Manhattan, was produced by Hasselfree Productions, a three-year-old company that performs mysteries in restaurants in New York and New Jersey and on

title: Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago revenue figures are restated.

title: Merrill Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a review to determine whether military hospitals have space to treat civilian AIDS patients and intravenous drug users misstated the number of Americans who have died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. It is 44,344, not 34,641.

title: Savings Unit Expert Gets J.E. Robert Post
description: Donald W. Crocker, an expert on running failed savings institutions, has been named president and chief operating officer of the J. E. Robert Companies, an enterprise that earns its money managing troubled assets.

title: Minor Gains in Ecology And Major Challenges
description: President-elect Bush, who described himself as an environmentalist in his election campaign, will have ample opportunity to prove it when he takes office.

title: Sidewalk Kiddie Rides Win an Early Vote
description: Molded plastic ponies and dinosaurs, baby-sized boats, airplanes and spaceships, too, all ready to gently toss their juvenile riders about for 25 cents a turn, may soon get the protection of the New York City Council.

title: Trims and New Twists for a 'Coriolanus'
description: Enter, in black jogging suit, Steven Berkoff, 51 years old, British playwright, actor and director of ''Coriolanus,'' William Shakespeare's latest hit.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PROVENCAL has become a culinary buzzword for the 1980's, especially in restaurants, where every dish that contains garlic and olive oil seems to be ''Provencal'' style. The cooking of Provence in southern France uses prodigious amounts of garlic, olive oil and tomatoes, as well as a potpourri of fresh herbs, specifically rosemary, thyme, oregano, tarragon and basil. It is country cooking at its best, fragrant and lusty, reflecting the abundant provender of this sun-drenched Mediterranean region.

title: Benjamin Heffner, Lawyer, 79,
description: Benjamin Heffner, a lawyer and a former New York State assistant attorney general, died of heart failure Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: At 50, Planning Commission's Influence Is Diminishing
description: Created 50 years ago to shape New York City's nature and future, the City Planning Commission has become a narrowly focused body that devotes as much energy to the particulars of zoning and land-use review as to the broad charting of the city's course.

title: Cachet and Corner Pockets: Young Urban Pool Shooters
description: LEAD: For years Manhattan sharpshooters have played pool in dingy brown halls tucked away in basements or in back rooms, where smoke and suspicion hang in the air. Comes now nouvelle pool. Three modish pool halls have opened in Chelsea since August, and tables are cropping up in nightclubs, health clubs and restaurants.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Elbow Room, Below SoHo

title: Soviet Parliament Opens Fateful Session
description: With ethnic tensions spilling over into its deliberations, the Soviet Parliament today began consideration of a government reorganization plan that would partly redistribute power from the Communist Party to popularly elected legislative bodies.

title: Eagle Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $67,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $76,850, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $21,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Lincoln Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IC to Buy Bottlers
description: IC Industries, the nation's second-largest bottler of Pepsi-Cola products, agreed to buy two Pepsi bottling operations in Wisconsin for an undisclosed sum. The franchises in Oshkosh and Wisconsin Rapids will become part of Pepsi-Cola General Bottlers Inc., an IC subsidiary that bottles about 125 million cases of soda annually. The Wisconsin operations, both owned by the Pennau family of Oshkosh, bottle five million cases annually. Pepsi-Cola General handles 12 percent of Pepsico Inc.'s domestic soft-drink volume, second only to the Pepsi-Cola Bottling Group, which is wholly owned by Pepsico. IC, based in Chicago, will change its name Thursday to the Whitman Corporation.

title: Shultz Vigorous in Defending Decision Denying Arafat Visit
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, under foreign pressure to reverse himself, stood firm today and vigorously defended his decision denying a visa to Yasir Arafat.

title: Education; Schools Add Service To Their Curriculums
description: At the age of 14, Pedro Reyes was a member of a Los Angeles street gang, among whose nonviolent pastimes was scrawling grafitti on buildings. Now 17 and a junior in the city's Belmont High School, Pedro finds himself cleaning off the grafitti as one of the volunteer jobs he does as a member of the school's community service program.

title: Reviews/Music; Pan-American Pop Sounds
description: In a concert so crowded that standing still became a contact sport, Los Bukis, one of Mexico's most popular groups, performed Sunday at the Palladium. The five-man band from the state of Michoacan played pop-rock songs with traditional roots peeking out behind rock showmanship and electric instruments.

title: Medical Technology Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Texas Eagle Journal; Rare Prairie Critter: an Amtrak Train
description: Britton McVey, who gives his age as ''three years and three-quarters, my birthday is in January,'' didn't understand why he couldn't roll down the window next to his big reclining seat.

title: Weather Threatens to Delay Secret Shuttle Mission
description: Preparations for the secret military mission of the space shuttle Atlantis continued today as officials, with growing apprehension, monitored the approach of high winds that threaten to delay the launching scheduled for Thursday morning.

title: Western Captives Are Linked To Iranians Held in Lebanon
description: As the West German Foreign Minister ended a visit here, an Iranian Government official indicated today that Iran is linking efforts to free foreign hostages in Lebanon with the fate of Iranians believed held there.

title: Reviews/Music; Of Impressionism and Jazz
description: The Longar Ebony Ensemble played three contemporary chamber pieces at Weill Recital Hall Sunday afternoon, each representing one of the many paths recent composers have chosen.

title: NORTH LOSES A BID TO DISMISS CHARGES
description: The Federal district judge in the Iran-contra case today rejected motions by Oliver L. North to throw out two of the main charges against him but dismissed a related charge involving wire fraud.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Rodino's Capital Plans
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee who decided against seeking election again from New Jersey's 10th Congressional District after 40 years in office, will not put Washington behind him when the new Congress convenes in January.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie, Paris, signed a contract with Tunis Air placing three firm orders for A320 aircraft and taking options on five others. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Stocks Climb Strongly as Dow Gains 20.09
description: Stock prices rose strongly yesterday, buoyed by higher bond prices and late program-related buying.

title: Dress Barn Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29

AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Clatskanie, Ore.
description: LEAD: RALPH and Tina Hildula have been raising quail for the Oregon and Washington restaurant trade at their wholesale Pacific Quail Farm near Clatskanie (pronounced CLAT-skun-eye), Ore., for eight years. Pacific Quail is the third-largest producer of the native European Coturnix quail in the United States, and the only quail farm of significant size on the West

title: Bayou Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yukon Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Television; What Moscow Watches
description: Glimpses of the loosening up of Soviet society are on display tonight on ''Larry King's Night of Soviet Television,'' a three-hour sampler, at 8:05 on TBS, of the newscasts, documentaries, quiz shows, comedies and assorted entertainments that have emerged as part of Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of openness. Although neither the degree of openness nor the quality of the offerings lives up to the cheerleading of Mr. King, who finds on Soviet television the message of ''kindness and generosity and selflessness, treasured Communist values,'' the contrast to the buttoned-up spirit of the Brezhnev era is striking.

title: U.S. Looking Into Undercover Drug Manipulation
description: The Justice Department said today that it would review a Drug Enforcement Administration practice of sometimes arranging for local police officers to make well-publicized seizures of narcotics that are brought into the United States in Federal undercover operations.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Heart Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tennis Foes Fight To Control Sport
description: They arrived on gimpy knees and tender feet, nursing sore shoulders, weary from the fatigue that is a byproduct of a 12-month season. The Nabisco Masters is supposed to be a reward for their labor, a lucrative payoff for the top eight tennis players in the men's game. But this year, the players' thoughts are of rebellion, and what goes on behind the scenes at Madison Square Garden this week will likely overshadow the match results.

title: Islanders Drop 5th Straight
description: The Islanders came to life in the third period tonight, but the danger they posed to the Red Wings was so shortlived as to be ludicrous.

title: Pipe Bomb Charges Denied By Animal-Rights Advocate
description: An animal rights advocate who is accused of planting a bomb at a surgical instruments company pleaded not guilty today in Superior Court here to charges of attempted murder, possession of explosives and manufacturing a bomb.

title: Gwendolyn Cafritz, 78, Washington Hostess
description: Gwendolyn Cafritz, known as one of Washington's leading hostesses for several decades, died of cancer Tuesday at her home. She was 78 years old.

title: Man Ignites Himself And Kills 2
description: A 27-year-old Queens man, depressed over a dispute with his girlfriend, set himself on fire last night and died in flames that also killed two members of his family and injured three others, police officials said.

title: Education; Boston U. Eases Overnight Guest Ban
description: A strict ban on overnight dormitory guests that set off an uproar at Boston University was eased slightly Monday, but students still will not be able to put up visitors of the opposite sex who are not their relatives.

title: Angola Rebel Disputes Count of Cubans
description: A leader of the Angolan guerrillas expressed grave concern today about the regional peace settlement negotiated under American sponsorship, saying it would permit thousands of Cubans to remain in his country.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Adam Stagliano has been appointed executive vice president at Doyle Graf Mabley.

title: TESTS SEEK VIRUS LINKED TO CANCER
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved kits to be used to test donated blood for signs of a rare cancer-causing virus that experts fear could slowly spread in the population through blood transfusions.

title: Ranald H. Macdonald, An Ex-Stockbroker, 97
description: Ranald Hugh Macdonald, a former stockbroker and investment banker, died of heart failure Sunday at the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home in Huntington, L.I. He was 97 years old and was a former resident of Manhattan.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Rumanian Leader Is Adamant on Rural Plan
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania has reaffirmed his Government's plan to consolidate rural communities by eliminating thousands of villages, declaring that ''resolving the problem of living places for villagers represents an objective necessity.''

title: Laurel Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chrysler Plant Closing Dec. 23
description: The Chrysler Corporation today set Dec. 23 as the date when it will close its assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis., putting 4,800 people out of work.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AS is her weekend wont, our friend-about-town was having cocktails one recent Friday evening in the faded, genteel lobby of the Algonquin Hotel. While she was sipping her vodka and tonic, our friend spotted the hotel's resident tabby cat, Matilda, as she made her evening entrance, rubbed her way around the room and acknowledged someone seated in an armchair here, a sofa there.

title: Soviets and Afghan Rebels to Meet At a High Level, Newspaper Says
description: The Soviet Union and Afghan rebel leaders are preparing for high-level talks, possibly in Saudi Arabia within the week, according to Afghans here.

title: U.S. Physicians Rule Marcos Fit to Travel to Arraignment
description: Government doctors say the former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos is healthy enough to travel to New York for arraignment on criminal racketeering charges, a spokesman said today.

title: Bush's Careful Efforts Slow Selection of Pentagon Team
description: President-elect Bush, while eager to round out his national security hierarchy, has found himself slowed by his struggle to piece together a Pentagon management team to tighten spending, aides said today.

title: Chess Mate Gets U.S. Visa
description: A Soviet chess grandmaster who married the captain of the American chess team last week during the World Chess Olympiad in Salonika, Greece, was granted a United States immigration visa today, an official at the United States Consulate in Frankfurt said. The Soviet player, Yelena Akhmilovskaya, the No. 2 player on the Soviet team, married the American, John Donaldson, on Friday and they flew to Frankfurt on Saturday.

title: Review/Theater; Skewering the Movies With Australia as Oz
description: Pragmatic self-interest is the key to success in David Williamson's new comedy, ''Emerald City.'' With sharp satiric thrusts, the playwright skewers opportunism in the movies and, tangentially, in publishing. In this new play at the Perry Street Theater, the Emerald City is Sydney, the heartbeat of Oz, or Australia. Sydney is, we are told, with all acerbity intended, ''New York without the intellect.'' The view is from Down Under, but the angle is wide and global.

title: Suspected Terrorist Convicted in Bomb Case
description: A suspected Japanese terrorist arrested after three bombs were found in his car in April was convicted here today in a rarely used nonjury proceeding that left his goals and targets shrouded in mystery.

title: Over the Years, Commission Marked Milestones in Zoning
description: Technically speaking, the New York City Planning Commission is almost a year late in celebrating its 50th anniversary. But that's not bad. It took the panel 31 years to prepare the first and only master plan.

title: Book Notes
description: Coping With Success

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology

title: Gunman Wounds a Sikh Leader
description: The president of the predominant Sikh political party was wounded in an ambush today after he initiated efforts to unite rival factions on the eve of an important Sikh conference, news reports said. Two people were killed in the attack.

title: Takieddin Solh, Ex-Lebanese Premier, 80
description: Former Prime Minister Takieddin Solh, a longtime conservative politician, died Sunday in a private Paris clinic, his family said. He was 80 years old.

title: Curbs Sought on South Korean Spy Agencies
description: In one of the boldest efforts yet to distance South Korea from its authoritarian past, a group of senior advisers to President Roh Tae Woo on Tuesday proposed barring the nation's most feared intelligence agencies from involvement in domestic politics.

title: Big Oil Output Seen Until 1989
description: Five Persian Gulf oil states, which together account for two-thirds of OPEC production, are expected to keep their output high until January, when new quotas take effect, oil industry people said today. Discussing oil shipments for

title: ITT Unit Sues Campeau Over Losses on Bonds
description: For the second time in less than a month, the ITT Corporation has filed suit to recover damages related to its bondholdings in companies involved in takeovers.

title: Education; Wesleyan to Sell Stock Linked to S. Africa
description: The trustees of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., have decided to sell the university's stock in four companies that do business in South Africa, the university said.

title: Education; School Trouble-Solvers To Win Cash Awards
description: Every day Bruce Trachtenberg receives a bag full of letters describing an array of problems in schools. A Middle Western school principal is coping with the drought. One at a Northeastern urban school is trying to keep automatic weapons out.

title: Nets Stage Rally, But Celtics Hold On
description: The Nets took too long to get started tonight, then fell short at the finish.

title: Bush Sends a Critic Her Own Silver Foot
description: President-elect Bush has sent Ann Richards a handwritten ''peace offering'' and a tiny silver pin shaped like a foot.

title: 91-Day Paper Falls At Citicorp Auction
description: At Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, interest rates failed to advance for the first time in a month.

title: Pretoria Aids Mozambique's Military
description: South Africa is underscoring its commitment to warmer relations with Mozambique by donating military equipment to help protect a major hydroelectric project from the rebels that Pretoria once supported.

title: Sports of The Times; New Up-Front Act For Wilander
description: MATS WILANDER has been known to play his guitar but always in the background, except for the one evening at his bachelor party when his pals deposited him in a Stockholm train station and made him sing for his krona.

title: Deadline Is Announced For Music Competition
description: Applications for the Concert Artists Guild's international New York Competition must be received at the guild office no later than Jan. 27, the guild has announced. The competition is open to all classical instrumentalists (except organists) and to singers and chamber ensembles, with no age limit. Two copies of a cassette tape prepared to specifications must accompany the application forms.

title: 3-Year-Old Is Given 5-Organ Transplant
description: A child's abdomen was virtually replaced today in a rare five-organ transplant that doctors said was the 3-year-old girl's only chance for survival.

title: World Court's Role in P.L.O. Mission Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Make Supercollider America's Challenge for the 90's; Not a Luxury
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; In Tribute to Churchill
description: Washington is the capital the British burned, but that was more than 174 years ago. Since then, American feelings toward the British have improved.

title: Brokers Securities reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ward Says New Drug Units Are Not the Whole Answer
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, conceded yesterday that the strategy of saturating neighborhoods with undercover narcotics officers had been ''perhaps oversold'' and is not a panacea for the city's drug problem.

title: Charity, and Crocodile Chukka Boots
description: A male whose idea of daring haberdashery is a cable-knit sweater and a new pair of Bass Weejun loafers was jolted recently by a report that somebody is actually buying hand-knit sweaters from Kaffe Fassett for $2,295 and crocodile chukka boots from Polo/Ralph Lauren for $1,275. Who buys this stuff? Whence the cash? And how can the buyer be sure other people recognize that this is, in fact, crocodile by Ralph and not lizard by Larry?

title: Britain Firm on Rate Policy
description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, his political credibility battered by a soaring trade deficit and rising inflation, pledged today to stick to his policy of using high interest rates to tackle the economy's troubles.

title: About New York; Mr. Levy's Pool: A Tale of Morals, Liver and a Ghost
description: In just this one column, you can read about one of New York City's first Jews, a ghost inhabiting a secret room, the importance of public baths to the general morality, chopped liver presented in heart-shaped molds, the city's fiscal crisis and a Borscht Belt comic who claims to know 30,000 songs and no clean jokes.

title: Education; For Private Schools, Popularity Brings Catch-22
description: Hallway is something of a misnomer for the 60-foot-long corridor on the fifth floor of the Nightingale-Bamford School, a private school for girls on East 92d Street in Manhattan.

title: Langley Corp reports earnings for 11mo to Sept 30
description: The company changed its fiscal year to Sept. 30 from Oct. 31. The figures for the latest period consisted of 11 months and the year-earlier period had 12 months which ended Oct. 31.

title: Rotech Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes $32,535 in income from discontinued operations.

title: College Hockey Notebook; Officials Are Quick To Quell Fighting
description: College hockey officials, on and off the ice, have worked hard to curb fighting and they have had some success. Their sport has less of the boring brawling common to the professional game, but on occasion the boys will battle.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Chameleon Woman

title: Results Plus
