description: Tennis McNeil Wins in Australia: Top-seeded Lori McNeil held off a fellow American, Tina Mochizuki, in the first round of the $100,000 Southern Cross Classic in Adelaide, Australia, yesterday. McNeil, ranked 11th in the world, held serve only once in the first set and came from 1-4 down in the second to beat Mochizuki, 1-6, 7-6, 6-3, at the Memorial Drive courts. Tine Scheuer Larsen of Denmark upset the second-seeded player, Nicole Provis of Australia, 5-7, 6-3, 6-3, in a second-round match. In another second-round match, No. 6 Dianne Balestrat of Australia beat Olga Tsarbopoulou of Greece, 6-7, 6-1, 6-2. In first-round action, No. 3-seeded Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia defeated Michelle Jaggard of Australia, 6-2, 6-0; Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia stopped Sabine Appelmans of Belgium, 1-6, 6-1, 6-1, and Christina Tessi of Argentina beat Louise Field of Australia, 7-6, 6-3. The only other seeded player to lose was No. 7 Beverly Bowes of Lubbock, Tex., who fell to Maria Strandlund of Sweden, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Skiing Zurbriggen Takes Cup Event: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland flashed down a wet, fog-shrouded course that his rival, Alberto Tomba, could not handle and won his second straight World Cup race yesterday. Zurbriggen, the defending overall World Cup champion, had a combined time of 2 minutes 9.32 seconds for the giant slalom in Val Thorens, France. The time was good enough for a victory by 16 one-hundredths of a second over Rudi Nierlich of Austria, who finished in 2:09.48. Another Austrian, Hans Enn, was third in 2:10.02. Tomba, who missed a gate in the first run, was disqualified.(AP)

title: Sailor Killed in Carrier Mishap
description: One seaman was killed and another was seriously injured early today in a fire on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Nimitz in the North Arabian Sea, Pentagon officials said.

title: Arbor Drugs reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Brown Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Editor of New York Takes Harper Post
description: Edward Kosner, editor and publisher of New York magazine, will become an editorial consultant to Harper & Row, effective immediately, while continuing at the magazine.

title: Assembly Offers Change in Deal Over Shoreham
description: New York State Assembly leaders have introduced a new condition for approval of the agreement to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant that Long Island Lighting Company officials say could kill the deal.

title: Long Helps Pacers
description: John Long scored 15 of his 18 points in the second half tonight as the Indiana Pacers beat the Detroit Pistons, 107-98.

title: Geneva Session Called a Long-Term Threat to U.N.
description: Diplomats here expressed concern today that a move to convene the General Assembly in Geneva could cause long-term damage to the United Nations' relations with its host country.

title: Talking of Terror
description: Bassam Abu Sharif was a terrorist and he was a victim of terrorism. Now, as chief spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization, he says ''I don't think there's a future for either one if there's no cooperation'' between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Article 948888 -- No Title
description: A well-known painting of waterlilies by Claude Monet was bought in London tonight for $10.53 million by Seibu, the Japanese department store.

title: Savings Industry Losses Fell 60% in 3d Quarter
description: Losses in the savings and loan industry declined by 60 percent in the third quarter, reflecting the rescue of many insolvent institutions by the Government, M. Danny Wall, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

title: Pennwalt Buyback Draws 72% of Stock
description: The Pennwalt Corporation, a Philadelphia-based chemical company, said that almost 9.2 million shares, or 72 percent of its stock, had been tendered under a stock buyback offer that expired Monday. The company said it would pay $85 each for about 4.75 million shares, or 37.6 percent of its stock. Centaur Partners, a New York investment partnership that owns 8.6 percent of Pennwalt, refused to comment on whether it had tendered its shares.

title: Valerie Harper to Get Custom-Tailored Series
description: CBS has announced that it will develop a new weekly comedy series for Valerie Harper. The network and MTM Entertainment, which from 1974 through 1978 produced ''Rhoda,'' one of Ms. Harper's most popular television programs, have entered into an agreement with A/V Productions and Paul Haggis Productions to create 13 episodes of the new series, which is to be called ''Desperate Women.''

title: When to Stop Oil Blackmail: Now
description: Once-mighty OPEC is alive but hardly well. The oil cartel has agreed to new limits on production, probably adding a few dollars to the price of a barrel. But with 15 percent of world capacity going untapped today, OPEC's $18 target remains pure fantasy.

title: American Telecommunicaions Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $775,819 extraordinary gain.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boston Co., Boston, a subsidiary of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., named William J. Nutt vice chairman of the holding company and vice chairman of its subsidiary Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Co. The company also announced the formation of its office of the chairman consisting of Mr. Nutt; George W. Phillips, chairman, and James N. von Germeten, president and chairman of Boston Safe Deposit.

title: Prime Computer Rejects MAI Offer
description: The board of Prime Computer Inc. announced today that it had unanimously rejected a $970 million offer by MAI Basic Four Inc., a small California computer company controlled by Bennett S. LeBow, a New York investor.

title: Gould Resigns Treasury Job
description: George D. Gould, the No. 3 official in the Treasury Department, resigned as of last Friday, the department announced today.

title: Joule Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Kohlberg Leads Latest Nabisco Bids
description: Amid a strange series of late-night maneuverings, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company won the latest round of bidding for RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday with a record offer worth as much as $24.3 billion.

title: Steam Irons Being Recalled; Fire Hazard Cited by Agency
description: VaporSimac steam irons are being recalled because of a danger of starting fires, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today.

title: International Consumer Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Tighter Race Law Is Rejected in South Africa
description: A presidential council formally rejected legislation today that would have tightened enforcement of residential segregation laws.

title: REAGAN NOSTALGIC FOR G.O.P. SENATE
description: President Reagan, saying Republicans ''need have no regrets'' about their record over the last eight years, said tonight that he would leave Washington wishing that his party had recaptured the Senate.

title: Kremlin Keeping Solzhenitsyn on Blacklist
description: The top Kremlin ideologist made it clear today that Alexander Solzhenitsyn would remain on the Soviet Union's blacklist of forbidden writers, saying that ''to publish Solzhenitsyn's work is to undermine the foundations on which our present life rests.''

title: Sports People; Flyers Trade Zezel
description: The Philadelphia Flyers sent Peter Zezel to the St. Louis Blues for Mike Bullard yesterday in a trade of experienced N.H.L. centers. ''The feeling of the organization and my own feeling was that we had to get more speed and we had to get more scoring up front,'' said Bob Clarke, the general manager of the Flyers.

title: Suit Seeks to Force F.B.I. to Seal Data In Terrorism Inquiry
description: Five groups demanded in a lawsuit today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation forever seal records of a 1983 inquiry on terrorism, one the bureau has since acknowledged was unnecessarily broad.

title: Rediscovering a Lost Heritage In Hanukkah Food Traditions
description: ON Saturday evening, the first night of Hanukkah, Karmella and Vladimir Raiz will be hosts at a party for 50 people in their four-room apartment in Vilnius, Lithuania. Because Karmella, a concert violinist, and Vladimir, a molecular biologist, have repeatedly applied over the last 15 years for visas to emigrate to Israel, they have gained a kind of celebrity in the local Jewish community. Their home, meanwhile, has become a gathering place for other Lithuanian Jews who want to emigrate or wish to rediscover their religious heritage.

title: Cleveland
description: PAT and Dan Conway have opened what may be the first brewery-pub combination in Ohio, in a 128-year-old former feed and seed store on the city's west side. The location of the business, the Great Lakes Brewing Company, is fitting, since many of the more than two dozen breweries that prospered here until Prohibition were scattered within a few blocks.

title: Clini-Therm Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Port Elizabeth Journal; Apartheid Could Part a Community That Works
description: The ramshackle houses built of corrugated metal and weathered scrap wood hardly make Kleinskool look like a model community. Its 1,500 families get by without electricity and indoor plumbing, using backyard privies and fetching their water from public spigots that leave mud puddles in the coarsely tufted earth.

title: Mary D. Costa, Housing Official, 69
description: Mary D. Costa, the former deputy general manager of the New York City Housing Authority, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. She was 69 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Australian Plan On Farm Trade
description: Australia on Monday put forward proposals for farm trade reform that European Community negotiators said could help break a deadlock in bargaining to free the flow of world commerce.

title: Lockheed Favored For Fokker Deal
description: The Lockheed Corporation is the favored candidate to build the Dutch-designed Fokker-100 airliners in the United States, a spokesman for N.V. Fokker said, but the American company emphasized that a deal was not at hand. Fokker's chief spokesman, Rob Mol, said negotiations were not finished, but he added, ''Lockheed is definitely the most serious candidate.''

title: Physician Says Blows Killed Lisa Steinberg
description: Blows to Lisa Steinberg's head were fatal even though they did not fracture her skull, a medical expert testified yesterday for the prosecution in the murder trial of Joel B. Steinberg.

title: For a Quiet Deal On Soviet Emigrants
description: LEAD: Three years into the glasnost era, Soviet policies on emigration and political freedom have reached a watershed. To a degree unimaginable before Mikhail S. Gorbachev's accession, the Kremlin is allowing people who want to leave to go. Despite the imposition of martial law in Azerbaijan, people who want to dissent are, increasingly, allowed to dissent.

title: Myerson Critisized '86 Inquiry
description: Bess Myerson screamed, cursed and described a Federal investigation of her as a ''witch hunt,'' a witness testified yesterday.

title: Books of The Times; Turgenev, Uneasy Romantic of Many Homelands
description: Turgenev By Henri Troyat Translated by Nancy Amphoux. 184 pages. E. P. Dutton. $18.95.

title: Bridge
description: While most of America's top-ranked players were fighting for the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team title here over the weekend, 105 squads at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals were contesting, with equal intensity, the National Swiss Team Championship. The winners of the three-day event were John Zilic, Houston; David and Allan Siebert, Little Rock, Ark.; Sylvia Summers, Long Beach, Calif., and Paul Munafo, Huntsville, Ala.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: George John Mitchell; Thoughtful Competitor
description: If you want to understand Senator George J. Mitchell, watch him play tennis.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Marcos Rebuttal
description: Since he went into exile in Hawaii two years ago, Ferdinand E. Marcos, the deposed President of the Philippines, has been accused of malfeasance, fraud and other felonies in both his own country and the United States, but until recently he has never defended himself in detail.

title: Larry's Ice Cream reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Analytical Surveys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: LABOR PARTY SPLIT ON TIES WITH LIKUD
description: Although the vote is likely to be close, the Labor Party's executive board is expected on Wednesday to approve further negotiations with Likud over forming another national unity government.

title: 'Samaritan' to Appeal Drug Case Sentence
description: The Brooklyn man who rescued a neighbor from a mugging by shooting two assailants filed a notice of appeal yesterday, saying he will challenge the jail sentence he received for a drug conviction, his lawyer said.

title: Sandy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an $860,000 tax credit.

title: A School Construction Authority Appears to Be Doomed in Albany
description: Legislation to create an authority to oversee construction of New York City schools is ''dead in its current form,'' the State Senate majority leader said today.

title: Software Arbitration Ruling Gives I.B.M. $833 Million From Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan must pay at least $237.2 million more to the International Business Machines Corporation to settle a six-year-old dispute over its copying of software necessary to build computers compatible with I.B.M.'s most powerful machines, two independent arbitrators ruled yesterday.

title: Market Place; Inside Information Becoming Scarce
description: WITH United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani getting closer to bringing criminal charges against Drexel Burnham Lambert, and possibly settling the nation's most sweeping insider trading case, the consensus on Wall Street is that insider trading has been heavily discouraged but has definitely not disappeared.

title: Economic Scene; The Recession Next Time
description: AFTER six years of prosperity, is the economy heading for a fall? Only if Washington makes a mistake.

title: Luis Barragan, Leading Architect Of Mexican Housing, Dead at 86
description: Luis Barragan, an intensely private man who has long been considered Mexico's greatest architect, died Nov. 22 in Mexico City. He was 86 years old and had been ill with Parkinson's disease for many years.

title: Washington
description: WHEN the cooking club at the Library of Congress decided to concentrate on its own collection as the basis for Monday's annual Christmas luncheon, Ann Bauersfeld asked for a printout of all the Christmas books. ''The librarian threw up his hands,'' said Ms. Bauersfeld, chairwoman of the luncheon. ''There were more than 4,000 titles beginning with the word Christmas.''

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Climb
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher again yesterday, helped by a dip in oil prices and the purchase of an estimated $3 billion to $4 billion in securities by the Federal Reserve.

title: A Restaurant Seasoned by the 1960's
description: THE display cases at La Fete Chez Vous are crammed with plates of rabbit stewed with figs and apricots, shrimp with nacho stuffing, ginger cheesecake and almond-hazelnut dacquoise. The tiny kitchen is filled with the aroma of freshly baked goods.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M.

title: Cadbury Lifts Bid
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. raised its offer for the 30.3 percent of Cadbury Schweppes Australia Ltd. that it does not already own by 9 percent, to $1.48 billion. The revised offer was $4.86 a share in cash, up from an earlier bid of $4.46. Shareholders can also choose one of two alternative offers. They can get 20 shares in the British company for 33 shares of Cadbury Schweppes Australia, or one British share plus $12.47 for four shares in the Australian company. The sweetened cash offer follows discussions between directors of the two companies, officials said.

title: 6 Firefighters Die in Blast at Kansas City
description: Six firefighters were killed by two powerful explosions at a construction site before dawn today as they battled fires that police officials believe were caused by arsonists.

title: Service for Robert Joffrey Is Told Of His Warmth and Resoluteness
description: In a memorial that was tinged with the affection of a family event, friends, colleagues and admirers paid tribute yesterday at City Center to Robert Joffrey, a founder and the director of the Joffrey Ballet. The speakers, many fighting tears, talked of Mr. Joffrey's humor and warmth. They also talked of his determination as he built his company into one of the major dance troupes in America.

title: Himont Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $21.5 million on the sale of assets. The shares outstanding for the 1987 year reflected averaging of 14,375,000 public offering shares issued in February 1987.

title: WTD Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the record sales are a reflection of 18 acquisitions made since December 1986.

title: KEY RATES
Play, by Definition, Suspends the Rules
description: SIR ALEXANDER FLEMING, the Scottish bacteriologist (1881-1955), had a most peculiar pastime. He liked to paint pictures in petri dishes with a palette of living germs. Being thoroughly familiar with microorganisms - their individual colors, textures, growth rates and so forth - he was able to produce striking portraits: a mother and child, a ballerina, his house.

title: INSIDE
description: British Jailings Denounced

title: Nuggets Outshoot Knicks
description: The Nuggets entered tonight's game against the Knicks as the highest scoring team in the league, averaging 132 points a game. New York was the second-highest scorer - at 121 points - but the Knicks did nothing to change those statistics, except to widen the gap a bit.

title: Pay Reform in Congress
description: Yesterday's election of George Mitchell of Maine as the Senate's new majority leader raises hopes for ending the odious system that saw members of Congress pocket a record $7.5 million last year in backdoor pay from special interests. Mr. Mitchell would replace the dubious fees with an increase in the current annual Congressional salary of $89,500. Such reform is long overdue.

title: Great Western
description: Great Western Bank, a unit of the Great Western Financial Corporation, is offering to the public $250 million of 9.80 percent senior notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.95 to yield 9.812 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: American Monitor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Talk Is Stacked Against Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Snag Delays the Restarting Of Carolina Arms Plant Reactor
description: The Energy Department said today that the first of three reactors at the Savannah River nuclear weapon plant could not be restarted until the spring or summer because safety programs were not completed. The huge complex in South Carolina had been scheduled to reopen next month.

title: Jews and Blacks Recall the Decades of Partnership
description: There were some moving remembrances of the past and some cautious tiptoeing around the tensions of the present as more than 70 black and Jewish veterans of the civil rights movement gathered here to record and celebrate a coalition that brought broad social change to this country.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Political reform is a kind of oxygen needed by the public organism.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A18:3. ]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Conde Nast Publications Ltd. has bought a 40 percent interest in Wagadon Ltd., a London-based publishing company that owns the magazines The Face and Arena.

title: Belgian Inquiry Into Philips Plan
description: Belgium's economic minister has begun an inquiry into plans by Philips N.V. to cut two-thirds of its work force at a Belgian plant, a ministry spokesman said. Philips said it would reorganize and cut 810 of the factory's 1,210 jobs. The news led to a protest Monday by some 100 employees, who shut the plant's director in his office and occupied its research and development center. The official was released during the night, but a Philips spokesman said the occupation was continuing.

title: FICO Offers Bonds
description: The Financing Corporation, also known as FICO, a mixed-ownership Government corporation chartered by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is offering $700 million of bonds that will reach maturity on Dec. 6, 2018, through Salomon Brothers Inc., which submitted the winning bid in competition yesterday. The 30-year bonds were given a 9.90 percent coupon and are offered at a price of 100.3839 to yield 9.86 percent.

title: U.S.-Japanese Plane Project
description: Japan and the United States today settled the details of a plan to develop a new jet fighter for Japan's Air Force, to be based on the United States F-16 fighter, Defense Agency officials said.

title: What Iran Wants Ignored
description: Iran and Iraq have each taken advantage of the August cease-fire in their long war to settle scores with dissenters at home. Iraq's lawless gassing of Kurdish villages has been deservedly condemned. Iran's mass killings of mainly leftist opponents have attracted less attention. But they have occurred on a scale sufficient to prompt a United Nations debate today on a report saying the executions ''justify international concern.''

title: Filion Pursues Victory Mark
description: With 767 victories in hand and needing only 4 more to reclaim the record for most triumphs by a harness racing driver in one year, Herve Filion was shut out of the winner's circle in eight races yesterday afternoon at Yonkers Raceway. Last night, he prepared to try again with seven scheduled drives on the 11-race card.

title: Historical Society Reshaping Itself for Survival
description: A revitalized board of trustees of the New-York Historical Society has begun taking steps in recent weeks to bring back the troubled institution from the brink of bankruptcy and to insure its future.

title: Sunstar Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $1,000 and $296,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $15,000 and $46,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: Essef Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Make Supercollider America's Challenge for the 90's; Remember the Deficit?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion as Seen Through Antonio's Own Eyes and Art
description: FOR more than 25 years, Antonio Lopez was one of the best known - some would say, the best known - fashion illustrators and artists. Antonio, who used only his first name professionally, died of AIDS last year at the age of 44, and as a tribute to him, his alma mater, the Fashion Institute of Technology, is showing 150 of his drawings, paintings and murals.

title: The PC's Broad New Potential
description: For personal computer users, the age of holding an entire encyclopedia in the palm of the hand has arrived.

title: Insider Filing May Tighten
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed rules that would force corporate insiders to file prompt reports of their transactions in their own company's securities.

title: Shamrock Names Head Of Broadcast Division
description: William L. Clark, who was named yesterday as president of Shamrock Holdings Inc.'s broadcasting division, owes his start in the business to Mike Wallace of CBS.

title: EATING WELL
description: MOST diets begin in January, and no wonder: Americans gain four to seven pounds, on average, from Thanksgiving to New Year's.

title: WINE TALK
description: EVERY autumn, the wine world waits for the third Sunday of November to find out what's happening in Burgundy. That's the day of the annual auction for the Hospices de Beaune, and the prices paid for the wines of the hospices are a steady, if not entirely accurate, indication of how the market is going to go in the months ahead.

title: JMB Realty Trust Corp reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain from the disposition of investment properties of $131,311.

title: Burlington Settles Suit Over Pipeline
description: Burlington Northern Inc. said it had agreed to pay more than $175 million to settle an antitrust suit brought by Energy Transportation Systems, a pipeline concern, ending a longstanding legal dispute. Energy Transportation had contended that Burlington Northern unlawfully blocked construction of a proposed coal pipeline from the Powder River Basin in Wyoming to Texas and Arkansas.

title: Acustar-Valeo
description: Acustar, the parts-making subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, agreed to establish a joint venture with Valeo of Paris to produce climate control and engine cooling systems. Valeo will have 51 percent of Valeo/Acustar Thermal Systems, which is to be based in Livonia, Mich. Details of the agreement were not disclosed, but a spokesman for Acustar said the venture was expected to have sales of $200 million to $300 million in its first year of operation. Acustar estimated its annual sales at $3.1 billion and those of Valeo at $2.7 billion, making Valeo Europe's second-largest manufacturer of auto parts.

title: Airlines Announce Fare Cut on Many Florida Flights in January
description: The nation's largest airlines announced fare reductions yesterday on many of their Florida routes during most of January and early February. But the price increases that went into effect last week remain intact for the rest of the nation.

title: Albert Decker, 93; Started Fertility Clinic
description: Albert Decker, founder and director emeritus of the Fertility Research Foundation in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: British Detention Law Is Ruled a Breach of Rights
description: A court in Strasbourg, France, ruled today that a British law permitting pre-arraignment detention for up to a week of people suspected of connections with terrorist groups was a breach of the European Convention on Human Rights.

title: Review/Music; Early Music, by Sequentia
description: Sequentia, an early-music ensemble formed in 1977, performs with different combinations of singers and players to suit its program. For its Sunday evening concert of medieval vocal music at the Metropolitan Museum, the group was a sextet: Benjamin Bagby, William Hite and Frank Kelley, tenors, and David Ripley, William Sharp and Sanford Sylvan, baritones. Mr. Bagby directed.

title: Buyout of Ann Taylor Chain Is Announced
description: The Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it would sell the Ann Taylor fashion stores for $430 million to a group formed by the chain's management, Merrill Lynch Capital Partners and Joseph E. Brooks, former chairman and chief executive of Lord & Taylor.

title: Torchmark Raises Offer for Insurer
description: The Torchmark Corporation said it had sweetened its tender offer for the Kansas City Life Insurance Company by $4 a share, to $47.50, a bid that values the insurer at $346.8 million. Kansas City Life's shares jumped $2.75, to $39.50, in over-the-counter trading. Earlier, Kansas City Life said its board had unanimously recommended that shareholders reject as inadequate a $43.50-a-share offer that Torchmark made on Nov. 16.

title: Paris Business Forms Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chief of Thruway Panel Announces Resignation
description: The chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority, William C. Hennessy, said today that he was resigning at the end of the year and would return to working full time at his engineering consulting concern in Albany, Hennessy and Plummer Inc.

title: Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Includes a charge of $827,000 from the sale of Abercrombie & Fitch for the quarter; the 9 months include a pretax gain of $23,884,000 from the sale of the company's Abercrombie & Fitch unit. c-Net loss Latest quarter and 9-month results include an after-tax LIFO charge of $150,000 and $432,000, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results include an after-tax LIFO charge of $85,000 and $349,000, respectively.

title: Review/Recital; Flutist's Debut Displays Variety Of Styles
description: Elizabeth Tallman, a flutist, made her New York recital debut at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening with an inventive program that ran the gamut of compositional styles and put her instrument in a variety of ensemble settings. Ms. Tallman's sound, however, is airy rather than lustrous, and one rarely got the impression that she had much to say interpretively.

title: Glut of TV Stations for Sale Being Met by Buyer Apathy
description: Nine more television stations have been put up for sale in the last two weeks, adding to the swelling list of properties being shopped around to a largely apathetic buying community.

title: Washington Talk: Armed Forces; Military Opening Offensive on Budget Cutbacks
description: At the conclusion of the eight-year buildup of American armed forces under the Reagan Administration, the nation's military leaders see harder times ahead, with the urge to reduce spending on the Pentagon spreading throughout the Government.

title: As Peru's Crisis Grows, Drastic Steps Are Urged
description: The pressure is mounting on President Alan Garcia to step down from office, call early elections, or simply surrender power to an independent Cabinet.

title: Sports People; Gedman in Accord
description: Rich Gedman, a second-look free agent as a result of the second collusion case, is staying with the Boston Red Sox. The catcher, who batted only .231 this year, reached agreement with the Red Sox yesterday on a one-year contract for $1.25 million.

title: MPSI Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1,470,000 loss from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 6 percent stock dividend distributed this month.

title: Sports People; Thomas Edges Thomas
description: One Thomas, Derrick of Alabama, edged another Thomas, Broderick of Nebraska, to win the Butkus Award as the nation's outstanding college linebacker yesterday.

title: Pillsbury Reportedly Talked To 15 Parties Seeking a Bid
description: Facing a hostile takeover bid from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain, the Pillsbury Company approached 15 third parties about the possibility of a friendly offer, but did not receive a single bid, an attorney representing Pillsbury shareholders said today.

title: Inter Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $334,000 for the quarter and $708,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $231,000 and $660,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The earnings per share have only been computed on the income from Aug. 21, 1987, the dale of stock issuance, to Sept. 30, 1987. The per share earnings for periods prior to Aug. 21, 1987 are not meaningful.

title: Kabul Army Looks Strong, Russian Says
description: A Soviet commander here says he does not agree with those who believe that everything will collapse once the Soviet military withdrawal is complete.

title: Sports People; Lemieux Satisfied
description: The contract talks between the Pittsburgh Penguins and Mario Lemieux have been a distraction since the start of the National Hockey League season. The discussions ended yesterday with the high-scoring center receiving a substantially upgraded and retroactive contract for this season and the possibility of a long-term contract.

title: Review/Television; British Political Thriller
description: For the last several weeks, Channel 13 has been broadcasting, late on Wednesdays, a series of made-in-Britain political thrillers. Tonight's entry, at 11:30, is ''The Secret Servant,'' an oddity in several respects.

title: It's Time for a Toast: The Grapes Are In
description: THE farmers stamped their feet, rubbed their hands together and hugged themselves in the time-honored gestures of people saying it was cold out. ''First day of winter,'' the host said over and over as more guests arrived, each nodding agreement with his astute observation.

title: Cut Is Urged in Capital Gains Tax
description: The president of the trade association for the nation's securities industry urged support today for a reduction in the capital-gains tax.

title: HIGH COURT RULES ON FAIR TRIAL ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court today made it more difficult for defendants to challenge prosecutors on the ground that the police mishandled evidence that could prove a defendant's innocence.

title: The Death Penalty Can Help Create a Better Prison Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Sony Sets Shift to CD's
description: The CBS Sony Group, the Japanese subsidiary of the Sony Corporation, will reduce production of records for sale in Japan, shifting to compact disks and tapes instead, a company spokesman said today.

title: Baby Baby Boom Boom: Later Pregnancies Mean More Twins
description: More twins will be born in the United States this year than ever before, according to statisticians, health-care professionals and organizations devoted to the study and support of twins.
